
<leme no="680">

<page sig="A1v">
<section type="Title-page">
<term lang="la">Gazophylacium Anglicanum</term>: 

CONTAINING THE

DERIVATION 

OF
English Words,

PROPER and COMMON;

Each in an Alphabet distinct:

Proving the Dutch and Saxon to be the prime
Fountains. And likewise giving the Similar 
Words in most European Languages, whereby
any of them may be indifferently well Learned,
and Understood.

Fitted to the Capacity of the English Reader, that may be
curious to know the Original of his Mother-tongue.

LONDON,

Printed by E. H. and W. H. and are to be
sold by Randall Taylor, near Stationers Hall,
and by most Booksellers in London and West&shy;
minster, MDCLXXXIX.
</section>
</page>

<page sig="A1r">
</page>

<page sig="A3r">
<section type="Preface">
<heading>THE 
PREFACE.</heading> 

'TIS not barely my Obligation to Cu&shy;
stom, that has prevail'd with me to
present the courteous Reader with a 
Preface to the following Essay, but
rather the necessity and usefulness thereof in
a Work of this nature, that he might not be
surpriz'd, when, after having read the Title, he
should fall foul upon what is promised therein,
without any Instructions so to do.

In the first place therefore, I desire the Rea&shy;
der to take notice of the
Method.
I. Of its Division into three Heads.
The first, Of Common Names.
The second, Of such Proper Names as are of a
German Original.
The third, Of Proper Names derived from
the Latin, Greek, or Hebrew, with their signi&shy;
fication. All done by way of Alphabet; so that any Word
desired, may be quickly found.
</page>

<page sig="A3v">
II. Observe that all along, through the Book,
that Word is set next the English, from which
I have judged it most likely to be derived; and
the Synonymous Words of the other European
Languages follow: Which shews, I have left it to
the Opinion of the Reader, to draw it from which
he pleases. Moreover, by a curious reading here&shy;
of, any of the European Languages may be indif&shy;
ferently well learned.

III. Note, that very many of the Words being
of a British or Saxon Original, have their Ex&shy;
plication set down.

The chief Reason why I busied my self here&shy;
in, was, to save my Time from being worse em&shy;
ployed: And, I did imagine (as, questionless,
these most indefatigable and ingenious Persons
did, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  Kilian, Vossius, Salmasius, Martinius,
Spelman, Bochart, Junius, Menagius and Skin&shy;
ner, from whom I took my Pattern) I could
not spend it more commendably, or profitably,
than in searching into the Original of my Na&shy;
tive Language; which is so strangely corrupted
through Time, that when I look'd an hundred,
or an hundred and fifty Years only behind me,
I could scarce imagine it ever to have been
the Language of my Ancestors, or even of the Coun&shy;
try I was born in, 'tis so chang'd through Com&shy;
merce,
</page>

<page sig="A4r">
Correspondence, Travellers, and such
like Accidents: Much more may you imagine
it to be alter'd in a thousand, or two thousand
Years, by Conquests, Invasions, Transmigra&shy;
tions of Government, &amp;c. which have been
very frequent over, and in this Isle, above
others: So that though this my native Country
might, at its first Settlement, have a Language
peculiar to it self; yet, as is said before, by
Conquest, Commerce, Travelling, Transmigra&shy;
tions of the Government, &amp;c. it is brought to
what we now find it, even a Composition of most,
if not all the Languages of Europe; especially
of the Belgick or Low-Dutch, Saxon, Teuto&shy;
nick or High-Dutch, Cambro-British or Welsh,
French, Spanish, Italian, and Latin; and now
and then of the Old and Modern Danish, and
Ancient High-Dutch; also of the Greek, He&shy;
brew, Arabick, Chaldee, Syriack and Turcick.

But I have forbore, as much as possible, the
setting down such as are purely of a Latin Ori&shy;
ginal, lest the Book should exceed the quantity
of Sheets design'd, and so possibly the Price of
the Buyer; it having been the only Fault of those
that have hitherto writ upon this Subject, to
be both voluminous, high-pric'd, and in Latin;
so that many Well-wishers to their Mother-Tongue
could neither reach the Value nor Knowledge thereof:
All which I hope I have remedied, by
</page>

<page sig="A4v">
doing this in English, and in a small Volume,
fitted to a small Price.

I have (that the Reader might not be at
a loss in such Words as are purely from
the Latin) prefix'd a few easie Rules, whereby ma&shy;
ny thousand English Words coming therefrom may
most easily be known, and made Latin again, usual&shy;
ly, by the Addition, Cutting off, or Changing of
a Letter

The Confusion of Languages at Babel (for
before it, all the then World spoke one and
the same Dialect, supposed to be Hebrew) gave
Rise to all the several Languages in the Uni&shy;
verse; of which, the primitive Language of
this Nation was one; and, had it not been
corrupted, perhaps as good and intelligible as the
best; but being so alter'd by the aforesaid
Accidents, it has quite lost its primitive Glo&shy;
ry, as well as that of the French, and other
Nations.

It may be justly wonder'd at, why we have
no more Words than we have from the Old
British, now the Welsh (which, no doubt, was
the Primitive Language of this Nation:) But
if we again consider how imperiously the Saxons
enter'd and subdued this Land, our Wonder
will in a great measure abate; for they did not,
</page>

<page sig="A5r">
 as Conquerors usually do, mix the Britains with
themselves, after they had yielded to, or were
not any ways able to resist the Conqueror; but
put all to the Sword that they met withal; on&shy;
ly some few, to shelter themselves from their
Rage, betook themselves to the Mountains of
Wales and Cornwall; which being inaccessable
to the Conquerors, for want of use, were suf&shy;
ficient Security to the distressed Britains, against
them; which Quarter they do still live in, and
retain their own Language, for the most part,
within themselves, as if they were another Na&shy;
tion; only by Commerce and Intercourse, there
has happen'd some Commutation of Language like&shy;
wise. So that our Language, in the main, is
composed of the Old English-Saxon, Dutch and
Normandy-French; but of the first principally,
for that the last did only in part subdue, not
destroy this Nation, which the former did endea&shy;
vour, and almost effect.

I might have added the Italian, because of
its Affinity to the French; as also because of
the great and frequent Communication there
was, in former Times, between England and
Italy, when this Nation was subject to the
Pope of Rome: For then all Ecclesiastical
Controversies, Confirmations of Priests, Abbots
and Bishops, in their several Benefices, were
to be solemnized and ratified by Rome's spiritual
</page>

<page sig="A5v">
Trader, the Pope: And, on the other
hand, the Pope sent hither many of his Crea&shy;
tures, Italians, for the better collecting of his
Peter's Pence; as also for their Preferment to
Bishopricks, Vicarages, &amp;c.

Though the Danes did, in some part sub&shy;
due England, yet we are little beholding to
them for the Corruption we now labour under,
except it be in the North and West of England;
which they subdued almost two hundred Years
before the rest of the Nation came in to their
Obedience; and when they had it, they did not
possess it above forty Years before the Normans
disturb'd them in their Enjoyments.

In a Word, All Words almost (except such as
come from the French and Latin, with their Ad&shy;&shy;
herents) owe their Original to the English-Saxon
and Low-Dutch, Dialects of the ancient Ger&shy;
man; for Spain did very little contribute there&shy;
to, except that some few Words have crept in by
Commerce, which are only useful to such as
trade thither.

Now, lest any one, more ignorant, should
not be perswaded of the vast Alterations,
and sometimes total Changes that have been
made in our Language, since this Isle was
first discover'd, let him read some of our
</page>

<page sig="A6r">
Chronicles of England, and he will be con&shy;
vinc'd of the necessity thereof; for the Saxons
did endeavour the total Destruction of the
Inhabitants, and did effect it, saving some
few that fled to the Mountains of Wales and
Cornwall, as is said before: And then is it
not reasonable to conjecture, that the Language,
the Ancient British (save what was preserv'd as
before, who, by a Law of the Conqueror, were
prohibited Intercourse with the Saxons) must
die with the People; and a new one, namely the
Saxon, be introduced in its stead?

I have many things to alledge in defence of
the Weakness and Inequality of this Perfor&shy;
mance; as namely, its being collected at di&shy;
vers times, and in haste, because of my other
more necessary Business; as also, its being prin&shy;
ted from a foul Copy, and the like; which first
may have alter'd the Style, and the two last
let many things pass Muster, which, upon more
mature deliberation, would not: But I hope
the discreet Reader will pass by such Failures,
without carping at them (as considering that
no Man is infallible;) and as for the Igno&shy;
rant and Envious, I value not their Censures;
but, with Martial, <term lang="la">In invidum</term>, count them un&shy;
fit for Humane Society.
</page>

<page sig="A6v">
<term lang="la">Qui ducis vultus, &amp; non legis ista libenter,
Omnibus invideas, invide; nemo tibi.</term>

I have nothing more to beg, but the kind
Reader's Charity for the Faults of the Press,
which, I hope, may consist chiefly in Literals,
and so may be the more easily mended with a
Pen; and that he would not be offended at the
unpleasantness of the Style, but rather consider
what the Subject will bear.
</page>

<page sig="A7r">
<heading>Rules whereby to know when a Word
is derived from the Latin, and
how it may be made Latin again;
composed to prevent the Book's
growing to too great a Bulk.</heading>

1. MOst Words in English, ending in nee, or
cy, are derived from the Latin,
ending in tia; as, <term lang="la">Temperantia, Clementia</term>; Tem&shy;
perance, Clemency, &amp;c.

2. Words ending in ion in English, are made Latin by&shy;
casting away n; as, Question, <term lang="la">Quaestio</term>;
Religion, <term lang="la">Religio</term>, &amp;c.

3. Words ending in ty, are made Latin, by
changing ty into tas; as, Liberty, <term lang="la">Libertas</term>;
Charity, <term lang="la">Charitas</term>, &amp;c.

4. Words ending in ude, are derived from the
Latin, by changing o into e; as, Fortitude, <term lang="la">For&shy;
titudo</term>; Gratitude, <term lang="la">Gratitudo</term>, &amp;c.

5. Words ending in d, denoting the order
or manner of a thing, the said Words being Ad&shy;
jectives, are made Latin, by adding us; as Ri&shy;
gid, Putrid; <term lang="la">Rigidus, Putridus</term>, &amp;c.
</page>

<page sig="A7v">
6. Words having t, n, or r, in the end, be&shy;
tween two Vowels, are made Latin, by changing
the last Vowel into us, being Adjectives; as,
Mute, Obscene, Obscure; <term lang="la">Mutus, Obsc&oelig;nus, Ob&shy;
scurus</term>.

 7. Most Words ending in nt, are made Latin,
by changing nt into ns; as, Latent, <term lang="la">Latens</term>;
Vigilant, <term lang="la">Vigilans</term>, &amp;c.

8. Many English Words ending in al, by ad&shy;
ding is, are made Latin Adjectives; as, Liberal,
<term lang="la">Liberalis</term>; Substantial, <term lang="la">Substantialis</term>, &amp;c.
</page>
</section>

<page sig="A8r">

<page sig="B1r">
<section type="Dictionary">
<heading>THE 
ETYMOLOGY 
OF THE 
English Tongue.</heading>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="A"><alpha>A</alpha>
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="a(n)">A,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Vowel that is often
superfluous in the be&shy;
ginning of words; as in
Arise, abide, abate, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abaisance(n)">Abaisance;</form> <xpln lang="en">which we falsly write
Obeisance, as if it came from the French <etym lang="fr">Obeisance,</etym> when
really it comes from <etym lang="fr">Abbaisser,</etym>
which signifies, to depress, or make an humble inclination
of the body; as we do, when
we do Abaisance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abandon(v)">Abandon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
French <etym lang="fr">Abandonner,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Abandonare;</etym>
if it may not better,
and likelier be drawn from the
Anglo-saxonick <etym lang="oe">Abannan</etym>,
that is, publickly to dis-inhe&shy;
rit: Or, which is most likely,
from our own word <etym lang="en">Bann,</etym>
or the Belgick <etym lang="bl">Bannen,</etym> that
is, to lie under a Curse, the <term lang="la">A
Otiosa</term>, or superfluous, being
added.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abase(v)">Abase,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Abbaisser,</etym>
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Abbassare,</etym> or the
Span. <etym lang="sp">Abaxar;</etym> to lessen, to
keep under.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abash(v)">Abash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Esbahir,</etym> to
affrighten; which comes from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Expaveo:</etym> If it
be not likelier from the Spanish
<etym lang="sp">Abaxar,</etym> to keep under; be&shy;
cause Inferiours are usually
abash'd, when suddainly ac&shy;
costed by Superiors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abate(v)">Abate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Abbattre, abatre,</etym>
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Abattere,</etym> or
the Spanish <etym lang="sp">Abatir;</etym> which in
one sence, signifie, to beat down; in another, to sub&shy;
stract, as in Arithmetick. The reverend Dr. Honywood de&shy;
rives it from the Privative A,
</page>

<page sig="B1v">
and the Belgick <etym lang="bl">Baete;</etym> which
signifies Profit, or Interest;
because by diminishing a thing,
it becomes less profitable. Let
the Curious judge, which is best to follow. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abbot(n)">Abbot,</form> <xpln lang="en">Anglo-saxonick <etym lang="oe">Abbud,
abbod</etym>, and <term lang="oe">abbad</term>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Abd,
abt,</etym> Teutonick <etym lang="tt">Abt,</etym> Fr. <etym lang="fr">Abbe,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Abbate,</etym> Spanish <etym lang="sp">Abad,</etym>
Lat. <etym lang="la">Abbas.</etym> It may seem to
be deduced from the Heb. <etym lang="het">Ab,</etym>
or Syr. <etym lang="syt">Abba,</etym> Father; which
an Abbot properly is: But, to be sure, we have it, by a small
corruption, from the English-&shy;
Saxon <etym lang="oe">Abbod,</etym> which signifies
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abridge(v)">Abbridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Abbreger,</etym>
and that from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Abbreviare,</etym> to curtail, or
make shorter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abet(v)">Abet,</form> <xpln lang="en">which, I think,
may not incommodiously
come from the Lat. Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">Ad</etym> to, and <etym lang="en">bet;</etym>
which, in composition, signi&shy;
fies, to stand by one, or
bet on ones side; and therefore
should seem to be right spell'd
Abbet; If it may not be de&shy;
duced from <etym lang="en">a</etym> priv. and the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Barten,</etym> to profit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abide(v)">Abide,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Abidan,
Bidan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beyden,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Badare,</etym> to subsist, stay, or
tarry; which may all of them,
perhaps, come from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, to inhabit, or dwell.
The word metaphorically sig&shy;
nifies, to endure or suffer any
hardship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="above(pp)">Above,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bufan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boven,</etym> and the super&shy;
fluous, particle <etym lang="en">a,</etym> and both
again from the AS. <term lang="oe">Ufan</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="about(adv)">About,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Abutan</etym>,
which is compounded of <etym lang="oe">ab,</etym>
from, and <etym lang="oe">utan</etym>, without,
abroad, the last, or extremi&shy;
ty; from whence comes the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Buyten</etym>, which signifies
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abroad(adv)">Abroad,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the superfluous Par&shy;
ticle <etym lang="en">a,</etym> and <etym lang="en">broad:</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abstain(v)">Abstain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Abstehen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Af-stain;</etym> which
signifie; to stand off from: If
it may not more commodi&shy;
ously be drawn from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Abstineo;</etym> which I incline to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="abuct(v)">Abuct,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Aboutir;</etym>
which signifies, to oppose, or
confront.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accompany(v)">Accompany,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Company,</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accomplish(v)">Accomplish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Accom&shy;
plir,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Accompire;</etym> if it
may not be better done from the <etym lang="la">Decomposit</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Adcom&shy;
plere,</etym> thoroughly to finish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="account(v)">Accompt, or Account,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Accompter,</etym> or the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Adcomputare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accord(v)">Accord,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Accorder,</etym>
the Ital. and Spanish Noun
<etym lang="sp">Accordo,</etym> the Lat. <etym lang="la">Accordare;</etym>
which all signifie, to agree, or
consent: But I think it is bet&shy;
ter deduced from the Lat.
Praep. <etym lang="la">ad,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Chorda,</etym> the
string of a musical Instru&shy;
ment, because they ought to
agree or accord in harmony:
</page>

<page sig="B2r">
And this is easily done, by ta&shy;
king away <etym lang="la">h</etym> in <etym lang="la">chorda,</etym> and
changing <etym lang="la">ad</etym> into <etym lang="la">ac,</etym> as is fre&shy;
quent in Composition. Hence
come our According, and Ac&shy;
cordingly. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accost(v)">Accost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Accoster,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Accostare,</etym> to draw near
one: It may not inelegantly be fetch'd from the Lat. pr&aelig;p.
<etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Costa</etym> a rib; which,
by a Synecdoche <term lang="la">partis pro to&shy;
to</term>, may signifie the whole
side; as Wrestlers do accost
one another, by joining side
to side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="account(v)">Account,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the obsolete Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Acconter,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Accontare,</etym>
to tell, declare, or shew. See
Accompt, and Recount.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accouter(v)">Accouter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Accou&shy;
trer,</etym> to cloath, or apparel; q.
d. Lat. <etym lang="la">Adconsutare,</etym> to tack
on together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accrue(v)">Accrew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Noun <etym lang="fr">Ac&shy;
crue,</etym> an increase, or addition; 
if you cannot, by the help of
a figure or two, deduce it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Accrescere,</etym> to
abound, or increase.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accurse(v)">Accurse,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Curse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="accustom(v)">Accustom,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Custom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ace(n)">Ace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Az;</etym> if you cannot draw it from the barbarous Greek <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&zeta;&#x1F70;&#x03c2;</etym>,
which signifies a
Dy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ache(n)" lexeme="ake(n)">Ach, Ake.</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ace,
Ece</etym>, grief, or pain; which
may be easily derived from
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F02;&chi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, that signifies the same
thing. I think it may most
truly be drawn from the
<etym lang="en">Ache bone,</etym> that part being ve&shy;
ry much subject to a distem&shy;
per called <etym lang="gk">Ischias,</etym> or Hip-&shy;
Gout; which we corruptly
enough call Sciatica.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="acknowledge(v)">Acknowledge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the pr&aelig;p.
<etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnaw</etym>, a con&shy;
tract of <etym lang="oe">Cnawan</etym>, to know,
or Knowledge it self, and <etym lang="oe">Le&shy;
gan</etym>, to put; that is, to put into my knowledge or under&shy;
standing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="acorn(n)">Acorn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aac</etym>, an
Oak, and <etym lang="oe">Cern</etym>, grane, or fruit; from whence flow the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aker, Aecker, Eeckel</etym>;
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eychel, Ecker</etym>,
which all signifie
an Acorn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="acquaint(v)">Acquaint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Accoin&shy;
ter,</etym> to acquire one's friend&shy;
ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="acquest(n)">Acquest,</form> <xpln lang="en">profit, or gain; from
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Acquest,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ac&shy;
quisto,</etym> and all of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Acquisitum, ab Ac&shy;
quiro</etym>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="acquit(v)">Acquit,</form> <xpln lang="en">to absolve, or free; from
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Acquitter,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat.
<etym lang="la">Adquietare,</etym> to make quiet:
So our Aquittance, from Ital.
<etym lang="it">Acquittanza,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="it">Adquie&shy;
tantia,</etym> or a quieting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adamant(a)">Adamant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Greek <etym lang="gk"> &#x1F08;&delta;&#x1F71;&shy;
&mu;&alpha;&#x03c2;</etym>, which comes from the
Privative &alpha; and <etym lang="gk">&delta;&alpha;&mu;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to
tame, by reason of its insupe&shy;
rable hardness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adder(n)">Adder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aetter</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Adder,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Matter,</etym> C.
Br. <etym lang="cb">Meidr,</etym> Dan <etym lang="da">Eder;</etym> which
all signifie the same thing.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="addle egg(n)">An Addle Egg</form> <xpln lang="en">AS. <etym lang="oe">Adel</etym>, a
disease, <etym lang="oe">Adlian</etym>, to be sick,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a sick, or rotten Egg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="address(v)">Address,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. <etym lang="fr">Addresser,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ad&shy;
drizzare,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat.
<etym lang="la">Addire&shy;
ctare;</etym> because all our prayers and arguments are directed to
some particular thing or per&shy;
son.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adieu(ex)">Adieu,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. <etym lang="fr">Adieu,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Adio,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Adios,</etym> farewel: <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<term lang="la">Ad Deum te commendo</term>, I
commend you to God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjourn(v)">Adjourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Jour,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giorno,</etym>
a day; which, not unlikely, comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Diur&shy;
num,</etym> daily.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjoining(a)">Adjoining,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Adjoin&shy;
dre,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Adjungere,</etym> to join
to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjudge(v)">Adjudge,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Iudge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adjust(v)">Adjust or Make even Accounts;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Adjuster,</etym> to ac&shy;
commodate, or fit to; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Adjustare,</etym> to make even
Accounts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="admiral(n)">Admiral,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Arabick <etym lang="ar">E&shy;
mir,</etym> a Lord, or Commander,
and the Greek <etym lang="gk">&#x1F03;&lambda;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, belong&shy;
ing to the Sea; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Prince
of the Sea: It may, not un&shy;
likely, be drawn from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ampt, meir, al;</etym> Office,
Sea, whole; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that hath
the sole Command of the Sea. Minsevus takes it from <etym lang="tt">Aen,
meer al;</etym> above, Sea, the whole;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  over the whole Sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ado(n)">Ado.</form> <xpln lang="en">with much ado; from the
Verb <etym lang="en">do.</etym> or <etym lang="en">act,</etym> and the ini&shy;
tial Particle <etym lang="en">A.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="advance(v)">Advance,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. <etym lang="fr">Avancer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">A&shy;
vanzare,</etym> to move profit, or
go forward; from <etym lang="la">ab</etym> and <etym lang="la">an&shy;
te</etym>; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  from what one was
before; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  from an inferior
degree to an higher.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="advantage(n)">Advantage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Avan&shy;
tage,</etym> profit, or help.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="adventure(v)">To adventure,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Adven&shy;
turare;</etym> as <etym lang="la">Adventura,</etym> or <etym lang="la">E&shy;
ventura,</etym> understand <etym lang="la">Fortuna,</etym> or
<etym lang="la">Hora.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="advertise(v)">Advertise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Adver&shy;
tere,</etym> to admonish, teach tho&shy;
roughly, or make sure of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="advice(n)">Advice, or Advise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Advis,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Aviso,</etym>
Counsel, or Opinion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="affair(n)">Affair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Affaire,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Affare,</etym> a business, or employ;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Adfacere,</etym> tied to do
a thing that lies upon me to
be done.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="affiance(n)">Affiance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Affiance,</etym>
faith, or trust.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="afford(v)">Afford,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Furdern,
Fordern:</etym> It may be also
brought from the Particle
<etym lang="en">A,</etym> or rather, the Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym>
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bord, a table;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to allow victuals for the
table.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="afraid(a)">Affraid, or Afraid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Effrayer, Effroyer,</etym> to scare,
or terrifie. I could willingly
deduce it from the Lat. Pr&aelig;p.
<etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and our English word
<etym lang="en">Fear,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Fear'd.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="affranchise(v)">Affranchise,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Enfranchise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="affright(v)">Affright,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our initial Par&shy;
ticle <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Fright;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="affront(v)">Affront,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. <etym lang="fr">Affront,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Af&shy;
fronto,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Afrenta,</etym> all sig&shy;
nifying the same thing; as if one
should say in Lat. <etym lang="la">Adfrontare,</etym>
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  set front against front, or
oppose one to the face.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="afore(pp)">Afore,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="afresh(adv)">Afresh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the initial <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Fresh;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aft(adv)" lexeme="abaft(adv)">Aft, and Abaft,</form> <xpln lang="en">Sea-terms, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aeftan</etym>, behind, or
after; that is, the hinder part
of the Ship. Somnerus useth
the word <etym lang="oe">Baeftan</etym> in the
same sence; a contract, as I
suppose, of <etym lang="oe">Abaeftan</etym>, to
which, by taking of the two
last Letters, we owe the Ori&shy;
ginal of our
Abaft.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="'after(adv)">After,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eft,
Aefter, Aeftan,</etym> after;
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Achter,</etym> after; Run and
Dan. <etym lang="da">Efter,</etym> the ancient Teut.
<etym lang="tt">After.</etym> Dr. Mer. Cas. ingeni&shy;
ously fetches it from the Greek
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&upsilon;&tau;&#x1F70;&rho;</etym>, <etym lang="la">Caeter&ugrave;m.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="again(adv)">Again,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Agen,</etym>
again; and both ours and the AS. from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eac</etym>, or
<etym lang="oe">Aec,</etym> again, and <etym lang="oe">Ana,</etym> toge&shy;
ther, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one after another immediately.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="against(pp)">Against,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Agen</etym>,
<etym lang="oe">Ogen</etym>, opposite to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aghast(a)">Agast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the superfluous Par&shy;
ticle <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gast</etym>,
a Spirit, Spectre, or Shadow;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  frighted with the sight of
some, Spectre, or Ghost. It may not unlikely be drawn
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&#x1F71;&zeta;&shy;
&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to wonder with horrour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agate-stone(n)">Agate-stone,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&chi;&#x1F71;&shy;
&tau;&upsilon;&#x03c2;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agnail(n)">Agnail:</form> <xpln lang="en">Somnerus does ingeni&shy;
ously derive it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ange</etym>, vexed, and <etym lang="oe">Naegle,</etym>
a Nail; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a pained Nail. It may very well be drawn from
<etym lang="la">Ad</etym> to, and our English <etym lang="en">Nail,</etym>
because it grows by the nails
of one's feet; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a nail to a
nail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ago(adv)">Ago,</form> <xpln lang="en">as we say, long ago, is ma&shy;
nifestly derived from <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">go;</etym> which see. There is an
AS. word, which signifies, By-past, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Agan,</etym>, from
which it possibly may come.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agony(n)">Agony,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&omega;&nu;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>,
whose root signifies, a stri&shy;
ving, or conflict, as people in
an Agony have.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="agree(v)">Agree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Aggreer;</etym>
but I think, more likely from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad</etym> and <etym lang="la">Gratum;</etym> q.
d. grateful, or acceptable to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aggrieve(v)">Aggrieve,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Grieve.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ague(n)">Ague,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Aigu,</etym> sharp;
because an Ague, at least, in
the Paroxism, is sharp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ah(ex)">Ah,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Oh;</etym> or, as all
other Interjections, from the
sound that by natural instinct,
one in misery puts forth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aid(v)">Aid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
<etym lang="fr">Aider,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Aiutare,</etym> and both of
them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Adjutare,</etym> to help.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aim(n)">Aim,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Esme,</etym>
a scope, or mark; though not unlike&shy;
ly, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aestimare,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="B3v"> 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  diligently to take heed,
as those that shoot at a Mark do </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="air(n)">Air,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Air,</etym> which
again comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aer,</etym>
and the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&#x1F74;&rho;</etym>, the Air.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ache(n)">Ake,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Ach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="acre(n)">Aker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.<etym lang="oe">Acere,
Aecer, Aeccer,</etym> Belg. and
Teut. <etym lang="bl">Acker,</etym> Fr. Norm. <etym lang="no">Acre,</etym>
a field, ground; also a mea&shy;
sure of ground; commonly deduced from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ager,</etym>
and that from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>.
Right spell'd, cre.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alarm(n)">Alarm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Alarme,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Alarma,</etym> signify&shy;
ing the same thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alas(ex)">Alas,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat <etym lang="la">Lassus</etym> wea&shy;
ry, or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lastare</etym> to relinquish, and the idle Particle
<etym lang="la">A</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Oh me lassum vel
derelictum!</etym> O me, weary or forsaken!</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alate(adv)">Alate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the idle Particle <etym lang="en">A,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Late</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Of late:
Which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="albeit(adv)">Albeit,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  be it all so.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alburn(a)">Alburn-colour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat <etym lang="la">Al&shy;
bus</etym> white, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Bur&shy;
no,</etym> by a Metathesis for <etym lang="it">Bruno,</etym>
brown; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a white Brown.
V. Brown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alchemy(n)">Alchymy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Alch&shy;
ymia,</etym> and that from the Arab.
<etym lang="ar">Al,</etym> and the Gr.<etym lang="gk">&chi;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&chi;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>,
to pour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alcoran(n)">Alcoran,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Al,</etym> and
<etym lang="ar">Koiran,</etym> he read, or collected;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Lecture, or Collection of Precepts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alderman(n)">Alderman,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eal&shy;
derman</etym>, and that from <etym lang="oe">Ael&shy;
dor, aldor,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Aldor,</etym>
older, and <etym lang="oe">Man</etym> man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ale(n)">Ale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.<etym lang="oe">Eale</etym> Run.
Dan. and Dan. rec. <etym lang="da">Oll.</etym> It
may possibly be drawn from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&lambda;&#x1F73;&alpha;</etym>, heat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alegar(n)">Alegar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word in use in Lincoln&shy;
shire, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Ale-eager,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
Sour Ale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alembic(n)">Alembick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Alam&shy;
bic,</etym> by an easie transmuta&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alight(adv)">Alight,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Light.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alike(a)">Alike,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alive(a)">Alive,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Live.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="all(n)">All,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.<etym lang="oe">Ael, Eal,
Ealle, Alle,</etym> Run. Dan. Dan.
rec. &amp; C Br.<etym lang="da">Oll</etym>, <etym lang="cb">All,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Al,</etym> Teut. and Belg <etym lang="bl">Alle,</etym>
the whole, all; all of them from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F4B;&lambda;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allay(v)">Allay,</form> <xpln lang="en">to mitigate, or lenifie, ei&shy;
ther from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Allier,</etym> to
bind, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to fasten, or re&shy;
strain; or from <etym lang="fr">Alleger,</etym> to
alleviate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allegiance(n)">Allegiance,</form> <xpln lang="en">or the faith that we
owe to the King; no doubt,
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Alligare</etym> to bind;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a tying, or binding; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the Bond of Faith due from
Subjects to Princes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alley(n)">Alley,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">All&eacute;e</etym> a
narrow Street.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ally(n)">An Ally,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Allie,</etym>
a Relation; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Adli&shy;
gatus,</etym> bound to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alliance(n)">Alliance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Alli&shy;
ance;</etym> which signifies, a con&shy;
federacy, or compact.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="B4r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allot(v)">To Allot,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="la">Ad</etym> and <etym lang="en">Lot;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allow(v)">Allow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Allo&uuml;er,</etym>
to approve.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alloy(n)">Alloy, or Allay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Aloy,</etym> a mixture of the coursest
of any thing with the best.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="allure(v)" lexeme="intice(v)">Allure, or intice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and the Eng. <etym lang="en">Lure;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almanac(n)">Almanack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Al,</etym>
and <etym lang="ar">Manach,</etym> to number ori&shy;
ginally; though possibly, we
may have it from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Al&shy;
manach:</etym> Some derive it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Al-maen-achte,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the Observation of all the
Months.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alms(n)">Alms,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.<etym lang="oe">&AElig;lmes,
&AElig;lmesse</etym>, and that from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&lambda;&epsilon;&mu;&tau;&#x1F77;&nu;&eta;&#x03c2;</etym>, pity, or
compassion; of which, Alms
are the effect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almighty(a)">Almighty,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Mighty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almond(n)">Almond,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A&shy;
mande,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Amandola,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Almendra;</etym> all of which come
from the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="la">Amygda&shy;
lium,</etym> <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&mu;&#x1F7B;&gamma;&delta;&alpha;&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, which sig&shy;
nifie the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almoner(n)">Almoner,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Au&shy;
mosne,</etym> an Alms.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="almost(adv)">Almost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg<etym lang="bl"> Al-meest,</etym>
for the most part, chiefly,
especially: It may be drawn from
our own words, <etym lang="en">All</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Most</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  most part of all.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aloft(a)">Aloft,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.<etym lang="bl">Al-heft,</etym> all
elevate, or sublime: But I think it may, without offence,
be taken from the Northern
word <etym lang="en">Loft,</etym> now in use, signi&shy;
fying, a Room above Stairs, the
initial Particle <etym lang="en">A</etym> being added;
which they not unlikely retain from the
Danish words, <etym lang="da">Loff&shy;
ter, Loffter-op,</etym> and <etym lang="da">Oploffter,</etym>
to elevate, or lift up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="alone(a)">Alone,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.<etym lang="bl">Al-een,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Alloin,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  only one.
See All, and One.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="along(adv)">Along,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our initial <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Long;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aloof(a)">Alooff,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  All-off. See <etym lang="en">All,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Off.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aloud(adv)">Aloud,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Loud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="already(adv)">Already,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg, <etym lang="bl">Alreed,
Alghereed,</etym> quite ready. See
<etym lang="en">All,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ready.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="also(adv)">Also,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lswa</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">All-soo,</etym> altogether so.
See <etym lang="en">All,</etym> and <etym lang="en">So.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="although(s)">Although;</form> <xpln lang="en">see <etym lang="en">All,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Though.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="altogether(adv)">Altogether,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Alte&shy;
gader,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  all in one colle&shy;
ctively. V. <etym lang="en">All, Together,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Gather.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="always(adv)">Always</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ealle&shy;
w&aelig;ga</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Allweg</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  by
all ways.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="be(v)">Am,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eom</etym>, which
may be derived from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&iota;&mu;&iota;</etym>, I am.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amadetto(n)">Amadetto</form> <xpln lang="en">Pear. Evelyn derives
it from one <etym lang="la">Amad&aelig;us,</etym> or <etym lang="la">A&shy;
madettus,</etym> that first grafted it,
or, at least, was an <emend err="extraordidinary">extraordinary</emend> lover of that fruit.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Amadetto" antedates first OED entry (1706).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amain(adv)">Amain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the idle Particle <etym lang="en">A</etym>
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;gan</etym> power;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  with all his force.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amass(v)">Amass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Amasser</etym>
to heap together; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat.
<etym lang="la">Admassare, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amaze(v)">Amaze,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to put one in a
Maze or Labyrinth, from the
idle Particle <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Maze;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amber(a)">Amber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ambre,</etym>
the Ital. and barbarous Lat. <etym lang="la">Ambra;</etym> or if you please, from
the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Ambar,</etym> which sig&shy;
nifies the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambergris(n)">Amber-griese,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Ambre gris,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Am&shy;
bra grigia.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amble(v)">Amble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ambler,</etym>
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ambu&shy;
lare,</etym> which by contraction is
<etym lang="la">Amblare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambry(n)" lexeme="amnry(n)">Ambry, or as North-Country-&shy;
men now speak it, Amnry,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old-fashion'd kind of Cup&shy;
boards; possibly, from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aumoire,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambury(n)">Ambury,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in Horses legs;
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Embe</etym>,
or Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&mu;&phi;&#x1F76;</etym>, about, and
<etym lang="oe">Beorg</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Berg</etym>, metapho&shy;
rically, a bump or swelling in
the body; but properly, a little rising in the ground, ar&shy;
tificial or natural.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambush(v)">Ambush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
buschir,</etym> to lay in wait privily
to catch or intrap one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amell(n)">Amell, or Ammel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Email,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amends(n)">Amends,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A&shy;
mende,</etym> which comes from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Emendare,</etym> to mend, or
make amends.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amerce(v)">Amerce,</form> <xpln lang="en">possibly from the an&shy;
cient Fr. Norm. <etym lang="no">Amercier,</etym> or
from the Fr. G. &amp; Ang. <etym lang="oe">Merci,
Mercie.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amiable(a)">Amiable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Amia&shy;
ble,</etym> of the same signification.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amiss(adv)">Amiss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Amissus,</etym>
lost; or more nearly, from
the English Verb, To <etym lang="en">Miss,</etym>
the idle initial Particle <etym lang="en">A</etym> being
added. V. Miss.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amity(n)">Amity,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Amitie,</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ami&shy;
citia.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ammunition(n)">Ammunition,</form> <xpln lang="en">Ital. <etym lang="it">Monitione,</etym>
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Munition,</etym>
and the pr&aelig;fix <etym lang="it">Am.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="among(adv)">Among,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
mang</etym>, between; this from
<etym lang="oe">Gemengan</etym>, Belg. and Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Mengen,</etym> to mingle; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
mingledly. v. Mingle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amorous(a)">Amorous,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Amo&shy;
reux,</etym> given to love; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat.
<etym lang="la">Amorosus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amort(adv)" lexeme="all amort(adv)">Amort, All-amort,</form> <xpln lang="en">as we say of a
Man as it were in an ecstasie;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Amorti,</etym> part.
of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Amortir,</etym> to mor&shy;
tifie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amount(n)">Amount,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mon&shy;
ter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Montare,</etym> to amount,
(<term lang="la">viz.</term> ) to a price, the idle Ini&shy;
tial Particle <etym lang="en">A</etym> being added.
v. Mount.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amours(n)">Amours,</form> <xpln lang="en">purely from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Amour,</etym> which is manifestly
derived from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Amor.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amper(n)">Amper, or Ampor</form> <xpln lang="en">a word much
used in Essex, denoting Swel&shy;
ling or Inflammation; from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Empor,</etym> upwards;
<etym lang="tt">Empor heven,</etym> to lift up; q.
d. the lifting up of the skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambs-ace(n)">Amm's-ace,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Ace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amulet(n)">Amulet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&mu;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, a
</page>

<page sig="B5r">
double diminutive Termina&shy;
tion being added. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="amuse(v)">Amuse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Amuser,</etym>
to think upon. V. Muse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ancestor(n)">Ancestors,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ance&shy;
stres;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">An&shy;
tecessores.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anchorite(n)">Anchorite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&nu;&alpha;&chi;&omega;&shy;
&rho;&eta;&tau;&#x1F74;&#x03c2;</etym>, (<term lang="la">viz.</term> ) one that goeth a&shy;
part from the Publick, an Hermit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anchoves(n)">Anchoves,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">An&shy;
chois,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Anchiove, Ancio&shy;
ve,</etym> a Loach, or small fish;
perhaps from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ancino,</etym>
an hook.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ancient(a)">Ancient,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ancien,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Anciano,</etym> old, ancient.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anchored(a)">Ancker'd,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Crux Anchore&shy;
tarum</etym>; from whence the
word comes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ankle(n)">Ancle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ancleow</etym>,
Dan. <etym lang="da">Anckle;</etym> and it may not
unfitly be drawn from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&kappa;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, crooked.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="and (c)">And,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">and,</etym> with&shy;
out all doubt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="andirons(n)">And-irons</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Hand-irons</etym>, or
according to Dr. Th. H. <etym lang="en">End&shy;
irons</etym>, because they are put at
the end of the fire. It may not unlikely be drawn from
the A S. <etym lang="oe">Brandiren</etym>,
Br being taken away, partly for
shortness, partly for sound-&shy;
sake.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anent(pp)">Anent,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word still used in the
North of England for Against,
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nean</etym>, near,
and the idle initial Particle
<etym lang="en">A.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="angel of gold(n)">Angel of Gold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the simili&shy;
tude of an Angel formerly
stamp'd upon our Guinneas, al&shy;
luding to that saying of Gre&shy;
gorius, who seeing two young
English Noble-men at the
Court of Rome, asked who they
were, and of what Country:
to whom 'twas answer'd, they
were Angli or English-men:
<term lang="la">Imo potius Angeli</term> Yea rather
(says he) Angels. For this,
consult Bede, Verstegan, and
others. An Angel, or Saint
of the Lord, comes from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Angelus,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&gamma;&shy;
&gamma;&epsilon;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, an Angel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="angelot(n)">Angelot Cheese</form> <xpln lang="en">; so called, as we
may suppose, from some Man,
whose name was <etym lang="it">Angeloto,</etym> or
<etym lang="it">Angelo;</etym> he making it, and
stamping his name on it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anger(n)">Anger,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Ange</etym>, vexed; Teut. <etym lang="tt">Angst,</etym>
vexation; Dan. <etym lang="da">Angrer,</etym> it
grieveth me: They may all be deduced from the barba&shy;
rous Lat. <etym lang="la">Angariare,</etym> to anger
or vex.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="angle(n)">Angle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Angel</etym>,
an hook. Mer. Cas. derives it
from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&kappa;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&eta;</etym>, crookedness;
because when the fish is hook&shy;
ed, the rod bends like to a Se&shy;
micircle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anguish(n)">Anguish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">An&shy;
goisse,</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">An&shy;
gustia,</etym> anxiety: The Teut.
is <etym lang="tt">Angst,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Angost,</etym>
which signifie the same
thing.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annoy(v)">Annoy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Annoiare,</etym>
to molest; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Adno&shy;
xare,</etym> to bring damage to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="annulet(n)">Annulets,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Diminutive
<etym lang="la">Annuli,</etym> little Rings, the di&shy;
minutive Termination <etym lang="la">et</etym> be&shy;
ing added.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anoint(v)">Anoint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oindre,</etym>
whence <etym lang="la">Enoindre</etym>; so that,
possibly, it should be Enoint,
to chafe in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anon(adv)">Anon,</form> <xpln lang="en">or presently; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">On
on,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  by succession present&shy;
ly after the word spoke: Most likely from the Particle <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nean</etym>, near; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  I
come presently.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="answer(v)">Answer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">And&shy;
sware</etym>, and that from <etym lang="oe">An</etym> for
On and <etym lang="oe">Swar</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Sw&aelig;r</etym>, se&shy;
rious; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to affirm a thing
seriously, or in earnest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ant(n)" lexeme="emmet(n)">Ant, or Emet</form> <xpln lang="en">corrupted
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aemet, Em&shy;
et</etym>, a Pismire. For a fur&shy;
ther derivation of it, consult
Skinner in his learned Etymo&shy;
logicon. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antelope(n)">Antelope,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&nu;&tau;&#x1F76;</etym> a&shy;
gainst, and <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F79;&phi;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, a neck;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Creature whose horns wreath back towards the neck,
and therefore is in Greek cal&shy;
led <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&epsilon;&phi;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F73;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anthem(n)">Anthem,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&nu;&tau;&phi;&#x1F7D;&nu;&eta;</etym>, says
Menagius, because of its be&shy;
ing sung or said alternately:
From <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&nu;&theta;&eta;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, says Minse&shy;
vus. I rather incline to think
it came from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&nu;&theta;&upsilon;&mu;&nu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym> i. 
e. hymn against hymn, alter&shy;
nately, of Priest and People;
from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&nu;&tau;&#x1F18;</etym> against, and <etym lang="gk">&#x1F5B;&mu;&shy;
&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> an hymn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saint Anthony's fire(n)">St. Anthony's fire,</form> <xpln lang="en">superstitiously
so called, because it was belie&shy;
<emend err="lie"></emend>ved that St. <etym lang="en">Anthony</etym> of Pa&shy;
tavia had a miraculous Art in
curing of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antics(n)">Anticks,</form> <xpln lang="en">certainly a corruption
of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Antiquus:</etym> Cut
with Anticks, <term lang="la">Sculptum figu&shy;
ris antiquis</term>: To dance An&shy;
ticks, <term lang="la">Choreas ducere Anti&shy;
quo more</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anticor(n)">Anticor,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in Horses; for
which see Markham; derived
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&nu;&tau;&#x1F76;</etym> against,
and <etym lang="la">Cor,</etym> an heart; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a dis&shy;
ease that only infests the heart,
called in Lat. <etym lang="la">Morbus Anti&shy;
cardiacus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antimony(n)">Antimony,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Mineral
amongst Chymists: In bar&shy;
barous Lat. it is <etym lang="la">Antimonium,</etym>
but by the true Lat. called
<etym lang="la">Stibium;</etym> by the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&#x1F77;&mu;&mu;&iota;</etym>:
It certainly comes from the
Arab. <etym lang="ar">Atimad,</etym> signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="antler(n)">Antlers,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Brow-antlers, per&shy;
haps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Andouil&shy;
lers;</etym> that is, the first knags
or branches in the horns of a
young Stag.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anvil(n)">Anvil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aenfilt,
Anfilt</etym>, the same; which
may derive from <etym lang="oe">An</etym> for On,
above, and the Verb <etym lang="oe">Feallan</etym>
to fall, because the Hammer
very oft, as it were, falls upon
the Anvil.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="any(a)">Any,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Anig, E&shy;
nig</etym>, and those from a Root of the same Language, <etym lang="oe">An</etym>,
one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apace(adv)">Apace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the initial <etym lang="en">A,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Pace;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apart(adv)">Apart,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A-part,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">A-parte,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ape(n)">Ape,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Apa</etym>, Dan.
<etym lang="da">Abe,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aep,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Aff,</etym>
the Welsh <etym lang="cb">Eppa;</etym> and all these
possibly from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&phi;&#x1F74;</etym>, a
touch; because an Ape is
thought to be the quickest to
perceive the touch, of any
creature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apostume (v)">Apostume,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Impostume.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apothecary(n)">Apothecary,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A&shy;
pothecaire;</etym> but most certain&shy;
ly, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&pi;&omicron;&theta;&#x1F75;&kappa;&eta;</etym>, a
Repository, because they put
up all their Medicines in Boxes,
Pots, Vials, &amp;c. from the Verb
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&pi;&omicron;&tau;&#x1F77;&theta;&eta;&mu;&iota;</etym>, to hide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appair(v)">Appair,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Impair.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appal(v)">Appal,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to affright; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Appalir,</etym> to grow pale,
as people in a fright. Chaucer
useth it for Decay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apparel(n)">Apparel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Appa&shy;
reil,</etym> and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad</etym>
to, and <etym lang="la">Parilis</etym> fit; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  made
fit to the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apartment(n)">Appartment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ap&shy;
partamento,</etym> a particular place &shy;
in an house divided from the
rest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appay(v)">Appay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Appagare,</etym>
to satisfie. I had rather deduce
it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad</etym> to, and
<etym lang="la">Pacare,</etym> to appease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appeach(v)">Appeach,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Impeach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appease(v)">Appease;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Appai&shy;
ser; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  </etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Appacare,</etym> or
<etym lang="la">Adpacare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appanage(n)">Appennage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Adpa&shy;
nagium,</etym> and that of <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and 
<etym lang="la">Panis.</etym> Spelman derives it 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Appendage,</etym> 
an Appendix.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appertain(v)">Appertain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
partenir</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat.
<etym lang="la">Adpertinere,</etym> to belong unto.
Hence the word Appurtenan&shy;
ces; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apple(n)">Apple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Apl,
Aepple, Aepl, Epl,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Appel,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ipffel,</etym> Dan <etym lang="da">Eb&shy;
le.</etym> I would draw it from
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&pi;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, soft or tender.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apply(v)">Apply,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the obsolete Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Applier,</etym> the same; or rather,
from the Lat. Pr<term lang="la">p.</term> <etym lang="la">Ad</etym> to,
and <etym lang="en">Ply,</etym> from <etym lang="la">Plicare</etym> to bend
or incline which way one
would have it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appoint(v)">Appoint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
pointer, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appose(v)">Appose,</form> <xpln lang="en">I suppose, for <etym lang="en">Oppose,</etym>
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Opponere, i&shy;
dem.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apprentice(n)">Apprentice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
prenti,</etym> that from the Verb
<etym lang="fr">Apprendre,</etym> and which is ma&shy;
nifestly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Appre&shy;
hendere,</etym> to apprehend; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
be of judgment to learn ones
Trade.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="approach(v)">Approach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
procher,</etym> this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Adproximare,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Adpropia&shy;
re,</etym> to come near to, or make
to pertain to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="appurtenance(n)">Appurtenance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
</page>

<page sig="B6v"> 
<etym lang="fr">Appartenance;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad&shy;
pertinentia,</etym> things belongi&shy;
ng to any person or thing. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apricot(n)">Apricocks,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A&shy;
bricots,</etym> and ought rather to
be spell'd Apricots in English;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Mala praecocia.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="apron(n)">Apron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aforan</etym>,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  English <etym lang="en">Afore one;</etym> from
whence, I suppose, proceeds
the Corruption.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arbor(n)">Arbour,</form> <xpln lang="en">possibly from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Arboretum;</etym> though the learn'd
and ingenious T.H. thinks it to
be so called, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Air-bower:</etym>
But because Chaucer useth the
word Herber in the same sence,
the industrious Dr. Skinner
thinks it rather comes from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hereberga</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Herberghe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herberg,</etym> a
Mansion; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Lodge made
of Trees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arch(n)">Arch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&rho;&chi;&omega;&nu;</etym>, a
Prince or Governor; first u&shy;
sed by the Romans; as a Pr&aelig;&shy;
fix, in the declining state of
the Empire; thus, Arch-duke,
Arch-knave, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arch(n)">Arch</form> <xpln lang="en">or Vault, manifestly from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Arcus,</etym> a Bow; from
the similitude.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="archer(n)">Archer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Archer,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Archiero,</etym> a shooter of
Arrows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="architrave(n)">Architrave,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture, from the Fr. G. and I&shy;
tal. <etym lang="it">Architrave.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="argent(n)">Argent,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry for
White, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Argen&shy;
tum</etym> Silver, and that from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&rho;&gamma;&upsilon;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; all of them
from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&rho;&gamma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; white.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aright(adv)">Aright,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the initial Particle
<etym lang="en">A,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Right;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arise(v)">Arise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the same initial <etym lang="en">A,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Rise;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arm(n)">Arm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eorm,
Earm</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Arm,</etym> and <etym lang="da">Arm-&shy;
hul,</etym> whence our Arm-hole; Belg. <etym lang="bl">Arm; Arm ter zee</etym>, an
Arm or Creek of the Sea; all
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Armus,</etym>
and that from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&rho;&mu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>,
from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to fit, as the arm
is fitted to the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="armada(n)">Armada,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Arma&shy;
ta,</etym> sup. <etym lang="la">Classis;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Navy
arm'd or mann'd: A word
purely Spanish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arm(n)">Arms,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word common to us,
with the French, from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Arma;</etym> because formerly
the Ensigns of Honour were
graven upon their Shields.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="armor(n)">Armorer,</form> <xpln lang="en">or maker of Arms;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Armorier.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="armory(n)">Armory,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Armoi&shy;
rie;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Armarium,</etym> a
place where Arms are preser&shy;
ved.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="armor(n)">Armour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ar&shy;
miere, Armure, Armeure;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Armatura,</etym> from
<etym lang="la">Arma,</etym> Arms.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arquebus(n)">Arquebuss,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Harquebuss.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrand(n)">Arrand,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Errand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrange(v)">Arrange,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ar&shy;
ranger,</etym> to put in order; this
from the Pr&aelig;p <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and the
Noun <etym lang="oe">Rang</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Rank</etym>, O&shy;
rder. v. Rank.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrant(a)">Arrant,</form> <xpln lang="en">as we say, Arrant Rogue:
</page>

<page sig="B7r"> 
It may, 'tis possible, be deri&shy;
ved from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Errant;</etym>
and so it signifies as much as
Vagabond-Rogue. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arras(n)">Arras,</form> <xpln lang="en">Ital. <etym lang="it">Arrazzi,</etym> from the
Metropolis <etym lang="it">Artois,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Arras;</etym>
where the people, named in
Lat. <term lang="la">Atrebates</term>, are famous
for making of Arras: In Lat.
<term lang="la">Atrebata</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="array(v)">Array,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Arroy,</etym> or&shy;
der; though Minshew draws
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&rho;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to fit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrears(n)">Arrears,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Arrie&shy;
rage</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Adre&shy;
tro</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to behind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrearages(n)">Arrearages,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Arrears.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrest(v)">Arrest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Arrester;</etym>
though I think it may well enough be drawn from the
Lat. Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and our <etym lang="en">Rest;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the case being decided
before a Judge or Umpire,
both parties are at quiet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrive(v)">Arrive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Arri&shy;
ver;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Adripare,</etym> to
come to shoar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arrow(n)">Arrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;rwe,
Arwe</etym>, the same; this from a
Root in the same Language,
<term lang="la">viz.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Gearwian</etym>, to prepare,
or make ready.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arse(n)">Ars,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ears</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eers, Aers,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Arsz,</etym>
It hath allusion to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&rho;&shy;
&chi;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, the Fundament, or Arse&shy;
gut, because principal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arsenal(n)">Arsenal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Arsenale;</etym>
but according to Minsevus,
<term lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F70; 
&tau;&#x1F78; &#x1F08;&rho;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu; &tau;&alpha;&#x1FD6;&#x03c2; &nu;&alpha;&upsilon;&sigma;&#x1F76;</term>,
from helping and defending of the Navy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arsy-versy(a)">Arse-versy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A-&shy;
Revers.</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">A Rinverso;</etym>
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad inversum,</etym>
Topsy-turvy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="be(v)">Art,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eart</etym>, thou
art.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="artichoke(n)">Artechoak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ar&shy;
tichault, Artichaud,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Artichoca,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Artischock,
Artsthock.</etym> Salmasius draws it
from a Greek Fountain; <term lang="la">viz.</term>  
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&rho;&tau;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F71;&kappa;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="artillery(n)">Artillery:</form> <xpln lang="en">Menagius draws it
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Artiller,</etym> to
furnish with Arms.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="artisan(n)">Artisan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Arti&shy;
san;</etym> which comes from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ars,</etym> Art.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="artist(n)">Artist,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Artisan.</xpln></wordentry>
