<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="as(adv)">As,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Als,</etym>
l being taken out for sound-sake.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ascertain(v)">Ascertain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Acer&shy;
tener,</etym> and that from the Lat.
Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Certus,</etym> sure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ash(n)">Ash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Acse, Aese</etym>,
Dan. <etym lang="da">Ask, Aske,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Esch:</etym>
It may be derived from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&nu;&omega;</etym>,
to kindle; because it easily
takes fire, and is very hot
when kindled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ashamed(a)">Ashamed,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Shame.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ash(n)">Ashes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ashan</etym>,
the same; Belg. &amp; Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Asche.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ash Wednesday(n)">Ash-Wednesday,</form> <xpln lang="en">without doubt,
corrupted from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Asche-woens-dach;</etym> the French
call it <term lang="fr">Le jour des cendres</term>,
the Day of Ashes; because of
sprinkling themselves there&shy;
with, in token of Repen&shy;
tance.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aside(adv)">Aside,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ask(v)">Ask,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ascian,
Acscian, Aescian, Ahsi&shy;
an, Axian, Geacsian</etym>, to
interrogate, or question: You
may derive it, if you please,
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&zeta;&iota;&#x1F79;&omega;</etym>, to re&shy;
quire, or expostulate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="askew(adv)">A-skew,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Skew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asleep(adv)">A-sleep,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Sleep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="a-slope(a)">A-slope,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Slope.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asp(n)" lexeme="aspen(n)">Asp, or Aspen-tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;sp, Espe</etym>; it always
trembles: 
In Lat. <term lang="la">Populus
Arbor, seu Populus tremula</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asquint(adv)">A-squint,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Squint.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ass(n)">Ass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Assa</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assail(v)">Assail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Assailler;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="fr">Adsalire,</etym> to leap upon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assassinate(v)">Assassinate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="fr">Assas&shy;
sinare,</etym> murtherously to assault.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assault(n)">Assault,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Assault,</etym>
or Ital. <etym lang="it">Assalto,</etym> the same; q.
d. Lat. <etym lang="la">Adsaltare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assay(v)">Assay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Essay:</etym>
But I rather incline to think it
might come from the Lat.
Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and the old Verb
<etym lang="la">Sagire;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to aspire to be
wise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assemble(v)">Assemble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">As&shy;
sembler,</etym> and that from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Simul,</etym> together;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Adsimulare,</etym> to gather
together in a body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assess(v)"  lexeme="sess(v)">Assess, or Sess,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Assessare,</etym> if not from <etym lang="it">Asses&shy;
sus,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Concessus,</etym> assent, or
consent; because the Men
on whom an Assessment is
made, give their assent to pay
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assiege(v)">Assiege,</form> <xpln lang="en">v Besiege.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assizes(n)">Assizes, or, Sizes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Assise,</etym> and that from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Assidere,</etym> from the Judges
sitting upon the Bench to hear
Trials.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assoil(v)">Assoil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Assoul&shy;
dre,</etym> and that from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Absolvere,</etym> to free, or let go
at liberty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assort(v)">Assort,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Sort.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assure(v)">Assure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Asseurer,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Assicurare;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat.
<etym lang="la">Adsecurare,</etym> so to demonstrate
a thing, as to leave no room for doubt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="assuage(v)">Asswage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and
<etym lang="la">Suadeo;</etym> that is, to appease or
pacifie by perswasion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astonish(v)">Astonish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eston&shy;
ner;</etym> but more likely from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Attonitus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="a-straddle(adv)">A-stradle,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Stradle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astray(adv)">Astray,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Stray.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="astride(adv)">Astride,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Stride.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="asunder(adv)">Asunder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Asun&shy;
dran, Asundron</etym>, and that
from the Verb <etym lang="oe">Aswyndrian</etym>
to separate, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sonderen,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Absondern,</etym> the same. v.
Sundry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="at(pp)">At,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;t</etym>, and
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="achieve(v)">Atchieve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Atche&shy;
ver,</etym> to perfect a thing under&shy;
taken.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attach(v)">Attach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Atta&shy;
cher</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the
barbarous Lat. <etym lang="la">Attaxare,</etym> or
<etym lang="la">Attactare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attack(v)">Attack,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Tack, and Attach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attain(v)">Attain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Attain&shy;
dre,</etym> and that from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Attenere.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attainted(a)">Attainted,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">At&shy;
taindre,</etym> or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">At&shy;
tingere;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  stained or tain&shy;
ted with a suspicion of Guilt,
says Minsevus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attempt(v)">Attempt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Atten&shy;
ter;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Attentare,</etym> to
venture upon a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attend(v)">Attend,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Atten&shy;
dre,</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">At&shy;
tendere;</etym> from the same Root
comes our Attendance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attire(n)">Attire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Attour,</etym>
dress for Women's heads: It
may not unlikely be drawn from the Praep. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and our
word <etym lang="en">Tire.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="atone(n)">Attone,</form> <xpln lang="en">rather Atone; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  at
one, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  friends again: But
if you spell it with tt, it
must be drawn from <etym lang="la">Ad</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Tone,</etym> by a Metaphor; a con&shy;
sort or Consonancy in Musick,
representing the agreement of
friends. I chuse the first.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="attorney(n)">Attorney,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. now
out of use, <etym lang="fr">Attour;</etym> the word
Tour signifiing Turns, being
still in use; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to serve a&shy;
nother's turn in his absence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avail(v)">Avail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Valoir,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Avalere</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat.
<etym lang="la">Advalere,</etym> to prevail with one
to do a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avant(adv)">Avant,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lat. <etym lang="la">Apage;</etym> but it is
a proper French word un&shy;
touch'd.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avant-mure(n)">Avantmure,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in War, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Avant,</etym> and <etym lang="fr">Mur,</etym>
a wall, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one wall before
another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avast(ex)">Avast,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word most common to
Sea-men: Possibly it may
come from the Lat. Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">Ab,</etym>
from, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haesten,</etym>
to make haste; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  make
haste hence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="audit(v)" lexeme="auditor(v)">Audit, and Auditor,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Audio,</etym> to hear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avenue(n)">Avenues,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ave&shy;
nue,</etym> an entrance: It is a mi&shy;
litary word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avenge(v)">Avenge,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Revenge.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aver(v)">Avere</form> <xpln lang="en">, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to assert the truth;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Averer,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Averare,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Adverare,</etym>
to affirm for truth. Vossius
says, that the Verb <etym lang="la">Verare</etym> was
formerly in use; whence Venus.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avery(n)">Avery, the King's Avery,</form> <xpln lang="en">the
place where Oats are put for
Horses. Minsevus drawe it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haver,</etym> (which
word is still in use in the North of England, where they call
Oats, Haver;) or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ha&shy;
ber:</etym> But it comes undoubted&shy;
ly, from the Barb. Lat. <etym lang="la">Ave&shy;
ria,</etym> an Avery. Hence like&shy;
wise Average.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auf(n)">Auff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Alf,</etym> or
<etym lang="bl">Alve,</etym> an earthly Daemon, l
in pronunciation being often
sounded as u; as in Psalm,
<term lang="la">quasi</term> Psaum; Holborn, <term lang="la">quasi</term>
Houborn, &amp;c. See Elf.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="auger(n)">Augar,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Wimble, from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Nauegar</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eveger, A&shy;
veger, Egger, Eggher, Ag&shy;
gher,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="B8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="awkward(a)">Aukward,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aewerd</etym>,
untowardly; the contrary to
Toward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="omelette(n)">Aumelet of Eggs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Aumelette, Omelette,</etym> a Fri&shy;
gacy of Eggs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aunt(n)">Aunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tante,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ame&shy;
ta;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ami&shy;
ta,</etym> an Aunt, by Father or
Mother's side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avoid(v)">Avoid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vuide,</etym>
void, and the initial Particle <etym lang="fr">A.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avouch(v)">Avouch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Avo&uuml;er,</etym>
to affirm: Not unlikely from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Advocare; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  </etym> to
take ones part: Or if you
had rather, take it from <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym>
and <etym lang="la">Votum,</etym> a Vote; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la"> Ad&shy;
votare,</etym> to give ones Vote for.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avow(v)">Avow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Avo&uuml;er;</etym>
or rather, from <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Vo&shy;
tum,</etym> to vote for.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="awe(n)">Aw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Acht, Achte,</etym> observance, or
respect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="awake(v)">Awake,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Wake.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="award(n)">Award,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the idle Particle
<etym lang="en">A,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weard</etym>,
towards, or against. Spel&shy;
man derives it from the Anglo-Norm. <etym lang="no">Agard,</etym> Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Garder;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  that which is to
be observed or kept.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aware(a)">Aware,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gewahr,
Werden,</etym> to perceive, to ani&shy;
madvert. v. Beware, Ward,
and Guard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="away(adv)">Away,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aweg</etym>,
absent, abroad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="awl(n)">Awl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Aele, Ale,</etym> Bel.
<etym lang="bl">Aelsene, Elsene, Els;</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Aa&shy;
el, Alsen, Elsen;</etym> whence, without doubt, comes the North-&shy;
Country word Elsen, or Hel&shy;
sen, signifying an Awl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="awry(adv)">Awry,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Wry.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="axe(n)">Ax,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Acse, Aex,
Eax, Aease</etym>; Dan. <etym lang="da">Oxe,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ackse, Axe, Aeckse;</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ar, Axt;</etym> all of them
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ascia,</etym> and that
immediately from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&shy;
&zeta;&#x1F77;&nu;&eta;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="axle-tree(n)">Axle-tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Assile,</etym>
and that from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Axile;</etym>
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the wood that passeth thr&ocirc;
the Nave of each Wheel, to
keep them together, and sup&shy;
port the Carriage. The Root
of all, is the Lat. <etym lang="la">Axis.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aye(adv)">Ay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">A, Awa</etym>, for
ever, always; Run. Dan. <etym lang="da">Ae</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Ewe, Euwe,</etym> an Age, Eternity:
All from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aevum.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="aye(adv)" lexeme="Aye(ex)">Ay me,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ai, Ahi;</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ahime,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Eheu, Heu;</etym>
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F4B;&iota;&mu;&omicron;&iota; &#x1F08;&#x1F76;, &#x1F08;&#x1F76;</etym>, all of
them from a natural tone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ail(v)">Ayl, or Ail;</form> <xpln lang="en">as, What ails thee?
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Adel, Adl</etym>,
a disease; which they that un&shy;
derstand Greek, may draw
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&theta;&lambda;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to la&shy;
bour or strive, as Wrestlers do,
or as sick people do in some
distempers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="airy(a)">An Ayry Man</form> <xpln lang="en">, from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Aire,</etym>
comliness, or a good presence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="azure(a)">Azure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Azur, A&shy;
sur;</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Azurro,</etym> Span. <etym lang="sp">Azul,</etym>
Arab. and Pers. <etym lang="ar">Lazurd,</etym> Gr.
Barb. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&zeta;omicron;&#x1F7B;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; all of them
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lazulus, Lapis.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>
</page>

<page sig="C1r">
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="B"><alpha>B</alpha> <wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baby(n)" lexeme="babe(n)">Babe, or Baby,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Babbolo, Bambo, Bambino,</etym> Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F71;&pi;&pi;&alpha;&#x03c2;</etym>, Heb. <etym lang="he">Ab.</etym>
Syr. <etym lang="sy">Abba,</etym> a father. I think
it rather comes from those almost inarticulate words, chil&shy;
dren are first heard to utter,
bab, dad, and mam; whence
the indulgent mother fawns
upon the child, and cries babe,
babbe, baby, daddy, mammy,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="babble(n)">Bable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Babel, Bebel,</etym>
insipid discourse; or from the Tower of <etym lang="he">Babel,</etym>
where all Languages were con&shy;
founded: Or, as Menagius
hath it, from <etym lang="it">Bambo, Bambi&shy;
no;</etym> from thence <etym lang="it">Bambinare</etym>,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to stammer, as doth a
child.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bauble(n)">Bables,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Babio&shy;
les,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Babbole,</etym> trifles: Or
rather, from our own word,
<etym lang="en">Babe,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Babbolo,</etym> an infant;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  children's toys. Right
Baubles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baboon(n)">Baboon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ba&shy;
bouin,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Babbuino,</etym> a kind
of Ape; perhaps from <etym lang="en">Babe,</etym>
and the termination <etym lang="en">On,</etym> great,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a great child; for they
most resemble Mankind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="back(n)">Back,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bac, Baec,
Baece</etym>, which denote the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="back-bite(v)">Back-bite,</form> <xpln lang="en">to slander one absent;
from our own word <etym lang="en">Back,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Bite;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  ashamed to
say it to the party's face.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bacon(n)">Bacon:</form> <xpln lang="en">Menagius doubteth not
to derive it from our own
word <etym lang="en">Bake,</etym> because it is dried
with smoak. It may not ab&shy;
surdly be drawn from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Pacchia,</etym> nourishing food;
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pascere,</etym>
to feed or nourish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bad(a)">Bad,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Quaed,</etym> I&shy;
dem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="badge(n)">Badge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bagghe,</etym>
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bacca,</etym> a Jewel, or Pearl; because the
Arms of renowned men were
adorned with precious stones.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="badger(n)">Badger,</form> <xpln lang="en">not unlikely from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Back,</etym> a Jaw-bone; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="tt">Backer;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) having strong
jaws.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baffle(v)">Baffle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Befler,</etym>
to supplant or cheat; or <etym lang="fr">Baf&shy;
fo&uuml;er,</etym> to cover the eyes with a
Veil; but this from the ini&shy;
tial Particle, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Be,</etym> and
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fol,</etym> which is pro&shy;
nounced Fou, a Fool; as we
say, to make a Fool of, or be&shy;
fool one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bag(n)">Bagg,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Belge</etym>,
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulga,</etym> sig.
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baggage(n)">Baggage,</form> <xpln lang="en">provision for an Army,
from our English <etym lang="en">Bagg;</etym> for
Soldiers Necessaries are often
carried in Bags or Snap-sacks:
From hence cometh that other Baggage, Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Bagasse,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Bagascia,</etym> a Whore, a com&shy;
mon Strumpet; in Soldiers
Camps, a Camp-whore.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bail(n)">Bail,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Surety, one that giveth
Security for another Man in an
Action of Trespass; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bail,</etym> a Keeper. V. Bai&shy;
liff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bailiff(n)">Bailiff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bailli,
Bailiff,</etym> formerly a Steward in
an house, Ital. <etym lang="it">Baglio,</etym> a Fo&shy;
ster-father; which, by a Me&shy;
taphor, manifestly flows from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bajulo,</etym> to carry on
ones shoulders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bain(n)" lexeme="bagnio(n)">Bain, or Bagnio,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Bain,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bagno,</etym> both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Balneum,</etym> an
Hot-house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bait(n)">Bait,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bagan</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Baissen;</etym> both these
may seem to come from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Be,</etym> nigh, and the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Aete</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Esseu,</etym> meat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bait(v)">To Bait,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  make one crea&shy;
ture fight with another; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Batan</etym>, or from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Battre,</etym> and this from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Batuere,</etym> to beat, or
strike; or rather from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bitan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bitten.</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Beissen,</etym> to bite. v. To Beat,
and Bite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bait(v)">The Hawk Baiteth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Hunting; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bat&shy;
tre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Battere,</etym> to strike;
for in raising his flight, the
Hawk clasheth his wings to&shy;
gether.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bait(v)">To Bait</form> <xpln lang="en">at an Inn, may proba&shy;
bly come from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bae&shy;
te</etym>, a commodity, or from
<etym lang="bl">Baitze, Baisse,</etym> victuals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baize(n)">Baize,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Baey,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bay,</etym> hairy cloth. Min&shy;
shew draweth it from the
English word <etym lang="en">Base;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
course sort of Cloth; ordina&shy;
rily spell'd Bays.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bake(v)">Bake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bacian</etym>,
if not more fitly from the
Dan. <etym lang="da">Bager,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ballad(n)" lexeme="ballet (n)">Balad, or Ballet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Balade,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ballata,</etym> a
Rhime, or Sonnet; and all of them from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baller,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ballare,</etym> to dance.
V. Ball.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balas(n)">Balass,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of precious stone,
from the barbarous Lat. <etym lang="la">Ba&shy;
lassius,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. The famous
Th. H. supposeth it to be of a
barbarous Indian Original, for
that many of their Cities
names begin with <etym lang="hi">Bal;</etym> which
indeed is likely enough.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balcony(n)">Balconey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Balck</etym>
a rafter, or beam. V. Balck.
Scaliger derives it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Palus,</etym> a stake, or post.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bald(a)">Bald,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bal,</etym> bald
before, this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&alpha;&shy;
&lambda;&alpha;&kappa;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, signifying the same.
I had rather draw it from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pel&egrave;,</etym> coming from the
Verb <etym lang="fr">Peler,</etym> to pull off the
hair, and this most plainly
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pilus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balderdash(v)">Balderdash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>,
and our <etym lang="en">Dash</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to mix
drink, or any thing without
discretion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bale(v)">To Bale,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing, to
cast water out of ships with
buckets. We may draw it
metaphorically from the Fr.
</page> 

<page sig="C2r"> 
G. <etym lang="fr">Bailler,</etym> to sweep, or make
clean. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bale(n)">Bale,</form> <xpln lang="en">a carriage of Merchants
Goods; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Balle,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Balle</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="la"> Pila,</etym> a
ball, from the similitude, as
to roundness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baleful(a)" lexeme="bale(a)">Baleful, and Bale,</form> <xpln lang="en">sad or sor&shy;
rowful; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">B&aelig;l</etym>,
a Funeral-pile; from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Balghen, Belghen,</etym> to take a
thing ill; or <etym lang="en">Bale</etym>, Sarcina,
a burthen; for grief is really
the burthen of the mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balk(n)">A Balk,</form> <xpln lang="en">made in plowing, from
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Valicare,</etym> to leap
over, or miss: From hence
our Eng. word, to balk, or
disappoint one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balk(n)">Balk,</form> <xpln lang="en">a piece of timber laid cross
the house; from the Belg. and
Teut <etym lang="tt">Basck</etym>. Scaliger, as be&shy;
fore, takes it from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Palus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ball(n)">Ball,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">P&egrave;l,</etym> in Lat.
<etym lang="la">Pila:</etym> Minsevus and Junius
will have it to come from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x03AC;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, <etym lang="la">jacio</etym>, to cast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ball(v)">Ball,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bal,</etym> and
this from the Verb <etym lang="fr">Baller,</etym> to
dance; perhaps it may flow
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&lambda;&lambda;&#x1F77;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, and this
from the Primitive <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x03AC;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, to
move or wag the feet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balance(n)">Ballance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bis,</etym>
and <etym lang="la">Lanx</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Bilanx, ha&shy;
ving two scales: From hence
comes the word Counter-bal&shy;
lance. Right spell'd, Balance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ballast(n)">Ballast,</form> <xpln lang="en">Gravel or Sand, where&shy;
with Ships are poised; from
the initial Particle <etym lang="tt">Be,</etym> and the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Last,</etym> Onus, a burthen; or
more probably from the Dan.
<etym lang="da">Baglast,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term> and this from
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Bag,</etym> and <etym lang="da">Last</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Wherry, or Scullar loaded.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ballocks(n)">Ballocks,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beal&shy;
lucas</etym>. Minsevus probably
enough deriveth it from our
English <etym lang="en">Ball,</etym> because of the
similitude. It may likewise be
drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">B&aelig;lig</etym>,
a purse or satchel, from the ga&shy;
thering the mouth when they
shut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balloon(n)">Balloon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ballon,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ballone</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a great
ball.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ballot(n)">Ballot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ballot&shy;
tre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ballottare,</etym> to cast
lots; or from the Noun <etym lang="en">Ball,</etym>
because a ball was used by
the ancient Italians in casting
lots.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="balm(n)">Balm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baume,</etym>
which comes from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Balsamum,</etym> signifying the
same. By the figures Syncope
and Apocope, Balm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="band(n)">Band,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Band,
Bend</etym>, Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bande,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Benda,</etym> Belg. &amp; Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bandt,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all of them from
our word <etym lang="en">Bind;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="band(n)">A Band,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bande,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Banda,</etym> a company of Sol&shy;
diers; or from the barbarous
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&nu;&delta;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a banner, or flag:
Yet I had rather derive them
all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fana</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fahn, Fahne,</etym> the same, by a
Metonymy of the Adjunct.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandroll(n)">Bandroll,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bande&shy;
rolle.</etym> See Band, and Roll.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandito(n)">Bandito,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Exile; from the I&shy;
tal. <etym lang="it">Bando,</etym> a Command sent
forth by publick Authority.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandog(n)">Bandog,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Band,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Dog</etym>;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Dog chained, that he
may do no harm; if you had
not rather draw it from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bana</etym>, a Man-slayer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandoleer(n)">Bandoleers,</form> <xpln lang="en">cases for Gun-pow&shy;
der, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bande</etym>,
fascia; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  fastned to a Belt
with strings, or thongs of Lea&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandore(n)">Bandore,</form> <xpln lang="en">a musical instrument;
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&nu;&delta;&omicron;&#x1FE6;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bandy(v)">To Bandy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ban&shy;
der,</etym> and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pandare,</etym>
to make crooked,
or to bend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bane(n)">Bane,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bana</etym>, a
slayer or killer of Men. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banns(n)">Banes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bans,</etym>
and both from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aban&shy;
nar</etym>, to publish. V. Banish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bang(v)">Bang,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bengel,</etym> a club; and this from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Baculus,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to beat
one with a stick or staff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bangle-eared(a)">Bangle-ear'd,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a flap-ear'd
Dog; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bendan</etym>,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Bendle-ears, hanging
flat down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banister(n)" lexeme="ballister(n)">Banisters,</form> <xpln lang="en">by some called Bal&shy;
listers, a term in Archite&shy;
cture; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Balu&shy;
stre, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; which, I suppose,
may come from the Noun
<etym lang="fr">Ball,</etym> for they are round.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bank(n)">Bank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Banc</etym>, <emend err="and
and">and</emend> this from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ban,</etym>
high. Fr. Jun. derives it
from the Gr.<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, an hill, or
heap of earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bank(n)">Bank,</form> <xpln lang="en">a table upon which an
Exchanger counteth money;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Banc,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Banco,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Benck,</etym> AS.
<etym lang="oe">Baence</etym>, a bench. V. Bench.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banquet(n)">Banket; or rather, Banquet,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Banquet,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Banchetto,</etym> a feast; from
<etym lang="en">Bank,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Bench;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bankrupt(n)">Bankrout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Banquerout,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bancerot&shy;
to</etym>; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  he hath cracked his
credit, and is marched off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ban(v)">Bann,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bannen,</etym>
to curse; which comes from
the Root <etym lang="bl">Ban,</etym> an Anathema,
or heavy curse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banner(n)">A Banner,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Standard. V.
<etym lang="en">Band.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banneret(n)">Banneret,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Noun <etym lang="en">Ban&shy;
ner;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Standard-bearer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="banish(v)">Bannish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aban&shy;
nan</etym>, to punish with Exilement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barb(v)">To Barb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Barba,</etym>
a beard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barb(n)">Barb,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Horse so called, from
<etym lang="en">Barbary,</etym> a Country where he
is bred.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barbed(a)">Barbed,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry,
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Barb&eacute;,</etym> having
a beard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barbel(n)">Barbel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish so called, from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Barba;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a kind of
Mullet, having, as it were, a
beard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barber(n)">A Barber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bar&shy;
ber,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Barbiere,</etym> a Shaver; all
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Barba.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bard(n)">A Bard,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Dunce, from the C.
Br. <etym lang="cb">Bardd,</etym> an old pedling
Poet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bard(n)">Bard,</form> <xpln lang="en">harness for Horses; from
the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Barder,</etym> Ital <etym lang="it">Barde;</etym>
which come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pa&shy;
ratus;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  put in readiness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bard(v)" lexeme="beard-wool(v)">To Bard, or Beard-wool.</form> <xpln lang="en">V.
Beard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bardasho(n)">Bardasho,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Bardas&shy;
cio,</etym> and this from <etym lang="it">Bardo,</etym> for
Bardato; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  he that put&shy;
teth his body in a lascivious
wanton posture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bare(a)">Bare,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&alpha;&epsilon;&shy;
&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, clear, from <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&#x1F71;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, light;
but it doth more than allude
to the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pareo,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Appa&shy;
reo,</etym> to be apparent, or vi&shy;
sible.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bargain(v)">To Bargain:</form> <xpln lang="en">Scaliger, writing
against Festus, draweth it from
an old Lat. word, <etym lang="la">Bargenna,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>. I had rather derive it
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Per,</etym> for <etym lang="it">Pro</etym>
and the Verb <etym lang="it">Gagnare,</etym> for <etym lang="it">Guadagnare,</etym> to gain, or pro&shy;
fit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barge(n)">Barge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">Bark;</etym>
which see hereafter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barge-couple(n)">Barge-couples,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archi&shy;
tecture; not unlikely from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bur</etym>, and the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Couple;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a beam, or one
piece of wood mortised into
another, to strengthen the
building.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bark(n)">Bark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Barck,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Berck;</etym> and this from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bergen,</etym> to cover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bark(v)">To Bark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beor&shy;
can</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bark(n)">A Bark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Barca,
Varca;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="it">Varcare</etym>, to row
over a shallow place; perhaps
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&rho;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, a kind of
boat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barken(n)">Barken,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word very common
in the County of Wilts, a
Yard of an house; either
from the word <etym lang="en">Bar,</etym> or the
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Bergen,</etym> to hide; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a place shut up from the field.
The famous Th. H. is of opi&shy;
nion, that it is depraved from
the word <etym lang="en">Barley.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barm(n)">Barm,</form> <xpln lang="en">the head, or workings
out of Beer or Ale; from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Fermen,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Fermentum;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a fermentation, which is
necessary for preserving the
strength of the liquor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barn(n)">Barn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bern</etym>, i&shy;
dem; this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bere</etym>,
and <etym lang="oe">Erne</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Reposi&shy;
tory for any sort of Grain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barnacle(n)">Barnacle,</form> <xpln lang="en">an instrument to set
on the nose of an unruly
Horse; from <etym lang="en">Bear,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Neck;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to make the Horse hold
up his head. See Bear, and
Neck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baron(n)">Baron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wer,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Varon,</etym> a Man; undoubt&shy;
edly, from that Germ. or
Goth. <etym lang="gr">Wer,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baron and femme(n)">Baron, and Femme,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Heraldry; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Man and
Woman. V. Baron.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"femme" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bar(n)">Barr,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Barreau,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Barra,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vara;</etym>
which, in Vitruvius, signifies
a stake.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barrel(n)">Barrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Barril,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Barile,</etym> C.
Br. <etym lang="cb">Baril,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; if I may
not deduce it from our Engl.
<etym lang="en">Bear,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Beer;</etym> because of its
being carried upon the Brewers shoulders; or from its containing of Beer. V. Bear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barren(a)">Barren,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dubre&shy;
rende,</etym> Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Unbarig,</etym> not
bringing forth. Mer. Cas. de&shy;
rives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F77;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
a kind of fish that fructifieth
not.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barrister(n)">Barrester,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Lawyer that pleads
at the <etym lang="en">Barr</etym>. V. Bair.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barretor(n)">Barretour,</form> <xpln lang="en">a wrangling or con&shy;
tentious person; from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Baratter,</etym> to put a trick
upon one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barricade(n)">Barricado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bar&shy;
riquer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Baricare,</etym> to erect
a Bulwark with wood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barrier(n)">Barriers,</form> <xpln lang="en">a military sport, or
pass time; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Barrieres,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Barriera;</etym> q.
d. an Exercise within certain
limits.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barrow(n)" lexeme="wheelbarrow(n)">Barrow, or Wheel-barrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Berewe</etym>, the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Berroette;</etym> and these from
the word <etym lang="en">Bear,</etym> or from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Vehere,</etym> to carry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barrow-hog(n)">Barrow-hog,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Barrow, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beargh</etym>, Belg. and
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Barg;</etym> all of them per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Porcus,</etym> a
Boar-pig, or Hog.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="barter(v)">Barter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Barat&shy;
ter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Barrattare;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to exchange one Commodity
for another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="base(a)">Base,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bas,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Basso,</etym> mean, ignoble; and
both these from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&sigma;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>,
or <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&iota;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&zeta;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, low. Mer.
Cas. is pleased to take it from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&sigma;&alpha;</etym>, infamy, or
shame.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bashaw(n)">Bashaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Turkish Magistrate.
Martinius hath it from the
Turc. <etym lang="tu">Basch;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a States-&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bashful(a)">Bashful,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">A&shy;
bash,</etym> or make ashamed;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bask(v)" lexeme="basker(v)">To Bask, or Basker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Backeren,</etym> this from the
word <etym lang="bl">Bake</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to warm
a young Child at the fire.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"basker" not recorded in OED as a form of the verb "to bask."
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="basket(n)">Basket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bas&shy;
gawd,</etym> and <etym lang="cb">Basged,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bason(n)">Bason,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bassin,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bacino,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bacin,</etym> a
wash-pot; which Covarruvias
derives from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&theta;&epsilon;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
hollow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baste(v)">To Baste</form> <xpln lang="en">Meat, from the other
<etym lang="en">Baste.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="baste(v)">Baste,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Batuere,</etym>
to beat; more likely from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baster;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to load
with blows. Salmasius judgeth, that it may be taken from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, a club, or cu&shy;
dgel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastard(n)">Bastard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Bosz,</etym>
and <etym lang="gr">Aerd,</etym> or <etym lang="gr">Art</etym>, ill-natur'd;
or on the contrary, from the
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Best,</etym> and <etym lang="gr">Aerd,</etym> for
such, for the most part, are
of a vertuous disposition: Or,
</page>

<page sig="C4r"> 
as Dr. Davis hath it, from the
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bas,</etym> and <etym lang="cb">Tardu</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
basely descended. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastard-wine(n)">Bastard-Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Bastaerd-Wiine,</etym> or from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Passum,</etym> and the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Aerd;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Wine made of
withered or dried Grapes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastile(n)">Bastile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bastide,</etym>
this from the Verb <etym lang="sp">Bastir,</etym> to
build, or erect, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a For&shy;
tress, or strong Hold; such as
is our Tower of London.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastion(n)">Bastion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the same Root.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bastonado(n)">Bastonado,</form> <xpln lang="en">a good cudgelling;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baston,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Bastone;</etym> and these from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F71;&zeta;&omega;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a staff sup&shy;
porteth the body. v. Ba&shy;
toon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bat(n)">Bat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Baphas</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Baet</etym>,
a Boat; because a Bat's wings,
spread out, do somewhat re&shy;
semble a Boat with Oars.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bat(n)">Bat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Batt</etym>, a
Staff, or Cane; which comes
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Batuere.</etym> V Baste.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brickbat(n)">Brick-Bat:</form> <xpln lang="en">Th. H. imagineth,
that it comes from our Eng.
<etym lang="en">Brick,</etym> and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bout,</etym>
the end of any thing; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the end of a Brick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bachelor(n)">Batchellor,</form> <xpln lang="en">an unmarried Man;
also a fresh-water Soldier, and
a Batchellor of Arts; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bacheliers,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Baciglieri</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="it">Bacillarii</etym>,
or <etym lang="it">Bacularii;</etym> because per&shy;
haps they were initiated under
a gilded Wand, lifted up by
the Cryer. Or, as Menagius
hath it, from <etym lang="fr">Bas Chavalier,</etym>
an Horse-man of an inferiour
Rank. There is found in Spel&shy;
man, and Calvin, in his <term lang="la">Le&shy;
xicon Juridicum</term>, Buccella&shy;
rius, a Warrier of a more ho&shy;
nourable Order; which com&shy;
eth from <etym lang="it">Buccella,</etym> a portion
of provision allowed for such
a Soldier's maintenance; be&shy;
ing, as it were, not married,
because he lives abroad from
his Wife.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bate(n)" lexeme="makebate(n)">Bate, as in Make-bate;</form> <xpln lang="en">certain&shy;
ly of the same rise with <etym lang="en">De&shy;
bate;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bate(v)">To Bate,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Abate; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bath(n)">Bath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">B&aelig;th</etym>,
and this contracted from <etym lang="oe">B&aelig;&shy;
&eth;an</etym>, to wash; if I may
not derive it from the Belg.
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bad;</etym> and this from
another Teut. word, <etym lang="tt">Bahen;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to nourish the natural
heat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="battle(n)">Battel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bat&shy;
taille,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Battaglia, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
all of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ba&shy;
tuere,</etym> to beat, batter, or com&shy;
bate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="batten(v)">Batten,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Northern word, sig&shy;
nifying, to grow big any way;
probably corrupted from the
word <etym lang="en">Fatten,</etym> or from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Batten,</etym> to do good. See more of it in Ski&shy;
nner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="batter(v)">Batter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Battre,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Battere,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Batuere.</etym>
v. Beat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="batter(n)">Batter for Pancakes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
</page>

<page sig="C4v"> 
same Root. Also Battery, a
wall to receive the blows of
warlike Engines, comes from
the same Root. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="battle(v)">To Battle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently u&shy;
sed in the University at Ox&shy;
ford, signifying to set down
the Scholars Commons; from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Betalen,</etym> which real&shy;
ly comes from the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;l&shy;
lan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">T&aelig;len, Tellen,</etym> to
pay, by adding the initial <etym lang="bl">Be.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="battledore(n)">Battle-door,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Batil&shy;
lum,</etym> and Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Dera, Dre, </etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a shovel made of wood.
The famous Th. H. derives it
purely from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bat&shy;
toir,</etym> in Lat. <etym lang="la">Pavicula,</etym> a rammer,
or instrument to pave withal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="battlement(n)">Battlements,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture, from <etym lang="en">Battle;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="batoon(n)">Battoon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ba&shy;
ston,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bastone;</etym> and both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Batuere:</etym> Or
rather, according to Salma&shy;
sius, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, a
Porter's staff. It alludes to
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&kappa;&tau;&rho;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="batoon(n)">Batune,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baston;</etym> a
staff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bawd(n)">Baud,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baude,</etym>
impudent; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A Bold Wo&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bavin(n)">Baven,</form> <xpln lang="en">not unlikely so called
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Feuine,</etym>
from <etym lang="fr">Feu,</etym> a fire. A lear&shy;
ned Man derives it from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bauwen,</etym> Teut <etym lang="tt">Bawen</etym>,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  slender sprigs shooting
out of the roots of trees that
are hewen down for ti&shy;
mber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bawl(v)">Bawl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Balare;</etym>
or which Minsevus very well
conjectureth, from <etym lang="en">Bau Bau,</etym>
a barking of Dogs. Mer. Cas.
draweth it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>,
to cry aloud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bawze(v)">Bawse, Bawsze,</form> <xpln lang="en">to cry out in a
rage; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>,
<term lang="la">Latro</term>, and <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, as before;
all of them, perhaps, not so
properly words, as sounds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bay(v)">Bay,</form> <xpln lang="en">To keep at Bay, a term in
Hunting and Fowling; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Abbayer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bai&shy;
are;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Dog, by instant&shy;
ly barking, stayeth the Fowl,
till shot by the Fowler: Or
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bidan</etym>, which
comes from the Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="en">By;</etym> as
to this day we say, He stays
by it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bay(n)">A Bay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Byge</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">B&aelig;ye,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew
draweth it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&iota;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>
little; because little, in re&shy;
spect of the Sea: Or lastly,
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Badare,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Beyden,</etym> to stay; because the
Sea is calm within the Haven.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bay(n)">Bay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&alpha;&iota;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, Ash-&shy;
colour'd; or <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&iota;&#x1F78;&nu;</etym>, a branch
of the Palm-tree; because it
resembles it something in co&shy;
lour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bay-tree(n)">A Bay-tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&iota;&#x1F78;&nu;</etym>,
the same; which heretofore
was a token of Victory, as the
Lawrel is now.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C5r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bay(v)">To Bay,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Sheep do, from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Balare,</etym> signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bay-window(n)">Bay-window:</form> <xpln lang="en">the learned Th.
H. supposeth it to be cal&shy;
led as it were <etym lang="en">Bow-window;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  made in the form of a
Bow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="base(n)">Bayes, or Bayze,</form> <xpln lang="en">to play or run
at Bayze, a Sport used by
some in Lincolnshire, not un&shy;
likely from the Noun <etym lang="en">Bayes,</etym>
because the Victors were pre&shy;
sented with a Garland of Law&shy;
rel, as a token of Valour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="be(pp)">Be,</form> <xpln lang="en">is a Preposition common to all
Germ. Dialects, but espe&shy;
cially so to the AS. Teut. and
Belg. often superfluous, yet
put before Verbs, Verbals and
Participles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beacon(n)">Beacon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Watch-tower; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beacn</etym>, and this from the initial Part. <etym lang="oe">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Cen&shy;
nan</etym>, Scire, because things are
therein discerned a-far off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beadle(n)">Beadle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bydel</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bedelle,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beutel,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bedel,</etym> the same; all of
them from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Biddan</etym>, or rather, <etym lang="oe">Beodan</etym>, to bid,
as Beadles do: Hence To Bid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bead-roll(n)">Beadroll,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beade</etym>,
and <etym lang="oe">Roll</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Catalogue
of Prayers, said by Beads.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bead(n)">Beads,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beade</etym>,
a Prayer: Hence Beads-man,
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bitten</etym> to pray
to: I suppose they may all
come from the Lat. <etym lang="tt">Petere,</etym> to
ask. v. Bid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beagle(n)">Beagle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bigles,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Piccolo,</etym> and this from
the Lat. <etym lang="it">Pauculus;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a
little kind of Hound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beak(n)">Beak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beck,</etym> Ro&shy;
strum, a snout, beak, or bill.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beaker(n)">Beaker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beker,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Becher,</etym> a cup; all of
them perhaps from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F77;&kappa;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a pitcher, or pot ha&shy;
ving handles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beam(n)">Beam,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beam</etym>,
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Boum,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bawm,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; but Fr. Jun. derives
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omega;&mu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, for
that the Ancients sacrificed in
Groves or Woods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beam(n)">Beam,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beam</etym>,
Radius, of the same derivation
with the other, because of the
similitude.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bean(n)">Bean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bean</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Boone,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bohne,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bear(n)">Bear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and the Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Beran, Bearan,</etym> Por&shy;
tare, to carry on ones shoul&shy;
ders; or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Baerer;</etym> all
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fero,</etym>
and this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&#x1F73;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to
carry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bear(v)">To Bear,</form> <xpln lang="en">or bring forth, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Beran</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bae&shy;
ren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gebohren,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bier(n)">Bear,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a dead body, from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Baere,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Baet,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Biere,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bara;</etym> all
from the word <etym lang="en">Bear,</etym> but
for distinction sake spell'd
Byer.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bear(n)">A Bear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bera</etym>,
Dan. <etym lang="da">Biorn,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bar,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Baere,</etym> and this may be drawn
from the &AElig;ol. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&#x1F74;&rho;</etym> for <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F74;&rho;</etym>,
Fera, &Kappa;&alpha;&tau;'&#x1F00;&zeta;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F75;&nu;.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beard(n)">Beard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beard</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Baerd,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bart,</etym> sig&shy;
nifying the same: It may
seem to flow from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&shy;
&rho;&#x1F7B;&tau;&eta;&#x03c2;</etym>, gravity, of which it is
a Symptom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bairn(n)">Bearn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a down-right Northern
word; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bearn</etym>,
Run. Dan. <etym lang="da">Bar,</etym> or <etym lang="da">Barn,</etym> a
son, or a child. Some derive
it from the Heb. and Syr. <etym lang="he">Bar</etym>,
<term lang="la">Filius</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beat(v)">Beat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Batuere,</etym> to
strike or buffet: If I may not
as well draw it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&tau;&#x1F71;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beautify(v)">Beautify,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the obsolete Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Beautifier;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Bellificare</etym>, to
make fine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beauty(n)">Beauty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.<etym lang="fr"> Beau&shy;
t&egrave;,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Belt&agrave;, Bellezza;</etym>
these from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bel,
Beau,</etym> and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bellus,</etym> neat, or handsom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="because(adv)">Because,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="en">By,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Cause;</etym> or rather, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Be</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Causa;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
for this or that cause.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beck(n)">Beck,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word very much used in
our Northern Quarters, from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bece,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Back,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Beck, Rivus,</etym> a little Ri&shy;
ver, or Stream.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beck(v)">Beck, or Beak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Beccare,</etym> To Peck; which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="becken(v)">Becken,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Becen&shy;
nan</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to make signs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="become(v)">Become,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">By,</etym> or the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Be</etym>, and <etym lang="en">Come.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="become(v)" lexeme="be meet(v)">Become, or to be meet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cweman</etym>, to please,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bequam,</etym> neat, or fit&shy;
ting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bed(n)">Bed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bed</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Bedde,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bett,</etym> and from
these cometh <etym lang="en">Bedding.</etym> It al&shy;
so signifies a plat, or quarter in
Gardens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bedlam(n)">Bedlem, or Bedlam,</form> <xpln lang="en">by our
Ancestors called the House of
Bethlehem. Minsevus draweth
it from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Beth Le&shy;
chem,</etym> the house of Bread. It
may also come from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bettelen, Betteler,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
Lodge, or Mansion for Beg&shy;
gars. V. Beggar, and Home.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="be(v)">Be,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beon</etym>; and
this I might derive from the
old Lat. <etym lang="la">Feo,</etym> which may not
unlikely flow from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&#x1F78;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">Nascor</term>, to be born.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bee(n)">A Bee,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Beo</etym>, Dan.
<etym lang="da">Bi,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bie, Bye,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bien,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Baedd,</etym> Apicula,
a little Bee. Mer. Cas. de&shy;
rives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Apis;</etym>
from hence, An Eat-Bee, a
Bird so called, because it feed&shy;
eth upon Bees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beech(n)">Beech,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bece</etym>,
Dan. <etym lang="da">Bog,</etym> which may not ab&shy;
surdly be drawn from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&eta;&gamma;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, Dor.,<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&alpha;&gamma;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C6r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beef(n)">Beef,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Beauf,</etym>
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bove,</etym> the
Ablat. of <etym lang="la">Bos,</etym> an Ox.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beer(n)">Beer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bere</etym>,
<term lang="la">Hordeum</term>, Barley, because
made of Barley. Some de&shy;
rive it, but not so well, from
the Heb. <etym lang="he">Bar</etym>, <term lang="la">Frumentum</term>,
Bread-corn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bison(a)">Beesen, Bisen, or Berzen,</form> <xpln lang="en">blind;
a word very frequent in Lin&shy;
colnshire; from our Eng. <etym lang="en">By,</etym>
for Besides, and the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Sinn,</etym> sight; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  deprived
of the most noble sense of all;
<term lang="la">viz.</term>  the Sight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="besom(n)">Beesom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Besm</etym>,
Teut. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Besem;</etym> per&shy;
haps better from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ver&shy;
sum,</etym> by striking out the r,
and turning v into b.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beestings(n)">Beestings,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beast</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Biest,</etym> the first milk af&shy;
ter a calving; whether it may
not come of our Engl. <etym lang="en">Best,</etym>
is somewhat dubious. It al&shy;
ludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F75;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, to
curd, or thicken. &AElig;lfricus
uses the word <etym lang="oe">Bysting</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beet(n)">A Beet</form> <xpln lang="en">of Flax, from the word
<etym lang="en">Beat.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beetle(n)">Beetle,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Pavior's Rammer,
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bytl</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Beytel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; perhaps from
the word <etym lang="en">Beat.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beetle(n)">Beetle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bitel</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>; probably from the
word <etym lang="en">Beat,</etym> because in the
evening, through blindness,
they hit against our faces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="befall(v)">Befall,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Befeolan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bevallen,</etym> to happen, to
fall out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="befool(v)">Befool,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Fool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="before(pp)">Before,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beforan</etym>,
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vore,</etym> Belg, <etym lang="bl">Voor,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bevor;</etym> all of them per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Porr&ograve;.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beg(v)" lexeme="beggar(n)">Beg, and Beggar,</form> <xpln lang="en">or perhaps
better Bagger, because they
carry their provision about
with them in bags; or from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Begeren,</etym> to ask:
Perhaps it may not unelegant&shy;
ly be drawn from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Vagari,</etym> to go from place to
place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beget(v)">Beget,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beget&shy;
tan</etym>, to obtain, or procure.
v. Get.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="begin(v)">Begin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aginnan</etym>,
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beginnen;</etym>
and this we may suppose, from
the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Go in;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to enter upon a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beguile(v)">Beguile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Guile;</etym> which see: unless you
would derive it from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Begalian</etym>, to bewitch, or in&shy;
chant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="behalf(n)">Behalf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Be</etym>, and
<etym lang="oe">Half;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="behave(v)">Behave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">Have,</etym>
and the pr&aelig;fix <etym lang="en">Be;</etym> but I ra&shy;
ther think it may have come
from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Behavan,</etym> to
contain ones self, or keep
within bounds; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to be
mannerly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="behead(v)">Behead,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="behest(n)">Behest,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Hest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="behind(adv)">Behind,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hindan</etym>,
</page>

<page sig="C6v"> 
Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hinden;</etym> all
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hynan</etym>, back&shy;
wards. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="behold(v)">Behold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Hold</etym>; q.
d. to look stedfastly on an ob&shy;
ject. V. Be, and Hold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belag(v)" lexeme="belagged(a)">Belag, and Belagged,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beleggen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Beladen;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  loaded, or clogged with
dirt, or any other thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belay(v)">Belay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and
the word <etym lang="en">Lay;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to en&shy;
snare one. V. Lay, and Way-&shy;
Lay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belch(v)">Belch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Balcet&shy;
tan</etym>; a word feigned from
the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beleaguer(v)">Beleaguer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bele&shy;
geren, Beleggen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Be&shy;
lagern,</etym> to make a Trench a&shy;
bout. v. Leaguer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="believe(v)">Believe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gelea&shy;
fan</etym>, which comes from the
part. <etym lang="oe">Ge,</etym> and the word <etym lang="oe">Ly&shy;
fan</etym>, to assent, or yield to.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bell(n)">Bell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bellan</etym>, to
roar, or make a great noise.
v. Bellow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belfrey(n)">Belfrey;</form> <xpln lang="en">either as Minsevus hath
it, from the Eng. and AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bell</etym>, and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fero,</etym> to
bear; or from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Beuffroy,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Bauffroy,</etym> a Watch-&shy;
Tower.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bellow(v)">Bellow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bellan</etym>,
Belg <etym lang="bl">Belken,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bolcken,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bugler,</etym> to bellow or
low as an Ox; Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bellen,</etym>
to howl; all of them from the
sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bellows(n)">Bellows,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bilig</etym>,
