Teut. <etym lang="tt">Balg,</etym> as Blast-Balg;
perhaps all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bul&shy;
ga,</etym> a purse, or satchel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belly(n)">Belly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Balch,
Balgh,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bauch;</etym> all from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Baelig</etym>, and that from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulga,</etym> or AS. <etym lang="oe">Buce</etym>,
a paunch: It may not unlike&shy;
ly be drawn from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Bellico,</etym> the navel. Cov. de&shy;
rives it from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Barri&shy;
ga,</etym> and this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&shy;
&rho;&upsilon;&#x03c2;</etym>, heavy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belong(v)">Belong,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Belan&shy;
gen,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beloved(a)">Beloved,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Belieben,</etym> to please. v. Love.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="below(adv)">Below,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Low.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belt(n)">Belt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan.
<etym lang="oe">Belte,</etym> <etym lang="da">Belt</etym>; both from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Baltheus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="belly(n)">Bely,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Belecgan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Belieghen,</etym> to accuse one
falsly; or from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Ly;</etym> which see in its
place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bemoan(v)">Bemoan,</form> <xpln lang="en">or deplore, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">B&aelig;m&aelig;nan</etym>. V. To Moan, or
Mone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bench(n)">Bench,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Baence</etym>,
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Banck,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Banc,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Banco, Panco,</etym>
the same; some derive all
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Abacus,</etym>
a cup-board.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bend(v)">Bend,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bendan</etym>,
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bender,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Bander,</etym>
to bow, or bend; all of them
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pandare,</etym> to
bow, or make crooked.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="C7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bend(n)">Bend,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bende,</etym> any thing
to tye round. V. Bind, or
Band.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bend(n)">Bend,</form> <xpln lang="en">frequently used by Mari&shy;
ners, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bende,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Benda</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a band hol&shy;
ding the sides of the ship to&shy;
gether.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bendlet(n)">Bendlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a diminutive from
<etym lang="en">Bend;</etym> that is, A small Bend;
a term in Heraldry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beneath(adv)">Beneath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beneo&thorn;,
Beneo&thorn;an</etym>, below, or un&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bent(n)">Bent, or Bents,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bintz,</etym> a bull-rush; this ei&shy;
ther from our word <etym lang="en">Bend,</etym> or
<etym lang="en">Bind.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="benumb(a)">Benumb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beny&shy;
man</etym>, this from <etym lang="oe">Niman</etym>, (i.
e.) the limbs of one stupified,
as being held fast with cold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bequeath(v)">Bequeath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym>
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwe&thorn;an</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to give one a legacy by word
of mouth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bewray(v)">Beray,</form> <xpln lang="en">to befoul: See the word
Array.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bereave(v)">Bereave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Berea&shy;
fan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Berooven,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Berauven,</etym> to spoil; all of
them, if I be not mistaken,
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rapere,</etym> to
snatch away. V. Rob, and
Robe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bergomet-pear(n)">Bergomet-Pear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="it">Bergo&shy;
mus,</etym> a famous City of Insu&shy;
bria, from whence they were
first brought over: Or as Me&shy;
nagius very well observeth,
from the Turc. <etym lang="tu">Bergamout,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="tu">Beg,</etym> a Prince,
and <etym lang="tu">Armout,</etym> a Pear; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the Prince of Pears.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coney berry(n)">Berry, Coney-Berry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bergen,</etym> to hide; or
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bure</etym>, a Par&shy;
lour; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a receptacle for
Coneys. It may be derived
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Byrgena</etym>, a
Sepulchre, for the similitude
of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="berry(n)">Berries,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Verb <etym lang="oe">Be&shy;
ran</etym>, to bring forth; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the product of trees or
shrubs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="berth(n)">Berth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word amongst Mari&shy;
ners, from our word <etym lang="en">Bear</etym>;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a space, or distance, in
which the ship riding at an&shy;
chor, is moved to and fro.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bezant(n)">Besance, or Bezant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Heraldry; so called, from an
old golden Coin first used at
Byzantium.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beseech(v)">Beseech;</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly, <etym lang="en">Beseek</etym>. v.
Seek.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beseem(v)">Beseem;</form> <xpln lang="en">if I mistake not, from
our word <etym lang="en">See,</etym> this from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Seon</etym>, to see; because
comely things are pleasant to
look upon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beset(v)">Beset,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Besittan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Besetten,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beset&shy;
zen;</etym> all from the part. <etym lang="oe">Be,</etym>
and <etym lang="oe">Settan</etym>, to set.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beshit(v)">Beshit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. Verb
<etym lang="tt">Bescheissen;</etym> metaphorically
signifying to defraud, or cheat,
or leave in the lurch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beshrew(v)">Beshrew,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from <etym lang="en">Shrew;</etym>
</page>

<page sig="C7v">
which see: or from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Beschreyen,</etym> to fascinate, or be&shy;
witch; and this from <etym lang="tt">Be,</etym> and
<etym lang="tt">Schreyen;</etym> as we say, to cry
down. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="besides(adv)">Besides,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Be</etym>, and
<etym lang="oe">Side</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  at ones side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="besiege(v)">Besiege,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Be</etym> Circum, about,
and <etym lang="en">Siege;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="besmear(v)">Besmear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Smear;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="be-smut(v)">Besmut,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Smut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="besot(v)">Besot,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Sot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bespeak(v)">Bespeak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the part. <etym lang="oe">Be,</etym> and
<etym lang="oe">Specan</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to speak for a
thing before-hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="besprinkle(v)">Besprinkle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Sprinkle;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="best(a)">Best,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Betest</etym>,
by contraction Best; this,
I suppose, from the word <etym lang="oe">Bid&shy;
dan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bitten,</etym> to pray
for; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a thing most desi&shy;
rable, and therefore most wor&shy;
thy to be asked of God in
prayer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bestir(v)">To Bestirr</form> <xpln lang="en">ones self, from the
part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Stire;</etym> so
as to sweat in doing any
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bestow(v)">Bestow;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsevus supposeth it
to come from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beste&shy;
den,</etym> to spend upon some per&shy;
son or thing: I had rather
draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Be</etym>, and
<etym lang="oe">Stow,</etym> a place; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to place
one out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bet(v)">To Bett,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wet&shy;
ten,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wedden,</etym> to wager.
v. Abett.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="betake(v)">Betake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Take; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  </etym> to fly to the Al&shy;
tar, or Sanctuary: Or rather,
from the AS. part. <etym lang="oe">Be</etym>, and
<etym lang="oe">Taecan</etym>, to commit ones self
to a thing, or person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bethink(v)">Bethink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Be&thorn;en&shy;
can</etym>, Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beden&shy;
cken,</etym> to ponder, or consider;
from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Think;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="betide(v)">Betide,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tid</etym>, time; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to
happen in time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="betimes(adv)">Betimes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Be</etym>,
near, or hard by; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  By
Time. v. Time.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="betoken(v)">Betoken,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beteec&shy;
kenen, Teeckenen,</etym> to denote,
or signifie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="betray(v)">Betray,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bedrie&shy;
ghen,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Betrager,</etym> to co&shy;
zen. Somnerus derives it from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dris</etym>, an Impostour,
or Cheat; this perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Trica,</etym> a Witch; <etym lang="la">Tri&shy;
care</etym> signifying, to intangle, or
bewitch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="betroth(v)">Betroth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Troth;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to make sure to a Wife,
by giving her ones Troth.
V. Troth, and True.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="betrust(v)">Betrust,</form> <xpln lang="en">to commit a thing to
ones trust; from the part. <etym lang="en">Be,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Trust;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="better(a)">Better,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Better</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beter,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Besser,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Bedre;</etym> all the same;
however, it alludes to the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F73;&lambda;&tau;&epsilon;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="between(pp)">Between;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it,
not improperly, from the
</page>

<page sig="C8r"> 
Belg. part. <etym lang="bl">Be,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">Tween,</etym>
two: See Twain, and Two. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beaver(n)">Bever,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Befor</etym>,
&AElig;lfrick <etym lang="oe">Befer</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Beff&shy;
ver,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Biber,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bievre;</etym> all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fiber,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; a Hat so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beaver(n)">Bever,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baviere,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Baviera,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bavera,</etym>
the Bever of an Helmet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bever(n)">Bever,</form> <xpln lang="en">Merenda, an After-noons
nunchion; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Be&shy;
vre,</etym> to drink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beverage(n)">Beverage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Breu&shy;
vage,</etym> this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">B&shy;
ibere,</etym> to drink; or rather,
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Beveraggio,</etym> and
that from the Verb <etym lang="it">Bevre,</etym> to
drink; because the money
laid out upon the first wea&shy;
ring of new cloths, &amp;c. is
spent in drink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pear beurre(n)">The Pear Beurre,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Pyrum
Butyraceum, Butter-pear, be&shy;
cause as soft as Butter.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"pear beurre" not found as a headword in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bewail(v)">Bewail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the prefix <etym lang="en">Be,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Wail;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beware(v)">Beware,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bewa&shy;
ren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bewahren,</etym> to
guard; and this from the Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Beuuaran,</etym> which Fr. Jun.
derives from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Omega;&rho;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>,
or <etym lang="gk">&Omicron;&upsilon;&rho;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to take care.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bewitch(v)">Bewitch,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Witch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bewray(v)">Bewray,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wre&shy;
gan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wroeghen,</etym> to dis&shy;
cover, and the prefix <etym lang="bl">Be.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="beyond(adv)">Beyond,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Yond, and Yonder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bez-antler(n)">Bezantler,</form> <xpln lang="en">the next knag in a
Stag's horn to the Browantler;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Bisantler, another Ant&shy;
ler. v. Antlers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bezel(n)">Bezeill of a ring,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word found
in Higginius; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bassin;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the broadest
part of a ring, wherein the
stone or signet is set.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bezoar(n)">Bezoar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Persick <etym lang="pe">Pazar,</etym>
or <etym lang="pe">Pazan,</etym> a Goat, because it
is found in the Belly of a cer&shy;
tain Goat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bezzle(n)">Bezzle,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Bevel, from the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bevere,</etym> this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bibere;</etym> or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Beastle,</etym> as we
say, to be as drunk as a Beast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bias(n)">Byass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Biais,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Sbiaggio,</etym> an inclination;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Byass of the Bowl
makes it incline to the Jack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bib(n)">Bib,</form> <xpln lang="en">a napkin, or such like cloth,
put upon children's breasts, to
keep their Cloths clean; from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bibere,</etym> to drink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bib(v)">To Bib,</form> <xpln lang="en">to drink a little and of&shy;
ten, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bibere,</etym> as
before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bicker(v)" lexeme="bickering(n)">Bicker, or Bickering,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bicre,</etym> a Conflict; but
I had rather derive it from the
word <etym lang="en">Pickeer,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Pike;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bid(v)">Bid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beodan</etym>, Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Gibinden,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bid(v)">To Bid</form> <xpln lang="en">Guests, from the Dan.
<etym lang="da">Beder, Biuder,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bidden;</etym>
all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Biddan</etym>, to
intreat, or earnestly invite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bid(v)">To Bid</form> <xpln lang="en">for a Commodity, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Biddan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bie&shy;
den,</etym> to offer; all perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Petere,</etym> to ask.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bigarreau(n)">Bigarreaur,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Pear, red
and white, from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bigarrer,</etym> in Lat. <etym lang="la">Bivariare;</etym>
</page>

<page sig="C8v"> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a party-colour'd Pear,
partly white, partly red. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="big(a)">Big,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Bug,</etym> AS.
<etym lang="oe">Buce</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one whose belly
struts out; or from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bucco</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one with thick,
fat cheeks. Bug may seem
to come of the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&upsilon;&kappa;&nu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>,
thick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="biggin(n)">Biggin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a child's coif, from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Beguin,</etym> and this from
St. <etym lang="tt">Begga,</etym> that first instituted
it, for a distinction of certain
religious women.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bight(n)">Bight,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; I sup&shy;
pose, 'tis as much as to say,
The Bought, or bending of a
cable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bildge(n)">Bildge,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bilig</etym>, a belly; a ship
is said to be Bildged, when it
springs a Leak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bile(n)">Bile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bile</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Buyle,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beul,</etym> an ulcer,
or sore; or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bul&shy;
la,</etym> because it stands out like a
bubble in water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bilk(n)">Bilk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bilck,</etym> an
huckle-bone, used in playing
at Cockall; also a Dy.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"bilk" not found in OED in this sense.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bill(n)">Bill of a bird,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bile</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: It alludes to the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&eta;</etym>, an entrance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bill(n)">A Bill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bill</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Byl,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beil,</etym> a sort of
Ax.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bill(n)">Bill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. rec. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F77;&lambda;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
for <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F77;&beta;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the Lat. <etym lang="la">Libellus</etym>,
by casting away the first syllable; or lastly, from the barb.
Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulla,</etym> a Bull, or Bill;
which, indeed, is most proba&shy;
ble.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="billet(n)">Billet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Billette;</etym>
perhaps from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Pile,</etym>
and this from the Lat. and Gr.
<etym lang="gk">Pyra,</etym> an heap of wood for
burning the dead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="billet(v)">Billet,</form> <xpln lang="en">to quarter Soldiers upon
command by a schedule, or
paper; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Billet,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bolletta;</etym> all, I suppose,
from the words <etym lang="en">Bill,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Bull,</etym>
whereof they are only Dimi&shy;
nutives.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="billiards(n)">Billiars,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Billart,</etym>
a stick or staff that we put the
ball from us with; and this
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pila,</etym> because
they play with round things
like balls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="billow(v)">Billow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bilg,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Bolge;</etym> both from <etym lang="da">Bul&shy;
lio;</etym> or rather, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bel&shy;
len,</etym> to make a noise like a dog,
as waves do, rolling one on
the back of another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bilter(n)">Bilter,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word found in a book
called <f type="i">The Art of Fowling</f>, a bird haunting fens (as saith the
Author) from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beltz,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pels</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  having a kind
of wool instead of feathers.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Bilter" not in OED except as "bilcock."
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bind(v)">Bind,</form> <xpln lang="en">most probably from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Binare,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Combinare,</etym>
by interposing d, for things
bound, are, as it were, united
in one body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bin(n)">Binn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Binne</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Benne,</etym> a basket for bread. Voss.
derives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ben&shy;
na:</etym> I would rather draw it from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pyndan</etym>, to inclose.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D1r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="birch(n)">Birch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Birc</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Birck,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Berck,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bird(n)">Bird;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsevus derives it from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broeden, Vrueden,</etym>
to sit upon: Somewhat more
nearly it may be taken from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bredan</etym>, to keep
warm. V. Breed, and Brood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burlet(n)">Birlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bourlet,</etym>
this from <etym lang="fr">Bourre,</etym> a lock of
wool, by adding the termina&shy;
tion <etym lang="fr">Let; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  </etym> stuffed with
wool or flocks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="birth(n)">Birth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beoryt</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Burt,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. V. To
Bear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bishop(n)">Bishop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bisceow,
Biscop</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bischoff,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Bischop;</etym> all from the Lat. and
Gr. <etym lang="gk">Episcopus</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="biscuit(n)">Bisket;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Biscoctus,</etym>
twice baked.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="be(v)">Bist,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bist</etym>, cor&shy;
rupted from <etym lang="oe">Beest.</etym> See Be.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bitch(n)">Bitch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bicce,
Bice</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Abr. Mill. af&shy;
firmeth, that the Persian word
<etym lang="pe">Bitse</etym> signifieth the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bite(v)">Bite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bitan</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Beyten,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Betssen,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bit(n)">Bitt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bitole</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gebisz,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghebit;</etym>
so called, because chawed by
the horse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bittackle(n)">Bittackle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bitte,</etym>
a mouthful, the Lat. <etym lang="la">Acus,</etym> a
needle, or <etym lang="en">Tackle;</etym> which
see.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See OED "binnacle" but this sense not found.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bitter(a)">Bitter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Biter</etym>,
which comes from <etym lang="oe">Bitan</etym>, to
bite; yet it seemeth to allude
to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&iota;&kappa;&rho;#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bittern(n)">Bittern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Butoor,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Butor,</etym> or <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="la"> Bos
Taurus,</etym> for thrusting its beak
into the ground, it bellows
like an Ox.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bitt(n)">Bitts,</form> <xpln lang="en">proper to Mariners, from
our Eng. <etym lang="en">Pight,</etym> a part. of the
Verb <etym lang="en">To Pitch.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blab(v)" lexeme="blabber(v)">Blab, or Blabber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Blapperen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Labberen,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Labia, Elabiare,</etym> to speak rashly, or
unadvisedly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blabber-lipped(a)">Blabber-lip'd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">La&shy;
bium, Labrum,</etym> a lip.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="black(a)">Black,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blac</etym>, Ink,
or <etym lang="oe">Blaecan</etym>, to make black like
Ink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blackberry(n)">Black-berrits,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bl&aelig;ce-Berian, Bl&aelig;ce-&shy;
Bergen</etym>, signifying the same.
See Black, and Berry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bladder(n)">Bladder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blaran</etym>,
to blow; because it is easily
filled with wind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blade(n)">Blade</form> <xpln lang="en">of a Sword, from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bl&aelig;d</etym>, a leaf, because broad
as a Leaf. Mer. Cas. derives
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F4C;&beta;&epsilon;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a
spit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blade(n)">Blade of Corn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Blaed</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Blad, Bladr,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blatt,</etym> a leaf; all imme&shy;
diately from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Latus,</etym>
and this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&alpha;&tau;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>,
broad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blain(n)">Blain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blaran</etym>,
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blaen,</etym> to blow;
</page>

<page sig="D1v"> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a blowing up in the Skin,
or a swelling. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blame(v)">Blame,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blas&shy;
mer,</etym> this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Blas&shy;
phemare,</etym> to reprove, or find
fault with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blanch(v)">Blanche,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blan&shy;
chir,</etym> to make white; V.
Blank: From, hence, To
Blanch Almonds; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) take
off the rind and husk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blanch(n)">Blanch,</form> <xpln lang="en">or White-Coat, a name
of a bitch. V. Blank.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blank(a)">Blank page in a book,</form> <xpln lang="en">where no&shy;
thing is writ, from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Blanc,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Blanco,</etym> white.
I had rather derive it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blitan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blicken,
Blincken,</etym> to shine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blank(n)">Blank,</form> <xpln lang="en">money newly coined or
stamped, from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Blanc,</etym>
signifying white.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blanket(n)">Blanket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blan&shy;
chet;</etym> both from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Bi&shy;
anchetta,</etym> white cloth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blanquet pear(n)">Blanquet-Pear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Le Poir Blanquet;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
somewhat white.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"blanquet pear" not found in OED. 
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blare(v)">Blare,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Blaren,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blarren;</etym> all perhaps
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Flare, Efflare,</etym>
to blow, or breath out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blast(n)">Blast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan.
<etym lang="da">Bl&aelig;st</etym>, a Blast; all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Flare,</etym> to blow; and
this perhaps from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&omega;, &Phi;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to be hot, to
make a noise, as doth seething
water. V. To Blow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blast(n)">Blast of my meat,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word com&shy;
mon in the Bishoprick of
Durham; perhaps from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bl&aelig;se</etym>, a torch, or flame;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that blusheth often
at table.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Blast of my meat" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blasted(a)">Blasted,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our En. <etym lang="en">Blast,</etym> struk
with a deadly puff of wind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blae(a)">Blay,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Bleak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blaze(v)">Blaze,</form> <xpln lang="en">to divulge; from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bl&aelig;se</etym>, properly, a torch, or
lamp; improperly, a manifesta&shy;
tion, or declaration; or from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blasen,</etym> to blow a&shy;
broad. V. Blast, and Blow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blaze(n)">Blaze,</form> <xpln lang="en">a violent or scorching
flame; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bl&aelig;se</etym>,
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blasen,</etym> to blow;
because, taking the wind, it
makes a great noise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blazon(n)">Blazon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bl&aelig;se</etym>,
metaphorically signifying, a
shew, or manifestation; or
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blason,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bla&shy;
sone,</etym> an Escutcheon, or Coat
of Arms for a great Family.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bleach(n)">Bleach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;blece</etym>,
to set a sunning, or whiten linen
in the Sun; and this perhaps
from the negative Prefix <etym lang="oe">&AElig;</etym>,
and <etym lang="oe">Blece</etym>, black; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  not
black.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bleak(a)">Bleak,</form> <xpln lang="en">lean and weak; also a
Bleak, or chill wind. It al&shy;
ludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&eta;&chi;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, in&shy;
firm, wanting strength.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blay(n)">Bleak, or Blay-fish;</form> <xpln lang="en">not unlike&shy;
ly, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&#x1F71;&zeta;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a fish worth little.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bleak(a)">Bleak,</form> <xpln lang="en">or pale. v. Bleach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blear-eyed(a)">Blear-eyed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Blaer,</etym>
a push, or wheal; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one
having a rheum, or humour
in the eyes: Or from the Fr.
</page>

<page sig="D2r"> 
G. <etym lang="fr">Blaireau,</etym> a badger, much
obnoxious to this disease in
the eyes. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bleat(v)">Bleat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bletan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bl&aelig;ten;</etym> all perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Balatus,</etym> a bleating of
lambs, or sheep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bleb(n)">Bleb;</form> <xpln lang="en">some take it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&#x1F72;&psi;</etym>, a vein: I had rather
draw it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blaen,</etym>
to swell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bleed(v)">To Bleed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bledan</etym>,
the same. v. Blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blemish(n)">Blemish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blesme,
Bleme;</etym> and these from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Plumbeus;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to make
a thing look pale like lead. v.
Blane.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blend(v)">Blend,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blendan</etym>,
to mingle; perhaps from the
word <etym lang="oe">Blind</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  by mix&shy;
ing one thing with another, their former relish is so much
altered, that you cannot per&shy;
ceive distinctly the taste of
each ingredient.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bless(v)" lexeme="bliss(n)">Bless, and Bliss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Blisse</etym>, gladness; this from
the Germ. <etym lang="tt">Be-lassen,</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Las&shy;
sen,</etym> to dismiss; because, at
parting, we use to wish one
another happiness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blue(a)">Blew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blaw,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Blauw,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Blawr,</etym>
sky-colour'd; all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Flavus,</etym> Blue. Write Blue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blue(a)">Blew</form> <xpln lang="en">as a Razour; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Blew as
Azare, saith D. Th. H. Right
Blue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blight(n)">Blight,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same that Mill-dew is;
perhaps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bleych.</etym>
pale, from the colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blind(a)">Blind,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan.
<etym lang="da">Blind</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Blinde,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Blind,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blind(n)">A Blind,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Blind;</etym> such a
thing as hindreth the Enemy
from seeing the transactions in
a Camp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blink(v)">Blink,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the Dan.
<etym lang="da">Blincker,</etym> or from the Belg.
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blincken,</etym> or the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blintzen,</etym> to be half
blind: from hence cometh
our Eng Blinkard, one born
blear-eyed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blink(v)">To Blink beer;</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequent&shy;
ly used in Lincolnshire; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blinnan;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to keep
it unbroached, till it grow
sharp.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"blink beer" is not found in this sense in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bliss(n)">Bliss,</form> <xpln lang="en">an abstract of the Adject.
<etym lang="en">Blith;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blister(v)">Blister,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bluyster:</etym>
they seem both to allude to
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to bubble up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blithe(a)">Blith,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bli&eth;e</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bliide;</etym> and all perhaps
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">L&aelig;tus,</etym> brisk, or
merry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blotch(n)">Bloach;</form> <xpln lang="en">it is, not unlikely, a
contract of the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blodig</etym>,
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a bloody tumour, or swel&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="block(n)">Block,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Block, Bloch,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bloc,</etym> a
log of wood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="block(v)">To Block up,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Be&shy;
luccan</etym>, to shut up; as saith
D. Th. H. v. Lock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blood(n)">Blood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blod</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bloed,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blut,</etym> id.
possibly, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>,
</page>

<page sig="D2v"> 
to spring out; yet I had ra&shy;
ther draw it from Goth. ant.
<etym lang="go">Blod,</etym> soft, gentle; or from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blaen,</etym> to swell; or,
which is most likely, from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Blosen,</etym> to grow red. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bloodings(n)">Bloodings,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same with Black-&shy;
Puddings. v. Blood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bloom(v)">Bloom,</form> <xpln lang="en">a contract from <etym lang="en">Blos&shy;
som;</etym> or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blum,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bloem,</etym> a flower. Fr.
Jun. derives it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to bud, or shoot forth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blossom(n)">Blossom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blosm</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bloessem,</etym> a flower; or,
which is better, from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&alpha;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F71;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to sprout forth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blot(v)">Blot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blotter;</etym>
which, for ought I know, may
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ablutare,</etym>
a Frequentative of the Verb
<etym lang="la">Abluere,</etym> to wash away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bloat(v)">Blote,</form> <xpln lang="en">to set a-smoaking, or dry&shy;
ing by the fire. Minsevus de&shy;
rives it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bloedt,</etym>
blood: I would rather draw
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Blosen,</etym> to
be red. Whence we say, Blote-&shy;
colour'd; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that hath
a ruddy countenance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blow(v)">To Blow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Blaran</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blaen,</etym> the same. v.
Blast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blow(n)">A Blow with a stick, &amp;c.</form> <xpln lang="en">Min&shy;
sevus derives it from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Blouwe,</etym> and this from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&#x1FF6;</etym>, for <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&#x1FF6;</etym>, to smite; but
Mer. Cas. from <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, to
cast; because, in fetching the
stroke, we, as it were, throw
our arm from us.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blubber(n)">Blubber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Babbolo,</etym>
a child; because children are
most subject to it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blunder(v)">Blunder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lunde&shy;
ren,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Boldern,</etym> to
make a noise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blunderbuss(n)">Blunderduss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Donder-buss;</etym> because it rat&shy;
tles like thunder; or from the
Dan. <etym lang="da">Buldrer,</etym> and <etym lang="da">Buyse,</etym> for
the same reason.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blunt(a)">Blunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plomb;</etym>
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Plum&shy;
bum;</etym> because, Lead being
sharpned, holds no edge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blur(n)">Blurr;</form> <xpln lang="en">for ought I know, from
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Borra,</etym> a blot; but
most probably, from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Abluere,</etym> to wash out. Meta&shy;
phorically.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blurt(v)">To Blurt</form> <xpln lang="en">out, from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Blatzen;</etym> and this perhaps from
the old Lat. <etym lang="la">Blatire,</etym> to prate,
or talk idly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="blush(v)">Blush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bloose,</etym>
redness; or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Blusel,</etym>
fear: We may metaphorically
derive it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>,
to diffuse; because, upon fear
or shame, the blood spreads
its self all over the face.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bluster(v)">Bluster,</form> <xpln lang="en">used instead of Blaster.
V. Blast, and Blow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bo(ex)" lexeme="boggle bo(v)">Bo, Boggle Bo,</form> <xpln lang="en">a saying in Lin&shy;
colnshire, to affright children
withal. See Boggle Bo.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="board(n)">Board,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Berd,</etym> a
plank. V. Bord.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boast(v)">Boast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Boan</etym>, Belg.
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pochen,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bost,</etym>
to vaunt; and all of them
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Boare,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Reboare;</etym>
</page>

<page sig="D3r"> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to make ones
own praises ring again. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boat(n)">Boat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bate,
B&aelig;t</etym>, Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Boot,</etym>
the same: Notwithstanding,
it may come from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bott,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  an <term lang="la">Internuncio</term> of
a fleet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boat-swain(n)">Boat-swain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bate</etym>,
a boat, and <etym lang="oe">Swan</etym>, a young
man, or servant. V. Swain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bob(v)">To Bob,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Fob off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bob(n)" lexeme="bob-tail(n)">Bob, or Bob-tail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Bobo,</etym> a fool; spoken in deri&shy;
sion of those that tuck up
their coats behind, as short as
an horses dock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bobbin(n)">Bobbin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bobine,</etym>
a little round thing to work
Bone-lace withal; both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bombyx,</etym> a Silk&shy;
worm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bode(v)">Bode,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fore-Bode, from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bodian</etym>, to fore-tell, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Vorbott,</etym> a prediction, or pro&shy;
phecy; both from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bode</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bott,</etym> a messen&shy;
ger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bodkin(n)">Bodkin:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsevus derives it
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bodkin,</etym> sig&shy;
nifying the same. It may ve&shy;
ry likely have been called Bo&shy;
dikin, a little body, for its
smalness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="body(n)">Body,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bodige</etym>,
stature. Minshew derives it
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boode,</etym> a co&shy;
ver; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the mansion of the
mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bog(n)">Bog,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouche,</etym>
an entrance; or rather, from
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Buca,</etym> an hole. A
learned man derives it from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boogen,</etym> to bend;
because it gives way to one
treading upon it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boggle-bo(n)">Boggle-Bo,</form> <xpln lang="en">a saying very usual
in Lincolnshire; <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="la">Bos,
Boans,</etym> a lowing Ox; in the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bulleman,</etym> from <etym lang="bl">Bulle,</etym>
a Bull, and <etym lang="bl">Man;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
monster, half a Bull, and half
a Man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boggle(v)">To Boggle,</form> <xpln lang="en">to stammer through
immoderate anger; from <etym lang="en">Bog,</etym>
a Quag-mire; and metapho&shy;
rically, one at a stand in speech,
as if he stuck in a Bog, or in
the clay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bo-peep(n)">Bo-peep,</form> <xpln lang="en">a play among children;
from <etym lang="en">Bo,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Peep;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boil(v)">Boil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Builler;</etym>
this from the barb. Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulli&shy;
re</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boisterous(a)">Boisterous:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsevus derives it
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bister</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Biise,</etym> a tempest. The learned
Th. H. by an easie Metaphor,
derives it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bois&shy;
teux,</etym> rough. Mer. Cas. from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omega;&sigma;&rho;&#x03AD;&omega;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to seek
one by clapping the hands, and
crying aloud.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bolk(v)">Boke,</form> <xpln lang="en">a common word in Lin&shy;
colnshire. It may be drawn
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Evocare,</etym> to re&shy;
voke; or better from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boocken,</etym> to thrust;
for vomiting is, as it were,
a thrusting out of things swal&shy;
lowed.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bold(a)">Bold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Boude,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baud,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Baldo,</etym> the fame; and all of
them from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bald,</etym>
hastily; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that run&shy;
neth head-long into dangers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bowline(n)">The main Boling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in sail&shy;
ing; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boline,
Bouline,</etym> a certain rope in a ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boister(n)">Boister,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bolster</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bolster,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pulster,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all of them from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pulwe,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">Ster;</etym>
which is manifestly corrupted
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pulvinus,</etym> or
<etym lang="la">Pulvinar,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bolt(v)">Bolt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Buydelen,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beutelen,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blu&shy;
ter,</etym> to sift.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bolt(n)">Bolt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a round ball to be thrown
with slings; from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bolt</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bout,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Boltz,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bolt,</etym> the same.
Dr. Davis draws it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F79;&lambda;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, and <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, to
cast, or throw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bolt(v)">To Bolt</form> <xpln lang="en">out, from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Voulte;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to bend out as
an arch: But more likely from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouter,</etym> to thrust
out; because it does, as it
were, force it self out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boltel(n)">Boltel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture;
from the preceding word
<etym lang="en">Bolt.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bombard(n)">Bombard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the barb. Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bombarda,</etym> a gun; both feig&shy;
ned from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bond(n)">Bond,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bond</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
an obligation, or binding.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bone(n)">Bone,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ban</etym>, Belg.
and Dan. <etym lang="da">Been,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bein,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bonfire(n)">Bone-fire;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Bonus ignis</etym>;
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  portending good luck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bone-lace(n)">Bone-lace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bon,</etym>
good, and <etym lang="en">Lace;</etym> which see.
D. Th. H. derives it purely
from <etym lang="en">Bone,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Lace;</etym> affir&shy;
ming, that in old times, bones served for
spindles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bongrace(n)">Bongrace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bonne-&shy;
Grace,</etym> an handsom mein; be&shy;
cause it becomes children well.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bonhomme(n)">Bonhommes,</form> <xpln lang="en">a third Order of a
Franciscan Fraternity; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bons Hommes; </etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
devout, good men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bonita(n)">Bonita,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish so named; either
<term lang="la">quasi</term>, <etym lang="la">Bonus natator,</etym> a good
Swimmer; or from the Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Bonito, Bonico,</etym> it being in&shy;
different good to eat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bonnet(n)">Bonnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bonnet,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bonnetto,</etym> the same. You
may likewise derive it from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bon a la nuit;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
good to wear in cold nights.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="booby(n)">Booby;</form> <xpln lang="en">I suppose, from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Bouvier,</etym> an Herds-man;
for such, most an end, are ve&shy;
ry ignorant. We may fur&shy;
ther derive it from the Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Bobo,</etym> or <etym lang="sp">Bovo,</etym> signifying a
fool. After all, it were not
absurd if we should draw it
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bube,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Boeve,</etym> a child; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that
will be a child still.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="book(n)">Book,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Boc</etym>, Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Buoch,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Bog,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Buch,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all, not unlikely,
</page>

<page sig="D4r"> 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bocce</etym>, a
Beech-tree; because the an&shy;
cient Germans writ upon the
barks of Beech-trees, instead
of paper. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boom(n)">Boom,</form> <xpln lang="en">a long pole; from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Beam</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boom,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Baum,</etym> a tree; it being made
of a whole young tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boon(v)">To Boon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word used in Lin&shy;
colnshire, signifying, to mend
the high-ways; from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Abonner,</etym> which formerly
signified, to make better. But
I think it may better be
brought from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bane,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bahn,</etym> a publick path.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"To Boon" antedates earlier OED citation (1783).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boon(n)">Boon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bene</etym>, a re&shy;
quest, or petition.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boon(a)">Boon,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Boon Blade, or Com&shy;
panion; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bon
Compagnon,</etym> a good fellow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bower(n)">Boor,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boer,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bawer;</etym> all from the Dan.
<etym lang="da">Boer;</etym> or, which is all one,
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, to inha&shy;
bit. Right Bower.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boot(n)">Boot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bot</etym>, a com&shy;
pensation, or reward. And
Whelocus draws it from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Betan</etym>, to make amends.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boot(v)">Boot,</form> <xpln lang="en">What Boot's it you? from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Baeten,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bat&shy;
ten,</etym> to profit, or avail. It
seems to allude to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&eta;&shy;
&theta;&#x03AD;&omega;</etym>, to help, or assist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boot(n)">Boots:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voot,</etym> a foot: I had
rather draw it from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Boteau,</etym> <term lang="la">fascis</term>; because, in
those ruder times, straw wrea&shy;
thed about their legs, was in&shy;
stead of boots.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="booth(n)">Booths,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boede,</etym> a
small cottage; Dan <etym lang="da">Bood,</etym> a
shop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="booty(n)">Booty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beutel,</etym> a
a purse; or, which is far more
probable, from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Baete,</etym> gain, or profit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="board(n)">Bord,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and C. Br.
<etym lang="oe">Bord</etym>, <etym lang="cb">Bord,</etym> a table. See
Board.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="board(v)">To Bord,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Run. Dan.
<etym lang="da">Bord,</etym> a side; Fr. G. Belg.
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bord,</etym> a brim; or from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Abborder,</etym> to ap&shy;
proach, or come near, as ships
do when they grapple. V. To
Border.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="border(n)">Border,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Borten;</etym>
or rather, from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bordure,</etym> a fringe; all, I sup&shy;
pose, from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Bort,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fort,</etym> on the out-side,
in sight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bore(v)">Bore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Borian</etym>, to
make an hole through; both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Forare,</etym> and
that from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F79;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, an
hole through any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boar(n)">Bore; or rather, Boar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bar</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eber,</etym> an
hog; all, not unlikely, from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aper,</etym> signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="borough(n)">Borough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Burg</etym>,
a city; or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Burg,</etym> a
defence, or fortification; these
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F7B;&rho;&gamma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a tower.
We likewise use the word, A
Burgess, coming from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Bourg,</etym> a city.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="borrow(v)">Borrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Borgian</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Borghen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Borgen,</etym>
to lend, or take upon loan.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bosom(n)">Bosom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Borm</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bosem,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Busem,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all, very probably,
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poser,</etym> for
<etym lang="fr">Reposer,</etym> to rest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boss(n)">Boss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bosse,</etym> the
same; and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Pusula,</etym> a blister; because it
somewhat represents a blister,
or any swelling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boss(n)">Boss,</form> <xpln lang="en">by Gardiners, a kind of
Cole-wort, full of bunches or
knobs; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bosse,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="botargo(n)">Botargo,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Italian word , but
now in use with us; from the
Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Botargues,</etym> the roan of
a Barbel pickled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="botch(n)">Botch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bosse,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Bozza;</etym> all of them from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pusula,</etym> a blister, or blain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="botch(v)">Botch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boetsen,</etym>
to mend; or from our Eng.
<etym lang="en">Patch;</etym> which see. From
hence, A Botcher.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="both(a)">Both,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Butu</etym>, and
this from <etym lang="oe">Be</etym>, according, and
<etym lang="oe">Tu</etym>, two.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bottle(su)">Bottle,</form> <xpln lang="en">the termination of ma&shy;
ny names of Towns and Vil&shy;
lages; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bode</etym>,
or our <etym lang="en">Abode</etym>; these from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bidan</etym>, to bide, or stay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bottle(n)">Bottle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Bouteille,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bottiglia,</etym> Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Bu&shy;
ticula,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Bitte;</etym> all the
same: Or perhaps it may be a
diminutive from <etym lang="en">Butt,</etym> as of
Beer; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bottle(n)">Bottle</form> <xpln lang="en">of hay, from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Boteau;</etym> or, for ought I know,
corrupted from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bon&shy;
del,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bundtel;</etym> with us,
A Bundle; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bottom(n)">Bottom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bodem,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Boden:</etym> King &AElig;lfric
calls it Botm; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) ground.
Minsevus draws it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F7B;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bottom(n)">A Bottom of thread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boteau,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bott(n)">Botts,</form> <xpln lang="en">worms in horses; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bote,</etym> a knot, or
heap; because they are often
drawn away in clusters: Or
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bitan</etym>,
to gnaw, or bite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="budge(v)">To Bouge</form> <xpln lang="en">out, from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bouge;</etym> this from <etym lang="fr">Bulga,</etym> a
bag; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  sticking out like a
blown bladder.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bough(n)">Bough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bog</etym>, id.
or from <etym lang="en">Bow;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bound(a)">Bound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bondt,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>. V. Bind, and Bond.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bound(a)">Bound:</form> <xpln lang="en">Whither are you
Bound? I am Bound for
London: Either from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Abunden</etym>, ready; and this
from <etym lang="oe">Bindan</etym>, to bind, by a
Metaphor taken from Sol&shy;
diers; who, when they are
in readiness to march, do truss
up bag and baggage: Or
from the other <etym lang="en">Bound,</etym> by a
Metaphor taken from Sailers;
who bind themselves, not to de&shy;
sert one another in any danger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bounds(n)">Bounds,</form> <xpln lang="en">corrupted, 'tis like,
</page>

<page sig="D5r"> 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bornes,</etym> id.
this perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fo&shy;
ran</etym>, before; and therefore
are called Frontiers, or fore&shy;
parts of a country, or field. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bounty(n)">Bounty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bont&eacute;,</etym>
goodness; of which it is an
effect.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bourn(n)">Bourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Burn</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Borne,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brunn,</etym> a
well, or spring; which Fr.
Jun. derives from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to spring forth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bout(n)">Bouts,</form> <xpln lang="en">many Bouts, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Beaten</etym>, to beat, Ital.
<etym lang="it">Botta,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coup,</etym> a box on
the ear; this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Colaphus, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all of
them from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&lambda;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>,
to hurt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bow(v)">Bow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bugan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Buygen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beugen,</etym>
to bend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bow(n)">A Bow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Boga</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boge,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bogen,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Bue,</etym> the same; all from
our word <etym lang="en">Bow.</etym> Mer. Cas. de&shy;
rives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&iota;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, a
bow, or arch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bowel(n)">Bowel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouyau,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; perhaps from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bottulus;</etym> as we say, Pud&shy;
dings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bower(n)">Bower,</form> <xpln lang="en">an anchor amongst Ma&shy;
riners, which a ship carrieth
often times to the <etym lang="en">Bow</etym> of the
ship, and from thence takes
its name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bower(n)">Bower,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bur</etym>, a
parlour. Minsevus derives it
from the Norm. <etym lang="no">Bough.</etym> I had
rather draw it from our word
<etym lang="en">Bow,</etym> because it is built with
crooked wood. Fr. Jun.
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F7B;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
an house, or mansion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bouge of court(n)">A Bowge of Court,</form> <xpln lang="en">a quantity of
provision allowed by the King
to his servants, beyond their
ordinary pay; from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Bouge;</etym> this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bulga,</etym> a Portmanteau. The
learned Th. H. draws it from
<etym lang="fr">Bouche,</etym> a mouth; as they call
one maintained at the King's
cost, <etym lang="fr">Il a Bouche en Cour;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he hath his mouth in
the Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bowl(n)">Bowl,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Menagius writes, from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulla,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Bolus,</etym> Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1FF6;&lambda;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, a round clod.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bowl(n)">A Bowl</form> <xpln lang="en">to drink in, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bolla</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. I had
rather draw it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulla,</etym> a round boss, or
knob in harness for horses;
because Bowls, especially,
those of any bigness, do gra&shy;
dually, from their basis, branch
into a round figure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bolt(v)">To Bowlt a Coney,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
hunting; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bouter,</etym> and this from the Lat.
frequentative <etym lang="la">Pultare,</etym> to beat
hard; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to knock her out
of her hole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bowse(n)">Bowse;</form> <xpln lang="en">Vossius draws it from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to fill. If
I were Grecian enough, I
should think it came from
<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&upsilon;&sigma;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to blow short; be&shy;
cause he that drinks greedily,
puts himself out of breath.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bursar(n)">A Bourser of a College,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boursier,</etym> this from
<etym lang="fr">Bourse,</etym> a Purse; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Pur&shy;
ser, or Treasurer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bow-sprit(n)">Bow-sprit, or Bolt-sprit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
our word, <etym lang="en">Bolt,</etym> and the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spriet,</etym> the Sail-yard.
v. Spritt-sail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bought(n)">The Bowt of the knee,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bug,</etym> the hamm; and
this again from <etym lang="tt">Beugen,</etym> to
bow, or bend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bowyer(n)">Bowyer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Boyert,</etym>
a swift Bark; perhaps so cal&shy;
led, from its being easily vee&shy;
red about, which way the
Boat-swain or Pilate pleases.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="box(n)">Box on the ear:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew in&shy;
geniously derives it from the
Gr. Adverb <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F7A;&zeta;</etym> or, it being
very probably of a German
original, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Po&shy;
chen,</etym> to strike, or smite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="box(n)">Box,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Boxe</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Buchs;</etym> all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bu&shy;
xus,</etym> a Box-tree; by the Sa&shy;
xons, <etym lang="oe">Boxtreow</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="boy(n)">Boy,</form> <xpln lang="en">possibly from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&iota;&shy;
&#x1F7B;&#x03c2;</etym>, little; though Minsevus
his derivation hereof from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bub,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Bube,</etym> is most
probable: Yet Minsevus, upon
second thoughts, appositely e&shy;
nough, derives it from the Heb.
<etym lang="he">Bob,</etym> a babe, or young child.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buoy(n)">The Boy</form> <xpln lang="en">of an Anchor: Dr. Th.
H. does ingeniously draw it
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bois,</etym> wood;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a piece of wood fastned
to the Anchor, and floating above water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brabble(v)">Brabble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brabbe&shy;
len,</etym> to scold: But it may be
more safely drawn from the
Lat. rec. <etym lang="la">Parabolare,</etym> to con&shy;
tend in words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brace(n)">Brace,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Embrasser;</etym>
or, which is all one, from
<etym lang="fr">Bras,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Brachium,</etym> a
cramp-iron to hook square
stones together withal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brace(v)">Brace,</form> <xpln lang="en">two, or a couple; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Embrasser,</etym> to em&shy;
brace: Hence, To Brace, or
couple two dogs in one collar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bracelet(n)">Bracelet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bra&shy;
chium;</etym> sometimes, though
seldom, read <etym lang="la">Brachiale</etym>, an arm,
upon which a bracelet is put.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brach(n)">A Brache,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word found in Flo&shy;
rius; perhaps from the Gr. v.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F71;&chi;&omega;</etym>, to sound or resound;
a kind of Hound of a strong cry, so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bracken(n)">Brackan, or Fern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our
own word <etym lang="en">Break;</etym> because, be&shy;
ing brittle, it is easily broken.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bracket(n)">Bracket, or Braget,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Architecture; if I be not mis&shy;
taken, from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Braciet&shy;
to,</etym> signifying, a little crotchet,
or cramping-iron.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bracket(n)">Brackets,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word used by Mari&shy;
ners; from the same root.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brackish(a)">Brackish, or salted;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brechen,</etym> to vomit; for
salt water provoketh vomiting</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brag(v)">Bragg,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Braguer,</etym>
to go stately, or proudly;
and this manifestly from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Paratus,</etym> ready, or fit;
for Braggadocio's consider
what they are to speak, or act
</page>

<page sig="D6r"> 
before-hand, lest they should be
trepann'd. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bragget(n)">Bragget,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Hydromel;
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Brag,</etym> Malt,
and <etym lang="cb">Goes,</etym> an honey-comb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="braid(v)">To Braid, or Bread hair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Breyden,</etym> to weave
together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brain(n)">Brain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Braegen</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Breyne, Breghe;</etym>
both from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x03AD;&gamma;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, which
signifies, the fore part of the
head, where the brains lie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brake(n)">Brake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word <etym lang="en">Break,</etym>
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Braeck,</etym> a wooden
instrument to break Flax
withal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bramble(n)">Bramble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bre&shy;
mel, Br&aelig;mbel, Brem&shy;
bel, Bremble,</etym> vexing;
because, tearing the hands,
&amp;c. with its sharp prickles, it
causes pain, or vexation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brambling(n)">Brambline,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of bird, so
called, from <etym lang="en">Bramble,</etym> in
