which it builds its nest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brancher(n)">Brancher,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Hawking;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Branchier,</etym> a
young hawk, a creature much
frequenting the boughs of
trees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="branch(n)">Branch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Branche,</etym>
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Branca;</etym>
which, before the declining
state of the Empire, signified
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brand(n)" lexeme="firebrand(n)">Brand, or Fire-Brand,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Brand</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Branden,</etym>
to burn; from hence, Brand,
a mark set upon cattel by the
owner. But our word Brand-&shy;
new, seemeth, by an elegant
Trope, to be taken from the
Smith's craft, being derived
from <etym lang="en">Brand,</etym> and <etym lang="en">New;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
just new out of the fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brandy(n)">Brande-wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Brande-wiin,</etym> burnt wine. V.
Brand, and Wine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brandish(v)">Brandish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bran&shy;
dir,</etym> to glister as a Sword does
in wielding; and so may, not
unlikely, be drawn from our
word <etym lang="en">Brand.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brandling(n)">Brandling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small worm to fish
with; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bran&shy;
diller,</etym> to wag, or move this
way and that way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brangle(v)">Brangle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Balgen,</etym>
to fight; and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bellum,</etym> war: Or from <etym lang="tt">Bran&shy;
gen,</etym> to be insolent, Bravo-like,
such people not easily suffer&shy;
ing an affront.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bran(n)">Brann,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bran,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Brenna,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Brann,</etym>
the same. Mer. Cas. derives
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F71;&sigma;&mu;&iota;&alpha;</etym>, i&shy;
dem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brant-goose(n)">Brant-geese,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Brand-Gans;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Geese of
a grayish colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brased(a)">Brased,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry,
Three Chevronels Brased; (i.&shy;
e.) three kids passing one ano&shy;
ther cross-wise; from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Emhrasser,</etym> to embrace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brass(n)">Brass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Braes</etym>, Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Bronze,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bronzo</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brassard(n)">Brassets,</form> <xpln lang="en">armour for the arms;
from the old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brasset;</etym>
which is a dim. of <etym lang="fr">Bras,</etym> an
arm.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Brassets" antedates earliest OED citation of "brasset" (1728).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D6v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brat(n)">A Brat,</form> <xpln lang="en">one come of an ob&shy;
scure parentage, a bastard;
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Fradde,</etym> a boy;
both, without any offence, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bredan</etym>, to
bring up. V. Breed, and
Brood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brat(n)">Bratt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a rag put before one;
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bratt</etym>, course
cloth; this from <etym lang="oe">Brittan</etym>,
to break; because it is a ro&shy;
ten remnant of cloth. V.
Brittle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brave(a)">Brave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brave,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bravo,</etym> stout, magnani&shy;
mous. It may also seem to be
derived from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&alpha;&beta;&epsilon;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>,
a Victor.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brawl(v)">Brawl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brullen,</etym>
to low as an Ox; but rather
from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Bawl,</etym> by an
interposition of the letter r.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brawn(n)">Brawn:</form> <xpln lang="en">the learned G. Rogers,
M. D. G. M. L. S. derives it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aprugna,</etym> sig&shy;
nifying the same; yet I had
rather derive it from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bar</etym>, a
Boar, and <etym lang="oe">Run</etym>, a
contract for <etym lang="oe">Runnen</etym>, hard&shy;
ned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brawny(a)">Brawny,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, from <etym lang="en">Brawn;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that hath hard and
brawny sinews, or nerves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bray(v)">Bray,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bracan</etym>,
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brayer,</etym> signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bray(v)">To Bray as an Ass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Braire;</etym> and this from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Barrire,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bray(n)">A Bray, or false Bray,</form> <xpln lang="en">a mili&shy;
tary word; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Braye, Fause Braye,</etym> a false
trench, made to hide the real
one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bread(n)">Bread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Breod</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broodt,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brodt;</etym>
all, I suppose, from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bredan</etym>, to nourish. V.
Breed. Fr. Jun. derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&omega;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, a mor&shy;
sel, and <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F7D;&sigma;&kappa;&omega;</etym>, to feed up&shy;
on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brake(v)">Break,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brecan</etym>,
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Brechan,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bre&shy;
chen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Breken,</etym> the same.
It may, not unlikely, be deri&shy;
ved from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F71;&kappa;&omega;</etym>, to
make a noise, or give a crack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breathe(v)">Breath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bra&eth;e</etym>,
the same. It may likewise be
drawn from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x03A1;&omicron;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
&AElig;ol. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F79;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, force, or noise;
for the breath, being stopped,
breaketh out by force.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breeches(n)">Breeches,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brec&shy;
ce</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broecke,</etym> the same:
From hence perhaps the word
Breech, if not more commo&shy;
diously from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bryce</etym>,
a rupture, or parting asun&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breed(v)">Breed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bredan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broeden,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bruten,</etym>
to nourish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breeze(n)">Breeze,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brio&shy;
sa</etym>, Teut. Dan. and Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Bremse, Brems,</etym> a gad-fly, or
hornet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breast(n)">Brest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Breost</etym>,
Dan. <etym lang="da">Bryst,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Borst,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bret(n)">Bret,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Nor. <etym lang="no">Berto&shy;
neau,</etym> a kind of Turbot: Or,
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brett,</etym> or
<etym lang="tt">Breit,</etym> a broad plank, or side,
because it is a broad sort of
fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brew(v)">Brew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Browen,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brawen,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brewess(n)">Brewess,</form> <xpln lang="en">bread dipped in pot&shy;
tage, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Abbreu&shy;
ver,</etym> to soften, make tender.
Fr. Jun. draws it from the C.
Br. <etym lang="cb">Briwbara,</etym> crusts, or mor&shy;
sels of bread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bribe(n)">Bribe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Briber;</etym>
this from <etym lang="fr">Bribe,</etym> a piece of
bread; because such as give
bribes, like importunate beg&shy;
gars, crave of the Judge to
avert the stroke of justice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brick(n)">Brick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bricke,
Briicke,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brique,</etym> the
same. Menagius draws it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Imbrex,</etym> a roof-&shy;
tyle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bride(n)">Bride,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brid</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bruyd,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Braut,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all of them from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bredan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bru&shy;
ten,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broeden,</etym> to keep
warm, or cherish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bridegroom(n)">Bridegroom,</form> <xpln lang="en">most manifestly
from <etym lang="en">Bride,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Groom;</etym> be&shy;
cause the man is, as it were,
groom, or servant to his bride
on the day of marriage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bridge(n)">Bridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brigge,</etym>
and this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ober</etym>,
above, and <etym lang="oe">Rige</etym>, a back:
Or rather, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Ober-ig</etym>;
that is, over the water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bridle(n)">Bridle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bridel</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Breydel,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Briglia,</etym>
the same; all, not unlikely,
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Breyden,</etym> to
Ride; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brief(n)">Brief,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. and Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Brief;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a short, concise
writing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="briar(n)">Brier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Br&aelig;r,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Abrojo, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. <etym lang="oe">Br&aelig;r</etym>,
I suppose, comes from the
Verb <etym lang="oe">Breacan</etym>, to break;
because it teareth the skin, or
cloths.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="breeze(n)">Brieze,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Brezza,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brize,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Brise,</etym> a
chill wind. It also alludes to
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&rho;&#x1F77;&kappa;&eta;</etym>, a trembling, or
shivering.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brigade(n)">Brigade,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bri&shy;
gade,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Brigata,</etym> a socie&shy;
ty; or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brigue,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Briga,</etym> a conflict, or
fight; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a band of war-like
men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brigandine(n)">Brigandine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bri&shy;
gantin,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Brigantino,</etym> id.
perhaps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bri&shy;
gand</etym>, a robber; because Pi&shy;
rates were wont to make use
of these ships, for their conve&shy;
niency. But you will say,
Whence cometh Brigand?
Faucherus draws it from the
Germ. <etym lang="tt">Brig,</etym> a bridge, or
<etym lang="tt">Brug;</etym> because robbers sieze
travellers upon bridges. Ni&shy;
cot. thinks it so called from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Berg,</etym> a mountain, and
<etym lang="tt">Gehen,</etym> to go; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that
goes among mountains to hide
himself.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bright(a)">Bright,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. supposeth it to
come from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Brith,</etym>
painted; or rather, party-co&shy;
loured.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brim(v)">To Brim as a Sow,</form> <xpln lang="en">possibly from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brine</etym>, heat; because
those creatures are very hot in
time of ingendring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brim(n)">Brimm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brime</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bram,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Bremme,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brimstone(n)">Brimstone;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Brenne-stone; or, which comes all to a thing,
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brine</etym>, fire,
and <etym lang="oe">Stone;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a burning-&shy;
stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brine(n)">Brine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bryne</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bryn,</etym> the same; and
both of them from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Brym</etym>, the salt sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bring(v)">Bring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bringan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brengen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brin&shy;
gen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brink(n)">Brink,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Brim.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brisk(a)">Brisk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frisch,</etym>
chearful; or from the Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Brio;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that is coura&shy;
geous and lively. V. Fresh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brisket(n)">Brisket,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Bresket, by ad&shy;
ding the diminutive termina&shy;
tion <etym lang="en">ket.</etym> v. Brest.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bristle(v)">Bristle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bristl</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Burstel,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Borstel</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>; yet not unlikely from
our word <etym lang="en">Burst,</etym> because a
bristle bursteth or breaketh
through the skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brittle(a)">Brittle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brytan</etym>,
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Brettan, Brittan,</etym> Dan.
<etym lang="da">Bryder,</etym> to break asunder. Fr.
Jun. derives them all from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, frail, or mortal.
Minsevus writeth it Brickle,
from the word <etym lang="en">Break;</etym> which
I cannot so well approve of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="broach(n)">Broach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Broche,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Broccia,</etym> a spit; hence
we say, Broach a vessel, meta&shy;
phorically.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="broad(a)">Broad,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brad</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Breyd,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Breit,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brocade(n)">Broccado; or rather, Brocado;</form> <xpln lang="en">
a word purely Spanish, but
frequently read in the English
Translation of Mandeslous;
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Brocca,</etym> a stud,
or boss; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  cloth of gold
and silver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brock(n)">Brock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Broc</etym>,
Ital. <etym lang="it">Burcho, Buchio,</etym> the
same; or rather, from the
word <etym lang="en">Break;</etym> because this
creature crusheth in pieces
whatsoever it fasteneth its
teeth upon; and hence comes
our saying, He bites like a
Badger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brocket(n)">Brocket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bro&shy;
cart,</etym> and both of them from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Broche,</etym> in our lin&shy;
gua, A Broach, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a stag of
two years old, having horns
without knags, like the end of
a spit, or broach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="broggle(v)">To Broggle for Eels,</form> <xpln lang="en">a saying
among Fisher-men; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brouiller</etym>, to trouble
the water; because by so do&shy;
ing, they are more easily ta&shy;
ken.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="broil(v)">Broil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the same root; if
not more properly from the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Broglio,</etym> for <etym lang="it">Imbroglio;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to canvass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="broker(n)">Broker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">Break;</etym>
because Bankrupts only were,
in former ages, permitted to
be of this trade. It may as
well be a contraction only of
the word <etym lang="en">Procurer.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brood(v)">Brood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bredan</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bruten,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broeden,
Brueden,</etym> to sit upon eggs:
It alludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to
grow big with young.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brook(v)">To Brook,</form> <xpln lang="en">to bear a thing pa&shy;
tiently, by inverting the sence
a little, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bru&shy;
can</etym>, to digest; or from the
Dan. <etym lang="da">Brugen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brauchen,</etym>
to have the use of a thing.
Mer. Cas. draws it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F7B;&kappa;&omega;, &Beta;&rho;&upsilon;&kappa;&#x1F71;&omega;, &Beta;&rho;&#x1F7D;&sigma;&kappa;&omega;</etym>,
to eat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brook(n)">Brook,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Broca</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broeck;</etym> and this Fr.
Jun. derives from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&alpha;&gamma;&#x1F78;&sigma;</etym>, a Marsh, or Fenn. But
Brook, when it signifies a ri&shy;
ver, is derived from <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&omicron;chi;&#x1F74;</etym>, a
shower. Mer. Cas. derives it
from the &AElig;ol. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&#x1F7A;&alpha;&zeta;</etym>, for
<etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F7B;&alpha;&zeta;</etym>, a river. Dr. Th. H.
draws the AS. <etym lang="oe">Broca</etym>, a ri&shy;
ver, from <etym lang="oe">Breacan</etym>, to break;
because, upon rain, they break
over their banks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="break(n)">A Brook,</form> <xpln lang="en">for an Impostume,
or sore; from the word
<etym lang="en">Break.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="broom(n)">Broom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brom</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brem,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfriem,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="broth(n)">Broth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bro&eth;</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broye, Brue,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bruhe,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brode,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Brodio,</etym> the same. Mer. Cas.
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&rho;&omega;&tau;&#x1F78;&nu;</etym>,
meat, or food.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brothel(n)">Brothel,</form> <xpln lang="en">by a Metathesis, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bordel, Bordeau,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bordello, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bord,</etym> the brink,
and <etym lang="fr">Eau,</etym> water; because, a&shy;
mongst the Romans, Stews
and Bawdy-houses were erect&shy;
ed upon the banks of rivers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brother(n)">Brother,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bro&shy;
&eth;er, Bro&eth;or,</etym> Fr. Th.
<etym lang="hd">Bruother,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broeder,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bruder,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Brawd,</etym> the
same; and all of them from
the word <etym lang="en">Breed;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  of the
same Brood.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brow(n)">Brow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Browa</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brauwe, Brouwe,</etym> the
eye-brow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brow(n)">Brow,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Brow of a thing;
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brauwe,</etym> the
brim of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brown(n)">Brown,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brun</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bruyn,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Braun,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bruno,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="browse(v)">Browse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brou&shy;
ser,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bruscare,</etym> to crop off
leaves and twigs. V. Brush.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bruise(v)">Bruise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS, <etym lang="oe">Brysed</etym>,
bruised; Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Froisser,</etym> to
bruise; or from <etym lang="fr">Briser,</etym> which
comes from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Bruz&shy;
zen;</etym> both not unlikely, from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pressare,</etym> to press, or
crush together.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="D8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bruit(n)">Bruit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bruit,</etym>
a report; this perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Furere,</etym> to be in a
rage, or fury.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brunt(n)">Brunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">to bear the Brunt of the
day; from the Teut. and Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Brunst;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Heat of the
day V. Burn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brush(n)">Brush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bresse,
Broisse,</etym> the same: Or, as
Minsevus saith, from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Burste,</etym> a bristle; be&shy;
cause made of bristles: From
hence Brush wood, from Brush
and Wood <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  young small
sprigs, in comparison, like to
Swines bristles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="brustle(v)">To Brustle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brust&shy;
lian</etym>, to rustle as Armour:
Or as Dr. Th. H. sagaciously
divineth, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  To <etym lang="en">Bristle,</etym> as
an enraged boar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bubble(n)">Bubble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bobble,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Boble,</etym> the same; per&shy;
haps corrupted from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bulla,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buck(n)">Buck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Baucle,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bucata,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bu&eacute;e,</etym> ley
made of ashes; all perhaps
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Focus,</etym> a fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buck(n)">A Buck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bucca</etym>,
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouc,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F75;&kappa;&eta;</etym>,
a Roe, or Hind. Martinius
derives it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Boc&shy;
ken,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Buquer,</etym> to re&shy;
pulse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bucket(n)">Bucket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bac&shy;
quet;</etym> and both perhaps from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Buc</etym>, a flaggon. Som&shy;
nerus draws it from the Lat. and
Gr. <etym lang="la">Baucalium,</etym> a kind of
water-pot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buckle(v)">To Buckle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Buc&shy;
ken,</etym> and this from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Bugan</etym>, signifying, to stoop
down, to Bow; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buckle(n)">Buckle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bokel,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boucle,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Buckel,</etym>
and all, I suppose, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bugan</etym>, to bend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buckler(n)">Buckler,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bou&shy;
cler,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Boccoliero,</etym> Fr. Th.
<etym lang="hd">Bukelere,</etym> a target like an half
moon; which Fr. Jun. de&shy;
rives from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bocken-&shy;
Leer,</etym> a Goat's skin. I suppose
rather that it comes from the
word <etym lang="en">Buckle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buckram(n)">Buckram,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bourgram,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bucherame,</etym> the
same: Once it signified a very
thin sort of Linen and wool&shy;
len cloth; in which sence we
may draw it from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bourre,</etym> a lock of wool, and
<etym lang="fr">Grain.</etym> v. Grogram.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bud(v)">Bud,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouter,</etym>
to put forth; and this Mena&shy;
gius draws from the Lat. fre&shy;
quentative <etym lang="la">Pultare,</etym> to beat
out often.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="budge(v)">Budge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouger,</etym>
both from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Volgere,</etym>
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Volve&shy;
re;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to move out of his
former place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="budge-barrel(n)">Budge-barrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a vessel used by
Mariners, containing about an
hundred pounds of gun-powder; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouge,</etym>
a bag, and <etym lang="en">Barrel.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="budget(n)">Budget,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bou&shy;
gette,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bolgia;</etym> and all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulga,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E1r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buff(n)">Buff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the similitude it has
to the skin of an Ox, which the French call <etym lang="fr">Buffle,</etym> and the
Italians, <etym lang="it">Buffale,</etym> much wore
by officers in an army.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buffet(n)">Buffet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Buffe,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Buffetto,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bofeton,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buffet-stool(n)">Buffet-stool;</form> <xpln lang="en">I suppose it may
come from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Buffet,</etym>
a table; because it might serve
for a little table, it being made
after the fashion of a table.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buffle(v)">To Buffle,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Muffle, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Abyffan</etym>, to mumble;
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Baffen,</etym> to bark; per&shy;
haps all of them feigned from
the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buffle(n)">Buffle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Byffel,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Beuffle,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Buffalo;</etym>
they all signifie a kind of wild
Ox: From hence, A Buffle-&shy;
head; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Ox-head, as we
may call one, that hath a great
head and little wit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buffoon(n)">Buffoon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Buf&shy;
fon,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Buffone,</etym> a talkative,
prating fellow. Salmasius
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bufo,</etym> a
Toad; because such a person
swells like a Toad, when irri&shy;
tated.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bug(n)" lexeme="bugbear(n)">Bugg or Bugbear,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Big. Dr.
Th. H. derives it from <etym lang="en">Pug</etym>,
or <etym lang="en">Pucke,</etym> a Devil V. Pug.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bug(a)">Bugg,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Big; as when 'tis said,
He looks very Bug of it. V.
Big.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bugger(v)">Bugger,</form> <xpln lang="en">to lay with a male;
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Bugerare,</etym> the
same. Menagius derives it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bulgari,</etym> a peo&shy;
ple infamous for unnatural
lust; or from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Bugio,</etym>
signifying an hole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bugle-horn(n)">A Bugle-horn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bu&shy;
cula;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the horn of an heifer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="build(v)">Build,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bythan</etym>,
and this from <etym lang="oe">Bili&eth;</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bild,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beeld,</etym> a statue,
or image.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bullfinch(n)">Bulfinch:</form> <xpln lang="en">Dr. Th. H. supposeth it
to be so call'd, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Bloodfinch.</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) crimson-colour'd; it
being in the Teut. primarily
called <etym lang="tt">Blutfinck.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bulk(n)">Bulk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Buce</etym>, Dan.
<etym lang="da">Bug,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bauch;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) big
in the body. It may likewise
be drawn from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bul&shy;
to,</etym> which denotes the stature
of the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bulk(n)">Bulkar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently used
in Lincolnshire; from the
Dan. <etym lang="da">Bielke,</etym> signifying, a
beam, or rafter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bull(n)">Bull,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bolle, Bul,</etym>
the same; or from the noise
he makes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bull(n)">Bull,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Denunciation, or Edict
from the Pope; from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&upsilon;&lambda;&#x1F74;</etym>, counsel; because, in
former ages, they were com&shy;
posed by the mutual consent
of a Council, or Senate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bullace(n)" lexeme="bullis(n)">Bullace, or Bullis,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from
<etym lang="en">Bowl,</etym> <etym lang="en">or Bullet,</etym> because they
are round; but I had rather
side with Dr. Th. H who
thinks it so called, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Bull-&shy;
eyes,</etym> from the similitude.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bull-beggar(n)">Bull-beggar:</form> <xpln lang="en">Dr. Th. H. thinks
it ingeniously so called, <term lang="la">quasi</term>
<etym lang="en">Bold Beggar,</etym> one that will
</page>

<page sig="E1v">
not be denied. V. Bull, and
Beggar. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bullet(n)">Bullet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boulet,</etym>
a little globe; perhaps from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1FF6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a round clod
of earth. It alludes to the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&lambda;&#x03AD;&omega;</etym>, to turn often.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bullion(n)">Bullion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1FF6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
a lump of earth; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  money
having no stamp or signature
upon it. I could almost ad&shy;
venture to derive it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&#x1FE6;&lambda;&alpha;</etym>, a signature; be&shy;
cause it is to receive the Prince
his signet, or effigies, before it
be currant coin. Minsevus
draws it from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Billon,</etym>
or <etym lang="sp">Vellon;</etym> which he interpre&shy;
teth, Bullion, or Copper to
make money of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bullock(n)">Bullock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bulluce</etym>;
a diminutive of <etym lang="oe">Bull;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bully(a)">A Bully fellow;</form> <xpln lang="en">either <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Bulky;</etym> or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Bull-eyed.</etym>
V. Balk, Burly, and Bull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bulrush(n)">Bull-rush,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a greater and
stronger kind of rush.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bulwark(n)">Bulwark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bol-&shy;
werck,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Boll-werck,</etym> from
<etym lang="tt">Boll,</etym> round, and <etym lang="tt">Werck,</etym>
work; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a spherical fa&shy;
brick. Salmasius draws it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1FF6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
work made of turf, or earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bum(n)">Bum,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bomme,</etym>
a cover for a vessel. A noted
Author draws it from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bodem;</etym> with us, the
Fundament.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bombasine(n)">Bumbasin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bum&shy;
basin,</etym> a web made of silk and
Cotton; both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bombyx;</etym> which, among the
Ancients, signified Cotton, as
well as silk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bombast(n)">Bumbast,</form> <xpln lang="en">linen doubled, and in&shy;
terwoven with flax: From
hence it is, that we say metaphorically, Bumbast words,
or stile.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bumble-bee(n)" lexeme="humble-bee(n)">Bumble, or Humble-Bee,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Humlen,</etym> the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bombilare,</etym> the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&mu;&beta;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>,
to hum, as doth a Bee.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bumpkin(n)">Bumkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boom&shy;
ken,</etym> a little tree; a fool in Lat.
being called <etym lang="la">Stipes;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
Block-head, one that has no
more sence than a tree. Dr.
Th. H. thinketh it so called,
<term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Pumpin,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Pumpion;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that liveth upon
pompions, or other course
fare, as the poorer sort of
country-people do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bunch(n)">Bunch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Bugno,</etym> or
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bosse,</etym> a wen, or knot.
Minshew derives it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&#x1FE6;&nu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, an hillock. v.
Botch, and Boss.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bunch(v)">To Bunch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pug&shy;
nus,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to smite one with
the fist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bundle(n)">Bundle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bondle,
Bundel,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Buntel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
and all from the word <etym lang="en">Bind;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bung(v)">Bung,</form> <xpln lang="en">to nip a Bung; which,
in the Rogue's language, sign&shy;
ifies, to pick a pocket; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pung</etym>, a purse, poc&shy;
ket, portmanteau, satchel,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bung(n)" lexeme="bung-hole(n)">Bung, Bung-hole,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl"> Bomme, Bom-gat</etym>, Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bondon,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. de&shy;
rives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F7D;&mu;&alpha;</etym>,
drink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bungle(v)">To Bungle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bou&shy;
gonner,</etym> to go about the doing
a thing awkardly; and this
again from <etym lang="fr">Bougeon,</etym> a great
arrow, or bolt; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to shoot with an arrow too big for the
white.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bun(n)">Bunn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp <etym lang="sp">Bunnelo,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bignet,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. We
may also form it of the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Bon,</etym> good; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a well-re&shy;
lished cake.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bunt(n)">Bunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Bunt of a sail; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the <etym lang="en">Bent</etym> of a sail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bunting(n)">A Bunting,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bondir,</etym> to hop up and
down upon the ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burbot(n)">Burbott,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bar&shy;
bote,</etym> and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Barba;</etym> because it is a Sea-&shy;
fish full of prickles: Or ra&shy;
ther, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bourbe,</etym>
mud; because it troubleth the
water, as it swimmeth near
the bottom.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burden(n)">Burden,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Byr&shy;
&eth;en</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Burde,</etym> the same.
Some there are, that derive it
from the barb. Lat. <etym lang="la">Burdo,</etym> a
mule, a creature naturally
proper to bear burthens.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burgonet(n)">Burganet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Bour&shy;
guignotte,</etym> a sort of net; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Burgundy-net.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burgeon(n)">Burgeon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bour&shy;
geon;</etym> and this perhaps from &shy;
<etym lang="fr">Bourre;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a tender sprig.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burger(n)">Burger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Borgher,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Burger,</etym> a Citizen. V.
Borough.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burglary(n)">Burglary,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Burg</etym>,
and the termination <etym lang="oe">Lary;</etym>
which, in composition, signifies, a robbery. It comes of
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Larron,</etym> a robber,
or robbery; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the robbing
and breaking open a castle;
for every man's house is his
castle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burlesque(n)">Burlesk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Burles&shy;
co, Burlare;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Mock-poe&shy;
try, composed of Jests to
make men merry withal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burley(a)">Burley,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Burley man; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Boor-like; (i e.) like a plow-&shy;
man, one that hath a big,
plump body. I might derive
it as well from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ge&shy;
buhrlich;</etym> this from the Verb
<etym lang="tt">Geburhen,</etym> to become; fat
men being generally the most
comely.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burn(v)">Burn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Baernan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Burnen,</etym> Teut. and Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Brennen,</etym> the same; and
probably, all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Furnus,</etym> an oven, or furnace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burnet(n)">Burnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">the herb Pimpernel; so
called, from the word <etym lang="en">Burn,</etym>
which it is good against: Or
perhaps from <etym lang="en">Bourn,</etym> a spring;
because it groweth most ple&shy;
ntifully near rivers and springs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burnish(v)">Burnish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Brunir,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Brunire,</etym>
to polish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bur(n)">Burr,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bourre,</etym>
a lock of wool; because it
hath such soft and light down,
</page>

<page sig="E2v">
that it is blown away by the
wind like wool. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bur(n)">Burr,</form> <xpln lang="en">the root of a young stag's
horn, from the same root;
for then 'tis tender and soft.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burrel-fly(n)">Burrel-fly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bur&shy;
reau,</etym> a tormentor; because it
miserably torments labouring
beasts in the summer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burrow(n)">Burrow of Rabbets,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Coney&shy;
berry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burse(n)">Burse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Borse,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Bourse,</etym> an Exchange; or
rather, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bursch,</etym>
a society; this from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Borg</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Burg,</etym> a sure&shy;
ty; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a society upholden by mutual stipulation, between
party and party.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bursar(n)">Burser,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boursier,</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he that hath the bag;
Purser.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="burst(v)">Burst,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Burstan</etym>,
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bursten;</etym> and
all perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bo&shy;
rian</etym>, to make an hole in any
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bury(v)">Bury,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Birian</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the Fr. Th.
<etym lang="hd">Berge,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Berg,</etym> an hill,
sometimes an heap. Minshew
draws it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ber&shy;
gen,</etym> to cover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bury(su)">Bury,</form> <xpln lang="en">a termination added to
the names of Towns, is the
same with Borough; which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bush(n)">Bush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Busch,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bosch,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bois,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bosco,</etym> a
wood. Fr. Jun. derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F79;&sigma;&kappa;&omega;</etym>, to crop.
I had rather derive it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Arbuscula</etym> shrubs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bushel(n)">Bushel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boisseau,</etym>
the same; or from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Buschel,</etym> a bundle; which
perhaps may be corrupted
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pugillus,</etym> an
handful.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="busk(n)">Busk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Busc,
Busg,</etym> the same; or more
commodiously from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Busto,</etym> the trunk of the bo&shy;
dy; because it is wore upon
women's breasts, to make
their Cloths sit tight, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buskin(n)">Buskin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Botine,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bottino,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and these
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bote,</etym> a boot,
they being a sort of little
boots.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buss(v)">Buss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boesen,
Bousen,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Baiser,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Basciare,</etym> to kiss; all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Basiare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bustard(n)">Bustard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bi&shy;
stard;</etym> and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Bis,</etym> twice, and <etym lang="la">Tardus,</etym> slow;
because being very big and
heavy, it raises it self, and flies
with great difficulty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bustle(v)">To Bustle,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Brustle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="busy(a)">Busy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bysgian</etym>,
to busy; Belg. <etym lang="bl">Be-sich,</etym> the
same: Or from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Besogner,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bisigare,</etym> to
be Busy, or meddle with a&shy;
ny thing. Somnerus draws
it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bisa</etym>, a
throng; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a throng of
Business.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="but(c)">But;</form> <xpln lang="en">as when we say, None but
</page>

<page sig="E3r">
he; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bute</etym>;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) None besides, or except
him. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="'but(n)">But,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bout,</etym> the
greater end of a thing, the
But-end of a tree, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butcher(n)">Butcher,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bou&shy;
cher,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Beccaro,</etym> the same.
Menagius derives them all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Buccea,</etym> because
he cutteth flesh in pieces, or
portions.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butler(n)">Butler,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouteil&shy;
lier,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Bottigliere,</etym> Lat.
barb. <etym lang="la">Buticularius,</etym> the same.
V. Bottle, and Butt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butt(n)">Butt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Butte</etym>,
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Butte,</etym> Fr. G.
and Ital. <etym lang="it">Botte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butt(n)">Butt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Plaice-fish; ei&shy;
ther from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Butte,</etym> or
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bott,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; an
Hallibutt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butt(v)">To Butt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Botten,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bucquer;</etym> or rather,
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">But&shy;
tare;</etym> all signifying, to run
against, or push with the
horn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butter(n)">Butter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Buttere</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Boter,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Butter,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butter-bump(n)">Butter bump,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird so called,
for its having smooth and soft
feathers. v. Buzzard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butterfly(n)">Butterfly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">But&shy;
ter-flege</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Butter-&shy;
fliege,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Botervliege,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buttery(n)">Buttery;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a place where
Butter is kept; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouter,</etym> to put; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Repository. V. Put.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buttock(n)">Buttock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bout;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Bolt of the bone.
Dr. Th. H. derives it from
<etym lang="bl">Bout,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hoh</etym>, in
English Hough.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="button(n)">Button,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouton,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bottone,</etym> the same. Me&shy;
nagius draws them all from
the Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Pultare,</etym> to
knock against a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="button(n)">Button</form> <xpln lang="en">in plants, from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Botte,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouton,</etym> a Bud;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buttress(n)">Buttress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fulta&shy;
re;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  props to support
the superstructure withal: Or
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brettesse,</etym> this
from <etym lang="fr">Brett&egrave;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the pin&shy;
nacles of a wall, being inden&shy;
ted like the teeth of a saw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="butwink(n)">A Butwink,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird so called, per&shy;
haps because it winketh of&shy;
ten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buxom(a)">Buxom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bocsum</etym>,
this from the Verb <etym lang="oe">Bugan</etym>,
to bend; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  flexible, or one
that will soon be perswaded to
a thing. Buxumness, by Chau&shy;
cer is interpreted, Lowliness,
or Submission.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buy(v)">Buy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bycgean</etym>,
the same. Minsevus draws it
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bieden,</etym> to bid
money for. V. To Bid.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="buzzard(n)">Buzzard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bu&shy;
zart,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Buzzago,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Bushard;</etym> and all of them pro&shy;
bably from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Buteo,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="by(pp)">By,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bi</etym>, Fr. Th.
<etym lang="hd">Bi,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">By,</etym> beside, or nigh
to. Hence By-name; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
nick-name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="by(su)">By,</form> <xpln lang="en">a termination of many
names of Villages and Towns,
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bye</etym>, an habita&shy;
tion; and this from <etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, to
dwell; or from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Bye,</etym>
a City, or Town.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="by-by(n)">By-By;</form> <xpln lang="en">Mer. Cas. derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&upsilon;&beta;&#x1FB6;&nu;</etym>, to
sleep; being sung by nurses,
to cause their nurslings to fall a-sleep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="byword(n)">By-word,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">By-&shy;
word</etym>, a proverb; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
saying always ready. v. By,
and <emend err="wlord">Word</emend>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="C"><alpha>C</alpha> <wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cabbage(n)">Cabbage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
bus,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cabuccio,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Raburs;</etym> and all from the Lat.
 <etym lang="la">Caput,</etym> a head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cabin(n)">Cabbin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Cabane,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cabanna,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Capan&shy;
na;</etym> and all of them from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavea,</etym> an hole, or
den. Salmasius derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&pi;&#x1F71;&nu;&eta;</etym>, a crib,
or manger</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cabinet(n)">Cabbinet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a diminutive of <etym lang="en">Cab&shy;
bin.</etym> See Cabbin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cable(n)">Cable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Cabel,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chable;</etym> all, not un&shy;
likely, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&lambda;&omega;&#x03c2;</etym>,
or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&mu;&iota;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caboshed(a)">Caboshed,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cabeca;</etym> or
rather, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
boche,</etym> an head; and all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caput.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caburn(n)">Caburn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among Sailers;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chevron,</etym> a
kid; it being a small rope,
compared with a Cable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cackle(v)">To Cackle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raec&shy;
kelen, Gaghelen,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
queter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Caccherare,</etym> the
same; all fictitious words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cackerel(n)">Cackrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">otherwise Cagarel so-&shy;
called a <etym lang="la">Cacando,</etym> because it
loosens the body, and moves
to stool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caddis(n)">Caddis,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Cod<emend err="m">w</emend>orm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cade(n)">A Cade lamb,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the
Lat <etym lang="la">Casa;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a lamb wea&shy;
ned, and bred up by hand in
the house, the dam dying:
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cade,</etym>
which seemeth to be contracted from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Delicatus;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  made much of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cage(n)">Cage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cage,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Gaggia,</etym> the same; all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavea.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cajole(n)">Cajoll,</form> <xpln lang="en">an up start word, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cageoler, Cajoler,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Gazzolare;</etym> and these
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Graculus,</etym> a Jack&shy;
daw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caining(n)">The Caining of a rope,</form> <xpln lang="en">a say&shy;
ing proper to Mariners; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
The <etym lang="en">Gaining of a rope;</etym> to
wit, when they weigh up an
anchor.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Caining" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caitiff(n)">Caitiff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chetif,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cattivo, Captivus;</etym> as
we say, a slave to the world.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cake(n)">Cake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kag,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kocck,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuch,</etym> the same.
Davis draws it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Coquo,</etym> to cook. V.
Cook.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calamanco(n)">Calamanco,</form> <xpln lang="en">possibly from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F78;</etym>, and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Man&shy;
tum;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  cloth fit to make
cloaks of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calamary(n)">Calamary-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Calamaro;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Cuttle&shy;
fish, having blood as black as
ink.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calendar(n)">Calendar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Calen&shy;
darium;</etym> that is, an enume&shy;
ration of all the Calends in the
year.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calendar(v)">To Calender,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Calendrer,</etym> to smooth cloth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calf(n)">Calf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Calf</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kalf,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kalv,</etym> the same.
From hence, The Calf of the
leg.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caliver(n)">Caliver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Calibre,</etym>
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">&AElig;quili&shy;
brium;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a piece of ord&shy;
nance, made after an exact
proportion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caulk(v)">To Calk a ship;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  mend it;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Calage,</etym> tow;
wherewithal it is stopped:
Or more probably from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;le</etym>, a Keel; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  C&aelig;&shy;
lage, or Keelage: Whence
we synecdochically say, To
Carine a ship; that is, to re&shy;
pair it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="call(n)">Call,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kalder;</etym> or
rather, the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&#x03AD;&omega;</etym>, the
same. Cardanus draws it
from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Col,</etym> Arab. <etym lang="ar">Caul,</etym>
signifying, a word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calico(n)">Callico-cloth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="hi">Calecut,</etym> a
great Mart-Town in India,
from whence it is brought.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calm(a)">Calm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kalm,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Calme,</etym> Ital. and Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Calma,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Cov. draws it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&#x1FE6;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, because
the wind ceasing, the air grows
warm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caltrop(n)">Caltrops,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Col&shy;
tr&aelig;ppe</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew
draws it from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Chausse trappes;</etym> so called,
because they cleave to ones
cloths. Th. H. Esq draws it
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cheval-at&shy;
trappe,</etym> because it also signi&shy;
fies, a warlike instrument to
ensnare the legs of horses
withal. V. Hose, and Trap. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Calvary(pn)">Calvary,</form> <xpln lang="en">Cross-Calvary, a term
in Heraldry; a cross erected
in imitation of Jacob's lad&shy;
der, says Morgan: Or rather,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a cross of <etym lang="en">Calvary,</etym> made
for a memorial of our Sa&shy;
viour's Cross, that was carried
up the mount, step by step.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cambric(n)">Cambrick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Cam&shy;
mertuth;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  cloth brought
from Cambray, a Town in
Picardy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cambering(a)">Cambring,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among Ship&shy;
wrights; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Came&shy;
ratus,</etym> Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&mu;&alpha;&rho;&omega;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
arched, or vaulted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comrade(n)">Camerade,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Chambre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Camera;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Chamber-fellow. v. Cham&shy;
ber.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cammock(n)">Cammock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cam&shy;
moc, Cammec</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Cammuc</etym>;
that which we call Rest-Har&shy;
row.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="camp(n)">Camp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Campe</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kamp,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kampff,</etym>
a fight, or battle; from hence
Champion; and all perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Campus,</etym> a field,
or plain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="can(v)">Can,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Konnen,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Kand,</etym> the same. It al&shy;
ludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F39;&kappa;&alpha;&nu;&#x1F79;&sigma; &epsilon;&#x1F76;&mu;&iota;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canary(n)">Canary-bird;</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, because
it is brought, from the <etym lang="en">Ca&shy;
naries.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cancel(v)">Cancel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cancel&shy;
ler,</etym> Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Cancellare,</etym> to
null, or rase out a writing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Candlemass(n)">Candlemass,</form> <xpln lang="en">or The Purifica&shy;
tion of the blessed Virgin;
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Candela,</etym> a can&shy;
dle, and <etym lang="en">Mass;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a festi&shy;
val celebrated with lighted
candles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="candy(n)">Candy,</form> <xpln lang="en">Sugar-Candy; either
from the Island <etym lang="it">Candia,</etym> for&shy;
merly Crete, which affordeth
great store of it; or, as Mena&shy;
gius has it, from the old Verb
<etym lang="la">Candire,</etym> to purifie, or make
white. Salmasius derives it,
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&nu;&tau;&#x1F79;&nu;, &Kappa;&alpha;&nu;&tau;&#x1F77;&omicron;&nu;;</etym>
because, when broken, it ap&shy;
pears all corner'd.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cane(n)">Cane,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Canna,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canker(n)">Canker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cancer,</etym>
any kind of spreading ulcer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="can(n)">Cann,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Canne</etym>,
Teut. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kanne;</etym> both
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cantha&shy;
rus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Dhuezius, not un&shy;
elegantly, draws it from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kahn,</etym> a skiff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cannel(n)">Cannel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of coal in Lan&shy;
cashire; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cene</etym>,
easie, and <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lan</etym>, to kindle;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  easie to be kindled.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cannel-bone(n)">Cannel-bone,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a bone near
the channel; that is, the throat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cannion(n)">Cannions,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  boot-hose-tops;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Canon,</etym> this
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Canna,</etym> a reed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cannon(n)">Cannon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Can&shy;
non,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cannone;</etym> and all,
for the similitude, from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Canna,</etym> a reed; as be&shy;
fore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canon(n)">Canon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
noine,</etym> Lat. barb <etym lang="la">Canonicus;</etym>
and all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&nu;&omega;&nu;</etym>, a
rule.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canopy(n)">Canopy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cano&shy;
p&eacute;e,</etym> and both from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omega;&nu;&omicron;&pi;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, and this from <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7D;&shy;
&nu;&omega;&psi;</etym>, a gnat, or fly; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
net spread over the face, to
keep off gnats or flies, whilst
one sleepeth: With us, it is
set up over Princes heads, for
a badge of imperial power.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canoe(n)">Canow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kahn;</etym>
or rather, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Can&shy;
na;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a small ship, long
and hollow, like a reed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cant(v)">To Cant;</form> <xpln lang="en">or, To use Canting
language, possibly from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tand,</etym> a ridiculous
phantasm; or from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cento,</etym> idle discourse; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to
use insignificant or nonsensical
discourse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cant(n)">Cant,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Canion.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E5r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantlet(n)">Cantlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Canton,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cantone,</etym> a corner; Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&nu;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"cantlet" antedates earliest OED citation (1700).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canton(n)">Canton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry,
from the same root ; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
quadrangular figure, set only
in the corner of an Escut&shy;
cheon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cantred(n)">Cantred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word used in Wales;
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Cant,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
an Hundred.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canvass(n)">Canvass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Can&shy;
nevas,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cannevazzo;</etym> all
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Can&shy;
nabis,</etym> hemp; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  made of
hemp, hempen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="canvass(v)">To Canvass,</form> <xpln lang="en">to search into, or
throughly examine a matter;
also to hunt eagerly after Votes in times of Elections;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Canabasser,</etym> or
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cannabis,</etym> hemp, by
a metaphor taken from beat&shy;
ing hemp, because nothing is
more laborious.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cap(n)">Cap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;ppe</etym>, Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cappa;</etym> and all of them from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caput.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capable(a)">Capable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Capa&shy;
ble;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ca&shy;
pax,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cap-a-pie(n)">Cap-a-pe,</form> <xpln lang="en">Armed Cap-a-pe,
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cap-a-pie</etym>;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) from head to foot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caparison(n)">Caparison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
parasson,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Capparisone;</etym> and all of them from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caput,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Paratus;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  ar&shy;
mour fitted for horses heads.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cape(n)">Cape,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cap,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Capo,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cabo,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cape(n)">Cape,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Cape of a cloak; by
a Synecdoche, from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">C&aelig;pe</etym>, Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cappe,</etym> Dan.
<etym lang="da">Kappe,</etym> a cloak, or riding-&shy;
coat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caper(v)">Caper,</form> <xpln lang="en">To cut a Caper, meta&shy;
phorically from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ca&shy;
per;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to skip or leap like
a goat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caper(n)">A Caper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capio;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a pirate, that taketh and
pillageth Merchants ships.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caper(n)">Capers,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capparis,</etym>
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&pi;&pi;&alpha;&rho;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capital(n)">Capital,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture,
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Capitello,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Chapiteau,</etym> the head of a
pillar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en"lexeme="capstan(n)">The Capstaw, Capstand, or Cap&shy;
stan of a ship,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>, an head, and <etym lang="oe">Steng</etym>,
a crane to draw up parcels
withal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="captain(n)">Captain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Capi&shy;
tain,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Capitano,</etym> or the
barb. Lat. <etym lang="la">Capitaneus;</etym> all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caput,</etym> because
he is the Head of his Com&shy;
pany.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="capuchin(n)">Capuchin,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Order of
St. Francis; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Capuchon,</etym> a Monk's hood;
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caput.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caravan(n)">A Caravan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Caravane,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Caravana,</etym>
and all from the Turc. <etym lang="tu">Ker&shy;
van,</etym> a company of Merchants
travelling through Turky with
a guard of Janizaries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caravel(n)">Caravel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cara&shy;
vella,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Caravela;</etym> and
</page>

<page sig="E5v">
both perhaps from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&rho;&alpha;&beta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a kind of flight&shy;
ship, somewhat resembling a
crab. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carbonado(n)">Carbonado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Car&shy;
bonade,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carbonata,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Carbonada,</etym> meat broiled up&shy;
on coals; and all of them,
not unlikely, from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Carbo,</etym> a coal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carcase(n)">Carcass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Car&shy;
quasse;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Caro Cassa</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
flesh without life.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="card(n)">Card,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kaerde,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="card(v)">To Card</form> <xpln lang="en">wool, perhaps from
<etym lang="la">Carduus,</etym> a Fuller's thistle</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="card(n)">A Mariner's Card,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Charta,</etym> paper</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cardinal(n)">Cardinal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cardi&shy;
nalis,</etym> and this from <etym lang="la">Cardo,</etym> as
being the Heads, or Hinges
of the Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="card(n)">Cards,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cartes,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Carte;</etym> and all of them
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Charta, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ear(n)">Care,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Care</etym>, Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cura,</etym> signifying the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caress(v)">Caress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cares&shy;
ser,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carezzare;</etym> and all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carus,</etym> dear, or
loving.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carfax(n)">Carfax,</form> <xpln lang="en">a saying at Oxford;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quarrefour,</etym> a
place where four ways meet:
Or rather, from <etym lang="fr">Quattre-Fa&shy;
ces,</etym> having four prospects.</xpln></wordentry>
