<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cargason(n)">Cargason,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Car&shy;
gaison,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cargacon,</etym> the car&shy;
go of a ship; and these from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Carguer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Car&shy;
icare,</etym> to load a ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carriage(n)">Carriage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
riage,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cariaggio,</etym> the
same. V. To Carry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cark(n)">Cark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Carc</etym>,
Care; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carcanet(n)">Carknet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Carcanet,</etym> a diminutive of
<etym lang="fr">Carcan,</etym> a neck-lace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carl(n)">Carl,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Churl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carling(n)">Carlings,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Char,</etym> Lat.
<etym lang="la">Carrus,</etym> a carriage, or suppor&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carnation(n)">Carnacion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caro;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a flesh-colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caroche(n)">Caroche,</form> <xpln lang="en">a French word; from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carruca,</etym> a kind of
chariot so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carol(n)">Carol,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F70;</etym>, joy,
or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to be glad; a cer&shy;
tain song usually sung on ones
Birth-day. Yet it may be de&shy;
rived from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Carl</etym>,
rustick; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a rural song.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carrot(n)">Carot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Carote,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Carota,</etym> signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carouse(v)">Carowse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
rousser;</etym> both from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Gar-Ausz;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  fill it all
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carp(n)">Carp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Carpe,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Carpa, Carpano;</etym> and all
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carpo,</etym>
to snatch greedily; for 'tis a
voracious greedy fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carpenter(n)">Carpenter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Car&shy;
pentier,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carpentiero;</etym>
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carpentum,</etym>
carved work.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carpet(n)">Carpet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Karpet,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Carpetta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and
</page>

<page sig="E6r">
this from the City Cairo and
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tapeto;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Tape&shy;
stry made at Memphis, alias
Cairo, a famous City in &AElig;&shy;
gypt. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carrabin(n)" lexeme="carabin(n)">Carrabin, or Carabin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Carabin,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carabi&shy;
no; </etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a gun to carry about
one. V. Carry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carrack(n)">Carrack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Car&shy;
raque,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Caracca,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Carraca;</etym> all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Carrus;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a ship of great
burthen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carat(n)">Carrat;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Carat,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Caratto;</etym> and all from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&epsilon;&rho;&#x1F71;&tau;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, an husk, or
cod; 'tis the weight of four
grains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="career(n)">Carreer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Car&shy;
riere,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carriera,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Carrera;</etym> as we say common&shy;
ly, To ride in a full Carreer;
from the Verb To Carry;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carrion(n)">Carrion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
rongne,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carogna,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Caronna;</etym> all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caro,</etym> flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carry(v)">Carry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
rier;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to carry in a cart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cart(n)">Cart,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cart</etym>, Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Charrette,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carretta;</etym>
all of them from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Carrus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; which Fr.
Jun. derives from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&rho;&shy;
&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, for <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F71;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, strength;
it being made strong, to sup&shy;
port weighty carriages.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cartel(n)">A Cartel</form> <xpln lang="en">of defiance, from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cartel, Cart&eacute;e,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cartello;</etym> and all, I suppose,
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Chartula;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
a provocatory paper, whereby
one man challengeth another
to a duel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cartridge(n)">Cartridge, or Cartage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cartouche,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Car&shy;
toccia;</etym> and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Charta; </etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  paper with
powder rammed into a gun,
when it is to be shot off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carve(v)">Carve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceorfan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kerven,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kerben;</etym>
and all of them, not unlikely,
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carpere;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
to cut or divide meat in por&shy;
tions.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="case(n)">A Case,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Casse;</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capsa,</etym>
a box, or coffer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="casemate(n)">A Casemat,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in war;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Casemate,</etym> I&shy;
tal. <etym lang="it">Casamatta,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Casa&shy;
mata,</etym> the same. Minshew
derives them all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Casa,</etym> an house, and the Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Matar,</etym> flowing from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Mactare,</etym> to kill, or slay;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an house out of which one
is slain unawares.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="casement(n)">Casement,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Casa&shy;
mento;</etym> because they are pla&shy;
ced outward, on the out-side
of the house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cash(n)">Cash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Casse,
Caisse,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cassa,</etym> a coffer to
hoard money in: And from
hence, A Casher, a Cash-kee&shy;
per, or Purser; all of them
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capsa,</etym>
a coffer.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cashier(v)">To Cashier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cas&shy;
ser;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cas&shy;
sare;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to disband a Sol&shy;
dier, and put him out of
pay.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="casing(n)">Casings,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Roth,</etym>
dung; which is gathered by
the poor people in some Coun&shy;
tries, to make fires withal; by
them called Casings.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cask(n)">Cask,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Casque,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Casco;</etym> and all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cassis,</etym> an helmet, or head-&shy;
piece.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cask(n)">Cask,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Caque,</etym>
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cadus,</etym> a pipe of
wine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="casket(n)">Casket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cas&shy;
sette,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cassetta;</etym> and all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capsula,</etym> a little
coffer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="casket(n)">Caskets,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among Mari&shy;
ners. V. Case, and Casket.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cassock(n)">Cassock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cas&shy;
aque,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Casacca,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ca&shy;
saca;</etym> and all of them from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Casa;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a long
vestment wore <etym lang="la">in casa,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
within doors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cast(n)">Cast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kaster</etym>, id.
Minshew draws it from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chasser,</etym> to drive
away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="castanet(n)">Castaniettoes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Castannetas,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Castagnet&shy;
te,</etym> the same; and all, not un&shy;
likely, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Casta&shy;
nea,</etym> chestnuts; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little
round shells, used by Dancers,
like unto chestnut-shells.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cat(n)">Cat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Katz,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Chat,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Gatto,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Gato;</etym> all from the barb. Lat.
<etym lang="la">Catus,</etym> the same; and this
from the Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Cattare,</etym>
for <etym lang="la">Captare,</etym> to catch at a
thing, as cats do at mice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="play at cat(v)">Cat,</form> <xpln lang="en">To play at Cat, from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kutte,</etym> an hole digged
in the ground, for the better
conveniency of raising the
ball, so as it may be hit with
the Cat-stick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catipan(n)">Catipan</form> <xpln lang="en">, to turn Catipan, from
a people called <etym lang="it">Catipani,</etym> in
Calabria and Apulia, who
got an ill name by reason of
their perfidy; very falsly by
us called Cat-in-pan.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See "to turn the cat in the pan", OED, "cat," 12. 
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catch(n)">A Catch,</form> <xpln lang="en">a ship, which, for its
lightness, soon overtaketh o&shy;
thers. Dr. Th. H. derives it from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ketsen,</etym> to run swift&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catch(v)">To Catch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chas&shy;
ser;</etym> or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ketsen,</etym>
to pursue one closely; or ra&shy;
ther, from the Ital. <etym lang="tt">Cattare,</etym>
and this from the Lat <etym lang="la">Capta&shy;
re, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catch(n)">A Catch,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Sonnet sung by
turns; so called, because eve&shy;
ry one <etym lang="en">Catches</etym> it from ano&shy;
ther. V. To Catch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catchpole(n)">Catch-poles,</form> <xpln lang="en">Serjeants to arrest
and lay hold on men; from
<etym lang="en">Catch,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Poll,</etym> an head.
v. Poll.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caterpillar(n)">Caterpillar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Chatte-peleuse;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a worm
hairy as a Cat. Dr. Th. H.
draws it from <etym lang="fr">Chair-peleuse,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  hairy flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cate(n)">Cates,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps contracted from
</page>

<page sig="E7r">
the word <etym lang="en">Delicates.</etym> Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Goth.
<etym lang="go">Cates,</etym> signifying the same:
From hence a Cater, or Ca&shy;
terer, a Steward at a feast. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cat-harpings(n)">Catharpings,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among Sai&shy;
lers, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Katerolle;</etym>
and this from <etym lang="bl">Katte,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">Roll,</etym>
with us, Rowl; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  small
ropes running in little wheels,
or pulleys.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="catlings(n)">The Catlings of Wall-nut-trees,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kattekens,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Katzleins,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chat&shy;
tons,</etym> down, or moss, which
grows about this sort of tree, much resembling the hair of a
cat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cattle(n)">Cattel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capita,</etym>
because they belong to one
head, or owner, by right of
possession: V. Chattels.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caterwaul(n)">Catterwawl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Cat,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Wawl.</etym> Dr. Th. H. thinks it
so said, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Gutterwawl.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cavalcade(n)">Cavalcade,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Cavalier.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cavalier(n)">Cavalier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
vailler,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cavaliere,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Cavallero;</etym> all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caballus,</etym> a pack-horse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="candle(n)">Candle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chau&shy;
deau, Chaudel&eacute;e;</etym> and these
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chaud,</etym> Lat.
<etym lang="la">Calidus,</etym> hot; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a confe&shy;
ction made of eggs, wine,
bread, sugar and spices, always
to be taken hot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cave(n)">Cave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cave,</etym> or
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavus,</etym> hollow; Ca&shy;
verna, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caver(n)">Cavers,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term amongst Mari&shy;
ners; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavea,</etym> a
cave.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"cavers" not found in OED in this sense.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caviar(n)">Caviary, or Caviare,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Caviaro,</etym> the spawn of a
Sturgeon pickled; caught in
Rha, or Volga, a river of Sar&shy;
matia, or Moscovy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caul(n)">Caul;</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the suet in which
the bowels are wrapped; so
called, because it representeth the form of a <etym lang="la">Cawl,</etym> or net:
in which sence, we may de&shy;
rive it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caveola,</etym>
because a net is, as it were, a
prison for fish. But when it is
taken for dress for women's heads, it seemeth to come of
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cavelli,</etym> or the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Capilli,</etym> hairs, saith Min&shy;
shew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cauldron(n)">Cauldron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chau&shy;
dron,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Chauderone;</etym> and
these from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chaud,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Caldo,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Calidus,</etym> hot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="causeway(n)">Causey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chaus&shy;
s&eacute;e,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Calzata,</etym> strewed
with chalk; or from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Calceus,</etym> a shooe; because be&shy;
ing paved with flints, it is
more commodious for foot&shy;
men than horse-men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cease(v)">Cease,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cesser;</etym>
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cessare,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cellar(n)">A Cellar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Ce&shy;
lier;</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cellarium,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="censer(n)">Censer,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Incenser, from the &shy;
Lat. <etym lang="la">Incendo,</etym> to burn; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a vessel wherein is burned In&shy;
cense; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sentry(n)">Centry,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Sentinel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="certain(a)">Certain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cer&shy;
tain;</etym> this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Certus,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="E7v">
certain, or sure. From hence the word Ascertain, or
assure one of a thing. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chafe(v)">To Chafe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chauf&shy;
fer;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cal&shy;
facere,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to heat, or warm
with rubbing: Hence, meta&shy;
phorically, To Chafe with an&shy;
ger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chafer(n)">A Chafer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
shauffer,</etym> to heat; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a ves&shy;
sel to heat things in.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chafer(n)">A Chafer,</form> <xpln lang="en">or yellow Beetle, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceafor</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Re&shy;
ver,</etym> Teut <etym lang="tt">Kafer,</etym> the same.
Scaliger derives it from the
Gr.<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&rho;&alpha;&beta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  having
a covering on its body resem&shy;
bling that of a crab.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chaff(n)">Chaff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaf</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kaf,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Martinius de&shy;
rives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavo,</etym> to
hollow; because when the
seed is struck out, the husk is
hollow. Fr. Jun. draws it
more ingeniously from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&#x1FE6;&phi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, light. Yet it may
be derived from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Caf</etym>,
swift; because it is easily car&shy;
ried away with the wind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chaffer(v)">To Chaffer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kauf&shy;
fer,</etym> to buy: it signifies, to
exchange one commodity for
another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chaffer(n)">Chaffer,</form> <xpln lang="en">Good Chaffer, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaf</etym>, good wares; or
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kooper,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kauf&shy;
fer,</etym> to buy, or purchase.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chaffinch(n)">Chaffinch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Caf</etym>,
swift; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  swift Finch. v.
Finch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chafing-dish(n)">Chafingdish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word
<etym lang="en">Chafe;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chain(n)">Chain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chain;</etym>
and both contracted from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Catena,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chair(n)">Chair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chaire;</etym>
and both contracted from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cathedra,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chabot(n)">Chalbot, rather Chabot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term
in Heraldry; from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caput:</etym> It is a sort of fish with
a great head, called a Gull,
Bull-head, or Miler's-thumb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chalice(n)">Chalice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Calice;</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Calix,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chalk(n)">Chalk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chaulx,</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Calx,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="challenge(v)">Challenge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
lenger, Chalanger,</etym> to lay
claim to a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chamber(n)">Chamber,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chambre,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Camera,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kammer;</etym> all
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&mu;&#x03AC;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, a roof,
or arch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chamberlain(n)">Chamberlain,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cambellan,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cambellano, Ciamberla&shy;
no,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kammerling,</etym> all
from the barb. Lat. <etym lang="la">Cammera&shy;
rius,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="camlet(n)">Chamblet.</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
melot,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Chamelote,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cambelotto;</etym> and these from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Camelus,</etym> a Camel;
this sort of stuff being made
of Camels hair.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chamfered(a)">Chamfer'd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Chambr&egrave;, Cambr&egrave;,</etym> crooked,
or arched; or, according to
Menagius, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ca&shy;
murus,</etym> for <term lang="la">Curvus</term>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
</page>

<page sig="E8r">
vaulted, or bent arch-wise. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chamois(n)">Chamois,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&epsilon;&mu;&#x1F70;&#x03c2;</etym>,
saith Scaliger; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the skin
of a young Faun: But Covar&shy;
ruvias derives it from the
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gamuza;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the skin
of a wild goat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chamomile(n)">Chamomil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Cammomille,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Camemil&shy;
la,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Camaemelum;</etym> all
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&mu;&alpha;&#x1F77;&mu;&eta;&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a
kind of apple, to which it is
like in smell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="champ(v)">To Champ,</form> <xpln lang="en">as doth a boar, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Champayer,</etym> to
feed; and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Campus,</etym> a field; or from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to devour greedi&shy;
ly; or <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&alpha;&mu;&phi;&#x170;</etym>, jaws; which
cometh from the Verb <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&mu;&shy;
&pi;&#x03AD;&omega;</etym>, to whet the teeth like a
boar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="champaign(a)">Champain, A Point Champain,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a term in Heraldry; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Champaigne,</etym> a field:
One that unhumanely slays a
captive in the field, after he
hath cried Quarter, says Guil&shy;
lam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="champion(n)">Champion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Champion,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Campione,</etym>
the same; all, not unlikely,
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Campus,</etym> a field,
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&mu;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to labour,
or take pains.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="champion-ground(n)">Champion-Ground,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Champaigne,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cam&shy;
pagna,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Campus,</etym> a plain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chance(n)">Chance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chance,</etym>
and this from <etym lang="fr">Cheance,</etym> a ver&shy;
bal of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Cheoir,</etym> to fall
out, or happen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chancel(n)">Chancel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Norm.
<etym lang="no">Chancel,</etym> and that from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cancelli,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Vestry,
anciently separated from the
rest of the Church by a parti&shy;
tion made lattisswise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chancellor(n)">Chancellour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Chancelier,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cancelliere;</etym>
all from the barb. Lat. <etym lang="la">Cancel&shy;
larius,</etym> and this from <etym lang="en">Cancel:</etym>
Hence Chancery, by contracti&shy;
on from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chanceliere,</etym>
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Chancellor's Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chance-medley(n)">Chance-Medley,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Law;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chance,</etym> chance,
and <etym lang="fr">Mesler,</etym> to mingle; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
unpremeditated death.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chandler(n)">Chandler,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chan&shy;
deliere;</etym> and both from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Candela;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one that
maketh candles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="change(v)">Change,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chan&shy;
ger,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cangiare, Cam&shy;
biare,</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cambire,</etym> the same. From
hence, To Counter-change;
also A Changeling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="channel(n)">Channel,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Kennel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chant(v)">Chant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chan&shy;
ter;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Can&shy;
tare;</etym> or rather, <etym lang="la">Cantillare,</etym>
to sing softly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chantecleer(n)">Chantecleer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a cock; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chanter,</etym> to sing, and
<etym lang="fr">Clair,</etym> clear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chanter(n)">Chanter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chan&shy;
tre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cantiere;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a
Singing master.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chanter(n)">Chanter,</form> <xpln lang="en">a dog's name; from
the same root ; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a dog
that filleth the woods with barking.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="E8v"> 
<wordentry type="h">
<form lang="en" lexeme="chantry(n)">Chantry,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Chant, above.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chap(v)">To Chap,</form> <xpln lang="en">corrupted from <etym lang="en">Gape;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chape(n)">Chape,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chappe,</etym>
the point of a scabbard, made
of iron; or perhaps from the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cappa,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the cover of
a scabbard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chaplet(n)">Chaplet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chape&shy;
let,</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caput,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an ornament for
the head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chapman(n)">Chap-man,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceap-&shy;
man</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kauffman,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Koopman,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. v. Cheap,
and Chaffer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chapel(n)">Chapel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
pelle,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Capella,</etym> the same.
From hence Chaplain, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chapelain</etym>; both
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chape,</etym> a
gown; or from the <etym lang="fr">Cappas</etym>
St. Martini. Spelman de&shy;
rives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capsella,</etym>
a little box, in which relicks
were kept.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chap(n)">Chaps,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaflas</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from <etym lang="oe">Ceafl</etym>,
a snout.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chapter(n)">Chapter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caput,</etym> a
head; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Convocation of
the Heads or Elders of the
Church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chapter(n)">The Chapter</form> <xpln lang="en">of a pillar, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chapiteau;</etym> both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capitulum,</etym> a
chapiter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chapter(n)">A Chapter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
pitre;</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caput,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="char(n)">Char,</form> <xpln lang="en">a task set one to do; ei&shy;
ther from the word <etym lang="en">Charge,</etym>
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Carc</etym>, care. V.
Charge, and Cark.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="char-woman(n)">Char-woman,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Keeren;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a woman hired
to rub, and make clean the
house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="char(n)">Char,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish very plentiful in
Winander Mere, a standing
water in Lancashire; not un&shy;
likely, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Car&shy;
ran</etym>, to turn; because it tur&shy;
neth it self swiftly in the wa&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charcoal(n)">Charcoal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Eng. <etym lang="en">Char,</etym>
clear, and <etym lang="en">Coal;</etym> for the
clear and vehement heat which
it casteth; it is most fit for
cunning workmanship, and
Chymical operations.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chard(n)">Chard,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Chard of an Arte&shy;
choke, from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Chard,</etym>
of the same signification. It
may likewise come from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Carduus.</etym> Gardiners term
that the Chard, that grows
out of the roots of old Arte&shy;
chokes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chardoon(n)">Chardon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among Gardi&shy;
ners; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Char&shy;
don,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cardone;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  an
Artechoke covered with earth,
till it become tender; from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carduus,</etym> a thistle;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a great thistle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charge(n)">Charge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Charge,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Carico,</etym> a burthen; and
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carrus,</etym> a
cart, or waggon. V. Carry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charger(n)">Charger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kahr,</etym>
signifying a deep platter; or
</page>

<page sig="F1r">
from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Charge;</etym> be&shy;
cause in it chargeable delica&shy;
cies are carried to the table. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chariot(n)">Chariot, or Charret,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chariot;</etym> and both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carrus,</etym> a cart,
or waggon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charitable(a)">Charitable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
ritabl&egrave;,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Charit&eacute;vole;</etym> and
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Charitas,</etym>
charity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chark(n)">Chark,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently used
in Lincolnshire; from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Acyrran</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Keh&shy;
ren.</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Keeren,</etym> to turn;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  beer kept unbroached,
till it becomes very stale, or
till it turns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charlatan(n)">A Charlatan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Charlatan,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ciarlatano,</etym>
a Circler, or Juggler; and this
from <etym lang="it">Ciarlare,</etym> to incircle;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that deludes men's
senses with jugling tricks, and
charming speeches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charm(n)">Charm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Charme,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ciarma;</etym> all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Carmen; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  </etym> a magick
Verse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charnel house(n)">A Charnel-house,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Charnier,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caro,</etym> flesh; be&shy;
cause thither must all flesh
come at last: Or from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cranium,</etym> a skull; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a repository for dead men's
skulls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charter(n)">Charter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Char&shy;
tre,</etym> publick acts, or commen&shy;
taries; this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Charta,</etym> paper.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Charterhouse(n)">Charter-house,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Chartreux,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Certosa,</etym> a
Monastery of Carthusian-&shy;
Monks; so called, from Car&shy;
thusia, a mountain near Gratianopolis, where Bruno, who
first instituted this Order, had
his seat: Or from the old Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Chartre,</etym> which formerly
signified, a prison, from <etym lang="fr">Car&shy;
cer,</etym> because they are shut up
in the Cloister, as it were in a
Gaol, being forbidden all hum&shy;
ane conversation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="charter-party(n)">Charter-party,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Law;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Charte,</etym> or
<etym lang="fr">Carte Partie,</etym> a writing, or
deed, delivered to each of
them that make a contract.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chary(a)">Chary,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cura,</etym> care,
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  careful, or wary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chase(v)">Chase,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chasser,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cacciare;</etym> and all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Captare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chase(n)">Chase,</form> <xpln lang="en">Chased Plate, a term in
the Gold-smith's craft, a con&shy;
tract of Inchase; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chasten(v)">Chasten,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Chastise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chastise(v)">Chastise,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chastier,</etym> both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Castigare,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chat(v)">To Chat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ca&shy;
quetter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Gazzolare,</etym> to
chatter, or chattle like a Iay;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chattel(n)">Chattels,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Law, from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Katheyl,</etym> moveables.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chatter(v)">Chatter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Citte&shy;
ren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zittern,</etym> to shake,
or tremble for cold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chatter(v)">Chatter</form> <xpln lang="en">as a Mag-pye, from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Caequeter, Caqueter,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="F1v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chaudron(n)">Chaudron,</form> <xpln lang="en">a measure of coals
consisting of 2000l. weight;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chauderon,</etym> or
our Eng. <etym lang="en">Cauldron</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) so
many coals as suffice for fires
under Dyars vats.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chavender(n)">Chavender,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. A Chevin, or
Chub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheap(a)">Cheap,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Cheapen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheapen(v)">To Cheapen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cea&shy;
pan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koopen,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kauffen,</etym> to buy. Hence Chep&shy;
stow, a City in Wales; from
the AS. <etym lang="la">Ceapstow</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
a place for merchandise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheer(n)">Chear,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Cheer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheerful(a)">Chearful,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Chi a buon
Ciera</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that is of
good cheer. V. Cheer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheat(n)">Cheat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cetta</etym>,
circumventions, frauds; or
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Achet,</etym> an agree&shy;
ment, or bargain; this from
the Verb <etym lang="fr">Acheter,</etym> which
comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Captare;</etym>
as we say when we are cheated
in buying any thing, We are
bought and sold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="check(n)">Check,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eschec,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Scacco,</etym> the play at Ta&shy;
bles. Hence, A Check with
a pawn, Check with a rook;
terms in gaming. V. Chess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="checkmate(n)">Check-Mate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Scaoco,</etym> and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mattus,</etym>
which comes from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to undergo; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
check cast under the table.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="check(v)">To Check,</form> <xpln lang="en">to repress, or keep
under; by a Metaphor from
the other <etym lang="en">Check.</etym> v. Chess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="checker(v)">Checker,</form> <xpln lang="en">to plant trees chec&shy;
ker-wise, or by squares. V.
Check, and Chess.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="checky(a)">Checkie,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eschiquette,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Inscacchiere,</etym> squared like
Checker-work. v. Check.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chick(n)">Checkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Zeccha,</etym>
or from the Hisp. and Arab.
<etym lang="ar">Cequi;</etym> it is a Venetian gol&shy;
den coin. Minshew derives
it from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Seca,</etym> a place
where money is coined.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheek(n)">Cheek</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Chece</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kaecke,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheer(n)">Cheer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chere,
Caire,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Xira, Cara,</etym> the
countenance: Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caro,</etym> when it is taken
for victuals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cherish(v)">Cherish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Che&shy;
rir,</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Charus;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to love one
dearly. v. Caress.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="churn(v)">Chern, or Churn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Keeren,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cerner,</etym> to
turn round: Or perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cernere,</etym> to divide;
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to separate the butter
from the milk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cherry(n)">Cherry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cerise,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ceregia;</etym> and all of them
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cerasum,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheeselip(n)">Cheslipor</form> <xpln lang="en">, Cheselip, v. Cheslop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheeselip(n)">Cheslop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cese</etym>,
cheese, and <etym lang="en">Lip,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Lauffen,</etym> to run; because it
presently diffuses it self in the
milk; separating the Hetero&shy;
genial, and gathering the Ho&shy;
mogeneal part, whereof cheese
is made.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="F2r">
 <wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chess(n)">Chess,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schaeek,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scach,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Scacco,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Escaque;</etym> all which Sal&shy;
masius derives from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Calculus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chest(n)">Chest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cest</etym>, or
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cista,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; by a
metaphor it signifies, the
breast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chester(su)">Chester, or Cester,</form> <xpln lang="en">a termina&shy;
tion frequently added to the
names of Towns; from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a City, or
Town; and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Castra.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chestnut(n)">Chestnut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cha&shy;
staigne,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Castagna;</etym> and
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Castanea,</etym> sc.
<etym lang="la">Nux</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheveril(n)">Cheveril,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cheve&shy;
reul,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ciavarello,</etym> a kid.
v. Chamots.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cheveron(n)">Cheveron,</form> <xpln lang="en">and thence Chevronel,
a term in Heraldry; from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Capreolus; </etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a little
goat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chevin(n)">Chevin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Che&shy;
vesne,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cefalo;</etym> and all
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x03AD;&phi;&alpha;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, an
head, this fish having a great
head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chew(v)" lexeme="chaw(v)">Chew, or Chaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Ceowian</etym>, or the Belg. and
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kauwen,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Kawen,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; perhaps all from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to gape wide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chick(n)">Chick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cicen</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kuycken,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">K&uuml;cklein,</etym> a
diminutive of <etym lang="en">Cock.</etym> Mer.
Cas. derives it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&iota;&kappa;&kappa;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>; which Hesychius in&shy;
terprets, a cock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chide(v)">Chide,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cidan</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schelten,</etym> the same.
Mer. Cas. draws it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to be angry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chief(n)">Chief,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chef,
Chief;</etym> both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caput:</etym> It also alludes to the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&epsilon;&psi;&alpha;&lambda;&eta;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chieftain(n)">Chieftain, or Cheftain,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a
captain, or leader; from the
Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Capitaneus.</etym> V.
Captain, and Chief, before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chilblain(n)">Chilblain,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a sore contracted
by cold. V. Chill, and Blain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="child(n)">Child,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cild</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kindt,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kind</etym> the same.
It alludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&#x03AD;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
and <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&epsilon;&nu;&nu;&#x1F71;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chill(n)">Chill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Killigh,</etym>
this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Celan</etym>, to be
Cold; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chime(n)">Chimes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gamme,</etym>
and this perhaps from our
<etym lang="en">Gammuth,</etym> a term in Musick.
Dr. Th. H. draws it ingenious&shy;
ly from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Chiamare,</etym>
because the sound thereof in&shy;
vites people to church.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chimney(n)">Chimney,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Che&shy;
min&eacute;e,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Chemen&eacute;a;</etym> and
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caminus,</etym>
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&mu;&iota;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chin(n)">Chin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cinne</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koon,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kinn</etym>, id.
Fr. Jun. derives it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&iota;&epsilon;&#x1F76;&nu;</etym>, to move; because,
when people talk, it moves. Mer. Cas. from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&nu;&shy;
&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the beard upon the chin.
Yet I had rather draw it from
the AS <etym lang="oe">Cinan</etym>, and this from
</page>

<page sig="F2v">
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to gape, or
open the mouth; because by
drawing down the chin to&shy;
wards the neck, the mouth
opens. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chincough(n)">Chin-cough, or Kin-cough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kinckhoest, Kich&shy;
hoest,</etym> and this from <etym lang="bl">Kinchen,
Kichen,</etym> to breath, and <etym lang="bl">Hoest,</etym>
a cough; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) A Cough, that causeth shortness of
breath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chine(n)">Chine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chignon,
Chinon,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Schiena;</etym> and all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Spina,</etym> the back-&shy;
bone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chink(n)">A Chink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cinan</etym>,
to gape as a wound or mouth.
Fr. Jun. derives it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to gape.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chink(n)">Chink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quin&shy;
quailles,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  money of cop&shy;
per, or tin, that chinketh
much, though of small value;
so called from the sound such
money makes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chip(n)">Chip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyp</etym>:
Hence To Chip; both perhaps
from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Chapler,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
to cut wood in small pieces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chirp(n)">Chirp,</form> <xpln lang="en">a feigned sound, from the
singing of birds.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chisel(n)">Chisel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a carving-tool; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ciseau,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cisello;</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scin&shy;
dere,</etym> to cut, or cleave.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chisel(n)">Chisel</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kiesel,</etym> an
husk, or cod.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chitt(n)">Chitt;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it from
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cito,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Chico;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a little boy. Th. H.
from <etym lang="en">Kitten,</etym> taken from the
saying, He plays like a Kit&shy;
ten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chitterling(n)">Chitterlings;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schyterlingh,</etym>
in Eng. q. <etym lang="en">Shitterling;</etym> be&shy;
cause in them are contained
the excrements. Yet I had rather draw it from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kutteln,</etym> the inwards.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chivalry(n)">Chivalry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Che&shy;
valiere, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. In our Law
it is termed Knights Service.
v. Cavalier.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chive(n)">Chives, or Cives,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small sort of
Onion; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cive;</etym>
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">C&aelig;pa.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chocolate(n)">Chocolate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Chuco&shy;
late,</etym> a cordial liquor; and
this from <etym lang="sp">Cacao,</etym> a certain nut,
which is the great ingredient in this confection. I might
draw it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Succus,</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Succulata,</etym> because it a&shy;
bundantly increaseth the nu&shy;
tritive moisture.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="choke(n)">Choke;</form> <xpln lang="en">Mich. Hon. derives it
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceoca</etym>, a cheek-&shy;
bone; because the halter is
tied under the cheek-bone of
criminals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="choose(v)">Choose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceosan</etym>,
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Choiser,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Colligere,</etym>
to gather together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chop(v)">Chop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kappen,</etym>
to mangle; or from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Choper, Chopper,</etym> to stumble,
or hit against a thing. Min&shy;
shew takes it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to cut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chop(v)">Chop,</form> <xpln lang="en">to Change, from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Koopen,</etym> to buy; for formerly
</page>

<page sig="F3r">
men dealt by change of one
thing for another. V. Chea&shy;
pen. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chopin(n)">Chopins, or as we say, Chopeens,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Chapin,</etym> a sock,
or upper sole; this from <etym lang="sp">Cha&shy;
pa;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a kind of rich shooe,
wrought with gold or silver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chopping boy(n)">Chopping-Boy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Caf</etym>, stout; (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) a stout
boy for his age: Or it may be
derived from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koo&shy;
pen,</etym> to buy; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a boy fit
to be sold, and capable of ser&shy;
vile business.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chough(n)">Chough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Picard.
<etym lang="pi">Chouette, Chue, Chouca,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cutta, Scotta,</etym> a crow; or
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kauw,</etym> a jack&shy;
daw; and this from <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to
gape often, saith. Fr Jun. but
all are better derived from the
sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chouse(v)">Chowse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gausser,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Goffo;</etym> as we say, To
make a fool of a man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chouse(n)">A Chowse,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Fool, from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joucher,</etym> to cheat one
with fair words; by a Meta&shy;
phor taken from Fisher-men,
who catch fishes with false nets
made of rushes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="christen(v)">Christen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Crist&shy;
nian</etym>, to Christen, Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chre&shy;
stionner,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="bon-chr&eacute;tien(n)">The Christian, or Boon Christian-&shy;
Pear,</form> <xpln lang="en">corrupted from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Crustumini,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Crustumiani,</etym>
a kind of Pear red on one side,
formerly much esteemed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Christmas(n)">Christmass,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the <etym lang="en">Mass</etym> of
<etym lang="en">Christ.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chub(n)">Chub,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>, a great-&shy;
headed fellow. See Iolthead,
and Iobbernoll.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chub(n)">A Chub, or Chevin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish with a
great head; from the old Eng.
<etym lang="oe">Cop,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chef,</etym> an
head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chuckle(v)">To Chuckle</form> <xpln lang="en">with laughter, from
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scuccherare,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Schachen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chuff(n)">Chuff,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Country-Chuff, not un&shy;
likely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyf</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuffe,</etym> an hogs-head,
or pipe; and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cupa, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; as we may, by a
Metaphor, call an ignorant,
and ill-shaped person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="church(n)">Church,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyric</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kercke,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kirch,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>: <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F77;&alpha; &Kappa;&upsilon;&shy;
&rho;&iota;&alpha;&kappa;&#x1F74;</etym>, the house of God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="churl(n)">Churl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceorl</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kuerle, Keerle,</etym> a stout
or big man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="churr-worm(n)">Churr-worm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Cyrran</etym>, to turn; because
this worm turneth about
quickly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cinder(n)">Cinders,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan.
<etym lang="da">Sinder</etym>, the dross, or scum
of metal: Or from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Cendre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cineri;</etym> or from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cineres,</etym> ashes; but I
rather incline to the former.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cinque(n)">Cinque,</form> <xpln lang="en">a cast at dice; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cinq,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cinco,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cinque;</etym> and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Quinque.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cipher(n)">Cipher,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chiffre,
Sifre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Zifra,</etym> the same;
but it is really an Heb. and
</page>

<page sig="F3v"> 
Arab. word, denoting Nume&shy;
ration. Right spell'd, Cy&shy;
pher. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cypress(n)">Cipress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cypres,</etym> the Lat <etym lang="la">Cupres&shy;
sus,</etym> the same. Right spell'd,
Cypress.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cypress(n)">Cipress,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of silk; from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cyprus,</etym> an Isle where
the workers of it first flou&shy;
rished. Right, Cypress.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="citadel(n)">Citadel,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Fortification, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Citadelle,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ci&shy;
ttadella;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a little City,
with respect to the strength
of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="citron(n)">Citron,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of fruit; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Citron,</etym> Lat. barb.
<etym lang="la">Citrum, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cithern(n)">Cittern,</form> <xpln lang="en">musick; from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Ghitarra;</etym> both corrupted
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cithara,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="city(n)">City,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cit&egrave;,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Citta;</etym> both contractions of
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Civitas,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="civet(n)">Civet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Civette,
Sivette,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Sibetto, Zibet&shy;
to,</etym> Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Zibethum,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clack(v)">To Clack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klack;</etym>
or possibly from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Clacquer,</etym> or C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Cleccian,</etym>
to rattle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clack(n)">A Clack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klats&shy;
chen,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Klaffen,</etym> to prate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="claim(v)">Claim,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Claim,
Clamer,</etym> and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Clamare;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  openly to
challenge to ones self.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clammy(a)">Clammy,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Clam, v. Cleam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clamp(n)">Clamps,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in sailing, from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klamme, Klampe,</etym>
crooked pieces of timber hol&shy;
ding the sides of a ship fast to&shy;
gether.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clap(v)">Clap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clappan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klappen, Kleppen,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Klapffen,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Clappeter,</etym>
the same. Hence, A Clap&shy;
per.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clap(n)">A Clap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cla&shy;
poir;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a swelling in the
groin and privities; the Vene&shy;
real disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clap(v)">Clap,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Hawking; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clappan</etym>, to shut close,
as does an hawk's bill, or
beak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="claret(n)">Claret,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Claret;</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cla&shy;
rus,</etym> clear; because Claret is
tenuous and transparent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clerk(n)">Clark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Clerc;</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cleri&shy;
cus, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. From hence, Cler&shy;
gy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clash(v)">Clash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klets,
Klettse,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1F71;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to
make a confused noise, like
the down-fall of an old house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clasp(v)">Clasp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghespe,</etym>
the same; yet I had rather
draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cleo&shy;
fan</etym>, to close.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clatter(v)" lexeme="clutter(v)">Clatter, and Clutter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cleadur</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klatte&shy;
ren, Kleuteren,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; they
are all feigned from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clover-grass(n)" lexeme="clover(n)">Claver, or Clover-grass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klawer,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klee</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>. I think it may as pro&shy;
bably be drawn from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Chefer</etym>, a violet; for the
scent of its flowers is not
</page>

<page sig="F4r"> 
much different from that of
the violet. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="claw(n)">A Claw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klawen,</etym>
AS. <etym lang="oe">Clapan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klauben,</etym>
to scratch, or tear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clay(n)">Clay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kley;</etym> and
both from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croye;</etym>
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Creta,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cleam(v)">To Cleam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word used in Lin&shy;
colnshire; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clae&shy;
mian</etym>, to dawb with clammy,
viscous matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clean(v)">Clean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cl&aelig;ne</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kleynsen, Klensen,</etym> to
make pure; by a Metaphor
taken from Destillers. It may
likewise be drawn from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to trim up, or
make neat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clear(a)">Clear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Clair;</etym>
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Clarus</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&alpha;&lambda;&epsilon;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cleave(v)">Cleave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cleofan</etym>,
<emend err="f">B</emend>elg. <etym lang="bl">Kleven,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klaven,</etym> 
to stick fast. v. Clay, and
Cleam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cleave(v)">Cleave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cleo&shy;
fan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kloven, Kluven,</etym>
to hew in pieces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cleft(n)">A Cleft, or Clift,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Verb, To <etym lang="en">Cleave.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clergy(n)">Clergy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Clerge,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Chieresia;</etym> all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Clericus,</etym> and this from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1FC6;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a lot, or inhe&shy;
ritance, they being the Lord's
Inheritance, dedicated to his
service.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clever(a)" lexeme="cleverly(adv)">Clever, and Cleverly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Leger,</etym> nimbly, or
quickly, like a Legerdemain;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clew(n)">A Clew of thread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Clype</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klowe,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Klawel, Klewel,</etym> the same;
and all very probably from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&upsilon;&lambda;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, to rowl, or
wind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clee(n)">Cleyes,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Cleyes of a Lobster;
Minshew derives it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&eta;&lambda;&alpha;&#x1F76;</etym> they somewhat re&shy;
sembling the mouth of a pair 
of tongs. V. Claw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="click(v)" lexeme="clink(v)">Click, or Clink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Klinken,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klingen,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Cliquer,</etym> to rustle, as doth
armour. v. Clack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clicket(n)">Clicket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cliquet,</etym>
and this from <etym lang="fr">Cliquer</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a knocker whereby we give
those that are within-doors in&shy;
telligence of our coming.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cleft(n)">Clift,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clyf</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Klif;</etym> and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Clivus,</etym> a steep place, or
rock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="climb(v)">Climb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clyman</etym>,
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klemmen;</etym>
and all perhaps from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1F77;&mu;&alpha;&xi;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to creep up
little by little, or step by step.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clinch(v)">Clinch;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Clingere,</etym> to gripe
hard with the fist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cling(v)">Cling,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Klynger,</etym>
to stick fast, or cleave to a
thing; and this perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Collinere,</etym> to dawb
over, to wit, with clammy
matter; as bird-lime.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="F4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clip(v)">Clip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clippan, Be&shy;
clippan</etym>, to embrace one hard
about the middle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clip(v)">Clip;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knippen, Snippen,</etym>
to cut off ones nails, cloth,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cloak(v)">Cloak;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to cover, or
hide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clock(v)">To Clock</form> <xpln lang="en">as an hen, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cloccan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klocken,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klucktzen, Glucktzen,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Closser,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Chioccia&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; they are all feigned
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clock(n)">A Clock,</form> <xpln lang="en">by inverting the sense a ;
little, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clugga</etym>,
Belg. and Dan <etym lang="da">Klocke,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Glocke,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cloche,</etym> a bell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clock(n)">A Clock,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain fly so called,
from the noise it maketh, like
the striking of a clock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clod(n)">Clod,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clud</etym>; or
rather, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kluyte,
Klot,</etym> the same. Hence Clot&shy;
ted-blood, and Clouted-milk;
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klotter-melck;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  thickned, or crudded
milk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clog(v)">Clog,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Noun <etym lang="en">Log.</etym> V.
Cumber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cloister(n)">Cloister,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Cloi&shy;
stre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Chiostro;</etym> both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Claustrum,</etym> signifying
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="close(v)">Close,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clysan</etym>,
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Clovre,</etym> to shut up;
and all manifestly from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Claudere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Hence
we say, A Close; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a field
hedged about.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="close by(a)">Close by,</form> <xpln lang="en">or very near; see the
other Close.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="closet(n)">Closet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a diminutive of <etym lang="en">Close;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a little Close place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cloth(n)">Cloth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cla&eth;</etym>,
Dan. <etym lang="da">Klede,</etym> the same. Hence
our participle Clad; perhaps it
may come of the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1F7D;&theta;&omega;,</etym> 
to spin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clotter(v)">Clotter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klotte&shy;
ren, Klouteren,</etym> to wax thick.
v. Clod.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cloud(n)">Cloud;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it from
the Verb <etym lang="la">Claudo,</etym> to shut up;
because it shutteth up the Sun
from us. Somnerus draweth
it from <etym lang="en">Clod,</etym> because it con&shy;
sisteth of condensed vapours.
It may also be drawn from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Clut</etym>, or the Eng. <etym lang="en">Clout,</etym>
because, like a curtain, it hi&shy;
deth the light of the Sun from us.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clove(n)">Cloves,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clufe</etym>, A
Clove of garlick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clough(n)">Clough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">Cleave;</etym>
which see. It is likewise deri&shy;
ved from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clud</etym>, a
rock, or cliff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clout(n)">Clout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clut</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lod,</etym> a remnant of
cloth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clouted milk(n)">Clouted-milk,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Clod.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clout-shoe(n)">Clouted-shoon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Clouet,</etym> a little nail; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one
that hath his shooes mended
with nails: or from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Clut</etym>, a clout, or patch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clouterly-fellow(n)">Clouterly-fellow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kloete,</etym> a stupid jolt-head:
Or from <etym lang="bl">Kluyte, Klouter,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="F5r"> 
thick; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an unprofitable
lump of flesh. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clown(n)">Clown,</form> <xpln lang="en">contracted from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Colonus,</etym> an husbandman; for
such, most an end, are of an
ungenteel carriage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cloy(v)">Cloy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Encloyer,</etym>
to satiate; and this from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Claudere,</etym> to shut; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
