so to fill, as that there is no
place left for any more.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="club(n)">Club,</form> <xpln lang="en">not unlikely from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klob,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kloppel,
Klove;</etym> and all of them from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Clava,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="club-law(n)">Club-law,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clea&shy;
fan, Cleofan,</etym> to cleave,
or split; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  every man to
pay an equal share.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clump(n)">Clumps,</form> <xpln lang="en">either contracted from
<etym lang="en">Clownish,</etym> or taken from the
Bel<emend err=",">.</emend> and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Clomp, Klompe,</etym>
one void of common sense, a
Num skull.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clung(a)">Clung,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clingan</etym>,
to stick fast to; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) shrunk
up with leanness, half famish&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cluster(n)">Cluster,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Clus&shy;
ter</etym>, a bough; by a Meto&shy;
nymy of the Adjunct.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="clutter(n)">Clutter,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Clatter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coach(n)">Coach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coche,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kutsche,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cocchi,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Minsevus derives it
from the Hung. <etym lang="hn">Kotczy,</etym> sig&shy;
nifying the same; because it is
said to be first invented by the
Hungarians. Dr. Th. H. de&shy;
rives it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Carosse,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Caroccia,</etym> the same; and
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Carruca,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coal(n)">Coal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Col</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kohl,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kole,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Kul,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>: But Vossius derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&eta;&lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, hot;
possibly, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caleo,</etym>
to be hot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coast(n)">Coast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coste,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Costa;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the side of
the sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coat(n)">Coat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cote</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kot,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coat(n)">Coat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cotte,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cotta;</etym> both by contraction
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Crocota,</etym> a saf&shy;
fron-colour'd garment, as says
Menagius. From hence,
A Coat of Arms, A Coat of
Mail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coath(n)">To Coath,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently u&shy;
sed in Lincolnshire; from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Co&eth;e</etym>, a disease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cob(n)" lexeme="sea-cob(n)">Cob or Sea-Cob,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kopff,</etym> the
head; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a bird having a
tuft.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cob(n)">The Cob of an herring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
same root .</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cob-iron(n)">Cob-irons,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kopff,</etym> an head, and <etym lang="en">I&shy;
rons;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) irons having great
round tops.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cobbler(n)">Cobler,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koppelen,</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Copu&shy;
lare,</etym> to couple together, as
Coblers do old shooes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cob-nut(n)">Cob-nut,</form> <xpln lang="en">a play amongst boys;
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kopff,</etym> an
head; or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>,
the top of any thing; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
</page>

<page sig="F5v"> 
the nut that breaketh the head
of another. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cob(n)">Cobs,</form> <xpln lang="en">round balls with which
fowls are crammed; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gob, Gobeau,</etym> a pellet;
<etym lang="fr">Gober,</etym> to swallow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cobweb(n)">Cobweb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kop&shy;
webbe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from
<etym lang="bl">Koppe,</etym> a spider, and <etym lang="en">Web;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cochineal(n)">Cocheneal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Co&shy;
chenille,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cochinillo,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cociniglia,</etym> all from the Lat.
barb. <etym lang="la">Cochinilla,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cock(n)">Cock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cocc</etym>, Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Coq,</etym> the same. Minshew
derives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&kappa;&kappa;&#x1F7B;&shy;
&zeta;&omega;</etym>. Hence Cocks-comb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cock(n)">Cock of a Conduit;</form> <xpln lang="en">so called,
because it is made in the shape
of a cock's comb.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cock(n)" lexeme="cock(v)">The Cock of a gun;</form> <xpln lang="en">or, To Cock
a gun, from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cocca,</etym>
the point of an arrow; or 
<etym lang="it">Coccare,</etym> to make the arrow
fit for the bow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cock(n)">Cock of hay;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">quasi</term>, A Cop of
hay, as they express it in 
Kent; which Cop manifest&shy;
ly comes from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>,
the top of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cockal(n)">Cockal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a play with huckle-&shy;
bones; from <etym lang="en">Cock,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a
Victor, by a Metaphor taken
from a Cock-fight; or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Cop-all, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>,
an head, and our <etym lang="en">All;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
he that is above all.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cock-apparel(n)">Cock-apparel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a saying in Lin&shy;
colnshire; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Quelque Appareil, </etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  ap&shy;
parel for the distinction of
Quality.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"cock-apparel" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cockatrice(n)">Cockatrice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Co&shy;
quatris,</etym> the same: Or from
<etym lang="en">Cock,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Atter</etym>,
with us <etym lang="en">Adder;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a viper
from a cock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cock-boat(n)">Cock-boat,</form> <xpln lang="en">by some called A
Coggle, or Cobble, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coque,</etym> a shell-fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cocker(v)">To Cocker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Co&shy;
queliner,</etym> to flatter; and this 
perhaps from <etym lang="fr">Coque,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to
play with shells, or such like
toys, to please children withal:
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coucher,</etym>
to keep one much in bed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cocket(n)">Cocket,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little paper exhibited
by the Receivers of the King's
Custom, for a testimony that
the Custom of any parcel of
goods is paid; not unlikely,
from the Eng. <etym lang="en">Cock boat;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a discharge of a boat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cockle(n)">Cockle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coque,
Coquille;</etym> and these from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&#x1F79;&kappa;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cockle(n)">Cockle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Coccel</etym>,
and this perhaps from the Verb
<etym lang="oe">Ceocan</etym>, to choke; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  tares
that choke the corn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cockney(n)">Cockney, or Cockneigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the word <etym lang="en">Cocker;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a boy
brought up tenderly in the
City. Dr. Th. H. derives it
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Accoquin&egrave;,</etym>
one given to idleness; and
this, I suppose, from <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> and
<etym lang="fr">Coquin,</etym> a beggar; beggars
being prone thereto.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cockquean(n)">Cockquean, Cotquean, or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Cook quean,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that playeth
the Cook among women: Or
</page>

<page sig="F6r"> 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kochin,</etym> a she-&shy;
Cook. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cock-stride(n)">Cock-stride; or rather, as it is
pronounced in Lincolnshire,
Cock-strinde.</form> <xpln lang="en">The learned
Dr. Th. H. telleth us, that it
cometh from the Eng. <etym lang="en">Cock,</etym>
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Strind;</etym> and
this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Strynan</etym>,
to tread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cockswain(n)">Cock-swain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Cock,</etym> for
Cock-boat, and <etym lang="en">Swain; </etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
the master of a boat, or barge.
See Cock-boat, and Swain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cod(n)">Cod,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Codde</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kodde,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kode,</etym> a
little shell; and all from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Codde</etym>, a scrip, or purse;
also a little sack. From hence
cometh the Northern word,
Cod, signifying a pillow. Fr.
Jun. derives it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&delta;&epsilon;&nu;&alpha;</etym>, any round thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cod-fish(n)">Cod-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Codde</etym>,
a pocket, or purse, from the
resemblance thereof.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="codling(n)">Codlins, or Coddle, Codlin,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the word <etym lang="en">Coddle;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Summer-apple, so acid,
that it is to be boiled before it
is eaten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cod-piece(n)">Cod-piece,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Codde</etym>,
a portmanteau, and the Eng.
<etym lang="en">Piece,</etym> because it formerly
stuck out in the form of a
portmanteau.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cod-worm(n)" lexeme="caddis(n)">Cod-worm, or Caddis,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Co&eth;de</etym>, a portman&shy;
teau; because of the resem&shy;
blance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cot(n)">Cot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cofe</etym>, and
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavea,</etym> be&shy;
cause it is a cave for diggers
under the ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coffer(n)">Cofers,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coffre,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the inner part of the roof;
but primarily, a box, or cof&shy;
fer, wherein roses, pomegra&shy;
nates and flowers, the orna&shy;
ments of a crown, are pla&shy;
ced.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coffee(n)">Coffee,</form> <xpln lang="en">not long known in Eng&shy;
land; from the &AElig;gypt. <etym lang="eg">Choa&shy;
va.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coffer(n)">Coffer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cofe,
Cofa;</etym> and these, not un&shy;
likely, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavea,</etym>
a cave, from the similitude.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cofferer(n)">The Cofferer</form> <xpln lang="en">of the King's hous&shy;
hold, whose office it is, to pay
His Majesty's Officers their sal&shy;
laries; from the Noun <etym lang="en">Coffer,</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Steward of the King's
Coffer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coffin(n)">Coffin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cofin,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cophano;</etym> and all from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cofa</etym>, a cave; tho
some derive it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&phi;&iota;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, which signifieth, a
basket. V. Coffer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cog(v)">To Cog,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coque-&shy;
liner;</etym> and this from <etym lang="fr">Coque,</etym>
a shell; a Metaphor from chil&shy;
dren's play.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cog(n)">The Cog of a Miln-wheel;</form> <xpln lang="en">so
called, from the sound it ma&shy;
keth in turning round.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coggle(n)">Cogle-stone,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cuo&shy;
golo;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cal&shy;
culus,</etym> and this from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Chi;&#x1F71;&lambda;&iota;&zeta;</etym>, a little stone.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="F6v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cognizance(n)">Cognisance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Connoissance,</etym> and this from
the Verb <etym lang="fr">Connoistre,</etym> to know,
or be assured of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coif(n)">Coif,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coiffe,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cuffia,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cofia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>:
And this Father Guadix de&shy;
rives from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Quehf,</etym>
an head; and from thence
<etym lang="ar">Quehfia</etym>, any ornament for the
head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coil(v)">To Coil, or Quoil a cable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cueillir,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cog&shy;
liere;</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Colligere,</etym> to gather up toge&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coil(n)">Coil,</form> <xpln lang="en">To keep a Coil, perhaps
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kollern,</etym> to
chide; and this from <etym lang="tt">Koller,</etym>
a collar; because combatants
take one another by the collar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coin(n)">Coin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coin,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Conio,</etym> stamped money:
Or, as Spelm. and Menagius
have it, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cuneus,</etym>
a wedge. Cironius derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F7C;&nu;, &#x1F18;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F79;&nu;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>,
an image; because it hath the
figure of the Prince's head up&shy;
on it. Some draw it from the &shy;
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cunnar,</etym> to coin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coin(n)">Coines,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture.
Adr. Jun. draws it from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coing,</etym> a corner; and
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cuneus.</etym> It
may possibly be drawn from the word <etym lang="la">Ancones</etym> found in
Vitruv. signifying the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cocker(n)">Cokers,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cocer</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koker,</etym> a case; they are
a sort of Fisher-men's boots,
into which their legs are put,
as it were, into cases.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cokes(n)">Cokes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cochon,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cochino,</etym> an hog; whence
we say, A lilly Hog: Or from
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Coco,</etym> a word where&shy;
with to fright children, which
in understanding are but fools:
Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gauck,
Geck,</etym> a fool.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Cokes" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cold(a)">Cold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cole</etym>, with
us Cool, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koel, Kaud,
Kaudt, Koud, Kout,</etym> the same:
Or not unlikely from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Colan, C&aelig;lan</etym>; and this per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gelu, Ge&shy;
lare,</etym> to freeze.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cole(n)" lexeme="colewort(n)">Cole, or Cole-wort,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cawl</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koole,</etym> Teut<emend err=",">.</emend>
<etym lang="tt">Kohl,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Choux, Caule,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cavoli, Coli,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Col,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all of them from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caulis,</etym> a stalk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colemouse(n)">Cole-mouse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Caule,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Mouse</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
bird that feedeth much upon
Cole-worts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="collet(n)">Collet of a ring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Colet, Collet,</etym> the palate;
this from <etym lang="fr">Col,</etym> the neck; allu&shy;
sively, the thickest part of
the ring, wherein the signet is
set.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="collar(n)">Collar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Collier,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Collar,</etym> a neck-lace; and
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Collare,</etym>
because it goeth about the
neck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="collation(n)">Collation,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Col&shy;
lation,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this most
manifestly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Col&shy;
latio,</etym> a treatment made by
</page>

<page sig="F7r"> 
one, or two, or more persons,
to entertain the company. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colly(v)">The Hawk Collieth;</form> <xpln lang="en">in Rider,
<etym lang="la">Collineat</etym>; in Gouldman, <etym lang="la">An&shy;
nuit</etym>; a term in Fowling;
perhaps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Col,</etym>
Lat. <etym lang="la">Collum,</etym> a neck; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  he
moveth his neck streight for&shy;
ward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="collogue(v)">Collogue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Collo&shy;
qui:</etym> Or rather, from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kosen,</etym> to talk, and <etym lang="tt">Lu&shy;
gen,</etym> to lye; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to deceive
one by fair speeches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="collop(n)">Collop;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&lambda;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to cut,
or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, food, or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&lambda;&alpha;&beta;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>,
which by Voss. is interpreted
<term lang="la">Offa</term>, a fat piece of flesh.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cauliflower(n)">Colly-flower,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Cole-wort.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coloier(n)">Coloier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the barb. Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F79;&gamma;&epsilon;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a good old
man. Dr. Th. H. derives it
from <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, and <etym lang="gk">&#x1F3B;&epsilon;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, good
and holy.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"coloier" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colonel(n)">Colonel,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Colonnel,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Colonello,</etym> a captain over a
thousand men: Not as Min&shy;
shew will have it, from <etym lang="la">Co&shy;
lumna,</etym> because they are the
pillars of an army; but from
<etym lang="la">Colonia,</etym> because at first they
were set over Colonies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colt(n)">Colt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Colt</etym>, the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="colter(n)">A Colter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cul&shy;
tor</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kouter,</etym> Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Coutre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Coltro, Coltello;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Culter</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comb(v)">Comb,</form> <xpln lang="en">Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kam&shy;
men,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Kemmer.</etym> It may
possibly come from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Como,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&mu;&#x03AD;&omega;</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
to trim ones locks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comb(n)">Comb,</form> <xpln lang="en">Dan. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kam,
Kamm;</etym> perhaps from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&mu;&mu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the ornament
of a cock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="combat(v)">Combat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
bat, Combatre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Combat&shy;
tere,</etym> to fight: Or from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Con,</etym> together, and <etym lang="la">Ba&shy;
tuere,</etym> to smite.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="combatant(n)">Combatant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Combatant,</etym> a
part. of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Combatre;</etym>
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a figure drawn like a
Gladiator standing upon his
guard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cumber(v)">Comber;</form> <xpln lang="en">Menagius draws it
from the Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Cumbrus,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Combre,</etym> an heap. From
hence, To Incomber, to hin&shy;
der the growth of things, as
trees hinder the increase of
corn sown under their shades.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="come(v)">Come,</form> <xpln lang="en">AS. <etym lang="oe">Coman</etym>, Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ku&shy;
man, Koman,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kom&shy;
men.</etym> It may be taken from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&mu;&#x1F77;&zeta;&omega;</etym>; which, in
Herodotus, signifies, to go.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comely(a)">Comely;</form> <xpln lang="en">Mer. Cas. draws it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&mu;&mu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
neat: I had rather deduce it
from our word <etym lang="en">Become;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comfit(n)">Comfit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Confit,</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Con&shy;
fectio.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comfort(v)">Comfort,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
forter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Comfortare,</etym> to
strengthen, or instruct with
</page>

<page sig="F7v"> 
Counsel. Dr. Th. H. draws it
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Comfort;</etym>
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  consolation. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coming wench(a)">A Coming-wench,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Cweman</etym>, to please.</xpln>
<lemenote>
See quotation of 1749 in OED, "coming", adj., 2.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="command(v)">Command,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Command,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Commando;</etym>
and these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Con,</etym>
and <etym lang="la">Mando,</etym> to command.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commence(v)">Commence,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Commencer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Comincia&shy;
re;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Con,</etym>
and <etym lang="la">Initium,</etym> a beginning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commendum(n)">A Commendum,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Commendo,</etym> and this most
evidently from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Com&shy;
mendare,</etym> to commend: It is &shy;
an Ecclesiastical Benefice va&shy;
cant, that is committed to the
management of a fit person,
till it be supplied.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commonalty(n)">Commonalty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Communaut&egrave;,</etym> or the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Communalitas, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="commune(v)">To Commune,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Communicare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="company(n)">Company,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
pagnie,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Compagnia,</etym> so
ciety, Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Compagnon,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Compagno,</etym> a companion; and
all these, either, as Caninius
saith, from <etym lang="la">Con,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Pagus;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one of the same town,
or street; or as Lipsius hath
it, from the Verb <etym lang="la">Combino;</etym>
or <etym lang="la">Combenno,</etym> in Festus; to
combine; or, which is most
probable, from <etym lang="la">Con,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Pa&shy;
nis,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one that participates
of the same bread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comparison(n)">Comparison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Comparison;</etym> and both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Comparatio,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compartiment(n)">Compartiment,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archi&shy;
tecture, and Heraldry; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Compartiment,</etym>
any equal Division; and this
from the Verb <etym lang="la">Compartiri,</etym> to
divide into equal parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compass(n)">Compass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Compas,</etym> Ital <etym lang="it">Compasso,</etym>
the same. Hence To Com&shy;
pass, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
passer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Compassare,</etym> to
environ, or stand about.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compassion(n)">Compassion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Compassion,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Compassione,</etym>
the same; these from the
Verbs <etym lang="fr">Compassioner, Compas&shy;
sionare,</etym> to commiserate, or
take pity on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="complain(v)" lexeme="complaint(n)">Complain, Complaint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Complaindre, Plain&shy;
dre;</etym> these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Plan&shy;
gere,</etym> to lament.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="complement(n)">Complement,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Compliment,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Compli&shy;
mento;</etym> or from our word,
<etym lang="en">Comply;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Complyments.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="complice(n)">Complice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
plice,</etym> the Lat. <etym lang="la">Complico,</etym> to
enfold; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one bound in a
confederacy, or league.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="complot(n)">Complot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
plot,</etym> a conspiracy confirmed
by oaths; or by a Metaphor
taken from playing at ball,
from <etym lang="la">Con,</etym> and <etym lang="fr">Peloter,</etym> when
a great many together, as it
were Confederates, do strive
against others of an equal
number.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comply(v)">Comply,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the Fr. G.
</page>

<page sig="F8r"> 
<etym lang="fr">Complaire,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Compiacere,</etym>
to please greatly: Or from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Complicare,</etym> to say as
another saith, without any
thwarting, to apply himself
to anothers humour. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="componed(a)" lexeme="counter-componed(a)">Componed, and Counter-com&shy;
poned,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Compone,
Counter-compone;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  made
of two colours contrariwise
set together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comport(v)">To Comport,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to behave ones
self; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">se Com&shy;
porter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Comportarsi,</etym> to 
behave ones
self well or ill.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compose(v)">Compose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
poser,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Componere,</etym> the
same: Or rather, from <etym lang="la">Con,</etym>
and <etym lang="la">Pausa;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to put an
end to differences. v. Re&shy;
pose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="comprise(v)">Comprise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
pris,</etym> part of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
prendre;</etym> both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Comprehendere,</etym> to compre&shy;
hend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compromise(v)">Compromise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Compromettre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Compro&shy;
mettere.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conceive(v)">Conceive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
cevoir,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Concipere;</etym> and
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Concipere,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="concern(v)">Concern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
cerner;</etym> both from the Lat. 
barb. <etym lang="la">Concernere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cond(v)" lexeme="cun(v)">To Cond, or Cun,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sai&shy;
ling; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cunnan</etym>,
to know; Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kond,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kund,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conduct(n)">Conduct,</form> <xpln lang="en">Safe Conduct, a guard
of soldiers that defend an ene&shy;
my from the violence of the
common people; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sauf Conduit,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Sal&shy;
vo Condotta,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conduit(n)">Conduit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
duite,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="confront(v)">Confront,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
fronter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Confrontare;</etym>
and these from <etym lang="la">Con,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Frons,</etym>
that is, to withstand one face
to face.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="congy(n)">Congy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a decent inflexion of the
body, when we salute or part
from any body; from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Conge,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Commiato.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conn(v)">Conn,</form> <xpln lang="en">to get a thing by heart,
by inverting the sence a little,
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Connan, Cennan</etym>,
to know.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conn(v)">Conn,</form> <xpln lang="en">to strike with the fist shut,
possibly from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&nu;&delta;&upsilon;&shy;
&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a knuckle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conn(v)">Conn,</form> <xpln lang="en">I Conn you thanks, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Connan</etym>, to know; 
(i. e) to retain a good turn in
ones memory; or from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kunden,</etym> to own a fa&shy;
vour, or gift.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"conn" antedates earliest OED citation ("con | conn, v. 3; 1721-1800)."
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="conquer(v)">Conquer.</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
querir,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Conquistare,</etym> to
subdue; Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Conqueste,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Conquisto,</etym> victory; all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Conquirere,</etym> to
acquire, especially by war.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="constable(n)">Constable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Co&shy;
nestable,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Conestabile;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Comes stabuli</etym>, Master of
the Horse, Generalissimo of
all His Majesty's Forces. Ver&shy;
stegan derives it from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Cyning</etym>, or Cunning, a
</page>

<page sig="F8v">
King, and <etym lang="en">Stable;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  King
of the stable. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="constrain(v)">Constrain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
traindre,</etym> to compel, or force
one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counter(n)">A Contore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kon&shy;
toor,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Comptoir,</etym> a ta&shy;
ble. See Account, Count, and
Compter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contrive(v)">Contrive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
trouver,</etym> to invent; or de&shy;
vise; this from <etym lang="la">Con,</etym> and the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Treffen,</etym> to find out;
also to hit of a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="control(v)">To Control,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
tre-rolle,</etym> to adjust Accounts.
From hence, A Controller of
the King's houshold. V. Roll.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="convey(v)">Convey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
voyer,</etym> to accompany one;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to carry away with, or
about one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="convoy(n)">Convoy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Convoy,</etym>
safe conduct, <etym lang="fr">Convoyer,</etym> to
conduct: Or, as Menagius
saith, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Convehe&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coney(n)">A Cony,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Konin,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Connil, Connin,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Coniglio;</etym> and all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cuniculus, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cook(n)">Cook,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Dan.
<etym lang="da">Cock,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Koch,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cuo&shy;
co;</etym> and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Co&shy;
quus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coom(n)" lexeme="comb(n)">A Coom, or Comb,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain
measure of corn so called;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Comble;</etym> and
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cumulus,</etym>
an heap.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coop(n)">Coop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cofa</etym>, a
cave; or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cuba,</etym> a
cage for birds; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a place
where fowls are kept, and
made fat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coup(v)" lexeme="couped(a)">Coop, or rather, Coupe, or Cou&shy;
ped,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Coup&egrave;,</etym> a Par&shy;
ticiple of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Couper,</etym> to
cut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cooper(n)">Cooper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kuyper,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuffer,</etym> the same; these
from <etym lang="bl">Kuype</etym>, <etym lang="tt">Kuffe,</etym> a tub, or
other vessel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coot(n)">Coot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koet,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Cot&eacute;e,</etym> a Moor-hen; Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cutta,</etym> a bird, which in Hig&shy;
ginius, is called a Felde-fare:
I suppose them all to be feig&shy;
ned from the note which this
fowl hath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cop(n)">Cop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>; Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kopff,</etym> a top; these from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Caput,</etym> an head; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
the tuft, or top of a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cop(n)">Cop of hay,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently
spoken in Kent; from the
AS <etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>; or, which is all one,
from <etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>, because it riseth
upwards like a tuft. V. A
Cock of hay.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"cop of hay"antedates the earliest use of the phrase in OED ("cop", n. 2, 5; 1695).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cope(n)">Cope;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kopff,</etym> an head;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to hit heads, as wrestlers
or fighters sometimes do. It
may be drawn from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&pi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, labour; (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) to
be-labour one stoutly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cope(n)">The Cope of heaven,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chape,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cappa;</etym>
and these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ca&shy;
put,</etym> because the heavens are
above the rest of the creation.
V. Cop. Possibly, from the
</page>

<page sig="G1r"> 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavus,</etym> hollow; as we
say, the concavity of the hea&shy;
vens. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cope(v)">To Cope together,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Coupler,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Coppiare;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Copula&shy;
re,</etym> to match with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cope(n)">Cope,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;ppe</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kappe,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chape,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cappa,</etym> a kind of Sacerdotal
habit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coping(n)">Coping,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture;
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>, and this
from Cop; (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) the roof, or
ridge of an house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="copper(n)">Copper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koper,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Kobber,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cobre,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Cuivre;</etym> and all from the
Barb. Lat. <etym lang="la">Cuprum;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Cy&shy;
prian copper; for Galen and
others say, that the Isle of Cy&shy;
prus was once famous for 
workmanship in copper.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="copperas(n)">Copperas,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Capar&shy;
rossa,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coupperouse, Cou&shy;
perouse:</etym> 'Tis nothing else but
(as Chymists say) an extract
of copper.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="copse(n)" lexeme="coppice(n)">A Copsy, or Coppis,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couper,</etym> to cut; or the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to hew down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="copy(n)">Copy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr"> Copie,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Copia, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cordelier(n)">Cordelier,</form> <xpln lang="en">one observing the In&shy;
stitution of St. Francis; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cordelier;</etym> this
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Chorda,</etym> a rope,
which they wear instead of a
girdle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cordwainer(n)">Cordwainer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Shooe maker;
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kordewaen,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cordouano,</etym> Fr. G. and
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cordouan,</etym> a sort of lea&shy;
ther brought from Corduba, a
City in Spain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="core(n)">Core,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Core in fruit, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coeur,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Core,
Cuore;</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cor;</etym> because like the heart,
it is in the midst of fruit, con&shy;
taining the seed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cork(n)">Cork,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Korck,</etym>
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Corcho,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Korcke,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gorch;</etym> all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cortex,</etym> the bark of a
tree; for it is really nothing
but the bark of a tree, compa&shy;
red with other trees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cormorant(n)">Cormorant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cor&shy;
morant;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Sea-crow,
that devours fishes as fast as
crows do the standing corn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corn(n)">Corn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Corn</etym>,
Dan. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Korn, Korne,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kern, Korn,</etym> the same.
Martinius, by the figure Me&shy;
tathesis, draws it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Granum,</etym> the same; but
Fr. Jun. from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&rho;&#x03AD;&nu;&shy;
&nu;&upsilon;&mu;&iota;</etym>, to satiate, or satisfie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corn(n)">Corn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in the toes; from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> an horn, for
the hardness of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornelian(n)">Cornelian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of stone so cal&shy;
led; from the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Car&shy;
neolus,</etym> and this from <etym lang="la">Caro;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  of a flesh-colour: Or
from <etym lang="la">Cornus,</etym> because it is red,
like the fruit of the Haw&shy;
thorn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornel(n)" lexeme="cornelian(n)">Cornel, or Cornelian,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Corneille;</etym> and both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cornum,</etym> the
fruit of the Haw-thorn.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="G1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornet(n)">Cornet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cornet,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cornetta;</etym> and all from
<etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> an horn; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a mu&shy;
sical instrument, made of
horn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornet(n)">Cornet,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Ensign of a Compa&shy;
ny of Horse; from <etym lang="en">Coronet,</etym>
because, in times of old, they
had their heads crowned with
Garlands; Or perhaps from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cornette.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornetfish(n)">A Cornet-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> an
horn, from the resemblance.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED except in another term for this fish, "flutemouth."
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cornub(v)">Cornub,</form> <xpln lang="en">I Cornub'd him, from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Keeren,</etym> to beat, and
<etym lang="bl">Knoop, Knobbe,</etym> a knuckle;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to strike with ones
knuckles.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Cornub" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coroner(n)">Coroner,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Corona,</etym>
a crown; because, in the
King's name, he maketh in&shy;
quisition into the casual and
unnatural death of a person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coronet(n)">A Coronet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Coro&shy;
netta,</etym> a little crown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="corpse(n)" lexeme="corse(n)">Corps, or Coarse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Corps;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a dead bo&shy;
dy: In the one we follow the
right writing; in the other,
the right pronouncing of the
French word. It may like&shy;
wise be derived from the Dan.
<etym lang="da">Crop,</etym> a body, by the figure
Metathesis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cozen(v)">To Cozen;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it
from the Eng. and Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
sin,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cugino;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to
impose upon one under pre&shy;
tence of Affinity: Yet I had
rather draw it from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Gosser, Gausser;</etym> as we say,
To play upon one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cost(n)">Cost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kost,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couster,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Co&shy;
stare;</etym> and all of them from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Constare,</etym> to cost.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="costermonger(n)">Costard-monger,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fruiterer;
from <etym lang="en">Costard,</etym> a kind of apple,
and <etym lang="en">Munger,</etym> a Trafficker.
Costard comes, perhaps, from
the word <etym lang="en">Cost,</etym> because it was
a dear sort of fruit. M. H.
derives it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Cost,</etym>
and <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Art;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
fruit that naturally grows out
of the earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coster(n)">Coster,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>, or
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kopff,</etym> an head;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Copster, or <etym lang="tt">Kopffster.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="costive(a)">Costive;</form> <xpln lang="en">M. H. S. Th. D. draw&shy;
eth it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Cost,</etym>
meat, and <etym lang="bl">Stiif,</etym> stiff; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that hath his excrements
dried within him.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="costrel(n)">Costrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a vessel to carry wine in.
Minshew draws it from the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Guastada;</etym> possibly from
<etym lang="en">Coster,</etym> signifying, a top, or
head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cottage(n)">Cottage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cote</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kot,</etym> the same. v. Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cottarels(n)">Cottarels,</form> <xpln lang="en">the meanest of clients;
so called from <etym lang="en">Cote,</etym> cottages,
which they live in.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Not found in OED, but see "cotterel", n.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cotton(n)">Cotton,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cotton,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cottone,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Cottwn,</etym>
the same; these from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cotogni,</etym> and this manifestly
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cydonium,</etym> a
quince; from the similitude of
the down that grows thereon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cotton(v)">To Cotton,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Coadu&shy;
nare,</etym> to make agreeable unto,
to unite.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="G2r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="couch(v)">Couch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coucher,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Coricare, Colicare, Colca&shy;
re,</etym> to lie down. Vossius and
Menagius derive it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Culcitra,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="couchant(a)">Couchant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couchant,</etym> a
Part of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Coucher,</etym> to
lie down close. v. Couch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="covenant(n)">Covenant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
venant, Convenancer,</etym> the
same; both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Conventum,</etym> a compact, or
agreement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="covent(n)">Covent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Convent,</etym> both from <etym lang="la">Conventus,</etym>
an assembly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cover(v)">Cover,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couvrir,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Coperire;</etym> and both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cooperire,</etym> the same.
From hence also cometh the 
Verbal Covert.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coverlet(n)">Coverlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
verlict,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Copraletto;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a cover bed. v. Cover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="covet(v)">Covet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Convoi&shy;
ter,</etym> to seek earnestly after a
thing. From hence Cove&shy;
tous. We also find it derived
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Covidigia;</etym>
which, 'tis likely, hath been
corrupted from the Lat <etym lang="la">Cupi&shy;
ditas,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cough(v)">Cough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kuch,
Kuchen,</etym> to puff and blow;
they are all words feigned
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="covey(n)">A Covie,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
v&eacute;e,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Covata;</etym> these from
<etym lang="it">Couver, Covare;</etym> and these
again from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cubare;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a brood of Partridges,
Pheasants, &amp;c. so many as are
hatched at once.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="council(n)">Counsel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
seil,</etym> Ital <etym lang="it">Consiglio;</etym> all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Consilium,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="count(n)">Count,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Comte,
Conte,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Conte;</etym> both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Comes:</etym> From hence,
A County; also, A Countess,
from the Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Comitissa,</etym>
a Count's wife. This word is
supposed to have crept into 
the Latin Tongue, in the time
of Dioclesian, and to have sig&shy;
nified, One of the King's Pri&shy;
vy Council, because he day
by day accompanied the Em&shy;
peror.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compt(v)" lexeme="count(v)">To Compt, or Count,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Conter, Compter,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Contare;</etym> and all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Computare,</etym> to cast Ac&shy;
count, or compute.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="countenance(n)">Countenance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Contenance;</etym> whence comes
the word Contenancer, with
us, To Countenance; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
favourably to look upon one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counter(n)">Counter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
ptoir,</etym> a table to count money
upon. V. To Accompt, and
Contore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contraband(a)">Counterband-goods,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Merchandise; from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Contrabando;</etym> (i. e) Goods
prohibited by Statute; and if
siezed, confiscated to the King.
v. Banes, and Banish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counterfeit(v)">Counterfeit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
trefaire,</etym> Ital <etym lang="it">Contrafare,</etym> to
imitate; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Contra&shy;
facere,</etym> to make contrary;
</page>

<page sig="G2v">
<term lang="la">viz.</term>  the same of different me&shy;
tal. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counterpoint(n)">Counter-point,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Contrepointe,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Contra&shy;
punto;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a coverlet made
up in seams, crossing each o&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counterpoise(v)">Counter-poise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Contrepoise,</etym> signifying the
same; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to counter-ba&shy;
lance. V. Poise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counter-poison(n)">Counter-poison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="la">Contra,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Poison;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an Anti&shy;
dote against Poison; which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="counterscarp(n)">Counter-scarf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Contrescarpe,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Contra&shy;
scarpa,</etym> a term in Warfare:
It may be derived from our
word <etym lang="en">Counter,</etym> and the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kerven,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scharven</etym> to
cut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="country(n)">Country,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Con&shy;
tr&eacute;e,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Contrado,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Conterrata;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one
Land joining to another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coup&eacute;(n)">Coupe,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry. V.
Coop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="couple(n)">Couple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couple,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuppel,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Coppia;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Copula,</etym>
signifying the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="courage(n)">Courage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
rage,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Coraggid;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the elevation of the heart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="courant(n)">Courant,</form> <xpln lang="en">written News; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Courant,</etym> a Part. of
the Verb <etym lang="fr">Courir,</etym> to run; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
running News.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cover(v)">To Coure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Covare,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couver;</etym> these from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cubare,</etym> by a Metaphor
drawn from hens sitting upon
their eggs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="course(a)">Course</form> <xpln lang="en">, or Ordinary, by the fi&shy;
gures Antithesis, and Meta&shy;
thesis, from the Noun <etym lang="en">Gross;</etym>
which see. Or 'tis contracted
from <etym lang="en">Currish,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Vile, fit
for nothing but the dogs; or,
rough as dog's hair.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="course(n)">A Course,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Course,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Corso;</etym> both from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cursus,</etym> an horse-race.
From hence Courser, a Race-&shy;
horse; and an Horse-Cour&shy;
ser.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="women's courses(n)">Womens Courses,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the same
original. V. Flowers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="court(n)">Court,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cour,
Courte,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Corte;</etym> which
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cohors.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="courteous(a)">Courteous,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cour&shy;
tois,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cortese;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one
that affecteth the fashions at
Court.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cousin(n)">Cousin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cousin,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cugino.</etym> Some derive it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Consanguineus;</etym>
all signifying the same thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cow(n)">Cow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cu</etym>, Dan.
and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ko, Koe,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Kuh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. I scarce credit
those that draw it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to bring forth; for
many other Animals multiply
more than these.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cow's thumb, to a(n)">To a Cow's thumb,</form> <xpln lang="en">with a little
alteration of the sense, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A la Coustume,</etym>
fashionably.(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coward(n)">Coward,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cow&shy;
ard,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cobarde, Covarde,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Codardo;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that
</page>

<page sig="G3r"> 
has his heart in his heels: Or,
perhaps from <etym lang="en">Cow,</etym> and the
Germ. <etym lang="tt">Aerd, Ard,</etym> nature;
(i. e) Cow-hearted: Or from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuh-Hirt;</etym> with us,
Cow-herd. Cov. ingeniously
derives the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Covarde,</etym>
from <etym lang="sp">Cueva;</etym> this from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Caverna,</etym> a cave; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that creepeth into an hole
in time of danger. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cucumber(n)">Cowcumber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Coucombre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Coucomere;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cucumer,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cowherd(n)">Cow-herd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cu</etym>,
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hirt,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hiran</etym>, to hire
for wages. v. Cow, and
Herd.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cowl(n)">Cowl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cugle</etym>,
this from <etym lang="la">Cucullus,</etym> in Juve&shy;
nal: Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ko&shy;
vel,</etym> and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Caveola,</etym> a little cave, for the
similitude of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cowslip(n)">Cowslip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cus&shy;
lippe</etym>; so called, because
Cows love to eat them; or,
as Dr. Th. H. supposeth, be&shy;
cause they have a smell like
that of a Cow's breath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coxcomb(n)">Coxcomb,</form> <xpln lang="en">I suppose it is corrup&shy;
ted from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cochon,</etym>
an Hog; for we often call a
fool, A Silly Hog: But see&shy;
ing it signifies one that hath
high thoughts of himself, I
may as well draw it from
<etym lang="en">Cock,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Comb.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coy(a)">Coy;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew very ingeniously
derives it from the Fr. G
<etym lang="fr">Quoy,</etym> What? which word
such persons often angrily re&shy;
peat. It may also be drawn
from the Noun <etym lang="fr">Quoi, Coi,</etym>
quiet; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) she that sitteth
silent, especially at the hearing
of lewd talk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coy(n)">Coy;</form> <xpln lang="en">a cage for fowls; from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koye,</etym> this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cavea,</etym> the same: Or from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coy,</etym> quiet; because
one must stand there very
still, lest the birds be frighted 
away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crab(n)">Crab,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish; from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Crabba</etym>, Dan. and Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Krabbe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krebs;</etym> and
all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&rho;&alpha;&beta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crab(n)">Crab,</form> <xpln lang="en">a wild apple; from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schrabben,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Schrappen,</etym> to bite; from the
sharp biting taste it hath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cravat(n)">Crabbat; or rather, Crabat,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a 
sort of band, not long worn
in England; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Rabat,</etym> a falling band, con&shy;
trary to a Ruff, which standeth
out round the neck. It may
also be taken from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Crabbat,</etym> comely; because it
is a comely wear: Or, more
probably, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cra&shy;
bat,</etym> a Croatian; because a
Croatian first wore it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crabbed(a)">Crabbed,</form> <xpln lang="en">morose; from <etym lang="en">Crab;</etym>
as we say, He looks as sowr as
a crab.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crack(v)">To Crack,</form> <xpln lang="en">as wooden vessels do,
for dryness; from the other
<etym lang="en">Crack.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="G3v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crack(n)">Crack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kraeck,
Krack,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krach,</etym> Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Crac,</etym> the same; they are all
feigned from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crack(v)">To Crack a nut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Croquer,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cracknel(n)" lexeme="crackling(n)">A Crackling, and Cracknel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Craquelin,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kraeckelinck,</etym> a cake that crack&shy;
leth when it is broke.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cradle(n)">Cradle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cradele</etym>,
by &AElig;lfricus, Cradel, C. Br.
<etym lang="cb">Cr&ucirc;d,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. It may like&shy;
wise be derived from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Cr&aelig;t</etym>, a cart, for the simi&shy;
litude thereof. v. Cart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="craft(n)">Craft,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cr&aelig;ft</etym>,
Fr. Th. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kraft,
Krafft,</etym> power; and these may
seem to flow from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F71;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, ability of doing a
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crag(n)">Crag,</form> <xpln lang="en">the neck; from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kraeghe,</etym> the throat: Or, not
unlikely, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kra&shy;
gen,</etym> a collar, or cape of a
garment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crag(n)">Crag,</form> <xpln lang="en">a craggy rock; from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kraeghe,</etym> the neck; for
the tops of mountains are of&shy;
ten full of hillocks, like to the
joints in the neck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cram(v)">Cram,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cram&shy;
man</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. V. Crum.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cramp(n)">Cramp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. and Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Krampe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krampft,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Crampe,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Granchio,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cramp-iron(n)">Cramp-irons,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Cramp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cranage(n)">Cranage,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Crane.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crane(n)">Crane,</form> <xpln lang="en">an animal; also an en&shy;
gine to unload ships with;
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cr&aelig;n</etym>, by &AElig;lfrick, Cran, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kraene,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kran,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crank(a)">Crank,</form> <xpln lang="en">sound, healthy; from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vn,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Onkranck,</etym>
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  not sick; the initial syl&shy;
lable being lost.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crank(n)">Crank,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; I sup&shy;
pose, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kranck,</etym>
weak; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a ship of small
strength, with small sails.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cranny(n)">A Cranny,</form> <xpln lang="en">or little chink: Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Cren, Cran,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Crena,</etym> the
nib of a pen, the notch of an
arrow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crash(v)">To Crash with the teeth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escraser,</etym> to crush
in pieces; <etym lang="fr">Croissir,</etym> to give a
crack. Minshew derives it
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rauschen,</etym> the
same; all feigned from the
sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crazy(a)">Crasy, or Crazy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F71;&sigma;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  of a weak con&shy;
stitution: Or, if you please,
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escrase,</etym> Part.
of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Escraser;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one wasted with sickness.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cratch(n)">A Cratch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Creic&shy;
che, Cresche,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and these,
if I am not mistaken, from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Craticula, Cratica,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crave(v)">Crave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Crafian</etym>,
Dan. <etym lang="da">Kreffver,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Min&shy;
shew takes it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&alpha;&upsilon;&gamma;&#x1F74;</etym>, a cry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="craven(a)">Craven,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Verb To <etym lang="en">Crave</etym>;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that presently asketh
</page>

<page sig="G4r">
pardon of an adversary: Or
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Creopan</etym>, to
creep; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that falleth
down at the feet of every one
he has at any time offended:
Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Crave-hen; that is,
one addicted more to Vene&shy;
real, than Marshal affairs. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="craw(n)">Craw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kroe;</etym> or
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kroeghe,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crawl(v)">Crawl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krielen,</etym>
to be full of worms. It may
as well be taken from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Grallari,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to go foot af&shy;
ter foot, as children do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cray(n)">The Cray,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mal
de Craye,</etym> a disease among
hawks. This from <etym lang="fr">Craye,</etym> chalk,
or clay. Minshew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crayfish(n)">Cray-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escre&shy;
vice,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kreeft;</etym> and all,
not unlikely, from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&rho;&alpha;&beta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a kind of crab.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cream(n)">Cream,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Creme,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Crema;</etym> and all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cremor, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crease(n)">Crease,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Creta,</etym>
chalk; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a line drawn with
chalk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="credit(n)">Credit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Credit,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Credito;</etym> all from <etym lang="la">Credo,</etym>
to trust.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Apostles creed(n)">The Apostles Creed,</form> <xpln lang="en">plainly e&shy;
nough from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Credo,</etym> to
believe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="creak(v)">To Creck, or Creek,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kreke, Krick,</etym> Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Cricquer, Craquer,</etym> the same;
all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="creek(n)">A Creek;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draweth it
from the Verb To <etym lang="en">Creck;</etym> yet
I had rather take it from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kriechen,</etym> to creep, as
the water doth, where the
bank is broken down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crick(n)">A Creek in the neck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
word <etym lang="en">Crack;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cringle(n)">Creengles,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing,
<term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Ringles;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) small
cords wound round like a ring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="creep(v)">Creep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Graper,</etym>
AS. <etym lang="oe">Creopan</etym>; and all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Repere,</etym> the same:
Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kruypen;</etym>
which Voss. deriveth from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F7B;&phi;&alpha;</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to come on
privily.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crescent(a)">Cressent, or Cressant;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la"> Lu&shy;
na Crescens,</etym> the Moon in the
Increase; a term in Heral&shy;
dry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crest(n)">Crest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crest&eacute;</etym>
both conspicuously from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Crista,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crevasse(n)">Crevase, or Crevis,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Crevasse;</etym> both from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Crepare,</etym> to burst in the
midst.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crevet(n)" lexeme="cruset(n)">Crevet, or Cruset,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Crewet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="creviss(n)" lexeme="crevice(n)" lexeme="crevish(n)">Creviss, Crevice, or Crevish,</form> <xpln lang="en">the
same with Cray-fish; which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crew(n)">Crew,</form> <xpln lang="en">a society of good fel&shy;
lows. Minshew taketh it
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Creu,</etym> aug&shy;
mented, or increased. I had
rather draw it from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kroeghen;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a company
of Pot-companions, or sons
of Bacchus: This from <etym lang="bl">Kro&shy;
egh,</etym> a pipe, or butt of wine.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crewet(n)">Crewet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krug,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="G4v"> 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cruche,</etym> an earthen
pot. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crib(n)">Crib,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Krybbe, Kribbe, Krippe,</etym> Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Cribbe, Crippe,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ge&shy;
reppia;</etym> all signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cribble(n)">Crible,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Crivello;</etym>
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cribellum,</etym>
