(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a sieve to separate the
good seed from the bad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crick(n)">Crick,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Creek, and Crack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cricket(n)">Cricket,</form> <xpln lang="en">I imagine, from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kriechen,</etym> to creep;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a little stool, almost as
low as the very ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cricket(n)">Cricket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kricken,</etym>
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F77;&zeta;&omega;, &Kappa;&rho;&#x03AD;&kappa;&omega;,</etym> to
chirp; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a minute animal,
that maketh a crackling about
the fire. See Creek.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cry(n)">Crie,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crier,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kriitten,</etym> which Fr.
Jun. takes from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F77;&shy;
&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to make a whining noise.
It doth more than allude to
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&alpha;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, to weep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crimson(n)">Crimson,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cher&shy;
mesin,</etym> Ital <etym lang="it">Chermesino, Cre&shy;
mesino,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Carmesino,</etym> the
same; these from the Fr. G.
and Arab. <etym lang="fr">Cherme, Chermes,</etym>
or <etym lang="ar">Kermes:</etym> V. Cocheneal.
Salmasius sagaciously draws
our Crimson, from the an&shy;
cient Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guermes,</etym> in Lat.
<etym lang="la">Vermis,</etym> a worm. v. Ver&shy;
million.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cringe(v)">Cringe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krie&shy;
chen,</etym> to creep; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to bow
ones face, in a manner, to the
very ground, for fear or cold,
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crinkle(v)">Crinkle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kronc&shy;
kelen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. v. Rumple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cripple(n)">Cripple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kreple;</etym>
this from <etym lang="bl">Krepen,</etym> to creep;
(<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) one that creepeth upon
hands and knees. V. Creep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crock(n)">The Crock,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease among
hawks; it is a kind of Cramp;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croc,</etym> an
hook; because it draweth up
the joints like an hook. V.
Cramp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="croft(n)">Croft;</form> <xpln lang="en">Spelman derives it from
the Gr&aelig;co-Lat. <etym lang="la">Crypta;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a field enclosed. V. Close.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="croisade(n)">Croisade,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croi&shy;
sade;</etym> this from <etym lang="fr">Croix,</etym> in Lat.
<etym lang="la">Crux,</etym> a cross; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an ho&shy;
stile Expedition, set on foot
by the Pope, for the Cause of
Religion, in which every Sol&shy;
dier bears a Crucifix on his
breast, as an emblem of spiri&shy;
tual warfare.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="croises(n)">Croises,</form> <xpln lang="en">Pilgrims for the sake of
Religion; also Knights of the
sacred Order of St. John of
Jerusalem; from the same
Original, and so called for the
same reason as before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="croak(v)">To Croke,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cro&shy;
care,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croaquer, Crou&shy;
asser, Croasser;</etym> all from the
noise which a toad makes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crome(n)" lexeme="cromb(n)" lexeme="crom(n)">A Crome, Cromb, or Crom of
iron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Krom,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krum,</etym> crooked, saith
Minshew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crone(n)">A Crone, or Old Crone,</form> <xpln lang="en">a decre&shy;
pit old woman; from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kronie,</etym> an old ewe. It
may, not unelegantly, be ta&shy;
ken
</page>

<page sig="G5r"> 
from the word <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F79;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>,
time; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) well stricken in
years. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crony(n)">Crony,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word in Colleges, and
elsewhere; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F79;&shy;
&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a good old friend:
Or 'tis contracted from <etym lang="it">Con&shy;
gerrone,</etym> of the same signifi&shy;
cation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crook(n)">Crook,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Crycce</etym>,
a trumpet: Or from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Croc,</etym> an hook; or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kroken,</etym> to bend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crooked(a)">Crooked,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kro&shy;
get;</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crochu,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crop(n)">A Crop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Crop&shy;
pas</etym>, ears of corn; or the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crope, Croupe,</etym> a top:
From hence, To Crop. Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Carpo</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. It may also be
drawn from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F7D;&pi;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>,
a reaping-hook.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crop(n)">The Crop,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Craw, from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kroppe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kropff,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crolier-staff(n)">A Crolier-staff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Crosse;</etym> this from <etym lang="la">Crux,</etym> a
cross; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Bishop's Pasto&shy;
ral-staff, having the figure of
the Cross on the top.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crosslet(n)" lexeme="crosset(n)">Croslet or Crosset,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croiselet, Croisette,</etym> now
out of use. It signifieth, a little
Crucifix in Heraldry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crosslet(n)">Croslet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a woman's brow-piece;
so called, because it is put
cross the forehead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cross(n)">Cross,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croix,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Croce;</etym> and all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Crux,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crotchet(n)">Crotchet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Musick; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crotchet;</etym> and this
from <etym lang="fr">Croc,</etym> an hook; because
the character thereof does
somewhat represent it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crouch(v)">Crouch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crochu,</etym>
crooked: V. Crook. Or,
which is most likely, from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krauchen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crow(n)">A Crow of iron,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. Crane. It
may be no mistake to draw
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to
knock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crow(v)">To Crow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cra&shy;
wan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krahen,</etym> the same;
these from the Nouns, <etym lang="oe">Crawe</etym>,
<etym lang="tt">Krae,</etym> a crow. Fr. Jun.
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&alpha;&upsilon;&shy;
&gamma;&#x1F74;</etym>, an hoarse noise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crow(n)">A Crow,</form> <xpln lang="en">as before: V. To
Crow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crowd(v)">Crowd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Crud</etym>,
the same. Or it may be
drawn from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>,
to knock; men being there&shy;
in jostled one against ano&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="croud(n)">A Crowd of Musick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Crwth,</etym> a fiddle; Cry&shy;
ther, a Fidler; both perhaps
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to beat,
and its derivative <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F79;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a
stroke. Spelman draws it
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Guerda,</etym> a
string: The derivation is as
easie from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cru&eth;</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crown(n)">The Crown,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kruyne,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Coronne.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crucible(n)">Crucible,</form> <xpln lang="en">Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Crucibilum,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="G5v"> 
&agrave; <etym lang="la">Cruciando;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
Chymical vessel, wherein Me&shy;
tals are melted, and purified.
Dr. Th. H. draws it from the
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&upsilon;&sigma;&#x1F78;&nu; &Beta;&#x1F71;&lambda;&lambda;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, because
gold is cast into it. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cruel(a)">Cruel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cruel;</etym>
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Crudelis,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from <etym lang="la">Crudus,</etym> 
raw; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that could even
eat his enemy alive, raw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cruel(n)" lexeme="crewel(n)">Cruel; or rather, Crewel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Klowe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kla&shy;
wel;</etym> which probably hath
been corrupted from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Globulus,</etym> a bottom of thread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crumb(n)">Crum,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cruma</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krume, Krummel,</etym> id.
from this last, To Crumble:
They all flow from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Grumus,</etym> clots of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crump(v)">Crump,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Krimpen, Krummen,</etym> to shrink
up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crumple(v)">Crumple,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. Crump.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crupper(n)">Crupper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crou&shy;
piere,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cropiera,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Grupera,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cruse(n)">Cruse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krus,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krug,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cruche,</etym>
a Potter's vessel. It is not
much dissonant to the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F7D;&sigma;&sigma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> a water-pot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cruise(v)">To Cruse up and down the sea,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Sea-term; from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kruys,</etym> a cross; as we say, To
Cross up and down.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crush(v)">Crush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escra&shy;
ser;</etym> and this, without any of&shy;
fence, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Excru&shy;
ciare,</etym> to torment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="crutch(n)">Crutches,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cricce</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krucke,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Croccie,
Crocciole;</etym> all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Crux,</etym> because they are made
something like a cross.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cub(n)">Cub,</form> <xpln lang="en">as a Fox-Cub, &amp;c. Min&shy;
shew derives it from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Cubare,</etym> to lie down; because
they abide in their holes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cucking-stool(n)" lexeme="ducking-stool(n)">Cucking-stool; or rather, Duck&shy;
ing-stool; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Choaking-&shy;
stool;</form> <xpln lang="en">because Scolds being
thus punished are almost sti&shy;
fled with water: V. Choke.
Dr. Th. H. takes it from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coquine,</etym> a Beggar-&shy;
woman; because sturdy Beg&shy;
gar-women are washed in it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cuckold(n)">Cuckold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cocu, </etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or more easily from
<etym lang="en">Cuckow,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Hold;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
poor man, like A Cuckow,
he bringeth up other men's
children for his own.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cuckoo(n)">Cuckow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
cou,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cucco,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Cucu&shy;
lus;</etym> all from the note this
bird hath.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cud(n)">Cud,</form> <xpln lang="en">To chaw the Cud, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cud</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; or it is
so called, q. Chewed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cudgel(n)">Cudgel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kudse,
Kodse,</etym> a knotted stick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cuerpo, in(n)">Cuerpo,</form> <xpln lang="en">To walk in Cuerpo,
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cuerpo;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to go in so extraordinary an
habit, as will draw the eyes of
people after one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cuff(n)">Cuff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Schiaffo,</etym> the
same; or <etym lang="it">Zuffa,</etym> a scuffle;
or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to
smite; or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&lambda;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to smite
with the fist.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="G6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Culdee(n)">Culdees,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Monks, for&shy;
merly of Schone, in Scotland,
so called, &agrave; <etym lang="la">colendo Deum</etym>, 
from worshiping God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cull(v)">Cull,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cueillir,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cogliere;</etym> and both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Colligere,</etym> to chuse,
or gather together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cull(v)" lexeme="coll(v)">Cull, or Coll  about the neck,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Col,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Col&shy;
lum</etym> a neck; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to clasp
about the neck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="collander(n)">Cullender,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
landiere;</etym> this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Colum,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Colo,</etym> to strain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cullis(n)">Cullis,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coulis,</etym>
&agrave; <etym lang="la">Colando,</etym> from straining;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  strained broth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cully(n)">Cully,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Coglione,</etym> a
Fop; also the stones of any
creature, fools being naturally
well gifted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="culver(n)">Culver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Culfre</etym>,
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Columba,</etym> a pid&shy;
geon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="culvering(n)">Culvering,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Co&shy;
louvrine,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Colubrina;</etym> and
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Coluber;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a warlike engine, made
after the form of a serpent;
or, that is very destructive,
like a serpent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="culver-tail(n)">Culvertail,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture; not unlikely from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couple-artail,</etym> this from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Copulo,</etym> to couple, and
<etym lang="la">Articulus,</etym> a joint; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a
joining of boards together ar&shy;
tificially.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cumble(n)">Cumble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Com&shy;
ble,</etym> an heap; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  measure
heaped up.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="con(v)">Cunn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Connan</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Konnen,</etym> to apprehend a
matter, to understand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cunning(a)">Cunning,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cun&shy;
ning</etym>, expert, skilful; this
from the word <etym lang="oe">Cunn,</etym> or
<etym lang="oe">Kenn;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cup(n)">Cup,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cuppe</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kop,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couppe,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Coppa,</etym> Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7B;&pi;&eta;</etym>, the same.
Hence cometh the Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Capula</etym>, an Acron-Cup,and
<etym lang="la">Capella</etym>, a Taster.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cupola(n)">Cupola, or Cuppola,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in
Architecture; from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Cupo,</etym> high; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an high
Tower arched, having but
little light. Evelin draws it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cupa,</etym> a Cup.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cupping-glass(n)">Cupping-glasses,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our Eng.
<etym lang="en">Cup,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Glass.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cuirass(n)">Curass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cuirasse,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Coraccia, Corrazza:</etym> Or
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cuir,</etym> a skin;
(i e.) made of leather: Or ra&shy;
ther, from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cuore,</etym> the
heart; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) armour for the
breast. From hence, A Cu&shy;
rassier.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curate(n)">Curate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. barb. <etym lang="la">Cu&shy;
ratus,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cur&egrave;;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
one that taketh care of his
flock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curb(v)">Curb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Courber,</etym>
to hold back.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curd(v)" lexeme="curdle(v)">To Curd, or Curdle,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps by
a Metathesis, from the word
<etym lang="en">Crowd;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to Crowdle, or
thrust together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curl(v)">Curl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krollen,</etym> or
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ciurlare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gyrulus;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
</page>

<page sig="G6v"> 
to twirl up: Or, which seem&shy;
eth more probable, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyrran</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Keh&shy;
ren,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Keeren,</etym> to turn
up. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curlew&(n)">Curlew</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cor&shy;
lieu,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Carlotta,</etym> Arab.
<etym lang="ar">Corli;</etym> all signifying a bird so
named.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cur(n)">Curr,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Korre;</etym> this
from <etym lang="bl">Kirren,</etym> to grin: Or
from <etym lang="bl">Kurr,</etym> tamed: Or <etym lang="la">Curo,</etym>
to take care; for such dogs
are commonly trained up to
keep sheep.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curr-fish(n)">Curr-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a dog-fish. V.
Curr.</xpln>
<lemenote>
No dated citation found in OED but see "cur", n., compounds.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="currant(n)">Currans,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Corinths.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="current(n)">Currant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
rant</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  good mo&shy;
ney, that, in Commerce, pas&shy;
ses from one to another with&shy;
out any scruple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="current(n)">A Current,</form> <xpln lang="en">or river running
swiftly; from the same root.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="courrier(n)">Currier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cour&shy;
rier,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Corriere,</etym> from
<etym lang="la">Currus,</etym> say some; but it may
better be taken from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Coriare,</etym> to Curry, to dress a
skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curry(v)">Curry,</form> <xpln lang="en">to rub an horse down;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Curer,</etym> Lat.
<etym lang="la">Curare,</etym> to take care about.
It will not be amiss to take it
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&rho;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to brush,
or make clean.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curry favour(v)">To Curry favour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Querir,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Qu&aelig;rere,</etym>
to seek.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curse(v)">To Curse;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew takes it
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Courrua,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Corruccio,</etym> anger. Another
judiciously draws it from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cursan</etym>, this from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cruciare;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to
curse one to hell.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cursed(a)">Curst,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Korsel,</etym>
contumacious, impious: Or
from the word <etym lang="en">Curse;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that breaks out into cur&shy;
sings upon the lightest occa&shy;
sion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curtain(n)">Curtain,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Courtine,</etym> Ital.
Hisp. and old Lat. <etym lang="la">Cortina,</etym>
the same: Perhaps from our
Eng. <etym lang="en">Court;</etym> which see. It
may likewise be taken from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coverte,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Co&shy;
perta,</etym> a covering. V. Co&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curtal(v)" lexeme="curtail(v)">Curtal, or Curtail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kertelen,</etym> to cut short;
or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escourter,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Accortare,</etym> to abridge;
or more immediately from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Curtus,</etym> short; or from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Court,</etym> short; and
our word <etym lang="en">Tail;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cutlass(n)">Courtelass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
telas,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Coltellaccio,</etym> a short
kind of sword, now called A
Cutlass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="courtesan(n)">Curtezan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cour&shy;
tisane,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cortegiana,</etym> one
that is clothed after the Court-&shy;
fashions. It is also common&shy;
ly taken for a Whore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="curver(n)">Curver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Corvetta,</etym>
a leap, or jump.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cushinet(n)">Cushinet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coussi&shy;
net,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Cucinetto,</etym> a little
Cushion; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cushion(n)">Cushion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kussen,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="G7r"> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kussen,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coussin,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Coscino, Cucino,</etym> the
same; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Coxa,</etym>
an hip; because it is laid un&shy;
der them. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cuskin(n)">Cuskin,</form> <xpln lang="en">either a corruption of
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cissybium,</etym> an Ivy-&shy;
cup, by adding the termina&shy;
tion <etym lang="en">kin;</etym> or taken from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gousse,</etym> bark; that is,
hollow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="custard(n)">Custard,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Gustard, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Gu&shy;
stando,</etym> from tasting. It may
also be derived from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Kost,</etym> meat, and <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> nature,
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) sustenance; by the fi&shy;
gure Antonomasia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="custom(n)">Custom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cou&shy;
stume,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Costume,</etym> Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Costumbre;</etym> all perhaps con&shy;
tracted from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Consue&shy;
tudo,</etym> the same. Custom, is
likewise taken for a tax due to
the King for foreign Goods
brought into England.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cut(v)">Cut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Couteau,</etym>
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cultellus,</etym> a
knife; or from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Couper,</etym> Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cuttle(n)">Cutle-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Cut&shy;
tel-visch,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuttel-fisch;</etym>
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cutis,</etym>
because it is little else but
skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cutler(n)">Cutler,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couste&shy;
lier, Coutelier;</etym> this from
<etym lang="fr">Cousteau,</etym> a knife, or sword;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a knife, or sword-ma&shy;
ker.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cut-water(n)">Cut-water,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing:
V. Cut, and Water.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="D"><alpha>D</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dab(v)">To Dabb</form> <xpln lang="en">on, from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Dauber, Dober,</etym> to
Dawb; which see. Yet I
had rather derive it from our
word <etym lang="en">Do,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Uf</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Auff,</etym> upon, by an A&shy;
postrophe; as in D'on, and D'off.
Hence we say, To lay
it on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dabble(v)">To Dabble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dab&shy;
belen, Dabben,</etym> to roll dirt in
the hand: Or from the C. Br.
<etym lang="cb">Diblo,</etym> a daggle-tail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dace(n)" lexeme="dares(n)">Dace,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire
Dares; and this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dare</etym>,
hurt; because it is a fish thought to be unwholsome
for the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dacker(v)">Dacker,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently used
in Lincolnshire; from the
Belg <etym lang="bl">Daeckeren,</etym> to move
swiftly; this from <etym lang="bl">Daeck,</etym> a
cloud; clouds being easily dispelled with the wind. V.
To Stagger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dad(n)">Dad,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word whereby infants
call their fathers; from the
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Tad,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bab,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Dada, Dadda, Pappa, Tata,
Tato,</etym> a father; feigned from
the sound, says Minshew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dag(n)" lexeme="rag(n)">A Dag, or Rag of cloth;</form> <xpln lang="en">either
from the said <etym lang="en">Rag,</etym> by the
changing of one letter; or
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dag</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a
</page>

<page sig="G7v">
rag hanging down from the
rest of the cloth. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dagger(n)">Dagger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Daggert,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dagge,</etym> Ital. and Hisp.
<etym lang="sp">Daga,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dague;</etym> all of
the same signification.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daggle(v)">Daggle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deagan</etym>,
to bedawb: Or from <etym lang="en">Dab&shy;
ble;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deign(v)">Daign,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Daig&shy;
ner,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Degnare;</etym> and both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dignari,</etym> to
vouchsafe, or be pleased to do
a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dainty(a)">Dainty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Dain,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from
<etym lang="fr">Dain, Daim,</etym> a Doe, whose
flesh is esteemed very much
by all nations. Minshew takes
it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dente,</etym> the
Ablat. of <etym lang="la">Dens,</etym> a tooth:
Whence may come our say&shy;
ing, He hath got a sweet
tooth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dairy(n)">Dairy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Derriere;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an house backward, where cheese is usually made.
V. Minshew.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daisy(n)">Daisy, or Daizy;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&alpha;&#x1F77;&zeta;&omega;</etym>,
to divide; for that the flowers
thereof are many, and divi&shy;
ded one from another. Yet I
had rather draw it from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dais,</etym> a canopy; be&shy;
cause this sort of flower does
somewhat represent it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daker-hen(n)">A Daker-hen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Dauchen, Tauchen,</etym> to dive;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a bird that dives.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dale(n)">Dale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Dan.
<etym lang="da">Dal, Dail,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Thal, Tahl,</etym>
any steep place: Or, not un&shy;
likely, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F71;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>,
to be green, or flourish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dally(v)">To Dally,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dolen,
Dollen,</etym> to play the fool. Dr.
Th. H. taketh it from the word
<etym lang="en">Delay.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="damask(n)">Damask,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Da&shy;
mas, Damasquin,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Da&shy;
maschino, Damasco,</etym> Damask-&shy;
Linen; so called, for <etym lang="en">Da&shy;
mascus,</etym> the most famous and
ancient city of Assyria. Da&shy;
mas is put, not only for the
city, but also from many
things that belong to it; as
Damask Rose, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dame(n)">Dame,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dame,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Dama,</etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Domina,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dam(v)">Dam,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Demman</etym>,
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dammen,</etym> to
set bounds to water that it
may not pass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dam(v)">Damm,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a mother among
brutes; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Dame,</etym> a dame; for she hath
some dominion over her
young. Somnerus takes it
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tyman</etym>, to
bring forth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="damage(n)">Dammage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Dommage,</etym> Dial Picard. <etym lang="pi">Dam&shy;
mage;</etym> all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dam&shy;
num,</etym> loss.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="damp(a)">Damp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Damp,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dampff,</etym> a va&shy;
pour, or exhalation; Dan.
<etym lang="da">Damper,</etym> to evaporate. From
hence, To Damp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="damsel(n)">Damsel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Damoi&shy;
selle,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Damigella, Donzel&shy;
la,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="G8r"> 
a Gentlewoman; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Dominicella,</etym> a little
Dame. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="damson(n)">A Damson,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Da&shy;
maisine,</etym> a plumb so called,
for that perhaps it was at first
brought over from Damascus,
into Europe. Right Dama&shy;
scen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dance(v)">Dance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Danser,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Danzare,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tant&shy;
zen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from
<etym lang="tt">Tand,</etym> a fantastical invention.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dandeprat(n)">Dandeprat,</form> <xpln lang="en">a dwarf; from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Danden,</etym> to play the
fool, and <etym lang="bl">Praet,</etym> trifles; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that holdeth a frivolous
discourse. It may be taken
from our word <etym lang="en">Dandle,</etym> and
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prest,</etym> ready; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one so little, that he may be
carried about in ones arms
like a child.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dandle(v)">To Dandle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Dantzen, Tantzen;</etym> with us,
To Dance a child: Or from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dandiner,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Danten;</etym> all from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Tand,</etym> a phantasm, a foolish
action.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dandruff(n)">Dandruff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tan</etym>, a
scab, and <etym lang="oe">Drof</etym>, dirty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="danger(n)">Danger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Dan&shy;
ger,</etym> the same. Minsevus takes it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F71;&nu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, death, 
the greatest of all dangers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dangle(v)">Dangle,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q. d.</term> Hangle, <term lang="la">v.</term> Hang. 
It may be drawn from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ciondolare;</etym> this from 
<etym lang="it">Ci,</etym> and <etym lang="it">Ondolare,</etym> to wag, as 
the waves flow; that is, too 
and again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dangle-wallet(n)">Dangle-wallet,</form><xpln lang="en">an exact ba&shy;
lance. <term lang="la">v.</term> Dangle, and Wal&shy;
let.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"dangle-wallet" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dank(a)">Dank,</form><xpln lang="en">somewhat damp; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Duncken;</etym> and this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tingo,</etym> to dip in 
the water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dapper(a)">Dapper,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tapffer, 
Dapffer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a man 
of a small stature, yet coura&shy;
geous and nimble.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dapple(n)">Dapple,</form><xpln lang="en">a colour peculiar to hor&shy;
ses; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Apffel;</etym> 
with us, Apple; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> full of 
divers spots, like a Pippin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dare(v)">Dare,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dearran</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Derren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Durffen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. I might also derive it 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ardire,</etym> by the 
figure Metathesis. <term lang="la">v.</term> Har&shy;
dy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dark(v)">Dark,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deorc</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&delta;&epsilon;&rho;&kappa;&#x1F74;&sigma;</etym>, invi&shy;
sible.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="darling(n)">Darling,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deor&shy;
ling</etym>; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Dearling. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Dear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dart(n)">Dart,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dard,</etym> 
Ital. and Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Dardo,</etym> the 
same. Fr. Jun. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&alpha;&rho;&delta;&#x1FF6;&sigma;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, for <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F77;&psi;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, 
to cast.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dash(n)">Dash,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Dask,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew draws 
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Derschen, 
Dorschen;</etym> both from the 
Heb. <etym lang="he">Dash, Dosch,</etym> he hath 
threshed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dash(v)">To Dash,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gasquer,</etym> to bespatter with   
</page>  

<page sig="g8v">  
dirt. Minshew takes it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&sigma;&alpha;</etym>; by Eustathius 
interpreted, <etym lang="la">Stercus</etym>, (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) 
dung. I could also derive it 
from the other <etym lang="en">Dash,</etym> or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tache,</etym> a splatch of 
dirt. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dash(v)">Dash,</form><xpln lang="en">to terrifie; from <etym lang="en">Dazle;</etym> 
this from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyselen;</etym> 
to be greatly afraid: Or, 
which is more probable, from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dwaes,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Dwaes</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) to be able to say nothing 
for fear.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dastard(n)">Dastard,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dwaes</etym>, 
abashed, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
nature; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> faint-hearted, ti&shy;
morous by nature.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="date(n)">Date,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Datte, 
Daite,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Datil,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dat&shy;
tero;</etym> and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Dactylus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daughter(n)">Daughter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Doh&shy;
tor</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dochter,</etym> Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Daater,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tachter,</etym> the 
same; perhaps from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Dos,</etym> a portion.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daunt(v)">Daunt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Domter,</etym> 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Domitare,</etym> 
to tame, or keep under.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daw(n)">A Daw;</form><xpln lang="en">possibly, from the note 
which it hath.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="daub(v)">Dawb;</form><xpln lang="en">not unlikely, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dauber,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dawn(n)">Dawn;</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dawevant Dagh,</etym> the 
dew of the day. The deriva&shy;
tion is not unnatural if we 
draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">D&aelig;&shy;
gian</etym>, to begin to be day.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="day(n)">Day,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">D&aelig;g</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dagh,</etym> Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Tak,</etym>  Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Dag,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tag,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dazzle(v)">Dazle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyselen,</etym> 
to stun; also to make giddy, 
or light-headed; which you 
may draw from <etym lang="bl">Dwaes,</etym> or 
the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Dwaes</etym>, abashed.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deacon(n)">Deacon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Degn;</etym> 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Diaconus,</etym> 
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&iota;&#x1F71;&kappa;&omicron;&nu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, one that 
ministreth in holy things.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dead(a)" lexeme="death(n)">Dead, Death,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Dead, Dea&eth;</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dood,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Todt,</etym> Dan <etym lang="da">Dod,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
Mer. Cass. deriveth Die, from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F7B;&omega;, &Delta;&#x1F7B;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to interr: 
Minshew, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&shy;
&delta;&omega;</etym>, to fright; whence it is 
called, the King of terrours. 
Dr. Th. H. takes it from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Devier;</etym> and this from 
<etym lang="fr">De,</etym> and <etym lang="fr">Vie,</etym> which signifies 
as much as to depart this life.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deaf(a)">Deaf,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deaf</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Doof,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dawf;</etym> this 
last especially from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omega;&phi;&#x1F78;&sigma;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deal(v)">Deal,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">D&aelig;lan</etym>, to 
divide; Belg. <etym lang="bl">Deel,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Theil,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dean(n)">Dean,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Doyen,</etym> or 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F73;&kappa;&alpha;&nu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, a Deacon.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dear(a)">Dear,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dyran</etym>, 
to account dear to himself; 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dier, Duyer,</etym> Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Diue,</etym>  Teut. <etym lang="tt">Thewer,</etym> the 
same. It may more ingeni&shy;
ously than truly be taken from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F75;&rho;&alpha;&omega;</etym>, to catch at 
greedily, every one being de&shy;
sirous of things valuable.</xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="h1r">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="debase(v)">Debase,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desbais&shy;
ser,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Dibassare,</etym> to Abase; 
which see; as also Base.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="debate(v)">Debate,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Debat,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Dibatto;</etym> whence come 
the Verbs <etym lang="fr">Debaire, Dibatte&shy;
re</etym>,  to contend, or be at va&shy;
riance. <term lang="la">v.</term> Bate, and Abate.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="debauch(n)">Debauch,</form><xpln lang="en">A Debauch, from the 
old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desbaucher,</etym> to de&shy;
flour.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deboist(v)" lexeme="debase(v)">To Deboist; or rather, Debase,</form><xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desbaisser,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Dibassare;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to De&shy;
bash, for Abash: See Bashful, 
Abase, and Base. Or, more 
naturally, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Desbaucher,</etym> to traduce, or 
lead amiss. <term lang="la">v.</term> Debauch.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Verb form of  "deboist" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="debonair(a)">Debonair,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
bonnair,</etym> kind, mil; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
<etym lang="fr">De Bon Aire</etym>; that is to say, 
one of a good, genteel na&shy;
ture, carriage, and behaviour.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="debt(n)">Debt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Debte;</etym>  
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Debi&shy;
tum,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decant(v)">Decant,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="vu">De&shy;
cantare,</etym> a word lately found 
out by more barbarous Chy&shy;
mists; which those mighty 
Zoilus's derive from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">De,</etym> and the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&nu;&theta;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, a 
corner.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decay(v)">Decay,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Decadere,</etym> 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Decheoir;</etym> and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">De,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Cadere,</etym> 
to fade, to come to nothing; 
metaphorically taken from 
plants shedding of flowers.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decease(v)">Decease,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
cez,</etym> death; <etym lang="fr">Deceder,</etym> to die; 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dece&shy;
dere,</etym> to depart.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deceive(v)">Deceive,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dece&shy;
voir;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">De&shy;
cipere,</etym>  the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decipher(v)">Decipher,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
chiffrer, Deschiffrer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">De&shy;
ciferare,</etym> to draw out, or de&shy;
lineate. <term lang="la">v.</term> Cypher.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deck(n)">Deck,</form><xpln lang="en">by a little variation of the 
sence, from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="bl">Decken;</etym> both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tegere;</etym> and this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&#x1F73;&gamma;&omega;</etym>, to cover.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deck(n)">Decks of a ship,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Decken,</etym> to cover, or defend.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="declension(n)">Declension,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
clinaison;</etym> both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Declinatio,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decrease(v)">Decrease,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
croistre;</etym> and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Decrescere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decree(n)">Decree,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Decret;</etym>  
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Decre&shy;
tum,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="decry(v)">Decry,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Descrier,</etym> 
openly to defame; also to cry 
down any Coin.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deed(n)">Deed,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">D&aelig;d</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Daed,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">That,</etym> the same. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Do.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deem(v)">Deem,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deman</etym>, 
to judge, or examine.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deep(a)">Deep</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deop</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Diep,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tieff,</etym> the same; 
which may be drawn from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Diepte,</etym>  Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tieffte,</etym> a 
gulf. Mer. Cas. violently 
wrests it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&theta;&#x1F7A;&sigma;</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deer(n)">Deer,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deor</etym>, 
Belg. and Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Dier,</etym> Teut.   
</page>  

<page sig="h1v">   
<etym lang="tt">Thier;</etym> and this manifestly 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F74;&rho;</etym>, any wild 
beast. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deface(v)">Deface,</form><xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
facer,</etym> to soil, or spoil the 
hape of any thing, to disfi&shy;
gure.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="defailance(n)">Defailance,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
faillance;</etym>  this from the Verb 
<etym lang="fr">Defaillir,</etym> to faint away as 
one in a fit; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">De,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Fallere.</etym></xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="defalk(v)">Defaulk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
falquer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Defalcare,</etym> to 
strike, or cut off; a term in 
Arithmetick; a Metaphor ta&shy;
ken from Reapers.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="default(n)">Default,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
faut;</etym> this from the Verb <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
faillir,</etym> to do amiss.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="defile(v)">Defile,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="la">De,</etym>  
and the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Ful</etym>, or the Eng. 
<etym lang="en">Foul;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deflower(v)">Deflour,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Defleu&shy;
rer;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Deflorare; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) 
to rob a virgin of the flower 
of her virginity.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="defray(v)">Defray,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
frayer,</etym> this from <etym lang="fr">Frais;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
to pay charges.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deft(a)">Deft,</form><xpln lang="en">a Northern word; from 
the AS.  <etym lang="oe">D&aelig;fe</etym>, pretty, or 
handsome.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="defy(v)">Defy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Defier, 
Deffier,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Disfidare, Sfida&shy;
re,</etym> to challenge one into the 
field.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="degrade(v)">Degrade,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
grader, Desgrader,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="degree(n)">Degree,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Degr&egrave;,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="delay(n)">Delay,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Delay,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Dilaio,</etym> to put off, or de&shy;
fer to a longer time.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="delay(v)">To Delay</form><xpln lang="en">wine, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Delayer, Dilaier,</etym> to mix, or 
mingle.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="delight(n)">Delight,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dele&shy;
ctor,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dilettare;</etym> all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Delectare,</etym> the same. 
Or it may more immediately 
flow from the old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
lict,</etym> which is found in an old 
Translation of the Bible, and 
may be englished, pleasure, or 
delight.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deliver(v)">Deliver,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Deli&shy;
vrer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Deliverare,</etym> to set 
at liberty.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="delve(v)">Delve,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Delfan</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Delven,</etym> to dig.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deluge(n)">Deluge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
luge;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Diluvium,</etym> the same; this 
from <etym lang="la">Diluo,</etym> to wash away.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="demand(v)">Demand,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
mander,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dimandare;</etym> 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Demanda&shy;
re, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</etym></xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="demeanour(n)" lexeme="demean(v)">Demeanour, Demean;</form><xpln lang="en">Min&shy;
shew derives them from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moyen,</etym> mean; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
to comport himself humbly; 
rather from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Deme&shy;
ner,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dimenare, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</etym></xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="demolish(v)">Demolish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
molir;</etym> and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Demoliri,</etym> to level with the 
ground.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="demure(a)">Demure,</form><xpln lang="en">reserved, coy, modest, 
serious; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des 
m&aelig;urs,</etym>  over-mannerly; or 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Demuth,</etym> gra&shy;
vity, or modesty.</xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="h2r">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="demur(v)">To Demurr,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Law; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Demeurer,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Dimorare,</etym> to delay; <term lang="la">i. e.</term> 
to stave off an Action to some 
other time.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="demi(n)">Demy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Demy;</etym> 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dimi&shy;
dium,</etym> the one half of a thing. 
Demy also signifieth a Degree 
in Magdalen-College, Ox&shy;
ford; A Demy-Fellow, one 
that hath half the salary due 
to a Fellow.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="denier(n)" lexeme="penny(n)">A Denier, or Peny;</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Denier,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Denaro;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dena&shy;
rius,</etym>  the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="den(v)">Den;</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Denne,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Tana,</etym> 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Taniere,</etym> the same. It 
may, if I may be allowed so 
much liberty, be taken from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F7B;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to go under.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="denizen(n)">Dennizen;</form><xpln lang="en">Davis draws it plain&shy;
ly from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dinaswr, 
Dinesidd,</etym> a Free-man; and 
this from <etym lang="cb">Dinas,</etym> a city. Min&shy;
shew derives it from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Donaison;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a Citizen 
by gift and Co-optation Or, it 
may be so said, <term lang="la">q.</term> Danes Son, 
from the Danes,  that adopt&shy;
ed such into their own tribes, 
when they invaded Egland.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dentil(n)">Dentels,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture; 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Dentelli, <term lang="la">idem</term>;</etym> 
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dentu&shy;
li,</etym> little teeth; which they re&shy;
semble.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deny(v)">Deny,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Denier;</etym> 
and both originally from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Denegare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="depaint(v)">Depaint,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
peindre;</etym> both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Depingere</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="depart(v)">Depart,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Depar&shy;
tir,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dipartire;</etym> and this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dispartiri;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term>to separate himself from 
others.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="descant(n)">Descant,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
chant,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Discanto,</etym> a fre&shy;
quent iteration of one thing; 
a term in Musick.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="descry(v)">Descry,</form><xpln lang="en">from the inseparable 
pr&aelig;p. <etym lang="en">Dis,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Cry;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to 
discover openly.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deserve(v)">Deserve,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Deser&shy;
vir,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Deservire,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="desire(n)">Desire,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desir,</etym>  
Ital. <etym lang="it">Desire;</etym> or from their 
Verbs <etym lang="fr">Desirer</etym>, <etym lang="fr">Desirare;</etym> all 
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Desi&shy;
derare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="desk(n)">Desk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Disch,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tisch,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Desco,</etym> <term lang="la">id.</term> 
'Tis a sort of table to write 
upon, and keep Accounts in.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="despair(n)">Despair,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
spoir,</etym> the Verb <etym lang="fr">Desperer;</etym> all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Desperare,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="despise(v)">Despise,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Despi&shy;
ter,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Dispettare;</etym> or their 
Nouns <etym lang="fr">Despit</etym>, <etym lang="it">Dispetto;</etym> all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Despicere,</etym> the 
same. See Despite.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="despite(n)">Despite,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Despit,</etym>  
indignation; or <etym lang="fr">Despiteux,</etym> 
stomachful. See Spite.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="despoil(v)">Despoil,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dispou&shy;
iller,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Spogliare;</etym> all from 
the Lat.  <etym lang="la">Spoliare,</etym> the same</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="destroy(v)">Destroy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Destruir;</etym>   
</page>  

<page sig="h2v">  
both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Destruere,</etym> to lay waste. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="detain(v)">Detain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dete&shy;
nir,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Detinere,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="developed(a)">Developed,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Invelop.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="devest(v)">Devest,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desve&shy;
stir,</etym> to put off a garment.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="devil(n)">Devil,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deofl</etym>, 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Diafl, Diafwl,</etym> Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Diable,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Diablo,</etym> Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Diavolo,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyvel,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Teuffel;</etym> all from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&iota;&#x1F71;&beta;&omicron;&lambda;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, an impeacher, a 
back-biter, an accuser.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="devise(v)">Devise,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Deviser, </etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="devoir(n)">Devoir,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Devoir, </etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deuce(n)">A Deuce, or Dews,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Dewx,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&upsilon;&#x1F70;&sigma;</etym>, 
the number Two, at Cards, 
or Dice.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dew(n)">Dew,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deawe</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dauw,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Taw,</etym> the 
same. It may also be drawn 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to water, 
or wet.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dewlap(n)">Dew-lap;</form><xpln lang="en">so called, because it 
laps the dew: Or from the 
AS.  <etym lang="oe">Deop l&aelig;ppe</etym>; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Deep-&shy;
lap.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dial(n)">Dial;</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q. d.</term> Lat. <etym lang="la">Diale,</etym> belong&shy;
ing to the day; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) shewing 
the hours of the day.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diamond(n)">Diamond,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dia&shy;
mant;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">A&shy;
damas,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diaper(n)">Diaper,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dia&shy;
prer, Diapre,</etym>  interwoven with 
flowers. We may reasonably 
suppose that all these flow 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Divair&egrave;,</etym> it 
being of a various contex&shy;
ture.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="diapered(a)">Diapered,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dia&shy;
pr&egrave;,</etym> variously interwoven; a 
term in Heraldry.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="didapper(n)">Didapper,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyck 
Dapper,</etym> a bird that dives 
well; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Dive-dapper. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Dip, Dive, Dapper.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="didder(v)">To Didder,</form><xpln lang="en">a word in Lincoln&shy;
shire;  from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sitte&shy;
ren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zittern,</etym> to chatter 
with cold.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dight(v)">Dight,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dihtan</etym>, 
to prepare, or make ready: 
Or from our word <etym lang="en">Deck;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dike-grave(n)">Digrave;</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q. d.</term> Dike, or Ditch&shy;
grave; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) a Collector of 
money for the repairing of 
high-ways, and ditches. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Grave.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dike(n)">Dike,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Ditch.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dildo(n)">Dildo,</form><xpln lang="en">contracted from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Diletto;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> woman's de&shy;
light. Or it may be drawn 
from our word <etym lang="en">Dally;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
a thing to play withal. See 
Dally.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dim(v)">Dim,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dim</etym>, the 
same: Or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Demmen, Dammen,</etym> to muz&shy;
zle.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dimple(n)">A Dimple</form><xpln lang="en">in the face, or chin; 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> Dintle, Dentle; from 
our word <etym lang="en">Dint,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Dent;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="din(n)">Din,</form><xpln lang="en">peradventure from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Dyn</etym>, noise; or <etym lang="oe">Dynan</etym>, to 
sound: Or perhaps from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tinnio,</etym> to tingle.</xpln></wordentry>    
</page>  

<page sig="h3r">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dine(v)">Dine,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Dinner.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ding(v)">To Ding,</form><xpln lang="en">hit against; perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dringen,</etym> to 
pinch, or bruise: Or from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tinnio,</etym> to ring, or 
tingle.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ding-dong(n)">Ding-dong,</form><xpln lang="en">from the sound of 
bells.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dinner(n)">Dinner,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Disner,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Desinare, Discinare,</etym> to 
dine. Some derive it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dejejunare,</etym> to break 
ones fast.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dint(n)">Dint,</form><xpln lang="en">an impression; from the 
AS.  <etym lang="oe">Dynt</etym>, a blow. Mena&shy;
gius derives it from <etym lang="la">Dente,</etym> 
the Abl. of <etym lang="la">Dens,</etym> a tooth; 
(<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) a mark made with the 
teeth.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dip(n)">Dip,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dippan</etym>, 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Dypper,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Doopen</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dirge(n)">A Dirge;</form><xpln lang="en">as Dr. Th. H.  informs 
us, from the Psalm that be&shy;
gins with <etym lang="la">Dirige nos Domi&shy;
ne.</etym> Mer. Cas. takes it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F4A;&delta;&upsilon;&rho;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, a lamenta&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dirt(n)">Dirt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drtit,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dreck,</etym> dung, filth; 
or from the Verb <etym lang="tt">Driiten,</etym> to 
shite.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disadventure(n)">Disadventure,</form><xpln lang="en">an ill chance. See 
Adventure.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dizzard(n)">Disard,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dizi</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Duysigh,</etym> vertiginous, amazed: 
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Disard,</etym> a 
pratler: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dwaes Aerd,</etym>  an Idiot, one 
moped. <term lang="la">v.</term> Dizzy.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disaster(n)">Disaster,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desa&shy;
stre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Disastro;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> <etym lang="la">Disa&shy;
strum</etym>, mis-hap occasioned by 
the influence of a malignant 
star.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disband(v)">Disband,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
bander,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Sbandare;</etym> these 
from <etym lang="it">Dis,</etym> and <etym lang="it">Bande;</etym> (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) 
to discharge, or remove from 
the troop.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disburse(v)">Disburse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
bourser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Disbor&shy;
sare,</etym> to unpurse. <term lang="la">v.</term> Purse.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discharge(v)">Discharge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
charger,</etym>  or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Discari&shy;
care,</etym> to set free. <term lang="la">v.</term> Charge.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disclose(v)">Disclose,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dis&shy;
clos,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Disclausus,</etym> 
discovered, brought to light.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discomfit(v)">Discomfit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dis&shy;
comfir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sconfig&shy;
gere,</etym> to rout an army.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discover(v)">Discover,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
couvrer,</etym>  or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scoprire,</etym> 
to uncover. <term lang="la">v.</term> Cover.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discount(v)">Discount,</form><xpln lang="en">Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Scontare,</etym> Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Discomputare,</etym> to count, or 
reckon off. <term lang="la">v.</term> Counts.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discourage(v)">Discourage,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
courager,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Scoraggiare,</etym> 
the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> Courage.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discourse(n)">Discourse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dis&shy;
cours,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Discorso;</etym> both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Discurrere;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> to run from one plea, or 
argument, to another.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discredit(n)">Discredit,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Credit.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="discreet(a)">Discreet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Discre&shy;
to,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="vu">Discre&shy;
tus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disdain(v)">Disdain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
daigner,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Sdegnare,</etym> to 
count a thing unworthy. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Daign.</xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="h3v">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disease(n)">Disease,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
saise,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Disagio,</etym> the same. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Ease.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disembogue(v)">Disembogue,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Disemboucher,</etym> now out of 
use; this from the Lat. pr&aelig;p. 
<etym lang="la">Dis,</etym> and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouche,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Bocca,</etym> a mouth; meant 
of that place of a river, where 
it emptieth it self into the 
sea.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disfigure(v)">Disfigure,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
figurer, Desfigurer,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dis&shy;
figurare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to spoil 
the shape of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disfranchise(v)">Disfranchise,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Desfranchir,</etym> to deprive one 
of his liberty. <term lang="la">v.</term> Frank, 
Franchise, and Enfranchise.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disgorge(v)">Disgorge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
gorger,</etym> to vomit up; meta&shy;
phorically taken from water, 
as it were, boiling up out of 
a gurges, or whirl-pool.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disgrace(n)">Disgrace,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dis&shy;
grace,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Disgratia,</etym> 
ignominy, or misfortune.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disguise(v)">Disguise,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
guiser;</etym> or from <etym lang="en">Dis,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Guise;</etym> which see; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to 
change habit and countenance.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disgust(n)">Disgust,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desgou&shy;
ster,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Disgustare;</etym> (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) 
to resent a thing ill.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dish(n)">Dish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Disc</etym>, <term lang="la">id.</term>
