or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Discus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disheveled(a)">Disheveled,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Di&shy;
schevel&egrave;,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Scapigliato;</etym> and 
these from their Nouns <etym lang="fr">Che&shy;
veux,</etym> and <etym lang="it">Capegli;</etym> which 
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Capilli,</etym> 
hairs; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) having it dang&shy;
ling loose upon the shoul&shy;
ders.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disengage(v)">Disingage,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G, <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
engager,</etym> to revoke an En&shy;
gagement. <term lang="la">v.</term> Engage, and 
Gage.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dislodge(v)">Dislodge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
loger,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Disloggiare, Slog&shy;
giare, </etym><term lang="la">idem</term>; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) to change 
ones lodgings. It is likewise a 
term in Hunting; as we say, 
To Dislodge a Deer, when 
we rouse him out of his 
Lodge.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disloyal(a)">Disloyal,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
loyal,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Disleale,</etym> the same. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Loyal.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dismal(n)">Dismal,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q. d.</term> <etym lang="la">Dies malus</etym>, an unlucky day, saith Minshew. 
I had rather draw it from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duys-Mael;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a stu&shy;
pendous time, or chance; or, 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> Dimnel,  from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Dim</etym>, dark; spoken in com&shy;
parison with hell, which is 
sometimes called, Utter 
Darkness.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dismantle(v)">Dismantle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
manteller,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Dismante&shy;
lar,</etym> to demolish the walls of 
cities; by an elegant Meta&shy;
phor, taken from stripping off 
ones garment.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dismount(v)">Dismount,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
monter,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Smontare,</etym> to a&shy;
light, or make to a-light. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Mount.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disobey(v)">Disobey,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dis&shy;
obeyr,</etym> the same; or, <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Disobedire.</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term> To Obey.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disorder(n)">Disorder,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Disor&shy;
dr&egrave;,</etym> the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> Order.</xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="h4r">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disparage(v)">Disparage,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
parager,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Dispareggiare;</etym> 
this from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parage;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> to compare with Infe&shy;
riours.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dispatch(v)">Dispatch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
pescher,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Dispac&shy;
ciare,</etym>  the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dispenser(n)">Dispencer,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
pensier,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Despensie&shy;
re;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Dispensator,</etym> a Steward. Min&shy;
shew.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dispeople(v)">Dispeople,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dis&shy;
peupler,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Depopula&shy;
ri,</etym> to lay waste.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dispart(v)">To Dispert,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="la">Dispertio,</etym> to 
divide; a term in Sailing, and 
in the Mathematicks. See 
Manwayring, in his Naut. 
Dict.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="displace(v)">Displace,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Place.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="display(v)">Display,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
plier,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Despiegare,</etym> to un&shy;
furl.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="disport(n)">Disport,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Sport.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dispose(v)">Dispose,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dispo&shy;
ser, <term lang="la">idem</term>;</etym> and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Disponere,</etym> to set in or&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dissemble(v)">Dissemble,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Des&shy;
sembler;</etym> and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Dissimulare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distain(v)">Distain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Destain&shy;
dre;</etym>  both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Di&shy;
stingere; </etym><term lang="la">q. d.</term> to paint with 
various spots.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distrain(v)">Distrain,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Law; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Destraindre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="distress(v)">Distress,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De&shy;
stresse,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Distretta;</etym> this 
from <etym lang="la">Dis,</etym> twice, and <etym lang="la">Strin&shy;
gere,</etym> to bind; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to la&shy;
bour hard under scarcity and 
want.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ditch(n)" lexeme="dike(n)">Ditch, or Dike,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Dice, Dic</etym>, or Dan. <etym lang="da">Diige, Dige,</etym> 
the same; and these from 
their Verbs <etym lang="oe">Dician,</etym> <etym lang="da">Dirger,</etym> to 
make a trench about: Or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Diik,</etym> which 
Fr. Jun.  derives from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Tau;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&chi;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, a wall. It may al&shy;
so be derived from our word 
<etym lang="en">Dig.</etym></xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ditty(n)">Ditty,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dictum,</etym> a 
saying; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a Sonnet com&shy;
prising but a few words.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dive(v)">Dive,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dippan</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Doopen,</etym> the same: Or per&shy;
haps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F7B;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to 
duck.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dizzy(a)">Dizzy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dizi</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyligh,</etym> the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Dazle.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doubler(n)">Dobeler; or rather, Doubler,</form><xpln lang="en">a 
great wooden platter. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Double.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dock(n)">A Dock,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Docca</etym>, a 
plant so called.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dock(n)">A Dock,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&omicron;&chi;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&omicron;&nu;</etym>; this from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;#x1F73;&chi;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, 
to receive; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a station for 
ships.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dodge(v)">To Dodge,</form><xpln lang="en">to run from one plea 
to another; derived from the 
word <etym lang="en">Dog,</etym> that runs this way, 
and that way in hunting. It 
is also attributed to the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Doddick,</etym> wavering; which 
comes from <etym lang="bl">Dodde,</etym> a spit that 
turneth often about.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dodkin(n)">Dodkin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyt&shy;
ken,</etym> the smallest coin that is;   
</page>  

<page sig="h4v">  
this from the diminutive ter&shy;
mination <etym lang="en">Kin,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">Duit,</etym> a 
farthing. <term lang="la">v.</term> Doit.  </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doe(n)">Doe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Da</etym>, Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Daa,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Das,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Daim,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="do(v)">To Doe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Don</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Thun,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dog(n)">Dog,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Doc</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dogge,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dock,</etym>  a 
Mongrel, or a Mastive. Hence 
To Dog one, to trace one like 
a dog. Minshew derives it 
from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F71;&kappa;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to bite.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dogged(a)">Dogged,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Dog;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> per&shy;
verse, of a crabbed, surly tem&shy;
per.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dogger(n)">Dogger,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Dog;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a lit&shy;
tle light ship, which, like an 
Hound, is soon turned this, 
or that way.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doit(n)">Doit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyt,</etym> Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Doigt;</etym> and this corrupted 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Digitus;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
a brass coin of a small value; so 
small, that it may be covered 
with the tip of the finger.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dole(n)">Dole,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dal, D&aelig;l</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Deyl,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Theil,</etym> a 
part, or pittance; these from 
the Verbs <etym lang="oe">D&aelig;lan</etym>, <etym lang="bl">Drylen, 
Theylen,</etym> to distribute. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Deal.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dollar(n)">Doller,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Daler,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Thaler,</etym> a German sil&shy;
ver-coin; both from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Talen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zahlen,</etym>  to pay. 
Martinius derives it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Thal,</etym> a Valley; it be&shy;
ing first coined in the Valley 
of Joachim, in Saxony.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dauphin(n)">Dolphin,</form><xpln lang="en">formerly the title of 
the Prince of Vienna; now, 
of the first-born of the French 
King; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Daul&shy;
phin,</etym>  and <etym lang="fr">Daulphine,</etym> a Dol&shy;
phin, which those princes car&shy;
ried in their Coat of Arms.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dolphin(n)">Dolphin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Daul&shy;
phin,</etym> the Lat. <etym lang="la">Delphinus,</etym> or 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&epsilon;&lambda;&phi;&#x1F76;&nu;</etym>, the same; this 
from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F73;&lambda;&phi;&alpha;&xi;</etym>, an hog; be&shy;
cause it somewhat resembleth 
one; or from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&epsilon;&lambda;&phi;&#x1F7A;&sigma;</etym>, a womb, 
for the bigness of its belly.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dolt(n)">Dolt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Doll,</etym> im&shy;
prudent; or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">At&shy;
tonitus,</etym> stupified.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Don(n)">Don,</form><xpln lang="en">properly a Spanish word; 
contracted from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Do&shy;
minus,</etym>  a master.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doom(n)">Doom,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dom, 
Dome,</etym> Teut. Vet. <etym lang="tt">Duom,</etym> 
Run. Dan <etym lang="ru">Dom,</etym> a Judgment. 
Whence the Verb <etym lang="da">Domner</etym>, 
to judge, or condemn. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Deem.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="door(n)">Door,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dure, 
Dora</etym>, Goth. <etym lang="go">Dore,</etym> Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Dor,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Thur, Thor;</etym> all 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F7B;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
Or rather, from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">&ETH;</etym>or, 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;urh,</etym> through.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dormant(a)">Dormant,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Dor&shy;
mant,</etym> a Participle of the Verb 
<etym lang="fr">Dormir,</etym> to sleep.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dormouse(n)">Dormouse;</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q. d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Mus Dormiens,</etym> 
a mouse that almost always 
sleepeth.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dor(v)">To Dorr,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Thor,</etym> 
a fool; or from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Dora</etym>, 
a drone; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to make one 
dull and stup<term lang="la">id.</term></xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="h5r">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dorser(n)" lexeme="dosser(n)">A Dorser, or Dosser;</form><xpln lang="en">that is, an 
horse-cloth; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Dossiere;</etym> both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Dorsum,</etym> a back.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dossel(n)">Dosel, or Dorsel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Dorsum,</etym> a back.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dote(v)">Dote,</form><xpln lang="en">from-the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dutten, 
Doten,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dotter,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dotterel(n)">Dotterel;</form><xpln lang="en">Cambden derives it 
from the Verb To <etym lang="en">Dote.</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Dote.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="double(n)">Double,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Double,</etym>  
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Doppio,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Duplum,</etym> two-fold.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doublet(n)">Doublet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Doub&shy;
let,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dobletto;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a 
vesture thicker than ordinary, 
to keep the stomach warm.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doubt(v)">Doubt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Doub&shy;
ten;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Dubitare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dove(n)">Dove,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dufa</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyf, Duyve,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dauv, Tauv,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Due,</etym>  the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dough(n)">Dough</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dah</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Deegh,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Deig, Teyg,</etym> 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Deyg;</etym> these from the 
Verbs <etym lang="da">Dyen, Deyen.</etym> Or it 
may be drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Deagan</etym>, to knead, to mix 
with water.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doughty(a)">Doughty,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Doh&shy;
tig</etym>, strenuous; or <etym lang="oe">Dugu&eth;</etym>, 
valour; which comes from 
<etym lang="oe">Dugan</etym>, to be strong: Or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Deuchd,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dugend,</etym> fortitude, courage. 
It also signifieth, a proud fel&shy;
<emend err="f">l</emend>ow; in which sence it may 
be so said, quasi Thoughty; 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> one that hath high 
thoughts of himself.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dowager(n)">Dowager,</form><xpln lang="en">a King's Widow; 
corrupted from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Douairiere,</etym> and this from 
<etym lang="fr">Douaire,</etym> a Dowry; which is 
allowed her by the Law.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dowlas(n)">Dowlas-cloth,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from 
<etym lang="en">Dowglas,</etym>  some Scotch-man, 
that first wrought it; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
Dowglas cloth: If it may 
not more probably be drawn 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dourlans,</etym> a 
Town in Picardy, once fa&shy;
mous for this kind of Manu&shy;
facture.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="down(adv)">Down,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dune, A&shy;
dune,</etym> downward.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="down(n)">Down,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Dun,</etym> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dunne;</etym> as, Dunne Ve&shy;
ders, (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) soft feathers. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Thin.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="down(n)">Downes,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyne,</etym> an heap of sand. 
Fr. Jun. deriveth all of them 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F76;&nu;</etym>, an heap. 
It may be better drawn from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&omicron;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F78;&sigma;</etym>, for <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F78;&sigma;</etym>, an hill.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dowry(n)" lexeme="dower(n)">Dowry, or Dower,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Douaire;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Dotarium,</etym> a portion. Mer. 
Cas. derives it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F7C;&rho;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a gift.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="douse(v)">To Dowse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dou&shy;
sen, </etym><term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tunsare,</etym> to beat.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doxy(n)">Doxy,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Docken,</etym> to yield willingly.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="doze(v)">To Doze,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyse&shy;
len,</etym> to be vertiginous, to 
stun: But more likely, from 
the word <etym lang="en">Dote;</etym> or from the   
</page>  

<page sig="h5v">  
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dw&aelig;s,</etym> stup<term lang="la">id.</term> Fr. 
Jun.  derives it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&upsilon;&#x1F71;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to talk foolishly. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dossil(n)">A Dozel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dou&shy;
sil, Doisil,</etym> a faucet.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dozen(n)">Dozen,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dou&shy;
zaine,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dozzina, Doz&shy;
zena,</etym>  the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drab(n)">Drab,</form><xpln lang="en">one that prostituteth her 
body for gain; from the AS. 
and Belg. <etym lang="oe">Drabbe</etym>, <etym lang="bl">Drabbe,</etym> 
course, common, or the refuse 
of any thing.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drab(n)">Draff,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Belg. 
<etym lang="oe">Drabbe,</etym> <etym lang="bl">Drabbe,</etym>  lees, or 
dregs: Or more immediately 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Draf,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drag(v)">Drag,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dragan</etym>, 
to draw along; the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Trecken,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drag&shy;
hen,</etym> the same; all possibly 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Trahere,</etym> to 
draw.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gum dragon(n)">Gum-Dragant, or Dragon,</form><xpln lang="en">cor&shy;
rupted from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Traga&shy;
cantha</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dragon(n)">Dragon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dra&shy;
gon,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Dragone;</etym> both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Draco,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&#x1F71;&kappa;&omega;&nu;</etym>, which comes 
from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F73;&rho;&kappa;&omega;</etym>, to see; a Dra&shy;
gon being quick-sighted.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dragoon(n)" lexeme="dragooner(n)">Dragoon, or Dragooners,</form><xpln lang="en">, in our 
modern Militia, Horse-men 
armed with Musquets; from 
<etym lang="en">Dragon,</etym> because at first they 
were as destructive to the E&shy;
nemy as Dragons. In the de&shy;
clining state of the Empire, 
the Standard-bearers were cal&shy;
led <etym lang="la">Draconarii,</etym> from <etym lang="la">Draco;</etym> 
because Dragons were painted 
upon their Standards, says Ve&shy;
getius.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drain(v)">Drain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trainer,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trainare;</etym> &agrave; <etym lang="la">Tra&shy;
hendo,</etym> from drawing; or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dringen,</etym> to squeese 
out the juice, or moisture.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drake(n)" lexeme="sea-drake(n)">Drake, Sea-Drake,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="la">Draco,</etym> 
a Dragon; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Water-Dra&shy;
gon.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drake(n)">Drake,</form><xpln lang="en">a warlike engine; <term lang="la">q. d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Draco;</etym> because it casteth 
out fire like a Dragon. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Culvering, and Serpentine.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drake(n)">A Drake,</form><xpln lang="en">A Male-Duck; not 
unlikely, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dreck,</etym> dirt; because it loves 
to feed in dirty places.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dram(n)">Dram,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Dramme,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Dramma;</etym> which 
comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Drach&shy;
ma,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Drap-de-Berry(n)">Drap de-Berry,</form><xpln lang="en">a kind of Frize 
brought from France. It is 
a pure Gallicism.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drape-sheep(n)">Drape-sheep,</form><xpln lang="en">I suppose from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Drefe</etym>, a severing; the 
same that Cullers; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="draper(n)">Draper,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Drapier,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Dra&shy;
ppiere, <term lang="la">idem</term>;</etym> these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Drap,</etym> and <etym lang="it">Drappo,</etym> cloth; 
which come from the Verb 
<etym lang="fr">Draper,</etym> to calender.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="draught(n)">Draught,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Droht</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Draght,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
this from the Verb <etym lang="bl">Draghen,</etym> 
to carry. <term lang="la">v.</term> Draw.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="draught(n)">The Draught,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.   
</page>  

<page sig="h6r">  
<etym lang="oe">Droge</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dreck,</etym> the 
excrements, dung. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="draught(n)">Draughts,</form><xpln lang="en">the single play at 
Chess; from our word <etym lang="en">Draw.</etym></xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="draw(v)">Draw,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dragan</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Draghen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tra&shy;
gen,</etym>  to bear. Minshew draws 
it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Traho,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dray(n)">A Dray,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Traha,</etym> 
which comes from <etym lang="la">Traho,</etym> to 
draw.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dread(n)">Dread,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dr&aelig;d</etym>, fear. Minshew draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Terret,</etym> the third per&shy;
son singular of <etym lang="la">Terreo,</etym> to af&shy;
fright.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dream(n)">Dream,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Droom,</etym> 
or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Traum,</etym> the same. 
Mer. Cas.  derives it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&#x1FB6;&mu;alpha;</etym>, a vision, it may 
likewise, by a Metathesis, be 
drawn from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dormi&shy;
re,</etym> to sleep.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dregs(n)">Dregs,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. and 
Belg. <etym lang="tt"></etym><etym lang="bl">Treck, Dreck,</etym> filth. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Dross.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drench(v)">Drench,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dren&shy;
can</etym>, to drink, to water. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Drink.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dress(n)">Dress,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Betres&shy;
cher;</etym> and both perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tracht,</etym> which may 
be interpreted, the fashion of 
a suit of cloths. Davis draws 
it from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Trwsio,</etym> to 
adorn, or deck.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drill(v)">To Drill,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dir&shy;
lian, Dirl</etym>, to make an hole 
through; this from <etym lang="oe">&ETH;urh</etym>, 
through. Hence, A Stone&shy;
cutter's Dril.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drink(v)">Drink,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Drink</etym>, 
of the Verb <etym lang="oe">Drincan</etym>, to 
drink, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drincken,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Trincken,</etym> the same. Some 
derive it from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Drin&shy;
care,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trinquer,</etym> 
to fuddle.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drip(v)">To Drip;</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Drop; perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trieffen,</etym> to 
drop.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drive(v)">Drive,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Drifan</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dreyven,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trei&shy;
van,</etym>  Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Dreven;</etym> as we 
say, To Drive on, as fast as 
he can Drive. In a metapho&shy;
rical sence, it may be taken 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&rho;&#x1F77;&beta;&omega;</etym>, to tear; 
as we say; To Drive off, or 
delay time.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drivel(n)">Drivel,</form><xpln lang="en">spittle; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Trieffen,</etym> to drop; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drizzle(v)">To Drizzle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rise&shy;
len;</etym> this from the Lat. dimi&shy;
nutive <etym lang="la">Rossulus,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Roscellus;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> to rain as small as dew.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="droil(n)">A Droil:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew deriveth it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drevel;</etym> this 
from <etym lang="bl">Drevelen,</etym> to turn any 
way; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> he that runneth 
this way, and that way, at his 
master's beck.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drole(n)">Drole,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Drole, 
Drolle,</etym> a merry Crony; as 
saith Menagius: Or perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Draucus, Drau&shy;
culus,</etym> a sort of mimick.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dromedary(n)">Dromedary,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Dromedaire,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Dromedario;</etym> 
</page>  

<page sig="h6v"> 
these from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&#x1F79;&mu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, a race; because of 
its swiftness. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drone(n)">Drone,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dr&aelig;n</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Traen,</etym> the same. 
Minshew derives it from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Droomigh,</etym> sleepy, slug&shy;
gish. I may also draw it from 
our Eng. Part. <etym lang="en">Droven,</etym> of the 
Verb To <etym lang="en">Drive;</etym> because they 
are driven away by the Bees, 
from their hives.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="droopish(a)">Droopish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Droef;</etym> 
this from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trub,</etym> of 
<etym lang="tt">Trubben,</etym> to vex; all, by a 
Metathesis, from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Turbare;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> troubled in 
mind; also sickly.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drop(v)">Drop,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Droppan</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trawffen, Tropffen;</etym> 
whence the Nouns <etym lang="tt">Dropa, 
Tropff, Trauff</etym>; in the Belg. 
<etym lang="tt">Droop, Drop</etym>; which Mer. 
Cas. draws from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&upsilon;&shy;
&pi;&epsilon;&tau;&#x1F74;&sigma;</etym>, (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) falling down&shy;
ward.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dropsy(n)">Dropsy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hydro&shy;
pisie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Hydropisia;</etym> 
or, more likely, from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Hydrops,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dross(n)">Dross,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dros</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Droes,</etym> the off-&shy;
scouring of things.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drove(n)">Drove,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Draf</etym>, 
herds of cattel. <term lang="la">v.</term> Drive.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drought(n)">Drought,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dru&shy;
go&eth;</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drooghte;</etym> 
parchedness; Derivatives of the 
AS.  <etym lang="oe">Drige, Drig</etym>, and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Droogh,</etym> torrid, or Dry; 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drowsiness(n)">Drousiness,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Verb To be 
<etym lang="en">Drousie;</etym> and this from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Droosen,</etym> always to 
slumber.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drown(v)">Drown,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Drunden,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Drunder,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drub(v)">To Drub,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Dub; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) to 
beat, as one beateth a Drum; 
or rather, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Druben;</etym> as we say, To lay it 
on; or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tru&shy;
ben,</etym>  to molest one greatly. 
It may also be taken from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&#x1FB;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&rho;&#x1F7B;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to 
bruise, or mangle.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drudge(n)">Drudge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Drec&shy;
can;</etym> because he is employed 
about the most servile offices: 
Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tragen,</etym> 
or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Draghen,</etym> to bear 
burthens. I may, without any 
offence, draw them all from 
the old Germ. <etym lang="gr">Dreck,</etym> dirt. 
Mer. Cas.  draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&rho;&upsilon;&gamma;&eta;&tau;&#x1F78;&sigma;</etym>, a vintage; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
to labour as hard as those that 
tread the wine-press.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drug(n)">Drug:</form><xpln lang="en">Salmasius draws it from 
the Pers. <etym lang="pe">Drova,</etym> a favour, or 
smell.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drug(n)">Drug</form><xpln lang="en">It is grown a meer Drug, 
from <etym lang="en">Dreg, Dregs;</etym> (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) it 
beareth no price, is of no value.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dragoman(n)">Druggerman,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Drogueman,  Trucheman;</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Torcimanno;</etym> which 
comes from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&alpha;&gamma;&omicron;&shy;
&mu;&#x1F71;&nu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>; and all possibly from 
the Chal. and Arab. <etym lang="cl">Targe&shy;
man,</etym> an Interpreter, or Ex&shy;
positor.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>  

<page sig="h7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="druid(n)">Druid,</form><xpln lang="en">a Priest among the an&shy;
cient Britains; from the AS. 
and Hib.  <etym lang="oe"></etym><etym lang="sp">Dry</etym>, a wise man. 
Martinius derives it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Druwed,</etym> one strong in 
faith. It may best of all be 
taken from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&#x1F7A;&sigma;</etym>, an 
Oak; under which they cele&shy;
brated their superstitious rites 
and ceremonies.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="drum(n)">Drumm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trom&shy;
mel,</etym> Teut. and Dan. <etym lang="tt">Trom&shy;
me;</etym> which are all words feig&shy;
ned from the sound. Some 
draw it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tympa&shy;
num,</etym> the same, by an Epen&shy;
thesis of the letter r.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dry(a)">Dry,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Drig, 
Drigge</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Droogh,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Durr,</etym> the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Thirst.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="deuce(n)">Duce,</form><xpln lang="en">Duce take you; perhaps 
from the Goth. and AS. 
<etym lang="go"></etym><etym lang="oe">Dues</etym>, a spectre; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) the 
Devil, or Evil Spirit take you.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duck(v)">To Duck,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="bl"></etym><etym lang="tt">Ducken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or, 
from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Gedufian</etym>, 
Ital. <etym lang="tt">Tuffare,</etym> to dive.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duck(n)">A Duck,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ducken, 
Duycken,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dauchen, 
Tauchen,</etym> to duck, or dive.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ducket(n)">Ducket,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Du&shy;
cat; </etym><term lang="la">q. d.</term> a Coyn having a 
Duke's Coronet stamped on 
it: Or, as Covarru<term lang="la">v.</term> saith, 
because great Dukes are per&shy;
mitted to coyn such money.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dudgeon(n)">Dudgeon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dolch,</etym> 
or <etym lang="tt">Dagen, Degen,</etym> a dagger. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Dagger.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dudgeon(n)">Dudgeon,</form><xpln lang="en">To take in Dudgeon; 
either from the other <etym lang="en">Dud&shy;
geon; </etym><term lang="la">q. d.</term> to resent a thing 
so ill, as to draw his sword to 
be avenged; or rather, from 
the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Dolg,</etym> a wound; 
and this &agrave; <etym lang="la">Dolendo,</etym> from grie&shy;
ving; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to bear an injury 
impatiently.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="due(n)">Due,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Deu,</etym> Part. 
of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Devoir,</etym> to be ow&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dug(n)">Dugg:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyght,</etym> a faucet; 
for milk is sucked thereout, as 
liquor through a faucet: Or, 
from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Dod, Dodin, </etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, a pap, or teat.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duke(n)">Duke,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Duc,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Duca,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dux,</etym> 
the same: From whence also 
cometh the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Duchesse</etym>, 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Duchessa</etym>, and the 
Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Ducissa</etym>. See Spel&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dulcimer(n)">A Dulcimer,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Dol&shy;
cemelle, Dolzaina;</etym> both from 
<etym lang="la">Dulcis,</etym> sweet.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dull(a)">Dull,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dole,</etym> Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="bl"></etym><etym lang="tt">Doll,</etym> stupid, slug&shy;
gish. It may, not unlikely, 
be drawn from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Do&shy;
lian</etym>, to suffer; for such take 
injuries more patiently than 
others.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dumb(a)">Dumb,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dumbe,</etym> 
in the Dan. and Teut. <etym lang="da"></etym><etym lang="tt">Dum, 
Thumb,</etym> stupid: Or from 
the old Germ. <etym lang="gr">Dumba,</etym> a fool: 
Or, as we say, A Dumb fel&shy;
low.</xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="h7v">    
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dump(n)">Dump,</form><xpln lang="en">from Dumb: Minshew 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Doma&shy;
re,</etym> to tame; for then our 
courage is cooled, and we are 
as it were amazed.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dunce(n)">Dunce,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tonto;</etym> 
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Attoni&shy;
tus,</etym> one affrighted: Or from 
<etym lang="en">Dumb,</etym> allusively, as it is ta&shy;
ken for him that is aukward 
to all instructions.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dung(n)">Dung,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dyngan</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dung, Dungen,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dungeon(n)">Dungeon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Don&shy;
geon,</etym>  a dark, strong and fen&shy;
ced place. Or perhaps it may 
be so called, because of its na&shy;
stiness, being all defiled with 
<emend err="with"></emend>the excrements of the 
imprisoned.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dun(v)">To Dun,</form><xpln lang="en">to be importunate in 
words; from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Dyn, 
Dynan</etym>, to make a great 
noise about any thing.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dun(n)">Dunn,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dun;</etym> as 
<etym lang="oe">Dun-fealu</etym>, a dun-foal.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="durgen(n)">Durgen,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dweorg</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dwergh, Dwargh,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zwarg,</etym> a Dwarf; 
which see.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"durgen" antedates earliest OED citation (1706).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dusk(n)">Dusk,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Dystre</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Duster,</etym> 
dark, or dull.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dust(n)">Dust,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dust</etym>, the 
same: Or from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Dyrre</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Durre;</etym> 
which signifies, dry.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duchy(n)">Dutchy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Duch&egrave;,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ducea, Ducato,</etym> the same. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Duke.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="duty(n)">Duty,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Due.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dwarf(n)">Dwarf,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dweorh,</etym> 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Duerre,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dwergh, 
Dwargh,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zwerch, 
Zwarg,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">i. e.</term> one of a 
small stature.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dwell(v)">Dwell,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Duelger,</etym> 
to abide. Somnerus draws it 
from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Dwelian,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dwaelen;</etym> because our Ance&shy;
stors once lodged in Tents, 
which they removed from 
place to place. Minshew  
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&iota;&alpha;&upsilon;&shy;
lambda;&#x1F77;&zeta;&zeta;&epsilon;&sigma;&theta;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, or the Goth. <etym lang="go">Dwale,</etym> 
to lodge in an Inn by the 
way.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dwindle(v)">To Dwindle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Dwinan,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duynen,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwinded,</etym> to de&shy;
crease; also to grow dim, or 
go out.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="die(n)">A Dy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Di&egrave;,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Dado,</etym> the same. It 
may not incommodiously be 
drawn from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F77;&kappa;&omega;</etym>, to 
cast; or from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, because it 
wipeth one of his money.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="die(v)">To Dy,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Death.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="dye(v)">To Dy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deagan</etym>, 
this perhaps from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Tingere,</etym> to dip in colours. 
Minshew draweth it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F77;&eta;&mu;&iota;, &Delta;&iota;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to make 
moist, or to besprinkle.</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>
</page>  

<page sig="h8r">
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="E"><alpha>E</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="each(pr)">EAch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Elc</etym>, in 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Elck,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">El&shy;
lick,</etym>  the same. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1B;&kappa;&alpha;&shy;
&sigma;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, every one.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eager(a)">Eager,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eagor</etym>, 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aigre,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Agro;</etym> all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Acer,</etym> sharp, 
fierce, cruel. It is also taken 
for the raging flux and re-flux 
of the river Trent, from the 
Run. Dan. <etym lang="ru">Eger,</etym> signifying, 
the Ocean.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eagle(n)">Eagle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aigle;</etym> 
both contracted from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Aquila,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eke(adv)">Eak,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;ce,</etym> Eter&shy;
nity. <term lang="la">v.</term> Eke.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eme(n)">Eam,</form><xpln lang="en">Mine Eam, from the 
AS.  <etym lang="oe">Eame,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oom,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ohm,</etym>  an unkle; all 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Amita,</etym> 
signifying an aunt.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ear(n)">Ear,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eare</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Oor,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Ore,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ohr,</etym>  
the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ear(n)">Ear of corn,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Eare</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ahr,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Are;</etym> 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Arista,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="arable(n)">Earable,</form><xpln lang="en">for Arable, from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Arabilis,</etym> fit to be plow&shy;
ed: Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea&shy;
rian,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Erren;</etym> which 
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Arare,</etym> to 
plow.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="earl(n)">Earl,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eorl,</etym> the 
old Dan. <etym lang="da">Eorla;</etym> these, not 
unlikely, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eer,</etym> ho&shy;
nour, or nobility.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="early(adv)">Early,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aer,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Eer,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eher,</etym>  signifying, 
before; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> before the rising 
of the Sun. <term lang="la">v.</term> Ere.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="earn(v)">Earn,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Earnian,</etym> 
or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Arnon,</etym> to get, or 
deserve; this perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, a stipend, or salary. 
Minsh. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&rho;&nu;&upsilon;&mu;&iota;</etym>, to receive, or acquire.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="earnest(a)">Earnest,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eor&shy;
nest,</etym> Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="bl">Ernst,</etym> 
vehement, serious, studious, 
earnest, a pledge given before&shy;
hand, to ratifie a bargain; 
from the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="la">Arrha,</etym> 
the same. the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Eor&shy;
nest,</etym> comes from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Arian,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eeren,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ehren;</etym> whence their Nouns 
<etym lang="tt">Are, Eer, Ehr</etym>, a salary, or 
stipend.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="earth(n)">Earth,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eard, 
Eor&eth;</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Erd, Aerde,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Erde,</etym> the same. They 
may all be drawn from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, the ground; 
whence comes the Ad<term lang="la">v.</term> &Nu;&#x1F73;&rho;&shy;
&theta;&epsilon;, below, beneath, or under.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="earwig(n)">Earwig,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ear&shy;
pigga</etym>, and this from <etym lang="oe">Eare</etym>, 
an ear, and <etym lang="oe">Wicga,</etym> a kind 
of moth, or small worm.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ease(n)">Ease,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aise,</etym> or   
</page>  

<page sig="h8v">  
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Agio;</etym> which Mena&shy;
gius  draws from the Lat. <etym lang="la">O&shy;
tium,</etym> pleasure, retirement; 
but most likely, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ea&eth;</etym>, easie. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="easement(n)">An Easement,</form><xpln lang="en">a privy, or jakes; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ausemente,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Agiamento,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="east(n)">East,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">East</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oest,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oest,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Easter(n)">Easter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Easter</etym>, 
in the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oster,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">O&shy;
stern. </etym>Somnerus draws it 
from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Eastre</etym>, a 
Goddess of the Saxons,  or 
Germans; in whose honour 
sacrifices were offered about 
this time of the year.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="easy(a)">Easy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ais&egrave;,</etym> the 
same: Or from the Noun 
<etym lang="en">Ease:</etym> Or, which is most like&shy;
ly, from the AS <etym lang="oe">Ea&eth;</etym>, <term lang="la">id.</term> 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> <etym lang="oe">Eathy</etym>; which Fr. Jun. 
derives from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&theta;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, 
custom; because use makes 
perfect, as we say.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eat(v)">Eat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Etan</etym>, Belg: 
<etym lang="bl">Eaten,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Essen,</etym> the same; 
and these from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ette</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">At,</etym> any sort of provi&shy;
sion; and all of them from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Edo,</etym> and this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&delta;&omega;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eat-bee(n)">An Eat-bee,</form><xpln lang="en">a bird so called, be&shy;
cause it feedeth upon <etym lang="en">Bees</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eave(n)">Eaves,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eaux;</etym> 
and this from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
water; because they receive 
the rain that runneth down 
from the house-top.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eavesdropper(n)">Eaves-dropper,</form><xpln lang="en">one that privily 
listeneth under the windows, 
what the people in the house 
say; from <etym lang="en">Eaves,</etym>  under which 
he stands; and <etym lang="en">Dropper,</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ebb(n)">Ebb,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Dan. 
<etym lang="bl"></etym><etym lang="da">Ebbe,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ebe, 
Hebbe,</etym> according to some; 
but most likely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ebba</etym>, the flux and re-flux of 
the Tide. <term lang="la">v.</term> Slide.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eddy(n)">An Eddy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ed</etym>, 
again, and <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water; a 
whirl-pool, wherein the water 
turneth round.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="edge(n)">Edge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eege</etym>; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Acies,</etym> 
and this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&kappa;&eta;</etym>, 
the sharp side or point of any 
thing.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eddish(n)">Edish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Edisc;</etym> 
this from <etym lang="oe">Ed</etym>, the second 
time; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> fog, or grass that 
groweth so fast, as to be mown 
twice in one Summer.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eel(n)">Eel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">El</etym>, Dan. and 
Teut. <etym lang="da"></etym><etym lang="tt">Aal,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ael,</etym> the 
same; and all from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F3C;&lambda;&upsilon;&sigma;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&lambda;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, mudd; be&shy;
cause they increase most in 
muddy waters.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eve(n)">The Eves</form> <xpln lang="en">of an Holy-day; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Evenings</etym> falling before a 
Fast-day.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="effort(n)">Effort,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Effort;</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) the putting forth of ones 
whole strength. <term lang="la">v.</term> Force.</xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="i1r">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="effrontery(n)">Effrontery,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ef&shy;
fronterie,</etym> impudence; and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Effrons,</etym> im&shy;
pudent, saucy, malapert.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"effrontery" antedates earliest OED quotation (1715).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eft(n)">An Eft or Evet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.  
<etym lang="oe">Ebeft,</etym> and this from <etym lang="oe">Efan</etym>, 
smooth; so called, for the 
smoothness of its skin.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eftsooners(adv)">Eft-soons,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Efso&shy;
na</etym>, by and by, immediate&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="egg(n)">Egg,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;g,</etym> Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Eg,</etym> Teut. and Belg. <etym lang="tt"></etym><etym lang="bl">Ey,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="egg(v)">To Egg,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Egger,</etym> 
Run. Dan. <etym lang="ru">Eggia,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">A&shy;
gacer,</etym> to instigate, or prick 
forward; and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Acutus,</etym> sharp. The same 
with Edge; which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eglantine(n)">Eglantine,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aig&shy;
lantier,</etym> a wild rose. Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Echinus,</etym> an hedge-hog; be&shy;
cause it is full of prickles, like 
unto it. It may also be taken 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eghel,</etym> an 
hedge-hog; and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Aculeus,</etym> a sting, or sharp 
prick.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="egret(n)">Egret,</form><xpln lang="en">a bird so named; because 
it is eager in hunting after its 
prey.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eight(n)">Eight,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eahta,</etym> 
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="bl"></etym> <etym lang="tt">Acht,</etym> Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Otto,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ootio,</etym> Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Huit;</etym> all from the Lat. and 
Gr <etym lang="gr">&#x1F4C;&kappa;&tau;&omega;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eyelet hole(n)">An Eilet-Hole,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Oilet-hole.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="either(a)">Either,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;g&eth;er,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from the Pre&shy;
position <etym lang="oe">&AElig;c,</etym> also, and <etym lang="oe">Der,</etym> 
afterwards.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eke(adv)">Eke,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eac</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Auch,</etym> moreover, again, also.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eke(v)">To Eke,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eacan, 
Gecan,</etym> to put a piece into a 
vesture, &amp;c. Or from <etym lang="en">Eke,</etym> 
again; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to make a-new in 
some parts.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ela(n)">Ela,</form><xpln lang="en">the highest note ascending 
in Musick; perhaps from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Eleva,</etym> elevation.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elbow(n)">Elbow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Elboga</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Elle-booge,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Albu;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> the bowt, or bent of the 
arm. <term lang="la">v.</term> Ell, and Bow.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elder(n)">Eldar,</form><xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, Hellar, 
in Westmorland, Ellar, from 
the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Ellarn</etym>, or the Teut. 
 <etym lang="tt">Holder,</etym> the same: Or perhaps 
 from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heller,</etym> clear; 
 from the bright colour if its 
 leaves.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elding(n)">Elden,</form><xpln lang="en">fuel for the fire; a word 
frequently used in Axholm 
in Lincolnshire, and else&shy;
where; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;ld</etym>, 
fuel for the fire; or <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lan</etym>, 
to kindle.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elder(n)">Elder,</form><xpln lang="en">a word frequently used 
in Lincolnshire; from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Elder,</etym>  an Vdder; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elder(n)">Elder,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;ld,</etym> old; 
whence <etym lang="oe">&AElig;ldor</etym>, the same: 
Hence <etym lang="oe">Ald</etym>, old age; and 
<etym lang="oe">Ealdorman</etym>, an Alderman; 
which see. It may also be de&shy;
rived from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Elter, 
Alter,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ouder,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>    
</page>  

<page sig="i1v">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eleven(n)">Eleven,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Elf,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eylff,</etym> AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Endlyfa</etym>, 
the same; and this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ene</etym>, one, and <etym lang="oe">Lyfan</etym>, to 
leave; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) one remaining, 
after the computation of ten.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elf(n)">Elf,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lf</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Alp;</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Alf, Alve,</etym> a Fairy, 
or Fiend, the Night-Mare; 
all perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ah&shy;
leapan</etym>, to leap upon; for 
such people as are troubled 
with the Night-mare, fansie 
that some witch, or hag invi&shy;
sible rides upon them. Min&shy;
shew  derives it from the Noun 
<etym lang="en">Half;</etym> because they are ima&shy;
gined to be of a small stature. 
Fr. Jun. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&lambda;&phi;&omega;</etym>, to change; be&shy;
cause they turn themselves in&shy;
to various shapes, and steal 
away pretty children out of 
their cradles, leaving in their 
stead deformed ones; which, 
for that reason, are called 
Changelings.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elixir(n)">Elixir:</form><xpln lang="en">Menagius draws it from 
the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Elixir,</etym> a breaking; 
this from the root <etym lang="ar">Chesre;</etym>  be&shy;
cause it breaketh, as it were, 
and cureth most diseases.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elk(n)">Elk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Elch</etym>, a crea&shy;
ture like an Ox: Or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Elsene,</etym> an awl; be&shy;
cause this beast hath horns as 
sharp as a Cobler's awl.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ell(n)">Ell,</form><xpln lang="en">by those of Lincolnshire 
Eln, from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">Eln</etym>, Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Aune, Aulne,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Alna;</etym> 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ulna,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elm(n)">Elm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Elm</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Olm,</etym>  Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Orme, Ormeau,</etym> 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Elme;</etym> and all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ulmus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="else(adv)">Else,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Elles,</etym> or 
contracted from the Lat. <etym lang="la">A&shy;
lias,</etym>  otherwise, but for that.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="elsin(n)">Elsin,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Awl.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embalm(v)">Embalm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
baumer,</etym> to preserve from cor&shy;
ruption. <term lang="la">v.</term> Balm.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embarrass(v)">Embarass,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
barasser,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Imbarazzare,</etym> 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Embaracar,</etym> to block 
up, to stop up a passage. It 
may also come of the Prep. 
<etym lang="en">Im,</etym> for In and <etym lang="en">Barr;</etym> <term lang="la">q. d.</term> 
to keep one within compass. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Barr.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embark(v)">Embark,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
barquer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Imbar&shy;
care,</etym> to go a-board a ship. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Bark.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ambassador(n)">Embassadour,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Ambassadeur,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Ambas&shy;
ciador,</etym>  Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Embaxadare,</etym> 
the same; and these from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ambyht</etym>, a message; 
and this from the inseparable 
Prep. <etym lang="oe">Amb,</etym> and <etym lang="oe">&AElig;htian</etym>, to 
esteem.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ember(n)">Ember,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ameren,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Emmer,</etym> a spark; 
and both from the old Goth. 
and Dan. <etym lang="go"></etym><etym lang="da">Eld,</etym> fire, and the 
AS. Verb  <etym lang="oe">Beran</etym>, to bring 
forth; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) that which the 
fire produceth.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ember-week(n)">Ember-weeks,</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives   
</page>  

<page sig="i2r"> 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Em&shy;
behren,</etym> to be abstemious; 
though I had rather derive it 
from <etym lang="en">Ember,</etym> for ashes; and 
<etym lang="en">Week;</etym> because the Ancients 
fasted  and humbled them&shy;
selves, in sack cloth and ashes, 
during that time. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emboss(v)">Embois,</form><xpln lang="en">To Emboss a Deer, a 
term in Hunting; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Embosquer,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Imboscare,</etym> to lodge in the 
wood; and these from their 
Nouns, <etym lang="fr"></etym><etym lang="it">Bois, Bosco,</etym> a wood, 
or forest. It is also derived 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ambasciare,</etym> to 
pant for breath.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embossed(a)">Emboss'd,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
bosse;</etym> this from <etym lang="fr">En,</etym> and 
<etym lang="fr">Bosse,</etym> a bump, or swelling; 
for the similitude.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embrace(v)">Embrace,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
brasser,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Abrazar,</etym> Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Imbracciare,</etym> to hug in ones 
arms.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embroil(v)">Embroil,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
brouiller,</etym>  or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Embrog&shy;
liare;</etym> which Menagius draw&shy;
eth from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brueil,</etym> a 
wood, which being cut down, 
blocks up the passage which 
lay through it. It may not 
incommodiously be taken 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brullen,</etym> to 
bawl, or brawl; in which 
sence it is also taken.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imburse(v)">Emburse, or Imburse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Embourser,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Imborsare,</etym> to put up in a 
Purse; which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emerald(n)">Emerald,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Es&shy;
meraude,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Esmeralda,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Smeraldo;</etym> all contract&shy;
ed from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Smaragdus,</etym> 
a precious stone so called, for 
its bright glistering colour.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emerods(n)">Emerods,</form><xpln lang="en">corrupted from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="la"></etym><etym lang="gr">H&&aelig;lig;morrhoides</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emmet(n)">An Emmet, or Emmot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;met;</etym> and this 
from <etym lang="oe">A</etym>, always, and <etym lang="oe">Mete</etym>, 
meat; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a creature, that 
by its natural industry, is ne&shy;
ver destitute of food. Min&shy;
shew  ingeniously draws it 
from the Pri<term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">A</etym>, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Musz,</etym> ease; because it 
is always busie.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impair(v)">Empair,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Empi&shy;
rer,</etym> to make worse; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Pire,</etym> worse.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emperor(n)">Emperour,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
pereur;</etym> from hence, An Em&shy;
peress; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Im&shy;
perium,</etym> an Empire.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="implead(n)">Emplead,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
plaider, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term> Plead, and 
P<emend err="">l</emend>ea.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="employ(v)">Employ,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
ployer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Impiegare,</etym> 
to set one his task.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="empoison(v)" lexeme="poison(v)">To Empoison, or Poison,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Empoisonner,</etym> <term lang="la">id.</term> 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Poison.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imprison(v)">Emprison,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
prisonner,</etym>  or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Impri&shy;
gionare,</etym> to cast one into Pri&shy;
son; which see.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emps-piece(n)">An Emps-Piece,</form><xpln lang="en">a word fre&shy;
quently used in Lincolnshire; 
from the AS.  <etym lang="oe">&AElig;mypce</etym>,   
</page>  

<page sig="i2v">   
egregious; this from <etym lang="oe">A</etym>, al&shy;
ways, and <etym lang="oe">Mypce</etym>, a note, 
or mark. </xpln>
<lemenote>
"emps-piece" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="empty(a)">Empty,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;mti, 
&AElig;mtig;</etym> these from the 
Verb <etym lang="oe">&AElig;mtian,</etym> to empty; 
or from the inseparable priva&shy;
tive Prep. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Mete</etym>, 
meat; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) without meat, 
hungry.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enamel(n)">Enamel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Es&shy;
mailler,</etym>  Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Esmalter,</etym> Ital.

<etym lang="bl"></etym><etym lang="tt">Enden,</etym> to terminate, or come

 <term lang="la">v.</term> Dammage.</xpln></wordentry>

<term lang="la">idem</term>; an herb so called, be&shy;
cause it groweth in high-way-&shy;
sides.</xpln></wordentry>

douairer,</etym> (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) to give one a

rer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Durare,</etym> to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enemy(n)">Enemy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Enne&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enfranchise(v)">Enfranchise,</form><xpln lang="en">to give one his

chise.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="engage(v)">Engage,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Enga&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="engender(v)">Engender,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
gendrer,</etym> to procreate.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="i3r">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="engine(n)">Engine,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Engin,</etym>  
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ingegno,</etym> ingenuity; 
so called, because of the cu&shy;
riousness of the workmanship 
thereof. From hence, the Fr. 
G <etym lang="fr">Enginier</etym>, and our Eng. 
Engineer, a maker of Engines.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entail(v)">Entail,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Law; from

Ital. <etym lang="it">Intagliare;</etym>  these from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En,</etym> in, and <etym lang="fr">Tail&shy;
ler,</etym> to cut; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to leave an 
estate to posterity, as sure, as 
if it were engraven in marble; 
and therefore to remain for 
ever. <term lang="la">v.</term> Fee-tail.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entangle(v)">Entangle, or  Intangle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Lat. Prep. <etym lang="la">In,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Tendicula,</etym> 
a snare, or net: Or it may be 
drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tangl</etym>, 
a twig; which being done o&shy;
ver with bird-lime, are laid to 
catch birds.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enter(v)">Enter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Entrer,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Entrare;</etym> and all 
of them from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Intra&shy;
re,</etym>  the same: From hence, 
An Entry, and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
tr&eacute;e</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<etym lang="fr">Enterchanger,</etym> the same. <term lang="la">v.</term>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="intermewer(v)">Entermewer,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Hawking; 
</page>  

<page sig="i3v">

mu&euml;ur,</etym> to change the feathers

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enterpen(v)">The Hawk Enterpenneth,</form><xpln lang="en">a term

between, and <etym lang="la">Penna,</etym> a fea&shy;
ther; (i. e) she tangleth her

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entertain(v)">Entertain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;

nere,</etym>  to defend, or receive; the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enthrall(v)">Enthral.</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Thrall.</xpln></wordentry>

Lat. <etym lang="la">Thronus,</etym> a throne; (i. e)

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entice(v)">Entice,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Attiser, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>,</etym> to make one, by fair 
words, commit things un&shy;
just: Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tih&shy;
tan</etym>, to over-perswade.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entire(a)">Entire,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Entier,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Intiero;</etym> and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Integer,</etym> whole, 
full and perfect.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entomb(v)">Entomb,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
tomber,</etym> to put into a Tomb; 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entrail(n)">Entrals,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
trailles,</etym>  or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Intraglie,</etym> 
the inwards.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entrap(v)">Entrap,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Entra&shy;
per,</etym> to catch, as it were, in a 
Trap; which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="environ(v)">Environ,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Envi&shy;
ronner,</etym> to surround; or to 
encompass.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enure(v)">Enure, or Inure,</form><xpln lang="en">to accustom 
ones self to a thing; from <etym lang="en">In,</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Vre;</etym>  which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="envy(n)">Envy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Envie;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Invi&shy;
dia,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equip(v)">To Equip,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
quipper,</etym> to put one in good 
equipage, or habit; by a Me&shy;
taphor taken from putting 
harness upon horses.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="equitable(a)">Equitable,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
quitable,</etym> just and lawful.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ere(adv)">Ere,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;re</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Eer,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eher,</etym> ere long, 
before that, in a short time.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ermine(n)">Ermin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Er&shy;
mine,</etym>  or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Armellino,</etym> 
a field-mouse. Jul. Scalig. 
supposeth it to be so called, 
from <etym lang="en">Armenia,</etym> from whence 
these skins are brought. Er&shy;
min, in Heraldry, is used for 
white, interspersed with black 
spots.</xpln></wordentry>
