<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="errand(n)">Errand,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;rend</etym>, 
a message: Or from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Erre,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Errare,</etym> 
to go up and down from 
place to place.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="errant(n)">Errant,</form><xpln lang="en">A Knight-Errant, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chivalier Errant,</etym> 
one that, Hercules-like, goeth 
about the world to discomfit 
Giants, Tyrants, Monsters, &amp;c. 
Taken ordinarily for one that   
</page>  

<page sig="i4r">  
will swear at random, as Tra&shy;
vellers may do, they not be&shy;
ing likely to be disproved. </xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="erst(adv)">Erst,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Erist,</etym> 
first of all. <term lang="la">v.</term> Ere.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escape(v)">Escape,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eschap&shy;
per,</etym>  Ital. <etym lang="it">Scappare, Scampa&shy;
re,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Escapar,</etym> to avoid 
any danger by cunning con&shy;
veying ones self away: Or 
from <etym lang="la">Ex,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Capi;</etym> (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) 
not to be apprehended: Or 
from <etym lang="la">Ex,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Campus</etym> (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) 
to flee out of the field: Or 
from <etym lang="la">Ex,</etym> and the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ca&shy;
po,</etym>  an head; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> to slip ones 
head out of the halter.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="escarbuncle(n)">Escarbuncle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Escarboncle, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</etym></xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eschew(v)">Eschew,</form><xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Es&shy;
chever,</etym>  Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schewen,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schouwen,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Schifare,</etym> to 
shun, or avo<term lang="la">id.</term></xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="espalier(n)">Espaliers, or Spaliers,</form><xpln lang="en">a term 
among Gardeners; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espallier,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Spalliere;</etym> these from the 
Nouns <etym lang="fr">Espaule,</etym> and <etym lang="it">Spalla,</etym> a 
stake. It signifies, to under&shy;
prop, as they do fruitful trees, 
with stakes, or pales of wood.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rspecial(a)">Especial,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espe&shy;
cial,</etym> individual, peculiar.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="espouse(v)">Espouse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espou&shy;
ser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sposare,</etym> to 
make sure, to betroth.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="espy(v)">Espy,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Spy.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="esquire(n)">Esquire,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escuir, Escuyr,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scudiero,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Escu,</etym> a shield; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a Shield-&shy;
bearer. <term lang="la">v.</term> Shield, and Bear.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="essay(n)">Essay,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Assay.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="establish(v)">Establish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stablir,</etym> or the Ital. and Lat. 
<etym lang="it">Stabilire,</etym> to confirm, or en&shy;
force.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="estate(n)">Estate,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estat,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stato,</etym> a state, or con&shy;
dition.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="estrange(v)">Estrange,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stranger,</etym>  to alienate; this 
from the Noun <etym lang="fr">Estrange,</etym> an 
alien. <term lang="la">v.</term> Strange.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="estra(n)">Estray,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Stray.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="even(adv)">Even,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;fen</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Effen,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Eben,</etym>  e&shy;
qual, alike; Belg. <etym lang="bl">Evenalo,</etym> 
even so.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="even(n)" lexeme="evening(n)">Even, or Evening,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&AElig;fen</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Avend,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Abend,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Afften,</etym> the same.
<etym lang="oe">Aefentio</etym>, the Evening-tide. 
From hence, Eve, or Eeve, a 
preparation, or night before a 
Fast.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ever(adv)">Ever,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;fre</etym>; 
this from <etym lang="oe">A</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Awa</etym>, for 
ever, Ay; which see.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="every(a)">Every,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;fre 
Eac, &AElig;fre Ene,</etym> all the 
whole number, every one.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="evil(n)">Evil,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Efel, yfel</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Evel,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vvel,</etym>  the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ewe(n)">Ewe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eowe,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Ouwe, Oye;</etym> and all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ovis,</etym> a sheep.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ewer(n)">Ewer,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aiguiere,</etym>  
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aqua,</etym> 
water; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a bason to put 
water in.</xpln></wordentry>   
</page>  

<page sig="i4v">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="exchange(v)">Exchange,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Eschanger,</etym> to barter. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Change.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="exchange(n)">Exchange,</form><xpln lang="en">The Exchange; so 
called, because Merchants, 
there meeting together, do 
make, give and receive Bills of 
<etym lang="en">Exchange</etym>, concerning money, 
or wares.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="exchequer(n)">Exchequer, Checker,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schatz,</etym> treasure; be&shy;
cause the King's taxes, or reve&shy;
nues were treasured up there&shy;
in. Some draw it from the 
Fr Norm. <etym lang="no">Eschequir,</etym> a place 
where money is coined, the 
Mint.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="excise(n)">Excise,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Acciise,</etym> 
tribute; so called, perhaps, 
because it is assessed according 
to the verdict of the <etym lang="fr">Assise,</etym> 
or a number of men deputed 
to that office by the King. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Size, and Assise.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="exploit(n)">Exploit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ex&shy;
ploit, Exploict,</etym> a noble at&shy;
chievement.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eye(n)">Ey,</form><xpln lang="en">An Ey of Pheasants, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Oy,</etym> plur. <etym lang="tt">Oyer;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> a brood, or covy of so 
many Pheasants as are hatched 
at one time.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eye(n)">Eye,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eag</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Ooghe,</etym> Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ougon,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Aug.</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oeil,</etym> the same; 
this last is contracted of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Oculus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; AS. <etym lang="oe">Eag 
&AElig;pl</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Aug Apffel,</etym> the 
apple of the eye; AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea&shy;
gan-Bregh</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oogh-&shy;
Brawe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Augen-Brawen,</etym> 
the eye brow: Teut. <etym lang="tt">Augen-&shy;
Lied,</etym>  Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ooghen-Lid,</etym> the 
eye-l<term lang="la">id.</term> Hence, To Eye; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) 
look upon.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eye-bite(v)">To Eye-bite,</form><xpln lang="en">an emphatical word, 
from <etym lang="en">Eye,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bite,</etym> (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) to 
bewitch whatsoever they look 
upon.</xpln></wordentry>  

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eyas(n)">Eyesse,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Falconry; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ey,</etym> an egg; 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> a young hawk just crept 
out of the shell. <term lang="la">v.</term> Nyas.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="F"><alpha>F.</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fake(n)">A FAck,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Naviga&shy;
tion; it is one circle of
a cable, twisted round; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faque,</etym> a bag, the
mouth of which being open&shy;
ed, it somewhat representeth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fade(v)">To Fade,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrd&shy;
den,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fade,</etym> impotent; also
flat, unsavoury; all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Vadere,</etym> to go; as we
say, He is going, or gone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fadge(v)">Fadge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gefegan</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fugen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voeghen,</etym>
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vogan,</etym> to agree, to
be adapted, made fit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fiddle-faddle(n)">Fadle, Fiddle Fadle,</form><xpln lang="en">trifles;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fade,</etym> or the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Fatuus,</etym> a fool; and
<etym lang="en">Fiddle;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to draw the
stick to and again hastily, and
to no tune: Or from <etym lang="en">Fiddle,</etym>
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Faden,</etym> thread;
(<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) a Fiddle-string; and
to this day, when we shew
</page>

<page sig="I5r"> 
our dis-like of any thing, we
say, A Fiddle-stick. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fag-end(n)">Fag-end,</form><xpln lang="en">a saying common to
Butchers, signifying the Hind-&shy;
joints; but by a Metaphor,
the Hind-end of any thing:
It is derived from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fe&shy;
gan, Gefegan,</etym> to couple
together in joints.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faggot(n)">Fagot,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fagot,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fagotto,</etym> a bundle
of sticks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fail(v)">Fail,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faillir,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Fallare,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fahl,</etym> a
default; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fal&shy;
lo,</etym> to disappoint, or frustrate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fain(adv)">Fain</form><xpln lang="en">, I would Fain, from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;gen,</etym> willingly, with
all ones heart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faint(v)">To Faint,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fa&shy;
ner, Fener,</etym> to fade as flowers
do with the heat of the Sun in
Summer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fair(a)">Fair,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;ger</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Fraey,</etym> the same; AS.
<etym lang="oe">F&aelig;gernesse</etym>, fairness;
<etym lang="oe">F&aelig;gere</etym>; as we say, Fair
and softly: Both Derivatives
of <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;ger</etym>, fair.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fair(n)">A Fair,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Feyer,</etym>
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Foire;</etym> and both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Feri&aelig;,</etym> holy-&shy;
days; because Fairs are gene&shy;
rally kept upon holy-days:
Or, which is most likely,
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Forum,</etym> a Mar&shy;
ket; a Fair being a Market
remarkable beyond others, for
buying and selling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fairy(n)">A Fairy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ferh&eth;</etym>,
a Spirit: Or from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">F&eacute;e Ph&eacute;e,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fata,</etym> a ter&shy;
restrial Elf. Minshew draws
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaerlick,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gevahrlich,</etym> terrible,
dangerous. I chuse rather to
draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Faran</etym>,
to go, or gad about; because
these evil Spirits are thought
to go all about, dancing in the
night, in companies together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faith(n)">Faith,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fede;</etym> and
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fides,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fall(v)">Fall,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feallan,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vallen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fallen,</etym>
the same: In the AS. there is
found <etym lang="oe">Fylle-seoc</etym>, turn-&shy;
sick, giddy-brain'd; as also
<etym lang="oe">Fylle-seocnysse</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fallenee-Sencht</etym>, the Falling-&shy;
sickness. It may be drawn from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Val,</etym> a fall; or the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Falle,</etym> a pit-fall; whence
comes <etym lang="tt">Aufallen</etym>, to fall on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fallow(a)">Fallow,</form><xpln lang="en">as Fallow-Deer, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Falewe, Fealewe,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaeluwe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Faal,</etym> or
<etym lang="tt">Fahl,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> of a palish
bay colour, like a brick half
burned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fallow(n)">Fallow,</form><xpln lang="en">land once plowed; from
the AS <etym lang="oe">Fealga, Fealh</etym>, an
harrow; because fitted, by
twice plowing, for the more
easie use thereof.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="falter(v)">Falter,</form><xpln lang="en">to commit mistakes in
speaking, also to stumble;
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Falteren,</etym> to
make balks in speech: Thence
<etym lang="bl">Falteringhe</etym>, an impediment
in ones speech. <term lang="la">v.</term> Fall, and
Fault.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="I5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="famble(v)">To Famble</form><xpln lang="en">in ones speech, from
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Famber;</etym> as <etym lang="da">Fam&shy;
ber min tale</etym>, I falter in my
tale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="famine(n)">Famine,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fa&shy;
mine,</etym> scarcity of provision
and forage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="famish(v)">To Famish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fa&shy;
mes,</etym> hunger; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to starve
one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fancy(n)">Fancy,</form><xpln lang="en">contracted from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Fantasie;</etym> and both from
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Phantasia,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fane(n)">Fane,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Vane.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fangle(n)">Fangles,</form><xpln lang="en">New Fangles, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fengan, Onfen&shy;
gan,</etym> to go about a matter,
to take a thing in hand. The
eminent Dr. Th. H. supposeth
it to be so called, q. New E&shy;
vangels, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) new Gospels.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fang(n)">Fangs,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fengan</etym>,
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Fahan,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fahen,
Fangen,</etym> to fasten upon, to
catch hold of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fan(n)">Fann,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fanne, Fan</etym>;
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vannus,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farcy(n)">Farcy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Farcina,</etym>
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Farcin,</etym> a dis&shy;
ease among horses, that filleth
the skin with swollen, running
ulcers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fardel(n)">Fardel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Far&shy;
deau,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fardello,</etym> a
packet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fare(v)">To Fare,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaeren,</etym>
to be well. Mer. Cas. draws
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&#x1F73;&rho;&epsilon;&sigma;theta;&alpha;&iota;</etym>,
to be in good liking. From
hence, Good Fare, plenteous
provision.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farm(n)">A Farm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ferme,</etym>
the same. Spelman draws it
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fearmian,
Feormian,</etym> to afford a live&shy;
lihood; whence <etym lang="oe">Feorm</etym>,
food. Some there are that de&shy;
rive it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feorh</etym>,
life; because by food we are
kept alive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="far(a)">Farr,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feor,
Feorran,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Varre,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ferr,</etym> Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Verro,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farrier(n)">A Farrier,</form><xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Ferrier,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ferraio;</etym>
these from the Nouns <etym lang="it">Fers</etym>
<etym lang="it">Ferri;</etym> and these from the
Verbs <etym lang="it">Ferrer</etym><etym lang="it">Ferrare,</etym> to
shooe horses; all from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ferrum,</etym> iron.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farrow(n)">Farrow, or Varrow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Faerh, Farr,</etym> a Boar-&shy;
pig; both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ver&shy;
ris,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Hence, To Farrow,
as a Sow that bringeth forth
young.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farsang(n)">Farsang,</form><xpln lang="en">a Persian word, yet of&shy;
ten found in English Histories
of Persian Affairs ; from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Parasanga,</etym> a measure
containing thirty furlongs in
length; almost the same with
our League; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farse out(v)">To Farse out,</form><xpln lang="en">a term among Ma&shy;
riners; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ferse,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to jag, or un&shy;
twist a rope, or cable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farset(n)">Farset,</form><xpln lang="en">a word found in a book
</page>

<page sig="I6r"> 
entituled <term lang="la">Janua Linguarum</term>,
signifying, a box, or cabinet;
perhaps from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Forzie&shy;
re, Forciere,</etym> a coffer, or <etym lang="en">For&shy;
cer;</etym> which see. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fart(n)">Fart,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fert,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vert,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Furtz,</etym> the same:
Whence come the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ver&shy;
ten</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Furtzen</etym>, to fart.
All fictitious words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fardel(v)">To Farthel</form><xpln lang="en">a Sail, from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Fardeau,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Fardel,</etym> of
the Verb <etym lang="fr">Fardeler,</etym> to fold
up, to wrap, or roll up in a
bundle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farther(a)">Farther,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Far.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farthing(n)">Farthing,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feor&shy;
&eth;ing;</etym> this from <etym lang="oe">Feor&eth;</etym>,
the fourth; or <etym lang="oe">Feower</etym>,
Four; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="farthingale(n)">Farthingal,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ver&shy;
dugalle,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Vertugala, Ver&shy;
tugado;</etym> which Dr. Th. H. in&shy;
geniously draws from <etym lang="fr">Vertu&shy;
garde;</etym> that is to say, the
guard of vertue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fashion(n)">Fashion,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Facon,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fattione,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Faz&shy;
zo,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fast(a)">Fast,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan.
<etym lang="oe">Fast</etym>, <etym lang="da">F&aelig;st,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vast,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fest,</etym> Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vaste,</etym>
firm, or sure; whence the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Festnian</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vesten, Va&shy;
sten</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="oe">Vestigen</etym>, to make
fast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fast(v)">To Fast,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;stan,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vasten,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fasten(v)">To Fasten</form><xpln lang="en">upon, from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Anfassen;</etym> both from our
word <etym lang="en">Fast;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to take fast
hold on.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fat(n)">A Fat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fatt,
Fatta,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vat,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fasz;</etym> all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vas,</etym>
a vessel for wine, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fat(a)">Fat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;t,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vet,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fett,</etym> the same:
Whence <etym lang="tt">Fetten</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vetten</etym>,
to make fat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="father(n)">Father,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;der</etym>,
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Fater,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Fader,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vader,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vatter,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pere,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Padre,</etym> the
same: Also AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;derleas,</etym>
fatherless; Dan. <etym lang="da">Stiffader,</etym> a
step-father; all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Pater,</etym> and this from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&tau;&#x1F74;&rho;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fathom(n)">Fathom, or Fadom,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;&eth;m,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vadem,</etym>
a measure of six feet, or so
much in length as the arms
stretched out can over-reach.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faucet(n)">Faucet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fausset,</etym>
or perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Val&shy;
licus,</etym> the Dim. of <etym lang="la">Vallus,</etym> a
pale, or stake; being forced
into the head of a vessel, like a
pale into the ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="falchion(n)">A Fauchion,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fauchon, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from
<etym lang="fr">Fauchet,</etym> a sickle; which
comes from <etym lang="fr">Faucher,</etym> to
reap.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="falcon(n)">Falcon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faucon,
Faulcon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Falcone;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Falco,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Hence cometh the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Falconnier</etym>; with us, A
Falconer.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="I6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fault(n)">Fault,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faulte,
Faute,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Falto,
Falta;</etym> and both from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Faillir,</etym> to Fail; which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fawn(n)">A Fawn,</form><xpln lang="en">or young Stag or Deer,
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faon, Fan,
Fam,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. A noted Ety&shy;
mologist draweth it from our
Participle <etym lang="en">Fallen,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Faln;</etym>
because lately fallen out of the
dam's belly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fawn(v)">To Fawn,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fandian</etym>,
to tempt, or entice: Or per&shy;
haps from our English <etym lang="en">Fain;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fealty(n)">Fealty,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Feaul&shy;
t&egrave;, Feaut&egrave;, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from
<etym lang="fr">Feal,</etym> faithful; and all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fides,</etym> faith; and <etym lang="la">Fi&shy;
delis,</etym> faithful, trusty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fear(n)">Fear,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;ran,
Af&aelig;ran,</etym> to affright; and
hence <etym lang="oe">Ferht</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Faer:</etym>
Hence also the AS. Afeared;
with us, Affeard; all perhaps
from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Peur,</etym> or the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Paura;</etym> which are both
manifestly derived from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pavor,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feasible(a)">Feasable,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fai&shy;
sable, Faisible;</etym> and these
from the Verb <etym lang="fr">Faire,</etym> <etym lang="la">Face&shy;
re, to do;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> easie to be
done.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fease(v)" lexeme="feague(v)">Fease, or Feag,</form><xpln lang="en">to beat; by
wresting the sence a little,
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fegen,</etym> to
brush; or <etym lang="tt">Ficken,</etym> to scratch
where it itcheth, as we say.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feather(n)">Feather,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;&eth;er</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veder,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Feder,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Fier,</etym> the same. There
is also in the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;&eth;er&shy;
leas,</etym> unfledg'd, or feather&shy;
less.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feature(n)">Feature,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fai&shy;
ture,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from the
Verb <etym lang="fr">Faire,</etym> to do.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fever(n)">Feaver,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. and Teut.
<etym lang="da">Feber,</etym><etym lang="tt">Fieber,</etym> or the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fievre;</etym> which are all derived
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Febris,</etym> the
same. Right spell'd Fever.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fee(n)">Fee,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fea, Feo</etym>,
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fio,</etym> a reward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feeble(a)">Feeble,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Foible,
Feble,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Feble,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fie&shy;
bole, Fievole;</etym> and all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Flebilis,</etym> to be la&shy;
mented; as we say, Lamen&shy;
table, and pitiful weak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feed(v)">Feed,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fedan</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voeden,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weyden,</etym>
Dan. <etym lang="da">Feder,</etym> the same; all
perhaps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pai&shy;
stre,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pascere,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feel(v)">Feel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Felan</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fielen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voelen,</etym>
to touch; also to feel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fegary(n)">Fegary,</form><xpln lang="en">Vagary,&agrave; <etym lang="la"> Vagando,</etym>
from roving, or roaming a&shy;
bout.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feign(v)">To Feign,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fein&shy;
dre;</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fingere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fist(n)">A Feist,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fist</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Feist,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veest;</etym>
and these from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Vesse, Vesser,</etym> a fart, to
fart.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="I7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fieldfare(n)">A Feldfare,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feal&shy;
for</etym>; and this from <etym lang="oe">Feal</etym>, a
field, and <etym lang="oe">Faran</etym>, far; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>
a bird that flieth a great way
before it alighteth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fell(v)">To Fell,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Velden,
Vellen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fallen,
Fellen,</etym> to cast to the ground:
Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feollan</etym>, to
fall. <term lang="la">v.</term> Fall.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fell(a)">Fell,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Felle</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Fel,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Felle,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fel&shy;
lone,</etym> fierce, cruel. <term lang="la">v.</term> Fel&shy;
lon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fell(n)">Fell,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Felle</etym>, or the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fell,</etym> a pelt, or skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="felon(n)">Fellon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fellon,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fellone;</etym> and all
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Felen</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fehlen,</etym> to offend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="felon(n)">Fellon,</form><xpln lang="en">a disease so called; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Felle,</etym> fierce, fell; for
the grievous pain it causeth in
the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fellow(n)">Fellow,</form><xpln lang="en">a companion; from
our word <etym lang="en">Follow;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fellow(n)">The Fellow of a wheel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Teut <etym lang="tt">Felge,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fellmonger(n)">Felmonger,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Felle,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fell,</etym> a skin, and the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Mangere;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a Skin-&shy;
Merchant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="felt(n)">Felt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Felt,</etym> the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Feutre,</etym> or the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Feltro,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="female(a)">Female,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Femelle,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fen(n)">Fen,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fen,</etym> or the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ven,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fence(v)">To Fence,</form><xpln lang="en">&agrave; <etym lang="la">Defendendo</etym>, from
defending.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fence(n)">A Fence,</form><xpln lang="en">mound, or hedge, for&shy;
med as the other <etym lang="en">Fence.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fender(n)" lexeme="fender-bolt(n)">Fenders, or Fender-bolts,</form><xpln lang="en">from
<etym lang="la">Defendo,</etym> to keep off; a term
in Sailing; for which, consult
Manwayring, in his Dict.
Naut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fennel(n)">Fennel;</form><xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, Fin&shy;
kel; by &AElig;lfricus, Fynel; in
Somnerus, Fenol; from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fenchel,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fenouil,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Finocchio;</etym> and all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">F&oelig;niculum,</etym> an herb
so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feoff(v)">To Feoff,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fief,</etym>
or the Verb <etym lang="fr">Fieffer,</etym> to en&shy;
feoff.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ferkin(n)">Ferkin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feower,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vier,</etym> four, and the
Dim. <etym lang="en">kin;</etym> it being the fourth
part of a barrel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fern(n)">Fern,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fearn</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaeren-kruyd,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Faren-kraut;</etym> and these from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Faran,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fah&shy;
ren,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaeren,</etym> to spread
out broad.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ferret(n)">Ferret,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ferret,
Feret,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Furet,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fe&shy;
retta,</etym> an animal so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ferry(n)">Ferry,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fahr,</etym> <term lang="la">id.</term>
and this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Faran,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fahren,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaeren,</etym>
to pass over.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fescue(n)">A Fescue,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaes&shy;
keu,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Festu;</etym> and
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Festuca,</etym>
a slender sprig, saith Fr.
Jun.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fesse(n)">Fess,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fesse;</etym> which Min&shy;
shew
</page>

<page sig="I7v"> 
draws from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fas&shy;
cia,</etym> a swathe. </xpln>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fester(v)">Fester,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Appe&shy;
stare,</etym> to infect: Or, which
is more probable, from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Festrir,</etym> to decay, to
putrefie.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="festoon(n)">Festoons,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fe&shy;
ston,</etym> a garland of flowers; so
called, because it was used on
Festival-days.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fetch(v)">Fetch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feccan,
F&aelig;ccean</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vatten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
all perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ve&shy;
ctare,</etym> to bring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fetch(n)" lexeme="vetch(n)">Fetch, or Vetch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Vesse,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vezza,</etym> or
<etym lang="it">Veccia;</etym> and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Vicia,</etym> the same; which Var&shy;
ro draws from <etym lang="la">Vincio,</etym> to
bind; because, like a vine, it
twisteth about that which is
next it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fetlock(n)">The Fetlock</form><xpln lang="en">joint; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the
joint between the leg and foot
of an horse; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Feetlock,</etym>
or Feet-locks; or rather, q.
Fetter-locks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fetter(n)">Fetter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fettere</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veter;</etym> and these from
their Verbs <etym lang="oe">Gefeterian,</etym>
<etym lang="bl">Vateren;</etym> properly, to put
chains upon the feet only.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="feud(n)">Feud,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">F&aelig;h&eth;</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veede, Veide,</etym> invete&shy;
rate grudge, or hatred: Or
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fehd, Fehde,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="few(a)">Few,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fea, Feawa,</etym>
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fuel(n)">Fewel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Feu,</etym> a
fire, and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Alere,</etym> to
feed; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> matter to feed the
fire. <etym lang="fr">Feu</etym> is derived from the
Ital <etym lang="it">Fuoco,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Fuego;</etym> and
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Focus,</etym> a
fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fibby(n)">Fibby,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Fable;</etym> and both
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fabula,</etym> a ro&shy;
mance.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"fibby" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fickle(a)">Fickle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ficol,</etym> in&shy;
constant; and this from <etym lang="oe">Fa&shy;
cen</etym>, to deceive: Or from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Facilis,</etym> easie; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> one
that is easily perswaded to
change his mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fiddle(n)">Fiddle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fi&eth;ele,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vedel,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fidel,</etym> the
same: Whence the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fi&shy;
delen</etym>, to play upon the Vio&shy;
lin; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fidicu&shy;
la,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="field(n)">Field,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Feld,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veld,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fiend(n)">Fiend,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fiende</etym>,
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Dfiant,</etym> the Devil;
these from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feond,
Fynd,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Fiend,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Feind,</etym> Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Fiian, Fian,</etym>
an adversary. Fr. Jun. de&shy;
rives all these from the AS.
and Goth. <etym lang="go"> Figan,</etym> to hate.
It may also be taken from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fandian</etym>, to tempt:
Whence the Devil is called, the
Tempter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fierce(a)">Fierce,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fier,
Farouche,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiero;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ferox,</etym>
cruel.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="I8r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fife(n)">A Fife,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fifre,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pifara,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: It
is so called, from its whizzing
sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fig(n)">A Fig,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Feige,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Figo, Fico,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Figue;</etym>
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ficus,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fig(v)">To Fig,</form><xpln lang="en">Feage, or Firk, from
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ficken,</etym>
to whip one hard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang=en" lexeme="fight(n)">Fight,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fyht,
Feoht</etym>, the same; and this
from the Verb <etym lang="oe">Fehtan,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vichtan,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fetchten,</etym> Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Fehtan,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Feyder, Fi&shy;
cter,</etym> to fight.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filander(n)">The Filanders, or Felanders in
an hawk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fi&shy;
landres,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Filandre,</etym>
worms breeding in hawks that
are too fat, say Florius and
Cotgra<term lang="la">v.</term></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filbert(n)">Filberd,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Eng. <etym lang="en">Full,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Beard;</etym> the skin thereof
being covered with a down, like to the first appearance of
the beard upon the chin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="file(n)">File,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feol</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Viile,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Feile,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Fiil,</etym>
the same: Whence the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Feolan</etym>. Belg. <etym lang="bl">Villen</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Feilen</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Fiiler</etym>, to file
off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="file(n)">A File,</form><xpln lang="en">to wit, of Pearl; from
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Filza;</etym> and both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Filum,</etym> thread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="file(n)">Files</form><xpln lang="en">of Soldiers, from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Files,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fila;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a Company of Soldiers,
drawn up ten in a file, like a
line, or thread; by a Meta&shy;
phor taken from weaving:
From hence, An Apothecary's
File.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fill(v)">To Fill,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Full.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fill-horse(n)">The Fill horse,</form><xpln lang="en">from our Eng.
<etym lang="en">File</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> the last of a team
of horses drawing a cart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fillet(n)">Fillet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fi&shy;
let;</etym> and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fi&shy;
lum,</etym> thread; fillets being
made of thread.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fillet of veal(n)">A Fillet of Veal,</form><xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Un Fi&shy;
let de veau;</etym> so called, be&shy;
cause in that part are strong
muscles and nerves, not un&shy;
like to so many threads, to
guide the feet in their regular
motion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fillip(n)">Fillip,</form><xpln lang="en">a feigned word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filly(n)">Filly,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fulle,
Fullen,</etym> a young mare. <term lang="la">v.</term>
Foal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="film(n)">Film,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Film;</etym> both
corrupted from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vela&shy;
men,</etym> a cover: It is a thin skin
over the eyes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filtch(n)">Filtch,</form><xpln lang="en">not unlikely from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Filizig,</etym> a niggard; or
<etym lang="tt">Filtzerey,</etym> avarice. It may also
be drawn from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pil&shy;
lar,</etym> to rob.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filth(n)">Filth,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fil&eth;</etym>, or
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Fulitha;</etym> and these
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ful,</etym> Foul;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="finch(n)">Finch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Finc</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Finck,</etym> the same. <etym lang="tt">Gold Finck</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Goud-Vinck,</etym> a Gold&shy;
finch; <etym lang="bl">Bloed vincke,</etym> a Bull&shy;
finch; all perhaps from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fengan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fingen,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="I8v"> 
to take; because these birds
are a prey to other ravenous
birds. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="find(v)">Find,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Findan</etym>,
Fr. Th. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Venden;</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Finden,</etym> the same.
From hence, A Foundling, a
child left in any place to be
brought up by the Parish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fine(a)">Fine,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fein,</etym> Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Fin,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fino,</etym> pure, sub&shy;
tile. Martinius derives them
all from the old Lat. <etym lang="la">Vinulus</etym>
comely, pleasant, gallant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="finger(n)">Finger,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. Dan. and
Teut. <etym lang="oe">Finger,</etym>  <etym lang="tt">Finger,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vinger,</etym> the same; all per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fangen,</etym>
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fengan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vanghen,</etym>
to take hold of a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="finn(n)">Finn,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fin, Finna;</etym>
and both perhaps from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pinna,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fire(n)">Fire,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fir,</etym> or
<etym lang="oe">Fyr</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vier, Vuyr,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fewer,</etym> the same: AS.
<etym lang="oe">Firscofl</etym>, a fire-shovel;
<etym lang="oe">Fyrstan</etym>, a flint-stone;
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vier-brand,</etym> a fire brand.
From hence, A Fire-fang,
Malt that hath a smatch of the
fire; from <etym lang="en">Fire,</etym> and the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Fengan</etym>, to take hold of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="firk(v)">To Firk,</form><xpln lang="en">v Fig.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="firmed(a)">Firmed,</form><xpln lang="en">Full Firmed, a term in
Falconry; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) well-fledg&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fir(n)">Firr,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Furh,</etym> Dan.
<etym lang="da">Fyr,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vueren,</etym> the same;
all perhaps from the word
<etym lang="en">Fire;</etym> because this sort of
wood quickly taketh fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="'first(a)">First,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">First,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vearst,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Verst</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Erst,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Forste,</etym> q. Forest;
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fore,</etym> Before;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fish(n)">Fish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fisc</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Visch,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fisch,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Fisk,</etym>
the same; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fircian</etym>, to go a fishing; all
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Piscis,</etym>
a fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fist(n)">Fist,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fyst</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vuyst,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Faust.</etym> I may
also, with Minshew, draw it
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Fassen,</etym> to fa&shy;
sten upon, to catch hold of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fit(a)">Fit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fait,</etym> a&shy;
dapted to any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fitchew(n)">A Fitcher, or Fitchew,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fissan,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Fisse,</etym> a
ram, strong scented Ferret.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fitter(n)">Fitters,</form><xpln lang="en">To cut into Fitters,
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fetta;</etym> this
from <etym lang="it">Fendre,</etym> to cut small, as
into morsels.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fit(n)">Fitts</form><xpln lang="en">quasi <etym lang="en">Fights;</etym> they being
conflicts between the disease
and nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="five(n)">Five,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fif</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Viive,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Funff,</etym> the same;
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fift, Fif&shy;
tig</etym>, the fifth, fifty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fizzle(v)">To Fizzle,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> To <etym lang="en">Feille;</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term>
Feist, or Foist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flabby(a)">Flabby,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiappo,
Fiacco,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flache,
Flaque,</etym> flat: Or more imme&shy;
diately from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Labilis,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="K1r">
slippery; for all wet things
are slippery. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flag(n)">A Flag,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlaghe,</etym>
a banner; this from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Fleogan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Flag&shy;
geren,</etym> to flap; from its flut&shy;
tering in the wind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flag(v)">To Flag,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Flagge&shy;
ren,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiaccare,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Flackeren,</etym> to flair, flap, or
waver as a sail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flageolet(n)">Flageolet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fla&shy;
geolet</etym>, <term lang="la">id.</term> and this from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Flabellum,</etym> a fan; it be&shy;
ing one sort of wind-musick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flagon(n)">Flagon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flaxa</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Flesche,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flasche,</etym>
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flascon,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiascone,</etym>
the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> Flask.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flair(n)">Flair,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> To Flag.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flail(n)">Flail,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vleghel,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flegel,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fleau;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Flagel&shy;
lum,</etym> any kind of lash, or
whip.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flake(n)">A Flake of Snow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Fiocco,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Floccus,</etym> a
lock of wool; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Lock
of snow, as soft as wool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flam(n)" lexeme="flim-flam(n)">Flam, Flim-Flam,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flyma</etym>, and this
from <etym lang="oe">Flean</etym>, to flee; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a
false story that is quickly dispersed over a Town or Coun&shy;
try.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flank(n)">Flank,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flanc,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fianco,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flanker(v)">To Flancker,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Flanquer,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Flanc&shy;
keren;</etym> and all from the word
<etym lang="en">Flank;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to fortifie the
walls of a City with bulwarks
or counter-mures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flannel(n)">Flannel,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Lanella,</etym> soft wool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flap(v)">To Flap,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Flabel&shy;
lum,</etym> a fan; or <etym lang="la">Labi,</etym> to slip
up and down, like the brim
of an old hat. Dr. Th. H.
draws it from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiap&shy;
pare,</etym> for the like reason.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flap(n)">Flap of the ear,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Ear-laepwe</etym>, or from the
Verb To <etym lang="en">Flap;</etym> because it is
softer, and more easily moved
than the rest of the ear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flap(n)" lexeme="fly-flap(n)">A Flap, Fly-Flap,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Flabbe,</etym> a fillip with the fin&shy;
ger; both fictitious words.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flare(v)">Flare</form><xpln lang="en">in ones eyes, perhaps from
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Flederen,</etym> to stare
one in the face.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flash(n)">Flash:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it from
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&#x1F78;&xi;</etym>, a flame. It
may also be taken from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Blitz,</etym> a glancing; or
from the Verb To <etym lang="en">Blaze;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flashy(a)">Flashy,</form><xpln lang="en">not unlikely, from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Flaccidus,</etym> having lost
the savour; as also weak,
hanging down the head like a
bull-rush.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flask(n)">Flask,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flaxa</etym>, Ital.
<etym lang="it">Fiascone,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Flasco,</etym> a Fla&shy;
gon; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flasket(n)">Flasket,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plesser,</etym>
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flechten,</etym> to
bend; so called, from the
make of it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flat(a)">Flat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plat,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Flach,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Platt,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Piatto,</etym>
even, plain.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="K1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flatter(v)">Flatter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flatter,</etym>
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlaeden,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
and both perhaps from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Lactare,</etym> to allure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flaw(n)">Flaw,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Floh</etym>, a frag&shy;
ment: Or from <etym lang="oe">Fleah</etym>, the
white of the eye; for a speck
in jewels is like to a white
speck in the eye.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flawn(n)">Flawn,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flan,</etym>
meat made of eggs and milk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flax(n)">Flax,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fleax</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vlas,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flachs,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flea(n)">Flea,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flea</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vloo,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Floh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or
perhaps from the Verb To <etym lang="en">Fly;</etym>
because she leapeth so quick&shy;
ly, that she may be thought to fly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flay(v)">To Flea, or Flay,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Flean</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlaen,</etym> or
<etym lang="bl">Vlaegen,</etym> to take off the skin
of any creature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phlegm(n)">Fleam,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. and Gr.
<etym lang="gk">Phlegma,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fleam(n)">A Fleam, or Phleam,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlieme,</etym> or the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Flammette;</etym> and all from the
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Phlebotomum,</etym>
an instrument to let blood
withal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flecked(a)">Flecked,</form><xpln lang="en">a word frequently used
in Lincolnshire, from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fleck,</etym> a spot; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>
speckled, or spotted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fledge(v)">Fledge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlegghe&shy;
ren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flucken,</etym> to begin
to have feathers; all from our
word <etym lang="en">Fly;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fleece(n)">Fleece,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flyse</etym>,
or <etym lang="oe">Fleos</etym>, or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vlies;</etym> which comes from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Vellus,</etym> signifying the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fleer(n)">Fleer,</form><xpln lang="en">to mock; from <etym lang="en">Leer;</etym>
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fleet(n)">Fleet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flota</etym>, the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flotte,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Flot&shy;
ta,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fleet(v)">To Fleet, or Flit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fliessen,</etym> the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Fliezen,</etym>
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlieten,</etym> to run
out as vessels do, to shed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fleet(v)">To Fleet</form><xpln lang="en">milk, <term lang="la">v.</term> Flotten-milk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flesh(n)">Flesh,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flesc</etym>, the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vleesch,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fleisch,</etym> the same: Or, not un&shy;
likely, from our word <etym lang="en">Flay.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fletcher(n)">A Fletcher,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fleche,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Flecha,</etym> or
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Freccia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>
a maker of arrows; all from
the word <etym lang="en">Fledge.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fleurett&eacute;e(a)" lexeme="flurte(n)">Fleuretty, or Flurte,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in
Heraldry; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fleurett&egrave;,</etym> a little flower;
this from <etym lang="fr">Fleur,</etym> a Flower;
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flicker(v)" lexeme="flutter(v)">To Flycker, or Flutter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fliccerian,</etym> or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Fliggeren,</etym> to wag the wings;
<term lang="la">v.</term> Fly, and Fledge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flinch(v)">Flinch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Verb To <etym lang="en">Fling;</etym>
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fliccerian</etym>,
to justle, to flutter as birds ta&shy;
ken in a net.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fling(v)">Fling,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fligere;</etym> a
word found in Lucretius, sig&shy;
nifying, to fling, by a Trope
taken from the Play at Hand&shy;
ball; for when the ball is hit,
it is as it were thrown up into
</page>

<page sig="K2r"> 
the air. It is very probable,
as one very well conjectures,
that it is contracted from <etym lang="en">Fly&shy;
ing;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> To set a thing Fly&shy;
ing. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flint(n)">Flint,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flint</etym>, or
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Flinte,</etym> and <etym lang="da">Flinte-&shy;
steen,</etym> a flint-stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flit(v)">To Flit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Flytter;</etym>
or from our word <etym lang="en">Fly.</etym> It is a
word used in Lincolnshire,
signifying, to remove from
place to place, without any
constant residence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flitch(n)">Flitch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Flicce</etym>, the
Dan. <etym lang="da">Flycke,</etym> or the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fliche;</etym> as <etym lang="fr">Fliche de Larde</etym>,
a flitch of bacon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flittermouse(n)">Flittermouse,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Fluttermouse,
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a flying mouse. <term lang="la">v.</term>
<etym lang="en">Flutter,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Mouse.</etym> It is that
which we call a Batt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="float(v)">To Float,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flot&shy;
ter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Flottare;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fluctua&shy;
re,</etym> to swim to and again upon
the water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flock(n)">Flock,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flocc</etym>, or
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Floccus;</etym> spoken pro&shy;
perly of such cattel as bear
fleeces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flock-bed(n)">Flock-bed,</form><xpln lang="en">Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlock-bed;</etym> this
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Floc, Floquet,</etym>
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Floccus,</etym> a lock of
wool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="floor(n)">Floor,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flor</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vloer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="floren(n)">A Floren,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Flo&shy;
rin,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiorino;</etym> a
French Coin so called, because
it was first coined in Florence,
having stamped upon it the fi&shy;
gure of a flower.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Florence(pn)">Florences,</form><xpln lang="en">a cloth brought to us
from <etym lang="it">Florence,</etym> a City of He&shy;
truria, taking its name there&shy;
from; as Arras, Cambrick,
&amp;c. take their names from
the Towns wherein they are
made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="float(v)">Flote,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlote,</etym> the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flotz,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlot&shy;
ten;</etym> and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fluitare,</etym> to fluctuate above
water, as a boat in harbour,
or wreck upon the main.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flotten milk(n)">Flotten-milk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vlieten,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Vloten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> to take away the cream
from the milk. <term lang="la">v.</term> To Fleet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flood(n)">Floud,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flod</etym>, the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flut, Fluth,</etym> or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vloed, Vlotte,</etym> a deluge;
whence <etym lang="bl">Vlotten</etym>, to over-flow;
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fluere,</etym> to
Flow; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flounder(n)">A Flounder,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Flyn&shy;
der,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both not unlikely
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fundulus;</etym> be&shy;
cause it mostly abideth in the
bottom of rivers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flounce(v)">Flounse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the <emend err="b">B</emend>elg. <etym lang="bl">Plons&shy;
sen;</etym> or from the noise that
any thing maketh when it is
cast into the water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flourish(v)">Flourish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fleu&shy;
rir;</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Florere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="float(v)">Float,</form><xpln lang="en">to mock, or jeer. Mer.
Cas. derives it from the Gr.
<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&alpha;&upsilon;&lambda;&#x1F77;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to contemn, or have
in scorn.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="K2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flow(v)">Flow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fleowan</etym>,
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vl elen,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fliessen;</etym> and all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fluere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flower(n)">Flower,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fleur,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiore;</etym> all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Flos,</etym> the same. Hence
Flower-de-Luce, from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Fleur de Lis</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flowery(a)">Flowry or Flory,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in He&shy;
raldry. <term lang="la">v.</term> Flower.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluret(n)">Fluret, or Flurt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Fleere,</etym> a light box on the
ear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flurt(n)">A Flurt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Flore,</etym> a
fool, a scurrilous person:
Which may possibly be deri&shy;
ved from <etym lang="bl">Flauw,</etym> weak; fools
being ordinarily called Weak-&shy;
men, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) with respect to
understanding. It does also
nearly allude to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&alpha;&#x1FE6;&rho;&shy;
&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, vile, base; or <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&upsilon;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>,
trifles; in which fools do u&shy;
sually busie themselves.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flurt(v)">To Flurt,</form><xpln lang="en">or make a noise with
the mouth; a fictitious word.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flush(n)">A Flush</form><xpln lang="en">at Cards, from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Flux,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Flusso</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) three, or more
cards in hand, all of a suit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flush(v)" lexeme="flushing(n)">To Flush, Flushing,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flughs,</etym> or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vlughs,</etym> presently, instantly;
Flushing being a suddain cir&shy;
culation of the blood: Or ra&shy;
ther, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fliessen,</etym>
to flow; because the blood,
upon any fright, or the like,
instantly flieth up into the
face.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flush(n)">Flush of money,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fluo,</etym> to flow; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> one that
hath plenty of money.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flustered(a)">Flustred,</form><xpln lang="en">half drunk; possibly
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to be
hot, to boil up: Or, which is
most likely, from <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, to
belch; whence &Omicron;&#x1F30;&nu;&#x1F79;&phi;&lambda;&omicron;&xi;,
drunken, is plainly derived.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flute(n)">Flute,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Fluye:</etym> Or
more immediately from the
Fr. G. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fleute,</etym> the
Hisp <etym lang="sp">Flauta,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Flau&shy;
to, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fluting(n)">Flutings,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture; the furrows, or gut&shy;
ters of pillars; so called, be&shy;
cause they are hollowed out
with a graving-tool, or rasp,
as those pipes are which are
called flutes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="flutter(v)">Flutter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flote&shy;
ran</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vledderen,</etym> or
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Flottern, Flittern;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Volitare,</etym>
a frequentative of <etym lang="la">Volo,</etym> to
fly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fly(v)">To Fly,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flean,
Fleogan,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fliehen,
Fliegen</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vlieden,
Vliegen,</etym> the same: Whence
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flyht</etym>, Fr. Th.
<etym lang="hd">Flught</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Fluct</etym> a flight:
As also the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flege</etym>, Dan.
<etym lang="oe">Flut</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vliege</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fliege</etym>, a fly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fob-pocket(n)">A Fob-pocket,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fuppe,</etym> a little purse.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"fob-pocket" antedates earliest OED citation (1837).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fob(v)">To fob</form><xpln lang="en">a man off, from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fobben,</etym> to give one the
trouble of coming often to
him, and to no purpose: Or
</page>

<page sig="K3r"> 
from <etym lang="tt">Fobis,</etym> or <etym lang="un">Pofisz,</etym> a no&shy;
vice; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to make a fool of
one: or from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fiab&shy;
bare,</etym> to put one off with fair
words. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fodder(n)">Fodder</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fodre,
Fo&eth;er,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voeder,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Futter,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fourrage,</etym> Ital.
<etym lang="it">Foraggio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. <term lang="la">v.</term> Feed, and
Food.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fodder(n)" lexeme="fother(n)">A Fodder, or Fother,</form><xpln lang="en">suppose of
lead, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fuder,</etym> a
burthen; this from <etym lang="tt">Fuhren,</etym>
to carry; all perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vehere;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> as
much as can be carried in one
cart.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foe(n)">Foe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Fah</etym>, an adver&shy;
sary. <term lang="la">v.</term> Fiend.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fog(n)">Fog,</form><xpln lang="en">mist. Minshew derives it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Focus,</etym> fire; be&shy;
cause it is thick, and looketh
like smoak. I chuse rather to
derive it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fog</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Foeghe,</etym> a gathering to&shy;
gether, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of vapours. <term lang="la">v.</term>
Fadge.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fog(n)">Fog,</form><xpln lang="en">is also taken for grass that
groweth after Autumn; which
may come perhaps from the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Affogare,</etym> to choak; be&shy;
cause it is, as it were, choaked
with the cold of approaching
winter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="faugh(ex)">Foh</form><xpln lang="en">an Interjection of Disdain&shy;
ing; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Foiy,</etym> or
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fi;</etym> and all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vah,</etym> away.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foil(v)">To Foil,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Affo&shy;
ler,</etym> to
wound; or <etym lang="fr">Fouler,</etym> to keep under, to oppress; which
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fullo,</etym> a
Fuller.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foin(n)" lexeme="foin(v)">A Foin, To Foin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Poindre,</etym> to prick; or the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fandian</etym>, to try; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
to try to run one into the
guts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foin(n)">Foines,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Foine,
Fouine,</etym> or the Hisp <etym lang="sp">Fuina,</etym> a
kind of Northern Ferret,
whose skin is much esteemed
for lining of Winter-gar&shy;
ments.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foist(n)">A Foist,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Fr.
G<emend err=" ">.</emend> <etym lang="fr">Fuste,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fusta,</etym> a
kind of boat: Or it may pos&shy;
sibly be derived from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Fast</etym>, in Eng. <etym lang="en">Fast;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>
strong built.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foist(v)">To Foist,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faus&shy;
ser,</etym> to adulterate; or <etym lang="fr">Faux,</etym>
false; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to thrust a thing
upon one by cologuing or
flattery.</xpln></wordentry>
