<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fold(n)">Fold,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fald,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; a sheep-fold, &amp;c. <term lang="la">v.</term>
To Fold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fold(v)">To Fold,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feoldan,</etym>
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vouden,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Falten,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Infaldare,</etym> the same:
From whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fealde</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voude</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Falte</etym>, Ital.
<etym lang="it">Falda</etym>, a fold, or pleat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foal(n)">Fole,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fola</etym>, Dan.
<etym lang="da">Fol,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Volen,</etym> Teut <etym lang="tt">Fu&shy;
len,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Pullus,</etym> a colt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="folk(n)">Folk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Folc</etym>, the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Volck,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vol&shy;
go;</etym> and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vul&shy;
gus,</etym> the common people.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="K3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="follow(v)">Follow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Folgian,</etym>
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Volgen,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Folgen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. There is also
found in the Dan. <etym lang="da">Folger efter</etym>,
to follow after.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foam(n)">Fome:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vomo,</etym> to vomit; it
in some sort representing it,
both as to colour, and man&shy;
ner of ejection: Though I
had rather draw it from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Faem</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Faum,</etym> froth;
and these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fu&shy;
mus,</etym> smoak; because being
risen above the water, it quick&shy;
ly vanishes like smoak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fond(a)">Fond,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veynt,</etym> foo&shy;
lish: Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vanus,</etym>
vain; one that affecteth vani&shy;
ties: Or, possibly, it is a cor&shy;
ruption of our word <etym lang="en">Fain'd;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) made fain, or glad.
You may likewise, if you
please, draw it from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Fundian</etym>, to gape like a
changeling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="font(n)">A Font,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. and Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fons,</etym> a spring; that being the
place of initiation into Christ,
the Fountain of Salvation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="food(n)">Food,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Foda</etym>, or
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Fode,</etym> sustenance. <term lang="la">v.</term>
Feed, Fodder, and Forrage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fool(n)">Fool,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fol,</etym> or
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Folle,</etym> the same:
From whence the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Fo&shy;
lie</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Follia</etym>, folly.
Menagius draws it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Follis,</etym> a pair of bellows;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> a fellow full of nothing
but wind. Dr. Skinner, upon
supposition, derives it from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Faul,</etym> a sluggard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foot(n)">Foot,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fot</etym>, Dan.
<etym lang="da">Fode,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voet,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fusz,</etym>
the same: Whence the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Voet-stap</etym>, and Teut. <etym lang="bl">Fusz&shy;
tapff</etym>, a foot-step. <term lang="la">v.</term> Step.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fop(n)" lexeme="foppish(a)">A Fop, or Foppish;</form><xpln lang="en">I suppose,
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fobis,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Po&shy;
fisz,</etym> spongy, vain, empty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="for(pp)">For,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">For</etym>, the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fur,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pour</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="for(px)">For,</form><xpln lang="en">in Composition, denieth,
and depriveth; as in Forbid,
Forget, &amp;c. and is derived
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">For&agrave;s,</etym>
without.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forbear(v)">Forbear,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Forb&aelig;&shy;
ran</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from <etym lang="en">For,</etym>
and <etym lang="en">Bear;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="'forbid(v)">Forbid,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Forbeo&shy;
dan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Verbieden,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Verbleten,</etym> Dan <etym lang="da">Forbluder,</etym>
the same; and all from the
Negative <etym lang="oe">For,</etym> and the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Beodan</etym>, to bid</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="force(n)">Force</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Force,</etym> or
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Forza;</etym> whence their
Verbs <etym lang="fr">Forcer</etym>, and <etym lang="fr">Forzare</etym>, to
urge, or compel</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ford(n)">Ford,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ford</etym>, or
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fuhrt,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
whence comes the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fa&shy;
ran</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fahren</etym>, to
ferry over.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fore(adv)">Fore,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forebode(v)">Forebode,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fore</etym>,
before, and <etym lang="oe">Bodian</etym>, to de&shy;
clare; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to fore-tell. <term lang="la">v.</term>
Bode.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="K4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forefather(n)">Fore-fathers,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS.
<etym lang="oe">For&eth;-faederas,</etym> or the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veur-vaeders.</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term> Fore,
Affore, and Fathers.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forfend(v)">Fore-fend,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Fore</etym> for <etym lang="en">Before,</etym>
and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Defendre;</etym> as
we say, God Fort-fend it;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) God forbid, or avert
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fore-land(n)">Fore-land,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fore</etym>,
before, and <etym lang="en">Land;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> land
next to the sea-shore; or pos&shy;
sibly, extending it self in a
corner, further into the sea
than the rest, the sea coming
in beyond it on each side.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foresee(v)">Fore-see,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">For&shy;
seon</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veursien,</etym> or
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fursehen,</etym> the same;
whence the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vorsicht</etym>, a
fore sight of things to come.
<term lang="la">v.</term> Before, and See.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forestall(v)">Fore-stall,</form><xpln lang="en">from our word <etym lang="en">Fore,</etym>
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stallen,</etym> or the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estaller,</etym> to expose to
sale; <term lang="la">v.</term> Stall: Or from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vorstellen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. It is
a saying taken from those that
bring forth their Goods to sell
before others. A Fore-staller,
in our Law, is he that buyeth
corn before-hand, in the way,
that it may not be brought in&shy;
to the market: And this Spel&shy;
man ingeniously derives from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fore</etym>, before, and
<etym lang="oe">Stal</etym>, a stall; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) they
buy it up before it is brought
to the market, and thereby
monopolizing the whole into
their hands, they afterwards
sell it at what rate they
please.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fore-ward(adv)">Fore-ward,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Before,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Ward.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forfeit(n)">Forfeit,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in the Law;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Forfaict,</etym>
from the Verb <etym lang="fr">Forfaire,</etym> or
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Forfare,</etym> in France
and Italy, to forfeit for some
fault; but among us, to lose
money or goods upon viola&shy;
tion of the Laws of the Realm,
as breaking a compact made
between man and man, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forge(n)">Forge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Forge,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Forgia,</etym> a Smith's
forge: And hence the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Forger</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="fr">Forgiare</etym>,
to forge a writing, or other
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forget(v)">Forget,</form><xpln lang="en">from the privative AS.
Preposition <etym lang="oe">For</etym>, the Belg.
and Teut. <etym lang="bl">Ver,</etym> and the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Geotan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghieten,</etym>
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Giessen,</etym> to get;
and these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gut&shy;
ta,</etym> a drop; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to let a thing
drop, or slip out of the me&shy;
mory: Or, which is better,
from the same <etym lang="oe">For</etym>, and
<etym lang="oe">Gytan,</etym> to learn; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) by
carelesness to unlearn what
was before learned.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forgive(v)">Forgive,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Forgi&shy;
fan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vergheven,</etym> or
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vergeven,</etym> to remit.
<term lang="la">v.</term> For, and Give.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forgo(v)">Forgoe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Forgan</etym>,
to forsake.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fork(n)">Fork,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Forc</etym>, or
</page>

<page sig="K4v"> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fourche;</etym> and all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Furca,</etym> the
same. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fork-fish(n)">Fork-fish,</form><xpln lang="en">a kind of Thorn-back;
so called, from its sharp forked
tail.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forlorn(a)">Forlorn,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Forlo&shy;
ren</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Verloren,</etym> or
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Verlohien,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) brought to ruin and de&shy;
solation: These are part. of
the Verbs <etym lang="oe">Forleoran</etym>, <etym lang="bl">Ver&shy;
liesen,</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Verlieren,</etym> to spoil,
or bereave of.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="form(v)">Formeth,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Hunting;
it is meant of an Hare, when
she squatteth down; from
the Noun <etym lang="en">Fourm;</etym> which
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foremost(a)">Formost or Foremost,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Formost</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Fyr&shy;
mest</etym>, the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> Be&shy;
fore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forage(v)">Forrage,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Four&shy;
rager,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Foraggiare,</etym>
to Fodder; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foreign(a)">Forrain, or Foreign,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Forain,</etym> an Alien, one
of another Nation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forest(n)">Forrest, or Forest,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Forest,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Foresta,</etym>
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Forst,</etym> the same.
Spelman draws it from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">For&agrave;s,</etym> or <etym lang="la">For&igrave;s,</etym> abroad;
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> a place far distant from,
and destitute of house or habi&shy;
tation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forsake(v)">Forsake</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Forse&shy;
can</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> never to seek any
more; <term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Seek:</etym> Or from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">For-Secgan</etym>, Fr.
Th. <etym lang="hd">Vitersagan,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Versa&shy;
gen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Versegghen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>,
to dis-own, to renounce.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="force(n)">Forses,</form><xpln lang="en">not unlikely, from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Force,</etym> power, or
strength; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a place where
the water falleth from a rock,
or steep place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forsooth(ex)">Forsooth,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">For&shy;
so&eth;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. <term lang="la">v.</term> For, and
Sooth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forswear(v)">Forswear,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fer&shy;
swerian,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Verswe&shy;
ren,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Verschwe&shy;
ren,</etym> to be guilty of perjury.
<term lang="la">v.</term> For, and Swear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forth(adv)">Forth,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">For&eth;</etym>,
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voord,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fort,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all perhaps from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">For&igrave;s, For&agrave;s,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Por&shy;
r&ograve;,</etym> abroad, without.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forthwith(adv)">Forthwith,</form><xpln lang="en">presently; from
<etym lang="en">Forth,</etym> and <etym lang="en">With;</etym> by a &shy;
Metaphor drawn from Soldiers,
that march instantly, at the
word of Command.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fort(n)">Fort,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Fortress.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fortify(v)">Fortifie,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Forti&shy;
fier,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from
<etym lang="fr">Fort,</etym> which comes from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Fortis,</etym> strong.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forward(adv)">Forward,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">For&shy;
weard,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. <term lang="la">v.</term> Before, and
Ward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="focile(n)">Fossel, or Focil,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Chi&shy;
rurgery; by which name two
bones in the arm, and other
two of the leg, are called;
the one of which is called the
great Fossel; the other, the
</page>

<page sig="K5r">
little Fossel; derived from the
Fr. G. and Ital. <etym lang="hd">Focile,</etym> signi&shy;
fying the same; (but proper&shy;
ly, a long piece of Steel that
Butchers whet their knives on,
to which these long bones are
not unlike;) and this from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Focus,</etym> fire; because
steel is used to strike fire
withal. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foster(v)">To Foster,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fos&shy;
trian</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Fosterer,</etym>
to educate, or bring up. Hence the AS <etym lang="oe">Foster-cild</etym>,
a foster-child; <etym lang="oe">Foster-f&aelig;&shy;
der</etym>, a foster-father; all from
the Verb To <etym lang="en">Feed.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foul(a)">Foul,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fulan, Be&shy;
fulan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vuylen,</etym> or
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Beuvollan,</etym> to be&shy;
foul: Thence the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ful</etym>,
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Faul</etym>, putrefied. <term lang="la">v.</term>
Filth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="found(v)">To Found,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Fon&shy;
der,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fundare,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to build, or raise
from the ground, to lay the
basis.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="founder(n)">A Founder,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Foundeur;</etym> and this from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fondre,</etym> or the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Fondere,</etym> to melt down, as
Founders do metals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="founder(v)">To Founder,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fondre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sfondrare,</etym>
the same; all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fundus,</etym> the ground; as be&shy;
ing, the occasion of an horse's
foundring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fountain(n)">Fountain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fon&shy;
taine,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fontana;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fons,</etym> the
same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="four(n)">Four,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feower</etym>,
Teut. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vier,</etym> the
same; whence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vier-&shy;
vould</etym>, four-fold, and the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Feor&eth;</etym>, the fourth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="form(n)">Fourm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fyrm&shy;
&eth;a</etym>, a seat; and this from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Feormian</etym>, to feed;
they being especially of use at
great feasts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fowl(n)">Fowl,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Fugel</etym>, the
Dan. <etym lang="da">Fugl,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vog&shy;
hel,</etym> a bird; whence the AS.
<etym lang="oe">Fugelan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voghel&shy;
en</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vogelen</etym>,
to go a fowling; all of them
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Volo,</etym> to
fly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fox(n)">A Fox,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fox</etym>, Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vosch,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Fucks,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fuchs,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foy(n)">Foy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Foy,</etym> or the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Voy,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a
treat given by those that are
going out of Town, or into
another Country.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="freight(n)">Fraight,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fracht,</etym>
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vracht,</etym> or the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Fret,</etym> a carriage, or fare;
whence the Teut. Verb <etym lang="tt">Frach&shy;
ten</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrachten</etym>, and the
Fr. G. <etym lang="hd">Freter</etym>, to load a ship:
All these may be drawn per&shy;
haps from the AS. and Teut.
<etym lang="oe">Oher</etym>, over, and the Teut. and
Belg. <etym lang="tt">Acht, Achten,</etym> to take
care of; for the Fraight is the
Sea-men's charge.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="K5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frail(a)">Frail,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fraile;</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fragi&shy;
lis,</etym> brittle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frame(n)">Frame,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frem&shy;
man</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew derives
it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Formare,</etym> to
fashion, or form.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="franchise(v)">To Franchise,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Frank, and En&shy;
franchise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frank(a)">Frank,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Franc,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Franco,</etym> free:
From hence Franchise, a pri&shy;
vilege; To Enfranchise, to
make one free of a City; and
Frankling, a Libertine; also
A Franch, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a pasture
where cattle are well fatted.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frank(n)">A Frank,</form><xpln lang="en">a coin so called; from
<etym lang="fr">France,</etym> the Nation where it
is coined.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frank(v)">To Frank fowl, Franked fowl;</form><xpln lang="en">
a word no where found but in
Higgin. from the Adj. <etym lang="en">Frank;</etym>
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> crammed fowls.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frankincense(n)">Frankincense;</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> frankly or
freely burned upon the altar.
V<emend err=" ">.</emend> Frank, and Incense.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frankling(n)">Frankling,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Frank.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"frankling" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frantic(a)">Frantick,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fre&shy;
natique,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Freneti&shy;
co;</etym> and all from the Lat. and
Gr. <etym lang="la">Phreneticus,</etym> frenzical. <term lang="la">v.</term>
Frenzy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fray(n)">A Fray,</form><xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Affray,</etym> a fight.
Minshew derives it from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Effrayer,</etym> to terrifie, or
affright.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fray(v)">To Fray,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fra&shy;
ger;</etym> and this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fricare,</etym> to rub. It is meant
of cloth, that being rubbed
against any thing hard, is fret&shy;
ted out, and tore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="freak(n)">A Freack,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frech,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a petulant fact:
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fraec</etym>, an
action shewing the discompo&shy;
sedness of mind to be volun&shy;
tary, and not forced.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="freck(n)" lexeme="freckles(n)">Freck, Freckles,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fleck,</etym> a spot, or stain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="free(a)">Free,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Freah,
Freoh</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Frii,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vrti,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frey,</etym> the same;
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Freoman</etym>,
a Free-man. It were needless,
after all, to derive it from the
Goth. <etym lang="go">Frigon,</etym> to love; be&shy;
cause all men love to be at li&shy;
berty.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="freebooter(n)">Free-booter,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Free,</etym> and
<etym lang="en">Booty;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Soldier who
hath liberty to take what boo&shy;
ty he can, because he receives
no other pay for his service in
the War.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frieze(n)">Freese,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Frize,</etym>
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Frisa,</etym> or the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Fresone,</etym> a course cloth, full
of naps; perhaps so called,
because those of Freezland
first made, or wore this sort
of cloth, to defend them from
the intenseness of the cold in
those parts.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="freeze(v)">To Freese, or rather Freeze,</form><xpln lang="en">from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frysan,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">At
Frys,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrosten, Vriesen,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frieren,</etym> the same;
whence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrost</etym>, Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Frost</etym>, frost, or ice; all per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frigeo,</etym> to
be cold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frieze(n)">The Freise,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture;
</page>

<page sig="K6r">
perhaps from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fraise,</etym> a ruff. Eve&shy;
lin draws it from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Freggio,</etym> with us, A Fringe;
which see. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frenzy(n)">Frensy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fre&shy;
naise,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Frenesia;</etym>
and both from the Lat. and
Gr. <etym lang="gk">Phrenitis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fresh(a)">Fresh,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fresch</etym>,
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Frisch,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Frais,
Fresche, Frez,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Fresco,</etym>
new; also brisk and lively.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fresh(a)">Fresh,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Frisch,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fresco;</etym>
and all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fry&shy;
san</etym>, and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vriesen;</etym> these
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frigeo,</etym> to be
cold; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> chill, or somewhat
cold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fret(v)">To Fret,</form><xpln lang="en">as cloth, &amp;c. from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Freo&eth;an</etym>, the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Frotter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Frotta&shy;
re;</etym> and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fri&shy;
care,</etym> to rub; rubbing being
a cause of fretting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fret(v)">To Fret,</form><xpln lang="en">to be perplexed, or
troubled; perhaps from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fretiller,</etym> to jaunt from
place to place, as men do
in their anger; this from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fritillum,</etym> by a Metaphor
drawn from a Lottery, where
the Gamester shaketh the dice
together in a box, before he
casteth them out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fretrots(n)">Fretrots,</form><xpln lang="en">a Sect of Hereticks,
much like to the Adamites;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Frere,</etym> a bro&shy;
ther; because they separated
themselves from the Church,
and erected themselves into
a Fraternity, in opposition
thereto.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"fretrots" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fricassee(n)">Fricassey,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fri&shy;
cass&eacute;e;</etym> and this from the
Verb <etym lang="fr">Fricasser,</etym> to make a fri&shy;
cassey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="friday(n)">Friday,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frige&shy;
daeg</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Frig-dag,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Freitag,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrydagh,</etym> the
same: Or from <etym lang="oe">Friga,</etym> the
ancient Anglo-Saxons God&shy;
dess Venus; which comes
from the Goth. <etym lang="go">Frigan,</etym> to
love; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> the Goddess of
Love, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Venus; whence
it is called <term lang="oe">Dies Veneris</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fridge(v)">To Fridge, or Frig</form><xpln lang="en">about, from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frican</etym>, to skip.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="friend(n)">Friend,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Freond</etym>,
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Freund,</etym> or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vriend,</etym> the same; which last,
Fr. Jun. derives from the
Goth. <etym lang="go">Frigon,</etym> to love. It
may probably be taken from
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frewen,</etym> to rejoice;
because we delight in our
friend's company: Or from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Freoh,</etym> free; for
friends act and speak freely,
and not flatteringly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="friar(n)">A Frier,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Frere,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Frater,</etym> a Brother: From
hence, A Friery; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a
Fraternity, or Order in the
Church of Rome.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frig(v)">To Frig,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Frega&shy;
re,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Fricciare;</etym> and these
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fricare,</etym> to
rub: Or from <etym lang="oe">Friga,</etym> the
</page>

<page sig="K6v">
name which the Saxons gave
to Venus. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frigate(n)">Frigat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fre&shy;
gate,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fregata,</etym> a
kind of flight-ship; and this
not unlikely from the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Fregare,</etym> to rub, or adorn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fright(n)">Fright,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frihtan</etym>,
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vurchten,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Vorch&shy;
ten,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Forchten,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>. <term lang="la">v.</term> Fear.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frill(v)">The Hawk Frilleth,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Friller,</etym> to tremble;
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frigus</etym>
cold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frim folk(n)">Frim folks,</form><xpln lang="en">a word frequently
used in Lincolnshire; from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fremd,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Fremvd,</etym> a stranger, one of
another Country; this from
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fram, Fra</etym>, far
from. <term lang="la">v.</term> From.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"frim folks" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fringe(n)">Fringe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Frange,</etym>
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fregio, Frangia,</etym> or
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frantze,</etym> the same:
Perhaps it may come from
<etym lang="la">Francis,</etym> the Ablat. of <etym lang="la">Fran&shy;
cus,</etym> a French-man; because
the French delight in these
things, beyond other Coun&shy;
tries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frippery(n)">Frippery,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fri&shy;
perie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fripperia,</etym>
a Broker's shop: Whence the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fripear</etym>; which comes
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frivolarius</etym>, a
word read in Vossius, which
signifieth, a Botcher, or men&shy;
der of old things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frisk(v)">To Frisk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Friz&shy;
zare,</etym> to skip about; and this
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Frisque,</etym>
Fresh, and <etym lang="en">Brisk;</etym> both which
see in their places.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frizzle(v)">Frisle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Friser,
Frizer,</etym> to curl the hair: Or
perhaps from the <etym lang="en">Frisians,</etym> or
<etym lang="en">Phrygians,</etym> that used to twirl
up their hair.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frit(n)">Frit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Verb To <etym lang="en">Fret;</etym> a
kind of salt used by Chymists,
more sharp than ordinary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frith(n)">Frith,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fretum,</etym>
the sea; q d. a place which
the tyde overfloweth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fritter(v)">Fritter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fri&shy;
teau, Frittier;</etym> as the learned
Dr. Th. H. hath it: Or from
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Frittella,</etym> the same; all
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frigere,</etym> to fry.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frock(n)">Frock,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Froc de
Moine,</etym> a Monk's hood. Me&shy;
nagius draws them both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Floccus,</etym> a lock of
wool. Vossius more proba&shy;
bly takes it from the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Rock,</etym> a coat; and this from
the AS. Verb <etym lang="oe">Wreon</etym>, to co&shy;
ver; it being made on pur&shy;
pose to keep other wearing ap&shy;
parel clean</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frog(n)">Frog,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frocca</etym>,
(by &AElig;lfricus, <etym lang="oe">Frogga</etym>,)
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrosck,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Frosch,</etym> the same; all, I sup&shy;
pose from the croaking hoarse
noise which they make.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frolic(a)">Frolick,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrolick,</etym>
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frolich, Froh,</etym>
wanton; these from their
Verbs <etym lang="bl">Vrolecken,</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Frolec&shy;
ken,</etym> to be merrily disposed.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="K7r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="from(pp)">From,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fram</etym>;
which comes from the AS.
and Dan. <etym lang="oe">Fra,</etym> far.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frontier(n)">Frontier,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fron&shy;
tiere,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Frontiera,</etym>
a bound, or limit; both from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frons,</etym> a front.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frontlet(n)">Frontlet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fron&shy;
teau;</etym> and both from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Frons,</etym> a fore-head; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> at&shy;
tire for the fore-head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frost(n)">Frost,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frost</etym>,
the Teut. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Frost,</etym> or
the Fr. Th. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrost,</etym>
the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> Freizi.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="froth(n)">Froth,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Fraade,</etym> the
same; this from <etym lang="da">Fraaer,</etym> to foam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frounce(n)">The Frounce, or Frownce,</form><xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
ease among hawks; from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fronser.</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term> Frown.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="froward(a)">Froward,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fram&shy;
weard</etym>, aukward: It is the contrary to Toward, and To&shy;
wardly; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frown(v)">Frown,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fron&shy;
guer, Fronser:</etym> Or perhaps
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frons,</etym> the fore-&shy;
head; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to wrinkle up the
brows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fruit(n)">Fruit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fruit,
Fruict;</etym> and both from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Fructus,</etym> the same: From
hence, A Fruiterer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frump(v)">To Frump,</form><xpln lang="en">to mock; from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krumpelen,</etym> to frizzle
up the nose, as people do in
derision.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fry(v)">To Fry,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Frire,</etym>
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Friggere, Frittare,</etym>
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vryten;</etym> all from
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frigere,</etym> the same;
and this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&rho;&#x1F7B;&gamma;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>,
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fry(n)">A Fry,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fray,</etym>
the spawn of fishes; and this
from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Fraade,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
also froth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fuck(v)">To Fuck,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Foutre,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fotere, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Futuo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&upsilon;&tau;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to
plant. Th. H. Esq derives it
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fuycken, Foc&shy;
ken,</etym> to thrust, or knock. It
may be derived from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fuchsen,</etym> the same; this
from <etym lang="tt">Futz,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Fotte</etym>,
<term lang="la">&agrave; pudendum muliebre</term>: Or last&shy;
ly, from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Foder,</etym> to
beget. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fuddle(v)">Fuddle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">Puddle;</etym>
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to drown himself, as it
were, with wine, or other li&shy;
quor: Or from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Affoler,</etym> to make a fool of;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to besot himself with
too much drink, which ener&shy;
vates the faculties of the mind.
<term lang="la">v.</term> Fool. An ingenious Ety&shy;
mologist supposeth that it
cometh of <etym lang="en">Full,</etym> by an inter&shy;
position of the letter d; and
from hence it is, that the Scots
use the word Full, for one
that is drunk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foumart(n)">Fulimart,</form><xpln lang="en">a word found in a
book entituled, <f type="i">The Compleat
Angler</f>; for the Etymon
whereof see Martin, and
Pole-cat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="full(a)">Full,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Full</etym>, the Fr.
Th. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vol,</etym> or the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Voll, Full,</etym> the same;
</page>

<page sig="K7v">
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fyllan</etym>, to
fill; <etym lang="oe">Fyllnese</etym>, fulness;
<etym lang="oe">Fullneh</etym>, full-nigh; <etym lang="oe">Full-&shy;
oft</etym>, full-often. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fuller(n)">Fuller,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fullere</etym>,
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voller,</etym> the same;
whence <etym lang="bl">Volders Aerde</etym>, Ful&shy;
ler's earth; all from the Lat.
<etym lang="la">Fullo,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fulsome(a)">Fulsom,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Foulsom, that
hath a foul taste, or smell. <term lang="la">v.</term>
Foul.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fumble(v)">Fumble,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan <etym lang="da">Famler,</etym>
to handle; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to handle, or
go about a thing unskilfully,
or aukwardly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fume(v)">To Fume:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fumare, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.
I had rather draw it from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Faum,</etym> froth; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to
foam, or froth at the mouth
for anger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fumet(n)">Fumets,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Hunting; I
suppose from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fimus,</etym>
dung; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> Crotel's, or Hare's
dung.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="foumart(n)">A Fummer,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fu&shy;
mus,</etym> a fume, or scent; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a
kind of Mart, casting a ram&shy;
mish, strong scent. A learned
Etymologist supposeth it to
have been contracted from <etym lang="en">Fu&shy;
limart,</etym> not without reason.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fundament(n)">Fundament,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fondement,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; a founda&shy;
tion; so called, because the
whole body leaneth upon it,
as upon a foundation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="funeral(n)">Funeral,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fune&shy;
railles,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Funus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="funk(n)">Funk,</form><xpln lang="en">an offensive smell; by al&shy;
tering the sense a little, from
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Funcke,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Funck,</etym>
a spark of fire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="funnel(n)">A Funnel,</form><xpln lang="en">contracted from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Infundibulum,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furbish(v)">To Furbish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fourbir,</etym> or the Ital <etym lang="it">Forbire,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and these from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Farb,</etym> a colour; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>
to renew the colour of a
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fourch&eacute;(a)" lexeme="cross-fourch&eacute;(a)">Furche, Cross-Furche,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in
Heraldry; from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Fourch&eacute;e, Fourch&uuml;e;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a
forked cross.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"fourch&eacute;" antedates earliest OED citation (1706).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furl(v)">To Furl,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fresler,</etym>
to fold up; and this from the
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pressus,</etym> pressed down;
for when a sail is folded up,
it lieth in less room than when
it is stretched out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furlong(n)">Furlong,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fur&shy;
lang</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from
<etym lang="oe">Furh</etym>, a furrow; and
<etym lang="oe">Lang</etym>, long. <term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Furrow.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="frumenty(n)">Furmety,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Four&shy;
ment&eacute;e, Froument&eacute;e;</etym> these
from <etym lang="fr">Fourment, Froument;</etym>
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Frumen&shy;
tum;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> pottage made of
Wheat, Rice, or other grain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furnish(v)">Furnish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Four&shy;
nir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fornire,</etym> <term lang="la">id.</term>
From hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Four&shy;
niture</etym>; in Eng. Furniture,
or house-hold goods.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furole(n)">Furole,</form><xpln lang="en">a Meteor, or fiery Ex&shy;
halation, which, at Sea, most
an end, appeareth among the
Sails, especially when there is a
</page>

<page sig="K8r"> 
storm a-coming: If it be in
two parts, it is called Castor
and Pollux, and is thought to
portend safety; but if it be but
one, it is called Helena, and
fore-bodeth ship-wrack. It
may be derived from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Feu,</etym> fire, and <etym lang="fr">Rouler,</etym> to
rowl; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> rowling, or wan&shy;
dring fire. <term lang="la">v.</term> Rowl. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fur(n)">Furr,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fourrer,</etym>
Ital. <etym lang="it">Inforrare,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Aforrar,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Futtern,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voede&shy;
ren,</etym> to line with skins; these
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fodro,</etym> Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Futter,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Furreau,</etym> a
furr, or skin for lining gar&shy;
ments withal; but properly,
a scabbard.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furrow(n)">Furrow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Furh</etym>,
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Furch,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Fur,</etym> Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Vore,</etym> the same; whence the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Furchen</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voren</etym>,
to make a furrow; all, I sup&shy;
pose, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Forare,</etym> to
pierce, or hollow; (<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) a
piercing, or hollowing of the
ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="further(v)">To Further,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fur&shy;
&eth;rian</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voorderen,</etym>
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Befurdern,</etym> to pro&shy;
mote; all from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vor&shy;
der,</etym> the former; and this
from <etym lang="en">Fore,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Before;</etym> as
we say, To put it forwards.
<term lang="la">v.</term> Before.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="further(adv)">Further,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Farther.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="furze(n)">Furze,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fyrs</etym>, a
sort of prickly Broom; this
from <etym lang="en">Fire,</etym> because good to
make fires with.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fusil(n)">A Fusil,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fuseau;</etym> and
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fusus,</etym> a
spindle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fustian(n)">Fustian,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fu&shy;
staigne,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fustagno,</etym> or
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Fustan,</etym> the same.
Bochartus derives it from <etym lang="en">Fu&shy;
stat,</etym> a Town in Egypt, where
it was first made.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fustian(n)">Fustian,</form><xpln lang="en">from the other <etym lang="en">Fustian,</etym>
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&upsilon;&sigma;&eta;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, blown up;
(<term lang="la">i. e.</term>) a bumbaste, ambitious
and affected style in writing.</xpln></wordentry> </wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="G"><alpha>G</alpha>
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gaberdine(n)">Gabardine,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Galleverdine, Galvardine,</etym>
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gavardina,</etym> the
same; these from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaban,</etym> and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gaba&shy;
nio, Gabanello, Gabano,</etym> a
Shepherd's coat, made of
course cloth. Some draw it
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gavan,</etym> a
cloak: All of them perhaps
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gabe,</etym> a gift;
or our word, To Give; which
see; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) apparel annually
given by masters, to their ser&shy;
vants, pages, &amp;c. which we
call Liveries. <term lang="la">v.</term> Livery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gabble(v)">To Gabble,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ja&shy;
violer, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gay, Jay, Jayon,</etym> a
Jay: <term lang="la">v.</term> Cajol. Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gabelen,</etym> to chirp as
</page>

<page sig="K8v">
birds; or <etym lang="bl">Gaepen,</etym> to gape;
or, which is most likely, from
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Habler,</etym> to prate;
this from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Hablar;</etym>
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fabu&shy;
lari,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gavel(n)">Gabel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr.
G. <etym lang="fr">Gabelle,</etym>
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gabella,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Alcavala,</etym> the same; which Covarru<term lang="la">v.</term> draws from the Heb <etym lang="he">Gabal,</etym> to limit; or <etym lang="he">Gabeloth,</etym> a Tax. I
had rather derive it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gafel</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Gafol</etym>, tribute; and these from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gifan</etym>, to give. <term lang="la">v.</term> Give.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gabion(n)">A Gabion,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ga&shy;
bion,</etym> or the Ital <etym lang="it">Gabbione,</etym>
a military term, which deno&shy;
teth, a basket filled with earth.
It may also be drawn from the
Ital. <etym lang="it">Gabbia;</etym> which Mena&shy;
gius draws from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ca&shy;
vea,</etym> a cave.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gable(n)">The Gable end of an house,</form><xpln lang="en">
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Giebel, Gib&shy;
ffel,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gheevel,</etym> the
same; all perhaps from the
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>, or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ca&shy;
put,</etym> an head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gad(n)">Gad,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gadd</etym>, <term lang="la">id.</term> 
a mass of iron, or steel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gad(n)">A Gad</form><xpln lang="en">fly, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Goad-fly;</etym> be&shy;
cause she pricketh like a goad: 
Or from our word <etym lang="en">Gad;</etym> be&shy;
cause she makes the cattle gad, 
or go a-stray.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gad(v)">To Gad;</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaen</etym>, to Go; 
which see. It may also be 
drawn from the Teut. or ra&shy;
ther, the old Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaden,</etym> to 
please, some people being 
never pleased, but when gad&shy;
ding about. Some also, by a 
Metaphor, take it from the 
<etym lang="en">Gad-fly;</etym> because they firk up 
and down, like an Ox stung 
therewith. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gad-fly.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gauge(n)">A Gage, or Gawge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gauge, Jauge,</etym> a rod to 
measure liquids withal; these 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gauchir,</etym> to 
turn round, saith Minshew; 
and this again perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealcan</etym>, to rowl; 
and this from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Volge&shy;
re,</etym> which manifestly cometh 
of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Volvere,</etym> to rowl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gauge(n)">A Gage or Pledge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gaggia,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="it">Gaggiare</etym>, to 
give a pledge; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Vas, Vadis,</etym> a Surety. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Engage.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gag(n)">Gagg:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaghel,</etym> the palate. 
Some draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geagl</etym>, the cheek bone; 
because it is thrust in between 
the jaws, and stretcheth them 
out, so as that the party so 
handled, can neither speak, 
nor cry out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gain(v)">Gain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaigner,</etym> 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ganar,</etym> or the Ita. <etym lang="it">Gua&shy;
dagnare,</etym> to profit; whence 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gain</etym>, and the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Guadagno</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Menagius 
draws them all from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gewen,</etym> gain; or <etym lang="tt">Gewinnen,</etym> 
to gain. It may also, not
</page>

<page sig="L1r"> 
improbably, be drawn from 
the Dan. and old Goth. <etym lang="go">Goff&shy;
ner,</etym> to profit. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gainsay(v)">Gain-say,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gean-&shy;
Secgan</etym>, to Say against; 
both which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gale(n)">A Gale of wind,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gahling, Gehling,</etym> suddain; 
that is, wind coming una&shy;
wares: Or from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Awel,</etym> wind; or a blast, by 
casting away A, and turning 
w into G, and e into a.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gall(v)">To Gall,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Galler,</etym> 
to claw, or itch.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gall(n)">The Gall of any creature,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gealla</etym>, Dan. <etym lang="da">Galde,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gall,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gal, Galle,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallant(a)">Gallant,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gal&shy;
lant,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Galante,</etym> 
brave, noble; also one that 
hath gorgeous attire on. 
Some there are that would 
draw it from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gala&shy;
no, Vestido a la Gala</etym>, signi&shy;
fying the same. Menagius 
draws it from the obsolete Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gale,</etym> joy; which may be 
a contract of the Lat. Dim. 
<etym lang="la">Gaudiolum,</etym> a little joy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallery(n)">Gallery,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Galle&shy;
rie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Galleria,</etym> the 
same; either from the figure 
of a ship, called a <etym lang="en">Gally;</etym> or 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="fr">Allerie;</etym> that is, a place to 
walk in; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Al&shy;
ler,</etym> to go. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gally.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="galliard(n)">The Galliard,</form><xpln lang="en">a kind of Dance; 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gagliardo,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaillard,</etym> airy, live&shy;
ly; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a merry Dance. 
C&aelig;sar Scaliger and Vossius de&shy;
rive it from <etym lang="fr">Gallus,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Galli&shy;
cus,</etym> a French-man, and the 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Art, Aerd,</etym> nature, or 
temper of mind; to wit, from 
the natural airiness or agility 
of that Country people.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="galligaskin(n)">Galligaskins,</form><xpln lang="en">or wide Hose, or 
Slops; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="la">Calig&aelig; Gailo-va&shy;
sconic&aelig;,</etym> slops so called, be&shy;
cause the Vascones used such, 
instead of spatter dashes.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallimaufry(n)">Gallimawfrey,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Galimaffr&eacute;e,</etym> a dish of meat, 
made of sundry sorts of flesh, 
chopped small. Minshew 
takes it to be so called, from 
the guts and garbage of beasts, 
cut in small pieces, for Gally-&shy;
slaves among the Romans. 
Some draw it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Galiffre;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> Lat. <etym lang="la">Gulifer,</etym> 
a Glutton.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallon(n)">Gallon,</form><xpln lang="en">a measure so called. It 
may possibly come, &agrave; <etym lang="fr">Gallis,</etym> 
from the French; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a 
French measure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="galloon-lace(n)">Galloon-Lace,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Galon,</etym> the same; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> Gal&shy;
lica Fimbria, a French lace: 
Or from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gala,</etym> a sort 
of trimming that makes a 
gay shew, yet of no great 
worth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallop(v)">Gallop,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Galop&shy;
per, Gallopper,</etym> to ride fast: 
Or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&pi;&#x1FB6;&nu;</etym>, or 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F71;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to run; as Salma&shy;
sius hath it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="galosh(n)">Galloshooes,</form><xpln lang="en">wooden slippers; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Galloches,
</page>

<page sig="L1v"> 
Galoches,</etym> or the Hisp. and 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Galocha,</etym> the same. Me&shy;
nagius supposeth that it com&shy;
eth, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Gallicis Soleis,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
French shooes. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallows(n)">Gallowes,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Galg, 
Gual, Gaflas</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Galg&shy;
he,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Gallie,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Galg, Galgen, Gabel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
There is also found in Varro, 
<etym lang="la">Gabalus,</etym> a cross, or gibbet, 
for the execution of Malefa&shy;
ctors.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="galley(n)">Gally,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gall&eacute;e, 
Gall&eacute;re,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gal&eacute;a,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gal&eacute;ra,</etym> the same. 
Minshew will have it called 
<etym lang="la">Navem Galeatam,</etym> a ship <emend err="hahaving">ha&shy;
ving</emend> an helmet, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Galeatis 
militibus,</etym> from Soldiers wea&shy;
ring helmets; to wit, Turkish 
and Moorish Pirates, with 
whom these ships were man&shy;
ned at the first. Covarru<term lang="la">v.</term> 
draws it from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Ge&shy;
lia,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) chargeable to main&shy;
tain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallipot(n)">Gally-pot,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gleye,</etym> 
Potter's clay sparkling, and 
<etym lang="bl">Pot;</etym> from whence perhaps, 
To Glaze a pipe. <term lang="la">v.</term> Glass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gallyworm(n)">Gally-worm:</form><xpln lang="en">so Muffetus calls 
the worm which in Lat. and 
Gr. is called <etym lang="la">Gulus,</etym> from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F3C;&omicron;&upsilon;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, down, for its 
downy roughness: But our 
Author perhaps calls it so, be&shy;
cause it somewhat resembleth 
a <etym lang="en">Gally</etym> in length.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gambade(n)">Gambades, or Gambadoes,</form><xpln lang="en">a 
kind of shooes used by Physi&shy;
cians, especially those that o&shy;
perate in London; from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Gamba,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jambe,</etym> the leg, or shin; be&shy;
cause they cover the shanks. 
It alludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&mu;&beta;&#x1F71;&shy;
&delta;&epsilon;&#x03c2;</etym>, buskins.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gambol(n)">Gamboles,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Gambade,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gam&shy;
baruole,</etym> wanton gestures; 
these from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gamba,</etym> 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Jambe,</etym> the leg; 
such tricks being generally performed by the agility of 
the legs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="game(n)">Games,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gamian, 
Gemian,</etym> to sport, or go a ga&shy;
ming. Minshew derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&#x1F71;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a wed&shy;
ding; because sports are most 
seasonable at Marriages.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gammon(n)">A Gammon</form><xpln lang="en">of Bacon, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jambon,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ja&shy;
mon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gambone,</etym> 
the same; and these from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jambe,</etym> and the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Gamba,</etym> a leg: <etym lang="fr">Gambone,</etym> sig&shy;
nifies, a great leg: All from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hamm,</etym> the hamm. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Hamm.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gamut(n)">Gammot,</form><xpln lang="en">a Time in Musick; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Game,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Gamma,</etym> the same; both 
of an Arab. original, as I sup&shy;
pose; unless you would draw 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&mu;&pi;&#x1F74;</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
&Kappa;&alpha;&mu;&pi;&alpha;&#x1F76; &tau;&#x1FC6;&#x03c2; &Phi;&omega;&nu;&#x1FC6;&#x03c2;, the turnings 
of the sound; or from <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&mu;&shy;
&pi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gammot(n)">Gammot,</form><xpln lang="en">a kind of edged tool in 
Gouldman; perhaps from the
</page>

<page sig="L2r"> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kampffen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kam&shy;
pen,</etym> to fight; that is to say, a 
weapon to fight withal. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ganch(v)">To Ganch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gan&shy;
cher,</etym> to cast headlong upon 
sharp stakes; or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gan&shy;
ciare,</etym> to make the end of a 
stick sharp: Whence the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Gancho</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gancio</etym>, 
an hook; which come from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Uncus,</etym> crooked. It 
alludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&kappa;&alpha;&nu;&theta;&alpha;</etym>, a 
thorn-tree.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gander(n)">Gander,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gan&shy;
dra</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gans,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gansz,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ganso,</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Gan&shy;
za,</etym> the same; all possibly 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Anser,</etym> a goose.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ganefish(n)">A Gane-fish,</form><xpln lang="en">a word found in 
Higginus only; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ganian</etym>, to yawn; 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Snacot-fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gannet(n)">A Ganett,</form><xpln lang="en">I suppose from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Canet,</etym> a young duck, 
or wild duck; this is the Dim. 
of the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cane,</etym> manifest&shy;
ly coming from the Lat. <etym lang="la">A&shy;
nas,</etym> a duck.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gang(v)">To Gang,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gan&shy;
gen;</etym> and this from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaen,</etym> to 
Go; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gang(n)">Gang;</form><xpln lang="en">as we say, He is of that 
Gang, or Fellowship; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gange</etym>, a walk, or 
way; and by translation, a 
company of men that go and 
act all alike.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gangrel(n)">Gangrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">A long Gangrel: in 
Higg. a slam fellow; perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gangere</etym>, the 
Verbal of <etym lang="oe">Gangan</etym>, to go; 
and <etym lang="oe">Ellen</etym>, strong; that is, 
one that, through the great 
length of his legs, soon goes 
over much ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gang-week(n)">Gang Week,</form><xpln lang="en">from our old word 
to <etym lang="en">Gang;</etym> it being the week, 
in which the bounds of every 
Parish are viewed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gauntlet(n)">Gantlet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gante&shy;
let,</etym> an iron-glove: Or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gant,</etym> the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Guante,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guanto,</etym> 
a glove; and these from the 
Gotho-Sw. <etym lang="gs">Want,</etym> the same; 
and this again from the AS. 
and old Goth. <etym lang="go">Windan</etym>, to 
wind, or wrap up; because 
in those cold countries, they 
used formerly to muffle up 
their hands in skins, instead 
of gloves, so to keep off the 
cold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gantlope(n)">Gantlope,</form><xpln lang="en">a military punish&shy;
ment; from a Town in Flan&shy;
ders, called in French <etym lang="fr">Gant,</etym> 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loop,</etym> a race; 
or <etym lang="bl">Loopen,</etym> to run; because 
this punishment was first in&shy;
vented there.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gaol(n)">Gaol,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghioole,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Geole, Jaule, 
Gayole,</etym> the same; whence 
Jolier, Geolier, a Gaoler, or 
Jailer; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ca&shy;
veola,</etym> a little cave. Fr. Jun. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, 
which denotes an hollow place 
under ground. Some draw it 
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Jaula, Xaula,</etym> 
a cage; as we sometimes call 
a prison.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="L2v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gape(v)">To Gape,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaepen,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gaffen,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Gaver,</etym> 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Geapan</etym>, all signifying 
the same: Which last, Som&shy;
nerus draws from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Geopnian</etym>, to open. It is not 
much dissonant from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to stand gazing at a 
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gape(v)">Gap,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Gape.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garb(n)">Garb,</form><xpln lang="en">or Attire, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Garbe,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Garbo,</etym> 
comeliness, decency; this 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gearwian</etym>, to 
trim up; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaer&shy;
wen, Gerwen,</etym> to adorn, or 
make ready.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garb(n)">Garb,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; from 
the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Gerbe,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Garbe,</etym> a sheaf.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garbage(n)">Garbage:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from our word <etym lang="en">Garble,</etym> that 
is, to cleanse; for when the 
guts are taken out, the body 
is thereby purged, and made 
clean.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garble(v)">Garble</form><xpln lang="en">, To Garble spices, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grabeller,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Garbellare</etym>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to 
make spices clean, by sifting 
them. Minshew draws it 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Garbo,</etym> cleanli&shy;
ness; because spices, after 
such sifting, are made clean. 
It may be drawn from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cribellare,</etym> to sift a lit&shy;
tle; whence <etym lang="la">Cribellum</etym>, a 
small sieve.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garboil(n)">Garboil,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gar&shy;
bou&iuml;l,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Garbaglio,</etym> 
an uproar. The learned Dr. Th. 
H. ingeniously draws it 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grand Bou&iuml;l&shy;
le,</etym> a great mutiny. We may 
also draw it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gar,</etym> wholly, and <etym lang="tt">Bou&iuml;llir,</etym> to 
boil with anger.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garboard(n)">The Garboard,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Sai&shy;
ling; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> the Gard-board. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Gard, and Board.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guard(n)">Gard,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gard,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guardia,</etym> custody; 
whence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Garder</etym>, 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guardare</etym>, to 
guard, or keep in custody; 
as also <etym lang="fr">Gardien</etym>, and <etym lang="it">Guar&shy;
diano</etym>, a Guardian. <term lang="la">v.</term> Ward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gardant(a)">Gardant,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gardant,</etym> a 
Part. of the Verb <etym lang="fr">Garder,</etym> to 
observe, or survey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garden(n)">Garden,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaerde, 
Gaerd,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gardin,</etym> Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Gardino,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Garte, 
Garten,</etym> the same; whence Gartner, a Gardener; which 
comes either from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Guarder</etym>, to guard; or from 
our word, To Ward; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guardian(n)">Gardian,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Warden.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gargle(v)">Gargle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gargel,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gargouille,</etym> the 
throat; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Gurges, Gurgulio,</etym> the wea&shy;
sand, a gulf; because the throat swalloweth like a gulf 
in the sea.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garish(a)">Garish,</form><xpln lang="en">gorgeously attired; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gearwian</etym>, to 
make preparation; that is, 
one so finically dress'd that it 
required a great deal of time 
to do it.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="L3r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garland(n)">Garland,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gar&shy;
lande, Ghirlande, Guirlande,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ghirlanda,</etym> the 
same; and all &agrave; <etym lang="la"> Gyrando,</etym> 
from surrounding the head; 
or from <etym lang="la">Corolla,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Corona,</etym> a 
coronet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garlic(n)">Garlick,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Garlec, 
Garleac</etym>, the same. Min&shy;
shew derives it from our 
words <etym lang="en">Garden,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Leek.</etym> I 
chuse rather to draw it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gar</etym>, a dart, or lance, 
and <etym lang="oe">Leac</etym>, a leek; because 
its blades grow streight 
upward, like a lance. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Leek.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garment(n)">Garment,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Garnishment. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Garnish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garner(n)">A Garner,</form><xpln lang="en">by a Metathesis, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grenier,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Granaro, Granaio,</etym> 
the same; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Granarium;</etym> and this from 
<etym lang="la">Granum,</etym> grain; it being a 
repository for all sorts of 
grain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garnet(n)">The Garnet,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Cranet,</etym> a little crane; 
an engine whereby ships are loaded and unloaded. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Crane.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garnet(n)" lexeme="granate-stone(n)">Garnet, or Granate-stone,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Granate,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Granata,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. 
<etym lang="la">Granatus,</etym> a kind of carbun&shy;
cle; so called from its red co&shy;
lour, like to that of the seed 
of a pomegranate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garnish(v)">Garnish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gar&shy;
nir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Garnire,</etym> to 
adorn; these perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gearwe, Gearo</etym>, 
readiness; or <etym lang="oe">Gearwian</etym>, to 
make ready. It may, and 
that not absurdly, be drawn 
from <etym lang="en">Cornish,</etym> a term in Ar&shy;
chitecture; which is an orna&shy;
ment to the whole fabrick. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Cornish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garr(v)">To Garr,</form><xpln lang="en">for To Force, a word 
common in the North of Eng&shy;
land; from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Gior,</etym> to 
force.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garret(n)">A Garret,</form><xpln lang="en">the uppermost floor 
in an house; by a small varia&shy;
tion of the sence, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Garite,</etym> a turret; which 
comes from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wah&shy;
ren, Wehren,</etym> to defend. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Ward, and Beware.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garrison(n)">Garrison,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gar&shy;
nison,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guarnigio&shy;
ne, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. <term lang="la">v.</term> Garnish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garter(n)">Garter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jarre&shy;
tiere, Jartiere,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Garrettiera,</etym> the same; all 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jarret,</etym> and 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Garetto, Garretto,</etym> 
the ham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garth(n)">Garth,</form><xpln lang="en">a word frequently used 
in Lincolnshire, for Yard; 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gartier(n)">Gartier, or Gartire,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in 
Heraldry; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) half of a 
<etym lang="en">garter</etym>. <term lang="la">v.</term> Garter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gash(n)">Gash,</form><xpln lang="en">to cut, or slash; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hacher,</etym> to hack, or 
cut in small chips; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Hache,</etym> an hatchet; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ascia,</etym> Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&xi;&#x1F77;&nu;&eta;</etym>, an 
ax.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="L3v">
