<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gasp(n)">Gasp,</form><xpln lang="en">by an Epenthesis of the 
letter s, from <etym lang="en">Gape;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ghastly(a)">Ghastly,</form><xpln lang="en">or terrible, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Ghost&shy;
ly;</etym> or rather, Ghost-like. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Ghost.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gastered(a)">Gastred,</form><xpln lang="en">or greatly affrighted; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gast</etym>, a ghost; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> terrified with the sight 
of some spectre: Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
Gastrid, or Ridden; that is, 
ridden by an Hag, or the 
Night-mare. <term lang="la">v.</term> Ghost, and 
Agast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gate(n)">Gate,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gate, 
Gaete</etym>, the same; this from 
<etym lang="oe">Gan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaen,</etym> to go.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gate(n)">Gate,</form><xpln lang="en">for Way, as they use it in 
Lincolnshire; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gat,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gasse,</etym> or the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Gade,</etym> a street, or path; 
all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gan</etym>, to Go; 
which see; and <etym lang="oe">Gate,</etym> be&shy;
fore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gather(v)">Gather,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ga&eth;e&shy;
rian</etym>, the same. Mer. Cas. 
derives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&epsilon;&iota;&shy;
&rho;&omega;</etym>, to gather.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gather(n)">Gather,</form><xpln lang="en">A sheep's Gather, from 
the other <etym lang="en">Gather;</etym> it being a 
collection, as it were, of all 
the small guts into one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gawd(n)">A Gaud,</form><xpln lang="en">or Scoff, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gaudir,</etym> to mock; also to 
quaff; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Gaudere,</etym> to rejoice, or take 
delight in, as in the misfor&shy;
tune of another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gaudy(a)">Gaudy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gaudeo,</etym> 
to be glad; because proud 
folks are much pleased with 
their gaudy, fantastick dress: 
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaude,</etym> a 
marigold; which comes from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Good,</etym> or the Teut. 
and Eng. <etym lang="bl">Gold,</etym> by reason of 
its yellow, or golden colour; 
which is the most glorious of 
all colours.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gavel(n)">Gavel,</form><xpln lang="en">a sheaf of corn; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gavelle,</etym> a 
sheaf; and this either from 
<etym lang="fr">Gerbel,</etym> the Dim. of the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gerbe,</etym> a sheaf; or from 
<etym lang="fr">Gabelle, Gabel,</etym> a tax; be&shy;
cause every tenth sheaf was 
reserved for the King's Tri&shy;
bute, both among the He&shy;
brews, and other Nations.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gavelock(n)">Gavelock,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. in &AElig;l&shy;
fricus <etym lang="oe">Gafelucas</etym>, shafts. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Iavelin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gaunt(a)">Gaunt,</form><xpln lang="en">lean; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="oe">Gewant,</etym> 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gewanian, 
Wanian</etym>, to wane, or de&shy;
crease; that is, one that hath 
lost his fat, or flesh. <term lang="la">v.</term> Wane, 
and Want.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gowk(n)">A Gawk,</form><xpln lang="en">or Cuckow, a word 
found in Somnerus; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gaec, Geac, G&aelig;c,</etym> a Cuc&shy;
kow; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gay(a)">Gay,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gay,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gaio,</etym> merry; both 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaden, Gayen,</etym> 
to please; which comes from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gaudere,</etym> to be glad. 
It is also derived from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gauw,</etym> chearful, or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gah,</etym> nimble, prompt; 
with us, one neat in apparel. 
Some draw it from the Gr.
</page>

<page sig="L4r">
<etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&alpha;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, to brag of, to be haugh&shy;
ty. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gaze(v)">To Gaze,</form><xpln lang="en">or look stedfastly at: 
Minshew draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&#x1F71;&zeta;&omega;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to admire. It 
may as plausibly be taken 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gesean</etym>, to 
look upon; or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Geachten,</etym> to attend unto.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gazette(n)">A Gazet,</form><xpln lang="en">or News-book, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gazette,</etym> the same; 
this from the Ital. in the Ven. 
Dial. <etym lang="it">Gazzetta, Gazetta,</etym> a 
small coin, of the value of 
our peny; because such News, 
or Narratives are bought com&shy;
monly for a peny; and this 
from the Lat. and Gr. Pers. 
<etym lang="gk">Gaza,</etym> a treasure;<term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="la"> Ga&shy;
zula,</etym> a little treasure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gear(n)">Gear,</form><xpln lang="en">He is in his Gears, or in 
readiness; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gearwe</etym>, ready; <etym lang="oe">Gear&shy;
wian</etym>, to make ready; which 
a Grecian Etymologist draws 
from the expletive AS. prefix 
<etym lang="oe">Ge</etym>, and the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to 
make fit. It may be drawn 
from the same <etym lang="oe">Ge</etym>, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Arwe</etym>, an arrow; be&shy;
cause, in the time of our An&shy;
cestors, famous for so many 
signal victories over the neigh&shy;
bouring nations, bows and ar&shy;
rows were their only arms, or 
war-like furniture: Or from 
the same <etym lang="oe">Ge</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Are,</etym> 
goods, or honour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geir(n)">A Geir,</form><xpln lang="en">in Higg. for a Vulture; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geyer,</etym> signi&shy;
fying the same; which comes 
from the old word <etym lang="tt">Geren,</etym> 
now <etym lang="tt">Begehren,</etym> to be gree&shy;
dy; and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Qu&aelig;rere,</etym> to seek; it being a 
sort of ravenous fowl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="geld(v)">To Geld,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gylte</etym>, 
having the stones cut off; or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghelten,</etym> to geld; 
from hence our word Gel&shy;
ding, a gelded horse; all per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geil,</etym> un&shy;
chaste, wanton; which is 
done to prevent carnal copu&shy;
lation: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gild</etym>, a child; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to make 
innocent as a child, as to the 
lusts of the flesh: Or rather, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Celan</etym>, to cool, 
to take away the spermatick 
heat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jelly(n)">A Gelly,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gel&eacute;e,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gelatina;</etym> which 
come both &agrave; <etym lang="la">Gelando,</etym> from 
thickening, or freezing; be&shy;
cause, being jellied, it repre&shy;
sents frost.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gemel(n)">Gemelles,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gemelli,</etym> twins; 
Bars Gemelles, a couple of 
bars of equal proportion eve&shy;
ry way.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gender(n)">A Gender,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gen&shy;
dre,</etym> and this from the Ablat. 
<etym lang="la">Genere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gennet(n)">A Gennet, or Ginnet-fur,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ginete;</etym> which Co&shy;
varruvius expounds, <etym lang="sp">Una 
species de Fuyina,</etym> a kind of 
Foine's skin; <term lang="la">v.</term> Foines. Per&shy;
haps so called, from <etym lang="en">Guinney,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="L4v"> 
where they are most com&shy;
mon, and from whence they 
are transported to us. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gennet(n)">Gennet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gennet,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gianetto,</etym> a Spa&shy;
nish Horse; and both from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gineta, Ginete,</etym> a 
light-armed horse-man. Co&shy;
varruvius derives them all 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&upsilon;&mu;&nu;&#x1F75;&tau;&eta;&#x03c2;</etym>, a 
light-armed Soldier. Min&shy;
shew derives our <etym lang="en">Gennet,</etym> from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Genus,</etym> a Kind; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
an horse of a good Race, or 
Breed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="genet(n)" lexeme="jenneting(n)">A Gennit, or Genniting,</form><xpln lang="en">a small 
Summer-apple; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geniwan</etym>, to renew; 
it being an apple that is soon 
ripe: Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ja&shy;
net,</etym> for <etym lang="en">Jean;</etym> for the same 
reason that we call another 
sort of apple, A Iohn-apple.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gent(n)">Gent,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gent,</etym> 
gallant, richly cloathed; a 
Contract of <etym lang="fr">Gentile.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gentle(n)" lexeme="gentles(n)" lexeme="gentils(n)">Gentels, Gentles, or Gentils,</form><xpln lang="en">
maggots; so called, from the 
gentle smoothness of their bo&shy;
dies. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gentle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gentile(a)">Gentile,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Gentle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gentle(a)">Gentle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gentil,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gentile,</etym> cour&shy;
teous, tame, mild: Hence 
Gentleman; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="il">&egrave; bona 
Gente</etym>, born of a good Coun&shy;
try, or Family. See Mena&shy;
gius.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="garb(n)">Gerbe,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; the 
same with <etym lang="en">Garb,</etym> above; which 
see, and Gripe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gyrfalcon(n)">Gerfalcon,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Ierfalcon.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gherkin(n)">Gerkin,</form><xpln lang="en">the same with Ierfalcon, 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="get(v)">Get,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Getan, 
Gettan</etym>, to obtain; and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Captare,</etym> 
to catch at a thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gewgaw(n)">Gewgiwes,</form><xpln lang="en">childrens toys; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gegaf</etym>, trifles; or 
<etym lang="oe">Heawgas</etym>, pictures, graven 
or carved images: Or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joyaux,</etym> Jewels; 
for such things are as much 
valued by children, as Jewels 
by those of understanding. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Iewels.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gherkin(n)">A Gherkin,</form><xpln lang="en">so we call a pickled 
Cucumber; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gorcken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; simply, a 
Cucumber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gueux(pn)">Gheus,</form><xpln lang="en">a French word, yet fre&shy;
quently read in the Histories 
of the Low-Countries, trans&shy;
lated into English; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gueux,</etym> a Beggar; for 
so were the Protestants called 
in the beginning of the Civil 
Commotions in those Coun&shy;
tries, and are yet so called 
there, from a banquet kept at 
the house of Florentius Pal&shy;
lan, Count of Culemburg; at 
which, the Ghests being Pro&shy;
testants, persons of Quality, 
put on the garb of Beggars, 
and were merry in their cups, 
whilst they laid a foundation 
of a Conspiracy for the liberty 
of their Religion. See Fam. 
Strad. lib. 5. Menagius de&shy;
rives this Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Gueux,</etym> from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Quaestus,</etym> gain. Some
</page>

<page sig="L5r">
draw it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vagus;</etym> 
as we say, A Vagabond. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gittern(n)">Ghittern,</form><xpln lang="en">a musical instrument; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghitterne,</etym> or 
the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Guiterne, Quiterne,</etym> 
the same; and all from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Cithara,</etym> a Cit&shy;
tern, or Harp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gizzard(n)">A Ghizzard, or Ghizzern,</form><xpln lang="en">as they 
pronounce it in Lincolnshire; 
from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Gesier, Jesier,</etym> 
the craw of a fowl; or <etym lang="fr">Gy&shy;
sier,</etym> which cometh from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Jecur,</etym> the liver; all, I 
suppose, from <etym lang="la">Gigerium;</etym> a 
word found in Festus, of the 
same signification.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ghost(n)">Ghost,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gast</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gheest,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Geyst,</etym> a spirit. Some draw it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gest</etym>, and the 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Gast,</etym> a guest; because 
the Ghost is but the Guest of 
the body: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gist, Gest</etym>, a whirl-wind, 
or blast, or puff of wind. 
They may all be derived from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gah.</etym> quickly; for 
what is more quick than a 
ghost, or blast? Mer. Cass. 
derives it from <etym lang="en">Gust;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="giant(n)">Giant,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Geant;</etym> and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gi&shy;
gas,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&#x1F77;&gamma;&alpha;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
same; this, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> &Gamma;&eta;&gamma;&eta;&nu;&#x1F74;&#x03c2;, 
born of the earth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gibe(v)">To Gibe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gabbe&shy;
ren,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaber,</etym> to 
mock: Or lastly, from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Gabbare,</etym> to deceive.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gibberish(n)">Gibberish,</form><xpln lang="en">foolish discourse; ei&shy;
ther <term lang="la">q.d.</term> Iabberish, from our 
word <etym lang="en">To Iabber;</etym> or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaber,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Gabbare,</etym> to put a trick on 
one; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> mystical talk, that 
none understand, but those 
that speak it, Rogue's lan&shy;
guage, Pedlar's French. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Iabber.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gibbet(n)">Gibbet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gibbet, 
Gibet,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giubetta,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="it">Gabalet,</etym> from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gabalum,</etym> a Gable, or 
place for the execution of cri&shy;
minals.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="giblet(n)">Giblets,</form><xpln lang="en">the offals, or entrails of 
a goose. Minshew taketh 
them to be called so, quasi 
<etym lang="en">Gobbets,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Goblets;</etym> from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gob, Gobeau,</etym> a 
mouthful, or <etym lang="en">Gobbet;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="giddy(a)">Giddy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gidig</etym>, 
vertiginous; which comes from 
<etym lang="oe">Giddian</etym>, to play like 
a fool; or <etym lang="oe">Glidan</etym>, to glide, 
or slip; whence Glid, slip&shy;
pery; and by translation, 'tis 
meant, of an unsetled mind.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gig(n)" lexeme="jig(n)">A Gig or Iig,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Giga,</etym> a little fiddle; both 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geige,</etym> or Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Gige,</etym> a violin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="giggle(v)">To Gigle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Giche&shy;
len, Gichen,</etym> to laugh wanton&shy;
ly: Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gocke&shy;
len,</etym> to jet; which is derived 
from <etym lang="tt">Geck,</etym> a fool; much 
laughter being a true indica&shy;
tion of a fool.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="L5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gigot(n)">A Gigot,</form><xpln lang="en">a French word , which 
signifies an hip. I suppose it 
to be taken from the Lat. <etym lang="fr">Ju&shy;
gum,</etym> a yoke; because it joi&shy;
neth the bones of the body 
and thigh together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gill(n)">Gill,</form><xpln lang="en">a small measure of things 
liqu<term lang="la">id.</term> Somnerus reads Gil&shy;
lo, and Gello, in his Gloss. 
perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
a kind of cup; or from <etym lang="en">Gill,</etym> 
for <etym lang="en">Juliana,</etym> a woman's name; 
as Jug, for Joan; for the 
Drunkard may be said meta&shy;
phorically, to bug the pot, as 
the Gallant hugs his Gill, or 
Miss.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gillyflower(n)">Gilliflower,</form><xpln lang="en">so called, because it 
is a flower that flourisheth in 
the month of July; or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Girofl&eacute;e,</etym> the Hisp. 
and Port. <etym lang="pt">Girofle,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Garofolo, Garifolo;</etym> all which 
come from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&rho;&upsilon;&#x1F79;&pi;&upsilon;&lambda;&shy;
&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, an Indian clove, to which 
this flower is like in scent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gill(n)">The Gills of a fish,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Lusitan. <etym lang="lu">Guelras de Peixe,</etym> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Agallas de Pesca&shy;
do,</etym> the same; which are de&shy;
rived from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Gillah,</etym> 
to open, or spread forth. 
Consult Minshew, and Dr. 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gimlet(n)">A Gimlet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gib&shy;
let, Gibelet,</etym> an instrument to 
bore holes, a piercer, these 
perhaps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zapff&shy;
let,</etym> from <etym lang="tt">Zapff,</etym> a faucet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gim(a)" lexeme="gimcrack(n)" lexeme="gin(n)">Gim, and Gimcrack, and Gin;</form><xpln lang="en">
all contracts of <etym lang="en">Engin;</etym> which 
see, and Grinn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ginger(n)">Ginger,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gengero, 
Zenzero,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gin&shy;
gembre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Zinziber;</etym> which 
comes from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Zeta;&iota;&gamma;&gamma;&#x1F77;&beta;&epsilon;&shy;
&rho;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ginger(n)">Ginger,</form><xpln lang="en">or Tingle, from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gipsy(n)">Gipsies,</form><xpln lang="en">canting vagabonds, cor&shy;
ruptly so called, because for 
their tawny colours, caused 
by the heat of the Sun, they 
are taken to be Egyptians.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gird(v)">Gird,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gyrdan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gorden,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gurten, Begurten,</etym> to gird; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gyrdel, 
Gyrdl</etym>, a girdle, and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gurt</etym>, the girt of an horse; as 
also Gurtler, a Girdler; all 
derived from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gyro,</etym> 
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&upsilon;&rho;&#x03CC;&omega;</etym>, to go 
round.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="girl(n)">Girl:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Garrula,</etym> because they 
are given to prating. It may 
also be drawn from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Givella,</etym> a weather-cock; 
which comes &agrave; <etym lang="la">Gyrando,</etym> from 
turning round; thereby de&shy;
noting their inconstancy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="girl(n)">Girle,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Hunting; sig&shy;
nifying an Hind of two years 
old; so called, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Gyrando,</etym> 
from running about.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="girn(n)">Girn,</form><xpln lang="en">for <etym lang="en">Grin,</etym> by a Metathesis. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Grin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="girt(n)">A Girt of an horse,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Gird.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guitar(n)">Gittar, or rather Ghittar,</form><xpln lang="en">a mu&shy;
sical instrument; from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ghitarra,</etym> or the Fr. G.
</page>

<page sig="L6r">
<etym lang="fr">Guiterre,</etym> the same; and all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cithara,</etym> an 
harp, the same. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="give(v)">To Give,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gifan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gheven,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geven,</etym> to give; from 
hence the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vbergeven</etym>, to 
give a thing over.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gift(n)">Gift,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gift</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghifte,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gave,</etym> a gratuity, or gift.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gyve(n)">Gives,</form><xpln lang="en">or Fetters: Some derive 
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghevangs,</etym> 
manacles; but I had rather 
draw it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ceps,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cippi,</etym> a pair of 
stocks.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glad(a)">Glad,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. and AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Glad, Gl&aelig;d, Glede,</etym> joyful, 
joy. Minshew draws it from 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Glat,</etym> 
smooth. I had rather draw it 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">L&aelig;tus,</etym> glad; 
by adding g by a Prothesis, 
and turning t into d, and the 
diphthong &aelig; into a.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glade(n)">To make a Glade</form><xpln lang="en">in a wood, 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x171;&delta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a 
bough; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> &Kappa;&lambda;&alpha;&delta;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&epsilon;&iota;&nu; &Kappa;&lambda;&alpha;&shy;
&delta;&omicron;&tau;&omicron;&mu;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;, to cut down boughs.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glance(v)">To Glance,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Glantzen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Glant&shy;
sen,</etym> to shine; whence the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Glantz</etym>, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Glants</etym>, a glance; all from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eslancer,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Sclanciare,</etym> to glitter like 
a lance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glander(n)">The Glanders:</form><xpln lang="en">the learned Dr. 
Th. H. derives it from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Glandules,</etym> which signifieth 
the same. Consult Mark&shy;
ham.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glare(v)">To Glare,</form><xpln lang="en">or strain the eyes with 
looking too intently upon the 
light; perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Glaerende ooghen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Glaer 
ooghigh,</etym> blue-eyed; which 
come from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Esclairer,</etym> to shine; and this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Clarare,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Excla&shy;
rare,</etym> to make to shine, or 
sparkle; for he that hath blue 
eyes sees clearer than if his 
eyes were gray or black, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glass(n)">Glass,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gl&aelig;s</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Glas, Ghelas,</etym> or the 
Teut. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Glasz,</etym> the 
same; these perhaps from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Glac,</etym> and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Glatt,</etym> smooth, slippery; or 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Glacies,</etym> ice; 
unto which it is like: <term lang="la">v.</term> Gal&shy;
ly-pot. Minshew and Mar&shy;
tin. draw it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gleissen,</etym> to glister; from 
hence comes the Dan. <etym lang="da">Time-&shy;
glass</etym>; with us, An Hour-&shy;
Glass.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gleam(n)">Gleam,</form><xpln lang="en">Warm Gleams, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leoma,</etym> light; or <etym lang="oe">Leo&shy;
man</etym>, to shine; and both 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lumen,</etym> 
light.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glean(v)">To Glean,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gla&shy;
ner,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sglanare,</etym> to 
gather ears of corn after reap&shy;
ing; which is supposed to 
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Grana,</etym> 
grains of corn, by changing r 
into l.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glaive(n)">A Gleave, or Glaive,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Glaive;</etym> and both
</page>

<page sig="L6v">
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gladius,</etym> a 
sword. Davis derives it from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Glaif,</etym> a reaping-&shy;
hook. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glede(n)">A Glede,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glida</etym>, 
a Kite; this from <etym lang="oe">Glidan</etym>, to 
glide, or slip down; because 
she cometh down swiftly up&shy;
on her prey.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glee(n)">Glee,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glie</etym>, 
joy; or <etym lang="oe">Gleowian</etym>, to jest, or re&shy;
joice. Minshew derives it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Glooren,</etym> to be 
refreshed. I may draw our 
word Glee, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glie</etym>, 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&#x1F73;&lambda;&omega;&#x03c2;</etym>, laugh&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gleek(n)">Gleek,</form><xpln lang="en">a Play at Cards; either 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gluck,</etym> luck, 
or fortune; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gelic</etym>, or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gleich,</etym> 
like.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glib(a)">Glib,</form><xpln lang="en">smooth, or slippery; per&shy;
haps (by a Prothesis &tau;&omicron;&upsilon; G, 
and by an easie Metaplasmus 
of ae into i, and of v conso&shy;
nant into b) from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">L&aelig;vis,</etym> slippery, or smooth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glide(v)">Glide,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glidan</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gliiden,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Glitschen,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Glisser,</etym> to slip, 
or slide; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glid</etym>, 
slippery.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glimmering(n)">A Glimmering,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Glimmer, Glimrer,</etym> to shine 
out faintly; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Glomang</etym>, the twi-light; 
or from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Gleam;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glimpse(n)">Glimpie,</form><xpln lang="en">either from <etym lang="en">Glimme&shy;
ring,</etym> or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gleis&shy;
sen,</etym> to glissen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glisten(v)">To Glissen, or Glisten;</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Gli&shy;
ster.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glister(v)">To Glister,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gli&shy;
steren,</etym> to sparkle; or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gleissen, Glitzen, Glitzern,</etym> to 
Glitter; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gleet(n)">Glitt,</form><xpln lang="en">thin matter issuing out of 
the nervous parts, when they 
are bruised, or hurt; perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gliedwasser,</etym> 
by the figure Ellipsis; this 
from <etym lang="tt">Glied,</etym> a limb, and <etym lang="tt">Was&shy;
ser,</etym> water; or perhaps from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gliiden,</etym> to glide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glitter(v)">Glitter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glites&shy;
san</etym>, to shine, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Glitzen, Glitzern,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Glicken,</etym> to be bright. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gli&shy;
ster.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glare(v)">To Gloar,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Glor&shy;
ren, Gluyeren,</etym> to look askew; 
or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gloeyen,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gluen,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Glowan</etym>, to glow, or spar&shy;
kle, by a Metaphor taken from 
fire. <term lang="la">v.</term> To Lowre.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gloomy(a)">Gloomy,</form><xpln lang="en">somewhat dark. Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Glimmen,</etym> to shine faintly, by 
an Antiphrasis. I had rather 
draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glo&shy;
mung,</etym> the twi-light; and 
this from <etym lang="oe">Leoma</etym>, light. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Gleamy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gloze(v)">Glose,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glesan</etym>, 
to favour; and this from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gleissen,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gli&shy;
tenan</etym>, to shine; the word 
implying, to speak fair, as to
</page>

<page sig="L7r"> 
an outward appearance, to 
collogue. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gloss(n)">Gloss,</form><xpln lang="en">The Gloss of colours, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gleissen,</etym> to shine; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> the brightness of any thing 
which it receiveth by art.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glove(n)">Glove,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glof</etym>, the 
same. Minshew draws it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gheloove,</etym> 
faithfulness; or from <etym lang="en">Gift 
Love.</etym> I had rather draw it 
from the old Eng. <etym lang="oe">Gol,</etym> the 
hand, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ob,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ober</etym>, over; be&shy;
cause it is put over, or upon 
the hand.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glow(v)">To Glow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glowan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gloeyen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gluen,</etym> to shine; from 
hence, A Glow-worm; that 
is, a worm that gloweth, or 
shineth like a torch by night.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glow(v)" lexeme="glout(v)">To Glow, or Glout;</form><xpln lang="en">in Gould&shy;
man, To Stare. <term lang="la">v.</term> To <etym lang="en">Gloar.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glow-worm(n)">Glow-worm,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Glow.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glue(n)">Glue,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Glu,</etym> the 
same; whence <etym lang="fr">Gluer</etym>, to glue; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gluten,</etym> <term lang="la">id.</term> 
which Fr. Jun. derives from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&lambda;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, a word found 
in Suidas, of the same signi&shy;
fication.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glum(a)">Glum,</form><xpln lang="en">To be Glum, as they say 
in Lincolnshire; it signifies 
as much as Sullen; perhaps 
from <etym lang="en">Gloomy;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glut(v)">To Glut,</form><xpln lang="en">or satiate himself, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Glutio,</etym> to gulp, or 
swallow: <term lang="la">v.</term> Glutton. Mer. 
Cas. derives it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&gamma;&gamma;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&sigma;&epsilon;&iota;&nu; ;;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&gamma;&gamma;&lambda;&upsilon;&kappa;&#x1F71;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, 
to sweeten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glutton(n)">Glutton,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Glou&shy;
ton,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gloton,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ghiotto, Ghiottone,</etym> the 
same: Or it may be derived 
&agrave; <etym lang="la">Glutiendo,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Deglutiendo,</etym> 
from swallowing, or glutting 
down; from hence the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Gloutonnie</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ghi&shy;
ottonia</etym>; with us, Gluttony.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="glee(v)">To Gly,</form><xpln lang="en">as they say in Lincoln&shy;
shire; it signifies, to look a&shy;
squint; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Glowan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gloeyen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gluen,</etym> to spar&shy;
kle. <term lang="la">v.</term> Glow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnarl(v)">To Gnarl, or Gnarr,</form><xpln lang="en">to grin like 
an angry dog; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Knarren, Snarren,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knarten, Knirren,</etym> to 
snarl. <term lang="la">v.</term> To Gnash, or Gnarr.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnash(v)">To Gnash, or Gnarr,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gnyrran</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Knarren, Knaschen, Knars&shy;
chen,</etym> the same; all from the 
sound. <term lang="la">v.</term> Knaw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnat(n)">Gnat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gn&aelig;t</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schnack,</etym> signifying 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnat-snapper(n)">Gnat-Snapper,</form><xpln lang="en">a bird so called, 
because it snappeth, or catch&shy;
eth Gnats, which it feedeth 
upon. <term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Gnat.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gnaw(v)">Gnaw,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gn&aelig;gan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knaghen, Knauwen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nagen,</etym> the same. 
It alludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&nu;&#x03AC;&omega;</etym>, to 
scrape; or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&nu;&alpha;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to crop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goad(n)">Goad,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gaad</etym>, the same; also a sharp point of 
any thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goal(n)">Goal,</form><xpln lang="en">or the staff which a Racer
</page>

<page sig="L7v">
intendeth for; either as Min&shy;
shew hath it, from <etym lang="en">Goe,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">All;</etym> because we all go to, or 
aim at some Goal; that is, 
some end, or other; or ra&shy;
ther, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Doel,</etym> the 
same. Dr. Th. H. derives it 
most ingeniously from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gaule,</etym> a pole; which is 
often set up for a Goal to be 
run to. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gore(n)">A Goar of a garment,</form><xpln lang="en">a piece 
sewed unto another; from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Goror,</etym> a border, 
hem, or seam, both possibly 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ora,</etym> an hem.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gore(v)">To Goar,</form><xpln lang="en">or prick through; ei&shy;
ther as Mins. hath it from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Forare,</etym> to make an hole 
through; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term> To <etym lang="en">Go over, or ore:</etym> 
Or it is a contract of 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geborian</etym>, to bore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goat(n)">A Goat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">G&aelig;te, 
G&aelig;t</etym>; in Elfricus, Gat, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gheete, Gheyte,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geisz,</etym> the same; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">G&aelig;te-&shy;
hierde</etym>, a Goat-herd. It 
may also be drawn from the 
Gr. barb. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&#x1F77;&delta;&alpha;</etym>, a she-goat; 
and this from <etym lang="gk">&Alpha;&#x1F30;&gamma;&#x1F77;&delta;&alpha;</etym>, the Ac&shy;
cus. of <etym lang="gk">&Alpha;&#x1F30;&gamma;&#x1F76;&#x03c2;</etym>, which comes 
from <etym lang="gk">&Alpha;&#x1F34;&zeta;</etym>, a goat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gobbet(n)" lexeme="gob(n)">A Gobbet, and Gob,</form><xpln lang="en">a great sop, 
or morsel; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Gober,</etym> to swallow greedily; 
<etym lang="fr">Gobeau, Gob,</etym> a mouthful; 
this from <etym lang="fr">Couper,</etym> to chop in 
pieces.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gobble(v)">To Gobble,</form><xpln lang="en">or eat voraciously. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Gobbet,</etym> above.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goblet(n)">Goblet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gobe&shy;
let,</etym> a greater kind of Chalice; 
perhaps <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="fr">Couppelette,</etym> a 
little cup; <term lang="la">v.</term> Cup. Dr. Th. 
H. draws it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Gober,</etym> to swallow.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goblin(n)">Goblins</form><xpln lang="en">or Fayries: Minshew 
draws it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Go&shy;
ber,</etym> to devour greedily. They 
may be so called possibly 
from <etym lang="en">Oberon,</etym> 
the feigned King 
of Fayries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="God(n)">God,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God,</etym> Dan-
<etym lang="da">Gud,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Goed,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gott,</etym> the same; this from 
<etym lang="tt">Gutt,</etym> good; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> good in 
the Abstract, Goodness it self. 
Hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Godsuna</etym>, a 
God-son, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="God-a-mercy(n)">God-a-mercy:</form><xpln lang="en">Dr. Th. H. sup&shy;
poseth it the same as Gramer&shy;
cy; which see. I suppose it 
is rather used for <etym lang="en">God have 
mercy.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="godwit(n)">A Godwit,</form><xpln lang="en">or Quail, as Rider 
hath it; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, 
good, and <etym lang="oe">Wita</etym>, a wise man; 
or rather, rich man; because 
it is a fowl that is seldom ser&shy;
ved up, but at great men's ta&shy;
bles: Or from the same <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, 
good, and <etym lang="oe">Wihta</etym>, an ani&shy;
mal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="go(v)">Goe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gan</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ge&shy;
hen,</etym> to go; whence the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Angehen</etym>, to invade, and <etym lang="tt">Ab&shy;
gehen</etym>, to go off, as in sale.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gog(n)">Gog,</form><xpln lang="en">He is A-Gog for it; that 
is, he earnestly, or greatly de&shy;
sires
</page>

<page sig="L8r"> 
such or such a thing. It 
may (with a little variation of 
the sence) be derived from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gogues,</etym> great delight; 
or <etym lang="fr">Se Goguer,</etym> to gratifie him&shy;
self, to fare splendidly. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goggle-eyed(a)">Gogle-eyed;</form><xpln lang="en">that is, one whose 
eyes stand out staring, and 
bigger than ordinary; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gogue,</etym> a kind of 
pudding made in a sheep's 
great gut, being a mixture of 
sweet herbs, small pieces of 
bacon, spices, eggs, cheese, and 
the blood of the sheep newly 
killed; which, in boiling, does 
swell and distend the skin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gold(n)">Gold,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Teut. 
<etym lang="da">Gold</etym>, the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Guold,</etym> 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Guld,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Goul,</etym> the same; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Goldfinc</etym>, a Gold-finch, 
and <etym lang="oe">Gildan</etym>, to gild; as also 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gulden</etym>, and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Guelden</etym>, golden; whence the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Guldeling</etym>, and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gulding</etym>, a Golding-apple; all 
perhaps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gel&shy;
ren</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghelden,</etym> to 
value.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="golden-eye(n)">Goldeny,</form><xpln lang="en">a fish so called, from its 
golden colour and spots: Or q. 
<etym lang="en">Golden-eye,</etym> its eyes being of 
the colour of gold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gold-hammer(n)">Gold-hammer,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gold-ammer, Gold-hammer,</etym> 
a bird so named, from its gol&shy;
den colour; and <etym lang="tt">Hammer,</etym> 
which cometh either from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hamme,</etym> the hamm, or 
leg; or from the other <etym lang="en">Hamme,</etym> 
a meadow; because it most 
an end feedeth and bideth in 
meadows.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"gold-hammer" antedates earliest OED citation (1706).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goll(n)">Golls,</form><xpln lang="en">the hands; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> Walls, 
or Walds; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Walten,</etym> to 
wield, or direct; because with 
our hands we direct and order 
our business; there being a 
certain affinity between W, 
and G; as in Guardian, War&shy;
den; Guard, Ward, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="good(a)">Good,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Goed,</etym> or the Teut. and 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="tt">Gut,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. What if 
it be taken &agrave; <etym lang="la">Gaudendo,</etym> from 
rejoicing?</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goodman(n)">Goodman,</form><xpln lang="en">a Country-term, or&shy;
dinary amongst the poorer 
sort of people; so called, quasi 
<etym lang="en">Good man:</etym> Which custom is 
common to the Inhabitants 
of Tuscany to this day, who 
call their men of mean rank, 
<term lang="it">Buon huomo</term>; that is, good 
man, or honest man. Som&shy;
nerus thinketh that it comes 
from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Gomman,</etym> an 
house-holder, or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gu&shy;
ma,</etym> an husband.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gool(n)">Gool,</form><xpln lang="en">frequently used in Lin&shy;
colnshire for a ditch, or pud&shy;
dle; not unlikely, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gouw,</etym> a water-wear: 
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaule, 
Gaiole;</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caveola,</etym> 
a prison, or Gaol: because 
when we fall into such a ditch, 
we are held, as it were, in jail: 
Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geweallian, 
Weallian,</etym> to bubble up as 
spring-water.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="L8v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goose(n)">Goose,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gos</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Goose, Goes,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Gaasz,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gourd(n)">A Gord of water,</form><xpln lang="en">in Gouldman; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gourd,</etym> or 
<etym lang="fr">Gourt,</etym> a brook running only 
in rainy weather; this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gurges,</etym> a gulf, or 
whirl-pool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gore(n)">Gore,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gore</etym>, 
blood; or <etym lang="oe">Gor,</etym> filth; the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Voor,</etym> matter, corrup&shy;
tion; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Goor,</etym> mud; 
or the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gor,</etym> snot; which 
Davis draws from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F3C;&chi;&omega;&rho;</etym>, corrupt matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gorbellied(a)">Gore-bellied,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gore,</etym> gore; <etym lang="oe">Gor</etym>, filth; 
and <etym lang="en">Belly;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one whose 
paunch being stuffed with 
corrupt and unwholesome 
blood, and fat stands out more 
than ordinary.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gorge(v)">To Gorge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gor&shy;
ger, Engorger,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Ingorgiare,</etym> the same; this 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gorge,</etym> the 
gullet, or wind-pipe: Or pos&shy;
sibly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gurges,</etym> a 
whirl-pool; because what is 
put down the throat, is hardly 
revoked.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gorgeous(a)">Gorgeous,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gorrier,</etym> of the same sence. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&alpha;&rho;&gamma;&alpha;&#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to glitter. 
They may all be derived from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Glorieux,</etym> in Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Gloriosus,</etym> self-conceited, foo&shy;
lish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gorget(n)">A Gorget,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gor&shy;
gietta, Gorgiera,</etym> or the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gorgerin,</etym> a collar; so cal&shy;
led because it covereth the 
throat; which in Lat. is called 
<etym lang="la">Gurges.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gormandize(v)">Gormandize,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Gourmandise,</etym> voracity; <etym lang="fr">Gour&shy;
mander,</etym> to eat greedily; or 
<etym lang="fr">Gourmand,</etym> a glutton: Ac&shy;
cording to Cambd. from the 
old Brit. or Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gormod,</etym> too 
much of a thing; this from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gor,</etym> over, and <etym lang="cb">Mod,</etym> 
measure; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to eat beyond 
measure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gorrara(n)">Gorrara,</form><xpln lang="en">a word only found in a 
book called <f type="i">The Compleat 
Angler</f>. I take it to be a bird 
that preyeth upon fishes; per&shy;
haps from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gorra,</etym> an 
hat.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"gorrara" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gosling(n)">Gosling,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Goosling, a young 
goose; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gos</etym>, a 
goose, and the dim. termina&shy;
tion <etym lang="oe">ling.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gospel(n)">Gospel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God&shy;
spell</etym>, or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Got&shy;
spel,</etym> the same; whence Got&shy;
spellon, to preach the Gospel; 
both from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, 
or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Got,</etym> God, 
good, and <etym lang="hd">Spell</etym>, an history; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> a divine history, or re&shy;
velation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gorse(n)">Goss, or Gors,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Georis, Georst</etym>, heath, 
or ling.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gossamer(n)">Gossemeer,</form><xpln lang="en">a word found in a 
book entituled <f type="i">The French 
Gardener</f>; where it is ex&shy;
pounded, the light down that
</page>

<page sig="M1r"> 
is blown off the Sow-thistle. 
The Author of an English Di&shy;
ctionary giveth this name to 
the morning dew; which, 
like to a cob-web, it spreads 
all the fields over, especially 
in the time of drought; 
which in the Teut. is called 
<term lang="tt">Vnser Frawen haar</term>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
hair of the Virgin Mary; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gossampine;</etym> 
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gossy&shy;
pium,</etym> cotton, for the simili&shy;
tude of it. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="goshawk(n)">Goss-hawk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gos&shy;
hafoc</etym>, the same; and this from 
<etym lang="oe">Gos</etym>, a goose, and <etym lang="oe">Hafoc</etym>, 
an hawk; because it pursueth 
geese: Or as Minshew hath 
it, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Gross-hawk;</etym> that is, 
a great hawk.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gossip(n)">Gossips,</form><xpln lang="en">or God-fathers at the 
baptism of a child, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">God,</etym> God, and <etym lang="oe">Syb, 
Sybbe,</etym> kindred; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a 
kins-man in God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="govern(v)">To Govern,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gou&shy;
verner,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Governa&shy;
re;</etym> and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gu&shy;
berno,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&upsilon;&beta;&epsilon;&rho;&nu;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, 
the same<emend err=" ">.</emend></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gound(n)">Gound,</form><xpln lang="en">matter issuing out of the 
eyes; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gund,</etym> 
gore, putrefied matter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gourd(n)">A Gourd</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gou&shy;
hourde, Couhourde, Courge, 
Cougourde, Cowrde;</etym> all con&shy;
tracted from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cucur&shy;
bita,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gout(n)">Gout,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Goutte,</etym> 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Gotta, le Gotte,</etym> Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Gota,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gicht,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Ghichte,</etym> the same; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="la">Gut&shy;
ta,</etym> a drop; because it is an 
humour that falleth down, as 
it were, by drops, into the 
joints. It is rightly called by 
modern Greeks, <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&omicron;&#x1F79;&sigma;&omicron;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, that 
is to say, Gout-sore.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gown(n)">Gown,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gonna,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gonnelle,</etym> or the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Gwn,</etym> the same: This Fr. 
Jun. draws from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Gwnio,</etym> to sow: <term lang="la">v.</term> Robe. It 
may also be taken from the 
Gr. barb <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&omicron;&#x1F79;&nu;&alpha;, &Gamma;&omicron;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F70;&sigma;, &Gamma;&omicron;&upsilon;&nu;&#x03AF;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, 
a skin. Minshew draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&#x1F79;&nu;&upsilon;</etym>, a knee; 
because it covereth, or reach&shy;
eth below the knees: Or from 
the Heb. <etym lang="het">Ghan,</etym> it hath cove&shy;
red; or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gau&shy;
nace,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F71;&kappa;&eta;</etym>; 
which, in Aristophanes, sig&shy;
nifieth, a coverlet, or thick 
napped cloth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gout(n)">Gowts,</form><xpln lang="en">a word much used in So&shy;
mersetshire, signifying canals, 
or pipes under ground; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gouttes,</etym> drops; 
whence comes the Verb <etym lang="fr">Es&shy;
gouter</etym>, to run down drop by 
drop; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gut&shy;
ta,</etym> a drop. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gatter.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="graff(n)">Graff,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Greffe,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Greffle,</etym> the same; 
and these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Greffer,</etym> and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grefflen,</etym> 
to plant, or graft. Menagius 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gra&shy;
phium,</etym> a pencil<emend err=" ">.</emend></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grain(n)">Grain,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grain,</etym> 
corn; and both from the Lat.
</page>

<page sig="M1v">
<etym lang="la">Granum,</etym> a grain. It is also 
taken for a colour to dye with. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Chermes, and Crimson. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gramercy(ex)">Gramercy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Grammercy,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gran&shy;
merc&egrave;, Grammerci&egrave;</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
<etym lang="la">Grandem mercedem det tibi 
Deus,</etym> that is, God give you 
a great reward.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grammar(n)">Grammar,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Grammaire,</etym> the same; and 
from thence <etym lang="fr">Grammairien</etym>, a 
Grammarian; all from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&#x1F71;&mu;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, a letter; because 
it teacheth the art of writing 
and speaking truly and pro&shy;
perly; or because it is the 
foundation of all learning.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grampell(n)">Grample,</form><xpln lang="en">a word read in an 
English Dictionary; where it 
is expounded, a Sea-Crab; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grampelle,</etym> 
the same; this from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Granchio,</etym> a crab; and both 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krampe,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crampon,</etym> a cram&shy;
ping-iron, or hook; because 
the cleys of this fish are like to 
hooks: Or lastly, from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cancer,</etym> a crab.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grampus(n)">Grampus,</form><xpln lang="en">the greater kind of 
whale; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Grand Poise,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Poisson,</etym> a 
great fish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grenade(n)">A Granado,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Gra&shy;
nada de fuego,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Grenade,</etym> a fire-ball; so cal&shy;
led because it is made like a 
Pomegranate; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grandam(n)">Grandam,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Grand,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Dam;</etym> which see; <term lang="la">q. d.</term> a 
grand, ancient mother, or 
dam.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grandeur(n)">Grandeur,</form><xpln lang="en">pomp, or state, by a 
little variation of the sence; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grandeur,</etym> 
dignity, highness; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Grandis,</etym> great, 
mighty, potent.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grange(n)">Grange,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grange,</etym> 
a garner, or barn; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Granum,</etym> grain. 
In Lincolnshire, and else&shy;
where, it is put for an house, 
or parcel of ground being far 
distant from any other houses, 
or towns; perhaps because 
such houses are commonly 
furnished with garners, or gra&shy;
naries; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gra&shy;
naia, Grancia,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Granja,</etym> 
a Country-farm, or tenement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gransire(n)">Gransire,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Grand,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Sire;</etym> which see; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a 
grand, ancient father, or sire.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grant(v)">To Grant:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gratuito,</etym> frank&shy;
ly, or freely. I had rather 
draw it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ga&shy;
rentir,</etym> to warrant. <term lang="la">v.</term> To 
Warrant.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grape(n)">Grape,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grappe,</etym> 
which now with them signi&shy;
fies a cluster, though hereto&shy;
fore taken to signifie a grape, 
according to the reverend Dr. 
Heinshaw; or from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Grappola, Graspola, Graspolo,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krap, Krapp;</etym> 
the same; which comes, not 
unlikely, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grii&shy;
pen,</etym> to gripe, or squeeze with 
the fist: Though Menagius 
derives them all from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trauv,</etym> a branch, or
</page>

<page sig="M2r">
grape; and this from the Fr. 
Th. <etym lang="hd">Rebon,</etym> which Fr. Jun. 
reads <etym lang="hd">Reuon</etym>, vines. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grapple(v)">Grapple,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grab&shy;
belen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Krappeln,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grappare,</etym> to catch 
hold of, to snatch greedily at 
a thing; whence the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Grappa, Grappello</etym>, an hook; 
all from the Verb, To <etym lang="en">Gripe;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grass(n)">Grase,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Grass, and Graster.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="graze(v)">To Grase;</form><xpln lang="en">The bullet Grased, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) ran along the ground, 
but enter'd not; perhaps from 
<etym lang="la">Ex</etym> and <etym lang="la">Rasare,</etym> the Frequen&shy;
tative of <etym lang="la">Radere,</etym> to shave, or 
scrape.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grazier(n)">A Grasier,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Grasier,</etym> the same; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Gras,</etym> fat, or our Eng. <etym lang="en">Grass:</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grasp(v)">Grasp,</form><xpln lang="en">to embrace, or take hold 
of; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Graspare,</etym> 
the same. <term lang="la">v.</term> Grapple, and Gripe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grass(n)">Grass,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gr&aelig;s, 
G&aelig;rs</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grass, 
Gars,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grasz,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">G&aelig;r-&shy;
shop</etym>, in the Teut. and Eng. 
a Grass-hopper. It may pos&shy;
sibly come from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Growan</etym>, to grow; q d. 
<etym lang="oe">Growas, Groas</etym>, that which 
groweth all the fields over.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grate(v)">To Grate,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gra&shy;
ter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grattare</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Corradere,</etym> to scrape.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grate(n)">A Grate of iron,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Grata,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Grada;</etym> this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Crates,</etym> the same; 
and this again from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&alpha;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to contain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grave(v)">To Grave,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gra&shy;
fan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Graven, Gra&shy;
veren,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Graben,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Graver,</etym> the same. 
It seems manifestly to come 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&#x1F70;&phi;&omega;</etym>, to write; 
or <etym lang="oe">&Gamma;&lambda;&#x1F71;&phi;&omega;</etym>, to grave.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grave(n)">A Grave</form><xpln lang="en">for the dead, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gr&aelig;f, Gr&aelig;fe,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Graf, Grave,</etym> the same: 
Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Graven,</etym> to 
dig; or Grave, as they express 
it in Lincolnshire: Or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grub,</etym> a sepulchre; 
or <etym lang="tt">Gruben,</etym> to delve; from 
hence cometh our Eng. To 
Grub.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grave(su)">Grave</form><xpln lang="en">, as Palts-grave, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gerefa,</etym> a Governor, or 
Consul, as &AElig;lfricus hath it; 
this from the expletive Initial 
<etym lang="oe">Ge</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Reafian</etym>, to exact, 
to despoil: Or from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Greffve,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grave, Graf, 
Graef,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Graffe,</etym> a Vis&shy;
count; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Rapere,</etym> to take by force; be&shy;
cause Graves perhaps were on&shy;
ly as griping Publicans, or 
Task-masters in the ancient 
German Empire; or rather, 
Princes Accomptants, as Jul. 
Capitol. calls them; but they 
are now come to greater ho&shy;
nour: From hence Burgrave, 
Landgrave, Margrave, that 
is, a Grave of a Borough, 
Lands, or Marches.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grave(v)">To Grave</form><xpln lang="en">a ship, to clean it, and
</page>

<page sig="M2v">
pitch it a-new; perhaps, by a 
little varying the sence, from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krauwen,</etym> to scrape. 
See Manwayring in Dict. 
Naut. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gravel(n)">Gravel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gra&shy;
velle, Gravois,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gra&shy;
vella,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gravel;</etym> 
all signifying the same: Or it 
may perhaps come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Glareola,</etym> the same, by 
changing l into r, and r into 
v: Or &agrave; <etym lang="la">Gravando,</etym> from load&shy;
ing; because ships are bal&shy;
lasted with it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grey(n)">A Gray,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Graio,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grisard,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grevel,</etym> a Gray, or Bad&shy;
ger; so called from its gray 
colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grey(a)">Gray,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Graeg</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Graa,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Grauw,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or possibly 
from the Run. Dan. <etym lang="da">Gram,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gris,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Grigio, Griso,</etym> ash-coloured.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grayling(n)">A Grayling,</form><xpln lang="en">a kind of fish, 
which is also called an <etym lang="en">Vm&shy;
ber;</etym> from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Umbre, 
Umbrete,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Um&shy;
bra,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; perhaps it is so 
called from its gray, or ash-&shy;
colour; for which reason the 
Dutch call it <etym lang="du">Asche.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grease(n)">Grease,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Graisse,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grasso, Grascia,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Crassus,</etym> thick, big; because big, 
corpulent bodies abound with 
fat. It alludes to the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&#x1F71;&sigma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, filth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="great(a)">Great,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Great</etym>, 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Groz,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Groot,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grosz,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gross,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grosso,</etym> gross, big; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Crassus,</etym> 
thick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="greave(n)">Greaves,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Greves,</etym> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Grevas,</etym> armour 
for the legs; these from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Greve,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Greva,</etym> 
the shank; or from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Gravis,</etym> heavy.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gree(n)">Gree,</form><xpln lang="en">in Gouldman; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gra&shy;
do,</etym> the will, or consent of the mind; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Gratum,</etym> a thing acceptable, 
or well pleasing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="greedy(a)">Greedy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gr&aelig;dig</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gretigh,</etym> the 
same; whence <etym lang="bl">Greten, Grey&shy;
ten</etym>, to covet greatly; all per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Begeren,</etym> 
or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Geran,</etym> to co&shy;
vet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="green(n)">Green,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grene</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grun,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Groen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or perhaps 
from our word <etym lang="en">Grow;</etym> be&shy;
cause most vegetative plants 
are of a green colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="greenfinch(n)">A Green-finch,</form><xpln lang="en">a bird so called, 
from its <etym lang="en">green</etym> colour. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Finch.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grece(n)">Greese, Griece, Greices,</form><xpln lang="en">or 
Stairs; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Degrees,</etym> as 
Minshew hath it: Or rather, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gr&egrave;,</etym> in the 
plur. <etym lang="fr">Grez;</etym> and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gradus,</etym> a step, or 
stair; or <etym lang="la">Gressus,</etym> a pace.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="greet(v)">To Greet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gre&shy;
tan</etym>,
</page>

<page sig="M3r">
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Groeten, Grue&shy;
ten,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grussen,</etym> to 
salute one; whence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gretan sendan</etym>, to send 
greeting. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grieve(v)">To Greeve,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gre&shy;
ver,</etym> to vex; or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gre&shy;
ve,</etym> grief; or <etym lang="it">Gravoso,</etym> grie&shy;
vous; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gra&shy;
vare,</etym> to burthen, or load.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="greyhound(n)">Grey-hound,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Grighund,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grevel;</etym> with us, a 
Grey, or Badger; and <etym lang="bl">Hund,</etym> 
an Hound; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a Dog that 
hunteth the Grey, or Badger. 
Minshew supposeth that it is 
so called, q. <etym lang="la">Gr&aelig;cus Canis,</etym> a 
Grecian dog; because the 
Greeks were the first that 
made use of such dogs for 
hunting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gridiron(n)">A Grid-iron,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Grate-iron. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Grate,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Iron.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="griffin(n)">A Griffin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grif&shy;
fon,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Griffone,</etym> or the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Grifo,</etym> the same: Or 
perhaps it is so called from its 
great claws; for <etym lang="en">Griffe</etym> signi&shy;
fies, the talons, or claws of 
birds of prey: <term lang="la">v.</term> Gripe. It 
may also be derived from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&#x1F7A;&psi;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this 
from <etym lang="oe">&Gamma;&rho;&upsilon;&pi;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, crooked.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grig(n)">A Grig,</form><xpln lang="en">the smallest kind of 
Eel; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Crecca</etym>, 
the brink of a river, under 
which they mostly lie, and in&shy;
crease.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grime(v)">To Grime,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Be&shy;
griemen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Beghremen,</etym> to 
make black, to stain, to dis&shy;
guise; or from <etym lang="en">Grimm,</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grim(a)">Grimm,</form><xpln lang="en">one that hath a glout&shy;
ing, austere look; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Grim, Gram</etym>, testy, 
cruel; the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grimm,</etym> an&shy;
ger, or <etym lang="tt">Gram,</etym> angry, enra&shy;
ged; or the Run. Dan. <etym lang="da">Grimt,</etym> 
cruel. Fr. Jun. derives them 
all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&upsilon;&mu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
cold of winter. I should ra&shy;
ther chuse to draw it from 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&iota;&mu;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, acid, sowre.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grind(v)">Grind,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grindan</etym>, 
to grind; whence <etym lang="oe">Grind&shy;
to&eth;as</etym>, the teeth called the 
grinders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grin(v)">Grin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grennian, 
Grinian</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Greynsen, Griinen,</etym> to whet 
the teeth as a boar doth his 
tushes: <term lang="la">v.</term> Girn. Some also 
derive it from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gyn,</etym> 
the jaw; which we may draw 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cinan</etym>, to gape.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grin(n)" lexeme="ginn(n)">Grinn, more usually Ginn,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grine</etym>, a trap, or 
snare. Minshew draws it from <etym lang="en">Engin;</etym> which see: Or 
from the Goth. <etym lang="go">Griuher,</etym> a 
snare.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gripe(v)">Gripe,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gripan, 
Begripan,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term> (whence 
<etym lang="oe">Grife</etym>, griping, niggardly) 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Griipen,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Greiffen,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gripper, <term lang="la">idem</term>:</etym> 
There is also in the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Griffer,</etym> and in the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grif&shy;
fare,</etym>
</page>

<page sig="M3v">
to gripe; all possi&shy;
bly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Corripere,</etym> 
to catch hold of. Mer. Cas. 
derives our word <etym lang="en">Gripings,</etym> 
that is, the gripings of the 
guts, from the Gr <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&eta;&pi;&#x1F79;&mu;&epsilon;&shy;
&nu;&alpha;</etym>; which in Hesychius, is ex&shy;
pounded &Sigma;&upsilon;&nu;&epsilon;&lambda;&kappa;&#x1F79;&mu;&theta;&iota;&alpha;, clung, 
or shrunk up; and Gilpe, 
from <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&iota;&pi;&#x1F77;&zeta;&omega;</etym>. Abr. Myl. 
draws it from <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&iota;&pi;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, to 
fish with the hands. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grip(n)">A Gripp,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grep, 
Graep,</etym> a ditch; the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Greppe, Grubbe, Gruype,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grube,</etym> a ditch; 
these from <etym lang="tt">Graven,</etym> to dig. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Grave.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grisly(a)">Grisly,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grislic</etym>, 
rough, squalid; and this from 
the Verb <etym lang="oe">Agrisan</etym>, to look 
frightfully.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grist(n)">Grist</form><xpln lang="en">, Grice, or Grees, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Grist</etym>, grinding; or 
from <etym lang="oe"> Grindan</etym>, to grind; 
or from <etym lang="oe">Gerst</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gheerste,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gersten,</etym> bar&shy;
ley.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gristle(n)">Gristle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gristle, 
Grisle</etym>, the same; both per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Crustula,</etym> a 
crust.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grit(n)">A Grit,</form><xpln lang="en">a word found in the 
English Dictionary, where it 
is expounded, a kind of Cra&shy;
fish; perhaps from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Grater,</etym> to grate, or scrape; 
because with its sharp fins, or 
prickles upon its back, it rub&shy;
beth or pricketh the hands of 
them that touch it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grit(n)">Gritt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gretta</etym>, 
brann; the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grezzo,</etym> 
rough; or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grez,</etym> a 
certain rough stone.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="groat(n)">A Groat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gros,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grosso,</etym> gross, or 
great. It is a certain coin, in 
value four pence; so called 
from its greatness, or quanti&shy;
ty; because formerly perhaps 
it was a brass, or iron coin.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grocer(n)">Grocers:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew saith, that at 
the first, as he proves out of 
our Laws, they used to sell 
nothing by little parcels; but 
all things <etym lang="it">al Grosso,</etym> by the 
great, <term lang="la">i.e.</term> by whole-sale. 
Or they may be so called, <etym lang="la">&agrave; 
Grossis,</etym> from figs; which 
they mainly trade in. In our 
Statute-book it signifieth, 
Merchants that ingross a com&shy;
modity.</xpln></wordentry>
