<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grogram(n)">Grogran,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gros-&shy;
Grain,</etym> gross or thick grain; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a thick web. <term lang="la">v.</term> Grain.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="groin(n)">The Groin,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Growan</etym>, to grow; from the 
increase of nature.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="groan(v)">Grone,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Granian</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Groonen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all very likely feigned from 
the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="groom(n)">Groom:</form><xpln lang="en">Verstegan and Min&shy;
shew derive it from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Grom,</etym> a boy, or youth: We 
may draw it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Guma</etym>, a man; also watch&shy;
ful; and this from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gyman,</etym> to regard, to take 
care of a thing.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="M4r">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grove(n)">Groove, or Grove,</form><xpln lang="en">a myne. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Grave.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grope(v)">Grope,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grapian</etym>, 
to touch lightly, to handle 
gently.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gross(a)">Gross,</form><xpln lang="en">or Big, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Grosz,</etym> the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Groz,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gros,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gros&shy;
so,</etym> great, grand; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Crassus,</etym> thick.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gross(n)">A Gross</form><xpln lang="en">of commodities, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grosse,</etym> the num&shy;
ber 144. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) twelve do&shy;
zen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grot(n)">A Grot,</form><xpln lang="en">or Cave, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Grotte,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grotta,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cry&shy;
pta,</etym> a cave; and this from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&rho;&#x1F7B;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to hide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grotes-work(n)">Grotes-work,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Grotesque,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Grot&shy;
tesca, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term> (a word frequent 
amongst Carpenters) and our 
word <etym lang="en">Work;</etym> which see.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"grotes-work" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grove(n)">A Grove,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grove, 
Graef</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from our 
word to <etym lang="en">Grow;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a Grow, 
or Growing of trees.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grove(n)">A Grove,</form><xpln lang="en">a word used in Lin&shy;
colnshire for a grip, or ditch; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Groeve,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Grave.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="groveling(n)">Groveling,</form><xpln lang="en">tumbling, or sprawl&shy;
ing on the ground; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Groundling;</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term> Ground: Or 
rather, from <etym lang="en">Grave,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Grove;</etym> 
which see; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> standing, or 
going in such a posture, as if 
he were about to dig the 
ground.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ground(n)">Ground,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. Teut. and 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Grund,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Grond,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from hence 
cometh that old word in our 
Law, Groundage, a tax which 
is laid upon ships in port or 
harbour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="groundling(n)">A Groundling,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Grundling,</etym> a fish so called; 
because it feedeth or stayeth 
near the bottom of the water.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grounds(n)">Grounds,</form><xpln lang="en">dregs; from <etym lang="en">Ground,</etym> 
because they sink down to the 
bottom of a vessel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="groundsel(n)">The Groundsel of a door,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the AS.<etym lang="oe"> Grund</etym>, the ground, 
and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sueil del huis,</etym> 
a threshold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grout(n)">Grout,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grut</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Griotte, Gruotte,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grutte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; the 
great of Oat-meal.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grow(v)">Grow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Growan</etym>, 
to grow; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Groyen, 
Groenen,</etym> to be green, or to 
flourish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="growl(v)">To Growl,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Groll,</etym> 
anger; or <etym lang="tt">Grollen,</etym> to be an&shy;
gry: Or it is a contract of 
<etym lang="en">Grumble.</etym> Mer. Cas. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&omicron;&gamma;&gamma;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omicron;</etym>, to mur&shy;
mur.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grub(v)">To Grub,</form><xpln lang="en">from our word <etym lang="en">Grave;</etym> 
which see: Or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gruven,</etym> to delve.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grubble(v)">To Grubble,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gru&shy;
belen,</etym> to search all over, or 
about.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"grubble" antedates the first OED citation (1690).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grudge(v)">Grudge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gruger,</etym> 
to murmur against; and this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cruciari,</etym> to be 
vexed.</xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="M4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gruel(n)">Gruel,</form><xpln lang="en">made of oat-meal and 
water; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grus,</etym> 
the same; and this from <etym lang="fr">Gruan,</etym> 
great oat-meal. <term lang="la">v.</term> Groue, and 
Grist.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grumble(v)">Grumble,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Grom&shy;
melen, Grommen,</etym> or the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Gromineler,</etym> to mutter, or 
murmur. <term lang="la">v.</term> Grudge, and 
Growl.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="grunt(v)">To Grunt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grunt&shy;
zen,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grogner,</etym> the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Grugnare, Grugnire,</etym> or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Grynter,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Grunnire,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from the 
sound, by an Onomatopoeia.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gubbins(n)">Gubbings,</form><xpln lang="en">the parings of Haber&shy;
dine; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gob, 
Gobeau,</etym> a morsel, or gobbet: 
Or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to 
cut.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gudgeon(n)">A Gudgeon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Goujon, Goyon, Goisson;</etym> and 
these corruptly wrested from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gobio,</etym> or the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7D;&beta;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guerdon(n)">Guerdon,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guer&shy;
don,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guiderdone,</etym> 
a reward; and this from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Guida,</etym> a guide; or <etym lang="it">Gui&shy;
dare,</etym> to guide, or lead; and 
<etym lang="it">Dona,</etym> in Lat. <etym lang="la">Donum,</etym> a re&shy;
ward; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> guidage, or re&shy;
ward for conduct. Abr. Myl. 
draws the first part of it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weerderen, Wier&shy;
deren,</etym> to value.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guess(v)">Guess,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghisse,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or <etym lang="bl">Ghissen,</etym> to conje&shy;
cture; and this perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weisen,</etym> to shew. 
Minshew derives them all 
from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Kesem,</etym> a divi&shy;
nation.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guest(n)">Guest,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan. 
<etym lang="oe">Gest</etym>, or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gast,</etym> the same; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gystnus</etym>, a guest-&shy;
house.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guggle(v)">To Guggle,</form><xpln lang="en">as drink poured out 
of a bottle; from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Gorgogliare,</etym> the same; and 
this from <etym lang="it">Gorgoglio;</etym> and all 
possibly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gur&shy;
ges,</etym> a gulf.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guide(n)">A Guide,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guide,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Guidon,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Guia,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guida,</etym> the same; 
whence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guider</etym>, 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guidare</etym>, to 
guide, or lead.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guidon(n)">Guidon,</form><xpln lang="en">an Ensign to a troop of 
Horse; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gui&shy;
don,</etym> a flag, or banner. See 
the other <etym lang="en">Guidon,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Guide.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guidon(n)">A Guidon,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guidon,</etym> a flag 
for a company of Horse; this 
from the word <etym lang="en">Guide,</etym> for Sol&shy;
diers follow their Ensign as a 
guide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gild(v)">To Guild, or rather Gild,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gyldan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence <etym lang="oe">Begylded</etym>, gilded, 
or gilt; and <etym lang="oe">Gylden</etym>, gol&shy;
den. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gold.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guild(n)">Guild,</form><xpln lang="en">as in Guild-hall; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gild</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gilde, Gulde,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gulte,</etym> a Society; these from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gheld,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gelt,</etym> money; because those
</page>

<page sig="M5r"> 
of any Society contribute mo&shy;
ney for the defraying of char&shy;
ges in common. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guilder(n)">A Guilder,</form><xpln lang="en">a certain coin; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gulden,</etym> the same; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> a gilt coin: Or from 
<etym lang="pt">Gueldria,</etym> a Province in the 
Low-Countries, where per&shy;
haps it was first coined.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guile(n)">Guile,</form><xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guile,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Guille,</etym> fraud, deceit; or 
<etym lang="fr">Guiller,</etym> to gull, or put a trick 
on one.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guilt(n)">Guilt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gilt</etym>, a 
crime; whence Giltig, guil&shy;
ty; and these from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gildan</etym>, to pay; taken from 
the custom of the ancient 
Germans, who expiated any 
crimes, even murther itself; 
and, which you will scarce 
believe, the massacre of Kings, 
with fines, and great sums of 
money.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gilt-head(n)">Guilt-heid,</form><xpln lang="en">or Sea-Bream, a 
fish so called, from the golden 
spots it hath upon its head. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Bream.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guimad(n)">Guimad,</form><xpln lang="en">a fish only caught in 
the river Dee in Cheeshire, and 
a Marsh called Pemble-Meer; 
not unlikely from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Guimauve,</etym> a kind of Mal&shy;
lows, which it is like for 
smoothness.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"guimad" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guise(n)">Guise,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guise,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guisa,</etym> a fashion. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Wise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guitar(n)">Guitar,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> Gittar.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gulchin(n)">A Gulchin,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Gulekin,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a little glutton; for kin di&shy;
minisheth. It alludes to the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Guccio,</etym> and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geck,</etym> 
a fool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gules(n)">Gules,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gueules,</etym> 
which in Heraldry is taken for 
red colour; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Gula,</etym> the gullet; perhaps 
from the redness of a Cock's 
gullet, or throat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gulf(n)">Gulf,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Goulfe, 
Golfe,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kolf, 
Kolp,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Golfo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; which 
comes from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&lambda;&pi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
a port. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gulp.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gulf(n)">Gulf,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Golpe,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gouffre, Goulfre,</etym> 
a whirl-pool; this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Gula,</etym> the gullet, or <etym lang="la">Gu&shy;
lo,</etym> a glutton; because, like a 
glutton, it sucks in, and swal&shy;
loweth every thing that is put 
therein.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gull(n)" lexeme="sea-gull(n)">A Gull, or Sea-Gull,</form><xpln lang="en">a bird so 
called from its natural voraci&shy;
ty; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="la">Gulosa,</etym> gluttonous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gull(v)">To Gull,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guelle,</etym> 
guile; or <etym lang="fr">Guiller,</etym> to cheat 
one; <term lang="la">v.</term> Guile. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&shy;
&lambda;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a Soldier's snap-sack.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gullet(n)">A Gullet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gula,</etym> 
the wind-pipe; or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Goulet, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gulp(v)">To Gulp,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Golpen,</etym> 
or the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Engoufrer, En&shy;
gouler,</etym> to swallow greedily: 
All from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gula,</etym> the 
gullet.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gum(n)">Gum, or rather Gound,</form><xpln lang="en">as they 
pronounce it in Lincolnshire. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Gound.</etym></xpln></wordentry>
</page>

<page sig="M5v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gum(n)">The Gumms,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Go&shy;
ma</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gaum, Gum,</etym> the palate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gun(n)">A Gun:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Canna,</etym> a reed; 
in imitation of the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Kohr,</etym> and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koer,</etym> which 
primarily signifie a reed, but 
are used to signifie a Gun. 
Somnerus ingeniously derives 
it from <etym lang="en">Mangon,</etym> by taking 
away the first syllable. Man&shy;
gon, was a warlike machine, 
used before the invention of 
guns.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gondola(n)">Gundola, or rather Gondola, and 
Gonda,</form><xpln lang="en">the name of a small 
vessel among the Venetians; 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F77;&nu;&delta;&upsilon;</etym>, a sort of 
cup: Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Con&shy;
chulae,</etym> a little shell. <term lang="la">v.</term> Cog&shy;
gle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gunstone(n)">Gunstones,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
otherwise called Ogresses; 
(i. e) balls put into guns; 
because at the first invention 
of guns, they shot with little 
round stones, not with bul&shy;
lets made of lead, as now.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gunwale(n)">Gunwale,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; 
perhaps from our word <etym lang="en">Gun,</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to 
wield, or direct; because it is 
the place where the guns lie 
upon stock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gurgeons(n)">Gurgians of meal,</form><xpln lang="en">a word found 
in Gouldman only. It is ta&shy;
ken for the courser part of 
meal, whereof hous-hold bread 
is made; perhaps from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escouvr&egrave;,</etym> to shake out; 
because it is that branny part, 
which remains in the sieve, 
when the finer meal is sifted 
out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gurgle(n)">Gurgle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gorghel,</etym> 
the wind-pipe; or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Gorgoliare,</etym> to gurgle, as li&shy;
quor doth when it is poured 
out of a strait-neck'd vessel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gurnard(n)">A Gurney, or Gurnard,</form><xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gourneau,</etym> a fish so 
called; and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Cornulum,</etym> of <etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> a little 
horn.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gush(v)">To Gush,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geo&shy;
tan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gosselen,</etym> 
to pour out, to be poured out. 
Somnerus draws it from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Gutta,</etym> a drop; or from 
the noise of water hastily pou&shy;
red out.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gusset(n)">A Gusset,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gous&shy;
set,</etym> a skirt, or border; or 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Consue&shy;
re,</etym> to sow together; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a 
piece put into a garment.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gust(n)">Gust,</form><xpln lang="en">a fierce blast of wind; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gist</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Gest</etym>, a whirl-wind; and 
both from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Giessen,</etym> 
to pour out. <term lang="la">v.</term> Ghost.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gut(n)">Gut,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Guttelen,</etym> 
the inwards. Perhaps it comes 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Guttus, Gut&shy;
turnium,</etym> a laver, or wash&shy;
pot.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gutt&eacute; d'eau(n)">Gutte d'Eau,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heral&shy;
dry; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gutte 
de l'eau,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">d'eau,</etym> drops of 
water; <etym lang="fr">Gutte Lachrymarum</etym>, 
or <etym lang="fr">Lachrymularum</etym>, drops of 
tears; <etym lang="fr">Gutte d'Or</etym>, drops of
</page>

<page sig="M6r"> 
gold; also <etym lang="fr">Gutte de Poix, &agrave; 
Guttis Piscis</etym>, from the drops, 
or spots of a fish: <etym lang="fr">Gutte de 
Sang</etym>, in the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Goutte 
de Sang</etym>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="fr">Guttatus San&shy;
guine</etym>, dropped, or sprinkled 
with blood. </xpln>
<lemenote>
"gutte d'eau" not found in OED except in "icicle", n. (citation of 1904).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gutter(n)">Gutter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gout&shy;
tiere,</etym> the same: Or from 
<etym lang="fr">Esgouter,</etym> to run over by 
drops; and this again from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gutta,</etym> a drop.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guy(n)">A Guy,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing. Man&shy;
wayring draws it from our 
word <etym lang="en">Guide;</etym> because it is a 
rope that guides the leaning, 
or inclination of any weighty 
thing that is craned up into a 
ship, lest it should be let down 
too hastily, and so mis-carry, 
or damage other things near 
it.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="guze(n)">Guzes,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guses,</etym> the 
compass of the eye.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gyron(n)">A Gyronne,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guyron,</etym> the 
same; or from <etym lang="fr">Giron,</etym> a lap: 
Or perhaps <etym lang="la">&agrave; Gyrando,</etym> from 
turning, or bending.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="H"><alpha>H</alpha>
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haberdasher(n)">HAberdasher,</form><xpln lang="en">a Seller of small 
wares; either, as Minshew 
will have it, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Habt ither das?</etym> will you take 
this? as Chap-men common&shy;
ly say: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Avoir d'Acheten,</etym> to have 
things that are to be bought.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haberdine(n)">Haberdine,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ha&shy;
bordeau,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Abber&shy;
daen;</etym> I suppose, a Whiting 
pickled and dried; or perhaps  
from <etym lang="en">Aberdene,</etym> a City in 
Scotland, where there is 
great  store of such fish. <term lang="la">v.</term> Aber&shy;
dene,  in the Proper Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="habergeon(n)">Habergeon,</form><xpln lang="en">
from th Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hau&shy;
bergeon,</etym> a coat of mail: Or 
from the Fr. Th <etym lang="hd">Halsberge,</etym> a 
breast-plate; which comes 
from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Hals,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Halsz,</etym> the neck; and 
<etym lang="tt">Bergen,</etym> to cover.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="habiliment(n)">Habiliments,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Habillemens,</etym> apparel; and 
this from the Verb <etym lang="fr">Habiller,</etym> 
to cloath; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Habitus,</etym> an habit.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hab nab(adv)">Hab-nab,</form><xpln lang="en">rashly,
without consi&shy;
deration; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hab&shy;
ban</etym>, to have, and <etym lang="oe">Nabban</etym>, 
not to have; by cutting off 
the two last syllables in each 
word: <term lang="la">v.</term> Have. Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
Hap n' hap, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) whether it
happen, or no. <term lang="la">v.</term> Happen.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatch(n)">An Hack,</form><xpln lang="en">a word
frequently u&shy;
sed in Lincolnshire; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hacca</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Heck,</etym> a door-barr, or place 
inclosed with bars; with us, an 
Hatch; which see.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hack(v)">To Hack,</form><xpln lang="en">from the
Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="bl">Hacken, Hachten,</etym> to 
mangle; <etym lang="tt">Hacke,</etym> an hatchet; 
or <etym lang="tt">Hackelen,</etym> to hackle: Or
</page>

<page sig="M6v">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hacher,</etym> to &shy;
cut in small pieces. All from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ascia,</etym> or Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&xi;&#x1F77;&shy;
&nu;&eta;</etym>, an ax. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hackney horse(n)">An Hackney-Horse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Hacquen&eacute;e,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; with 
us, an horse let out by the 
day, or week, &amp;c. for hire: 
Or from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Chinea;</etym> 
and this from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Schie&shy;
na,</etym> a back; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="it">Cavallo di 
Schiena</etym>, a back'd horse, a 
saddle-horse, or pad-nag.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="have(v)">Had,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hadde,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hette,</etym> he had.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haddock(n)">Haddock,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Hadot,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; a fish of the 
kind of whitings.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haft(n)">Haft,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;ft</etym>, 
Belg <etym lang="bl">Heft,</etym> an haft, handle, or 
hilt; this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;ftan</etym> 
to have, or hold; because a 
sword is held by the hilt.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haggard(n)">Hagard,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Faulconry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hagard,</etym> 
stubborn; or rather, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
<etym lang="fr">Vagard, &agrave; Vagando</etym>, from 
wandring: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;g, Hegge</etym>, an hedge; 
<term lang="la">q. d.</term> an hawk that delighteth 
to be in hedges. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hedge.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hag(n)">An Hagg,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;^shy;
se;</etym> which Somner. de&shy;
rives from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Egeslic</etym>, 
ghost-like, gastly. It may al&shy;
so be drawn from the Belg. 
and Teut <etym lang="tt">Hexe,</etym> a witch; or 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Saga,</etym> an hag; 
for S is often turned into H. 
v, Hagger.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haggard(a)">Hagger,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hager,</etym> 
lean; or from <etym lang="tt">Hagard,</etym> wild; 
for when hawks fly abroad 
wild in the woods, they are 
seldom fat.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haggis(n)">Haggess,</form><xpln lang="en">a sheep's maw, filled 
with suet, and other the en&shy;
trals of a sheep minced; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hacken,</etym> to hackle, 
or cut small.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heifer(n)">Haifer;</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
<etym lang="en">Hay,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Fare;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a young 
beast that beginneth to eat 
hay: But rather from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Heafore</etym>, the same; which 
comes from <etym lang="oe">Heah</etym>, high, and 
<etym lang="oe">Fore,</etym> a gate, or way of go&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hail(n)">Hail,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hagol, 
Hagle,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haeghel,</etym> 
or the Teut. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Hagel,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&#x1F71;&lambda;&alpha;&zeta;&alpha;</etym>, the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heinous(a)">Hainous,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hai&shy;
neux,</etym> odious; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Haine,</etym> hatred; and this again 
from <etym lang="fr">Hair,</etym> to hate, or ab&shy;
hor.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hair(n)">Hair,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;r, Heare,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haer, 
Hayr,</etym> the same; whence 
<etym lang="bl">Haer bosch</etym>, a bush of hair.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hake(v)">To Hake,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haec&shy;
ken,</etym> to hanker after a thing.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"hake" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hacot(n)">Hakot,</form><xpln lang="en">a word yet in use in the 
West of England; from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heket,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hecht,</etym> the fish called a pike: 
Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hacod</etym>, <term lang="la">id.</term> 
also a mullet.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="M7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halbert(n)">Halbert,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hale&shy;
barde, Hallebarde,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Helbarte, Hellebard,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; a weapon that woun&shy;
deth both ways; this from 
<etym lang="tt">Helle,</etym> glittering, and <etym lang="tt">Bard, 
Barte,</etym> an ax: Or from the 
old Germ. <etym lang="gr">Halle,</etym> an hall; be&shy;
cause the Life-guard-men of 
Kings were arm'd with hal&shy;
berts. Versteg draws it from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> a champion, 
and <etym lang="tt">Bard,</etym> an ax.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halcyon days(n)">Halcion-Days,</form><xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) pleasant 
days, fair weather; ab <etym lang="la">Alcyo&shy;
ne ave,</etym> from the bird called 
a King's-fisher; which whilst 
she is a-laying her eggs at her 
usual time of the year, the 
sea is calm all that time, and 
free from storms or tem&shy;
pests.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hale(v)">To Hale,</form><xpln lang="en">a term among Sailers, 
signifying to call to one, to 
salute him; either from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haelen,</etym> to call upon; 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hal,</etym> whole; 
whence <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;e</etym>, health, or safe&shy;
ty; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to wish one all 
health and happiness. <term lang="la">v.</term> All 
Hail.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hale(v)">To Hale,</form><xpln lang="en">for to pull any way by 
force; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hoh&shy;
len,</etym> to lead away, to drag one 
about by force.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="half(n)">Half,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Half</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Halfe,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Halb,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Halff,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
all not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hal,</etym> the whole, and <etym lang="oe">Of</etym>, 
off; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) that which is taken 
off from the whole.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hall(n)">An Hall,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Healle</etym>, 
or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aula,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&upsilon;&lambda;&#x1F74;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem iterum</term>. Fr. Jun. de&shy;
rives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0D;&lambda;&omega;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
the plat, or plot of an house.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halliard(n)">Halliards,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) those cables by means 
whereof they hoise upward 
many others about the Sails. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> To <etym lang="en">Hale;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to pull up 
by force.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halibut(n)">Hallibut,</form><xpln lang="en">a fish of the kind of 
plaice; perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Heyl,</etym> wholsome; or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Halig,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heiligh,</etym> holy, 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bot;</etym> as Bot&shy;
visch, a butt-fish. <term lang="la">v.</term> Butt.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hallow(v)">To Hallow,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Holy.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hollow(v)">To Hallow, or rather Hollow</form><xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haller,</etym> to cry 
aloud, as hunters do to ani&shy;
mate the dogs.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haulm(n)">Halm, or Haulm,</form><xpln lang="en">stubble; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Healm, healme,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or the blade of corn; 
and all, I suppose, from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Calamus,</etym> a reed; or 
from <etym lang="la">Culmus,</etym> a blade, or 
stalk.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hawser(n)">Halser, or Hawser,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in 
Sailing; from our word, To 
<etym lang="en">Hale.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halt(v)">To Halt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Healt,</etym> 
lame; or <etym lang="oe">Healtan,</etym> to halt; 
and these from the AS <etym lang="oe">Heal&shy;
dan,</etym> to hold; for such go 
slowly, as if they were detai&shy;
ned by something, or walk 
with a stick in their bands: 
Or from <etym lang="oe">Heald</etym>, leaning to 
</page>

<page sig="M7v"> 
one side; for such as are lame 
go not upright. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halt(n)">To make an Halt,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in War&shy;
fare; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Halten,</etym> 
to hold; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to stop, or 
leave off: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Alto,</etym> high; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to set pikes 
up on end, as Pike-men do 
when they stand or stop in 
their march.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halter(n)">An Halter,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;lf&shy;
tre,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haelter, 
Halchter, Halster,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Halftter,</etym> the same; and all 
from the AS. Teut. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hals,</etym> the neck: Or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Halten,</etym> to hold; be&shy;
cause with it we curb an horse, 
or make him to stand.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hame(n)">Hames,</form><xpln lang="en">a word in use in the 
Northern parts of England; 
where it is taken for two bent 
pieces of wood that are put 
over an horse's shoulders; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hami,</etym> hooks; 
or rather, from <etym lang="la">Camurus,</etym> in 
Virgil, which signifieth, croo&shy;
ked; and this from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&mu;&pi;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, bent.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hamlet(n)">Hamlet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ha&shy;
meau,</etym> a village; both from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;m,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Ham,</etym> an 
home, or village: <term lang="la">v.</term> Home. 
Spelman draws it from the 
same Ham, a village, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Let,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Lit,</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Glied,</etym> 
a member; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a part of a 
village.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ham(n)">Hamm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hamme, Ham,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hamm,</etym> the same; from 
hence, To Hammel a dog. 
Fr. Jun. derives the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hame,</etym> from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&mu;&shy;
&mu;&alpha;</etym>, a lump cut off from the 
rest.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hammer(n)">Hamer, or Hammer,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hamer</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hae&shy;
mer,</etym> or the Dan. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hammer,</etym> the same. It al&shy;
ludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&mu;&nu;&omega;, &#x1F1C;&kappa;&alpha;&shy;
&mu;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, to labour, or take pains.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hammock(n)">An Hammock,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ha&shy;
maca</etym>, a kind of Indian bed, 
hung by four corners; this 
perhaps from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cama,</etym> 
a bed; which in Isiodor. is ta&shy;
ken for a short, low bed. 
Some derive it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&mu;&alpha;&#x1F76;</etym>, on the ground.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hamper(n)">An Hamper,</form><xpln lang="en">a larger sort of bas&shy;
ket.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haunch(n)">Hanch,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hancke, 
Hencke,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hanche,</etym> 
or the Ital. and Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Anca,</etym> a 
thigh, or hamm: Or from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&gamma;&kappa;&eta;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&kappa;&#x1F71;&lambda;&eta;</etym>, an 
arm, or shoulder; from 
whence cometh the Gr. Barb. 
&#x1F0C;&nu;&tau;&zeta;&alpha;, a leg, or hanch.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hand(n)">Hand,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hand,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hant, Hand,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hand, Handt,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="handkerchief(n)">Handkerchief, or Handkercher,</form> 
<xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Hand,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Kerchief,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Kercher,</etym> to wipe.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="handle(n)">An Handle,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Han&shy;
dle</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; or <etym lang="oe">Handlian,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Handelen,</etym> to 
handle.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="handsome(a)">Handsom,</form><xpln lang="en">well shaped; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hand-saem,</etym> slight-handed: 
</page>

<page sig="M8r">  
whence <etym lang="bl">Handigh</etym>, with 
us, Handy, fit for any thing. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hang(v)">Hang,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hangan</etym>, 
or the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Han&shy;
gen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: This Fr. Jun. in&shy;
geniously derives from <etym lang="bl">Hahan,</etym> 
to heave, or lift up; and this 
from <etym lang="bl">Hoh,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hoch,</etym> high; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term> to lift one up on high.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hanger(n)">An Hanger,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hangher,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or 'tis so 
called from its hanging by 
one's side.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hanger(n)">Hangers,</form><xpln lang="en">or Pot-hooks, from 
our word <etym lang="en">Hang;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hanging(n)">Hangings,</form><xpln lang="en">Arras, Tapestry, &amp;c. 
from our word <etym lang="en">Hang,</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hank(n)">Hank;</form><xpln lang="en">as, He hath got an Hank 
of a thing, for an habit, cu&shy;
stom, or propensity of mind; 
from our word <etym lang="en">Hang</etym>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
to hang, or hanker after.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hanker(v)">Hanker,</form><xpln lang="en">to covet a thing ear&shy;
nestly. <term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Hake,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Hang.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hansel(n)">An Hansel,</form><xpln lang="en">when we sell the first 
parcel of a Commodity; ei&shy;
ther from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hansel,</etym> a 
New-years-gift, or a New-&shy;
days-gift: Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hand</etym>, an hand, and <etym lang="oe">Syllan</etym>, 
to give.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hans-towns(n)">Hans-Towns,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Hansz,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hans,</etym> a 
Fellow of a Society; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
towns of the same society and 
confederacy.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"hans-town" ("hans" in this sense) not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haunt(v)">To Hant,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Han&shy;
ter,</etym> to frequent.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hap(v)">To Hap,</form><xpln lang="en">as they say in Lincoln&shy;
shire, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heapian</etym>, 
to heap up; whence <etym lang="oe">Heape</etym>, 
an heap; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to heap up, or 
load with bed-cloths.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="happen(v)">To Happen,</form><xpln lang="en">or fall out: Min&shy;
shew derives it from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Happer,</etym> to snap up hasti&shy;
ly; and this from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Happen,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F09;&rho;&pi;&#x1F71;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, 
to snatch a thing up.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harangue(n)">Harang,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ha&shy;
rangue,</etym> a Sermon, or Ora&shy;
tion. Menagius derives it 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Horung;</etym> with 
us, Hearing; because it is spo&shy;
ken to the end that the Assem&shy;
bly may hear it. But since the 
Italians write it <etym lang="it">Arringo</etym>, I 
had rather derive it from our 
Eng. <etym lang="en">Ring;</etym> because at the 
making of a speech, the Audi&shy;
tors stand as it were in a ring; 
that is, on every side.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harass(v)">To Harass,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ha&shy;
rasser,</etym> to vex, or hurry; al&shy;
so to lay all waste; this per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hergian</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heeren,</etym> to spoil; 
and this again from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heer,</etym> an 
army. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hurry.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harbinger(n)">Harbinger,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Herberger;</etym> that is, one 
that goes before, and procures 
a lodging for others. <term lang="la">v.</term> Har&shy;
bour.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harbor(n)">Harbour,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Her&shy;
berghe,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herberg,</etym> Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Hauberge, Herberge,</etym> Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Alvergue,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Alber&shy;
go,</etym> an Inn, or place for enter&shy;
taining travellers; all from the 
Ger. <etym lang="gr">Her,</etym> hither, or here, and 
<etym lang="gr">Bergen,</etym> to hide, or cover.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="M8v">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hardy(a)">Hardy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hardi,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ardito,</etym> coura&shy;
geous; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ardor,</etym> heat; or <etym lang="la">Ardere,</etym> to be 
inflamed with desire.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hare(n)">An Hare,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hara</etym>, 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Hare,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haese,</etym> Teut. 
and Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hase,</etym> or the Arab. 
<etym lang="ar">Hazaz, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hare(v)">To Hare</form><xpln lang="en">one, to affright one, or 
harass him; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Harier,</etym> to vex; and this per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hergian</etym>, 
to pillage; which comes from 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an army.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hare-brained(a)">Hare-brain'd,</form><xpln lang="en">out of his right 
senses; from our word, to 
<etym lang="en">Hare,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Brain;</etym> that is, one 
that is hared, or scared out of 
his wits.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hare-foot(n)">An Hare-Foot,</form><xpln lang="en">a bird so called, 
from the similitude of an hares 
foot.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hare-lipped(a)">Hare-lipp'd;</form><xpln lang="en">that is, he or she 
whose lip is parted in two. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Hare,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Lip.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harrier(n)">Harier,</form><xpln lang="en">a dog's name; from 
<etym lang="en">Hare,</etym> because it implieth such 
a dog as is good at hunting 
the hare.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harken(v)">Harken, or Hearken,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Heorcnian,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Horchen,</etym> to lend an ear 
to; and both from the Verb 
to <etym lang="en">Hear;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harlot(n)">Harlot;</form><xpln lang="en">some derive it from one 
<etym lang="fr">Arlotta,</etym> that was Miss to Ro&shy;
bert Duke of Normandy, and 
Mother to William the Con&shy;
queror; or, as Cambden will 
have it, from one <etym lang="fr">Arlotha,</etym> 
that was Concubine to the 
Conqueror himself: Or most 
likely from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Arlotta,</etym> 
a proud Whore: Or lastly, as 
the ingenious Dr. Th. H. has it, 
q. <etym lang="en">Whorelet,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Horelet;</etym> (i. e) 
a little Whore.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harm(n)">Harm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hearm</etym>, 
loss, or damage: Or perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Arma,</etym> arms; 
because arms offensive are rec&shy;
koned among things harm&shy;
ful.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harness(n)">Harness,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Har&shy;
nisch,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Harnois, Har&shy;
nas,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Arnes,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Arneso,</etym> furniture for horses.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harp(n)">Harp,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hearpe</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haerpe, Harpe,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Harpse,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Harpe,</etym> or the 
Ital. and Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Harpa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F09;&rho;&shy;
&pi;&#x1F71;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to ravish, for the plea&shy;
santness of the musick.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harping-iron(n)">Harping-irons,</form><xpln lang="en">instruments of 
iron which Sea-men strike 
whales and great fishes withal; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Harpago,</etym> an 
hook; and this from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F09;&rho;&pi;&#x1F71;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to catch hold of.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harpsical(n)">Harpsical,</form><xpln lang="en">a kind of musical in&shy;
strument; from <etym lang="en">Harp,</etym> and 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chorde,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Chorda,</etym> a string to any musi&shy;
cal instrument.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harquebus(n)">Harquebuss,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ar&shy;
quebuse,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Archibugio, 
Arcobugio,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Arcke-&shy;
Buyse,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Haeck-Buyse,</etym> a 
greater sort of hand gun, or 
Musquet. Kilian derives it 
</page>

<page sig="N1r">  
from <etym lang="bl">Haeck,</etym> an hook, and 
<etym lang="bl">Busse, Buyse,</etym> a conduit-pipe: 
Menagius, from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ar&shy;
co,</etym> a bow, and <etym lang="it">Bugio,</etym> an hole; 
because such weapons are now 
used instead of bows. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sea haar(n)">A Sea-Harr,</form><xpln lang="en">as it is said in Lin&shy;
colnshire, when a storm is a-&shy;
coming from the sea-ward; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Harier,</etym> to 
hare: <term lang="la">v.</term> Harry. Or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;rn,</etym> a full tide.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harrow(n)">An Harrow,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Harse, Herce;</etym> and both from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scharren,</etym> to scrape: 
Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sarculum,</etym> 
the same, or a weeding-hook.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harry(v)">To Harry,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ha&shy;
rier,</etym> to torment, or to <etym lang="en">Hare,</etym> 
which see above.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harsh(a)">Harsh,</form><xpln lang="en">severe, crabbed, or sowr; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herbisch,</etym> 
somewhat sharp; this from 
<etym lang="tt">Herb,</etym> austere, rugged, intra&shy;
ctable, or rather, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hersch,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Has</etym>, 
hoarse; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he that hath a 
great and awful voice.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hart(n)">An Hart,</form><xpln lang="en">or Stag, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Heort</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hert, 
Herte;</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hersch,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heart(n)">Hart</form><xpln lang="en">of oak; not as many write 
it, Heart of oak; that is, the 
innermost part of an oak; 
but rather from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Harte,</etym> hardness; because it is 
the most firm or hard part of 
an oak. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hard.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harvest(n)">Harvest,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;r&shy;
fest</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Harfst, Herfst,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herbst,</etym> Autumn, 
all which the famous Dr. Th. 
H. derives from <etym lang="gr">Hertho,</etym> a 
God of the ancient Germans, 
whom they adored for Vesta, 
and <etym lang="gr">Feast;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> the feast of 
Vesta, or the earth: Or from 
<etym lang="gr">Herba,</etym> and <etym lang="gr">Feast;</etym> because it 
is the season wherein herbs 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term> corn) are gathered into 
barns; at which time Coun&shy;
try-Farmers do usually make 
a feast for their Reapers, ha&shy;
ving finished their havest.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haze(v)" lexeme="hawse(v)">To Hase, or Hawze,</form><xpln lang="en">to affright 
one with a suddain shout; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Has</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Heiser, Heischer,</etym> hoarse; or 
<etym lang="tt">Heischen,</etym> to be importunate 
in requesting any thing: Or 
from the Interjection of threatning, <etym lang="en">Haw.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hazel-nut(n)">Hasle-nut,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;sl-&shy;
nutu</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hasel-noot,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hasel-nuz,</etym> the 
same; all perhaps from our 
word <etym lang="en">Haste;</etym> because it is ripe 
before wall nuts and chest-&shy;
nuts.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="harslet(n)" lexeme="haslets(n)">An Hog's Haslets, or Harslets,</form><xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hastilles,</etym> 
the guts; and this per&shy;
haps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haste</etym> 
a spit; because they are 
fastned to a spit, and so 
roasted. Haste manifestly 
cometh from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hasta,</etym> 
a spear; and metaphorically, 
a spit.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hasp(n)" lexeme="reel(n)">An Hasp, or Reel,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Haspe,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Haspel,</etym> 
</page>

<page sig="N1v"> 
a reel to wind yarn or 
thread on. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hasp(n)">Hasp,</form><xpln lang="en">by a Metathesis, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;ps</etym>, a lock; also a 
button. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hasp, above.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"hasp" in this sense appears earliest in the OED in 1855 ("hasp", n., 1.b).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hassock(n)">Hassock,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hase,</etym> an 
hare, and <etym lang="en">Socks;</etym> because 
hare-skins are sometimes wore 
instead of socks, to keep the 
feet warm in Winter.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haste(v)">Haste,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hase,</etym> an 
hare; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> to run, or make 
haste, as an hare pursued.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hasting(n)">Hastings,</form><xpln lang="en">a forward kind of 
pease; from our word <etym lang="en">Ha&shy;
sten;</etym> because they are full, 
and in season before other 
sorts of pulse; and therefore 
may, in some sence, be said 
to make haste.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hat(n)">Hat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;t</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hut,</etym> or the Belg <etym lang="bl">Hoed,</etym> 
the same; these from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Huten,</etym> and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoe&shy;
den,</etym> to protect; because it 
defendeth the head.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatch(n)">The Hatch</form><xpln lang="en">of a door, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;ca</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heck, Hecke, </etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; usually put before 
doors, to keep out Beggars 
and Pilferers.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatchel(v)">To Hatchel</form><xpln lang="en">Flax, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hechesn,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence He&shy;
chel, an heckle. Minshew 
draws it, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ha&shy;
cher,</etym> to hackle, or cut small.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatch(n)">The Hatches of a ship;</form><xpln lang="en">Minsh. 
taketh them to be thus called, 
because they fall to like the 
<etym lang="en">Hatch</etym> of a door; which see.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatchet(n)">Hatchet,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hat&shy;
chette,</etym> a little ax; and this 
from <etym lang="fr">Hache,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ha&shy;
cha,</etym> an ax; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ascia,</etym> which comes from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&xi;&#x1F77;&nu;&eta;</etym>, the same; which 
again is derived from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&kappa;&eta;</etym>, 
the mouth, or sharp side of 
any edged-tool.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hate(v)">To Hate,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hatian, 
Hatan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haeten,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hassen,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hair, 
Hayr,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="have(v)">Have,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Halben,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Haven,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Habban</etym>, 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Avoir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">A&shy;
vere,</etym> the same; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Habere,</etym> to have.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haven(n)">Haven,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haven,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hafen,</etym> Dan. <etym lang="da">Haffn,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Havre,</etym> a port; 
which comes either from the 
old Brit. <etym lang="br">Aber,</etym> the mouth of 
any river, as Cambden hath it; 
or from the Dan. and Goth. 
<etym lang="go">Haff,</etym> the sea.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="avoirdupois(n)">Haver de poise,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Avoir du pooids,</etym> to have 
weight; because it is a weight, 
or pound, consisting of six&shy;
teen ounces; and therefore 
more weighty than Troy-&shy;
weight, where twelve ounces 
make a pound.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haughty(a)">Haughty,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hau&shy;
tain,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Haultain,</etym> proud, 
high-minded; this from <etym lang="fr">Haut,</etym> 
high; and this again from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Altus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="havoc(n)">Havock,</form><xpln lang="en">a wasting; from a ra&shy;
venous bird, which in the AS. 
is called <etym lang="oe">Hafoc</etym>; with us, 
Hawk.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="N2r">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haurient(a)">Hauriant;</form><xpln lang="en">as, a Dolphin Hau&shy;
riant, a term in Heraldry; not <etym lang="la">ab Hauxiendo</etym>, from draw&shy;
ing, as one would imagine at 
first sight; but from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Oriens,</etym> rising up; that is, ri&shy;
sing streight upward out of 
the water. It is also meant of 
any fish that is in such wise 
drawn upon an Escutcheon.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haw(n)">An Haw,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hagan</etym>, 
the fruit of the white-thorn; 
this not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;g,</etym> an hedge; because it 
groweth in hedges.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haw(n)">Haw,</form><xpln lang="en">a word frequently used in 
Kent; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Haga,</etym> 
or <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;g</etym>, a little field, or in&shy;
closed close; and this from 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;gian</etym>, to hedge about. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Hedge.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haw(n)">An Haw in the eye,</form><xpln lang="en">from some 
likeness of the other <etym lang="en">Haw,</etym> 
that groweth upon the haw&shy;
thorn.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hawk(n)">An Hawk,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ha&shy;
foc, Hafuc,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ha&shy;
vick,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Habick,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Vossius draws it from 
the belg. <etym lang="bl">Happen,</etym> to catch 
hold of. The learned Dr. Th. 
H. draws it from the Lat <etym lang="la">Fal&shy;
co,</etym> a falcon.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hawk(v)">To Hawk,</form><xpln lang="en">or to reach in spitting, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hauehen,</etym> to 
blow hard; or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Harc&shy;
ker,</etym> to hawk; and all feigned 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hawse(n)">Hawses,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; the 
great round holes, through 
which the cables are put when 
a ship rides at anchor; per&shy;
haps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hausser,</etym> 
to hoise up; because the an&shy;
chor is drawn upward by 
means of such holes.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hawthorn(n)">Haw-thorn,</form><xpln lang="en">the thorn that bea&shy;
reth the fruit called haw. 
Minshew will have it so called 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haeg doren,</etym> 
q. hedge-thorn. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hedge, 
Thorn, and Haw.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hay(n)">Hay,</form><xpln lang="en">to dance the Hay, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haye,</etym> an hedge; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> 
Dancer a la Haye, to dance 
in a ring, after the form of an 
hedge made about an hay&shy;
rick. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hedge.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"[to dance the] hay" antedates the single and earliest OED citation (1777).
</lemenote>
</wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hay(n)">Hay,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hieg, Hig</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hey, Heuy,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hew,</etym> hay; whence 
Hewstock, and the Dan Hoe&shy;
stack, a stack, or rick of hay. 
Fr. Jun. derives it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Epsilon;&#x1F34;&alpha;</etym>, which in Hesychius 
and Su<term lang="la">id.</term> is put for &Kappa;&#x1F79;&rho;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;, 
grass.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hay(n)">Hay,</form><xpln lang="en">a net to catch coneys 
withal; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haye,</etym> 
the AS <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;g, Hege,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haege,</etym> an hedge; which 
come from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hayer,</etym> 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hegian,</etym> and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haeghen,</etym> to hedge a&shy;
bout; because coneys are 
hedged up, and tangled in 
such a net.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hazard(n)">Hazard,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hazard,</etym> 
danger; and this from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Azar,</etym> an ace, or dog&shy;
chance at dice; which is an 
unlucky chance.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="N2v">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="He(pr)">He,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyse, Hise,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hy,</etym> he. The 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hise</etym>, is drawn from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Is,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Ipse,</etym> he.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="head(n)">Head,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heafod, 
H&aelig;fde</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoofd,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Haupt,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="head(su)">Head,</form><xpln lang="en">a termination denoting 
Quality, or State: See the 
termination Hood.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="headborough(n)">Head-borough,</form><xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Head,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Borge</etym>, a Surety: 
Not as Verstegan would have 
it, the Head of a Borough, 
or Town-corporate; but the 
same with that term in our 
Law, Frank-pledge; for which 
consult Cowel.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heal(v)">To Heal,</form><xpln lang="en">or Cure, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;lan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heelen,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heylen,</etym> to make 
whole; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;l, 
Hal</etym>, whole: All perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Helen, Halen,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Helan</etym>, to cover. Not&shy;
withstanding, the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;l, 
H&aelig;la</etym> may easily be drawn 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Salus,</etym> health, 
by turning S into H, or the 
Note of Aspiration; as, vice 
versa, is frequently done, in 
&#x1F5B;&lambda;&eta;, <term lang="la">Sylva</term>; &#x1F5B;&#x03c2;, <term lang="la">Sus</term>, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="health(n)">Health,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Heal:</etym> Minshew draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Omicron;&#x1F55;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, sound, 
healthful.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heap(n)">An Heap,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heape, 
Hype,</etym> Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Huffo, Hough,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hauff,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoop,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this last from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Copia,</etym> plenty.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hear(v)">To Hear,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyran</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hooren,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Horen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="herd(n)">An Heard or Herd</form><xpln lang="en">of cattle, 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Herde,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herd,</etym> a flock.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hearse-cloth(n)">Hearse-cloth,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hulse,</etym> an husk; and 
this from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helan</etym>, to 
cover; it being, as it were, 
the outer husk, or covering of 
a corps.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heart(n)">Heart,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heort</etym>, 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Hierte,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hertz,</etym> 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Hart,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hert,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Heorta</etym>, hearty, and <etym lang="oe">Hyr&shy;
tan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="oe">Herten</etym>, to hear&aelig;
ten, or animate.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hearth(n)">Hearth,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heor&eth;</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haerd, Heerd,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herd,</etym> the same; and 
all perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, 
the earth; or <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&nu;&epsilon;&rho;&theta;&epsilon;, &Nu;&#x1F73;&rho;&theta;&epsilon;</etym>, 
beneath, or under.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heat(n)">Heat,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heat, 
H&aelig;tn</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hitte,</etym> or 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Hizze, Hitze,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence <etym lang="hd">Hetza Sunna</etym>, the hot 
Sun: These from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hat</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heet,</etym> hot; 
and these again from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hatian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heeten,</etym> 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heitzen,</etym> to heat, 
make hot, or warm.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heath(n)">Heath,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;&eth;</etym>, 
Butcher's-broom; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Heyde, Heyd,</etym> Ling. Min&shy;
shew derives it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Alpha;&#x1F34;&theta;&omega;</etym>, to burn; because it 
soon taketh fire.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="N3r">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heath-cock(n)">Heath-cock,</form><xpln lang="en">a fowl so called, be&shy;
cause it abideth most com&shy;
monly among <etym lang="en">heaths</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heathen(n)">Heathen,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;&eth;en</etym>, 
or the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hey&shy;
den;</etym> and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ethnicus,</etym> a Pagan, or Gen&shy;
tile. Vossius derives it from 
the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Heyde,</etym> heath, or a 
barren place in the countries; 
because, when the Gospel was 
first preached to the Gentile-&shy;
world, throughout their se&shy;
veral cities, heathenish rites 
and ceremonies were for a 
long time celebrated in some 
places far remote from any ci&shy;
ty, in desarts; or, <etym lang="la">in Pagis</etym>, 
in villages; and hence it is, 
that such were called Pa&shy;
gans.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heave(v)">To Heave,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hea&shy;
fian,</etym> to lift up; and this 
from <etym lang="oe">Heah,</etym> high, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Heven, Heffen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">He&shy;
ben,</etym> or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Heffan,</etym> to 
lift up on high; and all per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Levo,</etym> to 
lift, or hold up.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heaven(n)">Heaven,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hefen, 
Heofen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this 
from <etym lang="oe">Heafian,</etym> to heave, or 
lift up; because it is placed 
above, on high; or because 
we lift up our eyes to behold 
it.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heavy(a)">Heavy,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heafig, 
Hefig</etym>, sad, weighty.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heckle(n)">Heckle,</form><xpln lang="en">an instrument to break 
flax withal; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hackelen,</etym> to break small, to 
hackle. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hack.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hedge(n)">Hedge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hegge, 
H&aelig;g,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haege,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hag. Hage,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hegian</etym>, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hagen</etym>, to hedge 
about; as also the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Quick-haege</etym>, a quick mound.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hedgehog(n)">Hedge-hog;</form><xpln lang="en">so called, because in 
body and bristles it is like an 
<etym lang="en">hog</etym>, and hides it self 
in <etym lang="en">hedges</etym>.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heed(v)">Heed,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hedan,</etym> to 
beware: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hoede,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hut,</etym> cu&shy;
stody; whence the Belg. Hoe&shy;
den, and Teut. Huten, to 
guard.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heel(n)">Heel of the foot,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hele</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">H&aelig;l,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heel(v)">Heels, the ship Heels;</form><xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) it 
leaneth to one side; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hylding</etym>, a leaning to 
one side: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Helden,</etym> to lean toward.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="here(adv)">Here,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;r, Here</etym>, or the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Her, Hier, Heic,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Heic, Hic,</etym> here: Hence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyr-Efter</etym>, hereaf&shy;
ter; and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Herwaerts</etym>, 
hereward.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="haggler(n)">Hegler,</form><xpln lang="en">a Fore-staller, or Huck&shy;
ster; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hacke,</etym> 
a Woman-Hegler: Or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heuchelen, Heuchen,</etym> 
to flatter; because such persons   
</page>

<page sig="N3v">
go to and again to great 
men's houses, where by fair 
and false words they insinuate 
themselves into favour, the 
better to put off their enda&shy;
maged commodities. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heir(n)">Heir,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hoir;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">H&aelig;&shy;
res, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hell(n)">Hell,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Helle,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hel</etym> the 
same. Mins. derives it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&lambda;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a lake, or 
pit. It may also be drawn 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hole,</etym> an hole, 
or hollow space under the 
earth.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helm(n)">Helm,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helm,</etym> Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Helm,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Heaume,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Elmo, Elmetto,</etym> an 
helmet; all from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;lme,</etym> a roof. The lear&shy;
ned Dr. Th. H. supposeth that 
Helmet is so called, q. Hel&shy;
mond; and derives it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helan</etym>, to cover, 
and the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="bl">Mond,</etym> <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a mouth, or 
face.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helm(n)">Helm</form><xpln lang="en">of a ship, from the other 
<etym lang="en">Helm;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="help(v)">To Help,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helpan,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Helpen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Helffen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Helpe, Ulph</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hulpe</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hulff</etym>, 
help, or a<term lang="la">id.</term> Minshew draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&lambda;&pi;&#x1F76;&#x03c2;</etym>, hope.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helter-skelter(adv)">Helter Skelter,</form><xpln lang="en">rashly, confu&shy;
sedly; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Heolster Sceado,</etym> the 
Chaos of darkness, the sha&shy;
dow of Hell, or Death, a 
place of unspeakable confu&shy;
sion, of which the indistinct 
Chaos was a type: Or rather, 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Holle,</etym> wholly, 
all over; <etym lang="bl">Ter,</etym> to; and 
<etym lang="bl">Schetteren,</etym> to scatter with a 
rustling, or chinking, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="helve(n)">Helve,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helfe</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Helm,</etym> an handle, or 
hilt; and this from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;lme,</etym> a roof, because it is 
the top of a sword, and serves 
to defend the hand: Or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heald</etym>, to hold; be&shy;
cause we hold weapons by 
their helves, or hilts.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hem(n)">An Hem,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hem,</etym> 
the same: Or from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ambire,</etym> to hem in, or to 
compass about.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hem(v)">To Hem,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hem&shy;
men,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Hummen,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Hannire,</etym> to call to one at a 
distance: Or rather, from the 
Lat. Interjection of Calling, 
<etym lang="la">Hem;</etym> all possibly from the
