sound.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hem in(v)">To Hem in,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hemmen,</etym> to detain, or 
to encompass one so that he 
cannot fairly withdraw him&shy;
self.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hemp(n)">Hemp,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hanff,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ramp</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Chauvre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Canna&shy;
pa, Cannevo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Canna&shy;
bis,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hen(n)">Hen,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan. 
</page>

<page sig="N4r">  
<etym lang="oe">Henne,</etym> <etym lang="da">H&aelig;n,</etym> or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="bl">Hen,</etym> <etym lang="tt">Henne,</etym> the 
same. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="henbane(n)">Hen-bane,</form><xpln lang="en">an herb so called, be&shy;
cause it is, or was formerly 
bane, or poison to hens The 
learned Dr. Th. H. surmizeth, 
that it may be so called, q. 
<etym lang="en">Hen-bean;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Hens</etym> 
<etym lang="en">bean;</etym> because its flowers are 
not unlike to a bean in its blos&shy;
som.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hence(adv)">Hence,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heonan</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hin,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hinc,</etym> 
henceforth, hereafter.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="henchman(n)">An Hench-Man,</form><xpln lang="en">the same with a 
Page; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">Hines-man;</etym> from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hine,</etym> a servant, and 
<etym lang="oe">Man,</etym> a man. Spelman draws 
it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hengift</etym>, an 
horse, and <etym lang="oe">Man;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term> a 
Groom, or he that looketh af&shy;
ter horses</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="happen(a)" lexeme="heply(a)">Heppen, or Heply,</form><xpln lang="en">a word fre&shy;
quently used in Lincolnshire, 
which signifieth handy, or in&shy;
dustrious: I suppose it is the 
same with <etym lang="en">Helply,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Helpful,</etym> 
which see.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"heply" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="herald(n)">Herald,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Herault, 
Heraut,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Araldo,</etym> the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Heraldo,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Herold,</etym> all the same; a Pro&shy;
claimer, or Crier. Versteg. 
derives it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, &shy;
an army, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> 
a champion; or it may be 
drawn from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heer-&shy;
Alt,</etym> an Elder, or Senior in an 
Army: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an army, or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herr,</etym> a master; that 
is, one that is sworn to be 
faithful to an army, or ma&shy;
ster: Or from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an army, and <etym lang="oe">Ald,</etym> a 
servant: Or lastly, as Min&shy;
shew hath it, from <etym lang="tt">Heierbol&shy;
den</etym> to put an end to; be&shy;
cause they are sent to bring 
wars to an end, and to pro&shy;
claim a future peace.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="herbal(n)">Herbal,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Herbale,</etym> 
a book that giveth a descri&shy;
ption of herbs; and this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Herba,</etym> an herb: 
From hence, an Herbalist; 
that is, one that by study 
searcheth into the nature of 
herbs.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heretofore(adv)">Heretofore,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Her&shy;
zuvor,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heritage(n)">Heritage,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Heri&shy;
tage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Hereditag&shy;
gio, Hereditanza,</etym> an inheri&shy;
tance; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Haeres,</etym> an heir. <term lang="la">v.</term> Inhe&shy;
rit.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hermit(n)">Hermit,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Her&shy;
mite, Ermite,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Her&shy;
mita,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ermita,</etym> all 
the same; one that, for the 
sake of Religion, renounceth 
humane society; all from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&rho;&eta;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a desart: From 
hence, an Hermitage; as also 
the Fr. G. Hermitage, that 
privy place where Hermits 
abide.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="heron(n)">Heron,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hairon, 
Heron,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Hierone, Airone,</etym> 
</page>

<page sig="N4v"> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ayrone,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and these from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ardea,</etym> the same; or 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aer,</etym> the air; 
because it is a bird that flieth 
aloft in the air: Or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eyer,</etym> eggs. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hurricane(n)">Herricane,</form><xpln lang="en">a word well known 
by such as sail to America, 
signifying a storm, or tem&shy;
pest; from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Hura&shy;
can, Uracan,</etym> a whirl-wind, 
or storm. <term lang="la">v.</term> Hurry.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="herring(n)">Herring,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="pe">H&aelig;&shy;
ring,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Herinck,</etym> the 
Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Hareng,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Haring,</etym> the same; whence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Herinc</etym>, a Ronde&shy;
let.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hurt(n)">Heurts,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Heurtes,</etym> 
blew pills. Guillim. taketh 
them to be drawn like Hurtle-&shy;
berries, Whortle berries, or 
Bill-berries.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hue(n)">Hew, or Hue</form><xpln lang="en">, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hewe, Hywe,</etym> colour, fa&shy;
shion; or <etym lang="oe">Hiwan,</etym> to form, 
or hew out.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hew(v)">To Hew,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heawian</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hauwen, Houwen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hawen,</etym> to cleave, 
to cut asunder.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hey-day(ex)">Hey-day,</form><xpln lang="en">an Interjection of Ad&shy;
miring; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> <etym lang="en">High-day,</etym> O 
joyful day! O happy day!</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hay(n)">An Hey-Net</form><xpln lang="en">used by Hunters: 
See <etym lang="en">Hay,</etym> of the same signifi&shy;
cation.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hickock(n)" lexeme="hicket(n)">Hickock, or Hicket,</form><xpln lang="en">from the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Hicken,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hick,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Houquet, Hoc&shy;
quet,</etym> a sobbing: In the AS. <etym lang="oe">Si&shy;
cettan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hicken,</etym> 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hixen,</etym> all sig&shy;
nifying to sob; from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hickwall(n)">Hick-wall,</form><xpln lang="en">Hick-way, or Wood-&shy;
pecker, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hic&shy;
gan</etym>, to try, to search tho&shy;
rowly; because it strikes its 
bill against a tree, or wall, and 
so maketh an hole therein.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hide(v)">To Hide,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hydan</etym>, 
to conceal; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoeden, 
Haeden,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Huten,</etym> 
to keep.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hide(n)">An Hide</form><xpln lang="en">or Skin, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hyde,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haude, 
Huyd,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Haut,</etym> <term lang="la">id.</term> 
and all perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hydan</etym>, with us, to Hide; 
for it hideth, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) covereth 
the body: Or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Huten,</etym> to guard; because it 
guardeth the body.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hideous(a)">Hideous,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hi&shy;
deux,</etym> that which astonisheth: 
Or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Epsilon;&#x1F34;&delta;&omega;</etym>, to see; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&epsilon;&nu;&#x1F78;&nu; &#x1F30;&delta;&#x1F73;&sigma;&theta;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, terrible to 
be seen. It is also derived of 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hedan</etym>, to take heed; 
or <etym lang="oe">Hydean,</etym> to hide; it sig&shy;
nifying a thing from which 
every one naturally takes care 
to hide himself.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="high(a)">High,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heah,</etym> the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Hey,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ho, 
Hoogh,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hoch,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hill(n)">Hill,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hill,</etym> the Fr. 
</page>

<page sig="N5r">  
Th. <etym lang="hd">Huuele,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hille,</etym> 
the same. It seemeth to be a 
Contract of the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hogel;</etym> 
or rather, as they pronounce 
it, <etym lang="tt">Higel,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Highel,</etym> which 
may come from the Eng. 
<etym lang="en">High,</etym> because it is higher than 
other parts of the earth. </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hillock(n)">Hillock,</form><xpln lang="en">a little hill; the Dimi&shy;
nutive of <etym lang="en">Hill;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hilt(n)">Hilt,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helt,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hilte, Hielte,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Elsa, Elza,</etym> an helve; or per&shy;
haps, <term lang="la">q.d.</term> the <etym lang="en">Hold.</etym> <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Hold.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="him(pr)">Him,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Him, 
Hime,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Him</etym> 
the same; the Cyprians used 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F32;&nu;</etym>, and the Poets <etym lang="gk">&mu;&#x1F76;&nu;</etym>, for him, 
or her.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hind(n)">An Hind,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hinde,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hiinde,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hinde,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hinnus,</etym> which comes 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F5D;&nu;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;, &#x1F3D;&nu;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> 
a colt, the foal of a mare, or 
mule, metaphorically.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hindberry(n)">Hind-berries,</form><xpln lang="en">the fruit of the 
Ras berry-tree; so called per&shy;
haps because they grow most&shy;
ly where <etym lang="en">hinds</etym> or deer fre&shy;
quent; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) in woods, or 
forests.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hinder(v)">To Hinder,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hin&shy;
drian,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hinderen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hindern,</etym> the 
same; whence the Dan. For&shy;
hindrer, to put one back in 
doing a thing.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hinge(n)">Hinge,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hinge,</etym> or 
<etym lang="bl">Henge,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from our 
word <etym lang="en">Hang,</etym> because the door 
hangeth upon it.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hint(v)">To Hint,</form><xpln lang="en">or give one a touch of a 
thing; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
ter,</etym> to implant.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hip(n)">Hip,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hipe,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heupe, Huppe,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hufft,</etym> all signifying a 
thigh.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hip(n)">Hippes,</form><xpln lang="en">in Chaucer, <etym lang="me">Hipe</etym>, the 
fruit of the greater bramble; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heopa,</etym> the 
same; or <etym lang="oe">Hiope</etym>, a wild 
rose; that is, the rose that 
groweth upon the great bram&shy;
ble.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hippocras(n)">Hippocras,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hi&shy;
pocras,</etym> an Aromatick wine; 
so called, because it is strained 
through a woollen cloth, cal&shy;
led <etym lang="gk">Hippocrates</etym> 's sleeve.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hire(v)">Hire,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyran,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hueren,</etym> to hire; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyre</etym>, and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Huere</etym>, signifying, ones 
hire, or wages.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="his(pr)">His,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">His,</etym> him, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hiss(v)">To Hiss,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hiscean,</etym> the 
Belg <etym lang="bl">Hissen, Hisschen,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zischen,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sis&shy;
chiare,</etym> to hiss; or Siss, as 
they say in Lincolnshire; all 
possibly from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="historian(n)">Historian,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Histo&shy;
rien, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Historia,</etym> an history.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hit(v)">To Hit:</form><xpln lang="en">Minshew ingeniously 
derives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ictus,</etym> 
a blow, by adding thereto the 
note of Aspiration.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="N5v">  
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hitch(v)">To Hitch,</form><xpln lang="en">a term in  Sailing; 
which is expounded, to catch 
hold of any thing with a ca&shy;
ble, or hook,  and so to hold 
it fast; perhaps from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Ficher,</etym>  and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Figere,</etym> to  fasten.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hitch(v)">To Hitch,</form><xpln lang="en">as we say, Hitch-but&shy;
tock, and Hitch-neighbours; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hicgan</etym>, to 
endeavour, to strive: Or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hocher,</etym> to shake; 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Quassare,</etym> to shake much. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
Level coyl.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hatchel(n)">Hitchel,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">v.</term> <etym lang="en">Heckle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hithe(n)">Hithe,</form><xpln lang="en">as Queen-Hithe, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hy&eth;</etym>, a port, or ha&shy;
ven.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hither(adv)">Hither,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hi&eth;er,</etym> 
whence <etym lang="oe">Hi&eth;erweard</etym>, hitherward.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hive(n)">Hive</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyfe,</etym> a 
bee-hive; this perhaps from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Huyven,</etym> to cover 
the head.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hive-dross(n)">Hive-dross,</form><xpln lang="en">that which bees 
make at the entrance of their 
hive, to expel the cold withal; 
not from Hive, and Dross, 
as one would verily think at 
first sight; but from <etym lang="en">Hive,</etym> 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trost.</etym> trust, or 
comfort; for it comforteth 
the bees, by saving them from 
the cold.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ho(ex)" lexeme="gee-ho(ex)">Ho, Gee-Ho,</form><xpln lang="en">a fictitious word 
used by our Coach men and 
Car-men, whilst they drive 
their horses.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoarse(a)">Hoarse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heersch,</etym> 
the same; and both from 
their harsh sound, thereby 
expressing hoarsness it self.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoary(a)">Hoary,</form><xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Har,</etym> 
gray; or <etym lang="oe">Harian,</etym> to grow 
gray. Minshew draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F6D;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; or rather, 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F69;&rho;&alpha;&#x1F77;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, timely.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoary(a)">Hoary,</form><xpln lang="en">musty; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Horig,</etym> filthy; this from 
<etym lang="oe">Horg, Horh,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Ho&shy;
rewen,</etym> nastiness, filth.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hob(pn)">Hob,</form><xpln lang="en">a contract of <etym lang="en">Robin;</etym> as, 
Robin-good-fellow. <term lang="la">v.</term> Gob&shy;
lius.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hobble(v)">Hobble,</form><xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Habbelen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Hobben,</etym> the 
same; with us, to leap a little 
way at once: To Hopple. <term lang="la">v.</term> 
<etym lang="en">Hop.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hobby(n)">Hobby,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haube&shy;
reau, Aubereau,</etym> an hawk that 
preyeth upon doves, larks, 
&amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hobby-horse(n)">An Hobby-Horse,</form><xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Hobin,</etym> a pad-nag: Or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aubere,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Hobero,</etym> an ash-co&shy;
lour'd horse; and these per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Albus,</etym> 
white.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hobgoblin(n)">Hobgoblins,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Robgoblins, 
from <etym lang="en">Robin-good fellow,</etym> or 
from <etym lang="en">Oberon,</etym> King of Fayries. 
<term lang="la">v.</term> Goblins.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoboy(n)">Hobotes,</form><xpln lang="en">a musical instrument; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haultbois,</etym> 
high wood; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a wooden 
instrument of an high sound.</xpln></wordentry>   

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hockle(v)">To Hockle,</form><xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term> Houghle; that is, 
to ham-string; from <etym lang="en">Hough,</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page>

<page sig="N6r">   
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hocktide(n)" lexeme="Hock-day(n)">Hock-tide, Hock-day,</form><xpln lang="en">and Hock-&shy;
Tuesday: Spelman saith, that 
it is a festival-day which the 
English set a-part, to be kept 
as a Memorial of the Danes
being driven out of the land; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heah tid</etym>, the
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoogh-tyd,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hochzelt,</etym> an high time; or as we say, an High Day. v. Tide.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hocus-pocus(n)">Hocus Pocus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Conjurer, or 
Jugler; perhaps from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Hocher,</etym> to shake, and <etym lang="fr">Po&shy;
cher,</etym> to poke, or thrust for&shy;
ward with the finger; for all 
the art in <term lang="fr">Leger de main</term> lies 
in this, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  in shaking their 
little balls in boxes, or the 
like; and so quickly, with 
dexterity of hand, snatching 
away what was there-under 
before, and leaving often&shy;
times somewhat else in its 
room, with which they be&shy;
guile the spectators.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ho(ex)">Hoe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">He, Eh&ograve;,</etym> 
an Interjection of calling; 
from the sound, as many o&shy;
ther Interjections besides it 
are.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hog(n)">Hog,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sheep of the second year; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hogan</etym>, to take 
care of; or <etym lang="oe">Hoga</etym>, care; be&shy;
cause they being young and 
tender, the Shepherd is to take 
more care about them than 
the rest of the flock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hog(n)" lexeme="swine(n)">An Hog or Swine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Suge, Sugu,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Soegh, Soech,</etym> a sow; 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sucu&shy;
la,</etym> a little sow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hogo(n)">Hogoo,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haut 
Goust,</etym> a great smell, or un&shy;
pleasant relish, fuming up out 
of the stomach, into the 
mouth, after the eating of vi&shy;
ctuals not well season'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hogshead(n)">Hogshead,</form> <xpln lang="en">a measure so called. 
Minshew derives it from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dekshood,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">Ogshood,</etym> 
the same. Some derive it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Orca,</etym> a great vessel 
for wine, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoofd,</etym> 
an head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoise(v)">To Hoise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Haus&shy;
ser,</etym> to lift up; and this from 
<etym lang="fr">Haut,</etym> high; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to heave 
up on high.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hold(v)">To Hold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heal&shy;
dan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Houden,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Halten,</etym> to hold, stay,
 and metaphorically to set a 
 rate on things to be sold; as 
 we say, What held he his 
 commodity at? All perhaps 
 from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Houd,</etym> an han&shy;
 dle, or helve, by which things 
 are held.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hold(n)">The Hold,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing, the 
lowest room in a ship, where&shy;
in provision is laid; from our 
word <etym lang="en">Hold,</etym> because it holds 
Sea-men's necessaries.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hold(v)">To Hold</form> <xpln lang="en">of the King, or a Lord: 
It may simply be drawn from 
our word, to <etym lang="en">Hold;</etym> that is, 
to enjoy some Living, or E&shy;
state by the King's, or a Lord's 
donation: And for this reason 
our Law hath made use of the 
</page> 

<page sig="N6v">
words Tenant, and Tene&shy;
ment; both coming from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Teneo</etym>, to hold: Or from 
the AS. and Belg. <etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, 
faithful; or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Huldi&shy;
gen;</etym> as we say, to pay Ho&shy;
mage to his Lord. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hole(n)">An Hole,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hole</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Hol,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Holian, 
Aholan,</etym> to hollow: There is 
also in the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hol,</etym> 
of the very same signification. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, hollow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="halidom(n)" lexeme="holidame(ex)">Holidom, Halidom, or Holi&shy;
dame,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient way of 
swearing; either, as Somne&shy;
rus hath it, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ha&shy;
ligdom,</etym> sanctity; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Halig,</etym> holy, and 
<etym lang="oe">Dom, Dome,</etym> doom, or judg&shy;
ment; or lastly, it may be 
drawn from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Holy-&shy;
Dame;</etym> that is, an oath taken 
in the name of the holy Dame, 
or the Virgin Mary; which is 
most likely.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="holly(n)">Holly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Holegen,</etym> 
the same; and this from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hol,</etym> whole, and <etym lang="oe">Eege,</etym> an 
edge; because the leaves of one 
sort of these trees are whole, 
without any breach in them: 
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Houx;</etym> 
which Menagius draws from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&xi;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, sharp; ano&shy;
ther sort thereof being prickly 
about the edges.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hollow(adv)">Hollow</form> <xpln lang="en">He carried it Hollow; 
that is, overcame by much; 
and is as much as if one should 
say, He carried it Wholly; 
either from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Allic,</etym> the 
whole, all; or <etym lang="oe">Wallig,</etym> whol&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hollow(n)">Hollow,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Hole.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="holm(n)">Holm,</form> <xpln lang="en">an AS. word , signifying 
an hill or isle encompassed 
with little brooks or rivers: 
It is also a termination to ma&shy;
ny words still in use.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="holster(n)">Holster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a case for a lesser sort of 
gun; either from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hulse,</etym> an husk, unto which 
it is like; or from our word, 
to <etym lang="en">Hold;</etym> or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">He&shy;
lan</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Helen,</etym> to co&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="holt(n)">Holt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Holt</etym>, a 
wood; in Lincolnshire it is 
put to signifie a forest, or a 
great number of any trees, 
set somewhat close one to 
another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="holy(a)">Holy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Halig,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heyligh,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Heylig,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Halgian</etym>, to hallow, or 
consecrate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homage(n)">Homage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ho&shy;
mage, Hommage,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Homaggio,</etym> allegiance, fideli&shy;
ty; these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Homme,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Homo,</etym> a 
man; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the duty of a man, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Client, or Beneficia&shy;
ry; for the word Man is ta&shy;
ken for a Servant, and a Sol&shy;
dier that receiveth pay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="home(n)">Home,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ham, H&aelig;m,</etym> 
ones habitation, or mansion; whence <etym lang="oe">Hamweard</etym>, home-&shy;
</page> 

<page sig="N7r"> 
ward; and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ha&shy;
meau;</etym> with us, an Hamlet. 
Fr. Jun. derives it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0D;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, together; because 
it is the place where we are 
wont to be together. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="homely(a)">Homely,</form> <xpln lang="en">not handsom: It pri&shy;
marily denotes one that hath 
course raiment on, such as is 
usually wore at <etym lang="en">home</etym>, where 
there is seldom need of splen&shy;
did or costly attire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hone(n)">An Hone:</form> <xpln lang="en">Mer. Cas. derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&kappa;&#x1F79;&nu;&eta;</etym>, a whet&shy;
stone. It may, with more like&shy;
lihood, be drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;n,</etym> a stone; and though this 
word be not read in Somne&shy;
rus, yet we read <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;nan</etym>, to 
stone; so that there is no 
doubt but the Noun <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;n</etym> 
was formerly used by the 
English Saxons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="honey(n)">Honey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hunig,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Honigh,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Honeg,</etym> the same; all not im&shy;
probably from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hife</etym>, 
an hive, or family; because 
it is made up by families, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) swarms, or hives of 
bees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr" lexeme="honi(a)">Hony,</form> <xpln lang="en">upon the King's Arms; 
the whole Motto is this, 
<term lang="fr">Hony soit qui mal y pense</term>; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) ill to him that ill 
thinks; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ho&shy;
ny,</etym> out of use; for which is 
now used <term lang="fr">Honte</term>, ignominy, 
shame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hood(su)">Hood,</form> <xpln lang="en">in composition, as in 
Man-hood, Priest-hood, &amp;c. 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heyd,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heit,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Had, 
Hade,</etym> a condition, or state.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hood(n)">An Hood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hod</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoed, Hoete,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hut</etym> the same; these 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoeden, Hue&shy;
den,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Huten,</etym> to 
defend, or keep safe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoof(n)">Hoof,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hof</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoef,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Huff,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hook(n)">An Hook,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Hoce,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haeckt, 
Hoeck,</etym> of the same significa&shy;
tion; all possibly from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Uncus,</etym> crooked.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoop(v)" lexeme="whoop(v)">To Hoop, or Whoop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Houper,</etym> to cry out in&shy;
significantly: Or from the Cimbr. <etym lang="ci">Op,</etym> a bewailing, or 
lamentation; all fictitious 
words.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoop(n)">An Hoop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hop,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoep,</etym> the same; all 
originally from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Couper,</etym> to cut, or cleave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoot(v)">To Hoot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Huer, 
Huyer,</etym> to whoop; both feig&shy;
ned from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hop(v)">To Hop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hoppan,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hippelen, Huppen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hupffen,</etym> to leap 
a little; whence <etym lang="tt">Hupff</etym>, an 
hop, or leap; all primarily 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Huppe,</etym> the 
hip, upon which the stress of 
hopping depends.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hop(n)">An Hop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hop, 
Hoppe,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Houblon,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hopff,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="N7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hope(n)">Hope,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hopa</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hope,</etym> the same; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hopian</etym>. Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hopen</etym>, and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hoffen</etym>, to 
hope.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hopper-arsed(a)">Hopper-ars'd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word 
<etym lang="en">Hop;</etym> for such, when they go 
along, seem, as it were, to hop 
on the way.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"hopper-arsed" antedates earliest OED citation (1699).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hopper(n)">Hopper,</form> <xpln lang="en">Mill-Hopper, we may 
call it a funnel, through which 
corn is poured into the mill; 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>, a 
top, or head; or from its <etym lang="en">hop&shy;
ping</etym> to and again when the 
Mill goes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoppet(n)">An Hoppet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word which in 
Lincolnshire is used for a bas&shy;
ket to carry fruit about in; 
perhaps from <etym lang="en">Corbet,</etym> a little 
basket; and this from <etym lang="la">Corbis,</etym> 
a basket, by adding the ter&shy;
mination <etym lang="la">et,</etym> which dimi&shy;
nishes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hopple(v)">To Hopple an horse,</form> <xpln lang="en">to tie his 
feet with a rope; from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Copulare;</etym> that is, to cou&shy;
ple his feet together.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoard(v)">To Hord,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hord</etym>, 
a treasure; or <etym lang="oe">Hordan</etym>, to 
lay up riches.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horn(n)">Horn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Teut. and 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Horn</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hooren, Horen,</etym> the same; all 
undoubtedly from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> an horn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hornet(n)">An Hornet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyr&shy;
net</etym>, a fly so called; because 
it hath little horns on its 
head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="horse(n)">Horse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hors,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rosz</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ros,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; from hence our word 
 Horse-leech, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a leech 
 that doth fasten it self upon 
 horses legs, and by sucking 
 away corrupted blood, help&shy;
 eth them in several distem&shy;
 pers. V. Leech.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hose(n)">Hose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hosa,</etym> the 
Belg. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Hose,</etym> the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Chausse,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Caleas</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Calzi,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hosen,</etym> the same. It may per&shy;
haps be drawn from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Huose,</etym> high-shooes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hospitable(a)">Hospitable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ho&shy;
spitable,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this again 
from <etym lang="la">Hospes,</etym> a guest; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one given to hospitality; he 
that entertaineth strangers 
kindly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hospital(n)">Hospital,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Hospital,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Hospedale,</etym> an house built <etym lang="la">pro 
Hospitio,</etym> for the entertain&shy;
ment of indigent, or diseased 
persons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="host(n)">An Host,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Host, 
Ost,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Hoste,</etym> an ar&shy;
my; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Hostis,</etym> an enemy in war.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="host(n)">An Host,</form> <xpln lang="en">he that keepeth pub&shy;
lick lodgings for passingers, or 
others; from the Fr G. and 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Hoste,</etym> which comes from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hospes,</etym> an host; al&shy;
so a guest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hostage(n)">Hostage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ho&shy;
stage, Ostage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ho&shy;
staggio,</etym> a pledge in war; all &shy;
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hostis,</etym> the ene&shy;
my; because hostages are de&shy;
</page> 

<page sig="N8r"> 
manded and received from the 
enemy. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hostry(n)" lexeme="hostelry(n)">Hostery, or Hostelry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hostellerie,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Hostaria,</etym> an Inn; this again 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hostel,</etym> an 
house, or hall.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hostess(n)">Hostess,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ho&shy;
stesse,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Hostessa,</etym> an 
Host's wife that keepeth a 
publick Inn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hotch-potch(n)" lexeme="hodge-podge(n)">Hotch-potch, or Hodge-podge,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hochepot,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hutspot,</etym> a Gallimaw&shy;
frey; and these from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Hocher,</etym> and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hutsen,</etym> to shake, and <etym lang="bl">Pot</etym>; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Shake pot. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hot cockles(n)">Hot-cockles,</form> <xpln lang="en">a play very well 
known; perhaps from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Hautes Coquilles.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hover(v)">Hover,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Huyveren,</etym> 
to chatter with cold: Or from 
the other <etym lang="en">Hover,</etym> because when 
we are a-cold, we stretch, or 
spread forth our hands to&shy;
wards the fire, so to receive 
more warmth, leaning for&shy;
wards with our bodies.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Sense of "hover" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hover(v)">To Hover,</form> <xpln lang="en">to fly about with 
wings stretched out at length, 
as a bird over her prey; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heafian</etym>, to heave 
up; or from our word, to 
<etym lang="en">Cover;</etym> or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Couver,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Covare,</etym> 
to coure, as an hen doth upon 
her eggs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hough(n)">Hough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hoh</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haessen,</etym> the hough, 
or ham.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="howlet(n)">An Houlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hu&shy;
lette, Houlotte,</etym> a little owl; 
all from our word <etym lang="en">Howl;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hound(n)">An Hound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hunde</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Houd,</etym> or 
the Teut. and Dan. <etym lang="tt">Hund,</etym> 
<etym lang="da">Hundt,</etym> the same Minshew 
and Fr. Jun. think that all of 
them are Contracts of the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F77;&delta;&iota;&nu;</etym>, a little dog. v.
Hunt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hour(n)">An Hour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Heure,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Huere,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Vhr;</etym> and all originally from 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="la">Hora,</etym> <etym lang="gk">&#x1F6F;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, 
an hour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="house(n)">House,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Hus</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Husz,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Huys,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Haus,</etym> the same; from hence 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Casa</etym>, unless it may 
rather seem to come from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Casa</etym>, a cottage; because 
perhaps about the declining 
state of the Empire, when 
good carriage, or breeding be&shy;
gan to propagate it self, out 
of palliated and flattering ci&shy;
vility, they called their sum&shy;
ptuous houses only <etym lang="la">Casas</etym>, cot&shy;
tages; perhaps after some such 
form as this, Will you please 
to grace <term lang="la">Casam meam</term>, my 
cottage with your presence.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="house of office(n)">An House of office:</form> <xpln lang="en">Versteg. 
writes it more truly, An
House of ease.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="houseleek(n)">House-leek,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, because it 
groweth upon thatched <etym lang="en">hou&shy;
ses</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoast(v)">Houst,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heostan,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="N8v">
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoesten,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Husten,</etym> to cough; all very 
likely from the sound. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="how(adv)">How,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ha</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hoe,</etym> or the Teut. and Fr. Th.
 <etym lang="hd">Wie,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="howl(v)">To Howl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heu&shy;
len,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Huylen,</etym> the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Houler,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ahul&shy;
lar, Aullar,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all origi&shy;
nally from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&lambda;&omicron;&lambda;&#x1F79;&zeta;&omega;, &shy;
&#x1F59;&lambda;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to howl; and this 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="howlsom(n)">Howlsom,</form> <xpln lang="en">a ship is so called when 
it hulls well; from <etym lang="en">Hull,</etym> 
which see.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"howlsom" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hoy(n)">Hoy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Heu,</etym> a 
kind of ship so called, because 
it saileth swiftly, saith Adr. 
Jun. Or perhaps from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoogh,</etym> or the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Hoch,</etym> high; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a ship 
 made high, considering her 
 burthen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huckle-bone(n)">The Huckle-bone,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hucken,</etym> to sit 
down; which part Nature has 
ordain'd for that use.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huck-shouldered(a)">Huck-shoulder'd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hocker,</etym> hunch-backed, and 
<etym lang="tt">Shoulder;</etym> which see.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"huck-shouldered" antedates earliest OED citation (1847-48).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huckster(n)">Huckster, or Hegler,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fore&shy;
staller; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hock,</etym> 
one that buyeth fruit, and 
such things, to sell again into 
the market.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huddle(v)">To Huddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">to do any thing too 
hastily, to mingle many things 
together carelesly and confu&shy;
sedly; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hu&shy;
deln,</etym> to mix: Or rather, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schutteln,</etym> to 
shake, by a Metaphor taken 
from lots, or dice, that being 
shook in the Lottery box, are 
thereby mixed without order.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hue and cry(n)">Hue and Cry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">H&uuml;er,</etym> to cry out aloud, to 
hoot: Or rather, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Oyez,</etym> hear ye.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huff(v)">Huff,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the play at tables; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
to take up a man which, by 
over-sight, was missed by the 
opponent; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Heben,</etym> to take up; because 
we first take up the man that 
is huffed, before we remove 
another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huff(v)">To Huff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hiighen,</etym> 
to puff, or blow: Or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heofen</etym>, to lift up; 
because such as breath thick, 
and strongly, may be percei&shy;
ved to rise and fall like a 
Smith's bellows.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hug(v)">To Hug,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Embrace, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hogan,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hugghen,</etym> to be careful and 
tender over: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hegian</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haeg&shy;
hen,</etym> to hedge; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to en&shy;
compass ones neck with the 
arms, as with an hedge, there&shy;
by to defend the party, as it 
were, from danger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huge(a)">Huge,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Great, either from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hefig,</etym> heavy; or, as 
Minshew supposeth, from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Augere,</etym> to increase; or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoogh,</etym> high, 
tall; or lastly, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Oga</etym>, terrour; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  terrible 
big.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="O1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hugger-mugger(adv)">Hugger-mugger,</form> <xpln lang="en">privately; per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hogan</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hugghen,</etym> to ob&shy;
serve, and the Dan. and Suec. 
<etym lang="se">Morker,</etym> darkness; the word 
importing the doing of any 
thing as it were in the dark, 
so that none shall know it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Huguenot(n)">Huguenots,</form> <xpln lang="en">a French name gi&shy;
ven the Calvinists; either 
from <etym lang="la">Huc nos,</etym> the beginning 
of their Apologetical Ora&shy;
tion, made before Cardinal 
Lotharingus; or the great 
Chancellor of France, in the 
time of Francis, the Second, 
or Charles the Ninth; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="fr">les Guenons de Hus</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
John Huss's Apes, or Fol&shy;
lowers; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="fr">les Guenots 
de Hus</etym>, John huss's Imps; 
or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eidgenos&shy;
sen,</etym> men of a confederacy; 
and this from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eid,</etym> 
with us Oath, and <etym lang="tt">Geniossen,</etym> 
to enjoy; this again from 
<etym lang="tt">Nuiz,</etym> profitable. <etym lang="fr">Guenot</etym> 
is taken from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Genius,</etym> 
a good or evil Angel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hulk(n)">Hulk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Holck,</etym> the 
<emend err="Belk">Belg</emend>. <etym lang="bl">Hulcke,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Heux,</etym> or the Ital <etym lang="it">Urca,</etym> a 
ship of burthen; and these 
perhaps from the AS <etym lang="oe">Hulc</etym>, 
a cottage, for the similitude.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hull(v)">To Hull</form> <xpln lang="en">as a ship, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to ride 
to and again upon the sea; 
perhaps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hol&shy;
len,</etym> to sail, or run swiftly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hull(n)">The Hull</form> <xpln lang="en">of a ship, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
body of a ship, without sails, 
cables, or mast; not impro&shy;
bably from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hulse,</etym> 
an husk; it being, as it were, 
only the husk, or bark of a 
ship.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hullock(n)">Hulluck, or Hullock,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in 
Sailing; perhaps from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hulle,</etym> an hood, or wo&shy;
man's veil; because it is but a 
small sail-cloth, as an hood in 
comparison; and this from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helan</etym>, to cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="humble-bee(n)">Humble-Bee,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Bumble-Bee.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="humbles(n)">The Humbles</form> <xpln lang="en">of a stag, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nombles d'un Cerf,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>: Or perhaps in a some&shy;
what different sence, from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Umbilicus,</etym> the navel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hum(v)">To Humm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hom&shy;
melen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hum&shy;
men, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hommel</etym>, and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hammel</etym>, 
a drone; all feigned from the 
sound</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="humour(n)">Humour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Hu&shy;
meur,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Humore;</etym> 
by interpretation, the natural 
inclination, or temper of 
mind; but it rather signifies 
an habit of acting according 
to the appetite, or some irre&shy;
gular affection, than accor&shy;
ding to reason; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Humor,</etym> an humour in 
the body; because such an ha&shy;
bit is thought to proceed from 
the predominancy of some 
corporeal humour: From 
hence the Ital. <etym lang="it">Humorista</etym>, an 
Humourist; he that acteth 
wholly according to, his own 
passions.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hunch(v)">To Hunch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Husch,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="O1v"> 
a blow with the fist; and this 
not unlikely from the Lat. <etym lang="la">I&shy;
ctus,</etym> a blow. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hunchbacked(a)">Hunch-backed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hocker,</etym> huck-shoulder'd, and 
<etym lang="tt">Back:</etym> Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hucken,</etym> to hang down to&shy;
wards the ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hundred(n)">Hundred,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hun&shy;
dred</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hondert,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hundert,</etym> a century. 
Some derive them all from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Cantred,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Centum,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hunger(v)">Hunger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hun&shy;
grian,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hongheren,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hungern,</etym> to be an
hungry; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hun&shy;
gor</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hongher</etym>, and 
the Dan. and Teut. <etym lang="da">Hunger</etym>; 
with us also Hunger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hunt(v)">Hunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hentan</etym>, 
to search out, to pursue; 
whence <etym lang="oe">Hunta</etym>, an Hunter; 
and <etym lang="oe">Huntian</etym>, to hunt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hurdle(n)">Hurdle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyrdl</etym>, 
or the Belg. and Teut <etym lang="tt">Hurde,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&rho;&delta;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&eta;</etym>; that 
is, any thing rowled up in a 
bundle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hurly-burly(n)">Hurly-Burly,</form> <xpln lang="en">a tumult; either 
immediately from the sound, 
or from our word, to <etym lang="en">Whirl,</etym> 
and the AS <etym lang="oe">Burh</etym>, a town; 
that is, an uproar, or com&shy;
motion in a city, or town; a 
city-tumult.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hurry(v)">To Hurry,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Harier, Ahurir,</etym> to hare, 
or affright one; or <etym lang="fr">Harseler,</etym> 
to provoke; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hergian</etym>, to destroy as in 
war.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hurt(a)">Hurt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyrt,</etym> 
hurt, wounded; or from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Omicron;&#x1F50;&tau;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to wound, by the 
interposition of the letter r; 
or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Heurter,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Urtare,</etym> to thrust, 
or squeese; and these again 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Urgere,</etym> to 
press.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="husband(n)">An Husband,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hus,</etym> an house, and our 
word <etym lang="en">Band,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bon&shy;
da</etym>, a ligament.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hush(v)">To Hush:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Haschah,</etym> to be 
silent. I should rather think 
it to be a corruption of the 
word <etym lang="en">Hiss,</etym> which we com&shy;
monly use when silence is re&shy;
quired.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="husk(n)">Husk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hulsche, 
Hulse,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="bl">Hul&shy;
len,</etym> to cover the head; and 
both from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helan</etym>, to 
cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="housewife(n)">Huswife,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the <etym lang="en">wife</etym> of the 
<etym lang="en">house</etym>; though we often take 
it for any woman that playeth 
the Cook well.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hut(n)">An Hut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Fr.
 G. <etym lang="fr">Hutte</etym>, or the Teut. 
 <etym lang="tt">Hutte,</etym> a cottage; all from 
 the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hueten,</etym> to keep 
 sheep, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hutch(n)">Hutch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hwaecca,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="O2r"> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Huche,</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Hucha,</etym> a chest to put corn in: 
All perhaps corrupted from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Arca,</etym> a chest. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="huzz(v)">To Huzz,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="hie(v)">To Hy,</form> <xpln lang="en">to make haste; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Higan</etym>, to hasten; 
or <etym lang="oe">Hiegen</etym>, to strive with 
might and main: Or from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hyghen,</etym> to puff: 
Or lastly, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ei&shy;
len,</etym> or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ilen,</etym> to 
make haste. This Fr. Jun. 
draws from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Epsilon;#x1F30;&lambda;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to 
rowl, or tumble.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="I"><alpha>I</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="I(pr)">I</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ic</etym>. the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Ich,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ick;</etym> 
 which are all derived from the 
 Lat and Gr. <etym lang="gr">Ego,</etym> I. We al&shy;
 so pronounce I, for Yes, Yea,
 which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jabber(v)">To Iabber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Ga&shy;
ber,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gabberen,</etym> 
to talk Gibberish, to speak 
much hastily and indistinct&shy;
ly: Or from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gabba&shy;
re,</etym> to fobb a man off with 
much speaking.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jack(n)">A Iack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Iack,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jaque,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Giacco di Maglia,</etym> or the 
Hisp <etym lang="sp">Jaco de Malla,</etym> a coat 
of Mail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jack(n)">A Iack,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish so called; per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jaculum,</etym> 
a dart; as a Pike-fish, from 
our word Pike; either from 
the long figure of its body, 
fashioned somewhat like to a 
dart, or spear; or because it 
hasteneth directly towards the 
bottom of the water, as a dart 
flieth from the hand of him 
that casts it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kitchen-jack(n)" lexeme="turnspit(n)">A Kitchin-Iack, or Turnspit,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from our word <etym lang="en">Iack,</etym> for 
John; because in most Gen&shy;
tlemen's houses, before the in&shy;
vention of jacks, little boys 
were employed solely to turn 
the spit, and do other drudge&shy;
ry of the kitchin, called al&shy;
ways by the name of Iack. 
That forked piece of wood, 
by the help of which we pull 
off our boots, is also called 
Iack, because it supplies the 
place of Iack the boot-&shy;
catcher.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jacket(n)">Iacket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ja&shy;
quette,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Iacke,</etym> 
a short coat: From hence 
that saying amongst the 
French, <term lang="fr">Tourner Jaquette</term>, 
to apostatize from the Faith, 
to alter his word, or promise; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) such an one as we call a 
Turn-coat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jacob's-staff(n)">Iacob's-Staff, alias Pilgrim's-&shy;
Staff.</form> <xpln lang="en">a name invented by 
such as for Religion sake went 
on Pilgrimage to St. James of 
Compostella, saith Minshew. 
It is more commonly put for 
an Astronomical instrument, 
</page> 

<page sig="O2v"> 
to find out the motion and di&shy;
stance of the stars; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
staff whereby we climb up in&shy;
to heaven, as it were upon Ja&shy;
cob's ladder, to contemplate, 
and view the stars. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jade(a)">A Iade,</form> <xpln lang="en">or tired horse, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eode</etym>, he went; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he went once, but can 
go no more; as we say in Lat. 
<term lang="la">vixit</term>, for <term lang="la">mortuus est</term>: Or 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cadere,</etym> to fall 
down: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gaad</etym>, a goad, or spur; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
an horse that will not go with&shy;
out the spur.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jag(v)">Iag,</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hacken,</etym> to cut in 
notches; or <etym lang="tt">Sagen,</etym> to cut 
with a saw; which comes 
from <etym lang="tt">Sage,</etym> a saw; and both 
<term lang="it">&agrave; secando,</term> from cutting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jail(n)" lexeme="jailer(n)">Iail, and Iailer,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Gaol,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Gaoler.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jakes(n)">Iakes,</form> <xpln lang="en">or house of ease: Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Jacere,</etym> to lie: Perhaps from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chasse,</etym> a case.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jamb(n)">Iambs of an house,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
<emend err="the"></emend> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jambes,</etym> or the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Jambas,</etym> the side-posts 
of a door; all from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jambe,</etym> a leg; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
shanks, or feet of an house, 
for the similitude.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jangle(v)">To Iangle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jangler,</etym> to wrangle, or con&shy;
tend: Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ianc&shy;
ken,</etym> to grin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="janizary(n)">Ianizaries,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Great Turk's 
Life-guard-men; either from 
the Turkish word <etym lang="tu">Genizeri,</etym> 
new men, or new soldiers; 
or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Janua,</etym> a 
gate; because, they guard, 
and stand Sentinels at the Em&shy;
peror's gate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jar(v)">To Iar,</form> <xpln lang="en">or to be at variance: 
Minshew derives it from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Garrire,</etym> to prattle. I 
chose rather, with Dr. Skin&shy;
ner, to draw it from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Guerroyer,</etym> to brawl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jar(n)">A Iar of oil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jare,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giarra, Zar&shy;
ra,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Jarro, Jar&shy;
ra, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jargon(n)">Iargon,</form> <xpln lang="en">barbarous, illiterate dis&shy;
course. Menagius derives it 
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Jerigonca,</etym> or 
<etym lang="sp">Gerigonca;</etym> but Minshew 
more ingeniously, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Garrien&shy;
do,</etym> from prating. Covarru&shy;
vias supposeth it to be so cal&shy;
led, q. <etym lang="la">Grecigonca,</etym> from the 
Greek Tongue; because when 
few of those former Ages un&shy;
derstood Greek, it seemed to 
many no better than Gibbe&shy;
rish. It would not be amiss 
to draw it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jargon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Jergone</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and these from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Chierico,</etym> a Clergy-man; for 
when the Laicks heard the La&shy;
tin Tongue, unknown to 
them, used in the Litur&shy;
gies, and Prayers of the 
Church, they called it, and 
all other Tongues which they 
understood not, Iargon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="javelin(n)">Iavelin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jave&shy;
line,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giavelotto,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Javalina,</etym> a dart; 
</page> 

<page sig="O3r"> 
all perhaps from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ja&shy;
vali Aper;</etym> as we say, a Boar-&shy;
Spear. Minshew draws it 
from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Jabel,</etym> an hun&shy;
ting-staff. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jaundice(n)">Iaundice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Jaul&shy;
nisse,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="fr">Jaune, 
Jaulne,</etym> yellow; whence this 
disease in horses is called the 
Yellows.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jaunt(v)">To Iaunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">used by us in a sence 
somewhat different from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jancer,</etym> to drive an 
horse about till he sweat; from 
whence we derive it. Or it 
may be drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hentan,</etym> to follow after.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jaunt(n)">The Iaunts of a wheel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jantes,</etym> spoaks.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"jaunt" antedates earliest OED citation (1706).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jaw(n)">Iaws,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geagl</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jo&uuml;e,</etym> the cheek-bone. But 
the learned Dr. Th. H. telleth 
us, that the Ancients writ it 
Chawes; and if so, it mani&shy;
festly flows from our word 
<etym lang="en">Chaw.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jay(n)">A Iay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jay, 
Jayon, Gayon,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kaa,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ka, Kaw,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Gazza,</etym> the same; all pos&shy;
sibly from its kawing note. 
Yet Fr. Jun. draws it from
 the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to gape; or
 <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&alpha;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, to be proud.</xpln></wordentry> 
 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ice(n)">Ice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Is, Isa,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eys,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eisz,</etym>
 the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="gr" lexeme="Ich dien(fw)">Ich Dien,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Motto of the 
Princes of Wales; from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ich,</etym> I, and <etym lang="tt">Dienen,</etym> or
 the AS. <etym lang="oe">Denian,</etym> to serve. 
It was the Motto or Symbol 
of John, King of Bohemia, 
whom Edward, the black 
Prince of Wales, slew in a 
Battle; who for a Monument 
of so great and signal a Victo&shy;
ry, made it the Motto of his 
own Arms; that so he might 
manifest his loyal Allegiance 
to King Edward the Third, 
his Father. Now to give a 
Reason why the Motto was 
such, the said King John took 
it, thereby emphatically to 
express a strange and unusual 
thing. It was as much as if 
he had said, I a King do serve; 
for at that time he served un&shy;
der Philip Valesius, King of 
France. Some derive it, and 
that ingeniously, from the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Irch Dien,</etym> I am your 
Country-man: in memory of 
Edward the Second, the first 
of English Blood that ever 
was advanced to the Principa&shy;
lity of Wales; whom his Fa&shy;
ther, Edward the first, ha&shy;
ving subdued all Wales, made 
Prince of, because he was born 
in the time of the Welsh 
Wars.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="idle(a)">Idle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Idel, 
Aydlige,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Idel, Ii&shy;
del,</etym> slothful, sluggish: Or &shy;
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eitel,</etym> vain, 
frivolous. Mer. Cas. derives 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F5D;&theta;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, tri&shy;
fles.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jealous(a)">Iealous,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ja&shy;
loux,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Geloso,</etym> id. 
</page> 

<page sig="O3v"> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Zealosus,</etym> full of zeal: 
From hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jalousie</etym>, the Ital <etym lang="it">Gelesia</etym>, and our word Iealousie. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jeer(v)">To Ieer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cear&shy;
cian,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Garrire,</etym> to 
prate: Or from the Ital <etym lang="it">Ga&shy;
rare,</etym> to strive; or <etym lang="it">Gara,</etym> a 
contention: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Keeren,</etym> to brush; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
touch one gently, or give one 
a gentle touch, as we say: 
Or, which is most likely, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scheeren,</etym> to 
provoke.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jollopped(a)">Iellopped, or Iowlopped,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term 
in Heraldry; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jo&uuml;e,</etym> a cheek, and <etym lang="fr">Loppe, 
Loppin,</etym> a sipp<emend err="p"></emend>et, or gobbet. 
It seemeth to signifie rather 
the gills that hang down from 
a cock's throat, like unto a 
Dewlap; and so ought rather 
to be written Dewlapped.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jelly(n)">Ielly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gel&eacute;e,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gelata, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all &agrave; 
<etym lang="la">Gelando,</etym> from friezing; for 
it is broth which, by standing 
till it be cold, grows into jel&shy;
ly, which represents ice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jeopardy(n)">Ieopardy,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">J'ay per&shy;
du,</etym> I have lost all: Or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jeu perdu,</etym> a lost 
game.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="gyrfalcon(n)">A Ierfalcon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Gerfaut,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gerfalcone,</etym> 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Girafalte,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gier Valck,</etym> or the Teut <etym lang="tt">Ger&shy;
falck,</etym> the same; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gyro,</etym> to turn round, 
and <etym lang="la">Falco,</etym> a faulcon, from its 
turning round in the air, 
which is contrary to the flight 
of other birds. Minshew 
draws it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Geyer,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghier,</etym> a vul&shy;
ture, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Falck,</etym> or 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Valck,</etym> a falcon; be&shy;
cause it is as ravenous as a vul&shy;
ture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jerk(n)">Ierk,</form> <xpln lang="en">the lash of a rod; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ge-rechen,</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Re&shy;
chen,</etym> to take revenge: Or 
from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Iacke,</etym> a whip; 
whence Iacken, to lash with 
a whip. Minshew derives it 
from the Goth. <etym lang="go">Gercken,</etym> to 
beat. It may be drawn from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gyrd,</etym> a rod.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jerkin(n)">Ierkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a short upper-coat; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyrtelkin,</etym> a little 
coat; the Dim of Cyrtel, 
a coat; formerly called, a 
Kertle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jerkin(n)">Ierkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a male-hawk; so called, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geye,</etym> a vul&shy;
ture, and the diminutive ter&shy;
mination <etym lang="tt">kin.</etym> Geyer is deri&shy;
ved from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gebren,</etym> 
for <etym lang="tt">Begehren,</etym> to covet; for 
its greediness: Or from <etym lang="tt">Keh&shy;
ren,</etym> to turn; or <etym lang="tt">Gaher,</etym> quick, 
or nimble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jess(n)" lexeme="jess-hawk(n)">A Iess, or Iess-hawk,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Eyass.</etym> </xpln>
<lemenote>
"jess-hawk" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jessant(a)">Iessant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
Iessant <term lang="fr">flowers de luces</term>; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Iettant,</etym> which 
comes from <etym lang="fr">Jetter,</etym> to cast 
forth; and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Jactare,</etym> to cast often.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jess(n)">Iesses,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gects,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Getti,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Zetti,</etym> 
ribbands hanging down from 
</page> 

<page sig="O4r"> 
garlands, or crowns. Hawks 
Iesses, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Jactando,</etym> from wag&shy;
ging to and again. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jest(n)">A Iest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Chistes,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew derives it 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gestire,</etym> or ra&shy;
ther <etym lang="la">Gesticulari,</etym> to ma&shy;
ke many motions, to be full of a&shy;
ction, as Actors are when they 
repeat some merry thing upon 
the publick stage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jet(n)">Iet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jet, Jaiet,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Jette;</etym> and all contracts 
of the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Gaga&shy;
tes,</etym> a river of Sicily, where 
the stone of this name was 
first found.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jet(v)">To Iet,</form> <xpln lang="en">to carry the ody state&shy;
ly, or proudly; from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Jetter,</etym> to toss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jewel(n)">Iewels,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joyau,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gioiello,</etym> the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Joyel,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Iuweel,</etym> 
the same; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Joca&shy;
lia,</etym> being things pleasant to 
the eye: Or, possibly, from 
our word <etym lang="en">Ioy.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Jews' trump(n)" lexeme="Jew's harp(n)">Iews-Trump, or Iews-harp,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the trumpet, or harp of the 
<etym lang="en">Jews;</etym> and it is so called, by 
way of contempt; for no&shy;
thing is more untunable, or 
less harmonious, than the 
hymns sung by the Jews, on 
their Festivals.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="if(c)">If,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, <etym lang="li">Gif</etym>, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gif</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
from <etym lang="oe">Gifan</etym>, to give, or 
grant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="island(n)">Iland,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ealand</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eylandt,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Igland</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
<etym lang="oe">Ea, Ig, Ige,</etym> water; and 
<etym lang="oe">Land;</etym> because it is land en&shy;
compassed on each side with 
water: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Isle,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Isola,</etym> (which 
are contracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Insu&shy;
la,</etym> an Isle,) and the same 
<etym lang="oe">Land.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="islet(n)">An Ilet,</form> <xpln lang="en">by contraction, an 
Eight; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Is&shy;
lette,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Isoletta,</etym> a 
little Island.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eyelet-hole(n)" lexeme="oillet-hole(n)">An Ilet or Ollet-hole,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oeillet,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Oi&shy;
ete,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Occhietto,</etym> an 
hole wherein a point is put; 
which are all Diminutives of 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oeil,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Oio,</etym> 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Occhio,</etym> an eye; 
which, in some sort, it doth 
resemble.</xpln></wordentry>
