<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ill(a)">Ill,</form> <xpln lang="en">a contract of <etym lang="en">Evil;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embargo(n)">Imbargo,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Em&shy;
bargo,</etym> a kind of imposition 
whereby ships are detained in 
port; this from <etym lang="sp">Embargar,</etym> 
to stay, or detain; and both 
from <etym lang="sp">En</etym> in, and <etym lang="sp">Barra,</etym> a 
bar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embark(v)">Imbark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
barquer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Imbar&shy;
care,</etym> to take ship. V. Bark.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embellish(v)">Imbellish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
bellir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Imbellire,</etym> 
to adorn; these from <etym lang="la">In,</etym> and 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bel;</etym> which comes 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bellus,</etym> pretty, 
fair.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="emboss(v)">Imboss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Imbossare,</etym> 
to adorn with bosses. V. <etym lang="en">Boss:</etym>
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="O4v"> 
 From hence Imbose'd-work; 
 which Higgin. calls Round-&shy;
 work. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="embroiderer(n)">Imbroiderer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Bordeur,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bordar,</etym> 
or the C Br. <etym lang="cb">Brodio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imbrue(v)">Imbrue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ab&shy;
breuver;</etym> to drink; or <etym lang="fr">Im&shy;
buer,</etym> to stain: Or from our 
own words, <etym lang="en">In,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Brew.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imburse(v)">To Imburs,</form> <xpln lang="en">to tender, or shew 
money; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
bourser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Imborsa&shy;
re,</etym> to disburse, or pay away 
money. V. Purse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imp(n)">Imp,</form> <xpln lang="en">a terrestrial spirit; either 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Impius,</etym> wic&shy;
ked; or from the other <etym lang="en">Imp,</etym> 
for a graff; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a little de&shy;
vil; because these evil spirits 
are said to appear to witches in 
the shape of little boys.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impale(v)">To Impale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Im&shy;
paler,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Impalare,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Empaler,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
these from <etym lang="la"> In</etym>, and <etym lang="la">Palus,</etym> a 
stake; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to put Criminals 
to death, by driving a stake 
up their fundaments; which 
is one way of executing Male&shy;
factors amongst the Turks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impeach(v)">To Impeach,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Law, sig&shy;
nifying to accuse one before a 
Magistrate, or Justice of the 
Peace; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Em&shy;
pescher,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Impaceia&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and these from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Impedire,</etym> to entangle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imp(n)">Imps,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Graffs, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Impan</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Imp&shy;
ffen,</etym> to plant. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&mu;&phi;&upsilon;&shy;
&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, ingrafted; or <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&mu;&phi;&upsilon;&shy;
&tau;&epsilon;&#x1F79;&nu;</etym>, to implant. I may 
as reasonably draw it from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ente,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Enter,</etym> and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Insitare,</etym> the Frequentative of 
<etym lang="la">Inserere,</etym> to plant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="implement(v)">Implement,</form> <xpln lang="en">according to Cowell, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Employer,</etym> to 
employ; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="fr">Employ&shy;
ments.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="importance(n)">Importance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Importance,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Im&shy;
portanza,</etym> a matter of mo&shy;
ment, or great concern; these 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Importer,</etym> and 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Importare,</etym> to be ef&shy;
fectual, to concern; and all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Importare,</etym> to 
import, or concern.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impose(v)">To Impose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Im&shy;
poser,</etym> to put upon one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impost(n)">Impost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Impost,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Imposta,</etym> a tax; 
all ab <etym lang="la">imponendo,</etym> from impo&shy;
sing; because it is imposed, or 
forced upon us.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impost(n)">Imposts,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture; ab <etym lang="la">Imponendo,</etym> from 
imposing; because they are 
imposed, or laid upon pil&shy;
lars.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impostume(n)">Impostume,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Im&shy;
postema,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Apo&shy;
stume,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Impostumare,</etym> and the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Apostumer,</etym> to grow 
into an impostume; and all 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&pi;&#x1F79;&sigma;&tau;&eta;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, i&shy;
dem.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impoverish(v)">Impoverish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. &shy;
<etym lang="fr">Empauvrir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Im&shy;
poverire,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="O5r"> 
to reduce to pover&shy;
t<emend err="o">y</emend> and want. V. Poor. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impregnable(a)">Impregnable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Imprenable,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
the Negative <etym lang="fr">In,</etym> and <etym lang="fr">Prena&shy;
ble;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) that which cannot 
be taken; this from <etym lang="fr">Prendre,</etym> 
to take; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Prendere,</etym> to catch hold of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="impressed(a)">Impress'd</form> <xpln lang="en">money, from the Pre&shy;
fix <etym lang="fr">In,</etym> and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prest,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Presto,</etym> in readi&shy;
ness; all &agrave; <etym lang="la">Praestando,</etym> from &shy;
performing; because it is mo&shy;
ney given to Soldiers, as it &shy;
were, for earnest; by recei&shy;
ving which, they are liable &shy;
readily to perform their duty &shy;
in military affairs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imprint(v)">To Imprint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. &shy;
<etym lang="fr">Empreint;</etym> and both from &shy;
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Imprimere, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="imprison(v)">To Imprison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. &shy;
<etym lang="fr">Emprisonner,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Im&shy;
priggionare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="improve(v)">To Improve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">In,</etym> &shy;
and <etym lang="la">Probus,</etym> good; that is, &shy;
to make a thing better in it &shy;
self: Or from the same <etym lang="la">In,</etym> &shy;
and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Preuve,</etym> a &shy;
proof or experiment of things; &shy;
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to bring a thing to per&shy;
fection by many trials, or es&shy;
says.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incarnadine(n)">Incarnadin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">In&shy;
carnadin,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Incar&shy;
nadino,</etym> a flesh-colour. v. &shy;
Carnation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incense(n)">Incense,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
cens,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Incenso,</etym> &shy;
Frankincense; all from <etym lang="la">In&shy;
cendo,</etym> to burn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inch(n)">Inch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ince, Ynce</etym>; 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Un&shy;
cia,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&gamma;&gamma;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="enchant(v)">Inchant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
chanter;</etym> and both from the &shy;
Ital. and Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Incantare, </etym> &shy;
<term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inchase(v)">To Inchase,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
chasser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Incastra&shy;
re,</etym> to set in gold; both from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chasse,</etym> and the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Castro,</etym> the collet of a ring. 
<etym lang="fr">Chasse</etym> is derived from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Capsa,</etym> a case; and <etym lang="it">Castro,</etym> 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Castrum,</etym> a ca&shy;
stle; for the collet is, as it 
were, the case, or castle of a 
ring, wherein the stone is kept 
from breaking, or losing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="encircle(v)">Incircle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Encer&shy;
cler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Incirchiare,</etym> &shy;
to compass about; all from 
<etym lang="la">In,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Circulus,</etym> a circle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="income(n)" lexeme="revenue(n)">Income, or Revenue,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Com&shy;
ings in.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="incontinent(adv)">Incontinent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">In&shy;
continent,</etym> presently; that is, &shy;
in the time continued, or im&shy;
mediately ensuing, without &shy;
the least intermission.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="encounter(v)">Incounter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
contrer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Incontra&shy;
re;</etym> which are both derived &shy;
from <etym lang="la">In,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Contra,</etym> against; &shy;
that is, to fight against, or &shy;
with another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="increscent(a)">Incressant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Encroissant,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the moon in the in&shy;
crease; to wit, from new, to 
full-moon.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="O5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indent(v)">Indent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Endon&shy;
ter,</etym> to cut like to a saw's 
teeth: From hence Inden&shy;
tures, a pair of writings so cut 
at the top and margin, that 
the sections being mutually 
fitted, the one supplies the de&shy;
fect of the other, and maketh 
the page to seem whole, as if 
it had not been cut.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indented(a)">Indented,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Bordure Indented, 
a term in Heraldry; from the &shy;
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Endente,</etym> toothed; &shy;
that is, cut in the form of 
sharp teeth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indisposed(a)">Indisposed,</form> <xpln lang="en">sickly, averse to 
some thing; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Indispos, Indispose,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) ill 
disposed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="endorse(v)">To Indorse,</form> <xpln lang="en">to write upon the 
back-side: A Book Indorsed, 
or written on the back; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Endosser,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Indossare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from 
<etym lang="la">In,</etym> and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dorsum,</etym> 
a back.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="endow(v)">To Indow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">In</etym> insignificant, 
and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Do&uuml;er,</etym> to en&shy;
dow. V. Dowry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="indue(v)">Indue,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Falconry, The 
Hawk does not Indue well; 
from <etym lang="en">In</etym> insignificant, and the 
Teut <etym lang="tt">Dawen,</etym> to concoct.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="endue(n)">Indue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">In</etym> insignificant, 
and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Do&uuml;er,</etym> to be&shy;
stow: Or from <etym lang="fr">End&uuml;e,</etym> en&shy;
dowed; and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Induta,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Imbuta.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="infanta(n)">An Infanta of Spain,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Spanish 
word; it is a name given to 
all Princes of the Royal Fa&shy;
mily of Spain; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Infans,</etym> 
an infant, &Kappa;&alpha;&tau;' <etym lang="gk">&#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the King's Infant, or Son.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="infantry(n)">The Infantry,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Foot-forces; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Infanterie,</etym>
 or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fanteria,</etym> an host 
 of foot-men; from <etym lang="it">Fante,</etym> a 
 foot-man, or servant; and 
 this from <etym lang="la">Infans,</etym> a boy; also 
 a servant, as we take it in a se&shy;
 cond sence; for the armies of 
 foot-men were formerly made 
 up of the servants or pages to 
 the companies of Horse. V. 
 Lansquenet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inform(v)">Inform,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Infor&shy;
mer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Informare,</etym> 
to give one an hint, or intelli&shy;
gence of things; these from 
<etym lang="la">In,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Forma,</etym> a form; the 
word implying, to imprint a 
form, or Idea of a matter in 
the understanding of another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ing(n)">An Ing,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently used 
in Lincolnshire, where it is 
put for a Meadow; and is 
derived from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Ing,</etym> a 
meadow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ing(n)">An Ingle,</form> <xpln lang="en">one abusive a&shy;
gainst nature, a Buggerer. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ingle,</etym> and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Inguen,</etym> the privities of 
man or woman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ingot(n)">Ingot</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lingot,</etym> 
a wedge of gold or silver not 
coined; this perhaps from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lingua,</etym> a tongue, 
which it somewhat resembles. 
But since Chaucer useth it for 
that hollow place, into which 
metal is poured when it is to 
</page> 

<page sig="O6r"> 
be melted, it may better he 
drawn from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ingie&shy;
ten,</etym> to pour into; or <etym lang="bl">Inghe&shy;
goten,</etym> poured in. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="engrailed(a)">Ingra<emend err="t">i</emend>led,</form> <xpln lang="en">Bordure Ingratled, 
a term in Heraldry. Guil&shy;
lim. draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">In&shy;
gredi,</etym> to enter in; from the &shy;
Lat. <etym lang="la">Gradus,</etym> a degree, saith &shy;
Upton. I had rather draw it &shy;
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Engrill&egrave;,</etym> &shy;
from <etym lang="fr">Grille,</etym> which is a con&shy;
tract of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Craticula,</etym> &shy;
an hurdle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ingross(v)">Ingross,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gros&shy;
soyer,</etym> (i. e) to write in 
great, capital letters. V. <etym lang="en">En&shy;
gross.</etym> It is also a term in 
Merchandise, when any one 
man buyeth up any com&shy;
modity by the gross, or 
great.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inherit(v)">Inherit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Enhe&shy;
riter,</etym> actually to make one 
heir; with us, to enjoy an in&shy;
heritance. There is also in 
the Fr. G. Heriter, to enter 
upon an heritage; and Heri&shy;
tier, an Heir; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ink(n)">Ink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Inck,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Encre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">In&shy;
chiostro,</etym> the same; and these 
from the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Encau&shy;
stum;</etym> because it is heated, or 
burnt upon the fire. In the 
Teut. it is written <etym lang="tt">Diute,</etym> in 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tinta;</etym> and these 
from the Lat <etym lang="la">Tincta,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Tin&shy;
ctura,</etym> a tincture, or colour&shy;
ing; &agrave; <etym lang="la">Tingendo,</etym> from stain&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inkling(n)">Inkling,</form> <xpln lang="en">an obscure and imper&shy;
fect hint of things. Minshew 
derives it ab <etym lang="la">Inclinando,</etym> from 
inclining, or leaning down&shy;
ward, as we do when we lend 
an ear to him that telleth us 
any news: Or it may be 
drawn from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eencke&shy;
linge,</etym> a Descant in Musick; 
or <etym lang="bl">Eenckelen,</etym> to run divisions 
in Musick; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to give one a 
touch of it: Or from <etym lang="en">In,</etym> and 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kallen,</etym> to tell; that 
is, to relate things obscurely.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inlaid(a)">In-laid</form> <xpln lang="en">work, from <etym lang="en">In,</etym> and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leyden, Ghe-leyden,</etym> to &shy;
lay. V. Lay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inmate(n)">Inmate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">In,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Mate;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inn(n)">Inn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Inne,</etym> the 
same. Verstegan derives it 
from the old word <etym lang="oe">Ingeat</etym>; 
this from <etym lang="oe">In,</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Gan,</etym> or 
<etym lang="oe">Gehen</etym>, to go: But Mer. 
Cas. from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&nu;&delta;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a 
mansion, or place of resi&shy;
dence.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inner(a)">Inner,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">ynner, 
Innor</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Inner,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the AS.
 <etym lang="oe">Eng</etym>, or Lat. <etym lang="la">In.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inquest(n)">Inquest,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Law; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Enqueste,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Inchiesta;</etym> and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Inquisitio,</etym> an inqui&shy;
sition, or search into affairs: 
From hence The Grand In&shy;
quest, Examiners of crimes; 
also such as examine measures 
and weights within their re&shy;
spective Wards.</xpln></wordentry>
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="O6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inroad(n)">In-rode,</form> <xpln lang="en">or an invasion of the 
enemy; from <etym lang="en">In,</etym> and our 
word <etym lang="en">Ride;</etym> because it 
is, as it were, a riding into another 
man's country, and lording it 
over him: Or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Einrotten,</etym> to come together 
by troops; from <etym lang="tt">Ein,</etym> in, 
and <etym lang="tt">Rotte,</etym> a troop, or band of 
men.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inside(adv)">In-side,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">In,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Side;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="insight(n)">In-sight,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">In&shy;
sicht,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; V. See.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="install(v)">Instal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Instal&shy;
ler;</etym> this from <etym lang="fr">In,</etym> and the &shy;
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stal</etym>, a stall; with us &shy;
it signifies, to initiate one so&shy;
lemnly in his place, or office, 
or dignity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="interest(n)">Interest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Inte&shy;
rest,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Interesse,</etym> u&shy;
sury; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">In&shy;
teresse,</etym> to belong to, or con&shy;
cern; because it concerns him 
that lendeth, to gain some&shy;
thing thereby.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="interlard(v)">To Interlard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Entrelarder,</etym> to stuff an hare, 
&amp;c. with lard. V. <etym lang="en">Lard.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="interloper(n)">Interlopers,</form> <xpln lang="en">such as play the 
Merchant contrary to the rules 
and customs of Commerce; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Inter,</etym> between, 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loopen,</etym> to run; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) such as run in between, 
and so prevent the commerce 
and correspondence of others 
in the way of trade.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="intermeddle(v)">Intermeddle,</form>
<xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Entremesler,</etym> to meddle
with anothers concern, to thrust his sickle into anothers harvest, as the
proverb is.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inter(v)">To Interr,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">En&shy;
terrer,</etym> to put in the ground; 
this from <etym lang="la">In,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Terra</etym>; 
<term lang="la">q.d.  in Terra condere</term>, to co&shy;
ver in the earth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="intoxicate(v)">To Intoxicate,</form> <xpln lang="en">or make mad; 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Intossicare</etym>, id. 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Toxicum,</etym> 
poison; because poison often 
causeth madness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="entreat(v)">To Intreat:</form> <xpln lang="en">the learned Dr. Th. 
H. derives it from <etym lang="en">In,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Treat;</etym> in the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Traiter,</etym>
 to treat: Or perhaps it may 
 come from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eintret&shy;
 ten,</etym> to enter into; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to 
 insinuate himself into a man's 
 mind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inveigh(v)">Inveigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Invehe&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term></xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inveigle(v)">Inveigle,</form> <xpln lang="en">to seduce, or allure; 
either as Minshew will have 
it, from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Invogliare,</etym> 
to beget a will in one to a 
thing; or rather, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aveugler,</etym> to make 
blind; and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ab,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Absque,</etym> without, and
 <etym lang="la">Oculus,</etym> an eye. It is also 
 drawn from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vagola&shy;
 re,</etym> to inveigle; and this from 
 <etym lang="it">Vago,</etym> fair; for fair things en&shy;
 tice most.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="envelop(v)">Invelop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Enve&shy;
loper,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="fr">Inviluppa&shy;
re,</etym> to wrap up; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Velum,</etym> a veil; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
cover with a veil.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="envenom(v)">Invenom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="la">En&shy;
venimer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="la">In,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="O7r"> 
and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Venenum,</etym> ve&shy;
nom; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to infect with ve&shy;
nom. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="invest(v)">To In&shy;
vest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Investir,</etym> or the Ital. and Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Investire,</etym> to cloath, as with 
honour, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inure(v)">Inure,</form> <xpln lang="en">to accustom ones self to, 
from <etym lang="en">Vre;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="inward(adv)">Inward;</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Ward.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jobbernowl(n)">Iobbernowl,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from our 
word <etym lang="en">Nowl,</etym> the crown of the 
head, and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gobelin,</etym> 
primarily, a gobling, but in a 
second sence, a fool; whence 
comes that vulgar saying of 
A great head, and little wit; 
or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Iobbe,</etym> 
dull, blunt, and the same 
<etym lang="en">Nowl.</etym></xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jocund(a)">Iocund,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giocon&shy;
do,</etym> jovial, merry; and this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jucundus,</etym> plea&shy;
sant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jog(v)" lexeme="joggle(v)">To Iog, or Ioggle:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew &shy;
derives it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Io&shy;
gen,</etym> to push. I chuse rather &shy;
to draw it from the Teut. &shy;
<etym lang="tt">Schockeln,</etym> to shove, or shog, &shy;
or totter as a cart upon stony &shy;
way; this from the Belg. &shy;
<etym lang="bl">Schocken,</etym> to shake; this &shy;
again from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scuotere, &shy;
Scossare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from &shy;
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Excussare,</etym> to shake &shy;
often.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joist(v)">To Ioice,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture. V. <etym lang="en">Ioises.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="join(v)">Ioin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joindre,</etym> &shy;
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jungere,</etym> &shy;
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joint(n)">A Ioint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jointe, &shy;
Joinct,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Junctus,</etym> joined; because 
there the bones are joined, or coupled together.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jointure(n)">Iointure</form> <xpln lang="en">or Dowry, q. d. <etym lang="la">Jun&shy;
ctura,</etym> a maintenance allotted, 
or joined to the wife at mar&shy;
riage, in consideration of the 
dowry she brought her hus&shy;
band.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joist(n)">The Ioises, or Ioists</form> <xpln lang="en">of an house, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joindre,</etym> to 
join; or <etym lang="fr">Adjuster,</etym> to make 
fit; because they are fitly joi&shy;
ned, or because they are pla&shy;
ced at an equal distance one &shy;
from another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joist(v)">To Ioist, or Ieist,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word fre&shy;
quently used in Lincolnshire, 
signifying, to feed other men's 
horses or cattle in his own pa&shy;
stures for a certain customary 
price; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gesir,</etym> 
to stay; or <etym lang="fr">Giste,</etym> a place of 
abode.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jolly(a)">Iolly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joli,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giolivo,</etym> merry, chear&shy;
ful; this, not unlikely, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jovialis;</etym> as we say, 
A Iovial fellow. Menagius 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F38;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
down; because young men 
that begin to have beards, 
which first resemble down, 
are for the most part jolly 
and jocund.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jolt(v)">To Iolt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jou&shy;
ster,</etym> to justle. v. Iusts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jolt-head(n)">Iolt-head,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps q. d. <etym lang="en">Gout-&shy;
head,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Gouty-head;</etym> (i. e.) 
Great-head; all great, and ill-shaped 
</page> 

<page sig="O7v"> 
things being vulgarly 
called Gouty. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jot(n)">A Iot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F38;&#x1FF6;&tau;&alpha;</etym>, id. 
or the Heb. <etym lang="he">Jod,</etym> the least of 
the letters.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jovial(a)">Iovial,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jovial,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jovialis,</etym> joyful; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that was born sub 
<etym lang="la">Jove laeto,</etym> under the chearful 
planet Jupiter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jouk(v)">The Hawk Iouks;</form> <xpln lang="en">V. To <etym lang="en">Iuke,</etym>
 or <etym lang="en">Iug.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="journal(n)">A Iournal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Li&shy;
vre Journal,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d. Liber 
Diurnalis</term>, a book wherein 
Travellers set down an ac&shy;
count of each day's journey; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jour,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Giorno,</etym> a day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="journey(n)">Iourney,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jour&shy;
n&eacute;e,</etym> a day's work; and this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Diurnum,</etym> done 
in, or belonging to the day: From hence, a Iourney-man, 
one that worketh for wages 
by the day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jowl(n)">Iowl</form> <xpln lang="en">or Head, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ceole</etym>, the jaws; this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gula,</etym> the gullet: 
From hence, a Iowl of Ling, 
Salmon, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jowler(n)">Iowler,</form> <xpln lang="en">an hound's name; from 
our word <etym lang="en">Iowl;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a dog 
having a great jowl, or head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joy(n)">Ioy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joye,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gioia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; which 
are both corrupted from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Gaudia,</etym> joys.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joiner(n)">A Ioyner,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called &agrave; <etym lang="la">Jungendo,</etym> 
from joining.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="irksome(a)">Irksom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Imp. Eng. 
<etym lang="en">It Irketh me</etym>; or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Argh,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Arg,</etym>
 evil; because evil things are 
 troublesome: Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ge-Reccan</etym>, for <etym lang="oe">Rec&shy;
 can</etym>, to punish: Or from <etym lang="oe">Ge-&shy;
 Recc</etym>, for <etym lang="oe">Recc</etym>, care: Or 
 lastly, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Waerc</etym>,
 in Chauc. <etym lang="me">Werk</etym>, and <etym lang="me">Wark</etym>,
 for <etym lang="en">Work,</etym> as any sore doth, 
 when it throbs with pain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="iron(n)">Iron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Iren;</etym> 
and both from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Hier&shy;
ro,</etym> which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ferrum,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; perhaps be&shy;
cause our ancestors made use 
of Spanish iron only, which is 
yet accounted the best.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="be(v)">Is,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Est,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F76;</etym>, it is; or, which is 
more likely, from the Fr. Th.
<etym lang="hd">Is,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="icicle(n)">Isickle,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Diminutive of <etym lang="en">Ice;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="isle(n)" lexeme="island(n)">An Isle, or Island,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Isle,</etym> the Hisp <etym lang="sp">Isla,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Isola;</etym> all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Insula,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this q. <etym lang="la">In Sa&shy;
lo,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) lying in the Sea: 
Hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Islette</etym>, an 
Eight, or small Island.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="issuant(a)">Issuant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Issant,</etym> rising; 
this from <etym lang="fr">Issir,</etym> to rise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="issue(n)">Issue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Issite,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Uscita,</etym> success, an 
end; these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Issir,</etym> and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Uscire,</etym> to 
succeed, or come to an end; 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Exire,</etym> 
to terminate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="it(pr)">It,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hit</etym>, or the 
</page> 

<page sig="O8r"> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Het,</etym> and all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Id,</etym> it, that. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="itch(v)">Itch:</form> <xpln lang="en">Mer. Cas. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&nu;&#x1F77;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;, &Kappa;&iota;&tau;&tau;&#x1FB6;&nu;</etym>; which 
Scaliger saith, is interpreted, 
itch, among the Tarentines. 
I chuse rather to draw it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F34;&chi;&omega;&rho;</etym>, corrupt mat&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="judge(n)">Iudge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Juge,</etym> a 
Judge; or from <etym lang="fr">Juger,</etym> to 
judge; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ju&shy;
dex,</etym> a Judge: From hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jugement</etym>, and our 
word Iudgment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jug(n)">A Iug,</form> <xpln lang="en">possibly from the Nick-&shy;
Christian-name <etym lang="en">Iug,</etym> for Ioan, 
for the same reason that the 
Kitchin-Iack is derived from 
Iack, for Iohn; V. Iack. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Jugulum,</etym> a throat; be&shy;
cause of the similitude it has 
to the neck of a man. It 
may also be drawn from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceac</etym>, and this from the 
Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Caucus,</etym> now Cya&shy;
thus, a cup.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="juggle(v)">To Iuggle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jougler,</etym> to play the Hocus 
Pocus, (whence Jouglear, a 
Jugler) the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Guychelen,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giocolare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
Or it may be derived from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gockelen,</etym> to play the 
fool, which comes from 
<etym lang="tt">Geck,</etym> a fool; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Joculari,</etym> to play the 
wag. Salmasius draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Caucum,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Caucu&shy;
lum,</etym> a cup, or little box, 
which Artists use for the bet&shy;
<emend err="">ter</emend> conveniency of performing 
their impostures.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="juice(n)">Iuice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jus,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Jugo;</etym> which are 
both derived from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Succus</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="juke(v)" lexeme="jug(v)">To Iuke, or Iug</form> <xpln lang="en">as birds do, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joucher,</etym> to 
cherp as birds when they go 
to roost; this from <etym lang="fr">Jouc,</etym> a 
perch that hens sleep upon; 
this again from <etym lang="fr">Joug,</etym> in Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Jugum,</etym> the cross beam of a 
balance: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Souche,</etym> the trunk of a tree, 
upon which birds rest; which 
comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Succus,</etym> 
juice, or sap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="julep(n)">Iulep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Julep,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giuleppe,</etym> the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Julepe,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. 
<etym lang="la">Julepus,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) water seasoned 
and made thick with sugar. 
It is originally an Arabick 
word .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jumble(v)">Iumble,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to Iumple, or 
<etym lang="en">jump</etym> against: Or from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Commolere,</etym> to grind to&shy;
gether; or from <etym lang="la">Compilare,</etym> 
to heap together: Or lastly, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Combler,</etym> to 
heap up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jump(v)">To Iump,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gum&shy;
pen,</etym> to leap, or dance; or 
perhaps, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Gup</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="en">Go up,</etym> as he that jumps seems 
to do by the elevation of his 
body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="junk(n)">A Iunk,</form> <xpln lang="en">a ship of burthen used 
by the Indians: Minshew 
derives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jun&shy;
cus,</etym> a bull-rush; because, for 
</page> 

<page sig="O8v"> 
its length, it may seem to re&shy;
semble a bull-rush. Or it may 
be derived &agrave; <etym lang="la">Jungendo,</etym> from 
joining. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="junket(n)">Iunkets,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jon&shy;
cade,</etym> sweet meats; or from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gioncata,</etym> fresh cheese 
and cream: These from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jonche,</etym> and the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Gionco;</etym> all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Juncus,</etym> a rush, or wicker; 
because such sweet meats are 
carried in baskets made of 
wicker.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="junto(n)">Iunto,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Conventicle, or pri&shy;
vate Council; from the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Junta, Gunta,</etym> an Assembly; 
this &agrave; <etym lang="la"> Jungendo,</etym> from joi&shy;
ning; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a company of 
men that join and unite them&shy;
selves into a confederacy to be 
true to this, or that perswa&shy;
sion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ivory(n)">Ivory,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ivoire,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Avorio;</etym> which 
are both derived from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ebur,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jordan(n)">A Iurden,</form> <xpln lang="en">a great chamber-pot; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gor</etym>, filth, ex&shy;
crements, and <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, a den; 
and figuratively, any kind of 
receptacle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="jury(n)">A Iury,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jur&eacute;e;</etym> 
which, in the French Law, is 
taken for a society of men ci&shy;
ted to give their Verdict upon 
a Trial had, that accordingly 
Sentence may be given in the 
Court; and in our Law, it 
consists of twelve men that 
are <etym lang="la">Jurati,</etym> sworn to give their 
opinion impartially.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="joust(n)">Iusts,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jouster,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giostrare,</etym> to run 
at tilt; whence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Jouste</etym>, and Ital. <etym lang="it">Giostra</etym>, id. 
Or perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ju&shy;
sta,</etym> ceremonies for the dead; 
in celebrating of which, men 
were formerly armed, cal&shy;
led Gladiatores, and stood out 
to challenge any that should 
speak ill of the deceased.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ivy(n)">Ivy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ifig</etym>, or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Iben,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Epsilon;&#x1F50;&#x1F70;&nu;</etym>; 
because this tree is dedicated, 
or sacred to Bacchus. Fr. 
Jun. from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F3E;&phi;&iota;</etym>, strongly; 
because it causeth trees to de&shy;
cay, by twisting so hard about 
them.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="K"><alpha>K</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carl cat(n)">A KAarl-Cat,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word fre&shy;
quently used in Lincolnshire for a male-cat; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Carl</etym>, a male, and 
<etym lang="en">Cat;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caw(v)">To Kaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kae</etym> or 
<etym lang="bl">Kaw,</etym> a jack-daw; and both 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caw(v)">To Kaw</form> <xpln lang="en">for breath, to draw 
breath with much pain; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kauchen,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kichen,</etym> to gape, or 
eck.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="P1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chill(n)">A Keal,</form> <xpln lang="en">as they say in Lincoln&shy;
shire, for Cold; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;lan,</etym> to wax cold. It 
implieth as much as a cough 
contracted by cold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keck(v)" lexeme="keckle(v)">To Keck, Kickle, or Keckle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kich,</etym> shortness of 
breath; <etym lang="bl">Kuch,</etym> a cough; or 
<etym lang="bl">Kuchen, Kichen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Keichen,</etym> to gape, or puff; 
all fictitious words.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keckle(v)" lexeme="keckling(n)">Keckle, or Keckling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in 
Sailing; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ku&shy;
gel,</etym> a globe; and this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7B;&kappa;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a circle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keel(n)">Keel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Caele</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kiel,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Keil,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guille, Quille,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Quilla,</etym> the same. 
Menagius, Fr. Jun. and Mer. 
Cas. derive it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, hollow; or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F73;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, to 
run swiftly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keel-vat(n)">Keel-fat,</form> <xpln lang="en">a vessel wherein boiled 
wort is put to cool, before it 
be put up into barrels; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;lan, Colan,</etym> to 
cool.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keen(a)">Keen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cene,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuhn,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Koen,</etym> sharp: Or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyn,</etym> fit; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) fit to 
make use of. Minshew draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&kappa;&#x1F79;&nu;&eta;</etym>, a whet&shy;
stone; this from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&kappa;&omicron;&nu;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to 
whet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keep(v)">Keep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kepen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; which comes from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cepan</etym>, to take care of. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Capere,</etym> to take, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
into custody.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="keg(n)" lexeme="cag(n)">A Keg, or Kag,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Cacque,</etym> a vessel wherein stur&shy;
geons and other salt-fish are 
pickled. Minshew derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&epsilon;&alpha;&gamma;&mu;&#x1F73;&nu;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a 
<emend err="a "></emend>Part of the Verb <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&epsilon;&#x1F71;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to cleave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kelter(n)">Kelter,</form> <xpln lang="en">He is not yet in his 
right Kelter, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he is not 
yet in readiness; from the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Kilter,</etym> to gird up the 
loins. The learned Dr. Th. 
H. interprets it thus, He is 
not yet in Culture. It 
may, by an easie Trope, be 
taken from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kelten.</etym> 
a wine press; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  he is not 
yet prepared to tread the 
wine-press, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he hath not 
his wine-press cloths on.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kemb(v)">Kemb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;mban</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rammen,</etym> to 
comb.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="akimbo(a)">A-Kembo,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">A&shy;
schembo,</etym> over-thwartly, a&shy;
wry; this of <etym lang="it">Ghembo,</etym> croo&shy;
ked, or <etym lang="it">Ghembare,</etym> to bend; 
and these again from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&mu;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to bend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ken(v)">To Ken,</form> <xpln lang="en">for to Know, from the
 AS. <etym lang="oe">Cennan</etym>, or the Belg. and 
 Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kennen,</etym> <etym lang="bl">Kunnen</etym>, to 
 know one. There is also 
 found in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ic Can</etym>, and 
 the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ich Bekenno,</etym> I 
 know him.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kennel(n)">Kennel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kennel,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chenal;</etym> which 
are both derived from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Canalis,</etym> a channel. Vossius 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&#x1F71;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
a ditch.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="P1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kennel(n)">A Dog's Kennel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Chenil, Chenin;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Canile,</etym> a place where <etym lang="la">Canes,</etym> 
dogs, are kept; as Ovile, a 
sheep-coat, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kenspecked(a)">Kenspecked,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently 
used in Lincolnshire; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cennan,</etym> to know, or 
ken; and <etym lang="oe">Specce</etym>, a speck, 
or spot; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  having specks, 
or marks, whereby a thing, or 
person may be known.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kerchief(n)">Kerchief,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Skull cap: It ought 
rather to be written Cover&shy;
chief, as it is in Chaucer; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couvre,</etym> to cover, 
and <etym lang="fr">Chef,</etym> the head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kern(n)">Kern,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Irish Kern, an Irish 
Robber. If it be not a word 
of an Irish original, I may de&shy;
rive it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyr&shy;
ran,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Keeren,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kehren,</etym> to turn; be&shy;
cause they, being very nimble, 
can easily and quickly turn 
themselves, to avoid being ta&shy;
ken, or to escape dangers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kersey(n)">Kersey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Karsaye,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Caris&eacute;e,</etym> or the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Car&igrave;sea,</etym> a sort of thick 
cloth, Linsey-woolsey: Or it 
may be so called, q. <etym lang="en">Course 
Say;</etym> v. Say, and Stuff; Or 
from the Isle of <etym lang="en">Jersey,</etym> 
where much of this sort of 
stuff was formerly made.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kestrel(n)">A Kestrel, or Kastrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quercelle, Cercelle</etym>, id. 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Circulus,</etym> 
a circle; because it hath fine 
feathers in its tail, with circles 
of divers colours; or because 
it spreadeth forth its tail circu&shy;
larly, like a fan.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ketch(n)">A Ketch,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small ship of bur&shy;
then; perhaps from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Caisse,</etym> a case; or <etym lang="fr">Cacque,</etym> a 
tub; which, if compared to 
a great vessel, it represents. 
The learned Dr. Th. H. draws 
it from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Caicchio,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kettle(n)">A Kettle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cetl, 
Cytel,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ketel,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kessel,</etym> the same. 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7B;&tau;&lambda;&omicron;&nu;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kevel(n)">Kevels,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term amongst Naviga&shy;
tors; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) little pins of 
wood, upon which the tackle 
and sails are hung to dry; per&shy;
haps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cheville,</etym> a 
wooden pin, or nail; and this 
Menagius derives from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Claviculus,</etym> the Dim. of 
<etym lang="la">Clavus,</etym> a nail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="key(n)">Key,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Caege</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Caeg</etym>, the same. Minshew 
derives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, 
to shut; or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F76;&#x03c2;</etym>, a key; by 
striking out &lambda;.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quay(n)">A Key</form> <xpln lang="en">for ships, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Kaeye,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kay,</etym> or the
 Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quay,</etym> a dock, or sta&shy;
 tion for ships. Jos. Scal. finds 
 <etym lang="la">Caiare,</etym> in the Gloss. of Isido&shy;
 rus, for <etym lang="la">Cohibere,</etym> to keep in; 
 &agrave; <etym lang="la"> Cohibendo,</etym> from keeping in 
 the sea; yet I had rather draw 
 it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cavea,</etym> an 
 hole; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a place for ships 
 to lie in.</xpln></wordentry> 
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="P2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kibe(n)">Kibe,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sore upon the heels; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kerben,</etym> to 
cut; for when the skin is 
broke, it gapeth as if it were 
cut: Or it may be drawn 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Kibws,</etym> a chil&shy;
blain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kick(v)">To Kick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kau&shy;
chen;</etym> and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Calcare,</etym> to trample upon, or 
hit with the heels. Minshew 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ico,</etym> to 
smite, or strike.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kickshaw(n)">Kick-shaws,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Quelques choses;</etym> and so we 
call several sorts of sawce, 
which the French are curious 
in, above other Nations.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kid(n)">Kid,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bundle of birch, a birchen 
rod; so called, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Caedendo,</etym> 
from cutting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kid(n)">A Kid,</form> <xpln lang="en">or young goat, from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kid,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hoedus,</etym> a kid; 
which comes from the Heb. 
<etym lang="he">Gheddi,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kidney(n)">Kidney,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cennan</etym>, 
to beget; because the kidneys 
are thought to be a great help 
to generation: Or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cynne</etym>, a sex, in a secon&shy;
dary sence, the genital parts, 
(which distinguish the one 
sex from the other,) and <etym lang="oe">Nigh;</etym> 
to wit, from the nighness of 
the genitals, especially the ves&shy;
sels wherein the seed is contai&shy;
ned, thereto.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kilderkin(n)">Kilderkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kin&shy;
dekin,</etym> a little vessel; this 
from <etym lang="bl">Kinderkin,</etym> a little child; 
it being but a small vessel, 
compared with greater, con&shy;
taining only the eighth part 
of an hogshead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kill(v)">To Kill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwellan</etym>, 
to slay; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kelen,</etym> to 
cut the throat; or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Quellar,</etym> to strangle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kiln(n)">A Kill, or Kiln,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cylene, Cyln,</etym> the same. 
Minshew derives it from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Calera;</etym> and this, &agrave;<etym lang="la"> Ca&shy;
lendo,</etym> from making hot. The 
learned Dr. Th. H. draws it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kuyl,</etym> a cave; 
this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, hol&shy;
low.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kin(n)">Kin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a diminutive termination, 
from the Teut. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Kind,</etym> a child.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kind(a)">Kind,</form> <xpln lang="en">bearing good will to any 
party; perhaps from the other 
<etym lang="en">Kind,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  come of a good 
kind: Or rather, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cyn</etym>, one that complieth, or 
agreeth with others: Or last&shy;
ly, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kond,</etym> 
known; which comes from 
<etym lang="bl">Konnen,</etym> to know one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kind(n)">A Kind,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Species, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cynne</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Cennan</etym>, to bring forth 
young: Or perhaps from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Geno;</etym> for <etym lang="la">Gigno,</etym> to be
get; and this from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&nu;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to be born; or <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&epsilon;&nu;&shy;
&nu;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to beget. V. Kindred.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kindle(v)">To Kindle,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zunden,</etym> to set on fire: 
Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tynder,</etym>
 tinder; or <etym lang="oe">Tyndelan,</etym> to lay 
 fire to.</xpln></wordentry> 
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="P2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kindle(v)">To Kindle,</form> <xpln lang="en">as we say of Coneys, 
when they conceive with 
young; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cen&shy;
nan, Acennan,</etym> to bring forth 
young; and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Geno,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Gigno,</etym> to be&shy;
get; which comes from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&epsilon;&nu;&nu;&#x1F71;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to conceive, or 
bear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="king(n)">King,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyng, 
Cyning</etym>, the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ku&shy;
ning,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koningh,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Konig,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
the AS. Cynedome, a king&shy;
dom: Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cen&shy;
nan, Connan,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Konnen,</etym> to know; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that by his prudence and un&shy;
derstanding searcheth out 
what will tend most to the 
making his Subjects happy: 
Or, which is more likely, 
from the Eng. <etym lang="en">Can,</etym> or the 
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Konnen,</etym> to 
have power; in imitation of 
the Greeks, that stiled Kings 
&alpha;&#x1F31; <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&xi;&omicron;&upsilon;&sigma;&#x1F77;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, and <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F71;&sigma;&tau;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, the 
Powers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kingsfisher(n)">King's-fisher,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird so called; 
because it feedeth upon fish, 
and hath blue feathers, re&shy;
presenting the purple habit 
wherewith Kings are usually 
cloathed upon any remarkable 
solemnity, for a token of di&shy;
stinction.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kindred(n)" lexeme="kin(n)">Kinred, Kindred, Kin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cynrene, Cynryn,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="oe">Cynne, a 
kind;</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Acennan</etym>, to bring 
forth. Or it may be drawn <emend err="drawn"></emend> 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kinde,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kind,</etym> a child; 
which are all derived from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&epsilon;&nu;&nu;&#x1F71;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to beget.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kirk(n)">Kirk,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Church.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kiss(v)">To Kiss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyssan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kussen,</etym> or the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Kuessen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the 
 AS. <etym lang="oe">Coss</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kus</etym>, 
 and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kusz</etym>, a kiss; 
 all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F7B;&shy;
 &sigma;&omega;</etym>, to kiss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kitchen(n)">Kitchin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cycene</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuchen,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Cuisine,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cucina,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; the two last from the 
 Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cuire,</etym> and the Ital. 
 <etym lang="it">Cuocere;</etym> and all from the 
 Lat. <etym lang="la">Coquere,</etym> to cook; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
 <etym lang="la">Coquina.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kite(n)">A Kite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyta</etym>, 
the same; this from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Cattare,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Captare,</etym> 
to catch; it being a ravenous 
bird, ever flying about for 
prey, which it snatches up ha
stily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kitling(n)">Kitling, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Katling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little 
cat; for the termination <etym lang="en">Ling</etym> 
diminisheth the signification.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kit(n)">A Kitt, or milk-pale;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kitte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Catinus,</etym> a 
wooden dish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="kittle(v)">To Kittle,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Tickle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="click(v)">To Klick up</form> <xpln lang="en">, a word frequently 
used in Lincolnshire, signify&shy;
ing, to snatch up a thing hasti&shy;
ly; perhaps from the Belg. &shy;
<etym lang="bl">Klacken,</etym> to tremble; or from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Clepere,</etym> which comes 
</page> 

<page sig="P3r"> 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1F73;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to 
steal. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knack(n)">A Knack,</form> <xpln lang="en">dexterity, or art in 
doing any thing; perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Knawincge,</etym> 
knowledge; which comes 
from <etym lang="oe">Cnawan,</etym> to know: Or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knap,</etym> nimble; 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Gnavus,</etym> quick, apt to do any 
thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knack(v)">To Knack with ones fingers</form> <xpln lang="en">, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knacken,</etym> to 
snap with the fingers. Min&shy;
shew derives it from our word 
<etym lang="en">Knock.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knag(n)">Knag,</form> <xpln lang="en">the knags that stick out 
of an hart's horn, near the 
fore-head: I suppose it was 
formerly written Knap, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cn&aelig;p</etym>, the knap of an 
hill, any thing that sticks out; 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knopff,</etym> a knot, 
or branch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knap(n)">The Knap of an hill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnaep</etym>, the same; also a 
button, or any thing that 
sticks out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knap(v)">To Knap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knap&shy;
pen,</etym> to snap asunder; both 
possibly from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knapsack(n)" lexeme="snapsack(n)">Knap-sack, or Snap-sack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knap-sack,</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Canapsa,</etym> a sack to put 
soldiers provision in; both 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnapa,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Knape,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knab,</etym> a 
boy, and <etym lang="tt">Sack;</etym> because, ve&shy;
ry likely, in time of war it 
was carried from place to 
place by a boy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knave(n)">Knave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnapa</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knape,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Knab,</etym> a boy, or servant; with 
us, a rogue, or dishonest fel&shy;
low. Martinus draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gnavus,</etym> active, craf&shy;
ty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knead(v)">Knead,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cn&aelig;dan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kneden,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Knetten,</etym> to turn meal into 
dough.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knee(n)">Knee,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cneou</etym>, or 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knie,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the Belg. Knie&shy;
len, to kneel; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Genu,</etym> a knee; which 
comes from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&omicron;&nu;&#x1F7A;, &pi;&alpha;&shy;
&rho;&#x1F70; &tau;&#x1F78; &epsilon;&#x1F30;&#x03c2; &gamma;&#x1FC6;&nu; &nu;&epsilon;&#x1F7A;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, from ben&shy;
ding down to the ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knell(v)">Knell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnyllan</etym>, 
to strike; the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knall,</etym> a 
clash; or <etym lang="tt">Knallen,</etym> to give a 
crack; all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knife(n)">Knife,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnif</etym>, or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Kniff,</etym> the same. 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Xi;&#x1F77;&phi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, in the &AElig;ol. Dial. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&#x1F77;&phi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a sword.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knight(n)">A Knight,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cniht</etym>,
 or the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knecht,</etym> 
 a servant; because formerly 
 there were none knighted but 
 such as were either domestick 
 Servants to the King, or of his 
 Life-guard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knit(v)">Knit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnyttan</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Knytter,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Knopffen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knoo&shy;
pen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Somnerus draws 
it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Connodare,</etym> to 
tie together in knots.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="P3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knob(n)">A Knob,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cn&aelig;p</etym>, 
the knap of an hill, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Knoop, Knobbel,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Knopff,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Knoppe,</etym> 
a knob, or knot in a tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knock(v)">Knock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnucian,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Knutschen,</etym> to break asunder; 
all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knot(v)">Knot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnotta,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knutte,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Knott,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnyttan</etym>, to knit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knot(n)">Knot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird so named; from 
King <etym lang="en">Canutus,</etym> with whom it 
was held in great esteem, saith 
Camden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="know(v)">Know,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnawan</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the old Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&nu;&#x1F79;&omega;</etym>, to know.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knubble(v)" lexeme="knub(v)">Knubble, Knub,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Knubel,</etym> a knuckle; or from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Knipier,</etym> to beat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knuckle(n)">Knuckle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnucl</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knokel,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Kuuchel,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nocca,</etym> or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Knogle,</etym> the same. 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F79;&nu;&delta;&upsilon;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. It may 
also be drawn from our Eng. 
<etym lang="en">Knock;</etym> the knuckles being 
of special use in fighting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knur(n)">Knur,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Knorr,</etym> a
 knot, or knob in wood.</xpln></wordentry> 
 </wordgroup1> 
 
 <wordgroup1 type="a" object="L"><alpha>L</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="label(n)">LAbel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lambel,</etym> 
a riband; this from <etym lang="fr">Lam&shy;
beau.</etym> Minshew draws it, &agrave; 
<etym lang="la">Lambendo;</etym> which is better 
done from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lapp,</etym> a 
small slip of a garment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lace(n)">Lace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lacet,</etym> the 
Dim. of the old word <etym lang="fr">Lace,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Lac,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; of <etym lang="fr">Lacer,</etym> to 
sow together; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Laqueus,</etym> a snare, or net.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lace(v)">To Lace,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Lash, from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Laqueus,</etym> an halter; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
beat, or lash one with a rope's 
end.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lack(v)">Lack,</form> <xpln lang="en">to want; possibly from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Laecken,</etym> to decrease, 
or fade away; whence Laecke, 
Lacke, a fault, or failing. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F75;&gamma;&omega;</etym>, to cease.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lackey(n)">Lackey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Laquay, 
Lacquay,</etym> a Page; or from 
the Vascon. <etym lang="fr">Lecaiou,</etym> a ser&shy;
vant, which is most likely; 
those being esteemed Pages, 
that come out of Gascoigne, 
into France. Minshew draws 
it from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Laach,</etym> he 
hath sent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lad(n)">A Lad;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
the Heb. <etym lang="he">Jalad,</etym> a boy, son, 
or young man. It may also 
be drawn from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ley&shy;
den,</etym> to lead; because they are 
led by the hand; or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lyte, Lyt,</etym> little.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="P4r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ladder(n)">Ladder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlaedre,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ladder, Leeder,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leyter,</etym> the same; 
these from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leyten,</etym> 
and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leyden,</etym> to lead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ladle(n)">Ladle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlaedle</etym>, 
the same; this from <etym lang="oe">Hladan</etym>, 
to draw out; because with it 
we, as it were, draw the pot&shy;
tage out of the pot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lady(n)">Lady,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlaedig</etym>: 
In Versteg. <etym lang="oe">Hleafdian, 
Leafdian,</etym> a dame, or ma&shy;
tron; which is derived from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlaf</etym>, a Loaf, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dienen,</etym> which comes 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Denian,</etym> to mi&shy;
nister, or serve; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a server 
of bread; for in ancient times 
Ladies of quality distributed 
Bread amongst their own Ser&shy;
vants, and the Poor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lag(v)">To Lag:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
our Eng. <etym lang="en">Logg</etym> of wood,; Fr. 
Jun. and Mer. Cas. from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F75;&gamma;&omega;</etym>, to delay, to cease. 
One may also imagine it to be 
so said, q Lang; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Lang,</etym> long: As we say, He 
stays long, He is long a-com&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lake(v)">To Lake,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequent in the 
North Parts of England; ei&shy;
ther from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Plaegan,</etym> 
to play, by casting away P,
 and turning &aelig; into a, and g 
into k; or from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lachen,</etym> to laugh; or, 
which is most likely, from the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Leeger,</etym> to play: And 
hence it is, that our Northern 
English alone use this word, 
because the Danes invaded 
and subdued their Country, 
near two hundred years before 
they conquered the whole 
Island.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lamb(v)" lexeme="slam(v)">To Lam, or Slam,</form> <xpln lang="en">to mawl with 
blows; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lah&shy;
men,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lamen,</etym> to 
make lame; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Slean</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slaen,</etym> 
to smite.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lamb(n)">Lamb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lamb,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Lam,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lambeau(n)">Lambeux</form> <xpln lang="en">, Cross-Lambeux, a 
term in Heraldry; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croix &agrave; Lambeaux,</etym> a 
Cross with Labels</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lame(a)">Lame,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laam, Lam</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Laem,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lahm,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lammas(n)">Lammas,</form> <xpln lang="en">the time when Lamb 
is out of Season, and rarely 
fold in our Markets. Somne&shy;
rus derives it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hlafmaesse,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  Loaf-mass; 
perhaps because the English, 
on that day, made an Obla&shy;
tion of Loaves made of new 
Wheat.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lampas(n)">The Lampers or Lampas,</form> <xpln lang="en">a dis&shy;
ease in Horses; from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Lampas,</etym> a Tumour in the 
Gums; so called, saith Min&shy;
shew, because they cut off the 
swelling, and sear the sore 
with a lamp, or lighted can&shy;
dle. I had rather draw it from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Lamparones,</etym> kernels, 
</page> 

<page sig="P4v"> 
botches, or lumps in the 
flesh; because it is a soft swel&shy;
ling, like to kernels in the 
flesh of a Man. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lamprel(n)" lexeme="lampern(n)">Lamprel, or Lampern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lamprillon,</etym> a little 
Lampry.</xpln></wordentry>
