<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lamprey(n)">Lampry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lam&shy;
proye,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Lamprea,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lampreda,</etym> the same; 
all perhaps <etym lang="la">&agrave; Lambendo Pe&shy;
tras,</etym> from licking the rocks; 
for they delight most amongst 
stones; and creeping over 
them, they leave a slime there&shy;
on, as if they were licked over 
with the tongue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lancelet(n)">Lancelet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chirurgeon's lance; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lancella,</etym> the 
Dim. of <etym lang="la">Lancea,</etym> a lance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lancepesade(n)">Lancepesado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
 <etym lang="fr">Lancepessade,</etym> or the Ital. 
 <etym lang="it">Lancia Spezzata,</etym> a broken 
 lance. It signifieth, an hono&shy;
 rary sort of Soldiers, that by 
 fighting courageously, have 
 broken their lances, or spears, 
 in the Fight (their Horses also 
 being slain under them) and 
 were put into the order of 
 Foot-men; but withal, they 
 were to receive double Pay. 
 v. Reformado.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lancet(n)">Lancet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chirurgeon's Instru&shy;
ment to let blood withal; 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">G. Lancette,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lancetta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lancea,</etym> 
a lance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="launch(v)">To Lanch</form> <xpln lang="en">a Ship, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Lancer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lan&shy;
ciare,</etym> to cast a lance or dart; 
and these again from <etym lang="la">Lancea,</etym> 
a dart; for a ship a-lanching, 
is darted, as it were, out of 
the Dock, into the River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="land(n)">Land,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Dan. Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Land,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Landa, <term lang="la">idem</term>:</etym> Likewise, To 
Land; which comes from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gelandian</etym>, or the 
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Landen,</etym> to 
come to land, or to shore.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="landgrave(n)">Landgrave,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that presides o&shy;
ver a small tract of land, or 
Province. V. Land, and 
Grave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="landscape(n)">Landskip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Landschafft,</etym> a table contai&shy;
ning a description of lands; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Land&shy;
scipe</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lands&shy;
chap,</etym> a region, or tract of 
land, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Shape, or de&shy;
lineation of lands; q. Land-&shy;
Shape.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lane(n)">Lane,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Laen,</etym> a 
street somewhat narrow; per&shy;
haps it may be a Contract of 
<etym lang="la">Latina</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  The Latin-Way; 
for in ancient Colonies, when 
the Romans and the Latins 
divided the lands by lot, the 
Romans paved and mended 
the broad streets, and the La&shy;
tins the narrow; or lastly, 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&iota;&nu;&#x1F74;</etym>, stony.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="langrel(n)">Langrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a warlike engine used 
at Sea; not unlikely, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Langrole,</etym> a kind 
of Lizard; (as Culverins, 
Drakes, and many other En&shy;
gines, have their names from 
</page> 

<page sig="P5r"> 
Serpents;) this from <etym lang="fr">Langue,</etym> 
the tongue, and <etym lang="fr">Rouler,</etym> to 
rowl. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="language(n)">Language,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lan&shy;
gage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Linguag&shy;
gio;</etym> and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Lingua,</etym> a tongue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="langued(a)">Langued,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Langue,</etym> 
long-tongue, or one that lol&shy;
leth out the tongue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="languish(v)">To Languish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Languir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lan&shy;
guire;</etym> and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Languere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lanyard(n)">Laniers,</form> <xpln lang="en">certain small ropes in a
 ship; perhaps from the Fr. G. 
 <etym lang="fr">Laniere,</etym> a long, narrow, lea&shy;
 thern thong; or from the Lat. 
 <etym lang="la">Linum,</etym> Line, Flax; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
 <etym lang="la">Linaria,</etym> because made of 
 Flax.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lank(a)">Lank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slank,</etym> 
slender, slim; or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Golenck,</etym> nimble; which 
comes from <etym lang="tt">Lencken,</etym> to bend, 
to stoop down.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lanneret(n)">A Lanneret, or Lenard-Hawk;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lanier,</etym> the 
Dim. of <etym lang="fr">Laneret,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lanet,</etym> the same. Dhuez. de&shy;
rives it elegantly &agrave; <etym lang="la">Laniando 
aves,</etym> from butchering birds.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lansquenet(n)">A Lansquenet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Lansquenet,</etym> a Foot-Soldier; 
which comes from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lance,</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Knecht,</etym> a servant; 
because Foot-men were for&shy;
merly as servants to Horse-&shy;
men arm'd with Lances.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lantern(n)">A Lantern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lan&shy;
terne,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lanterna;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">La&shy;
terna,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; which is deri&shy;
ved &agrave; <etym lang="la">Latendo,</etym> from lying 
hid: Which Etymology is 
most especially agreeable to 
that which we call A Dark 
Lantern.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lap(n)">A Lap:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&beta;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to re&shy;
ceive. Some draw it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laeppe</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lapp,</etym> a lappet of a garment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lap(v)">To Lap,</form> <xpln lang="en">to wrap, or cover up; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lapp,</etym> a lap, 
or lappet of a garment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lap(n)">Lap of a Garment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;ppe</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lapp,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lopin,</etym> a remnant; all 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">La&shy;
bium,</etym> a lip; because of its di&shy;
vision from the rest of the 
garment, or cloth. Fr. Jun. 
derives the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;ppe</etym>, from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&pi;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to leave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lap(v)">To Lap</form> <xpln lang="en">as a Dog, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Slabben, Labben,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lappen,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lapper,</etym> 
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
feigned from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lappet(n)">Lappet,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Dim. of <etym lang="en">Lap.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lapwing(n)">A Lapwing,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hleapewince</etym>, the same; 
this from <etym lang="oe">Hleapan</etym>, to clap, 
and <etym lang="oe">Wince</etym>, a wing; <term lang="la">quasi</term> Clapwing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="larboard(n)">Larboard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among Sea&shy;
men; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lever-board, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the left side of a ship; from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laevus,</etym> the Left, and 
<etym lang="en">Board;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="P5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="larceny(n)">Larceny,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lar&shy;
cin, Larrecin;</etym> and both Con&shy;
tracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Latroci&shy;
nium,</etym> robbery.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lard(n)">Lard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lard,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lardo,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Lardum,</etym> the fat of Bacon; 
these again from <etym lang="la">Lar,</etym> an 
house; because, for the use&shy;
fulness thereof, it is always 
kept in readiness in the house.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="larder(n)">A Larder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lar&shy;
diero, Lardiera,</etym> a place 
wherein provision is laid up; 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lardum,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Lardarium</etym>; from hence 
A Larderer, the Clerk of a 
Larder.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="largess(n)">Largess,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lar&shy;
gesse,</etym> a gift; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Largities,</etym> liberality; 
which is derived &agrave; <etym lang="la">Largiendo,</etym> 
from giving freely.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lark(n)">A Lark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laferc, 
Lauerce,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lerke, 
Lewercke,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lerch,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lash(v)">To Lash,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Slash with Rods or 
Whips; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schlagen,</etym> to smite; or from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laqueus,</etym> an halter; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to lash one with a ropes 
end; or &agrave; <etym lang="la">Lacerando,</etym> from 
tearing the flesh. Minshew 
derives it from the sound; or 
it may be drawn from the 
Heb. <etym lang="he">Lahats,</etym> he used me 
cruelly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lask(n)">Lask,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laxum,</etym> 
loose; as we commonly call 
it, A Looseness in the guts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lask(v)">To Lask,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lacer,</etym> to 
bind; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Laqueus,</etym> an halter, or other 
rope.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="last(n)">The Last,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">Latest;</etym> 
V. Late. Minshew derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&theta;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
last.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="last(n)">A Last, or Cobler's Last,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laeste</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Leiste,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leest,</etym> a 
wooden measure which Shoo&shy;
makers use.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="last(n)">Last,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of weight; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlaestan</etym>, to load, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Last,</etym> simply, a
 burthen, or load; from hence 
 our word Lastage, a tax le&shy;
 vied upon ships that are loa&shy;
 ded, or have their freight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="last(v)">To Last,</form> <xpln lang="en">or endure; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Laestan</etym>, to abide; both 
from the Adj. <etym lang="en">Last.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latch(n)">A Latch</form> <xpln lang="en">of a door, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Loquet,</etym> a string where&shy;
with the latch is drawn up, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Letse,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Laccio,</etym> a cord; which come 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laqueus,</etym> a 
rope.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latchet(n)">A Latchet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">La&shy;
cet,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Laccio,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Laqueus,</etym> a cord; for 
the similitude of binding.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="late(a)">Late</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laete, &shy;
Late,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Latt,</etym> the 
same; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">La&shy;
test</etym>, the latest, or last, and 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leutren</etym>, to delay; 
</page> 

<page sig="P6r"> 
as also our word Latter, q. 
Later; and Lately. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lath(n)">A Lath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laetta, 
Latta,</etym> or the Teut. Belg. 
and Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Latte,</etym> the same; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Latus,</etym> 
broad, from the manner of 
its cutting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lather(n)">A Lather, or Laver,</form> <xpln lang="en">water well 
mix'd with soap, till it froth 
in the wash-tub; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Laveure,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; Lavando,</etym> from washing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="latten(n)">Latten,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lattoen,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Letten,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Laiton,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Laton,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lattone, Ottone,</etym> a 
kind of metal so called; per&shy;
haps from one <etym lang="it">Otton,</etym> a Mi&shy;
ner, the inventor of it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lattermath(n)">Lattermath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Latter,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mae&eth;</etym>, grass; this 
from <etym lang="oe">Mawan</etym>, to mow; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
grass mown the second time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lattice(n)">Lattice</form> <xpln lang="en">, Lattice-work, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Net&shy;
tice-work, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="en">net-work</etym>, by 
changing N into L: Or from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Latte,</etym> a lath; it be&shy;
ing work made of laths, laid 
cross-wise in the form of a 
net.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laveer(v)">To Laveer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Sailing; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Laveren,</etym> or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Lavere,</etym> to stear some&shy;
times one way, sometimes 
another, as Mariners do when 
the wind lies contrary.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lavender(n)">Lavender,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">La&shy;
vande,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lavanda,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Lavendula,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or perhaps &agrave; <etym lang="la">Lavando,</etym> 
from washing; because Laun&shy;
dresses use this herb to make 
their linen smell sweet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laver(n)">A Laver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">La&shy;
voir,</etym> and this from <etym lang="la">Lava&shy;
crum,</etym> a bath, or any thing to 
wash in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laugh(v)" lexeme="laughing(n)">Laugh, Laughing,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hlian, Hlahan,</etym> or the 
Teut. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lachen,</etym> id. 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hleahtor</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lach, Gelachter</etym>, 
laughter, and the Run. Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Hleger mig</etym>, he makes me 
laugh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lavish(v)">Lavish,</form> <xpln lang="en">to spend much money 
idly. Minshew draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&pi;&#x1F71;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to destroy, 
to empty; or <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&phi;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, to 
gorge: Mer. Cas. from <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&shy;
&rho;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, dainty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laundress(n)">Laundress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G.
 <etym lang="fr">Lavandresse,</etym> now <etym lang="fr">Lavan&shy;
 diere,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lavandaia,</etym> 
 a Washer-woman; all <etym lang="la">&agrave; La&shy;
 vando,</etym> from washing cloths.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laurel(n)">Laurel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lau&shy;
riere,</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Laurus,</etym> a Laurel-tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="law(n)">Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lah, Laga</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Loy,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Lauwe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Lex Legis,</etym> a law.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lawn(n)">Lawn,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ingenious Etymolo&shy;
gist derives it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Linon,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="it">Leinwad,</etym> 
a linen web; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Lineum,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F77;&shy;
&nu;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, linen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lawn(n)">A Lawn,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Laund in a Park; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lande,</etym> or 
</page> 

<page sig="P6v"> 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Landa,</etym> a Plain ne&shy;
ver plowed. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lax(n)">Lax,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain fish without 
bones; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laxus,</etym> 
loose; for a fish without 
bones must needs be looser 
and softer than other fishes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lay(n)">A Lay,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Song; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ley,</etym> or the Teut. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Lied,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or possibly from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ladetta,</etym> an hymn; 
all from <etym lang="la">La,</etym> a note in Mu&shy;
sick. It may also be derived 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leo&eth;</etym>, the 
same; which comes from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Luit,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> the com&shy;
mon people; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a rural 
sonnet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lay(v)">To Lay,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, To Lig; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lecgan</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leggen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Legen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, or place; whence 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vdlegger</etym>, as we say, 
To Lay out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lay(n)" lexeme="lea(n)">A Lay, or Lea of Land,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ley,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, untilled 
land; this from <etym lang="oe">Leag, 
Lege,</etym> a pasture; or from 
our word <etym lang="en">Lay;</etym> for such lands 
are let lay a year, or two, or 
more so, to renew the fruit&shy;
fulness of the soil, when wore 
out with much tilling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lay(v)">To Lay,</form> <xpln lang="en">as it is commonly said, 
To Lay an evil Spirit; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leeghen,</etym> to thrust 
down; which comes from 
<etym lang="bl">Leegh,</etym> low, pressed down.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="layman(n)">Lay-man,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lai;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lai&shy;
cus,</etym> a Plebeian; q. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F00;&pi;&#x1F78; &tau;&omicron;&#x1FE6; 
&Lambda;&alpha;&omicron;&#x1FE6;</etym>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one of the Com&shy;
monalty, in opposition to the 
Clergy, or Ecclesiastical Or&shy;
der.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="laystal(n)">Laystal, or Dunghil;</form> <xpln lang="en">also an 
House of ease, a Jakes; from 
our Eng. To <etym lang="en">Lay,</etym> and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stal</etym>, a stall; or from the 
same <etym lang="en">Lay,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Stale.</etym> V. To
 Stale.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lazar-house(n)">Lazer-house,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">La&shy;
driere, Lazaret,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Lazzaretto,</etym> an Hospital for 
poor, sick and lame persons; 
(i. e.) a place, or house, where&shy;
in such as <etym lang="he">Lazarus</etym> was, ha&shy;
ving their bodies full of sores, 
or any way indisposed, are 
kept upon Charity, for a 
Cure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lazy(n)">Lazy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word used in Lincoln&shy;
shire, for a Vagabond, or wic&shy;
ked fellow; perhaps from the &shy;
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Losz, Lose,</etym> naughty; &shy;
which come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">La&shy;
xus,</etym> loose; as we say of a bad 
Man, He is a Loose Liver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lazy(a)">Lazy,</form> <xpln lang="en">idle; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lo&shy;
sigh, Leusigh,</etym> sluggish; this 
from <etym lang="bl">Loos,</etym> slack; or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leisz,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Leiser,</etym> slow; 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laxus,</etym> 
loose.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lead(v)">To Lead,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;dan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leyden, Leeden,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leyten</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lead(n)">Lead,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Laed, Leade,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loot,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lot,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence Loten, 
Vberloten, to solder with 
</page> 

<page sig="P7r"> 
Lead. Minshew draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&upsilon;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, fusible; 
because it is more easie to be 
melted than any other Metal. 
Some ingeniously derive it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;den,</etym> to 
lead; because it is easier to be 
drawn out than other course 
Metals, without the danger of 
breaking. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leaf(n)">Leaf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leafe,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loof, Loove,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Laub,</etym> the same. Min&shy;
shew derives them all from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F79;&pi;omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1FF6;&pi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a 
garment; because our first 
parents made use of leaves to 
cover their nakedness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="league(n)">League,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Confederacy, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ligue,</etym> the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Liga,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lega,</etym> id. 
all <etym lang="la">&agrave; Ligando,</etym> from binding.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="league(n)">A League,</form> <xpln lang="en">or three English 
Miles; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lie&uuml;e,</etym> 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Legua,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Le&shy;
ga,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Leuca,</etym> 
the same; perhaps it was thus 
called, because it was marked 
with <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&upsilon;&kappa;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&#x03c2;</etym>, (i. e.) white 
stones. Spelman draws it 
from the Fr. G. and old Brit. 
<etym lang="br">Leach,</etym> a stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leaguer(n)">Leaguer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan <etym lang="da">Leyger,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Legher,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lager,</etym> a Camp; whence La&shy;
gern, to pitch Tents; all from 
our old Eng. <etym lang="oe">Lig,</etym> for Lay; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Ligger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leak(v)">To Leak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leck, 
Leke,</etym> a chink or flaw in a 
ship; whence <etym lang="bl">Lecken, Leken</etym>, to run out: or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Loch,</etym> an hole; whence <etym lang="bl">Locheren</etym>, to make an hole 
through, and <etym lang="bl">Lechtzen</etym>, to 
cleave, to stave to pieces.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lyam(n)">Leam, or Liam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Hun&shy;
ting; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lien,</etym> 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ligamen,</etym> a band. V. Leash.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lean(v)">To Lean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hly&shy;
nian, Hlionan,</etym> id. which 
Fr. Jun. draws from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1F77;&nu;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to incline. It is also 
derived from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leynen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lehnen,</etym> to lean 
upon; and hence comes the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Steglehne</etym>, with us, 
A Lean-Stock; all from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F68;&lambda;&#x1F73;&nu;&eta;</etym>, the elbow, 
upon which we commonly 
lean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lean(a)">Lean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;ne, 
Hlaene</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; poor in 
flesh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leap(v)">To Leap;</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, To 
Lope; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlea&shy;
pian,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Hleap, 
Hlip</etym>, a leap, or jump; or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loopen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lauffen,</etym> to run; from 
hence Leap-year, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a year 
that leaps over, as it were, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) exceeds the rest one 
day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="learn(v)">Learn,</form> <xpln lang="en">originally from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">L&aelig;ran,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leeren,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lehren,</etym> to teach; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laere</etym>, and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leere</etym>, learning; and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leornian</etym>, and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lernen</etym>, to learn.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="P7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leas(v)">To Leas</form> <xpln lang="en">Corn, from the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lesen,</etym> to glean; 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Legere,</etym> to gather.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lease(n)">Lease,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Writing, whereby lands 
or houses are lett out by the 
Landlord, to his Tenant; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Laisser,</etym> to 
leave; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to leave one his 
lands or houses, or assign them 
to him upon such and such 
terms of agreement.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leash(n)">A Leash</form> <xpln lang="en">of Hounds, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Laisse,</etym> three of any 
thing joined; because perhaps 
not above three are coupled 
with one Leash.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leash(n)">A Leash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lesse,</etym>
 the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Letse,</etym> the Teut. 
 <etym lang="tt">Litse,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Laccio,</etym> or the 
 Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Lazo,</etym> a thong of lea&shy;
 ther; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">La&shy;
 queus,</etym> a collar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leasing(n)">Leasings,</form> <xpln lang="en">primarily from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leas, Lease</etym>, false; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Leasunge</etym>, a lye. Mer. 
Cas. draws these from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&Kappa;&alpha;&zeta;&#x1F7C;&nu;</etym>, one that telleth a 
lye, a lyer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="least(n)">The Least,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Laest;</etym> 
this from the Compar. <etym lang="oe">Laes</etym>, 
Less.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leisure(n)">Leasure, or Leisure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Loisir,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; which 
Menagius draws from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Otiari,</etym> to be at ease, to 
rest, by adding the Article <etym lang="fr">le,</etym> 
with an Apostrophus: Or ra&shy;
ther, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leisz,</etym>
 lazy, slow, (as<etym lang="tt">Leisz Gehen</etym>, to go leasurably, or leasurely;) 
 which comes from the Lat. 
 <etym lang="en">Laxus,</etym> loose.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leather(n)">Leather,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Le&eth;er</etym>, 
or the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leder,</etym> 
the same; from hence the 
Teut. Ledern, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="tt">Lederen</etym>, leathern.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leave(v)">Leave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lafe, 
Laf, Belaf</etym>, a remnant; 
whence <etym lang="oe">Belifan</etym>, to remain. 
Minshew derives it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&pi;&omega;</etym>, to leave. It 
may as well be drawn from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&omega;&phi;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to rest, to 
leave off.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leave(n)">Leave,</form> <xpln lang="en">To give Leave, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lyfan, Alyfan</etym>, to 
grant, or permit; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Leafe</etym>, leave, or liberty to 
do a thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leaven(n)">Leaven,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Le&shy;
vain,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Levatura, 
Lievito, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Levare,</etym> to lift up; be&shy;
cause it lifteth up the dough, 
as it were, and maketh it <etym lang="la">Le&shy;
viorem</etym>, more light.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lever(n)">A Leaver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Le&shy;
vier, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; also a bar; and 
this &agrave;<etym lang="la"> Levando,</etym> from lifting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lectern(n)">Lectern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lectrin, 
Letrin,</etym> a Pulpit, or the place 
where Common-Prayer is 
read; these again from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Legere,</etym> to read.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ledge(n)">A Ledge</form> <xpln lang="en">upon a wall, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lecgan</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lie&shy;
gen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leggen,</etym> to 
Lay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ledger(n)">A Ledger</form> <xpln lang="en">Ambassador, an Ambassador 
</page> 

<page sig="P8r"> 
for the King, or the 
Commonwealth; &agrave;<etym lang="la"> Legando,</etym> 
from sending away; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Licgan</etym>, to lay; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that watcheth, or 
lieth in Foreign Countries, for 
the interest of the King and 
Kingdom. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lee(n)" lexeme="leeward(adv)">To Lee, or Leeward,</form> <xpln lang="en">the leaning
 of a ship upon the Sea: I sup&shy;
 pose, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">a l'Eau;
 Vers</etym> or <etym lang="fr">envers l'Eau,</etym> leaning 
 towards the water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leech(n)">Leech,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;ce, 
Lyce,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">En Laeger,</etym> 
a Physician; from hence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lecnian</etym>, to heal, or 
cure; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Laecke</etym>, a 
blood-sucker, the Dan. <etym lang="da">L&aelig;ger</etym>, 
to heal, and <etym lang="da">L&aelig;gdom</etym>, a cure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leek(n)">Leek,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leac</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loock,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lauch</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. de&shy;
rives it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F71;&chi;&alpha;&nu;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, 
a pot-herb.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leer(v)">To Leer,</form> <xpln lang="en">or look a-skew; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lauren,</etym> to observe; 
or from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Leer,</etym> to 
laugh. Somner. derives them 
all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hleare,</etym> the 
face, forehead, or cheek-bone: 
Or it may be a Corruption of 
<etym lang="en">Lowr;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leer(n)">The Leer of a Deer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in 
Hunting; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Lodge 
of a Deer; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lager,</etym> a lodge; which comes 
from <etym lang="tt">Liegen, Ligen,</etym> to lay.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Leer" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lee(n)">Lees,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lies,</etym> 
dregs; this again from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Liggan, Licgean,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Liegen,</etym> to lie; because 
they lie at the bottom.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leet(n)">Leet,</form> <xpln lang="en">Courts-Leet: Spelman de&shy;
rives it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lite</etym>, 
little, a member: Or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;t</etym>, a censure; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an 
inferior Court where Losses 
are valued: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Laet,</etym> a Vice-Judge. Minsh. 
derives it <etym lang="la">&agrave; Litibus,</etym> from 
suits, or quarrels, or disagree&shy;
ments, that are decided there&shy;
in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leech(n)">The Leetch of a Sail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lesse,</etym> a Leash; or 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laxus,</etym> loose; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the loose part of a sail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leg(n)">Leg:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it <etym lang="la">&agrave; Li&shy;
gando,</etym> from binding, for the 
many Ligatures or nerves that 
are therein. It may also be 
drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leegh,</etym> 
low; because it is the lowest 
limb in the body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="legerdemain(n)">Leger de main,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Leger de main;</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  quick 
of hand; this q. Lever, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Levis,</etym> light; because 
jugling tricks are performed 
chiefly by the lightness or 
slight of hand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leman(n)">Leman,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Priest's Concubine, or 
a married Man's Harlot. Min&shy;
shew will have it to be a Con&shy;
tract of the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mighon,</etym> a 
Minion. Some chuse rather 
to draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;&shy;
dan</etym>, to lead; or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Laden,</etym> to invite. The learned 
Th. H. draws it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">L'Aimante,</etym> a Sweet-heart.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="P8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lemon(n)">Lemmon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Li&shy;
mon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Limone, Le&shy;
mone;</etym> and all from the Gr. &shy;
<etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&iota;&mu;&#x1F7C;&nu;</etym>, a garden. Write &shy;
Limon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lend(v)">Lend,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;nan</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leihnen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="length(n)">Length,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lenc, 
Leng,</etym> long; or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lenghde,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lange</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence Lang, 
long; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lon&shy;
gus,</etym> long.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lent(n)">Lent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lencten</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lente,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lentz,</etym> the Spring of the year; 
or from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Length,</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Long;</etym> because then the 
days begin to lengthen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lentil(n)">Lentil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Len&shy;
tille;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Lentis,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurry(n)">A Lerry;</form> <xpln lang="en">the learned Th. H. 
draws it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;&shy;
ran</etym>, to instruct; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;re</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Leere,</etym> learning, or a lesson. 
Some draw it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Loure,</etym> a bag-pipe; this from 
<etym lang="la">Lyra,</etym> an harp. We may also 
draw it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lire,</etym> 
a lesson, or lecture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="less(a)">Less,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;s,</etym> the 
same. Minshew derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&lambda;&#x1F71;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;&nu;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lesses(n)">The Lesses,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Laisses,</etym> the dung of wild 
beasts; this from <etym lang="fr">Laisser,</etym> to 
leave; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Laxare,</etym> to ease.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lesson(n)">Lesson,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Le&ccedil;on;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Le&shy;
ctio,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="least(a)">Lest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;st</etym>, the 
same; this from the Comp. 
<etym lang="oe">L&aelig;s</etym>, less.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="let(su)">Let,</form> <xpln lang="en">a termination diminutive; 
from the old AS. and Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Lit, Lyte,</etym> little; or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Glied,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Glid, Lid,</etym> a member, part, 
or portion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="let(v)">To Let,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;tan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Laeten,</etym> as Bloet 
Laeten, to let blood, the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Laisser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lasciare,</etym> 
to suffer; and all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Laxare,</etym> to loose, or ease.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="let(v)">To Let,</form> <xpln lang="en">for To hinder; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;tan</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Letten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Late, L&aelig;te</etym>, late.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lecher(n)">Letcher</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. derives it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F73;&chi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a bed; or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Luxure,</etym> lust; 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Luxuria,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. It may also be derived 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lasche,</etym> 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Laxus,</etym> loose; as we say, A
 Loose-liv'd fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="letter(n)">Letter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lettre,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lettera,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Litera,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lettuce(n)">Lettice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lai&shy;
ctile,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lattich.</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Lactuca,</etym> the same; this from 
<etym lang="la">Lac,</etym> milk; from the milky 
juice that is in it.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Q1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Levant(n)">Levant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Levant,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Levante;</etym> which 
are derived from the Lat. and 
Ital. <etym lang="la">Levare,</etym> to lift up; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">Sol levans</etym>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Sun lift&shy;
ing it self up, or rising in our 
Horison.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="level(n)">Level,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;fel</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Livel,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Livello,</etym> a Carpenter's rule, or 
any plain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liefer(a)">Lever,</form> <xpln lang="en">I had Lever, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ich wolte Lieber,</etym> I 
had rather; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leofre</etym>, rather, more free&shy;
ly; this from <etym lang="oe">Leof</etym>, ac&shy;
ceptable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leveret(n)">Leveret,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lev&shy;
raut, Levreteau,</etym> a young 
Hare; these again from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Lepus, Lep&#335;ris,</etym> an Hare.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="levy(v)">To Levy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Le&shy;
ver,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Levare,</etym> to 
exact Taxes; also to take up, 
or press Soldiers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lewd(a)">Lewd,</form> <xpln lang="en">or wicked; either from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bel&aelig;wa</etym>, a Traytor; 
or <etym lang="oe">Bel&aelig;wan</etym>, to betray; or 
from <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;wede</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;wed-&shy;
man</etym>, a Lay-man; because 
the Laity are generally look'd 
upon as lewd and wicked, in 
respect of the religious Cler&shy;
gy. Minshew derives it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Luy, Ley,</etym> idle; or
 the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leidig,</etym> wicked, or 
 sad; from <etym lang="tt">Leid,</etym> sadness; as 
 we say, A sad fellow. It 
 may also be drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leode</etym>, the common 
 people, who are most prone 
 to lewdness. It alludes to the 
 Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&upsilon;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, a dissolute Man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liable(a)">Liable,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Liable,</etym> 
obnoxious, exposed to; this 
from <etym lang="fr">Lier,</etym> and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ligare,</etym> to bind; or 
from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Ly,</etym> and the 
termination <etym lang="en">able;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he 
that lies under censure or pay&shy;
ment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lib(v)">To Lib,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lubben,</etym> 
to geld. Minshew derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&lambda;&#x1F77;&beta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to op&shy;
press, to afflict.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="leopard(n)">A Libbard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lie&shy;
pard,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Libaerd,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Leopardus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="library(n)">Library,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Li&shy;
brairie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Libraria,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these again <etym lang="la">&agrave; Libris,</etym> 
from books; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a reposi&shy;
tory for books.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lick(v)">To Lick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Liccian</etym>, 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lecken,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lecher, Licher,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Leccare,</etym> id. whence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leck-spit,</etym> a lick-spit; 
all probably from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&shy;
&chi;&omega;, &Lambda;&iota;&chi;&mu;&#x1F71;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lickerish(a)">Lickerish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Licera</etym>, 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Licchetto,</etym> glut&shy;
tonous: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Femme Lecheresse,</etym> a leche&shy;
rous woman; which comes 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lecher,</etym> to 
lick; or <etym lang="fr">Leschard,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Licchetto,</etym> a glutton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="licorice(n)">Licorish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Liqueri&shy;
tia;</etym> both from the Lat. and 
</page> 

<page sig="Q1v"> 
Gr. <etym lang="la">Glycyrriza,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F77;&zeta;&alpha; 
&Gamma;&lambda;&upsilon;&kappa;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&alpha;</etym>, a sweet root. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lid(n)">Lid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlid</etym>, a co&shy;
ver. Fr. Jun. derives it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&epsilon;&iota;&delta;&#x1F79;&omega;</etym>, to lock up, 
to cover up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liege(n)">Liege,</form> <xpln lang="en">Liege-People, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lige,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Li&shy;
gio,</etym> trusty, faithful; these &agrave; 
<etym lang="la">Ligando,</etym> from 
binding; from hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ligence, Li&shy;
geancy</etym>, Allegiance, or Obliga&shy;
tion, by which we are bound 
to be loyal Subjects.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="in lieu(adv)">In Lieu</form> <xpln lang="en">of, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lieu,</etym> 
room, or place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lieutenant(n)">Lieutenant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Lieutenant,</etym> q. Locum te&shy;
nens, one that acts in ano&shy;
ther's room, a Deputy, or 
Vicegerent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lift(v)">To Lift,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Lichten,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lever,</etym> or the Ital. 
and Lat. <etym lang="la">Levare, Elevare,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="light(a)">Light,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Licht,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leicht.</etym> id. whence 
<etym lang="tt">Leichtlich</etym>, lightly, or easi&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="light(n)">The Light,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leoht</etym>, 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Leohte,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Licht,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leicht, 
Leuchte,</etym> the same; these from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Liht, Lihtan</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leuchten,</etym> to light, 
or kindle; or, which is most 
probable, from the Abl. Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Luce,</etym> the light; which comes 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; Lucendo,</etym> from shining, or 
casting light; this again from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, to see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="light(v)" lexeme="alight(v)">To Light, or Alight,</form> <xpln lang="en">ofrom the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lihtan,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Alihtan</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Allichten,</etym> to get 
off horse-back; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to alight, 
or make light; for then the 
Horse is eased of his carriage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="light(v)">To Light</form> <xpln lang="en">on, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Licht,</etym> 
by chance; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to meet with 
by chance; this from our 
word <etym lang="en">Luck,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghe&shy;
luck,</etym> fortune.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lights(n)">The Lights,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called from their 
<etym lang="en">lightness</etym>, as being the lightest 
of the entrails, with respect 
to quantity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="like(v)">To Like,</form> <xpln lang="en">for To approve of, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Licean, Gelican</etym>, 
or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Lichan,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
or from the Noun <etym lang="en">Like,</etym> re&shy;
semblance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="like(n)">Like,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gelic</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gleich,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gheliick, Liick,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Licnysse</etym>, a like&shy;
ness, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Liicken,</etym> to 
liken, or compare. The lear&shy;
ned Dr. Th. H. draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lic, Lice,</etym> a body. 
Our word Alike, seemeth to 
come of the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&lambda;&#x1F77;&gamma;&kappa;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lill(v)">To Lill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lellen,</etym> 
to suck; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Lallare,</etym> to lull asleep.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="limb(n)">Limb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lim,</etym> or the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Lem,</etym> the same; which 
Fr. Jun. derives from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F73;&mu;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, a part; or <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a 
member, by a Metathesis.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="limbec(n)">Limbeck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Alem&shy;
bic,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lambico, Limbico,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Q2r"> 
or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Alem&shy;
bicus,</etym> an Alembick, or destil&shy;
latory vessel; or from the 
Arab. <etym lang="ar">Al,</etym> and the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&mu;&shy;
&beta;&iota;&xi;</etym>, a pot, according to He&shy;
sychius. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="limber(a)">Limber;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from <etym lang="en">Lime,</etym> for Bird-Lime: 
Other worthy Etymologists 
draw it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Liud,</etym>
 or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Linder,</etym> soft, 
 gentle; or from the Belg. 
 <etym lang="bl">Lencken,</etym> to bow, or bend; 
 <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lencker.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lime(n)">Lime,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leem, 
Liim,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leim,</etym> id. 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geliman</etym>, 
to glew, to dawb with lime; 
probably from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Li&shy;
mus,</etym> mud, or slime.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lime(v)" lexeme="line(v)">To Lime, or Line:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew 
writes it Ligne, and derives it 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ligner, A&shy;
ligner,</etym> to line, as a Dog does 
with a Bitch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="limner(n)">Limmer, or Limner,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Painter; 
from the AS <etym lang="oe">Liming</etym>, a blot 
or lim, a limb; or from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Enluminer,</etym> to paint, 
illustrate, or polish; and from 
thence <etym lang="fr">Enlumineur</etym>, a Limner, 
or Painter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="limp(a)">Limp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Limp&shy;
healt</etym>, lame, he that halteth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="limpin(n)">Limpin,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lompin, a little 
lump; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lompe,</etym> 
a lump; being so named from 
its lumpish body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lineage(n)">Linage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Linage, 
Lignage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lignag&shy;
gio,</etym> a race, or pedigree; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Linea, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="line(n)">A Line,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Linea,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="line(n)">A Line, or Cord,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Linum,</etym> flax.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ling(su)">Ling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a termination diminutive, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klein,</etym> little, 
when it denotes quality; or 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Langen,</etym> for 
<etym lang="tt">Belangen,</etym> to belong to.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ling(n)">Ling,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Heath, from the Run. 
Dan. <etym lang="rn">Ling,</etym> or the Dan. Mod. 
<etym lang="da">Lung,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ling(n)">Ling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fish, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Linghe, Linge,</etym> the same; or 
perhaps, <etym lang="la">&agrave; Longitudine,</etym> from 
its length.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linger(v)">To Linger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lan&shy;
gern,</etym> to prolong, to be long 
in doing a thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linget(n)">A Linger, or Linget,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird ha&shy;
ving its name from <etym lang="en">Ling,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Heath, which it mostly 
feedeth upon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lining(n)">Lining to a Suit of Cloths,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
our word To <etym lang="en">Line</etym> a Garment; 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Linum,</etym> 
flax, or linen; or from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Linere, Illinere,</etym> to dawb 
over; by a Metaphor drawn 
from Plasterers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="link(n)">Link in an Iron-team;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ligo,</etym> 
to bind; or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Rinck,</etym> a ring.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="link(n)">Links,</form> <xpln lang="en">Torches made of Rosin, 
Pitch, &amp;c. Minshew, with 
Mer. Cas. draw it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F7B;&chi;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a candle. It is also 
taken from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lencken,</etym> 
to end.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="link(v)">To Link</form> <xpln lang="en">or knit together, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lien,</etym> a chain; 
</page> 

<page sig="Q2v"> 
whence <etym lang="fr">Lier</etym>, to chain up; 
or rather, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ge&shy;
lenck,</etym> an iron link. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linen(n)">Linnen.</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Linen,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) made of line; whence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lienen-Kleed</etym>, linen-&shy;
cloth, and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lienwad</etym>, a 
linen web; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Linum,</etym> flax. Write Linen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linnet(n)">A Linnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Li&shy;
notte,</etym> a bird so called, because 
it feedeth upon Line-seed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linch-pin(n)">Linspin,</form> <xpln lang="en">the pin which keepeth 
the wheel upon its axle-tree; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Linkspin:</etym> Or from the 
Belg <etym lang="bl">Leyne, Laene,</etym> a prop or 
leaning-stock; for the wheel, 
by leaning against it, is kept on 
its axle-tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="linsey-woolsey(n)">Linsy-woolsy,</form> <xpln lang="en">cloth made of <etym lang="en">line</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">wool</etym>, mixed together, 
and interwoven.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lint(v)">Lint</form> <xpln lang="en">to stop a bleeding wound 
withal, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lin&shy;
teum,</etym> linen, whereof it is made.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lunt(n)">Lintel,</form> <xpln lang="en">the match wherewith 
Soldiers or Gunners fire their 
pieces; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lunte, 
Lunten,</etym> tinder; and this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Linteum,</etym> linen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lintel(n)">Lintle, or Lintels of a door;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Linteaux,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Lintel,</etym> id. this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Limen,</etym> a threshold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lion(n)">Lion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lion,</etym> and 
both from the Lat. and Gr. 
<etym lang="la">Leo,</etym> the same; this from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to see, from the 
sharpness of sight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lioncel(n)">Lioncel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; from
 the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lionceau,</etym> or the 
 Ital. <etym lang="it">Lioncello,</etym> a Lion's whelp.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lip(n)">Lip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Belg. Teut.
 and Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lippe</etym>, or the 
 Dan <etym lang="da">Laebe,</etym> the same; all possi&shy;
 bly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Labium, id.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lisp(v)">To Lisp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wlisp</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lispen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lispeln,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the sound; or, which is most 
likely, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F77;&sigma;&sigma;&eta;</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) &Gamma;&lambda;&#x1FF6;&sigma;&sigma;&alpha;, a lisping, stut&shy;
tering tongue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="list(n)">A List,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Liste,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lista,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, a ca&shy;
talogue; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lesen,</etym> to lease, or gather; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a paper or roll, wherein names 
are collected.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="list(n)">List,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lice,</etym> id. 
a place where wrestlers, com&shy;
batants, and such like, shew 
their manhood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="list(n)">A List in garments,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lez, Lesiere,</etym> an hemm, 
or border. Martinus draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&omicron;&#x1FD6;&sigma;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>; with 
us, The Last.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="list(n)">List,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Lust; Mer. Cas. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1FF6;</etym>, for <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F73;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, 
I will. V. Lust.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="listen(v)">To Listen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hly&shy;
stan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Luysteren,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lanstern,</etym> to hear&shy;
ken; all perhaps from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Lustrare,</etym> to ponder, or con&shy;
sider attentively.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="listless(a)">Listless,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Lustless</etym>, having 
no lust, nor desire to a thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lither(a)">Lither, or Lazy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Li&eth;</etym>, soft, also lazy; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Geli&eth;ian</etym>, to mollifie, and 
<etym lang="oe">Hli&eth;e</etym>, calm, pleasant.</xpln></wordentry>
</page> 

<page sig="Q3r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litter(n)">A Litter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Li&shy;
tiere, Lictiere,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Lettiera,</etym> a Sedan.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="litter(n)">A Litter,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Brood, which brute 
Animals, as Bitches, &amp;c. bring 
forth at once; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Litiere,</etym> litter, or straw; upon 
which they bring forth their 
young; this from <etym lang="fr">Lict,</etym> a bed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="little(a)">Little,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Litel,</etym> 
(Litling, a little one) the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lettel, Luttel,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lutzel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="live(v)">To Live,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Libban, 
Leofan,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leben,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leven,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Liflic</etym>, lively, and <etym lang="oe">Lif</etym>, the Run. Dan. 
and Dan. <etym lang="da">Liff</etym>, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Liva</etym>, life.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liver(n)">Liver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lifere</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Leffver,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Lever,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lever,</etym> id. 
possibly so called, because it 
was anciently esteemed the 
fountain of life.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="livered(a)">Liver'd,</form> <xpln lang="en">A White Liver'd Fel&shy;
low, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A White-Leather'd
 fellow; that is, one whose face 
 turns white as leather with 
 rage unrevenged.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="liverings(n)">Liverings,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of haggess; 
from our word <etym lang="en">Liver,</etym> because 
they are made of an Hog or 
Calf's Liver; or from <etym lang="en">Livery;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="livery(n)">A Livery,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Li&shy;
vr&eacute;e,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Livr&eacute;a,</etym> or the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Librea,</etym> the same. It 
signified heretofore victuals, 
as well as raiment, distributed 
amongst Servants by the Gen&shy;
try; now it only signifies ap&shy;
parel, or marks in Apparel, 
to distinguish one Man's Ser&shy;
vants from anothers; all from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Livrer,</etym> to deliver 
to, or bestow upon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lizard(n)">A Lizard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lai&shy;
sard, Lizarde,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Lusardo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lacerta,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lo(ex)">Lo,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">La</etym>, behold: 
Or it is a contract of the Im&shy;
perative <etym lang="en">Look.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="load(n)">A Load,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lade, 
Hlade</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ladung,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">La&shy;
dan, Hladian</etym>, and the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Laden,</etym> to load; all 
perhaps from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Li&shy;
than,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leiden,</etym> to 
endure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loadstone(n)">Load-stone:</form> <xpln lang="en">Somnerus derives 
it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;dan,</etym> to 
lead, and <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, a stone. It be&shy;
ing a sort of stone that draws 
other metals to it: Or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Laden,</etym> to invite, 
and <etym lang="en">Stone,</etym> for the reason be&shy;
fore-mention'd: Or lastly from 
the English <etym lang="en">Load,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Stone,</etym> 
because it is very weighty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loaf(n)">Loaf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlaf</etym>, the 
same. Luther also uses these 
words in the Teut. <etym lang="tt">cin Laib 
Brods,</etym> a loaf of bread.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loan(n)">Loan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;na, 
Hl&aelig;n</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loon,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lohn</etym>, id. Martin. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F7B;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to pay.</xpln></wordentry>
</page> 
 
<page sig="Q3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lob(n)" lexeme="lobcock(n)">A Lob, or Lobcock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lapp,</etym> a lubber, and 
<etym lang="tt">Cock;</etym> the name, possibly, of 
some foolish fellow, from 
whom others are proverbially 
so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lobby(n)">Lobby,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Laube,</etym> 
the porch of an house.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loblolly(n)">Lob Lolly,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from <etym lang="en">Lob,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Lubber,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Lully,</etym> which 
comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lallar&egrave;,</etym> 
to lull; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  slovens pottage: 
Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lappen,</etym> to 
lap like a dog, and the same 
<etym lang="la">Lallare,</etym> to lull.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lobster(n)">Lobster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a shell-fish, from the '
AS. <etym lang="oe">Loppestre</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&omicron;&pi;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
bank, from the similitude of 
its shell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lob-worm(n)">Lob-worm,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bait for Trouts; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Loppe,</etym> a Flea, 
for its similitude; or <etym lang="oe">Lib&shy;
ban, Leofan,</etym> to live; be&shy;
cause it is a lively, or long-&shy;
liv'd worm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loach(n)">A Loche, or Loach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Loche,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; thought 
to be a lesser kind of Ground&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lock(n)">A Lock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Loc</etym>, the 
same; whence <etym lang="oe">Belucan</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loken</etym>, to lock up, and 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lucco, Lochetto</etym>, a 
padlock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lock(n)">A Lock</form> <xpln lang="en">of hair, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Locca, Loccas</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lock(n)">A Lock</form> <xpln lang="en">of wool, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lock, Flock,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Vlocke;</etym> and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Floccus,</etym> the same. Fr. Jun.
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F71;&chi;&nu;&eta;</etym>, 
downe; Mer. Cas. from <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F79;&chi;&shy;
&mu;&eta;</etym>, a thick wood. It may al&shy;
so very probably be drawn 
from <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F79;&kappa;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a curled lock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lockram(n)">Lockram cloth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Locca,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lock,</etym> a 
lock of wool, and <etym lang="tt">Raum,</etym> 
thick, because it is made of 
thick threads.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodemanage(n)">Lodemanage,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fee which was
 usually paid the Commander 
 or Pilot of a ship; from our 
 Eng. <etym lang="en">Lead,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Manage;</etym> 
 which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodestar(n)">Lode-star,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word To 
<etym lang="en">Lead,</etym> it being a Star which 
leads or directs Mariners at 
Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lodge(v)">To Lodge a Deer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gelogian</etym>, to place, or stow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loft(n)">Loft,</form> <xpln lang="en">for an upper floor in an 
house; possibly from our 
word To <etym lang="en">Lift,</etym> the nature of
lifting being to raise any thing 
higher than naturally it is.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lofty(a)">Lofty,</form> <xpln lang="en">or proud; v. <etym lang="en">Loft,</etym> be&shy;
fore. It is a Metaphor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="log(n)">A Log</form> <xpln lang="en">of wood, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ligan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Liggen,</etym> 
to lig or lie, because of its 
bulkiness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loggerhead(n)">Loggerhead,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Luggen,</etym> to act like a fool or 
sluggard, and <etym lang="en">Head;</etym> or ra&shy;
ther because of the greatness 
and hardness of the head, like 
a log or block.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lohoch(n)">Lohoc, or Loche,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Phy&shy;
sick; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Liccian</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Licher,</etym> the Ital. 
</page> 

<page sig="Q4r"> 
<etym lang="it">Leccare,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&chi;&omega;</etym>, 
to lick; all feigned from the 
sound. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loll(v)">To Loll</form> <xpln lang="en">out ones tongue, from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lelle,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Lelleken 
van de tonghe</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lollard(n)">Lollards,</form> <xpln lang="en">the followers of Wick&shy;
liff the Arch Heretick; the 
Monks derive it from <etym lang="la">Lolium,</etym> 
tares, because their Heresie in 
the Church was like tares in 
the corn. But Trithemius 
draws it from Walter Lol&shy;
hard, a German, and a great 
promoter of this Sect, which 
is most likely.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lolling(n)" lexeme="loll(v)">Lolling, To Loll upon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a con&shy;
tract of <etym lang="en">Load</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to lay 
upon with ones whole load, 
or weight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="long(a)">Long,</form> <xpln lang="en">It is Long of you, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gelang</etym>, fault, 
blame; which comes from 
the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gelangen,</etym> and 
now <etym lang="tt">Belangen,</etym> to belong un&shy;
to.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="long(v)">To Long</form> <xpln lang="en">after, or for a thing; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Longen,</etym> to 
long after, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gelangen,</etym> 
to desire, or covet, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Verlangen,</etym> to desire very ear&shy;
nestly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="looby(n)">Looby,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Lobcock,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Lubber.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loft(n)">The Loof of a ship,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ufan</etym>, above; it being the 
highest, or uppermost part of 
it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="look(v)">To Look,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Locian, 
Aluccan,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lochten, 
Luchten,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lugen,</etym> 
to see, or behold. Minshew 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, 
to see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loom(n)">A Weaver's Loom:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Glo&shy;
mus,</etym> a clew or bottom of 
yarn</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loop(n)">A Loop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loopen,</etym> 
to run, for it is easily slipp'd 
off; and hence it is that we 
say, A Running Knot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loop-hole(n)">Loop-hole,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A <etym lang="en">Leap-hole</etym>, 
saith Minshew: Or it is 
drawn from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loopen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lauffen,</etym> to run.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loop-lace(n)">Loop-lace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lap&shy;
pen,</etym> to sow together; or from 
our Eng. <etym lang="en">Loop,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Lace;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry>
