<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loose(v)" lexeme="loosen(v)">To Loose, or Loosen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lesan,</etym> to set free, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lossen, Loosen,</etym> or the 
Fr. Th. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Losen,</etym> to 
loose; whence the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Losz</etym>, 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loos</etym>, loose, at 
liberty. Minshew and Fr. 
Jun. draw it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F7B;&omega;, &Lambda;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, to loose, or to 
pay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lose(v)">To Loose;</form> <xpln lang="en">as, To Loose ones life, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leosan</etym>, id. 
this from our word <etym lang="en">Loss, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  </etym> 
to suffer loss: Or from the 
other <etym lang="en">Loose;</etym> for when a thing 
is lost, it is loosed, as it were, 
from the hands of him that 
had it. Read Lose.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="louvre(n)">Loover,</form> <xpln lang="en">an hole in the top of an 
house, serving for a chimney; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">l'Ouverte,</etym> an 
opening.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lop(n)">A Lop,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  A Flea, a word used 
</page> 

<page sig="Q4v"> 
in Lincolnsh. from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Loppe,</etym> a Flea; this from our 
word To <etym lang="en">Leap,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Loopen,</etym> to run. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lop(v)">To Lop</form> <xpln lang="en">trees, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Loof, Loove,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Laub,</etym> a leaf: Or from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&lambda;&#x1F79;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to pill off the 
rind of any thing: A Meta&shy;
phor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loppered(a)">Lopper'd Milk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Lab, Laub,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; clotter'd 
milk; these from <etym lang="tt">Laben,</etym> to 
curdle, as milk kept too long 
in hot weather.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lord(n)">A Lord,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlaford</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Loverd</etym>, the same; this 
from <etym lang="oe">Hlaf</etym>, a loaf, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ford,</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Alford;</etym> be&shy;
cause Lords and Noble-men 
in old time gave loaves to a 
certain number of Poor, or 
because they maintain many 
servants at their tables.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lorimer(n)">Lorimers, or Loriners,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lormiers;</etym> or from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lora,</etym> the reins of a 
bridle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lot(n)">Lot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlot</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lod, Lolz,</etym> the Belg. 
and Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lot,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Lotto,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hleotan</etym>, and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lo&shy;
ten</etym>, to cast lots: Or from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Clotho,</etym> one of 
the three Sisters of Fate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loath(n)">Loth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">La&eth;e</etym>, it 
grieves me, or <etym lang="oe">La&eth;ian</etym>, to 
hate, or detest; whence <etym lang="oe">La&eth;</etym>, 
loathsom, odious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lover(n)">Lover,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leof, 
Leofa</etym>, ones Love, or Sweet&shy;
heart; whence <etym lang="oe">Lufe</etym>, love, 
and <etym lang="oe">Lufian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lie&shy;
ven</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lieben</etym>, to 
love.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="love(n)">Love,</form> <xpln lang="en">a very fine sort of Silk; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">L&aelig;vis,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, smooth, or soft.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Possibly OED, "love", 11.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lout(n)"  lexeme="country loon(n)">A Lout, or Country-Lown:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it &agrave; <etym lang="la">Luto,</etym> 
from clay; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one educa&shy;
ted in the Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="louse(n)">Louse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lus</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Lusz,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Luys,</etym>
 the same; whence <etym lang="bl">Luysen</etym>, 
 and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lausen</etym>, to louse 
 ones self, to catch Lice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="low(v)">To Low,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hlowan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loeyer,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Luyhen</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="low(a)">Low,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loh,</etym> or 
<etym lang="bl">Leegh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="low bell(n)">Low-bell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bell which Fowlers 
use to affright birds with in 
the night, and so take them; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Lowing-bell,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Lowd-&shy;
bell:</etym> Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lohe,</etym> 
a flame; it being only made 
use of in the night, and is ac&shy;
companied with a candle, or 
other light. Low, in West&shy;
-morland, is used for a flame, 
or suddain blaze.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loud(a)">Lowd,</form> <xpln lang="en">Loud, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hlud</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Luyde,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loon(n)">A Lown,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loen,</etym> a 
bard, or stupid fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lower(v)">To Lowre,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Loe&shy;
ren,</etym> to leer, or look askew.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Q5r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loyal(a)">Loyal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Loyal,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Leale,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or 
it is a corruption of <etym lang="en">Legal.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loin(n)">Loynes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lende,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lon&shy;
ges,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Longia, Lon&shy;
za,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Write Loins.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="loiter(v)">To Loyter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lote&shy;
ren,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Leuteren,</etym> to delay, to 
linger; which may come 
from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Late, Later;</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) not to perform a thing 
till it be late, or too late.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lozenge(n)">A Lozenge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lo&shy;
zenge,</etym> a medicine to preserve 
the lungs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lubber(n)">A Lubber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lapp,</etym>
 a fool; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lapper. Min&shy;
 shew derives it from the Gr. 
 <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F7D;&beta;&eta;</etym>, disgrace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luck(n)">Luck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Luck,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gluck,</etym> fortune, good 
or bad. Mer. Cas. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&gamma;&chi;&#x1F71;&nu;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;&Lambda;&alpha;&chi;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to cast lots.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lug(v)">To Lug,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gelug&shy;
gian</etym>, to pull, or pluck. It 
may also be drawn from the 
Eng. <etym lang="en">Lock,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to pull one 
by the locks or hair.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lug(n)">Lugs,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Ears, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ligan</etym>, to lig, or lay; be&shy;
cause the ears of Men and 
Women lie unmoved, contra&shy;
ry to most other Creatures.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luke-warm(a)">Luke-warm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wlaec</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Law,</etym> somewhat
 warm; which last comes from 
 the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lueck,</etym> soft, or the 
 Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to loose; for warm 
 things loosen, and soften the skin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lull(v)">To Lull</form> <xpln lang="en">a child asleep, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lullen,</etym> to sing; this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lallare,</etym> to sing 
asleep; and this again from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&lambda;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to speak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lullaby(n)">Lullaby,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word <etym lang="en">Lull,</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Abidan</etym>, to a&shy;
bide. Mer. Cas. writes 
it Laleby; which may be 
drawn from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&lambda;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, 
to speak, and our word <etym lang="en">by;</etym> 
q d. talk'd asleep.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lumber(n)">Lumber,</form> <xpln lang="en">furniture of little 
worth; so called, q. <etym lang="en">Cum&shy;
ber.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lumber(n)">Lumber, or Lumbar,</form> <xpln lang="en">as, To put 
ones Cloths to Lumbar, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
to pawn them; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Lombaerd,</etym> a Broker.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lump(n)">Lump,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lomp,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Klumpe,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lump-fish(n)">Lump-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish so named, from 
its lumpish, heavy body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lumpish(a)">Lumpish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lompsch,</etym> 
slow, heavy. V. Lump.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lunch(n)"  lexeme="luncheon(n)">A Lunch, or Luncheon of bread,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Lonja,</etym> from 
the length thereof, saith Min&shy;
shew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lune(n)">Lune,</form> <xpln lang="en">An Hawk's Lune, from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Longoli,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">la Longe Lanieres,</etym> a cord, 
or line, wherewith the Hawk 
is held; these from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Longus,</etym> long, and <etym lang="la">Laniere,</etym>
 from <etym lang="la">Lana,</etym> wool.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lungis(n)">A Lungis,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Lon&shy;
gis,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Longone,</etym> a 
long, slam fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lung(n)">Lungs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lungena</etym>, 
the Dan. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lunge,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Longhe,</etym> the same; 
</page> 

<page sig="Q5v"> 
all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lun</etym>, empty; 
for it is filled with nothing 
but wind. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurch(v)">To Lurch,</form> <xpln lang="en">to steal or pilfer, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lurcari,</etym> which Non. 
Marc. expounds, To snatch 
meat greedily. C&aelig;s. Scal. 
draws it from the old word 
<etym lang="la">Lura,</etym> a sack's mouth: Voss.
 from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&#x1FE6;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;&shy;
 &beta;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, greedy, voracious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurdan(n)">Lurdan,</form> <xpln lang="en">not from Lord, and 
Dane, but from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Lourd,</etym> a lazy person; whence 
<etym lang="fr">Lurdant</etym>, and <etym lang="fr">Lourdin</etym>, a 
dunce.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lurk(v)">Lurk,</form> <xpln lang="en">to lay hid, from <etym lang="en">Lark;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to hide himself in an 
hole, as a Lark doth in the 
furrows: or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Loeren,</etym> to lay in ambush.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luscious(a)">Lushious,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">Deli&shy;
cious;</etym> or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lu&shy;
xus,</etym> luxury.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lusk(n)">A Lusk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lasche,</etym> 
a loose fellow, saith Minshew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lust(n)">Lust,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lust</etym>, or 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lust,</etym> id. 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lustan</etym>, the 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Lustanne</etym>, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lusten</etym>, to lust after, to 
covet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="luster(n)">Luster,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Luster, 
Liister,</etym> the Fr. G. and Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Lustre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lustro,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lusty(a)">Lusty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lustig,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lustigh,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Leste,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Lesto,</etym> live
ly, strong.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lute(n)">Lute,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Lut, 
Luth,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Liuto,</etym> the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Lutte,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Laute,</etym> the same. It is also 
drawn from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Laud,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this &agrave;<etym lang="la"> Laudando,</etym> from 
praising, say Menagius and 
Covarruvius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lute(v)">To Lute,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lutum,</etym> 
clay, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to dawb with 
mortar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lye(n)">A Ly</form> <xpln lang="en">to wash withal, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Laeg</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lecke, 
Looghe,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Liscia,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Lexia,</etym> the same; all 
from the old Lat. <etym lang="la">Lix Aqua,</etym> 
now <etym lang="la">Lixivium,</etym> Ly made of 
ashes and water. Write Lee, 
or Ley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lie(v)">To Lie</form> <xpln lang="en">along, V. <etym lang="en">Lay.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="lie(v)">To Lye,</form> <xpln lang="en">to tell a Lye, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leogan</etym>, or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Liegen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="M"><alpha>M</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mace(n)">A MAce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Masse,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Maz&shy;
za,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Maca, Ma&shy;
za,</etym> a club; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Massa,</etym> a mass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mackerel(n)">Mackarel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
careau, Maquereau,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mackerel, Makrel,</etym> id. 
The learned Th. H. draws it 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Maccarello,</etym> the 
same: All <etym lang="la">&agrave; Maculis,</etym> from 
the longish, blue spots in the 
sides thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Q6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mad(a)">Mad,</form> <xpln lang="en">gone mad; from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Matto,</etym> a fool; this perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F71;&tau;&alpha;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, vain, 
foolish. Mer. Cas. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&epsilon;&sigma;&theta;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to be 
mad.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="madam(n)">Madam,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma 
Dame;</etym> this a Contract of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Domina,</etym> a Dame; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">Mea Domina</etym>, my Dame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="madder(n)">Madder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Madera,</etym> 
q. d. Lat. <etym lang="la">Materia,</etym> matter 
wherewith wool is died.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="madrigal(n)">Madrigal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Madrigal,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Madriale,</etym> a rural Song. The 
learned Th. H. draws it from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Madragar,</etym> to a&shy;
wake early, as Lovers do, to 
sing Love-Songs to their 
Sweet-hearts at their win&shy;
dows.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="magazine(n)">Magazin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
gazin,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Magazen,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Magazin,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maggot(n)">A Maggot</form> <xpln lang="en">in flesh, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Magaigne, Magagna,</etym> 
corruption: Or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maege,</etym> a Mite in bread; 
or <etym lang="bl">Muyck,</etym> soft, and <etym lang="bl">Rot,</etym> an 
hole; for they breed in holes 
full of moist, corrupt mat&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maid(n)">A Maid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maeg&shy;
den</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maeght, 
Maegho,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Magd,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>, a Virgin. Hence the 
 AS. <etym lang="fr">Maden-hade</etym>, a Maiden-&shy;
 head, or Virginity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mail(n)">Mail, A Coat of Mail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Maille,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Maglia,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Malla;</etym> 
as, <etym lang="sp">Cota de Malla</etym>, a coat of 
iron; all from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Maille,</etym> a mash in a net, from 
the similitude.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maim(a)">Maim,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mancus,</etym> 
lame, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="main(a)">Main,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Magne,</etym> this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Magnus,</etym> great; as in Charle-&shy;
main, which in the Fr. G. is 
<etym lang="fr">Charlemagne</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Carolus Magnus</etym>, Charles the Great. 
From hence, The Main, for 
the Ocean, or great Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="main(n)">Main,</form> <xpln lang="en">With all his Might and 
Main, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maegen</etym>, 
might, power; this again from 
<etym lang="oe">Magan</etym>, to may, or can.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maintain(v)">To Maintain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Maintenir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Man&shy;
tenere,</etym> to defend, to give su&shy;
stenance to; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Manu 
tenere,</etym> to hold, as it were, in 
ones hand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="major(n)">A Major,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Meyer,</etym> a Major to exe&shy;
cute Justice between Man and 
Man, within a City or Corpo&shy;
ration. Versteg draws it from 
the old Eng. <etym lang="oe">Maier,</etym> this from 
our Eng. <etym lang="en">May;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that 
has full power to judge and 
examine Causes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="make(v)">Make,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Macan</etym>, 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Machon,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Maken,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Machen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&omicron;&chi;&theta;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to labour, 
to work.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malady(n)">A Malady,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
ladie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Malatia,</etym> id. 
</page> 

<page sig="Q6v"> 
this &agrave; <etym lang="la">Malo,</etym> from evil; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that suffers evil; as we say, 
He is very ill, that is, sick: Or 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mala,</etym> evils, and 
our Eng. <etym lang="en">Die.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mallender(n)">The Malanders,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Malandres;</etym> this again from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mal Andare,</etym> to go 
ill, or with pain; for it makes 
the Horse go lamish, till he be 
well heated.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malapert(a)">Malapert, or Malepert,</form> <xpln lang="en">impu&shy;
dent, saucy; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la"> Male Par&shy;
tus,</etym> ill bred, according to 
Minshew: Or from the same 
<etym lang="la">Mal&egrave;,</etym> badly, and the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Appert,</etym> ready; q d. always 
ready to speak evil of others.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="male(a)">A Male</form> <xpln lang="en">Creature, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Masle,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Maschio;</etym> both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Masculus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malcontent(a)">Malecontent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Malcontent,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mal&shy;
contento</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Male Con&shy;
tentus,</etym> not well content.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Malkin(n)">Malkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Dim. of <etym lang="en">Mall,</etym> for 
Mary. It also signifies, A 
Mop, wherewith Women 
wash their houses.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mall(n)" lexeme="mallet(n)">A Mall, or Mallet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mail, Maillet,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Maglio;</etym> all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Malleus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Hence 
cometh the word, To Mall;
 (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to beat, as with a Mal&shy;
 let.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mallard(n)">Mallard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
lart,</etym> a wild Duck; this from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mallen,</etym> to be lasci&shy;
vious, or lecherous, and <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
nature.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mallow(n)">Mallows,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Malu</etym>, 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Malva,</etym> in 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F71;&chi;&eta;</etym>; so called, <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&shy;
&rho;&#x1F70; &tau;&#x1F78;&mu;&alpha;&lambda;&#x1F71;&sigma;&sigma;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, from making 
the belly soft.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malmsey(n)">Malmsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of hot wine; 
so called from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mar&shy;
visia,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Malvisia,</etym> a Promon&shy;
tory in the Isle of Chius: Or 
from <etym lang="la">Monenbasia,</etym> a port in 
Epidaurus, from whence 
good wine of this sort is 
brought.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="malt(n)">Malt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mealt</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mout,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Maltz</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mam(n)">Mam,</form> <xpln lang="en">some derive it from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Mam,</etym> a mother; and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mamma,</etym> a 
pap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mammock(n)">Mammocks,</form> <xpln lang="en">fragments, or pie&shy;
ces; perhaps from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Man,</etym> little, and the Dim. <etym lang="cb">Ock,</etym> 
as in Bullock, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="man(n)">Man,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Man, 
Mon,</etym> or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Man,</etym> the same; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Manslaga</etym>, a Man&shy;
slayer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manacle(n)">Manacles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
nicles,</etym> fetters for the hands; 
both from <etym lang="la">Manus,</etym> the hand, 
for that they are put upon the 
hands or arms.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manage(v)">To Manage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mesnager,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ma&shy;
neggiare,</etym> to handle; these 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Manus,</etym> an 
hand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manchet(n)">Manchet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. . <etym lang="fr">Mi&shy;
chette, Miche,</etym> fine, white 
</page> 

<page sig="Q7r"> 
bread; and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Mica,</etym> a crumb. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manciple(n)">Manciple,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Steward; from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mancipio,</etym> the same, 
saith Flor. this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Manus,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Capio.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mane(n)">The Mane of an Horse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Matne,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mahne,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manger(n)">A Manger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mangeoire,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Man&shy;
giatoia,</etym> the same; these from 
<etym lang="fr">Manger,</etym> and <etym lang="it">Mangiare,</etym> to 
eat; which again may be de&shy;
rived from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mandere,</etym> 
or <etym lang="la">Manducare,</etym> to eat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mangle(v)">To Mangle,</form> <xpln lang="en">or tear in pieces: 
Minshew draws it from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Mancus,</etym> maim'd. It 
may also be drawn from the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mangel,</etym> a 
defect.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mangy(a)">Mangy,</form> <xpln lang="en">or scabbed; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Demanger,</etym> to itch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manner(n)">Manner,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Maniere,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Maniera,</etym> the same; hence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mannerlick</etym>, man&shy;
nerly; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ma&shy;
nus,</etym> an hand; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a decent 
carriage, or motion of the 
hands in time of discourse, 
which is a principal point in 
good manners.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manor(n)">A Mannor,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Farm; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Manoir,</etym> or the Lat. 
Barb. <etym lang="la">Manerium,</etym> a Lordship; 
this from <etym lang="la">Manere,</etym> to remain; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Mansio</etym>, a mansion to 
abide in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mantle(n)">A Mantle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;n&shy;
tel</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mantel, 
Manteau,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Man&shy;
tello,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; also a manteau, 
a cloak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mantle(v)">The Hawk Mantleth,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
spreads out her wings like a 
<etym lang="en">Mantle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manteltree(n)">Mantle-tree of a Chimney:</form> <xpln lang="en">
Minshew draws it from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mantel de la Chemi&shy;
n&eacute;e,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mantello di 
Camino,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="manure(v)">To Manure</form> <xpln lang="en">the ground, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Manouvrier,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
this &agrave; <etym lang="la">Manu operando,</etym> from 
working with the hand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="many(a)">Many,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Manig</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Menig,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Manch,</etym> or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ma&shy;
nig,</etym> many, much; whence 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Mangfold</etym>, manifold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="map(n)">A Map,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mappe,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mappa,</etym> a schedule 
containing a description of the 
World, &amp;c. Minsh. draws 
it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mappa,</etym> a 
napkin; because it is large, 
and spread out like a napkin; 
as by a like Analogy we say, 
A Sheet of Paper.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maple tree(n)">Maple-tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ma&shy;
pul treo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mar(v)">To Mar:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew derives it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&mu;&alpha;&rho;&tau;&#x1F71;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to 
do amiss. It may be better 
drawn from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Marra,</etym> 
a fault or want; whence 
Marrar, to mistake: Or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Myrran</etym>, to spend 
lavishly, to destroy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marble(n)">Marble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Marbre;
</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Q7v"> 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mar&shy;
mor,</etym> the same; and this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&alpha;&rho;&mu;&alpha;&#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to shine. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="march(v)">To March,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Marcher,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mar&shy;
chiare,</etym> to move forward af&shy;
ter a marshal manner. Me&shy;
nagius draws it from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Varicare,</etym> to straddle as Sol&shy;
diers do, with one foot fore&shy;
most.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="merchant(n)">A Marchant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Marchand,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mer&shy;
cante,</etym> the same; these from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mercari,</etym> to buy, or 
<etym lang="la">Merx,</etym> wares, or merchandice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="march(n)">Marches</form> <xpln lang="en">or bounds of a Coun&shy;
try; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mearc</etym>, 
a land mark.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marchpane(n)">Marchpane,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Massepan,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mar&shy;
zapane,</etym> a Confection made 
of Pistach-nuts, Almonds, Su&shy;
gar and Rose-water; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Massa panis,</etym> a mass of bread 
candied.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mare(n)">Mare,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maere</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Merie,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mare, Merre,</etym> id<emend err="">em</emend> whence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nacht-Merie</etym>, the 
Night-Mare.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="margent(n)">Margent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mar&shy;
ge,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Margo,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="margrave(n)">Margrave,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) The Grave or 
Count of the Marches: V. 
<etym lang="en">Marquess,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Grave.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marriage(n)">Mariage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
riage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Maritag&shy;
gio,</etym> the same. V. Marry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marigold(n)">Marigold,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Mary's Gold;</etym> 
possibly from some Woman 
with yellow hair, that deligh&shy;
ted in this flower.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mariner(n)">A Mariner,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Marinier,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mari&shy;
naro,</etym> a Sea-man; both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mare,</etym> the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marjoram(n)">Marioram,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. and 
Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Majorana,</etym> the 
same. Gerard takes it to 
have been thus named, because 
it is sown <etym lang="la">in mense Maio,</etym> in 
May; or &agrave;<etym lang="la"> magnis virtuti&shy;
bus,</etym> from the great virtues 
thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mark(n)">Mark,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Silver Coin; so called, 
because it is stamped with the 
King's <etym lang="en">Mark.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mark(v)">To Mark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mear&shy;
can</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Marcken,</etym> 
to mark, to consider; whence 
the AS. Mearc, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Marck</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Marque</etym>, 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Marca</etym>, a mark 
to know a thing by.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="market(n)">A Market,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Marche,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mercato,</etym> 
the same; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Merces,</etym> Goods, Merchandice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marl(n)">Marl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Margel,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mergel,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Marne,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Marga,</etym> 
fat earth for manuring the 
fields; all perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Merg</etym>, marrow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marmelade(n)">Marmelate, or Marmelade,</form> <xpln lang="en"> 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Marme&shy;
lade,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Marmela&shy;
da,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marquis(n)">Marquess,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mar&shy;
quis,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Marchese,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Marchio,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Q8r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marrow(n)">Marrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Merg, 
Merih</etym>, the Dan. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Marg,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Marck,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Marolla,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marry(v)">To Marry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
rier,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Maritare,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marsh(n)" lexeme="marish(n)">Marsh, Marish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mersc</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maersche, 
Marse,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Marais, 
Marez,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, a fenny place; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mare,</etym> the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marshal(n)">Marshal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mare&shy;
schal,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Marescallo,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Marschalk,</etym> Master 
of the Horse. Some derive it 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Marescalco,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mareschal,</etym> a Far&shy;
rier; Or it comes from the 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Marre,</etym> a Mare, and 
<etym lang="gr">Schalck,</etym> a Servant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mart(n)">Mart,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">Market.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marten(n)">A Marten,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mar&shy;
tin, Marte,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Mar&shy;
ta,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Martino,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="martingale(n)">Martingal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Martingale,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mar&shy;
tingala,</etym> a small thong or rein 
to rule an horse withal; all 
perhaps from <etym lang="en">Mare,</etym> and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">In Kallen,</etym> to call in, 
to stop an Horse in a full ca&shy;
reer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="martlet(n)">Martlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Swallow; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Martelet,</etym> the 
Dim. of the name <etym lang="fr">Martin.</etym> 
Minsh. surmiseth this bird to 
be so called, because it cometh 
from hot Countries, to us, a&shy;
bout the end of March, and 
goes away about St. Martin's 
Day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="marvel(v)">Marvel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Esmer&shy;
veiller,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Maravig&shy;
liare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mash(n)">A Mash for an Horse;</form> <xpln lang="en">not un&shy;
likely from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mis&shy;
chen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Misschen,</etym> to 
mingle; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Miscella,</etym> 
a mislin, or mixture of things.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mash(v)">To Mash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mas&shy;
cher;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Masticare,</etym> to champ with the 
teeth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mask(n)">A Mask,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Masque,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Masche,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Maschera,</etym> a vizard 
to put over the face.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maskins(n)">Maskin,</form> <xpln lang="en">By the Maskins, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="en">By the Mass.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maslin(n)">Maslin, or Millin,</form> <xpln lang="en">bread of di&shy;
vers sorts of corn mixed toge&shy;
ther; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mesler,</etym> 
to mingle; and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Misceo, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mason(n)">A Mason,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mas&shy;
son,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Ma&ccedil;on,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mass(n)">The Mass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maesse</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Messe,</etym> the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Mesz,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Mis&shy;
 sa</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Missio,</etym> 
 or <etym lang="la">Dimissio populi,</etym> a mission, 
 or dismission of the people.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="massacre(n)">A Massacre,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Massacre,</etym> a slaughter; and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mactare,</etym> 
to slay, or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mazzare,</etym>
 to put to death with clubs and 
 staffs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="massy(a)">Massy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Massif,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Massivo, Massic&shy;
cio,</etym> solid, weighty; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Massa,</etym> a mass, or 
lump of any thing.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Q8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mast(n)">A Mast of a ship</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">M&aelig;st</etym>, the Belg. Dan. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mast,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mas, Mast, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mast(n)">Mast,</form> <xpln lang="en">to feed Swine with, from ]
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maest</etym>, or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mast,</etym> Acorns to 
fatten hogs withal; whence 
Masten, to make fat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="master(n)">Master,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mai
'stre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Maestro,</etym> the 
same; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Magister,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mastiff(n)">A Mastive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
stin,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mastino,</etym> the 
same; all from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Masten,</etym> to fatten.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mat(n)">A Mat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Meatte</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Maatte,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Matte,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Natte,</etym> 
the same. Minshew derives 
it from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Mittah,</etym> a 
bed. The Lat. <etym lang="la">Matta</etym> is also 
read in Ovid.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="match(n)">Match:</form> <xpln lang="en">Mer. Cas. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F71;&chi;&eta;</etym>, a fight: And the 
industrious Dr. Skinner, from 
the word <etym lang="en">Mate,</etym> (i. e.) a Com&shy;
panion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="match(n)">A Match</form> <xpln lang="en">that soon takes fire, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Meche, Mei&shy;
che,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Miccia, Mic&shy;
cio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mate(n)">A Mate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
car,</etym> the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maca</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maet,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. This last 
Fr. Jun. derives from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&epsilon;&tau;&#x1F70;</etym>, Cum, with: Though 
most likely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Metan</etym>, to meet one; for 
Birds of a feather flock toge&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="matter(n)">Matter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
tiere;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Materia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="matter(n)">Matter,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Corruption; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Matu</etym>, rotten; or 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Materia,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) fil&shy;
thy matter; or <etym lang="la">Maturus,</etym> 
come to maturity; for it 
cometh not out of a Sore, or 
Impostume, till it be ripe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="matins(n)">Mattins,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ma&shy;
tin,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mattina, 
Mattino,</etym> and all contracts 
of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Matutinus,</etym> of 
the morning, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Morning-&shy;
prayers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mattock(n)">A Mattock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mat&shy;
tuc</etym>, the same. Minshew 
draws it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Met 
haeck,</etym> with an hook.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maugre(pp)">Maugre,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mau&shy;
gre, Maulgre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mal&shy;
grado,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Mal&egrave; &shy;
Gratum.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mavis(n)">A Mavis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird so called; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mauvis,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Malviccio,</etym> the same: Or it is 
so called perhaps &agrave; <etym lang="la">Malo visu,</etym> 
from its ill sight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maund(n)">A Maund,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mand</etym>, 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mande,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a basket with handles; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Manus,</etym> 
an hand. Some very aptly 
draw it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mando,</etym> 
to eat, because provision is car&shy;
ried about in it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maunder(v)">To Maunder,</form> <xpln lang="en">to murmur against; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Maudire,</etym> to 
curse; this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ma&shy;
ledicere,</etym> to speak evil of.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maundy Thursday(n)">Maundy-Thursday:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew 
supposeth it to be so called, <etym lang="la">q. 
Dies Mandati,</etym> a day of a 
command, or charge; for on 
this day, our Saviour, institu&shy;
ting the Eucharist, left that 
great Command to his Disci&shy;
ples, Do this in remembrance 
of me.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maw(n)">Maw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maga</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maeghe,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Magone,</etym> 
id. the ventricle, or stomach.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="may(v)">To May,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Can, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Magan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Moghen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mogen,</etym> to be 
able; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maeht, Meaht</etym>, might, <etym lang="oe">Mage</etym>, 
mighty, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ick Mach</etym>, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ich Mag</etym>, I 
may, or can.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maypole(n)">May-pole,</form> <xpln lang="en">a pole so called, from 
the month of <etym lang="en">May,</etym> the most 
pleasant month in the year, in 
which the Country-people 
dance in the places wherein 
May-poles are set up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="maze(n)">A Maze,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Labyrinth, from 
the Belg <etym lang="bl">Missen,</etym> to miss, or 
lose ones way: Or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Mase</etym>, a gulf; for it is 
difficult to get out of the one, 
or the other.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meacock(n)">Meacock,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Coward, that, like 
Sardanapalus, loves to be a&shy;
mongst Women; q. d <etym lang="en">Mew&shy;
cock;</etym> for he mews, or shuts 
himself up in an hole when 
danger approacheth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mead(n)">Mead,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Medo</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Meede,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Meeth</etym>, a liquor made of ho&shy;
ney and water. Minsh. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&theta;&eta;</etym>, drun&shy;
kenness, or <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&theta;&upsilon;</etym>, wine, and 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F29;&delta;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, sweet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meager(a)">Meager,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maegre</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maeger,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Maigre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Magro;</etym> 
all which come from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Macer,</etym> lean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meal(n)">A Meal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maele,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meal(n)">Meal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mealepe</etym>, 
the Belg. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Meel,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mehl,</etym> the same; 
all possibly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mo&shy;
lere,</etym> to grind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mealy-mouthed(a)">Mealy-mouth'd,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en"> Mild-&shy;
mouth'd,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Mellow-mouth'd,</etym> 
saith the learned Dr. Th. H.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mean(n)">A Mean, or Means,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moyen,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mean(v)">To Mean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;&shy;
nan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Meenen,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Meynen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; to 
think, or suppose; all perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
mind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mean(a)">Mean,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Mean Man; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gemaene</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghe&shy;
meene,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gemein,</etym> 
an inferior person: Or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maene</etym>, course; as 
we say, A course, sorry fel&shy;
low.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="means(n)">Means, for Riches.</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <etym lang="en">De&shy;
means.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meer(n)">Mear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, the 
Teut. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Meer,</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mer,</etym> id. all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Mare,</etym> the Sea. Write Meer.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="merestone(n)">Mear-stones, or Meer-stones,</form> <xpln lang="en">for 
Mark-stones, or Bound-stones; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maera</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Meer,</etym> a bound, or li&shy;
mit: Or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&epsilon;#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, 
to divide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="measels(n)">Measels,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mase&shy;
len, Messelen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Masen,</etym> blisters; this last from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mal</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Maase,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mael,</etym> a spot; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Macula,</etym> a spot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="measure(n)">Measure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Me&shy;
sure,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Misura,</etym> the 
same; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Mensura,</etym> a measure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meat(n)">Meat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mete</etym>, id. 
Dr. Th. H. draws it from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mes, Mets,</etym> a mess; 
Minsh. from the Goth. <etym lang="go">Mate,</etym> 
or the Heb. <etym lang="he">Mazan,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meath(n)">Meath,</form> <xpln lang="en">as they say in Lincoln&shy;
shire, I give you the Meath 
of the buying, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) full 
power to buy; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">M&aelig;&eth;</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;gen</etym>, power; 
and this again from <etym lang="oe">Magan</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mogen,</etym> to may, 
or can.</xpln>
<lemenote>
This sense of "Meath" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="medal(n)">A Me&shy;
dal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Me&shy;
daille,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Medalla,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Medaglia,</etym> a certain 
ancient Coin, which is stam&shy;
ped for a Memorial of a King's 
Inauguration, or some other 
great Solemnity; all from 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Metallum,</etym> 
metal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meddle(v)">To Meddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Mell, as the Scots 
pronounce it; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mester,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mescolare,</etym>
 to mingle, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) intermeddle 
 with another's affairs; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
 To <etym lang="en">Middle,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) interpose
 ones self in the middle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="medley colour(a)">Medly-colour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Couleur Messe,</etym> id. a mixed 
colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meadow(n)">Medow or Meadow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;de</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Matte,</etym> a Mead; both from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mapan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Maeden,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mehen,</etym> 
to mow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="me(pr)">Me,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Me,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&mu;&#x1F72;</etym>, signifying the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meek(a)">Meek,</form> <xpln lang="en">mild; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Me&shy;
ca, Maca,</etym> a companion; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that with meekness 
submits himself to the hu&shy;
mour of every one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mere(n)">Meers,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <etym lang="en">Mear-stones,</etym> and
 <etym lang="en">Mark.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meet(v)">To Meet</form> <xpln lang="en">in the way, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Metan</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Meeten,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Gemoeten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
Hence The Moot-House, or 
Moot-Hall, in many Market-&shy;
Towns; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
mot</etym>, a Meeting, or Coun&shy;
cil.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meet(v)">To Meet,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Measure, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gemete</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Ghemet,</etym> a measure; both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Metiri,</etym> to measure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meet(a)">Meet,</form> <xpln lang="en">or fit, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">M&aelig;&eth;e</etym>, a measure, or <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;&shy;
&eth;ian</etym>, to meet; both from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Metior,</etym> to measure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meter(n)">Meeter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. and Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">Metrum,</etym> a true dimension.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mellow(a)">Mellow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mear&shy;
pa</etym>, soft, tender; and this a 
Contract of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Matu&shy;
rus,</etym> ripe; for all fruit grows 
mellow by ripening.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="melon(n)" lexeme="muskmelon(n)">A Melon, or Musk-Melon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from &shy;
the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Melon,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Melone, Mellone;</etym> these from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Malum,</etym> an Apple. 
It is called Musk-Melon, or 
Million, because of its smell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="melt(v)">To Melt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Myl&shy;
tan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smelten,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schmeltzen,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="menace(v)">To Menace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Menacer,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Amena&shy;
zar,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Minacciare,</etym> 
to threaten; all possibly from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Minari.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minnow(n)">A Menom, or Menow,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Le Poisson Menu,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Piscis Minutus,</etym> a small, 
or minute-fish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mercer(n)">A Mercer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Mer&shy;
cier,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Merciaro, 
Merciaio,</etym> the same; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Merx,</etym> wares.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mercy(n)">Mercy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Merces,</etym> a 
reward: Or, as Minshew will 
have it, a Contract of the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Miseresce,</etym> to have compassion 
on. <term lang="un">Dhuez.</term> hath the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Je vous crie Merci,</etym> I cry you 
mercy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="merkin(n)">A Merkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mere,</etym> a Mother, and <etym lang="en">kin,</etym> 
which diminisheth; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little 
mother, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) scarce fit for 
procreation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="merlin(n)">A Merlin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Mer&shy;
lin, Smerlin,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Es&shy;
merillon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sme&shy;
riglio,</etym> a kind of Hawk so cal&shy;
led, because he preyeth much 
upon <etym lang="la">Merulas,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Black-&shy;
birds.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="merlin(n)">Merlin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish; from the Ital. &shy;
<etym lang="it">Merlana,</etym> a fish of the kind of 
Whitings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mermaid(n)">Mermaid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mare,</etym> 
the Sea, and <etym lang="en">Maid;</etym> q. d. a 
Sea-Maid, or Sea-Nymph.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="merry(a)">Merry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Myrig,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, jovial: Or perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to enlarge; 
for mirth openeth and enlar&shy;
geth the heart.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mess(n)">A Mess,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mes,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Messo,</etym> or the Lat. 
Barb. <etym lang="la">Missus,</etym> the same; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">Cibus Missus</etym>, meat sent one. 
Some draw it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mese</etym>, or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Mesa, 
Messa,</etym> a table; both which 
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mensa,</etym> a 
table.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="message(n)">A Message,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mes&shy;
sage;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Messaggio, </etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, an errand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metheglin(n)">Metheglin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Med&shy;
dyglyn,</etym> the same; this from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Med,</etym> Mead, and 
<etym lang="cb">Glyn,</etym> clammy. v. Mead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mew(v)">To Mew,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Hart Meweth, or 
casteth his horns; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Muer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mutare,</etym> to 
change.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mew(v)">To Mew as a Cat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut <etym lang="tt">Mawen,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Me&shy;
auler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Miagolare,</etym> 
the same; all possibly from 
the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mew(n)" lexeme="seamew(n)">A Mew, or Sea-Mew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mew</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mewe,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moette, 
Mouette,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miser(n)" lexeme="micher(n)">A Micher, or Miser,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Miser,</etym> miserable; or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Miche,</etym> a 
crumb; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that counts 
every crumb that falls from 
the table.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mickle(n)">Mickle,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Much; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Micl</etym>, or the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Michol,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, muh. Worm. 
draws them all from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&gamma;&alpha;&#x03c2;, &Mu;&epsilon;&gamma;&#x1F71;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, great.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="middle(a)">Middle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Middel</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mittel,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Mid,</etym> the same: Hence the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mid-nacht</etym>, mid-night; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Medialis,</etym> 
medial, or <etym lang="la">Medius,</etym> the mid&shy;
dlemost.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="midge(n)">Midge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Micge</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mugge,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Myg,</etym> a Gnat; perhaps all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Musca,</etym> a Fly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="midriff(n)">Midriff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mid,</etym> be&shy;
tween, and <etym lang="oe">Hrif, Hrife,</etym> 
the womb; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a separation 
between the vital and natural 
parts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="midwife(n)">Midwife,</form> <xpln lang="en">so named, either be&shy;
cause she is in the midst of the 
Wives or because her business 
is with the middle parts, saith 
Minshew. Hensh. draws it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Medwif</etym>, a Wife 
hired for money; for the old 
word <etym lang="oe">Meed,</etym> signifies, a re&shy;
ward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="might(n)">Might,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mihte, 
Maeht,</etym> or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Maeht,</etym> power; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Mihtan</etym>, to be able, and 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Machtigh</etym>, mighty; 
from May. Mer. Cas. de&shy;
rives our word Mighty, from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&gamma;&iota;&sigma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, most mighty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mild(a)">Mild,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Milde</etym>, or the Teut. and Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Mild,</etym> mild, soft; all perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&epsilon;&iota;&lambda;&iota;&chi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, plea&shy;
sant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mile(n)">A Mile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Meil,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Miglia,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
and Lat. <etym lang="la">Mille;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a thou&shy;
sand paces.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="milk(n)">Milk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Meolc</etym>, 
the Belg. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Melck,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Milch,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mill(n)">Mill, or Miln,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mylen,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Molen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Muhlen,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mou&shy;
lin,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Molino,</etym> id. 
hence the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Muller</etym>, a 
Miller; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Me&shy;
la,</etym> a mill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="millet(n)">Millet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Millet;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mi&shy;
lium,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="million(n)">A Million,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mil&shy;
lion,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Millione,</etym> ten 
hundred thousand; these from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mille,</etym> a thousand, and 
the Term. Auct. <etym lang="en">on.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="milt(n)">The Milt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Milt</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Milte,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Milza,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Voss. draws it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Milt,</etym> mild, 
soft; <term lang="la">viz.</term>  A Mollitie, from the 
softness and tenderness of it.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R3r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mince(v)">To Mince,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Min&shy;
cer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Minuzzare,</etym> 
to cut small; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Minutus,</etym> small.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mind(n)">The Mind,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
mynde</etym>, the mind; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Myndigan</etym>, to put in mind, 
to admonish: Or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Minder,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mine(n)">Mine,</form> <xpln lang="en">It is Mine, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Min</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Miin,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mein,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mien,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mingle(v)">Mingle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gemen&shy;
gan,</etym> or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mingelen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&iota;&gamma;&nu;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
from hence, A Mingle-man&shy;
gle, an hotch potch, or mish-&shy;
mash.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minion(n)">Minion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mig&shy;
non,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mignardo,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Kilian draws it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Minnen,</etym> to love. 
Florius seemeth to draw it 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mignone,</etym> the 
seam in the middle of the te&shy;
sticles; which, in a secondary 
sense, may signifie, a Sodo&shy;
mite.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minikin(n)">Minneken.</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mini&shy;
cene</etym>, a Nun; with us, a pret&shy;
ty little Girl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="minster(n)">Minster,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Myn&shy;
ster</etym>; both contracted from 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Monaste&shy;
rium,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mint(n)">Mint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Minte</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mente;</etym> all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mentha,</etym> and this 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F77;&nu;&theta;&eta;</etym>, an herb 
so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mint(n)">Mint,</form> <xpln lang="en">the place where money is 
coined; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">My&shy;
net</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Mint,</etym> mo&shy;
ney; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mone&shy;
ta,</etym> money.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mire(n)">Mire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Moyer,</etym> id. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&iota;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, polluted.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mirror(n)">A Mirrour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mi&shy;
roir,</etym> a looking-glass; this 
from <etym lang="fr">Miror,</etym> to look into; 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mirari,</etym> 
to admire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mirth(n)">Mirth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Myrh&eth;e</etym>, 
the same. v. Merry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="myrtle(n)">Mirtle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Murtel&shy;
la;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Myrtus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misadventure(n)">Misadventure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Misaventura.</etym> v. Adventure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miscreant(n)">Miscreant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mescreant,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mis&shy;
credente,</etym> the same; these 
from the Adversative Particles 
<etym lang="fr">Mes,</etym> <etym lang="it">Mis,</etym> and the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Creant,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Croyant;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Male Credens,</etym> mis-belie&shy;
ving, an Infidel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misdeed(n)">Mis-deed,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <etym lang="en">Deed,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Doe.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mishmash(n)">Mish-mash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Misch-masch,</etym> a confused heap 
of things; this from <etym lang="tt">Mischen,</etym> 
to mingle, and <etym lang="tt">Massen,</etym> to 
meet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mizzle(v)">It Misleth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mit&shy;
selen,</etym> to rain small rain; or 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  To Mistle, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to rain 
in a <etym lang="en">Mist.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miss(v)">To Miss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Missen,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="R3v"> 
to be mistaken, to be decei&shy;
ved: Or from the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Missen,</etym> to want; as <etym lang="tt">Mistum 
thes kindes</etym>, they Missed the 
Child, saith Luther; all per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Amittere,</etym> 
to lose ones aim to shoot wide. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misshapen(a)">Mis-shapen,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Shape.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mist(n)">Mist,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mist</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mest, Mist,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
Minshew draws it from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Mistus,</etym> mixed; it being 
a mixture of vapours. Hensh. 
thinks it so called; q. <etym lang="en">Moist.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mystery(n)">A Mistery,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Trade; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mestier,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Mestiero,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mysterium,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&upsilon;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F75;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a mystery. Right 
Mystery.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mistletoe(n)">Mistletoe,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Missendine; accor&shy;
ding to Minsh. and Somn from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mistel-ta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mistress(n)">Mistress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mai&shy;
stresse,</etym> the same. v. Master.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misuse(v)">To Mis-use,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Misu&shy;
sare,</etym> to abuse, to use ill. V. 
Vse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mite(n)">A Mite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mite,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Miite,</etym> the least 
coin that is; all Contracts of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Minutus,</etym> small.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mite(n)">A Mite</form> <xpln lang="en">in Chese, so called, for 
the smallness of it; derived as 
above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="miter(n)">A Miter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mitre,</etym> 
or the Lat and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Mitra,</etym> id. 
Right Mitre.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mitten(n)">Mittens,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mi&shy;
taines,</etym> thick, woollen gloves, 
which Hermits and Country-&shy;
people commonly wear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mixen(n)">Mixen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mixen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, a dung-hill; this from 
<etym lang="oe">Meox</etym>, muck, or dung</xpln></wordentry>
