<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mo(a)">Mo</form> <xpln lang="en">, for More, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ma</etym>, more; and this a Con&shy;
tract of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Magis,</etym> the 
rather.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mock(v)">To Mock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moc&shy;
quer,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mocken,</etym> 
the same: Or perhaps from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&omega;&kappa;&#x1F71;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;, &Mu;&omega;&kappa;&#x1FF6;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, 
to deride.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="model(n)">A Model,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mo&shy;
del,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Modello,</etym> a 
form, or pattern; and these 
again from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Modulus,</etym> 
or <etym lang="la">Modellus,</etym> a little form.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="modern(a)">Modern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mo&shy;
derne,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Moderno,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mo&shy;
dernus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mohair(n)">Mohair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mo&uuml;&shy;
aire;</etym> and both from the O&shy;
riental word <etym lang="ar">Mojacar,</etym> a sort 
of Chamlet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moil(v)">To Moil,</form> <xpln lang="en">to work with might 
and main; from the old word 
<etym lang="en">Moil,</etym> for Mule; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
work like a Mule: Or from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Moddelen, Modden,</etym> 
to toil in the mud. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F79;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
or <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1FF6;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, labour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moist(a)">Moist,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moite</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mole(n)">A Mole</form> <xpln lang="en">in the skin, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mael,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mahl,</etym> a spot; and these from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Macula,</etym> a stain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mole(n)">A Mole,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Want; from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mol,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Maul,</etym>
</page> 

<page sig="R4r"> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mulot,</etym> the same. 
Menagius supposeth that it is 
so called, q. <etym lang="fr">Murot,</etym> a great 
Mouse; but the learned Hensh. 
derives our <etym lang="en">Mold-Warp,</etym> from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Molde</etym>, mold, and 
<etym lang="oe">Weorpan</etym>, to cast forth. In 
the Teut. it is <etym lang="tt">Maulwerff;</etym> 
and this we may draw from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Maul,</etym> the mouth, 
or snout, and <etym lang="tt">Werffen,</etym> to cast 
out; for it casts out the mold 
with its snout. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="molasses(n)">Molosses,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word strangely cor&shy;
rupted; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mal&shy;
lece,</etym> and both from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Melazzo,</etym> course, or dregs of 
Sugar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Monday(n)">Monday,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Monan&shy;
daeg</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Montag,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maendagh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
It may also be so called, q. 
<etym lang="en">Moon-day;</etym> and therefore in 
Latin rendred <term lang="la">Dies Lun&aelig;</term>, the 
Day of the Moon. v. Month, 
and Day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moan(v)">Mone,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maenan</etym>, 
to bemoan, to deplore. Minshew derives it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F79;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, alone, lonesome.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="month(n)">Moneth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mona&eth;</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maend,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Monat,</etym> the same; 
all from our word <etym lang="en">Moon;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monger(su)">Monger</form> <xpln lang="en">in Terminations, as in 
Fish-monger, Iron-monger, 
&amp;c. from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mangere,</etym> 
a Merchant: Or perhaps from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mango,</etym> a Broker: 
Or lastly, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Men&shy;
gan,</etym> to mingle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mongrel(n)">A Mongrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">Mingrel</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
of a mixed kind. V. ingle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monk(n)">Monk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Monch, 
Munch,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Monge,</etym> 
the same; all from the Lat. 
and Gr. <etym lang="la">Monachus,</etym> a Monk; 
and this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F79;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
solitary.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monkey(n)">Monky:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&iota;&mu;&#x1F73;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to imitate; 
which I shall not contradict, 
though I should rather suspect 
it to come from the old word 
<etym lang="en">Mon,</etym> for Man, and the Dim. 
Term. <etym lang="en">Kin;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Monikin</etym>, or <etym lang="en">Monkin</etym>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a little 
Man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="money(n)">Money,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mon&shy;
noye;</etym> and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Moneta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mood(n)">Mood,</form> <xpln lang="en">He is in an ill Mood; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mode</etym>, the Belg. 
and Run. Dan. <etym lang="rn">Moed,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Muth,</etym> the mind: As 
Belg. Wel Ghemoed, he is in 
a good Mood, or mind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moon(n)">Moon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mona,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maene,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Maane,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mond, Mon,</etym> the 
same; whence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maen&shy;
kind</etym>, a Moon-Calf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moor(n)">A Moor,</form> <xpln lang="en">Black-Moor, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">More,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Moro,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mohr.</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Maurus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and this again from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&mu;&alpha;&upsilon;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, dark, obscure; to 
wit, from its blackness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moor(n)">A Moor,</form> <xpln lang="en">incultivated ground; 
</page> 

<page sig="R4v"> 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mor,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Moer, Moor,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
perhaps from our word <etym lang="en">Mear,</etym> 
for Marsh. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moot(v)">To Moot</form> <xpln lang="en">a Case: Minsh. draws 
it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mot,</etym> a 
word; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  To word a Case: 
Or rather, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mo&shy;
tare,</etym> the Frequent. of <etym lang="la">Move&shy;
re,</etym> to move; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to move, 
or start a difficult case.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mop(v)">Mop,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Mow, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Mump, 
and Mew; not unlikely from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mompelen,</etym> to have 
the Mumps; this from <etym lang="bl">Mond,</etym> 
the mouth, and <etym lang="bl">Pellen,</etym> to 
pull up; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to make mouths 
at one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mope(v)">To Mope,</form> <xpln lang="en">or make stupid; per&shy;
haps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mompe&shy;
len,</etym> to mumble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="more(a)">More,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mare,</etym> the &shy;
Dan <etym lang="da">Meere,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Meer,</etym> &shy;
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Mere,</etym> or the Teut. &shy;
<etym lang="tt">Mehr,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Morglay(n)">Morglay,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a sword; from the &shy;
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mort,</etym> death, and <etym lang="fr">Glaive,</etym> 
a sword; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a deadly sword.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morning(n)">Morning,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Marne</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Morgen</etym>, the Belg <etym lang="bl">Mar&shy;
gen, Morghen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Morgen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Morghen-tiid,</etym> the mor&shy;
ning-tide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morphew(n)">A Morphew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Morph&eacute;e,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. 
<etym lang="la">Morph&aelig;a,</etym> the same: Or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Morte,</etym> death, and 
<etym lang="fr">Veue,</etym> a look.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morris dance(n)">A Morrice-dance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">A la Moresca,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Moresque;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Dance after 
the fashion of the Moors, q. 
Moorish-dance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morrow(n)">Morrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Morning.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="morsel(n)">A Morsel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mor&shy;
cel, Morceau,</etym> so much as the 
mouth will hold at once.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mort(n)">A Mort,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently used 
in Lincolnsh. for great store; 
from the old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mout, 
Moult,</etym> much; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Multum,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, much: 
Or it may come from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mor</etym>, a mountain; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
mountain, or heap of things.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Mort" possibly antedates OED, "mort," n. 6 (1694).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortar(n)">Morter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Morter,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mortel, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, 
Plastering made of Lime and 
Sand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mortise(n)">A Mortise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mor&shy;
taise,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, the laying of joi&shy;
ses into the beam in Archite&shy;
cture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mosaic(n)">Mosaick-work,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.&shy;
<etym lang="fr">Mosaique,</etym> checker, or in-laid &shy;
work.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mosque(n)">A Moschey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mos&shy;
qu&eacute;e,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Moscheta,</etym> or the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Meschita;</etym> which last is 
a Corruption of the Turkish 
<etym lang="tu">Meschit,</etym> a Turkish Mosque, 
or Church.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moss(n)">Moss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Meos</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mosg,</etym> or the Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Mousse,</etym> the same; all possibly 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Muscus,</etym> moss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="most(a)">Most,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maest, 
Mest,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Meest,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Meist,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
last from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&sigma;&tau;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, for 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&gamma;&iota;&sigma;&tau;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, the most, the greatest.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R5r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mote(n)">A Mote</form> <xpln lang="en">in the eye, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mot</etym>, the same: This Min&shy;
shew derives from the Heb. 
<etym lang="he">Mots,</etym> chaff; Mer. Cas. from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&tau;&omicron;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a mote in 
the Sun.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moot(n)">Mote, or Moot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS 
<etym lang="oe">Mot</etym>, a meeting, to wit, of 
Men about civil affairs; this 
from <etym lang="oe">Metan</etym>, to meet toge&shy;
ther: From hence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mot-heal</etym>; with us, the 
Moot-hall.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moth(n)">Moth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Me&eth;</etym>, or 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Motte,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mother(n)">Mother,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Mo&eth;or</etym>, 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Mudder,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Moeder,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mut&shy;
ter,</etym> the same; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Mater,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F75;&shy;
&tau;&eta;&rho;</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mother(n)">The Mother of Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Moeder,</etym> lees, thickning; 
this again from <etym lang="bl">Modder, Mo&shy;
der,</etym> mud.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="motley colour(a)">Motly-colour,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Medly-colour.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="motto(n)">A Motto,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Symbol, from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Motto,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mot,</etym> a word; this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Mutire,</etym> to mutter; which 
is again derived from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1FE6;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a speech.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mought(v)">Mought,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mot</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mochte,</etym> I mought, 
or might; this from <etym lang="bl">Moghen,</etym> 
to may, or can.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mould(n)">Mould, or Mold in the earth;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Molde,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mul,</etym> the dust of the 
earth; perhaps from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Moles,</etym> any great weight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mould(n)">A Mould, or Mold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moule,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Molde,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Moele,</etym> a form, or 
pattern; whence the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">A&shy;
moldar,</etym> to mold, or cast in 
a mold; all from the word 
<etym lang="en">Model;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moulder(v)" lexeme="milder(v)">Moulder, or Milder away,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
<etym lang="en">Mold;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to be turned in&shy;
to mold, or dust.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mouldy(a)">Mouldy, or Moldy bread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Goth. Sue. <etym lang="se">Mogel,</etym> moul&shy;
diness, or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moisi;</etym> 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mucidus,</etym> 
musty, or <etym lang="la">Mollities,</etym> softness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moult(v)">Moult,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Muyten,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Miter,</etym> to lose 
the feathers, as birds do; and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mutare,</etym> 
to change; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to change 
the feathers</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mound(n)">Mound,</form> <xpln lang="en">for an hedge: Minsh. 
derives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Muni&shy;
mentum,</etym> a fortification, or 
fence. It may also be drawn 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mons,</etym> an hill, 
or mountain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monsieur(n)">Mounsire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moun&shy;
sieur,</etym> O my Master. V. Sig&shy;
nieur, and Sir.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mount(n)">A Mount,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mont,</etym> 
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mons,</etym> 
a mountain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mount(v)">To Mount,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mon&shy;
ter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Montare,</etym> to 
mount an Horse; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Montem scandere,</etym> to climb, 
as it were, up a mount.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mountain(n)">Mountain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mon&shy;
taigne,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Montag&shy;
na,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mountebank(n)">Mountebank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mon&shy;
tinbanco,</etym> the same; so called, 
because he mounteth a Bench, 
Stage, or Bank, for the better 
conveniency of being seen and 
heard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mourn(v)">Mourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Murnan</etym>, 
to lament, or deplore.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mouse(n)">Mouse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mur</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Muys,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mausz,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Mus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mouth(n)">Mouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mu&eth;</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mond,</etym> or the Dan. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Min&shy;
shew and Jun. derive it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1FE6;&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a word.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mow(n)">A Mow of Hay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mawan</etym>, to mow; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) so 
much as is mown in one day: 
or rather, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mowe,</etym> 
an heap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mow(v)">To Mow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mawan,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mayen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mahen,</etym> to cut, or mow the 
grass; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Me&shy;
to,</etym> to mow; which comes 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&mu;&epsilon;&tau;omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
Harvest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mow(v)" lexeme="mop and mow(v)">To Mow, or Mew; as we say, 
To Mop and Mow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faire la Mo&uuml;e,</etym> to make 
a mouth, from <etym lang="fr">Mo&uuml;e,</etym> a wry 
mouth; which comes from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Manl,</etym> a mouth, or 
<etym lang="tt">Maulen,</etym> to mouth at one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="much(a)">Much,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Mucho,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muck(n)">Muck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Meox,</etym> or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Mog,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all ei&shy;
ther from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mucus,</etym> 
filth, or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mucg,</etym> 
an heap; because it is laid up 
on the land in heaps.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muckender(n)">A Mucketter, or Muckender,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Mocadero,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mouchoir,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Moccaiuolo,</etym> an handkerchief 
to wipe the nose.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mud(n)">Mud,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Modder,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Minsh. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&upsilon;&delta;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, to be wet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muff(n)">Muff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Moffe, 
Moffel, Muffel,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mouffle,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Mu&eth;</etym>, the mouth, and 
Felle, a skin; which we of&shy;
ten hold to our mouths, to 
keep off cold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muffle(v)" lexeme="maffle(v)">To Muffle, or Maffle in ones 
speech,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maffe&shy;
len, Moffelen,</etym> to stutter; all, 
by an Anamatopoeia.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muffle(v)">To Muffle</form> <xpln lang="en">up ones face, from the 
AS <etym lang="oe">Mu&eth;</etym>, the mouth, and 
<etym lang="oe">Fealdian,</etym> to hide, or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Velare,</etym> to cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mug(n)">Mug,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Muryglo,</etym> 
to be warm; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a cup for 
warming drink, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mulberry(n)">Mulberry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut <etym lang="tt">Maul&shy;
beer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="tt">Maul,</etym> 
the mouth, and <etym lang="tt">Beer,</etym> a berry; 
q. d. a Mouth berry; so cal&shy;
led, from the soveraign virtue 
it hath to cure Ulcers, or Gar&shy;
garisms in the mouth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mullar(n)">Mullar,</form> <xpln lang="en">the upper stone where&shy;
with Painters mix their Co&shy;
lours; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mou&shy;
leur, Moulleur,</etym> a Miller; this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Molere,</etym> to grind.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mulled(a)">Mulled</form> <xpln lang="en">Sack, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Mollitum &shy;
Vinum</etym>, mollified Sack; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) &shy;
made more mild by mixing &shy;
Sugar with it, and boiling of &shy;
it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mum(n)">Mum,</form> <xpln lang="en">Brunswick Mum, from &shy;
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mumin,</etym> or the Belg. &shy;
<etym lang="bl">Momne,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; a strong li&shy;
quor brought from Bruns&shy;
wick in Germany: Or perhaps 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Momnelen,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mummeln,</etym> to mum&shy;
ble, or mutter; as we say, 
Drink that will make a Cat 
speak: Or from our word 
<etym lang="en">Mum,</etym> a note of silence; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
drink so strong, that it soon 
takes away the use of the 
tongue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mumble(v)">Mumble</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mom&shy;
nelen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mum&shy;
meln,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mummer(n)">A Mummer,</form> <xpln lang="en">having a vizard on; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mommer,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mummer,</etym> or the Fr G. 
<etym lang="fr">Mommeur,</etym> a silent Masker: 
Or from our word <etym lang="en">Mum,</etym> an 
Interjection of silence; for 
they go silent, giving signs to 
each other to do as they would 
have them.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mumps(n)">Mumps,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mom&shy;
pelen,</etym> to mumble, as he that 
hath a sore mouth, or throat, 
saith Minshew. He hath the 
Mumps, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he is angry, 
and silent with it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="monk seam(n)">Munk-seam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a way of sowing 
sails together; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  The 
<etym lang="en">Monks-seam,</etym> or such a seam 
as was formerly sowed in the 
apparel of Monks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="murk(n)">Murk, or Mirk,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Dark; 
from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Morck,</etym> dusky; 
whence <etym lang="da">Morker</etym>, darkness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="murre(n)">A Murr-Bird,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A <etym lang="en">Moorish 
Bird;</etym> or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mur&shy;
ren, Morren,</etym> to murmur, to 
make a doleful noise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="murrey(n)">Murrey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mo&shy;
r&eacute;e, Moreau,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Mo&shy;
rado,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Morello,</etym> the 
same; so called, from the 
Moors, or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mo&shy;
ra,</etym> a Mulberry; <term lang="la">q.d.</term> of the 
colour of Mulberries.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="murder(v)">Murther,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mor&shy;
&eth;re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Myr&shy;
&eth;rian</etym>, to slay, or murther.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muscadel(n)">Muscadine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Muscat, Muscate,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Moscatello,</etym> wine so called; be&shy;
cause it is made of Grapes that 
smell like Musk: Or, as Bo&shy;
chartus saith, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Muscis,</etym> from 
Flies, that feed upon this 
Grape, rather than any other.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muscat(n)">The Muscat-Pear,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, from 
its perfuming smell, like to 
that of Musk.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mussel(n)">Muscle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Muscle,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Muschel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Musca,</etym> a 
Fly; for Rondel. saith, that 
they are called, <etym lang="fr">Mousches de 
mar,</etym> Sea-flies. Right Mussel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muse(v)">To Muse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mu&shy;
ser,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Muysen,</etym> to 
pry into secrets with great si&shy;
lence; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Mussare,</etym> to mumble; which 
is again derived from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to shut the mouth.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mushroom(n)">Mushrom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mous&shy;
cheron,</etym> the same; and this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Musca,</etym> a Fly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="musician(n)">Musician,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mu&shy;
sicien,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; a Professor of 
Musick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="musk(n)">Musk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Muschio,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Musc,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="musket(n)">Musket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mous&shy;
quet,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Moschetto,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; a lesser sort of Gun.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="must(v)">Must,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mussen,</etym> 
to be necessary, or needful.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mustache(n)">Mustaches,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mou&shy;
stache,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mostaccio,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Mostacha,</etym> the same; 
all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&tau;&alpha;&xi;</etym>, which 
comes from <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to shut; for 
they encompass, as it were, the 
mouth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mustard(n)">Mustard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mous&shy;
tarde,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mostarda,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Mostaerde,</etym> the same: 
Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Mustum ardens,</etym> 
hot, or sharp Must.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muster(v)">To Muster,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mu&shy;
stern,</etym> to take a view of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mutiny(n)">Mutiny,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Mutino,</etym> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Motin,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; a 
Sedition in an Army.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mutter(v)">Mutter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Muy&shy;
ten;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mu&shy;
tire,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="mutton(n)">Mutton,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mou&shy;
ton,</etym> a Ram, or Weather.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="muzzle(n)">A Muzzel,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Mouth-Seal;</etym> 
saith Minshew: Or from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Musolare,</etym> to cover the 
face with a Muzzel.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="N"><alpha>N</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nacre(n)">A NAcker, or Naker-Fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nacca&shy;
ra,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nag(n)">A Nag,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Negge,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nickel,</etym> a little 
Horse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nail(n)">Nail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Naegl</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Naeghel,</etym> or the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Nagel</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the nail 
 of a Man's hand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nail(n)">A Nail of Iron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Naeghel,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nagel,</etym> 
the same; whence the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Naeghelen</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Na&shy;
geln</etym>, to drive a nail; all per&shy;
haps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nae,</etym> to, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eege</etym>, a point, 
or edge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naked(a)">Naked,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Naced</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Naeckt,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Nacket,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="name(n)">Name,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nama</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Naem,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nahme,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nom,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nome,</etym> 
or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Namo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nap(n)" lexeme="knop(n)">A Nap in Cloth, or Knop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hnoppa</etym>, or the Belg. 
and Dan. <etym lang="da">Noppe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nap(n)">Nap,</form> <xpln lang="en">To take a Nap, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hnappian</etym>, to sleep a 
little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nape(n)">Nap of the Neck;</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, from 
short, soft hair growing there&shy;
in, like a <etym lang="en">Nap</etym> of wool.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="napery(n)">Napery,</form> <xpln lang="en">table-linen, from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Nappa,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Map&shy;
pa,</etym> a napkin.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="R7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nappy ale(n)">Nappy-Ale,</form> <xpln lang="en">that is, soft, fat Ale, 
that causeth one to take a <etym lang="en">nap</etym> 
after it, or that warmeth one 
like a <etym lang="en">nappy</etym> garment; figu&shy;
ratively so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="narrow(a)">Narrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nea&shy;
rewe, Nearo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
this from <etym lang="oe">Near</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Nahr,</etym> near.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nasty(a)">Nasty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nasz,</etym> 
moist, or damp: Or from 
<etym lang="tt">Nesg,</etym> stale, or piss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nave(n)">The Nave of a wheel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Nau&eth;e</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nave,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nave,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="navel(n)">Navel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nafel</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Naevel,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Nable,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Nawl,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="naught(n)">Naught,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Naht, 
Neaht,</etym> id. whence Naht&shy;
ness, naughtiness, lewdness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="navy(n)">Navy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nav&eacute;e,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Navata, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Navis,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&alpha;&#x1FE6;&#x03c2;</etym>, a ship.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nay(ex)">Nay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Na</etym>, no, not; 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ne,</etym> 
not.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="near(adv)">Near,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Near</etym>, or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">N&aelig;r,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neat(n)">Neat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Neat</etym>, a 
labouring beast, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Nod,</etym> an Ox, Bull, or Cow; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nea&eth;yrd</etym>, 
a Neat-herd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neat(a)">Neat,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Cleanly; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Net,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Netto,</etym> 
spruce; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ni&shy;
tidus,</etym> clean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nether(a)">Neather,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Neder,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nieder,</etym> beneath, 
lower; from hence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nederland</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Niederland</etym>, the Neather-Lands, 
or Low-Countries, adjoining 
to Germany.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neb(n)">Neb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nebbe</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Neb,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snedde</etym> 
a snout.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neck(n)">Neck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Necca</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Neck, Nack,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nack, Nacken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="niece(n)">Neece,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Niece,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nezza,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Nift</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="need(n)">Need,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Nood,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Noth,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Nead, Nyd</etym>, necessity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="needle(n)">Needle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Naedl</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Naedel,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Nadel,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Naal;</etym> all 
signifying the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neger(n)">A Neger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. and Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Negro,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Negre,</etym> 
an Ethiopian; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Niger,</etym> black.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neigh(v)">To Neigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hn&aelig;&shy;
gan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Negen,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neighbour(n)">Neighbour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Neah,</etym> 
nigh, and <etym lang="oe">Gebure</etym>, an Inha&shy;
bitant: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Nae,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nahe,</etym> near, 
and <etym lang="tt">Byer,</etym> a Dweller.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="neither(adv)">Neither,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Na&eth;er,</etym> 
or <etym lang="oe">Nou&eth;er</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ne,</etym> not, and <etym lang="en">Either;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="anemone(n)">A Nemony,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. and 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Anemone,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a flower 
</page> 

<page sig="R7v"> 
of the wind; all from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&nu;&epsilon;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the wind; because 
it springeth in the beginning 
of the Spring, when the winds 
blow strong. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nephew(n)">Niphew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ne&shy;
pheu,</etym> the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nefa</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Neve,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nepos,</etym> a Ne&shy;
phew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ness(su)">Ness,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Termination of many 
words; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Naese</etym>, 
a Promontory.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nest(n)">Nest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Belg. and 
Teut.<etym lang="tt">Nest,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="net(n)">Net,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Net</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Netre</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew 
and Fr. Jun. draw it from the 
<emend err="the"></emend> Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&#x1F75;&theta;&omega;</etym>, to knit toge&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nethermost(n)">Nethermost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Nie&eth;ermert,</etym> the lowest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nettle(n)">Nettle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Netl</etym>, the 
Belg <etym lang="bl">Netel,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nessel,</etym> 
or the Dan <etym lang="da">Nedle, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="never(adv)">Never,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Naefre</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="oe">Na</etym>, not, 
and <etym lang="oe">Aefre</etym>, ever.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="new(a)">New,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nipe, 
Neowe</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nieuw,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Neuf,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">New,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Novus,</etym> or the Gr <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&epsilon;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="newt(n)">A Newt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">An Eut,</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Eft.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="next(a)">Next,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Next</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nechst,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nibble(v)">Nibble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Knibbe&shy;
len,</etym> to gnaw, to bite a little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nick(n)">Nick,</form> <xpln lang="en">He took him in the Nick 
of time; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nick,</etym> 
a nod; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he took him at 
his nod; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Nictare,</etym> to give a sign by 
winking.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nick(v)">To Nick</form> <xpln lang="en">it, to hit the nail on the 
head; a Metaphor taken from 
Archers, that set the string of 
the bow in the notch of the 
arrow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nickname(n)">A Nick name,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Nicht Nahm;</etym> not a name; 
(i. e) not a true name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="niggard(n)">Niggard:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it from 
<etym lang="en">Nigh Guarder</etym>: Skinner, &agrave; 
<etym lang="la">Negando,</etym> from denying; for 
a covetous Man denies himself 
and his family things necessa&shy;
ry: Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Nicks hard,</etym> 
(i. e.) goes as near as he can.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nigh(a)">Nigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">From the AS. <etym lang="oe">Neah</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nat,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nihe,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="night(n)">Night,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Niht</etym>, the 
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nacht,</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nuict,</etym> the night; all 
from the Lat. Ablat. <etym lang="la">Nocte,</etym> 
by night.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nightingale(n)">Nightingale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Nichtgale, Nihtegale</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Nactegal,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Nacht-Gael,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Nachtigal,</etym> the same; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">nocte canens Gallus,</etym> a 
bird that sings in the night, as 
Cocks do; all from the Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Nacht,</etym> the night, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Galm,</etym> an echo, or <etym lang="bl">Galmen,</etym> 
to re-sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nill(v)">To Nill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nillan</etym>, 
to be unwilling; which is a 
</page> 

<page sig="R8r"> 
Contract of <etym lang="oe">Na</etym>, not, and 
<etym lang="oe">Willan</etym>, to will. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nimble(a)">Nimble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old word To
 <etym lang="oe">Nimm,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to catch up a 
thing hastily and secretly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nim(v)">To Nimm,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Steal away, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Niman</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Nemen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nem&shy;
men, Nehmen,</etym> to take, to 
catch privately.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nine(n)">Nine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nigen</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Neghen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Nean,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="tt">Nenute</etym>, 
the ninth, and <etym lang="tt">Neuntig</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Neghentig</etym>, ninety.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ninny(n)">Ninny,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ninno,</etym> 
a child, or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nencio,</etym> a 
fool.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nip(v)">Nip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Niippen,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kneipen,</etym> to pinch, 
or squeeze with the fingers, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Knip,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nipple(n)">Nipple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nypele</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nit(n)">Nits,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hnitu</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Gnid,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Note,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nisz,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
possibly from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, 
to prick, or pinch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="no(ex)">No,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Na</etym>, or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">No,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noble(n)">A Noble, or Rose-Noble,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a noble Coin; so called, from 
the purity and excellency of 
the Gold it was made of, and 
because it was stamped with 
the figure of a Rose. It was 
first coin'd by King Edward 
the Third, in the Year 1344. 
about which time, he institu&shy;
ted the noble Order of the 
Garter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noble(a)">Noble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nobilis.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nock(n)">Nock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nocke,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nocca, Nocchia,</etym> a 
nock of an arrow; whence 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Noccare</etym>, to notch, or 
nick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nod(n)">A Nod,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nutus,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Nu;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to nod.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noddle(n)">Noddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">the head; from the 
Heb. <etym lang="he">Nod,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nutare,</etym> 
to nod, saith Minshew. Or it 
may be drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hnol</etym>, the nowl, or the crown 
of the head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noddy(n)">A Noddy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nau&shy;
din,</etym> a fool; this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Nutatione,</etym> 
from nodding often in time 
of speaking.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noise(n)">Noise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Noise,</etym> a 
tumult, scuffle, or wrangling; 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Noxia,</etym> noi&shy;
some, harmful.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="none(n)">None,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nan</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Nin</etym>, 
none.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nook(n)">Nook,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Niche,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nicchio,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Een Hoeck,</etym> id. saith Hensh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noon(n)">Noon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">None</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Noen,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">None,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nona,</etym> Noon, or 
Mid-day, Dinner-time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noose(n)">Noose,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Halter; perhaps from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nodus,</etym> a knot, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Noost,</etym> hurt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nor(c)">Nor,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Neg. <etym lang="en">Ne,</etym> not, 
and <etym lang="en">Or,</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="north(n)">North,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nor&eth;</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Noord,</etym> or the Teut. 
and Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nord, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nose(n)" lexeme="nostril(n)">Nose, Nostril,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
</page> 

<page sig="R8v"> 
<etym lang="oe">N&aelig;se</etym>, the nose, and <etym lang="oe">&ETH;yrl</etym>, 
an hole; whence <etym lang="oe">&ETH;yrlian</etym>, 
to make an hole through. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="not(adv)">Not,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Niet,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nicht,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; in no 
wise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novelty(n)" lexeme="novel(a)">Novelty, Novel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Nouvellet&eacute;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Nouvelle,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Novella,</etym> 
a Novel, a new Fable; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Novus, Novellus,</etym> 
new, somewhat new.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nought(n)">Nought,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nowit, 
Nowhit</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nicht,</etym> 
nothing: Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Na,</etym> 
not, and <etym lang="oe">Wiht</etym>, a creature; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) no creature. V. Ought, 
and Wight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="novice(n)">A Novice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">No&shy;
vice,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Novitio,</etym> or the 
Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Novitius,</etym> an Up&shy;
start; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">No&shy;
vus,</etym> new.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noun(n)">A Noun,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nom,</etym> 
the same; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Nomen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nourish(v)">Nourish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nour&shy;
rir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Nodrire,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nutrire,</etym> id. 
Hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nourriture</etym>; with us, Nurture, education, 
nourishment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="now(adv)">Now,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS Fr. Th. and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nu,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nuh, 
Nun;</etym> all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nunc,</etym> 
or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&#x1FE6;&nu;</etym>, now, at this 
time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="noll(n)">Nowl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from he AS. <etym lang="oe">Hnol</etym>, the 
crown of the head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="number(n)">Number,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nom&shy;
bre;</etym> and both Contracts of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Numerus,</etym> a num&shy;
ber.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="numbed(a)">Nummed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Niman</etym>, 
to nimm; whence <etym lang="oe">Beny&shy;
man</etym>, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Benemen</etym>, 
to take away; as we say of 
one that has the Palsie, His 
limbs are taken away. Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Heb. 
<etym lang="he">Nom,</etym> to sleep.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nun(n)">A Nun,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nun</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Nonne,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nonn,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nonne,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
or the old Egypt. <etym lang="eg">Nonn,</etym> holy, 
chaste.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nurse(n)">A Nurse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nour&shy;
ri&eacute;e,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nutrix,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nut(n)">Nut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hnut</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Noot,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Nuss,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Noix,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Noce;</etym> all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nux, </etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nutmeg(n)">Nutmeg,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Eng. <etym lang="en">Nut,</etym> 
and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Muguette;</etym> 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Moschata.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nuzzle(v)">Nuzzle,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Nestle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nyas(n)">A Nyas-Hawk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">un Niais,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ni&shy;
diace, Nidaso,</etym> a Nest-hawk; 
these from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nid,</etym> or 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nidus,</etym> a nest.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 
</page> 

<page sig="S1r"> 
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="O"><alpha>O</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oak(n)">OAk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aac, Ac, 
&AElig;c</etym>, the Run. Dan. <etym lang="rn">Eik,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eycke,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Eych, Eyche,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oar(n)">Oar</form> <xpln lang="en">to row with, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, the Dan <etym lang="da">Aare,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oor,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ore(n)">Oar, as Lead-Oar; or rather, 
Ore;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ore</etym>, 
metal, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Or, Oore,</etym> 
a Mine: Or from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&rho;&#x1F7B;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to dig.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oat(n)">Oats,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aten</etym>, id. 
and this perhaps from <etym lang="oe">Etan</etym>, 
to eat; for it is forage for 
Horses in all places; and in 
some, provision for Men.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oath(n)">Oath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">A&eth;</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eed, Eedt,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Eyd,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="obey(v)">To Obey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Obe&iuml;r;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Obe&shy;
dire,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="occamy(n)">Ockamy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain mix'd metal, 
of the colour of Silver, yet of 
little worth. A Depravation 
of the word <etym lang="en">Alchymy.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="odd(a)">Odd,</form> <xpln lang="en">in numbers, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Ood,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Oed, Ode,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, alone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="of(pp)">Of,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Of</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Af;</etym> and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ab,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="offal(n)">Offals,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Off Falls</etym>; to wit, 
that which falls off the table, 
or the fragments that are left.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="offence(n)">Offence,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Of&shy;
fence,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Offendere,</etym> to offend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="offering(n)">An Offering,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Of&shy;
fring,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Offrande,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Offrenda</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Res Offerenda,</etym> a thing 
to be offered.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="offertory(n)">An Offertory</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Offertoire,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. 
<etym lang="la">Offertorium,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all <etym lang="la">ab 
Offerendo,</etym> from offering.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="officer(n)">An Officer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Officier,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Of&shy;
ficiario,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Officiarius,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="often(adv)" lexeme="oft(n)">Often, Oft,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Oft</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Offte,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Offt,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oil(n)">Oil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ael, Ele</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Oel,</etym> the same; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Oleum,</etym> and this 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&lambda;&alpha;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ointment(n)">Ointment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oin&shy;
dre,</etym> to anoint; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oyster(n)">Oister,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oester,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Huistre,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Auster,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ostreum,</etym> or the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&sigma;&tau;&rho;&epsilon;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, an Oister.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="old(a)">Old,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eald</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oud,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Alt,</etym> 
the same: Or perhaps from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&lambda;&delta;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to grow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="omelette(n)">An Omelet</form> <xpln lang="en">of Eggs, V. <etym lang="en">Aume&shy;
let.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="on(pp)">On,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">An,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="one(n)">One,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">An, &AElig;ne,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Een,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ein,</etym> id. whence Aenig, once.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="S1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="only(adv)">Onely,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">An, Ana</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="onion(n)">Onion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oignon,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ognone,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">yneleac</etym>, the same; which 
last comes from our words 
<etym lang="en">Young,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Leek.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="open(v)">To Open,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Openian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ope&shy;
nen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Olfaen,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Obuer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Offen</etym>, and the Belg <etym lang="bl">Open</etym>, 
open, manifest; as also <etym lang="bl">Open 
Hertig</etym>, open hearted</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppose(v)">Oppose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oppo&shy;
ser;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Opponere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oppress(v)">To Oppress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Op&shy;
presser;</etym> and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Opprimere</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="over(adv)">Or,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of the old Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Over,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="or(n)">Or,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Or,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Oro;</etym> 
the same; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Aurum,</etym> Gold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orange(n)">Orange,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Orenge, 
Orange,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Arancia,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Aurantium,</etym> id. 
all ab <etym lang="la">Aureo Colore,</etym> to wit, 
from its golden colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orchard(n)">Orchard,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. Hort. or Wort-Yard,
 from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wyrt-geard</etym>, 
 <term lang="la">idem</term>, says Skinner. V. Yard,
 and Garden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ordain(v)">To Ordain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Or&shy;
donner,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ordinare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: From 
hence the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Ordonnance</etym>; 
with us, An Ordinance, Edict, 
or Decree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ordnance(n)">Ordnance,</form> <xpln lang="en">A piece of Ordnance, 
a Canon, or great Gun; so 
called, because it is placed <etym lang="la">in&shy;
ter Ordines,</etym> amongst the 
ranks of Soldiers; or because 
it breaks through <etym lang="la">Ordines ho&shy;
stium,</etym> the ranks of the Ene&shy;
mies, cutting off many at once.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ordure(n)">Ordure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ordure,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ordura,</etym> dung; 
these from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ord,</etym> fil&shy;
thy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="organ(n)">Organ,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F4C;&rho;&gamma;&alpha;&nu;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, 
an instrument; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an in&shy;
strument, &Kappa;&alpha;&tau;' &#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;, for its 
excellency.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oriflamme(n)">Oriflamb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ori&shy;
flambe,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Aureum 
Flammeum,</etym> a golden flag, 
such as the French Kings had 
in the Wars against Infidels.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orison(n)">An Orison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Orai&shy;
son;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ora&shy;
tio,</etym> a prayer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="orpiment(n)">Orpiment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Or&shy;
piment,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Oper&shy;
ment,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both which come 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Auripigmen&shy;
tum,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="osprey(n)">An Osprey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird that haunts 
the waters; not unlikely, from 
the Ital. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Ossifraga</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Bone breaker; so called, 
from the strength of its beak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ostler(n)">An Ostler</form> <xpln lang="en">in a Stable, from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ostiere,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Hostelier,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ostrich(n)">An Ostrich,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Austruche,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Avestr&uacute;z.</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Struzzo,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Strausz,</etym> the same; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Struthio-camelus,</etym> id. 
</page> 

<page sig="S2r"> 
a bird so called, because it is 
like, &Tau;&#x1FF7; <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&theta;&#x1FF3;</etym>, a Spar&shy;
row, in feathers; having a 
long, high neck, not unlike 
that of a Camel. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="other(a)">Other,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">O&eth;er, 
Au&eth;er</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">O&shy;
&eth;erhwile</etym>, otherwhile.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="otter(n)">Otter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Oter</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Odder,</etym> or the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Otter,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lutra,</etym> the same; 
which comes from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to wash; from its diving 
under water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oven(n)">Oven,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ofne</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oven,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ofen,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Own,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="over(pp)">Over,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ober, 
Ofer</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ober,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Over,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="overcome(v)">Overcome,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ofer&shy;
cuman</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Overko&shy;
men,</etym> the same. V. Over, and 
Come.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oversee(v)">To Oversee,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <etym lang="en">Over,</etym> and <etym lang="en">See.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="overture(n)">Overture,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Offrir,</etym> 
to offer, or <etym lang="fr">Ouvrir,</etym> to lay 
open.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="overwhelm(v)">Overwhelm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">O&shy;
ber-Apylfan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. V.
 Over, and Whelm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ought(n)">Ought,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Owiht</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Owuht;</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ought(v)">It Ought,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Impers. of <etym lang="en">Owe;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ounce(n)">An Ounce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Once,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vncia,</etym> dem; the 
twelfth part of a pound Troy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="our(pr)">Our,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Owre, 
Ure,</etym> or the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Vor,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="out(adv)">Out,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ut</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Vut,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ausz,</etym> id. 
whence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vutwaerts</etym>, outwards.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="outlandish(a)">Outlandish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ausz&shy;
landisch,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Fo&shy;
reigner, one coming from out&shy;
lands. V. Out, and Land.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="outlaw(n)">Outlaw,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a person <etym lang="en">out</etym> of the 
<etym lang="en">Law,</etym> whom the Laws do no 
longer protect.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="outmost(a)">Outmost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">yte&shy;
maest</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="outrage(n)">Outrage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Out&shy;
rage, Oultrage,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Oltraggio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="outstrip(v)">To Out-strip at running, or in 
vertue;</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Out</etym> and <etym lang="en">Strip,</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="outward(a)">Outward,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ut&shy;
weard</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vutwaerts,</etym> &shy;
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Auszwart</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. &shy;
V. Out, and Ward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ouzel(n)">Ouzel,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Black-bird, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Osle</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this per&shy;
haps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oiseau,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vccello,</etym> a little 
bird.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="owl(n)">Owl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ule</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Vgle,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vul,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eul</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; these 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vlulo,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&lambda;&omicron;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to howl: All 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ooze(n)">Owse, or Ouse,</form> <xpln lang="en">the bark of the 
Oak-tree, which Tanners use 
to thicken and colour their 
</page> 

<page sig="S2v"> 
hides withal. It may possibly 
come from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ost</etym>, the 
scale of a fish; for the bark is, 
as it were, the scale of a tree. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ox(n)">Ox</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Oxa</etym>, the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Ore,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Os,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ochsz, Ochs,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oxgang(n)">Organg of land,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnsh. 
Oskin; from <etym lang="en">Ox,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Gang</etym>; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  as much land as may be 
plow'd with one gang or team 
of Oxen in one day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="oyez(ex)">Oyes,</form> <xpln lang="en">the word used by the 
Crier of a Court when he pro&shy;
claims Silence; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Oyez,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Hear you me.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ozier(n)">An Ozier</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Osier,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Ozier,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; a low Wil&shy;
low growing in the water; 
both perhaps from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Omicron;&#x1F30;&sigma;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, a Willow.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="P"><alpha>P</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pace(n)">A PAce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pas,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Passo;</etym> both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Passus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pacify(v)">To Pacifie,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
cifier,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; to appease, to 
make one to be at Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pack(n)">A Pack</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Pack,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pacquet,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pacchetto,</etym> the same: 
Hence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pack-kleed</etym>, 
pack-cloth, and <etym lang="bl">Packen</etym>, to pack up wares.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pack(v)">Pack,</form> <xpln lang="en">He Pack'd away, or got 
him away in all haste; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sich Packen,</etym> to be 
gone, or <etym lang="tt">Pack dich,</etym> be gone; 
by a Metaphor taken from 
Warfare, when Soldiers are bid 
pack up bag and baggage, the 
camp being to be removed 
with all expedition.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="padded(a)" lexeme="pad(v)">Padded away, To Pad, to tread,
or make it level;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&tau;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to tread upon, or <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F71;&shy;
&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a way much frequented: 
Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Paad,</etym> a path.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paddle(v)">To Paddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
touiller,</etym> to move the water 
with hands or feet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paddock(n)">Paddock:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Padde,</etym> a Toad; for
