that Toads do usually hide 
themselves under them in the 
day-time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="padlock(n)">Padlock:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. supposeth that it is so called, q. <etym lang="en">Pend-lock;</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an hanging lock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pad-nag(n)">A Pad-Nag,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the 
Noun <etym lang="en">Path,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Nag fit to 
ride a journey upon; or from 
<etym lang="en">Pad,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a saddle stuffed 
with straw; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A Saddle-&shy;
Horse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="page(n)">Page,</form> <xpln lang="en">or side in a book, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pag&eacute;;</etym> both Con&shy;
tracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pagina,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="page(n)">Page,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Foot Page, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Page,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pag&shy;
gio,</etym> the same: Or from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&iota;&delta;&#x1F77;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a little Boy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pageant(n)">A Pageant:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it 
from our word <etym lang="en">Page,</etym> which 
see before: Skinner, from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F75;&gamma;&nu;&upsilon;&mu;&iota;</etym>, to conjoin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pail(n)">Pail</form> <xpln lang="en">, Milk-Pail, from the Gr. 
</page> 

<page sig="S3r"> 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F73;&lambda;&lambda;&alpha;</etym>, the same: Or from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Paila,</etym> which Minshew 
says, signifies a Milk-Pail. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pain(n)">Pain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peine,</etym> the 
AS <etym lang="oe">Pin</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pein</etym>, id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">&oelig;na,</etym> or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&iota;&nu;&#x1F74;</etym>, punishment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paynim(n)" lexeme="pagan(n)">Painim, or Pagan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Payen,</etym> a Pagan; this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pagus,</etym> a village; 
for at the coming in of Chri&shy;
stianity, they were, by little 
and little, thrust out of the ci&shy;
ties, and forced to worship 
their heathenish Deities in pri&shy;
vate villages only.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paint(v)">To Paint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peint,</etym> 
painted; which comes of 
<etym lang="fr">Peindre,</etym> the same; whence 
also <etym lang="fr">Paintre</etym>, a Painter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pair(n)">A Pair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Paire,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Paer,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Paio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; two of any sort 
of things; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Par,</etym> a pare, couple, or match.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pale(a)">Pale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pasle,</etym> pale, 
as in the face; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pallidus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pale(n)">Pales,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Fr. G.
<etym lang="fr">Pal</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Palus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, a stake, or 
wooden pin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palfrey(n)">A Palfrey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pale&shy;
froy,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Palafreno,</etym> a 
Courser, a Post-horse. Min&shy;
shew derives it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Pale</etym>, a young Horse, and 
<etym lang="oe">Freoh</etym>, free: Skinner, from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F71;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, to shake, and 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fraenum,</etym> a bridle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pall(n)">A Pall,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Palla,</etym> a 
pall, consecrated, and sent by 
the Pope, to an Archbishop of 
the Romish Church, at his 
Consecration; which he pays 
His Holiness for.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pallet(n)">A Pallet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little low bed. Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Paille,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Paglia,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Palea,</etym> chaff; because it 
is stuffed with chaff or straw. 
It may also probably be drawn 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pellis,</etym> a skin; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a bed made of skins.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palisado(n)">Pallizado,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Warfare; 
from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Palisada,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Palissade,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Palificata;</etym> all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Palus,</etym> a stake, or post.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmer(n)">A Palmer,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Pilgrim for Reli&shy;
gions sake; so called, from a 
staff made of the <etym lang="en">Palm-tree</etym>, 
which they carried as they re&shy;
turned from the Holy War.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmer-worm(n)">A Palmer-Worm;</form> <xpln lang="en">&agrave; <etym lang="la">Palmis</etym>, 
from Palm-trees, whose leaves 
it chiefly eateth: Or, as Muf&shy;
fetus has it, because it is con&shy;
tinually in motion, as A <etym lang="en">Pal&shy;
mer,</etym> going on continual Pil&shy;
grimage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palmistry(n)">Palmestry,</form> <xpln lang="en">&agrave; <etym lang="la">Palmis</etym>, from the 
palms of the hands, which 
Chiromancers look upon, pre&shy;
tending to predict futurities 
thereby.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Palm Sunday(n)">Palm-Sunday,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">&agrave; Palmarum ra&shy;
mis,</etym> from branches of the 
Palm-trees, which the Jews, 
on that day, carried before 
Christ, when they met him in 
the way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palsgrave(n)">Palsgrave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Palts&shy;
grave,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfaltsgraff,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="S3v"> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Grave, Count, 
or Earl of the King's Palace. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="palsy(n)">Palsy,</form> <xpln lang="en">contracted from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Paralysie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pa&shy;
ralesia,</etym> which come from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Paralysis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, 
a resoluton, or loosning of 
the nerves: When both the 
motion and sense is lost, we 
call it, A Dead Palsy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paltry(a)">A Paltry</form> <xpln lang="en">Knave, from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Paltone, Paltoniere,</etym> a most 
profligate Knave; or from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poltron,</etym> a coward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pamper(v)">To Pamper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pam&shy;
berare,</etym> to make fat: Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="fr">Pan,</etym> &amp; <etym lang="en">Beer;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) bread, 
and Beer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pamphlet(n)">Pamphlet</form> <xpln lang="en">: Minshew draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1FB6;&nu;</etym> all, and <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F75;&shy;
&theta;&omega;</etym>, to fill: Skinner, from the &shy;
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pamplet,</etym> which is a 
Contract of the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pam&shy;
pier;</etym> which he draws from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Papyrus,</etym> paper.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pan(n)">Pan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Dan. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Panne,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfan,</etym> id. 
any sort of a pan.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panada(n)">Panado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
nade,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Panada;</etym> all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Panis,</etym> bread.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pancake(n)">Pancake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pan&shy;
koeck,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfankuch,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pander(n)">Pander,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pimp, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pander,</etym> one that takes a bribe 
to hold his tongue; this from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pand,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Pfand,</etym> a pawn, or pledge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pang(n)">Pangs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Peini&shy;
gen,</etym> to torment, or from 
our word <etym lang="en">Pains;</etym> both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">P&oelig;na,</etym> punishment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="panguts(n)">A Panguts,</form> <xpln lang="en">or fat belly, from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1FB6;&nu;</etym>, all, and <etym lang="en">Guts;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  all guts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pannier(n)">Pannier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
nier,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Paniere,</etym> the 
same; all from <etym lang="la">Panis,</etym> bread.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pant(v)">To Pant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pan&shy;
teler</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>, to puff, to draw 
breath short.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pantler(n)">A Pantler,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
netiere,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Panatiere,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, he that has the keys of 
the Pantry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pantofle(n)">A Pantofle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pantoufle,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Panto&shy;
fola,</etym> a slipper, or sock: Or 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&sigma;
&nu;&tau;&#x1F79;&phi;&epsilon;&lambda;&lambda;&omicron;</etym>, all 
made of Cork: Or from <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&shy;
&tau;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to tread on, and <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&#x1F73;&lambda;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
Cork; because they were for&shy;
merly, for lightness, made of 
Cork.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pantry(n)">Pantry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pane&shy;
terie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Panateria,</etym> 
a chest or closet wherein bread 
is kept; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pa&shy;
nis,</etym> bread.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pap(n)">Pap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pappe,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pappin,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Pappa,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paper(n)">Paper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Papier,</etym> 
the same; and both from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F71;&pi;&upsilon;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a certain reed 
in Egypt, of which paper was 
made.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paragon(n)">A Paragon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
ragon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Paragone,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a curious pattern, or 
Sample: Originally, from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F70;</etym>, nigh to, and <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&gamma;&#x1F7C;&nu;</etym>, 
a trial.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="S4r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paramount(a)">Paramount,</form> <xpln lang="en">supream, from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Para,</etym> to, and <etym lang="sp">Montar,</etym> 
to mount, or get above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paramour(n)">Paramour,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Paran&shy;
do amorem,</etym> from procuring 
love.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parapet(n)">A Parapet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
rapet,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Parapetto,</etym> 
a wall breast-high, made of 
clods of earth, or turves, to 
keep off bullets; these from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parer,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Parare,</etym> to defend, and the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Petto,</etym> the breast.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parboil(v)">To Parboil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pourbouiller,</etym> to half boil; or, 
as Minshew has it, <etym lang="la">Parum 
bullire,</etym> to boil a little; or ra&shy;
ther, q. <etym lang="en">Part-boil,</etym> to boil in 
part.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parcel(n)">A Parcel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Par&shy;
celle;</etym> this a Contract of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Particella,</etym> a small part, 
or pittance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parch(v)">To Parch,</form> <xpln lang="en">or almost burn; perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Percoquere,</etym> to 
boil thoroughly: Or from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F73;&rho;&kappa;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, black; for things 
parched contract a brownish 
black colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parchment(n)">Parchment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parchemin,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Perga&shy;
mina,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Perga&shy;
ment,</etym> the same: It is thus cal&shy;
led, because it was invented at 
Pergamus, in Asia Minor, by 
King Eumenes, when Paper, 
that was then in Egypt only, 
was prohibited by Ptolomy, to 
be transported into Asia.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pardon(n)">Pardon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Par&shy;
don,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pardono</etym>, id. 
whence Pardonner, and Par&shy;
donare, to pardon, to forgive.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pare(v)">To Pare,</form> <xpln lang="en">to cut off, from the &shy;
Lat. <etym lang="la">Separare,</etym> to separate, 
saith Minshew: Or rather, 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Parare,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;&shy;
parare,</etym> to make ready, or fit; 
whence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parer les 
Ougles</etym>, to pare, or cut away &shy;
an Horse's hoofs, that the shooes may be fitted accor&shy;
dingly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="nonpareil(n)">Non Pareil,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Letter so 
called by Printers; from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Non,</etym> and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
reil,</etym> like to; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  none such, 
or none like it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parentage(n)">Parentage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
rentage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Paren&shy;
taggio,</etym> kinship, affinity; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Parens,</etym> a Pa&shy;
rent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parish(n)">A Parish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
roisse,</etym> a chappel; this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Par&oelig;cia,</etym> or the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&rho;&omicron;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, an holy neighbour&shy;
hood; to wit, as many as are 
committed to the cure of one 
Curate, or Priest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="park(n)">Park,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pearroc</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Paerck,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Parc,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Parco</etym>, id.
 all perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&pi;' &shy;
 &#x1F1D;&rho;&kappa;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, from its being inclosed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parliament(n)">Parliament, or rather, Parle&shy;
ment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parle&shy;
ment,</etym> a County-Court, or As&shy;
sises; but with us, a Council 
of Lords and Commons of the 
whole Realm; this from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parler,</etym> to speak; or 
from our word <etym lang="en">Parley.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="S4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parlor(n)">Parlour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Par&shy;
loir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Parlagio,</etym> id. 
these from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parler,</etym> 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Parlare,</etym> to talk; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a place for private dis&shy;
course.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parley(v)">To Parley,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Par&shy;
ler,</etym> to speak; that is, to treat 
upon Articles of Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parmacety(n)">Parma-citty,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Corruption of 
<etym lang="la">Sperma Ceti,</etym> the spawn of 
the Whale; for it was former&shy;
ly accounted the seed of a 
Whale; but now it is disco&shy;
vered to come out of the 
Whale's head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parmesan(n)">Parmesan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Par&shy;
mesan,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Parmegia&shy;
no,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, cheese so called, be&shy;
cause it is brought from <etym lang="it">Par&shy;
ma.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parol(n)">Parol,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parole,</etym> 
a word; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Parabola,</etym> a parable. A Ca&shy;
ptive in War is by the Enemy 
released upon Parol, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
upon his word, promising to 
return within the time appoin&shy;
ted, when he can procure no 
Ransom, nor get another Ca&shy;
ptive of his King, to remain a 
little while in Captivity for 
him. A verbal Will is also cal&shy;
led A Will Parol.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parrot(n)">A Parrot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parroquet, Perroquet,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the old word 
<etym lang="fr">Perrot,</etym> little Peter, saith Me&shy;
nagius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parse(v)">To Parse</form> <xpln lang="en">Latin, Greek, &amp;c. 
from our word To <etym lang="en">Pierce;</etym> or 
to divide it into parts, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
to examine every word tho&shy;
roughly by its self.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="parson(n)">Parson,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Parish-Son, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Pastor, or Son of a Parish. 
v. <etym lang="en">Parish.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="part(v)">To Part,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Partiri,</etym>
 to part, or divide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="partial(a)">Partial,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Partiale,</etym> 
he that favoureth this or that 
Party, having a prejudice, a&shy;
gainst such as hold a contrary 
Opinion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="partisan(n)">Partisan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parti&shy;
san,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Partaggiano,</etym> 
he that joins himself to a Par&shy;
ty, or Faction.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="partisan(n)">Partizan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Per&shy;
tuisane,</etym> or the Hisp. and Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Partesana,</etym> an halberd, an old 
kind of spear: These, saith 
Skinner, not as Minsh. hath 
it, from the Parthians, the in&shy;
venters of it; but from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Pertugiare,</etym> to make an 
hole through.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="partner(n)">Partner,</form> <xpln lang="en">q.<etym lang="en"> Part Owner;</etym> or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Personnier,</etym> a 
partaker; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Paer&shy;
tenaer,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="partridge(n)">A Partridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Perdrix,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pernice,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. and 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">Perdix,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="party(n)">A Party,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Par&shy;
tie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Partito,</etym> a Fa&shy;
ction; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pars,</etym> 
a part.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pass(v)">To Pass,</form> <xpln lang="en">Well to Pass, I am 
come to a fine Pass; from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wohl zu Pasz seyu,</etym> to 
be well, to be in good health. 
It is also taken from the Gr. 
</page> 

<page sig="S5r"> 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F71;&sigma;&chi;&omega;</etym>, as in &Pi;&#x1F71;&sigma;&chi;&omega; &tau;&omicron;&#x1FE6;&tau;&omega;, this 
hath happened to me, this is 
come to pass. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pass(v)">To Pass,</form> <xpln lang="en">or go, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Passer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Passare,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pas&shy;
sus,</etym> a pace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passade(n)">Passade,</form> <xpln lang="en">an alms given to a poor 
Passenger; also the teaching 
an Horse to pace; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Passade,</etym> the same. V. 
Pass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passage(n)">Passage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pas&shy;
sage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Passaggio,</etym> id. 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Passus,</etym> a 
pace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passant(a)">Passant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Passant,</etym> pas&shy;
sing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passenger(n)">Passenger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pas&shy;
sager,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Passaggiere,</etym> 
one that passeth from place to 
place, from country to coun&shy;
try.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Passover(n)">Pass-over,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Pesah,</etym> 
to pass over; because the de&shy;
stroying Angel passed over the 
houses that were besprinkled 
with the Lamb's blood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passport(n)">Passport,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Passe&shy;
port,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Passa-porto</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, safe conduct; liberty to 
pass through <etym lang="la">Portus</etym> or <etym lang="la">Por&shy;
tas,</etym> ports or gates.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pastime(n)">Pastime,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Passe&shy;
temps,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Passatem&shy;
po,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, any recreative Exer&shy;
cise to pass away the time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="passe-volant(n)">Passvolant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Soldier hired by 
the Centurion, to fill up his 
number; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Passer,</etym> to pass, and <etym lang="fr">Voler,</etym> to 
fly; (i. e.) one that passeth a&shy;
mongst Soldiers one day, be&shy;
ing <etym lang="la">Volaturus,</etym> to fly off the 
next.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paste(n)">Paste,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Paste,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pasta,</etym> the same; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pascere,</etym> to feed. 
From hence the word Pastry, 
the place where paste is made.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pasture(n)">Pasture,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
sture,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pastura,</etym> id.
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Pastus,</etym> food, or pro&shy;
vender.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pasty(n)">A Pasty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Past&egrave;,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pasticcio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
Hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pastissier</etym>, 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pasticciere</etym>; with 
us, A Pasterer, or Pastry-&shy;
Cook; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that makes 
pasties.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pat(a)">Pat,</form> <xpln lang="en">fit, that which is suitable 
to; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pas,</etym> fit&shy;
ness; or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Aptus,</etym> 
by a Metathesis. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&pi;&alpha;&nu;&shy;
&tau;&#x1FB6;&nu;</etym>, to fit every way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pat(n)">A Pat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bat,</etym> id. 
or <etym lang="fr">Patte,</etym> a foot, hoof, or nail; 
all perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&shy;
&tau;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to trample upon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="patch(v)">To Patch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pezza&shy;
re,</etym> to piece, or mend. Some 
draw it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pata&shy;
gium,</etym> a border, or one thing 
sowed upon another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="path(n)">Path,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pa&eth;, Paad</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pad, Pat,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfad,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Batuere,</etym> to beat, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
A Beaten Way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pattern(n)">Pattern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
tron,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Patroon,</etym> id. 
</page> 

<page sig="S5v"> 
an example; perhaps it is thus 
called, because in doing a 
thing, we follow it, as a Client 
his Patron, or Advocate. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="patten(n)">Pattin, or Patten,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Patin,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pat&shy;
tin,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) wooden soles. Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&tau;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to tread on.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pave(v)">To Pave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Paver,</etym> 
the same; or from the old Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pavire,</etym> to beat; which com&shy;
eth of the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym> to strike; 
and from hence, A Pavement, 
because the stones are knock'd 
into the ground forcibly, with 
a beetle, or rammer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pavilion(n)">Pavilion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pa&shy;
villon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Padiglione,</etym> 
a tent; so called from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Papilio,</etym> a Butter-fly, which 
spreads out its wings after the 
<emend err="gk">the</emend> fashion of a painted tent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paunch(n)">A Paunch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pance, Panse,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pan&shy;
&ccedil;a,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pancia,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pansse,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pantz,</etym> or
 the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pantex,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or, 
 <etym lang="la">&agrave; Pandendo,</etym> from stretching 
 out, as Voss. observes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="paw(n)">A Paw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Pawen,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Patte,</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Pata,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; also a foot, or 
hoof of a brute; all perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to tread 
upon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pawn(n)">Pawn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pand,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfand,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pan,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pegno,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pignus,</etym> a 
pledge, or pawn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pay(n)">To Pay Debts,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Payer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pagare,</etym> id.
 these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pacare,</etym> to 
 content, or give satisfaction 
 to.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pay(v)">To Pay,</form> <xpln lang="en">for To Beat, from the
 Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, to beat; or from 
 the other <etym lang="en">Pay;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to pay 
 one the blows he owes him.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peace(n)">Peace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Paix;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pax,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peach(n)">A Peach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pesche,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pesca,</etym> the same; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Persicum 
Malum,</etym> a Peach.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peacock(n)">A Peacock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Papa</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pauw,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Pfaw,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Paon,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Pa&ouml;ne, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to extend; from 
his spreading forth his tail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peak(n)">Peak,</form> <xpln lang="en">as The Peak in Darby&shy;
shire, a sharp topp'd moun&shy;
tain; so called, because it is 
<etym lang="en">piked</etym> like a spear or pike.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peaking(a)">A Peaking Fellow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pequenno,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Piccino,</etym> a little fellow: Or, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Paeca</etym>, a decei&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peal(n)">A Peal of Bells:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws 
it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Apeller,</etym> to 
call; because it calls people to 
Church.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pear(n)">Pear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pepe</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Paere,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peere,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poire,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Pero, Pera,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perch(n)">A Pearch</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Perche,</etym> 
the Ital <etym lang="it">Perca,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&rho;&shy;
&kappa;&#x1F74;</etym>, a fish so called. Rondel. 
</page> 

<page sig="S6r"> 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&rho;&kappa;&alpha;&#x1F77;&shy;
&nu;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, ,, to have spots of various 
colours. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pearl(n)">Pearl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Perle,</etym> or 
the Ital. and Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Perla,</etym> id. 
Hence the Ital. Madre di Per&shy;
la, Mother of Pearl; to wit, 
the shell of the pearl-bearing &shy;
Oister.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peasant(n)">A Peasant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pai&shy;
sant,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Paesano,</etym> &shy;
a Country-man; these from 
<etym lang="fr">Pais,</etym> and <etym lang="it">Paese,</etym> the country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pea(n)">Pease,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pisa</etym>, the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pois,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Piso,</etym> or 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Pisum,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peccadillo(n)">A Peccadillo,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Peccadille,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pec&shy;
cadillo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Peccatillum,</etym> a small fault, a 
venial sin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peck(v)">To Peck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Picken, 
Pecken,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Becquer,</etym> 
to hit with the beak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="woodpecker(n)">A Wood Pecker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pick;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pi&shy;
ca;</etym> or rather, from our word 
<etym lang="en">Peck,</etym> for it makes holes in 
trees, by pecking with its beak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pedant(n)">A Pedant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pe&shy;
dant,</etym> or the Ital. and Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Pedante;</etym> and these from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">P&aelig;dagogus,</etym> a 
petty School-master.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pedet(n)">A Pedet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pedes,</etym> a 
Foot-man, or Page, to follow 
at ones foot or heels.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"pedet" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pedigree(n)">Pedegree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Degres de Peres,</etym> the de&shy;
grees of Fathers: Or, <etym lang="la">&agrave; Pe&shy;
tendo gradus,</etym> from deriving degrees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pedestal(n)">Pedestal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Architecture, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pied-stal,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Piedestallo,</etym> the basis 
of a pillar; this from <etym lang="it">Piede,</etym> 
the foot, and <etym lang="it">Stallo,</etym> a stand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pedlar(n)">Pedler;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aller a Pied,</etym> to go 
a foot: Skinner, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bettiler,</etym> a beggar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piece(n)">A Peece,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fowling-piece; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Buyse, Busse,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Buechse,</etym> a pipe, also the 
same. V. Harquebuss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peel(n)" lexeme="pill(n)">A Peel, or Pill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pellis,</etym> a skin; hence the Fr. G. 
Peler, with us, to pill off 
skin, rind, or bark.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peel(n)">A Baker's Peel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pelle, Paelle,</etym> or the Ital. Hisp. 
and Lat. <etym lang="la">Pala,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; also a 
shovel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peep(v)">To Peep</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pepier,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pipire,</etym> to peep 
like a Chicken; all feigned 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peep(v)">To Peep,</form> <xpln lang="en">or look in, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Opheffen,</etym> to heave, or 
lift up; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to lift up the 
eyes upon something. Skin&shy;
ner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peer(n)">A Peer of the Realm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pair,</etym> id. both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Par,</etym> equal; for in giving 
their Votes in Parliament, 
they are held equal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peevish(a)">Peevish</form> <xpln lang="en">, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Beeish</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) as 
we say, Waspish, one as soon 
provoked as a Bee or Wasp.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peg(n)">A Peg,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&eta;&gamma;&nu;&#x1F7B;&omega;, 
&Pi;&#x1F75;&gamma;&nu;&upsilon;&mu;&iota;</etym>, to fasten, or join; 
or the Dor. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F71;&gamma;&omega;</etym>, to fix.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pelf(n)">Pelf,</form> <xpln lang="en">for temporal riches, from 
</page> 

<page sig="S6v"> 
the Fr. Nor. <etym lang="no">Peuffe,</etym> Fripery; 
which see: Or rather, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fela, Feo</etym>, much 
money, a fee. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pellet(n)">Pellet,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="fr">Ballette,</etym> a little 
ball. Some draw it from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pella,</etym> a little round 
thing; this from <etym lang="la">Pila,</etym> a ball.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pell-mell(adv)">Pell-mell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pesle 
mesle,</etym> confusedly, without 
order; from <etym lang="fr">Pesles,</etym> locks of 
wool, and <etym lang="fr">Meslez,</etym> mixed to&shy;
gether.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pelt(n)">Pelt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Peltz,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beltz,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pellis,</etym> a skin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pelt(v)">To Pelt,</form> <xpln lang="en">as, to throw stones at: 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&lambda;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, brandished, sha&shy;
ken; or from <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F75;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to smite. 
v. Palt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pen(n)">A Pen</form> <xpln lang="en">for sheep, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Pyndan</etym>, to shut in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pencil(n)">Pencil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pensel, 
Pinsel,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pinceau,</etym> 
or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Penicillum,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pendant(n)">Pendant,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ear-ring, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pendant,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) hang&shy;
ing; for <etym lang="la">Pendet ab aure,</etym> it 
hangs down from the ear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pendant(n)">A Pendant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pennon,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pennone,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pendon,</etym> a flag, or 
banner; these again from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Penna,</etym> a feather; for it 
flies in the air like a feather: 
Or &agrave; <etym lang="la">Pendendo,</etym> from hanging, 
because it hangs in the air.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penance(n)">Pennance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Penence,</etym> the same; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Poenitentia,</etym> re&shy;
pentance, contrition.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penny(n)">Penny,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Penig</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Penntuck,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfenning,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence 
<etym lang="da">Gotts Pfenning</etym>, God's Penny, 
earnest-money, and the Dan. 
Rede Penge, ready money: 
All perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pe&shy;
cunia,</etym> money.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pensioner(n)">Pensioner,</form> <xpln lang="en">one that is maintain'd 
in a Colledge, or Hospital, at 
the King's charge only; from 
the Fr. G. and Eng. <etym lang="en">Pension,</etym> '
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pensio,</etym> a pension.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pensive(a)">Pensive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pensif,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="fr">Penser,</etym> which 
comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pensare,</etym> 
to weigh, or ponder in mind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="penthouse(n)">Penthouse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
pentis,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pendice,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pendere,</etym> to hang; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an 
hang-by, or an addition to an 
house.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="people(n)">People,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peuple,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Poefel, Pobel,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Populus,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pepper(n)">Pepper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peper,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfeffer,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Poivre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pevero,</etym> 
the same; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Piper,</etym> or the Gr. Barb. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F73;&pi;&epsilon;&rho;</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perceive(v)">Perceive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
percevoir,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Perci&shy;
pere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perform(v)">Perform,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Perfor&shy;
mare,</etym> to compleat, to bring 
to a form, or to perfection; 
or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parfournir,</etym> 
to finish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perfume(n)">Perfume,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Per&shy;
fume,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="S7r"> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Parfum,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Profumo,</etym> the same. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perhaps(adv)">Perhaps,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Per,</etym> by, 
and <etym lang="en">Hap,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Happen;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peril(n)">Peril,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peril,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Periglio;</etym> and these 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Periculum,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="periwig(n)">Periwig,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Per&shy;
ruque,</etym> the same: Or perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&rho;&iota;&#x1F73;&chi;&omega;</etym>, to com&shy;
pass about.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="periwinkle(n)">Periwinkle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Sea shell&shy;
fish; perhaps from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;</etym>, a circuit; to wit, from 
its spiral form; being, as it 
were, in wreaths.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perk(v)">To Perk, or Pirk up,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  To 
<etym lang="en">Pearch</etym> <etym lang="en">up;</etym> by a Metaphor 
taken from Hens standing up&shy;
on pearches.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="perry(n)">Perry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Per&egrave;,</etym> or 
<etym lang="fr">Poir&egrave;,</etym> a Pear; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Wine 
made of the juice of Pears.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="personage(n)">Personage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Per&shy;
sonnage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Personag&shy;
gio,</etym> the same; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Persona,</etym> a person.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pert(a)">Pert,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Appert,</etym> 
lively, sharp; this perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ad,</etym> to, and <etym lang="la">Pe&shy;
ritus,</etym> skilful.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pertain(v)">Pertain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pertine&shy;
re,</etym> to belong unto. v. Ap&shy;
pertain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peruse(v)">Peruse,</form> <xpln lang="en">to read over; from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Per,</etym> through, over, and 
<etym lang="en">Vse;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pester(v)">To Pester,</form> <xpln lang="en">to vex, or molest; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Empester,</etym> to 
trouble; this from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Impestare,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Appestare,</etym> to 
bring a pest, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) some great 
mischief upon one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pestle(n)">A Pestle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
steau,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pistello, Pe&shy;
stello,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pistare,</etym> to pound, or <etym lang="la">Pi&shy;
stillum,</etym> a pestil.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petard(n)">A Petard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pe&shy;
tart, Petard,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Petar&shy;
do,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pedard,</etym> a 
warlike engine to batter and 
demolish the walls of a city 
beleaguer'd; all from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Peter,</etym> to fart, <term lang="fr">allusiv&egrave;.</term></xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petticoat(n)">Peticoat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pe&shy;
tite cotte,</etym> a petty, or little 
coat; to wit, with respect to 
a gown, or upper coat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petronel(n)">A Petronel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Trooper's gun; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Petrinal,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Petrinale,</etym> id. Min&shy;
shew surmiseth, that it is so 
called, because <etym lang="la">Pectori appen&shy;
di solebat</etym>, it was usually hung &shy;
at the breast.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pett(n)">To take Pett<emend err="">e</emend>,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F73;&nu;&shy;
&theta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, sorrow, or <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&nu;&theta;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to 
grieve, to repine; or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Impetum capere,</etym> to take a 
passion, or fit of anger; or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Despit,</etym> as 
<etym lang="fr">Prendre Despit</etym>, to take a de&shy;
spite; by casting away the 
former syllable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pettifogger(n)">Pettifogger,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Informer; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Petit,</etym> little, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fogere</etym>, a suitor; this 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gefegan</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voeghen,</etym> or the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Fuegen,</etym> to adapt himself to a&shy;
 nother's humour, so to curry 
 favour.</xpln></wordentry> 
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="S7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="petty(a)">Petty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Petit,</etym> 
little. Menag. draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Putus,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Putto,</etym> a little one, a child.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pew(n)">A Pew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Puye, 
Puyde,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Podium,</etym> a 
pew, or stall; this from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, a foot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pewter(n)">Pewter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peauter,</etym> 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Peltre,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Peltro,</etym> the same; from hence 
the Fr. G. Espautrer, to bruise, 
to bildge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pheasant(n)">A Pheasant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fai
'san,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Fasciano, Fasano,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Phasan;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Phasian fowl, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) brought at 
first from Phasis, a river in 
Colchos.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="physician(n)">Physician,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Phy&shy;
sicien,</etym> or the old Ital. <etym lang="it">Physi&shy;
ciano;</etym> or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Physicus;</etym> 
which comes from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Psi;&#x1F7B;&shy;
&sigma;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, nature (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that is 
exercised in things natural.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pick(v)">To Pick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pycken,</etym> 
the same; this from <etym lang="en">Beak,</etym> 
which see: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Piquer,</etym> to pick. This Turneb. 
draws from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Spica,</etym> an 
ear of corn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pick out(v)">To Pick out,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pick&shy;
en,</etym> to cut down corn; this 
from <etym lang="bl">Picke,</etym> a Sickle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pickax(n)">A Pickax,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a <etym lang="en">Picking ax.</etym> V. 
Ax, and Pick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pickeer(v)">To Pickeer,</form> <xpln lang="en">to skirmish; from 
our word <etym lang="en">Pike;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to fight 
with pikes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piquet(n)">Picket,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain Play at Cards; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Picquet,</etym> or 
the Ital <etym lang="it">Picchetto,</etym> the same; all 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Piquer,</etym> to pick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pickle(v)">Pickle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pekel;</etym> 
Hence the Belg. Pekelen, with 
us, To Pickle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piddle(v)" lexeme="pittle(v)">To Piddle, or Pitle,</form> <xpln lang="en">to go about 
to do things of small moment; 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Picolo, Picciolo,</etym> 
little; or our Eng. To <etym lang="en">Peddle;</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Petit,</etym> with us, 
Petty.</xpln>
<lemenote>
The sense of "piddle" appears to antedate the earliest OED citation (1743).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piece(n)">Piece,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Piece,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pezzo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pied(a)">A Pied Horse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pie,</etym> party colour'd: Or, which 
is not unlikely, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Pi&shy;
catus,</etym> pied: that is, of divers 
colours, like to a Mag-Py.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pierce(v)">To Pierce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Per&shy;
cer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Perciare,</etym> id. 
Minsh. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to go through: Skin&shy;
ner, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Per,</etym> 
through, and <etym lang="la">Ico,</etym> to strike.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pig(n)">Pig,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bigge,</etym> the 
same; this perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Piga</etym>, a little girl; and 
catachrestically, a Pig.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pigeon(n)">A Pigeon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
geon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pigione,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pike(n)">A Pike,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Piqu&eacute;,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Picca,</etym> the same: 
Hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Piquer</etym>, to 
prick, or pierce.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piked(a)">Piked,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">Pike;</etym> that 
is, having a sharp point, or 
top; like that of a pike; or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Piquer,</etym> to 
prick, as all sharp things do; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Peac</etym>, a peak, 
or the sharp top of an hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilch(n)">A Pilch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pylche</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="S8r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilchard(n)">Pilchard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish so called, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pylche</etym>, a pilch, and 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> nature; to 
wit, from its smoothness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pile(n)">Pile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Piile,</etym> a 
sharp pale, or stake, driven 
into the earth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pile(n)" lexeme="cross and pile(n)">Pile, Cross and Pile,</form> <xpln lang="en">the back&shy;
side of a piece of money; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pile,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Pila,</etym> the same: Hence, 
<etym lang="fr">Je n'ay Croix ny Pile</etym>, I have 
neither cross nor pile; that 
is, I have no money at all.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pile(n)">Pile,</form> <xpln lang="en">for an heap, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Pile,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pila,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Piile,</etym> an heap; all per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pyra,</etym> or 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&upsilon;&rho;&#x1F70;</etym>, a funeral pile, 
or heap of wood to burn the 
dead with; a custom amongst 
Heathens.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilfer(v)">Pilfer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pilare,</etym> to 
steal: Or from our word <etym lang="en">Pill,</etym> 
and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fero,</etym> to carry. 
V. Pill, and Pillage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilgrim(n)">Pilgrim,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pelgrim,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bilgram, Bilgerin,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pelegrino,</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peregrin,</etym> the same; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Peregri&shy;
nus,</etym> a traveller, to wit, for 
the sake of Religion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pill(n)">A Pill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pille;</etym> 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pilula,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pill(v)">To Pill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pellen, 
Polen,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peler,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Pelare, Spelare,</etym> to pill 
off the bark, or skin; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pellis,</etym> a skin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pill(v)" lexeme="pillage(v)">To Pill, or Pillage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Piller, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, to plun&shy;
der: Or from the Obsolete &shy;
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pilare,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Expilare,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pillar(n)">Pillar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pillier,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Piliere,</etym> the same; 
all from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pile,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Pila,</etym> a pile, or heap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="peeled(a)" lexeme="pilgarlic(n)">Pill'd, or Peel'd Garlick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
our word, To <etym lang="en">Pill,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Peel;</etym> 
or &agrave; <etym lang="la">Pilis,</etym> from wool, or hair; 
for it is spoken properly of a 
Sheep, whose wool peeleth 
off; metaphorically, of a Man 
whose hair sheds by reason of 
some disease, especially the Ve&shy;
nereal disease.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pillion(n)">A Pillion,</form> <xpln lang="en">or seat for Women to 
ride upon; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Peluwe, Poluwe,</etym> a pillow, be&shy;
cause it is soft as a pillow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pillory(n)">Pillory,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&upsilon;&lambda;&eta;</etym>, a 
gate, and <etym lang="gk">&#x1F49;&rho;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to see; for 
here the Criminal looketh, as 
it were, out at the wicket of 
a door. Spelm. draws it from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pilleur,</etym> a Robber, 
Extortioner, or Pillager. It 
may likewise be drawn from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pile,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pila,</etym> a sort of pillar; because 
the place where Criminals 
were punished was heretofore 
encompassed with pillars.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pillow(n)">Pillow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pile</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peluwe, Poluwe,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pulvinus,</etym> a 
pillow, or bolster.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilot(n)">A Pilot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pilot,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pilota,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pi&shy;
loto,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Piloot,</etym> the 
Guider of a ship. Kilian 
draws it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pey&shy;
len, Piilen,</etym> to found, or to try 
</page> 

<page sig="S8v"> 
the depth of water; and <etym lang="bl">Loot,</etym> 
lead. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilot fish(n)">Pilot-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <etym lang="en">Pilot;</etym> so named, 
because it follows the ship's 
helm, where the Pilot sit&shy;
teth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pimp(n)">A Pimp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pinge,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pinco,</etym> a Man's 
yard; these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pe&shy;
nis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pimping(a)">A Pimping</form> <xpln lang="en">thing, or thing of 
no moment; in imitation of 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pimpel Meese,</etym> a 
Tit-mouse; also a little pim&shy;
ping fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pimple(n)" lexeme="pumple(n)">A Pimple, or Pumple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pompette,</etym> a blister; 
this perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&mu;&shy;
&phi;&#x1F79;&lambda;&upsilon;&xi;</etym>, a pimple.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pin(n)">Pin,</form> <xpln lang="en">as in Linspin, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Pyndan</etym>, to hinder; for it 
keeps the wheels from falling 
off the axle-tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pin(n)" lexeme="pinfold(n)">A Pin, or Pinfold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Pyndan</etym>, to shut in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pin(n)">A Pin</form> <xpln lang="en">to pin the cloths withal, 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pinna,</etym> the fin 
of a fish; or from <etym lang="la">Spina, Spi&shy;
nula,</etym> a thorn, &agrave; similitudine. 
Hence, he is on the merry Pin, 
from a way of drinking in a 
cup in which a pin was stuck, 
and he that could drink to the 
pin, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) neither under nor 
over it, was to have the wa&shy;
ger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pin(n)">A Pin</form> <xpln lang="en">of a musical instrument, 
from the Dan <etym lang="da">Pinde,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and both from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pyn&shy;
dan</etym>, to shut in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pin(n)" lexeme="pin and web(n)">The Pin,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Web in the eye, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pyndan</etym>, to inclose; 
or it incloseth and covereth 
the whole sight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pincer(n)">Pincers,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pinces, 
Pincettes,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pincet&shy;
te, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pincer,</etym> to pinch, to 
pluck out. V. Pinch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pinch(v)">To Pinch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pin&shy;
cer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, to squeese hard: 
Or perhaps from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&phi;&#x1F77;&gamma;&gamma;&omega;</etym>, to bind fast.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pin-dust(n)">Pin-dust,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Pin,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Dust;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pine(v)">To Pine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pinian</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pilnen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Peinen,</etym> to punish, or tor&shy;
ment; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Poena affi&shy;
cere,</etym> to put one to punish&shy;
ment: Or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&epsilon;&iota;&shy;
&nu;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to be an hungry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pink(n)">Pink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pinck,</etym> a 
little eye; whence <etym lang="bl">Pinckoo&shy;
gen</etym>, to pink with the eyes, 
and <etym lang="bl">Pingken</etym>, 
to sparkle, or shine a little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pink(n)">Pinks,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pin&shy;
ces,</etym> a sort of wild Gilly&shy;
flower: Or from the Belg. &shy;
<etym lang="bl">Pincke,</etym> an eye; or <etym lang="bl">Pincken,</etym> &shy;
to shine, to look bright.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pinnace(n)">A Pinnace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
nasse,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pinazza,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, a kind of light ship; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pinus,</etym> a 
Pine-tree; which formerly 
was the only timber to make 
ships of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pinnacle(n)">Pinnacle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
nacle;</etym> and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pinna,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pinnion(n)">Pinnion, or Pinion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the <emend err="from the"></emend> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pignon;</etym> this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pinna,</etym> the pi&shy;
nion of a wing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pint(n)">Pint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pynt</etym>, or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pinte;</etym> with us, a 
pound weight of things li&shy;
quid. Minsh. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to drink.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pintle(n)">A Pintel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small iron pin; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a <etym lang="en">Pointel,</etym> or little <etym lang="en">Point.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pintle(n)">Pintle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pint,</etym> id. or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Punt,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pointe,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Puncto,</etym> a point; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
A Man's <etym lang="en">Pointel.</etym> It is also 
drawn from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pinco,</etym> 
and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pinge,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Penis,</etym> 
the same; Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pioneer(n)">A Pioneer</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pion&shy;
nier,</etym> a Digger; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Pion,</etym> a Foot man. Some de&shy;
rive it <etym lang="la">&agrave; P&oelig;onibus,</etym> from the 
<etym lang="la">P&oelig;ones,</etym> a people of Asia, that &shy;
were wont to dig and under&shy;
mine the earth, either to live 
there, or to search for Gold, 
or other metals.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pip(n)">Pip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pippe,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pepie,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pipa,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pippis,</etym> a disease 
among Hens and other fowls; 
all, not unlikely, Depravations 
of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pituita,</etym> flegm; 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pipe(n)">Pipe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pipe</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Piibe,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfeiffe,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Piipe.</etym> Hence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pipere</etym>, a Piper.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pipe(n)">A Pipe,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a wine-vessel, from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pipa,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pippe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or perhaps it is 
so called, because it is hollow 
and long like a pipe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pippin(n)">Pippin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pup&shy;
pingh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or, not unlike&shy;
ly, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pepin,</etym> the 
seed of fruit; perhaps because 
it yieldeth more seed than 
other apples.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pismire(n)">Pismire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Puyde,</etym> 
an heap, and <etym lang="bl">Miere,</etym> or the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Myre,</etym> an Ant; for they 
cast up heaps of dirt where&shy;
soever they lodge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="piss(v)">To Piss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pisser,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pisciare,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Pisser,</etym> id. Hence the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Pisz</etym>, piss, or urine: All most 
 probably from the noise a 
 Man makes in pissing; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
 <etym lang="en">Hissing.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pistachio(n)">Pistachoes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pi&shy;
stacho,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pistachio,</etym> 
a nut so called, from Psitta&shy;
ca, a city in Tygris, according 
to Stephanus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pistol(n)">A Pistol,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
stole, Pistolet,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pi&shy;
stola,</etym> a little gun for Horse&shy;
men; and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Fistula,</etym> a pipe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pistole(n)">A Pistole,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
stole,</etym> a certain coin in Italy, 
Spain and France; so called, 
because it was first comed in 
<etym lang="it">Pistoia,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Pistoria,</etym> a city of 
Hetruria.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pit(n)">Pit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pit</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Putte,</etym> or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Pyt,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Puteus,</etym> a 
well.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pitch(n)">Pitch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Picts,</etym> the 
pitch or stature of the body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pitch(n)">Pitch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pic, Pix,</etym> 
(<etym lang="nn">Pick</etym>, as they say in the 
North) the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poix,</etym> the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Pece,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peck,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pech,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all a&shy;
gain from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pix,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pitch(v)">To Pitch</form> <xpln lang="en">upon ones head in fal&shy;
ling, perhaps from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Peser,</etym> to weigh; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to fall 
on the head with the whole 
weight of the body. It al&shy;
ludes to the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&iota;&tau;&nu;&#x1F73;&omega;, &Pi;&#x1F77;&tau;&shy;
&nu;&eta;&mu;&iota;</etym>, to fall: Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pitchfork(n)">Pitch-fork,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word, To 
<etym lang="en">Pitch,</etym> or fasten, and <etym lang="en">Fork;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pith(n)">Pith,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pit, Pitte,</etym> 
marrow, or sap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pittance(n)">A Pittance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
tance,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pitanca,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pietanza,</etym> a little por&shy;
tion of meat; these from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pietas,</etym> piety; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
portion given one out of pity, 
or piety: Or from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&iota;&tau;&tau;&#x1F71;&kappa;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a table; because 
the names of the Monkish Bre&shy;
thren (to whom this dole was 
given) were written down in 
a table together, with each 
Man's allowance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pity(n)">Pity,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pitie,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Piet&agrave;,</etym> mercy; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pietas,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
The Scots write Pietie, where 
we write Pity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pizzle(n)">Pizzle,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pese,</etym> a nerve; in which sense 
the Italians call it, Il Nerbo.
Minshew supposeth that it is 
so named from the sound of 
pissing; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Pisse. Rogers 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pessu&shy;
lus,</etym> a little bolt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="place(n)">Place,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Place;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pla&shy;
tea,</etym> a street; which comes 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&alpha;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&alpha;</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
&#x1F49;&delta;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;, a broad way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="placket(n)">A Placket,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plagghe,</etym> a piece cut out 
of a garment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plague(n)">Plague,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plaghe,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Plage,</etym> the Plague; 
whence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plaghen</etym>, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Plagen</etym>, to plague, 
or torment; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Plaga,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&eta;&gamma;&#x1F74;</etym>, a 
blow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plaice(n)">A Plaice, or Plaise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Floc</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plate,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&alpha;&shy;
&tau;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, broad.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plaint(n)">Plaint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plainte,</etym> 
a complaint; this from <etym lang="fr">Plain&shy;
dre,</etym> to complain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plaintiff(n)">Plaintiff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plain&shy;
tif,</etym> an Impeacher; this from 
the Verb <etym lang="fr">Plaindre,</etym> to com&shy;
plain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plaster(n)">Plaister,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plae&shy;
ster,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pflaster,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Emplastre,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Empiastro,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&mu;&pi;&lambda;&alpha;&sigma;&tau;&rho;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plait(v)">To Plait,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ples&shy;
ser,</etym> to knit, or intangle; or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plier,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Ployen,</etym> the Lat. <etym lang="la">Plicare,</etym> or 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F73;&kappa;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to twist, or 
interfold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plane(n)">A Plane,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Plana,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="T2r"> 
an instrument to make wood 
plain withal; both
