<etym lang="la">&agrave; Compla&shy;
nando,</etym> from making plain. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plank(n)">Plank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plancke,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Planche,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Palanca,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Menagius 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Planus,</etym> 
plain, or even.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plantain(n)">Plantain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plan&shy;
taine;</etym> and both Contracts of 
the Abl. <etym lang="fr">Plantagine,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plash(n)">A Plash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plasch,</etym> a 
ditch wherein water standeth; 
whence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plaschen</etym>, to 
plash the water, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Plaiz</etym>, the plashing of water, 
falling downward upon the 
stones.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plash(v)">To Plash</form> <xpln lang="en">tender branches of 
trees, to plait them, or twist 
them up together; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plesser,</etym> id. this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Plectere,</etym> to bend, or 
pleat, as hair.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plat(n)" lexeme="plot(n)">The Plat, or Plot of an House,</form> <xpln lang="en">
either from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plat,</etym> 
plain, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a plain foundation 
of an house; or the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F71;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to form, or frame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plate(n)">Plate of metal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Plate,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Plata,</etym> id. 
all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&alpha;&tau;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
broad, or <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F71;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to form.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="platform(n)">A Platform,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Archite&shy;
cture; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plate&shy;
forme, Platteforme,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Piatta forma,</etym> a plain 
form, or draught of the work.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="platter(n)">A Platter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plat,</etym> 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Plato,</etym> or the 
Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Platte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&alpha;&tau;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, broad, or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Patina,</etym> a platter, by an 
Epenthesis <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&omicron;&#x1FE6;</etym> l.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="play(v)">Play,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Plaegan</etym>, 
to play; whence <etym lang="oe">Pleg</etym>, a Play, 
and <etym lang="oe">Pleghus</etym>, a Play-house. 
Minsh. draws it from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Placere,</etym> to please: Spelman, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pleoh</etym>, hazard; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to run hazards at play.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plead(v)">To Plead,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Plea, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plaid,</etym> a Suit at Law, 
Cause, or Action; whence 
<etym lang="fr">Plaider</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Piadire</etym>, 
to plead a Cause.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pleasant(a)">Pleasant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plai&shy;
sant,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Placens,</etym> that 
which pleaseth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="please(v)">Please,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plaire,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Placere</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pleasure(n)">Pleasure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plaisir;</etym> both from <etym lang="fr">Plaire,</etym> to please.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pledge(n)">Pledge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plege, 
Pleige,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; also a Surety: 
Whence P<etym lang="fr">leger, Pleiger</etym>, to 
pledge, to give Bail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pledge(v)">To Pledge</form> <xpln lang="en">in drinking; some 
will have it come of the other 
<etym lang="en">Pledge,</etym> because, in the time 
of the Danes, one of the com&shy;
pany gave himself a Pledge, 
that he that drank, should not 
be slain whilst he was drink&shy;
ing; but rather from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pleghen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Plle&shy;
gen,</etym> to take care of; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  I 
will take care to drink the 
next.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plenty(n)">Plenty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plent&egrave;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Plenitudo,</etym> 
fulness.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pleurisy(n)">A Pleurisie,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pleuresie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pleure&shy;
sia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pleuritis,</etym> the same; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
pain, or inflammation in the 
side, caused by stoppage of 
blood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pliant(a)">Pliant,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Pliable, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plier,</etym> to bend, to be 
flexible; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Plicare,</etym> to fold; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Plicatilis,</etym> that which will 
fold up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plight(n)">Plight,</form> <xpln lang="en">as To Plight Faith; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plechten,</etym> to 
promise frankly and sincerely.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plod(v)">To Plod,</form> <xpln lang="en">or labour earnestly in 
a matter; perhaps from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ploeghen,</etym> to plow; or 
from our word <etym lang="en">Plot;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plump(v)">To Plomp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Plom&shy;
pen,</etym> to plomp, as a stone cast 
into water; or rather, from 
the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plot(n)">Plot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">Complot:</etym> 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F71;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to form; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to contrive, or design some&shy;
thing to come.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plover(n)">A Plover,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plu&shy;
vier</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: It is a bird so 
called, perhaps, <etym lang="la">qu&ograve;d Pluvia 
gaudet,</etym> because it loves the 
rain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plough(n)">A Plough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ploegh,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pflug</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence <etym lang="bl">Ploeghen</etym>, and <etym lang="tt">Pflu&shy;
gen</etym>, to plow; all from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Pluccian</etym>, to pluck; for 
the Oxen pluck the plough 
through the ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pluck(v)">To Pluck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Pluccian</etym>, 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Plucken,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Peluccare</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pluck(n)">Pluck,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Sheep's Pluck, &#x1F08;&pi;&#x1F78; &tau;&#x1F78; 
&zeta;&omega;&tau;&iota;&kappa;&#x1FC6;&#x03c2; <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&lambda;&omicron;&gamma;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, from the vital 
heat residing therein.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plug(n)">A Plug,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Splug, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plugghe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plum(n)">A Plum,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Plum</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pflaume,</etym> or the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Blumme,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Prunum,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plumb(adv)">Plum,</form> <xpln lang="en">He fell down Plum, that 
is, perpendicularly, like a 
<etym lang="en">Plummer.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plumber(n)">A Plummer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Plombier,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Plum&shy;
barius;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he that solders 
or cements, cum <etym lang="la">Plumbo</etym>, with 
Lead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plummet(n)">A Plummet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Plombeau,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
<etym lang="la">Plumbum,</etym> Lead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plunder(v)">Plunder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Plun&shy;
deren,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Plundern,</etym> 
to lay waste, to pillage. It 
alludes also to our words <etym lang="en">Pull 
under.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plunge(v)">To Plunge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Plon&shy;
ger,</etym> to sink. Minsh. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&#x1F7B;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to 
wash.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plungeon(n)">A Plungeon, or Plongeon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the word, To <etym lang="en">Plunge;</etym> a bird 
that often plungeth it self in the 
water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="plush(n)">Plush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peluche,</etym> 
plush, or shag; or perhaps 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Peluzzo,</etym> a little 
hair; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pilus,</etym> 
an hair.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ply(v)">Ply,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pleghen,</etym> or 
</page> 

<page sig="T3r"> 
the Teut <etym lang="tt">Pflegen</etym> to be care&shy;
ful, to use diligence; or from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Pleyer,</etym> to accustom; 
as we say to Water-men, At 
what Stairs do you Ply? 
Henshaw draws it from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Faire Pleier;</etym> as we say, 
Ply your work. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poached egg(n)">Poch'd-Eggs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Oeufs Pochez</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
from <etym lang="fr">Pocher</etym>, to dig out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pock(n)" lexeme="pox(n)">Pock, Pox, and Pocks,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Poc-ald</etym>, 
or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pocken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pocket(n)">Pocket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pochcha</etym>, 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pochette,</etym> a poc&shy;
ket, or purse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poesy(n)">Poesie</form> <xpln lang="en">and Poetry, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poesie, Poetrie,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Poesia;</etym> all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Poesis,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&#x1F77;&eta;&sigma;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="point(n)">Point,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poinct, Point&eacute;,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Punto,</etym> id. all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pungere,</etym> to prick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="point-blank(adv)">Point-blank,</form> <xpln lang="en">straight to the 
mark; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sur ou vers le Point blanc</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
in aiming at a white, point, or 
mark.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poise(n)">Poise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pois, Poids,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from <etym lang="fr">Poiser,</etym> to 
poise, or weigh; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pensare,</etym> to weigh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poison(n)">Poison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poison;</etym> 
whence <etym lang="fr">Poisonner</etym>, or <etym lang="fr">Empoi&shy;
sonner</etym>, to poison; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Potio,</etym> a potion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poke(v)">To Poke</form> <xpln lang="en">with the finger, or a 
stick; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pocher,</etym> 
to dig into; this a Contract 
of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fodicare,</etym> to dig, 
or bore.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pole(n)">Pole,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pole</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pols,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pole-axe(n)">Poleax,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a pole fortified 
with an ax; or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a <etym lang="en">Polo&shy;
nish</etym> ax, because the Polandors 
use it much: Or from our 
word <etym lang="en">Poll,</etym> for an head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="polecat(n)">Pole-cat,</form> <xpln lang="en">that is, a <etym lang="en">Polonish</etym> Cat; 
because Poland abounds with 
them.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="policy(n)">Policy,</form> <xpln lang="en">craft, especially in civil 
affairs; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&lambda;&iota;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the Eng. Poli&shy;
tick, crafty, or cunning.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poll(n)">Poll,</form> <xpln lang="en">for an Head; from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Polle, Poll,</etym> an head, or 
top, hence Poll-money, a tax 
to be levied poll by poll, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
upon every body; and hence 
also, A Poll of Ling, for a 
jowl of Ling. Poll is also ta&shy;
ken from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1F79;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pollard(n)">Pollard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish so called, from 
the greatness of its <etym lang="en">poll</etym>, or 
head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pomade(n)">Pomado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pom&shy;
ade,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pomada,</etym> 
an ointment made of apples.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pomander(n)">Pomander,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pomme d'Ambre;</etym> or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pomum Ambr&aelig;,</etym> an Ap&shy;
ple of Amber, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) smelling 
like Amber.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pomegranate(n)">Pomegranate</form> <xpln lang="en">, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Pomum Gra&shy;
natum</etym>, a kind of apple having 
many grains, or much seed: 
Or from <etym lang="sp">Granata,</etym> the place 
where they most grow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pommel(n)">A Pommel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pommelle,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pomel&shy;
la,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; so called, <etym lang="it">&agrave; similitudine 
</page> 

<page sig="T3v"> 
Pomi,</etym> from the simi&shy;
litude of a little apple. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pompion(n)">Pompion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pom&shy;
pon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Popone,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pond(n)">Pond,</form> <xpln lang="en">q.<etym lang="en"> Bond;</etym> because there 
the water is bound, that it 
cannot pass; Minsh. Or from '
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pyndan</etym>, to inclose; 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poniard(n)">A Poniard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Poignard,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Pun&shy;
gendo,</etym> from pricking; or <etym lang="la">&agrave; 
Pugnis,</etym> from the fists; or <etym lang="la">&agrave; 
Pugnando,</etym> from fighting: 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pool(n)">Pool,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Pul</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Poel,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfuhl,</etym> id. 
Minsh. and Fr. Jun. draw it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&eta;&lambda;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, clay or 
mud.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poop(n)">Poop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pouppe,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Popa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Puppis,</etym> a ship.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poop(v)">To Poop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Poepen,</etym> 
to fart softly; both from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poor(a)">Poor,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Povre,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Povero,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pauper</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pop(v)">To Pop</form> <xpln lang="en">with the mouth, from 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Poppysmus,</etym> 
a smacking with the mouth; 
all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pope(n)">Pope,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pape,</etym> or 
the Ital. and Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Papa,</etym> 
the Pope, or Bishop of Rome; 
though, in the time of Sidon. 
Apollinar. it was the title of 
any Bishops or Pontiffs what&shy;
soever.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poplar(n)">A Poplar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Peu&shy;
plier,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Populus,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poppinjay(n)">Poppinjay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. Teut. 
and Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Papejay,</etym> or the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Papejoy,</etym> id <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Pope's 
delight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poppy(n)">Poppy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Popig</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porch(n)">Porch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Porche;</etym> '
and both Contracts of the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Porticus</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porcupine(n)">Porcupine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Porc 
Espi,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Porco Spino,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Porcus Spi&shy;
natus,</etym> a thorny Hog; to wit, 
&agrave; <etym lang="la">Spinis,</etym> from its prickles, and 
the likeness of an Hog.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pore(v)">To Pore, or look near letters;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1FF6;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, pur-blind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="porpoise(n)">A Porpus, or Porpis;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Por&shy;
cus Piscis,</etym> an Hog-fish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="port(n)">Port,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Ottoman Port, or 
Court; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Porta,</etym> a 
gate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="portage(n)">Portage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Por&shy;
tage,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Portaggio,</etym> a 
Porter's fee; this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Portare,</etym> to carry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="portal(n)">Portal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Portail,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Portella,</etym> a little 
port; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Por&shy;
ta,</etym> a gate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="posset(n)">Posset:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Potus,</etym> drink; but ra&shy;
ther from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poser,</etym> to 
settle; for when the milk is 
curded, the thick part cometh 
together at the top.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="post(n)">A Post,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poste,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Posta,</etym> a Letter-car&shy;
rier.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="postern(n)">Postern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Po&shy;
sterne,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Posterla,</etym> a 
</page> 

<page sig="T4r"> 
back-door, or gate; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Post,</etym> behind. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="postilion(n)">A Postilion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Po&shy;
stillon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Postiglione,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="postil(n)">A Postill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Po&shy;
stille,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Postilla,</etym> id. 
Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Post illa,</etym> after 
these words, that is, after the 
Text.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="posture(n)">Posture,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Posture</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Positura,</etym> a position 
of the body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="posy(n)">Posy,</form> <xpln lang="en">for A Nosegay; I suppose, 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; Ponendo,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Componendo,</etym> 
from composing, or making 
up: Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">But&shy;
zen,</etym> to cleanse or perfume the 
nostrils.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pot(n)">Pot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pot,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Potto,</etym> a pot, or cup; this 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; Potu,</etym> from drink; or the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&tau;&#x1F75;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a cup.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="potato(n)">Potatoes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pota&shy;
dos,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Potades,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Potates,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="potentate(n)">A Potentate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Potentat,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Potentato,</etym> 
or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Potentatus,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pottage(n)">Pottage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Potage,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Potaggio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="potter(n)">A Potter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Po&shy;
tier,</etym> a Maker of earthen ves&shy;
sels. v. Pot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pouch(n)">Pouch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pocca</etym>, or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poche,</etym> a pocket, or 
pouch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="powder(n)">Pouder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poudre, 
Pouldre;</etym> both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pulvere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="poulterer(n)">Poulterer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pou&shy;
letier;</etym> this from <etym lang="fr">Poulette,</etym> 
with us, a Pullet; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pullus,</etym> a chicken.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pounce(v)">To Pounce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ponzo&shy;
nare,</etym> to pounce paper, Skin&shy;
ner. Minshew draws it from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Pon&ccedil;ar,</etym> to break in 
pieces.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pound(v)">To Pound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Punyan</etym>, 
to bray.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pound(n)">A Pound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pund</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pond,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Pfund,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pondo,</etym> a pound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pound(n)">A Pound</form> <xpln lang="en">to put Horses in, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pfand,</etym> a pawn, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to keep an Horse in pawn, till 
compensation be made for the 
damage he hath done: Or 
rather, from the AS, <etym lang="oe">Pyn&shy;
dan</etym>, to shut in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="power(n)">Power,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pou&shy;
voir,</etym> the Infinitive of <etym lang="fr">Puis,</etym> I 
am able; to wit, taken nomi&shy;
nally in imitation of the 
Greeks; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Possum,</etym> I am able.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="eel-pout(n)">Powt, Eel-Powt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Aelepute</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Puddy,</etym> a Lamprey.
v. Burvot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="practice(v)">To Practise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pra&shy;
tiquer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pratticare,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&rho;&#x1FB6;&shy;
&xi;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, a practice; this from 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&rho;&#x1F71;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to do.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="praise(n)">Praise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Priis,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Preisz,</etym> id. whence 
<etym lang="bl">Priisen</etym>, and <etym lang="tt">Preisen</etym>, to 
praise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prank(n)">Prank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pronck,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="T4v"> 
ostentation; whence <etym lang="bl">Pronc&shy;
ken</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Prangen</etym>, 
to glory in ones self. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prate(v)">Prate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Praten,</etym> 
to wrangle. Minsh. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&rho;&#x1F71;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to speak: 
Mer. Cas. from <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&rho;&#x1F71;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to 
do, or speak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prance(v)">Praunce,</form> <xpln lang="en">as a stout Horse. V. 
<etym lang="en">Prank.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pray(v)">To Pray,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prier,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pregare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Precani,</etym> to 
pray.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preach(v)">To Preach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pre&shy;
sher,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="fr">Pres&shy;
cheur</etym>, a Preacher, and <etym lang="bl">Pres&shy;
ch&egrave;</etym>, a Sermon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="preamble(n)">Preamble,</form> <xpln lang="en">a prologue, or pre&shy;
face; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pream&shy;
bule,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Preambulo,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prebend(n)">A Prebend,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pre&shy;
bende,</etym> or the Ital. and Lat. 
Barb. <etym lang="la">Prebenda,</etym> id. all from 
<etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;beo,</etym> to allow, or afford; 
for it formerly signified, a cer&shy;
tain measure, or pittance, of 
meat, or other necessaries, 
which were allowed to Cano&shy;
nical Persons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="predecessor(n)">Predecessor,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pre&shy;
decesseur,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one 
that <etym lang="la">Pri&ugrave;s decessit &egrave; vita</etym>, has 
departed this life before us.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="premise(v)">To Premise, and Premises</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Praemittere,</etym> to set 
before, or <etym lang="la">Praemissum,</etym> a thing 
set before, or above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prentice(n)">Prentice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
prentis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="fr">Ap&shy;
prendre,</etym> to learn; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Apprehendere,</etym> to ap&shy;
prehend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="presto, be gone(ex)">Presto be gone,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Leger&shy;
demain; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pre&shy;
sto,</etym> quickly; q. d. be gone 
presently.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pretty(a)">Pretty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pr&aelig;te</etym>, or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pretto,</etym> neat, hand&shy;
som: Or, as Minshew has it, 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Practigh,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Prachtich,</etym> proud. 
Hensh. draws it from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Petit,</etym> little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prevail(v)">To Prevail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pre&shy;
valoir;</etym> both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;valere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prey(n)">Prey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Proye,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;da,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="price(n)">Price,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pris,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Prezzo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pretium,</etym> a 
price.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prick(n)">Prick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pricca</etym>, 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Pricke;</etym> hence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Priccan</etym>, to prick, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Prekel</etym>, a prickle, and 
<etym lang="bl">Prekelen</etym>, to prickle: All 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Per,</etym> 
through, and <etym lang="la">Ico,</etym> to strike.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prick(v)">To Prick</form> <xpln lang="en">up ones self, to go 
fine; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Priic&shy;
ken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both possibly 
from the Teut. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pracht,</etym> pride.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pricket(n)">Pricket,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Stag of the second 
year; so called, because his 
horns are then straight like a 
prick or spit, without knags.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="priest(n)">A Priest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Preost</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Priester,</etym> the Fr. G.
</page> 

<page sig="T5r"> 
<etym lang="fr">Prestre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Prete,</etym> the 
same; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pres&shy;
byter,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&rho;&epsilon;&sigma;&beta;&#x1F7B;&tau;&epsilon;&shy;
&rho;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, an Elder of the Church, 
or a Senior. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prime(v)">To Prime a Gun,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to put in 
<etym lang="la">Primum pulverem,</etym> the pow&shy;
der that first takes fire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primer(n)">A Primmer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Primier,</etym> the first; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Primus,</etym> the first Book that 
Children are to learn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="primrose(n)">Primrose,</form> <xpln lang="en">that is, <etym lang="la">Prima Rosa,</etym> 
the first Rose, the first flower 
at the coming in of the Spring.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prince(n)">A Prince,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Prince,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Prenze,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Prin&shy;
ceps,</etym> a Prince. Hence the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Princesse</etym>, and the Ital. 
<etym lang="fr">Principessa</etym>, a Princess.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="princock(n)">A Princock:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;cox,</etym> early 
ripe; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a young Man of a 
forward wit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="print(n)">Print,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Printe,</etym> a 
print, or impression; whence 
Printer, to print; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Premere,</etym> to press.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prize(v)">To Prise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Prii&shy;
sen,</etym> to value, or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Priser,</etym> to set a price on.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prize(n)">A Prise,</form> <xpln lang="en">Who wun the Prise? 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prise, Prinse,</etym> 
a taking, or seizing; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Prendre,</etym> to take, or seize.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prison(n)">A Prison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pri&shy;
son,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Prigione,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Priso&shy;
na,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="privy(n)">A Privy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prive</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Locus Pri&shy;
vatus,</etym> a private place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prove(n)">Prove, or Tryer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chirurgeon's instrument, <etym lang="la">quo vulnus pro&shy;
batur,</etym> wherewith the depth of 
a wound is proved, or tried.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Tryer" not found in OED in this sense.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="process(n)">A Process,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pro&shy;
ces,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Processo,</etym> id. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Processus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proctor(n)">Proctor</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Civil Law, a 
Contract of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Procura&shy;
tor,</etym> a Proctor, or Attourney.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="profit(n)">Profit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Profit,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Profitto,</etym> id. gain; 
whence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Profiter</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Profittare</etym>, to profit, to gain; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Proficere,</etym> to profit, or 
prevail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="promoter(n)">A Promoter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Promoteur,</etym> he that promo&shy;
teth, causeth, or brings things 
on.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prompt(v)">To Prompt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pron&shy;
tare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Prom&shy;
ptum facere,</etym> to make one rea&shy;
dy in repeating, or doing any 
thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prong(n)">A Prong,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Prang&shy;
hen,</etym> to press, or pinch; for 
with it we press Hay, squeez&shy;
ing it into less room.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prove(v)">Proove,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prou&shy;
ver,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Provare,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Probare</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Preuve</etym>, and the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Pruova</etym>, a proof, or trial. 
Write Prove.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prop(n)">Prop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Proppe,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Propff,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
hence <etym lang="bl">Proppen</etym>, and <etym lang="tt">Prop&shy;
ffen</etym>, to prop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proper(a)">Proper,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Tall; possibly a cor&shy;
ruption of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Procerus,</etym> 
tall.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proud(a)">Proud,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Prut</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence <etym lang="oe">Pryde</etym>, pride, 
swelling; and <etym lang="oe">Prutian</etym>, to 
grow proud.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="provender(n)">Provender,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Pro&shy;
vande,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Provende,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pourvoir,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Provedere,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Providere,</etym> to pro&shy;
vide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="provost(n)">Provost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pra&shy;
fast</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Provosz,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prevost,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Provosto,</etym> the same; all Con&shy;
tracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;positus,</etym> 
one set before, or over others.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="provost marshal(n)">Provost Marshal,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. d. <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;posi&shy;
<emend err="si"></emend>tus Marescalli,</etym> Judge of the 
Marshalsea; or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;positus Martialis,</etym> an Examiner 
of crimes committed against 
the Martial Law.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prow(n)">The Prow of a ship,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pro&uuml;e;</etym> this from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="la">Prora</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prowess(n)">Prowess,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Proii&shy;
esse,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Prodezza,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="proxy(n)">Proxy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Deputy; he that pleads, 
or does business in the name 
of another; a Contract of the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Procuratie,</etym> a Proctor&shy;
ship, the office of a Proctor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pry into(v)">To Pry into,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Preuver,</etym> to try, or prove.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="publish(v)">Publish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Publier,</etym> 
or the Ital. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Publicare,</etym> 
to make publick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pucker(v)">To Pucker</form> <xpln lang="en">in sowing a seam, 
perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&#x1FE6;&kappa;&alpha;</etym>, 
closely; or <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&upsilon;&kappa;&nu;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, thick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="powder(n)">Pudder,</form> <xpln lang="en">To make a Pudder, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
To make a <etym lang="en">Powder,</etym> or Dust, 
as an Horse that runs at full 
speed: Or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Polderen,</etym> to raise a tumult, 
beat, make a noise, or knock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pudding(n)">Pudding,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bou&shy;
din,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the 
Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Botulus,</etym> a blood-&shy;
pudding; by changing B in&shy;
to P.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="puddle(n)">Puddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word <etym lang="en">Pool,</etym> 
by inserting d by an Epenthe&shy;
sis; or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Puteo&shy;
lus,</etym> a little well, by contra&shy;
ction.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="puff(n)">Puff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Poff,</etym> a 
cheek; whence <etym lang="bl">Poffen</etym>, to puff, to blow: All not un&shy;
likely from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="earth-puff(n)" lexeme="puff(n)">Puffs, or Earth Puffs,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
puffings, or tumours of earth, 
which the Italians call Tar&shy;
tuffi, and make of them a de&shy;
licate dish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pug(ex)">Pug,</form> <xpln lang="en">a soothing word; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Piga</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Pige,</etym> 
a little Girl. Hensh. draws it 
from <etym lang="en">Pug,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Bug,</etym> a Devil; 
as we say in a coaxing way, 
My little Devil; and the 
French, <etym lang="fr">Mon petit Diable</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="puissant(a)">Puissant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">P&uuml;is&shy;
sant,</etym> a Part. of the Verb, <etym lang="fr">Puis,</etym> 
I am able; hence the Eng. 
and Fr. G. Puissance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pule(v)">To Pule,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Piuler,</etym> 
to cheap as young Chickens; 
and both from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pull(v)">Pull,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Pullan</etym>, or 
the Belg <etym lang="bl">Pellen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pullet(n)">Pullet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poulet,</etym> &shy;
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pouletta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pullus,</etym> a 
Chicken; by adding the Ter&shy;
mination <etym lang="la">et,</etym> which diminish&shy;
eth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pulley(n)">A Pulley</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word, To 
<etym lang="en">Pull,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poulie,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Poliga,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pump(n)">Pump,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Pompe,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Pompa,</etym> the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Bombu,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Pumpe</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pump(n)">Pumps,</form> <xpln lang="en">shooes having but one 
sole; perhaps such as were u&shy;
sed <etym lang="la">Pompaticis ludis,</etym> in pom&shy;
pous shews, which we call 
Balls, and Masks; or from 
the sound they make, when 
leap'd in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="punch(n)">Punch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ponzona&shy;
re,</etym> to bore, or strike in holes; 
hence Ponzone, a punchion, 
or piercer; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pungere,</etym> to prick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="punctilio(n)">A Punctilio,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Puntillo,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poin&shy;
tille;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Punctillum,</etym> 
a little point.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="punk(n)">Punk,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a Bawd, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Pung</etym>, a drawing purse, or 
satchel; in the same sence al&shy;
most, that an old Whore is 
called in Lat. <term lang="la">Scortum</term>, which 
primarily signifies, the hide of 
a beast; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an old Bawd, as 
dry and wrinkled, with strad&shy;
ling over the fire, as an Horses 
hide, dried in the Sun, which, 
being continued there, draws 
up like a purse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="puny(n)">Puny,</form> <xpln lang="en">a younger Brother; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Puis n&egrave;</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="la">Post 
natus,</etym> born afterward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="puppet(n)" lexeme="puppy(n)">Puppet, and Puppy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Puppe,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Poup&eacute;e,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; also a Puppy, 
or Whelp, by a Catachresis; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pupulus,</etym> a 
little boy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purl(v)">To Purl</form> <xpln lang="en">as a Spring of water, 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Bullire,</etym> 
to bubble; by adding r by 
Epenthesis.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purloin(v)">Purloin,</form> <xpln lang="en">to steal away, to deal 
treacherously; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Purloigner,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pro&shy;
longare,</etym> to prolong, to put 
off.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purple(n)">Purple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pour&shy;
pre,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Porpora,</etym> the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Purpura,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&omicron;&rho;&phi;&#x1F7B;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purpose(n)">Purpose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pro&shy;
pos;</etym> both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pro&shy;
positum</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purse(n)">Purse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bourse,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Borsa,</etym> id. All from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F7B;&rho;&tau;&alpha;</etym>, a skin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pursevant(a)" lexeme="pursuivant(a)">Pursevant, Pursuivant;</form> <xpln lang="en">by a 
little alteration of the sence, it 
may be drawn from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Poursuivant,</etym> pursuing, or fol&shy;
lowing after.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pursue(v)">To Pursue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pour&shy;
suivre,</etym> to follow after; from 
<etym lang="fr">Pour,</etym> for, and <etym lang="fr">Suivre,</etym> to fol&shy;
low; this from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Se&shy;
quire,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sequi,</etym> to follow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="purvey(v)">To Purvey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pour&shy;
veoir;</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Providere,</etym> 
to provide, to fore-see; hence 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pourvoyeur</etym>, a Pur&shy;
veyor.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="push(v)">To Push,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Poul&shy;
ser,</etym> to force forward, the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Bussare,</etym> to strike, or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pulsare,</etym> to knock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="push(n)">A Push,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contraction of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pustula,</etym> a pimple, or bli&shy;
ster; both from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&upsilon;&shy;
&sigma;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to blow up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="puss(n)">A Puss,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sluttish Wench; from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Puzzolente,</etym> stinking, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peesele,</etym> id. saith 
Minshew: Though Kilian 
draws <etym lang="bl">Poesele</etym>, from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pulsa,</etym> which he expounds, a 
fat Girl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="put(v)">To Put:</form> <xpln lang="en">Skinner draws it from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bouter,</etym> to force in: 
Minsh. from <etym lang="fr">Poser,</etym> to put: 
But most probably from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Botten,</etym> to push with the 
horn; or our word <etym lang="en">Butt,</etym> as, 
The Ram Butts; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Puts, 
or thrusts forward; the word 
being promiscuously used in 
some parts of England.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="puzzle(v)">To Puzzle,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  To Poile, from 
our word, To <etym lang="en">Pose</etym> with an 
hard question: Or from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pucello,</etym> a Maid; or 
<etym lang="fr">Puceller,</etym> to make a Maid of; 
that is, to make to blush; 
Maids being prone thereto.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pie(n)">Py,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pie,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Pica,</etym> a bird so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pie(n)">Py,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Py-crust: Skinner sup&shy;
poseth it to come from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bycgan</etym>, to build, or 
fashion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Piepowder Court(n)">Py-Powders, or Pie-powders 
Court,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Court in which chan&shy;
ces, or contingent Causes, are 
decided at Bartholomew-Fair, without the form of Law; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pied,</etym> a foot, 
and <etym lang="fr">Poudre,</etym> powder, or dust; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Court wherein Stran&shy;
gers Causes are heard, and de&shy;
cided out of hand, before ever 
the dust or clay is dried on 
their shooes.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="Q"><alpha>Q</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quack(v)">To Quack</form> <xpln lang="en">like a Duck, from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Quacken;</etym> 
and both from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quack(n)" lexeme="quacksalver(n)">A Quack, or Quacksalver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Quacksalver,</etym> a 
Mountebank, or upstart Phy&shy;
sician; this from the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Quack,</etym> frivolous, a 
vain tatler, and <etym lang="tt">Salb,</etym> the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sealf</etym>, or the Belg. and Eng. 
<etym lang="en">Salve.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quaff(v)">Quaff,</form> <xpln lang="en">to drink stoutly; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Go off;</etym> or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Caf</etym>, 
quick; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to tope it off ha&shy;
stily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quag(n)" lexeme="quagmire(n)">Quag, or Quagmire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our 
Eng. <etym lang="en">Quake,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Mire;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quail(v)">To Quail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="bl">Quelen,</etym> <etym lang="hd">Quelien,</etym> to 
vex, or afflict; or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cwellan</etym>, to slay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quaint(a)">Quaint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coint,</etym> 
neat; this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Com&shy;
ptus,</etym> spruce, or <etym lang="la">Cinctus,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
in readiness.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quake(v)">Quake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwacian</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, to tremble: Minshew 
draws it from <etym lang="la">Quatio,</etym> to shake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="qualm(n)" lexeme="swooning(n)">Qualm, or Swouning,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwealm</etym>, death; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Cwellan</etym>, to kill; for swoun&shy;
ing is but a shorter sort of 
death.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quandary(n)">Quandary,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dilemma, or am&shy;
biguity; from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Qu'n&shy;
diray je?</etym> What shall I say? 
I know not what to say or do.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarrel(n)">A Quarel</form> <xpln lang="en">of glass, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quareau</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Quadrula,</etym> a four-squar'd 
piece of glass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarrel(v)">Quarrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Que&shy;
relle, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence Querel&shy;
ler, to quarrel, or fall out; 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Querela,</etym> 
a complaint, or <etym lang="la">Queror,</etym> to com&shy;
plain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarry(n)">A Quarry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quar&shy;
riere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence Quarrier, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that digs in a Quar&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarry(a)">A Quarry,</form> <xpln lang="en">or fat Man, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">un homm&egrave; Quarr&egrave;,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a squary Man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quart(n)">A Quart,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Quarta pars,</etym> the 
fourth part of a gallon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarter(v)">To Quarter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Quar&shy;
tare,</etym> to cut, <etym lang="la">in Quatuor par&shy;
tes,</etym> into four parts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quartermaster(n)">Quartermaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Maistre de Quartiers,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Maestro di Quartiere,</etym> 
the Master of the Quarters; 
whose office it is, to appoint 
each Company of Men their 
Quarters, or Lodgings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quash(v)">To Quash,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Law; from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cassare,</etym> to make 
void.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quash(v)">Quash,</form> <xpln lang="en">to squeeze asunder; the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Casser,</etym> to break, or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scassiare,</etym> to squeeze 
together.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quarter costus(a)">Quarter Costus,</form> <xpln lang="en">as we say con&shy;
cerning those that bear a pri&shy;
vate grudge against each o&shy;
ther, They are not Cater, or 
<etym lang="la">Quater-Costus;</etym> that is, they 
are not of any of the four chief 
degrees of Kinship; for there 
are seven degrees of Kin&shy;
ship, the first four whereof 
are chief.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"Quarter Costus" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quaver(n)">Quaver,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Musick, q. <etym lang="en">Waver;</etym> 
or from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Quatere,</etym> to 
shake, saith Minshew, because 
the sound in playing is shook, 
or, as it were, made to waver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quean(n)">Quean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwean</etym>, or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Quinde,</etym> a Woman, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  common Woman; or from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Quene,</etym> a Whore, 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwean</etym>, a barren 
Cow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="queen(n)">Queen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwen, 
Cwena</etym>, or the old Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Quena,</etym> a Woman, Wife, or 
Consort; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Wife, or 
Consort, &Kappa;&alpha;&tau;' &#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;. Or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Roniginne,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Roenigin,</etym> a Queen: 
V. King. Fr. Jun. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&upsilon;&nu;&#x1F74;</etym>, a Woman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quell(v)">To Quell,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Subdue, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwellan</etym>, to kill, or the 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Quellan,</etym> to vex.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quench(v)">Quench,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwen&shy;
can</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quest(n)">Quest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Queste,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Chiesta,</etym> an inqui&shy;
sition; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Qu&aelig;situm,</etym> a 
thing sought.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quitch grass(n)" lexeme="couch grass(n)">Quich-grass, or Couch-grass,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwice</etym>, Dogs 
grass; perhaps because it re&shy;
fresheth Dogs, when faint: 
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Herbe 
Couchante,</etym> Grass couchant; 
because it coucheth &amp; spread&shy;
eth close by the earth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quicken(v)">Quicken,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwic&shy;
can</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Quicken,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwic</etym>, and the Belg. and Eng. Quick, 
or alive. Hence also the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cwic-fyre</etym>, quick-fire, or 
wild-fire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quicksand(n)">Quick-sands,</form> <xpln lang="en">sands so called, be&shy;
cause they tremble and move, 
as if they had life.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quicksilver(n)">Quick-silver,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, from its 
slippery and moveable nature, 
or vertue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quiddany(n)">Quiddany,</form> <xpln lang="en">a conserve made 
chiefly &agrave; <etym lang="la">Cydoniis,</etym> of Quin&shy;
ces.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quill(n)">A Quill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ruehl,</etym> 
a stalk; or from the old 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Rul,</etym> round.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quill(n)">A Quill</form> <xpln lang="en">of a Barrel, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guille,</etym> a spigot,</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quilt(n)">Quilt,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">Welt;</etym> it being stitch&shy;
ed, or sowed in, in the nature 
of the welt of a shooe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quince(n)">Quince,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coin</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both Contracts of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cydonium,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an apple 
brought from <etym lang="la">Cydon,</etym> a town 
in Crete.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quinsy(n)">Quinzy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Squi&shy;
nance,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Squinantia,</etym> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Esquinancia,</etym> the 
same; all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&nu;&chi;&omega;</etym>, 
to choke, or strangle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quip(v)">Quip,</form> <xpln lang="en">to bite one in words; 
from our word <etym lang="en">Whip;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to whip one with words. 
Minshew draws it from our 
word, To <etym lang="en">Quicken.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quire(n)">Quire,</form> <xpln lang="en">where Mass or Prayers 
are said or sung; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Choeur,</etym> the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cho&shy;
rus,</etym> or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&omicron;&rho;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
Write Choire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quire(n)">Quire</form> <xpln lang="en">of Paper, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Quayer</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quirk(n)">A Quirk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Circui&shy;
re,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Cir&shy;
cumvenire,</etym> to cir&shy;
cumvent with cavils, and ca&shy;
ptious speeches.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quit(v)">To Quit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quit&shy;
ter,</etym> to relinquish, remit, or 
absolve; hence our Eng. Ac&shy;
quittance, a writing whereby 
one is acquitted of a debt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quite(n)">Quite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quitte,</etym> 
quitted, or free; by a Meta&shy;
phor drawn from a Debtor, 
that has paid his debts, and is 
quite, or wholly quitted.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quote(v)">To Quote,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Quo&shy;
ter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cotare,</etym> to cite 
an Author in defence of ones 
Opinion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quoth(v)">Quoth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwe&eth;an</etym>, 
to say, or <etym lang="oe">Cy&eth;an</etym>, to relate: 
Or, as Minshew has it, from 
</page> 

<page sig="T8r"> 
the old Cimbr. <etym lang="cb">Quath,</etym> he 
said. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="quoin(n)">Quoyns, Printers Quoyns,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Coing,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cuneus,</etym> a wedge.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="R"><alpha>R</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rabbit(n)">RAbbet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rob&shy;
beken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew 
draws it very ingeniously from 
the Heb. <etym lang="he">Rabah,</etym> to procreate; 
for they multiply exceeding&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rabble(n)">Rabble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rabbe&shy;
len,</etym> to prate: Or from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Rabula,</etym> a brawler; for 
the vulgar sort are addicted to 
talk much.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="race(n)">A Race,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rannen,</etym> 
to run, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="bl">Rauce;</etym> by stri&shy;
king out n, for better sounds 
sake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="race(n)">Race,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Lineage, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Race,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Razza,</etym> a 
stock, or pedegree; both Con&shy;
tracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Radice,</etym> a 
root.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="race(n)">A Race</form> <xpln lang="en">of Ginger, from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Rayz de Gengibre,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rack(n)">A Rack of Hay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Recken,</etym> to reach; 
for it reacheth from one end 
of the stable, to the other: Or 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ranff,</etym> a crib; 
or a Contract of our word 
<etym lang="en">Cratch,</etym> for a manger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rack(n)">Rack,</form> <xpln lang="en">as A Cart-Rack; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rilck,</etym> a track, or 
trace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rack(v)">Rack, or Torment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
 Belg. <etym lang="bl">Racke,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
 <etym lang="bl">Racken</etym>, to rack on a tortu&shy;
 ring engine: Or from the 
 Teut. <etym lang="tt">Recken,</etym> to reach forth, 
 to stretch the joints of a Male&shy;
 factor. Minsh. draws it from 
 the Heb. <etym lang="he">Rakak,</etym> to rack, or 
 grind in pieces.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rack(n)">Rack of Mutton,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hracca</etym>, the hind part of the 
head, or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F71;&chi;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, the 
back-bone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rack(n)">Rack, or Kitchin-Rack to lay 
the spit upon;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the si&shy;
militude of the back-bone, 
which is also called, The <etym lang="en">Rack.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="racket(n)">A Racket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ra&shy;
quette,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rachetta,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Re&shy;
ticulum,</etym> a little net.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="radish(n)">Radish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Raedic</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Radis,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Rettig,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Ra&shy;
dix,</etym> a root, by an Antono&shy;
masia.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raffle(n)">Raffle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Play at Dice; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Raffler,</etym> to snap up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rafter(n)">Rafter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Raefter</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rafter,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rag(n)">Rag,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hracode</etym>, 
ragged, or the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Rawyg,</etym> 
a rupture: Or, perhaps from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F71;&kappa;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, an old torn 
garment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rage(n)">Rage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rage,</etym> the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Rabbia,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ra&shy;
bies,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="T8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rail(n)">Rail of wood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Riegel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rail(n)">A Woman's Rail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">R&aelig;gl</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minsh. draws it from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Realah;</etym> an ornament for Women, made of fine linen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rail(v)">To Rail,</form> <xpln lang="en">or revile in words; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rallen,</etym> id. the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Railler,</etym> to mock. to deride, 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Rayler,</etym> to skream 
out like a clucking Hen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raiment(n)">Raiment,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Arrayment. V. 
<etym lang="en">Array.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rain(n)">Rain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ren</etym>, 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Regan,</etym> or the Dan. 
and Teut. <etym lang="da">Regn,</etym> id. hence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Regan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Reghenen,</etym> and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reg&shy;
nen,</etym> to rain: All perhaps from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&alpha;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to besprinkle, 
or <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&alpha;&iota;&nu;&#x1F76;&#x03c2;</etym>, a drop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rein(n)">Rains of a Bridle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Resne,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Retine,</etym>, id. 
&agrave; <etym lang="la">Retinendo,</etym> from staying, or 
holding back. Write Reins.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raisin(n)">A Raisin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rai&shy;
sin,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Racemus,</etym> a bunch of Grapes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rake(n)">A Rake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Race</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raecke,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rachen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="bl">Raec&shy;
kelen</etym>, and <etym lang="tt">Rechen</etym>, to rake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rakehell(n)">Rake-hell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Rake,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Hell;</etym> 
as we say proverbially, Rake 
Hell, and Skin the Devil, 
and you will never meet with 
such a fellow: Or from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Racaille,</etym> the dregs of 
the people.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ralliery(n)">Ralliery,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rail&shy;
liere,</etym> jesting waggery; whence 
<etym lang="fr">Railler</etym>, to play the wag; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Ridiculari,</etym> to 
ridicule, to make ridiculous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rally(v)">To Rally,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ral&shy;
lier,</etym> to put disorder'd ranks 
into order again; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Realligare,</etym> to bind up toge&shy;
ther again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ram(n)">Ram,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Belg.
 <etym lang="bl">Ram</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ramin</etym>, id. 
 Fr. Jun. draws it from the 
 Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&omega;&mu;&eta;</etym>, strength.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ram(v)">To Ram,</form> <xpln lang="en">or knock in; perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hremman</etym>, to 
disturb, to trouble; or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Remo&uuml;er,</etym> to remove: 
Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rammeln,</etym> 
to make a noise by tossing any 
thing; and from hence, A 
Rammer, to pave withal; 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ramble(v)">To Ramble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Ram&shy;
melen, Remmelen,</etym> to go a 
gossipping from house to 
house; or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Re&shy;
ambulo,</etym> to walk to and again; 
or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&epsilon;&mu;&beta;&omega;</etym>, to go 
round, or <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&omicron;&mu;&beta;&epsilon;&upsilon;&omega;</etym>, to go a&shy;
stray, to range up and down.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rammish(a)">Rammish,</form> <xpln lang="en">stinking as a Goat, or 
casting a strong smell, like 
that of a <etym lang="en">Ram</etym> in riding-time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ramp(a)" lexeme="rampant(a)">Ramp, Rampant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in He&shy;
raldry; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ram&shy;
pant,</etym> climbing up; whence &shy;
<etym lang="fr">Ramper</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rampa&shy;
re</etym>, to climb up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rampire(n)">Rampire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ram&shy;
par,</etym> a fence.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rancour(n)">Rancour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ran&shy;
coeur,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rancore,</etym> 
inveterate hatred; from <etym lang="fr">Re</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="U1r"> 
again, <etym lang="fr">En,</etym> in, and <etym lang="fr">C&oelig;ur,</etym> the 
heart; because it is deeply 
rooted in the heart. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rand(n)">A Rand,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rand,</etym> a seam, or list.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="at random(adv)">At Random,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">&agrave; Ran&shy;
dello,</etym> rashly, without any de&shy;
liberation: Or rather, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rendon,</etym> an uncer&shy;
tainty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="range(v)">To Range up and down,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rannen,</etym> to run, or 
<etym lang="bl">Ranghen</etym> to wag, as a Spaniel 
doth his tail, in seeking the 
prey.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="range(v)">To Range</form> <xpln lang="en">Meal, to sift; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ranghen,</etym> to shake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rank(a)">Rank Corn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ranc</etym>, 
proud. It is meant of a field 
that bringeth forth more corn 
than it can support to maturi&shy;
ty, by reason of its weakness.</xpln></wordentry>
