<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rank(n)">A Rank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rancke,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rang,</etym> a degree. 
This Menagius draws from 
the Teut. and Eng. <etym lang="en">Ring.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rank(a)">Rank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rancidus,</etym> 
stinking.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rank(a)">A Rank Rogue, or profligate 
Knave;</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ranck,</etym> policy, craft, or guile; 
or from the other <etym lang="en">Rank,</etym> for 
rammish, or stinking; that is 
to say, One so bad, that one 
cannot chuse smelling him out 
by his words and actions.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rankle(v)">Rankle,</form> <xpln lang="en">to begin to be ulcerous; 
from the Lat <etym lang="la">Ranceo,</etym> to stink; 
for Rankling presently turns 
to rottenness and corruption.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ransack(v)">To Ransack,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Spoil; from the 
Negative <etym lang="la">Re</etym> in, and <etym lang="la">Saccus</etym> a 
sack; that is, to rob sacks, to 
shake out what is therein.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ransom(n)">Ransom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ran&shy;
&ccedil;on;</etym> which Menagius derives 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; Redemptione,</etym> by a Systole.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rant(v)">To Rant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Randen,</etym> 
or <etym lang="bl">Randten,</etym> to act like a Mad&shy;
man, to play the fool.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rap(v)">Rap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hreppan</etym>, 
to touch; a word feigned 
from the sound, by an Ano&shy;
matopoeia.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rap and rend(v)">Rap and Rend,</form> <xpln lang="en">What he can Rap and Rend; from the AS.
 <etym lang="oe">Reafian</etym>, or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rapere,</etym> 
 to snatch, and <etym lang="en">Rend;</etym> which 
 see in its place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rape(n)">A Rape,</form> <xpln lang="en">a violent ravishing a 
Woman; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ra&shy;
pere,</etym> to ravish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rape-apples(n)">Rape-Apples,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, from the 
similitude of a <etym lang="en">Rape</etym>, or Tur&shy;
nep.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"rape-apple" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rapier(n)">A Rapier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ra&shy;
piere,</etym> a long, narrow sword; 
both, not unlikely, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Rapien&shy;
do</etym> vitam, from taking away 
life.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raspberry(n)" lexeme="raspis(n)">Rasberry or Respis:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F7C;&psi;</etym>, a 
shrub, or <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1FF6;&pi;&epsilon;&#x03c2;</etym>, shrubs, and 
<etym lang="en">Berry;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rascal(n)">Rascal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rascal</etym>, 
an hairy beast; this from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rahn,</etym> lean, and <etym lang="tt">Chael,</etym> 
a shell, or bark: Or from the 
Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Racaille,</etym> the off scou&shy;
ring of the people.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rase(v)">To Rase,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ra&shy;
ser, Razer,</etym> to level with the 
ground, or <etym lang="fr">Rayer,</etym> to blot out; 
</page> 

<page sig="U1v"> 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Radere,</etym> to scrape. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rash(a)">Rash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rasch,</etym> swift, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rasen,</etym> to be mad. 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F71;&gamma;&delta;&eta;&nu;</etym>, abruptly: Cam&shy;
den, from <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&rho;&alpha;&sigma;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, bold, ad&shy;
venturous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rasher(n)">A Rasher of Bacon,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. d. <etym lang="la">Rasura</etym> 
Lardi, a shaving of Bacon, or 
slice broiled on the coals.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="razor(n)">Rasour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rasoir,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rasciere</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; Radendo,</etym> from shaving.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rasp(v)">To Rasp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Raspen,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Raspare,</etym> or the Fr G. 
<etym lang="fr">Rasper,</etym> to file, or shave into 
powder; these from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Raspa,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Raspe,</etym> a 
file; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rado,</etym> 
to scrape, or shave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rat(n)">Rat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ratte, 
Rotte,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rat, Ra&shy;
ton,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ratta,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rat, Ratz,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Ratte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rate(v)" lexeme="rattle(v)">To Rate, and Rattle,</form> <xpln lang="en">for To chide 
one; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">R&aelig;'&eth;e,</etym> 
full of wrath, or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ira&shy;
tus,</etym> angry. Mer. Cas. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&rho;&#x1F71;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, to 
rail at.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rate(v)">To Rate, or Prize,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">pro Rata,</etym> sc. Portione, esti&shy;
mare, to value according to a 
portion of the same bigness 
sold before.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rath-fruit(n)">Rath-fruit,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Early fruit, that 
is ripe in the beginning of 
Summer; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ra&eth;, 
Ra&eth;e</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rade, 
Raede,</etym> soon: All Contracts 
of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rapidus,</etym> swift. 
V. Rath, following.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"rath-fruit" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rath-wine(n)">Rath-wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">wine made of grapes 
gathered before full maturity. 
See the other <etym lang="en">Rath.</etym> </xpln>
<lemenote>
"rape-wine" not found in OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rather(adv)">Rather,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ra&eth;or</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, or sooner; this from 
<etym lang="oe">Ra&eth;e</etym>, soon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rattle(v)">Rattle,</form> <xpln lang="en">I Rattl'd him; from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ratteln,</etym> to trouble, or 
vex.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rattle(v)">To Rattle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wreo&shy;
tan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ratelen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ravage(v)">To Ravage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ra&shy;
vager,</etym> to rob, to ransack; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rapere,</etym> to 
take away forcibly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rave(v)">To Rave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ravas&shy;
ser,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reven,</etym> id. 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rabies,</etym> 
madness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ravelin(n)">A Ravelin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ra&shy;
veln,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ravellino,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ravel(v)">To Ravel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rave&shy;
len,</etym> to tangle: Hence To Vn&shy;
ravel, to dis-entangle, to free 
from knots, to expound dark 
or mystical expressions.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raven(n)">Raven,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hr&aelig;fn, 
R&aelig;fen</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Raffn,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rave,</etym> id. all from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Reafian</etym>, to snatch 
away; so called, <term lang="la">propter Ra&shy;
pacitatem</term>, for its rapacity, 
saith Somnerus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ravenous(a)">Ravenous,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Greedy; from the 
word <etym lang="en">Raven;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  he that 
</page> 

<page sig="U2r"> 
plays the Raven; for a Raven 
is reckon'd one of the chief 
of the birds of prey. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ravish(v)">To Ravish,</form> <xpln lang="en">or deflour a Maid a&shy;
gainst her will; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Ravir,</etym> to take away by force; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rapere,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raw(a)">Raw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hreaw</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rauw, Rouw,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Roh.</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="raw-boned(a)">Raw-boned,</form> <xpln lang="en">very lean and rough; 
q. <etym lang="en">Rough boned,</etym> saith Hensh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ray(n)">A Ray of the Sun,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. 
<etym lang="fr">Ray</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both Con&shy;
tracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Radius,</etym> the 
same</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ray-fish(n)">Ray-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. and Lat. 
Barb. <etym lang="la">Raia,</etym> a Thornback; so 
called, &agrave; <etym lang="la">Radio Osseo,</etym> from 
the bony strike it hath on its 
back.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reach(v)">Reach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">R&aelig;can</etym>, to 
overtake; the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Recken,</etym> to 
reach forth; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reichen,</etym> 
to reach, to touch, or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Recare,</etym> to catch hold of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retch(v)">To Reach in vomiting,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Recere,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bre&shy;
chen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Braecken.</etym> 
to vomit: Or the same with 
the other <etym lang="en">Reach</etym> above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="read(v)">To Read,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">R&aelig;dan</etym>, 
id the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reden,</etym> 
to speak, or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Ra&shy;
den,</etym> to perswade.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="read(v)">To Read;</form> <xpln lang="en">as we say, I can Read 
in a Man's face, what he is; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ar&aelig;dan</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raeden,</etym> to guess, or 
divine.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ready(adv)">Ready,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geredian</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reeden,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Bereyten,</etym> to make ready: Or 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hrade</etym>, ready, 
or quick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reak(n)">Reaks,</form> <xpln lang="en">He played Reaks: Some 
derive it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rex,</etym> a 
King; that is, He played <etym lang="la">Rex</etym>; 
as if he had absolute power to 
do what he would: Others, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rice</etym>, a King&shy;
dom, or Dominion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="realm(n)">Realm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Royaume,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Reame,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ream(n)">Ream of Paper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Riem Papfers,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Rame,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reap(v)">Reap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rippan</etym>, id. 
whence Rifter, a reaper; 
or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ruepen, 
Ruppen,</etym> to crop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rear(v)">To Rear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hre&shy;
ran</etym>, id. whence <etym lang="oe">Arehr</etym>, 
 raised.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reason(n)">Reason,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Raison,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Ratio,</etym> the 
same: From hence the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Raisonner</etym>, to reason, and <etym lang="fr">Rai&shy;
sonable</etym>, reasonable, agreeable 
to reason.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebate(v)">To Rebate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rab&shy;
battre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ribattere,</etym> 
to discount. V. Abate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebatement(n)">Rebatement,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heral&shy;
dry; from <etym lang="en">Rebate;</etym> for it is a 
note, or character of infamy 
upon a Coat of Arms, and an 
abatement of honour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebeck(n)">A Rebeck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rebec,</etym> 
or the Ital <etym lang="it">Ribecca,</etym> id. a sort 
of musical instrument.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="U2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebound(v)">To Rebound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
bondir,</etym> id. to leap again, like 
a ball; or, with a little varia&shy;
tion of the sence, from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Ribombare,</etym> to re-sound, or 
make an echo; this from the 
Prefix <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, and the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&omicron;&mu;&beta;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, to bumble, or hum&shy;
ble like Bees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebuke(v)">To Rebuke,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
boucher,</etym> to stop ones mouth; 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ribuffare, Rimboc&shy;
care,</etym> to reprove, or upbraid; 
these from <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, and the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boucher,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Bocca,</etym> a mouth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receive(v)">To Receive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
cevoir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ricevere;</etym> 
which come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Re&shy;
cipere,</etym> id. Hence our word a 
Receipt for a Medicine, or o&shy;
ther thing, because it is to be 
received by the Patient.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recheat(n)">Recheat,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Hunting, when 
the Hunts-man calls back the 
Dogs, that they should not 
pursue a counter-scent; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rachet,</etym> a redeem&shy;
ing, or <etym lang="fr">Racheter,</etym> to redeem.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reckon(v)">Reckon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Reccan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reckenen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rechnen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reckeninghe</etym>, and the 
Teut <etym lang="bl">Rechnung</etym>, a reckoning, 
or computation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reclaim(v)">Reclaim,</form> <xpln lang="en">or re-call from evil 
courses; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ri&shy;
chiamare,</etym> to re call; or from 
<etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again; and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cla&shy;
mare,</etym> to call.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recoil(v)">Recoil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reculer,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riculare,</etym> to re&shy;
treat, or go backward, as a 
ball rebounding.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recorder(n)">Recorder,</form> <xpln lang="en">a musical instrument, <etym lang="la">&agrave; Recordando,</etym> from calling 
to mind; because the great 
exploits of renowned Men, re&shy;
maining upon record, were ce&shy;
lebrated upon it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="record(n)">Records,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Records,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ricordi,</etym> registers, 
or monuments; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Recordari,</etym> to remember: 
Hence a Recorder, one of the 
Lord Mayor's Council, that 
has the charge of registring 
things worthy of remark, and 
to be left upon record.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recover(v)">To Recover,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
couvrir, Recouvrer,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Ricoverare,</etym> id. all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Recuperare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recount(v)">To Recount,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ra&shy;
conter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Racontare,</etym> 
to count again. V. To Count.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recourse(n)">Recourse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
cours;</etym> or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Recur&shy;
sus,</etym> a running back again, a 
place to run back into.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recreant(n)">Recreant,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Infidel; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Recredens,</etym> unbelieving; from 
the Neg. <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Credo,</etym> to 
believe. V. Miscreant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recruit(v)">To Recruit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
cr&ucirc;e,</etym> a supply of Men; this 
from <etym lang="fr">Recroistre,</etym> to increase 
again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="red(n)">Red,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Red, Read,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rood,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Rod,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Roth,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Rouge,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rosso,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="U3r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="redouble(v)">To Re-double,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Redoubler,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Redu&shy;
plicare,</etym> the same. V. Double.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="redoubt(v)">To Redoubt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
doubter,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Redubi&shy;
tare,</etym> to doubt much; for Re &shy;
does here increase.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="redress(v)">To Redress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
dresser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rindriz&shy;
zare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Redi&shy;
rigere,</etym> to direct again, to 
bring to a better frame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="redshank(n)">A Red-shank,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird so called, 
from the red, bloody colour 
of its shanks and feet. V. <etym lang="en">Red,</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Shank.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="red-start(n)">A Red-start,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word <etym lang="en">Red,</etym> 
and the AS. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stert,</etym> 
a tail; q. d Red-tail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reed(n)">A Reed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hreed, 
Red,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ried,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Riet,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rick(n)">A Reek of Hay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hreac</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reek(v)">To Reek,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Smoak, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Recan</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rauchen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Hence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Rec</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reuck</etym>, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rauch</etym>, smoak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reel(n)">A Reel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Reol</etym>, id. 
this from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rollen,</etym> to 
rowl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reel(v)">To Reel,</form> <xpln lang="en">or stagger; See the o&shy;
ther <etym lang="en">Reel,</etym> and To <etym lang="en">Rowl.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="refine(v)">To Refine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Raf&shy;
finer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Raffinare,</etym> to 
purifie. V. Fine.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reformado(n)">Reformado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rifor&shy;
mare,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Reformar,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Reformare,</etym> to 
reform.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="refrain(v)">To Refrain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">se 
Refraindre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Refringere,</etym> to break 
off; or from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Raffre&shy;
nare,</etym> to abstain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="refresh(v)">To Refresh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
freschir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rifescare,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. V. Fresh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="refuse(v)">To Refuse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Refu&shy;
ser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rifusare,</etym> id. 
Hence the Refuse of things, or 
off-scourings; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) things 
not worth acceptance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="regard(v)">To Regard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
garder,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riguar&shy;
dare,</etym> to mind, to look upon. 
v. Gard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="regiment(n)">A Regiment,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
giment,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Regimen&shy;
to,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Regimentum,</etym> the same; and 
this from <etym lang="la">Rego,</etym> to rule.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="register(n)">A Register,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
gistre,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Registero,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb <etym lang="la">Registrum,</etym> a re&shy;
gister of things for memory's 
sake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="regret(n)">Regret,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Regret,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Regretto,</etym> inward 
sorrow, grief; this from the 
Negative <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Gratum,</etym> ac&shy;
ceptable; or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Regra&shy;
ter,</etym> to grate again; (i. e.) that 
which grates and wounds the 
mind again and again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rehearse(v)">Rehearse,</form> <xpln lang="en">to repeat; from <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> 
again, and <etym lang="en">Hear;</etym> that is to say, 
to exhibit, or present to the 
hearing the second time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reign(v)">To Reign,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reg&shy;
ner,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Regnare,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="U3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reimburse(v)">Reimburse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
inbourser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rim&shy;
borsare,</etym> id. all from the Pre&shy;
fix <etym lang="la">Re</etym> in, and the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Bourse,</etym> &shy;
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Borsa,</etym> a purse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reins(n)">Reins,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reines,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Renes,</etym> id. which 
last Voss. draws from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to flow, or run.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reinforce(v)">To Reinforce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Renforcer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rinfor&shy;
ciare,</etym> id. to give force and cou&shy;
rage, to supply an Army with 
new forces. V. Force.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rejoice(v)">To Rejoice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Res&shy;
jouir,</etym> to be glad; this from 
the increasing Prefix <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> and 
<etym lang="la">Gaudere,</etym> to be glad; that is, 
to be very joyful, to joy again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="relate(v)">To Relate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rela&shy;
tare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="release(v)">To Release,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
laisser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rilasciare,</etym> 
to leave again: Or rather from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Relascher,</etym> to let 
loose, or set at liberty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="relent(v)">To Relent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ralen&shy;
tir,</etym> or the Ital <etym lang="it">Rallentare,</etym> to 
grow soft or limber, to begin 
to melt: Metaphorically, to 
repent of a thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="relieve(v)">To Relieve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
lever</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Rele&shy;
vare,</etym> to lift up again: Hence 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rilievo</etym>, and the Fr. G. 
and Eng. <etym lang="fr">Relief</etym>, for aid, or 
succour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="relish(v)">To Relish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
lecher,</etym> to lick again; this 
from <etym lang="fr">Re,</etym> again, and <etym lang="fr">Lecher,</etym> 
to lick; it being usual to 
lick the lips again and again 
after any thing that relisheth 
well.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rely(v)">To Rely,</form> <xpln lang="en">or put confidence in, 
from the augmentative Prefix 
<etym lang="en">Re,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ly,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to lie, lean, 
or depend solely upon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="remain(v)">To Remain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Remaindre</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Remanere,</etym> to abide; 
from hence, A Remnant, and 
Remainder.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="remarkable(a)" lexeme="remark(n)">Remarkable, Remark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Remarquable,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Remarcabile,</etym> worthy of 
remark; these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Remar&shy;
quer,</etym> or the Ital <etym lang="it">Remar&shy;
care,</etym> to remark, or take special 
notice of; q. d to mark again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="'remember(v)">To Remember,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Remembrer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Re&shy;
membrare</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">In 
memoriam Revocare</etym>, to call 
to mind, to bear in memory: 
Hence also the Fr. G. and our 
word Remembrance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="remove(v)">To Remove,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
mouvoir,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rimu&oacute;vere,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Removere,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="remorse(n)">Remorse</form> <xpln lang="en">of Conscience, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Remors de Conscience,</etym> 
the Ital <etym lang="it">Remorso di Conscienza</etym> 
or the Hisp <etym lang="sp">Remorso de Con&shy;
sciencia;</etym> these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Remordre,</etym> the Ital <etym lang="sp">Rimorde&shy;
re,</etym> and the Hisp. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Re&shy;
mordere,</etym> to gnaw, or bite hard; 
for Re is here augmentative.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reynard(n)">Renard,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a Fox; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Renard,</etym> a Fox; this <etym lang="la">&agrave; 
Renibus,</etym> from his hot Reins, 
from which his rammish smell 
</page> 

<page sig="U4r"> 
ariseth. Hensh. draws it from 
<etym lang="tt">Reinard,</etym> a Man's name; which 
see in the Proper Names. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="render(v)">To Render,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G <etym lang="fr">Ren&shy;
dre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rendere,</etym> id. 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Reddere,</etym> 
to give, or restore; by an E&shy;
penthesis &tau;&omicron;&#x1FE6; n.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rendezvous(n)">Rendevouz,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Ren&shy;
dezvous;</etym> that is to say, the 
place where every Soldier 
must render himself, or ap&shy;
pear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="renew(v)">Renew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the augment. Pre&shy;
fix <etym lang="en">Re,</etym> and <etym lang="en">New;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rennet(n)">Rennet, or Runnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">to make 
Cheese with; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Rennen, Runnen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rinnen,</etym> to curdle: Or from 
the Belg <etym lang="bl">Runnen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rennen,</etym> to run; for the thin, 
or wheyie parts run together, 
and separate themselves from 
the thick, or cheesy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rennet apple(n)">The Rennet-apple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. 
<etym lang="fr">Pomme Renette,</etym> id. a kind of 
Pepin so called, from <etym lang="fr">Renes,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Rennes,</etym> a town in Gallia 
Celtica.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="renounce(v)">Renounce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
noncer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rinoncia&shy;
re,</etym> to forsake; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Renunciare,</etym> to forbid 
ones self any vice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="renown(n)">Renown,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
nom,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Renomm&eacute;e,</etym> 
fame, or esteem; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. &shy;
<etym lang="la">Renomen,</etym> an after-name, or 
good repute acquired by ex&shy;
cellency in any thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rent(v)" lexeme="rend(v)">Rent, or Rend,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hrendan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rent(n)">Rent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rente,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rendita,</etym> a revenue; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Reditus,</etym> a 
rent, or return; to wit, so 
much money as returns to the 
Owner, from lands or houses, 
in a year.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repair(v)">Repair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Repai&shy;
rer;</etym> or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Reparare,</etym> to 
make ready again, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) mend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repast(n)">Repast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Repas; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  </etym> Lat. <etym lang="la">Repastus,</etym> a plentiful 
feeding, or feeding again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repeal(v)">To Repeal,</form> <xpln lang="en">or take off a Law; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rapeler, Rap&shy;
peler,</etym> to revoke; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Reappellare,</etym> to call back.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repine(v)">Repine,</form> <xpln lang="en">or to Envy, from the 
augmentative Prefix <etym lang="en">Re,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Pine,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Pain;</etym> that is, to be 
in great pain or uneasiness at 
another's prosperity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="replenish(v)">Replenish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, and 
<etym lang="la">Plenus,</etym> full; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to fill again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reply(v)">To Reply,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Repli&shy;
quer,</etym> or the Ital. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Re&shy;
plicare</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="report(v)">To Report,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Rap&shy;
porter</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Re&shy;
portare,</etym> to bring back what 
others say.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="repose(v)">To Repose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">se 
Reposer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riposar&shy;
si,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reprisal(n)">Reprisals,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
prisailles,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ripresag&shy;
lia,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Repre&shy;
salia,</etym> Letters of Reprisal to 
keep the Subject harmless, if 
accosted by a Subject of any 
confederate Prince; at Sea 
chiefly.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="U4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reproach(v)">To Reproach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
procher,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riproccia&shy;
re,</etym> id. to slander: These from 
the Explet Prefix <etym lang="fr">Re,</etym> and the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Proche,</etym> near; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
revile one face to face; as we 
say, To put it home, by a Me&shy;
taphor drawn from Sword-&shy;
players.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reprove(v)">To Reprove,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
prouver,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riprova&shy;
re,</etym> id. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Reprobare,</etym> to 
prove against one, or not to 
approve of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="request(n)">Request,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
queste,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Richiesta,</etym> 
a demand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="requite(v)">Requite,</form> <xpln lang="en">with us, To Recompense; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Requiter,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rearward(n)">Rereward, or Rere-Guard,</form> <xpln lang="en">by 
contraction Rear; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Arrieregarde,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Retroguardia</etym>; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
back-guard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rescue(v)">To Rescue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Res&shy;
courre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riscuote&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resemble(v)">To Resemble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Res&shy;
sembler,</etym> id to be like another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resent(v)">To Resent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">se Res&shy;
sentir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Risentire,</etym> 
id. These from the Augmen&shy;
tative <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Sentio,</etym> to per&shy;
ceive.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resolve(v)">To Resolve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">se 
Resouldre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Risol&shy;
vere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Resolvere,</etym> to unty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resound(v)">To Resound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
sonder,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Risuonare,</etym> or 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Resonare,</etym> to sound 
again, to echo.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="respite(n)">Respit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Respit,</etym> id. 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Respectus,</etym> 
a looking back; it signifying 
a time allowed to review and 
consider of what is past.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rest(n)" lexeme="remainder(n)">The Rest, or Remainder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reste,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Resto,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rest(n)">The Rest of a Lance or Musquet,</form> <xpln lang="en">
stay, or stop. V. Arrest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rest(n)">Rest from labour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rest</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raste,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rust,</etym> the same: 
Whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Restan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rasten</etym>, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rusten</etym>, to be at rest; all pro&shy;
bably from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Restare,</etym> to remain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="restore(v)">Restore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital, <etym lang="it">Ristorare,</etym> &shy;
the same; and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Restaurare,</etym> to 
repair, or make good again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="restrain(v)">To Restrain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
straindre,</etym> to keep in; from 
hence also Restraint.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resty(a)">Resty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Restif,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Restivo,</etym> id. stubborn; 
this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Restitando,</etym> from stop&shy;
ping often in the way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="resty(a)">Resty Bacon,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Rusty Bacon. &shy;
v. <etym lang="en">Rust.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retail(v)">To Retail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
tailler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ritaglia&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retain(v)">To Retain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
tenir,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Retinere,</etym> to 
keep in memory.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retch(v)">To Retch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Recken,</etym> to extend; or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hraecan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or 
</page> 

<page sig="U5r"> 
from our word <etym lang="en">Reach;</etym> which 
see. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retinue(n)">A Retinue, or Train,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Retenir,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Retinere,</etym> to retain; also to 
maintain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retire(v)">To Retire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reti&shy;
rer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ritirare,</etym> to re&shy;
turn, or retreat; these from <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> 
back, again, &amp; the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tirer,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tirare,</etym> to draw.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retreat(n)">A Retreat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
traicte,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ritretta, id.</etym> 
a drawing back of an ar&shy;
my; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Retra&shy;
here,</etym> to draw back.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="retrench(v)">To Retrench,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
trencher,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ritrin&shy;
ciare,</etym> to lop off: These from 
<etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, and the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tren&shy;
cher,</etym> to cut.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="return(v)">To Return,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
tourner,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ritorna&shy;
re,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="revel(v)">To Revel</form> <xpln lang="en">all night long, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reveiller,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Rifvegliare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, to wake 
much; these from <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, 
and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vigilare,</etym> to be 
vigilant, or watchful; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
to be doubly watchful.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="revenge(v)">To Revenge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
venger,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Vengar,</etym> or
 the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vindicare,</etym> to take 
 engeance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="revenue(n)">Revenue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reve&shy;
nue,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. V. Rent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="review(v)">To Review,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
veoir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rivedere</etym>, id. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Revidere,</etym> to see, 
or look on the second time: 
From hence, A Review.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="revile(v)">To Revile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the augmenta&shy;
tive <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vilis,</etym> 
vile, or base; for it signifieth, 
to play upon one, as if he 
were good for nothing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="revive(v)">To Revive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Re&shy;
viver,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ravivare,</etym> 
to make alive again; this from 
<etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vivus,</etym> 
alive, or living.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="revolt(v)">To Revolt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Revol&shy;
ter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rivoltare,</etym> to 
go over to the Enemy; this 
from <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, and the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Voltare,</etym> to turn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reward(v)">Reward,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Re,</etym> again, and 
<etym lang="en">Award:</etym> Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Weard</etym>, toward; to do one 
good turn for another. V. 
Award.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhubarb(n)">Rheubarb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Reu&shy;
barbe,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ruibarbo,</etym> 
a root so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="real(n)">A Real,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Reale,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a royal Coin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rib(n)">Rib,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Ribbe,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rippe,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ribald(n)">A Ribald,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ri&shy;
bauld,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ribaldo,</etym> a 
Whoremonger; this from <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> 
the Intensive Part. and the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Baud, Bauld,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Baldo,</etym> bold; as we say, a 
bold, impudent fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="riband(n)">Riband,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Re-bind, from <etym lang="en">Re,</etym> 
again, and <etym lang="en">Bende,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Bind;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ribble-rabble(adv)">Ribble Rabble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Rabbelen,</etym> to speak confused&shy;
ly. V. Rabble.</xpln></wordentry>
</page> 
 
 <page sig="U5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rice(n)">Rice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Riis,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ris,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reisz,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the Lat. 
and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Oryza,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; a sort 
of grain so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rich(a)">Rich,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Riick,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Riche,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ryc</etym>, the same; 
from hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Richesse</etym>, the Ital. <etym lang="it">Richezza</etym>, and 
our word Riches.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rid(v)">Rid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hreddan</etym>, 
to make free of; or the Run. 
Dan. <etym lang="rn">Eg Ryd,</etym> I rid; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
I unload a ship, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="riddle(n)">A Riddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of sieve; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hriddel</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="riddle(n)">Riddle or Probleme,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg <etym lang="bl">Raedsel,</etym> the same; and 
this from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raeden,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Araedan</etym>, to in&shy;
terpret. V. Read. Or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Readle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ride(v)">To Ride,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ridan</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reitten,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Riiden,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ridge(n)">A Ridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rug&shy;
ghe,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Ryg,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hrige</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rife(a)">Rife,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ryfe,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
that which spreadeth much, 
as contagious diseases do.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="riff-raff(n)">Riffraff,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Rifken Rafken;</etym> whereby 
they signifie any confused dis&shy;
order.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rifle(v)">To Rifle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Riiffe&shy;
len,</etym> to pilfer; or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Rifler,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: all, not unlike&shy;
ly, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rapere,</etym> to 
take away in haste.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rift(n)">A Rift,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">River.</etym> </xpln>
<lemenote>
"rift" antedates the earliest OED citation (1727).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rig(v)">To Rig</form> <xpln lang="en">a Ship, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rihtan</etym>, to mend; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
right a ship.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="right(a)">Right,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Recht,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ritto,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Riht;</etym> and all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Rectus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rim(n)">Rim,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rima,</etym> a 
brim.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rim(n)">The inner Rim of the belly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rind</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the inner 
rind of the belly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rhyme(n)">Rime,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Rime</etym>, or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rima;</etym> all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rythmus;</etym> this 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x03CD;&theta;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>, 
Metre.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rime(n)">Rime-Frost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hrime</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Riim,</etym> 
the same; all corruptions of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pruina,</etym> hoar-frost.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rind(n)">Rind,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rind</etym>, or 
the Teut. and Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Rinde,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ring(v)">To Ring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ringan, 
Hringan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; both pos&shy;
sibly from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ring(n)">A Ring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hring</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ringhe,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ring,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="devil's gold ring(n)">The Devil's Gold Ring,</form> <xpln lang="en">a worm 
so called, because it is of the 
colour of gold, of a round 
form, and very destructive to 
Vines: Higginius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rinse(v)">To Rinse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rinser, 
Reinser,</etym> id. or from the AS. 
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> clean; 
 the end of rinsing being to 
 make clean.</xpln></wordentry> 
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="U6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="riot(n)">A Riot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Riote,</etym> 
of the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riotto,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, a 
disturbance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rip(v)">To Rip</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ryppan</etym>, 
to undo that which is sow'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ripe(a)">Ripe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ripe</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reiff,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Riip,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all not unlikely from 
the AS <etym lang="oe">Rippan,</etym> to reap; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
fit to be reaped. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F73;&pi;&omega;</etym>, 
to creep; for ripe corn lean&shy;
eth toward the ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rise(v)">To Rise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rissen,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Arisan</etym>, to arise; 
in another sence from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Reisen,</etym> to rise, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) swell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="risgoe(n)" lexeme="risk(n)">Risgo, or Risk,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term among 
Sailers; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Risque,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rischio,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Riesgo,</etym> danger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rive(v)">To Rive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ryf&shy;
tan</etym>, to slit or cleave, or the 
Dan <etym lang="da">Riffver,</etym> to tear asunder.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rival(n)">A Rival,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rivalis,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="river(n)">A River,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ri&shy;
viere,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Riviera,</etym> 
the same; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Rivus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rivet(v)">To Rivet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ri&shy;
ver,</etym> to drive a nail in sure&shy;
ly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rix-dollar(n)">Rix Doller,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dutch Coin, from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reich,</etym> a kingdom, 
and <etym lang="en">Doller;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roan(n)" lexeme="roe(n)">The Roan, or Roes of a fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Raun,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rogen,</etym> the same; all 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Renes,</etym> 
the reins or kidneys.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roan(a)">Roan-colour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. &shy;
<etym lang="fr">Ro&uuml;an, Roan,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Roa&shy;
no, Rouano,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roar(v)">To Roar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Raran,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rob(v)">To Rob,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rubbare,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Robber,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Reafian</etym>, 
to spoil; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Rapere,</etym> to take violently.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="robe(n)">A Robe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Robbe,</etym> 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ref, Reaf</etym>, 
a vestment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roche(n)">A Roche,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hreoce</etym>, 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rosse,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or 
'tis so called, <etym lang="la">&agrave; Ruben colore,</etym> 
because of its reddish colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rochet(n)" lexeme="rocket(n)">A Rochet, or Rocket,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of 
cloak; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ro&shy;
chet,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rocc</etym>, or the Teut. 
and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rock,</etym> a coat; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a little coat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rock(n)">A Rock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Roe,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rocca,</etym> the same; 
and all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Rho;&#x1F7C;&xi;</etym>, a 
ragged clift.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rock(v)">To Rock a child,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Rocquer un Enfant,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and this perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rucken,</etym> to move to 
and fro.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rocket(n)">Rockets or Rochets,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Rocchelli, Rocchetti,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ragetten,</etym> squibs to 
cast into the air: Or from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Rogus,</etym> a fire, and <etym lang="la">et</etym> a Ter&shy;
mination diminutive.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rod(n)">Rod,</form> <xpln lang="en">a measure of sixteen feet, 
and an half; from the Belg. 
</page> 

<page sig="U6v"> 
<etym lang="bl">Roede,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Radius,</etym> a Geometrician's 
staff.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rod(n)">A Rod to correct Offenders:</form> <xpln lang="en">
Minshew draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F71;&beta;&delta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this 
from <etym lang="gk">&Rho;&alpha;&pi;&#x1F77;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to scourge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="road(n)">The Rode,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word, To 
<etym lang="en">Ride,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reede,</etym> or the 
<emend err="the"></emend>Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rade,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roe(n)">A Roe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rha</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Rah deor</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ree&shy;
beck,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rehe-bock,</etym> 
a Roe-buck.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rogue(a)">Rogue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rogue,</etym> 
bold: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Roagh</etym>, to curse, to hate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="romance(n)">A Romance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ro&shy;
man,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Romanzo,</etym> a 
pamphlet having nothing real 
or true in it; primarily so 
called from the Romans, who 
were famous for such kind of 
stories.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rood(n)">A Rood</form> <xpln lang="en">of Land, v. <etym lang="en">Rod,</etym> for 
a Geometrician's staff.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roof(n)">Roof,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hrof</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence The Roof of the 
mouth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rook(n)">Rook,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hroc</etym>, 
or the Belg <etym lang="bl">Roeck,</etym> a Crow that 
wasteth the corn; all perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Raucus,</etym> hoarse. 
From hence, A Rook at Chess, 
and To Rook, to cheat in ga&shy;
ming; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to play the Rook, 
or act thievishly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="room(n)">Room,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rum</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ruym,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Raum,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roost(n)">Roost.</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hrost</etym>, 
the same; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Roe&shy;
sten,</etym> to sleep as birds do; this 
perhaps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rusten,</etym> 
to rest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="root(n)">Root,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Roed,</etym> the 
same, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kraut,</etym> or the 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Crut,</etym> a pot-herb.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="root(v)">To Root,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wro&shy;
tan</etym>, to cast up with the snout 
like a Sow; or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Roeden, Roden,</etym> to pluck up 
by the root.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rope(n)">A Rope,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rape</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Reeb,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Roop,</etym> the same. Fr. Jun. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1FF6;&shy;
&pi;&epsilon;&#x03c2;</etym>, small twigs; others from 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&#x1F79;&phi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a turning, or twist&shy;
ing about.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ropy(a)">Ropy Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">or other Liquors, 
from our word <etym lang="en">Rope,</etym> it be&shy;
ing tough liquor, that hangs 
down in ropes from the 
spoon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rosemary(n)">Rosemary,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rou&shy;
marin,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Romarino,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb <etym lang="la">Rosmarinus,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) dew of the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rosin(n)">Rosin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Resine,</etym> or 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Resina,</etym> id. this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F72;&omega;</etym>, to run out; for 
it is a clammy juice, running 
out of trees, like gum.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roast(v)">To Rost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rosten,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rostir,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Rostire,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rot(v)">To Rot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rotan</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rotten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rottle(v)" lexeme="ruttle(v)">To Rottle, or Ruttle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rotheln,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
</page> 

<page sig="U7r"> 
<etym lang="fr">Raller,</etym> to draw breath un&shy;
evenly, as dying people do. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rove(v)">To Rove,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Roffver,</etym> 
to rob; or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Roder,</etym> 
to ransack. Where have you 
been Roving, v. Robbing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rough(a)">Rough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ruh, 
Hruh</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rouw,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rauch,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ruffo,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Roide,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rudis,</etym> without 
form.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rouncival pea(n)">Rounceval Pease,</form> <xpln lang="en">a great, sweet 
kind of Pease, so called from 
<etym lang="sp">Ronceval,</etym> a place in the Con&shy;
fines of Spain, at the foot of 
the Pyrenean Mountains, fa&shy;
mous for the increase there&shy;
of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="round(a)">Round,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rond,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rundt;</etym> all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rotundus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
this from <etym lang="la">Rota,</etym> a wheel: 
Hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">La Ronde</etym>, 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">La Ronda</etym>, the 
rounds, or circuits of the 
watch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="round(v)">To Round</form> <xpln lang="en">one in the ear, or ra&shy;
ther <etym lang="me">Rown</etym>, as Chaucer has it; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ruman</etym>, to whis&shy;
per; whence <etym lang="oe">Run, Rune</etym>, 
a secret.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roundelay(n)">Roundelay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the F. G. <etym lang="fr">Ron&shy;
deau,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or, from the 
old word <etym lang="en">Lay,</etym> a song, and 
<etym lang="en">Round;</etym> because it is sung in 
a round, or, as we say, in
parts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rouse(v)">To Rouse, or Rowse,</form> <xpln lang="en">v. <etym lang="en">Raise.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rousing(a)">A Rousing Lye,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the other 
<etym lang="en">Rouse;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a lye so notorious 
and loud, that it would even 
rouse one out of sleep.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rout(v)">To Rout</form> <xpln lang="en">an Army, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Route,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rotta,</etym> a 
dissipation, or vanquishing of 
an Enemy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="row(v)">To Row,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rowan, 
Rewan,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Roeden, 
Roeyen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ruyen,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="row(n)">A Row,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reih, 
Reihe,</etym> a rank; this perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Regula,</etym> a 
rule.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rowel(n)">A Rowel of a Spur,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rouelle,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rota,</etym> a wheel; 
for you may turn it as a 
wheel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="roll(n)">A Rowl, or rather Roll,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rol,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rolle,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rolle, Roule,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Rollo,</etym> a schedule, 
or catalogue; these from the 
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rollen,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rouler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ro&shy;
vigliare,</etym> to rowl up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="royal(a)">Royal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Royal,</etym> 
the same; this from <etym lang="fr">Roy,</etym> a 
King; from hence, A Roya&shy;
list, for a loyal Subject.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rub(v)">To Rub,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rei&shy;
ben,</etym> the same: Or from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&#x1F7B;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to wipe, or make 
clean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ruby(n)">A Ruby,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Rubi,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rubis,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Rubino, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all <etym lang="la">&agrave; Rubeo</etym> 
colore, from its red colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rudder(n)">Rudder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ro&eth;er</etym>, 
</page> 

<page sig="U7v"> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Roider,</etym> the Rud&shy;
der of a Ship; Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">Righter,</etym> from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rih&shy;
tan</etym>, to direct. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ruddy(a)">Ruddy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rudu,</etym> 
Redness. See Red.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rude(a)">Rude,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. Ital. and 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Rude;</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ru&shy;
dis,</etym> without form; or ra&shy;
ther, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Re&eth;e</etym>, &shy;
ungovernable; also unpolish&shy;
ed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rudge-washed(a)">Rudge Washed,</form> <xpln lang="en">Kersey made 
of wool wash'd only on the 
sheeps back, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ruck,</etym> or Belg <etym lang="bl">Rugghe,</etym> the 
Ridge-bone, or the Back it 
self.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rue(n)">Rue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the F. G. <etym lang="fr">Rue;</etym> this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ruta,</etym> id. the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&upsilon;&shy;
&tau;&#x1F74;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Write Rhue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rue(v)">To Rue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Reopian,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rouen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rewen,</etym> to repent; perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F48;&rho;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to con&shy;
dole.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ruff(n)">A Ruff,</form> <xpln lang="en">to wear about the neck, 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ruyffel,</etym> a Ruf&shy;
fle; or <etym lang="bl">Ruyffelen,</etym> to rumple, 
or wrinkle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ruffian(n)">A Ruffian,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ruf&shy;
fien,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Rufian,</etym> or the 
It. <etym lang="it">Ruffiano,</etym> a Pimp.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rug(n)">A Rug,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our word <etym lang="en">Rough.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rule(n)">A Rule,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Regula,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rumble(v)">Rumble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rom&shy;
melen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rummeln;</etym> 
or the It. <etym lang="it">Rombolare,</etym> the 
same; and all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rummage(v)" lexeme="room(v)">To Rummage, or Rume Goods 
in a Ship;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rau&shy;
men,</etym> to make room. Hence 
<etym lang="tt">Raum</etym>, Room.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rump(n)">Rump,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rumpff;</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Rumpe,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rumple(v)">To Rumple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Rompelen,</etym> id. or from <etym lang="bl">Rom&shy;
pel,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Hryympelle</etym>, a 
Rumple.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rundlet(n)" lexeme="roundlet(n)">Rundlet,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Roundlet, <etym lang="la">&agrave; ro&shy;
tunda figura</etym>, from its round 
form.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="run(v)">To Run,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rynan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Runnen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rennen,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="runagate(n)">Runnagate</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Run,</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Gate;</etym> 
or from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Renegado,</etym> 
one that apostatizeth from 
the Faith; this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Renegando,</etym> 
from denying his Religion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="runt(n)">Runt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Scotch, or Welsh Runt, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rind,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rund,</etym> an Ox.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rush(n)">A Rush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Risc</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rush(v)">To Rush,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hre&shy;
osan</etym>, the same; hence <etym lang="oe">In&shy;
resan</etym>, to rush in; and 
<etym lang="oe">Hrysca</etym>, a Rushing in, an Irruption.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="russet(n)">Russet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Rousset;</etym> 
or the It. <etym lang="it">Rossetto,</etym> a light 
red somewhat red. Fr. Jun. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
of the colour of Pomegra&shy;
nates.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="russeting(n)">A Russeting,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Roussette,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of a Russet 
colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rust(n)">Rust,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Roest,</etym> Dan. 
</page> 

<page sig="U8r"> 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rost,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rust</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Roesten</etym>, and Teut. <etym lang="oe">Rosten</etym>, 
to gather Rust; all perhaps 
from <etym lang="en">Rest,</etym> for Arms resting, 
and not used, become rusty. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rustle(v)">Rustle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hristlan</etym>; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ruysselen,</etym> to clash together; all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rye(n)">Ry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ryge</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rogghe,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="S"><alpha>S</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sable(n)">Sable;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sable,</etym> 
a term in Heraldry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sack(n)">A Sack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sac,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sacco,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sacc, Saec</etym>, the same; and all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Saccus;</etym> which 
again comes from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&#x1F71;&tau;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to load; from hence 
cometh to Sack, Saccage 
and Satchel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sack(n)">Sack,</form> <xpln lang="en">otherwise Canary-wine, 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; siccando,</etym> from Drying, 
saith Minsh. Or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sacke,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Seck,</etym>
