<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sackbut(n)">Sackbut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Saca
buche,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sad(a)">Sad,</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. takes it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schatte,</etym> a shadow; for 
men of sorrow affect shady 
places, or solitude, hating all 
society: It may also be drawn from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sat,</etym> full, to 
wit, of grief; or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sa&shy;
tur,</etym> full, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) full or dark 
with colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saddle(n)">Saddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. and
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sadel,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sat&shy;
tel,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Saol</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
These from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Setl</etym>, 
a Seat, or Settle: Or they 
may be all contracts of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Sedile,</etym> a Seat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="safe(a)">Safe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sauf,</etym> or 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Salvus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saffron(n)">Saffron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Saffran;</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Saffrano,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Zaffrano,</etym> the 
same; 'tis of an Arabick O&shy;
riginal .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sage(n)">Sage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Sauge;</etym> 
and both contracts of the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Salvia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this <etym lang="la">&agrave; salvifi&shy;
cis facultatibus</etym>, from its 
salving, or healing qualities.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sage(a)">Sage,</form> <xpln lang="en">for discreet, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Sage,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Saggio,</etym> 
wise; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sagire,</etym> to perceive quickly, 
or sagaciously.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sail(n)">A Sail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Seyl,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Segel,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Segl</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the 
Verbs, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Seylen</etym>, Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Segelen</etym>, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seg&shy;
 lian</etym>, to sail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saint(n)">Saint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sainct;</etym> 
or the It. <etym lang="it">Santo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both 
which are derived from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Sanctus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sake(n)">Sake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sake, 
Saecke,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sach;</etym> or 
</page> 

<page sig="U8v"> 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sac, Saca</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saker(n)">Saker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Sacre,</etym> 
a kind of Hawk so called; 
this from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Sacar,</etym> to 
pull out; it being a ravenous 
Fowl. Minsh. draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sacer,</etym> consecrated, 
or dedicated, to wit, to Ju&shy;
piter, as being of the kind of 
Eagles.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saker(n)">Saker,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of greater Camp-&shy;
Gun, as the other <etym lang="en">Saker,</etym> 
which see; this Gun being no 
less destructive to Men, than 
that Hawk is to other Birds.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salient(a)">Saliant,</form> <xpln lang="en">as, a Lion saliant; a 
term in Heraldry; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Saillant,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Saliens,</etym> leaping.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sallet(n)">Sallet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Salade,</etym> 
or the It. <etym lang="it">Salata,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sallow(n)">A Sallow, or Sally-tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Saux, Saule,</etym> or the 
It <etym lang="it">Salice,</etym> the same; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Salix,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sallow(n)">A Sally</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sail&shy;
lie,</etym> a sudden eruption of the 
Besieged upon the Besiegers; 
this from <etym lang="fr">Saillir,</etym> to break 
out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salt(n)">Salt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sealt</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Saltz,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sel,</etym> the It. <etym lang="it">Sale,</etym> or the Lat <etym lang="la">Sal,</etym> 
the same; all from the Gr, 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F0D;&lambda;&#x03c2;</etym>, the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salt(a)">Salt, as a Salt Bitch;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Salax,</etym> lecherous, infla&shy;
med with lust.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saltpetre(n)">Salt-Petre,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Saltpetre,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Salpetre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Salpie&shy;
tra,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Sa&shy;
lis petra,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Salt petrefied, 
or grown into an hard stony 
substance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salt-cellar(n)">Salt-sellar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sali&shy;
ere,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Saliera,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
The learned Th. H. takes Salt 
to be a Pleonasm, supposing 
Sellar, in it self to express as 
much, q. Salter; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a thing 
to contain Salt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="salve(n)">A Salve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Sal&shy;
va,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Salf,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Salb;</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sealf</etym>, 
the same; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Salvus,</etym> whole; or <etym lang="la">Salvare,</etym> 
to heal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="same(a)">Same,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Same</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Samo,</etym> 
so: or, perhaps from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F0D;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, Together, by a Pros&shy;
thesis of the Letter s.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="samphire(n)">Sampire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Saint-&shy;
pierre,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Sancti Petri </etym> her&shy;
ba, Saint Peter's herb, Minsh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sample(n)">Sample,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Sampler, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Exemple,</etym> or, <etym lang="fr">Ex&shy;
emplaire,</etym> an Example or Pat&shy;
tern.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sand(n)">Sand</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sand,</etym> Sand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sanjak(n)">Sangiack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the It. <etym lang="it">Sangiac&shy;
co,</etym> a Turkish word, denoting a 
degree next to that of a Ba&shy;
shaw. Leunclavius draws it 
from the Turkish Words <etym lang="tu">San&shy;
zac,</etym> a Standard, and <etym lang="tu">Beg,</etym> a 
Master.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sap(v)">To Sap,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Dig, a Military 
term, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sapper,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Zappare,</etym> to dig 
</page> 

<page sig="X1r"> 
with a spade; this from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, id. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sap(n)">Sap,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Trees, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sap,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Safft,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Saepe,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saracen(n)">Saracen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sarace&shy;
ni,</etym> a People so called; both 
from the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Essarak,</etym> Rob&shy;
bers; they being infamous 
for robbery and depredations, 
among their neighbors.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sarcenet(n)">Sarcenet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a thin Silk, so called 
from the <etym lang="en">Saracens,</etym> by whom 
it was first sent into Europe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sardel(n)" lexeme="sardine(n)">Sardel, or Sardin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fish ta&shy;
king its name from <etym lang="it">Sardinia,</etym> 
an Island in the Lybick Sea, 
affording great plenty of this 
sort.</xpln>
<lemenote>
Antedates first citation of "sardel" in OED (1721).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sark(n)">Sark,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Shirt, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Syrc</etym>, the same: or from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Messe Sercke,</etym> A 
Surplice, or Mass-Shirt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="searce(n)">A Sarse or Serse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Sas,</etym> a Sieve; or <etym lang="fr">Sasser,</etym> 
to sift.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satchel(n)">Satchel,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Dimin. of <etym lang="en">Sack,</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saturday(n)">Satterday,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sea&shy;
terdaeg</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sa&shy;
terdagh;</etym> this from <etym lang="oe">Seater,</etym> the 
same with Saturn: Or 'tis so 
called q. <etym lang="en">Saturn day</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the day of Saturn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="satin(n)">Sattin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Satin;</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sattino,</etym> the same. 
Voss. draws it from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sindon,</etym> very fine linen; and 
this from the Syriack <etym lang="sy">Sadin,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="savage(a)">Savage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sau&shy;
vage;</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Selvaggio,</etym> 
r <etym lang="it">Selvatico,</etym> untamed; which 
comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sylvati&shy;
cus,</etym> belonging to the wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sauce(n)">Sauce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sauce, 
Saulse;</etym> or the Ital. and Span. 
<etym lang="sp">Salsa,</etym> id. all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sal,</etym> Salt; for that, seasons all 
things.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saucer(n)">A Saucer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sau&shy;
cier,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Saulsiere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="save(v)">To Save,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sau&shy;
ver;</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Salvare, id.</etym> 
from hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sau&shy;
veur</etym>, a Saviour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="safeguard(n)">A Save gard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sauve garde;</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Sal&shy;
va Guardia,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saunter(v)">To Saunter</form> <xpln lang="en">up and down, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sauter, Sauteller,</etym> 
 to skip about.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="savory(a)">Savory,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Savou&shy;
r&eacute;e,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="savour(n)">A Savour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sa&shy;
veur,</etym> id. both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sapor,</etym> a relish, or smack; 
from hence Savory, grateful 
to the taste.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saucy(a)">Sausy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sassaem,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Satsaem,</etym> 
the same; this from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sat,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Satt,</etym> satiated; for it 
denotes one that abuseth ano&shy;
thers patience, even to a nau&shy;
seous excess.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saw(n)">A Saw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Syge</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Saga</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sage,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Saeghe;</etym> or the It. 
<etym lang="it">Sega,</etym> the same; and all <etym lang="la">&agrave; se&shy;
cando,</etym> from cutting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="saw(n)">Saw,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old Saw; from the 
</page> 

<page sig="X1v"> 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Saga</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sage,</etym> 
a saying, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an old Say. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="say(v)">To Say,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sagen,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Segghen;</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Saegan</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Secgan</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="say(n)">Say</form> <xpln lang="en">, Stuff; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sayette;</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Saietta,</etym> 
the same; these from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Saye,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Saio,</etym> or 
the Span. <etym lang="sp">Saye,</etym> a Cassock, cal&shy;
led in Latin <etym lang="la">Sagum.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scabbard(n)">Scabbard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&#x1F73;&pi;&omega;</etym>, 
to cover; or the old Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schabbe,</etym> a Cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scaffold(n)">Scaffold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escha&shy;
fant;</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schabot,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scalado(n)">A Scalado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scalade,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Scalada,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scalata,</etym> a mount&shy;
ing the Walls of a Town <etym lang="la">per 
scalas,</etym> with Ladders.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scald(v)">To Scald,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
schauder</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schan&shy;
den, </etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the It. 
<etym lang="it">Scaldare</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="la">calidum face&shy;
re</etym>, to make hot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scald-head(n)">Scald-Head</form> <xpln lang="en">,<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">scaled head,</etym> 
from the abundance of Scales 
that fall there from.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scale(v)">To Scale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Esca&shy;
lar,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escaller;</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scalare,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) per 
<etym lang="la">scalas ascendere</etym>, to go up by 
Ladders.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scale(n)">Scales of Fishes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Escaille,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Scaglie,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scallion(n)">A Scallion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the It. <etym lang="it">Sca&shy;
logna,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scalonie;</etym> 
primarily so called from <etym lang="la">Sca&shy;
lona</etym> of Pal&aelig;stina, according &shy;
to Skinner; or from <etym lang="he">Ascalon</etym> 
of Jud&aelig;a, according to Min&shy;
shew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scalp(n)">Scalp,</form> <xpln lang="en">hairy Scalp, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schelpe,</etym> a Shell; or 
It. <etym lang="it">Scalpo,</etym> the Skull; also a 
shell, by an easie similitude.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scalping iron(n)">A Scalping-Iron</form> <xpln lang="en">for Chirurge&shy;
ons; so call'd <etym lang="la">&agrave; scalpendo,</etym> 
from scraping the corrupted 
flesh from the bones.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scamble(v)">To Scamble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&alpha;&mu;&beta;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, bandy-legg'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scan(v)">To Scan</form> <xpln lang="en">a Verse, from <etym lang="la">scando</etym> 
to climb; for in scanning we 
ascend as it were by steps, 
from one finger to another, so 
taking an account of each 
foot and syllable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scant(a)">Scant,</form> <xpln lang="en">that which lacketh 
somewhat; possibly from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Canthus,</etym> a corner, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
that which wants something 
to fill up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scar(n)">A Scar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escare, 
Escarre,</etym> the same; or from 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Escara,</etym> id. 
a crust made on a wound 
with a searing-iron, when the 
blood cannot otherwise be 
stopped.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scarce(a)">Scarce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escars,</etym> 
the It. <etym lang="it">Scarfo,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schaers,</etym> the same; all pro&shy;
bably from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Careo,</etym> to 
want.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scare(v)">To Scare</form> <xpln lang="en">one, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schier,</etym> on a sudden; for 
things that fall out suddenly, 
do most affright: Or from 
the It. <etym lang="it">Scorare,</etym> to discou&shy;
rage.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="X2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scarf(n)">Scarf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escarpe, 
Escharpe,</etym> id. or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sceorp</etym>, any vestment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scarlet(n)">Scarlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escar&shy;
late,</etym> the Hisp <etym lang="sp">Escarlata;</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scharlack,</etym> or the 
It. <etym lang="it">Scarlato,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skate(v)">Scates,</form> <xpln lang="en">to slide along the ice 
withal. Fr Jun. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Sigma;&kappa;&upsilon;&delta;&#x1F77;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to kick. 
Skinner, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schaetse;</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
schasse,</etym> forked Stilts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scatter(v)">To Scatter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schetteren,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scavenger(n)">Scavenger,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Scaef&eth;a</etym>, shavings, and 
<etym lang="oe">Fengan</etym>, to take up; or from 
<etym lang="oe">Scafan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schaben,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schaben,</etym> to shave, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fegen,</etym> to make 
clean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="school(v)">To School,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schulen</etym> to chide, or reprove, 
as a Master does his Scholar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scion(n)">A Scien,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sci&shy;
on,</etym> a young tree. Minsh. 
draws it <etym lang="la">&agrave; scindendo,</etym> be&shy;
cause it is cut off from a tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scoff(v)">To Scoff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schop&shy;
pen;</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Schobben</etym>, id. to ca&shy;
vil, or mock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scold(v)">To Scold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schel&shy;
den;</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schelten,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, to chide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sconce(n)">Sconce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schantse;</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schantz,</etym> a for&shy;
tify'd place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scoop(n)">A Scoop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scoepe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, this from <etym lang="bl">Schoepen,</etym> to scoop, or draw out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scorch(v)">To Scorch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scorcher.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scorn(n)">Scorn.</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Escorne;</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scorno,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, Con&shy;
tempt; this from <etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> a 
Horn; hence, <term lang="la">Cornu Rhinocerotis habet</term>, he is a jearing 
fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scoundrel(n)">A Scoundrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the It. <etym lang="it">Scon&shy;
daruolo;</etym> this from <etym lang="it">Scondere,</etym> 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Abscondere,</etym> to hide; ta&shy;
ken for a man whom a bad 
Life and a guilty Conscience 
force to abscond.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scour(v)">To Scour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scurer;</etym> Ital. <etym lang="it">Scurare,</etym> to take 
care of; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scheue&shy;
ren,</etym> to rub, or clean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scourge(n)">Scourge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escour&shy;
g&eacute;e;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scoreggia,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Corium,</etym> a Hide, or Leather.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scout(n)">A Scout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escoute,</etym> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schouwt,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Scolta, Ascolta,</etym> a Spy; all <etym lang="la">ab 
auscultando,</etym> from listening.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scowl(v)">To Scowl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceol-&shy;
Eag</etym>, squint-eyed; or 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schehl, 
Schahl,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Schielen,</etym> to look 
askew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrabble(v)">To Scrabble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Krabbelen,</etym> to tear with the 
nails; also to scribble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scramble(v)">To Scramble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Screopan</etym>; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schraeffen,</etym> to scrape up; or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krabbelen,</etym> to rend 
and tear with the nails.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrape(v)">To Scrape,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Screo&shy;
pan</etym>; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schraepen;</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schrappen, 
</page> 

<page sig="X2v">
Schrapffen,</etym> id. and all <etym lang="la">&agrave; sca&shy;
bendo,</etym> from scratching, by 
interposing the Letter r. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrap(n)">Scraps</form> <xpln lang="en">of victuals left; v. <etym lang="en">Scrape</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scratch(v)">Scratch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Krat&shy;
sen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kratzen,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grater,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Grattare,</etym> the same. Minsh. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F71;&sigma;&shy;
&sigma;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scratches(n)">Scratches,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease amongst 
Horses, like the Itch in mans 
body, from the Verb, to 
<etym lang="en">scratch.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrawl(n)">Scrawls,</form> <xpln lang="en">Letters not even, nor 
uniform in writing; a con&shy;
tract of <etym lang="en">Scrabbles.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="screw(n)">A Screw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Bel <etym lang="bl">Schroeve</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schraubt,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schroeven</etym>, 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schrauben</etym>, to screw 
up; yet most likely from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escro&uuml;e,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrip(n)">A Scrip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scr&aelig;pe</etym>, 
convenient, useful.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scritch-owl(n)">Scritch Owl</form> <xpln lang="en">, (q. d) a shrieking 
Owl; see to <etym lang="en">Shriek</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrivener(n)">A Scrivener,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scri&shy;
vano,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both <etym lang="la">&agrave; scri&shy;
bendo,</etym> from writing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scroll(n)">A Scroul</form> <xpln lang="en">of paper, a depravation 
of the word <etym lang="en">Roll;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scrub(v)">To Scrub,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scre&shy;
opan</etym>, to shave; or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schrabben,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schrapiten,</etym> to scrape.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scribbled(a)">Scrubled,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Skrubbet,</etym> rough.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scud(v)">To Scud,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Schud&shy;
den, Schudderen,</etym> to be sca&shy;
red; or from the It. <etym lang="it">Squittire,</etym> 
to run away, to escape by 
flight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scuffle(n)">A Scuffle,</form> <xpln lang="en">or tumultuous rou<emend err="">w</emend> from <etym lang="en">Shuffle;</etym> by a Metaphor 
taken from Card-playing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skulk(v)">Sculk,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps a depravation of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Abscondere,</etym> to hide; 
or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schudden,</etym> 
to be frighted.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skull(n)">Scull,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) the shell of the 
head; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schedel, Schadel</etym> the same; 
see Shell and Scale.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="school(n)">A Scull,</form> <xpln lang="en">of Fishes, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceole</etym>, a shole, or 
multitude of fishes: Or per&shy;
haps from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cueil&shy;
ler,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Cogliere,</etym> to ga&shy;
ther together.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scullion(n)">A Scullion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sou&shy;
illon,</etym> the same; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Sou&iuml;ller,</etym> to soil: Or from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Culina</etym> a Kitchen; for he 
is there to give his attendance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scum(n)">Scum,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">skum;</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schaum,</etym> the Ital.
<etym lang="it">Schi&uuml;ma,</etym> or the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Escume,</etym> 
the same; all possibly from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Spuma,</etym> froth. From 
hence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escumer</etym>, to 
scumm, and <etym lang="fr">Escumoir</etym>, a 
Scummer, or Skimmer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scurf(n)">Scurf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceorfa</etym>; 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schort,</etym> id. It is 
also drawn from the Lat <etym lang="la">Scro&shy;
fa,</etym> a Sow, which is seldom 
free from it. Mer. Cas. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&rho;&phi;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, Dry&shy;
ness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scurvy(n)">Scurvy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schorf&shy;
tig,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schurbock,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scut(n)">The Scut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwy&eth;</etym>, 
</page> 

<page sig="X3r"> 
or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kutte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
from our word <etym lang="en">Cut;</etym> it being 
so short, as that part seems to 
be cut off. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scutcheon(n)">Scutcheon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scussion;</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Scuccione, 
Escuccione,</etym> the same: these 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scutum,</etym> a shield.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scuttle(n)">Scuttle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escou&shy;
tillon,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Escotilon;</etym> or 
(which is most likely) from 
the AS <etym lang="oe">Scutel</etym>, the same; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scutella,</etym> id. this 
from <etym lang="la">Scutum,</etym> a shield.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scuttle(n)">The Scuttles of a Ship,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escoutilles,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sea(n)">Sea,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sae</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">See,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Zee,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
This last Vossius draws <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F70; 
&tau;&#x1F78; &zeta;&#x1F73;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, from boiling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seal(n)">A Seal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sigel</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Seghel</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Siegel,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Seau,</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Sello,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all Contracts of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sigillum,</etym> a mark or 
Seal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seam(n)">A Seam,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seam</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">So&shy;
omen,</etym> to make a seam.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sear(v)">To Sear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Searan</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Essorer,</etym> 
to dry up; this perhaps from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Exhaurire,</etym> to draw 
out, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  the moisture. Some 
take it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zehren,</etym> 
to waste or consume; or the 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Seren,</etym> to hurt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cerecloth(n)">Sear-cloth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ser&shy;
cla&eth;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) Lat. <etym lang="la">Pan&shy;
nus ceratus;</etym> or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sar</etym>, a Sore, and <etym lang="en">Cloth;</etym> it 
being a cloth to wrap up 
sores or pained parts of the 
Body withal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="search(v)">To Search,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cer&shy;
cher;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cercare,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="season(n)">A Season,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Sai&shy;
son;</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stagione,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sayesone</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; the It. 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Statio,</etym> a station, 
to wit, of time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="season(v)">To Season,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Sazo&shy;
nar,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sasonare,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seat(n)">A Seat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seotole</etym>, 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Saede,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sitz,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sate,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">sedes, sedile,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="second(a)">Second,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Second,</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Secun&shy;
dus,</etym> id. this <etym lang="la">&agrave; sequendo,</etym> from 
following; because it imme&shy;
diately follows the first.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sedan(n)">A Sedan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sedile,</etym> 
a seat, or <etym lang="la">Sedere,</etym> to sit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sedge(n)">Sedge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Saecg</etym>; 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Seck,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="see(v)">To See,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seon</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sien,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Seer,</etym> id. or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Sie,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Siehe,</etym> see, lo, or be&shy;
hold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seed(n)">Seed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">S&aelig;d</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Saed,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Saat</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sa&shy;
tum,</etym> that which is sown.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seek(v)">To Seek,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Soeken;</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Secan</etym>, id. hence 
<etym lang="oe">Sohte</etym>, sought. Minsh. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Zeta;&eta;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
Others from our word <etym lang="en">See.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="X3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ceiling(n)">Seeling, or Cieling,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Cielo,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">C&oelig;lum;</etym> 
which, in a secondary sence, 
is taken for any high arch: 
Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Coelare,</etym> to 
carve, or garnish, according to 
Minshew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seem(v)">It Seemeth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sembler,</etym> to seem; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">si&shy;
mile esse,</etym> to be like unto: Or 
from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Zaemen,</etym> to be&shy;
come one. From hence we 
take the word Seemly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seethe(v)">To Seeth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieden,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Seo&eth;an</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Zeta;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to 
be very hot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seize(v)">To Seise</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sai&shy;
sir,</etym> to lay hold on. Salma&shy;
sius draws it from the Lat. 
Barb. <etym lang="la">Sasire,</etym> and this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Zeta;&alpha;&kappa;&kappa;&#x1F77;&zeta;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to sack, or 
ransack.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seldom(adv)">Seldom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Selden,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Selten,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Seldon</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="self(n)">Self,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Selff,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Solve,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Selb,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Silf</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sallender(n)">Sellander,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sore in the pastern-&shy;
joint of an Horse; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sel;</etym> or rather, from 
the AS, <etym lang="oe">Sealt</etym>, salt, and <etym lang="oe">Am&shy;
pre</etym>, a swelling in the legs, 
or from the Germ. <etym lang="tt">Emper,</etym> 
upward; it being a salt hu&shy;
mour, which, centring in that 
joint, causeth swelling upward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="selvage(n)">Selvage,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">Salvage,</etym> because it 
saveth (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) strengthens a gar&shy;
ment, to make it last longer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="semblance(n)">Semblance</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sem&shy;
bianza,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sem&shy;
blance,</etym> likeness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="send(v)">Send,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sendan</etym>, 
or the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sen&shy;
den,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seneschal(n)">Seneschal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Se&shy;
neschal,</etym> r the Ital. <etym lang="it">Senes&shy;
ciallo, Siniscalco,</etym> a Prince's 
Steward; originally from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sind, Gesind,</etym> a fami&shy;
ly, and <etym lang="tt">Scalt,</etym> a servant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sennight(n)">Sennight,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">Seven Nights;</etym> 
as Fortnight, q. Fourteen 
Nights.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scent(n)">A Sent,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">&agrave; Sentiendo,</etym> from per&shy;
ceiving. Write Scent, for di&shy;
stinction sake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sentiment(n)">Sentiment,</form> <xpln lang="en">ones opinion, or 
verdict; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sen&shy;
tir,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sentio,</etym> to 
judge, or suppose.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sentinel(n)">A Sentinel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sentinelle,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Senti&shy;
nella,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sentire,</etym> to perceive, 
or discern; for he is set to 
observe the approach of the 
Enemy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="serge(n)">Serge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Sarge,</etym> 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Serge,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Sargia,</etym> a cloth so called; all 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Seri&shy;
cum,</etym> silk; it being but a thin, 
subtile Stuff.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sergeant(n)">A Sergeant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sergeant,</etym> the Teut. and Sax. 
<etym lang="sx">Scherge,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sergente,</etym> 
id. all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Serviens,</etym> 
one that serveth, or waiteth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seraglio(n)">Serraglio,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Italian word, sig&shy;
nifying the Great Turk's Palace 
</page> 

<page sig="X4r"> 
where his Concubines are 
kept; from the Ital <etym lang="it">Serrare,</etym> 
to lock up: Or rather, <etym lang="en">Se&shy;
raglio,</etym> from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Serare,</etym> 
to lock up. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="servant(n)">A Servant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ser&shy;
vant,</etym> coming from <etym lang="fr">Servir;</etym> 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Servire,</etym> to 
serve.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="set(v)">Set,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Settan</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Setzen,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Setten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from hence 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Setzling</etym>, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Setten</etym>, Setts, or young 
trees planted: All from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Sedes,</etym> a seat, or place to 
sit on.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="setting dog(n)">A Setting-Dog,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cane 
Sentacchione,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from 
the Verb <etym lang="it">Sentacchiare,</etym> to set;
this from <etym lang="la">Sentare,</etym> to sit; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
A Sitting dog.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="settle(n)" lexeme="settle bed(n)">Settle, Settle-bed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Setl</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Setol</etym>, or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sessel,</etym> a seat, bench, 
or settle; and all from our 
word, To <etym lang="en">Sit.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="seven(n)">Seven,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seofen</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieben,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Seven,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Septem;</etym> this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F19;&pi;&tau;&#x1F70;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sever(v)">Sever,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sevrer,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scevrare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Separare,</etym> 
to separate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="several(a)">Several,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Separal, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Separare,</etym> to part one 
from another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sewer(n)">Sewer, Sewers,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a Com&shy;
mon-shore, or Water-course. 
Minshew saith, that it wa<emend err="">s</emend> 
formerly written Seward 
from <etym lang="en">Sea,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ward</etym>. Cowell 
draws it from our Verb, To 
<etym lang="en">Issue;</etym> as if it might be called 
Issuer; Spelman, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Suer,</etym> to sweat; or 
<etym lang="fr">Su&euml;ur,</etym> sweat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suet(n)">Sewet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Suif,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and these from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Sebum,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sexton(n)">Sexton,</form> <xpln lang="en">the word is a Deprava&shy;
tion of <etym lang="en">Sacristan,</etym> now out 
of use; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sacras,</etym> <term lang="la">viz.</term>  Res, things con&shy;
secrated to an holy use; and 
<etym lang="la">Teneo,</etym> to keep, to have in 
charge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shackle(n)">Shackles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schaeckel,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scacul</etym> 
a word found in Elfric. of 
the same signification: Or, 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schaeckelen,</etym> 
to intangle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shad(n)">A Shad:</form> <xpln lang="en">Gesner saith, that the 
Germans called it <etym lang="tt">Schad,</etym> 
which he takes from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schade,</etym> hurt, or damage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shadow(n)">Shadow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schae&shy;
duwe,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schatte,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scade</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence 
<etym lang="oe">Sceadwig</etym>, shady <etym lang="oe">Eceadewan</etym>, to over-shadow. Mer. 
Cas. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&iota;&#x1F71;&delta;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a little shadow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shaft(n)">A Shaft,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Arrow, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceaft</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schaft,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all perhaps 
from our word, To <etym lang="en">Shave,</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Sheaf;</etym> for that they are 
</page> 

<page sig="X4v"> 
bound up in bundles, in the 
form of a sheaf. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shag(n)">Shag,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceacga</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Sceacged</etym>, shaggy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shake(v)">To Shake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scea&shy;
can</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schocken,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chocquer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Quatio, 
Quasso,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shall(v)">Shall,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Scall,</etym> 
or <etym lang="hd">Sal:</etym> Or rather, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceal</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shallop(n)">A Shallop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Schaluppe,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scal&shy;
fa, Scalfo,</etym> a ship, or boat; 
so called, from the similitude 
of the fish called a <etym lang="en">Scallop.</etym> 
Minshew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shallow(a)">Shallow,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Sea Low:</etym> 
or from <etym lang="en">Shew,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Low</etym>; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) water so low, that you 
may see clearly to the bot&shy;
tom.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shambles(n)">Shambles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg.
 <etym lang="bl">Schacmel, Schemel,</etym> or the 
 AS. <etym lang="oe">Scamol</etym>, a bench, or block, 
 upon which Butchers cut their 
 meat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shame(n)">Shame,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scham,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scame</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
hence <etym lang="oe">Scamian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schaemen</etym>, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schamen</etym>, to be ashamed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shank(n)">Shank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceanc</etym>, 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Skenckel</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="chancre(n)">A Shanker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Chancre;</etym> this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Cancer.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shape(v)">To Shape,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scea&shy;
pan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schaepen,</etym> or 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Scaphon</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
these from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schaep, 
Schape,</etym> a shape, or form.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="share(v)">To Share,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scy&shy;
ran</etym>, to divide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="share(n)">Share,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Plough Share, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scear</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schaar,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from our 
word <etym lang="en">Shear,</etym> because it shea&shy;
reth, or cutteth the ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shark(n)">A Shark, or Sherk,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a shif&shy;
ting Knave; from our word 
<etym lang="en">Search:</etym> Or more immediate&shy;
ly from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chercher,</etym> 
to seek.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sharp(a)">Sharp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scearp</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Scyrpan, Ascyrpan</etym>, to make sharp: 
Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scharp,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scharpff,</etym> sharp, or 
rough.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shave(v)">To Shave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sca&shy;
fan</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Sc&aelig;fan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schaven,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scha&shy;
ben</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; all probably from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scabere,</etym> to rub, or 
scrape.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheaf(n)">A Sheaf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schoof, 
Schoove,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceaf</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shear(v)">To Shear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schee&shy;
ren, Scharen,</etym> the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scea&shy;
ran</etym>,<etym lang="oe"> Scyran</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schaeren,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shard(n)">A Sheard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Sceard</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scherb,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Scherf, Scherve,</etym> a splinter of 
wood, or a piece of a shell: 
Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escharde,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="X5r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheath(n)">Sheath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scea&eth;e, 
Sc&aelig;&eth;</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scheed,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scheide,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shed(v)">To Shed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scea&shy;
dan</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scheiden,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scheeden,</etym> to part, 
or separate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shed(n)">Shed,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a Hovel; a Contract 
of <etym lang="en">Shadow.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="she(pr)">Shee,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seo</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sii,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sie,</etym> id. and all not unlikely from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ea,</etym> she, by a Prosthesis of the letter s.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheep(n)">Sheep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceap</etym>, the 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Scaaph,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Scaep,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schaff,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>: Or perhaps from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&#x1F73;&pi;&omega;</etym>, to cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheet(n)">A Sheet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceat</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Scete</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Scyte</etym>, id. and hence, 
for similitude sake, A Sheet 
of Paper; which may, not ab&shy;
surdly, be drawn from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Scheda,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheldrake(n)">A Sheldrake,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird so called, 
perhaps because its feathers are 
partly like unto <etym lang="en">scales</etym>, and be&shy;
cause it destroyeth fishes, as a 
<etym lang="en">Dragon</etym> does other earthly 
creatures.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shell(n)">Shell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceala</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Scala</etym>, the Bel. <etym lang="bl">Schaele, Schelle,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schal, Schele,</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escaille,</etym> id. Whence 
the Verbs AS. <etym lang="oe">Scealian</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schellen</etym>, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Shahlen, Schelen</etym>, to shell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shelter(n)">A Shelter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Eng. <etym lang="en">Shell;</etym> 
for which cause it is in Latin 
called <term lang="la">Testudo</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shelving(n)">Shelving,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Bending down&shy;
ward; as also, Shelves, or 
Sands in the Sea; from our 
word <etym lang="en">Shelf;</etym> and this from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scylf</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schelf,</etym> bent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheriff(n)">Sheriff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scir-&shy;
Geref</etym>, the Grave, or An&shy;
cient of a Shire, or County. 
V. Grave, and Shire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sherry(n)">Sherry,</form> <xpln lang="en">a wine so called, because 
it was first made at <etym lang="sp">Xeres,</etym> a 
City in Spain, now called 
Granata.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="show(v)">To Shew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scea&shy;
wian</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schauwen, 
Schouwen,</etym> id. from hence 
A Shew at Fairs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="schides(n)">Schides, or Chips of wood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceadan</etym>, or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scheyden,</etym> to di&shy;
vide: Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Schi&shy;
dia,</etym> a chip of wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shield(n)">Shield,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Scild, 
Scilt,</etym> the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schild,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scyld</etym>, id. 
Hence <etym lang="oe">Scyldan, Sceoldan</etym>, 
to shield, or protect one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shift(n)">Shift,</form> <xpln lang="en">To make a Shift: Min&shy;
shew draws it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schaffen,</etym> to be a doing; but 
rather from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scyf&shy;
tan</etym>, to remove, or put away; 
as we say, To Shift off, for to 
cast any troubles upon ano&shy;
ther: And from hence the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schifft</etym>, a shifting fel&shy;
low.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shilling(n)">Shilling,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scilling</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schilling,</etym> or the 
</page> 

<page sig="X5v"> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schelling,</etym> the same; 
and all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scild</etym>, 
a shield; it being instamped 
with a shield, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the King's 
Arms. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shin(n)">Shin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scina</etym>, or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schien,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shine(v)">Shine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scinan</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scheinen</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shingle(n)">The Shingles,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease which, if 
it incircle the body, bringeth 
death; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cingu&shy;
lum,</etym> a girdle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shingle(n)">Shingles, or Schindles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schindel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scandula,</etym> 
a slate; and this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Scinden&shy;
do,</etym> from being cloven; or <etym lang="la">&agrave; &shy;
Scandendo,</etym> from climbing 
up; they being placed upon 
the house, in the form of 
steps.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ship(n)">Ship,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schip, 
Schep,</etym> the Run. Dan. <etym lang="rn">Skip,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Skib,</etym> id. and all 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scapha,</etym> 
a skiff; this from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to dig out, or to 
make hollow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shire(n)">A Shire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scir</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Scire</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="oe">Scy&shy;
ran</etym>, to share, or divide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shirt(n)">A Shirt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scyric, 
Scyrc</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schurtz,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Skiorte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shit(n)">Shite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scitan</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schiiten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shuttlecock(n)">Shittle cock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schuetein,</etym> to shake; or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceotan</etym>, to shoot, and 
<etym lang="en">Cock;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shiver(v)">To Shiver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schawern, Schaudern,</etym> to 
tremble. v. Shudder.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shiver(n)">A Shiver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schier&shy;
feren,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scheveren,</etym> 
to cut in shivers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shock(n)">A Shock of Corn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schocke,</etym> an heap; or perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schosz,</etym> a tri&shy;
bute; because every tenth 
sheaf was laid by for tythes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shoe(n)">Shooe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceo</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Sco</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sko,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schoe,</etym> or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Scu,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="schooll(n)">Shole of Fishes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sceole</etym>, or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scuolo,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Cueillir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Cogliere,</etym> 
to gather together.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shoot(v)">To Shoot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceo&shy;
tan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schieten</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schent&shy;
vry,</etym> shot-free; and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Scoten</etym>, shot off: All per&shy;
haps from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scuotere,</etym> 
or <etym lang="it">Scotere,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Excu&shy;
tere,</etym> to shake off, with a little 
variation of the sence.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shoot(n)">A Shoot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scheute,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schoz,</etym> a sapling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shop(n)">A Shop</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceoppe</etym>, 
a treasury; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schafft,</etym> an armoury, or 
<etym lang="tt">Schopff,</etym> a place to walk in; 
or <etym lang="tt">Schaffen,</etym> to work.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shore(n)">A Shore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Score</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schoore, 
Schore,</etym> earth washed up by 
the waves: Or perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scheuren,</etym> to scour.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="X6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="common shore(n)">The Common-Shore,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Depra&shy;
vation of <etym lang="en">Common-Sewer,</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="short(a)">Short,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceort</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence <etym lang="oe">Asceortian</etym>, 
to shorten: Or from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Corto,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Courte,</etym> id. 
and these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Curtus</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shotten herring(a)">Shotten Herring,</form> <xpln lang="en">such Herrings 
as have already spawn'd; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schutten,</etym> to shoot 
forth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shove(v)">To Shove,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceo&shy;
fan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schuyven,</etym> 
to thrust, or jog one. Mer. 
Cas. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to toss, or shake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shovel(n)">Shovel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scofl</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schauffel,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schoeffel,</etym> id. whence 
<etym lang="bl">Schuyffelen</etym>, to shovel up; 
and all from the word, To 
<etym lang="en">Snow;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="should(v)">Should,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceol&shy;
dan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schuld,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schoud,</etym> that which 
should, or ought to be.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shoulder(n)">Shoulder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scul&shy;
dor</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Skulder,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schouder,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schulter,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shower(n)">Shower,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scur</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Scheure,</etym> 
a breaking forth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shred(v)">To Shread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scre&shy;
dan</etym>, to cut small: Or from 
our word <etym lang="en">Shear.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrew(n)">A Shrew,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Clamorous Woman; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schreyen,</etym> to 
cry out upon; or <etym lang="tt">Beschreyen,</etym> 
to defame one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrewd(a)">Shrewd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Be&shy;
schreyen,</etym> to bewitch; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Be&shy;
wiched: Or from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Crudus,</etym> cruel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrike(n)" lexeme="shriek(n)">A Shrike, or Shriek,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Skriger,</etym> to shrick; or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schrieken,</etym> to be 
struck with terrour, or fear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrill(a)">Shrill,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schreyen,</etym> to cry aloud.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrimp(n)">Shrimp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teutonick 
<etym lang="tt">Schrump,</etym> a Cray-fih, or wrin&shy;
kle; or it is so called, from 
the similitude.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrine(n)">A Shrine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scrin</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escrin,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Scrigno,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scrinium,</etym> 
a place where relicks of Saints 
are kept.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrink(v)">To Shrink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scrin&shy;
can</etym>, to be drawn in, or made 
less: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schrucken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrivel(v)">To Shrivel,</form> <xpln lang="en">Shrivell'd, perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schrumpeln,</etym> 
to rumple: whence <etym lang="tt">Schrump, 
Schrumpel</etym>, a furrow, or 
wrinkle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shroud(n)">A Shroud,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Scrud</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Scrydan</etym>, to 
cover with a garment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shrove-tide(n)">Shrovetide,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  The time of 
Shriving; from the old word 
<etym lang="en">Shrive,</etym> signifying, to exhibit 
a Confession of sins before a 
Priest, because it immediately 
preceeds Lent; and was there&shy;
fore, by the Clergy of Rome, 
appointed to be the time for 
more general Confessions.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrub(n)">A Shrub,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scrobbe</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="X6v"> 
<etym lang="oe">Scrybe</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Strubbe, Strobbe</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shrug(v)">To Shrug,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schrec&shy;
ken,</etym> to shake: Or rather from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schroeven,</etym> to shri&shy;
vel up as a Snail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shudder(v)">To Shudder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schaudern,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schudderen,</etym> to shake; and 
this from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scuotere,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Excutere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shun(v)">Shun,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ascunian</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schewen,</etym> to avoid, or eschew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shut(v)">To Shut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Scut&shy;
tan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schutten,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="get shut(v)">To get Shut of a thing,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
To get Rid; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sceadan</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schey&shy;
den,</etym> to separate; or <etym lang="tt">Schewen,</etym> 
to shun; or <etym lang="tt">Schutten,</etym> to eject.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shuttle(n)">A Weaver's Shuttle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Schutteln</etym>, to shove, or 
shake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shy(a)">Shy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Schifo,</etym> nice; 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schow, Schowig,</etym> 
skittish; and all from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schouwen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schewen,</etym> to eschew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sice(n)">Sice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Eng.
<etym lang="en">Six;</etym> and this from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F1D;&xi;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sick(a)">Sick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seoc</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Sing,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Siech,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sicck,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. 
Jun. draws them all from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swack,</etym> weak, faint: 
Or from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&iota;&kappa;&chi;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, one 
that has lost his stomach, ac&shy;
cording to Hesychius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sickle(n)">Sickle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sicol</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sickel,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Si&shy;
chel, Sechel,</etym> id. and all from 
the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Secula,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Secando,</etym> from cut&shy;
ting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="side(n)">Side,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Side, Sid</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Seyte,</etym> or the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Siide,</etym> id. whence the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Siidelinck</etym>; with us, Sideling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="side-man(n)">Side-man,</form> <xpln lang="en">so called, because he 
stands, as it were, by the 
Church-warden's <etym lang="en">side</etym>, to as&shy;
sist.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="siege(n)">Siege,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Siege,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Assedio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sedes;</etym> as we 
say, To Sit down before a 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sift(v)">To Sift,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Siften,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sichten,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Siftan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sigh(v)">To Sigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seo&shy;
fian</etym>, to deplore, <etym lang="oe">Sciettan</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sight(n)">Sight</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gesih&eth;e</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sicht, Gesicht,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signal(n)">Signal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Segnale,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Signale,</etym> famous, 
worthy of animadversion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signet(n)">A Signet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Sig&shy;
net,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Signare,</etym> to sign, or 
seal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="signor(n)">Signiour,</form> <xpln lang="en">The Grand Signiour, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Seigneur,</etym> the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Signore,</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Sennor,</etym> Master: all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Senior,</etym> an Elder: Or, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Insignior,</etym> a man of 
more worth than others.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="X7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="silk(n)">Silk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Silcke,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seolc</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Seolcen</etym>, silken.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sill(n)">Sill,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Door-Sill, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sueil,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both 
probably from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Solum,</etym> 
the ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cilery(n)">Sillery, or Cilery,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in 
Architecture; from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">C&oelig;lare,</etym> to carve, or engrave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sillabub(n)">Sillibub:</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew surmiseth, 
that it may be called so, <term lang="la">quasi</term>
<etym lang="en">Swilling Bub.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="silly(a)">Silly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat Barb. <etym lang="la">Sil&shy;
lus;</etym> and this a Contract of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Simplex,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Sim&shy;
plus</etym> without deceit, or poli&shy;
cy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="silver(n)">Silver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Fr. 
Th. <etym lang="hd">Silver,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sil&shy;
ber,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seolfer</etym>, id. 
and all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sel</etym>, 
well, and <etym lang="oe">Feran</etym>, to have 
good success.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scimitar(n)">A Simitar, or Scimitre,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Simiterre,</etym> the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cimitarra,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Scimitarra,</etym> a Persian, or Tur&shy;
kish sword. Covarruv. draws 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cimitarra</etym>, from 
the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Scyth-Mittarra,</etym> a 
Scythick sword; because the 
Scythians first formed it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sin(n)">Sin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sinne</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Synne</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sund,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sonde. Sunde,</etym> id. 
Minsh. and Fr. Jun. draw it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to do harm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="since(c)">Since,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sint,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sind,</etym> id. Or it is a 
contract of the Eng. <etym lang="en">Sithence.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
