<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="singe(v)">To Sindge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">S&aelig;ngan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Senghen,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sengen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, to 
burn a little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sinew(n)">Sinew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sinu</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Sene,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Se&shy;
nuwe,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Senue,</etym>
 the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sing(v)">Sing.</form> <xpln lang="en">Sung, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Singhen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Singen,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Singan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: In 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sungen, Gesun&shy;
gen,</etym> sung; whence the AS. 
and Dan. <etym lang="oe">Sang</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sangh, Gesangh</etym>, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gesang</etym>, a song.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sink(v)">To Sink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sencan</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Besencan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Senc&shy;
ken,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sincken,</etym>
to fall, or sink down: From 
hence also A Sink.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sip(v)">Sip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sippen,</etym> to 
sup a little: or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sipan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sippet(n)">Sippets,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Civets,</etym> 
slices of bread sopp'd in things 
liquid: Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ci&shy;
bus,</etym> food: Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Soppers.</etym> 
v. Sop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sir(n)">Sir,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sieur, Sire,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ser, Sere,</etym> Master.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sire(n)">Sire,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Father, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sire,</etym> Master; a Father being, 
by the Law of Nature, Ma&shy;
ster of his Family.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sirrah(n)">Sirrah,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Sir ah.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="syrup(n)">Sirrop, or Syrup,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sirope,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sir&shy;
roppo,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Syru&shy;
pus,</etym> id. Or it is so called, <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&upsilon;&rho;&#x1F77;&alpha;&#x03c2; &#x1F40;&pi;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, juice of Syria.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="X7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sister(n)">Sister,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sweosten</etym>, 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Suester,</etym> the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Soster;</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Suster,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwester,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sit(v)">Sit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sittan</etym>; 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sitzen,</etym> the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Soder;</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sitten,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sedere,</etym> to sit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sith(adv)">Sith,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sit&eth;an</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sint,</etym> since that.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sith(n)">A Sithe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Si&eth;e</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sieve(n)">Sive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sibi</etym>, in 
&AElig;lfric. <etym lang="oe">Syfe</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Sib,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sef, Sefce,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; now spelt Sieve.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="six(n)">Six,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Syx</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sisse,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Sechs,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Sex,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1D;&xi;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="size(n)">Size,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Plasterers, from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Sisa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="size(n)">Size,</form> <xpln lang="en">for stature; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Assise,</etym> a Verbal of the Verb
 <etym lang="fr">Asseoir,</etym> to appoint; it being 
 the proportion of body which 
 Nature hath allowed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scissors(n)">Sizers, or Scissors</form> <xpln lang="en">rom the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Ciseaux,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tiseras, 
Tixeras;</etym> or the Ital <etym lang="it">Cesoire,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all <etym lang="la">&agrave; scindendo,</etym> 
or <etym lang="la">c&aelig;dendo,</etym> from cutting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skene(n)">Skain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">S&aelig;egene</etym>, 
a short sword; this <etym lang="la">&agrave; secando,</etym>
from cutting; or from <etym lang="la">Sica,</etym> 
a pocket-dagger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skein(n)">A Skain, of Thread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escaigne,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skate-fish(n)">A Skate-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sceadda</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Skade;</etym> or 
the It. &amp; Lat. <etym lang="la">Squatina,</etym> id. this 
<etym lang="la">&agrave; squalore,</etym> from roughness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skillet(n)">A Skellet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little pan or pot; 
possibly from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eskue&shy;
lette,</etym> a plate; this from the 
Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Scutella,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Scutula,</etym> 
a Platter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skiff(n)">A Skiff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Esquif;</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Schiffo, Schaffo;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sca&shy;
pha,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skill(n)">Skill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Skell,</etym> the 
Mind; also Reason. Minsh. 
draws it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Schola,</etym> 
a School; or <etym lang="la">Scio,</etym> to under&shy;
stand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skim(v)">To Skim</form> <xpln lang="en">over a thing, to do 
it slightly; from the old Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Sciumo,</etym> soon, quickly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skin(n)">Skin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Skind;</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schinde</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence the Teut. and Belg. 
<etym lang="tt">Schinden</etym>, to flea off the skin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skip(v)">To Skip</form> <xpln lang="en">up and down, from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Squittire,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skirmish(n)">A Skirmish</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scarmouche,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Escara&shy;
muca,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schaermutse,</etym> &shy;
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Scharmutzel,</etym> or 
the Ital <etym lang="it">Scaramuccia,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skirmish(v)">To Skirmish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scarmoucher,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Escara&shy;
musar,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Scaramucoi&shy;
are,</etym> id. Fr. Jun. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&#x1F71;&rho;&mu;&eta;</etym>, a Fight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="skittish(a)">A Skittish</form> <xpln lang="en">Horse; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Schouwt,</etym> a Scout, or Spy; 
it being an horse that will 
boggle at the least sound, or 
motion, always listning like a 
Spy. Minsh. draws it from 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&alpha;&#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to leap. Skinner 
</page> 

<page sig="X8r"> 
from <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&kappa;&iota;&rho;&tau;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to skip and 
jump about. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="screaking(n)">The Skreaking of a Saw,</form> <xpln lang="en">a de&shy;
pravation of the word <etym lang="en">Creak,</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scream out(v)">To Skream out,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hreman, Hraeman,</etym> to 
cry out; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schreyen</etym> to shriek.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="screen(n)">A Skreen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scran, Escrein,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schermen, 
Beschirmen,</etym> to defend, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
to keep off the heat of the 
fire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sky(n)">The Sky,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sky,</etym> 
a Cloud; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Scinan</etym>, to shine; or from 
<etym lang="oe">Sceawian</etym> to shew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slabby(a)">Slabby,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slabben,</etym> 
to slabber with water, to drop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slack(a)">Slack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sl&aelig;ec, 
Sleac</etym>, slow, remiss; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Aslacian</etym>, to loosen; or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slaeck</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence <etym lang="bl">Slaecken</etym>, to unty; 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Laxus,</etym> 
unbound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slam(a)">A Slam fellow,</form> <xpln lang="en">tall and skrag&shy;
ged, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slim,</etym> 
or <etym lang="bl">Slim,</etym> slender; or perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlang,</etym> a 
Snake, for the similitude.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"slam" antedates earliest OED citation (1691).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slander(n)">Slander,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
sclandre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="fr">Esclandrir</etym>, to slander; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scandalum,</etym> a 
stumbling block; or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schande,</etym> disgrace; 
whence <etym lang="tt">Schanden</etym>, to defame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slap(n)">Slap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlapp,</etym> 
a Cuff on the ear, or buffet; 
and both from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slape(a)">Slape,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old word signifying 
Slippery; from our Word, to 
<etym lang="en">Slip.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slash(v)">Slash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlagen,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slaghen,</etym> to whip, 
and both from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slate(n)">A Slate,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Slet, 
Sleet,</etym> smooth; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Slecht, Slicht,</etym> plain, even: 
The learned Th. H. draws it 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Esclates,</etym> or 
<etym lang="fr">Esclats,</etym> shivers of stones.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slave(n)">A Slave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slave, 
Slaef,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Schiavo,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Esclave;</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Esclavo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slaver(v)">Slaver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slabben, 
Slabberen,</etym> to slabber; or 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Saliva,</etym> Spittle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slaughter(v)">Slaughter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Sl&aelig;&shy;
gan, Slean,</etym> to stay; or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slachten,</etym> or Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schlachten,</etym> to kill; or <etym lang="tt">Schla&shy;
gen,</etym> to slash.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slay(n)">The Slay</form> <xpln lang="en">of a Weavers Loom; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sl&aelig;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
this not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sl&aelig;gan</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Aslean</etym>, to strike.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sled(n)">A Sled,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Sledge, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sledde, Slidde,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlitte;</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Slede,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the word to <etym lang="en">Slide.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sleep(v)">To Sleep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sl&aelig;pan</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Slapan</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlaf&shy;
fen;</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slaepen</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sleeve(n)">Sleeve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slief, 
</page> 

<page sig="X8v"> 
Slyf, Slyfa</etym>; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sloeve,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sleeveless(a)">Sleeveless</form> <xpln lang="en">Errand, q. d. a <etym lang="en">Live&shy;
less,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Lifeless Errand.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slender(a)">Slender,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slinder</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from our word 
<etym lang="en">Slim.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slice(n)">A Slice,</form> <xpln lang="en">as of bread; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Slite</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Slitan</etym>, to cut, or slice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slick(a)">Slick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slicht, 
Sleyck,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlicht, 
Schlecht;</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Slet,</etym> 
mooth: Whence the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Slichten</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlichten</etym>; 
and the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Slihten</etym>, to 
make slick, or smooth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slide(v)">Slide,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slidan</etym>; 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slidden,</etym> to slip.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sleight(n)">Slight,</form> <xpln lang="en">as the slight of hand, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlaw,</etym> cun&shy;
ning; or from our word 
<etym lang="en">Light</etym>, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) lightness, or 
agility of hand; or from the 
Engl. word <etym lang="en">Sly;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slight(a)">Slight,</form> <xpln lang="en">for course, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slicht, Slecht,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlecht,</etym> plain, unpo&shy;
lished, as we say of ordinary 
things, This is Plain Stuff.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slim(a)">Slim</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlimm;</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slim,</etym> naughty, 
vile; for such a disproporti&shy;
oned stature is held a bad sign 
in Astrology.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slime(n)">Slime,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slim</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sliim,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schleim,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Limus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sling(n)">Sling,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Slynge,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slinghe,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlinge,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slinghen</etym>, and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schlingen</etym>, to sling a stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slink(v)">Slink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slincan</etym>, 
to creep out of the way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slip(v)">Slip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slippan</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Slupan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slippen, 
Slibberen,</etym> or the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Sliafan,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; in the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Slipperud;</etym> from whence we 
have our word Slippery.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slipper(n)">Slipper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slip&shy;
per</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; from <etym lang="en">Slipping</etym> 
off and on, according to 
Minsh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slit(v)">To Slit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Slitder,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slitan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
<etym lang="oe">Slite, Geslite</etym>, a Slit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sliver(v)">To Sliver, or Slive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Slifan</etym>, to cleave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sloe(n)">A Sloe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sla, 
Slae</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlehe,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slee</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sloe-worm(n)">Sloe-worm,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) a <etym lang="en">Slow 
worm;</etym> or a worm that most&shy;
ly abides amongst Sloe-trees, 
according to Minsh. Or, (q.
d.) <etym lang="en">Slay-worm,</etym> from its ve&shy;
nomous nature.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"sloe-worm" antedates earliest OED citation (1753).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slop(v)" lexeme="slap up(v)">To Slop, or Slap up,</form> <xpln lang="en">either 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlurpfen,</etym>
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from our word, to 
<etym lang="en">Lap;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slope(n)">Slope, or Sloping,</form> <xpln lang="en">not unlike&shy;
ly from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slap,</etym> loose, 
slack, as a rope not fast tied.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slop(n)">Slops,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sciloppi;</etym> 
and both corrupted, from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Syrupi,</etym> Syrups.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slops(n)">Slops,</form> <xpln lang="en">Country-mens hose, Gallygaskins, 
</page> 

<page sig="Y1r"> 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slobbe,</etym> a great Shooe; or 
from <etym lang="bl">Slap,</etym> loose. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sloth(n)">Sloth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schoolsz,</etym> 
negligent; or from our word 
<etym lang="en">Slow,</etym> and ought rather to 
be writ Slowth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slot(v)">To Slot a door,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schliessen</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sluy&shy;
ten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; to bolt the door.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slotter(v)" lexeme="slatter(v)">Slotter, or Slatter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schloosz,</etym> inconside&shy;
rate, careless; or <etym lang="tt">Schlotter,</etym> 
remiss; or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Slodde, Sloore,</etym> a sluttish 
woman: See Slut.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sloven(a)">Sloven,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sloef,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slough(n)">Slough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slog</etym>, 
or from <etym lang="oe">Luh</etym>, id. a hollow 
place full of water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slow(a)">Slow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slap</etym>; or 
the Dan <etym lang="da">Sloff,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slouch(n)">Slowch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sloff,</etym> 
dull to understand; or from 
<etym lang="da">Slung,</etym> or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlanch,</etym> 
a gluttonous Sot; or from 
<etym lang="tt">Schlausz,</etym> a Sluggard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slubber(v)">To Slubber</form> <xpln lang="en">over, or to do slight&shy;
ly; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlupf&shy;
fen,</etym> to slip, to mistake of&shy;
ten.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sluice(n)">Sluce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sluyse,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schleuse,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Escluse;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sclusa,</etym> 
a Flood-gate, that excludes 
the water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sluggard(n)">Sluggard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lug&shy;
ghen,</etym> to do things awkardly; or 
from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Slung,</etym> a gree&shy;
dy fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slumber(v)">Slumber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slume&shy;
ran</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sluymeren,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schlummeren,</etym> 
to be half asleep; and all per&shy;
haps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Somniare,</etym> 
to dream, by an interposition 
of the Letter l.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slur(v)">To Slur, or blot with Ink,</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
haps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sloore, 
Soorken,</etym> a Slut; whence 
<etym lang="bl">Slooren, Sleuren</etym>, to slotter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="slut(n)">Slut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slodde,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both not unlikely 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Lutum,</etym> Dirt; 
a foul and filthy woman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sly(a)">Sly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Slidan</etym>, to 
slide, or slip out of; or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Slicht,</etym> plain; 
for that most sly men pretend 
to a great deal of plain-dealing 
and sincerity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smack(n)" lexeme="smatch(n)">A Smack, or Smatch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sm&aelig;c</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Smaeck,</etym> or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schmack,</etym> 
a Taste; hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smac&shy;
can</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smaecken</etym>, and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schmacken</etym>, to have 
a smatch or taste.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smack(n)">Smack,</form> <xpln lang="en">a squeezing kiss; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schmatz</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="small(a)">Small,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smael</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Smale,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smael, 
Small;</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schmal,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smart(v)">Smart,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smeor&shy;
tan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smerten</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the Belg. and 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Smerte</etym>, the smarting of 
a wound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smatter(n)">Smatter,</form> <xpln lang="en">he that has a smat&shy;
tering in Learning; from 
</page> 

<page sig="Y1v"> 
the word <etym lang="en">Smatch,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Smack</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that has a smatch or 
taste of Learning. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smear(v)">To Smear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sme&shy;
ran</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schmuren,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bosmetren, Smee&shy;
ren,</etym> id. to besmear; and this 
Fr. Jun. draws from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F7B;&rho;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, Ointment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smell(n)">Smell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg, <etym lang="bl">Smoel, 
Smul,</etym> warm; for every smell 
causes more or less heat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smelt(n)">Smelt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Smelt</etym>, a Fish so called from 
its pleasant smell or relish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smile(v)">To Smile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smny&shy;
len,</etym> or Dan. <etym lang="da">Smiler,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smite(v)">To Smite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smitt&shy;
en,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schmelssen</etym>, 
id. Fr. Jun. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&mu;&#x1FF6;&xi;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, which from Eu&shy;
stathius is translated <term lang="la">percute&shy;
re</term>, to strike or smite.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smith(n)">A Smith</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smi&eth;</etym>, &shy;
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smed, Smid,</etym> id. 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smi&eth;ian</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smeden</etym>, and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schmiden</etym>, to beat upon a 
Smith's forge; and all from 
the Verb to <etym lang="en">Smite.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smock(n)">Smock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smoc</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smoke(n)">Smoke,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smoca</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Smic</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sindock,</etym> id. 
Whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Smocian</etym>, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smooken, Smucken</etym>, 
to smoke. Fr. Jun. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&mu;&#x1F7B;&chi;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to in&shy;
flame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smooth(a)">Smooth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Smae&eth;e</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Smae&eth;ian</etym>, 
to make smooth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smother(v)">Smother,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Smoo&shy;
ren,</etym> to choke, or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Smorod</etym>, stifled.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smug(a)">Smug,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Emicre</etym>, 
neat or clean: Or perhaps 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&mu;&#x1F75;&chi;&omega;</etym>, to wipe 
or make clean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="smut(v)">Smut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Besmitan</etym>, 
or Belg <etym lang="bl">Besmetten,</etym> to make 
smutty; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schmutzen,</etym> to make foul; 
hence <etym lang="tt">Schmutz</etym>, filthiness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snaffle(n)">A Snaffle,</form> <xpln lang="en">or bit for an horse, 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Suavel, Sne&shy;
vel,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schnabel,</etym> 
a snout, or nose, over which 
it is put.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snail(n)">Snail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Snegel,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schneck,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Snaegl</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
<etym lang="oe">Snican</etym>, to creep softly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snake(n)">A Snake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snake,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Snaca</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Snican</etym>, to creep 
softly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snap(v)">To Snap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snap&shy;
pen, Knappen,</etym> to catch at; or 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schnappen,</etym> 
to snatch up with the mouth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snap(v)">To Snap with ones finger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">mit den flugern 
knacken,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snare(n)">A Snare,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snare,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schnur</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
<etym lang="tt">Schnuren,</etym> to tie fast with a 
rope.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snarl(v)">To Snarl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schnurren,</etym> to grin like a dog; 
or <etym lang="tt">Snarchen,</etym> to snort; and 
all from the found.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snatch(v)">Snatch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snoec&shy;
ken,</etym> to cut off; or from 
</page> 

<page sig="Y2r"> 
<etym lang="bl">Snappen,</etym> to snap. Spelman 
draws it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schach,</etym> Felony, or Rapine. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sneak(v)">To Sneak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sni&shy;
can</etym>, id. to get privately out of 
harms way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sneeze(v)" lexeme="neeze(v)">Sneeze, or Neeze,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Niesan</etym>, or the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Niesen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snip(n)">Snip, to go 
Snips,</form> <xpln lang="en">for to go 
halfs, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snip&shy;
pen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Schnitzen,</etym> to cut, or 
divide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snipe(n)">A Snipe, or Snite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Snite</etym>, a bird so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snite(v)">To Snite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schneutzen,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snutten, 
Snotten,</etym> to clean the nose of 
Snot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snithe(a)">A Snithe-wind,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="pe">Sni&eth;an</etym>, the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Sut&shy;
than,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schneiden,</etym> 
to cut; as we say, a sharp 
cutting wind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snort(v)">To Snort,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Snore, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snorcken,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Snorchen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snot(n)">Snot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Snote</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snot,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schnott,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&omicron;&tau;&#x1F76;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
Moisture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snout(n)">Snout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snuyte,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schnautze,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snow(n)">Snow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Snaw</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Snee,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schnee,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sneeuw,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Neve,</etym> or Lat. <etym lang="la">Nive.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snow(v)">To Snow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sna&shy;
wan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sneeuwen,</etym> or 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schneen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snub(v)">To Snub</form> <xpln lang="en">one, from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Neffve,</etym> a fist; or the Teut, 
<etym lang="tt">Knuebel,</etym> a knuckle; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
threaten, by holding up the 
fist doubled at one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snub(v)" lexeme="sob(v)">To Snub, or sob,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Snoffen, Snuffen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Snoe&shy;
ven,</etym> to sigh bitterly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snudge(n)">Snudge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sniger</etym> 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Snican</etym>, to 
creep, or sneak up and down.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snuff(n)">Snuff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snuf, 
Snof,</etym> the Snuff of a Candle. 
See Snuffle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snuffle(v)">To Snuffle</form> <xpln lang="en">in the nose, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Snoeve,</etym> a respiration; 
whence <etym lang="bl">Snoeven</etym>, to snivel; 
or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schnau&shy;
ben, Schniben</etym>, to puff; all 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snuffle(n)">Snuffle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Snofl</etym>, 
snot; whence <etym lang="oe">Sniflung</etym>, 
snivling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="so(adv)">So,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swa</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Soo,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">So,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sore hawk(n)">A Soar Hawk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">un Faulcon sar,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Essorer,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sorare</etym>, to Soar, to 
fly aloft.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sob(v)">Sob,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seofian</etym>, 
to lament; or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sobben, Sobbelen,</etym> to faulter 
in speaking.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="socket(n)">The Socket of a Candlestick,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Souohette,</etym> 
the hollow trunk of a Tree; 
</page> 

<page sig="Y2v"> 
From hence the Sockets of 
the teeth. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sock(n)">Socks,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Socci</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sod(n)">A Sod,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sode, 
Soode,</etym> a thick Turf; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">solida terra</etym>, solid or firm 
earth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sodder(v)">To Sodder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sou&shy;
der,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Saldare,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Souderen,</etym> to cement; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Solidare,</etym> 
to make firm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soft(a)">Soft,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Soft</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Saufft,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Saft, Saeft,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sojourn(v)">To Sojourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sojourner,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Soggi&shy;
ornare;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Sub&shy;
diurnare,</etym> to stay abroad for 
some time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soak(v)">To Soke,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Socian</etym>, 
to macerate, or make tender; 
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Succus,</etym>
 Juice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="solace(v)">To Solace,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sola&shy;
cer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Solazzare,</etym> to
comfort; and these from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Solatium,</etym> consolation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soldan(n)" lexeme="sultan(n)">Soldan, or Sultan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Souldan, Sultan,</etym> the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Sultano,</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Soldan,</etym> a King or Governor; 
also, Dominion or Power, as 
Covarruv. saith; who draws 
this last from the Heb. <etym lang="he">Silton,</etym> 
a Principality.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="some(su)">Som,</form> <xpln lang="en">a termination denoting 
some quality, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Som</etym>, or the Eng. <etym lang="en">Some;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
having somewhat of such a 
quality.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="some(pr)">Some,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Som, Sume, 
Sum</etym>, some body; <etym lang="oe">Sum&eth;ing</etym>, 
something. Merc. Cas. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&#x1FF6;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, a Body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="son(n)">A Son,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Suna</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sone</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sohn,</etym> 
or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Sun,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sonnet(n)">A Sonnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Son&shy;
net,</etym> or the It <etym lang="it">Sonnetto,</etym> a short 
song; all <etym lang="la">&agrave; sonitu,</etym> from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soon(adv)">Soon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sona</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soot(n)">Soot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sot, Soote,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both not unlikely 
from the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Si&shy;
eden,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seodan</etym>, 
to seeth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sooth(v)">To Sooth one,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Geso&eth;ian</etym>, to flatter, or 
humour one; this from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">So&eth;</etym>, true; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to take 
all that one saith, for true, as 
Parasites craftily do.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soothsayer(n)">Soothsayer,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a Diviner, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">So&eth;</etym>, true, and <etym lang="en">Say</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that saith what's 
true; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Truth-sayer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sop(n)">Sop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Soppe,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Soupe,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Soppa,</etym> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Sopa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Supan</etym>, to sup.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soap(n)">Sope,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sape</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Sabe,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Seepe,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Seiff;</etym> id. whence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sapan</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="oe">Se&shy;
iffen</etym>, and the Belg. <etym lang="oe">Seepen</etym>, 
to dawb with sope; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sapo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this <etym lang="la">ex 
Sapore,</etym> from the smell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sorcerer(n)">Sorcerer,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Sorcery, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sorcier,</etym> a Magici&shy;
an; <etym lang="fr">Sorciere,</etym> a Witch; and 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sortire,</etym> to 
cast lots.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Y3r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sore(a)">Sore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swaer,</etym> &shy;
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwer,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Swaer, Swar</etym>, id. grievous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sore(n)">A Sore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sore,</etym> 
the Run. Dan. <etym lang="rn">Sar,</etym> or the 
Dan <etym lang="da">Saar,</etym> a wound, or ulcer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sorrel(n)">Sorrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">an herb; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sorel, Surelle,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from our word <etym lang="en">Sowre.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sorrow(n)">Sorrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Sorry, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sar</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sor&shy;
rig,</etym> id. hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sarian, 
Besargian</etym>, to be sorrowful: 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sorge</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sorg,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sorghe,</etym> sorrow, or care.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sort(n)">Sort,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. or Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Sorte,</etym> a kind; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sors:</etym> And from 
hence the Ital. <etym lang="it">Assortare</etym>, to 
sort; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to divide into di&shy;
stinct parcels.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sot(n)">Sot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and F. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Sot,</etym> a Fool, or very stupid 
fellow. Menag. draws it from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stolto,</etym> striking out 
t and l. Skinner draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&sigma;&omega;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a glut&shy;
tonous person; as we say, 
a Drunken Sot.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sovereign(n)">Soveraign,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sou&shy;
verain,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sovrano, 
Soprano,</etym> he that is placed 
<etym lang="la">supra omnes,</etym> above all.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soul(n)">Soul,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sawl, 
Sawul</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Siel,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Siele,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Seele,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soldier(n)">Souldier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sol&shy;
dat,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Soldato;</etym> or the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Soldado,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Souldoyer</etym>, and It. 
<etym lang="it">Assoldare</etym>, to make one a Soul&shy;
dier in pay; and all from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Soldo,</etym> a Shilling; for 
that's the Money commonly 
given a Souldier when his 
Name is entred into the list.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sound(a)">Sound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Sund</etym>; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Shesond,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sesuud,</etym> firm, 
whole or safe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sound(n)">A Sound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Son,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Sonus,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sound(v)">To Sound</form> <xpln lang="en">the depth of water, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sonder,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
<etym lang="fr">Sonde</etym>, a sounding Line.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="source(n)">Source,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Source,</etym> 
a Fountain, whose waters <term lang="oe">sur&shy;
sum surgunt</term>, spring up 
aloft.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sour(a)">Soure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Sur</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Suer, 
Soer,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Seure,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sawer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Surigan, 
Asurigan</etym>, to grow soure 
or tart.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="south(n)">The South,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Suyd,</etym> the Teut. Fr. G. and It. 
<etym lang="it">Sud,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Su&eth;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sow(n)">A Sow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sugu</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Saw,</etym> or the Belg.
 <etym lang="bl">Soegh,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Souwe,</etym> id. which 
 come all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sus,</etym> 
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from the Gr. 
 <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to sacrifice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sow(v)">To Sow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sawan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Saeden, Saeyen;</etym>
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Saen,</etym> to sow 
</page> 

<page sig="Y3v"> 
seed; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sero,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sew(v)">To Sow, or Sew, a Garment,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Syer,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Siewan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Suo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="souse(v)" lexeme="pickle(v)">Sowse, or Pickle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Salsum,</etym> that which is salt or 
briny.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soil(n)">Soyl for ground,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital.
 <etym lang="it">Sogliare,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Souil&shy;
 ler,</etym> to sully.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soil(n)">A Soyl,</form> <xpln lang="en">as A fat Soyl, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Solum,</etym> land, or soil.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="soil(v)">To Soyl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Souil&shy;
ler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sogliare,</etym> to 
make foul; these from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Solum,</etym> earth; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
bespatter with clay. Mena&shy;
gius draws it from the word 
<etym lang="la">Suillare,</etym> to play the Sow. 
Write Soil.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spade(n)">A Spade,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spadu</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spate,</etym> or the Dan.
 and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spade,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spall(n)">Spalls,</form> <xpln lang="en">chips of wood; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spalten,</etym> to split.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="span(n)">A Span,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Span</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espan,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Spanna,</etym> or the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spanne,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
all from the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Spannen,</etym> to extend, or stretch 
forth; and this Martin. de&shy;
rives from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Expande&shy;
re,</etym> to spread out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spangle(n)">A Spangle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Spanghe,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spang, 
Spange,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spaniel(n)">Spaniel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Epag&shy;
neul,</etym> or <etym lang="sp">Espaignol,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Canis Hispanicus,</etym> 
a Spanish Dog; because the 
best of that kind are bred in 
Spain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spar(n)">The Spar</form> <xpln lang="en">of a Door, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sparre, Sperre,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sparr,</etym> a bar, or bolt; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sparran</etym>, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sperren, Em&shy;
sperren</etym> to spar, or bolt a door.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sparable(n)">Sparables,</form> <xpln lang="en">little iron nails; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Sparrow bills,</etym> for the simi&shy;
litude: Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spar&shy;
ran</etym>, to spar, or shut up, and 
the productive Term. <etym lang="en">able.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spare(v)">To Spare,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spa&shy;
rian</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espargner,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sparagnare,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spaeren,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Parcere,</etym> to spare.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sparkle(v)" lexeme="spark(v)">Sparkle, and Spark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sp&aelig;rc</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Spaercke, Sparcke,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence <etym lang="bl">Sparckelen</etym>, to spar&shy;
kle. From hence the word 
following, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sparkle(v)">To Sparkle,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Wine, or Cyder, 
when filled out. Skinner 
draws it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spar&shy;
teln,</etym> to move upward hastily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sparrow(n)">A Sparrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Spearwa</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sper&shy;
ling,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Spurre,</etym> id. 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Passer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spar(n)">Spars, for an House,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sperren,</etym> to stretch 
forth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spatter(v)">To Spatter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sp&aelig;&shy;
tlian</etym>, to slabber. V. Spit.</xpln></wordentry>
</page> 
 
 <page sig="Y4r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spattle(n)">A Spattle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Spato&shy;
la, Spatella,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Spa&shy;
thula,</etym> a slice wherewith Chi&shy;
rurgeons spread their pla&shy;
sters.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spavin(n)">A Spavain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
spavent, Espervain,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Spavano,</etym> a disease among 
Horses.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spawn(n)">Spawn of fishes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Spene, Spenne,</etym> breast-milk; 
for the similitude: Or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spana</etym>, a pap, or nip&shy;
ple.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="speak(v)">To Speak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sp&aelig;can, 
Spr&aelig;can</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spreken,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sprechen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
Whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sp&aelig;ce</etym>, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spraach</etym>, a speech. 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&pi;&omega;</etym>, to speak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spear(n)">A Spear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Speare</etym>, 
in &AElig;lfricus, <etym lang="oe">Spere</etym>, or the &shy;
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spehr, Speer,</etym> id. or 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sparus,</etym> 
a dart. Fr. Jun. draws it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&pi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to 
brandish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="speck(n)">A Speck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Specce</etym>, 
a spot; from hence the Dimi&shy;
nutive Speckle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="special(a)">Special,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Specialis,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spectacles(n)">Spectacles,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">&agrave; Spectando,</etym> from 
looking, or seeing through.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="speed(n)" lexeme="good speed(n)">Speed, as Good Speed;</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sped</etym>, a progression; 
whence <etym lang="oe">Spedian</etym>, to grow 
rich, or happy: Or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spoed,</etym> haste; whence 
<etym lang="bl">Spoeden</etym>, to make haste; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Expedire,</etym> to 
dispatch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spell(v)">To Spell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spel&shy;
len:</etym> Or from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
speler,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all, not un&shy;
likely, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spel</etym>, an 
history, or speech.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spend(v)">To Spend,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spen&shy;
dan, Aspendan</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Spenden,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Spendere,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Despendre,</etym> id. 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Dispen&shy;
dere,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Expendere,</etym> to lay 
out money.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sperage(n)" lexeme="asparagus(n)">Sperage, or Asparagus,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sparge, Spargen,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Asperge,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">A&shy;
sparagus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spew(v)">To Spew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spiwan</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Speyen,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Spouwen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Spuo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spice(n)">Spice,</form> <xpln lang="en">He has a Spice of it; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espece,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Species,</etym> a species, or kind 
of things; and from hence al&shy;
so the plural word Spices.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spider(n)">Spider,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Spinder, or Spin&shy;
ner, from our word <etym lang="en">Spin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spill(v)">To Spill,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Spoil, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Spillan</etym>, or the Belg <etym lang="bl">Spil&shy;
len,</etym> to waste. V, Spoil.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spin(v)">To Spin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spinnan</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Spinder,</etym> or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="bl"></etym><etym lang="tt">Spinnen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
Mer. Cas. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&pi;&alpha;&theta;&#x1FB6;&nu;</etym>, to weave. I 
should chuse rather to take it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&pi;&#x1FB7;&nu;</etym>, to draw 
out.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Y4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spin out(v)">To Spin out,</form> <xpln lang="en">as water out of a 
fountain; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Spin&shy;
gere, Spingersi,</etym> to break out 
violently.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spinach(n)">Spinage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spina&shy;
gie,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Spinacchia,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Spinachia,</etym> the 
same; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Spinata her&shy;
ba,</etym> a prickly, or acuminated 
herb.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spindle(n)">Spindle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spindel</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Spindl</etym>, id. and all from 
our word <etym lang="en">Spin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spink(n)">Spink,</form> <xpln lang="en">a bird by some so cal&shy;
led; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Spinus,</etym> 
a Sisken, a bird that sings 
<etym lang="la">inter Spinas,</etym> among Sloe&shy;
trees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spinner(n)">A Spinner,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spinne,</etym> a little Spi&shy;
der; and both from our word 
<etym lang="en">Spin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spire(n)">A Spire</form> <xpln lang="en">of a Steeple: Minsh. 
draws it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spy&shy;
rian</etym>; with us, to spy: O&shy;
thers, from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Spira,</etym> a 
sharp topp'd Tower; and this 
we have from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pyra,</etym> a <emend err="a"></emend> funeral-pile, for the simili&shy;
tude.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spit(n)">A Spit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spitu</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spit, Spet,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="tt">Spedo, Spiedo,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Spetto,</etym> id. 
Or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spitz,</etym> a 
point.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spit(v)">To Spit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sp&aelig;tan</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sputzen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Pi;&tau;&#x1F79;&omega;</etym>, to spit, s being added; 
or from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spite(n)">Spite,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spiit,</etym> 
hatred; whence <etym lang="bl">Spiiten</etym>, to 
hate, to have a spite against 
one; and both Contracts of 
<etym lang="en">Despite;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spit-fish(n)">Spit-fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Spetto,</etym> id. 
a fish so called, from the simi&shy;
litude of a spit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spitter(n)">A Spitter,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Hart of two years 
old, from our word <etym lang="en">Spit;</etym> for 
at that age his horns, not yet 
knagg'd, stand streight forth, 
like the end of a spit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spittle(n)">Spittle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">Hospital;</etym> 
which see in its place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="splatch(n)">A Splatch of dirt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Specce</etym>, a spot, or speck; by 
an Epenthesis of the letter l.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="splay(a)" lexeme="splay foot(n)">Splay, as Splay-foot;</form> <xpln lang="en">either 
from <etym lang="gk">Plautus</etym> the Comedian, 
having feet wonderfully dis&shy;
torted; or from our word 
<etym lang="en">Display,</etym> to spread out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="splinter(n)">Splinter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Splin&shy;
ter,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Splind,</etym> id. 
whence Splinteren, to cut in 
splinters; and all from our 
Verb, To <etym lang="en">Split.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="splint(n)">Splint,</form> <xpln lang="en">a disease in Horses; from 
the preceding word <etym lang="en">Splinter,</etym> 
because of its hardness, and 
painful pricks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="split(v)">To Split,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Split&shy;
ten, Splitten, Spletten,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spalten,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Splitter,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spoke(n)">Spokes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spacan</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Speyche,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Spighe della Rota,</etym> the 
spoaks of a wheel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spool(n)" lexeme="spooling-wheel(n)">Spole, and from thence The 
Spoling Wheel;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spoelen,</etym> to wind on 
</page> 

<page sig="Y5r"> 
such a wheel; or <etym lang="bl">Spoele,</etym> a 
clew of thread; and from 
hence the word Spoel-worm, 
being a worm in Man's body,
 in form like a spole of thread. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sport(n)">Sport,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Diporto,</etym> or 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Deport,</etym> pass-time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spot(n)">Spot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spott,</etym> 
disgrace, ignominy; as we use 
the phrase, A Blot, or Spot, 
in his Escutcheon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spouse(n)">Spouse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espouse,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sposa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sponsa,</etym> a 
Bride; and this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Spondendo,</etym> 
from betrothing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spout(n)">A Spout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Sprutze,</etym> the same; whence 
<etym lang="tt">Sprutzen</etym>, to sprinkle: Or 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spuyte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence <etym lang="bl">Spuyten</etym>, to spout, or 
spin out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sprat(n)">A Sprat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sprot,</etym> a fish so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sprawl(v)">To Sprawl,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Prea&ucirc;,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sprieel,</etym> a grass-plat; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to tumble, as it were, 
wantonly upon the grass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spread(v)">Spread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sprei&shy;
ten,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Spraeder,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spreeden, Spreyden,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sprig(n)">A Sprig,</form> <xpln lang="en">or young branch, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spric</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spring(n)">A Spring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spring</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sprung,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Springh</etym>, id. whence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Spryngan</etym>, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Springhen</etym>, id. From hence, 
The Spring-time. To Spring 
a Mine; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">eine mine Sprengen</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="springal(n)">A Springal, or brisk Youth;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from our word <etym lang="en">Spring,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
A Sprigg of a Man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sprinkle(v)">To Sprinkle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Sprengen,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sprinckelen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Sprenghen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Some draw it from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Besprenger,</etym> to dash, 
or bespatter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sprout(n)">Sprout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spryt&shy;
tan</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Sprutan</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Sprossen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sprot&shy;
ten, Spruyten,</etym> to spring forth 
in stalks and sprigs; whence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sprote</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sprosz</etym>, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spruyte</etym>, 
a branch of a tree, or 
plant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spruce(a)">Spruce,</form> <xpln lang="en">fine, gallant; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Preux,</etym> dexterous, or 
nimble; and this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Probatus,</etym> one approved 
of, or well liked.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spur(n)">Spur,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spora</etym>, 
the Dan. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spore,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spohr,</etym> id. whence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sporen</etym>, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Spohren</etym>, to spur an 
Horse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spurn(v)">To Spurn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Spor&shy;
nan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; also to contemn. 
v. Spur.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spurt(v)">To Spurt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sprutte</etym> 
a spout; or <etym lang="bl">Spruyten,</etym> to spring 
upward. V. Squirt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="spy(v)">To Spy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espier,</etym> the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Spiare,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Espiar,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Spien,</etym> to spy; whence 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espie, Espion</etym>, the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Spia</etym>, and the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Espia, 
Espion</etym>, a Spy, or Scout.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Y5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squadron(n)">A Squadron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Squadron, Escadron,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Squadrone,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Quadrata 
Acies,</etym> an Army drawn up in 
square form.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squall(v)" lexeme="squeal out(v)">To Squall, or Squeal out,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Skellan,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schallen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squander(v)">To Squander,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Spandere,</etym> to spend: Or from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Espandre,</etym> to waste 
riotously; and both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Expandere,</etym> to display.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="square(n)">Square,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Carr&egrave;,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="fr">Carrer, Qua&shy;
drer,</etym> or the Ital. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Qua&shy;
drare,</etym> to make square.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="square(n)">A Square for Carpenters,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Esquierre,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Squadra,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Quadra,</etym> a 
square trencher.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squat down(v)">To Squat down,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Quatto, Chiatto,</etym> flat upon 
the ground; these from the 
Verbs <etym lang="it">Quattare,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Chiattare,</etym> 
to fall flat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squeak(v)">Squeak</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Quac&shy;
ken, Queken,</etym> to quake like a 
Duck: Or from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Squittire,</etym> to squeak like a 
Parrot; all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squeamish(a)">Squeamish,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Qualmish, V. 
<etym lang="en">Qualm:</etym> Or from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Vaemmis,</etym> to loath, or to be 
ready to vomit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squeeze(v)">To Squeese,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cwy&shy;
san</etym>, or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Schizzare,</etym> 
or <etym lang="it">Scassiare, Squacciare,</etym> to 
press; and this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Quassare,</etym> to bruise; or <etym lang="la">Cas&shy;
sare,</etym> to make void, or empty 
(to wit) of juice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squib(n)">Squibs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schie&shy;
ben,</etym> to cast forth, or throw.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squint(v)">Squint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&iota;&sigma;&chi;&upsilon;&nu;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>; 
for that Squint-eyes cause 
shame, and are a bad sign in 
Physiognomy: Or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Scendan</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schenden, Schanden,</etym> to scan&shy;
dalize.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squire(n)">A Squire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scuyer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scudiere, 
Scudiero,</etym> id. and these from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Escu,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Scu&shy;
do,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Scutum,</etym> a shield.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squirrel(n)">A Squirrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
scurieu,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Schiriuo&shy;
lo, Sciurro,</etym> id. and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sciurus;</etym> and this 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&pi;&#x1F78; &tau;&#x1F78; &sigma;&kappa;&iota;&#x1FB6;&#x03c2; &tau;&#x1F78; &omicron;&#x1F50;&rho;&#x1FB6;&#x03c2;</etym>, from the 
shadow of its tail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="squirt(v)">To Squirt,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <etym lang="en">Spirt.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stab(v)">To Stab,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sta&shy;
ven,</etym> to thrust in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stack(n)">A Stack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stacca, 
Staccia,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stock 
Hew,</etym> a stack of Hay: Or 
from the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stecken,</etym> to stick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="staff(n)">Staff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">St&aelig;f</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Staf,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sab,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&beta;&omega;</etym>, to walk.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stag(n)">Stag,</form> <xpln lang="en">Minshew takes it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&beta;&omega;</etym>, to walk; tho 
more likely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sti&shy;
can</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stecken,</etym> 
to push; for that his horns 
are adapted thereto.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stage(n)">Stage:</form> <xpln lang="en">Some draw it from the 
</page> 

<page sig="Y6r"> 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estage,</etym> the planking, 
or laying a floor: Others, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stigan</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Steigen,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Steeghen, Stiighen,</etym> to go 
up. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stage(n)">Stage,</form> <xpln lang="en">as A Stage-Coach, 
wherein we are carried a jour&shy;
ney, limited for each day; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Statio,</etym> a sta&shy;
tion, or standing place, to 
wit, for the Coach.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stag-fly(n)">Stag-Fly,</form> <xpln lang="en">having this name from 
the similitude of its horns to 
those of a <etym lang="en">Stag</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stagger(v)">To Stagger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Staggeren,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from hence 
also The Staggers, a disease 
among Horses.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stain(v)">To Stain,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Distain, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Desteindre</etym>, id. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Distingere,</etym> to undye, or 
spoil the colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stainand(a)">A Stainand colour,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in 
Heraldry; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A <etym lang="en">Stai&shy;
ning colour,</etym> disgracing Nobi&shy;
lity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stair(n)">A Stair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">St&aelig;&shy;
ger</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stegher</etym>,
