<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sti&shy;
gan</etym>, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Steeg&shy;
hen, Stegghen,</etym> to ascend by 
steps.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stake(n)">A Stake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Esta&shy;
ca,</etym> a wooden stake; and both 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stecken,</etym> to 
stick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stake(n)">A Stake, or Wager,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
word To <etym lang="en">Stick;</etym> it being pub&shy;
lickly stuck up, for the Win&shy;
ner's reward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stale(a)">Stale Liquors,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from 
the word <etym lang="en">Stale,</etym> for Urine; 
but rather from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Stel,</etym> old.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stale(v)">To Stale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stal&shy;
len,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stalen,</etym> to 
piss; whence <etym lang="bl">Stalle</etym>, piss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stalk(n)">A Stalk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stiel,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Steel, Stele,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and these from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stigan</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stei&shy;
gen,</etym> to go up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stalk(v)">To Stalk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">St&aelig;l&shy;
can</etym>, to step a little and soft&shy;
ly, to go in stilts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stall(v)">To Stall,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  to eat till ye loath it; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stal</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stall,</etym> a stable; by a Metaphor 
drawn from a beast fatted in 
the stable, or at the stall.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stall(n)">Stall,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stal</etym>, the 
Dan. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stall,</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Stalla,</etym> the same; whence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Styllan</etym>, to put into 
its stall, or place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stallion(n)">Stallion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Esta&shy;
lon,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stallone,</etym> a 
stoned Horse; all from the 
AS. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stal</etym>, or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Stalla,</etym> a stable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stammer(v)">To Stammer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sta&shy;
mor</etym>, he that stammereth: 
Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stameren,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stammeln,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stamp(n)">A Stamp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stampe,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Estampa,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stampa,</etym> an im&shy;
pression; whence the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Estamper</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stam&shy;
pare</etym>, to stamp.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Y6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stamp(v)">To Stamp with the foot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stampffen,</etym> the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Stamper,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Stampen,</etym> to stamp upon, to 
trample under the feet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stanch(v)">Stanch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estan&shy;
cher,</etym> to stop blood; both 
from the Ital. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Stag&shy;
nare,</etym> to stand as water; 
(i. e.) to make the blood 
stand or remain in the vessels, 
as water in a pond, without 
issuing out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stanchion(n)">Stanchion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stanson,</etym> a prop; this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Stan&shy;
do,</etym> from standing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stand(v)">To Stand,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sta&shy;
ndan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Staen</etym>, id. 
whence <etym lang="en">Stand</etym>, a standing-&shy;
place; from hence, To Stand 
at out, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beystenen</etym>, to stand by one, to take 
his part; all from the Gerund 
<etym lang="la">Stando.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="standard(n)">Standard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
standart,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Estandar&shy;
te,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stendardo,</etym> id. 
all <etym lang="la">ab Extendendo,</etym> from be&shy;
ing extended, or displayed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stang(n)">Stang,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stange,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Staeng</etym>, a wooden 
bar, or stake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stanza(n)">Stanza,</form> <xpln lang="en">a method of Verses, con&shy;
taining four, six, or eight lines 
a-piece; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stan&shy;
za,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Stantia,</etym> a Chamber, or 
room; these rows of Verses 
being proportion'd one to ano&shy;
ther, like to the floors or con&shy;
tignations of an house; and 
both <etym lang="la">&agrave; Stando,</etym> from standing. 
It is metaphorically borrowed 
of Architects.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="staple(n)">Staple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estape,</etym> 
or the Dan. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sta&shy;
pel,</etym> a Market, or place con&shy;
stituted for the sale of all such 
Goods as are by Law to be 
there exposed, and no where 
else. Boxhorn. draws it from 
the word <etym lang="tt">Stapelen,</etym> to heap 
up in one place, this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stipare,</etym> to cram, or 
fill up. Spelman seemeth to 
draw it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stabu&shy;
lum,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Statio,</etym> for that there 
are in such a Market stalls, and 
standing-places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="staple(n)">The Staple of a door,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Staple</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Stapul</etym>, the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="star(n)">Star,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steorra</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sterre,</etym> or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stern, Sterne,</etym> 
the same; all from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F74;&rho;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the 
<emend err="the"></emend> Pers. <etym lang="pe">Ster,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, saith 
learned Vossius in voc. Stella.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="starboard(n)">Starboard,</form> <xpln lang="en">the right side of a 
ship, where the Pilot is exer&shy;
cised; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steo&shy;
ran</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stieren, Stuy&shy;
eren,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stewren,</etym> to
 stear a course, and <etym lang="en">Board.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="starch(n)">Starch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Starck,</etym> 
stiff; whence <etym lang="tt">Starcken</etym>, to 
stiffen, to starch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stare(n)" lexeme="starling(n)">A Stare, or Starling,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Staer</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Staar,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Starre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sturnus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
</page> 

<page sig="Y7r"> 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&omicron;&rho;&epsilon;&#x1FD6;&nu;</etym>, is 
spread, by reason of the great 
numbers they fly in. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stare(v)">To Stare,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sta&shy;
rian</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Starren</etym>, 
id. Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ster&shy;
ren,</etym> to shine like a star; the 
eyes exerting themselves, draw 
up such plenty of the optick 
spirits, that they look like stars.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stark(a)">Stark,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sterc</etym>, 
the Belg. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Sterck,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Starck,</etym> or the Fr. 
Th. <etym lang="hd">Starc,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&eta;&rho;&#x1F77;&omega;</etym>, 
to make firm. Somnerus in&shy;
geniously draws it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Strace</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; by a 
Metathesis <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&omicron;&#x1FE6;</etym> r.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="start(v)">Start,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Starren,</etym> 
to stare like one terrified, to 
be affrighted; when any thing 
affrights us unawares, we start 
back, thinking to decline the 
danger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="starve(v)">Starve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steor&shy;
fan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sterven,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sterben,</etym> to die, or 
perish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stately(a)">Stately,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">State&shy;
lick, Staerigh,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stattlich,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stact,</etym> with us State; 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Status,</etym> 
a condition.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stationer(n)">Stationers,</form> <xpln lang="en">Tradesmen so called, 
perhaps because they lived to&shy;
gether in one station, or street 
primarily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="staved(a)">A Ship Staved to pieces,</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
haps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stowen,</etym> 
to drive; for it is meant of a 
ship forcibly struck against 
the shore, and so split.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stay(n)">A Stay,</form><xpln lag="en"> from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Staeyt, 
Staede,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estaye,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="fr">Estayer</etym>, to 
sustain, or hold up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stay(v)">To Stay,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Staen,</etym> 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Staar,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Steben,</etym> to stand; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F39;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F71;&nu;&alpha;&iota;, &#x1F3D;&sigma;&tau;&sigma;&theta;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, 
to stand: From hence, To 
Stay one, or detain him.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stead(n)">Stead,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stad, Stede,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Staet,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steady(a)">Steady,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">St&aelig;&eth;ig</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stedigh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, a 
place, or stead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steak(n)">Steak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sticce</etym>, 
r the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stuck,</etym> a chop, 
or piece of flesh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steal(v)">To Steal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">St&aelig;lan</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Stieler,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stelen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stehlen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steam(n)">Steam,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steam</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Steman</etym>, to 
cast a steam, and <etym lang="oe">Styman</etym>, 
to smoak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steer(v)">To Stear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Stiureu,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stuyren,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stewern,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Steoran</etym>, to rule, or 
guide a ship; all from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stier,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stewer,</etym> the stern, or helm.</xpln></wordentry>
 </page> 
 
 <page sig="Y7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steadfast(a)">Stedfast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, 
a Place, and <etym lang="en">Fast;</etym> q. d. that 
which is fast or unmoveable 
from its place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steed(n)">Steed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Stod</etym>, a stoned Nag; or 
perhaps from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stadi&shy;
um,</etym> a course; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Courser, 
or Race-horse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steel(n)">Steel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Staal</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stahl,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Stael,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steep(v)">To Steep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stip&shy;
pen,</etym> to sop; or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Si&shy;
pan</etym>, to soke.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steep(a)">Steep, Steep Hill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Steap</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both per&shy;
haps from the word <etym lang="en">Step;</etym> 
for steep places are generally 
made with steps, for the easi&shy;
ness of ascent and descent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steeple(n)">Steeple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steopl</etym>, 
in &AElig;lfricus <etym lang="oe">Stypel</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and both from our word 
<etym lang="en">Steep.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steer(n)">A Steer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Styre, 
Steor, Styrc</etym>, or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stier,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stem(n)">Stem,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stamm,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Stemma,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="step(n)">Step,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">St&aelig;p</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stap,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Step,</etym> id. 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steppan, 
St&aelig;pan</etym>, to step; Fr. Jun. 
draws it from the Gr <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&beta;&omega;</etym>, 
to tread upon, to walk.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="step(px)">Step,</form> <xpln lang="en">in composition, as in Step&shy;
mother, &amp;c. from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Steop</etym>, cruel, or rigorous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sterling(n)">Sterling,</form> <xpln lang="en">not as Buchanan 
would have it, from Sterling, 
a town in Scotland; nor be&shy;
cause of its having been stam&shy;
ped with the figure of a Star 
or Starling, as some fondly 
conjecture; but from an Ea&shy;
stern People, called Ester&shy;
lings, Dosterlingers, who 
dwelt near the Balthick 
Sea, and in those days were 
held the best Artificers in 
Gold, Silver, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stern(a)">Stern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sterne</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from the word 
to <etym lang="en">Stare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stew(v)">To Stew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estuve,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stufa,</etym> or the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Stue,</etym> a hot house; and from 
hence a Stewes, or Bawdy-&shy;
house.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stewed(a)">Stew'd-Meat,</form> <xpln lang="en">Mer. Cas. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&alpha;&theta;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&omega;</etym>, to 
boil with a soft fire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="steward(n)">Steward,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stede,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, a Place, or 
Town, and <etym lang="en">Ward,</etym> a Keeper, 
or Guardian; or from <etym lang="en">Stow</etym>, 
a Place, and the same <etym lang="en">Ward.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stick(v)">To Stick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sti&shy;
can</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sticken,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stecken,</etym> to prick 
or stab.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stick fast(v)">To Stick fast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stican</etym>, or the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stecken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stick(n)">A Stick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Steck, 
Stock,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stecco,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stiff(a)">Stiff,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Stiif,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Steiff,</etym> or the AS. 
</page> 

<page sig="Y8r"> 
<etym lang="oe">Stife</etym>, obstinate, setled in 
resolution: Hence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stifian</etym>, to grow stiff or 
stark </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stifle(v)">To Stifle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stoufler,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stippen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Stuppen,</etym> 
to stop, to wit, the breath; 
and these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stipa&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stile(n)">Stile,</form> <xpln lang="en">to go over hedges by, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stigele</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Steeghe, Stegher,</etym> 
a stake or step; these from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stigan</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Steigen,</etym> and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ste&shy;
ighen,</etym> to climb.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stiletto(n)">Stiletto,</form> <xpln lang="en">a short Italian Dagger. 
I suppose from the similitude 
of a Roman <etym lang="la">Style,</etym> made small 
and sharp toward the point.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="still(a)">Still,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Dan. and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stille</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Still,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Styllan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stillen</etym>, 
and Dan. <etym lang="da">Steller</etym>, to appease.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="still(n)">A Still,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">&agrave; Stillando</etym>, or <etym lang="la">Destil&shy;
lando,</etym> from destilling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stilt(n)">Stilts,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Steltze,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stelten,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">St&aelig;elc</etym>, id. whence <etym lang="oe">St&aelig;lcan</etym>, 
to go in stilts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sting(v)">Sting,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stingan</etym>, 
to sting, <etym lang="oe">Stinge</etym>, a sting; 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stingo,</etym> 
to prick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stink(v)">Stink,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stenc</etym>, id. 
hence <etym lang="oe">Stencan</etym>, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Stincken</etym>, to cast a strong 
smell, to stink.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stint(v)">To Stint one,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stincan</etym>, to keep in; or 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stento,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Esten&shy;
to,</etym> the utmost Extent of any 
thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stir(v)">Stir,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Styran, 
Astirian,</etym> to move, to make 
a rout; or 
from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Stooren,</etym> to stir up or pro&shy;
voke.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stirrup(n)">Stirrop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stigan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Steeghen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Steigen,</etym> to ascend, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rape</etym>, or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Reep, Roop,</etym> a Rope.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stitch(n)">Stitch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stice</etym>, 
or Teut <etym lang="tt">Stich</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence 
<etym lang="tt">Sticken</etym>, to stitch or prick 
with a needle. See Stick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stithy(n)">Stithy,</form> <xpln lang="en">for a Smith's Forge, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sti&eth;</etym>, hard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stiver(n)">A Stiver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stuy
ver,</etym> or the Teut <etym lang="tt">Stuver,</etym> a 
Dutch Coyn so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stock(n)">Stock of a Tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stocce</etym>, the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stock,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estoc,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and from hence our 
words, Stock-blind, and 
Stock-still.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stock(n)">Stock, for Progeny;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stock,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stocco,</etym> a stock or 
race.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stock(a)">Stock,</form> <xpln lang="en">Money to trade withal, 
from the other <etym lang="en">Stock</etym> of a 
Tree, by an elegant Meta&shy;
phor; for as the Fruit and 
Branches receive nourishment 
from the stock of a Tree, so 
men are maintained out of 
</page> 

<page sig="Y8v"> 
that gain which doth accrew 
to them by managing well 
their stocks. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stock-fish(n)">Stock-Fish,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Fish as hard 
as the <etym lang="en">Stock</etym> of a Tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stocking(n)">Stockings,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stec&shy;
ken, Steken,</etym> to stick Minsh. 
draws it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stec&shy;
ken,</etym> to put on.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stocks(n)">Stocks,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stock,</etym> 
a pair of Stocks, and both 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stocce</etym>, or the 
Belg. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Stock,</etym> the 
stock of a tree, by a Metony&shy;
mia of the Matter, for the 
Thing made of that Matter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stone(n)">Stone,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Steen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stein, Steyn,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, id. Whence 
<etym lang="oe">St&aelig;nan</etym>, to stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stool(n)">Stool,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stole</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stoel,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stul, 
Stuhl,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a 
Pillar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stoop(v)">To Stoop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stoe&shy;
pen, Stuypen,</etym> to bend or in&shy;
cline the body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stop(v)">To Stop,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stop&shy;
pen,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Stopper,</etym> the 
Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Estouper,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Stoppare,</etym> to stop with flax, or 
tow; this from <etym lang="it">Stuppo,</etym> Tow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="store(n)">Store, for plenty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Stuyr,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stewer,</etym> 
an Alms whence <etym lang="tt">Stuyren</etym>, and <etym lang="tt">Stewern</etym>, to bestow, or contri&shy;
bute to the poors maintenance</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="storm(n)">A Storm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Storm</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sturm,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Stormo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stove(n)">Stove,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stofa</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stube,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Estuve,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stove,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stufa,</etym> a hot-house. 
Menag. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F7B;&phi;&omega;</etym>, to raise a smoak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stout(a)">Stout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stout,</etym> 
courageous; also high-min&shy;
ded; or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stoltz,</etym> 
proud. Skinner draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stut</etym>, a Stoat, or 
Stallion, which are remarka&shy;
ble for strength and fierceness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stow(v)" lexeme="steeve(v)">To Stow, Stove, or Steave,</form> <xpln lang="en">to 
put in its place, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stow</etym>, a Place; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Stouwen,</etym> to accumulate, to 
heap up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="straddle(v)">To Straddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">Striddle, from 
our word <etym lang="en">Stride.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="straggle(v)">To Straggle,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. Straygle, from 
our word <etym lang="en">Stray;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strain(v)">To Strain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
streindre, Estraindre,</etym> id. and 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Extrin&shy;
gere.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strain(n)">A Strain,</form> <xpln lang="en">in writing, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Strenge</etym>, Progeny; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
an hereditary faculty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strain(v)" lexeme="sprain(v)">To Strain or Sprain the foot,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estraindre,</etym> 
to squeeze; or from <etym lang="la">Dis,</etym> and 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trainer,</etym> to draw, 
pull. Mer Cas. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&eta;&nu;&#x1F74;&#x03c2;</etym>, sharp, or 
pricking.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="straight(a)">Strait,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Strait Line, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Strace</etym>, or the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Strack,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Astrec&shy;
can</etym>, or the Belg. and Teut. 
</page> 

<page sig="Z1r"> 
<etym lang="tt">Strecken,</etym> to stretch, or ex&shy;
tend; and from hence the Ad&shy;
verb Straight, or Straight&shy;
way. Write Streight. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="straight(a)">Strait,</form> <xpln lang="en">narrow; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Estroit, Estroict,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Stretto,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Strictus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from 
hence the Straits, or Narrow Seas.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strake(n)">The Strake of a Wheel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Belg <etym lang="bl">Streke,</etym> a streak, or 
line; it being the impression 
the wheel leaves in the dirt.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strand(n)">Strand,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Strand</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Strande,</etym> a shore, or bank of 
a river.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strange(a)">Strange</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Strano,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estrange,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Extraneus,</etym> foreign, 
one of another land: From 
hence, A Stranger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strangles(n)">Strangles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Les 
Estranguillons,</etym> or the Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Strengel,</etym> a disease in Horses: 
Or perhaps <etym lang="la">&agrave; Strangulando,</etym> 
from choaking; because it 
stoppeth the wind pipe in such 
sort, that the beast infected 
breaths with pain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strap(n)">Strap</form> <xpln lang="en">of Leather, from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Struppi, Stroppi,</etym> leather loops, 
or thongs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strappado(n)">The Strappado,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Estrapade;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Strap&shy;
pata,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strapping(a)">A Strapping,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Lusty Lass, 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Strappare,</etym> to 
tear, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  una Massara <etym lang="it">Strap&shy;
pante,</etym> a Tearing Wench.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="straw(n)">Straw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Streow</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stroo.</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stroh</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Straw, Strew,</etym> Litter
 laid under Horses: All from 
 the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stratum,</etym> that which 
 is spread or strewed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stray(n)">A Stray,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Estray, from the
 Ital. <etym lang="it">Straviare,</etym> to go astray; 
 or <etym lang="la">ab extrahendo,</etym> from draw&shy;
 ing out; for that stray Cat&shy;
 tel are to be drawn or taken 
 out of other mens grounds.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="streak(n)">A Streak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Strice</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Streke,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Strich;</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Stricca,</etym> a Line: Whence the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Strucken</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Streichen</etym>; and Ital. <etym lang="it">Stricca&shy;
re</etym>, to draw in Streaks or 
Lines: All from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stri&shy;
ga,</etym> a Furrow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stream(n)">Stream,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stream</etym>, 
the Belg <etym lang="bl">Stroom;</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Strom,</etym> the current of a river.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="streamer(n)">Streamer,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Colours of a Ship, 
so called, because it flaggs to 
and again like <etym lang="en">streams</etym> or 
waves of water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="street(n)">Street,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stret, 
Straete,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Straede,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Straet,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Strada,</etym> a way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stress(n)">Stress,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Strece</etym>, 
force; see Distress, and Strain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stretch(v)">Stretch</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Astr&aelig;&shy;
can</etym>; or the Teut. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Strecken,</etym> to extend. Minsh. 
derives it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ex&shy;
tractus,</etym> drawn, or pluckt out.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strew(v)">To Strew, or Strow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Strewian, Stregian</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stroyen</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Strawen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&#x1F71;&nu;&nu;&upsilon;&mu;&iota;</etym>, of the old 
Verb <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&#x1F79;&omega;</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strickle(n)">A Strickle,</form> <xpln lang="en">to mete corn justly 
withal, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Strei&shy;
chen,</etym> to stretch or reach; also 
to make even; and from hence 
a Strike of Corn, a Lincoln&shy;
shire Measure, equal to the 
London Bushel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stride(v)">To Stride,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Straede</etym>, a Pace; the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schreiten,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schriiden,</etym> 
to straddle, <etym lang="bl">Beschryden,</etym> to 
<etym lang="bl">Bestride</etym> a horse. Or from the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Staar til Strids,</etym> to 
stand astride.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strike(v)">To Strike,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">A&shy;
strican</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Strei&shy;
chen,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Stricker,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strike sail(v)">To Strike Sail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Striicken het Seil;</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Die segel Streichen,</etym> to 
lower, or to gather up the 
sails.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="string(n)">String,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Strenge</etym>, 
or the Belg <etym lang="bl">Strenghe, 
Stringhe,</etym> id. Or most likely, 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Strenga,</etym> or 
<etym lang="it">Stringa,</etym> a point with tags; 
all <etym lang="la">&agrave; Stringendo,</etym> from ty&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="string(n)">Strings of an instrument,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Streng,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. V. 
String, above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strip(v)">To Strip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg <etym lang="bl">Stroo&shy;
pen,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Af-stroopen,</etym> to strip 
off ones cloths.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stripe(n)">Stripe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Strepe,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="bl">Strepen</etym>, to 
make striped or streaked: Or 
secondarily, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Streichen,</etym> to scourge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stripling(n)">Stripling,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Tri&shy;
pling, <etym lang="la">&agrave; Tripudiando,</etym> from tripping: Or 
rather, from the word <etym lang="en">Stripe,</etym> 
and the diminutive Termina&shy;
tion <etym lang="en">Ling,</etym> denoting a Youth, 
not yet exempt from the cha&shy;
stisement of the rod.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strive(v)">To Strive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stre&shy;
ven,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Streben,</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estriver,</etym> to contend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stroke(v)">To Stroke gently, or softly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
 the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stracan</etym>, the Dan. 
 <etym lang="da">Stryger,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stricca&shy;
 re,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Stregolare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. V. 
 Streak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strong(a)">Strong,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Strang</etym>, 
the Teut. and Dan. <etym lang="da">Streng,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Strengh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
and all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stre&shy;
nuus,</etym> stout; this from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&eta;&nu;&#x1F74;&#x03c2;</etym>, valiant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stroppings(n)">The Stroppings of a Cow's milk,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stroppen,</etym> to 
press hard; or from the word, 
To <etym lang="en">Stroke;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Strokings.</xpln>
<lemenote>
The noun "stroppings" not found in OED, but see "strop", v.2.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="struggle(n)">Struggle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a depravation of our 
word <etym lang="en">Strove;</etym> or q. Strougle, 
from <etym lang="en">Strong. Casau.</etym> draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&gamma;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, or 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&rho;&alpha;&gamma;&gamma;&epsilon;&#x1F7B;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to waste, or 
be spent drop after drop, little 
by little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strumpet(n)">A Strumpet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tromper,</etym> to cheat one; or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stront,</etym> excrements, and 
our word <etym lang="en">Pot;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  fit only---</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="strut(v)">To Strut,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Strut&shy;
zen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minshew reads it, 
Strout, q.<etym lang="en"> Stretch out.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stub(n)">A Stub,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stybbe</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stobbe,</etym> id. and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Stipes,</etym> a 
stick, or stock of a tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stubble(n)">Stubble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stop&shy;
pel,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stoppole,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estouble,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>, and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Stipula,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stubborn(a)">Stubborn,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">Stout born</etym>, Min&shy;
shew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stud(n)">Stud,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Studu</etym>, a 
broad nail, or boss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stuff(n)">Stuff,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of cloth; from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stoffe,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stoffe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stuff(n)">Stuff,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Matter; from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Stoffo, Stoffa,</etym> matter 
whereof any thing is made.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stum(n)">Stum of Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stom,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Stumm,</etym> dumb; it being so 
hard stopped, as that it cannot 
purge it self: Or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stumpff,</etym> dull, without 
spirits.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stumble(v)">To Stumble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Snubler,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stol&shy;
pern,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stump(n)">Stump of a Tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Stump,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stompe,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stumpff,</etym> id. whence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Stompen</etym>, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stumpffen</etym>, to cut a 
tree off at the stump.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stun(v)">To Stunn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stonner,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Attonitum facere,</etym> to 
make afraid.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sturgeon(n)">Sturgeon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">E&shy;
stourgeon,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Storione,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Steur,</etym> or the Lat. 
Barb. <etym lang="la">Sturio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stutter(v)">Stutter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Stut&shy;
zen,</etym> id. also to cast headlong; 
all from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sty(n)">A Sty for Hogs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Stige</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Suine-Stig,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sty(n)">Sty,</form> <xpln lang="en">a swelling upon the eye&shy;
lid; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stigan</etym>, 
to grow up; or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, 
a peble, for its hardness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="subdue(v)">To Subdue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sub&shy;
dere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="such(a)">Such,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swylce</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Solt, Sulk,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Solch,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suck(v)">To Suck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Suc&shy;
can</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Succer,</etym> or the 
Ital <etym lang="it">Succhiare,</etym> id. all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sugere,</etym> id. this from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F59;&gamma;&rho;#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, moist.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sudden(a)">Suddain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sou&shy;
dain,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Soden</etym>, id. 
and all of them Contracts of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Subitaneus,</etym> hasty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suds(v)">Suds,</form> <xpln lang="en">to wash withal, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Seo&eth;an</etym>, to seeth; whence 
<etym lang="oe">Aso&eth;en</etym>, sodden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sue(v)">To Sue at Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Suivre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Seguire,</etym> 
to pursue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sugar(n)">Sugar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. . <etym lang="fr">Sucre,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Zuccaro,</etym> the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">A&ccedil;ucar,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zucker,</etym> or 
the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Saccharum,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suit(n)">Suit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Suitte,</etym> a 
prosecution at Law; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Suivre,</etym> to follow.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sullen(a)">Sullen,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Solaneus,</etym> one &shy;
that loves to be all alone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sultry(a)">Sultry,</form> <xpln lang="en">dark, close weather; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Sweltry, from the word 
To <etym lang="en">Swelt,</etym> or stifle with too 
much heat; or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Sul&shy;
phury,</etym> from <etym lang="en">Sulphur,</etym> brim&shy;
stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="summer(n)">Summer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sunna</etym>, 
the Sun; or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Belg. <etym lang="bl">Son &shy;
Heer,</etym> Master of the Sun: Or 
from the same <etym lang="bl">Sunne,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;ra</etym>, marks, or 
limits; q. Sunmer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="summon(v)">To Summon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Semondre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Submonere,</etym> to warn, or 
give notice; from hence, A 
Summoner, and Summons, 
or Citation to appear before 
lawful Authority.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sumpter horse(n)">Sumpter-Horse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Somme,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Soma, 
Salma,</etym> a burthen; these from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&#x1F71;&gamma;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sun(n)">Sun</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sunne</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Son,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sonne,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sundry(a)">Sundry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Sunder</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sonder,</etym> seve&shy;
ral; whence <etym lang="tt">Sunderlich</etym>, sin&shy;
gularly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sup(v)">To Sup,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Supan</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sober,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Soffen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Supffen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="supple(a)">Supple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Souple,</etym> 
soft; this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sub,</etym> 
somewhat, and <etym lang="la">Plico,</etym> to fold; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  that which may be fol&shy;
ded or bent as you will.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suppliant(n)">A Suppliant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Suppliant,</etym> humble; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Supplicare,</etym> to 
beseech, or make supplica&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suppose(v)">To Suppose,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Supposer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Supponere,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surbate(v)">To Surbeat, or be Surbeaten 
upon the feet,</form> <xpln lang="en">by travelling 
far; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Soubat&shy;
tre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sobbattere</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Subtus Ba&shy;
tuere</etym> v. Beat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surcharge(v)">To Surcharge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Surcharger,</etym> to over-charge, 
or load.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sure(a)">Sure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Seur,</etym> id. 
and this a Contract of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Securus,</etym> safe: And from 
hence our word Surety.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surface(n)">Surface,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sur&shy;
face;</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Superficies,</etym> the out-side of 
any thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surfeit(v)">To Surfeit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">So&shy;
prafare,</etym> to load, or oppress: 
Or from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Supra,</etym> and 
<etym lang="la">Facere,</etym> to do too much, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
to eat more than tends to the 
conservation of health.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surge(n)">Surge,</form> <xpln lang="en">an high wave; <etym lang="la">&agrave; Sur&shy;
gendo,</etym> because it riseth up 
aloft.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surgeon(n)">Surgeon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chirurgien;</etym> and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Chirurgus,</etym> id. 
this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&epsilon;&#x1F76;&rho;</etym>, the 
hand, and <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&rho;&gamma;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a work;
 <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Manual Operator.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surrejoinder(n)">Surjoinder,</form> <xpln lang="en">or rather Surrejoin&shy;
der, a term in the Law, which 
</page> 

<page sig="Z3r"> 
denotes a Trippling, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Plaintiff's second Defence, 
made against the Defendant's 
Rejoinder; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Surjoindre,</etym> now out of use; 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Suprajun&shy;
gere,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Superrejungere,</etym> to 
join the third time; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to 
adjoin a new Answer to the 
two former. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surly(a)">Surly,</form> <xpln lang="en">morose; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Surlic</etym>, sowrly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surmise(n)">A Surmise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G <etym lang="fr">Sur&shy;
mise,</etym> id. a Verbal of the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Supermittere,</etym> to put above; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to place first in the mind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surmount(v)">To Surmount,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Surmonter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sur&shy;
montare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Super Montem ascendere,</etym> to 
get upon a mountain. V. To 
Mount above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surname(n)" lexeme="sirname(n)">Surname, Sirname,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Surnom,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Sopranome,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat <etym lang="la">Supernomen,</etym> a name ad&shy;
ded over and above the name 
given in Baptism.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surplice(n)">A Surplis,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sur&shy;
plis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surplus(n)" lexeme="surplusage(n)">Surplus, or Surplusage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Surplus,</etym> that which 
doth remain; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Su&shy;
pra plus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surprise(v)">To Surprise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Surprendre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">So&shy;
praprendere,</etym> to take hold on 
unawares; and from hence 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Surpris</etym>, and the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Soprapreso</etym>, a surprise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="surrender(v)">To Surrender,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Surrendre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="survey(v)">To Survey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Surveoir,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Super,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Videre,</etym> to 
over-look. v. View.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="survive(v)">To Survive,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Survivre</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Super vivere,</etym> to out-live.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sustain(v)">To Sustain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Su&shy;
stenir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Sostenere,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Sustinere,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="suit(n)">A Sute of Cloths,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Suta,</etym> a Participle of <etym lang="la">Suo,</etym> to 
sow up: Or rather, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Suitte,</etym> a Verbal of 
<etym lang="fr">Suivre,</etym> to follow; because 
one thing is agreeable to, or 
followeth another: As we say, 
I'll follow him; that is, have 
such cloths as he has; and so 
sute, or fit him.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sutler(n)">A Sutteler,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Soe&shy;
teler,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sudler,</etym> a
 Seller of subtile, or small 
 wares.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swaddle(v)">Swaddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swe&shy;
&eth;ele</etym>. or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swadel,</etym> 
a swadling cloth; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Beswe&eth;an</etym>, to swathe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swagger(v)">To Swagger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swaddern,</etym> to be huffish, or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swegan</etym>, to keep a 
bustle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swain(n)">Swain,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Country-Swain, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swan</etym>, a Herds&shy;
man, or <etym lang="oe">Swang</etym>, a Labourer; 
this from <etym lang="oe">Swincan</etym>, to work.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swallow(n)">A Swallow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swa&shy;
lewe</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Svale,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swaeluwe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swallow(v)">To Swallow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Swelgan</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwel&shy;
gen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swelghen,</etym> 
to devour whole; from 
<etym lang="bl">Swelgh,</etym> the jaws.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swamp(n)" lexeme="swomp(n)">Swamp, or Swomp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwanck,</etym> slim, or 
lean.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swan(n)">Swan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swan</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwan,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swaen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swarm(n)">Swarm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ewearm</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swerm,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Busverm,</etym> a 
swarm of Bees; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Swearmian</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swermen,</etym> and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schwarmen,</etym> to fly in 
swarms.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swarthy(a)">Swarthy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sweart</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sort,</etym> 
brown: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swart,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwartz,</etym> 
tauny skinn'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swashbuckler(n)">Swash-Buckler,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bravado, 
one that can swash or clat&shy;
ter his Buckler and Arms to&shy;
gether better than fight; that 
makes a great cry, and a little 
wool: From the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swad&shy;
deren,</etym> to make a noise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swath(n)">A Swath of Grass or Hay,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swade,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sway(v)">To Sway,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Bear Rule; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schweben,</etym> 
to move a cause as one plea&shy;
seth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sweal(v)">To Sweal</form> <xpln lang="en">away as a Candle, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sw&aelig;lan</etym>, to 
flame out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swear(v)">To Swear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swe
rian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sw&aelig;ren,</etym> 
or the Teut <etym lang="tt">Schweren,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sweat(v)">To Sweat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swe
tan</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sv&aelig;der,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sweeten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sw&aelig;tte</etym>, the 
Da. <etym lang="da">Sved</etym>, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sweet</etym>, sweat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sweep(v)">To Sweep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sweopan, Swapan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sweepen,</etym> to 
lash.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sweet(a)">Sweet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sw&aelig;t, 
Swete</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Suess,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Soet, Suet,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swell(v)">Swell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swellan</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwellen,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swellen,</etym> the same. V. 
Swollen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swelt(v)" lexeme="swelter(v)">Swelt, and Swelter,</form> <xpln lang="en">to be 
stifled with heat; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sweltan</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swelten,</etym> to faint away.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swerve(v)">To Swerve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swerven,</etym> to go from.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swift(a)">Swift,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swift</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this perhaps from the 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Sueven,</etym> to swim; 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schweben,</etym> to 
move.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swill(v)">To Swill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swel&shy;
gan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swelghen,</etym> 
to swallow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swim(v)">Swim,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swim&shy;
man</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwimmen,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swimmen,</etym> the 
</page> 

<page sig="Z4r"> 
same: Ali&agrave;s, from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swimelen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schwimmeln,</etym> to have a swim&shy;
ming in the head. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swine(n)">Swine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swin</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Svin,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swiin,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwein,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swing(v)">Swing,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swen&shy;
gan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swinghen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwinghen,</etym> 
to shake, or brandish: Or 
secondarily, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Swangettan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swancken,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schwancken, Wancken,</etym> to 
wag, or swing upon a 
rope.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swinge(v)">Swinge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swin&shy;
gan</etym>, to scourge one; 
whence <etym lang="oe">Swing</etym>, a scourge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="swoon(v)">Swoon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aswu&shy;
nan</etym>, to faint: Or from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Svinder,</etym> to pine 
away; or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swin&shy;
dan</etym>, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swin&shy;
den,</etym> to be in a fit. The ju&shy;
dicious Dr. Th. H. draws it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swesn</etym>, a 
dream, or ecstasie.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sword(n)">A Sword,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schwerd,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Sverd,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sweerd,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Sweord, Swurd</etym>, the 
same; from hence, A Sword-&shy;
fish. Mer. Cas. draws them 
all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&#x1F77;&delta;&eta;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
iron.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sward(n)">A Sword of Bacon;</form> <xpln lang="en">not from 
the other Sword, as one 
would think; but rather 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sweard</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swaerde,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schwarte,</etym> an Hog's skin; 
this from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swert, 
Swart,</etym> or the Teutonick 
<etym lang="tt">Schwartz,</etym> swarthy; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the outward skin, or rind of 
Bacon.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="T"><alpha>T</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tabby(n)">TAbby,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ta&shy;
bi,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Tabino,</etym> a sort of 
wrought silk; or perhaps from 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="la">Ta&shy;
pes,</etym> Tapestry; any stuff wrought 
with pictures, or distinct co&shy;
lours.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taber(n)">Taber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tam&shy;
burro,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Atambor,</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tabour,</etym> a mu&shy;
sical instrument so called: 
Hence the Diminutive Ta&shy;
beuret.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="table(n)">Tables,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;fl</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Taffel,</etym> the Fr. G.
 <etym lang="fr">Tablier,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tavo&shy;
 liere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
 the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tabula,</etym> a board, or 
 plank.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tack(v)">To Tack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">At&shy;
tacher,</etym> to attach; also to 
make fast.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tackle(n)">Tackle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Taeckel, 
Taeckelinghe,</etym> the Tacklings 
of a Ship; <etym lang="bl">Opteeckelen</etym>, to 
put up the Tacklings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taffeta(n)">Taffety,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. and 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Taffet&agrave;;</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Tafetan,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Covarruv. 
draws it from <etym lang="en">Tiff Taff,</etym> the 
Ruffling noise it makes</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tail(n)">Tail,</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it from 
<etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F73;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, an end, or <etym lang="la">&agrave; tegen&shy;
do,</etym> from hiding or covering; 
or rather from the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;gl</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; which Fr. Jun. draws 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&eta;&gamma;&alpha;&#x1F73;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> sharp; 
or <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&alpha;&upsilon;&lambda;&#x1F73;&alpha;</etym>, a word found in 
Hesych. put for &omicron;&#x1F50;&rho;&#x1F70; a Tail. 
Some have drawn it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Talla,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Thallus,</etym> the 
blade of an Onion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tailor(n)">A Tailour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tailleur,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Tailler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tagliare,</etym> 
to cut.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taint(v)">To Taint,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tein&shy;
dre,</etym> to infect; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tingere,</etym> to 
stain, to give a tincture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="take(v)">To Take,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tager,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tacken,</etym> 
 to take hold on; or the Fr G. 
 <etym lang="fr">Attaquer,</etym> to attach; or from 
 the old word <etym lang="la">Tago,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Tango,</etym> 
 to touch. Mer. Cas. derives 
 it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F73;&chi;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talbot(n)">Talbot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dog whose Tail turns 
up like that of a Lion, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;gl</etym>, a Tail, and 
<etym lang="oe">Butan</etym>, to turn again.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tale(n)">A Tale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Talu</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Tellan</etym>, and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Talen, Taelen,</etym> to Tell,
 or relate; from hence Talk.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tale(n)">Tale, in numbring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Get&aelig;l</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both 
from our word <etym lang="en">Tell,</etym> or rec&shy;
kon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tall(a)">Tall,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">T&acirc;l,</etym> id. 
which Davis draws from the 
Heb. <etym lang="he">Telal,</etym> he hath lifted up; 
or the Arab. <etym lang="ar">Tala,</etym> he was 
long.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tallow(n)">Tallow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Talg, 
Telle,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Talgh,</etym> 
or <etym lang="bl">Talch,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="talon(n)">Tallons,</form> <xpln lang="en">Birds claws, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Talon,</etym> or the Ital.
 <etym lang="it">Tallone,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tally(n)">A Tally,</form> <xpln lang="en">or stick to notch num&shy;
bers upon; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ta&shy;
lea,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tame(a)">Tame,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tame</etym>; 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Taem, Tam,</etym> id. 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tamian</etym>, 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tammen</etym>, to 
tame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tamper(v)">To Tamper</form> <xpln lang="en">with, by applying 
various Medicines; from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Temperare,</etym> to mix (q.
d.) to attempt a Cure with 
change of Medicines.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tankard(n)">Tankard;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. takes it to be 
a corruption of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Can&shy;
tharus,</etym> a Jug; perhaps from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tangue,</etym> a little 
Cistern; or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tunc&shy;
ken,</etym> to fill, and <etym lang="tt">Aerd,</etym> Na&shy;
ture; or from the sound its 
Cover gives in falling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tan(v)">To Tan,</form> <xpln lang="en">Tanner, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tanner, Tanneur,</etym>
 
</page> 
 
<page sig="Z5r"> 
 or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tanner, Taener,</etym>
 a Tanner. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tantivy(adv)">Tantivy,</form> <xpln lang="en">To ride Tantivy, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tant&acirc; vi,</etym> with so 
much force as you can; 
or from <etym lang="la">Tent&acirc; vi,</etym> with the 
strength of the Horse, and his 
Rider, exerted as much as can 
be.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tap(v)">Tap,</form> <xpln lang="en">To give one a Tap, from
 the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tappen,</etym> to feel, or 
 touch; or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Taper,</etym> 
 to hit one lightly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tap(v)">To Tap a vessel of Ale,</form> <xpln lang="en">&amp;c. from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;ppan</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Zapffen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tappen,</etym> 
to broach; hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;p&shy;
pe</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zapff</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Tappe</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="tt">Tappa</etym>, a 
tap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tape(n)">Tape,</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0D;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to bind, or knit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taper(n)">Taper,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Taper</etym>, id. 
Minsh. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F71;&phi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, a Burial; for that it 
is used at Funerals.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tapestry(n)">Tapestry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tapis
serie,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tapezzaria,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the Lat. and 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">Tapes,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tar(n)">Tar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tarre, 
Terre,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Teorwe,
 Tare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tardy(a)">Tardy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tardif,</etym> 
slow; or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tarde,</etym> slowly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tare(v)">To Tare,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term amongst Mer&shy;
chants; from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tarare,</etym>
to substract out of the price, 
for some consideration of loss 
in wares; and this perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Terere,</etym> for <etym lang="la">De
terere,</etym> to diminish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tare(n)">Tares</form> <xpln lang="en">among Corn, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zehren,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Te
ren, Teeren,</etym> to waste; which 
last comes from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tere&shy;
re,</etym> to spend, or consume.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="target(n)">Target,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Targ, 
Targa</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Targe,</etym>
 the Ital. <etym lang="it">Targa, Targhetta,</etym> or
 the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Targeta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tarry(v)">To Tarry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Ta&shy;
rger, Tarder,</etym> or the Ital. and 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tardare,</etym> to delay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tarse(n)">Tarse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zersch,</etym>
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Teers,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Teors</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Teres,</etym> round, according 
to Kilian.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tart(a)">Tart,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Teart</etym>, 
sowre, or sharp; or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Zart,</etym> thin. Physicians say, that 
all sowre things consist of rare 
or tenuous parts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="task(n)">Task,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tasche,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Taxare,</etym> to value, or impose; 
which comes from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F71;&sigma;&sigma;&omega;</etym>, to appoint.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taste(v)">To Taste,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ta&shy;
sten.</etym> to touch lightly; the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Taster,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ta&shy;
stare,</etym> to try. Menag. derives
 it from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tangere,</etym> to 
 touch; or <etym lang="la">Tactare,</etym> to touch a 
 little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tatters(n)">Tatters,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tattere,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;tteran</etym>, rags.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tattle(v)">To Tattle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ta&shy;
deln,</etym> to find fault; which is 
the property of tatlers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tavern(n)">Tavern,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ta&shy;
verne,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Taverna;</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z5v"> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ta&shy;
berna,</etym> the same. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taught(v)">Taught,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;h&shy;
ten</etym>, I taught; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Tucht,</etym> discipline, according 
to Minshew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="taunt(v)">To Taunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tan&shy;
ser, Tancer,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from
 the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tangere,</etym> to touch; 
 as when any, under colour of
