 jesting, speaks home, we say, 
 There's a touch for you.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tawny(a)">Tawny,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tan&egrave;, 
Tann&egrave;,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Taneto,</etym> a 
Chestnut-colour. V. Tan.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="teach(v)">To Teach,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;can</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="oe">Bet&aelig;can</etym>, 
<etym lang="oe">Get&aelig;can</etym>, to put in trust 
with, also to betake himself 
unto.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="teal(n)">A Teal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Te&shy;
elingh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="tt">Teeln,</etym> 
to procreate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="team(n)">A Team, or Teem of Oxen,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tyme</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
tyme</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tear(v)">To Tear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;&shy;
ran</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Abzerren,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tear(v)">To Tear and Roar,</form> <xpln lang="en">A Tearing 
voice; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tie&shy;
ren,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tear(n)">Tears,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tear</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zaehr, Zehr,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to af&shy;
flict, and <etym lang="gk">&Zeta;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to trouble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tease(v)">To Tease Wool,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Teesen,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;san</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>: From hence, A Teasel,
or Fuller's Thistle; and Tease 
or nettle one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="teat(n)">A Teat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Titte</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tette,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Tetta,</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Teta,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="teem(v)">To Teem,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Team</etym>, 
Off-spring; whence Team&shy;
ful, fruitful; as we say, A 
Teeming Woman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="teem out(v)">To Teem out,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Empty; a Nor&shy;
thern word; from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Tommer,</etym> to draw out, to em&shy;
pty: Whence Tom, empty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tell(v)">To Tell,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Number, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Taelen, Tellen,</etym> the AS.
 <etym lang="oe">T&aelig;llan</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">T&aelig;lter,</etym> 
 <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tell(v)">To Tell,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Speak; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Tellan</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Ta&shy;
ler,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F73;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, for 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&nu;&tau;&#x1F73;&lambda;&lambda;&omega;</etym>, to command.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temple(n)">The Temples,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Temples,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tempia;</etym> 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tempora,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temporize(v)">To Temporise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Temporiser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tem&shy;
poreggiare,</etym> to serve, or adapt 
ones self to the Times.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="temse-bread(n)">Tems'd Bread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Temsen, Teemsen,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tamiser,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tami&shy;
sare,</etym> to sift; which come 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Teems,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tamis,</etym> and the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Tamigio, Tamiscio,</etym> a sieve.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ten(n)">Ten,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tyn, Tien</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Thien,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Zehen,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenant(n)">Tenant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Te&shy;
nant,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tenent,</etym> id. 
</page> 

<page sig="Z6r"> 
or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Tenens,</etym> he that 
holds or possesseth lands or 
houses, upon terms agreed 
upon, betwixt him and his 
Landlord. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tench(n)">Tench,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tince</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tenche, Tanche,</etym> the
 Ital. <etym lang="it">Tenca,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tinca,</etym> 
 a fish so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tender(v)">To Tender,</form> <xpln lang="en">or ex<emend err="h">i</emend>bit Writings, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tendre,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tendere,</etym> for <etym lang="la">Pretendere,</etym> 
to hold, or reach forth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tender(a)">Tender,</form> <xpln lang="en">or, Delicate, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tendre,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Te&shy;
ner,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tendril(n)">Tendrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ten&shy;
drillon,</etym> an old Vine-stock, cut 
down, that young branches 
may spring out of it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenement(n)">Tenement,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Te&shy;
nement,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tenimen&shy;
to</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all <etym lang="la">&agrave; Tenendo,</etym> from 
holding, or possessing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tent(n)">A Tent</form> <xpln lang="en">to dwell in, from the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Tenda,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tien&shy;
da,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tente,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tentorium,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tent(n)">A Tent</form> <xpln lang="en">for Sores or Wounds, <etym lang="la">&agrave; 
Tentando</etym>, from trying, or 
searching into.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tent wine(n)">Tent-Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Vi&shy;
no Tento,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vinum Tinctum,</etym> co&shy;
lour'd wine.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tenter(n)">A Tenter,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">&agrave; Tendendo</etym>, from 
stretching out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terce(n)">A Terce</form> <xpln lang="en">of Wine, from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Terzaruolo,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tiers,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Triens,</etym> 
the third part of a pipe of wine</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="terrier(n)">A Terriar,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Canis Ter&shy;
rarius,</etym> an Earth-dog.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="territory(n)">A Territory,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Territoire,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Territorium,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tester(n)">A Tester, or Testern of a Bed,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Testiera,</etym> id. 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Testa,</etym> an 
head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="testy(a)">Testy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Testu,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Testardo,</etym> stubborn, 
angry; these from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Teste,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Testa,</etym> the 
head; by a Metaphor drawn 
from headstrong Horses.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tether(n)">A Tether,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Rope to tie a Beast 
withal to graze; from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tentor,</etym> an holder; <etym lang="la">quia 
Tenet,</etym> because it holds the 
beast in compass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tetter(n)">A Tetter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Teter</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tew(v)">To Tew, or Toss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS.
 <etym lang="oe">Tawian</etym>, to stir up and down; 
 to rowl in the mire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thank(v)">To Thank,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;anc&shy;
gian</etym>, or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dancken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tharm(n)" lexeme="chitterling(n)">Tharms, or Chitterlings,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Darm,</etym> a 
gut; or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tarmens,</etym> 
the inwards.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="that(d)">That,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;&aelig;t</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Das,</etym> the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Thaz,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dat,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thatch(n)">Thatch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;ace</etym>, 
thatch, or straw; whence 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;acian, &ETH;accian</etym>, to thatch 
an house.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thaw(v)">Thaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tawen,</etym> 
to thaw. V. Dew.</xpln></wordentry>
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="Z6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="the(d)">The,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Particle; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Die,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">De,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thee(pr)">Thee,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pronoun; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;e, Te</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dy,</etym> or 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Thich, Te,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F72;</etym> 
thee.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thief(n)">A Theif,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eof</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tiuff,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dief,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;eofian</etym>, to thieve, or steal; 
and <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eof&eth;e</etym>, theft. Write 
Thief.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="them(pr)">Them,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dem,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heom</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="then(adv)">Then,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;&aelig;nne</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dann,</etym> or the Fr. 
Th. <etym lang="fr">Thanne,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thence(adv)">Thence,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">There hence,</etym> accor&shy;
ding to Minshew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="there(adv)">There,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;&aelig;r, 
&ETH;ar</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Der,</etym> or the 
Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Daer,</etym> id. hence the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Daer toe</etym>, thereto; and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;aerof</etym>, thereof; and <etym lang="oe">&ETH;ar&shy;
&aelig;ften</etym>, thereafter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="therefore(adv)">Therefore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Daer&aelig;voor,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="these(d)">These,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dese,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Diese,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thick(a)">Thick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;icce</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dick,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dicht,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tyck,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from 
hence, Thicket, a little place 
set thick with trees and shrubs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thigh(n)">Thigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eoh</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Die, Diege,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thimble(n)">Thimble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from Thumb, q.
 <etym lang="en">Thumb bell,</etym> according to 
 Minshew.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thin(a)">Thin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;inne</etym>, id. 
whence <etym lang="oe">&ETH;innian</etym>, to make 
thin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thine(pr)">Thine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;ine</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Diin,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dein,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thing(n)">Thing,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;ing</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dingh,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ding,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="think(v)">To Think,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;in&shy;
can</etym>, or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dencken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Sin Thunkit</etym>, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">My Dunckt</etym>, methinks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="third(n)">Third,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;ridda</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dryde,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dritte, Tritte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thirst(n)">Thirst,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;yrst, 
&ETH;urst,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dorst,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Durst,</etym> id. whence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;yrstan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dorsten</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dursten</etym>, to thirst.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thirteen(n)">Thirteen,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;redt&shy;
tyne</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dertien</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. V. Thite, and Ten.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thirty(n)">Thirty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rittig</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dertich,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="this(d)">This,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;is, &ETH;es, 
&ETH;eos</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dirse,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thistle(n)">Thistle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;istel</etym>, 
or the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Distel,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thither(adv)">Thither,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;ider, 
&ETH;yder,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thong(n)">Thong,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eong,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thorn(n)">Thorn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;orn,</etym> 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Torn,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Doorne,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dorn,</etym> 
id: all perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Taeran</etym>, to tear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thorough(a)">Thorough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Deur, 
Door,</etym> the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Thurgh, 
Thurnh,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;urh, 
&ETH;ruh</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thou(pr)">Thou,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Du,</etym> or the AS. and Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;u;</etym> all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tu,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thousand(n)">Thousand,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;u&shy;
send</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tausent,</etym> or
 the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dusent,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
 from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tien, Ten,</etym> and 
 <etym lang="oe">Send</etym>, for Sent, an hun&shy;
 dred.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thraldom(n)">Thraldom,</form> <xpln lang="en">Thrall, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;rael</etym>, a Vassal, or Slave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thread(n)">Thread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;raed</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Draat,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Draedt,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="threap(v)">To Threap,</form> <xpln lang="en">a word frequently 
used in Lincolnsh. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;reapian</etym>, to stand 
arguing; or <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rafian</etym>, to 
be urgent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="threaten(v)">To Threaten,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Dreyghen,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rea&shy;
tian,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; also to rebuke, 
or chide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="three(n)">Three,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rie, 
&ETH;rea</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drie,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trey, Drey,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
 all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&rho;&epsilon;#x1FD6;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thresh(v)">To Thresh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;re&shy;
scian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dresschen</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Treschen;</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Treggiare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="threshold(n)">Threshold,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;re&shy;
scian</etym>, to thresh, and our 
word <etym lang="en">Hold.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thrive(v)">To Thrive,</form> <xpln lang="en">or grow rich, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) 
to <etym lang="en">drive on,</etym> or go forward in 
the world.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="throat(n)">Throat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rot</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rot-bolla</etym>, the 
Throat-bowl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="throb(v)">Throb,</form> <xpln lang="en">or sigh, from the Gr.
 <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&omicron;&rho;&upsilon;&beta;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Minsh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="throng(n)">Throng,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rang</etym>, 
a Crowd; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;ringan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dring&shy;
hen,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tringen,</etym> or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Trenger,</etym> to thrust.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="throttle(n)">Throttle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tros&shy;
sel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or 'tis rather a di&shy;
minutive of <etym lang="en">Throat.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="throw(v)">To Throw,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;rawan</etym>, to cast.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="throes(n)">Throwes of Women in travail,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rowian</etym>, to 
suffer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thrum(n)">A Thrum,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Trum, 
Getrum</etym>, a Knot, or Thrum.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thrush(n)" lexeme="throstle(n)">A Thrush, or Throstle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;risc, &ETH;rostle</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drostle,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trostel,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thrust(v)">Thrust,</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Trudere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
though more probably from 
the Frequentative of it, <etym lang="la">Tru&shy;
sitare.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thumb(n)">Thumb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duym,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Daum,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;uma</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Z7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thump(n)">A Thump,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Thum&shy;
bo, Thombo</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F7B;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, 
to beat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thunder(n)">Thunder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;un&shy;
der</etym>, or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Donder, Donner,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;unnan</etym>, 
the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="bl">Dondern, 
Donneren</etym>, and the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tonner</etym>, to thunder; all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tonare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thursday(n)">Thursday,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;un&shy;
resdaeg,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Donder&shy;
dagh,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Donnerstag,</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Thorsdag,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
this from <etym lang="oe">Thor,</etym> the Heathen-&shy;
Saxons great God, <etym lang="la">Jupiter;</etym> 
or the God of <etym lang="en">Thunder,</etym> and 
<etym lang="oe">Dag,</etym> a day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thus(adv)">Thus,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;us</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thwack(n)">Thwack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zwac&shy;
ken,</etym> to strike; or from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tick-tack(n)">Tick-Tack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G 
<etym lang="fr">Trictac,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tricche 
Tracche,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all perhaps 
from a Law at gaming, <etym lang="en">Touch 
and Take</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ticket(n)">A Ticket,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Eti&shy;
quet, Etiquette,</etym> a Schedule, 
or Bill; or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tegoda,</etym> 
a Billet sent the Inhabitants, 
for the quartering of Soul&shy;
diers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tickle(v)" lexeme="kittle(v)">To Tickle, or Kittle,</form> <xpln lang="en">as 'tis used 
far North; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Tinclan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tin&shy;
telen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Kittle, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Citelan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Kittelen</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kitzlen,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from <etym lang="en">Cat, Kitten,</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Kitling,</etym> that love to be 
stroak'd and tickled.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tide(n)">Tide,</form> <xpln lang="en">the ebbing and flowing 
of the Sea; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tid</etym>,
 the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zeit,</etym> or the Belg. 
 and Dan. <etym lang="tt">Tiid,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tider(adv)">Tider,</form> <xpln lang="en">as, The Tider you go 
the better, an expression fre&shy;
quently used in the North of 
England; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tid</etym>, 
Tide, or Time; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
sooner you go the better.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tiding(n)">Tidings,</form> <xpln lang="en">or News, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tiidinghe,</etym> or the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Zetiung,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tike(n)" lexeme="tick(n)">Tike, Tick, or Teeck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from
 the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tic, Tique;</etym> 
 or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tike, Teecke,</etym> 
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; 'tis a vermin that an&shy;
 noys Cows, Sheep, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tick(n)">Tike, or Tick of a Bed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tiicke,</etym> the same; 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tego,</etym> to 
cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tile(n)">Tile,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tigel</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Tegl,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tuile,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Cichel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tegula,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tile(n)">Till,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Til</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="till(v)">To Till,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tilian, 
Tilean</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tuy&shy;
len</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tilt(v)">To Tilt</form> <xpln lang="en">a Vessel, or make it 
stoop afore; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Tillen,</etym> to lift up, to wit, be&shy;
hind; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Tollere,</etym> to lift up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="timber(n)">Timber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tim&shy;
bre</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tommer,</etym> or 
</page> 

<page sig="Z8r"> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Timber, Timmer,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Atim&shy;
 brian</etym>, to build with Tim&shy;
 ber. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="timbrel(n)">Timbrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tym&shy;
bale,</etym> and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Tympanum,</etym> the same; this 
from <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F7B;&pi;&tau;&omega;</etym>, to beat upon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="thyme(n)">Time,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Herb, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tyn,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Thymus,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="time(n)">Time,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tima</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Time,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Temps,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tempus;</etym> which comes 
from <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F73;&mu;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to divide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tin(n)">Tin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Tin,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zinne,</etym> the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estain,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Stagno,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Stannum,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tinder(n)">Tinder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zun&shy;
der, Zundel,</etym> or the AS. and 
Dan. <etym lang="oe">Tynder</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; which 
last comes from <etym lang="oe">Tynan</etym>, to 
kindle; from hence To Tine 
or Tin a Candle, for to 
Light a Candle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tingle(v)">Tingle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tinnire,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the 
sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tinker(v)">Tinker,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">&agrave; tinniendo,</etym> from ring&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tiny(a)">Tiny,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tynt,</etym> 
small, little; both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Tenuis,</etym> slender, or small.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tip(n)">Tip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tipken, 
Tip,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zipffel,</etym> 
the point or end of a thing. 
Minshew draws it from our 
word <etym lang="en">Top.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tipple(v)">To Tipple,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tipu&shy;
la</etym>, a Water-Spider; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">Tipulam agere,</etym> to play the 
Water-Spider; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to be al&shy;
ways drinking; or, from the 
Verb to <etym lang="en">Tipple;</etym> see Tip.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tire(v)">To Tire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tirian</etym>, 
to make weary.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tire(v)" lexeme="attire(v)">To Tire, or Attire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Attour,</etym> Dress for 
Womens heads; the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Zieren,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ziehren,</etym> 
to adorn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tire(n)">A Tire</form> <xpln lang="en">of Ordnance, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tuyer,</etym> a Row, to wit, 
of Guns, planted by each o&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="phthisic(n)">Tissick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tisico,</etym> 
one that's short-winded; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Phthisis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
this from <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&theta;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, to decay, or 
waste: Write Phthisick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tit(n)">Tit,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little Nag, from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Tau;&upsilon;&tau;&theta;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, little, dwarfish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tithe(n)">Tithe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Teo&eth;a</etym>, 
the tenth part; whence Te&shy;
o&eth;ian, to take Tithe of; 
from hence Tithing, a Term
 in Law.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="to(pp)">To,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">To</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Toe, Te,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zu,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toad(n)">Toad,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tudtze,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tade</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toe(n)">A Toe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ta</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Teen;</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Zehe</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. draws 
it from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to ex&shy;
tend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="together(adv)">Together,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tog&aelig;&eth;ere</etym>, 
</page> 

<page sig="Z8v"> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Te 
Gader,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; V. Gather. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toy(n)">Toies for Children;</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh. 
draws it from the Bel <etym lang="bl">Toyen,</etym> 
or <etym lang="bl">Tooghen,</etym> to adorn, or 
varnish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toil(n)">Toiles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Toiles,</etym> 
a sort of Nets.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="token(n)">Token,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tacn</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Teecken,</etym> the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Zeichn,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zeychen,</etym> 
a sign; whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tac&shy;
nian</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zeychnen</etym>, 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Teeckenen, Be&shy;
teeckenen</etym>, to betoken, or sig&shy;
nifie.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toll(n)">Toll,</form> <xpln lang="en">to pay Toll, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Toll</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tol,</etym> the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Told,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zoll,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tomb(n)">Tomb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tombe, Tombeau,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Tomber,</etym> or the Hisp <etym lang="sp">Tumba,</etym> 
a Sepulchre; <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F7B;&mu;&beta;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tong(n)">Tongs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tong</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tanghe,</etym> or the 
Dan. <etym lang="bl">Tang,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tengo,</etym> to hold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tongue(n)">Tongue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tunga, 
Tunge,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zung,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tonghe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all perhaps from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Phi;&theta;&#x1F79;&gamma;&gamma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, a sound; which 
comes from <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&theta;&#x1F73;&gamma;&gamma;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to 
speak, or give a sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tool(n)">A Tool,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Instrument, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Tol, Tohl</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Tool</etym>, in 
&AElig;lfr. <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tuylen,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Tilian</etym>, to labour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tooth(n)">Tooth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">To&eth;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; Te&eth;, the Teeth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="top(n)">Top,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. Dan and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Top,</etym> the top of any thing: 
Belg. and Dan. Topseyl, the 
top sail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="top(n)">A Top to be whipp'd on the 
Ice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Dan. 
<etym lang="bl">Top</etym> or <etym lang="da">Dop,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Topff,</etym>
 or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Toupie,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tope(v)">To Tope,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tou&shy;
pir,</etym> to be turn'd about, as 
in Drinkings we say, Put it 
about: Or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Toppen,</etym> to be mad; as we 
say, Too much drink makes
 him mad.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="topsy-turvy(adv)">Topsy-Turvy,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. d, the <etym lang="en">tops of 
Turves</etym> downward, Metapho&shy;
rically taken from Gravers of 
Turfs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="torch(n)">A Torch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Torche,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Torchia,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Torcia,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Torris,</etym> a Fire-brand; or <etym lang="la">&agrave; 
torquendo,</etym> from being twist&shy;
ed up together.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tortoise(n)">A Tortois,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Tortue,
 Tort&uacute;gue,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tartuga,</etym>
 or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tort&uacute;ga,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tory-rory(adv)" lexeme="Tory(n)">Tory-Rory, and an Irish Tory, 
or Thory,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Thor</etym> mad frantick; if not of 
an Irish original .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toss(v)">To Toss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tassen;</etym> 
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tasser,</etym> to 
throw on heaps.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toast(v)">To Tost,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tostare</etym> 
the Frequent. of <etym lang="la">Torrere,</etym> to 
rost.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="totter(v)">Totter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Teul&shy;
trian</etym>, to wag; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Touteren,</etym> to tremble.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toot(v)">To Tote, or Toot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tuyte, Tote,</etym> a Horn; 
whence <etym lang="bl">Tuyten, Toten</etym>, to 
wind a Horn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="touch(v)">To Touch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tou&shy;
cher,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Toccare;</etym> or 
the Sp. <etym lang="sp">Tocar,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tough(a)">Tough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Toh</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Taey;</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Zahe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tow(n)">Tow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tow</etym>, or
 the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Touw</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; both 
 not unlikely from the AS. 
 <etym lang="oe">Teon</etym>, to draw out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="toward(adv)">Toward,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zu&shy;
warts,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="towel(n)">Towel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Touaglio 
Touaglia,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Toualle;</etym> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Toalla,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tower(n)">Tower,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tor</etym>,
 the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tour;</etym> or the Ital. 
 and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Toure;</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
 from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Turris,</etym> the 
 same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="town(n)">Town,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, 
id. <etym lang="oe">Tunesman</etym>, a Towns-&shy;
man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="touse(v)">To Towze,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&omega;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&shy;
&omicron;&omega;</etym>, to run at one like a 
dog at a sheep; or from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&shy;
&tau;&#x1F7B;&zeta;&omega;</etym>, to terrifie.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trace(n)" lexeme="track(n)">A Trace, or Track,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the &shy;
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trace, Trac;</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Traccia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tractus,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tract(n)">Tract,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Treatise, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Traht</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tractatus,</etym> a 
Treatise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trade(n)">Trade,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tratta,</etym> 
Commerce; which comes, <etym lang="la">&agrave; 
Tradendo res necessarias,</etym> 
from yielding us things neces&shy;
sary.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traffic(n)">Traffique,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tra&shy;
fique;</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trafike,</etym> &shy;
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from <etym lang="la">Trans,</etym> be&shy;
yond (to wit) the Sea, and 
<etym lang="la">Facere,</etym> to act, or do.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trail(v)">To Trail,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Train, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trelen,</etym> to draw with 
ropes; or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Trainer, Traisner;</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Trainare,</etym> to draw by 
force.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="train(n)">Train,</form> <xpln lang="en">or guard, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Train,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Traina,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traitor(n)">A Traitour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Traistre,</etym> the Ital <etym lang="it">Traditore,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Traditor,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>;
 <term lang="la">i.e. qui tradit,</term> he that de&shy;
 livers up his Prince or Coun&shy;
 try to the enemy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trammel-net(n)">A Tramel-Net,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tramail, Tremaille,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trample(v)">Trample,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Trampeln,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Trampolare,</etym> to go in 
Stilts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trance(n)">A Trance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Transe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trap(n)">Trap,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Treppe</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trape,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Trappola,</etym> a Trap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trap-door(n)">Trap-door,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Trap,</etym>
 id or from the other <etym lang="en">Trap.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traipse up and down(v)">To Trapt up and down,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Traven,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Drabben,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trash(n)">Trash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut, <etym lang="tt">Tru&shy;
sen. Drusen,</etym> the Dregs, or 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa1v">
off-scourings of things; or 
the Teut. and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Dreck,</etym> 
Dung. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="travail(n)">Travail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tra&shy;
vail,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Travaglio,</etym> 
the same; whence the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Travailler</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tra&shy;
vagliare</etym>, to Travail; all 
from <etym lang="la">Trans,</etym> beyond, and 
<etym lang="la">Valere,</etym> to be able.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="traverse(a)">Traverse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="la">Tra&shy;
versa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; overthwart, or 
cross-wise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trave(n)">Traves,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Traves 
de bestia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; they are put 
upon a Horses Legs when 
he is taught to amble, or pace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="travested(a)">Travested,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Travesti,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Travestita,</etym> 
one disguised in apparel he 
was not wont to wear, q. d, 
<etym lang="la">Trans vestitus,</etym> having on 
change of raiment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tray(n)">Tray, for Butchers,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tragen,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Draeghen,</etym> to carry; these 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Trahere,</etym> to 
draw.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treachery(n)">Treachery,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tricherie,</etym> Fraud; this from 
<etym lang="fr">Tricher,</etym> to impose, or put 
upon one; both metapho&shy;
rically from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tric&aelig;,</etym> 
Gins, Snares.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treacle(n)">Treacle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tria&shy;
eckel,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Thria&shy;
cle, Theriaque,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Theriaca,</etym> a 
remedy against the poisonous 
bitings of wild beasts; this 
from <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&eta;&rho;#x1F77;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, a Viper, the 
powder of Vipers being the 
principal ingredient in it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tread(v)">Tread,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tredan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Treden,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Tretten,</etym> to go or tread.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treason(n)">Treason,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trahi&shy;
son,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Traditione,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; see Traitour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treasure(n)">Treasure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Thre&shy;
sor,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tesoro,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Thesaurus,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this &Pi;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F70; &tau;&#x1F78; <etym lang="gk">&epsilon;&#x1F30;&#x03c2; &alpha;&#x1F04;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&nu; 
&tau;&iota;&theta;&#x1F73;&nu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to lay up against to 
morrow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treat(v)">To Treat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trai&shy;
cter,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trattare,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Traitar,</etym> to enter&shy;
tain; also to have a Treaty 
or Discourse with one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treatise(n)">A Treatise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. Barb. 
<etym lang="la">Tractatus,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Traict&eacute;,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trattato,</etym> any 
book in which any Argument 
<etym lang="la">tractatur,</etym> is handled and ex&shy;
pounded.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treble(a)">Treble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Triple,</etym> 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Triplex,</etym> three-fold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="treddle(n)" lexeme="treadle(n)">The Treddles, or Treadles of a 
Weaver's Beam,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our 
word to <etym lang="en">Tread;</etym> for that a 
Weaver in weaving, treads on 
these pieces of wood, first 
with one foot, and then with 
the other.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tree(n)">Tree,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Treo, 
Trew</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tree</etym>, id. 
Minsh. and Mer. Cas. draw it 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&rho;&#x1F7A;&#x03c2;</etym>, an Oak-&shy;
tree, which at first signified 
a Tree in general.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trefoil(n)">Trefoil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Treffle</etym>, 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa2r"> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tri&shy;
folium;</etym> this <etym lang="la">&agrave; tribus foliis,</etym> 
for that it is three-leav'd. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tremble(v)">To Tremble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Trembler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trem&shy;
bolare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Tremere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trench(n)">Trench,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tren&shy;
ch&eacute;e,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trincea,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trendle(n)">The Trendel of a Mill,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Trendl</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Tren&shy;
del</etym>, a globe, centre, or cir&shy;
cle; see Trundle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trepan(n)">Trepan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chirurgeon's Tre&shy;
pan, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&rho;&#x1F7B;&pi;&alpha;&nu;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&rho;&#x1F7B;&pi;&alpha;</etym>, a 
Hole, or <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&rho;&upsilon;&pi;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to pierce 
through.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trespass(v)">To Trespass,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Trespasser,</etym> to violate a Law; 
this from <etym lang="la">Trans,</etym> beyond, and 
<etym lang="la">Passus,</etym> a step, or Path.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tress(n)">A Tress of hair,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tresse,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Treccia,</etym> a 
lock of hair curled.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trestle(n)">A Trestle of a Table,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tresteau,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Tretteau,</etym> 
a prop or stay, consisting of 
three feet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tret(n)">The Tret,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Term in Merchan&shy;
dice, which is an allowance or 
overplus given in goods that 
are tainted; not unlikely from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tritus,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Attritus,</etym> 
wasted, or impair'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trivet(n)">A Trevet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rie&shy;
fet</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trepied,</etym> or 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tripus,</etym> a three foot&shy;
ed stool.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trick(n)">A Trick,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Tuck,</etym> craftiness, by an inter&shy;
position of the Letter r; or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tricher,</etym> to 
put a trick upon one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trick up(v)" lexeme="deck(v)">To Trick up, or deck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&rho;&#x1F76;&xi;</etym>, Hair, saith Minsh. 
From the Lat. <etym lang="la">Intricare,</etym> to 
intangle, or plait the hair, 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trickle(n)">Trickle,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps, (q. d.) <etym lang="en">Drip&shy;
ple,</etym> and this from <etym lang="en">Drip,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Drop</etym>. Minsh. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&rho;&#x1F73;&chi;&omega;</etym>, to run. Skin&shy;
ner from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trecken,</etym> 
or its Dimin. <etym lang="bl">Treckelen,</etym> to 
draw out in length.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trifle(n)">Trifles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Treyfe&shy;
leu,</etym> to trifle; or from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Tricae,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Triccare;</etym> to play the wag.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trig(v)" lexeme="trig your trig(v)">Trig, and Trig your Trig,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Tricker,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trucken,</etym> to press, (i.
e.) to tread firm in the place 
marked.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"trig your trig" not found as a phrase in the OED.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trill(n)">Trill in Musick,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Trillo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tril&shy;
len, Drillen,</etym> to shake, or 
quaver; or the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;rilian</etym>, 
to pierce, as we say of a shrill 
sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trim(a)" lexeme="neat(a)">Trim, or neat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Getrymed</etym>, trimm'd up; 
this from, the AS. <etym lang="oe">Trim&shy;
man</etym>, to build up, to make 
sure and sound, by a Meta&shy;
phor drawn from Archite&shy;
cture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trip(v)">To Trip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trip&shy;
pen, Trippelen;</etym> or the Fr. Gr. 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa2v"> 
<etym lang="fr">Treper,</etym> to dance; all, not 
unlikely, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tri&shy;
pudiare,</etym> to dance. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tripe(n)">Tripe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tripe,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trippa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="troupe(n)">A Troup,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Troupe,</etym> 
or the Hisp: <etym lang="sp">Tropa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Turba,</etym> a Com&shy;
pany, by a transposition of 
the Letter r.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trot(v)">To Trot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trot&shy;
ter,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trottare,</etym> the 
Hisp <etym lang="sp">Trotar;</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Trotten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trouble(v)">To Trouble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Troubler,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Torbola&shy;
re,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Turbare,</etym> to disturb, by a 
Metathesis.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trough(n)">A Trough,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Trog</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Troch,</etym> the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Trug,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Truogo;</etym> or 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Thruk,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trout(n)">Trout,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Truht</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Truite,</etym> the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Trucha,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trutta;</etym> or 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Trocta,</etym> a Fish so 
called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trow(v)">I Trow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tru&shy;
pian</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trawen,</etym> or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Troer,</etym> to believe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trowel(n)">A Trowel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tru&shy;
elle;</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Troweel,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Trulla,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="troll away(v)">To Trowl away;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Drollen,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trol&shy;
ler,</etym> to walk unseemly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="troy weight(n)">Troy-weight,</form> <xpln lang="en">not from Troy, a 
City in Phrygia, as 't would 
seem at first sight; but from 
the chief City of the <etym lang="fr">Troyes,</etym> a 
People in <term lang="la">Gallia Celtica</term>, 
which is now called <term lang="fr">Troyes en 
Champaigne</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truant(a)">Truant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trou&shy;
want;</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Truant,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the AS <etym lang="oe">&ETH;urh</etym>, 
 through, and <etym lang="oe">Wendan</etym>, to 
 wander.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truce(n)">Truce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Treues,</etym> 
or the It and Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tregua,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truck(v)">To Truck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tro&shy;
quer,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Truccare,</etym> or 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Trocar,</etym> to exchange 
one commodity for another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truckle-bed(n)">Truckle-bed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Troch&shy;
lea,</etym> a pully, or wheel, saith 
the learned Th. H. It being a 
low sort of Bed having wheels, 
so that it may be drawn which 
way one pleases.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trudge(v)">Trudge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trucca&shy;
re, Truggiolare,</etym> to run from 
place to place; or from our 
word <etym lang="en">Trot.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="true(a)">True,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tripe</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trouw;</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Trew,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; AS. <etym lang="oe">Treop&eth;e</etym>, 
truth, or Fidelity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trull(n)">A Trull,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. and Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Trulla,</etym> a sluttish woman. Mer. 
Cas. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Mu;&alpha;&tau;&rho;&#x1F7B;&lambda;&lambda;&eta;</etym>, a Bawd, or com&shy;
mon Prostitute.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trump(n)" lexeme="Jew's-trump(n)">Trump, Jews-Trump,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trompe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trump(n)">Trum<emend err="">p</emend> in Cards,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Triomphe,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Trionfo,</etym> 
or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Trumpff,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Triumphus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa3r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trumpery(n)">Trumpery,</form> <xpln lang="en">or old Lumber, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tromperie,</etym> fraud, 
or guile; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  vitiated goods, 
in buying whereof, people 
are frequently cheated.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trumpet(n)">A Trumpet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Trompette, Trompe,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Trombetta;</etym> or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Trom&shy;
peta, Trompa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truncheon(n)">A Truncheon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tronson, Transon,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trundle(n)">Trundle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Trendl</etym>, a globe, or circle; 
or from the Fr. Picard. <etym lang="pi">Tron&shy;
deler,</etym> to run like a Ball. V. 
Round.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trunk(n)">A Trunk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Trun&shy;
cus,</etym> the trunk of a tree; and 
hence the other Trunk, a Cof&shy;
fer, for similitudes sake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="truss(v)">To Truss,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trous&shy;
ser,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trossen,</etym> to 
truss up Bag and Baggage: 
Whence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Trousseau</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Trosse</etym>, and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Trosz</etym>, a Truss or Pack.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="trust(n)">Trust,</form> <xpln lang="en">V. <etym lang="en">True,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Trow.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tub(n)">Tub,</form> <xpln lang="en">by a little variation of the 
sence, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tobbe,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ruffe,</etym> a cup; 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Cuba de vino,</etym> a 
Pipe of wine; this last from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cupa,</etym> a Tun, or 
Pipe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tuck(n)">A Tuck,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Estoc,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Stocco,</etym> a sort of 
long sword so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tuck(v)">To Tuck up the Bed-cloaths,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tuch,</etym> Cloth; 
or <etym lang="tt">Tucken,</etym> to hide or co&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tuesday(n)">Tuesday,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, 
the Saxons God of War, and 
<etym lang="oe">D&aelig;g</etym>, a day; q. Tun's-day. 
Tun was the same with Twis&shy;
co, the God of the Almanes, 
or Osterlingi, a People of 
Germany; and Mars of the 
Latins: Whence in Lat. <etym lang="la">Dies Martis</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tuft(n)">A Tuft,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zopff;</etym> &shy;
or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Touffet, Touffe,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tug(v)">Tug,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Getogen</etym>, 
drawn out, being a Part. of 
the Verb, <etym lang="oe">Teon</etym>, to draw;
 or more likely from the old 
 Belg. <etym lang="bl">Toghen,</etym> to pull.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tulip(n)">Tulip,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Tulippe,</etym> 
or <etym lang="fr">Tulipan;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tuli&shy;
pa,</etym> or <etym lang="it">Tulipano,</etym> a kind of 
Flower, so called, from the 
similitude of a Tulipan, or 
Turbant, a sort of Cap wore 
by the Turks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tumble(v)">To Tumble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tom&shy;
melen,</etym> or the Ital <etym lang="it">Tombolare, 
Tomolare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Tumler,</etym> to slip.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tun(n)">A Tun,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tunne</etym>, 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tonne, Tonneau,</etym> the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Tono;</etym> or the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Tonne;</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tune(n)">Tune,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. d Tone, from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Tonus,</etym> and this from <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&epsilon;&#x1F77;&nu;&omega;</etym>, 
to extend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tunnel(n)">Tunnel, or Funnel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Entonnoir,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Infundibulum,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tunny(n)">A Tunny,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Thon&shy;
nin, Tonnin,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Atun,</etym> 
or the It. <etym lang="it">Tonno,</etym> a fish, so cal&shy;
led; all from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F7B;&nu;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turban(n)">A Turbant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Tourban;</etym> or the Ital. and Sp. 
<etym lang="sp">Turbante,</etym> a sort of Turkish 
Cap. It is of a Turc. or Arab. 
Original .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turbot(n)">A Turbot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tur&shy;
bot,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Turbutt;</etym> or Fr. G.
 <etym lang="fr">Turbot,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>: It may like&shy;
 wise be drawn from <etym lang="la">Turbo,</etym> 
 or the Eng. <etym lang="en">Tuen,</etym> and the 
 Teut. <etym lang="tt">Butte,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bot,</etym> 
 an End; a Fish of the kind of 
 Plaice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turd(n)">Turd,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tord</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Torde, Tort,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turf(n)">Turf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Turfe, 
Tyrf</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Torf, Turf,</etym>
 the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Torff;</etym> or the Ital.
 <etym lang="it">Tuffo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all perhaps from 
 the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F7B;&phi;&omega;</etym>, to raise a smoke, 
 as it doth in burning.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turkey(n)">Turky,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a <etym lang="en">Turkish,</etym> or Afri&shy;
can Fowl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Turkey colour(a)">Turky-colour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tur&shy;
chino,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or perhaps, be&shy;
cause <etym lang="en">Turks</etym> affect that co&shy;
lour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turmeric(n)">Turmeric,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Terra merita,</etym> 
as Lobel. and D. H. surmise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turmoil(n)">Turmoil,</form> <xpln lang="en">to trouble or afflict, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tremouille,</etym> a 
Mill-hopper, or <etym lang="fr">Tremouiller,</etym> 
to grind; all perhaps <etym lang="la">&agrave; Tre&shy;
mendo,</etym> from trembling and 
shaking.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turn(v)">To Turn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tyr&shy;
nan</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tourner,</etym> or
 the Ital. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Tornare,</etym> 
 to turn or work with the 
 wheel; from hence the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">par Tourn&eacute;e</etym>, with us, by 
turns, as also <etym lang="fr">Tourneur</etym>, a 
Turner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tournament(n)">Turnament,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Tourney, from 
the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Tournoy,</etym> the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Torneo;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Tornea&shy;
mento,</etym> the exercise at Tilts; 
all from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tourner,</etym> 
or Ital. <etym lang="it">Tornare,</etym> to turn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turnip(n)">Turnep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our words, <etym lang="en">Turn</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">up,</etym> from its growing 
spire-wise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turpentine(n)">Turpentine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Turbentine;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ter&shy;
pentina,</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>, all from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Terebinthina,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turret(n)">Turret,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dimin. of <etym lang="en">Tower;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="turtle(n)">Turtle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Turtle</etym>, 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Tourterelle;</etym> or the 
Ital. <etym lang="it">Tortora, Tortola,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Turtur,</etym> of 
the same signification.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tusk(n)">Tusks,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tuxas</etym>, 
the Jaw-teeth of a Boar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tut-mouthed(a)">Tut-mouth'd,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Tit-mouth'd,</etym> 
by an Antiphrasis; or from 
Teat, and <etym lang="en">Mouth;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twain(n)">Twain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Twegen</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zween,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twang(n)">Twang,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">&agrave; Tango,</etym> to touch, 
Minsh. Or from the sound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twattle(v)">To Twattle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Swetsen,</etym> or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwat&shy;
zen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twelve(n)">Twelve,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Twelf</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Twaelve,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zwelff,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa4r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twenty(n)">Twenty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Twen&shy;
tig</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tweentigh,</etym> 
the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Vingt;</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Venti,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Viginti,</etym> Twenty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twig(n)">A Twig,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Twig, 
Twiga,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zweig,</etym> or
 the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Twtigh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twilight(n)">Twilight,</form> <xpln lang="en">because it partakes of 
<etym lang="en">two Lights</etym>, to wit, of the 
Sun and Moon; or for that 
it is between two Lights, the 
one setting and the other ri&shy;
sing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twine(n)">Twine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Twin</etym>; 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tweyn, Tween,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Twinan</etym>, or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Tweynen, 
Twimen,</etym> to twine, or make 
a double thread. V. Twain, 
and Two.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twinge(v)">To Twinge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Zwingen,</etym> to squeeze, or the 
 Dan. <etym lang="da">Tvinger, Fvinger,</etym> to 
 wrest out, to extort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twinkle(v)">Twinkle,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Winkle,</etym> from 
the Verb, to <etym lang="en">Wink;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twin(n)">Twins,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Getwpin</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; see Twine, and Two.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twirl(v)">To Twirl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ciur&shy;
lare, Zurlare,</etym> to turn about 
hastily; or from our Word 
<etym lang="en">Whirl;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twist(v)">To Twist,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
twistan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Twi&shy;
sten,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twit(v)">To Twit,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Edwi&shy;
tan</etym>, to upbraid; this from 
the Prefix <etym lang="oe">Ed</etym>, again, and 
<etym lang="oe">Witan</etym>, to blame; or, as it 
were, to give to wit, that is, 
to make one understand his fault.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twitch(v)">To Twitch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Twic&shy;
can, Twiccian</etym>, or the Teut.
 <etym lang="tt">Zwicken,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="twitter(v)">Twitter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zittern,</etym> 
to tremble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="two(n)">Two,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tu, Tua</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Twa</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Twii, 
Twee;</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Zwey, 
Zwo;</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="tie(v)">To Ty,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tian</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="V"><alpha>V</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veil(n)">A VAil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Voile,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Witle, Wiele,</etym>
