<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ve&shy;
lum,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Velo,</etym> to cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vail(v)">To Vail his Bonnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Avaller le bonnet,</etym> to 
put off his Hat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vain(a)">Vain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vain,</etym> and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vanus,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaivode(n)">Vaivod,</form> <xpln lang="en">as the Vaivod of Tran&shy;
sylvania, from the Scla. and 
Sarm. <etym lang="sa">Waiwod,</etym> a Governor 
of a Province.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valance(n)">Vallens, or Valances of a Bed,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Valenzane,</etym> id. 
first used perhaps at Valentia 
in Spain.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valiant(a)">Valiant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vail&shy;
lant,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Valens,</etym> able.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valour(n)">Valour,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Valeur,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; and Valorous, from 
 the Ital. <etym lang="it">Valoroso.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="valley(n)">A Valley,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr: G <etym lang="fr">Vall&eacute;e, 
Val&eacute;e,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Valla&shy;
ta,</etym> entrenched, to wit, with 
Hills.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="value(n)">Value,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Val&uuml;e,</etym> 
or the It. <etym lang="it">Valuta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Valor,</etym> the price
 or worth of a thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="van-courier(n)">Vancurriers</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Avant coureur,</etym> a Precursour,
 or light-arm'd Souldier, that 
 runs before the Army; this 
 from <etym lang="fr">Avant,</etym> before, and 
 <etym lang="fr">Courir,</etym> to run.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fang(v)">Vang,</form> <xpln lang="en">he vang'd for me at the 
Vant, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he undertook 
for me at the Font; 'tis an 
expression used by West-&shy;
Country-men, and is derived 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fengan, An&shy;
fengan</etym>, to undertake. 
Vant, cometh from the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Vand,</etym> Water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vanguard(n)">The Vanguard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Vanguardia,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Avant Garde,</etym> the Front of an 
Army, or Fore-Guard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vanish(v)">To Vanish;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Es&shy;
vanovir,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Svanire,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Va&shy;
nescere,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Evanescer,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vanquish(v)">To Vanquish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Vaincre,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vincere,</etym> to 
overcome.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="varlet(n)">Varlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Var&shy;
let,</etym> now <etym lang="fr">Vallet,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Valletto,</etym> a Servant, or Foot&shy;
page.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="varnish(n)">Varnish,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vernis,</etym>
 the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vernice,</etym> or the Hisp, 
 <etym lang="sp">Varniz.</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="varvel(n)">Varvels, for a Hawk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G <etym lang="fr">Vervelles,</etym> certain rings 
put about a Hawks Legs, ha&shy;
ving the Owner's Name en&shy;
graven upon them.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vassal(n)">Vassal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vassal,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vassallo,</etym> a Client,
 a Fee-Farmer, or Copy-holder; 
 or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gesel,</etym> one 
 bound to accompany or at&shy;
 tend others in times of war, 
 Spelman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vault(n)">A Vault,</form> <xpln lang="en">or Arch, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Voulte, Voute,</etym> the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Volta,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Voute,</etym> an 
Arch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vault(v)">To Vault,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the F.G. <etym lang="fr">Voltiger,</etym>
 the Ital. <etym lang="it">Volteggiare,</etym> or the 
 Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Boltear,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from 
 the Lat. <etym lang="la">Volitare,</etym> to fly, or 
 <etym lang="la">Volutare,</etym> to tumble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vaunt(v)">To Vaunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Van&shy;
ter,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vantare,</etym> id. 
these from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Van&egrave;,</etym> or 
<etym lang="la">Vanitas,</etym> Vanity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="udder(n)">Vdder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Uder</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vder, Euder;</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Euter,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Uber,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="veal(n)">Veal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Veau,</etym> id. 
both Contracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vi&shy;
tellus,</etym> a young Calf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vein(n)">A Vein,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Veine,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wegn</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
</page>

<page sig="Aa5r"> 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vena,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vellam(n)">Vellam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a smoothed skin, or 
parchment; from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Velamen,</etym> a cover; or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Velin,</etym> parchment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="velvet(n)">Velvet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Velours,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Veluto,</etym> id. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Villosum,</etym> hairy, or shaggy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vengeance(n)">Vengeance,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Ven&shy;
geance,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. V. Revenge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venison(n)">Venison,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Venai&shy;
son,</etym> id. or <etym lang="la">&agrave; Venatione,</etym> from
 hunting.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="venom(n)">Venom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Venim,</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vene&shy;
num,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vent(v)">To Vent,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Eventare, 
Sventare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ventus,</etym> wind; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>)
 to give wind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vent(v)">Vent,</form> <xpln lang="en">to sell off; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vente,</etym> the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Ven&shy;
ta,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vendita,</etym> id. all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vendere,</etym> to sell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdure(n)">Verdure,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ver&shy;
deur,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Verdezza,</etym> 
greenness</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verd(n)">Verd,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term in Heraldry; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Verd,</etym> or the
 Ital. <etym lang="it">Verde,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all Con&shy;
 tracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Viridis,</etym> 
 green.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdict(n)">Verdict,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Ver&egrave; dictum,</etym> a 
thing truly spoken, it being 
the consentaneous opinion of 
the Jury concerning a Delin&shy;
quent; which, according to 
Law, is held true and war&shy;
rantable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verdigris(n)">Verdigrease,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Verdegris,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Vertdegris,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verger(n)">A Verger,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ver&shy;
ger,</etym> an Apparitor, or Beadle; 
this from <etym lang="fr">Verge,</etym> which is again 
derived from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Virga,</etym> 
a wand, or Officer's staff.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verjuice(n)">Verjuice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ver&shy;
jus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Viridis,</etym> green, and <etym lang="en">Iuice.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vermilion(n)">Vermilion,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Ver&shy;
miglio,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vermi`l&shy;
lon, Vermeil,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vermin(n)">Vermin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ver&shy;
mine,</etym> or the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Ver&shy;
mina,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="virtue(n)">Vertue,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vertu,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Virtu;</etym> all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Virtus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="very(adv)">Very,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ver&egrave;,</etym> tru&shy;
ly: Or more immediately from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vray,</etym> true.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vespers(n)" lexeme="evening prayers(n)">Vespers, or Evening-Prayers;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vespres;</etym> and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vesper,</etym> the 
evening.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vessel(n)">Vessel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vaisselle, 
Vaisseau,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vascello,</etym>
 <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vas&shy;
 culum, Vascellum,</etym> the Dim. of 
 <etym lang="la">Vas,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestry(n)">Vestrey,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Vestiarium.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vesture(n)">A Vesture,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ve&shy;
sture,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vestura,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vestire,</etym> to 
cloath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ugly(a)">Vgly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ogelic</etym>, 
id. Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ooghen,</etym> 
the eyes, and <etym lang="bl">Laeden,</etym> to loath; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) that which is offensive 
or loathsome to look upon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vial(n)">Vial,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Phiole,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Phiala,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viceroy(n)">Vice&shy;
roy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vice&shy;
roy,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vicer&egrave;,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="victual(n)">Victuals,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vi&shy;
ctuailles,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vittouag&shy;
lia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Victua&shy;
lia,</etym> things appertaining to the 
feeding the body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="view(n)">A View,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ve&uuml;e,</etym> 
a view, or sight of; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Videre,</etym> to see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="village(n)">Village,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Village,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Villaggio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Villa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="villain(n)">A Villain,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vi&shy;
lain,</etym> a filthy, wicked fellow; 
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vilis,</etym> 
contemptible, of no esteem.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vinegar(n)">Vinegar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vinai&shy;
gre,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vinagro,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vinum Acre,</etym>
 sharp or eager wine; q. d. 
 Wine-eager.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vineyard(n)">Vineyard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Win-&shy;
Geard</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wilingaerd,</etym> 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vinyaard,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weingart,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vintage(n)">Vintage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ven&shy;
denge, Vendange,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Vindemia,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vintner(n)">Vintner,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vina&shy;
tiere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and both from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vinum,</etym> wine.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="violet(n)">Violet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Violette,</etym> 
or the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Violeta;</etym> all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Viola,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viol(n)">A Viol,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Violle,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Viola,</etym> a musical 
instrument so called: From 
hence comes the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Violin</etym>, 
and the Ital. <etym lang="it">Violino</etym>; with 
us, A Violin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="virginal(n)">Virginal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a musical instrument 
so named, because that <etym lang="en">Vir&shy;
gins</etym> are mostly taught to play 
upon it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="visage(n)">Visage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Visage,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Visaggio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Visus,</etym> sight.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vizard(n)">Visard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Visiere,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Visiera,</etym> or the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Vizera,</etym> the holes, or eyes of 
an helmet; with us, any o&shy;
ther mask; also a spirit ap&shy;
pearing by night.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="viscount(n)">Viscount, or Vicount,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Viconte,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Visconte,</etym> id. all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Vicecomes,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vice(n)" lexeme="screw(n)">A Vise, or Skrew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vis,</etym> a skrew; or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vuse,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
<etym lang="bl">Vusen</etym>, to skrew up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vitriol(n)">Vitriol,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vitriol,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vitriolo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
all from the Lat. Barb. <etym lang="la">Vitrio&shy;
lum;</etym> this again <etym lang="la">&agrave; Vitreo co&shy;
lore,</etym> because it is of a trans&shy;
parent, glassy colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umber(n)">Vmber,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Um&shy;
bre, Umbrette,</etym> a fish so cal&shy;
led; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Um&shy;
bra,</etym> a shadow; because the 
gall of it is good against 
specks, or film of the eyes, 
and prevents blindness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbles(n)">Vmbles,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Nom&shy;
bles d'un Cerf</etym>, the Umbles of 
a Deer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umbrage(n)">Vmbrage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Om&shy;
brage,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Umbraculum,</etym> a thing to 
keep off the Sun.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="umpire(n)">Vmpire,</form> <xpln lang="en">or an Arbitrator, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Empairer,</etym> to 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa6r"> 
couple together; this from 
<etym lang="fr">En,</etym> and <etym lang="fr">Paire,</etym> a pair. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="un(px)">Vn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Preposition Negative; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">In,</etym> which, in 
Composition, is often Nega&shy;
tive: Or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">On,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ohn,</etym> or the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&nu;&epsilon;&upsilon;</etym>, without.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="unawares(adv)">Vnawares,</form> <xpln lang="en">It came Vnawares, 
from <etym lang="en">Vn,</etym> a Prefix Neg. Insep. 
and <etym lang="en">Aware;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uncouth(a)">Vncouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">and old word, signify&shy;
ing strange; from <etym lang="en">Vn,</etym> or <etym lang="en">In,</etym> 
Negative, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cu&eth;</etym>, 
known.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="under(pp)">Vnder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Under</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Onder,</etym> or the Teut. 
and Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vnder,</etym> id. from 
hence, An Vnderling. Vnder 
is frequently put in composi&shy;
tion with other words; as with 
Vnderstand, Vndertake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ungainly(a)">Vngainly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ohue 
Gewinn,</etym> without progress; 
or from <etym lang="en">Vn,</etym> a Prefix Neg. 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wine</etym>, grateful, 
or acceptable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uncle(n)">Vnkle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Oncle;</etym> 
both Contracts of the Lat. <etym lang="la">A&shy;
vunculus,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="unless(c)">Vnless,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">One less,</etym> one thing 
excepted: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Onlesan</etym>, to let pass, or 
omit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="unwieldy(a)">Vnweildy,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Vn,</etym> signifying 
not, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, 
to wield, or govern.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voyage(n)">Voiage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Voyage,</etym>
 or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Viaggio,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voice(n)">A Voice,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Voix;</etym> 
both from the Lat <etym lang="la">Vox,</etym> a voice, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="void(a)">Void,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vuide,</etym> 
or the Ital <etym lang="it">Vuoto,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="voided(a)">Voided, Cross-Voided,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term 
in Heraldry; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Croix Vuid&eacute;e,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln>
<lemenote>
For "cross-voided", see "voided per cross" (OED, "'voided," adj., 2c).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vogue(n)">Vogue,</form> <xpln lang="en">as, The Common Vogue, 
or speech of the vulgar; from 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Voga,</etym> or the Fr. G.
 <etym lang="fr">Vogue,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; these from the 
 Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Voguer,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vo&shy;
 gare,</etym> to sail freely; all from 
 the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vagari,</etym> to wander.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="volunteer(n)">Voluntier,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Vo&shy;
luntaire,</etym> voluntary; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that, out of his own free will, 
lists himself a Soldier; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Voluntas,</etym> the 
will.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vouchsafe(v)">Vouchsafe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the word <etym lang="en">Vouch,</etym> 
for <etym lang="en">Avouch,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Safe;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
to promise one secure posses&shy;
sion of any thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vow(n)">A Vow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">V&oelig;u,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence <etym lang="fr">Vouer</etym>, to vow; 
which comes from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Vovere</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vowel(n)">Vowel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Voyelle;</etym> 
and both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Voca&shy;
lis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="up(adv)">Vp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Op,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Auff.</etym> the Fr. 
Th. <etym lang="hd">Vf,</etym> or <etym lang="hd">Vph,</etym> or the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Up</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; Uper, upper. 
Divers Compounds arise from 
hence; as, Vphold, Vpright, 
Vpstart, Vpward, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="upbraid(v)">Vpbraid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Up-ge&shy;
braedan</etym>, id. Also, To make 
<etym lang="en">Broad,</etym> or amplifie; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to 
make more of a thing or fault 
than it is.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="upholster(n)">Vpholster,</form> <xpln lang="en">he that sells all sorts 
of bedding; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A <etym lang="en">Bolsterer,</etym> 
saith the learned Dr. Th. H. 
or rather, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Vpholder.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="uproar(n)">Vprore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Op,</etym> with 
us Vp, and <etym lang="bl">Roeren,</etym> to touch, 
or lay hands on; or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Auff,</etym> upon, and <etym lang="tt">Ruchren,</etym> to 
make a confusion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vpshot(n)">Vpshot,</form> <xpln lang="en">the end, or event of 
things; a Metaphor drawn 
from Vintners, or Victuallers, 
who say, The <etym lang="en">shot</etym> is paid, All 
is paid, and all is in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="urchin(n)">Vrchin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ircing, 
Ercen</etym>, an Hedge-hog; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ericinus,</etym> or 
<etym lang="la">Ericius,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ure(n)">Vre,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of the Lat. <etym lang="la">U&shy;
sura,</etym> an accustoming to; and 
this <etym lang="la">ab Utendo,</etym> from using.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="us(pr)">Vs,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Us</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Ons,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Vns,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="usage(n)">Vsage,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Usage,</etym> 
custom; this from <etym lang="fr">User,</etym> to 
use, or to get a custom of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="usher(n)">Vsher,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Huissier,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Usciere,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="usurer(n)">Vsurer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Usurier,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Usuriere, Usura&shy;
so,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; hence the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Usure</etym>, and the Ital. <etym lang="fr">Usura</etym>, 
usury.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="utter(v)">Vtter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Utter, 
Uttor</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Uttur</etym>, the 
same. V. Out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="volcano(n)">A Vulcano, or Volcano,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Ita&shy;
lian word, signifying a moun&shy;
tain that casts out smoak and 
flames, as &AElig;tna doth; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Lat. <etym lang="la">Mons Vulcanius</etym>, Vul&shy;
can's Mount.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="W"><alpha>W</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waddle(v)">WAddle,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wadeln, Wedeln,</etym> to wag 
the tail, this from <etym lang="tt">Wadel,</etym> the 
tail; or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wagghelen, 
Waegelen,</etym> to waggle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wade(v)">To Wade,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wadan</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waden, Waeden,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wadten, Watten,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Va&shy;
dare,</etym> to wade over; or <etym lang="la">Va&shy;
dum,</etym> the ford of a river.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wafer(n)">A Wafer,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wae&shy;
sel,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Waffell</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gauffre,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waft(v)">To Waft a Ship, or Navy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a term 
amongst Mariners, and by 
them used, when a Man, or 
Men of War conduct and pro&shy;
tect Ships of burthen upon 
the Seas; from the Teut and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wachten,</etym> to watch, or 
guard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wag(n)">Wag,</form> <xpln lang="en">A notable Wag from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;gan</etym>, to play the 
wag; or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Vago,</etym> acute, 
witty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wag(v)">To Wag,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeg&shy;
hen,</etym> or the AS <etym lang="oe">Wagian</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; from hence the word 
Wagtail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wage(v)">To Wage</form> <xpln lang="en">War, or Law, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wagen,</etym> to run ha&shy;
zards; this from <etym lang="tt">Wag,</etym> a pair 
of scales.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wager(n)">A Wager,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ga&shy;
geure,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence Gager, 
to contend for a wager: Or 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;gan</etym>, to 
play; as, I will play Ten 
Pounds on my Horse's side, 
against yours.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wage(n)">Wages</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gages,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. V. Engage, and Gage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wagon(n)">Wagon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;gen</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeghen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wagen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeghner</etym>, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wagner</etym>, a Wagoner: 
Or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Wag on.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wayfaring man(a)">A Waifaring-Man,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Eng. <etym lang="en">Way,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fa&aelig;ran</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaeren,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fahren,</etym> to go. Write 
Wayfaring.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wail(v)">To Wail,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guala&aelig;re, Guaire,</etym> to lament: Or 
from the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guai,</etym> the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">V&aelig;,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wa</etym>, Interje&shy;
ctions of sorrow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wainscot(v)">To Wainscot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wand,</etym> a wall, and 
<etym lang="bl">Schotten,</etym> to defend (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to 
strengthen a wall.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wait(v)" lexeme="waiter(n)">Wait, Waiter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
and Teut <etym lang="tt">Wachten,</etym> to watch; 
whence <etym lang="tt">Wacht</etym>, a watch, and 
<etym lang="tt">Wachter</etym>, a Watch-man: Or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guetter,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guatare,</etym> to observe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wayward(a)" lexeme="morose(a)">Waiward, or Morose;</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weigern,</etym> to 
refuse, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
nature; it denoting one that 
by nature is averse to good ad&shy;
vice. Write Wayward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wake(v)">To Wake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waec&shy;
ken,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wachen,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wacian</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wake(n)">Wakes,</form> <xpln lang="en">Feasts used among Chri&shy;
stians, both for the first day 
of the Consecration of any 
Church, and for the Anniver&shy;
sary of it; from the word, To 
<etym lang="en">Wake</etym>; for that the night is 
often spent in watching, and 
singing Chorus's. Spelman 
draws it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wac</etym>, 
drunkenness; in which, such 
Feasts too frequently termi&shy;
nate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="walk(v)">To Walk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan <etym lang="da">Vane&shy;
ker,</etym> id. or, the sence some&shy;
what varied, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wealcan</etym>, to rowl from one 
side to another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waulker(n)">Walker,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Northern word, sig&shy;
nifying a Fuller of Cloth; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Walcker,</etym> id. 
this from <etym lang="bl">Walcken,</etym> or the 
Ital <etym lang="it">Gualcare,</etym> to full, or press 
cloth so as to make it smooth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wall(n)">Wall,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wall, 
Wealle,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Walle,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wall</etym>, id and all from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vallum,</etym> a trench.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wallet(n)">A Wallet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr G. <etym lang="fr">Valise,</etym> 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Valigia,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Fellis,</etym> id. Or, more likely from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wallen,</etym> to travel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wallow(v)">Wallow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Walwian, 
Awylian,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weltzen,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wellen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wallowish(a)">Wallowish, or Walsh,</form> <xpln lang="en">Taste, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
raw, and without salt; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Walghe,</etym> Loathsom&shy;
ness, or <etym lang="bl">Walghen,</etym> to be nauseous; 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa7v"> 
or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wealh</etym>, or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Welsch,</etym> 
strange, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  strange tastes. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="walnut(n)">Walnuts,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Walh-&shy;
Hnutu</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Walsche 
Nuts, that is, Nuts brought 
from a strange Country. V. 
Welch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wamble(v)">To Wamble,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wamb</etym>, 
the womb.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wan(a)">Wan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wan</etym>, pale; 
hence <etym lang="oe">Wannan</etym>, to grow pale.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wand(n)">Wand,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vaand</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from our word, to 
<etym lang="en">Wind;</etym> because it is flexible.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wander(v)">To Wander,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wandrian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wan&shy;
deren;</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wandeln,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wane(v)">To Wane,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wa&shy;
man</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Gewanian</etym>, to de&shy;
crease; this from <etym lang="oe">Wana</etym>, that 
which wanteth somewhat; 
from hence the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wan</etym>, 
and our word Want.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wang-tooth(n)">The Wang, or Wong Tooth,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wang, Wong</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wange,</etym> the 
Cheek bone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="want-louse(n)">Want Louse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wand,</etym> a Wall, and 
<etym lang="en">Loust;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wanton(a)">Wanton,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">Want one,</etym> <term lang="la">viz.</term>  one 
that wanteth one to play with, 
Minsh. Perhaps from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waenen,</etym> to imagine 
many vain things; or <etym lang="bl">Wend&shy;
telen,</etym> to jaunt up and down.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wapentake(n)">Wapentake,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;&shy;
pen</etym>, Weapons, and <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
t&aelig;can</etym>, to deliver; from 
the delivering of Arms to the 
Lord of the Mannor as a sign 
of subjection, according to 
Somner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="war(n)">War,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;r</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weere,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Werre,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guerre,</etym> or the It. 
and Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Guerra,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gar</etym>, or Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wehr,</etym> Arms; whence <etym lang="tt">Weh&shy;
ren</etym>, to put on Arms: Or 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Werian</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeren,</etym> or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wah&shy;
ren,</etym> to defend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warble(v)">Warble,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Wervelen, Worvelen,</etym> to take 
rounds; with us, to play a 
Roundelay in Musick; this 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wervel,</etym> a 
whirl pool; and this perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Verticulum,</etym> a 
Whirl for a Spindle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ward(su)">Ward,</form> <xpln lang="en">in composition, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weard</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ward(n)">Ward,</form> <xpln lang="en">to keep in Ward, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weard</etym>, Custody, 
or <etym lang="oe">Weardan</etym>, to watch; all 
not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Werian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waerden,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Waeren,</etym> the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Garder,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guardare,</etym> 
to guard or defend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warden(n)">Warden,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Church-Warden, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gardien,</etym> or 
the Ital. <etym lang="it">Gardiano,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. V. 
Guard, and Ward</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warden-pear(n)">A Warden-Pear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wearden</etym>, to preserve; for 
that it keeps long before it 
rots.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa8r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wardmote(n)">Wardmote,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Ward,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mot</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Gemot</etym>, a 
meeting together; it being 
the Council of one Ward in a 
City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wardrobe(n)">Wardrobe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gar&shy;
derobbe,</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guarda&shy;
robba,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ware(n)">Ware,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ware</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waere,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Waar, Wahr,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all, not 
unlikely, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wa&shy;
rren,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wahren,</etym> to 
warrant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warfare(n)">Warfare,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Eng. <etym lang="en">War,</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Faran</etym>, to go; 
or <etym lang="oe">Fare</etym>, an Expedition.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warm(v)">To Warm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wear&shy;
mian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waermen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Warmen;</etym> these 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wearm</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waerm,</etym> the Dan. <etym lang="da">Varm,</etym> 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Warm,</etym> warm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warn(v)">To Warn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Waer&shy;
man</etym>, to admonish; or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Warnen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warp(n)">The Warp of a Web,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wearp</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Werp, 
Waerpie,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Werff&shy;
te,</etym> the same: Hence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Weorpan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Werpen</etym>, 
 and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Werffen</etym>, 
 to warp, to cast out.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warp(n)" lexeme="mouldwarp(n)">Warp, Mould-Warp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Maul,</etym> the Mouth, and 
<etym lang="tt">Werffen,</etym> to cast up; or from 
<etym lang="en">Mould,</etym> and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Worpen,</etym> 
to cast forth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="warrant(v)">To Warrant,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ga&shy;
rentir;</etym> or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guaren&shy;
tare,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Werian</etym>, or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeren,</etym> 
to defend; or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wahren, 
Gewahren,</etym> to make good; or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeren</etym> to secure 
or warrant the Goods.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="coney warren(n)">A Cony-Warren,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Garenne,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wae&shy;
rande,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from <etym lang="bl">Wae&shy;
ren,</etym> to have in custody. V. 
Ward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wart(n)">Wart,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weart</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Warize,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Warte, Waerte,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wary(a)">Wary,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;r</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;re</etym>, a 
Caution; both from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Werian</etym>, to defend. V. Be&shy;
ware.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="was(v)">Was,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;s</etym>, or 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vuas,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wash(v)">To Wash,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Was&shy;
can</etym>, or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="bl">Waschen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and hence 
<etym lang="bl">Wasche</etym>, a Wash or Wash&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waskite(n)">Waskite,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of Hawk of 
Virginia, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Vast Kite;</etym> un&shy;
less of some barbarous Ame&shy;
rican original to us unknown.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wasp(n)">Wasp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;ps; 
W&aelig;fs</etym>, the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guespe,</etym> 
or the Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wespe,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; and all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Vespa,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wassail(n)">Wassail,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Festival Song, which 
about the Epiphany is 
sung in some Countries at 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa8v">
every respective house; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;s-h&aelig;l</etym>, All-hail; 
v. Hail. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waste ground(n)">Wast Ground,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Weste</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wust,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Woest, Wuest,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waist(n)">The Wast of the Body,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vastus,</etym> vast or big; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;stm</etym>, the 
increase of the Body; this 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weaxan</etym>, to 
wax or grow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="watch(n)">Watch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wacht,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; hence <etym lang="tt">Wachten</etym>, to 
watch; these from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wacian</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wachen,</etym> 
or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waecken,</etym> to wake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="watchet colour(n)">Watchet-Colour,</form> <xpln lang="en">a faint Blue, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Woadchet</etym> colour, the 
colour of <etym lang="en">Woad,</etym> an Herb 
wherewith Cloth is dyed 
blue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="water(n)">Water,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;ter, 
W&aelig;tere</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wasser,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeter,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
from hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;tran</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wassern,</etym> and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Waeteren,</etym> to water; all from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;tan</etym>, to wet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wath(n)">Wath or Ford,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Watt, Wadt,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vadum,</etym> a 
Ford; <term lang="la">vide</term> Wade.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wattled wall(a)">A Watled Wall,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Northern 
word; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;tl</etym>, 
a Bundle, to wit, of small 
wood; or <etym lang="oe">Watel</etym>, a Tile.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wattle(n)">The Wattles of a Cock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wadeln,</etym> or the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeghelen, Wagghelen,</etym> 
to wag.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wave(n)">Wave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;g</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeghe,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Vague,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wagian</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Waeghen, Gewaeghen,</etym> to 
move or wag.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wave(v)">To Wave</form> <xpln lang="en">an Argument, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guesver,</etym> to leave, 
or omit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waver(v)">To Waver,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wa&shy;
fian</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. See Wag, and 
Waddle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wax(n)">Wax,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;xe</etym>, the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Vax,</etym> or the Belg. and 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wachs,</etym> id. all from 
the AS <etym lang="oe">Wac</etym>, soft, or flexi&shy;
ble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wax(v)">To Wax,</form> <xpln lang="en">or increase, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Weaxan</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wach&shy;
sen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wassen.</etym> id. 
all from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wack,</etym> soft. 
Things increase while they are 
soft, slender and juicy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="way(n)">Way,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weg, 
W&aelig;g</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weg,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wegh,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weak(a)">Weak,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wac, 
Wace</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weeck, 
Wack,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schwach,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>. These from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sweken,</etym> and the Teut 
<etym lang="tt">Swachen, Swechen,</etym> to wea&shy;
ken.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weal(n)">Weal,</form> <xpln lang="en">as the Common Weal, or 
Wealth, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wel</etym>, 
well; or <etym lang="oe">Welan</etym>, Wealth, 
Riches.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wean(v)">Wean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wennen.</etym> 
</page>

<page sig="Bb1r"> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Entwehrien,</etym> id. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weapon(n)">Weapons,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;&shy;
pen</etym>, in &AElig;lfr. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;&shy;
pna</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wapen,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wapffen, Waffen,</etym> the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Vaaben,</etym> or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vua&shy;
phane,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Hence the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Waepnian, Bewaepnian</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vebner</etym>, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Waffen</etym>, to furnish with a 
Weapon, to arm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wear(n)" lexeme="water-wear(n)">Wear,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Water-Wear, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;r, Wer</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weiher</etym>, id. these 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Werian</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wieren,</etym> to guard.</xpln>
<lemenote>
"water-wear" antedates earliest OED citation (1905).
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wear(v)">To Wear,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">We&shy;
ran</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Aweran</etym>, to put on, &shy;
<etym lang="oe">Weornian</etym>, to wear out; &shy;
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Waeren, Weh&shy;
ren,</etym> to last.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weary(a)">Weary,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Werig</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Werigan</etym>, 
to be weary, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Vaeren</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weasand(n)">Weasand, or Gullet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wasend</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wether(n)">Weather,</form> <xpln lang="en">Sheep, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">We&eth;er</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Veder</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wieder,</etym> or Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Weder,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weather(n)">The Weather,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the sky; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weder</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wetter,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Weder, Wedder</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. We&shy;
derwits, weatherwise; from 
hence also a Weathercock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weave(v)">To Weave,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wea&shy;
fan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weven,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wieben, Weben,</etym> id. 
Hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;bbe</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Weff</etym>, and Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Webbe</etym>, a Web.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="web(v)">To Web,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wed&shy;
dian, Beweddian,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wetten,</etym> to make a Co&shy;
venant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wedge(n)">Wedge,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wecg</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vegge,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Wegghe,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wednesday(n)">Wednesday,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wod&shy;
nesdag</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">O&shy;
thinszdag, Odensdag,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
originally from the God of 
the Germans, Woden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wee(a)">Wee,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">We</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wii,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Wi,</etym> 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weed(n)">Weed,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wedd</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Weodian</etym>, 
and Belg. <etym lang="oe">Wieden</etym>, to weed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="week(n)">Week,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weoc, 
Wuca, Wic</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Woche,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weke,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wick(n)">The Wick of a Candle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wac, Wace</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wack,</etym> gentle, or 
flexible; also soft. Write 
Wiek.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weel(n)">Weel, for a Whirl pool,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;l</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Weel, Wiel,</etym> a Swallow, or 
Gulf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="ween(v)">Ween,</form> <xpln lang="en">for think; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wenan</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waenen,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wahnen,</etym> to sup&shy;
pose.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weep(v)">Weep,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weopan, 
Bewepan,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weasel(n)">Weesel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wesle</etym>, 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wisel, Wiesel</etym> or 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vesel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weigh(v)">Weigh</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;gan</etym>, 
the Belg <etym lang="bl">Weghen, Wichten,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wegen,</etym> to weigh, 
or ponder; from hence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wiht</etym>, the Belg <etym lang="bl">Wicht</etym>, 
Wight, and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gewicht</etym>, 
weight. <etym lang="tt">Wichtig</etym>, weighty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="well(n)">A Well,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Welle, 
W&aelig;ll,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. This from 
<etym lang="oe">Weallan, Aweallan,</etym> to 
spring forth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="well(adv)">Well,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Adverb, from the Belg. 
and AS. <etym lang="oe"> Wel</etym>, the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Vuola,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wol, 
Wohl,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Belle,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="welladay(ex)">Welladay,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) <etym lang="en">Wail the 
day; Wellaway,</etym> from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Welan</etym>, wealth, plenty 
of, and <etym lang="oe">Wa</etym>, Woe, or Sor&shy;
row.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="welt(n)">Welt, for a Hem,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">W&aelig;ltan</etym>, to rowl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="welter(v)">Welter,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;l&shy;
tan</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weltzen,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Woelteren,</etym> or the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Veaultrer,</etym> to wallow, 
or tumble. All from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Volutare,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wench(n)">Wench,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wenche</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="west(n)">West,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. and Teut. 
<etym lang="oe">West</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>. <etym lang="oe">West&shy;
weard</etym>, Westward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wet(a)">Wet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;t</etym>, 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vaad,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence <etym lang="da">Vaeder</etym>, and AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;&shy;
tan</etym>, to wet, to make moist.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="whale(n)">Whale,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hwale, 
Hw&aelig;l</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Walvisch,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Walfisch,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="whorl(n)">Wharl, or Whorl.</form> <xpln lang="en">Minsh draws 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wurtel,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Werdel, Wordel,</etym> id. 
This from <etym lang="bl">Wervelen,</etym> to turn 
round. Somner draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hweorsa</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
from <etym lang="oe">Hweorsian</etym>, to turn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="what(d)">What,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wat,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hw&aelig;t</etym>, the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="weal(n)">Wheal,</form> <xpln lang="en">or blister, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hwele</etym>, Corruption, or Mat&shy;
ter; this from <etym lang="oe">Hwelan</etym>, to 
putrefie; or from the Belg. 
and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Welle,</etym> the bubling 
of water; whence Wellen, 
to spring up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wheat(n)">Wheat,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hw&aelig;t,

or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weyde,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wheel(n)">Wheel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hweol</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. 
Jun. draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Epsilon;&#x1F30;&lambda;&#x1F73;&omega;</etym>, to rowl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wheeze(v)">To Wheese, or Whease,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hweosan</etym>, id. <etym lang="oe">Hweos</etym>, 
a rutling, or wheesing; all 
from the sound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whitsontide(n)">Whitsontide,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Welssentag,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; both 
from <etym lang="en">White, Sun</etym> and <etym lang="en">Tide;</etym> 
because such as had been 
baptized between Easter and 
Pentecost, appeared together 
in the Temple, all apparelled 
in white raiment on White-&shy;
Sunday.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="whole(a)">Whole,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Walg, Hal</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Heel, Al</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
or perhaps from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F4D;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
whole, or <etym lang="gk">&omicron;&#x1F56;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, sound.</xpln>

</lemenote>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="whore(n)">Whore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hure</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoere,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Huhr,</etym> or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Hore,</etym> the 
same; the AS. <etym lang="oe">Huredom</etym>, 
whoredom; the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoeren,</etym> 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Huren,</etym> to go a 
whoring. Verstegan draws it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyrian</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hueren,</etym> to hire; for 
that she becomes a prostitute 
for money.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared after the entries for Wife-Wonder (Bb3 Recto-Bb4 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote>
 </wordentry>

because they grow in the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wicked(a)">Wicked,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wicce</etym>, a Witch; <etym lang="oe">Wicci&shy;
an</etym>, to bewitch, <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;cean</etym>, 
to afflict or torment; or 
<etym lang="oe">Wigend</etym>, a Souldier, one 
that usually bears the Cha&shy;
racter of Wicked; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wirgean</etym>, to curse; 
or lastly, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Vitia&shy;
tus,</etym> one that hath corrupted 
himself.</xpln>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="witch(n)">Witch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wicce</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">Wiccian</etym>, 
to bewitch; or from <etym lang="oe">Wic&shy;
nian</etym>; to prophesie, or fore&shy;
tell. Minsh. and Kilian sur&shy;
mise that it is primitively 
drawn from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Witche&shy;
len,</etym> to whinny; for that the 
ancient Germans, as Tacitus 
saith, were wont to divine by 
the whinnying or neighing of 
Horses.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote>
 </wordentry>

In composition it is put for 
<term lang="la">Contra</term>, against; as in these 
words, Withdraw, with&shy;
stand, &amp;c.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order.

&eth;erod</etym>, withered; this from 
<etym lang="oe">Wi&eth;er</etym>, contrary; as we

</lemenote>
 </wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wizard(n)">Wizard;</form> <xpln lang="en">or a Magician, from 
the word <etym lang="en">Wise;</etym> for that a&shy;
mong the Chaldeans, Persi&shy;
ans, and others, they were 
accounted the wise men; and 
such Impostors now a-days, 
are vulgarly called Wise men.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote>
 </wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="woe(n)">Wo,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS, <etym lang="oe">Wa, W&aelig;</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wee.</etym> the Teut <etym lang="tt">Wiche</etym> 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vet,</etym> sorrow; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">V&aelig;,</etym> wo to, fie 
upon thee; and this from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Omicron;&#x1F50;&alpha;&#x1F76;</etym>, the same.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote>
 </wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="woad(n)">Woad,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wad</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wedde, Weed,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wetd,</etym> the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Guede,</etym> 
or the Ital. <etym lang="it">Guade,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Guadum,</etym> Woad 
wherewith they dye blue.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote>
 </wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wolf(n)">Wolf,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wulf</etym>, 
the Dan <etym lang="da">Viff,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wolff,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wolf,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote>
 </wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="woman(n)">Woman,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wiman, 
Wimman,</etym> id. This from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wif</etym>, (which comes 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Omicron;&#x1FD6;&phi;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to join 
issue,) and <etym lang="oe">Man</etym>, by cor&shy;
ruption of time call'd <etym lang="gr">Wa&shy;
man,</etym> for the Saxons gene&shy;
rally us'd i, instead of o.</xpln> 
<lemenote>
 The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote>
 </wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="womb(n)">Womb,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wamb</etym>, id.</xpln> 
<lemenote> The page on which this entry occurred was ordered incorrectly in the EEBO edition: it appeared before the entries for Wherry-Wife (Bb2 Recto-Bb3 Verso). It has here been restored to its correct order. 
</lemenote> 
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wonder(n)">Wonder,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wun&shy;
dor</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wonder,</etym> or 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb4r"> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wonder,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
whence the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wunderen</etym>, 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wonderen</etym>, to 
wonder. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wont(a)" lexeme="be wont(v)">Wont, to be Wont,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wunian</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ge&shy;
woonen,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gewoh&shy;
nen,</etym> to accustom ones self to.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="woo(v)">To Wooe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wo&shy;
gan</etym>. Minsh, draws it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Woude,</etym> I Would.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wood(n)">Wood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Woud,</etym> 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wald,</etym> the Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Veed,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wude, Weald,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wood(n)">Wood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wod</etym>, 
raving mad; or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Woed, Woode,</etym> madness; 
whence <etym lang="bl">Woeden</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wuten</etym>, and the AS. <etym lang="bl">We&shy;
dan</etym>, to be wood, or furi&shy;
ous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="woof(n)">Woof,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wefta</etym>, 
weft, as our North-Coun&shy;
try-men rightly pronounce it; 
or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wievel,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Waffel,</etym> the same. 
V. Weave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wool(n)">Wool,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wulle</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wolle,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wulle,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="word(n)">Word,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Word</etym>, 
the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vuort,</etym> the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Woord,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wort,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="work(n)">Work,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weorc</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Verck,</etym> the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Vuerch,</etym> or the Belg. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Werck,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Weorcan</etym>, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wircken</etym>, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Werc&shy;
ken</etym>, to work.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="world(n)">World,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weorld</etym>, 
World, the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Vuorolt,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">World, Wereld,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from <etym lang="bl">Weren,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wehren,</etym> to abide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="worm(n)">Worm,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wyrm</etym>, 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Orm,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wurm,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Worm,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ver&shy;
mis,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wormwood(n)">Wormwood,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Worm,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Wood,</etym> because it is good a&shy;
gainst the worms; or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wehren,</etym> to wear off, 
or expel, and <etym lang="tt">Muth,</etym> the 
Heart, or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weran</etym>, 
to Defend, and <etym lang="oe">Mod</etym>, the 
Mind, or Spirit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="worry(v)">To Worry,</form> <xpln lang="en">or disquiet greatly, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Werigean</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="BL">Warren, Werren,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="TT">Wurgen,</etym> to tor&shy;
ment grievously; also, to 
strangle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="worse(a)">Worse,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wirs, 
Wierse</etym>, or the Fr. G. <etym lang="FR">Wi&shy;
ersero,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="worship(n)">Worship,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="OE">We&shy;
or&eth;-Scype,</etym> Dignity. V. 
Worth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="worsted(n)">Worsted,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Yarn, from 
<etym lang="EN">Worsted,</etym> a Town in Nor&shy;
folk, famous for this sort of 
Manufacture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wort(su)">Wort,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the terminations of the 
names of herbs; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wypt</etym>, and <etym lang="OE">Herb</etym>; the Teut. 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb4v"> 
<etym lang="tt">Wurtzel,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Worte,</etym> 
a root. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wort(n)">Wort,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wyrt</etym>, 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Worte, Werte,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or, not unlikely, from 
our word <etym lang="en">Work,</etym> for that it 
is continually working whilst 
new.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="worth(n)">Worth,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Worthy, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Weor&eth;, Wyr&eth;e</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weerd,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Werth, Wurdig,</etym> wor&shy;
thy; also the worth or value 
of a thing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="worth(su)">Worth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Termination in many 
proper names; as Thistleworth 
&amp;c. from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wor&eth;</etym>, 
a Farm; or <etym lang="oe">Weor&eth;ig</etym>, a 
field.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wot(v)">Wot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Witan</etym>, or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Weten,</etym> to know.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="would(v)">Would,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Woud,</etym> 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wolte,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. 
v. Will.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wound(n)">A Wound,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wund</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wonde,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wunde,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; from hence 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wundian</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Wonden,</etym> and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wun&shy;
den,</etym> to wound.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrack(n)">Wrack,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wracke,</etym> 
or <etym lang="bl">Vrack,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrangle(n)">Wrangle</form> <xpln lang="en">: Minsh derives it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wrangh, Wranck,</etym> 
bitter; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to be imbitter'd 
against one; but rather, from 
our word <etym lang="en">Wrong,</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrap(n)">Wrap</form> <xpln lang="en">: Minshew draws it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Werp, Werpte,</etym> the 
warp of a web: But it may 
be better drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hweorfian</etym>, to turn, or 
wind about.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrestle(v)">Wrastle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS <etym lang="oe">Wraest&shy;
lian</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Worstelen</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; or from our word 
<etym lang="en">Wrest.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrath(n)">Wrath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wra&eth;, 
Wra&eth;e</etym>, or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Vrede,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; all probably from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wry&eth;an</etym>, to writh, 
or shrivel up the face, as Men 
do in their anger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wreath(n)">A Wreath,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wreo&eth;e,</etym> a garland; or 
<etym lang="oe">Wreo&eth;ian</etym>, to wreath, or 
tye round like a garland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wren(n)">Wren,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wrenne</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; both Contracts of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Regina,</etym> a Queen, by a 
Catachresis.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrest(v)">To Wrest,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wr&aelig;
stan</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; whence <etym lang="oe">A&shy;
wraestan</etym>, to wrest out, or 
extort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wretch(n)">Wretch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wr&aelig;c&shy;
ca</etym>, an exil'd person: Or 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wr&aelig;can</etym>, to 
revenge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wright(n)">Wright,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wryh&shy;
ta, Wyrhta,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; this 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weorcan,
