Wyrcan</etym>, to work.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wring(v)">To Wring,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wrin&shy;
gan</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vringhen, 
Wringhen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrinkle(n)">A Wrinkle,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wrincle</etym>, the Dan. <etym lang="da">Rinckle,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wrinckel,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
</page>

<page sig="Bb5r"> 
whence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wrinclian</etym>, 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wrinckelen</etym>, to 
wrinkle. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrist(n)">Wrist,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wyrest, 
Wyrst,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; or from 
our word <etym lang="en">Wrest;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="write(v)">Write,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Writan</etym>, 
the same: Or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wrotan</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Wroeten,</etym> to plow the ground; 
by a Metaphor taken from A&shy;
griculture; whence it is, that 
in Latin we use <term lang="la">Exarare</term>, to 
write.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wrong(a)">Wrong,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wrange</etym>, 
<term lang="la">idem</term>; this from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wringan</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Wringhen,</etym> to wring, or ex&shy;
tort contrary to justice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wry(a)" lexeme="awry(adv)">Wry, Awry,</form> <xpln lang="en">from our words 
<etym lang="en">Writhe,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Wreath;</etym> which 
see. Mer. Cas. draws it from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&omicron;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&#x1FEC;&alpha;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
bent, or crooked.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="won(v)">To Wun;</form> <xpln lang="en">as, Where do you 
Wun? <term lang="la">i.e.</term> Live; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wunian, Gewunian,</etym> 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Woonen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wohnen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> </wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="Y"><alpha>Y</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yacht(n)">YAcht,</form> <xpln lang="en">a kind of ship; per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Iagt,</etym> this from the word <etym lang="tt">Iagen,</etym> to 
pursue; it being but a slight 
ship, more fit for Piracy, than 
transportation of goods.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yard(n)">A Yard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geard</etym>, 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Gaard,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; al&shy;
so a grass plat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yard(n)">A Yard to measure withal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gerd, Gyrd,</etym> the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Garde, Gaerde,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gerte,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yare(a)">Yare,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old word, signifying 
desirous, or covetous; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gather,</etym> impatient.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yarn(n)">Yarn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gearn</etym>, 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yawn(v)">To Yawn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ga&shy;
nian</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Geonan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gewehn, Gheewen,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gehnen,</etym> id. all from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cinan</etym>, or the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&alpha;&#x1F77;&shy;
&nu;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>, to gape.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yea(ex)">Yea,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gea</etym>, <term lang="la">idem</term>; 
or the AS. Belg. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ja</etym>, 
yes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yean(v)" lexeme="ean(v)">To Yean, or Ean,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Eanian</etym>, to bring forth as the 
Ewe doth; and this from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Eowe</etym>, an Ewe.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="year(n)">Year,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gear</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Iaer,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Iahr,</etym> 
the Dan. <etym lang="da">Aaar,</etym> or the Run. 
Dan. <etym lang="rn">Ar,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. Fr. Jun. 
draws it <etym lang="la">&agrave; Gyrando,</etym> from 
turning round; and therefore 
in Latin called <term lang="la">Annus</term>, from 
<term lang="la">Annulus</term>, a ring.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yearn(v)">To Yearn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ear&shy;
nian, Geearnian,</etym> to com&shy;
miserate; hence <etym lang="oe">Earnunge</etym>, 
an earning, or commiser&shy;
ation.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yeast(n)">Yeast,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gest, 
Gist</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghest, 
Ghist,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yield(v)">Yeeld, or Yield,</form> <xpln lang="en">for to submit 
himself; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gil&shy;
dan</etym>, to pay, or perform; to 
wit, what the Subduer de&shy;
mands.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yell(v)">To Yell, or Yawl,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghillen,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schallen, Schellen,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yellow(n)">Yellow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gea&shy;
lewe, Geeluwe</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gheluwe,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gaelb, 
Geelb,</etym> the Ital. <etym lang="it">Giallo,</etym> the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Yalde,</etym> or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jaulne, Jaune,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yelp(v)">To Yelp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghil&shy;
pen,</etym> to yelp like a bird.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yeoman(n)">Yeoman,</form> <xpln lang="en">either from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gem&aelig;ne</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ge&shy;
metu,</etym> common; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Com&shy;
mon man, or one of the 
Commonalty; or q. <etym lang="oe">Eowe&shy;
man</etym>, an Ewe man, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one 
that follows Husbandry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yes(ex)">Yes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gyse</etym>, the 
same. <term lang="la">Vide</term> Yea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yesterday(n)">Yesterday,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
osterlic</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghis&shy;
teren</etym> id. or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gesteen,</etym> 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hesternus,</etym> of 
the day before. See Day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yet(adv)">Yet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Get, Geta,</etym> 
<term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yew(n)">Yew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Iw</etym>, the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">If, Yf,</etym> the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Iven, 
Iiif</etym>. <term lang="la">idem</term>; or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Eyden-Baum,</etym> the Yew tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yoke(n)">Yoke,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Goc, Geoc</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Iock,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ioth,</etym> or the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Joug,</etym> id. 
all from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jugum;</etym> 
this <etym lang="la">&agrave; Jungendo,</etym> from yo&shy;
king or joining together.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yon(adv)">Yon,</form> <xpln lang="en">Yonder, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Geond</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghen&shy;
der,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yore(n)">Of Yore,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geara, 
Geagora,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>; as, <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
ara Dagum</etym>, in the days 
of yore.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="you(pr)" lexeme="your(pr)">You, and Your,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Juh, Eow</etym>, the Fr. Th. 
<etym lang="hd">Iuth,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ghy,</etym> you; 
from these the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eower</etym>, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ewer,</etym> your.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="young(a)">Young</form> <xpln lang="en">and Younger from the AS 
<etym lang="oe">Jong</etym>, <etym lang="oe">Geunga</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Iong,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Iung,</etym> 
Young. Hence the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ge&shy;
onger</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ionger</etym>, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Iunger</etym>, youn&shy;
ger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="yule-block(n)">Yule-Block,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Christmass-&shy;
Block, a word frequently u&shy;
sed in Lincolnshire, and else&shy;
where; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gehul</etym>, 
or the Dan. <etym lang="da">Juledag</etym>, Yule&shy;
day, or Christmass-day; this 
not unlikely from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Jubilum,</etym> a voice of glad&shy;
ness, a Jubile.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb6r"> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="Z"><alpha>Z</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zany(n)">ZAni,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fool. Mer. Cas. 
draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&#x1F71;&nu;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, foolish; proba&shy;
bly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sanna,</etym> a 
<emend err="a"></emend> mocking, or derision; 
or from the word <etym lang="it">Zane,</etym> 
the Dim. of the Italian name 
<etym lang="it">Giovanni,</etym> of <etym lang="en">John;</etym> whence 
we say, an idle Iack.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zeal(n)">Zeal,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Zelus,</etym> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Zele,</etym> or the Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Zelo,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zealot(n)">Zealot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Zealotes,</etym> 
or <etym lang="la">Zealota,</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<closing>
FINIS.
</closing>
</section>
</page> 

<page sig="Bb6v"> 
</page> 

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++


<page sig="Aa1r"> 
<section type="Onomasticon"> 
<heading>ETYMOLOGICON ONOMASTICON: 
OR, 
An Etymological Explication 
OF THE 
Proper Names of Men and Women: 
As also, 
Of Rivers, Countries, Cities, Towns, Villages, Hills, 
Mountains, Ports, and Promontories, which were 
formerly used by the English-Saxons, or are now 
common amongst us: 

Particularly the Names of such Men, Women, and 
Places, as are of a German Original, and do occurr 
frequently in our English History, whether they be 
real or fictitious; those coming from the Latin, 
Greek and Hebrew being reserved to be added as 
an Appendix at the latter End, where the Reader 
is desired to look for them. </heading>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="Aa"><alpha>AA</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aa(n)">AA,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River, which sepa&shy;
rates: Picardy from Flan&shy;
ders, and consequent&shy;
ly parteth France from 
the Netherlands; from the Fr. 
Th. <etym lang="hd">Aha,</etym> Streams of Water; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, Water. 
See Ea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abberbury(pn)">Abberbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in old time a fa&shy;
mous Monastery; which is 
as much as to say <etym lang="en">Abbots&shy;
bury;</etym> just as Abbeville, is used 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa1v"> 
by those of Picardy, the word 
in it self signifying, a residence 
for an Abbot. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abent(pn)">Abent,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name. Cam&shy;
den asserteth that it once sig&shy;
nified a steep place; and so 
perhaps might come from 
the word <etym lang="en">Bend.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abercom(pn)">Abercom,</form><xpln lang="en">in Scotland; it was 
formerly call'd Abercurvig 
or Abercurving; if I mis&shy;
take not, from the Brit. 
<etym lang="br">Aber,</etym> the Mouth of a River, 
and the River <etym lang="en">Curving,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the Mouth of the River Cur&shy;
ving.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aberconwey(pn)">Aberconwey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City in Caer&shy;
narvanshire in Wales, which 
was Rebuilt by King Edward 
the Third, out of the Ruins 
of an ancient British City 
once named Caerbaen; it sig&shy;
nifieth the Mouth of the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Conwey;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aberdene(pn)">Aberdene,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop's Sea, and 
an University, from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Aber Don,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Mouth 
of the River Dee.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aberfraw(pn)">Aberfraw,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Isle of An&shy;
glesey; from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Aber</etym> a 
Mouth, and the River <etym lang="en">Fraw;</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Mouth of the Ri&shy;
ver Fraw.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abergevenny(pn)">Abergevenny,</form> <xpln lang="en">by contraction 
Abergenny, and which is 
more common Abergany; 
a City in the County of Mon&shy;
mouth. Situate nigh the meet&shy;
ing together of the Rivers 
Gevenny and Vsk; from 
<etym lang="cb">Aber</etym> a Mouth, and <etym lang="en">Geven&shy;
ny,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Mouth of Ge&shy;
venny.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abingdon(pn)">Abingdon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Barks, a Town first called 
Sheovesham, afterward Abban&shy;
dune by the English-Saxons; 
rather from an Abby there 
founded by Cissa a King of 
the Vice-Saxons, and so call'd 
<term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Abby Town,</etym> than from 
Abbenus an Irish Hermit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abus(pn)">Abus,</form> <xpln lang="en">I suppose from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Aber,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Port or Ha&shy;
ven of a River, where be&shy;
like it is situate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Acmanchester(pn)">Acmanchester;</form> <xpln lang="en">See Bath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Acton(pn)">Acton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Middl. 
and a Village elsewhere; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aac</etym>, an Oak; 
and <etym lang="en">Town</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Town 
encompassed with Oaks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adalgisus(pn)">Adalgisus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Son of the last 
King of the Longobardi, whose 
Name was Desiderius, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel</etym> nobility, and 
<etym lang="tt">Geitz</etym> covetousness, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
greedy of honour, ambitious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adder(pn)">Adder,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River, so call'd from 
its many Windings, like to 
a Snake rowling it self up. 
See <etym lang="en">Adder</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adderbourn(pn)">Adderbourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Wilts, so call'd for its 
crooked windings; from <etym lang="en">Ad&shy;
der</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bourn,</etym> which see 
in the Common Names; and 
Willybourn, from Willow 
and Bourn, because of the 
many Willow-trees growing 
thereabout.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adelard(pn)">Adelard,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen-name of 
a Man, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Edel</etym> 
noble, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
nature, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one of a ge&shy;
nerous Spirit.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adelbert(pn)">Adelbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Longo&shy;
bardi of Italy. Junius derives 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> no&shy;
ble, and <etym lang="tt">Bart,</etym> a Beard, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a man, that hath a grave, 
large Beard; and he suppo&shy;
seth that it is the same with 
Albert, which see. I had 
rather derive, it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> Nobility, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorhte</etym>, light, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the very Splendor of Nobili&shy;
ty; suppos'd to be the same 
with Ethelbert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adeleidis(pn)">Adeleidis,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of Lothair 
King of the Longobardi of Ita&shy;
ly; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> no&shy;
bility, and <etym lang="tt">Leiden,</etym> to suffer, 
which is as much as to say, 
one that could patiently to&shy;
lerate the Haughty carriage 
of the Nobles.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adelhidis(pn)">Adelhidis,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of the 
Emperour Lewis Balbus; per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> 
nobility, and <etym lang="tt">Heyde,</etym> a place 
where Broom, or Heath 
groweth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adelin(pn)">Adelin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;del</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> 
a Nobleman or Prince.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adelm(pn)">Adelm,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop of Sherborn, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, felicity, 
and <etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, an Helmet, which 
secondarily signifies a Prote&shy;
ctor or a Preserver of hap&shy;
piness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adelrad(pn)" lexeme="Ethelrad(pn)">Adelrad, or Ethelrad,</form> <xpln lang="en">the 
Christen-name of a man, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> a Nobleman, &amp; the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Raht,</etym> counsel; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an able Counsellor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adelwaldus(pn)">Adelwaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Longobardi of Italy; from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> nobility, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to go&shy;
vern; that is to say, a noble 
Governour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adewaldus(pn)">Adewaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">A&eth;e</etym>, an Oath, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to govern, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
One that will not Swear, or 
else one, that bound those 
to him, which he subdued, 
by an Oath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adhlingi(pn)">Adhlingi,</form> <xpln lang="en">Saxon Germans, 
saith Nithardus in his French 
History: They are divided 
into three ranks, namely, 
into the Adhlingi, that is the 
Nobles; into the Frilingi (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the free-born, and into the 
Lazzi, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) those which 
served for their freedom, 
call'd Libertines: Now the 
word Adhling is manifestly 
derived from the AS. and 
Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> 
a Nobleman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adler(pn)">Adler,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adler,</etym> an Eagle, or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ae&eth;el</etym>, noble, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Edeler,</etym> more Noble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ado(pn)">Ado,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop of Vienna, 
a Writer of Annals; per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Aad Ade</etym>, 
a funeral Pile.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adoaldus(pn)">Adoaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy, perhaps con&shy;
tracted and corrupted from 
</page> 
 
<page sig="Aa2v"> 
<etym lang="oe">Adelwald,</etym> and this from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Adel</etym>, felicity, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to govern; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that overcometh his own 
Fortune; and is neither cast 
down with Adversity, nor 
puffed up with a prosperous 
State. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adolph(pn)">Adolph,</form> <xpln lang="en">either the same with 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eadulph</etym>, which see 
in its place; or, if we may 
credit Verstegan, it is contra&shy;
cted from <etym lang="tt">Adelulph,</etym> and 
this from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> 
nobility, <etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> noble, AS. 
<etym lang="oe">E&eth;el</etym>, noble, and <etym lang="oe">Vlph,</etym> 
help, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that stood 
up for, and assisted the No&shy;
bility.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adrana(pn)">Adrana,</form> <xpln lang="en">Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eder,</etym> a River, 
that runneth through the Catti, now call'd Hassi; 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ed&shy;
dre</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ader,</etym> a Vein; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eddran</etym>, 
the Reins; from the Simi&shy;
litude of the Veins, or 
Reins.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&AElig;lfegus(pn)">St. &AElig;lfegus,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop 
of Canterbury, and Martyr; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;l</etym>, all, and 
<etym lang="oe">F&aelig;gen</etym>, merry, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  always 
merry; it answereth the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Hilarius</etym>. See Alpheg here&shy;
after.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&AElig;lfgine(pn)">&AElig;lfgine,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lf</etym>, 
an Elf, a Witch, and <etym lang="oe">Gin,</etym> 
the jaws, or <etym lang="oe">Ginan,</etym> to gape.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&AElig;lfred(pn)"  lexeme="Alfred(pn)" lexeme="Alured(pn)">&AElig;lfred, Alfred, or Alured,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Proper Name of a man, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;l</etym>, all, and 
<etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, Peace, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  all Peace, 
which was remarkable in 
&AElig;lfred, that invincible, yet 
pious King of the English-&shy;
Saxons, who by his Prudence 
and Fortitude composed ma&shy;
ny destructive Seditions that 
arose in his time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&AElig;lgive(pn)">&AElig;lgive,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of Edgar 
King of the English-Saxons, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;l</etym>, all, and 
<etym lang="oe">Gifan</etym>, to give.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&AElig;thelingey(pn)">&AElig;thelingey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Somerset; an Island where 
the Rivers Pedrid and Thone 
meet, in which, King &AElig;l&shy;
fred, being discomfited by the 
Danes, hid himself for a 
while; therefore so called as 
it were The Isle of Nobles; It 
is now by Contraction call'd 
Athelney. See <etym lang="oe">Adelm</etym> above, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ea.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Agelnoth(pn)">St. Agelnoth,</form> <xpln lang="en">commonly called 
the good Arch-Bishop of Can&shy;
terbury; perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Eglan</etym>, to grieve, and 
<etym lang="oe">noht</etym>, not at all, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) void 
of Grief.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Agilmundus(pn)">Agilmundus,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ammianus, a 
Petty King of the Germans; he 
is described by Adr. Jun. to 
have had a Jaw crook'd in 
the manner of an Eagles bill. 
It may possibly be derived 
from the dormant Particle <etym lang="la">A,</etym> 
and <etym lang="la">Gilde Mund,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
Golden Mouth, for his great 
Eloquence. See Gold, and 
Eagle in their proper places.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa3r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Agilulphus(pn)">Agilulphus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="tt">Ei&shy;
lulph,</etym> from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eilen,</etym> 
to hasten, &amp; <etym lang="tt">Vlph,</etym> help; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
speedy succour or help; or 
which is yet more probable, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Egle</etym>, grief, and 
the same <etym lang="oe">Vlph,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an 
allayer of Sorrow and An&shy;
guish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aidon Castle(pn)">Aidon Castle</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Northumberland. Now <etym lang="cb">Aidon</etym> 
in the C. Br. signifieth the 
Wing of an Army; from 
whence Camden supposeth, 
that it was a Station of the 
Roman Army under Julius 
C&aelig;sar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ailesford(pn)">Ailesford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Kent; AS. <etym lang="oe">Eaglesford</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Eagles Ford; a 
Town noted for a great over&shy;
throw given Hengist and his 
English-Saxon Army by Vor&shy;
timer the British King.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aken(pn)">Aken,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Imperial City of Ger&shy;
many, formerly the Court of 
Charles the Great, so named 
from <etym lang="la">Aquis Calidis,</etym> the Baths.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alahis(pn)" lexeme="Alachis(pn)">Alahis or Alachis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Captain 
among the Longobardi, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">All</etym> all, and <etym lang="tt">Heisz,</etym> 
hot, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  fierce and daring.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alan(pn)">Alan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name of a 
man. Jul. Scaliger derives it 
from the Sclavon. <etym lang="sl">Alan,</etym> a 
Dog, as among the Romans 
<etym lang="la">Caninius</etym>, from <etym lang="la">canis</etym>, a dog. 
Camden from the Lat. <etym lang="la">&AElig;li&shy;
anus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alani(pn)">Alani,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a warlike Peo&shy;
ple of Scythia; or the Tribe 
of Messaget&aelig;. Jul. Scaliger 
affirmeth that <etym lang="sh">Alan</etym> in the 
Scythian Tongue signifieth a 
Dog, and were perhaps so 
call'd from the figure of a 
Dog displaying its self in 
their Streamers. Adr. Jun. 
derives it from <etym lang="oe">Al,</etym> all, and <etym lang="oe">an</etym> 
for on, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  always go on; ei&shy;
ther because they always 
went on in Triumph over 
their Enemies; or because 
they had no settled place of 
abode. Dr. Skinner explo&shy;
deth this Etymon as spu&shy;
rious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alaricus(pn)">Alaricus,</form> <xpln lang="en">that invincible King 
of the Ostrogothi; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Alle</etym>, all, and Ric. Teut.
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> rich, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) aboun&shy;
ding in riches; or it is a con&shy;
tract of <etym lang="tt">Adelric,</etym> which comes 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> noble, 
and <etym lang="tt">Ric,</etym> rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  nobly 
rich; or perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> nobility, and <etym lang="tt">Ric,</etym> 
a Kingdom, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Flower 
of a Kingdom, for such are 
the Nobility.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alberic(pn)">Alberic,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same that Alaric 
above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Albert(pn)">Albert,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Al&shy;
brecht,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  All bright, 
which see in their Places: 
To it answers the Lat. Ful&shy;
gentius, Lucilius. Verstegan 
thinketh, that it is contra&shy;
cted from <etym lang="oe">Ethelbert;</etym> which 
see. Kilian draws it from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel</etym> nobility, and 
<etym lang="tt">Pracht,</etym> pomp, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
Pomp of Nobility.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Albis(pn)">Albis,</form> <xpln lang="en">now call'd Elbe, a fa&shy;
mous River in Germany; from 
the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Elle, Elleboogh,</etym> 
an ell or elbow, because it 
runneth in a Current, that 
windeth like the Elbow, 
when it is bent a little.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alboinus(pn)">Alboinus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the first King of the 
Longobardi of Italy, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">All-bewin,</etym> i. e.one that 
wun all. It is also the same 
with Alwin; which see here&shy;
after.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Alban's(pn)">St. Alban's,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Hertford, a Town much no&shy;
ted for the Murther of St. Al&shy;
ban, who was the first British 
Martyr. By the Eng. Saxons 
it was call'd Werlamceas&shy;
ter, from the River Wer&shy;
lam, saith Camden, from 
whence it is call'd in La&shy;
tin <etym lang="la">Verulamium</etym>, in English 
Verulam.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alchester(pn)">Alchester,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Old Chester, 
in the County of Oxf. AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Aldceaster</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Old 
Town. See Old and Che&shy;
ster.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alcini(pn)">Alcini,</form> <xpln lang="en">now call'd Silesii. Adr. 
Jun. derives it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heiligen</etym> (i. e.) Holy: 
Which see in its place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alcmar(pn)">Alcmar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Town in 
Holland. Adr. Jun. tells us it 
was once written Almer, and 
derives it from <etym lang="hd">All</etym> and 
<etym lang="bl">Meer,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  all in a Marsh, 
from fifteen Moats of Wa&shy;
ter wherewith it is encom&shy;
passed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alcwinus(pn)">Alcwinus,</form> <xpln lang="en">an English-Saxon, 
Master to Charles the Great; 
the same with Alwin; which 
see hereafter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldburgh(pn)">Aldburgh,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Yorkshire, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="en">Old Bo&shy;
rough.</etym> See Old and Bo&shy;
rough among the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldelm(pn)">Aldelm,</form> <xpln lang="en">at the first a Christen&shy;
name, but now a Sirname, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eald</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Alt,</etym> an Old man, and <etym lang="tt">Helm</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an Helmet or Prote&shy;
ctor of old People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldersgate(pn)">Aldersgate,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Gates 
of the City of London. Ac&shy;
cording to Camden from <etym lang="oe">Al&shy;
dric</etym> a Saxon, who first ere&shy;
cted it; or perhaps because 
it was the Senatour's Gate, at 
whose Cost it was either first 
Founded, or at least after&shy;
ward repaired, which is most 
likely; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Elders-Gate.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldgate(pn)">Aldgate,</form> <xpln lang="en">another of the Gates 
of the said City, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Old 
gate,</etym> because of the Anti&shy;
quity thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldingham(pn)">Aldingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Lanc. 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lding</etym>, a put&shy;
ting off, <etym lang="oe">Eldian</etym>, to detain 
or hinder; so call'd from 
its craggy, rough ways, which 
hinder Travellers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldred(pn)">Aldred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, con&shy;
tracted, from Alured, which 
it self is Corr. from <etym lang="en">Alfred,</etym> 
or <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lfred;</etym> which See. Or 
more naturally from <etym lang="en">All</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Dred,</etym> fear; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  all fear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldulph(pn)">Aldulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">Arch-Bishop of Litch&shy;
field in the year 790. from 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa4r"> 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eald</etym>, ancient, and 
<etym lang="oe">Vlph,</etym> help, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) old help. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aldworth(pn)">Aldworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Berks, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ald</etym>, 
old, and <etym lang="oe">Wor&eth;</etym>, a Walk, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the old Walk. Camb&shy;
den.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alegund(pn)" lexeme="Alelgund(pn)">Alegund for Adelgund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Wo&shy;
mans Name, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">E&eth;el</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> noble, 
and <etym lang="tt">Gunnen,</etym> to favour, that 
is to say, a favourer of the 
Nobility.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alesbury(pn)">Alesbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Bucks, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;gles&shy;
burg</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Eaglesbury, as 
at this time Aquila is the chief 
Town of a Province of the 
Samnites, now call'd Abruz&shy;
zo.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alfreton(pn)">Alfreton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Derby; some think that it 
was built by King Alfred; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lfredtun</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Alfred's Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alfric(pn)">Alfric,</form> <xpln lang="en">Verstegan supposeth that 
it is corrupted from <etym lang="oe">&AElig;lfred</etym>, 
<etym lang="en">Alfred</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Alfrid;</etym> yet I 
rather conjecture, that it 
cometh from our English 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Half</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, 
Rich, that is to say, half 
rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alice(pn)">Alice,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans name, con&shy;
tracted from the Bar. Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Adeliza,</etym> and this from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> nobility; AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, noble, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Heissen,</etym> to be call'd, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
descended of a great Fa&shy;
mily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Allen(pn)">Allen,</form> <xpln lang="en">Verstegan supposeth, that 
it hath been corrupted from 
<etym lang="en">Alwin;</etym> which see. It may 
also be drawn from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Alanus.</etym> See Alan.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Allingham(pn)" lexeme="Allington(pn)">Allingham, and Allington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Hants; not 
unlikely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Al&shy;
linga</etym>, altogether, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, 
a Village; or <etym lang="oe">Ton</etym>, for 
Town, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a very famous 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alman(pn)">Alman,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ale&shy;
man, Alleman,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) All 
man, as we say, a man every 
inch of him, See German: 
Or as Cluverius and Agathias 
have it, from <etym lang="la">Allemanni,</etym> be&shy;
cause they were a mish&shy;
mash of Men of all Nations 
or Countries.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Almondbury(pn)">Almondbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of York, once called <etym lang="la">Cambo&shy;
dunum</etym>; where Paulinus, the 
Apostle of the North built a 
Cathedral, and dedicated it 
to St. Alban, the first Martyr 
in England, and thence it be&shy;
gan to be call'd <etym lang="en">Albonbury,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the City or Grove of 
St. <etym lang="en">Alban.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alncester(pn)">Alncester,</form> <xpln lang="en">famous for an an&shy;
cient Synod of English-Sax&shy;
ons; perhaps it is so call'd 
from the River <etym lang="en">Aln,</etym> that 
runneth by it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alne(pn)">Alne,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Cum&shy;
berland, by the ancient Ro&shy;
mans it was call'd <etym lang="la">Alone.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alne(pn)">Alne,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Nor&shy;
thumberland, by Ptolemy call'd 
<etym lang="gk">Alaunus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alpheg(pn)">Alpheg,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; not 
unlikely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Alle</etym>, 
all, and <etym lang="oe">Fegan</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fu&shy;
gen,</etym> to conjoin, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a man 
fit for all things, one that can 
do any thing, Jack of all 
Trades.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alphons(pn)">Alphons,</form> <xpln lang="en">Hisp. Alfonso, a man's 
Name very common among 
the Spaniards, from the 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Helfuns,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) help 
us; which see in their pro&shy;
per places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alresford(pn)">Alresford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Hants, famous for a pitch'd 
Battel fought there; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the <etym lang="en">Ford</etym> of the River <etym lang="en">Alre.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alric(pn)">Alric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Kent, the same 
with Alaric; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alswold(pn)">Alswold,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Nor&shy;
thumbrians: perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Alle</etym>, all, and <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, 
to rule, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  to govern all. 
Or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Alle</etym>, all, 
and <etym lang="oe">Weald</etym>, a Wood; his 
Territories consisting most of 
Woods and Forests.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alvaro(pn)" lexeme="Alvares(pn)">Alvaro, or Alvares,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Name 
frequently given to Spa&shy;
niards; Covarruvias suppo&shy;
seth it to be the same with 
<etym lang="en">Albert;</etym> which see. It might 
also be taken from the Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">All,</etym> and the AS. and Goth. 
<etym lang="go">Wer</etym>, a man; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  all 
man, a valiant man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Away(pn)">Alway,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland; by Ptole&shy;
my, <etym lang="gk">Alauna,</etym> from the River 
<etym lang="la">Alon.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alwerton(pn)">Alwerton,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">All Wear</etym> and <etym lang="en">Town;</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Town 
furnished with many Banks 
to keep off the Waters.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alwin(pn)">Alwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">that eminent English-&shy;
Saxon, Tutor to Charles the 
Great; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Alle, 
Eal</etym>, all, and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Vi&shy;
ctour, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that wun 
all at Disputing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amalaberga(pn)">Amalaberga,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Queen of the 
Turingi; it is exp. by Jun. 
an Heavenly Mount, from the 
old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hamal,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Him&shy;
mel,</etym> Heaven, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Berga,</etym> a Mount.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amalafrida(pn)">Amalafrida,</form> <xpln lang="en">a womans Name; 
from the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hamal,</etym> 
now <etym lang="tt">Himmel,</etym> heaven, and 
<etym lang="tt">Fried,</etym> peace, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  heaven&shy;
ly peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amalaricus(pn)">Amalaricus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Spanish Vice-Gothi; from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hammel,</etym> a Weather; 
and <etym lang="tt">Ric;</etym> rich, that is to 
say, rich in Cattel or Sheep.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amalasunta(pn)">Amalasunta,</form> <xpln lang="en">a most learned 
Queen of the Italian Ostro&shy;
gthi; Kilian derives it from 
the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hamel</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Ha&shy;
mal</etym> for Himmel; Heaven, 
and <etym lang="tt">Suenta, a Wench,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
an Heavenly woman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amali(pn)">Amali,</form> <xpln lang="en">a renowned Family of 
the ancient Goths; as Jun. 
saith, from the Teut. or Goth. 
<etym lang="tt">Hamal,</etym> now Himmel, Hea&shy;
ven.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ambleside(pn)">Ambleside,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Westm. the Ruins of an an&shy;
cient City call'd by the Ro&shy;
mans <etym lang="la">Amboglana.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ambresbury(pn)">Ambresbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Wilts; so call'd from 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa5r">
<etym lang="br">Ambrose</etym> King of the Britains, 
that was there Slain, and 
our English <etym lang="en">Bury.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amerford(pn)">Amerford,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Holland, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the <etym lang="en">Ford</etym> of the River 
<etym lang="bl">Ems.</etym> See Ford in its 
place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amersham(pn)">Amersham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Bucks, AS. <etym lang="oe">Agmundesham</etym>, 
this not unlikely from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Aac, Ac</etym>, an Oak, 
<etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, a Fence or Mound, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, a Village, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a Village fenced from the 
injuries of the Winds and 
Cold, with a row of Oaks 
planted on every side there&shy;
of: Or from <etym lang="la">Agmundus</etym> the 
Builder.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amery(pn)">Amery,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  AS. <etym lang="oe">Eme</etym> <etym lang="oe">rice</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) always rich. Camden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amie(pn)" lexeme="Amade(pn)">Amie, or Amade,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aim&eacute;,</etym> beloved.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amisius(pn)">Amisius,</form> <xpln lang="en">Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ems</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Eems</etym>, 
a River in Germany; by Stra&shy;
bo call'd Amisias; perhaps 
from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Am,</etym> nou&shy;
rishing; because it maketh 
the Fields fructify, or nou&shy;
risheth the Inhabitants that 
live next it. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Almus a&shy;
mnis,</etym> a kind River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amsterdam(pn)">Amsterdam,</form> <xpln lang="en">the most famous 
Mart-Town in Holland, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the <etym lang="en">Dam</etym> or Bank of the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Amster;</etym> see Dam. Jun. 
also supposeth it to be so 
call'd from <etym lang="la">Giselbertus Amste&shy;
lius,</etym> a Noble man, who was 
Founder thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amandale(pn)">Amandale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, a Val&shy;
ley nigh the River <etym lang="en">Annan;</etym> 
See <etym lang="en">Dale.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amaraud(pn)">Amaraud,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Christen-&shy;
name, corrupted from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Honoratus,</etym> much estee&shy;
med. Cambden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ancaster(pn)">Ancaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Lincolnshire, by Antoninus Cro&shy;
cocalana, from <etym lang="en">An</etym> and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a Castle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Andernesse(pn)">Andernesse,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Lancaster; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Acmundesnesse</etym>, comp. of 
<etym lang="oe">Ac, Aac,</etym> an Oak, <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, 
a Mound, and <etym lang="oe">N&aelig;se</etym>, a Pro&shy;
montory; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Promon&shy;
tory encompassed with great 
plenty of Oaks to defend it 
from the Air.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Andover(pn)">Andover,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Hant. AS. <etym lang="oe">Andeafaran</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Ferry-place of the 
River Anton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Andredswald(pn)">Andredswald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Wood part in 
Kent, and part in Essex; from 
the old word <etym lang="oe">Andred,</etym> fear; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a terrible dreadful 
Wood; and therefore call'd 
by Ethelward <etym lang="la">immunis</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Andrews(pn)">St. Andrews</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, in old 
time call'd Regimund, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
St. Regulus's Mount, which 
Ungus King of the Picts, con&shy;
verted into an Archiepisco&shy;
pal See, and gave much 
Church Land to it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Angelbert(pn)">Angelbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same with En&shy;
gelbert; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Angevin(pn)">Angevin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">l'Angevin</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Anjovin</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one 
of <etym lang="fr">Anjou,</etym> a Province in France.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa5v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anglesey(pn)">Anglesey,</form> <xpln lang="en">Lat. <etym lang="la">Mona,</etym> C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Mon</etym> and <etym lang="cb">Tir mon</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="la">terra 
mon,</etym> by the English-Saxons 
it was at first call'd <etym lang="oe">Moneg</etym>, 
afterward when the English 
had took Possession of it, it 
was call'd <etym lang="oe">Engles Ea</etym> and 
Anglesey, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Isle 
of the English.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Angrivarii(pn)">Angrivarii,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient Peo&shy;
ple of Germany, now a part 
of Westphalia. Adr. Jun. draws 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Angreif&shy;
fen,</etym> to take away by force, 
they being a stout and war&shy;
like People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ankerwike(pn)">Ankerwike,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village upon 
the Coast of the River 
Thames, once famous for a 
Nunnery; from our English 
<etym lang="en">Anchor,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, 
a Haven; because the Shore 
is there fit to cast Anchor at.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ansbrand(pn)">Ansbrand,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; 
from the old Goth. <etym lang="go">Anse,</etym> a 
Nobleman, and <etym lang="go">Brenne,</etym> a 
Headpiece.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ansegisus(pn)">Ansegisus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dutch Name, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hansz,</etym> a So&shy;
ciety, and <etym lang="tt">Gis</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Geisel,</etym> 
a Pledge, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Pledge of 
Society; or from the same 
<etym lang="tt">Hansz,</etym> Society, and <etym lang="tt">Geitz,</etym> 
covetousness, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a good 
fellow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anselm(pn)">Anselm,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; 
perhaps <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Germ. <etym lang="gr">Vns&shy;
helm,</etym> or <etym lang="gr">Vnser-helm,</etym> that 
is our Helmet, or our Prote&shy;
ctor; or, as Cambden hath 
it, from the Goth. <etym lang="go">Anses,</etym> a 
Nobleman, and <etym lang="go">Helm,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the Hero's helmet or de&shy;
fence; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hanszhelm,</etym> a Defender of 
his Companions.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ansuarii(pn)">Ansuarii,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a People 
of the Netherlands. Adr. Jun. 
draws it from the old Goth. 
<etym lang="go">Anses</etym> a Noble man, that is, 
such an one as excelled the 
rest in Wealth and good 
Fortune.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anton-haven(pn)">Anton-haven,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Hants. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Haven</etym> 
of the River <etym lang="en">Anton,</etym> from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Antonus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Antrim(pn)">Antrim</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland; but that 
it is an Irish Name, and very 
likely of an Irish Original, 
it might be drawn from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">An</etym> for Un, without, and 
the word <etym lang="oe">Trimman</etym>, to 
Build; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Country un&shy;
inhabited, a desert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Anwick(pn)" lexeme="Alnick(pn)">Anwick, or Alnick,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
County of Northumberland; 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ealnwic</etym>, from the River 
<etym lang="oe">Aln,</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, an Haven, 
remarkable for the Captivity 
of William, and the Death of 
Milcolmb the III. Kings of 
Scotland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Appleby(pn)">Appleby,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Westmorland, once a Military 
Fort, called by the Romans 
<etym lang="la">Aballaba.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aragisus(pn)">Aragisus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a General of the 
Longobardi at Beneventum; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, honour, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geitz,</etym> cove&shy;
tousness; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  covetous of 
fame, for he was a very am&shy;
bitious man.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arbogastes(pn)">Arbogastes,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Frenchman, 
Count of the West, Tyrant 
to Valentinian the Second; 
perhaps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Erb,</etym> 
Inheritance, and <etym lang="tt">Gast,</etym> a 
Stranger; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Stranger 
made Heir of an Inheritance 
by Adoption.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Archibald(pn)">Archebald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a proper Name a&shy;
mongst the Scots, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a bold 
observer; formerly <etym lang="en">Erchen&shy;
bald;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arcklow(pn)" lexeme="Wicklow(pn)">Arcklow, or Wicklow,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pro&shy;
vince in Ireland, once the 
Seat of the Cauci; and, but that 
I suspect it to be of an 
Irish Original, I might de&shy;
rive it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ear</etym>, 
an ear of Corn, and <etym lang="oe">Clowe</etym>, 
a Globe; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a round Coun&shy;
try that affords plenty of 
Corn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ardaburius(pn)">Ardaburius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Consul under 
the Emperours Valentine the 
Third, and Theodosius the 
Less, about the year 447, a 
Goth born; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Erd,</etym> Earth, and <etym lang="tt">Bawer,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Tiller of the Earth, or an 
Husbandman, as George signi&shy;
fyeth amongst us.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ardaricus(pn)">Ardaricus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Ita&shy;
lian Ostrogothi; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Eard</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Erde Aerde,</etym> &shy;
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Erd,</etym> Earth, and <etym lang="tt">Ric,</etym> 
rich; that is to say, rich in 
Lands.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arfast(pn)">Arfast,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> ho&shy;
nour, and the AS. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">fast</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vest,</etym> firm, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that holds fast his ho&shy;
nour. Kilian thinketh it to 
be one and the same with 
<etym lang="la">Ariovistus,</etym> in C&aelig;sar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Argile(pn)">Argile,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Province of Scotland; 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ar-Gwithil,</etym> that is next 
the Irish, for the Brit. call'd 
the Irish <etym lang="br">Gwithil</etym> and <etym lang="br">Gao&shy;
thel.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ariaminus(pn)">Ariaminus,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, honour, and <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, 
great; that is, one greatly 
honoured: Or from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Are</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to in&shy;
crease; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that more 
and more augmenteth his 
fame by noble Atchieve&shy;
ments.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aribertus(pn)" lexeme="Aripertus(pn)">Aribertus, or Aripertus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
King of the Longobardi of 
Italy, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, 
honour, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, illu&shy;
strious; or from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, Teut, <etym lang="tt">Er</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Werth,</etym> 
worth; that is, one worthy 
of honour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arioaldus(pn)">Arioaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Longo&shy;
bardi of Italy; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eere,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> 
honour, and the old Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Walden,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to 
rule, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that reigns 
in much honour and Pomp.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ariovistus(pn)">Ariovistus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sweedish King, 
grand Enemy of C&aelig;sar the 
Dictatour, a most warlike 
Prince. Many suppose, that 
it is the same with <etym lang="en">Arfast;</etym> 
which see before.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arminius(pn)">Arminius,</form> <xpln lang="en">that famous Cap&shy;
tain of the Cherusci, and a 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa6v"> 
most valiant Protector of 
the German Liberty against 
the Romans. Some there 
are, who make it all one 
with <etym lang="en">Herman.</etym> It may be 
derived from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, 
honour, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mey&shy;
nen,</etym> to think, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one 
whose very thought is ho&shy;
nourable. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arnold(pn)">Arnold,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> 
honour, and the word <etym lang="tt">Hold,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that holdeth fast 
his honour; or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, faithful, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
faithful to his honour. See 
Arfast.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arnulph(pn)">Arnulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eere,</etym> honour, 
and <etym lang="bl">Vlph,</etym> help, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) ho&shy;
nour's help; one that stand&shy;
eth up for the upholding of 
honour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arondel(pn)">Arondell,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Arondelle,</etym> a Swal&shy;
low; because this Family 
bears Swallows in its Coat-&shy;
of-Arms.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arran(pn)">Arran,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, once call'd 
Cluyd; but that it is of a Sco&shy;
to-Irish Original , I might 
draw it from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ar,</etym> 
a field, and <etym lang="cb">Rhann,</etym> a par&shy;
cel, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Tract of Land; 
or better perhaps from the 
inseparable Preposition <etym lang="cb">Ar,</etym> 
which in comp. augmenteth 
the sense, and the same 
<etym lang="cb">Rhann,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a good large 
parcel of Ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arrow(pn)">Arrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in the County 
of Warwick, as Tigris, that in 
the Persian Tongue signifieth 
an <etym lang="en">Arrow</etym>, so called for its 
swiftness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arundell(pn)">Arundell,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Sussex, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Arundale, a 
<etym lang="en">Dale</etym> or Valley by the River 
<etym lang="en">Arunn.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arus(pn)">Arus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in the County 
of York; from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ara, 
Araf,</etym> calm, running slowly, 
whence the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Araris</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Arwenath(pn)">Arwenath,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ar,</etym> a field, and <etym lang="cb">Gwinn,</etym> 
white, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one of a plea&shy;
sant Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Asaph(pn)">St Asaph,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Flints, a Bishop's See, C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Llan Elwy,</etym> (i. e.) the 
Temple Elwy; a small Brook 
so call'd from St. Asaph a Bri&shy;
tain, that in his time was an 
Abbot in that place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ascough(pn)" lexeme="Ascogh(pn)">Ascough, or Ascogh;</form> <xpln lang="en">as Cam&shy;
den saith, from the old name 
<etym lang="oe">Ascuith,</etym> which is the same 
with Hasculph, Hastulph, 
and Astolphus; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ashdown(pn)">Ashdown,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Essex, once <etym lang="la">Assandun,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
an Hill for Asses; famous for 
the great overthrow given 
there to Edmond Ironside, by 
Canutus the Dane.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aspar(pn)">Aspar,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arrian, the Son of 
Ardaburius; and a famous 
Captain under Leo the Great; 
if I be not mistaken, a Goth 
by descent; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hat</etym>, hot, furious, 
and <etym lang="oe">speare</etym>, a Spear, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa7r"> 
good at wielding a Spear. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Asprandus(pn)">Asprandus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Longobardi of Italy, perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hausz,</etym> a 
House, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brand</etym>, 
a brand, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a house-brand, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Branden,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brant 
Brennen,</etym> to burn, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Burner of Houses, one that 
layeth all wast with fire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ashen-shire(pn)">Ashen-shire,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Country in Scot&shy;
land, perhaps from the great 
plenty of <etym lang="en">Ash</etym>-trees growing 
therein.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Astolphus(pn)">Astolphus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King but 
one of the Longobardi of Italy; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haesten,</etym> to 
hasten, and <etym lang="bl">Vlph,</etym> help, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that hasteneth help, a 
ready helper.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aterith(pn)">Aterith,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, vulgarly 
call'd Athenry, from the 
<etym lang="la">Auteri,</etym> an ancient People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Athalaricus(pn)">Athalaricus;</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Ita&shy;
lian Ostrogothi; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Adel,</etym> nobility, and <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> 
AS. <etym lang="oe">ric</etym>, rich, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) rich 
in nobleness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Athanagildus(pn)">Athanagildus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Spanish Vice-Goths, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">A&eth;</etym>, pl. <etym lang="oe">A&eth;an</etym>, an 
Oath, and <etym lang="oe">Agildan</etym>, to pay, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that keepeth his 
Oath, payeth his Vow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Athanaricus(pn)">Athanaricus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Italian Ostrogothi, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">A&eth;</etym> an Oath, and <etym lang="oe">ric</etym>, 
rich, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that took 
many Oaths, or struck ma&shy;
ny Bargains, and so grew 
rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Athaulphus(pn)">Athaulphus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same with 
Adolph; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Athelin(pn)">Athelin,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop of 
Canterbury, if it were not, that 
I suppose it to be the same 
with <etym lang="en">Adelm</etym> above, I might 
draw it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">A&eth;</etym>, 
an Oath, and <etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a keeper of his Oath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Athelstanford(pn)">Athelstanford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, that 
is the Ford of <etym lang="en">Athelstan</etym> King 
of the Eng. Saxons, who at 
this place ferry'd over his 
Army against the Scots.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Atkins(pn)">Atkins</form> <xpln lang="en">contracted from Ar&shy;
thurkins, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) little <etym lang="en">Ar&shy;
thur,</etym> for the termination <etym lang="en">kin</etym> 
diminisheth, as saith &AElig;lfric.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Attila(pn)">Attila,</form> <xpln lang="en">that Puissant King of 
the Hunns, deservedly called 
the Scourge of God: Kilian 
draws it from the old Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Atte,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Father.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Attrebatii(pn)">Attrebatii,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People of the 
County now call'd Berks, once 
the Inhabitants of Attrebatum; 
ut there is certainly a Colo&shy;
ny in the Netherlands, call'd 
Attrebates, which, as Camden 
tells us, some derive from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Attrech,</etym> signifying a 
Land of Bread. But this word 
is not now in use; therefore 
I had rather draw it from 
the initial C. Br. part. <etym lang="cb">A.</etym> 
which in Composition is aug&shy;
mentative, &amp; <etym lang="cb">Tref,</etym> a Town; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a great Town; and 
who knows but the At&shy;
trebatii took their Name 
from some great Town as 
among the Greeks the Megalopoli, 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa7v"> 
the Germ. Meck&shy;
lenburgh? </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aubry(pn)">Aubry,</form> <xpln lang="en">once a Christen-name, 
but now a Sirname, contra&shy;
cted from <etym lang="en">Alberic;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Audley(pn)">Audley,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly call'd de Al&shy;
dalegh; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ald</etym>, 
old, and <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, a field, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the old field.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Audley-end(pn)">Audley-end,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Essex, the sumptuous Palace 
of the Dukes of Suffolk, Built 
by <etym lang="en">Thomas Audley</etym> Chancellor 
of England, who assumed to 
himself the Monastery for his 
own House.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Audre(pn)">Audre</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cambr. once call'd 
Athelred, from St. <etym lang="en">&AElig;thel&shy;
dred,</etym> to whose memory was 
a Temple there, it is likely, 
erected.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Audrey(pn)">Audrey,</form> <xpln lang="en">by contraction for 
<etym lang="oe">Etheldreda,</etym> that was an 
Abbotess of the Royal Eng&shy;
lish-Saxon blood, the Wife 
of Tombert a Prince of the 
Girvii, and after that of Elg&shy;
frid King of Northumberland, 
Canoniz'd after her Death. 
From the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, noble, 
and <etym lang="oe">Dread</etym>, fear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aventon(pn)">Aventon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Glocester, by Antoninus Avone 
or Abone, from the River 
<etym lang="en">Avon,</etym> by adding <etym lang="en">ton;</etym> as 
Waterton, Riverton, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Avery(pn)">Avery,</form> <xpln lang="en">once a Christen-name, 
but now a Sirname. I sup&shy;
pose it to be a contract of 
the old Goth. <etym lang="go">Haveric,</etym> the 
name of a certain King.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Avice(pn)">Avice,</form> <xpln lang="en">a womans Name, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="oe">Hawis,</etym> according to 
some: corrupted from <etym lang="oe">Hel&shy;
wis,</etym> and this from <etym lang="oe">Hilden&shy;
vig,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the safeguard of 
Women; but I had rather 
draw it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hell,</etym> 
clear, and <etym lang="tt">Weisz,</etym> wise, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that excelled in Wis&shy;
dom.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aulcaster(pn)">Aulcaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Warw. from the River <etym lang="en">Aln;</etym> 
for which cause it is that 
Matth. Paris writes it Allen&shy;
cester, AS. <etym lang="oe">Allenceaster</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a perfect City. See 
Allingham.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Avon(pn)">Avon,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of divers Ri&shy;
vers in Wales; from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Afon,</etym> signifying simply a 
River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Austria(pn)">Austria,</form> <xpln lang="en">Teut. <etym lang="tt">Oestereich,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Eastern Kingdom; from 
the situation thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Autharis(pn)">Autharis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">All</etym>, all, and <etym lang="oe">&ETH;earran</etym>, 
to dare, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that dares 
undergo any dangers, how 
great soever they are: Or 
from the same AS. <etym lang="oe">All</etym>, and 
Jupiter; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">&ETH;or</etym>, one that 
wholly devoted himself to 
Jupiter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Axholm(pn)">Axholm,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Lin&shy;
coln, AS. <etym lang="oe">Eaxanholm</etym>, from 
the chiefest Town Axey, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="oe">Axel,</etym> &amp; <etym lang="oe">Holm</etym>, an Isle 
having many Rivers in it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Axminster(pn)">Axminster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Devon, from the River <etym lang="en">Ax,</etym> and 
a <etym lang="en">Minster,</etym> for which it was 
accounted famous.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="B"><alpha>B</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Badbury(pn)">BAdbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Dorset, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Baddan-byrig</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the Town of Hostage. 
It was once the Court of the 
Vice-Saxon Kings; so call'd 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bad</etym>, a Pledge, 
and <etym lang="oe">Byrig</etym>, a City, perhaps 
because the Vice-Saxon Kings 
had the Hostages of subdued 
Countries here in Custody.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bain(pn)">Bain,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River; which see in 
the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bainard's-castle(pn)">Bainard's-Castle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in London, 
so call'd from William Bainard 
Baron of Dunmow, the Buil&shy;
der thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baldread(pn)">Baldread,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King of Kent. 
Verstegan draws it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, bold, and <etym lang="oe">rede</etym>, 
counsel; that is bold in Coun&shy;
sel. Or from the same <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reden,</etym> to 
speak; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Bald,</etym> soon, and the same 
<etym lang="tt">Rede,</etym> counsel, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that 
was quick at giving advice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baldwin(pn)">Baldwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Bald,</etym> soon, 
and <etym lang="gr">Winnen,</etym> to overcome, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that winneth or 
overcometh quickly. Ac&shy;
cording to Lips. 'tis derived 
from <etym lang="tt">Gewal,</etym> Power, and 
<etym lang="tt">Winnen,</etym> to overcome, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
powerful to conquer: Or as 
Camb. would have it, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, bold, and 
<etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Victour, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a bold 
Winner or Victour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Balthi(pn)">Balthi,</form> <xpln lang="en">a most famous People 
of the ancient Goths. Jun. 
draws it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, 
bold, they being a bold, un&shy;
daunted People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bamba(pn)">Bamba,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spanish 
Vice-Goths: perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pamp,</etym> a Glutton, 
or one that pampereth his 
Belly too much.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bamborough(pn)">Bamborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Northumberland, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Bebbanburgh</etym>; and that 
from a Queen call'd <etym lang="oe">Bebba</etym> 
that erected it, saith Bede. 
It was once the Court of the 
Kings of Northumberland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bambury(pn)">Bambury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Oxford, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bana</etym>, 
Man-slaughter, and <etym lang="oe">Byrigh</etym>, 
a City, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Town of 
Man-slaughter, perhaps so 
call'd for some great Slaugh&shy;
ter there. It is also found 
</page> 

<page sig="Aa8v">
in Somner, written <etym lang="oe">Banbe&shy;
orgas</etym>; in Kilian <etym lang="tt">Been&shy;
berge</etym>, Boots or Buskins, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ban</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Been,</etym> 
a Bone, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beor&shy;
gan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Berghen,</etym> to hide, 
either because this Colony is 
somewhat like a Boot; or 
because the making of Boots 
was the chief Trade of the 
Country. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bangor(pn)">Bangor,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Ches. 
or rather Ban-chor or Bon-&shy;
chor, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Quire</etym> <etym lang="en">Ban</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Bon,</etym> a Town once fa&shy;
mous for a Minster of the 
Britains.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bangor(pn)">Bangor,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Caern. 
once <etym lang="oe">Banchor,</etym> q. <etym lang="oe">Penchor,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Capital Quire; for it 
is to this day a Bishop's See.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Banna(pn)">Banna,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, a Town 
upon a Promontory, which 
in Irish sig. <etym lang="ir">Sacred</etym>; and by 
Ptolemy, the whole Promon&shy;
tory is call'd &#x1F31;&epsilon;&rho;&#x1F79;&nu;.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Banocksbourn(pn)">Banocksbourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the River of <etym lang="en">Banock,</etym> 
remarkable for the Slaughter 
of Edward the Second King 
of England.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barbacan(pn)">Barbacan,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arabick word 
, Sig. a Spy or Watch Tower.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bardney(pn)">Bardney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Lincoln, a Town memorable 
for the Tomb of St. Oswald 
the King, not unlikely from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beere,</etym> an Horse, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, Water, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a Pasture for Horses by the 
water side.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bardulph(pn)">Bardulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">Bartulph, Ber&shy;
tulph. Verstegan saith that 
it was formerly writ <etym lang="bl">Beriht-&shy;
Vlph,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) help in Coun&shy;
sel, I had rather draw it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, fa&shy;
mous, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help; that 
is a brave or famous helper.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barkley(pn)">Barkley,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Glocester, AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorcenlau</etym>, 
a Town; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorce</etym>, a Beech tree, and 
Lan for <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, a Field; by 
reason of the great Plenty of 
Beech Trees growing there&shy;
about.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barkshire(pn)">Barkshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Berroc</etym>, a Wood; so call'd 
because of the abundance of 
Box wood growing there; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Bare Oke</etym> in which the 
Natives in troublesom times 
met to consult about their 
affairs. See Bare and Oak 
in their proper places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barrow(pn)">Barrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Ireland, by 
Ptolemy call'd Brigus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barry(pn)">Barry</form> <xpln lang="en">Island in the County of 
Glamorgan, from <etym lang="en">Baruch</etym> a de&shy;
vout man that was interr'd 
there.</xpln></wordentry>
