<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bartlet(pn)">Bartlet,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Diminutive of 
<etym lang="en">Bartholomew.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barton(pn)">Barton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire. Spel&shy;
man saith, that the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Berton</etym>, signifieth a Barn, 
and if so, it may very 
commodiously be drawn 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bere</etym>, Barley, 
and <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, a Town, (i. e.) a 
Town for Barley.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Basing(pn)">Basing,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town and Castle in 
the County of Hants; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Basing</etym>, a Coat of 
Mail; because of the resem&shy;
blance it has thereto.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Basingshall(pn)" lexeme="Bassishaw-street(pn)">Basingshall, or Bassishaw-&shy;
street in London,</form> <xpln lang="en">once call'd 
Basingis-hawe, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Basing</etym>, a Cloak, and <etym lang="oe">hawe</etym>, 
an Hall, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a place for 
Cloth, of which Cloaks and 
other Garments are made.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Basset(pn)">Basset,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Basset,</etym> a Dwarf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bastile(pn)">The Bastile,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Royal Tower 
in the Imperial City Paris 
in France, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Bastille,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Fort, or 
strong Hold, for the excel&shy;
lency of it; and this from 
<etym lang="fr">Bastir</etym> to build.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Batavia(pn)">Batavia,</form> <xpln lang="en">now Holland, the 
most famous Province of the 
People call'd Belgii. Adr. Jun. 
supposeth that it is call'd so, 
q. <etym lang="en">Batons Have,</etym> that is to 
say, Baton's Substance, who 
was a General of the Catti, 
now call'd the Hassi, and first 
founded a Colony there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Batersea(pn)">Batersea,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Surrey, once call'd <etym lang="oe">Patryc's 
Ea,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Patrick's Isle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bath(pn)">Bath,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Somer&shy;
set, by Antoninus, call'd the 
Waters of the Sun, by AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hat Ba&eth;an</etym>; and from the 
great Concourse of Diseased 
People, <etym lang="oe">Acmanceaster</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Sick folks Town. 
See Ake and Chester in their 
proper places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Battle Abby(pn)">Battle Abby,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Sussex, so call'd by William 
the Conqueror, in token of 
a signal Victory over Harald 
the last English-Saxon King, 
which was the first step to 
his conquering the whole 
Kingdom to himself.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Battle Bridge(pn)">Battle Bridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of York, where Harald the 
last English-Saxon King dis&shy;
comfited and slew Harald 
Hardred the then King of 
Norway.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baxter(pn)">Baxter,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="en">Baker.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beauchamp(pn)">Beauchamp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Beau Champ,</etym> that is, of a good 
or fair Field.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beauchief(pn)">Beauchief,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Abby in the 
County of Derby, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Beau Chef,</etym> a good 
Head; possibly so call'd, be&shy;
cause a great many Learned 
Men lived therein.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beaudesert(pn)">Beaudesert,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Stafford, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a brave De&shy;
sert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beaufoe(pn)">Beaufoe,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Beau,</etym> 
good, and <etym lang="fr">Fau,</etym> a Beech tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beaufort(pn)">Beaufort,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Beau</etym> and <etym lang="fr">Fort,</etym> that is, a 
sumptuous or commodious 
Fort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beavis(pn)">Beavis,</form> <xpln lang="en">Camden supposeth, that 
it is contracted from the Vet. 
G. <etym lang="gr">Bellovesus,</etym> the Name of a 
King; as the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Beavois,</etym> 
from the <etym lang="la">Bellovaci</etym> an ancient 
People in France.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beauly(pn)">Beauly,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Tract of Land in 
Hantshire, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Beau</etym>, 
<etym lang="fr">lieu</etym>, a brave, pleasant place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beaumarish(pn)">Beaumarish,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G, <etym lang="fr">Beaumarais,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb1v">
in the Isle of Anglesey; for&shy;
merly call'd Bonover, that 
is, a fair Fen or Marsh. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beaumont(pn)">Beaumont,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the F. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Beau mont,</etym> that is, a pretty 
Mount.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beaupre(pn)">Beaupre,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Beau Pr&egrave;,</etym> a fine Meadow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beawdley(pn)">Beawdley,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Worcester, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Beau lieu,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a brave 
pleasant place for its situ&shy;
ation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bede(pn)">Bede,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beade</etym>, a Prayer. 
St. Bede being so call'd from 
his earnestness in Prayer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bedford(pn)">Bedford,</form> <xpln lang="en">AS. <etym lang="oe">Bedanford</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Beds,</etym> or publick Inns, 
by <etym lang="en">a Ford.</etym> See Bed and 
Ford in their places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Bees(pn)">St. Bees</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumberland, so 
call'd from St. <etym lang="oe">Bega</etym> an Irish 
Virgin, that lived a solitary 
Life there,</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Belfast(pn)">Belfast,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Province of Ul&shy;
ster in Ireland, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Bel</etym> fair, and our old Eng&shy;
lish word <etym lang="en">Fast,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Festen&shy;
ne</etym>, a Fortress, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a fair 
Fortress.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Belgae(pn)">Belgae,</form> <xpln lang="en">a stout People, famous 
for Sea Affairs. Ad. Jun. de&shy;
rives it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bul&shy;
ghen,</etym> to fight; for they were 
a warlike People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Belinsgate(pn)">Belinsgate,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Wharff for Ships 
in London, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">B&aelig;l&shy;
ge</etym>, a Purse or Wallet, for 
that those that go there, car&shy;
ry ready Money, if they in&shy;
tend to buy any thing: Or 
possibly from the word <etym lang="oe">Bel&shy;
lan,</etym> to roar, from the noise 
of many waves beating a&shy;
gainst the shore. But, which 
is most likely, from K. <etym lang="br">Belin</etym> 
or <etym lang="br">Belinus,</etym> the first Founder, 
according to Stow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bellasise(pn)">Bellasise,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Belle 
Assize,</etym> a pleasant situation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bellew(pn)">Bellew,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bel-Eau,</etym> a plea&shy;
sant Water or River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Benion(pn)">Benion,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Name common in 
Wales; that is to say, <etym lang="cb">Ap-&shy;
Enion,</etym> the Son of Enion; 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bennet(pn)">Bennet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">B&egrave;noist, Benoit,</etym> and 
both from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Benedictus,</etym> 
blessed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Bennet's in the Holm(pn)">St Bennet's in the Holm,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
County of Norfolk (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
Church of St. Bennet in 
the <etym lang="en">Holm;</etym> see Holm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bensbury(pn)">Bensbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Surrey, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="oe">Cnebensbury,</etym> 
so call'd from one <etym lang="oe">Cneben,</etym> a 
Captain under &AElig;thelred, King 
of Kent, that was there 
slain in a fight against 
Ceaulin King of the Vice-&shy;
Saxons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Benson(pn)">Benson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, not as 
Camden will have it, q. <etym lang="en">Ben&shy;
net's Son,</etym> but from <etym lang="en">Benja&shy;
min,</etym> q. Ben's Son.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bent(pn)">Bent,</form> <xpln lang="en">Camden supposeth it so 
call'd from the abundance 
of <etym lang="en">Bents;</etym> which see in 
Com: Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berald(pn)" lexeme="Beroald(pn)">Berald or Beroald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Saxon, 
the first Prince of Savoy; not 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb2r">
unlikely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bera</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bahr.</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Beer,</etym> a 
Bear, and the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wal&shy;
den,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to wield, 
to rule. See Bernard. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bergamsted(pn)">Bergamsted,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorg</etym>, a Fort, 
<etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, a House, and <etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, 
a Stead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beringer(pn)" lexeme="Beringard(pn)">Beringer, or Beringard,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Beringarius</etym>, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bahren,</etym> Bears and 
<etym lang="tt">Gard,</etym> that is a Keeper of 
Bears; see Bernard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berkley(pn)" lexeme="Barkley(pn)">Berkley or Barkley,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
Counties of Somerset and Glo&shy;
cester; see Barkley above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bermundsey(pn)">Bermundsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Bermund's Ea</etym>, that is Ber&shy;
mund's Isle, formerly famous 
for an Abby, erected by Ber&shy;
mund, either Lord or Abbot 
of the place. Now Bermund 
may be derived either from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bera</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bahr,</etym> 
a Bear, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> 
a Mouth; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beran</etym>, to bear, and <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, 
Peace, that is to say, a Peace-&shy;
bringer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bernard(pn)">Bernard,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a most 
devout Abbot, either, as 
Camden saith, from our Eng&shy;
lish <etym lang="en">Barn,</etym> a Child, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ard,</etym> Nature; or, as 
Verstegan, saith, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Beorn&shy;
hart,</etym> that is, one of a stou<emend err="r">t</emend> 
heart. It may as probably 
be drawn from <etym lang="en">Bear</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Ward,</etym> that is to say, a War&shy;
der or Keeper of Bears.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bernicia(pn)">Bernicia,</form> <xpln lang="en">AS. <etym lang="oe">Beornica-&shy;
Meg&eth;e</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Beornica&shy;
rice</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Province 
of Berwick; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorn</etym>, a Barn 
that is a Man-Child, and <etym lang="gk">&nu;&iota;&kappa;&#x1F74;,</etym> 
Victory; so call'd for the 
warlike disposition of the 
Natives.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bernulph(pn)">Bernulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Mercii, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bearn</etym>, issue 
and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that helpeth, or provideth for 
his Children.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berry(pn)">Berry,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same with Bo&shy;
rough; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bertha(pn)">Bertha,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Woman's Name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, no&shy;
ble, amous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berthold(pn)">Berthold,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bericht,</etym> 
learning, and <etym lang="en">Hold,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that retaineth what he 
has learn'd; or as Kilian 
saith, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Be&shy;
richt</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Berit,</etym> a League, 
and <etym lang="tt">Hold,</etym> that is, one that 
will keep his promise; or, 
which is yet more likely, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
Brave, and <etym lang="en">Hold</etym>, a Ruler, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a good Ruler or Go&shy;
vernour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berthulph(pn)">Berthulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop of Winche&shy;
ster in the year 900, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, illustrious, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a fa&shy;
mous helper.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berten(pn)">Berten,</form> <xpln lang="en">see Barton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bertran(pn)">Bertran,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name. 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb2v">
Camden draws it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous, and 
<etym lang="oe">rand</etym>, pure. It may as well 
come of the same <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
brave, and <etym lang="oe">ran Hran</etym>, a 
Whale; or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rande,</etym> 
a brink of a River. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bertrud(pn)">Bertrud,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of Clothair, 
King of France in the year 
628. perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, fair, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Drut Druit,</etym> faithful, loyal, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  fair and faithful.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bertwald(pn)">Bertwald,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop of 
Canterbury, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous, and <etym lang="oe">Weal&shy;
dan</etym>, to rule.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berwent-fels(pn)">Berwent-Fels,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Coun&shy;
ty of Cumberland, Mountains; 
from the River <etym lang="en">Berwent</etym> 
running there-through, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Felsz,</etym> a Rock, or 
Cliff.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Berwick(pn)">Berwick,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland, 
formerly a famous strong 
Hold, which Ingulph inter&shy;
prets a Mannor. Leland 
draws it from <etym lang="oe">Aberwic,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
a Town at the Mouth of a 
River. Somn. maketh it the 
same with the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bere&shy;
tun</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Corn Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bets(pn)">Bets,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
name, but now a Sirname; 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Beatus,</etym> blessed, 
saith Camden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bevans(pn)">Bevans,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname common 
to the Welsh, as much as to 
say, <etym lang="cb">Ap Evans,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  come 
of Evan or John. See E&shy;
van.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bever(pn)">Bever,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, formerly 
<etym lang="fr">Belvoir,</etym> a French word; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Castle fair to look at; 
so call'd for the Pleasantness 
of its situation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beverley(pn)">Beverley,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in the 
County of York, AS. <etym lang="oe">Be&shy;
verlega</etym>, Bede's Abby in 
Deir-wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Beverwiick(pn)">Beverwiick,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Hol&shy;
land, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Beyer,</etym> 
a Bavarian, and <etym lang="tt">Wiic,</etym> AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, an Haven; or per&shy;
haps from the word <etym lang="en">Bever,</etym> 
which this Town might plen&shy;
teously afford in former 
Ages.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Biggin(pn)">Biggin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, 
to possess, or rather from 
<etym lang="oe">Bycgan</etym>, to build.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bigot(pn)">Bigot,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bigot,</etym> 
an Hypocrite, or superstitious 
Person. Menag.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Biland(pn)">Biland,</form> <xpln lang="en">that is, <etym lang="fr">de Belle-Lande,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  of good Land; See 
Land in its place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Binchester(pn)">Binchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Bishoprick 
of Durham, by Antoninus <etym lang="la">Vino&shy;
vium</etym>, by adding the AS. 
termination <etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a 
City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Birtyc(pn)" lexeme="Birthryc(pn)" lexeme="Bithric(pn)">Birtyc, Birthryc and Bith&shy;
ric;</form> <xpln lang="en">Verstegan draws it from 
our word <etym lang="en">Birth,</etym> and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">ric</etym>, rich, that is, born to 
riches, an Heir to an Estate; 
It might also be drawn 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
Illustrious, and <etym lang="oe">ric</etym>, rich, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  noble and rich.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb3r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bisset(pn)">Bisset,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bizet,</etym> 
a kind of Dove, this from <etym lang="fr">Bis,</etym> 
ash colour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Blackney(pn)">Blackney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Norfolk, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
an Isle, and our word <etym lang="en">Black,</etym> 
that is, the Black Isle; See 
Black.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Black-water(pn)">Black-water,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, by Pto&shy;
lemy Idumanum, from <etym lang="en">Black</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">water;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Blanch(pn)">Blanch,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans name, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blanche.</etym> Ital. 
<etym lang="it">Bianca,</etym> white.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bletsoe(pn)">Bletsoe,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Bedfordshire, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="oe">Bletnesho;</etym> from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Bletsian</etym>, to bless, and <etym lang="oe">seo</etym>, 
a Sight, to wit for the plea&shy;
santness of its prospect.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Blundell(pn)">Blundell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Blond,</etym> red and the 
dim. <etym lang="fr">el.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Blunt(pn)">Blunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname from the 
same root .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bodmin(pn)">Bodmin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Cornwall, 
perhaps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bod,</etym> 
a Kite, and <etym lang="cb">Min,</etym> the Bank 
of a River, by reason of the 
great number of Kites that 
frequent it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bodvari(pn)">Bodvari,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Flintshire, from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bod,</etym> a River and 
<etym lang="cb">Varis,</etym> a Ferry; see Fer&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bormund(pn)">Bormund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Prince of Apulia 
and Antioch; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bode</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bott,</etym> 
an Embassador, and <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> 
a Mouth; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that 
hath a fluent Tongue as Am&shy;
bassadours ought to have; or 
from the same <etym lang="oe">Bode</etym>, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, Peace, that is, 
a Messenger of Peace. From 
this name came our word 
Bowman, a name now gi&shy;
ven to Hounds; as the fa&shy;
mous Th. H. ingeniously no&shy;
teth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bois(pn)">Bois,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bois,</etym> a 
Wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bold(pn)">Bold,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; Camden de&shy;
rives it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bol,</etym> 
a Marsh, which word I no 
where find in that sence. So 
that I had rather draw it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bolde</etym>, a Vil&shy;
lage, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  of a Village; or yet 
more naturally from our 
own word <etym lang="en">Bold,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  ad&shy;
venturous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bonaventure(pn)">Bonaventure,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-&shy;
name; from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bonne 
Aventure,</etym> a lucky Chance; 
see Adventure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bond(pn)">Bond,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
word <etym lang="en">Bond</etym> or <etym lang="en">Band,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the tye of a Family; see 
Band and Bind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bonevill(pn)">Bonevill,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">De Bonne ville,</etym> that is, 
of a good Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Boscastle(pn)">Boscastle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Cornwall, corrupted from <etym lang="en">Bo&shy;
tereaux-Castle,</etym> from the 
Norm. name <etym lang="no">Boterau,</etym> which 
signifieth a Garter; that Fa&shy;
mily bearing a Garter in its 
Coat of Arms.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Boseham(pn)">Boseham</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, formerly 
<etym lang="en">Bosenham,</etym> from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Busz,</etym> a Bush, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an House; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bosih</etym>, a Fence. 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb3v"> 
Somner, saith, that it was for&shy;
merly call'd <etym lang="en">Bosauham,</etym> 
and he seemeth to derive it 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bois,</etym> a Wood, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">ham</etym>, an habita&shy;
tion, which, if it were so, 
ought to be written Bo&shy;
isham. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bostock(pn)">Bostock,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Botestock,</etym> 
in Cheshire; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Bote</etym>, Boot, or overplus, 
and <etym lang="oe">stocce</etym>, a trunk or bo&shy;
dy of a Tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Boston(pn)">Boston,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, a Mar&shy;
ket-Town, so call'd, q. 
<etym lang="en">Botolph</etym> 's <etym lang="en">Town,</etym> who had a 
Monastery in Warw. and was 
had in much reputation at 
this place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bosworth(pn)">Bosworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Leicestershire, 
memorable for the Death of 
the famous Richard the Third, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bosz,</etym> an 
Apple-tree, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wors&eth;</etym>, a Court, or 
<etym lang="oe">Weor&eth;</etym>, worthy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Botolph(pn)">St. Botolph,</form> <xpln lang="en">Camden supposeth 
that it is derived from the 
Noun <etym lang="en">Boat,</etym> and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help; because per&shy;
haps he was the Mariners tu&shy;
telar Saint, and for this rea&shy;
son was so much adored at 
Boston.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Botontines(pn)">Botontines,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Hunt. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Buttings,</etym> heaps 
of Earth. See Buts amongst 
the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bottle(pn)">Bottle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Botl, Botle</etym>, a Vil&shy;
lage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bottle-bridge(pn)">Bottle-bridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hunt. that is 
to say, <etym lang="en">Botolph</etym> 's Bridge; or 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Botle</etym>, a Vil&shy;
lage, and <etym lang="en">Bridge;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Boverton(pn)">Boverton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glamorganshire, 
by Antoninus <etym lang="la">Bovium.</etym></xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bovil(pn)">Bovil,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">B&oelig;uf,</etym> 
an Ox, and <etym lang="fr">Ville,</etym> a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bourchier(pn)">Bourchier,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps deri&shy;
ved from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bourg,</etym> 
a Town, and <etym lang="fr">Cher,</etym> dear; 
yet I rather think, that it 
cometh of the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bour&shy;
cier,</etym> for Boursal a term in 
Law, which signifies that 
which is a younger Brother's 
right.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bourn(pn)">Bourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, that is 
a Town hard by a <etym lang="en">Bourn</etym> or 
River, where King Edmund 
was crown'd; see Bourn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bowen(pn)">Bowen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname frequently 
given to the Welsh, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="cb">Ap Owen,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  from, or 
the Son of, Owen; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Boyl(pn)">Boyl,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Country in Ireland, so 
call'd from the River <etym lang="en">Boyl,</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Buellio,</etym> in the County 
of Roscommon, a Province of 
Cannaught.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brabant(pn)">Brabant,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Province 
of the Netherlands, from 
the old Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brad,</etym> now 
<etym lang="bl">Breed,</etym> broad, and <etym lang="bl">Bandt,</etym> 
a Garter, or Swathe, saith 
Adr. Jun. so call'd with rela&shy;
tion to the vast extent there&shy;
of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bracton(pn)">Bracton,</form> <xpln lang="en">at the first a Towns 
name, from whence Henry 
of Bracton, an expert Lawyer, 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb4r"> 
and Lord Chief Justice of 
England in the Reign of King 
Henry the Third, had his 
Sirname. It may not unlike&shy;
ly be derived from <etym lang="en">Brake</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Town;</etym> which see. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bradford(pn)">Bradford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Wilts, formerly <etym lang="en">Bradanford,</etym> 
that is, the <etym lang="en">broad Ford;</etym> see 
Broad and Ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brakley(pn)">Brakley,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Northampton, a Towns name, 
from <etym lang="en">Brake,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Fern, 
because it was formerly much 
overspread with Fern; see 
Brake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brancaster(pn)">Brancaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norfolk, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="la">Brannodunum,</etym> by ad&shy;
ding of the AS. term. 
<etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a Town or Ca&shy;
stle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brandon(pn)">Brandon,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a famous 
Country. Leland derives it 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Brane</etym> or 
<etym lang="cb">Bran,</etym> a Crow, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, an Hill; or from the 
same Dune, and the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Bren,</etym> a King; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Kings-&shy;
Mount. Yet I had rather 
draw it from <etym lang="tt">Brant,</etym> burnt, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, a Town; 
that is to say, a burnt 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brandsford(pn)" lexeme="Brandsford-Bridge(pn)">Brandsford, or Bransford-&shy;
Bridge</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Leicester, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Ford of 
<etym lang="en">Brands,</etym> for some dreadful 
Fire, that once happened 
there; see Burn amongst 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bray(pn)">Bray,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Barkshire, 
from the <etym lang="la">Bibroci,</etym> that for&shy;
merly inhabited this place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Breach(pn)">The Breach,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Kent, where the River Thames 
bursting through the Banks, 
overflowed many Acres of 
Ground; see <etym lang="en">Break.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brecknockmere(pn)">Brecknockmere,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Coun&shy;
ty of Brec. C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Linsave&shy;
than,</etym> that is, a standing 
Slough; by Girald called Cla&shy;
mosus, from the thundering 
noise it maketh, when the Ice 
is thawed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brecknockshire(pn)">Brecknockshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bre&shy;
chiniau;</etym> from <etym lang="cb">Brechanius</etym> a 
Prince, that begat 24 Daugh&shy;
ters, which were all canoni&shy;
zed in the Choire of Saints.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Breda(pn)">Breda,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous and most for&shy;
tified City of Brabant. I sup&shy;
pose from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Breed,</etym> 
broad, and the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Aa,</etym> 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water; because it 
lyeth nigh Merck, a River 
somewhat broader than Or&shy;
dinary.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brederode(pn)">Brederode,</form> <xpln lang="en">the name of an 
Illustrious Family in Holland, 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Brede, Breed,</etym> 
broad, and <etym lang="bl">Roede,</etym> a rod.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bremicham(pn)" lexeme="Birmingham(pn)">Bremicham, or Birmingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">
in the County of Warwick, 
famous for Workmanship in 
Metals; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Bryme, Breman</etym>, famous, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an Habitation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brentknoll(pn)">Brentknoll,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somersetshire, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Knol</etym>, the Top 
of a Mountain, and <etym lang="oe">Brent,</etym> 
burnt, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  parched with the 
heat of the Sun.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brent Marsh(pn)">Brent marsh,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Burnt 
marsh,</etym> in the County of Somerset; 
</page>

<page sig="Bb4v"> 
as the Monks of Gla&shy;
stenbury expound it, Frogs 
Marsh, as if Brent had for&shy;
merly signified a Frog. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brentstreet(pn)">Brentstreet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Middlesex, from the River 
<etym lang="en">Brent,</etym> and <etym lang="en">street;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brentwood(pn)">Brentwood,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="en">Burnt wood,</etym> see <etym lang="en">Burn</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Wood.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bretenham(pn)">Bretenham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Suffolk, formerly by Antoni&shy;
nus called <etym lang="la">Combretonium,</etym> that 
is, a Village on both sides of 
the River Breton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bretton(pn)">Bretton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a National term, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one of <etym lang="en">Britain.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brian(pn)">Brian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; in 
old Books it is written Bri&shy;
ant and Brient, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Bruiant,</etym> clamorous; 
this from <etym lang="fr">Bruire,</etym> to make a 
noise.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bridchurch(pn)">Bridchurch,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumberland, q.
d. the Church of St. <etym lang="en">Bridget,</etym> 
an Irish Saint.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bridewell(pn)">Bridewell,</form> <xpln lang="en">an House of Cor&shy;
rection, formerly, an Hall in 
the City of London; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Bride</etym> 's <etym lang="en">Well,</etym> or St. <etym lang="en">Bridget</etym>'s 
<etym lang="en">Well.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bridgewater(pn)">Bridgewater,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Somerset, a famous Port, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Walters-burgh;</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Burgh-Walter,</etym> from one 
<etym lang="en">Walter</etym> a Soldier under Wil&shy;
liam the Conquerour, that 
received this Town for his 
Service in the Wars.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="De Briewer(pn)">De Briewer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a name taken 
from the place of Birth; from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Brugere, Briere</etym> a 
Heath; because the first of 
that Name, was found by 
King Henry the Second, as he 
was Hunting in the same 
Heath where he was born 
and brought up; and after&shy;
wards came to be greatly in 
favour with Richard III. Son 
to the said King Henry II.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brig(pn)">Brig,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, formerly 
Glandford, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Town by 
a <etym lang="en">Bridge;</etym> see Bridge in its 
proper place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brigthelmsted(pn)">Brigthelmsted,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Brigh&eth;ealmertun</etym>, so cal&shy;
led from St. <etym lang="en">Brigthelm;</etym> see 
<etym lang="en">Bright</etym> and <etym lang="en">Helm</etym> amongst 
the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brigid(pn)" lexeme="Bridget(pn)">Brigid, ali&agrave;s Bridget,</form> <xpln lang="en">the 
name of a certain Irish Saint; 
as also a certain Queen of 
Sweden, her equal for San&shy;
ctity; from our English 
<etym lang="en">Bright.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brill(pn)" lexeme="Briel(pn)">Brill, or as Adr. Jun. writeth 
it, Briel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dutch Port and 
Fortress; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Bril,</etym> a Prospective-Glass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brill(pn)">Brill,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Bucks, 
a contract from <etym lang="en">Burr-hill,</etym> 
for the many <etym lang="en">Burrs</etym> that grow 
there; see Burr in the 
Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bristow(pn)">Bristow,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous and rich 
Sea-Port Town, AS. <etym lang="oe">Briht&shy;
stow</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Beorhtstow</etym>, 
a bright, pleasant place, right&shy;
ly so called for its pleasant 
Situation, and sumptuous 
Buildings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Britain(pn)">Britain</form> <xpln lang="en">, Camden deriveth it 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Brith,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb5r"> 
painted, and <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&alpha;&nu;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, a Na&shy;
tion. I had rather draw it 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bri,</etym> Honour, 
and <etym lang="cb">Tain,</etym> a River; for it is 
an Island exceeding all o&shy;
thers in Europe, from the 
great and many Rivers where&shy;
with it abounds; amongst 
which Thames, Tagus, and Pa&shy;
ctolus, are the chief. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Britholm(pn)">Britholm,</form> <xpln lang="en">Bishop of Bath and 
Wells, about the year 955. AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht-helm</etym>, a bright 
Helmet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brithwold(pn)">Brithwold,</form> <xpln lang="en">Bishop of Winche&shy;
ster, in the year 996. from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brith</etym>, famous, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wealden</etym>, to bear rule.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brittenbury(pn)">Brittenbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Holland. If 
we may credit Adr. Jun. it 
was once the Romans Maga&shy;
zine, in which they laid up 
Ammunition for the main&shy;
tenance of their Forces,
bringing it over from Bri&shy;
tain; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Britains Borough,</etym> 
<etym lang="en">Britainople;</etym> because a Band 
of Britains Quarter'd there. 
See Borough.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Broken-bridge(pn)">Broken-bridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Wilts, formerly call'd 
<etym lang="oe">Caerderburge,</etym> the Court of 
the Petty Saxon Kings; per&shy;
haps from <etym lang="oe">Caerdure,</etym> some 
petty King that settled him&shy;
self there, and <etym lang="oe">Burg</etym> for 
Borough; which see: Or 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer,</etym> a Town, 
and <etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> water, that is, a 
Town seated by the water 
side.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bromfield(pn)">Bromfield,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Broom-Field;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bructeri(pn)">Bructeri,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a People of 
Germany, where now is West&shy;
phalia. Adr. Jun. supposeth 
'em to be call'd <term lang="la">quasi</term>, <etym lang="gr">Brouck&shy;
ters</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Inhabitants of Fens 
or watry Grounds; from the 
Ger. <etym lang="gr">Broucken,</etym> Marshes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bruiton(pn)">Bruiton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somersetshire, from 
the River <etym lang="en">Bry,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ton</etym> 
for Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brunehault(pn)">Brunehault,</form> <xpln lang="en">by the Writers 
of that Age, Brunechileis; a 
most wicked Queen of France, 
perhaps from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Bruyen,</etym> brown, and <etym lang="tt">Helde,</etym> 
a Dame, or noble Matron.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Brunswick(pn)">Brunswick,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Imperial City 
in Germany, from <etym lang="gr">Bruno</etym> the 
Founder thereof, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, a Fortress.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Buckingham(pn)">Buckingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">the County 
Town, so call'd from the 
abundance of <etym lang="en">Beech-trees</etym> 
growing there; and AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an Habitation; see 
Beech.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Buelth(pn)">Buelth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Breckn. perhaps from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bwlch,</etym> broken, to 
wit, for the scraggy Rocks 
there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bugden(pn)">Bugden,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Huntingtonshire, 
memorable for the Bishop of 
Lincoln's Seat; from our 
word <etym lang="en">Bog,</etym> and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, a Dale, that is a wa&shy;
try squashy Dale; or per&shy;
haps from the same <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bog</etym>, a bough, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a Valley shaded with the 
Boughs of Trees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bullingbrook(pn)">Bullingbrook,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb5v"> 
of Lincoln, noted for the Birth of Henry the Fourth; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Bull</etym> 's <etym lang="en">Brook;</etym> see 
Bull and Brook. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bullinger(pn)">Bullinger,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Boulenger,</etym> a Baker, 
which Menag. draws from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Polenta,</etym> fryed Bar&shy;
ley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bullnesse(pn)">Bullnesse,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumberland, from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bwlch,</etym> a Separa&shy;
tion, and the AS. Term. 
<etym lang="oe">Nese</etym>, a Promontory; for 
England is there parted from 
Scotland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burcester(pn)">Burcester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Oxfordshire, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bern</etym>, a Barn, 
and <etym lang="oe">ceaster</etym>, a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burchard(pn)">Burchard,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a name 
of Office and Dignity, Ver&shy;
steg. saith, that it was for&shy;
merly written <etym lang="oe">Burg-Gard,</etym> 
a Burgess of a Corporation: 
See Borough and Gard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burdred(pn)">Burdred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Mercia, 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Burh</etym>, 
a Town, and <etym lang="oe">Draed</etym>, dread, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Terrour of Towns.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burford(pn)">Burford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Oxfordshire; AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorford</etym>, from <etym lang="oe">Beor</etym>, 
Beer, and <etym lang="oe">Ford;</etym> see both 
Beer, and Ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burg(pn)">Burg,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of West&shy;
morland, whence it is com&shy;
monly call'd <etym lang="en">Stan-more 
Burg,</etym> that is, the Town 
under <etym lang="en">Stan-more;</etym> see <etym lang="en">Stone</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Moor.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Burg(pn)">The Burg,</form> <xpln lang="en">Belg. <etym lang="bl">de Burgh,</etym> 
an ancient Tower at Lyons in 
Holland, erected by Hengist, 
an English-Saxon, that first 
subdued Britain; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Burg</etym>, a Tower or strong 
Hold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burgh-castle(pn)">Burgh-Castle</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suffolk, AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cnobhers-burg</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Town of one <etym lang="oe">Cnobher,</etym> 
some petty King, that built 
it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burgoin(pn)">Burgoin,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">de Burgoigne,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one of Burgundy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burgundy(pn)" lexeme="Burgundions(pn)">Burgundy or Burgundions,</form> <xpln lang="en">
formerly a People of Germa&shy;
ny, now of France; from 
the old Germ. <etym lang="gr">Burg,</etym> AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorg Burg</etym>, a Fort or 
Castle, and that from <etym lang="oe">Beor&shy;
gan</etym>, to fortify.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Buriens(pn)">St. Buriens,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall, from 
<etym lang="en">Burien,</etym> an Irish Saint, to 
whom a Church was there 
consecrated.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burnell(pn)">Burnell,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G.
 <etym lang="fr">Bournal,</etym> an Hony-Comb; or 
 by the figure Metathesis from 
 the old word <etym lang="fr">Brunel,</etym> that 
 is somewhat Brown; see 
 Brown.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burrow(pn)">Burrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Leicester, formerly <etym lang="oe">Burgh,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Bulwark; see Bo&shy;
rough.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burrow Bank(pn)">Burrow Bank</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex; see <etym lang="en">Borough</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bank.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bursted(pn)">Bursted,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="en">Burghsted,</etym> 
in Essex, from <etym lang="en">Borough;</etym> 
which see: and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, a place, and this 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">status</etym> or <etym lang="la">statio,</etym> 
a station, or place of a&shy;
bode.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burton Lazers(pn)">Burton Lazers,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Leicester&shy;
shire, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Burton</etym> of <etym lang="en">Laza&shy;
rus</etym> 's, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an Hospital of Lepers. Burton is so call'd 
q. <etym lang="en">Bur Town,</etym> from the a&shy;
bundance of Burs there grow&shy;
ing; see <etym lang="en">Bur</etym> and <etym lang="en">Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Burton(pn)">Burton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Derbyshire, AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Baddecan</etym>, that is, hot 
Baths; see Bath amongst 
the Com. Names; I think, 
it cometh rather from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bocce Beocce</etym>, a Beech-&shy;
tree, and <etym lang="oe">Town;</etym> by reason 
of the plenty of Beech-trees 
growing thereabout.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Byron(pn)" lexeme="Buron(pn)">Byron, formerly Buron,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Buron,</etym> a Cottage, 
this from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Buer</etym> 
the same, and this again 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bur, Bure</etym>, 
a Parlour; all from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, to inhabit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bythell(pn)">Bythell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname frequent 
among the Welsh, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="cb">Ap 
Ythell,</etym> born of <etym lang="cb">Ythell,</etym> 
the Son of Ythell; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="C"><alpha>C</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caburn(pn)">CAburn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the other 
<etym lang="en">Caburn,</etym> a term in 
Sailing; which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cadbury(pn)">Cadbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somerset&shy;
shire, formerly by C. Br. 
call'd <etym lang="cb">Cathbregion,</etym> memora&shy;
ble for a great overthrow 
given the Saxons there by 
King Arthur.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cadwan(pn)">Cadwan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Bri&shy;
tains, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Cad&shy;
wen,</etym> a Fight; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a stout 
Warriour; or on the con&shy;
trary from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">C&acirc;d,</etym> 
a Fight, and <etym lang="cb">Gewahanu,</etym> to 
part, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that putteth 
an end to Wars.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cadwallader(pn)">Cadwallader,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of 
the last King of the Britons, 
according to Lloyd, and Da&shy;
vis; from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">C&acirc;d,</etym> a 
Battel, and <etym lang="cb">Gwaladr</etym> a Cap&shy;
tain of War.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cadwallon(pn)" lexeme="Cadwalla(pn)">Cadwallon, or Cadwalla, 
</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King but one of the 
Britons, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">C&acirc;d,</etym> 
a fight, and <etym lang="cb">Gwallow,</etym> to 
pour out, as being indeed a 
most stout Warriour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="C&aelig;ling(pn)">C&aelig;ling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Cornwall, not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cele</etym>, cool, <etym lang="oe">Celan</etym>, to be 
cool, <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;ling</etym>, a cooling; 
from the coldness of its 
water.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caer Custenith(pn)">Caer Custenith,</form> <xpln lang="en">in C&aelig;rn. 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the City of Constantius, 
<etym lang="oe">Caerderburge;</etym> see Bro&shy;
ken-bridge, above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caerdiff(pn)">Caerdiff,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Glam. C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caerdid,</etym> per&shy;
haps <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the City of <etym lang="la">Di&shy;
dius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caer Gai(pn)">Caer Gai,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Mer. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Castle of 
<etym lang="la">Gaius,</etym> a Roman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caer-guby(pn)">Caer-Guby,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Isle of An&shy;
glesey; from St. <etym lang="en">Kibius,</etym> Scho&shy;
lar of St. Hilary, a Bishop of 
the Picts, that here lived a 
Monk's life; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Tem&shy;
ple of St. Kibius, or Kibio&shy;
polis.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caer Laverock(pn)">Caer Laverock,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, 
not unlikely so called, because 
it was either Founded or Re&shy;
built by one <etym lang="en">Laverock.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caer Leon upon Usk(pn)">Caer Leon upon Vsk,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
County of Monm. in the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer Leon ar Uske,</etym> by 
Antoninus Isca, and the Second 
Legion, because C&aelig;sar's se&shy;
cond Legion, otherwise call'd 
the Welsh second Legion, 
were placed here; It was 
formerly an Arch-Bishop's 
See, but now a poor Vil&shy;
lage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caermarden(pn)">Caermarden,</form> <xpln lang="en">C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer Fird&shy;
hin,</etym> by Ptolem. Maridunum, 
by Anton. Muridunum; famous, 
as some say, for the Birth of 
Merlin the Conjurer; perhaps 
it was so called, because it 
was the Town of Marius, not 
of Merlin, as it is commonly 
taken to be; it being long 
before Merlin's time by the 
Romans called <term lang="la">Maridunum</term>, 
and by the Welsh Caermar&shy;
den.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caernarvon(pn)">Caernarvon,</form> <xpln lang="en">it is thus call'd, 
because it is over against the 
Isle of Man, from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Caer,</etym> a Town, <etym lang="cb">Ar,</etym> at, and 
<etym lang="cb">Von,</etym> or <etym lang="cb">Mon</etym>, the Isle of 
Man; a Town famous for the 
Birth of King Edward the 
Second.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caishow(pn)">Caishow,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Bucks. A certain Region or 
Tract so call'd from the <etym lang="la">Cassii,</etym> 
an ancient People of Britain, 
that formerly inhabited this 
place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caishowbury(pn)">Caishowbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hartfordshire, 
so call'd from the <etym lang="la">Cassii,</etym> and 
the Term. <etym lang="en">Bury,</etym> which sig&shy;
nifieth a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Camalet(pn)">Camalet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somers. an high 
Hill memorable for the Ru&shy;
ins of an old Castle of Roman 
Workmanship, perhaps the 
same with <etym lang="cb">Caer Calemion,</etym> 
or <etym lang="cb">Camelion</etym> in Ninius, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
Chamaelion's City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Camb Alan(pn)">Camb Alan,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Camel in 
Cornwall, a River so called 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Cam,</etym> crook&shy;
ed, full of windings; both 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Camurus</etym> in 
Virg. signifying a wriggling 
Current.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cambray(pn)">Cambray,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cam&shy;
bray,</etym> in the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kamme&shy;
rick,</etym> a famous Arch-Bishops 
See, for ought I know from 
<etym lang="la">Camera,</etym> some Court of Judi&shy;
cature formerly held there; 
or perhaps contracted from 
the old word <etym lang="oe">Samarobrina,</etym> 
</page>

<page sig="Bb7r"> 
that is to say, the Bridge 
or Ford of the River <etym lang="oe">Sa&shy;
mara.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cambridge(pn)">Cambridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City and fa&shy;
mous University; in the AS. 
<term lang="oe">Grant-ceaster, Grant-&shy;
brycge, Grante-bricge</term>, (i. e.) Grant Bridge; now 
Grant may be deriv'd from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gron</etym>, a Fenn; but 
this new word Cambridge 
seemeth more likely to come 
of the old Br. word <etym lang="br">Cam,</etym> 
(whence Anton. in Itin. men&shy;
tions a City call'd Cambori&shy;
tum) then the name of this 
River, and this from the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Camm,</etym> full of windings; 
this Davis draws from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Camurus,</etym> crooked.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cammon(pn)">Cammon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cam&shy;
mec, Cammuc</etym>, the Herb 
rest-harrow, or the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Camus,</etym> flat-nosed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Campden(pn)" lexeme="Camden(pn)">Campden or Camden,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
County of Glocester, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Camp,</etym> a Fight, or <etym lang="oe">Cempa,</etym> 
a Souldier, and <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, a Den 
or Valley; from this Town, 
our illustrious Antiquarian 
Camden had his name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Camulodunum(pn)">Camulodunum;</form> <xpln lang="en">see <etym lang="en">Mal&shy;
don.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caninefates(pn)">Caninefates,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient Peo&shy;
ple of the Rhine. Adr. Jun. 
thinks that they were call'd 
so, q. <etym lang="fi">C&aacute;nine fratres,</etym> which 
in the Language of Friezeland 
signifies Cony-catchers; for 
certain it is, that Country af&shy;
fords plenty of them.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cannington(pn)">Cannington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somersetshire, 
call'd Cannings, and Win&shy;
canton, as also Cangton and 
Caing-sham, from the <etym lang="la">Cangi,</etym> 
a small People of the Belgick-&shy;
Brit. that came, and dwelt 
here.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Canotwood(pn)">Canotwood,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Staffordshire, 
commonly call'd Cank&shy;
wood; perhaps, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">Wood</etym> of King <etym lang="en">Canute.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Canterbury(pn)">Canterbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Kent, a famous City, for&shy;
merly the Metropolis of the 
Kings of Kent, AS. <etym lang="oe">Cantwara 
Birig</etym>, formerly in the Lat. 
called <term lang="la">Durovernum, Darvern&shy;
um;</term> these from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> and <etym lang="cb">Whern,</etym> a fierce wa&shy;
ter or River. By Nenn. it was 
called <etym lang="cb">Caer Cent,</etym> that is, the 
City of <etym lang="en">Kent.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cantire(pn)">Cantire,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, or <etym lang="en">Can 
Tire,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Corner or head 
of Land.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cantlow(pn)">Cantlow,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="la">de Cante-lupo,</etym> 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chante-loup,</etym> an howling 
Wolf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cantred(pn)">Cantred,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Caern. a Tract 
wherein are comprised an 
hundred Villages, from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Cant,</etym> an hundred.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Capell(pn)">Capell</form> <xpln lang="en">Camden saith, that it is the 
same with <etym lang="en">Chappell:</etym> 
yet I had rather draw it from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chapeau,</etym> It. <etym lang="it">Capello,</etym> 
a Cap, or Hat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cardigan(pn)">Cardigan,</form> <xpln lang="en">by the C. Br. Aber 
Tivi, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the mouth of the 
River Tivi; not unlikely from 
<etym lang="cb">Caer</etym> and <etym lang="cb">Decan,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Dean's 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Careg(pn)">Careg,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. from the word 
<etym lang="en">Crag;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caresbrook(pn)">Caresbrook,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Castle in the 
Isle of Wight, remarkable for 
the Captivity of King Charles 
the First; by contraction, for 
<etym lang="oe">Whitgares burg,</etym> because it 
was built by one <etym lang="oe">Whitgar,</etym> a 
Saxon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carew(pn)">Carew,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire, perhaps 
from the old English word 
<etym lang="oe">Car</etym> a Scar, or rocky Hill; 
but I had rather derive it 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Charr&uuml;e,</etym> a 
Carve of Land.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carlile(pn)">Carlile,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Cum&shy;
berland, a Bishop's See, 
by the ancient Brit. and 
Rom. it was call'd <etym lang="la">Luguvallum</etym> 
or <etym lang="br">Lugu ballium,</etym> by the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Luell</etym>, as saith Beda, which 
is contracted from <etym lang="oe">Lugu&shy;
vall;</etym> from which Luell and 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer,</etym> a Town, the 
word Carlile manifestly 
cometh. By Nenn. it is call'd 
<etym lang="cb">Caer Lualid,</etym> from the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Lugu,</etym> a Tower, &amp; <etym lang="cb">Gwall</etym> 
or <etym lang="cb">Gwawl,</etym> a Mound or 
Trench, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Fort nigh a 
Trench: for there is a Ro&shy;
man Trench to be seen just 
by the City to this day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Carmouth(pn)">Carmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dors. q. d. the 
<etym lang="en">mouth</etym> of the River <etym lang="en">Car.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="caroloman(pn)">Caroloman,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Italy, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceorl</etym>, a Carle, 
and <etym lang="oe">Man.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Castellum Denis(pn)">Castellum Denis,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. 
the Danes Castle in their 
Dialect , so call'd, because 
the ravaging Danes pitch&shy;
ed their Tents there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caster(pn)">Caster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norf. by the Brit. 
call'd <etym lang="br">Caer Guentum,</etym> per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wenta&shy;
ceaster</etym>, and afterward by 
contraction <etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a 
Town, out of the Ruins 
whereof the City Norwich 
was rais'd. It was formerly 
call'd <term lang="la">Venta Icenorum</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Caster(pn)">Caster</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hunt. formerly <etym lang="oe">Kin&shy;
neburgceaster,</etym> from <etym lang="oe">Kinne&shy;
burg,</etym> the Daughter of Penda, 
an Heathen King of the Mer&shy;
cii, the Wife of Alfred King 
of Northumb. who here took 
upon her a Monastick life, 
and built a Nunnery for 
Women.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Castle Dinas(pn)" lexeme="Bren(pn)" lexeme="Bran(pn)">Castle Dinas, Bren, or Bran,</form> 
<xpln lang="en">in the County of Denb. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Bren</etym> 's Castle, or 
King's Palace, for <etym lang="cb">Bren</etym> sig&shy;
nifieth a King, and <etym lang="cb">Dinas</etym> 
in Welsh sgnifieth a City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Castleford(pn)">Castleford</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, by 
Marian. Casterford, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
<etym lang="en">Castle</etym> upon the <etym lang="en">Ford</etym>. By 
Anton. <term lang="la">Legeolium</term>, and <term lang="la">Leage&shy;
tium</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catalonia(pn)">Catalonia,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sp. <etym lang="sp">Catalunna,</etym> 
It. <etym lang="it">Catalogna,</etym> Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Cata&shy;
loigne,</etym> a part of Arragon, ei&shy;
ther from the <etym lang="la">Castellani,</etym> an 
ancient People formerly the 
Natives hereof, or from the 
<etym lang="la">Catalauni,</etym> ancient Inhabi&shy;
tants likewise of this Region; 
or as some suppose, from the 
<etym lang="la">Gothi</etym> and <etym lang="la">Alani,</etym> who mix&shy;
edly settled themselves here.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catarrick(pn)" lexeme="Catarrick-bridge(pn)">Catarrick and Catarrick-&shy;
bridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, by Ptol. 
and Anton. <etym lang="la">Catarractonium,</etym> 
</page>

<page sig="Bb8r"> 
in Bede <etym lang="oe">Catarracton,</etym> from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&tau;&alpha;&#x1FE4;&#x1FE5;&#x1F71;&kappa;&tau;&eta;&sigma;</etym>, or rather 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&tau;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F71;&kappa;&tau;&eta;&#x03c2;</etym>, the steep fall 
of a River, a Sluce, <etym lang="gk">&pi;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F70; &tau;&#x1F78; 
&kappa;&alpha;&tau;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F71;&sigma;&sigma;&epsilon;&iota;&nu;</etym>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cathnesse(pn)">Cathnesse,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Province in Scot&shy;
land, which the <etym lang="la">Catini</etym> for&shy;
merly inhabited, in some of 
Ptol. Copies erroneously cal&shy;
led Carini.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catti(pn)">Catti,</form> <xpln lang="en">now call'd Hassi, a Peo&shy;
ple of Germany. Adr. Jun. 
draws it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Cat&shy;
ten,</etym> signifying noble and 
famous Men; but seeing this 
word is scarcely to be found, 
I had rather deduce it from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Katz,</etym> a Cat, from 
the sharp and wary nature 
of this People, wherein they 
much resembled Cats.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catumerus(pn)">Catumerus,</form> <xpln lang="en">so call'd from the 
<etym lang="en">Catti,</etym> whereof he was Prince, 
and <etym lang="tt">Meyer,</etym> a Major, or Pr&aelig;&shy;
fect, says Tacitus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catwick(pn)">Catwick,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Holland, 
near the mouth of the Rhine, 
so call'd from the <etym lang="en">Catti,</etym> a 
People, that settled a Colony 
there; and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, 
a Port, or Fort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catzenellebogen(pn)">Catzenellebogen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City of 
the Catti, now call'd Hassi: 
In the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Catzen-elboge,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an Elbow of the 
Catti.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cauci(pn)">Cauci or Cauchi,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient 
People of Germany, between 
the Rivers Ems, and Weser, 
perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Kaawken,</etym> a red Crow; 
which this People perhaps 
bore for their Arms.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cand(pn)">Cand,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumberland, by the 
ancient Rom. call'd Gavata.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ceaulin(pn)" lexeme="Ceolin(pn)">Ceaulin, or rather Ceolin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
King of the West-Saxons; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceola</etym>, a Cot&shy;
tage, and <etym lang="oe">Inne</etym>, an Inn, from 
the Verb <etym lang="oe">Innan</etym>, to lodge at 
a place; or from <etym lang="oe">Ceol</etym>, 
a Ship, and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a winner, 
or Victour. <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to 
win, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Conquerour by 
Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Celric(pn)">Celric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the West-&shy;
Saxons, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceol</etym>, 
a Ship, and <etym lang="oe">ric</etym>, rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Powerful by Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ceolulph(pn)">Ceolulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Northum&shy;
berland; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceol</etym>, 
a Ship, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cerdic(pn)">Cerdic,</form> <xpln lang="en">the first King of the 
Vice-Saxons; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cerre</etym>, bent or crooked, 
and <etym lang="oe">Dic, Dice,</etym> a Ditch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Chad(pn)">St. Chad,</form> <xpln lang="en">Bishop of Litchfield, 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceod</etym>, 
a Purse, or Scrip.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chamavi(pn)" lexeme="Chanani(pn)">Chamavi, or as some write it, 
Chanani,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People of the 
Lower Germ. now call'd 
<term lang="la">Frisii Sevenwoudi</term>; or as o&shy;
thers will have it, <term lang="la">Campani</term>; 
not unlikely from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Kampen,</etym> to sight, and the 
obsolete word <etym lang="bl">Au,</etym> which, as 
Adr. Jun. saith, signifies Land; 
that is to say, a People that 
fight for their Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Champernoun(pn)">Champernoun,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dev. Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">de Champ Arnou,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of 
Arnulph's Field.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Bb8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Champfleur(pn)">Champfleur,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Champ,</etym> a Field, and <etym lang="fr">Fleur,</etym> a 
Flower.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Champion(pn)">Champion,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly, as Camd. 
saith, <etym lang="fr">de Champaigne,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
of <etym lang="fr">Campania,</etym> a Province of 
France.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Champneis(pn)">Champneis,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Champanois,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) born in 
Campania.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chardford(pn)">Chardford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="en">Cerdeford,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Cer&shy;
dicsfourd</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Ford 
of King Cerdic, over the Ri&shy;
ver Avon, where he discom&shy;
fited the Britains.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Charing(pn)" lexeme="Cerring-Cross(pn)">Charing, formerly <etym lang="en">Cerring-&shy;
Cross.</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">Somnerus ingeniously 
draws it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyr&shy;
ran, Acyrran</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kee&shy;
ren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kehren,</etym> to turn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Charoloman(pn)">Charoloman,</form> <xpln lang="en">Brother to Char&shy;
lemain, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Care</etym>, 
stout, or <etym lang="oe">Ceorl</etym> a Carle, or 
Country Clown, and <etym lang="en">Man.</etym> 
Adr. Jun. draws it from <etym lang="la">Cha&shy;
ritas,</etym> Charity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chaucer(pn)">Chaucer,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Homer or Parent 
of all English Poetry; possi&shy;
bly from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chausseur,</etym> 
formerly <etym lang="fr">Chauceur,</etym> Part. of 
the Verb <etym lang="fr">Chausser,</etym> formerly 
<etym lang="fr">Chaucer,</etym> to put on ones shoes, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Shoe-maker. So 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chaumound(pn)">Chaumound,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chauve,</etym> bald, and 
<etym lang="fr">Mont,</etym> a Mount.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chaworth(pn)">Chaworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Nottingham, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="fr">de Cahors.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cheardesly(pn)">Cheardesly,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Buckinghamshire, 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cerdicslega</etym>, from 
the Fight between Cerdic the 
Saxon, and the Britains in 
that place; for <etym lang="oe">Slege</etym> in 
the AS. signifieth a Slaugh&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cheausey(pn)">Cheausey,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly an Abby, 
but demolished by the Danes; 
perhaps so call'd from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ceosl</etym>, Gravel, and <etym lang="oe">Ige</etym>, 
an Isle, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an Isle full 
of Gravel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chegford(pn)">Chegford,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Devon. 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">C&aelig;g, C&aelig;ge</etym>, 
a Key, and <etym lang="oe">Ford;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chelred(pn)">Chelred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Mercii; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceol</etym>, a Ship, 
and <etym lang="oe">rede</etym>, counsel, <etym lang="oe">redan</etym>, 
to give counsel; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that is Skilful in Navigation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chelsey(pn)">Chelsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middlesex, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Shelfsey,</etym> from <etym lang="en">Shelves</etym> of 
<etym lang="en">Sand;</etym> it is also call'd in old 
writing, <etym lang="en">Chelche-Hyth;</etym> not 
unlikely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cealc</etym> 
Chalk, and <etym lang="oe">Hy&eth;</etym>, a Port, 
for the term. ey, AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
signifieth Water, and also 
Land lying next the Wa&shy;
ter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cheney(pn)">Cheney,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, formerly 
<etym lang="fr">de Chesnoye,</etym> from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Chesnoye,</etym> a place where Oaks 
grow, this from <etym lang="fr">Chesne</etym> an 
Oak; which Mendg. again 
draws from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Quernus</etym>; 
Skin. from <etym lang="la">Quercinus</etym> Oaken, 
made of Oak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chensford(pn)">Chensford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
</page> 

<page sig="Cc1r">
<etym lang="en">Chelmsford</etym>, so call'd from the 
River <etym lang="en">Chelmer.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cheorl(pn)" lexeme="Ceorl(pn)">Cheorl or Ceorl,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Mercii, the same with 
Charles now.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chepstow(pn)">Chepstow,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Monmouthshire, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Market, or place 
for Chapmen; See <etym lang="en">Cheap</etym> 
<etym lang="en">Chapman,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Stow.</etym> It 
is by the Brit. call'd Castle&shy;
went, because it was rais'd 
out of the Ruins of old Went, 
therefore call'd by the Brit. 
Caerwent; Went is either 
derived of the C. Br. Gwe&shy;
nith, Wheat, for the great 
Crops of Wheat it did af&shy;
ford; or of Guynn, white, 
for the white colour of the 
Soil in that place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cherebert(pn)">Cherebert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of France; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="oe">Cyning</etym>, or King <etym lang="fr">He&shy;
rebert;</etym> see Herbert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chertsey(pn)">Chertsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="oe">Certs Ea</etym>, Cert's Isle, a Village 
heretofore famous for an Ab&shy;
by there erected.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cherusci(pn)">Cherusci,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People of Hercy&shy;
nium in Germany, where the 
Bishopricks of Munster and 
Paderborn now are; perhaps 
from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Kehren,</etym> to 
sweep, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Oost,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ost;</etym> the East, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
People that spoiled the East-&shy;
Country, committing sundry 
Robberies therein; Or, from 
the same <etym lang="bl">Oost,</etym> and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Keeren,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kehren,</etym> to 
turn, because they often put 
to flight the Inhabitants of 
those Eastern Countries. Adr. 
Jun. draws it from the Belg.
<etym lang="bl">Keer-Vsz,</etym> to turn out of 
doors, or beat back; because 
under Arminius, they drove 
the Romans out of their Ter&shy;
ritories.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chesill(pn)">Chesill,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dorsetshire, a bank 
of Gravel; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ceosl</etym>, Sand or Gravel. 
Somner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chester(pn)">Chester,</form> <xpln lang="en">by the Brit. call'd 
<term lang="br">Caer-Legion, Caer-Leon-&shy;
Vaur</term>; It was also by the &shy;
AS. call'd <etym lang="oe">Legeaceaster</etym>, 
because the twentieth Le&shy;
gion, quartered here; and 
<etym lang="oe">West-ceaster</etym>, West-&shy;
Chester, for its Situation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chester upon the Street(pn)">Chester upon the Street,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
Bishoprick of Durham, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Castle or Town upon the 
High way; by the Saxons call'd 
Conceaster.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chesthunt(pn)">Chesthunt,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hartfordshire, so 
called from the abundance of 
<etym lang="en">Chestnuts</etym> there; see Fuller in 
his History of Waltham Ab&shy;
bey.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chevercourt(pn)">Chevercourt,</form> <xpln lang="en">some exp. it, 
one head of the Court, but 
they are mistaken; for then 
it should be written Cheve&shy;
court, or Chefcourt; so that 
I think it not amiss, to draw 
it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Chevre,</etym> a 
shee Goat, and <etym lang="fr">Cour,</etym> a 
Court.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chichester(pn)">Chichester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, a Bishop's 
See: By the Sax. call'd 
<etym lang="oe">Cissanceaster</etym>, by the
