Brit. <etym lang="br">Caercei,</etym> from <etym lang="oe">Cissa</etym> 
King of the South Sax. who 
built it.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chidley(pn)">Chidley,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cid</etym>, a wrangling, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ley</etym>, a Dock, or <etym lang="oe">Leag, 
Lege,</etym> a Field, or Pasture, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Ground, about which 
Controversies arise, the right 
of Possession thereof being 
disputable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Childebert(pn)">Childebert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of France, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Cyning</etym> or King <etym lang="fr">Hil&shy;
debert</etym>, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> 
a Nobleman, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, illustrious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Childerick(pn)">Childerick,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of France, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Cyning,</etym> or King <etym lang="fr">Hil&shy;
deric,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">Hulderic,</etym> from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hulde,</etym> a Vote, and 
<etym lang="bl">Ric,</etym> rich (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that 
hath not a man against him, 
one that every body stands 
up for.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chilham(pn)">Chilham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, formerly 
<etym lang="oe">Iulham,</etym> from <etym lang="la">Julius C&aelig;sar,</etym> 
that encamped there, in his 
second Expedition; see <etym lang="oe">Ham.</etym> 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chilperic(pn)">Chilperic,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of France, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Cyning,</etym> or King <etym lang="fr">Hil&shy;
peric;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chiltern(pn)">Chiltern,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Buck. the upper 
part whereof was by the Sax. 
call'd <etym lang="oe">Cyltern</etym>, by reason 
of the chill Air thereupon, or 
from <etym lang="oe">Cylt</etym>, clay, as saith 
Camden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chintilla(pn)">Chintilla,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Vice-&shy;
Gothi of Spain, about the year 
636. Not unlikely, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kanne Kante,</etym> a Cann 
or Cup, and <etym lang="tt">Theilen,</etym> to 
divide, to give each man his 
share; that is to say, a Cup-&shy;
bearer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chippenham(pn)">Chippenham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Wilts, AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyppanham</etym>, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyppan</etym>, to 
cheapen, and <etym lang="oe">Cypman</etym>, 
a Chapman, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Market 
or Market-place. See Chap&shy;
man and Cheapen.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chonodomarius(pn)">Chonodomarius,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Amm. Mar&shy;
cell. a King of the Alemanni. 
Kilian and Jun. interpret it 
a furious Rider, or Horseman 
in the time of need; perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuhn</etym> bold, 
and Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ademen,</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Athemen,</etym> to breathe, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that panteth, like 
as doth an indefatigable 
Soldier or Warriour. Jun. 
seemeth to draw it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Noth Nothen,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Noode,</etym> Need, and <etym lang="bl">Meyer,</etym> 
a Major.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chund(pn)" lexeme="Hund(pn)">Chund, or Hund,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuhn;</etym> valiant, mag&shy;
nanimous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cicester(pn)">Cicester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glocestershire, though 
'tis writ Cirencester; by 
the Sax. 'twas call'd <etym lang="oe">Cyren&shy;
ceaster</etym>, by the Brit. <etym lang="oe">Caer, 
Cari,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Ceri,</etym> from the River <etym lang="oe">Churn,</etym> in Lat. <etym lang="la">Ceri&shy;
nus?</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cicester(pn)">Cicester,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People of Chersone&shy;
sus, formerly the terrour of 
the Romans; perhaps from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Kommer, Kom&shy;
ber,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rummer,</etym> da&shy;
mage, loss, by reason of the 
great damages this warlike 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc2r">
People did the neighbour&shy;
ing Countries round about. 
It is thought by some, that 
the ancient Brit. descended 
from these Cimbri, and as an 
Argument say, that they call 
Wales their <etym lang="br">Cumro</etym>, and 
themselves <etym lang="br">Cumr&aelig;ci</etym>, or <etym lang="br">Cum&shy;
rages</etym>?</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cimenshore(pn)">Cimenshore,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, so call'd 
from <etym lang="oe">Cimen,</etym> a Saxon; who 
with his Brother Ella, the 
first King of the South-&shy;
Saxons, arrived first at this 
place; Cimen may be ta&shy;
ken from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cuma</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Cyma</etym>, a Guest, deriva&shy;
tives of the Verbs <etym lang="oe">Cuman</etym>, 
and <etym lang="oe">Cyman</etym>, to come un&shy;
to.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cindeswindus(pn)">Cindeswindus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Vice-Gothi of Spain, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kind des Wind,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Son of the Wind, so 
call'd, for the sharpness and 
readiness of his wit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cisbury(pn)">Cisbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, near an 
ancient Military Fort, built 
by King <etym lang="oe">Cissa;</etym> see <etym lang="oe">Borough.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cissa(pn)">Cissa,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the South-Sax&shy;
ons, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cissan</etym>, 
to kiss.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clan-ricard(pn)">Clan-Ricard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname in 
Ireland, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of the Family 
of <etym lang="en">Richard.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clare(pn)" lexeme="Clarence(pn)">Clare, otherwise Clarence,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
Village in Suffolk, a title 
given to Dukes of the Blood 
Royal, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Clarus,</etym> 
famous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clepho(pn)" lexeme="Clapho(pn)">Clepho or Clapho,</form> <xpln lang="en">the second 
King of the Longobardi of 
Italy; not unlikely from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cleofan</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Clie&shy;
ven,</etym> to cleave, because possi&shy;
bly he us'd to cleave his E&shy;
nemies in two with his 
Sword.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cleveland(pn)">Cleveland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, a Tract 
of Land; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Cliffland;</etym> 
for it is very steep, and al&shy;
most unpassable with Clifts, 
and Rocks; see Clift:</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cleybrook(pn)">Cleybrook,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Leicestershire, 
the remains of the old Town 
<etym lang="en">Cleycester;</etym> see <etym lang="en">Clay</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Brook.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cliff(pn)">Cliff,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex; see <etym lang="en">Clift.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clodobert(pn)">Clodobert, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="oe">Cyning,</etym> or 
King <etym lang="oe">Lodobert,</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Leode</etym>, 
People, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous, 
also light, that is, the light 
of the People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clodomir(pn)">Clodomir,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="oe">Cyning,</etym> 
or King <etym lang="oe">Lodomir,</etym> from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leode</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> 
People, and <etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to 
make more, to increase, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that extended the Limits 
of his Dominions.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clotair(pn)" lexeme="Clothair(pn)">Clotair or Clothair,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King 
of France; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Cyning,</etym> or 
King <etym lang="fr">Lothair;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clothilde(pn)">Clothilde,</form> <xpln lang="en">by Kilian <etym lang="oe">Luithild,</etym> 
a Womans name, sig. a Prin&shy;
cess of the People; from the 
old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Luit</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leode</etym>, People, and 
<etym lang="oe">Helde,</etym> a Lady, by adding C. 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyningin</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ko&shy;
niginne,</etym> a Queen; see Lo&shy;
thild.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cloves-ho(pn)">Cloves-ho,</form> <xpln lang="en">now Cliff, AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cleofesho</etym>, memorable for 
a Council of English-Saxons 
held there; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cleofa, Cliof, Clif</etym>, 
a Clift, and <etym lang="oe">Ho</etym>, the heel; 
perhaps so call'd, because it 
is seated at the bottom of an 
Hill, or Rock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clun(pn)">Clun,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in the Coun&shy;
ty of Salop, by the Brit. 
<etym lang="br">Colun,</etym> and <etym lang="br">Colunwy:</etym> it 
would be too bold a deriva&shy;
tion if I shou'd draw it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Colonus</etym>, a farmer; 
because, like the River Nile, 
it makes the Fields fruit&shy;
ful, and so advantageous to 
Farmers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cluy(pn)">Cluy,</form> <xpln lang="en">by the Brit. and AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Clud,</etym> a clift, from thence 
<etym lang="oe">Alcluid</etym>, a Town so call'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cob(pn)">Cob,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Camden, it signifieth 
a Port made with hands; 
it might also be drawn from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>, a top, or 
tuft, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kopff,</etym> an Head; 
or as the eminent Dr. Th. H. 
telleth us, it is an abbrevia&shy;
tion of <etym lang="en">Iacob.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cockington(pn)">Cockington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire, a 
Village, likely so call'd, for 
some great <etym lang="en">Cock-fighting</etym> kept 
there; see <etym lang="en">Cock</etym> and <etym lang="en">Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cockly-chapell(pn)">Cockly-Chapell,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lancashire, 
by Anton. <etym lang="la">Coccium,</etym> by adding 
the AS. Term. <etym lang="oe">Ley</etym>, an 
Haven for Ships; see Lay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Codenor(pn)">Codenor,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Coutenoure</etym> 
Castle, in Derb. perhaps from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Contenir,</etym> to keep 
in, to curb, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the stay of 
the People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Coker(pn)">Coker,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cocer</etym>, 
a Quiver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Colchester(pn)">Colchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, the prin&shy;
cipal Town; by the Sax. 
<etym lang="oe">Coleceaster</etym>, Brit. <etym lang="cb">Caer-&shy;
Colin,</etym> from the River <etym lang="oe">Coln.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cole(pn)">Cole,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middl. a River, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="cb">Coh,</etym> which in the 
Welsh sig. red; see Hert&shy;
ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cole(pn)">Cole,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
name, but now a Sirname, 
contracted from <etym lang="en">Nicol,</etym> and 
this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&iota;&kappa;&omicron;&lambda;&alpha;&#x1F7B;&#x03c2;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Colebrook(pn)">Colebrook,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Buckinghamshire, 
by Anton. the Bridges, because 
the River <etym lang="en">Cole</etym> is here parted 
into four Currents, but it 
joined together by four 
Bridges.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Coleham(pn)">Coleham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middl. from the 
River <etym lang="en">Cole</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ham;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Collet(pn)">Collet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, being a Di&shy;
minutive of the Christen-&shy;
name <etym lang="en">Nicol</etym> for <etym lang="en">Nicolas.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Collins(pn)">Collins,</form> <xpln lang="en">according to Camden, 
corrupted from <etym lang="en">Nicolin,</etym> the 
Dimin. of <etym lang="en">Nicolas;</etym> but it is 
now become a Sirname.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Colman(pn)">St. Colman,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Scotch Bishop of 
Lindisf. in the year 653. 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Columbanus;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Colson(pn)">Colson;</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Nicolson,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the Son of Nicolas.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Columbs(pn)">St. Columbs,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Temple of St. <etym lang="en">Columb</etym>, 
a Scotchman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Comb(pn)">Comb,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dev. a Termination 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc3r">
for many words, as New&shy;
comb, &amp;c. from the AS.<etym lang="oe">Comb, 
Comp</etym>, C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Kum,</etym> Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Combe,</etym> a Dale encompassed 
on each side with Hills. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Compton in the Hole(pn)">Compton in the Hole,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. 
so call'd from the low situa&shy;
tion thereof; for <etym lang="oe">Compton,</etym> 
or <etym lang="oe">Combtown,</etym> in AS. sig&shy;
nifies a Village in a Valley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Congell(pn)">Congell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a devout Irish-man, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a good Pledge; see 
Congersbury.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Congersbury(pn)">Congersbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Somerset, from <etym lang="en">Conger,</etym> a 
Pious man that lived there as 
an Hermit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Connaught(pn)">Connaught,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Province in Ire&shy;
land, by the Natives call'd 
Conaughty, formerly the 
Seat of the ancient <etym lang="la">Concani</etym> &amp; 
<etym lang="la">Nagnati,</etym> from whom the name 
of the Province seemeth to 
be derived.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Connisborough(pn)" lexeme="Coninesborough(pn)">Connisborough or Conines&shy;
borough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, by the 
Brit. <etym lang="br">Caer Conan,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Town of <etym lang="oe">Conan,</etym> a King, 
that erected it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Connisby(pn)" lexeme="Consby(pn)">Connisby or Consby,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. 
I suppose so called from <etym lang="en">Co&shy;
nys</etym>, by adding thereto the 
AS. Termination <etym lang="oe">by</etym>, which 
signifieth an Habitation, se&shy;
condarily a Village; this 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, to abide, 
or dwell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Conrade(pn)">Conrade,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Con, Coon</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuhn,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koen,</etym> 
valiant, able; and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Raed, Rad, Rede</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Raht,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raed,</etym> coun&shy;
sel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Conway(pn)">Conway,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Caern. formerly <etym lang="la">Conovius;</etym> 
from whence the Town of 
this Name, out of the Ruins 
whereof was rais'd a little 
Town call'd Aber-Conway, 
(i. e.) the mouth of Con&shy;
way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cope(pn)">Cope,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Coppe</etym>, a Top, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<emend err="the"></emend>top of an Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Copenhagen(pn)" lexeme="Copenhaven(pn)">Copenhagen, or Copenhaven,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Lat. Barb. <term lang="da">Haffnia</term>, 
by the Dan. <etym lang="da">Koppenhaffn;</etym> 
from the Dan. <etym lang="da">Koppen,</etym> Mer&shy;
chants, and <etym lang="da">Haffn</etym> an Ha&shy;
ven, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Merchants 
Haven.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Copland(pn)">Copland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumberland, a 
Tract of Land; from the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Kopa,</etym> sharp top'd Moun&shy;
tains, for which it is con&shy;
spicuous: or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cop</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kopff</etym> an head, 
and <etym lang="en">Land;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Corbet(pn)">Corbet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; it was for&shy;
merly, according to Camden, 
a Christen-name, being, a 
dim. of the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Corbeau,</etym> 
a Crow, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a little 
Crow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Coriton(pn)">Coriton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Devon&shy;
shire, perhaps from the great 
income they have by <etym lang="en">Cori&shy;
ander,</etym> which in the AS. &amp; Gr. 
is call'd <etym lang="gk">Corion</etym>, &amp; <etym lang="en">Town;</etym> 
which see. Or from one <etym lang="en">Corius</etym> 
that founded it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cornwal(pn)">Cornwal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County, in the Sax. 
called Cornwealh, from the 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc3v">
Lat. <etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> an Horn; because 
in this part England is ex&shy;
tended in the form of an 
Horn; and <etym lang="oe">Wealh,</etym> which 
name the Saxons gave to all 
Strangers, and especially to 
the Britans; see Wales. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cornwallis(pn)">Cornwallis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
come of <etym lang="en">Cornwall;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Corobridge(pn)">Corobridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland, 
by Hoveden called Coro&shy;
brige, by Henr. Hunt. <etym lang="en">Cure;</etym> 
from its old Original, by 
adding the termination 
<etym lang="en">bridge.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cotswold(pn)">Cotswold,</form> <xpln lang="en">a place in Gloc. so 
called from the abundance of 
Sheep-Cotes there; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cote</etym>, a Sheep-Cote, 
and <etym lang="oe">Wold</etym>, a place, that 
hath not so much as a tree 
in it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cove(pn)">Cove,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cofe, Cofa,</etym> a Cave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Coventry(pn)">Coventry,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. a famous 
City and Bishop's See, either 
from a <etym lang="en">Convent</etym> or Monastery; 
or from <etym lang="en">Coven,</etym> a small Ri&sh+y;
ver.</xpln></wordentry> 


<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Covert(pn)">Covert,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Couverte,</etym> a Shelter; see 
to Cover.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Coway stakes(pn)">Coway Stakes,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surr. a 
place so call'd from the 
<etym lang="en">Stakes,</etym> which the Britains 
set up upon the adverse 
Shore, against C&aelig;sar, where 
he passed over the Thames 
in the Ford; but Coway 
evidently cometh of <etym lang="en">Cow</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Way,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a passage for 
Cows.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cowbridge(pn)">Cowbridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glam. so call'd 
for the frequent passing of 
Cows that way, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">Cows Bridge</etym>; by the Brit. 
<term lang="br">Pont Van</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cranburn(pn)">Cranburn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dors. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
River or <etym lang="en">Bourn</etym> of <etym lang="en">Cranes</etym>; 
see Crane and Bourn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Craven(pn)">Craven,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
York, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Craeg,</etym> 
a Rock, or Stone, and <etym lang="cb">Pen</etym> 
an Head; for it is a stony 
place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cray(pn)">Cray,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River, perhaps from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Craye</etym> Chalk, from 
the Chalky Channel it run&shy;
neth through.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Creccelade(pn)">Creccelade,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little Town in 
Wilts; by Marianus Creccan&shy;
ford, by some <etym lang="en">Grekelade,</etym> 
from a School, which the 
Greek Philosophers institu&shy;
ted there, which was after&shy;
ward removed to Oxford. 
Somnerus supposeth this to 
be a meer Fable; and, as I 
think, not without cause; 
For, he supposeth, that the 
Town was formerly call'd 
<etym lang="en">Crecca-gelade,</etym> from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Crecca</etym>, a Brook, and <etym lang="oe">La&shy;
dian</etym>, to empty, for there&shy;
about some Brooks disem&shy;
bogue themselves into the 
Thames.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Crediton(pn)" lexeme="Kirton(pn)">Crediton, or Kirton</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. 
either from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cr&aelig;t&shy;
tun</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Cart Town; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Crede</etym>, the 
Apostles Creed, because perhaps 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc4r"> 
in this Town the first 
Bishop's See was founded a&shy;
mong the Saxons, and from 
thence the Christian and A&shy;
postolick Faith was propaga&shy;
ted through the whole King&shy;
dom of the South-Saxons; or, 
which is yet more probable, 
q. <etym lang="oe">Credian-tun,</etym> from the 
River <etym lang="oe">Creden</etym> that runs close 
by it. It is a Town over and 
above the honour of a Bi&shy;
shop's See, famous for the 
Birth of St. Boniface, or Wi&shy;
nifred the Apostle of Ger&shy;
many. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Crebequer(pn)">Crebequer,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Crevecoeur,</etym> It. <etym lang="it">Crepa 
Cuore;</etym> from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cor,</etym> the 
Heart, and the Verb <etym lang="la">Crepare</etym> 
to burst.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Creyford(pn)">Creyford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, AS. <etym lang="oe">Crec&shy;
canford</etym>, from the River 
<etym lang="oe">Crey</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Ford.</etym> This Crey 
gave Names to the little Vil&shy;
lages St. Mary-Crey, Paul's-&shy;
Crey, Votes-Crey, North-&shy;
Crey; it is a place memo&shy;
rable for an overthrow given 
the Britains, by Hengist a 
Saxon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cripplegate(pn)">Cripplegate,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gate of the 
City of London; from an Ho&shy;
spital of <etym lang="en">Cripples</etym>, which was 
once erected there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Crockhern(pn)">Crockhern,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Som. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cruccerne</etym>, and that from 
a Fountain in the same Lan&shy;
guage, <etym lang="oe">Cruce</etym>, a Cross, al&shy;
so a <etym lang="oe">Cruse</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Herne</etym>, 
a Cottage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Croft(pn)">Croft,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Croft</etym>, a little Close.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Croon(pn)">Croon,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Croen,</etym> 
a Skin; this Fr. Jun. and Da&shy;
vis derive from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&rho;&#x1FF6;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
the Skin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Crowland(pn)">Crowland,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly Croy&shy;
land, in Linc. famous for an 
Abbey, and Fowling; per&shy;
haps so called from the mul&shy;
titude of <etym lang="en">Crows</etym>; see Crow. 
Fuller supposeth it so call'd, 
<etym lang="la">quasi terra cruda</etym>, raw Land.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Crowch(pn)" lexeme="Croychback(pn)">Crowch, or rather Croych&shy;
back;</form> <xpln lang="en">so was Edmund, Bro&shy;
ther to K. Edward the First, 
call'd, not, as one would 
presently imagine, from his 
hunch-back; but from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Croise,</etym> signed with a 
Cross; because when he was 
bound for the Holy Land, he 
wore a Cross on his Back for 
a Badge of his sacred War&shy;
fare.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Crutchet Friars(pn)">Crutchet Friars,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Freres 
Croisez,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Friars signed 
with the Bross, and had a fa&shy;
mous Convent in London, the 
<emend err="the"></emend>name whereof the place 
retaineth to this day.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cumberland(pn)">Cumberland,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Coun&shy;
try of the <etym lang="la">Cumbri,</etym> Britains, 
who remain'd here a long 
time after all England was 
Conquered.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cunebert(pn)">Cunebert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Ita&shy;
lian Longobardi; either from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuhn,</etym> adventu&shy;
rous; and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
brave; or as Kilian has't, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="bl">Kuniwerd,</etym> from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Kuin,</etym> stout, &amp; <etym lang="bl">Werd,</etym> famous.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cunegild(pn)" lexeme="Conegild(pn)">Cunegild, or Conegild,</form> <xpln lang="en">a <emend err="a"></emend> Womans name, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Konig,</etym> a King, and the 
old word <etym lang="oe">Hild,</etym> for Hold, a 
Friend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cunigund(pn)">Cunigund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyning</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Koning,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koningh,</etym> a 
King, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gunnen,</etym> 
to favour, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) she that is in 
favour with the King.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cunimund(pn)">Cunimund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Ge&shy;
pidae, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuhn,</etym> 
valiant, and <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a Mouth, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an high spoken man; or 
from the same <etym lang="tt">Kuhn,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mundan</etym>, to protect, 
or pacify, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an able Pro&shy;
tectour, or Peace-maker.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Cuthberd(pn)">St. Cuthberd,</form> <xpln lang="en">Arch-Bishop of 
Canterbury; not, as some think, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Cut-Beard,</etym> but from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cu&eth;</etym>, known, and 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous. Or ac&shy;
cording to Versteg. from the 
said <etym lang="oe">Cu&eth;</etym>, and the old Engl. 
<etym lang="oe">Beright,</etym> of a settled mind; 
but the former is most 
likely.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cuthred(pn)">Cuthred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cu&eth;</etym>, known, and 
<etym lang="oe">Rade, Rede,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Raht,</etym> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raed,</etym> Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cuthwin(pn)">Cuthwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cu&eth;</etym>, known, 
and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Conquerour, 
<etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to win, (i. e.) 
one that behaves himself, so 
as to win the love of all men. 
See Win.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cuts(pn)">Cuts,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. the Dim. 
of <etym lang="en">Cuthbert,</etym> which see a&shy;
<emend err="a"></emend>bove.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cynehelm(pn)">Cynehelm</form> <xpln lang="en">, Verstegan supposeth 
it to be contracted from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyning</etym>, a King, and 
<etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, an Helmet. It might 
also be derived of <etym lang="oe">Cene</etym>, 
strenuous, and <etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, an 
Helmet, secondarily a Pro&shy;
tectour.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="D"><alpha>D</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dabscot(pn)">DAbscot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a National 
name, as Cambden 
saith, first <etym lang="fr">D'Am&shy;
precourt,</etym> and from 
thence <etym lang="en">Dabridge-court,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
of a Town in France former&shy;
ly call'd <etym lang="fr">Amprecour.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dacres(pn)">Dacres,</form> <xpln lang="en">a National name, Fuller 
supposeth that it is taken 
from <etym lang="ar">Acra</etym> a City of Syria, 
at the besieging and assault&shy;
ing whereof, one of this 
Country fought most courageously, 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc5r">
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">D'Acres:</etym> 
or from <etym lang="en">Dacor</etym> a little River, 
after the name of which, a 
Castle in Cumb. was call'd. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dagalaiphus(pn)">Dagalaiphus,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the time of 
the Emperor Valentinian the 
First; he was elected Consul 
with Gratianus the Empe&shy;
ror's Son, Anno U. C. 1118. 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dag&shy;
en</etym> Daggers or Swords, and <etym lang="tt">Lieven,</etym> 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lufian</etym>, to love, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that delighted in his 
Sword, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) to be ingaged 
in War or Duels.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dagobert(pn)">Dagobert,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Franco-&shy;
Galli, either from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dagen,</etym> a Sword, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an 
incomparable Swords-man; 
or from the same <etym lang="tt">Dagen,</etym> and 
<etym lang="tt">Berichten,</etym> to instruct, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a notable Sword-Player; 
Jun. draws it from the same 
<etym lang="tt">Dagen</etym> a Sword, and <etym lang="tt">Bart</etym> 
a Beard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dairell(pn)">Dairell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname in Corn. 
and Buck. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of <etym lang="en">Hairell,</etym> 
and <etym lang="fr">Hairel</etym> in the Fr. G. sig&shy;
nifieth an Hair-Cloth, perhaps 
from our word <etym lang="en">Hair,</etym> or, 
which is more plausible, 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Airelles,</etym> 
Black-berries.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dallison(pn)">Dallison,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) 
<etym lang="fr">D' Alencon,</etym> of Alencon, a 
City in France.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Damport(pn)">Damport,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cheshire, other&shy;
wise call'd <etym lang="en">Davenport,</etym> from 
the River <etym lang="en">Dan</etym> or <etym lang="en">Daven,</etym> 
and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Porta,</etym> a Port.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dantzick(pn)">Dantzick,</form> <xpln lang="en">the greatest Mart-&shy;
Town in Borussia, which, as 
Adr. Jun. says, in the Henetian 
Dialect signifieth, a Fort made 
to keep off the Danes; it 
may perhaps be drawn from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Danne,</etym> a Fir-tree, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, a Fort, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="oe">Danneswic,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Dan&shy;
nenwic,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a strong hold 
among Fir-trees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Danubius(pn)">Danubius,</form> <xpln lang="en">the most famous 
River in all Europe, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Donner,</etym> Thunder, 
<etym lang="tt">Donnern,</etym> to Thunder, be&shy;
cause by its violent running, 
and the dashing of Stones a&shy;
gainst its hollow Banks, it 
maketh a noise like that of 
Thunder: or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dannen,</etym> Fir-trees, which 
are planted all along its 
Banks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Darby(pn)">Darby,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous County-&shy;
Town, by the Saxons <etym lang="oe">Deor&shy;
by</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Derwenthy,</etym> from 
the River <etym lang="en">Derwent.</etym> In the 
AS. it is termed <etym lang="oe">Nor&eth;&shy;
wor&eth;ig</etym>, from <etym lang="oe">Weor&eth;ig</etym>, 
a Farm, and <etym lang="oe">Nor&eth;</etym>, Nor&shy;
thern.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dartford(pn)">Dartford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, so call'd, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Ford of the River 
<etym lang="oe">Darta,</etym> formerly <etym lang="oe">Darenta.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Darwent(pn)">Darwent,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River. Leland 
draws it from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> water, and <etym lang="cb">Gwen</etym> or 
<etym lang="cb">Gwin,</etym> clear, neither of which 
are found in this sence, yet 
<etym lang="cb">Gwynn</etym> is found to signifie 
white.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="D'aubeny(pn)">D'aubeny,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. perhaps 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc5v"> 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Aubain,</etym> 
an Alien; or rather from a 
Town called by the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Aubigny.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Davids(pn)">St. Davids,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Pembr. for&shy;
merly Menew, so call'd 
from St. <etym lang="en">David,</etym> who remo&shy;
ved the Archiepiscopal See 
hither from Uske. In the C. 
Br. Tuy Devi, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Da&shy;
vid's house.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Davids-land(pn)">St. Davids-Land,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Pembr. 
in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Pebideauc</etym>, and 
<etym lang="cb">Cantred Devi</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) David's
