<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Daukins(pn)">Daukins,</form> <xpln lang="en">q. <etym lang="en">Davikins,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
little <etym lang="en">David.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dauney(pn)">Dauney,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Daunaye,</etym> from <etym lang="fr">Aune,</etym> an Elder-&shy;
tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dauson(pn)" lexeme="Davison(pn)">Dauson, for Davison,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Son of <etym lang="en">David.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dautry(pn)">Dautry,</form> <xpln lang="en">Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">d' Haute Rive,</etym> 
of an high Bank.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Deal(pn)">Deal,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Kent, 
formerly <etym lang="en">Dole,</etym> memorable 
for the first arrival and fight 
made here by C&aelig;sar; from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dole,</etym> a Dale, or Plain 
lying next the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Debenham(pn)">Debenham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suff. from the 
River <etym lang="en">Deben,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ham;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dee(pn)">Dee,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Ches. in the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Deva,</etym> C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dyffyr Dwy,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Water <etym lang="cb">Dwy,</etym> be&shy;
cause it riseth out of two 
heads, for <etym lang="cb">Dwy</etym> signifieth 
Two; some call it the Black 
Water, others the Sacred 
Water, because the ancient 
Brit. worshipped Rivers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dee(pn)">Dee,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Scotland, by 
Ptolemy called <etym lang="gk">Dea</etym>, from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dee,</etym> black; perhaps 
from the blackness of the 
water thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dee(pn)">Dee,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Marre in Scot&shy;
land, from the same root .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Deemouth(pn)">Deemouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ches. (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) the 
Mouth of the River <etym lang="en">Dee.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Deira(pn)">Deira,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deora 
rice</etym>, the Kingdom of <etym lang="oe">Deira,</etym> 
after which name the South 
part of Northumberland, lying 
between the Rivers Humber 
and Tweed, was formerly 
call'd. Leland draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deor</etym>, a wild Beast, 
namely from the Forests and 
Warrens, for which this 
Country is very remarka&shy;
ble.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Delft(pn)">Delft,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City in Hol&shy;
land. Adr. Jun. derives it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Delven,</etym> to 
dig, or delve, from the great 
Trench there call'd <etym lang="bl">Delf-&shy;
haven.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dell(pn)">Dell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the word 
to <etym lang="en">Delve;</etym> which See in the 
om. Nam.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Denbigh(pn)">Denbigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County Town in 
Wales; in the C. Br. it is call'd <etym lang="cb">Diffryn Cluyd</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Val&shy;
ley Cluyd, so called from a 
River of that name; it may 
be drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, 
a Dale, and <etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, to abide 
in, or <etym lang="oe">Bigan</etym>, to inhabit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dengy(pn)">Dengy,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, so call'd from 
the <etym lang="en">Danes</etym> that besieged it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Denis(pn)">Denis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname in Devons. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Dane, or <etym lang="en">Danish</etym>; or, 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc6r"> 
as the eminent Dr. Th. H. has 
it, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Denis,</etym> Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">Dionysius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Denis(pn)">Denis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, from 
the Gr. and Lat. <etym lang="la">Dionysius,</etym> a 
Name of Bacchus, this from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F76;&#x03c2;</etym> in the Gen. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&iota;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym> 
Jupiter, whose Son he was, 
and Nysa, a City of India, 
where he rode in Triumph, 
and taught the use of Wine.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Denmark(pn)">Denmark,</form> <xpln lang="en">Adr. Jun. draws it 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dannen,</etym> 
Fir-trees, to wit from the 
copious store of Fir-wood 
therein, and the termina&shy;
tion <etym lang="en">Mark,</etym> a Bound or 
Limit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Depeford(pn)">Depeford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent (i. e.) the 
<etym lang="en">Deep Ford</etym>; see Deep and 
Ford in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Deping(pn)">Deping,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. according to 
Ingulphus, q, d. a <etym lang="en">deep</etym> or 
hollow Meadow or <etym lang="en">Ing</etym>. See 
Deep and Ing, in their 
places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Derham(pn)">Derham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Gloc. from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Deor</etym>, Deer, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, 
a Lodge; see Deer and Ham, 
in their places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dertmore(pn)">Dertmore,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonsh. a bar&shy;
ren place, from the River 
<etym lang="en">Dert,</etym> running thereby, and 
<etym lang="en">Moor;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dartmouth(pn)">Dertmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonsh. a fa&shy;
mous Port, (i e.) the <etym lang="en">Mouth</etym> 
of the River <etym lang="en">Dert.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Desiderius(pn)">Desiderius,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King of 
the Longobardi of Italy, by 
the French Writers he is 
call'd Didier; They may for 
better sounds sake have 
used this in the place of the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Theodehr,</etym> which de&shy;
noteth the Peoples glory, or 
honour; from the AS. and 
old Teut. <etym lang="tt">&ETH;eor</etym>, the Peo&shy;
ple, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> ho&shy;
nour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Deventer(pn)" lexeme="Daventer(pn)">Deventer or Daventer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town 
in the Netherlands. Adr. 
Jun. wrests it from the Arti&shy;
cle <etym lang="bl">Dee,</etym> and the <etym lang="la">Attuarii</etym> an 
ancient People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dever Rill(pn)">Dever Rill,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wilts, a Rivu&shy;
let, which like the Mole in 
Surr. runneth under ground, 
and about a Mile further, 
breaketh out again, and then 
runneth above ground, per&shy;
haps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Deur,</etym> 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Durh</etym>, through, be&shy;
cause it passeth through the 
Earth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="D'evreux(pn)">D'evreux,</form> <xpln lang="en">a French Sirname, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  of <etym lang="fr">Evereux,</etym> a Town in 
France.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dewsborough(pn)">Dewsborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Diw,</etym> God, 
and <etym lang="en">borough;</etym> which see in 
the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Diego(pn)">Diego,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Spanish Sirname, Co&shy;
varr. supposeth that it is a 
corruption of the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">San-&shy;
Jago,</etym> or <etym lang="sp">San-Diago,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
St. James, the Tutelar Saint 
of the Spaniards.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Diganwy(pn)">Diganwy,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Caern. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Digel</etym>, hidden, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wic, Wice,</etym> a Bay, or Bank, 
because it runneth calmly 
between the Banks; or from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Digoni,</etym> to satiate, 
and <etym lang="cb">Gwig,</etym> a Forest, because 
it runneth through Forests.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dilston(pn)" lexeme="Dwilston(pn)">Dilston or Dwilston,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Nor&shy;
thumb. by Bede <etym lang="oe">Deviles-&shy;
burn,</etym> memorable for the 
overthrow of Cedwalla a fa&shy;
mous Britain, perhaps <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Devils-bourn,</etym> because Ced&shy;
walla for his barbarous Cru&shy;
elty was call'd a Devil; see 
Bourn and Devil in their 
places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dimmock(pn)">Dimmock,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dim</etym>, 
and our word <etym lang="en">Oak</etym>, AS. <etym lang="oe">Aac, 
Ac,</etym> an Oak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dinham(pn)">Dinham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from our 
English word <etym lang="en">Diun,</etym> noise, 
and <etym lang="en">Ham</etym>, a Village.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dinsoll(pn)">Dinsoll,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. not un&shy;
likely from the AS. and Eng. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;in</etym>, <etym lang="en">Thin</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Sol</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Disart(pn)">Disart,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Castle in Flintsh. so 
call'd because it stands in a 
<etym lang="en">Desart</etym> or Wilderness; or from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Disathr,</etym> a way not 
frequented, because it stand&shy;
eth in a steep place, and 
therefore hard to be come 
at.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ditmars(pn)" lexeme="Dietmars(pn)">Ditmars or Dietmars,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Peo&shy;
ple of Germ. or rather of 
Cimbr. Cheronesus. Adr. Jun. 
thinketh, that they are so 
call'd, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="la">Teutomarsos,</etym> 
the Dutch of the Marshes; see 
Dutch and Marsh in the 
Com. Nam.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dobbins(pn)">Dobbins,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Dobs, a Con&shy;
tract and Corrup. of <etym lang="en">Robert,</etym> 
by adding thereunto the 
Patronymick termination <etym lang="en">in,</etym> 
which is as much as to say 
Robert's Son.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Don(pn)" lexeme="Dune(pn)">The Don, or Dune,</form> <xpln lang="en">in York&shy;
shire, a River so call'd, be&shy;
cause it runneth in a shallow 
channel; for <etym lang="cb">Don</etym> in the C. 
Br. signifieth shallow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Donald(pn)">Donald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name fre&shy;
quently given to the Scoto-&shy;
Irish; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, 
an Hill, and <etym lang="oe">Eald</etym>, Old. But 
I suppose it is of an Irish 
Original.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Doncaster(pn)">Doncaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, by 
Nennius <etym lang="cb">Caer Daun,</etym> from 
the River <etym lang="en">Dune,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Don;</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Ceaster</etym>, a Town. AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Donaceaster</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dorchester(pn)">Dorchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">the County Town 
in Dors. by Anton. <etym lang="oe">Durnovaria,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) C. Br. the waters 
Ford; for <etym lang="cb">Dwr</etym> signifieth 
water, and <etym lang="cb">Vara,</etym> a Ford; 
see Fare in the Com. Names. 
There's also another Dor&shy;
chester in Oxfordshire, that 
heretofore was a Bishop's 
See, which by Leland is in&shy;
geniously call'd &#x1F59;&delta;&rho;#x1F79;&pi;&omicron;&lambda;&iota;&#x03c2;, 
Hydropolis, a Town where 
there is much water. It is 
of the same Original with 
the other.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dornford(pn)">Dornford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hunt. where here&shy;
tofore stood a City, that in 
the AS. was call'd <etym lang="oe">Dorm&shy;
ceaster</etym>, in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Caer Dorm,</etym> by Anton. <etym lang="oe">Duro-&shy;
Briv&aelig;,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Ford of a 
Water or River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dorsetshire(pn)">Dorsetshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Du&shy;
rotriges,</etym> this from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> Water, and <etym lang="cb">Trig,</etym> an In&shy;
habitant; that is to say, a 
People upon the Sea Coast, 
or that inhabit near the Sea.
</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dort(pn)">Dort,</form> <xpln lang="en">a great Mart Town in 
<emend err="in"></emend>Holland, a contract of 
<etym lang="bl">Dordrecht,</etym> or according to 
Adr. Jun. <etym lang="bl">Durdrecht;</etym> the 
same Jun. calleth it <etym lang="la">Dureti 
Forum,</etym> from <etym lang="la">Duretus</etym> a Noble
man, who perhaps was the 
Builder thereof, and <etym lang="bl">Drecht,</etym> 
a Market-Town: Or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Dort-Dutch,</etym> or 
<etym lang="tt">Dort-hin,</etym> there, that way, 
for thereabout is the Ford of 
the Rhine, and a Thorough&shy;
fare.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dover(pn)">Dover,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, AS. <etym lang="oe">Dofra</etym>, 
a very famous Port of Kent, 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dufyrrh&aacute;,</etym> a 
steep place, from the steep 
Rocks not far rom thence. 
Leland calleth it <etym lang="cb">Dorim</etym> or 
<etym lang="cb">Durum,</etym> as if it came of the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Douglas(pn)">Douglas,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Sirname 
among the Scots; from the 
River <etym lang="en">Duglass,</etym> and this not 
unlikely from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> 
water, and <etym lang="en">Glass,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Glassy 
water, so call'd from its 
clearness; see Duglass be&shy;
neath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dousabel(pn)">Dousabel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christen-&shy;
Name; from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Douce-belle,</etym> sweet and pret&shy;
ty.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Douze(pn)">Douze,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christen&shy;
name, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Douce,</etym> 
sweet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dowgate(pn)">Dowgate,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gate belonging 
to the City of London; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Dourgate,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Water&shy;
gate, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dwr.</etym> 
water, and the AS. and Eng. 
<etym lang="en">Gate.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Drifield(pn)" lexeme="Driffield(pn)">Drifield or Driffield,</form> <xpln lang="en">in York&shy;
shire, memorable for the Tomb of Alfred, a famous 
King of the Saxons, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">dry Field;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Drinkwater(pn)">Drinkwater,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; not, 
as one would think at first, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  abstemious, one that 
drinketh nothing but water; 
but, as Camden observeth cor&shy;
rupted from <etym lang="en">Derwent wa&shy;
ter,</etym> a River so call'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Droitwich(pn)">Droitwich,</form> <xpln lang="en">otherwise Durt&shy;
wich in Worcestershire, per&shy;
haps from its dirty situation; 
see <etym lang="en">Dirt,</etym> and <etym lang="en">wich</etym> in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dru(pn)">Dru,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Proper name of a man; 
Camden draws it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dru</etym>, crafty, subtile; and 
Nicot. draws it from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Dru,</etym> airy, lively, but I 
can find neither of 'em in 
this sence; therefore I had 
rather draw it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dry</etym>, a Magician, one of 
the Druides, that were so 
call'd from Oaks, which they 
worshipped; or from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Dru,</etym> thick, massy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dublin(pn)">Dublin,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, in the Irish 
<term lang="ir">Bala Cleigh</term>. It was formerly the Seat of the <etym lang="ir">Eblani,</etym> 
from whence it is, that in La&shy;
tin it is call'd <term lang="la">Eblana</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Duglass(pn)" lexeme="Douglass(pn)">Duglass or Douglass,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River 
in Scotland, so call'd from 
the greenish colour of its 
water; see <etym lang="en">Douglass.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dugless(pn)">Dugless,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small River in Lanc. 
see <etym lang="en">Duglass</etym> above.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Duisburg(pn)">Duisburg,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City in Holland; 
Adr. Jun, supposeth that here&shy;
tofore it was call'd <etym lang="en">Drus&shy;
burg;</etym> from <etym lang="la">Druses C&aelig;sar,</etym> and 
the old Teut. and AS. <etym lang="oe">Burg</etym>, 
a Town; see Borough in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunbarton(pn)">Dunbarton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, for 
<etym lang="en">Dun-britton,</etym> that is, the Hill 
of the Britons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dundee(pn)">Dundee,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, by some 
call'd <etym lang="la">Taodunum</etym>, from the 
River Tao, and the AS. and 
C. Br. <etym lang="oe">Dun,</etym> a Bank, or Hill, 
that is, an Hill by the River 
<etym lang="en">Dee.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunkirk(pn)">Dunkirk,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City and 
Port of Flanders; from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duyne,</etym> a shelve of 
Sand, and <etym lang="bl">Kirk,</etym> a Church; 
because it lyeth betwixt the 
Sands of the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Duninow(pn)">Duninow,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, formerly 
<etym lang="oe">Dunmawg,</etym> in the Dooms&shy;
day Book, <etym lang="oe">Dunmaw,</etym> from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, an Hill, and 
<etym lang="oe">Mawan</etym>, to mow, it being 
a fruitful Hill, that yieldeth 
a great crop to the Mowers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Duns(pn)">Duns,</form> <xpln lang="en">Iohn Duns, a Scotch&shy;
man, a subtile Doctor; those 
that make him an English&shy;
man, derive it from a small 
Village in Northumberland, 
in the Parish of Emildon, cal&shy;
led <etym lang="en">Dunston;</etym> but those, that 
make him an Irish-man, draw 
it from <etym lang="en">Donne,</etym> a Bishop's 
See in Ireland; But what if 
it come of <etym lang="en">Duns,</etym> a Contract 
of <etym lang="en">Dunstan?</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Duns(pn)">Duns,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">Dunstan.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunsby(pn)" lexeme="Duncansby(pn)">Dunsby, or Duncansby,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, an Hill, and 
<etym lang="oe">Byan</etym>, to dwell; see Down 
and By in the Com. Names: 
or it might be so call'd from 
its being the House of King 
<etym lang="en">Duncan.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunstable(pn)">Dunstable,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Bedfordshire, from 
<etym lang="en">Dunus,</etym> a Robber in the time 
of King Henry the First, that 
made it dangerous to Tra&shy;
vellers by his continual Rob&shy;
beries: By Anton. It is call'd 
Magintum, Magint, where&shy;
of there are yet these Re&shy;
liques; for the common Peo&shy;
ple call Nine Acres of Land 
in the neighbouring Field, 
Madingbour, and Mad&shy;
ningbour; and some Roman 
Coyns, which are ever and 
anon found there, they call 
Madning Money.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunstafag(pn)">Dunstafag,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
in the AS. and C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Stephen</etym>'s 
Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Dunstan(pn)">St. Dunstan,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop 
of Canterbury; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dun</etym> a Bank, or Hill, and 
<etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, a Stone. Anno 937.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunwich(pn)">Dunwich,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, an Hill, and <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, 
a Fort; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Fort upon 
an Hill: It was heretofore 
by the Sax. call'd <etym lang="oe">Dunmoc</etym>, 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, 
a bank, and <etym lang="oe">Mueg</etym>, an heap.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunwolph(pn)">Dunwolph,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, an Hill, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, 
Help, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an Hill of help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Durham(pn)">Durham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop's See, ac&shy;
cording to Camden by the 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc8r">
AS. <etym lang="oe">Dunholm</etym>, from <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, 
an Hill and <etym lang="oe">Holm</etym>, an Holm; 
because the River Vedra doth 
almost encompass the Hill, 
whereon it stands, on each 
side: But by Somner. it is 
call'd in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Deor-&shy;
Ham</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Town for 
Deer; or from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> 
Water, and <etym lang="oe">Ham,</etym> an Home, 
or Habitation; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  A wa&shy;
try Habitation. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Durstede(pn)">Durstede,</form> <xpln lang="en">the most ancient 
Town of Holland, by the an&shy;
cient Romans called <etym lang="la">Batavo&shy;
durum;</etym> some remains of 
which are yet in the Sylla&shy;
ble Dur, by adding there&shy;
to <etym lang="bl">Stede,</etym> a place or Town; 
see Stead in the Com. 
Names. Now <etym lang="la">Batavodurum</etym> 
may seem to come of the 
<etym lang="la">Batavi,</etym> or Dutch, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Deure Dore,</etym> a Door, 
it being the Entrance into 
Holland. See Door in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dutch(pn)">Dutch,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Duytse,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Teutsch,</etym> a German, 
or the same; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Deod, Deode,</etym> a People. 
Kilian draws it from the old 
word <etym lang="oe">Deudisch,</etym> and this 
from the old word <etym lang="oe">Deud</etym> or 
<etym lang="oe">Dud,</etym> God; as he also sup&shy;
poseth that the Gothi were so 
call'd from <etym lang="oe">Got</etym>, God.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="E"><alpha>E</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Ea(pn)">THE Ea,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little River 
in Lincolnshire, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water, 
from whence the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Eau</etym>, Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Aha</etym> Dan. 
<etym lang="da">Aa</etym>, water, all from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Aqua,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eadbert(pn)">Eadbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Northum&shy;
berland, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, 
happiness, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
illustrious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eadgar(pn)">Eadgar,</form> <xpln lang="en">that most mighty, yet 
peaceable King of the Eng&shy;
lish Saxons; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Eadig</etym>, happy, and <etym lang="oe">Ar, Are,</etym> 
Honour; yet Verstegan draws 
it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">A&eth;</etym>, 
an Oath, and <etym lang="oe">Gard,</etym> to keep, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that keepeth his 
Oath; and he supposeth that 
it is the same with Ed&shy;
ward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eadulph(pn)">Eadulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, happiness, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help, that is to 
say, Happy aid, or from 
</page> 

<page sig="Cc8v">
<etym lang="oe">Ea&eth;</etym>, easie, and the same 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) ready help. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eadwin(pn)">Eadwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, happi&shy;
ness, and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, an obtainer, 
<etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to overcome, or 
acquire, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that at&shy;
taineth to happiness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ealdred(pn)">Ealdred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; see 
Eldred, and Aldred.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ealphegus(pn)">Ealphegus;</form> <xpln lang="en">see St. Aelphe&shy;
gus above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ealred(pn)">Ealred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eal</etym>, All, and 
<etym lang="oe">Rede, Rade</etym>, Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eanswyd(pn)">Eanswyd,</form> <xpln lang="en">Verstegan draws it 
from the old word <etym lang="oe">Eans</etym> 
now once, and <etym lang="oe">Wyd,</etym> con&shy;
secrated, a Part. of the Verb 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weihen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiien,</etym> 
to consecrate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Earmenheld(pn)">Earmenheld,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Earme</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Arm,</etym> Poor, 
and <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> a Champion; that 
is, one that protects the 
Needy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Easterlings(pn)">Easterlings,</form> <xpln lang="en">so are the Borussi, 
Pomerani, and other Inhabi&shy;
tants of the Balthick Sea, 
call'd, from their <etym lang="en">Eastern</etym> si&shy;
tuation with respect unto 
our England.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eaton(pn)">Eaton,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, wa&shy;
ter, and <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, a Town, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  , 
a watry Town, for it is seated 
upon the Shore of the River 
Thames.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eay(pn)">Eay,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suffolk, an Isle or 
Holm, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
water, it lying next the wa&shy;
ter side.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Ebba(pn)">St. Ebba,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Daughter of 
Edilfrid King of Northumb. 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ebbe</etym>, 
the Ebbing, or flowing of 
the Sea; she gave the Name 
to a Town corruptly call'd 
Saint Tabbs, for St. Ebbs, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Temple of St. 
Ebba.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ebchester(pn)">Ebchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Bishoprick 
of Durham, from St. <etym lang="en">Ebba;</etym> 
which see above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eboricus(pn)">Eboricus,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Spanish 
Swedes; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Ever Ric,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Rich,</etym> always rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edam(pn)">Edam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Holland, ra&shy;
ther <etym lang="bl">Yedam,</etym> for <etym lang="bl">Ya</etym> seem&shy;
eth to be a corruption of the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water; see Dam 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edbald(pn)">Edbald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Kentish King, from 
the AS. prefix <etym lang="oe">Ed</etym>, again, and 
<etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, bold, one that after 
fear, taketh Courage again: 
or from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eed,</etym> an 
Oath, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bald,</etym> 
presently, one that raps out 
an Oath upon the lightest oc&shy;
casion; or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, 
felicity, and <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to 
reign; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that ruleth 
the People happily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edelburgh(pn)">Edelburgh,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of Ed&shy;
win King of Northumb. Daugh&shy;
ter to Ethelbert King of Kent, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">E&eth;el</etym>, noble, 
and <etym lang="oe">Borg</etym>, a Pledge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edenborough(pn)">Edenborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">the chief City 
of the Scots, by the Scoto-&shy;
Irish <term lang="ir">Dun Eaden</term>, the Hill 
Eden, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Adain,</etym> a 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd1r">
Wing, either from the Wings 
of Horse Regiments, or from 
Wings or Pinnacles in Ar&shy;
chitecture; because there are 
two Walls rising upwards, 
not unlike unto two Wings. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edenburgh Frith(pn)">Edenburgh Frith</form> <xpln lang="en">, by Ptol. Bo&shy;
derio, which Camden seemeth 
to draw from the depth 
thereof, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Boden,</etym> a Bottom; but I find 
no such word.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edenburg-castle(pn)">Edenburg-Castle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Castel myned Agued,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
Maiden's or Virgin's Castle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ederington(pn)">Ederington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, former&shy;
ly the Haven of <etym lang="en">Adurn,</etym> that 
is to say, <etym lang="en">Adurn Town,</etym> 
perhaps from one <etym lang="en">Adurnus</etym> 
the Founder thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edgecomb(pn)">Edgecomb,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from 
<etym lang="en">Edge,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Comb 
Comp</etym>, a Valley environ'd 
with Hills; see Edge and 
Comb in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edinton(pn)" lexeme="Edindon(pn)">Edinton &amp; Edindon</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wilts, 
memorable for King Alfred's 
signal Victory over the Danes, 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea&eth;</etym>, 
easie, and <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, an Hill, that 
is, Hills of an easie ascent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edith(pn)">Edith,</form> <xpln lang="en">Wife to Edward the 
Confessor, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, 
Prosperous, &amp; <etym lang="oe">y&eth;ian</etym>, to re&shy;
dound, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that over&shy;
flowed in Prosperity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edmonton(pn)">Edmonton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middlesex, AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Aedelinton</etym>, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ae&eth;el</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> famous, 
or AS. <etym lang="oe">Ae&eth;eling</etym>, an Heir to 
the Crown; if it might not 
more simply be drawn from 
<etym lang="en">Edmundus</etym> a King, and Mar&shy;
tyr, of the East-English, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Edmund's <etym lang="en">Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edmund(pn)">Edmund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the East-&shy;
English cruelly Martyr'd by 
the Heathenish Danes. Cam&shy;
den draws it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Erd</etym>, blessedness, and <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, 
Peace, that is, blessed Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edmundsbury(pn)">Edmundsbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">a pleasant 
Town in Suffolk, for short&shy;
ness Bury; from <etym lang="en">St. Ed&shy;
mund,</etym> that here suffered 
Martyrdom under the Danes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edric(pn)">Edric,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of Kent; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, felicity, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) happy and 
rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edward(pn)">Edward,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Man's name, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, happiness, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, a Keeper, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
happy Keeper. Verstegan 
makes it one and the same 
with Edgar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Edwy(pn)">Edwy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the English-&shy;
Saxons; from the A S. <etym lang="oe">Ead</etym>, 
happiness, and <etym lang="oe">Wy</etym>, sacred, 
this from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weihen,</etym> 
to consecrate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egbert(pn)" lexeme="Ecbert(pn)">Egbert, or rather Ecbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">ac&shy;
cording to Camden the first 
Monarch of England; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ece</etym>, eternal, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
flourishing, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  always flou&shy;
rishing. Verstegan saith, that 
it was heretofore writ Eah&shy;
beriht, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eght</etym>, 
equity, and <etym lang="oe">Berht</etym>, propense, 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd1v">
ready, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) greatly 
inclining to Equity. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egerton(pn)">Egerton,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a Vil&shy;
lage, and for that cause a 
Sirname, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Egor</etym>, 
Cruel, and <etym lang="en">Town;</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egicha(pn)">Egicha,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Spanish 
Vice-Gothi, perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Egesa</etym>, dread, terrour, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Terrour of his 
Enemies. In the year 687.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egric(pn)">Egric,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the East-Eng&shy;
lish, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ece</etym>, al&shy;
ways, and <etym lang="oe">Rice</etym>, a Kingdom, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) whose Kingdom is du&shy;
rable; or from the same <etym lang="oe">Ece</etym>, 
and <etym lang="oe">ric</etym>, rich, that is to say, 
always rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egthrid(pn)">Egthrid,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of Northumber&shy;
land, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ece</etym>, 
perpetually, and <etym lang="oe">Frith, 
Frede</etym>, Peace, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one 
that maintaineth a perpetual 
Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Egwin(pn)">Egwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ece</etym>, 
sorrow, or <etym lang="oe">Ege</etym>, fear, and 
<etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to overcome, 
that is to say, one that man&shy;
fully overcometh grief and 
fear; or from <etym lang="oe">Ece</etym>, always, 
or <etym lang="oe">Ecge</etym>, an edge of a Sword, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that overcom&shy;
eth with the edge of the 
Sword.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Einsham(pn)">Einsham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Oxfordshire, per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eig</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Ig</etym>, an Isle, because it is en&shy;
compassed with Marshes like 
an Island.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eldred(pn)">Eldred,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same that Aldred; 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eleanor(pn)">Eleanor,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christen&shy;
name. Camden supposeth, that 
it is a Corr. of the Lat. and 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">Helena.</etym> It may be drawn 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;l Eamer</etym>, 
all fruitful, from <etym lang="oe">&AElig;l</etym> all, and 
<etym lang="oe">Eanian</etym>, to Yean or Ean, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a teaming Woman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elenborough(pn)">Elenborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumb. Here&shy;
tofore a Garison was kept 
thereat; derived from the 
River <etym lang="en">Elen</etym> and <etym lang="en">Borough;</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elflede(pn)">Elflede,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen-name of 
a noble Princess come of the 
Royal English-Saxon Blood; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eal</etym>, all, and 
<etym lang="oe">Flede</etym>, puffed up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elgiva(pn)">Elgiva,</form> <xpln lang="en">Daughter to Richard 
the First Duke of Normandy, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helpe</etym>, help, 
and <etym lang="oe">Gifan</etym>, to give.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ella(pn)">Ella,</form> <xpln lang="en">the First King of the 
South-Saxons, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ellen</etym>, valour, fortitude. 
It answers to the Gr. &Beta;&#x1F77;&alpha;&#x03c2;, 
&Beta;&#x1F77;&omicron;&nu;.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ellis(pn)">Ellis,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen&shy;
name, now a Sirname, ac&shy;
cording to Camden Corr. from 
the Heb. <etym lang="he">Elias.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elm(pn)">Elm</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall, with us El&shy;
bow, perhaps so call'd from 
its figure, as Ancona in Italy, 
from &#x1F08;&gamma;&kappa;&#x1F7C;&nu;, an Elbow.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elmelin(pn)">Elmelin</form> <xpln lang="en">in Caern. from <etym lang="en">Elm&shy;
trees</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elmer(pn)">Elmer,</form> <xpln lang="en">heretofore a Christen-&shy;
name, but now a Sirname, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;elm&aelig;re</etym>, 
this from <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, noble, and 
<etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, famous; or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Adelmer,</etym> and this 
from <etym lang="tt">Adel</etym>, Nobility, and 
<etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to increase. It 
answers the Lat. <term lang="la">Honorius</term>, Gr. 
<term lang="gk">Eugenius</term>, Lampridius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elmham(pn)">Elmham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norfolk, former&shy;
ly a Bishop's See; so call'd 
from <etym lang="en">Elm-trees</etym>, and <etym lang="en">Ham;</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ely(pn)">Ely</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cambridgesh. from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water, or <etym lang="oe">Elige</etym>, Eeles, 
as Beda conjectureth, and is 
most likely; or as some will 
have it, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F1C;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
a marsh, or from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Helig,</etym> a Willow, for as Fen&shy;
ny places mostly do, it a&shy;
boundeth with Willow-trees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Embden(pn)">Embden,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Metropolis of 
East-Freezland; from the 
River Ems, whereupon it 
is situate, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, 
a Cave or Den. Adr. Jun. 
telleth us that it was the 
Seat of the ancient Chauci 
the less.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Emeric(pn)">Emeric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, q. 
<etym lang="en">Immeric</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) ever rich, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Immer</etym> al&shy;
ways, and <etym lang="tt">Ric</etym>, rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Emme(pn)">Emme,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of Edward 
the Confessor's Mother; ac&shy;
cording to some a corrup. of 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Amie,</etym> beloved, or 
sweet-heart; according to o&shy;
thers, and that indeed more 
likely, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Amme,</etym> 
as, <etym lang="tt">Sang-Amme</etym>, a Nurse. It 
answers the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Eutrophime</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Emson(pn)">Emson,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. (i. e.) the 
Son of <etym lang="en">Emme.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Enchuysen(pn)">Enchuysen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port Town in 
Holland, according to Adr. 
Jun. so call'd <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="bl">Enckel&shy;
huysen,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of few 
Houses.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Engelbert(pn)">Engelbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
either from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Engel</etym>, 
an Angel, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
shining; or, according to 
Verstegan, from the same <etym lang="oe">En&shy;
gel</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Beriht</etym>, Teut: 
<etym lang="tt">Bericht</etym> warned, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  instru&shy;
cted by an Angel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="England(pn)">England,</form> <xpln lang="en">not from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Enge</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Enghe,</etym> nar&shy;
row, nor from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Angel, Hangel</etym>, a Hook, 
an Angling-Rod, to wit, be&shy;
cause they went a Fishing for 
a livelyhood; but from a 
People call'd <etym lang="la">Angli</etym> English&shy;
men, for in our Primitive 
Language, Englishmen were 
call'd <etym lang="oe">Engle.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Enion(pn)">Enion,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Christen-name, 
There are some that suppose 
it to be corrupted from the 
Lat. and Gr. <etym lang="gk">&AElig;neas.</etym> I had 
rather draw it from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Union, uniawn,</etym> just, upright.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ent(pn)">Ent,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ente</etym> a Duck, this from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Anas,</etym> the same; or from 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd2v">
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ent</etym>, a Giant, this 
from <etym lang="la">Ant&aelig;us,</etym> whom Hercules 
encountred with; or lastly, 
as the learned Th. H. sup&shy;
poseth, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ente,</etym> 
a graff. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eoves(pn)">Eoves,</form> <xpln lang="en">a certain Shepherd; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eowe</etym>, an Ewe, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Keeper of Ewes. In the 
year 708.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Erchenbald(pn)" lexeme="Erchenwald(pn)">Erchenbald or Erchenwald, </form> <xpln lang="en">
a Bishop of London, the Son 
of Offa, King of the Ostro-&shy;
English, by the Scots call'd 
Archebald, according to 
Camden, a bold observer; I 
suppose it may come of the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Erkennen,</etym> to under&shy;
stand, and <etym lang="tt">Bald</etym>, bold. Ver&shy;
stegan supposeth that it ought 
rather to be written Earcon&shy;
weald, as if it were drawn 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, Honour, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Kuhn,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Con, Coon,</etym> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koen,</etym> magnanimous; 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to 
rule, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Strenuous main&shy;
tainer, and Avenger of Ho&shy;
nour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Erchenwin(pn)">Erchenwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">the first King of 
the East-Saxons, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Ere</etym>, renown, 
<etym lang="oe">Con</etym>, Valiant, and <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, 
to acquire, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that 
by his Valour cometh to 
Honour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ercombert(pn)">Ercombert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Kent, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are, &AElig;re</etym>, 
Honour, <etym lang="oe">Con</etym>, adventurous, 
and <etym lang="tt">Beorht</etym>, famous, q. d. 
Famous for Valourous un&shy;
dertakings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eric(pn)">Eric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Danish Christen-name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym> Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eere,</etym> Honour, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> Rich; some take it 
to be a Contract of <etym lang="en">Henric;</etym> 
see <etym lang="en">Henry.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Erigena(pn)">Erigena,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) born in 
Ireland, which by the Na&shy;
tives is call'd <etym lang="ir">Erin;</etym> see 
Ireland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ermanaricus(pn)">Ermanaricus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Gothi. Adr. Jun. taketh it 
to be so called from <etym lang="bl">Erm</etym> 
or <etym lang="tt">Arm,</etym> Poor, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Rich, 
q. d. Rich and Poor in a 
trice; or rather <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Her&shy;
manric,</etym> Rich in Souldiers, 
for <etym lang="en">Herman</etym> signifieth a Soul&shy;
dier, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, 
an Army, and <etym lang="oe">Man.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Erminfrid(pn)">Erminfrid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Earme</etym>, in the Plural <etym lang="oe">Ear&shy;
man</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Arm,</etym> Plur. 
<etym lang="tt">Armen,</etym> a Poor man, Poor 
men, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fried,</etym> Peace, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the refuge of the Poor, or 
their Sanctuary.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ermingstreet(pn)">Ermingstreet,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Earme</etym>, a Beggar, for such 
frequent the Highways, for 
a better conveniency of ask&shy;
ing Alms; or, as it were, 
<etym lang="en">Herman street,</etym> the Soul&shy;
diers Street, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Army, and <etym lang="oe">Man,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd3r">
see Man and Street in the 
Com. Names. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ernestus(pn)">Ernestus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a German Christen-&shy;
Name, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eor&shy;
nest</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ernst,</etym> earnest, 
or serious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ervigius(pn)">Ervigius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spa&shy;
nish Vice-Gothi; perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, 
Honour, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiic,</etym> a Fort, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
Patron of Honour; he lived 
in the year 631.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Esham(pn)">Esham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. formerly 
<etym lang="en">Eovesham,</etym> as the Monks 
writ it, from one <etym lang="en">Eoves</etym>, 
Egwin's Shepherd that was 
Bishop of Worcester. It was be&shy;
fore that called Eathome, or 
Heathfield.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eskdale(pn)">Eskdale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, the In&shy;
habitants whereof were here&shy;
tofore call'd Horesti or Ho&shy;
resci, in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ar Esk,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) nigh the River <etym lang="cb">Esk.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Essex(pn)">Essex,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. <etym lang="oe">East-&shy;
Seaxa</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">East-sex&shy;
scire</etym>, it being heretofore 
the Shire or Country of the 
East-Saxons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eswulph(pn)">Eswulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">rather <etym lang="oe">Esnewulph,</etym> 
a King of Northumb. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Esne</etym> a Man, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, 
Help, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that assisteth 
others manfully.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelard(pn)">Ethelard,</form> <xpln lang="en">sometimes found 
writ Adelard, an Arch-&shy;
Bishop of Canterbury; deriv'd 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Edel,</etym> a Noble man, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Nature, for&shy;
wardness. He lived in the 
year 799.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelbald(pn)">Ethelbald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a man's Christen-&shy;
Name, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, 
Noble, and <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, Bold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelbert(pn)">Ethelbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a man's Christen-&shy;
Name; either, as Camden 
saith, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, 
a Noble man, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
illustrious; or, according to 
Verst. from the same <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, 
and <etym lang="oe">Berht</etym>, furnished with 
advice; see Adelbert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelbild(pn)">Ethelbild,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, 
noble or gentile, and <etym lang="oe">Bili&eth;</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bild,</etym> a Stature, (i. e.) 
one of a comely portly Sta&shy;
ture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Etheldred(pn)" lexeme="Ethelred(pn)">Etheldred, or rather, as Cam&shy;
den will have it, Ethelred;</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, noble, 
and <etym lang="oe">Rade, Rede,</etym> counsel; 
or, if it ought rather to be 
written Etheldred, from the 
same <etym lang="oe">Ae&eth;el</etym>, a Nobleman, 
and <etym lang="oe">Dred</etym>, dread or fear; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the terrour of the 
Nobles.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelfrid(pn)">Ethelfrid,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, 
noble, and <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, 
Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelgund(pn)">Ethelgund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Wom. Christen-&shy;
Name; see Alegund.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelric(pn)">Ethelric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Northumb. 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, a No&shy;

one that ruleth over the Nobility; 
</page>

or, one that governeth 
Prince-like. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelstan(pn)" lexeme="Athelstan(pn)">Ethelstan, or Athelstan,</form> <xpln lang="en">the 
most invincible Prince of the 
English Saxons; from the

the Land; or from <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el&shy;
sta, &AElig;&eth;elstan</etym>, the 
most noble of all, the Superl. 
of &AElig;&eth;el.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelward(pn)">Ethelward,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Man's Christ. Na. 
ali&agrave;s <etym lang="en">&AElig;lward,</etym> from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, a Nobleman, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, a Keeper, q. d. a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelwin(pn)">Ethelwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelwold(pn)" lexeme="Edelwald(pn)">Ethelwold, or Edelwald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
Bishop of Winch. the Foun&shy;
der of an Abby, at Abbing&shy;
don; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>,

to govern, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that 
had the tutoring of the No&shy;
bles.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ethelwolph(pn)">Ethelwolph,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Second King

the AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;&eth;el</etym>, a Nobleman, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, aid, he being a 
man that stood by the No&shy;
bility.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Evan(pn)">Evan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Christen-Name, 
a Contract, and corrup. of 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Johannes, John,</etym> as the 
Hisp. Juan.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Evellmouth(pn)">Evellmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somers. a place, 
which the Tide cometh up 
to, from the River <etym lang="en">Ivel,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Mouth.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Everard(pn)">Everard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
according to Gesner; from 
our own word <etym lang="en">Ever,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, honour; the 
word signifying one that is 
always much honoured; or 
it may be from the AS. and 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ober</etym>, over, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> nature, (i. e.) 
one that is too good natured; 
Camden. It may not abrupt&shy;
ly be drawn from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Eber,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Eofor</etym>, a Boar, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, a Keeper; see 
Bernard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Euric(pn)">Euric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Vice-Gothi, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eafora</etym>, issue, 
or <etym lang="oe">Efre</etym>, ever, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, 
Rich, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that had a 
numerous Issue, or that was 
ever wealthy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eusdale(pn)">Eusdale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, from the 
River <etym lang="en">Eusus</etym> and <etym lang="en">Dale,</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eustow(pn)">Eustow,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Bedfordsh. formerly 
<etym lang="en">Helenstow,</etym> it being then a 
Covent dedicated to St. <etym lang="en">He&shy;
len,</etym> Mother to Constantine 
the Great.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eutharicus(pn)">Eutharicus.</form> <xpln lang="en">Adr. Jun. derives 
it from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Euther,</etym> 
or <etym lang="gr">Vther,</etym> with us <etym lang="oe">Vtter,</etym> 
and <etym lang="gr">Reich</etym> Rich, as we say, a 
vast rich man; or from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Euder,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Euter,</etym> 
an Udder, and AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  rich in Cows.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ewelin(pn)" lexeme="Newelin(pn)">Ewelin or Newelin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a noted 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd4r">
Village in Oxfordshire, from 
the Elms there growing. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ex(pn)">Ex,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire, in Lat. <etym lang="la">Isca,</etym>
 a River; either from the C. 
 Br. <etym lang="cb">Hesk,</etym> Reeds, or <etym lang="cb">Iscaw,</etym> 
 a Saw; and from hence Ex&shy;
 more, a barren place, through 
 which. Ex runneth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Excester(pn)">Excester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire, a fa&shy;
mous City, and Bishop's Sea; 
in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Exanceaster</etym>; 
and Monketon, from the 
Monks; in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer 
Isk,</etym> from the River <etym lang="en">Ex</etym> run&shy;
ning thereby; now call'd 
Exceter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Exmouth(pn)" lexeme="Exanmouth(pn)">Exmouth, or Exanmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">
in Devonshire, the Fishermens 
Village, at the <etym lang="en">Mouth</etym> of the 
River <etym lang="en">Ex.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
