<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fairfax(pn)">FAirfax,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. in 
Yorkshire, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Faeger</etym>, fair, and 
<etym lang="oe">Feax</etym>, hair; there is 
likewise a Fr. Th. word, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  
<etym lang="hd">Fahs-Vahs,</etym> sig. a Head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Fair Foreland(pn)">The Fair Foreland</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, by 
Ptolemy call'd Robogdium, a <emend err="a"></emend>Promontory, so called from 
the Robogdii, the ancient In&shy;
habitants thereof. It may 
probably be so called from 
the Pleasantness of its situa&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fane(pn)">Fane,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Fane</etym>, 
Slender; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Fana</etym>, a flag.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Faramund(pn)" lexeme="Pharamond(pn)">Faramund, or Pharamond.</form> <xpln lang="en">
Versteg. draws it from our 
word <etym lang="en">Fair</etym> and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a Mouth, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a fair 
tongue, or Flatterer, Kilian 
derives it from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Waer,</etym> true, and the same 
<etym lang="bl">Mund,</etym> a mouth, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that speaketh the truth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Farnham(pn)">Farnham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fearn, Feorn,</etym> Fern, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an Habitation; 
see Fern and Ham in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fastrada(pn)">Fastrada,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of Charles 
the Great, from our word 
<etym lang="en">Fast,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vast,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fest,</etym> 
constant, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raed,</etym> 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Raht,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Rade, 
R&aelig;d,</etym> counsel, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) she 
that keepeth counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Faymouth(pn)" lexeme="Falmouth(pn)">Faymouth or Falmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">an 
Haven in Cornwall, from the 
River <etym lang="en">Fal,</etym> that there disem&shy;
bogueth it self into the Sea, 
and <etym lang="en">mouth.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd4v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fell(pn)">Fell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a National Name. Cam&shy;
den expoundeth it, a rough 
rocky Hill; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Felsz,</etym> a Rock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ferdinando(pn)">Ferdinando,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Germ. Sirname. 
Camden supposeth, that it is 
a Corruption of the name 
<etym lang="en">Bertrand,</etym> which see. I had 
rather draw it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pferdt,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peerd,</etym> 
an Horse, and <etym lang="tt">Dienend,</etym> one 
that serveth; It signifying 
such an one, as serveth in 
War upon Horseback.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ferrers(pn)">Ferrers,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from the 
old Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Ferrier,</etym> It. <etym lang="it">Fer&shy;
raro, Ferraio,</etym> a Farrier, a 
Smith that makes Horse-&shy;
shooes, which in the Fr. G. 
are call'd <etym lang="fr">Fers.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fienes(pn)">Fienes,</form> <xpln lang="en">this Family came of 
one Ingram Fienes, the Hus&shy;
band of Sybilla, Heiress of 
Faram. of Bononia, to whom 
William of Bononia, Son 
to King Stephen, gave the 
Town Mattock; perhaps so 
call'd from some Town in 
France of that Name .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fifness(pn)">Fifness</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Neese</etym>, a Promontory, 
and <etym lang="en">Fife</etym>, the County, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the Promontory of Fife.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fingall(pn)">Fingall,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Country in Ireland, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  in Irish a Country for 
Foreigners; for the Irish call 
the English <etym lang="ir">Gall,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Fo&shy;
reigners, &amp; Saissones, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
Saxons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Finland(pn)">Finland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Lat. Barb. 
<etym lang="la">Finnonia,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Fineland, a 
fine Country; see Fine in 
the Com. Names, and Scandia 
in its place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fishgard(pn)">Fishgard,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Pembr. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
<emend err="a"></emend><etym lang="en">Gard</etym> of <etym lang="en">Fishes,</etym> so call'd 
from the commodiousness of 
fishing therein; see Gard and 
Ward in the Com. Names, 
in the C. Br. it is call'd <etym lang="cb">Aber 
Gwain</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Mouth of the 
River Gwain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fitz-county(pn)">Fitz-County,</form> <xpln lang="en">a National Name 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Son of a <etym lang="en">Coun&shy;
ty</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fitz-pain(pn)">Fitz-Pain,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Norm. Sirname; 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fils,</etym> hereto&shy;
fore <etym lang="fr">Filts,</etym> a Son, and <etym lang="fr">Payen,</etym> 
a Pagan, that is to say, a Pa&shy;
gan's Son.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Flamborough-head(pn)">Flamborough-head,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorksh. 
in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fleamburg</etym>, 
either from <etym lang="oe">Flam</etym>, a flame, 
for Mariners give it the Fi&shy;
gure of a Blazing-Star; or 
from <etym lang="da">Flemsburg</etym> in Dane&shy;
land or Chersonesus of the 
Cimbri, in imitation of which 
our Ancestors built this, 
and gave it the same name, as 
a Memorial thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Flatbury(pn)">Flatbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Worcest. in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fleodan&shy;
byrig</etym>, not unlikely from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fleding</etym>, a Flood, 
or Deluge, and <etym lang="oe">Byrig</etym>, a 
City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fleamdike(pn)">Fleamdike</form> <xpln lang="en">in Camb. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Flean</etym>, to flee, <etym lang="oe">Fleam</etym>, 
flight, and <etym lang="oe">Dike</etym>, a Ditch; 
perhaps because of some o&shy;
verthrow given there. See 
Dike in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 
/page> 

<page sig="Dd5r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fleet(pn)">Fleet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the City of London, 
now of little use, but for the 
conveying away of common 
Shoars, though formerly 'twas a Navigable River. 
See Flood in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Flemming(pn)">Flemming,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Flyming, Flyma,</etym> an 
Exile, a Banish'd man, be&shy;
cause, as it is made clear out 
of Histories, they were often 
forced to change their Habi&shy;
tations, and to go into neigh&shy;
bouring Countries, by reason 
of the Inundations of the 
Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Flint-castle(pn)">Flint-Castle,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Flint; 
perhaps from <etym lang="en">Flint</etym> Stones, 
wherewith it aboundeth; 
for it is a very rough craggy 
Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Flixton(pn)">Flixton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suffolk, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Foe&shy;
lixton;</etym> from one F&oelig;lix a 
Burgundian, who reclaim'd 
and confirmed the East-&shy;
English, when they revol&shy;
ted.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Flodoard(pn)">Flodoard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Flod</etym>, a River 
and <etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, a Warder, or 
Keeper.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Floid(pn)" lexeme="Flud(pn)">Floid, or Flud,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Lhuid</etym> ruddy. 
It alludes to the Lat. <term lang="la">Rufus, 
Rufinus</term>; and the Gr. <term lang="gk">Pyrrhus</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Flushing(pn)">Flushing,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port and City of 
Trading in Zealand, in the 
Belg. <etym lang="cb">Flissingen</etym>; perhaps 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Fluysen,</etym> to 
flow violently; because this 
City and all Zealand is en&shy;
dangered by the waves of the 
Sea, but that the Inhabi&shy;
tants by much pains prevent 
such peril.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Folshaw(pn)">Folshaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village, from the 
old word <etym lang="oe">Foll,</etym> for Fall, and 
<etym lang="oe">Shaw,</etym> a Forest, where are 
many trees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Foreland(pn)">The Foreland</form> <xpln lang="en">of Kent; see 
<etym lang="en">Foreland</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Forest of Dean(pn)">The Forest of Dean,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Gloc. 
either from the <etym lang="en">Danes,</etym> some 
ancient Authors writing 
it the Danes Forest, for the 
English-Saxons called the 
Danes, <etym lang="oe">Dene;</etym> or from the 
old Br. and Gall. <etym lang="ga">Arden,</etym> a 
Forest; and hence it is, 
that the AS. <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, signi&shy;
fyeth, a Desert, or un&shy;
cultivated place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Forness(pn)" lexeme="Foreland(pn)">Forness, and Foreland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Lancashire, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Nese</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Naese</etym>, a Promon&shy;
tory, and <etym lang="en">Fore;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Forster(pn)">Forster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, a Contract 
of <etym lang="en">Forester,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) belonging 
to a Forest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fortescue(pn)">Fortescue,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, by con&shy;
traction Forscue, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fortescu,</etym> a strong 
Shield.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Fosters(pn)">St. Fosters,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Foster,</etym> a 
Saint of that Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Foster(pn)">Foster;</form> <xpln lang="en">see <etym lang="en">Forster</etym> above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fosway(pn)">Fosway,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fossa,</etym> 
a Trench, and <etym lang="en">Way;</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Foulgiers(pn)">Foulgiers,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd5v"> 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Fougiere, Feu&shy;
chiere</etym> Fern. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fulk(pn)" lexeme="Foulk(pn)">Foulk, or Fulk,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-&shy;
Name; some, draw it from 
the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Volly,</etym> generous, 
which is no where read of. 
Camden derives it more pro&shy;
bably from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Folc</etym>, 
Folk, or the common Peo&shy;
ple. I might also take it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Folgian</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fol&shy;
gen,</etym> to follow, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Page,
or Footman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Foulness(pn)">Foulness,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, a Fore&shy;
land wherein there is plenty 
of Fowls; from our word 
<etym lang="en">Fowl,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nese</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">N&aelig;se</etym>, a Promontory.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Foy(pn)" lexeme="Fovey(pn)">Foy, or Fovey</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. from
the River <etym lang="co">Fawey,</etym> which 
there runs into the Sea; this 
perhaps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Faw,</etym> 
fame, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a famous Ri&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Francis(pn)">Francis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen Name, 
either <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  AS. <etym lang="oe">Francisc</etym>, 
a Frenchman; or from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Franc,</etym> Frank, or 
free.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frandingham(pn)">Frandingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">not unlikely 
from the AS. and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Fremd</etym>, in the plural 
<etym lang="tt">Fremden</etym>, Foreigners, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, a Village; It being 
probably so called from the 
Foreign Danes, that took 
Possession of it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frankfurt(pn)">Frankfurt,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of two 
famous Cities in Germany, the 
one upon the River Meyn, 
and the other upon the Ri&shy;
ver Oder; from the <etym lang="en">Franks</etym> or 
French, and <etym lang="en">Ford</etym>; see 
Franks, or French beneath, 
&amp; Ford in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Franklin(pn)">Franklin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from 
our word <etym lang="en">Frank,</etym> which see 
in the Com. Names, and the 
dim. Termination <etym lang="en">ling</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">lin,</etym> the word importing a 
Libertine; or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Francolin,</etym> a Bird, so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Franks(pn)" lexeme="French(pn)">Franks, or French,</form> <xpln lang="en">hereto&shy;
fore a famous People among 
the Germans. Adr. Jun. makes 
them all one with the Peo&shy;
ple of Freezland, and he 
thinketh that they were both 
so call'd from their liberality. 
See <etym lang="en">Frank</etym> and <etym lang="en">Free</etym> in the 
<emend err="the"></emend>Com. Names. According 
to the same Jun. they were 
call'd <etym lang="la">Franci,</etym> q. <etym lang="la">Fryonci,</etym> that 
is to say, free from Taxes, 
for that ci which Junius puts 
for <etym lang="tt">Zinsz,</etym> is plainly of a 
Lat. Original, from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Census,</etym> a Tax or Tribute; 
&amp; therefore, I think the for&shy;
mer Derivation is far better.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fradmar(pn)">Fradmar,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient Germ. 
Sirname, Adr. Jun. expound&shy;
eth it, <etym lang="tt">Frey Meyer,</etym> (i. e.) 
a free Mayor; see Free and 
Mayor, in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frea(pn)">Frea,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frea</etym>, a 
Master; see Friga, beneath, 
and Friday in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fredegund(pn)">Fredegund,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christ. Name 
of a Woman, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> Belg. 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd6r">
<etym lang="bl">Vrede,</etym> Peace, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gunnen,</etym> to favour, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Favourer of Peace. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frediswid(pn)">Frediswid,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen-name 
of a certain Saint; not un&shy;
likely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;</etym>, 
Peace, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wei&shy;
hen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiihen,</etym> to de&shy;
dicate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Freedstoll(pn)">Freedstoll,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, other&shy;
wise call'd Frithsocn, and 
Frithstow, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;</etym>, Peace, and <etym lang="oe">Stole</etym>, 
a Seat; it formerly being a 
place of immunity for Cri&shy;
minals, a Sanctuary.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Freezland(pn)">Freezland,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Province in the 
Netherlands, in the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Vriesen,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">West Vrie&shy;
sen,</etym> West-Freezland, to di&shy;
stinguish it from East-Freez&shy;
land, which is in Germany. 
Adr. Jun. makes the ancient 
Frisii, all one with the 
Franks, deriving both from 
<etym lang="en">Free</etym> and <etym lang="en">Frank;</etym> which see 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fremund(pn)">Fremund,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Freoh</etym>, 
free, and <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, Peace; it 
was the Name of Offa's Son, 
King of the Mercii.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frery(pn)">Frery,</form> <xpln lang="en">probably from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Freah, Freoh</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Frey,</etym> 
free, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> Rich, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Rich 
in Freedom, or very free; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frea</etym>, a 
Master or Lord, &amp; the same 
<etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich, or <etym lang="oe">Rice</etym>, a Kingdom, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a rich Lord, or Ruler 
of a Kingdom.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Freshmersh(pn)">Freshmersh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; see 
<etym lang="en">Fresh,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Marsh</etym> in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fridigast(pn)">Fridigast,</form> <xpln lang="en">a German General, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Frede, Fri&eth;</etym>, Peace, and 
either from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gast,</etym> 
a Guest, or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gast</etym>, 
a Ghost, or Fiend.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fridigernus(pn)">Fridigernus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Gothi. Jun. saith, that it sig&shy;
nifieth one inclining to 
Peace, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> 
Peace, and <etym lang="tt">Gern,</etym> freely, or 
<etym lang="tt">Geren</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Begeren,</etym> to de&shy;
sire. Geren may have its 
rise <etym lang="la">&agrave; Qu&aelig;rendo,</etym> from seek&shy;
ing after.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fridstan(pn)">Fridstan,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frede, 
Fri&eth;</etym>, Peace, and <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, 
a Stone, it denoting a Stone 
of refuge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Friga(pn)">Friga,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Goddess of the An&shy;
cient Germ. the same with 
Venus of the Romans, per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frig</etym>, 
free, and surely nothing is 
more free than carnal Plea&shy;
sure, nothing more indo&shy;
mitable; see Friday in the 
Common Names, and Frea 
above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Friling(pn)">Friling,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the time of the 
ancient Germ. Saxons it sig&shy;
nified as much as one that is 
born free, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Frey,</etym> free; see Adhling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frith(pn)">Frith,</form> <xpln lang="en">in our Northern, and 
Scotish Idiom is frequently 
used for Freto in the Termi&shy;
nations of many Names; manifestly 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd6v">
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Fretum,</etym> 
the raging Sea. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frithwold(pn)">Frithwold,</form> <xpln lang="en">Prince of Surrey, 
the Founder of the Mona&shy;
stery or Abbey at Chertsey; 
deriv'd from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;</etym>, 
Peace, and <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to 
rule; the word signifying a 
Peaceable King, or Ruler.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frodoard(pn)">Frodoard,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frode, 
Frod,</etym> weary, afflicted, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, a Guardian, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the Patron of the afflicted.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frompton(pn)">Frompton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dors. from the 
River <etym lang="en">Frome.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Frumarius(pn)">Frumarius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Spanish Swedes, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fromm, Frommer,</etym> 
Honest; or from the same 
<etym lang="tt">From,</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Meyer,</etym> a Mayor. 
He liv'd in the year 461.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fulbert(pn)">Fulbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
rom the AS. <etym lang="oe">Full</etym>, full, and 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, splendent, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one full of Splendour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Fulham(pn)">Fulham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middlesex, in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fullon Ham</etym>, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) 
Fowl-Town; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Fugel</etym>, a Fowl, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, 
a Village: It is now remar&shy;
kable for the Bishop of 
London's Country-House. See 
Fowl, and Ham, in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="G"><alpha>G</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gaina(pn)">GAina,</form> <xpln lang="en">a General of the 
Arians, often mention&shy;
ed in Ecclesiastical Hi&shy;
story; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">W&aelig;gen</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wagen,</etym> 
a Chariot, or Waggon; or 
from that other Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wa&shy;
gen,</etym> to run a hazard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gainsborough(pn)">Gainsborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, 
in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Genes-buruh</etym>, 
or perhaps <etym lang="oe">Geners-buruh</etym>; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Genes</etym>, a San&shy;
ctuary, and <etym lang="oe">Buruh</etym>, a Town; 
the word signifying a Town 
of refuge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Galliard(pn)">Galliard,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gaillard,</etym> It. <etym lang="it">Gag&shy;
liardo,</etym> stout, or Gallant; 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Galloway(pn)">Galloway,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop's See in 
Scotland, from the Irish, which 
in their Tongue are call'd 
<etym lang="ir">Gael.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gam(pn)">Gam,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gam,</etym> Hunch-back'd, 
and this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Camu&shy;
rus,</etym> crooked.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gambrivii(pn)">Gambrivii,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People 
of Germany, where Hamburgh 
</page>

<page sig="Dd7r"> 
is now; from the Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Gans,</etym> all, wholly, and 
<etym lang="gr">Brauwe,</etym> the brow, or fore&shy;
head, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) all Brows, which 
in Physiognomy is a sign of a 
generous Mind. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Garagantua(pn)">Garagantua,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hisp. 
<etym lang="sp">Garganta,</etym> a Glutton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Garcias(pn)">Garcias,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Spanish Christen-&shy;
Name, perhaps from the 
Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Jarcias, Xarcias,</etym> Ca&shy;
bles.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Garibaldus(pn)">Garibaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Longobardi of Italy, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gar,</etym> altogether, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, bold, ventu&shy;
rous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Garnet(pn)">Garnet,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent, for <etym lang="en">Gar&shy;
ner,</etym> which signifies a Grana&shy;
ry. See Garner in the Com. 
Names. Or it may more pro&shy;
bably come from <etym lang="la">Granatum,</etym> a 
Pomegranat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Garret(pn)">Garret,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, a 
corruption of <etym lang="en">Gerard;</etym> which 
see beneath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gateshead(pn)">Gateshead,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Haven in the Bi&shy;
shoprick of Durh. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">gate-shefed</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Heued</etym>, 
Goatshead, in the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gabro&shy;
sentum</etym>, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gaffr</etym>, 
a Goat, and <etym lang="cb">Hen</etym>, for Pen an 
Head; perhaps from some 
Inn, at the Sign of the Goat; 
as the three Sisters in Spain, 
the Pear in Italy, as may be 
found in Antoninus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gausenna(pn)">Gausenna,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient City in 
Linc. some Reliques of which 
Name yet remain in the Ri&shy;
ver Guash, or Wash: It 
is now call'd Bridge Ca&shy;
sterton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gawen(pn)">Gawen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a feigned Christen-&shy;
name; if it be not a Corrup. 
of <etym lang="en">Walwin, Waldwin;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gebericus(pn)">Gebericus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Goths; 
Adr. Jun. draws it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geben,</etym> to give, or be&shy;
stow, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> 
Rich; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a charitable man. 
It answers the Gr. Eleuthe&shy;
rius, Polydorus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gebhard(pn)">Gebhard,</form> <xpln lang="en">according to Jun. 
Liberal by Nature, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Geben,</etym> to give, and 
<etym lang="tt">Aerd,</etym> Nature.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gedney(pn)">Gedney,</form> <xpln lang="en">for Godney in Som. 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, God, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, Water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Geffrey(pn)">Geffrey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen. name; as 
Camden expounds it, Joyful 
Peace; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gaw,</etym> 
glad, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;, 
Frede</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Vrede,</etym> Peace. It answers 
the Gr. Iren&aelig;us.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gelt(pn)">Gelt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Cumberland, 
heretofore <etym lang="en">Gelta;</etym> not un&shy;
likely from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">G&ecirc;l,</etym> an 
Horsleech, from the great 
store of Leeches which breed 
therein.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Genatrud(pn)">Genatrud,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of Dago&shy;
bert King of the Franks, per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Genad, 
Gnade, Gnad,</etym> Clemency, 
and <etym lang="tt">Reden,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Rathen,</etym> to 
speak, or consult; or from 
the same <etym lang="tt">Genad,</etym> and our 
word <etym lang="en">Truth,</etym> or <etym lang="en">True,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
submissive, and loyal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gensalaricus(pn)">Gensalaricus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd7v">
Spanish Vice-Gothi, from the &shy;
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gans,</etym> all, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, 
Rich. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gensericus(pn)">Gensericus.</form> <xpln lang="en">He instituted the 
Government of the Vandals 
in Africa. It is deriv'd as 
Gensalaricus above .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gerard(pn)">Gerard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, ac&shy;
cording to Gesner corrupted 
from <etym lang="en">Eberard,</etym> which see; 
Or as Camden has it, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gar,</etym> all, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Nature: Or, as Ki&shy;
lian saith, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Geyer,</etym> a Vulture, and <etym lang="tt">Aerd,</etym> 
nature, (i. e.) such an one, 
as hath an unsatiable, rave&shy;
nous appetite; this from the 
word <etym lang="tt">Begeren,</etym> to beg, or 
<etym lang="tt">Beger,</etym> Avarice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="German(pn)">German,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gar,</etym> 
all, and <etym lang="tt">Man,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  All man; 
see Alman. Jun. draws it, 
from <etym lang="tt">Geert man,</etym> an honou&shy;
rable man, this from <etym lang="tt">Eere,</etym> 
Honour, or <etym lang="tt">Eeren,</etym> to Ho&shy;
nour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Germans(pn)">St. Germans,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. (i e.) 
the Temple of St. German, 
Bishop of Antisiodora, that ex&shy;
tirpated the Pelagian He&shy;
resy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gernon(pn)">Gernon,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. not un&shy;
likely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Georn, 
Georne</etym>, Studious, Indu&shy;
strious. It answers the Lat. 
<term lang="la">Sedulius</term>, Gr. <term lang="gk">Philoponus</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gertrude(pn)">Gertrude,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christen-&shy;
name, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gar,</etym> 
all, and our words <etym lang="en">True, 
Truth,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  faithful, one 
true to her trust. 
See True and Truth in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gerbas(pn)">Gerbas,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gar,</etym> all, and 
<etym lang="tt">Vast,</etym> Fast, which see in 
the Common Names. It 
answers to the Lat. <term lang="la">Constan&shy;
tius</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gibbcliff(pn)">Gibbcliff,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. or rather 
<etym lang="en">Guy-Cliff,</etym> from <etym lang="en">Guy of 
Warwick</etym>, that fam'd Heroe 
that lived as an Hermit in 
this place; or from <etym lang="en">Guy 
Beauchamp</etym> Earl of War&shy;
wick.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gibs(pn)">Gibs,</form> <xpln lang="en">and Gibson, a Contract 
and Corruption of <etym lang="en">Gilbert;</etym> 
as also Gibbons, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
Son of Gilbert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Giffard(pn)">Giffard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
S. <etym lang="oe">Gifan</etym>, to give, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> nature, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that is naturally given to 
Liberality.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gilbert(pn)">Gilbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Geale&thorn;e</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gheel,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gael,</etym> yellow; 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Guelden,</etym> golden, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, fa&shy;
mous. Verstegan surmiseth 
that it is so call'd q. <etym lang="oe">Gild&shy;
beriht,</etym> from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gild</etym>, 
a College, or Fraternity, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Berichten,</etym> to in&shy;
struct; or from the old word 
<etym lang="tt">Gild,</etym> Liberal.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Giles(pn)">Giles,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, wrested 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&AElig;gidius,</etym> and 
this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&iota;&gamma;&#x1F76;&#x03c2;</etym>, a 
Goats-Skin, also the Shield 
of Minerva, perhaps so called 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd8r"> 
because the Shields of the 
Ancients were cover'd with 
Goats-Skins. It may be taken 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Julius,</etym> and this 
from <etym lang="la">Iulus,</etym> the Sirname of 
Ascanius, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F34;&omicron;&upsilon;&lambda;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
Down; or it may possibly 
come from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Gelasius,</etym> 
and this from <etym lang="gk">&gamma;&epsilon;&lambda;&#x1F71;&omega;</etym>, to 
laugh. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gilimer(pn)">Gilimer,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King of the 
Vandals in Africa. Adr. Jun. 
draws it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Gu&shy;
le&uuml;,</etym> safe Conduct, &amp; <etym lang="bl">Meyer,</etym> 
a Mayor; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Geal, Geale&thorn;e</etym>, yellow, and 
<etym lang="oe">Maere</etym>, remarkable, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
conspicuous beyond others 
for his yellow Locks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gill(pn)">Gill,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the Fr. 
G. <etym lang="fr">Guille,</etym> a Quill, or Fau&shy;
cet; also a Keel of a Ship.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gillingham(pn)">Gillingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Dors. 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gyl&shy;
lan</etym>, to make a noise, from the 
parting of some Brook run&shy;
ning swiftly thereby.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gilpin(pn)">Gilpin,</form> <xpln lang="en">according to Camden, 
a Contract, and corrup. of 
<etym lang="en">Gilbert.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Girvii(pn)">Girvii,</form> <xpln lang="en">whose Country was in 
the AS. call'd <etym lang="oe">Girwa-land</etym>; 
after this name were former&shy;
ly call'd the Inhabitants of 
the Moorish part of the 
Countries of Norfolk, Cam&shy;
bridge and Linc. from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gyr</etym>, a Fen, and <etym lang="oe">Land.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Giselbert(pn)">Giselbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gei&shy;
sel,</etym> an Hostage, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, illustrious.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gizeric(pn)" lexeme="Giseric(pn)">Gizeric, or Giseric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gothick 
Christen-name. Adr. Jun. sur&shy;
miseth that it implyeth one 
Rich in Geese. I had rather 
draw it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Geysz,</etym> a She Goat, and 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> Rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gladuse(pn)">Gladuse,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; pos&shy;
sibly a Corruption of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Claudius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Glasnith(pn)">Glasnith,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gl&aelig;sen, Glas&shy;
sen</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Y&eth;a</etym>, a wave.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Glastonbury(pn)">Glastonbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somers. it was 
call'd by the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Inis Wi&shy;
trin,</etym> also in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Glasen&shy;
ey</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Isle of Glass; 
memorable for the Tombs of 
two Kings, Arthur and Edgar, 
and of Joseph of Arimathea, 
and many of the Primitive 
Saints in England, from <etym lang="en">Glass</etym> 
(which see in the Common 
Names) and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Byrig</etym>, 
a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Glendal(pn)">Glendal,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland, 
from the River <etym lang="en">Glen;</etym> it be&shy;
ing a <etym lang="en">Dale</etym> by the same Ri&shy;
ver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Glentworth(pn)">Glentworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lanc. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Glen, Glene</etym>, C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Glynn,</etym> a Valley, and <etym lang="oe">Wor&eth;</etym>, 
a Court, or Hall, seated in 
a Valley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Glinn(pn)">Glinn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Hib. and C. Br. 
 signifieth a Dale encompassed 
with trees, but <etym lang="en">Glin,</etym> a Sir&shy;
name, signifieth a Knee, saith 
Davis.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Dd8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Glocester(pn)">Glocester,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop's Sea; in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gleanceaster</etym>, a fair 
City, not unlike the Gr. Cal&shy;
lipolis; and in this County 
are Fairford, &amp; Fairley, &amp;c. 
hence it is in Lat. call'd <etym lang="la">Gle&shy;
vum</etym> or <etym lang="la">Clevum,</etym> not from 
Claudius C&aelig;sar, as some will 
have it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godard(pn)">Godard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, God, Good, and 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> nature, to&shy;
wardness, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one endowed 
with a Compliant and Divine 
disposition of mind. Versteg. 
supposeth it so call'd, <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
<etym lang="en">good heart.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godelif(pn)" lexeme="Godlaf(pn)">Godelif, or Godlaf.</form> <xpln lang="en">Verstegan 
thinketh it so call'd, <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
<etym lang="en">good Love.</etym> It is a Womans 
Christen-name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godfrey(pn)">Godfrey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">God, God,</etym> Good, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;, Frede</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrede,</etym> Peace; 
the word implying, God-like 
Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godmanchester(pn)">Godmanchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hunt. from 
<etym lang="da">Gormon,</etym> or <etym lang="da">Guthrun</etym> a Dane, 
that first of all the Danish 
Princes embraced the Chri&shy;
stian Faith. He here erected 
a Palace, which heretofore 
was by Anton. call'd Duroli&shy;
ponte, by Camden Durosiponte, 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="br">Dwr</etym>, water, 
the River Ouze, and the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Pons</etym>, a Bridge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godolphin(pn)" lexeme="Godolcan(pn)">Godolphin, or Godolcan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
Sirname. In the Cornwallian 
Dialect, it signifies a white 
Eagle , which the Family of 
Godolphins wears in its Coat 
of Arms.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godrich(pn)">Godrich,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, 
God, Good, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godscalk(pn)">Godscalk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, 
and <etym lang="oe">Scalk</etym>, a Servant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godstow(pn)">Godstow,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, 
Good, and <etym lang="oe">Stow</etym>, a place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Godwin(pn)">Godwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, 
God, and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Conque&shy;
rour, or from <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to 
get, and <etym lang="oe">God</etym>, Good, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that is a Conquerour in 
God, or that hath obtain'd 
vertue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Goedel(pn)">Goedel,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Abbotess, or Prio&shy;
ress of a Covent; from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Goed,</etym> Good, and <etym lang="bl">De&shy;
elen, Deylen,</etym> to deal, or 
divide (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Liberal and 
Munificent. It answers the 
Gr. <term lang="gkt">Eleutheria, Polydora.</term></xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Goedeland(pn)">Goedeland,</form> <xpln lang="en">the name of a Coun&shy;
try in Holland. Adr. Jun. suppo&shy;
seth that it is taken from 
<etym lang="bl">Goedel</etym> the Abbotess above 
mention'd, to whom the Em&shy;
perour Otho gave this place, 
and so call'd q. <etym lang="en">Goedels Land</etym>. 
It is now corruptly call'd 
Goeyland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Golf(pn)">Goff,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Goff,</etym> a Farrier.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gogh(pn)">Gogh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gogh,</etym> ruddy; see 
Gouge beneath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gorcom(pn)">Gorcom,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a City 
in Holland. Adr. Jun. de&shy;
rives it from the word 
<etym lang="bl">Gorck,</etym> a Poor man, and 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee1r">
<etym lang="en">Home,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an Habitation 
for the Poor; but the word 
Gorck is not to be found in 
Kilian. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gorges(pn)">Gorges,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Gurges,</etym> 
which this Family bears in 
its Coat of Arms.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gorney(pn)">Gorney,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, in Som. 
from <etym lang="fr">Gurnay,</etym> a Town in 
Normandy; this perhaps from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gourneau,</etym> a Curr 
Fish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gorst(pn)">Gorst,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, Camden ex&shy;
pounds it Shrubs. I had ra&shy;
ther draw it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Georst, Gorst</etym>, Ling, 
Heath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gothi(pn)">Gothi,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a famous Peo&shy;
ple, that subdued the Ro&shy;
mans. Adr. Jun. draws it 
from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Got thienen,</etym> 
or <etym lang="gr">Dienen,</etym> from <etym lang="gr">Got,</etym> God, 
and <etym lang="gr">Thienen,</etym> to serve; for 
Odinus, that erected them in&shy;
to a Colony, instructed them 
in the things of God.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gouda(pn)">Gouda,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City in Holland 
upon the River Isel. Adr. 
Jun. draws it from the Goth. 
or Cimbr. <etym lang="ci">Gow,</etym> the Fence 
about, a Trench, also the 
Chanel of a Conduit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gouge(pn)">Gouge</form> <xpln lang="en">and Gogh, a Sirname, 
either from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gouge,</etym> 
an Hunting-Staff, or from 
the Germ. <etym lang="tt">Gow,</etym> which Spel&shy;
man translateth, <term lang="la">Pagus</term>, a 
Village. See Gogh above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gower(pn)">Gower,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glam. in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Guhir,</etym> a Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Graham-dike(pn)">Graham-Dike</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, the 
Wall or Fortress of the Em&shy;
perours Antoninus Pius and 
Severus, either from <etym lang="en">Graham</etym> 
a Scot, that first broke 
through it, or from a 
neighbouring Mountain call'd 
<etym lang="en">Grampius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grampius(pn)">Grampius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mountain in 
Scotland, now call'd Grant&shy;
shame, which in the Scot. Hib. 
Dialect, signifieth an uneven, 
or crook-back'd Mountain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Graves(pn)" lexeme="Grave(pn)">Graves, or Grave,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, 
so call'd from <etym lang="en">Grave,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Grove;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gravesend(pn)">Gravesend,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port in Kent, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the end or limit of the Coun&shy;
ty. See <etym lang="en">Grave,</etym> and <etym lang="en">end,</etym> in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Greenvile(pn)">Greenvile,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Eng. <etym lang="en">Green,</etym> and the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Ville,</etym> a Town or Village: or 
perhaps it was formerly writ&shy;
ten <etym lang="fr">Granvile,</etym> and so de&shy;
riv'd from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Grande 
Ville,</etym> a Grand or great 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Greenwich(pn)">Greenwich,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, from 
<etym lang="en">Green</etym> and <etym lang="en">Wich,</etym> a Port or 
Haven; which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grig(pn)">Grig,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Krig,</etym> Hoarse; or, as 
the learned Th. H. tells us, 
'tis a Contract of <etym lang="en">Gregory.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grim(pn)">Grim,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Grim,</etym> strong; or from 
our <etym lang="en">Grim,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that 
hath a grim, stern look.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grimbald(pn)">Grimbald,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen-name 
of that St. who with St. Need, 
in the time of King &AElig;lfred, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee1v">
the Founder of the Univer&shy;
sity of Oxford, professed Di&shy;
vinity there. It is thought 
to be the same with Grimo&shy;
aldus, derived either from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Grim, Gram</etym>, 
Grim, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Grimm,</etym> 
Anger, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weal&shy;
dan</etym>, to rule, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Sup&shy;
pressor of wrath, or bridler 
of Passion: Or, on the con&shy;
trary, from the same <etym lang="tt">Grimm,</etym> 
anger, <etym lang="tt">Gram,</etym> angry, and 
<etym lang="tt">Bald,</etym> soon; or from the 
same <etym lang="tt">Grim, Gram,</etym> angry, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, bold, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that in his anger feareth 
nothing. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grimoaldus(pn)">Grimoaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Longobardi of Italy. See Grim&shy;
bald.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grimsby(pn)">Grimsby</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. noted for the 
birth of D. Whitgift, Arch&shy;
bishop of Canterbury, perhaps 
so call'd from one <etym lang="en">Grimus</etym> that 
built it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grishild(pn)" lexeme="Grissel(pn)">Grishild, now Grissel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. 
Name of a Woman; perhaps 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Gris,</etym> gray, 
and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Helde, Hel&shy;
dinne,</etym> a Noble-woman, a 
Lady.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Groenland(pn)">Groenland,</form> <xpln lang="en">Dan. <etym lang="da">Gronland,</etym> a 
Country lying very far North&shy;
ward; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Groen,</etym> 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Gron,</etym> Green, so call'd 
q. Green-Land; and yet 
it is longer white with 
Snow, than green with 
Grass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grovenour(pn)">Grovenour,</form> <xpln lang="en">Grubenor, or Gros&shy;
venour, a Sirname in Che&shy;
shire, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">le Gros&shy;
veneur,</etym> a great Hunter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Grouthead(pn)">Grouthead,</form> <xpln lang="en">Robert Grouthead, 
that most learned Bishop of 
Lincoln, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">le Grosse 
teste,</etym> one that had a great 
Head. In the year 1245.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gruffin(pn)">Gruffin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; 
either, as Camden surmiseth, 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Rufinus:</etym> Or, 
which is as likely, the same 
with <etym lang="cb">Gryffith,</etym> which in the 
C. Br. signifieth Credulous, 
or strong Faith'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guelpho(pn)">Guelpho,</form> <xpln lang="en">a General in Saxony, 
I suppose, either from <etym lang="tt">Vlph,</etym> 
and then it implies, Help, or 
an Helper; or from <etym lang="tt">Wolf,</etym> 
and then it answers the Lat. 
<term lang="la">Lupus</term>, and Gr. <term lang="gk">Lycias</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guildford(pn)">Guildford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Golden Ford;</etym> from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Gild</etym>, a College, or 
Fraternity, and <etym lang="oe">Ford,</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gundebertus(pn)">Gundebertus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Longobardi of Italy, from the 
old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gunde,</etym> now 
<etym lang="tt">Gunst,</etym> favour, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gunderic(pn)">Gunderic,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gunde,</etym> 
now <etym lang="tt">Gunst,</etym> good will, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that hath the good will 
of many.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guniberga(pn)">Guniberga,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Wife of Arioald, 
King of the Longobardi of Ita&shy;
ly; deriv'd from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gunde,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Gunst,</etym> favour, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee2r"> 
and <etym lang="tt">Bergen,</etym> to hide; that 
is to say, one that smothereth 
or concealeth her love. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gundobaldus(pn)" lexeme="Gundebaldus(pn)">Gundobaldus, or Gundebal&shy;
dus;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the old Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gunde,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Gunst,</etym> and 
<etym lang="tt">Wald,</etym> abundance, this from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to go&shy;
vern; or from the Teut: 
<etym lang="tt">Gunnen,</etym> to favour, and 
<etym lang="tt">Bald,</etym> soon; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  prone to 
favour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gundomar(pn)">Gundomar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Bur&shy;
gundians, from the old Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gunde,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Gunst,</etym> favour, 
and <etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to amplifie, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one that daily getteth more 
and more into mens fa&shy;
vour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gunhild(pn)">Gunhild,</form> <xpln lang="en">an English-Saxon, 
the Apostle of Norway; per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Con, Conn</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Kuhn,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Koen,</etym> 
valiant, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> 
a Nobleman. He liv'd in the 
year 1024.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guntaric(pn)">Guntaric,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King of the 
Vandals of Africa; not un&shy;
likely from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gunst,</etym> 
formerly <etym lang="tt">Gunde,</etym> favour, and 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> formerly <etym lang="tt">Ric,</etym> Rich, 
that is to say, one that is kind 
to others, or that is beloved 
of others.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guntram(pn)">Guntram,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Bur&shy;
gundians. Kilian writes it 
<etym lang="tt">Gutram,</etym> from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gut,</etym> good, and the old 
word <etym lang="tt">Ram,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Ruhm,</etym> a 
rumour, or fame. It might 
likewise be taken from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gunst,</etym> favour, and 
the same <etym lang="tt">Ram</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Ruhm.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gusman(pn)">Gusman,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Spanish Sirname, 
well known to us by that 
Embassadour of the Spanish 
King sent to King James the 
First. 'Tis as much as to 
say, in the Goth. and Eng. 
<etym lang="oe">Goodman.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Guthlac(pn)">St. Guthlac,</form> <xpln lang="en">an English-Saxon 
Monk, in the honour of whom 
&AElig;thelbald king of the Mercii 
built the most stately Abbey 
of Crowland in Lincolnshire; 
derived from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gu&eth;</etym>, 
War, and <etym lang="oe">Laac</etym>, praise, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
one praised for his warlike 
Exploits; or <etym lang="oe">Lac</etym>, a Victim, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) He that is Sacrificed, 
or Slain in the Wars.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guthred(pn)">Guthred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Kent, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gu&eth;</etym>, war, and 
<etym lang="oe">Rede</etym>, counsel, or <etym lang="oe">Redan</etym>, 
to give advice; that is to say, 
a great Politician; or Coun&shy;
sellour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guthremion(pn)">Guthremion,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Castle in Rad&shy;
norsh. by Nennius Guarthenio, 
which was by King Vortimer 
given a German Saint, in 
compensation of the ill 
treatment which he met 
with from King Vortigern, 
whom he had friendly and 
justly reproved; 'Tis drawn 
from the C. Br <etym lang="cb">Guarsh,</etym> a re&shy;
proach, and <etym lang="cb">Enjaw,</etym> Just.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Guy(pn)">Guy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, from 
<etym lang="en">Guide,</etym> Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Guia,</etym> a Lea&shy;
der; or from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Guidon,</etym> a Banner, or Ensign.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gwischard(pn)">Gwischard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name; see 
<etym lang="en">Wischard</etym> in its place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hacomb(pn)">HAcomb,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in 
Devonshire, perhaps 
from <etym lang="en">Hay,</etym> and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Comb, Comp</etym>, a 
Dale encompass'd with Hills, 
so call'd from the great crops 
of Hay which the Place af&shy;
fords.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hadington(pn)">Hadington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scot. in the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Hadina,</etym> by adding the AS. 
Term. <etym lang="oe">tun</etym>, a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Haw(pn)">Haga,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hagan</etym>, Rasberries, or rather <etym lang="en">Haws;</etym> see Haw in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hague(pn)">Hague,</form> <xpln lang="en">the most famous Vil&shy;
lage in all the World, being 
the Seat of the States of Hol&shy;
land, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hegge, 
H&aelig;g</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haege,</etym> an Hedge, 
perhaps from some great 
Fence made about the Prin&shy;
ce's Palace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hagworthingham(pn)">Hagworthingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincoln&shy;
shire, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;g</etym> 
an Hedge, <etym lang="oe">Wor&eth;ig</etym>, a 
Street, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an Home 
or Habitation; see Hedge in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hains(pn)">Hains,</form> <xpln lang="en">Camden draws it from 
the old Christen-Name <etym lang="en">Ai&shy;
nulph,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Arnulph;</etym> this 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ana</etym>, alone, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one that 
needs not the assistance of 
others.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Halard(pn)">Halard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, pro&shy;
bably from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hal</etym>, 
whole, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
nature, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one, that is of 
an healthy temperament and 
constitution of Body. It an&shy;
swers to the Gr. Hyginus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Halberstad(pn)">Halberstad,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Bishop's 
See in Germany, perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Halber,</etym> half, and 
<etym lang="tt">Statt,</etym> a City; because in 
all likelihood not above the 
one half of the Ground is 
built upon, that was laid out 
for the compass thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Haledon(pn)">Haledon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumb. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Heafenfield</etym>, the place 
where King Oswald by a Di&shy;
vine help got the Victory 
over C&aelig;dwalla the Britain; 
drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Halig</etym>, 
holy, and <etym lang="oe">Dun</etym>, an Hill, or 
the Termination <etym lang="en">ton,</etym> AS. 
<etym lang="oe">tun</etym>, a Town. Heafen&shy;
field, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heo&shy;
fon, Hefen</etym>, Heaven, and 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee3r"> 
Field, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) the Heavenly 
Field, whereunto Aid was 
sent from above. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Halifax(pn)">Halifax,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, hereto&shy;
fore called <etym lang="en">Horton,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">Halifeax,</etym> Holy hair, from 
the Sacred hair of a certain 
Virgin, whom a Clerk, be&shy;
cause she would not prosti&shy;
tute her Body to him, be&shy;
headed. She was afterwards 
Canonized for a Saint. It 
might be called Horton, 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Hortus,</etym> a Gar&shy;
den; or rather q. <etym lang="en">Hors-&shy;
Town,</etym> because good Horses 
were bred there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Halyston(pn)">Halyston,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumb. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Holy Stone,</etym> where St. Paul 
the first Apostle of the North 
of England, baptized many 
Thousands of Men and Wo&shy;
men; See Holy and Stone, 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hamburg(pn)">Hamburg,</form> <xpln lang="en">a most famous Mart-&shy;
Town, and Port in Germany. 
Adr. Jun. draws it from the 
<etym lang="la">Gambrivii,</etym> an Ancient Peo&shy;
ple of Germany that came and 
dwelt here, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the <etym lang="en">Borough</etym> 
of the Gambrivii; See Bo&shy;
rough in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hampton(pn)">Hampton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middl. formerly 
by Leland call'd Avona, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Avontown; now Avon in 
the old Br. is taken in the 
general, for a Water or 
River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hankin(pn)">Hankin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract. and Cor&shy;
rup. of <etym lang="en">Randal,</etym> by adding 
thereto the Dim. Term. <etym lang="en">Kin,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little Randal; see 
Randal. Or as the famous 
Th. H. telleth us, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
Son of <etym lang="en">Hanna.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hanson(pn)">Hanson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from <etym lang="en">Han</etym> 
the Diminutive of <etym lang="en">Randal,</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Son;</etym> that is to say, 
the Son of Randal. V. 
Hankin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hantshire(pn)">Hantshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hante&shy;
scire</etym>; so call'd from the 
River Anton; See Southam&shy;
pton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harborough(pn)">Harborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Haver&shy;
burgh,</etym> in Leicest. from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Haber,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Haver,</etym> 
Oats, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Burg</etym>, a 
Town or Borough, from the 
great plenty of Oats, which 
the place affordeth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harbottle(pn)">Harbottle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland,
