my, and <etym lang="oe">Botle Botl</etym>, an 
<emend err="an"></emend> House, it being formerly 
a Place, where Souldiers kept 
their Quarters. 'Tis also a 
Christen-Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harden(pn)">Harden,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Flintsh. heretofore 
<etym lang="en">Hawarden,</etym> Castle; a con&shy;
traction of <etym lang="en">Haward,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Ho&shy;
ward,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, 
a Den, Valley, or Forest; 
See Howard beneath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harduicus(pn)">Harduicus,</form> <xpln lang="en">Hardewic, and 
Hardwick, a Tyrant of Ita&shy;
ly, either from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hard,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hart,</etym> hard, and 
the Teut. and AS. <etym lang="oe">Weg</etym>, 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wech,</etym> a way; or from 
the same <etym lang="bl">Hard,</etym> and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, a Fort; that 
is to say, an hard, rough 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee3v"> 
way, or a Fort hard to be 
won. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harewich(pn)">Harewich,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, an Haven 
remarkable for a War be&shy;
tween the English and Danes; 
drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, 
an Army, and <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, a Bay, 
or a fenced place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harfager(pn)">Harfager,</form> <xpln lang="en">Harald Harfager, 
a Dane King of England, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;r-f&aelig;ger</etym>, fair 
haired.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harhold(pn)">Harhold,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Danish Christen-&shy;
Name, either from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Army, and <etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, 
an Emperour, or <etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, 
faithful; or from our Eng. 
word to <etym lang="en">Hold,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the main 
Pillar of the Army; or from 
the same <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Wold</etym>, 
which comes from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to rule; or the 
old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Aid,</etym> a Servant. 
See Herauld in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harlem(pn)">Harlem,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fair City in Holland, 
not unlikely from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Haer,</etym> an hair, and <etym lang="bl">Leme,</etym> 
the Chaff or off-scowring of 
Flax, this City being much 
noted for the Manufacture 
of fine Linen, and good 
napp'd Cloth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hartle-pool(pn)">Hartle-pool,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Bishoprick 
of Durham, by Beda <etym lang="oe">Heorta,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Isle of Harts; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Heort</etym>, an Hart, and 
<etym lang="en">Pool.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Harvy(pn)">Harvy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, formerly, 
as Camden saith, a Christen-&shy;
name; possibly from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Army, and <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, 
a Fort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hastings(pn)">Hastings,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex. Camden 
surmiseth, that it is so call'd 
from one <etym lang="da">Hasting</etym> a Dane, a 
great Robber, that either 
built, or seiz'd, or fortified 
this Town. Somnerus writes 
it in the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;sting</etym>, and 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;stingaceasten</etym>, and 
he draws it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">H&aelig;ste</etym>, heat, because of 
the bubbling or boiling of 
the Sea in that place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hatfield(pn)">Hatfield,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, it is call'd 
King's-Hatfield, from the 
King's Country-House; Hat&aelig;field Bradoak, from a broad 
Oak; perhaps in general 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hat</etym>, hot, and 
<etym lang="en">field;</etym> from the hot, sandy 
soil of the Ground.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hatto(pn)">Hatto,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name; Ki&shy;
lian draws it from the old 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Atte,</etym> Father.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Haverford West(pn)">Haverford west,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous and 
large Haven in Pembr. from 
the Brit. and old Gal. <etym lang="ga">Aber,</etym> 
a Port, a Ford hard by, 
and its situation to the West. 
See Haven in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Havering(pn)">Havering,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, from <etym lang="en">aver,</etym> 
as before, and a <etym lang="en">Ring,</etym> which 
a Pilgrim here gave to Ed&shy;
ward the Confessour, as if it 
had been sent from St. John 
the Baptist.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hawgh(pn)" lexeme="Howgh(pn)">Hawgh, or Howgh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, 
yet in use in the North of 
England, which Camden expoundeth, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee4r">
a little Meadow, 
lying in a Valley. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hawis(pn)">Hawis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name. It 
is sometimes written <etym lang="en">Avice,</etym> 
formerly <etym lang="oe">Helwisa;</etym> perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hell,</etym> famous, 
and our word <etym lang="en">Wise;</etym> or 
from the old Name <etym lang="oe">Hilde&shy;
vig</etym> or <etym lang="oe">wig,</etym> which implyeth, 
Ladies Defence, as saith 
Camden; or more probably 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Helde,</etym> or 
<etym lang="tt">Heldinne,</etym> a Lady, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, a Fort; or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hilde</etym>, love, and the 
same <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>. It may be the 
same with <etym lang="tt">Heddewig, Hed&shy;
vig</etym>, which according to Ki&shy;
lian signifieth a Father's re&shy;
fuge, from the old Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hede Atte,</etym> a Father, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiick,</etym> a place of 
Refuge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Heddewig(pn)">Heddewig,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name; 
see Hawis.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Heile(pn)">Heile,</form> <xpln lang="en">the ancient English-&shy;
Saxons &AElig;sculapius, or God 
of Physick, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Heyl,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;l, H&aelig;lo</etym>, 
Health.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Helen's Head(pn)">St. Helens head,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, 
from St. <etym lang="en">Helen</etym> the Mother of 
Constantine the Great, that had 
a Temple here.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Helmsted(pn)">Helmsted,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, 
an Helmet, and <etym lang="oe">Sted</etym>, a 
Place; or from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, secondarily, a safe&shy;
guard, and the same <etym lang="oe">Sted</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Fort, a place of re&shy;
fuge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Helvald(pn)" lexeme="Helwald(pn)">Helvald or Helwald,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Eng. 
Saxon, an Apostle and Mar&shy;
tyr of the Frisii; either from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;l</etym>, health, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to rule, or from 
<etym lang="oe">Hel, Helle,</etym> hell, and the 
same <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to rule, 
because through the Preach&shy;
ing of the Gospel, and cast&shy;
ing out Devils by Miracles, he 
triumph'd over the Gates of 
Hell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hengist(pn)">Hengist,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Captain, the 
first English-Saxon that laid 
wast Britain; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hengest</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hengst,</etym> 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Hest,</etym> an Horse; per&shy;
haps so called because he had 
the figure of an Horse upon 
his Standard; or because 
his Brother's Name was 
Horsa.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hengston Hill(pn)">Hengston Hill</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hengesdoun</etym>, the 
Downes, or Banks of <etym lang="oe">Hengist,</etym> 
a Saxon-General, a Place for&shy;
merly famous for Stanna&shy;
ries, or Mines of Tinn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Heningham(pn)">Heningham,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Hed&shy;
ningham,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Hengham,</etym> in 
the County of Essex, perhaps 
from one <etym lang="en">Hedning</etym> the Buil&shy;
der of it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Henry(pn)">Henry,</form> <xpln lang="en">Camden draws it from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Honore,</etym> honour, and 
I suppose it is the same with 
<etym lang="oe">Honoric,</etym> the Name of a King 
of the Vandals of Africk; 
Verstegan draws it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Han,</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Haven,</etym> to 
have, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rice</etym>, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee4v">
rich. Kilian writes it Heyn&shy;
rick, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="bl">Heymrick,</etym> rich 
at home; See Home and 
Rich, in the Com. Names. 
I might also not obscurely 
draw the Name Honoric, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hohn,</etym> modesty &amp; 
<etym lang="tt">Rich.</etym> See Hunerick. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Henshaw(pn)">Henshaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Chesh. 
that gave the Sirname to the 
Family of that worthy Gen&shy;
tleman Sir Th. Henshaw, de&shy;
rived from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Han</etym> 
for <etym lang="tt">Haven,</etym> to have, and the 
Eng. <etym lang="en">Shaw</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schawe,</etym> 
a Wood, also a Shade.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herbert(pn)">Herbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, now a Sirname, either 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Ar&shy;
my, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, bright, 
or <etym lang="oe">Beorhte</etym>, light, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
Glory of an Army; or as 
Verstegan hath it, from the 
same <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Army, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bericht,</etym> instru&shy;
cted, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) an expert Soul&shy;
dier.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hereford(pn)">Hereford,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop's Sea, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Army, 
and <etym lang="en">Ford,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Ford through 
which an Army passed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hereswide(pn)">Hereswide,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Abbatess of Kent, 
not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Army, &amp; the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Weyden,</etym> to feed. She lived 
in the year 649.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hereward(pn)">Hereward,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, 
an Army, and <etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, a 
Keeper. It answers the Gr. 
Straton and Archestratus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herman(pn)">Herman;</form> <xpln lang="en">See Harman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermegild(pn)" lexeme="Ermegild(pn)">Hermegild or Ermegild,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
Christen-name frequent a&shy;
mongst the Spanish Vice-&shy;
Gothi, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Earme</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Arm,</etym> a Poor man, a 
Beggar, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gildan</etym>, 
to exhibit, or give, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an 
Almoner, he that giveth Alms 
to the Poor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermelinda(pn)">Hermelinda,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Queen of the 
Longobardi; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Earme</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Arm</etym> an in&shy;
digent Person, and <etym lang="tt">Lind,</etym> 
mild; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  kind to the 
Poor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermenegild(pn)">Hermenegild,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Son of Levi&shy;
gildus, King of the Spanish 
Vice-Gothi, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hereman</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heerman,</etym> 
a Souldier, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gildan</etym>, to pay, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that payeth his Souldiers 
well.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermenericus(pn)">Hermenericus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the first King 
of the Spanish Swedes, from 
the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Hereman,</etym> a Soul&shy;
dier, and <etym lang="gr">Ric</etym>, rich, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that is furnished with 
numerous Forces.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermenfridus(pn)">Hermenfridus,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the 
Turingi, either from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Armen, Ermen,</etym> Poor men, 
and <etym lang="tt">Fride</etym> Peace, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
Patron of the Poor; or from 
<etym lang="tt">Heremen</etym> Souldiers, and 
<etym lang="tt">Fride,</etym> Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermingard(pn)">Hermingard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christ. 
Name, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Earme</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Arm,</etym> in the Pl: 
<etym lang="tt">Armen,</etym> Poor men, and 
<etym lang="tt">Gard,</etym> a Keeper, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee5r">
she that preserveth the 
Poor. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermiones(pn)">Hermiones,</form> <xpln lang="en">the third Division 
of Germany. Adr. Jun. draws 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Her-mid&shy;
woners,</etym> the Inhabitants of 
the midst of the Island.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hermundory(pn)">Hermundory,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People in Ger&shy;
many adjoining to the Catti. 
Adr. Jun. supposeth them to 
be so call'd, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="tt">Arm-und&shy;
frey,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vrii,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Poor 
and Free.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hern(pn)">Hern,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, which in the 
AS. signifieth a Cottage, or 
House, saith Camden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herst(pn)">Herst,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hyrst</etym>, a Wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hertford(pn)">Hertford,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County Town, in 
the AS.<etym lang="oe"> Herudford</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Red Ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herthus(pn)">Herthus,</form> <xpln lang="en">as Tacitus relateth, the 
God of the ancient Germans, 
so call'd either from <etym lang="en">Earth,</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Hearth,</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names; It answers 
the Romans Vesta, by the Gr. 
call'd &#x1F18;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F77;&alpha;, which signifies a 
Fire-hearth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herty Point(pn)">Herty Point,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire. It 
was formerly call'd <etym lang="la">Hercules</etym>'s 
Foreland, or Promontory.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herton(pn)">Herton,</form> <xpln lang="en"><etym lang="la">Hercules</etym> Town; also 
Hertlond a Village, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Land of Hercules, not 
because Hercules ever arriv'd 
at this place, for he ne'r came 
further than the Gades, and 
the Sea, which after his 
Name was called the Hercu&shy;
lean Sea; but because some 
Temple was here erected in 
honour of him.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Herwin(pn)">Herwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Army, 
and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Conquerour, this 
from <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to overcome, 
or from the same <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, 
and <etym lang="oe">Wine</etym>, beloved. It an&shy;
swers the Lat. Vincentius, and the 
Gr. Nicostratus and Phi&shy;
lostratus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hewald(pn)" lexeme="Ewald(pn)">Hewald or Ewald,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">&AElig;</etym>, Law, and <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, 
to rule. It answers the Gr. 
Dic&aelig;archus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hexam(pn)">Hexam,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland, by 
Beda call'd Hangustaid; I 
rather think it ought to be 
written Hagulstad, former&shy;
ly call'd Hextoldesham, from 
the River <etym lang="en">Hextold.</etym> It was 
heretofore a Bishop's Sea. 
Somnerus draws it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;gsteald</etym>, a Batchel&shy;
lour, for an Order of Monks 
called the Culdei or Calidei 
all liv'd a single life here 
with the Bishop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Higgins(pn)" lexeme="Huggins(pn)" lexeme="Hutchinson(pn)">Higgins, Huggins, and Hut&shy;
chinson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of <etym lang="en">Hugh,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little Hugh, or Hugh's 
Son; for the termination <etym lang="en">in</etym> 
signifies a Son, as saith &AElig;l&shy;
fricus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Higham(pn)">Higham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, that is to 
say, an <etym lang="en">high</etym> House, or Habi&shy;
tation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Hilda(pn)">St. Hilda,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Abbatess, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hilde</etym>, affection, or 
desire. She liv'd in the 
year 639.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hildebert(pn)">Hildebert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> a Nobleman, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee5v">
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
famous. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hildebrand(pn)">Hildebrand,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> a Nobleman, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Brand</etym>, a firebrand, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he that destroyeth the 
Enemy's Fields with fire; 
or, as Kilian saith, an Incen&shy;
diary, one that eggeth on 
the Nobles; or from the old 
Cimbr. <etym lang="ci">Helt.</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> a 
Nobleman, and <etym lang="tt">Bren,</etym> an 
Helmet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hildegard(pn)">Hildegard,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christ. Name 
of a Woman, from the old 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hilde,</etym> Love, (from 
which came the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, 
a Sweet-heart) and <etym lang="tt">Gart</etym> for 
<etym lang="tt">Garten,</etym> a Garden, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Garden of love, according to 
Aventinus. I had rather draw 
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hulde,</etym> fa&shy;
vour, and <etym lang="bl">Gard,</etym> a Keeper, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) she that keeps in favour 
with every body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hilderic(pn)">Hilderic,</form> <xpln lang="en">a French King; more 
frequently written Childe&shy;
ric, by adding C for <etym lang="oe">Cy&shy;
ning</etym>, a King; deriv'd ei&shy;
ther from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hilde</etym>, 
Desire, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, a Kingdom; 
or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hulde,</etym> fa&shy;
vour, and the same <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> a Kingdom, or <etym lang="tt">Ric</etym> 
rich; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> a Nobleman, and the 
same <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, or <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hilperic(pn)">Hilperic,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of France, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Helpe</etym>, help, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a rich or 
free Helper; In the French 
Annals it is written Chilpe&shy;
ric, by adding C, for <etym lang="oe">Cy&shy;
ning</etym>, a King, q. d. King 
Hilperic.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Hincmar(pn)">St. Hincmar,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Archbishop of 
Mentz in Germany, not un&shy;
likely from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hinc&shy;
ken,</etym> to halt, and <etym lang="tt">Meyer,</etym> a 
Mayor, or Prelate; It an&shy;
swers the Lat. Claudius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hith(pn)">Hith,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Kent, 
one of the five Ports; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hy&eth;</etym>, a Port, &kappa;&alpha;&tau;' 
&#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hobkins(pn)" lexeme="Hopkins(pn)">Hobkins, or Hopkins</form> <xpln lang="en">a Di&shy;
minutive of <etym lang="en">Hobs,</etym> as that 
is of <etym lang="en">Robert,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little 
Robert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hobs(pn)">Hobs,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, but now a Sirname, 
a Corr. of <etym lang="en">Robert;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hockley in the Hole(pn)">Hockley in the hole,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
County of Bedford, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hoc</etym>, dirt, and <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, 
a Pasture, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a dirty 
field.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hogarth(pn)">Hogarth</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Heah</etym>, high and <etym lang="oe">Geard</etym>, 
earth; or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Hoogh,</etym> high, &amp; <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> nature: 
or, lastly, from the same 
<etym lang="bl">hoogh,</etym> high, and our word 
<etym lang="en">Heart.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hodgekins(pn)">Hodgekins,</form> <xpln lang="en">corrupted from 
<etym lang="en">Hodges,</etym> and this from <etym lang="en">Roger,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little Roger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hodges(pn)">Hodges,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, though here&shy;
tofore it was a Christ. Name, 
Corr. from <etym lang="en">Roger;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hodson(pn)">Hodson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Son of <etym lang="en">Hod,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Otto;</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hoel Dha(pn)">Hoel Dha,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the good 
Prince, or Lawgiver of the 
North Part of Wales: Some 
there are that draw Hoel 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Helius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Holderness(pn)">Holderness,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, by 
Ptolemy called the <term lang="la">Promon&shy;
tory Ocellum</term>, from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Ykill</etym>, a Foreland. By a cer&shy;
tain Monk it is call'd <etym lang="en">the hole 
Deira;</etym> See hole and Deira 
in their places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Holdward(pn)">Holdward;</form> <xpln lang="en">see Howard be&shy;
neath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Holland(pn)">Holland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. Ingulphus, 
writes it Hoiland, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  hol&shy;
low Land, because it abounds 
with Ditches full of Water; 
see <etym lang="en">Hole</etym> in the Com. Names. 
Adr. Jun. draws the other 
Holland beyond the Sea from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoy, Hey, Houw,</etym> 
Hay, and <etym lang="bl">Land,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Country that affordeth store 
of Hay; the same Author in 
another place more probably 
Conjectures that the Danes 
that conquered it, call'd it 
<etym lang="da">Olandia,</etym> from an Isle in the 
Balthick Sea, of the same 
name, and this he draweth 
from the Cimbr. <etym lang="ci">Ol,</etym> Ale, 
and <etym lang="ci">Land,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Aleland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Holm Castle(pn)">Holm Castle</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Castle in an <etym lang="en">Holm</etym>; see Holm 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Holmsdale(pn)">Holmsdale</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Holm</etym>, an Holm, and 
<etym lang="en">Dale,</etym> a Valley, for it a&shy;
bounds in fruitful Pastures.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Holm Pierpont(pn)">Holm Pierpont,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Nott. the 
Residence of the famous Mar&shy;
quis of Dorset; <etym lang="en">Holm</etym> signi&shy;
fies a place encompassed with 
Rivers, <etym lang="fr">Pierpont,</etym> a Stone 
Bridge, from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pierre</etym> 
a Stone, and <etym lang="fr">Pont</etym> a Bridge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Holstein(pn)">Holstein,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Holt, 
Hout,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Holtz,</etym> Wood, 
and <etym lang="tt">Stein,</etym> a Stone, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Country where there is plen&shy;
ty of Wood and Stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Honnyton(pn)">Honnyton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonsh. so called 
<term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Honey-Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Honoric(pn)">Honoric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Vandals 
in Africk; the same with 
Huneric and Henry; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hope(pn)">Hope,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hofe</etym>, an House, 
Cave, or Farm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hope Castle(pn)">Hope Castle in Flintsh.</form> <xpln lang="en">C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer Gurley</etym>. V. <etym lang="en">Hope</etym> be&shy;
fore.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Horden(pn)">Horden,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname. Camden ex&shy;
pounds it a Steward, and 
derives it from our Eng. 
<etym lang="en">Hoard,</etym> Treasure, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
Steward of ones Substance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Horn(pn)">Horn,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Metropolis of West-&shy;
Freezland, a famous City and 
Port; Adr. Jun. a Citizen, 
and the Glory thereof, sup&shy;
poseth that it is so called 
from a great Inn in the Mar&shy;
ket-Place, having the <etym lang="en">Horn</etym> 
for a Sign; or because their 
Coat of Arms had upon it 
the figure of an Horn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Horn Church(pn)">Horn Church</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, formerly 
call'd Horn-Minster; so call'd 
because on the East part 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee6v">
of the Church certain pieces 
of Lead jutt forth like unto 
<etym lang="en">Horns.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Horsa(pn)">Horsa,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Saxon Com&shy;
mander, Brother to Hengist; 
so called from the figure of
 an <etym lang="en">Horse</etym>, which he and his 
 Brother had upon their Coats 
 of Arms; see Hengist above, 
 and Horse in the common 
 Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Horsham(pn)">Horsham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, from <etym lang="en">Horsa</etym> 
the Brother of Hengist, a fa&shy;
mous Saxon Captain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Horsted(pn)">Horsted,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Kent, from 
<etym lang="en">Horsa</etym> the Saxon, whose 
Corps were there burned.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hoskins(pn)">Hoskins,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same with 
Hodgekins.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="How(pn)" lexeme="Hoo(pn)">How or Hoo,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; Cam&shy;
den saith, that it signifies an 
high place, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Hoch,</etym> high.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Howard(pn)">Howard,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Sirname of a 
great and illustrious Family. 
According to Spelman, <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
<etym lang="en">Hofward,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the <etym lang="en">Warden</etym> 
of an Hall; or according to 
Verstegan, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Hold ward,</etym> 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Keeper of a Strong 
Hold, or he that is set over 
the Ward or Watch: Or 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, a Tri&shy;
bune, and <etym lang="en">Ward</etym>, Ward or 
Custody. It might formerly 
imply as much as the word 
Marquess; which see in 
the Common Names. Or it 
may be drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, Hospitality, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  kind to Strangers: 
or it is so call'd q. <etym lang="oe">Here&shy;
ward</etym>, the Keeper, or Pillar 
of an Army. It may also be 
taken from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hoch,</etym> 
high, and <etym lang="tt">Ward</etym>, a War&shy;
der, as Camden has it; or 
from the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hold,</etym> 
favour, and <etym lang="tt">werd</etym> worthy, as
saith Kilian.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Howburn(pn)">Howburn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">H&aelig;g</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Haga</etym>, a 
Field, and <etym lang="oe">Bourn;</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Howel(pn)">Howel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname. Camden 
draws it from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">Helius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hoxon(pn)">Hoxon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suff. formerly He&shy;
gilsdon, memorable for the 
Martyrdom of St. Edmund, a 
King; perhaps by a Meta&shy;
thesis for <etym lang="oe">Haligtun,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) an 
Holy Town, or the Town of 
an Holy Man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hubald(pn)">Hubald,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps formerly Hu&shy;
wald, at first a Christen-&shy;
Name, but now a Sirname, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hiwe</etym>, a Family, 
&amp; <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to govern, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
an Housholder.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hubert(pn)">Hubert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hewe</etym>, colour, and 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, clear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Huet(pn)">Huet,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Diminutive of the 
Christen-Name <etym lang="en">Hugh;</etym> which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hugh(pn)">Hugh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, from 
our English word to <etym lang="en">Hew,</etym> 
according to Aventin. or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hawen,</etym> formerly 
<etym lang="tt">Hougen,</etym> to cleave. It may 
also be drawn from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoogh,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hoch,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee7r"> 
high. It answers the Latin 
<term lang="la">Celsus</term>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Hulda(pn)">St. Hulda,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Prophetess, from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Huld, Hulde,</etym> sa&shy;
vour; It answers our word 
Grace, a Christen-Name, 
frequently given to Women.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Huldericus(pn)">Huldericus,</form> <xpln lang="en">if it be not the 
same with Ilderic, or Hil&shy;
deric, which see, I may draw 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hulden,</etym> to 
honour one with his Vote, 
and <etym lang="tt">Ric</etym>, Rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  such an 
one whose Vote will go far 
in ones favour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hulet(pn)">Hulet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Houlette,</etym> a Shepherd's 
Crook.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hull(pn)">Hull,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River, from whence 
that famous Fortification in 
Yorkshire, formerly called 
Kingston upon Hull, takes 
its name; because it is situ&shy;
ate upon the mouth of this 
River, where it disembogueth 
it self into Abus or Humber. 
It may be drawn from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Heulen,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Huylen,</etym> 
to howl, from the noise it 
maketh when it meets with 
the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hulsok(pn)">Hulsok,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, q. d. the 
Son of <etym lang="oe">Vlric,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Huldric.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Humber(pn)">Humber,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous River where 
the Tide cometh at fixed 
times, as in the Thames, by 
Ptolemy call'd Abus, in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Humbre, Humbre Ea</etym>, 
the water Humber, not from 
Humber a King slain there, 
as is commonly believed, but 
as Somnerus hath it, from 
<etym lang="en">Humming,</etym> because the wa&shy;
ters thereof make a great 
huzzing at the flowing and 
ebbing of the Tide. Leland 
taketh it to be a Contract of 
<etym lang="en">Humm,</etym> and <etym lang="cb">Aber,</etym> which in 
the C. Br. signifieth the mouth 
of a River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Humbert(pn)">Humbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last Prince of 
Vienna Narbonensis; Kilian 
exp. it <etym lang="tt">Vnwert,</etym> (i. e.) not 
dear. I would rather draw 
it from our word <etym lang="en">Home,</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names, &amp; the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
famous, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that is mag&shy;
nificent at Home, or that 
liveth sumptuously, or keeps 
a good House.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Humfrey(pn)">Humfrey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from our word <etym lang="en">Home,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frede, Fri&eth;</etym>; 
Peace, that is to say, one 
that maketh Peace at home.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Huneric(pn)">Huneric,</form> <xpln lang="en">according to Kilian, 
and Jun. it is derived from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hun,</etym> an Hen, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich; one that has 
many Cocks and Hens. See 
Henry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hungerford(pn)">Hungerford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Barkshire, here&shy;
tofore <etym lang="en">Ingleford,</etym> perhaps so 
called, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Engla-ford</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Ford of the English.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hunsden(pn)">Hunsden,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Herefordsh. possi&shy;
bly from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hunde</etym>, a 
Hound, and <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, an Hill, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Hounds Town, or 
Hill; because it was a place, 
whither many perhaps re&shy;
sorted to hunt.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Huntington(pn)">Huntington,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County-Town, 
by Marianus Huntantun, else&shy;
where Huntersdune, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Mount of Hunters; for&shy;
merly Amesbury, as it were 
Arnulphs bury, from Ar&shy;
nulph, an Holy man that 
was there interr'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hurn(pn)" lexeme="Hyrn(pn)">Hurn or Hyrn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; 
&AElig;lfricus exp. it a Corner. It 
may be deriv'd from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hyrn</etym>, horn, for a Corner 
is generally crooked like a 
Horn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hurst(pn)" lexeme="Hyrst(pn)">Hurst, or Hyrst,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, 
also the name of a Castle. 
Camden interpreteth it a 
Wood. It may be derived 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hyrsta</etym>, Horse 
trappings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hurstly(pn)">Hurstly,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hurst</etym>, 
which as Camden saith, sig&shy;
nifies a Wood, and <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, 
with us a Lea, or Ley, a 
Field unplow'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hussey(pn)">Hussey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Housse,</etym> a sordid Gar&shy;
ment: also <etym lang="fr">Housse,</etym> one that 
hath such a Cloak on.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="I"><alpha>I</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iames(pn)">IAmes,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jacobus,</etym> 
yet more immediatly 
corrupted from the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Jayme,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Gia&shy;
como,</etym> the same; and all from 
the Hebrew Name <etym lang="he">Iacob</etym> im&shy;
plying a Supplanter, because 
Jacob cunningly deceived 
his Brother.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iane(pn)">Iane,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name of a 
Woman, in the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Geanne,</etym> 
a corruption of <etym lang="en">Ioan,</etym> which 
see in its place, if it may not 
rather come of the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Jana,</etym> answering the Man's 
Name <etym lang="la">Janus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iasper(pn)" lexeme="Gaspar(pn)">Iasper, or Gaspar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-&shy;
Name, the Name of one of 
the Wise men that came to 
worship our Saviour, (if we 
may credit Chronology) and 
if so, it must needs be of an 
Arab. Original , for the Wise 
men are thought to have 
come out of Arabia.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iceni(pn)">Iceni,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People of Brit. from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Iken,</etym> a Wedge, for 
this Region is extended to&shy;
ward the Ocean in the form 
of a Wedge. This People 
had in Possession the Coun&shy;
tries of Suffolk, Norfolk, Cam&shy;
bridge, and Huntingdon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Long Iehindon(pn)">Long Iehindon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. for&shy;
merly <etym lang="en">Vchindon,</etym> not unlikely 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee8r"> 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wyc, 
Wycing</etym>, a Sanctuary, and 
<etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, an Hill, or 
Town. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ienks(pn)" lexeme="Ienkins(pn)" lexeme="Ienkinson(pn)">Ienks, Ienkins, Ienkin&shy;
son,</form> <xpln lang="en">corrup. and contract. 
from <etym lang="en">Iohn,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Son 
of John.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iennings(pn)">Iennings,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Diminutive of 
the Christen-Name <etym lang="en">Iohn;</etym> 
or as Th. H. telleth us, 'tis 
derived from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Jannin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iessop(pn)">Iessop,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, but now a Sirname, 
corrupted from the Heb. 
<etym lang="he">Ioseph.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iew(pn)">Iew,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Juif.</etym> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Iode,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Jud,</etym> all 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Jud&aelig;us,</etym> the 
same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iewry(pn)">Iewry,</form> <xpln lang="en">Palaestina, Jud&aelig;a, or the Holy Land; and in a 
Secondary sence, a Street in 
London, where the Jews dwelt 
together formerly. There 
is found in an ancient Tran&shy;
slation of the French Bible 
<etym lang="fr">Iuerie,</etym> of the very same 
sence, so that it is thought, 
that, He, whom we call a 
Iew, was heretofore in the 
Fr. G. called un J&uuml;e, though 
at this day both the words 
are out of use, and Juif is 
written in the room of the 
word J&uuml;e.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Iies(pn)">St. Iies,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
Temple of Jie, an Irish Saint 
so called.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ikeneld Street(pn)">Ikeneld Street,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Roman Circuits, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Gate of the <etym lang="la">Iceni.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ilchester(pn)">Ilchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Ivelche&shy;
ster,</etym> a Town in Somers. from 
the River <etym lang="en">Ivel,</etym> upon or by 
which it is built: by Floren. 
of Worcester, Gwelcester; by 
Nenn. call'd Pont-Ivel-Coit, that is to say, Ivel Bridge in the Wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ildericus(pn)">Ildericus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King but &shy;
one of the Vandals of Africa. 
Adr. Jun. derives it from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Elder,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Ilder,</etym> an 
Udder, and <etym lang="bl">Ric</etym>, Rich, that 
is, rich in Cattle. But if his 
right Name was <etym lang="en">Hilderic,</etym> as 
some write it, I had rather 
draw it from <etym lang="bl">Held,</etym> a Noble&shy;
man, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Rich, 
that is, one that had many 
Nobles within his Kingdom.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ildobaldus(pn)">Ildobaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Ostro-Gothi of Italy, not un&shy;
likely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Eald, &AElig;ld</etym>, an Old man, and <etym lang="oe">Bold</etym>, 
Bold, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a stout, courage&shy;
ous Old man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ilekely(pn)">Ilekely,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, by Pto&shy;
lemy call'd <etym lang="gk">Olicana,</etym> by adding 
thereto the AS. Term. <etym lang="oe">Ley</etym>, 
a Pasture. V. Lea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Immeric(pn)">Immeric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Kent, de&shy;
rived from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Im&shy;
mer,</etym> ever, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  ever, or 
always rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Inchkeith(pn)">Inchkeith,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Isle in Scotland, 
in the C. Br. it sign. <etym lang="cb">Guith,</etym> 
a Separation, for it is thought 
to have been parted from 
the rest of Scotland, by the 
force of the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ee8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ing&aelig;vones(pn)">Ing&aelig;vones,</form> <xpln lang="en">the third Division 
of the Germans, as Tacitus 
writes, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Woh&shy;
nen, Gewohnen,</etym> to dwell, 
and the prefix <etym lang="tt">In,</etym> for they 
were Inhabitants of the in&shy;
ner or middle Part of Ger&shy;
many.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ingram(pn)">Ingram,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, a 
Contract of <etym lang="en">Engelram,</etym> this 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Engel</etym>, an 
Angel, and perhaps, <etym lang="oe">Rein</etym>, 
Purity, that is, of an Ange&shy;
lical Purity; or from <etym lang="tt">In,</etym> 
and <etym lang="tt">Gram</etym>, angry, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
very furious, according to 
Aventinus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ingulphus(pn)">Ingulphus,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Abbot of Crow&shy;
land, and an Historian; not 
unlikely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Enge</etym>, 
a Straight, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a present help in times 
of adversity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Iohn's Foreland(pn)">St. Iohn's Foreland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ire&shy;
land, by Ptolem. Isanium, from 
the C. Br. Isa, signifying ve&shy;
ry Low.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iolland(pn)" lexeme="Iollan(pn)">Iolland, or Iollan,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly 
a Christen-Name, but now a 
Sirname, corrupted from the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Julianus, Julian.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ioscelin(pn)">Ioscelin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, as 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Justulinus</etym>, as <etym lang="la">Justu&shy;
lus, Justinus</etym>, and <etym lang="la">Justilianus</etym>, 
all from <etym lang="la">Justus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ipswich(pn)">Ipswich,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Port 
and Place of Trading in Suffolk, 
in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gipswich</etym>, which, 
according to Somnerus, was 
heretofore written Gypes&shy;
wic, from the River <etym lang="oe">Gyp&shy;
ping,</etym> and this from the AS. 
Noun <etym lang="oe">Geap</etym>, crooked, to 
wit, from its winding Cur&shy;
rent; and <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, a Bay, Port, 
or Haven.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Irchenfeld(pn)">Irchenfeld,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Herefordsh. in 
the Doomesday-Book, Ar&shy;
chenfeld. Somner. saith that 
it was formerly written <etym lang="oe">Ir&shy;
cingafeld</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Ur&shy;
chins Field; see Vrchin 
and Field in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ireland(pn)">Ireland,</form> <xpln lang="en">by the Natives call'd 
<etym lang="ir">Erin</etym>, by Orpheus, Aristotle, 
and Claudian, <etym lang="gk">Jerne</etym>; by Eusta&shy;
thius, <etym lang="gk">&Omicron;&#x1F50;&epsilon;&rho;&nu;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Yverden,</etym> from the Hib. <etym lang="sp">Hiere,</etym> 
the West, for it is the far&shy;
thest West of any Isle in 
Europe, and ought rather to 
be call'd Iberia or Hesperia, 
from Hesperus the Evening 
Star rising in the West. Wa&shy;
raeus draws it from the <etym lang="la">Iberi,</etym> 
the first Inhabitants thereof. 
Bochartus from the Ph&oelig;nic. 
<etym lang="ph">Ibernae,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the uttermost 
Habitation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Irmenseal(pn)">Irmenseal,</form> <xpln lang="en">the God of the 
ancient Germans; in Versteg. 
<etym lang="gr">Ermensewl.</etym> Jun. will have 
it to be written <etym lang="gr">Hermonstal,</etym> 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Herr,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Heer,</etym> a Lord, <etym lang="bl">Mon</etym> the 
Moon, and <etym lang="bl">Stal,</etym> a Stall, or 
Seat. Verstegan, who makes 
him the same with the Mer&shy;
cury of the Romans, derives 
the Name better from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Armen,</etym> Poor men, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff1r"> 
and <etym lang="tt">Seale,</etym> a Pillar, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
Pillar, or refuge for the Poor. 
Spelman likewise supposeth 
that it should rather be call'd 
<etym lang="gr">Hermenseal,</etym> from <etym lang="la">Hermes</etym> 
that is Mercury, and the same 
<etym lang="tt">Seale,</etym> a Pillar, or Statue. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Isabel(pn)">Isabel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name of a 
Woman, by the Spaniards 
and Italians; contracted from 
<etym lang="en">Elisabeth,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="it">Elisa-bella,</etym> 
pretty Bess.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Isbrand(pn)">Isbrand,</form> <xpln lang="en">Adr. Jun. derives it 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Eysen,</etym> Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Iisen,</etym> Iron, and the old 
Goth. <etym lang="go">Bren,</etym> an Helmet; that 
is to say, one Armed with
an Helmet of Iron. I had 
rather draw it from the 
same Germ. <etym lang="gr">Eysen,</etym> Iron, and 
our Eng. <etym lang="en">Brand,</etym> a Torch, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a searing Iron.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iselste(pn)">Iselste,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City in Holland, from 
the River <etym lang="bl">Isel,</etym> (which Jun. 
makes one and the same 
with Sala of the Franks) and 
<etym lang="bl">Stein,</etym> a Stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Islington(pn)">Islington,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Iseldon,</etym> 
a Village near the Suburbs of 
London, perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gisel</etym>, an Hostage or Inn 
for Entertainment, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, a Bank, or Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Islip(pn)">Islip</form> <xpln lang="en">in Oxfordsh. memorable 
for the Birth of Edward the 
Confessour; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Gest</etym>, a Guest, and <etym lang="oe">Leof</etym>, 
dear, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an Hospitable 
Town, kind to Strangers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Istevones(pn)">Istevones,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Third Division 
of Germany, as Tacitus writes, 
from the Ger. <etym lang="gr">Est,</etym> the East, 
and <etym lang="gr">Wonen, Gewonen,</etym> to 
inhabit, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="gr">Est-Woners,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Inhabitants of the Ea&shy;
stern Quarter. The same 
with Ing&aelig;vones before.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Iubilius(pn)">Iubilius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Her&shy;
mundur&aelig;, Co-temporary with 
Claud. Nero; perhaps from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Guftel,</etym> free, libe&shy;
ral, and this from the Verb 
to <etym lang="en">give;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ivel(pn)">Ivel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Somersetshire,
which joining with another 
running the same way into 
the Sea, is then by Ptolemy 
call'd <etym lang="gkt">Uzella,</etym> now Evell&shy;
mouth.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Katlage(pn)">KAtlage,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly Kid&shy;
lington, perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cat</etym>, a Cat, 
and <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, a Pasture, 
or Field.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kellenton(pn)">Kellenton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Westm. by An&shy;
tonin. <etym lang="la">Gallana,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Callana,</etym> by 
adding the Term. <etym lang="en">ton,</etym> which 
signifies a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kelnsey(pn)">Kelnsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, which 
is derived from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Ocellum,</etym> by adding the AS. 
Termination <etym lang="oe">sey</etym>, which 
comes from <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
an Isle, or Land lying next 
to the Water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kemp(pn)">Kemp,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cempa</etym>, a Souldier.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kenard(pn)">Kenard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
Cambd. derives it from <etym lang="en">Kind,</etym> 
and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Nature. 
It may be better drawn from 
<etym lang="en">Keen,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Cene</etym>, Sharp, 
and <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Nature, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one 
acute and ingenious by Na&shy;
ture: See Keen in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kenchester(pn)">Kenchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Heref. by Anton. call'd Arico&shy;
nium out of the Ruins where&shy;
of Hereford was built.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kendale(pn)" lexeme="Kandale(pn)">Kendale, or rather, Kandale,</form> 
<xpln lang="en">in Westm. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Dale by 
the River <etym lang="en">Kan,</etym> which runs 
close by it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kenham(pn)">Kenham,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, now a Sirname; de&shy;
rived from the Welsh name 
<etym lang="cb">Cynan</etym> or <etym lang="cb">Conan,</etym> as saith Cam&shy;
den. If it be not a corrup&shy;
tion of the AS. <etym lang="oe">Kenhelm</etym>, 
which see beneath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Kenhelm(pn)">St. Kenhelm,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
English-Saxons. Camden sup&shy;
poseth it to be so call'd q. 
<etym lang="en">Kindhelm,</etym> that is, the Hel&shy;
met, or Protector of his 
Kindred , or Relations. Ver&shy;
stegan draws it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyning</etym>, a King, and 
<etym lang="oe">Helm,</etym> an Helmet or Head-&shy;
piece.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kennet(pn)">Kennet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltshire; in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cynetan</etym>, in the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cu&shy;
nelio,</etym> the name of a River. 
We have very likely deri&shy;
ved the name from the 
Welsh .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kenneth(pn)">Kenneth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Scots, 
unless it be of a Scoto-Hib. 
Original , (which I suspect) 
it may be drawn from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cennan</etym>, to know, or 
own a thing, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Eed,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">A&eth;</etym>, an Oath, that 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff2r">
is, one that owneth, and viola&shy;
teth not his Oath. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kenred(pn)" lexeme="Cenred(pn)">Kenred, or rather Cenred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
King of Northumberland, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cene</etym>, courageous, 
and <etym lang="oe">Rede</etym>, counsel, i. e.
one that is bold in Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kenric(pn)" lexeme="Cenric(pn)">Kenric, or rather Cenric,</form> <xpln lang="en">
King of the West-Saxons, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cene</etym>, bold, 
warlike, valiant, and <etym lang="oe">Rice</etym>, 
a Kingdom, or <etym lang="oe">Ricsian</etym>, to 
rule, or reign, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a valiant 
Ruler.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kent(pn)">Kent,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cent</etym>, from 
whence <etym lang="oe">Centise</etym>, a Kentish 
man. Lambard, draws it 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caine,</etym> a 
Leaf, because it formerly a&shy;
bounded in Woods. Camden 
draws it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Can&shy;
ton,</etym> a corner, because Eng&shy;
land, in this place stretcheth 
out it self in a corner toward 
the North-east; and hence 
it is; that such a corner in 
Scotland is call'd <etym lang="fr">Cantire</etym>, and 
that the Inhabitants of ano&shy;
ther corner in Scot. are by 
Ptol. call'd <etym lang="fr">Canta</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kenwulph(pn)" lexeme="Cenulph(pn)">Kenwulph, or <etym lang="en">Cenulph,</etym></form> <xpln lang="en">a 
King of the West-Saxons, 
Founder of Wincham Abby in 
<emend err="in"></emend> Gloc. from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cene</etym>, 
bold, valiant, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, 
help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kester(pn)">Kester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. formerly in 
the AS. 'twas call'd <etym lang="oe">Dwang&shy;
ceaster</etym>, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dwang</etym>, a Thong, &amp; <etym lang="oe">ceas&shy;
ter</etym>, a Town, or Castle so 
call'd, because Vortigern King 
of the Britans, gave Hengist 
the Saxon so much ground 
in this place, as he could 
compass about with an Oxes 
Hide cut into as small 
Thongs as could be: Thong 
Castle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kesteven(pn)">Kesteven,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. perhaps cor&shy;
rupted from the ancient 
Name <etym lang="la">Gausenna,</etym> or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceosl</etym>, Gravel, or 
Sand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Keston(pn)">Keston,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small Village in Kent, 
where C&aelig;sar, then Dictator, 
had a Conflict with the Bri&shy;
tains; in the AS. 'twas call'd 
<etym lang="oe">Cesars-tun</etym>, <etym lang="la">C&aelig;sar</etym> 's Town, 
in imitation of the Gr. <etym lang="gk">C&aelig;
saria</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kettleby(pn)">Kettleby,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a Town 
in Linc. derived from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ketel</etym>, a Kettle, and <etym lang="oe">By</etym>, 
an Habitation; because per&shy;
haps this place was formerly 
much noted for such kind of 
Workmanship.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Kew(pn)">St. Kew,</form> <xpln lang="en">possibly the same with 
St. <etym lang="en">Kibius</etym> the Britain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kilkenny(pn)">Kilkenny</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, so called 
from <etym lang="oe">Cella</etym> a Cell, and <etym lang="oe">Cani&shy;
cus</etym> a holy Hermit that lived 
therein.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Killian(pn)">Killian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Scotland, 
heretofore called <etym lang="sc">Kelin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Killingworth(pn)">Killingworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. for&shy;
merly <etym lang="en">Kenelworth,</etym> from a 
<etym lang="oe">Kenel</etym> or Ditch hard by it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kimbolton(pn)">Kimbolton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hunt. formerly 
<etym lang="oe">Kinnivantum,</etym> from the ini&shy;
tial of the old name <etym lang="en">Kin,</etym> the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Bolde</etym>, a Village, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ton</etym>, a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kinburgh(pn)">Kinburgh,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen Name 
of a Woman; Camden draws 
it from our Eng. <etym lang="en">Kin,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Borh</etym>, a Surety, 
that is, she that engageth for 
her Kindred.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kingils(pn)">Kingils,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the West-&shy;
Saxons, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Cyne</etym>, 
Kingly, and <etym lang="oe">G&aelig;lsa</etym>, Luxu&shy;
ry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kingsdelf(pn)">Kingsdelf,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hunt. a great 
Ditch, which King Canutus 
caused to be digged at his 
own great charges; so call'd 
from <etym lang="en">King,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Delve;</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names. Kingsdelf, <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
Kings ditch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kingston(pn)">Kingston</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey; in the 
time of the Danish Wars it 
was the Seat of the English-&shy;
Saxon Kings, in which three 
Kings were Crown'd, from 
<etym lang="en">King,</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Ton</etym>, for Town, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Kings Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kinton(pn)" lexeme="Kenton(pn)">Kinton, or</form> <xpln lang="en">Kenton in Warw. <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Kines</etym> <etym lang="en">Town</etym>, from Kine 
and Town, which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kinulph(pn)" lexeme="Cenulph(pn)" lexeme="Cinulph(pn)">Kinulph, rather Cenulph or Cinulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King 
of the West-Saxons; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Cene</etym>, strong, bold, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kirk Oswald(pn)">Kirk Oswald,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumb. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Church of <etym lang="en">Oswald</etym>, a King 
and Martyr, in whose honour 
a Temple was here erected, 
which bears his Name 
to this day. Vulgarly Kirk 
Vzzald.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kirk Patrick(pn)">Kirk Patrick</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotl. that is 
to say, the Church of St. <etym lang="en">Pa&shy;
trick.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Kirton(pn)">Kirton</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. from a Stately 
Church there erected by A&shy;
lexander Bishop of Lincoln, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Kirk Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knevet(pn)">Knevet,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. corrup&shy;
ted from the old Name <etym lang="en">Du&shy;
venet,</etym> saith Camden, which 
perhaps cometh of the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Duvet</etym> soft feathers, where&shy;
with Bolsters are filled.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knoc Fergus(pn)">Knoc Fergus</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
Mount of Fergus; <etym lang="ir">Careg 
Fergus,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Crag, or 
Rock of Fergus, so call'd 
from King <etym lang="ir">Fergusius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knoc Patrick(pn)">Knoc Patrick,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Irel. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
St. <etym lang="en">Patrick</etym> 's Mount.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knolles Pacis(pn)">Knolles Pacis</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotl. Duni 
Pacis, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Hills of 
Peace, from AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnolle</etym>, 
the top of a Mountain, and 
<etym lang="la">Pax,</etym> peace; see Downes in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knolls(pn)">Knolls,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Cnolle</etym>, the top of an 
Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knotsford(pn)">Knotsford</form> <xpln lang="en">in Chesh. that is to 
say, the <etym lang="en">Ford</etym> of King <etym lang="oe">Ca&shy;
nutus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Krich(pn)">Krich,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Krisp,</etym> curled, or twirl'd 
up. It answers the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cri&shy;
spianus,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Crispus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>
</page> 

<page sig="Ff3r">
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="L"><alpha>L</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lade(pn)">LAde,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; Camden 
expounds it an Aqu&aelig;&shy;
duct, or Conduit-Pipe, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lada, 
Water Lada</etym>, signifying 
the same; this from <etym lang="oe">Water</etym>, 
Water, and <etym lang="oe">Laedan</etym>, to Lead.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lambert(pn)">Lambert,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christ. 
Name, but now a Sirname, 
either from the Engl. <etym lang="en">Lamb,</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, fair, 
as saith Camden; or as Ver&shy;
steg. hath it, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Lamb 
heart;</etym> having a gentle inno&shy;
cent heart like a Lamb. 
Kilian exp. it <etym lang="tt">Lang Werd,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Long in favour, Isle&shy;
bius, <etym lang="tt">Landbrecht,</etym> that is, 
a Breaker of Land.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lambeth(pn)">Lambeth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, formerly 
<etym lang="en">Lomehith,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Loam 
Port or Wharf. But <etym lang="en">Loam</etym> 
for Mudd, not being found 
in Somner. I may draw it from 
<etym lang="en">Lamb hith</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Lambs</etym> 
Port or Wharf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lancaster(pn)">Lancaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Shire-Town; 
better, as the Inhabitants 
pronounce it, <etym lang="en">Loncaster;</etym> by 
the Scots <etym lang="sc">Longcastell,</etym> from 
the River <etym lang="sc">Lon,</etym> and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a Castle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lancelot(pn)">Lancelot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fictitious Christen-&shy;
Name; perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lansz,</etym> or the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Lancea,</etym> a Spear; or from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Laeten,</etym> to Cast, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an Horseman armed with 
a Spear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lancels(pn)">Lancels,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall, not im&shy;
probably from the old Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Lancelle,</etym> a Lancet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Landaff(pn)">Landaff</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glam. (i. e.) the 
Church upon the River <etym lang="en">Taff;</etym> 
a Bishop's See.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Landulph(pn)">Landulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Land</etym>, 
ones Country, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, 
help, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that fighteth 
for his Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Laney(pn)">Laney,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. from the 
old Fr. G. yet used in Savoy, 
<etym lang="fr">Lanoy,</etym> a kind of Hawk; 
see Lanneret, or Lanard 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lanfranc(pn)">Lanfranc,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Land</etym>, 
a Land, and <etym lang="oe">Franc</etym>, Free, 
that is to say, made a Free 
Denizen of a place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lange(pn)">Lange,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lanc. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Billangho</etym>, memorable for 
a signal overthrow given 
Captain Wade a Rebel, by 
Ardulph King of Northum&shy;
berland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Langport(pn)">Langport,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Somerset, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">long 
Port.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Langworth(pn)">Langworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lang</etym>, long, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Weor&eth;</etym>, 
for <etym lang="oe">Weor&eth;ig</etym>, a Village.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lanladron(pn)">Lanladron,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. per&shy;
haps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Lain,</etym> a 
Sword, and <etym lang="cb">Ladd,</etym> to slay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lanthony(pn)">Lanthony,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient Abby 
in Monm. q. <etym lang="cb">Lanthodeney,</etym> from 
<etym lang="cb">Lhan</etym> an Abby, or Ecclesiasti&shy;
cal Place, and the River <etym lang="cb">Hode&shy;
ney,</etym> as saith Girald a Welsh 
Interpreter; also <etym lang="cb">Lahn Devi 
Hodeney,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) St. David's 
upon Hodeney.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lan Vethlin(pn)" lexeme="Methlin(pn)">Lan Vethlin, or Methlin,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Montgomer. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Methlin 
Church; by Antoninus, <etym lang="la">Medio&shy;
lanum,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Town between 
two Brooks or little Rivers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lanwitham(pn)">Lanwitham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Cornw. 
perhaps from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Llenwi,</etym> to fill up.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Latimer(pn)">Latimer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Latinier,</etym> a Latiner, 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  He that can translate 
any Tongue into Latin, for 
in the time of the Romans, 
Interpreters were wont to 
turn every strange Tongue 
into Latin, that Language 
being known to all in a man&shy;
ner, as Menagius relateth 
it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Launston(pn)">Launston,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. a Con&shy;
tract of <etym lang="co">Lanstaphodon,</etym> which 
in their Dialect signifieth 
as much as St. <etym lang="en">Stephen</etym> 's 
Church.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Law(pn)">Law,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Scotish Sirname , which 
among them signifieth an 
Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lawson(pn)">Lawson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, q. d. <etym lang="en">Law&shy;
renceson,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Son of 
<etym lang="en">Lawrence.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lazzi(pn)">Lazzi,</form> <xpln lang="en">among the ancient Ger&shy;
man Saxons, it signified Li&shy;
bertines, or such as were 
made free, said Nithard. in 
his <term lang="la">Hist. Francorum</term>; drawn 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Freylassen,</etym> 
or <etym lang="tt">Freygelassen,</etym> made free. 
See Adhling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lea(pn)">Lea,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Hertf. formerly 
<etym lang="en">Lygean,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Lyg-ea,</etym> or the 
River <etym lang="oe">Lyg.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lechlade(pn)">Lechlade,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Town in 
Gloc. in which there was a 
famous Latin School, which 
with Crekelade, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
Greek School, King &AElig;lfred 
removed to Oxford, when he 
built that University. Som&shy;
nerus supposeth that this 
Town was call'd in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leuegelade</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Leuelade</etym>, 
and he derives it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leccian</etym>, to water, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ladian</etym>, to Purge; see 
Crekelade, or Creccelade.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ledbury(pn)">Ledbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Heref. from the 
River <etym lang="en">Ledden,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bury,</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lee(pn)" lexeme="Ley(pn)" lexeme="Leigh(pn)">Lee, Ley, or Leigh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sir&shy;
name, either from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">le,</etym> a place, or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ley, Leag, Lege</etym>, Land 
unplow'd for some years, 
Lee, or Ley as it is call'd in 
the North of England.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leeds(pn)">Leeds</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Loydis</etym>, heretofore the Kings 
of Northumberland's Palace; 
not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leode</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leut,</etym> People; 
all from the Greek <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&alpha;#x1F78;&#x03c2;, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff4r">
&Lambda;&epsilon;&#x1F7C;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a populous Ci&shy;
ty. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leerdam(pn)">Leerdam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City in Holland, 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;r, 
Gel&aelig;r</etym>, empty, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lar</etym>, 
<etym lang="tt">Lehr,</etym> the same, and our 
English word <etym lang="en">Dam.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leland(pn)">Leland,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, made fa&shy;
mous by our famous Anti&shy;
quarian of that Name; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, a Pasture, 
and <etym lang="en">Land.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Le Herbert(pn)">Le Herbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Merionethshire, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Herbert's Way, from 
<etym lang="en">Herbert</etym> an Earl of Pembr. 
that with much ado made 
his way over the Mountains 
there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leicester(pn)">Leicester,</form> <xpln lang="en">the County Town. 
Matth. Par. writes it <etym lang="en">Lege&shy;
cester;</etym> this Camden surmiseth 
to be the same with Nennius's 
<etym lang="cb">Caer Lerion:</etym> It may be 
derived perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leagceaster</etym>, which 
again is derived from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, which signifies 
Ground laid fallow, and 
<etym lang="oe">ceaster</etym>, a Town or Castle, 
it being built hard by a Com&shy;
mon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lemster(pn)">Lemster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Heref. heretofore 
called <etym lang="en">Leon Minster,</etym> from 
a <etym lang="en">Lion,</etym> as some relate, 
which appear'd to a Monk in 
a Dream; or from <etym lang="en">Line</etym> which 
yieldeth great increase in 
this place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lemster(pn)">Lemster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Province in Ireland; 
in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Lein,</etym> by the 
Natives call'd <etym lang="ir">Leighnigh,</etym> 
Ptolemy saith, that it was the 
Country of the Brigantes, Me&shy;
napii, Cauchi, and Blanii; 
perhaps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Llam,</etym> 
a leap, or jump, or <etym lang="cb">Llam&shy;
mu,</etym> to leap, because it is 
full of Hills and uneven 
Places.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leneham(pn)">Leneham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Kent, 
from the old word <etym lang="la">Durolenum</etym> 
in Anton. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the water of 
the River <etym lang="en">Len,</etym> by adding 
the Termination <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym> signi&shy;
fying a Village.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lennox(pn)">Lennox,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Province in Scot&shy;
land, from the River <etym lang="en">Levin,</etym> 
which by Ptolem. is call'd 
Lelalonius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leodegar(pn)">Leodegar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Leodgard,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
<emend err="the"></emend>Peoples Gard, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, People, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Gard,</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names; see also Luitgard, 
beneath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leofhold(pn)">Leofhold,</form> <xpln lang="en">Versteg. draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leof</etym>, Love, and 
<etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, faithful.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leofric(pn)">Leofric,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Eng. Sax. Comman&shy;
der of the Mercii, who com&shy;
pass'd the City of Coventry 
about with that strong Wall, 
that was pull'd down some 
years since; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leof</etym>, love, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, a 
Kingdom, also rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
beloved of all, or rich in 
love.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leofstan(pn)">Leofstan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
Camden saith that it is the 
Superlat. of <etym lang="oe">Leof</etym>, dear. In 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff4v">
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leofsta</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  most 
dear: Or from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Leof</etym>, dear, and <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, a 
Stone, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Precious Stone, 
or Jewel. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leofwin(pn)">Leofwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leof</etym>, Love, 
and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Victour, or 
<etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to obtain, q. d. 
one that obtains the love of 
every one.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leonard(pn)">Leonard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leon</etym>, a Lion, 
and <etym lang="oe">Aerd,</etym> nature, that is to 
say, one that hath a stout 
courage like a Lion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leonegildus(pn)">Leonegildus,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christ. Name, 
of a King of the Spanish Vice-&shy;
Gothi, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leon</etym>, 
or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lowe,</etym> in the Plu&shy;
ral <etym lang="tt">Lowen,</etym> a Lion, and the
