AS. <etym lang="oe">Gildan</etym>, to shew, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
he that makes a show of Li&shy;
ons for the People to see it: 
or rather from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lean</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lohn,</etym> Dan. and Goth. 
<etym lang="go">Lon,</etym> a reward, and <etym lang="oe">Gilfan</etym>, 
to give, (i e.) such an one as 
payeth his Souldiers accor&shy;
ding to their deserts.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leopold(pn)" lexeme="Leodpold(pn)">Leopold, or Leodpold, either,</form> 
<xpln lang="en">as Camden hath it, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, People, and <etym lang="en">Vp&shy;
hold;</etym> or as Verstegan, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, Dear, also 
Love, and <etym lang="oe">Hold,</etym> that is, He 
that maintaineth Friendship 
and Concord It answers the 
Gr. Demosthenes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leskerd(pn)">Leskerd,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Cornwall, 
perhaps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Llefg,</etym> 
low or gentle, and <etym lang="cb">Cerdd,</etym> 
Musick, namely from the gen&shy;
tle Humming noise it maketh 
in its course.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="L'Estrange(pn)">L' Estrange,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from 
the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">L' Estrange,</etym> an 
Alien, a Foreigner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lettice(pn)">Lettice,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christ. Name of 
a Woman, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">L&aelig;
titia,</etym> Joy; It answers to the 
Gr. Euphrosyne.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leveney(pn)">Leveney,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Breckn, 
nigh to which was formerly 
a Town, which Ptolem. calls 
<etym lang="gk">Loventium,</etym> by adding there&shy;
to the AS. Term. <etym lang="oe">Ey</etym>, for 
<etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water; perhaps from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Llewa,</etym> to Eat, because 
by overflowing its Banks it 
carrieth away some of the 
surface of the Neighbouring 
Fields.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leverton(pn)">Leverton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Linc. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Leofrie</etym> 's <etym lang="en">Town,</etym> from 
<etym lang="oe">Leofric</etym> an English-Saxon the 
Founder of it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leveson(pn)">Leveson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Lewe&shy;
son,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Son of <etym lang="en">Lewis,</etym> 
which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Levigildus(pn)">Levigildus,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Spa&shy;
nish Vice-Gothi; from the old 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Leuwe,</etym> a Lyon, and 
<etym lang="bl">Gild,</etym> a Fellow, according 
to Junius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Levin(pn)">Levin,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christ. name, 
but now a Sirname; a con&shy;
tract of <etym lang="oe">Leofwin,</etym> which see 
above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leviston(pn)">Leviston,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, a Cor&shy;
ruption of the Christ. Name 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff5r"> 
<etym lang="oe">Leofstan,</etym> which see above: 
or from <etym lang="en">Levins,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Leof&shy;
wins,</etym> by adding <etym lang="en">Ston.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lewes(pn)">Lewes,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port in Suss. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">L&aelig;swe</etym>, a Pasture, it 
being surrounded on each 
side with good Pasture 
Lands.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lewis(pn)">Lewis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name, im&shy;
mediately from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">Louis,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Luigi;</etym> among 
the Venetians 'tis call'd <etym lang="it">Aluise;</etym> 
all from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ludwig,</etym> 
the same; and this from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> Peo&shy;
ple, and <etym lang="oe">Wic,</etym> a Castle, or 
Fort, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Safeguard, 
or Support of the People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lewlin(pn)">Lewlin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name fre&shy;
quent among the Welsh , <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
like a Lion. It answers the 
Gr. Leon and Leontius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ley(pn)">Ley,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Essex, in 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lygean</etym>, perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Licgean</etym>, 
to Lie; because it runneth 
so softly, that one would 
think it stood still.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leyden(pn)">Leyden,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City in Hol&shy;
land, perhaps from the old 
AS. and C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Lug</etym>, or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lich</etym>, a Lake, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, 
an Hill, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an Hill envi&shy;
ron'd with a Lake or Lough, 
which see, and also Downes 
in the Common Names. Adr. 
Jun. draws it from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Luyck,</etym> a Cloyster, and <etym lang="bl">Dun,</etym> 
an Hill, or from <etym lang="bl">Lege Du&shy;
nen,</etym> from the lowness of the 
Hills.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Leyton(pn)">Leyton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Durolitum,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Town 
upon the River <etym lang="en">Ley.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lhan Badern Vaur(pn)">Lhan Badern vaur,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cardi&shy;
ganshire, that is to say, the 
Temple of Badern, the Great, 
or St. Badern the Bishop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lhanberon(pn)">Lhanberon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. not un&shy;
likely from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Lhan,</etym> 
a Church, and <etym lang="cb">Herwa</etym> to fly 
unto, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Sanctuary, or 
place of refuge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Libertas de Anstie(pn)">Libertas de Anstie,</form> <xpln lang="en">in York&shy;
shire, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="en">de Ancienty,</etym> 
which comes from the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Anciente,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Anti&shy;
quitas.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lichfield(pn)">Lichfield,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Staff. a Bishop's 
See. Beda writes it <etym lang="oe">Licid&shy;
feld,</etym> which signifieth the 
Field of dead Bodies, be&shy;
cause a great many here suf&shy;
fer'd Martyrdom in Diocle&shy;
sian's days. 'Tis derived from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lice</etym>, or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lich&shy;
nam,</etym> a dead Carcass, and 
<etym lang="en">Field.</etym> Somnerus, draws it 
<emend err="it"></emend>from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Liccian</etym>, to 
lick, and the same <etym lang="en">Field;</etym> 
because it is as it were, lick&shy;
ed by the River that runs 
by it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lid(pn)">Lid,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Devonshire, from 
thence Lidstow, a Market, 
and Lidford, a Village upon 
the Ford of Lid; see Stow, 
and Ford, in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Liege(pn)">Liege,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Liege,</etym> the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Luttich, Luttig,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Luck;</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Luick,</etym> 
a City, and Bishop's See, 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff5v">
of the Eburones. See Leedes. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Liffy(pn)">Liffy,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, by Ptolem. 
Libnius, by Gyrald, a Welsh&shy;
man, <etym lang="cb">Aven Liff,</etym> that is to 
say, the River <etym lang="cb">Liff.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lime(pn)">Lime,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, by Anton. it is 
called <etym lang="la">Portus Lemanis,</etym> by 
Ptolem. <etym lang="gk">&Lambda;&iota;&mu;&#x1F72;&nu;</etym>, a Port; whence 
Lime, a small Port in the 
County of Dorset, derives its 
Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lin(pn)">Lin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in the County of 
Nottingh. from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Lhin,</etym> a Lake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Linn(pn)" lexeme="King's Linn(pn)" lexeme="Linn Regis(pn)">Linn, King's Linn, or Linn 
Regis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Town and 
Port in the County of Norf. 
with water surrounding it, 
for the Britains meant thus 
much by their word <etym lang="br">Llyn;</etym> 
and <etym lang="la">Regis</etym> was added to it, 
because in the time of King 
John, and Henry the Third, 
the Inhabitants hereof va&shy;
liantly opposed the designs 
of some Rebels, maintain&shy;
ing their King's part to the 
last.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lincoln(pn)">Lincoln,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop's See; by 
Ptolem. and Anton. it is call'd 
<etym lang="la">Lindum,</etym> by Beda,<etym lang="la"> Lindecolli&shy;
num,</etym> in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lynde&shy;
collyne</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Lind cyl&shy;
lon-ceaster,</etym> in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Lindcoit;</etym> from <etym lang="cb">Llyn,</etym> a Lake, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Collyne</etym>, an 
Hill, because in the times of 
the English-Saxons it was all, 
or the greatest part of it built 
upon a Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lindisfarn(pn)">Lindisfarn,</form> <xpln lang="en">heretofore a Bi&shy;
shop's See; in the AS. 
call'd <etym lang="oe">Lindesfearona-ea</etym>, 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Isle of <etym lang="en">Lindisfarn,</etym> 
which is to this day call'd 
the Holy Island, from some 
Holy men and Monks that 
dwelt there; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Linde</etym>, a Linden tree, 
or <etym lang="oe">Lindene</etym>, made of Lin&shy;
den, and <etym lang="oe">Faer</etym>, an Entrance, 
or Fare, a way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lindsey(pn)">Lindsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnsh. the grea&shy;
test Quarter of this County, 
so call'd from <etym lang="la">Lindum,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Lin&shy;
coln</etym> its chief City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lionel(pn)">Lionel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name, from 
<etym lang="en">Lion,</etym> with the dim. Term. <etym lang="en">el</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a young Lion, or a 
little Lion. It answers to the 
Gr. Leontius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lisard Point(pn)">Lisard Point,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Cornw. perhaps so called from 
some likeness it hath to a 
<etym lang="en">Lizard;</etym> see Lizard in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lisle(pn)">Lisle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Isle</etym> an Isle, by put&shy;
ting before it L' with the 
note call'd Apostrophus. I 
suppose that it is rather de&shy;
rived from <etym lang="bl">L'isle,</etym> a famous 
City in Flanders.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Listithel(pn)">Listithel,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. by the In&shy;
habitants <etym lang="co">Lest. Vthiell,</etym> by 
Ptolem. called <etym lang="gkt">Uzella;</etym> the 
Town formerly stood on an 
Hill, but now in a Valley, 
so that it might be so call'd 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Uchel,</etym> 
high.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lith(pn)">Lith</form> <xpln lang="en">of Pickering, in York&shy;
shire, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Liberty</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff6r"> 
of Pickering, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Li&eth;</etym>, a Member. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lithquo(pn)" lexeme="Linlithquo(pn)">Lithquo or Linlithquo,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
<emend err="in"></emend>Scotland, from the neigh&shy;
bouring Lake <etym lang="en">Lin,</etym> which a&shy;
bounds with Fish.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Littleborough(pn)">Littleborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Notting. (i. e) a <etym lang="en">little</etym> <etym lang="en">Bo&shy;
rough</etym>, or Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Liuba(pn)">Liuba,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spanish 
Vice-Gothi, not unlikely, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Lufian</etym>, to love.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Liver(pn)">Liver,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Cornw. per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Li&eth;, 
Li&eth;er</etym>, Lither, or idle, be&shy;
cause it floweth calmly and 
slowly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Liverpool(pn)" lexeme="Lirpool(pn)">Liverpool or Lirpool,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port 
in the County of Lanc. from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Liferpoole</etym>, which 
comes from <etym lang="en">Liver,</etym> which 
see above, and <etym lang="en">Pool,</etym> which 
see in the Common Names; 
because it either is or was 
compassed about with Pools, 
or Ponds.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Logh Cure(pn)">Logh Cure</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotl. see <etym lang="en">Logh</etym> 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="London(pn)">London</form> <xpln lang="en">, England's Epitome, a 
City and Port inferiour to 
none in Europe. In Tacit. 
Ptolem. and Anton. it is call'd 
<etym lang="gkt">Londinum,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Longidinium,</etym> 
in Ammian. <etym lang="la">Lundinium,</etym> 
in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Lundayn,</etym> in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Lundenceaster, Lun&shy;
denbyrig</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Lunden&shy;
wyc</etym>, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Llong,</etym> 
Ships, and <etym lang="cb">Dinas,</etym> a City, in 
which sence it answers the 
Gr. <etym lang="gkt">Naustahmos</etym>, and <etym lang="gkt">Nauplia</etym>; 
or as Somner hath it, from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Llawn,</etym> full and 
populous, and the same <etym lang="cb">Di&shy;
nas,</etym> a City. This famous 
City, no ways inferiour to 
the greatest and most famous 
in all Europe, for riches and 
greatness, in the time of the 
Britains and Romans was an 
Arch-Bishop's See, but at 
the Arrival of the Saxons, it 
was deprived of this Honour, 
and, being made the Metro&shy;
polis or Mother-City, and 
the Archbishop's See, re&shy;
mov'd to Canterbury, it be&shy;
came only a Bishop's See.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Longobardi(pn)">Longobardi,</form> <xpln lang="en">a victorious Peo&shy;
ple. At first they were In&shy;
habitants of Germany, after 
that of Pannonia, and lastly 
of Italy. Many suppose, that 
they were so call'd from the 
length of their Beards, from 
the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Lang,</etym> Long, and 
<etym lang="gr">Bart,</etym> a Beard. Some draw 
it from <etym lang="la">Allebaudi,</etym> Halberts, 
which they used in times of 
War; See Halbert in the 
Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lonsdale(pn)">Lonsdale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Westm. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
<etym lang="en">Dale</etym> by the River <etym lang="en">Lon.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Loo(pn)">Loo,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in the County of 
Cornw. perhaps from the low&shy;
ness and shallowness of the 
water, or from the old words 
<etym lang="oe">Loo, Low, Logh,</etym> a Lake, 
(which last see in the Com. 
Names) because perhaps it 
standeth like a Pool.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Loopool(pn)">Loopool,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from <etym lang="oe">Loo,</etym> 
as above, and <etym lang="en">Pool;</etym> which see 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lopp(pn)">Lopp,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the English to 
<etym lang="en">Leap,</etym> because, saith Camden, 
it implieth such an uneven 
place as cannot be pass'd 
over without leaping; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Loppe</etym>, a Flea, or 
<etym lang="oe">Lop,</etym> according to the Lin&shy;
colnshire Dialect.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Loquaber(pn)" lexeme="Logh Aber(pn)">Loquaber, or Logh Aber,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Scotland, from <etym lang="sc">Logh,</etym> a Lake, 
which see in the Com. Names, 
and the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Aber,</etym> the 
mouth of a River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lora(pn)">Lora,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christ. Name of a 
Woman; from the obsolete 
word <etym lang="oe">Lore,</etym> which signifies 
Learning.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Loring(pn)">Loring,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, as much 
as the Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Lorain,</etym> or <etym lang="fr">le 
Lorain,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  of <etym lang="fr">Lorain.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lorty(pn)">Lorty,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">de l' Ortie,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  of 
the Nettle; and this from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Urtica,</etym> the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lothair(pn)">Lothair,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname from which 
came the Name <etym lang="en">Luther,</etym> ac&shy;
cording to Verstegan; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lauter,</etym> famous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lothbrook(pn)">Lothbrook,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Danes 
. Camden interpreteth it, Lea&shy;
ther Breeches.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lothild(pn)" lexeme="Clothild(pn)" lexeme="Clothildis(pn)">Lothild, or Clothild, or Clo&shy;
thildis;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Le&shy;
ode</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> People, 
and <etym lang="tt">Helde,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Helduine,</etym> a 
Lady, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Lady much be&shy;
loved of the People, the Peo&shy;
ples Darling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Love(pn)">Love,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Loup,</etym> a Wolf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lovell(pn)">Lovell,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Louvel,</etym> a 
Sirname, the dim, of <etym lang="fr">Loup,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a little Wolf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Louvet(pn)">Louvet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Louvet,</etym> a young Wolf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lough Regit(pn)">Lough Regit,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, a 
<etym lang="en">Lough</etym> upon which stood a 
Town by Ptol. called <etym lang="gk">Rigia,</etym> 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Luh</etym>, or Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Logh,</etym> a Lake.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lough(pn)">Lough,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Scotland, from 
the same root.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Loughborough(pn)">Loughborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Leicester, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Lig, Lige</etym>, a flame, per&shy;
haps from some Fire happen&shy;
ing there; or from some 
<etym lang="en">Lough</etym> or Pool near the place, 
and <etym lang="en">Borough,</etym> which see in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Louvre(pn)">Louvre,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Palace of the 
King of France; from the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">L'ouvre,</etym> (i. e) the Work or 
Fabrick so call'd, &Kappa;&alpha;&tau;' &#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;, 
for the Curious workmanship 
thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ludfrid(pn)">Ludfrid,</form> <xpln lang="en">Versteg. draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> 
the People, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;, Frede,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> 
Peace, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one that reform&shy;
eth the Disorders of the Peo&shy;
ple, and settles 'em in Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ludgate(pn)">Ludgate,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Gate of the City 
of London, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Fludgate,</etym> 
from a little River that for&shy;
merly ran under it; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Luc</etym>, false, and <etym lang="en">Gate,</etym> 
that is to say, a False Port; 
or as the eminent Th. H. in&shy;
geniously surmiseth, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, the People, and 
<etym lang="en">Gate,</etym> as Porto del popolo Rom&aelig;, 
not from one <etym lang="br">Ludd</etym> a King of 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff7r">
the Britains, as is vulgarly 
believ'd from the Informa&shy;
tions of several ancient Chro&shy;
nicles. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ludovic(pn)" lexeme="Lodowick(pn)">Ludovic, or Lodowick,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Chri&shy;
sten-Name; see <etym lang="en">Lewis,</etym> a&shy;
bove.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ludulph(pn)" lexeme="Ludolph(pn)">Ludulph, or Ludolph,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> 
the People, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, Help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Luitbald(pn)">Luitbald,</form> <xpln lang="en">Duke of Bavaria, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Leod</etym>, Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> People, and <etym lang="tt">Bald,</etym> 
Bold; that is, valorous a&shy;
mong, or for, the People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Luitbert(pn)">Luitbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Longo&shy;
bardi of Italy, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Luit,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> AS. <etym lang="oe">Le&shy;
ode</etym>, the People, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous or bright, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Illustrious in his Peo&shy;
ple, or the light of his 
People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Luitgard(pn)" lexeme="Luidhard(pn)">Luitgard, or Luidhard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bi&shy;
shop, Chaplain to Bertha 
Queen of France, then Wife of 
Ethelbert, the first Christian 
King of Kent, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leode</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> former&shy;
ly <etym lang="tt">Luit,</etym> the People, and 
<etym lang="oe">Gard,</etym> which see in the 
Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Luitprand(pn)">Luitprand,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy, from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Luit,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Leute,</etym> AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leode</etym>, the People, and our 
English <etym lang="en">Brand,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  Fire&shy;
brand, according to Aventi&shy;
nus, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  One that set the 
People at variance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lumbard-street(pn)">Lumbard-street,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Street in 
London, so called either from 
some Merchants of <etym lang="en">Lombardy</etym> 
in Italy that liv'd here, or 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Lumber Street,</etym> that is 
to say, a Street where old 
Garments or such like Lum&shy;
ber, was vented in former 
times; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lum&shy;
pe,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Lompe,</etym> a 
Rag, or Tatter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Luxenburg(pn)">Luxenburg,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County Town 
in the Netherlands, perhaps 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Luchs,</etym> a 
Libbard, and <etym lang="tt">Burg,</etym> a Castle, 
or City, from the Plenty 
of those sort of Creatures 
there.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>
</page> 

<page sig="Ff7v"> 
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="M"><alpha>M</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mab(pn)">MAb,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, also 
the Name of the Queen of Fairys. I 
suppose, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">M&acirc;b,</etym> a Child, or a 
little Boy, for those terre&shy;
strial Elfs, are imagin'd to 
take upon them the shapes 
of little Children, the better 
to invite the Eyes of the 
Beholders.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mabel(pn)">Mabel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christen-&shy;
Name; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Ama&shy;
bilis,</etym> amiable; or, as some 
will have it, from the Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">ma Belle,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">mia 
Bella</etym> my fair one, my Dar&shy;
ling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Macquire(pn)">Macquire,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, per&shy;
haps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Mag&shy;
wyr,</etym> barrenness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Machlin(pn)" lexeme="Mechlin(pn)">Machlin, Mechlin,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Malines,</etym> and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Me&shy;
cheln;</etym> a County, and Arch-&shy;
Bishop's See in the Nether&shy;
lands, perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Maeckelen,</etym> to pass over, to 
traffick, to wit from the 
great Trading of several 
Countries thereto.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mac Mahon(pn)">Mac Mahon,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Irish Sir&shy;
name ; by interpretation, a 
Bear's Whelp.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Madoc(pn)">Madoc,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Brit. Proper name, 
Camden draws it from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">M&acirc;d,</etym> good, and the 
Latin <etym lang="la">Occa,</etym> an Harrow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maedhart(pn)">Maedhart,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christ. 
Name, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Maiden Heart,</etym> 
from our English <etym lang="en">Maid</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Heart,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
Nature, or disposition of 
Mind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Magdeburg(pn)">Magdeburg,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City in 
Germany, formerly the Me&shy;
tropolis;---from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Magd</etym> in the Pl. <etym lang="tt">Magden,</etym> 
a Maid, and <etym lang="tt">Burg,</etym> a City, 
or Fort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maiden Bradley(pn)">Maiden Bradley</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltshire, 
from a Noble young Woman, 
a Virgin, who being seiz'd 
with the Leprosy her self, 
built here an Hospital for 
such as should be taken with 
the like Disease for the fu&shy;
ture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maiden-head(pn)">Maiden-head,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Coun&shy;
ty of Berks, at first cal&shy;
led Southealington, after 
that <etym lang="oe">Maiden hyth;</etym> so call'd 
from the Superstitious ado&shy;
ring the <etym lang="en">head</etym> of a certain 
British <etym lang="en">Maid,</etym> one of the 
11 Thousand Companions 
of Ursula. It was before 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff8r"> 
call'd Southealington, from 
South, Ea, the Dim. Ter&shy;
mination ling, and Town, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a small Town lying 
Southward by the waters 
side; see Ea. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maidstone(pn)">Maidstone,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent hereto&shy;
fore <etym lang="oe">Medweageston,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="en">Medways</etym> Town, from the 
River <etym lang="en">Medway,</etym> running close 
by it; but by Corr. Maid&shy;
stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mainard(pn)">Mainard,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, but now a Sirname. 
Verstegan draws it from 
<etym lang="en">Man,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Heart,</etym> that is, 
one that hath the Heart of a 
Man, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  stout hearted; or 
from <etym lang="en">Man</etym> and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Nature. Aventinus 
seemeth to draw it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Meine,</etym> mine, and 
the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">hard,</etym> AS. 
 <etym lang="oe">Hord</etym>, a Treasure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Malc(pn)">Malc,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, formerly 
<etym lang="ir">Macolicum.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maldon(pn)">Maldon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, by Tacitus 
and several others called <etym lang="la">Ca
malodunum;</etym> by Anton. <etym lang="la">Camu
lodunum;</etym> in the AS. it is 
call'd <etym lang="oe">Maledune</etym>, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Meal
dune</etym>, from <etym lang="br">Camulus,</etym> or 
<etym lang="br">Camalus,</etym> a God of the Bri&shy;
tans, (the same with Mars 
of the Romans,) and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, a Mount, or Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Malleverer(pn)">Malleverer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, possi&shy;
bly from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mal,</etym> 
evil, and <etym lang="fr">Levrier,</etym> a Grey&shy;
hound, or Hunter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mallobaudes(pn)">Mallobaudes,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Mael,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mahl,</etym> a Meal, 
and the obsolete word <etym lang="tt">Be&shy;
haud,</etym> an Upholder, from 
<etym lang="tt">Hauden,</etym> now <etym lang="tt">Houden,</etym> to 
uphold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mallory(pn)">Mallory,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mal,</etym> bad, and <etym lang="fr">Lievre,</etym> 
an Hare.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mallovel(pn)">Mallovel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mal,</etym> ill, and <etym lang="en">Lovell,</etym> which 
see above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Malmesbury(pn)">Malmesbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Wilts, built by <etym lang="br">Malmutius</etym> a K. 
of the Britains, says Skinner, 
but questions whether there 
ever was any such man. By 
the Brit. it was call'd here&shy;
tofore <etym lang="br">Caer Bladon</etym>, after that 
Ingelborn, then <etym lang="br">Maidulfes&shy;
burg,</etym> from <etym lang="br">Maidulph,</etym> (a 
Scotish Saint and Hermit 
that built an Abby there, and 
opened the Publick School,) 
and <etym lang="oe">Bury,</etym> a Town; whence 
for shortness it begun to be 
call'd <etym lang="oe">Malmesbury</etym>. Beda 
calls it Adelmesbirig, from 
Adelm Scholar to Mai&shy;
dulph, and the first Abbot 
of that Abby. Maidulph 
may be drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">M&aelig;den</etym>, a Maiden, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Malpas(pn)">Malpas,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cheshire, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mal,</etym> ill, and <etym lang="en">Pass,</etym> which 
see in the Common Names, 
in the AS. it is written 
<etym lang="oe">Depenbach</etym>, from <etym lang="oe">Deope</etym>, 
deep, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Becc</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bach</etym>, 
a Brook, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a bad way, 
or deep passage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mancester(pn)">Mancester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Maen,</etym> a Stone, and the 
</page> 

<page sig="Ff8v">
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a Town, 
possibly from the great Quar&shy;
ry of Stones there. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Manchester(pn)">Manchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">a rich Town of 
Trade in the County of 
Lancaster, in the Neigh&shy;
bouring places call'd Man&shy;
castle; deriv'd from the C. &shy;
Br. <etym lang="cb">Maen</etym> or <etym lang="cb">Mana</etym> a Stone, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mandevill(pn)">Mandevill,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; in the 
Lat. Barb. it is written <etym lang="la">Mag&shy;
na Villa,</etym> in the Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Magne 
ville,</etym> from whence by cor&shy;
ruption Mandevill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Manfred(pn)">Manfred,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of Naples and 
Sicily, from <etym lang="en">Man,</etym> and the 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Friede, Frede,</etym> Peace, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Pacifyer of Men, or 
one, that makes it his Bu&shy;
siness to keep his Subjects in 
Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mannours(pn)">Mannours,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
of the <etym lang="en">Mannors,</etym> from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Manoir,</etym> a Mannor, or 
Farm.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mansfield(pn)">Mansfield,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Nottingh. from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Maen,</etym> a Stone, and 
<etym lang="en">Field;</etym> or more simply from 
the old AS. <etym lang="oe">Mangian</etym>, to 
Trade, or Traffick, and the 
same <etym lang="en">Field,</etym> because it was, 
and is a place of great Trade. 
Some report, that it gave 
name to the Mansfelts, 
Counts of Germany.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Manwaring(pn)">Manwaring,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, not 
unlikely from our word <etym lang="en">Man,</etym> and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wa&shy;
ren, Wehren,</etym> to protect; 
see Ward in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mapletoft(pn)">Mapletoft,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mapul</etym>, a Maple, and 
<etym lang="oe">toft</etym>, a tuft, or top.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maraboduns(pn)">Maraboduns,</form> <xpln lang="en">(in the time of 
the Emperours Tiberius, and 
Caligula) King of the Suevi-&shy;
Marcomanni, in Germany; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re, Mare</etym>, a 
Mare, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Bott,</etym> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Bode,</etym> a Messenger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marcomanni(pn)">Marcomanni,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People of Ger&shy;
many, a Tribe of the Suevi, 
that heretofore took into 
Possession part of Bohemia, 
and Moravia, and in the time 
of the Emperour Marcus 
greatly invaded the Roman 
Empire, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Markman, 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  Men of the Marches, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mearc</etym>, Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Marck,</etym> Teut. <etym lang="tt">Merck,</etym> a 
Mark, or Limit, and <etym lang="en">Man,</etym> 
a man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marcomirus(pn)">Marcomirus,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the 
Franks of Sicambria, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Marck,</etym> a Mark, and 
<etym lang="bl">Meyer,</etym> a Major, according 
to Jun. and so it implieth 
the same that our word 
Marquess; which see in 
the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Margerie(pn)">Margerie,</form> <xpln lang="en">some suppose, that 
it is the same with <etym lang="en">Mar&shy;
garet,</etym> and if so, it may be 
drawn from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Marga&shy;
rita,</etym> a Pearl; others derive 
it from <etym lang="la">Marjoria,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Marjorana,</etym> 
the Herb <etym lang="en">Marjoram,</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marlborough(pn)">Marlborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Wilts, from our word 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg1v"> 
<etym lang="en">Marl,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  fat soil, and 
<etym lang="en">Borough;</etym> or rather from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Marl</etym>, Chalk; for 
it standeth upon a chalky, 
clammy Soil; or as some 
will have it, from that fabu&shy;
lous Prophet <etym lang="en">Merlin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marlow(pn)">Marlow,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Bucks; from <etym lang="oe">Marl,</etym> Chalk, 
and <etym lang="oe">Lea,</etym> Ground, (which 
see in the Common Names,) 
or <etym lang="oe">Ea,</etym> water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marmaduc(pn)">Marmaduc,</form> <xpln lang="en">a feigned Christ. 
Name; as Camden saith, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mare M&aelig;htig</etym>, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mehu Mach&shy;
tig,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) more mighty; and 
<etym lang="la">Dux,</etym> a Captain, or our word 
<etym lang="en">Duke.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Marn(pn)">Marn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County in Scotland, 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mara</etym>, 
Marches, or Bounds.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Charles Martel(pn)">Charles Martel,</form> <xpln lang="en">that invinci&shy;
ble French Captain; from the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Marteau,</etym> formerly 
<etym lang="fr">Martel,</etym> a Hammer, or the It. <etym lang="it">Martello</etym> the same; and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Marculus,</etym> 
a little Mallet; which deri&shy;
vation of his Name he vindi&shy;
cated by his hammering the 
Saracens, at that time ma&shy;
king War with the French.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maseras(pn)">Maseras,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spa&shy;
nish Suevi, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mause,</etym> a scarr, and <etym lang="tt">Tres&shy;
chen,</etym> to beat; so called, 
from the Scars he had in his 
Body.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mathasuenta(pn)">Mathasuenta,</form> <xpln lang="en">Wife to Vitigis, 
King of the Ostro-Gothi of Ita&shy;
ly; perhaps from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Matt,</etym> slender, and the ob&shy;
solete word <etym lang="tt">Swenth,</etym> a 
Wench, according to Jun. 
See Wench in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Matison(pn)">Matison,</form> <xpln lang="en">and <etym lang="en">Madison,</etym> a 
Sirname, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Son</etym> of 
<etym lang="en">Matthew;</etym> or as the famous 
Th. H. rather fansies, the 
Son of <etym lang="en">Matilda,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Mathil&shy;
dis.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mattiaci(pn)">Mattiaci,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People 
of the Netherlands, formerly 
the Inhabitants of the Coun&shy;
try now call'd Zealand. Adr. 
Junius draws it from <etym lang="bl">Mat,</etym> or 
as they now write it, <etym lang="bl">Maet,</etym> 
a Mate, which was a fami&shy;
liar Appellation whereby 
they signify'd their good will 
one to another.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maud(pn)">Maud,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen-Name of 
a Woman, the same that 
<etym lang="bl">Mathildis,</etym> which is drawn 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maecht,</etym> a 
Maid, and <etym lang="bl">Helde,</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Hilde,</etym> 
a Lady; that is to say, a 
Maid of Honour, a Princess.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Maugre(pn)">Maugre,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
see <etym lang="en">Maugre</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Manley(pn)">Manley,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, not un&shy;
likely from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mal,</etym> 
bad, and <etym lang="fr">Lieu,</etym> a place, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
born in a bad Clime, or bar&shy;
ren part of a Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Mawes(pn)">St. Mawes,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Cornwall (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Church 
of St. <etym lang="ir">Mawe,</etym> an Irish Bishop.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Maze(pn)">The Maze,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous River of 
France, the Netherlands, and 
Germany; see Mosa, beneath.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg1v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mean-borough(pn)">Mean-Borough,</form> <xpln lang="en">also East, 
West-Mean in Hantsh. from 
the <etym lang="la">Meanvari,</etym> a People men&shy;
tion'd in Beda; which possi&shy;
bly may be drawn from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Menn,</etym> a Wagon, Cart, 
or Coach, and <etym lang="cb">Gwar,</etym> a Neck.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Meares(pn)">Meares,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; either 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, a 
Marsh, or <etym lang="oe">Mara</etym>, Marches, 
or Limits.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Meath(pn)">Meath,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County in Ireland, 
by the Inhabitants call'd 
<etym lang="ir">Miith,</etym> by Girald, in Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Media</etym>, because it is proba&shy;
bly in the Middle of Ireland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Meckleborough(pn)">Meckleborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mechel burg,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
Megalopolis, or great City 
of Germany; so call'd from 
the largeness thereof, from 
<etym lang="en">Mickle,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  much, and 
<etym lang="en">Borough,</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Medemenham(pn)">Medemenham;</form> <xpln lang="en">not unlikely 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Medeme</etym>, 
mean, in another sence, wor&shy;
thy, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, a Village.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Medeshamsted(pn)">Medeshamsted,</form> <xpln lang="en">the old Name 
of a Bishop's See, now call'd 
Peterborough; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">M&aelig;de, Med,</etym> a Mead, 
<etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, a Village, and <etym lang="oe">Steda, 
Stede</etym>, a place; to wit, from 
the Meads laying on each 
side thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Medley(pn)">Medley,</form> <xpln lang="en">now Midgley in 
Yorkshire, in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mede&shy;
ly</etym>, because it lyeth in the 
mid'st as it were, between 
two Rivers. Hence the An&shy;
cient Family of the Midgleys 
took its Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Medway(pn)">Medway,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Kent, perhaps from the Pa&shy;
stures and Meadows it run&shy;
neth close by; see <etym lang="en">Mead,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Way,</etym> in the Com. Names. 
Somner supposeth it so call'd, 
because it runs through the 
<etym lang="en">middle</etym> of Kent; see Middle, 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Melton Mowbray(pn)">Melton Mowbray,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
County of Leicester, from the 
<etym lang="en">Mowbrays,</etym> formerly Land&shy;
lords thereof; and <etym lang="en">Melton,</etym> 
which comes either from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Meldian</etym>, to betray, 
or from the Eng. to <etym lang="en">Melt,</etym> 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  from melting Metals, 
for which Art perhaps it was 
heretofore accounted fa&shy;
mous; or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mele</etym>, 
a Cup, because the place was 
perhaps famed for the Pro&shy;
fession of Cup-making. Or 
as Dr. Th. H. supposeth, from 
<etym lang="en">Mell,</etym> which in Kent is yet 
used for a Mill; so that 
Melton may be so call'd q. 
Mill-Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mentz(pn)">Mentz,</form> <xpln lang="en">by Tacit. and Ammian. 
call'd <etym lang="la">Magantiacum,</etym> by Eutrop. 
<etym lang="la">Moguntia.</etym> 'Tis a famous City 
of Germany, an Arch-Bishop's 
See, who is generally Elector 
of the German Empire. In the 
time of Aurelian the Empe&shy;
ror, it begun to be for short&shy;
ness, call'd <etym lang="la">Montiacum,</etym> and 
after that Mentz, which name 
it still retains.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mephistophiles(pn)">Mephistophiles,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Hellish Imp. 
Dr. Faustus's Page, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="gk">Me&shy;
phitophilus,</etym> (says Dr. Skinner) 
a lover of a rawmish or sul&shy;
phureous smell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Meraud(pn)">Meraud,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name of 
Woman frequent in Cornwall; 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Esmeraude,</etym> by 
them call'd Meraud, with 
us Emerauld, which see in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mercia(pn)">Mercia,</form> <xpln lang="en">the greatest Kingdom 
of the Heptarchy, call'd in 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mearclond</etym>, from 
<etym lang="oe">Mearc</etym>, a Mark, or Limit; 
because it was bounded on 
every side to keep it safe 
from the inroads of any of 
the other Six Kingdoms of 
the English Heptarchy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Meredith(pn)">Meredith,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Merweyridd,</etym> the 
roaring of the Sea; says 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merionethshire(pn)">Merionethshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Sire Verioneth,</etym> in the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Mervinia,</etym> a County in Wales.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merkin(pn)">Merkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a dangerous Port in 
Cornwall, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Jove's Mar&shy;
ket, so called from the ma&shy;
ny Storms arising therein.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merlin(pn)">Merlin,</form> <xpln lang="en">he whom the Welsh 
cry up so much for the gift 
of Prophecy; from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Maehr, Maehre,</etym> a Fa&shy;
ble, whence <etym lang="tt">Mahr Lein</etym>, 
a little Fable; these from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Maere</etym>, famous. 
This Etymology seems apt 
enough, if ever there was 
such a man, which I am not 
so apt to believe, by reason 
of the many fabulous Stories 
which are blown about con&shy;
cerning him.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mernerfridus(pn)">Mernerfridus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Prince of the 
Turingi; Junius thus ex&shy;
pounds it, <etym lang="bl">Meerner des fri&shy;
des,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Author of 
Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merouee(pn)">Merouee,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Third King of 
the Franks. Adr. Jun. draws 
it from <etym lang="bl">Meroua,</etym> a River in 
Holland, where he assigns to 
the ancient French their first 
Seat and beginning. I might 
also draw it from the Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Meyer,</etym> a Mayor, and <etym lang="gr">Weg</etym> 
a Way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merric(pn)">Merric,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name among 
the Welsh; Camden suppo&shy;
seth, that it is a corruption 
of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mauritius,</etym> with us 
Maurice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mersh Ware(pn)">Mersh Ware,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County 
of Kent, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) in the AS. 
Inhabitants of the Marshes, 
for so were the Inhabitants 
of the place call'd Rumney 
Marsh formerly named, 
from <etym lang="oe">Mersc</etym>, a Marsh, and 
<etym lang="oe">Waer</etym>, a Man, in the Plural 
<etym lang="oe">Wara</etym>, Men.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merton(pn)">Merton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, a Marsh, and 
<etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, a Bank, or <etym lang="oe">tun</etym>, a 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merwald(pn)">Merwald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, famous, and <etym lang="oe">Weal&shy;
dan</etym>, to rule; and so by in&shy;
terpretation it may signifie, an 
illustrious Prince, or Ruler.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Merwin(pn)">Merwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, glo&shy;
rious, and <etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Conqueror, 
or <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to conquer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mesnill(pn)" lexeme="Menill(pn)">Mesnill, or Menill,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sir&shy;
name; from the old Fr. 
Norm. <etym lang="no">Mesnil,</etym> an House; and 
this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mansio,</etym> a 
Mansion, or place of a&shy;
bode.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Metaris(pn)">Metaris,</form> <xpln lang="en">heretofore in the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Maltraith,</etym> a place, where 
the Waters Ebb and Flow 
upon the Coast. of Norfolk, 
and not far from Lincolnshire, 
now call'd the Washes; per&shy;
haps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Mall,</etym> 
corrupt, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) muddy, and 
<etym lang="cb">Traide,</etym> a Passage, or Ford; 
this from <etym lang="cb">Treiddio,</etym> to Ferry 
over.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mews(pn)">Mews,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, possibly 
from the Episcopal seat in 
France, call'd <etym lang="fr">Meaux.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Michelgrove(pn)">Michelgrove,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suss. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the great Grove; See <etym lang="en">Mic&shy;
kle,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Grove,</etym> in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Micklethwaight(pn)">Micklethwaight,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, 
from our word <etym lang="en">Mickle,</etym> or 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Micl</etym>, much, and 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;weaht</etym>, washed, a Parti&shy;
ciple of the Verb <etym lang="oe">&ETH;wean</etym>, 
to wash. Camden draws it 
from the said <etym lang="oe">Micl</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Micel</etym>, 
great, and <etym lang="oe">Hwoit</etym>, which, 
he says, signifies a Pasture; 
See Thwaight in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Middleborough(pn)">Middleborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Middelburg,</etym> a famous City 
in Zealand, so call'd, because 
it stands in the middle of 
Walachia.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Middleton(pn)">Middleton,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Middle-&shy;
Town</etym> in Dorsetshire; former&shy;
ly famous for an Abby ere&shy;
cted there by King Ethelstan, 
for Expiation of the Murder 
of Edwin his Brother.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Milburg(pn)" lexeme="Milborough(pn)">Milburg, or Milborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">the 
Christen-Name of a Woman. 
Verstegan draws it from the 
AS. and Eng. <etym lang="en">Mild,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Burg,</etym> a Town, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  kind to 
her Towns-folk: or it may 
be derived from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Mild,</etym> &amp; <etym lang="oe">Borge</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Borh</etym>, 
a Bondsman, in a seconda&shy;
ry sence.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mildred(pn)">Mildred,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen-Name 
of a Woman, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Milde</etym>, mild, and, the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Reden,</etym> to speak; or from 
the same <etym lang="oe">Milde</etym>, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, Counsel, (i. e.) mild 
in Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Miles(pn)">Miles,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Milo,</etym> or from <etym lang="la">Mili&shy;
um</etym> millet; as Fabius, from fa&shy;
ba, a Bean, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Millet(pn)">Millet,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Diminutive of the 
Christen-Name <etym lang="en">Miles,</etym> says 
Cambden. Some also draw it 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Millet;</etym> as Cice&shy;
ro, &agrave; Cicere, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Pease.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Milton(pn)">Milton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Kent, by some a Contract of 
<etym lang="en">Middleton:</etym> Others draw it 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Mola,</etym> a Mill, 
q. Mill-Town; see Mill 
in the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Minours(pn)">Minours,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; possibly 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg3r"> 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mineur,</etym> a 
Miner, a Digger in a Mine. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Modbery(pn)">Modbery,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Devonshire, either from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mod, Mode</etym>, Valour, and Bury, a Town: or, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Mudbury,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="en">Muddybury</etym>; See Mud, in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Moigne(pn)">Moigne,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname. It alludes to the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Moine,</etym> a Monk.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mole(pn)">Mole,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Surrey; so 
call'd, because like a <etym lang="en">Mole</etym>, 
or Want, it forceth its pas&shy;
sage under Ground, and 
thereby mixes its Water 
with the River of Thames.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Molesey(pn)">Molesey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Surrey; from the River <etym lang="en">Mole,</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">ea</etym>, water, or 
waterish Ground; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Mole's 
Water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Molines(pn)">Molines,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, formerly 
<etym lang="en">de Molines;</etym> derived from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Moulin,</etym> or the It. <etym lang="it">Mo&shy;
lino,</etym> a Mill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Molineux(pn)">Molineux,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname: (i e.) 
Molitor, a Miller; derived as 
<etym lang="fr">Molines</etym> before.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Monmouthshire(pn)">Monmouthshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly 
called Wentset, and Wen&shy;
sland, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Went, 
Setas</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Inhabi&shy;
tants of the Country called 
Went, which is a Corrup&shy;
<emend err="rup"></emend>tion of Venta, the name 
of the chief Town in the 
County, and which was by 
the Britains call'd <etym lang="br">Caer Guent</etym>. 
Leland, draws 'em both from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gwynn</etym>, white, 
which he might do perhaps 
from the colour of the Soil. 
It now takes its Name from 
<etym lang="en">Monmouth,</etym> the County 
Town; memorable for the 
Birth of that invincible 
Prince, Henry the Fifth; which 
in the C. Br. is call'd <etym lang="cb">Mongwy,</etym> 
from the Rivers <etym lang="cb">Munow</etym> 
and <etym lang="cb">Wy,</etym> at the meeting of 
which it is seated. And there&shy;
fore call'd Monmouth; q. 
Munow's <etym lang="en">mouth</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montchensey(pn)">Montchensey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mont Chesneux,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Mount beset, or 
Planted with Oaks, says 
Skinner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montfichet(pn)">Montfichet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; so 
called <etym lang="la">&agrave; Monte fixo,</etym> from a 
Mount that stands firmly, 
unmoveable; or from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mont,</etym> a Mount, and <etym lang="fr">Fichet,</etym> 
a Graff.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montfort(pn)">Montfort,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Fr. G. 
<etym lang="fr">de Mont fort,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of a for&shy;
tified Mount. There is also 
a Town in Holland of the 
same Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montgomery(pn)">Montgomery,</form> <xpln lang="en">from Roger de 
<etym lang="en">Montgomery,</etym> E. of Shrewsb. 
that subdued the Country 
and built the Castle: Born 
in France, and took his Name 
from Montgomery, in that 
Kingdom: So call'd, q. <etym lang="la">Mons 
Gomeris,</etym> the Mount of <etym lang="fr">Go&shy;
mer.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Monthermer(pn)">Monthermer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; By 
interpretat. <etym lang="en">Hermer's Mount,</etym> 
or Mount of Hermer. Or <etym lang="la">Mons 
Eremit&aelig;,</etym> q. Hermits-Hill, or 
Mount.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montjoy(pn)">Montjoy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">Mons Jovis,</etym> or Jove's Mount. 
Skinner draws it from the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Mont,</etym> a Mount, and <etym lang="fr">Joye,</etym> Joy. 
See Ioy, in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montperson(pn)">Montperson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; pos&shy;
sibly a Contraction for 
<etym lang="fr">Mont Peterson,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">Mount</etym> of <etym lang="en">Peter</etym> 's <etym lang="en">Son</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montross(pn)">Montross</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">Mount</etym> of <etym lang="en">Roses</etym>; Some draw 
it from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Mont-Rosse,</etym> 
the Horses Mount; others 
from <etym lang="en">Mount,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ros,</etym> 
by the Britains taken for 
Heath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montsorrel(pn)">Montsorrel,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Leicestershire; 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mont,</etym> a Mount, 
and the River <etym lang="en">Sora</etym> that runs 
near it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Moorgate(pn)">Moorgate,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Gates of 
the City of London; so call'd 
from a Marsh or <etym lang="en">Moor</etym> that 
formerly was hard by it, 
but now dried up; and 
<etym lang="en">Gate.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Moravia(pn)">Moravia,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mahren,</etym> 
and by Contraction <etym lang="tt">Marn.</etym> 
It was heretofore the Seat of 
the Quadi, and the <etym lang="tt">Marco&shy;
manni;</etym> from which last, I 
suppose it had this Name: 
Or it may be drawn from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, famous, for 
that the Marcomanni were re&shy;
nown'd above any other 
the Inhabitants under the 
Empire of Germany, for war&shy;
like Exploits; witness their 
Conquest over the Roman 
Empire, in the time of the 
Emperor Marcus, and their 
wasting even Italy it self with 
Fire and Sword, almost to the 
very Gates of Rome.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Morgan(pn)">Morgan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Mor,</etym> the 
Sea, and <etym lang="cb">Gan,</etym> born; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
born by the Sea side. It was 
formerly, and not without 
some colour, taken to be the 
same with the Gr. Pelagius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Morice(pn)">Morice,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, in 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Mauritius;</etym> this from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Maurus,</etym> a Moor; and 
this again from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&mu;&alpha;&nu;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym> dark, obscure.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mortimer(pn)">Mortimer,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mort,</etym> dead, and 
<etym lang="fr">Mer,</etym> the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mortlack(pn)">Mortlack,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Surrey, 
upon the side of the Thames, 
either <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Mortuus La&shy;
cus,</etym> a dead Lake; or from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mor&eth;</etym>, Death, and 
<etym lang="oe">Lac</etym>, a Victim.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mosa(pn)">Mosa,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Belg. <etym lang="bl">de Mase,</etym> 
and <etym lang="bl">Maes,</etym> the Teut. <etym lang="tt">d'et 
Maasz,</etym> and in the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Meuse;</etym> 'tis a famous River, 
running through Germany, 
and the Netherlands. Per&shy;
haps originally from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Maes,</etym> as, <etym lang="bl">Maes-hout</etym>, 
a Maple-tree, from the great 
plenty thereof growing upon 
the Banks of it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mougrave Castle(pn)">Mougrave Castle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; 
possibly from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Moult 
Grace,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  much Grace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Montague(pn)">Montague,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Mont Aigu,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg4r">
the sharp top'd Mountain. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mount Norris(pn)">Mount Norris,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fort in Ire&shy;
land, erected by Charles 
Montjoy, in memory of 
the most courageous <etym lang="en">John 
Norris,</etym> Knight, under whom 
Montjoy serv'd as a Volon&shy;
tier.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mowbray(pn)">Mowbray,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; per&shy;
haps, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mowe,</etym> 
an Heap, and <etym lang="oe">Br&aelig;de</etym>, by 
Chaucer <etym lang="oe">Brede,</etym> Bread.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Muckelney(pn)">Muckelney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somersetshire, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the great Isle, caus'd 
by the meeting together of the Rivers Ivell and Pedrid; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Micel</etym>, great, 
or <etym lang="sc">Mickle</etym> as they say in 
Scotl. and elsewhere, and <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
Water, or Land encompassed 
with Water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Mullins(pn)">Mullins,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; formerly 
<etym lang="en">de Mullins;</etym> from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mou&shy;
lin,</etym> a Mill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Muschamp(pn)">Muschamp,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mousche,</etym> a Fly, and <etym lang="fr">Champ,</etym> 
a Field; or rather, as the lear&shy;
ned Th. H. tells us, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Mousse,</etym> Moss, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Moss-&shy;
Field.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="N"><alpha>N</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Naerdem(pn)">NAerdem,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City in 
Holland, memorable 
for a great Slaugh&shy;
ter made by the 
Spanish, contrary to their 
Covenant. It may be drawn 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Nae, Naer,</etym> 
near, and <etym lang="bl">Dem</etym> for <etym lang="bl">Dam,</etym> 
a Wear, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a City upon 
the Wears; or from the same 
<etym lang="bl">Naer,</etym> near, and <etym lang="bl">Deme, De&shy;
men,</etym> a Cows Udder.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Naples(pn)">Naples,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City in Cam&shy;
pania, from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Naples,</etym> 
or the It. <etym lang="it">Napoli,</etym> and all from 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Nu;&epsilon;&#x1F71;&pi;&omicron;&lambda;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, (i. e.) the 
new City. It began to be so 
called in the time of the se&shy;
cond Punick War, as Livy 
writeth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neal(pn)">Neal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; a 
Contract of the Lat. <etym lang="la">Nigellus.</etym> 
It is now a Sirname.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neath(pn)">Neath,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glam. by Anton. 
call'd <etym lang="la">Urbs Nidum</etym>; and the River 
Neath, Nidus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neccar(pn)">Neccar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Necker</etym> 
by Flav. Vopisc. in the life of 
Marc. Aurel. Val. Prob. called 
Nicer, or Nicrus; a famous 
River in Germany.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Needes(pn)">Saint Needes,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Huntindon. 
</page>

<page sig="Gg4v"> 
(i. e) the Church of St. Need, 
who died in this Town; it 
being before called Aines&shy;
bury, which might be taken 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Agen</etym>, 
ones own, and Bury; which 
see in the Com. Names. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neene(pn)">Neene,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a River, 
according to Leland; 'tis cor&shy;
rupted from <etym lang="en">Avene,</etym> and this 
from <etym lang="en">Avon.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nelson(pn)">Nelson,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Son of <etym lang="en">Neal,</etym> 
which see above; or from 
<etym lang="en">Nell</etym> for <etym lang="en">Eleanor,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Son;</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Eleanor's Son.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nemetes(pn)">Nemetes,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Ancient People 
of Germany. Ortelius saith, 
that the Sclavonians call all 
the Germans <etym lang="sl">Nemiz,</etym> that the 
Turks call them <etym lang="tu">Nimzi,</etym> the 
Hungar. <etym lang="hn">Nemet,</etym> and the Bo&shy;
hem. <etym lang="bo">Nemec;</etym> and these per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Neh&shy;
men,</etym> to take away, to steal, 
because this People lived by 
Robberies, Piracies, and Ra&shy;
pines.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nese(pn)" lexeme="N&aelig;se(pn)">Nese or N&aelig;se,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Foreland in 
Kent, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Nose of Land; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">N&aelig;se, Nese</etym>, 
a Promontory, or Nose.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nest(pn)">Nest,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christ Name, 
frequent among the Welsh: 
'Tis supposed to be a Con&aelig;
tract. or corrup. of the Lat. 
and Gr. <etym lang="gk">Agnes.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Netherland(pn)">Netherland,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Netherland,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Niderlandt;</etym> that is to say, 
a Lower Land, with respect 
to Germany.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nevill(pn)">Nevill,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Neuve ville,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of 
a new Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newbottle(pn)">Newbottle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the new Building; for the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Botle</etym>, signifieth a Vil&shy;
lage or House.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newbury(pn)">Newbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Berkshire; that 
is, the new Town, raised out 
of the Ruins of Spinham, 
the old Town; from whence 
it is, that part of the New is 
yet call'd Spinham: Deri&shy;
ved from our word <etym lang="en">New,</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Borg</etym>, a Town, 
or Bury, or Borough.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newcastle(pn)">Newcastle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland, 
a Sea-Port Town. Be&shy;
fore the times of William the 
Conquerour, it was call'd 
Monckchester, because it ap&shy;
pertain'd to Monks. It may 
be derived from <etym lang="en">New</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Castle.</etym> It answers the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Neuf Chastel</etym>, and the Gr. <etym lang="gkt">Neo&shy;
castron</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newcastle under Lime(pn)">Newcastle under Lime,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Staffordshire, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) under the 
River <etym lang="en">Lime.</etym> Derived as 
above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newenden(pn)">Newenden,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Kent, in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer An&shy;
dred</etym>, in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Andred-&shy;
Ceaster</etym>, also, <etym lang="oe">Britten&shy;
den</etym>, i. e. the Valley of the 
Britains; from whence the 
Hundred was called <etym lang="oe">Sel 
Brittenden</etym>; for the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, signifieth a Valley, 
<etym lang="oe">Syl</etym>, a Pillar; and <etym lang="oe">Britten</etym>, 
a Briton, or Britain.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg5r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newmarch(pn)">Newmarch,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="en">de New March;</etym> pos&shy;
sibly from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Neuf,</etym> New, 
and <etym lang="fr">March&egrave;,</etym> a Market.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newmarket(pn)">Newmarket</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suffolk, from 
our own words, <etym lang="en">New</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Market.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Newport(pn)">Newport,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire; from 
our word <etym lang="en">New,</etym> and 
<etym lang="la">Portus,</etym> 
a Port.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nidderdale(pn)">Nidderdale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, from 
the River <etym lang="en">Nidd,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Dale;</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Neel(pn)">Neel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Noel,</etym> and 
this, by a great Corruption, 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Natalis.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nokton(pn)" lexeme="Noketon(pn)">Nokton, or Noketon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. 
from <etym lang="en">Nook,</etym> that is, a Cor&shy;
ner; and the AS. <etym lang="oe">tun</etym>, with 
us, Town: <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Town in 
a Corner.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nonesuch(pn)">Nonesuch,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Palace in Surrey; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">none</etym> like or compara&shy;
ble to it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Norfolk(pn)">Norfolk,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County in England; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">North folk,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Men 
of the North, with respect 
unto Suffolk, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) South 
folk.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Norham(pn)" lexeme="Northam(pn)">Norham, or Northam,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Nor&shy;
thumberland, from <etym lang="en">North;</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an Home 
or Habitation; in the AS. 
'tis call'd <etym lang="oe">Ubbanford</etym>, 
either 
from one Ubba, the Founder 
thereof; or from the River 
Ubba, and Ford; or was so 
call'd, <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="oe">Ufan-Ford</etym>, 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the upper Ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Norman(pn)">Norman,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Northman,</etym> 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a man of the North; for 
so were the mixt Inhabitants 
of the Northern Countries, 
called, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  Of Sweden, Den&shy;
mark, and Normandy; A 
People that continually were 
making Incursions upon 
France, the Netherlands, and 
England, laying waste and 
spoiling many places there&shy;
of, even to the Besieging of 
Paris, subduing England, Mag&shy;
na Gr&aelig;cia, and Sicily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Normanton Fields(pn)">Normanton Fields,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northamp&shy;
tonshire, corruptly for <etym lang="en">Dor&shy;
manton Fields;</etym> from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Dormanceaster</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
old Town of <etym lang="en">Dormford.</etym> Som&shy;
ner writes it Dorm-ceas&shy;
ter, and derives it from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dor</etym> or <etym lang="cb">Dwr,</etym> water, 
and withal placeth it in Hun&shy;
tingdonshire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Norris(pn)">Norris,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; probably 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Nourrice,</etym> a 
Nurse.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Northallerton(pn)">Northallerton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; 
in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ealfertun</etym>, 
perhaps from <etym lang="oe">Elf</etym>, an Elf, 
Fairy, or Fiend; because 
it is thought that such terre&shy;
strial D&aelig;mons haunted 
this place, and <etym lang="oe">tun</etym>, a Town; 
now call'd North-Allerton, 
or <etym lang="oe">Ealfertun</etym>, from its si&shy;
tuation to the North.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Northamptonshire(pn)">Northamptonshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from Nor&shy;
thampton, the County Town 
thereof; which is so called 
from its Northern situation, 
(that is with respect to 
Southampton,) and the River 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg6v">
Anton, or Avon, according 
to Camden. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Northumberland(pn)">Northumberland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Northan-Humberland</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a <etym lang="oe">Land</etym> on the <etym lang="oe">North</etym> 
side of the River <etym lang="en">Humber.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Norwich(pn)">Norwich,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norf. a City and 
Bishop's See; in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Nor&eth;wyc</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Nor&shy;
thern Bay, Harbour, or Ca&shy;
stle; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Nor&eth;</etym>, 
North, and <etym lang="oe">Wyc</etym>, a Port 
or Castle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Nottingham(pn)">Nottingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Coun&shy;
ty-Town, in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Snot&shy;
tengaham</etym>, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Snottenga</etym>, Caves, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an House or Habi&shy;
tation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Novantes(pn)">Novantes,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People 
of Scotland, formerly Inha&shy;
bitants of the Country now 
call'd Galloway; perhaps from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Nofio,</etym> to swim, 
and <etym lang="cb">Antur,</etym> having attempt&shy;
ed, from <etym lang="cb">Anturio,</etym> to at&shy;
tempt.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="O"><alpha>O</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Obotriti(pn)" lexeme="Abotriti(pn)">OBotriti, or Abotriti,</form> <xpln lang="en">
an ancient People of 
Germany, on both 
Sides of the River 
Elbe, where now are the 
Dukedoms of Lunenburg and 
Megalopolis. Adr. Jun. sup&shy;
poseth them to be so called 
<term lang="la">quasi</term>, <etym lang="bl">About riiters,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">A&shy;
bene reiters,</etym> that is, Even&shy;
ing or Night-Riders, that is, 
such as on Horseback made 
inroads upon the neighbour&shy;
ing Nations despoiling them 
of their Goods, and laying 
waste their Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ochy Hole(pn)">Ochy hole,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Cavern in Som. 
drawn from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ogo,</etym> a 
Cave; or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Oga</etym>,
