terrour, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a place fright&shy;
ful to be look'd into.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ockham(pn)">Ockham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, a Village 
where William de Ockham, 
(Author of the Sect of Nomi&shy;
nalists) was born; perhaps 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Okeham,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  Oak-&shy;
Town, from the abundance 
of Oaks growing in or a&shy;
bout it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ockhampton(pn)">Ockhampton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire; 
from the River <etym lang="en">Ock,</etym> and 
Anton, now Avon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ockley(pn)">Ockley,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, a Village; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ac</etym>, an Oak, 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg6r"> 
and <etym lang="oe">Lea</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, a 
Field. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oder(pn)">Oder;</form> <xpln lang="en">see Via&shy;
der, and Viadrus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Odoacer(pn)">Odoacer,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Heruli, 
Rugii, Turcilingi, and at last 
of Italy, the same with Ot&shy;
tocar, or Odgar; which 
see. Adr. Jun. writes him 
Haudovacrius, or Adovacrius; 
but what Authors he has for 
it, I know not, saving his 
Supposition drawn from the 
Motto written upon his Stan&shy;
dard, <etym lang="we">houd u Wacker</etym>, which 
is by Interpretation, Hold, or 
keep thy self watchful. It may 
also be drawn from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Hold</etym>, trusty, and <etym lang="we">Wacker,</etym> 
vigilant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Offchurch(pn)">Offchurch,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. from <etym lang="oe">Offa,</etym> 
King of the Mercii, and the 
Builder thereof, whose Son, 
Fremund, was there in&shy;
terr'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oger(pn)">Oger,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, according to Camden, 
but now a Sirname; perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Oga</etym>, ter&shy;
rour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Okeham(pn)">Okeham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Rutland, from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ac</etym>, an Oak, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, 
an House.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Okenyate(pn)">Okenyate,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small Village in 
the County of Shropshire, by 
the Rom. call'd Usocona: Now 
it hath its name from our 
word <etym lang="en">Oak</etym> and <etym lang="en">Gate,</etym> from 
some Oak growing at the 
Gate; or because the Gate 
is made of Oak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oker(pn)">Oker,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, formerly 
<etym lang="oe">Okover,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) over Oak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oldbury(pn)">Oldbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Gloc. 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the <etym lang="en">old</etym> <etym lang="en">Borough,</etym> see Bury 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Old Carlile(pn)">Old Carlile;</form> <xpln lang="en">see <etym lang="en">Carlile.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Old Perith(pn)">Old Perith,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumberland, 
by the Romans called <etym lang="la">Pe&shy;
trian,</etym> from the Petreian Band 
that Quartered there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Old Town(pn)">The old Town</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hereford&shy;
shire; in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Castle 
Hen,</etym> the old Castle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Old Winchester(pn)">Old Winchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northum&shy;
berland; elsewhere called 
<etym lang="la">Vindolana,</etym> by adding thereto 
the AS. termination <etym lang="oe">Ceas&shy;
ter</etym>, a Town, is now de&shy;
generated into Old Win&shy;
chester.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oliver(pn)">Oliver,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Olivier,</etym> an Olive 
Tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Omer(pn)">St. Omer</form> <xpln lang="en">'s, an University, 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">St. Omer,</etym> a City 
over against Flanders, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Church of St. Omer; or 
Omeropolis, the City of St. O&shy;
mer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ordevices(pn)">Ordevices,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People 
of Wales, from <etym lang="cb">Oar Devi,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) upon the River <etym lang="cb">Devi;</etym> 
for there is a Tract by the 
Sea, which the Welsh to this 
day call Ardudwy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ordulph(pn)">Ordulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">King Edgar's Son, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ora</etym>, a Port, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help; or from the 
same <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Ord</etym>, an 
Army; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ort,</etym> a place, and the same 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Orial College(pn)">Orial College,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the University 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg6v">
of Oxford; Fuller surmiseth 
that it is so called from its 
<etym lang="en">Oriental</etym>, or Eastern Situa&shy;
tion; though I think rather 
q. <etym lang="la">Aurea Aula,</etym> a Golden Hall, 
or <etym lang="la">Collegium Aureolum,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a fair and stately College. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Originall(pn)">Originall,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
I suppose the same with 
the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Origenes,</etym> and Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Origen.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ormond(pn)">Ormond,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, by the 
Irish call'd, <etym lang="ir">Orwowen,</etym> that 
is, the Front of Munster; 
see Munster.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ormus(pn)">Ormus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Haven upon the 
Persian Coast, famous in the 
time of our Progenitours; 
now greatly impaired be&shy;
cause of the Commerce or 
Tradings being removed to 
another place; from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F4D;&rho;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, an Harbour; be&shy;
cause perhaps it was the 
Harbour for the Ships, which 
Alexander the Great sent with 
his Captains Onesicritus, and 
Nearchus to view the Shores 
of India.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Orpington(pn)" lexeme="Orpinton(pn)">Orpington, or Orpinton</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Kent; perhaps from our word 
<etym lang="en">Orpin,</etym> a Plant so called, and 
<etym lang="en">Town,</etym> from the abundance 
thereof thereabout.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Osborn(pn)">Osborn,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hus</etym>, 
an House, and <etym lang="oe">Bearn</etym>, a 
Child; or Osborn, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Hous-born;</etym> that is, born at 
home.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Osith(pn)">St. Osith,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">O&eth;</etym>, ever, and <etym lang="oe">Si&eth;</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Gesi&eth;</etym>, mild.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Osmund(pn)">Osmund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hus</etym>, an House, 
and <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Osney(pn)">Osney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of Ox&shy;
ford, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Ousney,</etym> from the 
River <etym lang="en">Ous,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
Water, or Land by the Ri&shy;
vers side.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Osred(pn)">Osred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Northumber&shy;
land; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Os</etym>, for 
<etym lang="oe">Hus</etym>, an House, and <etym lang="oe">Rede</etym>, 
Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oswald(pn)">Oswald,</form> <xpln lang="en">that Pious King of 
Northumberland; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Hus</etym>, an House, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wald</etym>, Power, or <etym lang="oe">Weal&shy;
dan</etym>, to rule, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  an House&shy;
holder, or Master of a Fa&shy;
mily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oswaldsaw Hundred(pn)">Oswaldsaw Hundred</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wor&shy;
cestershire, from <etym lang="en">Oswald</etym> Bi&shy;
shop of Worcester, that begg'd 
the inspection thereof of 
King Edgar; and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, water; <term lang="la">quasi</term> Oswald's 
<etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oswestre(pn)">Oswestre,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Shropshire, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="en">Oswaldstre,</etym> in the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Croix Oswald,</etym> Oswald's 
Cross; from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Tre,</etym> 
a Town, and <etym lang="en">St. Oswald</etym> King 
of Northumberland, that was 
here slain in Fight by Penda, 
a General of the Mercii.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oswin(pn)">Oswin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hus</etym>, an House, and 
<etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to Win, or acquire; 
or rather from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Hus</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Wine</etym>, dearly be&shy;
loved.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oswy(pn)">Oswy,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of Northumberland, 
Founder of the Cathedral 
Church at Litchfield, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hus</etym>, an house, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wie</etym>, consecrated, which 
comes from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wei&shy;
hen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiihen, &shy;
Wiien,</etym> to consecrate, or de&shy;
dicate.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Otford(pn)">Otford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, memorable 
for an overthrow of the 
Danes; perhaps from a Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Ott,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ford.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Othes(pn)">Othes,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; pos&shy;
sibly from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Otho,</etym> 
though Kilian derives it from 
the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Atte,</etym> Fa&shy;
ther.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ottadini(pn)">Ottadini,</form> <xpln lang="en">a British People, that 
setled themselves in the 
County of Northumberland; 
possibly from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Uch 
Tin;</etym> that is, beyond the 
<etym lang="en">Tine.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Otterey(pn)">Otterey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire, from 
<etym lang="en">Otter,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ottgar(pn)">Ottgar,</form> <xpln lang="en">King Edgar's Father-&shy;
in-Law; perhaps, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Oath 
Gard,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Keeper of his 
Oath. See Odoacer, and 
Ottocar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ottocar(pn)">Ottocar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Puissant Prince of 
Bohemia, Duke of Austria, and 
Lord of many other Domi&shy;
nions. Kilian draws it from 
the old Teut. <etym lang="tt">Oede,</etym> untilled, 
and <etym lang="tt">Acker,</etym> a Field; and 
takes it to be the same with 
Odoacer. Some write it 
Ottgar, and draw it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Atte,</etym> Father, &amp; <etym lang="tt">Gard,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  his Father's Advocate. 
See Ottgar.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Overborough(pn)">Overborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lancashire; 
see <etym lang="en">Over,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Borough,</etym> in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Mary Overey(pn)">St. Mary Overey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Street in 
the Borough of Southwark, 
beyond London Bridge, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
St. Mary <etym lang="oe">Over Ea,</etym> that is, 
St. Mary over, or on the other 
side the water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ougthred(pn)" lexeme="Uctred(pn)">Ougthred, or Vctred,</form> <xpln lang="en">former&shy;
ly a Christen-Name, but now 
a Sirname; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Uht</etym>, early, the 
Morning Tide, and <etym lang="oe">Redan</etym>, 
to give Counsel; that is to 
say, He that gives seasonable 
Advice; or as the learned 
Th. H. telleth us, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Hoch,</etym> high, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">rede</etym>, Counsel, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
noble Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oundle(pn)" lexeme="Oundale(pn)">Oundle, or Oundale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the 
County of Northampton. It 
implieth as much, as Avon&shy;
dale; from the River A&shy;
von.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ousbourn(pn)">Ousbourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire, a little 
River, which runneth into 
<etym lang="en">Owse;</etym> See <etym lang="en">Bourn</etym> in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Martin Outwich(pn)">Martin Outwich,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">St. 
Mary Otirwich</etym> in London; 
not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Otyr, Oter,</etym> an Otter; 
and <etym lang="oe">Wyc</etym>, a Dock, or 
Wharf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Owdewater(pn)">Owdewater,</form> <xpln lang="en">or rather as the 
Belg. write it <etym lang="bl">Oudewater;</etym> 
that is, the Old Waters, a 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg7v">
Town in Holland, famous for 
the Birth of Arminus the Di&shy;
vine; see Old and Water 
in the Com. Names. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Owen(pn)">Owen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; Cam&shy;
den supposeth it a Corrup&shy;
tion of the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Eugenius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Owse(pn)">Owse,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in 
Yorkshire, in 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Isis;</etym> which Name is 
met with frequently in read&shy;
ing of History; which makes 
me think that Owse and 
Avon were taken by the Bri&shy;
tains for any River, or Water 
in general.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Oxford(pn)">Oxford,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bishop's See, and 
one of the two famous Uni&shy;
versities of England; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Oxenford</etym>, deri&shy;
ved as the Gr. Bosphorus, or 
the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Oschenfart</etym>, say 
some. Leland will have it to 
be so called <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="en">Owseford,</etym> 
that is, the <etym lang="en">Ford</etym> of <etym lang="en">Owse;</etym> 
which I take to be a better 
derivation of the Name.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="P"><alpha>P</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Padstow(pn)">PAdstow,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in 
Cornwall, a Contract 
of <etym lang="co">Petroch-Stow,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Place, or 
Church of <etym lang="en">St. Petroch,</etym> a Bri&shy;
tish Saint.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pain(pn)">Pain,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen and Sirname; 
possibly from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Payen,</etym> 
which may be contracted 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Paganus,</etym> a 
Pagan.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The English Pale(pn)">The English Pale</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) that part of Ireland 
wherein the English former&shy;
ly lived apart from the Irish 
by Laws of their own; pro&shy;
bably it might have this 
Name from the <etym lang="en">Pales</etym> or 
Stakes set round about it to 
keep off the Irish Robbers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pancerolt(pn)">Pancerolt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; per&shy;
haps from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pancerotte,</etym> 
a small Paunch or Belly; 
see Paunch in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Parnell(pn)">Parnell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Contract of the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Petronilla,</etym> a Womans 
Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Parret(pn)">Parret,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Som. for&shy;
merly call'd <etym lang="oe">Pedrid.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Parry(pn)">Parry,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="cb">Ap Harry,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Son of 
<etym lang="en">Henry.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Passelew(pn)">Passelew,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg8r"> 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Passez l' Eau,</etym> from 
passing, or swimming, over 
the water. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Patison(pn)">Patison,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Patrickson,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the <etym lang="en">Son</etym> of <etym lang="en">Patrick.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Patrick's Purgatory(pn)">St. Patrick's Purgatory,</form> <xpln lang="en">St. 
<etym lang="en">Patrick</etym> 's Isle in Ireland, from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">Patricius</etym> and <etym lang="en">Pur&shy;
gatory;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Patrington(pn)">Patrington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; by 
Antoninus, <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;torium,</etym> and by 
corrup. <etym lang="en">Patrington,</etym> as the 
Italians have turned their 
<etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;torium</etym> into <etym lang="it">Petrovina</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Paunton(pn)">Paunton</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, by 
Anton. called <etym lang="la">ad Pontes,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a Town upon the Bridges.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Paynell(pn)">Paynell,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="la">Paganellus,</etym> a 
little Pagan, a Christ. Name; 
see Pain above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peagkirk(pn)">Peagkirk,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the County of 
Northampton; from <etym lang="oe">Peag,</etym> a 
<emend err="a"></emend>sacred Virgin Sister to 
St. Guthlac, and <etym lang="oe">Kirk;</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Peak(pn)">The Peak,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mountain in Der&shy;
byshire; Among us Peak sig&shy;
nifies a jutting forth, and a&shy;
mong the Spaniards, the 
Mount in the Isle Tenariff, is 
called Pico, because perhaps 
it hath a sharp top like a Pike; 
see <etym lang="en">Pike</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pearson(pn)">Pearson,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Pe&shy;
ter</etym> 's Son, in the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pietre;</etym> 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Petrus,</etym> and 
our Eng. <etym lang="en">Son.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peche(pn)">Peche,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pech&egrave;,</etym> a fault; or rather 
from <etym lang="fr">Pesche,</etym> fishing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pedderton(pn)">Pedderton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somersetshire; 
heretofore <etym lang="en">Pedridan,</etym> from 
the River <etym lang="en">Pedrid,</etym> formerly 
famous for the Court of King 
Ina, our first Saxon Law-&shy;
giver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peg(pn)">Peg,</form> <xpln lang="en">for <etym lang="en">Margaret</etym>; Versteg. 
draws it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Piga</etym>, 
a Girl.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pembroke(pn)">Pembroke,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Pen 
Bro,</etym> a Mount or Head by 
the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pen(pn)">Pen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the C. 
Br. <etym lang="cb">Pen,</etym> an Head; in a se&shy;
condary or figurative sence, 
The top of a Mountain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pen(pn)">Pen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Surrey, where 
the Britains received a great 
overthrow from Xeniwalch, a 
West-Saxon; and Canutus 
the Dane, from Edmond Iron&shy;
side. It is situate near to 
Wincaunton, which took 
its Name from our word 
Wine; or rather from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to overcome, 
and King Canutus, that was 
there overcome; <etym lang="cb">Pen</etym> in the 
C. Br. as was said above, sig&shy;
nifieth an Head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pencridge(pn)" lexeme="Pancridge(pn)">Pencridge, or Pancridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Staffordshire; perhaps from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Pen,</etym> an Head, and 
<etym lang="cb">Cr&ucirc;g,</etym> a Crag, Bank, or 
Ridge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pendennis(pn)">Pendennis,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall; a 
Castle built by King Henry 
the Eighth in the Port of 
Falmouth. In their Dialect 
it is called <etym lang="co">Pen Dinas,</etym> that is, 
the Head of the Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pendle Hill(pn)">Pendle Hill</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lancash. from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Pen,</etym> an Head, 
</page> 

<page sig="Gg8v">
as the Alpes are called by 
the Latins, <etym lang="la">Pennini montes</etym>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Penigent(pn)">Penigent,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Hill in Lanc. from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Pen gwin,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
from its Snow-white Top.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Penmaen-maur(pn)">Penmaen-maur,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mountain 
or Hill in Caern. by interpre&shy;
tation, the great Moor-head, 
or Top ; there is likewise, 
<etym lang="we">Pen-maen-bychan</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
lesser Stony Top or Head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pennant(pn)">Pennant,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
in the C. Br. the Valleys 
Head.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Penry(pn)">Penry,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, frequent 
among the Welsh, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="cb">Ap 
Henry,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="en">Henry</etym> 's Son; 
see Henry.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pensans(pn)">Pensans,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Cornwall, 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Head of Saints or 
Sands; either from our word 
<etym lang="en">Saints,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Sands,</etym> and 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Pen,</etym> a Head; or 
from the same <etym lang="cb">Pen,</etym> and the 
Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sans</etym> without.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Penwith(pn)">Penwith</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. (i. e.) a 
Promontory on the left .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Percival(pn)">Percival,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
possibly from <etym lang="fr">Perchevaal,</etym> a 
Village in Normandy, which 
comes perhaps from the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Perche,</etym> an Head, or Horn; 
and the old word <etym lang="fr">Val,</etym> a 
Valley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Perin(pn)">Perin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, formerly a 
Christen-Name; from the 
<emend err="the "></emend>Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pierrin,</etym> in the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Petrinus,</etym> little <etym lang="la">Peter;</etym> for the 
termination <etym lang="la">in</etym> diminisheth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Perkin(pn)">Perkin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pierre,</etym> Peter; and our 
diminut. termination <etym lang="en">kin,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little Peter, or Peter's 
Son; see Kin in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Perpoint(pn)" lexeme="Pierpoint(pn)">Perpoint, and Pierpoint,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
Sirname of a noble Fami&shy;
ly; from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pierre,</etym> a 
Rock, or Stone, and <etym lang="fr">Pont,</etym> a 
Bridge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Perrot(pn)">Perrot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pierrot,</etym> that is, Great 
Peter, this from <etym lang="fr">Pierre,</etym> Peter, 
and the augmentative Ter&shy;
mination <etym lang="fr">ot.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Persho(pn)" lexeme="Parshoro(pn)">Persho, in Worcestersh. vulgarly 
Parshoro,</form> <xpln lang="en">(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a <etym lang="en">Shore</etym> 
planted with Pear-trees; for 
it is not far from the River 
Sabrina.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pertharitus(pn)">Pertharitus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Longobardi of Italy; perhaps 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Peere,</etym> an 
Horse, and <etym lang="bl">Richten,</etym> for 
<etym lang="bl">Berichten,</etym> to teach; the 
Name implying as much as 
Horse-Courser.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peterborough(pn)">Peterborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northampton&shy;
shire; so called from an Ab&shy;
by and Church erected there 
formerly by Peada and Wul&shy;
pher, Kings of the Mercii, in 
honour of St. <etym lang="en">Peter.</etym> It 
is now a Bishop's See.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pevensey(pn)">Pevensey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Peofen-Sea</etym>, now 
by contraction <etym lang="en">Pemsey</etym>. 
Somn. writes it <etym lang="oe">P&aelig;fena-S&aelig;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Peverell(pn)">Peverell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Poivrel,</etym> or the It. 
<etym lang="it">Peverello,</etym> a small Peper Corn, 
these from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Poivre,</etym> or 
the It. <etym lang="it">Pevere, Pevero,</etym> a Peper 
Corn.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Philebert(pn)">Philebert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fela</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Veel,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Viel,</etym> 
much, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, bright, 
or splendid.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Picardy(pn)">Picardy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Province of France; 
perhaps from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">les 
Piques,</etym> Pikes, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> nature; they being 
mostly accustom'd to fight 
with Pikes. This Province 
had not this Name till the 
year of our Lord 300.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Picts Wall(pn)">The Picts Wall,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cumberland; 
in the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gual, Gal, Bal</etym>, 
or <etym lang="cb">Mur Sever</etym>; by the Scots 
<etym lang="sc">Scottish-Waith</etym>; by the 
English Inhabitants there&shy;
upon, <etym lang="en">Picts wall, Pehits 
wall,</etym> or Keep wall, and 
the Wall by way of excel&shy;
lency; a very sumptuous 
work first begun by the Em&shy;
perour Adrian, and after&shy;
wards continued by Seve&shy;
rus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Piercy(pn)">Piercy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, according 
to Camden; not from piercing 
or darting out the Eye of a 
King of the Scots, as Boe&shy;
tius relates; but from <etym lang="oe">Pierce,</etym> 
which among the Ancients 
was the same that Peter is 
amongst us. Pierce cometh 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Pierre,</etym> Sig. Pe&shy;
ter, also a Stone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pigot(pn)">Pigot,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; Camden 
saith, that it signifieth a 
thing that is Speckled, and 
so may be derived from the 
It. <etym lang="it">Piga,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pica,</etym> a 
Mag-Py, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  party-colour'd 
like a Mag-Py. The learned 
Th. H. supposeth that it comes 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Bigot.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pipinus(pn)">Pipinus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of France; 
Adr. Jun. draws it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Pipen,</etym> to make a 
shrill sound; It may be drawn 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Pepin,</etym> a Pip&shy;
pin; or from <etym lang="fr">Pi&egrave;,</etym> a Foot, 
and <etym lang="fr">Pein,</etym> Pain; as the Gr. 
Oedipus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pitchford(pn)">Pitchford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Shropshire; so 
called from a Spring rising in 
a private House, upon which 
<etym lang="en">Pitch</etym> continually floateth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Plaicy(pn)">Plaicy,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex; <etym lang="la">&agrave; Placendo</etym> 
from pleasing, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a plea&shy;
sant place; as Placentia in 
Italy.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Plantagenet(pn)">Plantagenet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; pro&shy;
per to the Dukes of Andium; 
and afterward to several 
Kings of England; from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Plante Geneste,</etym> that is, a 
Plant of Broom, from one of 
the Dukes of Andium; who, 
(to expiate the Death of his 
Brother, whom he, to obtain 
the Empire for himself, had 
put to Death,) took a Jour&shy;
ney into the Holy Land, and 
every Night during his Jour&shy;
ney, scourged himself with 
a rod of Broom, for Pen&shy;
nance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pleasaunce(pn)">Pleasaunce,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Plai&shy;
sance,</etym> the It. <etym lang="it">Piacenza,</etym> or the 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Placentia;</etym> so called from 
its pleasant Situation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Plegmund(pn)">Plegmund,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop 
of Canterbury; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Plega, Plaga,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh1v">
Play, and <etym lang="oe">Mundian</etym>, to up&shy;
hold. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Plimouth(pn)">Plimouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City and 
Sea-Port Town in Devonsh. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the <etym lang="en">Mouth</etym> of the River 
<etym lang="en">Plim.</etym> Or it may be taken 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Pi;&lambda;&eta;&mu;&mu;&#x1F7B;&rho;&alpha;</etym>, the 
Tide.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Plonket(pn)">Plonket,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; not un&shy;
likely from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Blond,</etym> 
red-hair'd, and the Dim. ter&shy;
mination <etym lang="en">Ket.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Poik(pn)">Poik,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Worcestersh. Camden writes it <etym lang="en">Powick,</etym> which 
may be derived from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Pol</etym>, a Pole and <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, 
a Bay, or Fort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Poitevin(pn)">Poitevin,</form> <xpln lang="en">now Pelfin, a Sir&shy;
name, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Fr. <etym lang="fr">le Poitevin,</etym> 
come of a <etym lang="fr">Pict;</etym> or from <etym lang="fr">Pi&shy;
ctavia</etym> in France.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pollard(pn)">Pollard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
Fish called a <etym lang="en">Pollard;</etym> see 
Poll and Pollard in the 
Com. Names. Or from our 
Eng. Verb, to <etym lang="en">Poll,</etym> or cut 
the hair.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Polton(pn)">Polton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall; that is to 
say, <etym lang="en">Pool Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pont Eland(pn)">Pont Eland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumber&shy;
land; from the River <etym lang="en">Pon&shy;
tus;</etym> by the Romans 'twas 
call'd <etym lang="la">Pons &AElig;lii.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pontfret(pn)" lexeme="Pontfract(pn)">Pontfret, or Pontfract,</form> <xpln lang="en">com&shy;
monly call'd Pomfret, in 
Yorkshire, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lat. <etym lang="la">Pons fra&shy;
ctus,</etym> the broken Bridge. It 
is Historied that the Bridge 
was broken down by the 
vast Number of People that 
met here to give a welcom 
to the Arch-Bishop Wilhelm, 
King Stephen's Nephew by 
his Sister; so that many did 
fall into the River, and had 
been all inevitably drown'd, 
but that a Tear which Wil&shy;
helm let fall, saved them 
all.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Portlock(pn)">Portlock,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somers. a small 
Harbour, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the <etym lang="en">Ports Lock</etym>; 
see Lock in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Portland(pn)">Portland,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Isle in Dorsetshire; 
either from the <etym lang="en">Port</etym> Wey&shy;
mouth, which is over against 
it; or from Portus, a noted 
Saxon Pirateer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Portland(pn)">Portland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire, an&shy;
ciently call'd <etym lang="en">Portsey,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Portchester;</etym> possibly here&shy;
tofore remarkable for some 
noted <etym lang="en">Port</etym> of Trade: 
from our old word <etym lang="oe">Port,</etym> 
carriage or behaviour, and 
<etym lang="en">Land;</etym> which see in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Portslade(pn)">Portslade,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small Village in 
Sussex; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a way <etym lang="en">Leading</etym> 
to the <etym lang="en">Port</etym>, according to 
Camden. Some derive it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sled</etym>, a Valley; that 
is, a Port or Haven in Val&shy;
ley or Bottom.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Portsmouth(pn)">Portsmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Sea-Port 
Town in Hantsh. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">Mouth</etym> of the <etym lang="en">Port</etym>; see Mouth 
and Port, in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Powell(pn)">Powell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Sirname; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="cb">Ap Howell,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  Howell's 
Son; see Howell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Preston(pn)">Preston,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lanc. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Priests 
Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Price(pn)">Price,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; proper to 
the Welsh; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="cb">Ap Rice,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the Son of <etym lang="en">Rice</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Prichard(pn)">Prichard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname frequent 
in Wales, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="cb">Ap Richard,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
the Son of <etym lang="en">Richard.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Prindle(pn)">Prindle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; perhaps 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Pr&aelig;diolum,</etym> a 
small Farm, to which agrees 
Camden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Probert(pn)">Probert,</form> <xpln lang="en">properly a Welsh Sir&shy;
name, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="cb">Ap Robert,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
begotten of <etym lang="en">Robert</etym>, Robert's 
Son; see Robert.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Prodhow(pn)" lexeme="Prudhow Castle(pn)">Prodhow, or Prudhow Castle,</form> <xpln lang="en">
in Northumberland; by the 
Romans called <etym lang="la">Protolitia,</etym> or 
<etym lang="la">Procolitia,</etym> a Military Fort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Prono(pn)">Prono,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the ancient 
Germans; perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brandt,</etym> a Brand, or 
Fire; for he is imagin'd to 
be the Germans Vulcan, or 
God of Fire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Prud(pn)">Prud,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="cb">Ap Rhud,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="cb">Rhud</etym> 's Son; 
Rhud denoteth one that 
is red-hair'd; See Red in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pudsey(pn)">Pudsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Puis,</etym> a Well, and our 
word <etym lang="en">Sea;</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
Water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pugh(pn)">Pugh</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="cb">Ap Hugh;</etym> that is, <etym lang="en">Hugh</etym> 's 
Son.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Pull Hely(pn)">Pull hely,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Caern. in the 
C. Br. it implieth as much, as 
Salt Marsh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Putney(pn)">Putney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, on the 
Bank of thee Thames; from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Put,</etym> in the Plural 
<etym lang="bl">Putten,</etym> a Well, and <etym lang="bl">Ea,</etym> 
Water.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="Q"><alpha>Q</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Quixot(pn)">QVixot,</form> <xpln lang="en">Don Quixot, 
The noted Spanish 
Rhodomantado; from 
the Hisp. <etym lang="sp">Quixotes Ter&shy;
ces,</etym> Armour for the Thigh; 
this again from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Coxa,</etym> 
the Hip; or it may come 
from <etym lang="sp">Quixada, Quixar,</etym> a Cheek&shy;
bone, possibly so call'd from 
the greatness of his Jaw 
bones, and leanness of his 
Cheeks. Quixar, may be 
drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceac, 
Ceoca</etym>, a Cheek, or Cheek&shy;
bone.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Quinborough(pn)">Quinborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
<etym lang="en">Queens</etym> <etym lang="en">Borough</etym>; a Castle 
built by King Edw. the Third 
in the honour of his Wife 
Philippa of Hannonia.</xpln>
</wordentry>
</wordgroup1>
</page> 

<page sig="Hh2v"> 
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="R"><alpha>R</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rachisius(pn)">RAchisius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of 
the Longobardi of Ita&shy;
ly; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Raach,</etym> Revenge, or 
<etym lang="tt">Rachen,</etym> to revenge, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
an Avenger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Radbod(pn)">Radbod,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Freezland, f
rom the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, Coun&shy;
sel, and <etym lang="oe">Bode</etym>, a Messen&shy;
ger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Radegisus(pn)">Radegisus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Gothi; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Read</etym>, the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rood,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rot,</etym> Red, and <etym lang="tt">Geisz,</etym> a 
Goat. Jun.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Radegonde(pn)">Radegonde,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Wom. Name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rade, Rede</etym>, 
Counsel, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gun&shy;
nen,</etym> to favour; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one 
that favoureth, or submits to 
good Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Radnor(pn)">Radnor,</form> <xpln lang="en">old Radnor; in the 
C. Br. Pencrag, from its high 
top; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, a Road, and <etym lang="oe">Ofer</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Ober</etym>, over.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Radulph(pn)" lexeme="Rodulph(pn)">Radulph, or Rodulph;</form> <xpln lang="en">see 
Ralph, beneath it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Raginbert(pn)">Raginbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Longo&shy;
bardi, Duke of Narvisium, 
in the year 701. perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rechen,</etym> to avenge, 
or <etym lang="tt">Raach,</etym> vengeance, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ralph(pn)">Ralph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; a 
Contract of <etym lang="en">Radulph,</etym> which 
is the same with <etym lang="en">Rodulph;</etym> 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, Coun&shy;
sel, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, Help, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that assisteth in Coun&shy;
sel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rams Head(pn)">Rams head</form> <xpln lang="en">, in Ireland; per&shy;
haps so called from the like&shy;
ness of a <etym lang="en">Ram</etym> 's <etym lang="en">Head</etym> and 
Horns.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ramsey(pn)">Ramsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Huntingtonshire; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, Water, or 
an Isle, and <etym lang="en">Ram,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Rams Isle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Randal(pn)">Randal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
Camden takes it to be a cor&shy;
ruption of <etym lang="en">Ranulph,</etym> and 
derives it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> Pure, and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, Help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ratcliff(pn)">Ratcliff,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middl. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Red 
Cliff.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ravensbourn(pn)">Ravensbourn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Kent; 
from <etym lang="en">Raven,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bourn;</etym> 
see both in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Raulins(pn)">Raulins,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Raoul, Radulph,</etym> by adding 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh3r">
the Patronymick Termina&shy;
tion <etym lang="en">ins,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Ralph</etym> 's Son, 
or little Ralph; see Ralph. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Raymund(pn)">Raymund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> Pure, 
and <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a Mouth, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that abstains from wan&shy;
ton Discourses; or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ruh,</etym> rest, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, Peace; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that answereth not a&shy;
gain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reading(pn)">Reading,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Berks, a Town of 
great Trade; Camden draws 
it from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Redin,</etym> 
Fern, which groweth there&shy;
abouts in great abundance. 
Leland supposeth that it is 
thus nam'd, from the meet&shy;
ing together of other waters, 
with the River <etym lang="en">Rhe,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Rhea.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reafan(pn)">Reafan,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Banner, or Flag 
of the Danes, from the figure 
of a <etym lang="en">Raven</etym> embroidered 
thereupon by King Lodbroke's 
Daughter. See Raven in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reccaredus(pn)" lexeme="Richaredus(pn)">Reccaredus, or Richaredus,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a King of the Spanish Vice-&shy;
Gothi; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym> 
Rich, and <etym lang="oe">Rede</etym>, Counsel; 
or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reden,</etym> to 
say, and the same <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, that 
is, one of a fluent and elo&shy;
quent Tongue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rechilla(pn)">Rechilla,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spanish 
Swedes; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Re&shy;
chen,</etym> revenge, and <etym lang="tt">Ellen,</etym> 
to make hast; that is, one 
quick to revenge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reciswindus(pn)">Reciswindus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Spanish Vice-Gothi; not un&shy;
likely from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Re&shy;
chen,</etym> to avenge, and <etym lang="tt">Gesch&shy;
wind,</etym> speedily.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reculver(pn)">Reculver,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Raculf</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Redbridge(pn)">Redbridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantsh. in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Reed</etym>, <etym lang="oe">ford</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
Reed-ford, or <etym lang="en">Reed-bridge.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Redwall(pn)" lexeme="Redwald(pn)">Redwall, or rather Redwald,</form> <xpln lang="en">
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rede</etym>, Coun&shy;
sel, and <etym lang="oe">Wald</etym>, Power, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
one that beareth Sway in 
Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reeve(pn)">Reeve,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Refa</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Genefa</etym>, 
a Tax-Master, or <etym lang="en">Grave;</etym> 
see Grave in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reginfred(pn)" lexeme="Reinfred(pn)" lexeme="Rainfred(pn)">Reginfred, Reinfred, or Rain&shy;
fred;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> 
Upright, and <etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Regni(pn)">Regni,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People of 
Britain, that formerly had 
the Shires, Surrey and Sussex, 
and part of Hantshire in Pos&shy;
session; not unlikely from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Rh&ecirc;g,</etym> a Gift, and 
<etym lang="cb">Neges,</etym> a Messenger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reinard(pn)">Reinard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> un&shy;
corrupt, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
Nature, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Honestly min&shy;
ded.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reiner(pn)">Reiner,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> un&shy;
spotted, and <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> Belg. <etym lang="bl">Eere,</etym> 
Honour, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one, whose good 
Name is unstain'd.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh3v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reinfraw(pn)">Reinfraw,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland; Ptol. 
calls it <etym lang="gk">Randuara.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Reinhold(pn)" lexeme="Rainhold(pn)" lexeme="Renard(pn)">Reinhold, Rainhold, or Re&shy;
nald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> Pure, and 
<etym lang="tt">Hold,</etym> Friendship, saith Cam&shy;
den: From the same <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> 
and <etym lang="tt">Held,</etym> a Nobleman, saith 
Versteg. I might also draw it 
from the same <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> and our 
English <etym lang="en">Hold;</etym> that is, one, 
that holdeth fast his Inte&shy;
grity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Remismundus(pn)">Remismundus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Spanish Swedes, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="tt">Ru&shy;
mismund;</etym> from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ruhm,</etym> fame or Report; 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym> Peace, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a Mouth; 
that is, famous for Peace, or 
Eloquence.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ren&egrave;(pn)">Ren&egrave;,</form> <xpln lang="en">Titular King of Naples 
and Sicily, from the prefix 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Re,</etym> again, and the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">N&egrave;,</etym> born, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) reborn, born 
again; as to the Kingdom.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Renimed(pn)">Renimed</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middlesex; that is 
to say, <etym lang="en">Running Mead,</etym> me&shy;
morable for the rebellious 
meeting of the Barons against 
King John.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Repton(pn)">Repton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Derbishire, a Town 
memorable for the over&shy;
throws of &AElig;thelbald, and 
Buthred, two Kings of the 
Mercii; not unlikely from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> clean, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">tun</etym>, a Town, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a clean Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rheadsdale(pn)">Rheadsdale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumber&shy;
land; that is to say, the 
Dale of the River <etym lang="en">Rhead,</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Rhe.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Rhein(pn)">The Rhein,</form> <xpln lang="en">next after Danu&shy;
bius, the most famous River 
not in Germany only, but in 
all Europe; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rein,</etym> clear, pure, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
clear Water; they used to 
wash and purifie new-born 
Babes therein, to try whe&shy;
ther they were Genuine or 
no; or from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rin&shy;
nen,</etym> to flow, or <etym lang="tt">Runnen,</etym> 
to run.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rhese(pn)">Rhese,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Christ. Name; 
Camden draws it from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Riese,</etym> a Giant. It 
may also not improbably be 
drawn from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Rhesel,</etym> 
a Crib or Rack to put Hay in 
for Horses.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rhie(pn)">Rhie,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, a Sea-Port; 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Rive,</etym> a Shore, 
or Bank of a River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rian(pn)">Rian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Scotland; at 
the Mouth of which was a 
Town, by Ptolem. called, <etym lang="gk">A&shy;
bravanus,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="sc">Aber Ruani,</etym> the 
Mouth of the River <etym lang="sc">Rian,</etym> or 
<etym lang="sc">Ruan.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ribblechester(pn)">Ribblechester,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old Town in 
Lanc. Ptolem. calls it, <etym lang="gk">Ri&shy;
bodunum,</etym> and corruptly <etym lang="gk">Rigo&shy;
dunum.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ribell(pn)">Ribell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a place in Lanc. whi&shy;
ther the Tide cometh; by Ptolem. called <etym lang="gk">Bellisama,</etym> and 
by adding the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rhe</etym>, a 
River, to the beginning of 
the old Name, Bellisama, it 
comes now to be call'd Ri&shy;
bell.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ricciarius(pn)">Ricciarius</form> <xpln lang="en">, King of the Spa&shy;
nish Swedes, in the Year 48. 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh4r"> 
not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> 
Rich, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Are</etym>, or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ehr,</etym> Honour, that 
is, one greatly honoured. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rice(pn)">Rice,</form> <xpln lang="en">see <etym lang="en">Rhese.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Richard(pn)">Richard,</form> <xpln lang="en">Versteg. draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> Rich, &amp; our Eng. word 
<etym lang="en">Heart,</etym> that is, Liberal, or as 
we say, open hearted. Some 
draw it from the same <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, 
Rich, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> 
Nature; that is, one that 
hath great natural Parts; 
others, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rice</etym>, 
a Kingdom, and <etym lang="oe">Ward</etym>, a 
Keeper. Aventin. writes it 
<etym lang="tt">Reichgard,</etym> from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> rich, and <etym lang="tt">Gard,</etym> to 
keep. Jun. writes it <etym lang="tt">Reich&shy;
raht,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Rich Senatour, 
from the same <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> rich, 
and <etym lang="tt">Raht,</etym> Counsel, also a 
Senatour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Richborough(pn)">Richborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, for&shy;
merly <etym lang="oe">Richberge;</etym> in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Repti mu&eth;</etym>, by Anton. <etym lang="la">Rhi&shy;
tupis Portus;</etym> by Marcell. <etym lang="la">Rhu&shy;
tupi&aelig; Statio,</etym> all which are but 
little dissonant one to ano&shy;
ther. Camd. draws it from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ryth Tusyth,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Sandy Ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Richmond(pn)">Richmond,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, 
Rich, and <etym lang="oe">Mond</etym>, Peace, or 
<etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, a Mouth, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Peace&shy;
able, or Eloquent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ricimerus(pn)" lexeme="Richimerus(pn)">Ricimerus, or Richimerus,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a Swede by descent, that 
most nefariously usurp'd the 
Roman Empire; either from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, a Kingdom, and 
<etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, famous, or from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> a Kingdom, and 
<etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to increase.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ridvers(pn)" lexeme="Rivers(pn)">Ridvers, for shortness Rivers,</form> <xpln lang="en">
in Hart. <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="la">de Ripariis,</etym> per&shy;
taining to the Banks; a Sir&shy;
name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Riegate(pn)">Riegate</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
<etym lang="en">Gate</etym>, or Course of the River 
<etym lang="en">Rie.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ring(pn)">Ring,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; possibly from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hring</etym>, a Circle, or 
Compass.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ringwood(pn)" lexeme="Regnewood(pn)" lexeme="Rincewood(pn)">Ringwood, Regnewood, or 
Rincewood,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantsh. for&shy;
merly the Metropolis of the 
People call'd Regni, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the 
<etym lang="en">Wood</etym> or Forest of the <etym lang="la">Regni</etym>, 
into which they fled for 
Protection, as wild Beasts in&shy;
to a Wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ripley(pn)">Ripley,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Surrey, 
where William Ripley, the 
Chymist was born; from our 
word <etym lang="en">Ripe,</etym> and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Leag, Leg</etym>, a Field, or 
Pasture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rising(pn)">Rising,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norfolk; heretofore 
noted for a Castle call'd <etym lang="en">Ri&shy;
sing-Castle;</etym> from its <etym lang="en">rising</etym> 
or high Situation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rithy(pn)">Rithy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; probably 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ryth,</etym> a 
Ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Robert(pn)">Robert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
Camden draws it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, Counsel, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
famous. Versteg. saith, that 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh4v"> 
it was heretofore written 
<etym lang="en">Ruberiht,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ruberight,</etym> 
and draws it from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Rou</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Ruh,</etym> rest, and the 
Termination <etym lang="tt">Beright,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
forward, or prone to any 
thing. It may be taken from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Roth,</etym> Red, and 
<etym lang="tt">Bart,</etym> a Beard. The Dutch 
write it <etym lang="du">Ruprecht,</etym> which 
may seem to come from 
<etym lang="du">Ruh,</etym> Quietness, or Peace, 
and <etym lang="du">Pracht,</etym> Pomp, or Splen&shy;
dour. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Roch(pn)">Roch,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, in the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">de le Roche;</etym> from <etym lang="fr">Roche,</etym> a 
Rock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rochester(pn)">Rochester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, a Bishop's 
See; Anton. writes it. <etym lang="la">Roibis,</etym> 
The Eng. Saxons <etym lang="en">Wrowe&shy;
ceaster</etym>; and not many 
Ages since, it was called 
<etym lang="en">Rewchester.</etym> It may possibly 
be called Rochester, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Roche,</etym> a Rock; and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ceaster</etym>, a Castle or 
City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rodelinda(pn)">Rodelinda,</form> <xpln lang="en">Wife to Perthari&shy;
tus King of the Longobardi of 
Italy; from the AS. and old 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Rade,</etym> Counsel, and 
<etym lang="tt">Lind,</etym> mild.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Roderic(pn)">Roderic,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name, fre&shy;
quently given to the Spanish 
Vice-Gothi; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Raht,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Raed,</etym> Counsel, 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, or Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> Rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rodoaldus(pn)">Rodoaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy; derived ei&shy;
ther from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, 
Counsel, and <etym lang="oe">Wald</etym>, Power, 
whence Wealdan, to rule, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) he, that ruleth pru&shy;
dently; or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Rood,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">Wald,</etym> a Wood.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Roger(pn)">Roger,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ruh,</etym> Rest, and 
<etym lang="tt">Gard,</etym> a Keeper. Kilian draws 
it from the same <etym lang="tt">Ruh,</etym> Qui&shy;
etness, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ge&shy;
ren, Begeren,</etym> to covet, or 
desire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Roiston(pn)">Roiston,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hert. from <etym lang="en">Roisia,</etym> 
a Pious Lady, who in the 
time of the Normans, here 
set up a Crucifix, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Roi&shy;
sia's Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rolland(pn)" lexeme="Rowland(pn)">Rolland, or Rowland,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. 
Name; Camden draws it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rade</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Rod</etym>, 
Counsel, and <etym lang="en">Land;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
his Countries Patron or Coun&shy;
sellor. Verstegan, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Row,</etym> Peace, and the 
same <etym lang="en">Land,</etym> that is, a Paci&shy;
fier of his Country.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rollo(pn)">Rollo,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Duke of Normandy; 
perhaps from the Teut. 
and Goth. <etym lang="go">Roth,</etym> Red, 
and <etym lang="go">Luwe,</etym> a Lion, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
bloody Lion; hence styl'd 
the bloody Brother.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Romeswork(pn)">Romeswork,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; a place 
near the Sea, where it is 
thought that Caesar the Dicta&shy;
tour at his first Arrival in 
this Land, pitch'd his Tents; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Work</etym> of the <etym lang="en">Ro&shy;
mans.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Romoaldus(pn)">Romoaldus,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the Longo&shy;
bardi, 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh5r"> 
Duke of Beneventum; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ruhm,</etym> Glo&shy;
ry, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, 
to reign, or <etym lang="oe">Wald, Gewalt</etym>, 
Power; or from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Raum,</etym> Room or Space, and 
<etym lang="tt">Wald,</etym> a Wood. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rosamund(pn)">Rosamund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from <etym lang="la">Rosa,</etym> a Rose, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a Mouth; 
from her rosie-colour'd Lips.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rosland(pn)">Rosland,</form> <xpln lang="en">a small Province in 
Cornwall; from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Ros,</etym> Heath, and <etym lang="en">Land;</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ross(pn)">Ross,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Foreland in Scotland, 
the Seat of the ancient Can&shy;
t&aelig;; perhaps from the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Ros,</etym> Heath or Ling.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rotharis(pn)">Rotharis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Longo&shy;
bardi of Italy. Kilian draws 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Retter,</etym> a 
Deliverer; this from the Verb 
<etym lang="tt">Retten,</etym> to deliver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rotherfield(pn)">Rotherfield,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex, former&shy;
ly <etym lang="en">Rotheram;</etym> from the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Rither,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Rother,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Field;</etym> which see: from 
hence also Rotherbridge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rotterdam(pn)">Rotterdam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a chief City of 
Trade in Holland; Adr. Jun. 
interpreteth it, the <etym lang="en">Dam</etym> or 
Wear of <etym lang="bl">Rota</etym>, or <etym lang="bl">Roter</etym>, a small 
River that runs hard by it, &amp; 
disembogueth it self into the 
River Mosa; see Dam in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="De Rougemont(pn)">De Rougemont,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Rouge,</etym> Red, and 
<etym lang="fr">Mont,</etym> a Mount.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rous(pn)">Rous,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Roux,</etym> red-hair'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Routon-castle(pn)">Routon-Castle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Shropshire; 
Anton. calls it <etym lang="la">Rutanium,</etym> 
whence <etym lang="en">Routon.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Row(pn)">Row,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; our North-&shy;
Country-men pronounce it 
Raw; from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Rue,</etym> a 
Street, or Lane.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Roward(pn)">Roward,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rouw-&shy;
Waerd,</etym> a Title of great Dig&shy;
nity in Brabant, with Power 
not much less than that of a 
Dictatour of the Romans. It 
may be compared to our 
Constable or Master of the 
Horse; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rouw,</etym> 
Quietness, and <etym lang="bl">Waerden,</etym> 
to Ward, or keep, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Defender of Publick Concord.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rowen(pn)">Rowen,</form> <xpln lang="en">Daughter to Hengist 
the English-Saxon, Wife to 
Vortigern, King of the Britons; 
not unlikely from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ruh,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Rouw,</etym> Peace; 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to ac&shy;
quire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Roxburg(pn)" lexeme="Roxborough(pn)">Roxburg, or Roxborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Scotland, heretofore call'd 
Marchidun, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Hill 
of the Marches, which see; 
as also Mark and Downes 
in the Com. Names. It is 
now call'd Roxborough, pos&shy;
sibly from some <etym lang="en">Rocks</etym> or 
Crags adjoining.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rugii(pn)">Rugii,</form> <xpln lang="en">a warlike People of 
Germany upon the Balthick 
Sea; Adr. Jun. draws it from 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ruge,</etym> rough, hairy, 
probably from the natural 
roughness of their Bodies; 
or because they were cloathed 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh5v">
with the shaggy Skins of 
<emend err="of "></emend>Wild-Beasts; See Rough 
in the Com. Names. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rumney(pn)" lexeme="Romeney(pn)">Rumney, or Romeney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Kent, formerly <etym lang="en">Romenal;</etym> 
perhaps from the <etym lang="en">Romans,</etym> 
that first Landed on that 
Shore. It is also the proper 
Name of a Man.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rumsey(pn)">Rumsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire, in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Rumseg</etym>, memorable 
for a Nunnery of veiled 
Nuns, erected by King Ed&shy;
gar; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Rum</etym>, Broad, or Large, 
and <etym lang="oe">S&aelig;eg</etym>, Sedge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Russel(pn)">Russel,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Roux,</etym> Red, and the dim. 
Term. <etym lang="fr">el,</etym> that is to say, 
somewhat Red; for the old 
Fr. word <etym lang="fr">Russel</etym>, signified 
formerly the same that Ros&shy;
seau doth now.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ruthin(pn)">Ruthin</form> <xpln lang="en">in Denb. in the Lat. 
call'd <etym lang="la">Ruthunia,</etym> in the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Ruthun;</etym> perhaps from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Rhwth</etym> spacious, Broad.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ruthlan(pn)">Ruthlan,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Flintshire; from 
the red Rock or Bank of the 
River <etym lang="cb">Cluyd,</etym> and <etym lang="cb">Llan,</etym> a 
Temple, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Red Church.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rutlandshire(pn)">Rutlandshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Rote&shy;
land</etym>; from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Rud,</etym> 
or <etym lang="gr">Rote,</etym> red, or ruddy, that 
being the colour of the Soil; 
and our words <etym lang="en">Land,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Shire;</etym> which see in the 
Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1>
