<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sacy Forest(pn)">SAcy Forest</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northam&shy;
ptonshire, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Sal&shy;
sey,</etym> from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Salicetum,</etym> a place 
where Willows grow.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saffron Walden(pn)">Saffron Walden,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex; 
from the great store of <etym lang="en">Saf&shy;
fron,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Walden,</etym> which 
comes from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wall</etym>, a 
Trench, or <etym lang="oe">Wall</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, a Dale.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Salisbury(pn)" lexeme="Sarisbury(pn)">Salisbury, <term lang="la">ali&agrave;s</term> Sarisbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">
in Wiltshire, a Bishop's See, 
from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sarisberia;</etym> in 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Searisbyrig</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Searoburg</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Dry 
Town; for the old Town 
stood upon an Hill where no 
Water was, but it is now si&shy;
tuate in a Vailey, and a lit&shy;
tle Brook runs through the 
Streets thereof. See to Sear, 
</page>

<page sig="Hh6r"> 
and Borough, in the Com. 
Names. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saltmersh(pn)">Saltmersh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, by the 
change of one letter, from 
<etym lang="en">Salt,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Marsh.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Samond(pn)">Samond,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
St. <etym lang="en">Amand.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sampier(pn)">Sampier,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Saint Pierre,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
of St. Peter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sampoll(pn)">Sampoll,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Saint Paul,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  of 
St. Paul.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sandon(pn)">Sandon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; (i. e.) San&shy;
dy Town; from <etym lang="en">Sand</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Town;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sandwich(pn)">Sandwich,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; from 
<etym lang="en">Sand,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Wich;</etym> which see 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sassem(pn)">Sassem,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Holland; 
Adr. Jun. supposeth that it 
is called so <term lang="la">quasi</term> <etym lang="bl">Sachsen 
Hiem,</etym> the Saxons Home; 
for its certain that the Sax&shy;
ons once subdued a great 
part of the Low-Countries.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saucheverell(pn)">Saucheverell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Saute,</etym> a Forest, and 
<etym lang="fr">Chevrelle,</etym> a young She-Goat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Saxon(pn)">Saxon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. we find <etym lang="oe">Seaxna &ETH;eod</etym>, the People 
of Saxony, and <etym lang="oe">Eald Seax</etym>, 
an old Saxon; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Seax</etym>, the Goth. Cimbr. 
<etym lang="cb">Saks,</etym> or the Fr. Th. <etym lang="hd">Sahs</etym> 
a Poniard, which the An&shy;
cient Saxons always wore in 
stead of Swords. Mer. Cas. 
draws the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seax</etym>, from 
the Gr. and Pers. <etym lang="pe">&Sigma;&#x1F71;&gamma;&alpha;&rho;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
a kind of short Sword. These 
ancient Saxons were former&shy;
ly divided into a threefold 
People; namely, into the 
Ostphali, Westphali, and An&shy;
garii.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scales(pn)">Scales,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; see <etym lang="EN">Scale</etym> 
in the Com. Names. It is 
the same with the It. <etym lang="it">de la 
Sc&aacute;la,</etym> and Fr. <etym lang="fr">de l' Eschelle,</etym>
made famous by the Princes 
of Verona, and two most 
learned Monarchs, the Fa&shy;
ther and Son, of that 
Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scandia(pn)">Scandia,</form> <xpln lang="en">by the Inhabitants 
called <etym lang="tt">Schoenland</etym>; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="oe">Schoen, Schon</etym>, 
fair, which may come from 
<etym lang="tt">Scheinen</etym>, to shine; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
fair Land, or pleasant Coun&shy;
try.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scarborough(pn)">Scarborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port in York&shy;
shire; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scear</etym>, 
a Scar, and <etym lang="oe">Burg</etym>, a Town, 
saith Camden. Skinner draws 
it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scearp</etym>, 
Sharp, and the same <etym lang="oe">Burg</etym>, 
(i. e.) a Town or Fort by 
a sharp or picked Rock, the 
same, as Scharpenberg, in 
Brabant, and the Fr. Mon&shy;
taigue.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scardale(pn)">Scardale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonsh. a Valley 
encompassed with Rocks; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scear</etym>, a Scar 
or Cape; or from <etym lang="oe">Scearres</etym>, 
Scars, or Rocks; and <etym lang="en">Dale.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scarr(pn)">Scarr,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
other <etym lang="en">Scarr;</etym> which see in 
the Com. Names, and <etym lang="en">Scar&shy;
borough</etym> above.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Schiedam(pn)">Schiedam,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Hol&shy;
land. Adr. Jun. calls it the 
<etym lang="en">Dam</etym> or Wear of the River 
<etym lang="bl">Schie;</etym> see Dam in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Schoon-haven(pn)">Schoon-haven,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City in Hol&shy;
land; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schoon</etym> 
or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schon,</etym> fair, and 
<etym lang="tt">Have,</etym> a Sheep Coat, <etym lang="bl">Hoeve,</etym> 
a Farm, or our Eng. <etym lang="en">Haven.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scots(pn)">Scots,</form> <xpln lang="en">Inhabitants of Scotland; 
also the Name of the People 
call'd Scyth&aelig;. Adr. Jun. draws 
it from our word to <etym lang="en">Shoot,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Archers &kappa;&alpha;&tau;' &#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;; 
see Shoot in the Common 
Names, and Scythae following.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Scyth&aelig;(pn)" lexeme="Scythian(pn)">Scyth&aelig;, or Scythians.</form> <xpln lang="en">Adr. 
Jun. and Voss. suppose that 
they formerly used the Ger&shy;
man Tongue, and that they 
derived their Name from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schieten,</etym> to shoot, 
or cast Darts, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="tt">die Schieters</etym>, the Shooters, by 
way of excellency. See 
Shoot, in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seater(pn)">Seater,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the Germans ; 
Verstegan distinguisheth it 
from Saturn, though without 
ground. Consult Verstegan, 
and see Saturday in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seaton(pn)">Seaton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire; that is 
to say, <etym lang="en">Sea town;</etym> and by 
our Ancestors call'd <etym lang="cb">Moridu&shy;
num</etym>, from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Mor</etym>, 
the Sea, and <etym lang="cb">Dun</etym>, a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en"  lexeme="Sebald(pn)" lexeme="Sewald(pn)">Sebald, or Sewald;</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">S&aelig;</etym>, the Sea, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to rule.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sebart(pn)">Sebart,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the East-&shy;
Saxons, who was the first of 
that People that embraced 
Christianity. Verstegan taketh 
it to be a Contract of <etym lang="oe">Si&shy;
gebert.</etym> It may be drawn 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">S&aelig;</etym>, the Sea, 
and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
renown'd for Sea-Conquests.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seckington(pn)">Seckington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. in the 
Saxons time, call'd <etym lang="oe">Seccan&shy;
dune</etym>; from <etym lang="oe">Secce</etym>, a Fight, 
and <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, a Town or Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seghill(pn)">Seghill,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Secce</etym>, a Fight, 
or <etym lang="oe">Secg</etym>, a Warrier, or 
<etym lang="oe">Sagene</etym>, a Sword, and our 
word <etym lang="en">Hill;</etym> or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieg,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sighe,</etym> Victory, and 
the same <etym lang="en">Hill.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seimore(pn)">Seimore,</form> <xpln lang="en">a noted Sirname 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of <etym lang="en">St. More;</etym> from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Saint Mor,</etym> or 
<etym lang="fr">Maur.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Selby(pn)">Selby,</form> <xpln lang="en">famous for a great Con&shy;
vent, or Abby, the Abbot 
whereof had the Title of 
a Baron of the Realm; from 
the AS, <etym lang="oe">Sel</etym>, Good, Con&shy;
venient, and <etym lang="en">By,</etym> an Habi&shy;
tation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sellenger(pn)">Sellenger,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, a Corr. 
of <etym lang="en">Saintleger,</etym> which comes 
from <etym lang="en">Saint</etym> <etym lang="en">Leodegar</etym>; which 
see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Selrid(pn)">Selrid,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the East-&shy;
Saxons; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sel</etym> 
well, and <etym lang="en">Rede</etym>, Counsel, or 
<etym lang="en">Redan</etym>, to give Advice.</xpln></wordentry>
 
</page> 
 
 <page sig="Hh7r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Selsey(pn)">Selsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex; formerly a 
Bishop's See; but that au&shy;
thority is now removed to 
Chichester, and the place 
become of very small Consi&shy;
deration, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seol</etym>, 
a Seol-fish, and <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Ige</etym>, 
an Isle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Semarc(pn)">Semarc,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from <etym lang="en">Saint 
Medard.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Semarton(pn)">Semarton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
<etym lang="en">Saint Martin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Senly(pn)">Senly,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from <etym lang="en">Saint 
Lizy.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Senilo(pn)">Senilo,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from <etym lang="en">Saint 
Loid.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sentlow(pn)">Sentlow,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Saint Loup,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Saint 
Love.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Seofrid(pn)">Seofrid,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the East-&shy;
Saxons; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Seo</etym>, 
the Sight, and<etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sevenoke(pn)" lexeme="Senoke(pn)">Sevenoke, or Senoke,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; 
so called from 7 great <etym lang="en">Oaks</etym> 
that grew there, but were 
cut down long ago.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Severn(pn)">Severn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River, in the C. Br. 
call'd <term lang="cb">Haffren</term>, in the Lat. <term lang="la">Sabrina.</term></xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shaftsbury(pn)">Shaftsbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dorsetshire; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceaft</etym>, a 
Shaft, or Arrow; or as Cam&shy;
den will have it, a Spire 
Steeple, and <etym lang="en">Bury,</etym> a 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shannon(pn)">Shannon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland, Ptolem. 
calls it <etym lang="la">Senus, Oros. Sena,</etym> and 
in some Copies it is written 
<etym lang="la">Secana,</etym> whence by corrup&shy;
tion Shannon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shaw(pn)">Shaw,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; Camden ex&shy;
pounds it a <etym lang="en">shady</etym> Forest; see 
Shadow in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sheal(pn)">Sheal,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, by inter&shy;
pretation, a Cottage, not un&shy;
likely from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceala</etym>, &shy;
Shells or Rings; because as &shy;
Houses defend the Inhabi&shy;
tants, so Shells the Bird in 
the Egg, and the Rind the 
Pap in the Apple.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shene(pn)">Shene,</form> <xpln lang="en">now Richmond, in 
Surrey, the King's Country 
House, upon the shore of the 
Thames; so called from its 
<etym lang="en">shining</etym>; See Shine in the 
Common Names. Or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Schon,</etym> Fair.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sheppy(pn)">Sheppy,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Isle in the County 
of Kent; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceap-&shy;
Ea</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Sceap-Ige</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
Sheeps Isle, from Sheep 
that abundantly multiply 
therein; and therefore, not 
unelegantly, called by Le&shy;
land, <etym lang="la">Ovinia</etym>, from <etym lang="la">Ovis</etym>, a &shy;
Sheep.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sherborn(pn)">Sherborn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dors. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Scire-burn</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
clear Fountain; see <etym lang="en">Sheer</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Bourn</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sherwood(pn)">Sherwood,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Nottingh. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="en">Sheer Wood;</etym> see <etym lang="en">Sheer,</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Wood,</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shipston(pn)">Shipston,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
<etym lang="en">Sheeps-Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shobery(pn)">Shobery,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sceo</etym>, a Shooe, and <etym lang="oe">Byrig</etym>, 
a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh7v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shoreham(pn)">Shoreham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Scoreham</etym>, and 
this again from <etym lang="oe">score</etym>, a 
shore, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, an home; 
so called, because it lieth to 
the Shoreward; see Shore 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shot(pn)" lexeme="Shut(pn)" lexeme="Shute(pn)">Shot, Shut, or Shute,</form> <xpln lang="en">per&shy;
haps from the Verb to <etym lang="en">shoot;</etym> 
which see in the Com. Names. 
It may likewise be taken 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Schot,</etym> the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Escot,</etym> or our own word 
<etym lang="en">Shot,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Reckoning or 
Club amongst good-fellows.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Shrewsbury(pn)">Shrewsbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">the County 
Town of Shropshire; from 
<etym lang="en">Shrubs</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bury:</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names. In 
the Welsh it is now called 
<term lang="we">ymwithig</term>, from the pleasant 
situation thereof; as the Lat. 
<term lang="la">Placentia</term>, or the Gr. <term lang="gkt">Callipolis</term>, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sicambri(pn)">Sicambri,</form> <xpln lang="en">a People of the 
Netherlands; Jun. draws it 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Such om her,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) Look about thee; which 
he supposeth to have been a 
Motto wrought upon their 
Standard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sichild(pn)">Sichild,</form> <xpln lang="en">Wife to Clothair, 
King of France; perhaps from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieg,</etym> Victory, and 
<etym lang="tt">Helde,</etym> for <etym lang="tt">Heldinne,</etym> a Noble 
Woman.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sidenham(pn)">Sidenham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Devon&shy;
shire; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sid</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Side</etym>, long, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, 
a Village.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sigebald(pn)">Sigebald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieg,</etym> Conquest, and 
<etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, Bold; also swift, saith 
Verstegan, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that is 
quick in pursuit of Victories; 
or that becometh more cou&shy;
rageous than usually after a 
Victory obtain'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sigebert(pn)">Sigebert,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the East-&shy;
English; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieg,</etym> Victory, and 
<etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous. Verstegan 
draws it from the same 
<etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Briht</etym>, advised. 
Kilian from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Sighe,</etym> 
Victory, and <etym lang="bl">Werd,</etym> worthy; 
that is, one worthy of the 
Victory.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sigemer(pn)">Sigemer,</form> <xpln lang="en">Jun. derives it from 
the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Sige,</etym> Victory, and 
<etym lang="gr">Meyer,</etym> a Major; or it may 
be drawn from the same 
<etym lang="gr">Sige,</etym> and <etym lang="gr">Mehren,</etym> to aug&shy;
ment.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sigeric(pn)">Sigeric,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, 
Victory, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, Rich, (i. e.) 
Rich in Conquests.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sighere(pn)">Sighere,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the East-&shy;
Saxons; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, 
Victory, and <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an Ar&shy;
my.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sigismund(pn)">Sigismund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
either as Camden hath it, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, Victory, 
and <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, Peace; that is, 
one that procureth Peace, 
yet so as by Victory; or as 
Jun. and Verstegan write, 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieg,</etym> Victo&shy;
ry, and <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a Mouth; 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh8r"> 
that is, one that conquers his 
Enemies by good words, or 
fair means. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Silcester(pn)">Silcester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire, by Nenn. 
<etym lang="cb">Caer Segonte</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the City, 
or Town of the Segontiacks; 
Camden saith, that the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Selceaster</etym>, denotes a great 
Town; yet I think it rather 
implieth, a fair Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Silly Islands(pn)">Silly Islands;</form> <xpln lang="en">Sulp. Severus 
calls them <etym lang="la">Sillin&aelig; Insul&aelig;;</etym> in 
the Lat. Bar. <etym lang="la">Sorlinges,</etym> 
more frequently; the Greek 
Geographers call 'em Cassite&shy;
rides, namely, from the Stan&shy;
naries, or Mines of Tin.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Simberd(pn)">Simberd,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
<etym lang="en">St. Barbary;</etym> perhaps it was 
formerly read <etym lang="en">Simberb,</etym> which 
in French is rendred <etym lang="fr">de &shy;
Sainte Barbe,</etym> and this is the 
Dim. of the Fr. name <etym lang="fr">Bar&shy;
bare,</etym> with us Barbara, as 
before.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Singlis(pn)">Singlis,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Irish Sirname; 
from <etym lang="en">St. Gelasius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sisebubus(pn)">Sisebubus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spa&shy;
nish Vice-Gothi, in the year 
621; perhaps from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Susz,</etym> sweet, and <etym lang="tt">Butte,</etym> a 
Lip, or Cup.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sisenandus(pn)">Sisenandus,</form> <xpln lang="en">another King of 
the Spanish Vice-Gothi; not 
unlikely from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Susz,</etym> sweet, and <etym lang="tt">Sohnend,</etym> 
coming of the Verb <etym lang="tt">Sohnen,</etym> 
to reconcile.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sitsilt(pn)">Sitsilt,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Sirname , now 
<etym lang="cb">Cecill.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Siwald(pn)">Siwald,</form> <xpln lang="en">heretofore a Christ. 
Name, but now a Sirname; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, Victory, 
and <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to rule.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Siward(pn)">Siward,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
Verstegan saith, that it was 
formerly read <etym lang="en">Sighward;</etym> 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieg,</etym> or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Sighe,</etym> Victory, and <etym lang="tt">Ward,</etym> 
a Keeper; that is, he that 
doth not carelesly lose the 
advantages of a Conquest.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Siwe(pn)">Siwe,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the Germans; 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sige</etym>, 
or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Sieg,</etym> Victory, which 
the Romans worshipp'd as a 
Deity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Skeffington(pn)">Skeffington,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a 
Village; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceap</etym>, 
a Sheep, and <etym lang="en">Town,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Sheeping Town, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
Shepherd's Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Skell(pn)" lexeme="Schell(pn)">Skell, or Schell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Sceale</etym>, a pair 
of Scales.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Skrekingham(pn)">Skrekingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, 
corruptly for <etym lang="en">Trekingham,</etym> 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Place of three Kings; 
because three Danish Kings 
fell here in Battle; from 
<etym lang="en">tre</etym> for three, <etym lang="en">King,</etym> and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, which signifies an 
home or habitation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Smeth(pn)" lexeme="Smeath(pn)">Smeth, or Smeath,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sir&shy;
name; Camden expounds it, 
a Plain, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Smae&eth;e</etym>, smooth, even.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Snell(pn)">Snell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
Belgic. <etym lang="bl">Snel,</etym> the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Schnell,</etym> the It. <etym lang="it">Snello,</etym> or 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Isnel,</etym> swift and nim&shy;
ble.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Hh8v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Snowden(pn)">Snowden,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Caernarv. from 
<etym lang="en">Snow,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, a 
Den, or any receptacle; in 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Craig Eriry</etym>, from 
Snow always seen upon the 
top thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sole(pn)">Sole,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; Camden saith 
that it signifies a Puddle, or 
Pool; yet <etym lang="oe">Sol</etym>, in the AS. is 
put for an Halter, or Stay.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Somersetshire(pn)">Somersetshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">from <etym lang="en">Somer&shy;
ton,</etym> that was formerly the 
chief Town in the County; 
in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Somertun&shy;
scire</etym>, perhaps so called, 
because of the Pleasantness 
of Dwelling in the Summer 
time.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Southampton(pn)">Southampton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Port; 
Anton. calls it <etym lang="la">Clausentum</etym>, from 
<etym lang="la">Clausus</etym>, and the River <etym lang="la">An&shy;
ton:</etym> It is now drawn from 
the same <etym lang="la">Anton,</etym> and <etym lang="en">South,</etym> 
to distinguish it from Nor&shy;
thampton lying more to the 
North. Leland calls it Avon&shy;
dunum, and draws it from the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Avon</etym> or <etym lang="cb">Afon</etym>, a Wa&shy;
ter, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, a 
Bank, or <etym lang="la">tun</etym>, a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Southwark(pn)">Southwark,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey, over 
against London, in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Sou&eth;werc</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a <etym lang="en">Work</etym> 
or Building on the Southside 
of London; see <etym lang="en">South</etym> in 
the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Spencer(pn)">Spencer,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">le Despen&shy;
cer,</etym> a Sirname of a Noble 
Family; from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">le De&shy;
spensier,</etym> that is, a Steward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Spene(pn)">Spene,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Berkshire; 
the old Town called by Anton. 
<etym lang="la">Spen&aelig;.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stafford(pn)">Stafford,</form> <xpln lang="en">a County Town; 
Somner. draws it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stef</etym>, a Staff, and 
<etym lang="en">Ford.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Standard Hill(pn)">Standard hill,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sussex; so 
called, because William the 
Conquerour set up his <etym lang="en">Stan&shy;
dard</etym> on this <etym lang="en">Hill</etym>, before he 
joined Battel with Harhold; 
see Standard and Hill in 
the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stanes(pn)">Stanes,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middlesex; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stana</etym>, Stones.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stanford(pn)">Stanford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, a Stone, and 
<etym lang="en">Ford,</etym> that is, a Stony Ford.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stanley(pn)">Stanley,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, a Stone, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>, 
a Pasture.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stanton(pn)">Stanton,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, 
a Stone, and <etym lang="en">Town,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a Stony Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stany-street(pn)">Stany-street,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey; that 
is to say, <etym lang="en">Stony-street.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stert(pn)">Stert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Foreland in Devonsh. 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stert</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Steort</etym>, a Tail; because like 
a Tail it is stretched out in 
length into the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stert Point(pn)">Stert point</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somersetsh. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a Tailed Promontory; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stert, Steort</etym>, 
a Tail.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stey(pn)">Stey,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stige</etym>, a Path; yet 
Camden, and before him &AElig;l&shy;
fricus, render it a Bank, or 
Wear.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stigand(pn)">Stigand,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop of 
Canterburry, about the time 
of the Arrival of William the 
Conquerour; perhaps from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stigend</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Sti&shy;
gand</etym>, coming of the Verb 
<etym lang="oe">Stigan</etym>, to climb; and sure&shy;
ly none will except against 
his climbing that has the 
good luck to see himself 
seated in an Arch-bishop's 
Chair, without a fall by the 
way.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stiliard(pn)">Stiliard,</form> <xpln lang="en">in London, by the 
Thames side; Minsh. and the 
Learned Th. H. take it to be 
so called from <etym lang="en">Steel,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Yard,</etym> because Merchants 
bring in and set to sale great 
store of Steel therein. There 
is read also <etym lang="en">Stile Yard,</etym> in 
some ancient Writings, which 
may be taken from the 
<etym lang="en">Stile,</etym> that parted it from the 
next Street, that Carts, Coa&shy;
ches and such like Annoyan&shy;
ces, might not interrupt men 
there met together to com&shy;
mune about Merchandice.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stilico(pn)">Stilico,</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Still,</etym> quiet, and 
<etym lang="tt">Leich,</etym> a Funeral.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stoke(pn)">Stoke,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, the same 
with <etym lang="en">Stow,</etym> which signifieth 
a Place, saith Camden: yet 
I had rather draw it from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stocce</etym>, the Trunk 
of a tree; see Zouch, be&shy;
neath.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stoke Flemming(pn)">Stoke Flemming,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonsh. 
from a Noble <etym lang="en">Flemming,</etym> the 
Land-Lord hereof in times 
of yore, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stocce</etym>, 
the Body of a Tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stoneham(pn)">Stoneham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire; see 
<etym lang="en">Stone</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ham,</etym> in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stonehenge(pn)">Stonehenge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltshire; some 
surmise that the great Stones 
seeming as it were to hang 
in this place, were set up for 
Monuments of some famous 
Men that were there slain; 
from <etym lang="en">Stone</etym> and <etym lang="en">Hang:</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stony Stratford(pn)">Stony Stratford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Buck. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Stony-street-ford.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stourminster(pn)">Stourminster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dorsetshire; 
from the River <etym lang="en">Stowr,</etym> and 
a <etym lang="en">Minster,</etym> that formerly 
stood there; from hence like&shy;
wise Sturton, a Village, <term lang="la">quasi</term> 
Stowe Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stow(pn)">Stow,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stow</etym>, a Place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stradling(pn)">Stradling,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, Cor&shy;
ruption of <etym lang="en">Easterling;</etym> which 
see, and <etym lang="en">Sterling</etym> in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Strasburg(pn)">Strasburg,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City in 
the Empire of Germany; per&shy;
haps from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Strasz,</etym> 
a Way, and <etym lang="tt">Burg,</etym> a 
City.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Strathern(pn)">Strathern,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland; from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Straith Ern,</etym> 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Valley by the River 
<etym lang="cb">Ern,</etym> says Skinner, though 
Straith is not found in 
Davis.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Stratton(pn)">Stratton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Shropshire, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="en">Street Town,</etym> or rather 
<etym lang="en">Strait Town,</etym> that is, a 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii1v">
narrow, and strait Town, or 
a Town in a Valley. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Streanes Hall(pn)">Streanes hall,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly fa&shy;
mous for a Covent of English-&shy;
Saxons. Somner draws it 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Streond, 
Strand</etym>, a Strand, or Shore; 
and <etym lang="oe">Heal</etym>, a Corner, or 
<etym lang="oe">Healc</etym>, otherwise <etym lang="oe">Hylc</etym>, a 
Bending, or Turning.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sturbridge(pn)">Sturbridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; that is 
to say, the <etym lang="en">Bridge</etym> of the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Stur.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Suevi(pn)">Suevi,</form> <xpln lang="en">of late <etym lang="tt">Schwauben</etym>, 
formerly a most renowned 
People of Germany; perhaps 
from <etym lang="tt">Schweben,</etym> to move, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a nimble, or active 
People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Suffolk(pn)">Suffolk,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Su&eth;&shy;
folc</etym>, that is, Folk, or Peo&shy;
ple of the South, in opposi&shy;
tion to those of Norfolk.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Suintilla(pn)">Suintilla,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spa&shy;
nish Vice-Gothi; not unlikely 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Suenth,</etym> a 
Wench, by adding the Dim. 
Term. <etym lang="tt">illa,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  little Wench; 
from his pretty little Stature 
or Countenance.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sully(pn)">Sully,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glamorg. an Isle; 
either from <etym lang="en">Sully,</etym> the 
Lord of the Mannor, or from 
the <etym lang="en">Silures,</etym> an ancient Peo&shy;
ple so call'd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sureby(pn)">Sureby,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; Ptole&shy;
my calls it <term lang="gk">&#x1F18;&upsilon;&lambda;&#x1F77;&mu;&epsilon;&nu;&omicron;&nu;</term> <term lang="la">Gabran&shy;
tovicorum</term>; others call it the 
Bay of Safety; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Sure 
Bay.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Surrey(pn)">Surrey,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Su&eth;</etym>, 
the South, and <etym lang="oe">Rea</etym>, a River, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  South of the River, 
as saith Camden. It may also 
come of <etym lang="en">South,</etym> and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Ricg</etym>, a Ridge; or 
from the Fr. G. <etym lang="fr">Sud,</etym> the 
South, and <etym lang="fr">Rive</etym> by contra&shy;
ction <etym lang="fr">Rie,</etym> the Bank of a 
River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sureteyes(pn)">Sureteyes,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Sur Teyse,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  upon 
the River <etym lang="fr">Teyse.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sussex(pn)">Sussex,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Su&eth;sex</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  South Saxony.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Suthred(pn)">Suthred,</form> <xpln lang="en">the last King of the 
East-Saxons; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">So&eth;</etym>, true, and <etym lang="oe">Redan</etym>, 
to speak.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Suthwell(pn)">Suthwell,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Nott. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
<etym lang="en">South Well.</etym> Beda calls it <term lang="oe">Tio&shy;
vul Fingacester</term>, where St. 
Pauline, Arch-Bishop of York 
baptized the People of this 
Country in the River Trent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sutton(pn)">Sutton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Devon&shy;
shire, and elsewhere, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">South Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Swain(pn)">Swain,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Danish 
Christ. Name , but now a Sir&shy;
name; from the old word 
<etym lang="en">Swain</etym> a Countryman, or 
Farmer; see Swain in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Swaldale(pn)">Swaldale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; from 
the River <etym lang="en">Swale,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Dale,</etym> a Valley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Swanescomb(pn)">Swanescomb,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; either 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">Swaines-camp,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Swaines-comb,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
Valley of <etym lang="da">Swaine,</etym> a General of 
the Danes; that pitched his 
Tents here.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii2r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sweden(pn)">Sweden,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly the Seat 
of the ancient Gothi, the Van&shy;
dali, and the <etym lang="la">Suiones;</etym> from 
which last in tract of time, 
the Country came to be 
called Sweden.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Swithelm(pn)">Swithelm,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the East-&shy;
Saxons; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Swi&eth;e</etym>, 
greatly, and <etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, proper&shy;
ly, an Helmet, and by tran&shy;
slation, Safegard, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that protecteth others with 
might and main.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Swithin(pn)">St. Swithin,</form> <xpln lang="en">Bishop of Winche&shy;
ster; formerly <etym lang="en">Switheahn;</etym> 
Camden draws it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Swi&eth;e</etym>, greatly, and <etym lang="oe">Heah</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Heahn</etym>, high: It may al&shy;
so not improbably be drawn 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Swith,</etym> Va&shy;
liant, and <etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, an Hel&shy;
met, and so may seem to be 
a depravation of <etym lang="en">Swith&shy;
helm</etym> next above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Syncler(pn)">Syncler,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Sainte Claire,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
of <etym lang="en">St. Claire.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="T"><alpha>T</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Tabb's(pn)">St. Tabb's,</form> <xpln lang="en">(i. e.) the 
Church of <etym lang="en">St. Ebba;</etym> 
see St. Ebba above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tadcaster(pn)">Tadcaster,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tade</etym>, a Toad, and 
<etym lang="oe">ceaster</etym>, a Castle, perhaps 
because the Ditch or Trench 
cast round it might abound 
with Toads.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tailbois(pn)">Tailbois,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Tailler,</etym> to cut, and 
<etym lang="fr">bois,</etym> a Wood, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Car&shy;
penter.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tamerton(pn)">Tamerton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall; for&shy;
merly called <etym lang="en">Tamara;</etym> from 
the River <etym lang="en">Tamara,</etym> and by 
adding the AS. <etym lang="oe">tun</etym>, a Town, 
Tamerton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tamworth(pn)">Tamworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Staffordshire; 
from the River <etym lang="en">Tama,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weor&eth;</etym>, or 
<etym lang="oe">Wor&eth;</etym>, an Isle, or Holme, 
also a Court, or Country-&shy;
house; as in Germany, <etym lang="tt">Kei&shy;
serwert</etym>, and <etym lang="tt">Bomelswert</etym>, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Isle of C&aelig;sar, and 
Bomelius.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tancred(pn)">Tancred,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of Naples and 
Sicily, of the Norman race; 
not unlikely from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;ancgian</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dancken,</etym> to give thanks; 
it may also be drawn 
from <etym lang="tt">Danck,</etym> thanks, and 
<etym lang="tt">Reden,</etym> to speak.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii2v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tanfara(pn)">Tanfara,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the ancient 
Germans, whose most stately 
Temple Germanicus C&aelig;sar le&shy;
velled with the ground. Jun. 
draws it from the Article 
<etym lang="en">The,</etym> and <etym lang="tt">Anfang,</etym> a begin&shy;
ning; perhaps he was among 
them the same that Saturn 
was among the Romans.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tavistoke(pn)">Tavistoke,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Devonsh. 
from the River <etym lang="en">Teav,</etym> and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stow</etym>, a place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Taunton(pn)">Taunton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fine Town in Som. 
q. <etym lang="en">Thonton;</etym> from the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Thon,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ton,</etym> for 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tees(pn)">Tees,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in the Bishop&shy;
rick of Durham called by 
Ptolemy <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&omicron;&#x1F7B;&alpha;&sigma;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&Tau;&#x1F7B;&epsilon;&sigma;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, and 
thence by corruption Tees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Teifedale(pn)">Teifedale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a <etym lang="en">Dale</etym> by the River <etym lang="en">Tefy,</etym> 
or <etym lang="en">Teviat.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Teiguemouth(pn)">Teiguemouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire; 
that is the <etym lang="en">Mouth</etym> of the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Teigue.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bishops Teiguton(pn)">Bishops Teiguton</form> <xpln lang="en">, a place of 
Refuge or Sanctuary in for&shy;
mer times; a Village upon 
the same River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="St. Telean(pn)">St. Telean,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welshman, Bi&shy;
shop of Landaff. I take it 
to be a corruption of the 
Heb. <etym lang="he">Elias,</etym> or the Lat. <etym lang="la">AElig;lius;</etym> 
though some allusively, in 
the respect of his Piety and 
Learning, have call'd him 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F25;&lambda;&iota;&omicron;&nu;</etym>, that is, Apollo, or the 
Son.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Temesford(pn)">Temesford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Bedfordshire; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Ford</etym> of the <etym lang="en">Thames,</etym> 
and Owse; see Thames 
below.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Temple Bruer(pn)">Temple Bruer,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire; 
from <etym lang="en">Temple,</etym> and the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Bruyere,</etym> a place where Heath, 
Briars, &amp;c. grow. Temple, 
a Sirname, from the <etym lang="en">Knights 
Templars,</etym> or Officers in the 
Temple of Jerusalem.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Isle of Tenet(pn)" lexeme="Isle of Thanet(pn)">Isle of Tenet or Thanet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Kent; Solinus calls it <etym lang="la">Atha&shy;
naton,</etym> and from hence 
<etym lang="la">Thanaton,</etym> which may come 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Theta;&#x1F71;&nu;&alpha;&gamma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, death, 
because, as our Author re&shy;
lates, it killeth Serpents that 
are brought into it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Teringham(pn)">Teringham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village, as also 
a Sirname of a Family; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eorian</etym>, to faint, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, a Village; or <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Tiringham,</etym> because, being 
situate upon an Hill, the a&shy;
scent is difficult, and causes 
weariness.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Terry(pn)">Terry,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name for&shy;
merly, though now a Sir&shy;
name only; from the Fr. 
<etym lang="fr">Thierry,</etym> and this very pro&shy;
bably a Contract of the Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Theodoric;</etym> which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Teukesbury(pn)">Teukesbury</form> <xpln lang="en">in Gloc. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
Church of <etym lang="en">St. Teuke,</etym> an Her&shy;
mit.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Teutobocchus(pn)">Teutobocchus,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient King 
of the <etym lang="la">Teutones</etym>, who with his 
Army was vanquished by 
Caius Marius; in the Germ. 
he is call'd <etym lang="tt">Theodway</etym>, from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, People, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wagian</etym>, Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeghen</etym>, 
to move, or put forward; or 
<etym lang="tt">Theodweck</etym>, from the same 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii3r">
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wec&shy;
ken</etym>, to awake. Jun. writes 
it <etym lang="oe">Stautebec,</etym> and derives 
it from <etym lang="en">Stout,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Beak;</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thames(pn)">Thames,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Latin <etym lang="la">Tamesis,</etym> a 
famous River; the Port of 
London; so called from the 
meeting together of the Ri&shy;
vers <etym lang="en">Tame,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Owse.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thelwall(pn)">Thelwall,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cheshire; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;el</etym>, the Trunk 
of a tree, and <etym lang="oe">Wall,</etym> a 
Trench.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theobald(pn)">Theobald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
either, as Camden hath it, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, People, 
and <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, Bold; or as Verst. 
and Kiliam <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Belg. <etym lang="bl">Theud&shy;
bald,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="bl">Bald Deughde&shy;
lick,</etym> early Virtuous or Vali&shy;
ant, from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Deughde,</etym> 
Virtue, or Valour, and <etym lang="bl">Bald,</etym> 
soon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theodebert(pn)">Theodebert,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, People, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
famous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theodelinda(pn)">Theodelinda,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Queen of the 
Longobardi of Italy; from the 
old Teut. and AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eode</etym>, 
People, and <etym lang="oe">Lind</etym>, mild; 
whence <etym lang="oe">Linden</etym>, to asswage.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theodohatus(pn)">Theodohatus,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the 
Ostro-Gothi of Italy; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, People, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Hatan</etym>, 
to hate, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that was 
hated of the People.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theodomir(pn)">Theodomir,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Spanish Swedes, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, People, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to augment, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one that extends the Limits 
of his Empire by adding 
more People or Countries to 
his own.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theodoric(pn)" lexeme="Derrick(pn)">Theodoric, by Contraction 
Derrick,</form> <xpln lang="en">and in Fr. <etym lang="fr">Thierry</etym>, 
in the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Diderick</etym>, saith 
Versteg. from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Deughde,</etym> Virtue, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, 
Rich. Camden draws it more 
near, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, 
People, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, a Kingdom; 
also Rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theodulph(pn)">Theodulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="gk">&ETH;eod</etym>, People, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theofred(pn)">Theofred,</form> <xpln lang="en">Son to Reciswindus, 
King of the Spanish Vice-&shy;
Gothi, from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, 
People, and <etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thetford(pn)">Thetford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norfolk; from 
the River <etym lang="en">Thet,</etym> and <etym lang="en">ford.</etym> 
It was heretofore a Bishop's 
See.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theudebald(pn)">Theudebald,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Goths; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Deughde,</etym> Valour, and <etym lang="bl">Bald,</etym> 
soon, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) valiant betimes. 
I may also draw it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, People, and 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym> to rule.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theudes(pn)" lexeme="Thudo(pn)">Theudes, or Thudo,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of 
the Spanish Vice-Gothi; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod</etym>, People. It 
answers the Lat. Poplicola.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Theudomar(pn)">Theudomar,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient Ger&shy;
man Name; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Deughde,</etym> formerly <etym lang="bl">Theude,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii3v">
valour, and <etym lang="bl">Meyer</etym>, a Ma&shy;
jor; or from the AS. and 
old Germ. <etym lang="tt">Theod, Theode,</etym> 
People, and the same <etym lang="tt">Meyer,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, famous, 
or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to aug&shy;
ment; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;eoden</etym>, to Master, and the 
same <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, famous. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thirlwall Castle(pn)">Thirlwall Castle</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northum&shy;
berland; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;irl</etym>, 
a hole, (whence <etym lang="oe">&ETH;irlian</etym>, to 
make a hole through, to 
drill,) and <etym lang="en">Wall;</etym> Because 
the Scots in their Invasion of 
England, made several holes 
or gaps in the Partition Wall 
which the Emperor Severus 
built for the division of the 
two Kingdoms, for their bet&shy;
ter conveniency of entring 
and retreating.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thistleworth(pn)">Thistleworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middlesex, 
formerly <etym lang="en">Gistleworth;</etym> from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">gisle</etym>, or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Gistel,</etym> a Hostage, and <etym lang="tt">Worth,</etym> 
a Court, or Hall, because the 
Hostages from Foreign Coun&shy;
tries were here kept by 
the Triumphant West-Saxon 
Kings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thor(pn)">Thor,</form> <xpln lang="en">the chief God of the 
ancient Germans, equal to 
Jupiter of the Romans; either 
a Contract of <etym lang="en">Thunder,</etym> be&shy;
cause he was their God of 
Thunder; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">teran</etym>, to tear, because he 
may be said to rend the 
Clouds; or from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Tieren,</etym> to cry with a loud 
voice. See Thunder, Tear, 
and Thursday, in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thorismundus(pn)">Thorismundus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the 
Spanish Vice-Gothi; either 
from <etym lang="en">Thor</etym> above, and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> a Mouth, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
He that doth as it were 
thunders with his voice, or 
speaketh as majestically as 
Jove himself: or contrari&shy;
wise from the AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;ore, 
&ETH;ure</etym>, a Door, and <etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, 
Peace, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Gate of 
Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thorney(pn)">Thorney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire; in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">&ETH;orn Ige</etym>, the Thorny 
Isle; see Thorn, and Ea, 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thory(pn)">Thory,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; either from 
<etym lang="en">Thor,</etym> the ancient Saxon and 
Germans Jupiter; or from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Thore,</etym> a Door, or 
<etym lang="tt">Thor,</etym> distracted.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Thrasimund(pn)">Thrasimund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name 
frequent among the Longo&shy;
bardi of Italy; Kilian draws 
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Te Rasch,</etym> 
too Rash, and <etym lang="bl">Mund,</etym> a 
Mouth, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that 
speaketh without delibera&shy;
tion.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Throckmorton(pn)">Throckmorton,</form> <xpln lang="en"><term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="en">The Rock-&shy;
Moor-Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tilbury(pn)">Tilbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex; Beda calls it 
<etym lang="en">Tilabury,</etym> from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Tilian</etym>, to toil, or labour 
greatly, and <etym lang="oe">Burg,</etym> a Town; 
so call'd, from the hard and 
even stony life of St. Ceadda, 
Bishop of the East Saxons.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tindall(pn)">Tindall,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberl. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii4r"> 
a <etym lang="en">Dale</etym> or Valley by the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Tine.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tine(pn)">Tine,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lat. <etym lang="la">Tina</etym>, a River in 
Northumb. from <etym lang="cb">Tin,</etym> which 
in the C. Br. signifieth nar&shy;
row. If it may not come 
from our word <etym lang="en">Tiny</etym> or lit&shy;
tle; see Tiny in the Com. 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tinmouth(pn)">Tinmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the <etym lang="en">Mouth</etym> of the Ri&shy;
ver <etym lang="en">Tine.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tipkins(pn)">Tipkins,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
<etym lang="en">Tib,</etym> for <etym lang="en">Tibald,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Theo&shy;
bald,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Kin,</etym> which dimi&shy;
nisheth, q. d. Little Theobald; 
see Theobald, above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tir-conell(pn)">Tir-Conell,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ireland; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">Terra Cornelii,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Land 
of <etym lang="la">Cornelius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tiroen(pn)">Tiroen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Country in Ireland; 
the ancient Irish call'd it 
<etym lang="ir">Tir-Eogain,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) <etym lang="la">terra 
Eugenij,</etym> or the Land of <etym lang="la">Eu&shy;
genius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tirrell(pn)">Tirrell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; in French 
<etym lang="fr">de la Tourelle,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of a 
Turret: or as the Learned 
Th. H. telleth us, from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">Tiret,</etym> to shoot; the first 
of this Name having been 
Archer to William the Se&shy;
cond, when he went a Hunt&shy;
ing.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tivi(pn)">Tivi,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Cardig. in 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Dwr Tivi,</etym> the Wa&shy;
ter of <etym lang="cb">Tivi.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tolestale(pn)">Tolestale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dublin in Ireland, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Toll-takers or Pub&shy;
licans Stall; see <etym lang="en">Toll,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Stall,</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tong Castle(pn)" lexeme="Thong Castle(pn)">Tong Castle, or rather Thong 
Castle</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent; so called, 
because Vortigern King of the 
Britains gave Hengist the 
Saxon so much Land here, as 
he could compass about with 
an Oxe's Hide cut into as 
small <etym lang="en">Thongs</etym> as he could.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tooly(pn)">Tooly,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; if Camden's 
authority may be rely'd on, 
it was formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, and a Corruption of 
<etym lang="en">St. Olave.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Torbay(pn)">Torbay,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Bay in Devonshire; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tor</etym>, a Tower, 
and <etym lang="en">Bay;</etym> which see in the 
Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Torcester(pn)">Torcester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northamp. from 
the AS. <etym lang="en">Tor</etym>, a Tower, and 
<etym lang="oe">ceaster</etym>, a Castle, though 
Marian calls it <etym lang="en">Tovecester;</etym> 
as if it should come of the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Towe</etym>, Tow or Flax, and 
<etym lang="oe">ceaster</etym>, a Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Torkesey(pn)">Torkesey,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Turcesige</etym>, for <etym lang="oe">Troge&shy;
sige</etym>, saith Somner, from 
<etym lang="oe">troge</etym>, a Cock-boat, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ige</etym>, an Island.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Torold(pn)">Torold,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, according to Camden, 
but now a Sirname; deri&shy;
ved from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tor</etym>, a 
Tower, and <etym lang="en">Old,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Old 
Castle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tory(pn)">Tory,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Caern. Ptole&shy;
my calls it <term lang="gkt">Tobius</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Totnes(pn)" lexeme="Totenais(pn)">Totnes, or Totenais, in De&shy;
vonshire;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Totene,</etym> 
the fish called a Polypus, which 
is often caught there.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii4v">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Traith-taff(pn)">Traith-Taff,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Glam. Ptole&shy;
my calls it <term lang="gkt">Ratostabius</term>; from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Traith,</etym> the Tide, 
and the River <etym lang="cb">Taff.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tre-baldwin(pn)" lexeme="Trefaldwin(pn)">Tre-Baldwin, or Trefald&shy;
win,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Montgom. that is 
the Town of one Baldwin 
Bollers, the Land-Lord there&shy;
of; from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Tre</etym> a 
Town, and <etym lang="en">Baldwin.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Treboeth(pn)">Treboeth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
in the C. Br. The Burnt 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tregenie(pn)">Tregenie,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornwall; from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Tre,</etym> a Town, and 
<etym lang="cb">Geneu,</etym> a Port. Gate, or En&shy;
trance, so call'd from its be&shy;
ing situate near Falmouth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tregian(pn)">Tregian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; perhaps 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Tre,</etym> a Town, 
and <etym lang="en">Giant,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Giants 
Town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trekingham(pn)">Trekingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Linc. from 3 
Danish Kings there slain in 
Battle .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trent(pn)">Trent,</form> <xpln lang="en">a noted River; Som&shy;
ner takes it to be a Contract 
or Corruption of the C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Dour-went, Dar-went,</etym> or <etym lang="cb">Da&shy;
rent;</etym> see Darwent.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tribocci(pn)">Tribocci,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People 
of one of the Provinces of 
Germany, now call'd Alsatia. 
Some do suppose that they 
had this name from their 
love to Luxury; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="tt">Trey 
bauchen,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) having three 
Bellies, from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Trey,</etym> 
or <etym lang="tt">Drey,</etym> three, and <etym lang="tt">Bauch</etym> 
a Belly, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  big Belly'd peo&shy;
ple. Glareanus, to wipe off 
the disgrace cast upon his 
Country by such a deriva&shy;
tion, draws it from <etym lang="tt">Trey,</etym> 
three, and <etym lang="tt">Buchen,</etym> Beech-&shy;
trees.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trino-bantes(pn)">Trino-bantes,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient Bri&shy;
tish-People, that resided in 
Middlesex and Essex; not from 
<etym lang="la">Troja nova,</etym> as say Chronolo&shy;
gers, for we have nothing 
to do with the Trojans; but, 
as Camden surmiseth, from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Tre-nant,</etym> that is 
to say, a Town in a Valley; for 
this Country is lower and 
lower, as it draws nearer to 
the Thames, in the fashion of 
a Valley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trisanton(pn)">Trisanton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Ptolem. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  C. Br. 
<etym lang="cb">Traith Anton.</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Tide 
of the River Anton.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tristram(pn)">Tristram,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-name, 
perhaps for <etym lang="en">Tristan,</etym> which 
may come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Tri&shy;
stis,</etym> sad; or it may be the same 
with <etym lang="en">Turstan;</etym> which see 
below.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tru-ar-drait-bay(pn)">Tru-Ar-Drait-Bay,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Corn&shy;
wall, in the British tongue , it 
implieth as much as, the Bay 
at a Town built upon the Sand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Trubridge(pn)">Trubridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltshire; in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Tru&eth;abyrig</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
secure, or firm Town; see 
True, Bury, Borough, and 
Bridge, in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Truro(pn)" lexeme="Trura(pn)">Truro, or as they say in Cornw. 
Trura,</form> <xpln lang="en">from three Rows, or 
Streets encompassed with 
two Rivers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tuisco(pn)">Tuisco,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the ancient 
Germans; in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tues</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Tiwes</etym>, from <etym lang="oe">&ETH;wean</etym>, in 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii5r">
the Theot. <etym lang="tt">Thuagan, Thu&shy;
ahan,</etym> to wash, or Purge; 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the expiatory God; see 
Tuesday, in the Com. Names, 
and Dutch in its place. We 
may also with some probabi&shy;
lity draw it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">&ETH;eod,</etym> People, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">&ETH;eodisc</etym>, 
(i. e.) the People's tutelar 
God. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tulga(pn)">Tulga,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spanish 
Vice-Gothi, in the Year 640. 
perhaps from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Dolch,</etym> a Poinado, or Poy&shy;
nard.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tunbridge(pn)">Tunbridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, from 
<etym lang="en">Town</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bridge;</etym> It an&shy;
swers the Gr. <term lang="gkt">Gephyra</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Turbervill(pn)">Turbervill,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="la">de Turbida Villa,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  of the 
turbulent Village.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Turchill(pn)">Turchill;</form> <xpln lang="en">Camden saith, that 
it was formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name; however it is now 
become a Sirname; and may 
be drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Tor</etym>, 
a Tower, and <etym lang="oe">Cild</etym>, a Child, 
that is, a Child born, or found 
in a Tower.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Turstan(pn)">Turstan,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, but now a Sirname. 
Camden derives it from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Treowestan</etym>, the Su&shy;
perlative of <etym lang="oe">Treow</etym>, true, 
faithful; or 'tis the same 
with <etym lang="en">Tristram,</etym> above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tutbury(pn)" lexeme="Sturesbury Castle(pn)">Tutbury, or Sturesbury Ca&shy;
stle in Staff.</form> <xpln lang="en">perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Stod</etym>, a Stallion, and 
<etym lang="oe">Byrig</etym>, a Town; there be&shy;
ing Plenty of good Horses 
bred there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tuttle Fields(pn)">Tuttle Fields,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Tut&shy;
hill Fields</etym> near Westmin&shy;
ster; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Stod</etym>, 
a Horse, and our words <etym lang="en">hill</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Fields.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Twedale(pn)">Twedale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
a Valley by the River <etym lang="en">Twede,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Twede-dale.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Twerton(pn)">Twerton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Devonshire, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Twifford-Town,</etym> a <etym lang="en">Town</etym> 
having <etym lang="en">two</etym> <etym lang="en">Fords</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Twiford(pn)">Twiford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumb. that is 
to say, a <etym lang="en">twofold Ford.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Twinamburn(pn)">Twinamburn,</form> <xpln lang="en">now Christ-&shy;
Church, in Hantshire; so 
called, because it is situate 
between <etym lang="en">two</etym> <etym lang="en">Bourns</etym> or lit&shy;
tle Rivers; see Two, and 
Bourn, in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Twist(pn)">Twist,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Kent; so 
called from its <etym lang="en">Twistings</etym> and 
Windings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Tyburn(pn)">Tyburn,</form> <xpln lang="en">a place near London, 
the Publick place for Execu&shy;
tion of Criminals within Lon&shy;
don and Middlesex, not from 
Tying, and Burning, as some 
will have it, but from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Twy</etym>, Two, and <etym lang="oe">Byrna</etym>, 
in our old English Bourn, a 
small River; from two Brooks 
that formerly run thereby, 
but are now dry'd up.</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>
</page>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vadomarius(pn)">VAdomarius,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of 
the Alemanni, Co&shy;
temporary with Ju&shy;
lian the Apostate; 
perhaps from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Wade,</etym> a Garment and <etym lang="bl">Mey&shy;
er,</etym> an Overseer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vachalis(pn)" lexeme="Vahalis(pn)">Vahalis, or as Adr. Jun. has 
it Vachalis,</form> <xpln lang="en"> in the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Waal,</etym> a River in the Ne&shy;
therlands; or rather an Arm 
of the Rhine. Jun. draws it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Waeghen,</etym> to 
waggle. I had rather draw 
it from <etym lang="bl">Wallen,</etym> to be trou&shy;
bled, or to flow to and a&shy;
gain.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vale of Red Horse(pn)">Vale of red Horse,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Warw. 
from the Figure of an <etym lang="en">Horse,</etym> 
in a <etym lang="en">Valley,</etym> on whose Neck 
were <etym lang="en">red</etym> marks.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vally of White Horse(pn)">Vally of White Horse,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Berkshire; so call'd from the 
form of a <etym lang="en">Horse</etym> represented 
upon a <etym lang="en">white</etym> or Sunny 
Bank.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vandal(pn)">Vandals,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People of 
Scandia, as also Germany, fa&shy;
mous for their remarkable 
Conquests, even to the Sub&shy;
version of the Roman Em&shy;
pire; either from the Germ. 
<etym lang="gr">Wandelen, Wandeln,</etym> to 
<emend err="to "></emend>wander abroad; for com&shy;
ing from Sweden and Dane-&shy;
Land, the remotest Parts in 
the North, they extended 
their Victories over Spain and 
Mauritania. Adr. Jun. de&shy;
rives it from the <etym lang="la">Dalii,</etym> a Peo&shy;
ple of Scandia, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Van De</etym> or <etym lang="bl">Der Dalen;</etym> 
or Teut. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="tt">Von die Tha&shy;
len,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  People that inha&shy;
bit the Valleys.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vannius(pn)">Vannius,</form> <xpln lang="en">Cotemporary with 
Claudius Nero, a King of the 
Swedes; perhaps from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wan</etym>, wan, or pale.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vaughan(pn)">Vaughan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; per&shy;
haps from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Vachan,</etym> 
little, small.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vaux(pn)">Vaux,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from a Town 
in France of the same Name .</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ubii(pn)">Vbii,</form> <xpln lang="en">an ancient People of 
Germany, that lived where 
the famous City of Colonia A&shy;
grippina now stands; perhaps 
from the Germ. <etym lang="gr">Ob,</etym> or <etym lang="gr">Oben,</etym> 
above; that is to say, the Up&shy;
per People compared with 
those of the Low-Countries.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ubsford(pn)" lexeme="Ufford(pn)">Vbsford, or Vfford,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village 
so call'd, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Ford of 
<etym lang="oe">Ubba,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Uffa,</etym> the first King 
of the East-English.</xpln></wordentry>

<page sig="Ii6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Uchtred(pn)">Vchtred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
Camden draws it from the 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Hoch</etym> or <etym lang="gr">Hoogh,</etym> lofty, 
and <etym lang="gr">Rede,</etym> Counsel.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Velleda(pn)">Velleda</form> <xpln lang="en">the Germans Sibylla; 
Kilian draws is from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Veel,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Viel,</etym> much, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Leeden,</etym> or Teut. <etym lang="tt">Leiden,</etym> 
to suffer.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vernulph(pn)">Vernulph,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Goth that slew 
King Athaulph; Jun. expounds 
it, an old beaten Soldier; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Fern, Ferner,</etym> old, 
and <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Veromirus(pn)">Veromirus,</form> <xpln lang="en">Chief of the Teu&shy;
tones in Aug. C&aelig;sar's time; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vere,</etym> pas&shy;
sage by Water, and <etym lang="bl">Meyer,</etym> 
a Major. I could also draw 
it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Werre,</etym> 
with us War, and <etym lang="tt">Meyer,</etym> 
a Major; see War, and Ma&shy;
jor in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Verulamium(pn)">Verulamium,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City 
of England, in the time of 
the Romans, out of the Ru&shy;
ins whereof was raised St. Al&shy;
bans in Hertfordshire; perhaps 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gw&ecirc;r,</etym> fatness, 
and <etym lang="cb">Llonn,</etym> pleasant; from 
the pleasantness and fertility 
of the place.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Viader(pn)" lexeme="Viadrus(pn)">Viader, or Viadrus,</form> <xpln lang="en">now O&shy;
der, a famous River in Ger&shy;
many; perhaps from the 
breadth of its Current, <term lang="la">viz.</term>  
from <etym lang="en">Wider,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Wide,</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names; Or 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Oed,</etym> or <etym lang="tt">Oe&shy;
der,</etym> without Inhabitants, be&shy;
cause it runs through a Land, 
where no body dwelleth.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Viander(pn)">Viander,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City in Holland; 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wije,</etym> or 
<etym lang="bl">Wiide,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weide,</etym> 
a Willow-tree; from the 
plenteous increase of Wil&shy;
lows, which all Holland, as 
being low &amp; fenny, is full of.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Victericus(pn)">Victericus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Spa&shy;
nish Vice-Gothi; from the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wicht Gewicht,</etym> 
weight, and <etym lang="tt">Reich,</etym> or the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vidishindus(pn)">Vidishindus,</form> <xpln lang="en">another King of 
the Spanish Vice-Gothi; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weide,</etym> a Willow, 
and <etym lang="tt">Winden,</etym> to winde, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Basket-maker.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Vizes(pn)">The Vizes,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltsh. perhaps 
from our word to <etym lang="en">Devise;</etym> 
which see in the Com. Names. 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Castle built with much 
curiosity of Workmanship 
and Art.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vipount(pn)">Vipount,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; former&shy;
ly <etym lang="en">de Vipount;</etym> from the 
Fr. <etym lang="fr">de Vieux Pont,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) of the 
old Bridge.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Visurgis(pn)">Visurgis,</form> <xpln lang="en">now <etym lang="en">Weiser,</etym> a famous 
Riv. in Germ, from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Weisz, Weisser,</etym> white; from 
the whiteness of its Water.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vitigis(pn)">Vitigis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Ostro-&shy;
Gothi of Italy; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wittig</etym>, or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wit&shy;
tigh</etym>, witty; which see, and 
Wit, in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Vitsan(pn)">Vitsan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a place upon the Fr. 
shore over against Kent; not 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gwith</etym>, a par&shy;
tition, as Camden surmiseth, 
but corrupted from the Eng&shy;
lish <etym lang="en">Whitesand.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
