<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ulster(pn)">Vlster,</form> <xpln lang="en">a large County toward 
the North in Ireland; in Lat. 
call'd <etym lang="la">Ultonia</etym> and <etym lang="la">Ulidia,</etym> in 
Irish <etym lang="ir">Cui Guilly,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
County Guilly. It was for&shy;
merly the Seat of the Darni, 
Robogdii, Erdini and <etym lang="la">Voluntii;</etym> 
from which last, 'tis proba&shy;
ble, came the Names Ultonia, 
Ulidia, and Guilly.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Unulphus(pn)">Vnulphus,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
frequent among the Longo&shy;
bardi of Italy; from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Ohne,</etym> without, and <etym lang="tt">Ulph</etym>, 
help; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) forlorn.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Urdehead(pn)">Vrdehead,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ord</etym>, an Edge, and 
<etym lang="en">Head,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a piked Pro&shy;
montory.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ure(pn)">Ure,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Vrus,</etym> a River 
in Yorkshire, which in the 
Romans time wash'd Isurium, 
a Town of the Brigantes, 
which is now call'd Ald&shy;
borough. Urus was after&shy;
ward by the English Saxons, 
called <etym lang="en">Oure,</etym> now <etym lang="en">Owse.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Urian(pn)">Vrian,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Danish Christ. Name ; 
the same with our Name 
George; which see above.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ushant(pn)">Vshant,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Cornw. the Romans 
call'd it <etym lang="la">Uxantissa Insula.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Usk(pn)">Vsk,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Monm. in 
Lat: <etym lang="la">Isca.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Uther Pendragon(pn)">Vther Pendragon,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of 
the Britains; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Head 
of a Dragon; because he 
had upon his Standard the 
form of a Dragon's Head, as 
the Romans also had in the 
last Ages of the Empire, saith 
Claudian. Vther is derived 
either from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Uthr, 
Uther,</etym> to be admired; or 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Eutherius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Utrecht(pn)">Vtrecht,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City and 
County in the Netherlands, 
formerly a Bishop's See; in 
Lat. call'd <etym lang="la">Trajectum ad Rhe&shy;
num,</etym> and <etym lang="la">Ultrajectum,</etym> of 
which it is a Contract, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the best Trajection, or passage 
over the Rhine; <etym lang="la">Ultrajectum</etym>, 
from the People <etym lang="la">Wulti,</etym> or 
<etym lang="la">Wilti,</etym> and the old Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Drecht,</etym> a Town, as some 
will have it; or because it 
was <etym lang="la">Ulpius Trajan</etym> the Empe&shy;
rour's Trajection.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Uxbridge(pn)">Vxbridge,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Middl. formerly 
<etym lang="en">Waxbridge,</etym> because the Clay 
is soft under foot like <etym lang="en">wax</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Uxeter(pn)">Vxeter,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Staffordshire; a con&shy;
tract of <etym lang="en">Vtoxeter,</etym> by the 
Romans called <etym lang="la">Etocetum.</etym> </xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="W"><alpha>W</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wacho(pn)" lexeme="Wacarius(pn)">WAcho or Wacarius,</form> <xpln lang="en">
a King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi, in the year 
500. either from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wacker,</etym> of a quick, 
sharp Nature; or from <etym lang="tt">Wa&shy;
cher,</etym> a Part. of the Verb 
<etym lang="tt">Wachen,</etym> to watch.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wainfleet(pn)">Wainfleet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lincolnshire, re&shy;
markable for the Nativity of 
William Bishop of Winchester, 
the Founder of Magdalens 
College in Oxford, and of a 
Grammar-School in this 
Town; perhaps from <etym lang="en">Wain,</etym> 
the Contract. of <etym lang="en">Wagon,</etym> 
and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fleot</etym>, a 
River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wakeman(pn)">Wakeman,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Watchman, from the Verb 
to <etym lang="en">Wake;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walarand(pn)">Walarand,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christ. 
Name, but now a Sirname; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Walpian</etym>, to 
rowl, and <etym lang="oe">Rand</etym>, in the old 
Danish <etym lang="da">Raund,</etym> and <etym lang="da">Ren&shy;
dur,</etym> a Shield, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that 
brandisheth his Shield. The 
Sirname Waldron is a Con&shy;
tract of Walarand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walbert(pn)" lexeme="Gualbert(pn)">Walbert, or Gualbert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
Germ. Christen-Name; from 
the AS. and Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wall,</etym> a 
Wall, and the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Berd,</etym> 
a Board; or from the same 
<etym lang="tt">Wall</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, famous.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wallbrook(pn)">Wallbrook,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Street in London, 
from Lucius <etym lang="la">Gallus</etym> a Roman 
Captain, that was slain there, 
and a <etym lang="en">Brook</etym>, which is now 
dried up; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Gallbrook.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walburg(pn)">Walburg,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christ. Name of 
a Woman; possibly from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wall</etym>, a wall, and <etym lang="oe">Burg,</etym> 
for Borough, a Town; or 
from the same <etym lang="oe">Wall</etym>, and 
<etym lang="oe">Borh</etym>, a Bail, or Surety; 
(i. e.) She that defendeth 
the Walls.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Waldemar(pn)">Waldemar,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Danish Christen-&shy;
Name, from the old Goth. 
and Germ. <etym lang="gr">Wald,</etym> Power, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mehren,</etym> to am&shy;
plifie, that is to say, he that 
amplifieth his Dominions by 
Victories; or from the same 
<etym lang="gr">Wald,</etym> and the AS. <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, 
famous. Jun. draws it from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wald,</etym> a Wood, 
and <etym lang="tt">Meyer,</etym> a Major.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Waldron(pn)">Waldron,</form> <xpln lang="en">see Walarand.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Waldwin(pn)">Waldwin,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii7v">
rule, or <etym lang="oe">Wald</etym>, Power, and 
<etym lang="oe">Win</etym>, a Conquerour, or 
<etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to Win. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walfleet(pn)">Walfleet</form> <xpln lang="en">in Essex, famous for 
good Oysters; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wall</etym>, a wall, and <etym lang="oe">Fleot</etym>, 
a River.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walleys(pn)" lexeme="Wallis(pn)">Walleys, or Wallis,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sir&shy;
name; see Walsh.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wallingford(pn)">Wallingford,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Berkshire; from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Guall Hen,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the 
old Wall, by retaining where&shy;
of, and adding thereto <etym lang="en">Ford,</etym> 
the Eng. Saxons called it 
<etym lang="oe">Gualengaford</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Wal&shy;
lengaford</etym>, with us Wal&shy;
lingford, as before.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wallmer(pn)">Wallmer,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Kent, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wall</etym>, and <etym lang="la">Mare</etym> the Sea, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Wall for the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wallop(pn)">Wallop,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Brook in Hantshire; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weallian</etym>, 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Wallen, Waellen,</etym> 
to bubble forth, and <etym lang="gr">Vp,</etym> 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Op,</etym> upward.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wallsend(pn)">Wallsend,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland; 
(<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) the <etym lang="en">Walls-end,</etym> in 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Vindobala</etym> and <etym lang="la">Vindomora,</etym> 
(<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) <etym lang="la">finis Valli,</etym> and <etym lang="la">finis 
Muri,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Trenches End, 
and the Walls End.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wall-town(pn)">Wall-town,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumberland; 
upon the Wall, formerly a 
Palace Royal, where Segbert 
King of the East-Saxons was 
baptized, by St. Pauline; from 
<etym lang="en">Wall,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walsh(pn)">Walsh,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, that is, to 
say, a <etym lang="en">Welsh</etym> -man; see Welsh 
below.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walsingham(pn)">Walsingham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norfolk; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;l</etym>, a Weel, or 
Whirl-Pool, this from <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;l&shy;
wan</etym>, to wallow, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, 
a Habitation, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a dirty 
boggy Town, or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">W&aelig;lipe</etym>, Southern-wood, 
which grows plenteously 
there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Walter(pn)">Walter,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; here&shy;
tofore <etym lang="en">Waldher,</etym> saith Cam&shy;
den; either from the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wald</etym>, a Wood, and <etym lang="tt">Herr,</etym> 
a Master; or from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wealdan</etym>, to rule, &amp; <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, 
an Army.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Waltham(pn)">Waltham,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Essex, 
memorable for a stately Ab&shy;
by, the Abbot whereof was 
reckoned among the Barons 
of Parliament; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Weald</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wald,</etym> a 
Wood, and <etym lang="oe">Ham;</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Town standing by a 
Wood. It answers the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Delta;&#x1F73;&nu;&delta;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, and the Lat. <etym lang="la">Sylviacum</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wandle(pn)">Wandle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Surrey, 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Gwaneg,</etym> a 
Wave, from whence <etym lang="cb">Gwanegn</etym>, 
to overflow, for the Ebbings 
and Flowings thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wandregisel(pn)">Wandregisel,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Eng. Saxon 
Saint; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wan&shy;
drian</etym>, to wander; and the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gesell,</etym> a Companion, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Companion of Pil&shy;
grims.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wandsworth(pn)">Wandsworth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Surrey; here&shy;
tofore <etym lang="en">Wandlesworth;</etym> from 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii8r">
the River <etym lang="en">Wandle</etym> or <etym lang="la">Van&shy;
dali,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Worth,</etym> a Plat&shy;
form, or Village, or from the 
Dan. <etym lang="da">Vand,</etym> water, and the 
same <etym lang="en">Worth,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a Town 
by the waters side. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wansdike(pn)">Wansdike,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltshire, the 
Limit of the West-Saxons 
and the Mercii; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  <etym lang="oe">Wo&shy;
dens dike,</etym> the Ditch of 
<etym lang="oe">Woden,</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Odin,</etym> the God 
of the Saxons, which was 
the Mercurius of the Romans; 
nigh to this is a small Town 
called Wodensburg, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Town of Woden; see 
Wednesday, Wood, &amp; Dyke, 
in the Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wantage(pn)">Wantage,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Village in Berk&shy;
shire; perhaps from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wanta</etym>, less, from the small&shy;
ness thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ware(pn)">Ware,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hertf. from our Eng. 
<etym lang="en">Wear,</etym> which is a Ditch 
made to keep off the over&shy;
flowing of Water; see Wear 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Warin(pn)">Warin,</form> <xpln lang="en">now a Sirname; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Gar,</etym> all, and <etym lang="tt">Win,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that wins always.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Waring(pn)">Waring,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; Spelman 
draws it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wa&shy;
rian</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Werigan</etym>, to 
Curse or Back-bite. It may 
be drawn from the <etym lang="la">Waringi,</etym> 
a People in Germany, oppo&shy;
site to the English Coast, in 
the time of Tacitus.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Warnafred(pn)">Warnafred,</form> <xpln lang="en">the right Sirname 
of Paul, called the Deacon, a 
Chronographer of the Longo&shy;
bardi; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">War&shy;
nen,</etym> to fore-warn, and <etym lang="tt">Fried,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, Peace, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  he that exhorts unto 
Peace.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Warwick(pn)">Warwick,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the C. Br. <term lang="cb">Caer Leon</term>, the Legions Camp, 
where the Major of the Dal&shy;
matian Horse acted under the 
Command of the Duke of 
Britain. Camden draws it 
from the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Guarth,</etym> a 
Safegard, or Garrison, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wyc</etym>, a Port or 
City. Somner saith, that it 
was formerly call'd <etym lang="en">W&aelig;ring,</etym> 
or <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;ring Wic,</etym> and de&shy;
rives it from the AS. <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;&shy;
ring</etym>, a Wear, and <etym lang="oe">Wyc</etym>, 
a Fort.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="The Washes(pn)">The Washes</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norfolk, so cal&shy;
led because it is <etym lang="en">wash'd</etym> by 
the Tides dashing against it, 
a Shore almost as dangerous 
as the Quicksands in Africa.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wassenaer(pn)">Wassenaer,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Sirname of an 
ancient and noble Family in 
Holland. Adr. Jun. expounds 
it <etym lang="bl">Wasser Heer,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  the Ma&shy;
ster of the Waters.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Watling Street(pn)">Watling-street,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the four 
Circuits, dividing London in 
the midst as it were from 
South to North, either from 
some man nam'd <etym lang="la">Vitellian;</etym> or 
as Somner supposeth from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wedla</etym>, a Beggar, or 
<etym lang="oe">Wedlian</etym>, to beg; because 
Beggars sat therein as their 
constant place to ask Alms. 
It may also very probably be 
drawn from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wenselen,</etym> 
</page> 

<page sig="Ii8v">
to rowl, from its crook&shy;
ed Windings. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Webba(pn)">Webba,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of the Mercii, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Webba</etym>, a 
Weaver.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wedon(pn)">Wedon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Leicest. Anton. calls 
it <term lang="cb">Bannoventa</term>, the principal 
Seat of the Bennoni or Ven&shy;
noni.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Welsh(pn)" lexeme="Welch(pn)">Welch, or rather Welsh,</form> <xpln lang="en">from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wealh</etym>, a Stranger, 
or Foreigner; and this pro&shy;
bably from <etym lang="la">Gallus,</etym> a French 
man; for the Gallo-Belg&aelig; and 
Brit. for a time used the same 
Speech. And it is manifest, 
that the Franks that subdued 
Celtica, called the Gallo-Belg&aelig;, 
Wallones; and that the Ger&shy;
mans in the Neighbouring 
Countries of Italy, called Lom&shy;
bardy, and Gallia, on this side 
the Alps, the Welsh Land; 
and that the Fr. call our 
Wales, <term lang="fr">Pais de Gales</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Welles(pn)">Welles,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Som. a Bishop's See; 
so called from <etym lang="en">Wells</etym>, that 
spring forth all over, after 
the manner of Pagase of the 
Macedonians, Susa among the 
Persians, and Croia in Dal&shy;
matia; which all had their 
Names from Springs or 
Wells.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wellingborough(pn)">Wellingborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly 
<etym lang="en">Wedlingborough,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Wod&shy;
lingborough,</etym> in Northampton&shy;
shire; from <etym lang="en">Wells</etym> that have 
a Medicinal virtue; or, if it 
ought to be called Wedling&shy;
borough, from <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;dla,</etym> a beg&shy;
gar, or <etym lang="oe">W&aelig;dlian,</etym> to beg; 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Beggars Town; 
and if it ought to be pro&shy;
nounced Wodlingborough, 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wod</etym>, Wood 
or Mad, and the Dim. <etym lang="oe">Ling,</etym> 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Town of People 
half Mad; to wit from the 
impatience of infected Peo&shy;
ple coming to the Wells for 
ease. See Borough in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wellington(pn)">Wellington,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Som. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the 
<etym lang="en">Town</etym> of <etym lang="en">Wells.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Welsh-pool(pn)">Welsh-pool,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Montgom. from 
<etym lang="en">Welsh,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Pool;</etym> which 
see in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wentsbeck(pn)">Wentsbeck,</form> <xpln lang="en">a little River in 
Northumb. upon which stood 
an old Town called <term lang="cb">Glano&shy;
venta</term>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a little River 
running into or out of the 
 River <etym lang="en">Went;</etym> See 
 <etym lang="en">Beck</etym> in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Were(pn)">Were,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in the Bish. 
of Durham; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Weorg</etym>. Ptolemy call'd it 
Vedra, and Beda Wirus; and 
from hence cometh </xpln>
<lemenote>
A lead-in to the next entry, on Weremouth.
</lemenote>
</wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Weremouth(pn)">Weremouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the same Bish. 
and Monks Weremouth, 
which Beda writes <etym lang="oe">Wirau&shy;
mouth</etym>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Mouth of 
the River Were.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Werminster(pn)">Werminster,</form> <xpln lang="en">an old Town in 
Wiltshire, heretofore <etym lang="la">Verlucio;</etym> 
from <etym lang="la">Ver,</etym> the beginning of 
the old Name, and <etym lang="oe">Minster</etym>. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Werthrada(pn)">Werthrada,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Queen, Wife to 
Charles the Great. Jun. sup&shy;
poseth that it comes of the 
Germ. <etym lang="gr">Werth,</etym> worth, or wor&shy;
thy, and <etym lang="gr">Rade,</etym> Counsel.</xpln></wordentry>
</page> 

<page sig="Kk1r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Westchester(pn)">Westchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Bishop's 
See; so called to distinguish 
it from <etym lang="en">Chester</etym> in the Street 
in Durham, which lies to the 
East as this does to the <etym lang="en">West</etym>. 
The Eng. Saxons called it 
<term lang="oe">Leaga ceasten</term>, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
the Legions Town; because 
a Roman Legion quarter'd 
here.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Westminster(pn)">Westminster,</form> <xpln lang="en">our Royal City 
in Middlesex; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a <etym lang="en">Minster</etym> 
i'th' <etym lang="en">West</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Westphalia(pn)">Westphalia,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Country in Ger&shy;
many, from its <etym lang="en">Western</etym> Situ&shy;
ation, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Falle,</etym> 
a Trap or Snare; because 
through the number &amp; thick&shy;
ness of Woods, and many 
Ditches, and Whirl-Pools, it 
was formerly a Place very fit 
to lay an Ambuscado in.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Westphaling(pn)">Westphaling,</form> <xpln lang="en">Nom. Gent. (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
one come from <etym lang="en">Westphalia.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="West-seaxanric(pn)">West-Seaxanric,</form> <xpln lang="en">(i. e.) the 
Kingdom of the West-Sax&shy;
ons; for <etym lang="oe">Seaxan</etym>, signifieth 
Saxons, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, a Kingdom; 
See Saxon.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Weymouth(pn)">Weymouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Port and little 
Mart-Town in Dors. so call'd 
from the River <etym lang="en">Wey,</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Mouth,</etym> that is, the Mouth 
of Wey.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whaley(pn)">Whaley,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lanc. not unlikely 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Weallian</etym>, 
to be full of Springs, and 
<etym lang="oe">Leag</etym>; a Field, or Pasture, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Field, well watered.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whealop Castle(pn)">Whealop Castle</form> <xpln lang="en">in Westm. Ptole&shy;
my calls it <term lang="gkt">Gallagium</term>, Anton. <term lang="la">Gallatum</term>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wheelock(pn)">Wheelock,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wioloc</etym>, Purple, saith 
Somner, he means the Purple-&shy;
fish, or rather a Cockle, or 
Sea-Snail, which in Linc. 
they call Wilk; See Wilk 
in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wherf(pn)">Wherf, or Wharf,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in 
Yorkshire; from the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Wervel,</etym> a Whirl-Pool, or 
<etym lang="bl">Wervelen,</etym> to run round a&shy;
bout.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whitby(pn)">Whitby, or Whiteby,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Yorkshire; (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a <etym lang="en">white</etym> 
Town, or <etym lang="en">Bay</etym>, in the AS. 
<term lang="oe">Streanesheale</term>; <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  
Streanes hall, which see.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whitchurch(pn)">Whitchurch,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Shropshire; from 
<etym lang="en">White</etym> and <etym lang="en">Church;</etym> which 
see in Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Whitney(pn)">Whitney,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Oxfordshire; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hwit</etym>, white, and 
<etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, a Water, or <etym lang="oe">Ige</etym>, an 
Island.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wibert(pn)" lexeme="Guibert(pn)">Wibert, or Guibert,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-&shy;
Name; from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wei&shy;
hen,</etym> or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiihen,</etym> to 
consecrate, and <etym lang="oe">Beorht</etym>, 
bright, also, light, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Sa&shy;
cred Light.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wiberton(pn)">Wiberton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Linc. 
from <etym lang="en">Wiburt, Wibert,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Guibert,</etym> an English-Saxon 
Knight the Builder thereof, 
and <etym lang="en">Town,</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Town 
of one Wibert, that about 
the year 870. fought under 
Algar, in a Battel against the 
Danes.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wickham(pn)">Wickham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Buckingh. rather 
<etym lang="en">Wicomb;</etym> from the AS. 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk1v">
<etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, the winding of a Ri&shy;
ver, or a Port, and <etym lang="oe">Comb</etym>, a 
Valley. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wickliff(pn)">Wickliff,</form> <xpln lang="en">Iohn Wickliff, who 
so mawl'd the Triple-Head, 
that he obtain'd from her 
the Title of Arch-Heretick; 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hwit</etym>, white, 
and <etym lang="oe">Clif</etym>, a Rock, or Clift.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wien(pn)">Wien,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lat. <etym lang="la">Vienna,</etym> the Court 
of the Arch-Dukes of Austria; 
perhaps from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wtie, 
Wiide,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weide,</etym> 
a Willow-tree; or, from the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiien Wiihen,</etym> or 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weihen,</etym> to consecrate; 
because perhaps here was a 
Temple consecrated to some 
Deity in times of Heathe&shy;
nism.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wierdale(pn)">Wierdale,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lanc. from the 
River <etym lang="en">Wy,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Dale,</etym> a 
Valley.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wigelinda(pn)">Wigelinda,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Daughter of 
Pertharitus, King of the Lon&shy;
gobardi of Italy; not unlike&shy;
ly from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wiga</etym>, a 
noble Man, or Woman, and 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Lind,</etym> mild.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wight Isle(pn)">Wight Isle,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wuit&shy;
land</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Wick-Ea</etym>, in the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Guith,</etym> which denotes 
a Division, or Separation; 
because it is thought that this 
Isle was cut off and parted 
from the rest of England by 
the force of the Sea.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wiggin(pn)">Wiggin,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Lanc. commonly 
called <etym lang="en">Wiggon,</etym> in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wibiggin</etym>, from <etym lang="oe">Wi</etym>, Sa&shy;
cred, or <etym lang="oe">Wibed</etym>, an Altar, 
and <etym lang="oe">Biggin</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Bicgan</etym>, 
to build, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Sacred Build&shy;
ings.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wigmore(pn)">Wigmore,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Heref. in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wigingamere</etym>, per&shy;
haps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wine</etym>, 
praised, <etym lang="oe">Geong</etym>, young, and 
<etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, famous; though it 
may more immediately be 
drawn from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wic</etym>, a 
Fortress, and <etym lang="oe">Mor</etym>, a Moor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wigod(pn)">Wigod,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly a Christen-&shy;
Name, but now a Sirname; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weihen,</etym> or 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiien,</etym> to conse&shy;
crate, and <etym lang="en">God,</etym> that is to 
say, consecrated unto the 
Lord.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wilberham(pn)">Wilberham,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly Wil&shy;
burgham in Kent; perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wild, Wilda,</etym> 
untamed, <etym lang="en">Burg,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ham;</etym> 
which see in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wilbram(pn)">Wilbram,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly nam'd 
<etym lang="en">de Wilburnham;</etym> from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Wille-burne</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a 
Well Spring, and <etym lang="en">Ham,</etym> a 
Village; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Town of Wells; 
as Welles in Somersetshire.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wilcock(pn)">Wilcock,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from the 
obsolete Eng. <etym lang="oe">Wald,</etym> for 
Wood, and <etym lang="en">Cock;</etym> which 
see in the Common Names: 
Or, as the Eminent Th. H. 
telleth us, 'tis a Dim. of 
<etym lang="en">William,</etym> as the Nurse's Bi&shy;
licock.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wilfred(pn)">Wilfred,</form> <xpln lang="en">Arch-Bishop of York, 
in the year 672. from the AS. 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk2r">
<etym lang="oe">Willa</etym>, the will, and <etym lang="oe">Frede</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;</etym>, Teut. <etym lang="tt">Friede,</etym> 
Peace; that is, one, whose 
Mind inclines to Peace, and 
quietness. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Willebald(pn)">Willebald</form> <xpln lang="en">, in the year 762. from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Willa</etym>, the Will, or 
<etym lang="oe">Willan</etym>, to Will, and <etym lang="oe">Bald</etym>, 
Bold.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Willebrod(pn)">Willebrod,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name, 
made famous by that most 
holy English-Saxon, the first 
Bishop of Utrecht, and Apo&shy;
stle of the Belg&aelig;. Verstegan 
writes it <etym lang="en">Willebrord,</etym> or ra&shy;
ther <etym lang="en">Wilberord,</etym> and ex&shy;
pounds it an Active will or 
Mind; for he saith, that 
<etym lang="bl">Berord</etym> denoteth, one, that 
is Active: It may be taken 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Well</etym>, well, 
and <etym lang="oe">Beord</etym>, Speech, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
well spoken; or from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Willan</etym>, to covet, and 
<etym lang="oe">Breod</etym>, the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Brodt,</etym> 
or the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Broodt,</etym> Bread; 
that is, a great lover of Bread.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Willet(pn)">Willet,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Dim. of <etym lang="en">Will,</etym> as 
Will is of <etym lang="en">William.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="William(pn)">William,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wil&shy;
helm,</etym> not, as Luther will 
have it, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Vielhelm, i. e. 
the Shield of many; nor as 
some would have it, q d. a 
voluntary Defence, from Will 
and helm. But as Verstegan 
ingeniously, from <etym lang="tt">Guild 
helm</etym> (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one furnished 
with a guilt Helmet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wilnolde(pn)">Wilnolde,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Abbatess of Kent, 
in the year 694. not unlikely 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Willa</etym>, the will, 
and <etym lang="oe">Nolde</etym>, she would not; 
that is, one that doubteth in 
Mind.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wilton(pn)">Wilton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltshire; from the 
Brook <etym lang="en">Willey,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Ton</etym>, a 
Town; q. Willy-Town, 
heretofore called <etym lang="en">Alan,</etym> 
therefore by the Romans 
call'd <etym lang="la">Ellandunum.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wiltshire(pn)">Wiltshire,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wil&shy;
setta</etym>, either from the 
Town <etym lang="en">Wilton,</etym> or the River 
<etym lang="en">Willy,</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Setta</etym>, which 
signifieth neighbouring Inha&shy;
bitants.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wimbleton(pn)">Wimbleton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Sur. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wibandune</etym>, which Som&shy;
ner writes <etym lang="oe">Wibbandune</etym>, 
and saith it had this Name 
from one <etym lang="oe">Wibba</etym> the Builder 
thereof, and <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, an Hill. 
Wimbleton seems to be so 
call'd q. <etym lang="en">Wimble-Town.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wimear(pn)">Wimear,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, formerly 
<etym lang="en">Wydmear,</etym> saith Versteg. from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wid</etym> wide, broad, 
and <etym lang="oe">M&aelig;re</etym>, famous; that 
is, one that is well spoken of 
by many.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wimund(pn)">Wimund,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Weihen,</etym> or 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiien, Wiihen,</etym> to 
consecrate, and the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Mund</etym>, Peace; or from <etym lang="bl">Wi,</etym> 
Sacred, and the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Mund,</etym> 
a Mouth; that is, one of chaste 
and undefiled Lips.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winanderinere(pn)">Winanderinere,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Westmorland; 
perhaps from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wine</etym>, 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk2v">
Pleasant, <etym lang="oe">Wad</etym>, a Ford, and 
<etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, a Marsh; or from 
the AS. and Eng. <etym lang="oe">Wind,</etym> or 
<etym lang="en">Winds,</etym> &amp; the same <etym lang="oe">Mere</etym>, 
that is, a Water often trou&shy;
bled, and rowled on heaps 
with the Wind. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winburn(pn)">Winburn,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Dors. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wynburaham</etym>, corr. from 
its old Name <etym lang="oe">Vindogladia;</etym> in 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Windagledy,</etym> imply&shy;
ing a Town between two 
Glades, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) two Rivers, 
for the Britains used <etym lang="la">gladium 
pro Amne</etym>, for a River or Brook; 
<etym lang="en">Winburn</etym> may be derived 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wine</etym>, Plea&shy;
sant, and <etym lang="oe">Bourn,</etym> a Spring, 
or Rivolet.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winchcomb(pn)">Winchcomb,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Gloc. remarka&shy;
ble for its Minster in former 
times: In the AS. call'd 
<etym lang="oe">Wincel-Combe</etym>, from 
<etym lang="oe">Wincel</etym>, a Corner, and 
<etym lang="oe">Comb</etym>, a Valley environ'd 
on each side with Hills.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winchelsey(pn)">Winchelsey,</form> <xpln lang="en">Old Winchelsey, 
in Sussex, in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Win&shy;
cels Ea</etym>, from <etym lang="oe">Wincel</etym>, a 
Corner, and <etym lang="oe">Ige</etym> or <etym lang="oe">Ea</etym>, 
an Isle.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winchester(pn)">Winchester,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Hantshire, a 
Bishop's See; in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wantanceaster</etym>, in the 
C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Caer Guent,</etym> which 
comes from <etym lang="cb">Gwin</etym> or <etym lang="cb">Gwen,</etym> 
white, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  white City, be&shy;
cause it is built upon a Chal&shy;
ky Soil.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Windham(pn)">Windham,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="en">Wimund&shy;
ham,</etym> in Norfolk, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) 
<etym lang="en">Wi&shy;
mund</etym> 's home; see Wi&shy;
mund.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Windogast(pn)">Windogast,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Dutch Christen-&shy;
Name; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Win&shy;
nen,</etym> to get, and <etym lang="bl">Gast,</etym> a Guest, 
(<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) one that through Ci&shy;
vility wins the love of his 
Guests, or Customers.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Windsor(pn)">Windsore,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Barkshire; in 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Windele-shora</etym>, 
so called from the winding 
of the Thames at that place; 
see <etym lang="en">wind</etym> and <etym lang="en">shore</etym> in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wine(pn)">Wine,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wine</etym>, Beloved. 
Or 'tis a Contract of </xpln>
<lemenote>
A lead-in to the next headword, 
"Winefred."
</lemenote>
</wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winefred(pn)">Winefred;</form> <xpln lang="en">so was Boniface the 
Eng. Sax. Apostle of the 
Germans, called in his Mo&shy;
ther Tongue; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to get, and <etym lang="oe">Fri&eth;, 
Frede</etym>, Peace, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a 
Procurer of Peace; 'tis also 
a Womans Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winoc(pn)">Winoc,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, or the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Winnen,</etym> to obtain, and the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Aac</etym>, or <etym lang="oe">Ac</etym>, an Oak, 
that is, one that for his merits 
is rewarded with a Civick 
oaken Garland.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winterton(pn)">Winterton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Norf. so called from its cold situation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Winwidfield(pn)">Winwidfield,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Yorkshire; so 
called from a Victory, which 
Oswin, King of Northumberland, 
obtain'd here over Penda the 
Mercian. There is also Win&shy;
field, in Germany, where 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk3r"> 
Q. Varus, was slain with 
his Legions: From the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Winnan</etym>, to conquer, 
and our word <etym lang="en">Field.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wischard(pn)">Wischard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name; 
the Italians write it <etym lang="it">Guiscard,</etym> 
by interpretation a Crafty 
Shifter, says Skinner, quo&shy;
ting an Anonymous Author 
for it; but adds. I find not 
Wisch of this Signification, 
and therefore I chose rather to 
draw it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wis&shy;
chen,</etym> or Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wisschen</etym>, to 
purge, or wipe, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Nature, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that 
is sincere.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wismar(pn)">Wismar,</form> <xpln lang="en">by some call'd Viso&shy;
marus, King of the Vandals, 
and Founder of Weismar in 
Germany, a City upon the 
Coast of the Balthick Sea. 
Jun. expounds it <etym lang="tt">Wiise 
Meyer,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Wise Major; 
see Wise, and Major, in the 
Common Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Witekind(pn)">Witekind,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Christen-Name 
of the renown'd German-&shy;
Saxon that was Tutor to so 
many Princes, Kings, and 
Emperours. He was the first 
of the Princes of that Na&shy;
tion, that embraced the Chri&shy;
stian Faith; from the old 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wite,</etym> or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Hwit, 
Hwita,</etym> white, and the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Kind,</etym> a Child. Kilian writes 
it <etym lang="bl">Wide-kund,</etym> and draws 
it from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wiide,</etym> 
wide, and <etym lang="bl">Kund,</etym> known.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Withericus(pn)">Withericus,</form> <xpln lang="en">by some called 
Videricus, a Goth, Christ. 
Name. Adr. Jun, draws it 
from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wither,</etym> or 
<etym lang="bl">Wider,</etym> a Weather, and 
<etym lang="bl">Rich,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Rich in Cattel, 
or Weathers; see Rich and 
Weather in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Withred(pn)">Withred,</form> <xpln lang="en">a King of Kent; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wi&eth;</etym>, against, and 
<etym lang="oe">Redan</etym>, to counsel; that is, 
one that ever Contradicts 
others.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Withringdon(pn)">Withringdon,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Northumber&shy;
land; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wi&eth;e&shy;
rian</etym>, to wither, and <etym lang="oe">Dune</etym>, 
an Hill, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a dry Hill.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wivelscomb(pn)">Wivelscomb,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Somers. from 
the old Eng. words <etym lang="oe">Weevel,</etym> 
for Weezel, and <etym lang="oe">Comb,</etym> a 
Valley with Hills on each 
side.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Woden(pn)">Woden,</form> <xpln lang="en">a God of the Goths 
and Germans, the same with 
Mars of the Romans; his 
Statue was set up with a Pa&shy;
noply, or compleat Armour, 
and a drawn Sword upon it, 
his Etymon agreeing with 
his Figure; for it is derived 
of the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wedan</etym>, the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Woeden,</etym> or the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wu&shy;
ten,</etym> to be Wood, or Mad, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
the furious God, that is, he 
that inspired a warlike fury 
into the Minds of Men; see 
Wood, and Tuesday, in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Woerden(pn)">Woerden,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Hol&shy;
land; from the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Woorde,</etym> 
a Drake, and the AS. <etym lang="oe">Den</etym>, 
a Valley, or Den; perhaps 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk3v"> 
from the plenty of Wild 
Ducks. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Woldsbury(pn)">Woldsbury,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltshire; from 
<etym lang="en">Wold</etym> and <etym lang="en">Bury;</etym> that is to 
say, a Town amongst Hills; see 
Wold, and Bury, in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wolfard(pn)">Wolfard,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Saxon Christen-&shy;
Name; from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wulf</etym>, 
the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wolf,</etym> or the Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Wolff,</etym> a Wolf, and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Aerd,</etym> Nature, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) crafty 
and greedy as a Wolf.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wolfart(pn)">Wolfart,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ Name; from 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wol,</etym> well, and the 
Belg. <etym lang="bl">Vaeren,</etym> to be in 
health; or the same with 
<etym lang="en">Wolfard</etym> above, q. Wolf-&shy;
heart.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wolfgang(pn)">Wolfgang,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christ. Name; 
from <etym lang="en">Wolf,</etym> and the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Gangen,</etym> to go, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a thie&shy;
vish fleering gate, like that 
of a Wolf. Verstegan writes 
it <etym lang="en">Wulfang,</etym> and <etym lang="en">Welfeng,</etym> 
and draws it from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wulf</etym>, the Belg. <etym lang="bl">Wolf,</etym> or 
the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Wolff,</etym> a Wolf, and 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Fengar</etym>, to catch, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a Wolf-Catcher. Isleb. 
writes it <etym lang="en">Hulfong,</etym> and de&shy;
rives it from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Hulf,</etym> 
or the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help, and 
<etym lang="tt">Gang,</etym> to go.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wolfred(pn)">Wolfred,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Arch-Bishop of 
Canterbury, in the year 816. 
either from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, 
Aid, and <etym lang="oe">Redan</etym>, to give 
counsel, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  He that assi&shy;
steth others with his Advice; 
or from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wulf</etym>, a 
Wolf, and the same <etym lang="oe">Redan</etym>, 
<term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one that instils into 
others cruel, and Wolf-like 
designs.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wolver Hampton(pn)">Wolver Hampton,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Staff. 
heretofore <etym lang="en">Vlfraneshamp&shy;
ton,</etym> or <etym lang="en">Wulfraneshampton,</etym> 
from Wulfruna a Pious Wo&shy;
man, that built an Abby 
there.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Woodreeve(pn)">Woodreeve,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wude Gnefa</etym>, a 
Wood Grave; see <etym lang="en">Reeve</etym> in 
its place, and <etym lang="en">Wood</etym> and 
<etym lang="en">Grave</etym> in the Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Woodstock(pn)">Woodstock,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Oxfordsh. from 
the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wude</etym>, a Wood, and 
<etym lang="oe">Stoc</etym>, for Stop, a place; or 
from <etym lang="oe">Stocce,</etym> the Stock of 
a tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Worcester(pn)">Worcester,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City, and Bishop's 
See, in the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wegeorna&shy;
ceaster</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Wire-cea&shy;
ster</etym>, which comes from 
<etym lang="oe">Wire</etym>, a Forest, and <etym lang="oe">ceas&shy;
ter</etym>, a Town, in the Lat. 
Barb. it is called <etym lang="la">Wigornia</etym>; ei&shy;
ther from the Wiccii, a People 
that once lived here; or from 
the said <etym lang="oe">Wegeorna-ceaster</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Worsted(pn)">Worsted,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town in Norfolk, 
from whence Wool spun 
there is also called Worsted, 
as Callico from the City Ca&shy;
lecutt, where the best of this 
sort of Cloth is or was made; 
Worsted may be drawn 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wor&eth;</etym>, a 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk4r"> 
Hall or Village, and <etym lang="oe">Steda</etym>, 
or <etym lang="oe">Sted</etym>, a Place. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wray(pn)">Wray,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; not unlike&shy;
ly from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wreon</etym>, 
to cover, or from <etym lang="oe">Wr&aelig;c, 
Wr&aelig;ce</etym>, Wreck of the Sea, 
the first of the name having 
been cast upon some un&shy;
known shore, and so might 
acquire his Name.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wrexham(pn)">Wrexham,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Denb. in the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Writtlesham</etym>, perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wri&eth;els</etym>, 
Wreaths, or any thing that 
goes round, and <etym lang="oe">Ham</etym>, a 
Village.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wroxeter(pn)" lexeme="Wreckceter(pn)">Wroxeter, and Wreckceter,</form> <xpln lang="en">in 
Shropsh. from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Wre&shy;
cen-ceaster</etym>. Neun. calls it 
<etym lang="oe">Caer Vruach</etym>, and Ptolem. <etym lang="gkt">Vi&shy;
roconium</etym>. It was formerly the 
chief City of the Cornarii.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wulfhad(pn)">Wulfhad,</form> <xpln lang="en">Son to Wulpher King 
of the Mercii, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Wulf</etym>, a Wolf, and <etym lang="oe">Hade</etym>, 
a Kind; or rather q. <etym lang="en">Wul&shy;
pherhade,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  of the Kind or 
Nature of <etym lang="en">Wulpher,</etym> his 
Father.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wulphelm(pn)">Wulphelm,</form> <xpln lang="en">Arch-Bishop of 
Canterb. about the year 930. 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help, and 
<etym lang="oe">Helm</etym>, an Helmet, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) a 
Protectour.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wulpet(pn)">Wulpet,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Suff. that is to say, 
a Pit of Wolves, from <etym lang="en">Wolf,</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Pit;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wulpher(pn)">Wulpher,</form> <xpln lang="en">King of the Merdii, 
Founder of the Minster of 
Peterborough, now a Cathe&shy;
dral Church, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ulpher</etym>, an Helper; see Help 
in the Com. Names; or from 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help, and <etym lang="oe">Here</etym>, an 
Army.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wulphric(pn)">Wulphric,</form> <xpln lang="en">formerly <etym lang="oe">Vlpheric,</etym> 
saith Verstegan, from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, help, and <etym lang="oe">Ric</etym>, rich, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
Rich in Help.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Wulphstan(pn)" lexeme="Wulfstan(pn)">Wulphstan, and Wulfstan,</form> <xpln lang="en">a 
Christ. Name; from the AS. 
<etym lang="oe">Ulph</etym>, aid, and the AS. Su&shy;
perl. Term. <etym lang="oe">Stan</etym>, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  one 
that assisteth greatly, in the 
highest degree.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk4v"> 
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="ZY"><alpha>Y</alpha> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yale(pn)">YAle,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Tract of Land in 
Denb. perhaps so call'd 
from the River <etym lang="en">A&shy;
lan.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yanesbury(pn)">Yanesbury</form> <xpln lang="en">in Wiltsh. remarka&shy;
ble for a Trench and Wall of 
Roman Workmanship, which 
Vespasian perhaps cast up, or 
built: for <etym lang="en">Yanes</etym> may be a 
Corruption of <etym lang="la">Vespasian,</etym> q. 
Vespasian's-bury.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yarborough(pn)">Yarborough,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; from 
the obsolete word <etym lang="en">Gerber,</etym> 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  one that binds new 
mown Grass in bundles; this 
from the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Gerbe,</etym> or the 
Teut. <etym lang="tt">Garbe,</etym> a Sheaf, whence 
the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Gerber</etym>, and Teut. 
<etym lang="tt">Garben</etym> to bind up in 
Sheaves; or it may be 
drawn from the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Ger&shy;
ber,</etym> a Fellmonger.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yare(pn)">Yare,</form> <xpln lang="en">a River in Norfolk, in 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Guern,</etym> which like&shy;
wise is taken for an Eldar-&shy;
Tree, perhaps from the great 
abundance of such Trees; Or 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Gar</etym>, the an&shy;
cient Name thereof.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yarmouth(pn)">Yarmouth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous Harbour 
in Norfolk, (<term lang="la">i.e.</term>) the Mouth 
of the River <etym lang="en">Yare,</etym> which in 
the AS. is written <etym lang="oe">Jer</etym>, and 
<etym lang="oe">Gar</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yarrow(pn)">Yarrow,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Bishopr. of 
Durham, memorable for the 
Birth of Beda, formerly called 
<etym lang="oe">Girwy,</etym> and <etym lang="oe">Girway lond,</etym> 
which in the AS. implieth, 
a Fenny Land, from <etym lang="oe">Gyras, 
Geres,</etym> Fenns, or <etym lang="oe">Ger</etym>, 
Mud.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yates(pn)">Yates,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, from <etym lang="en">Yate,</etym> 
for <etym lang="en">Gate;</etym> which see in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ybell(pn)">Ybell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Christ. Name; 
by corruption from the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">Eubulus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yedburgh(pn)">Yedburgh,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Scotland, upon 
the Confluence of the Ri&shy;
vers <etym lang="en">Yed,</etym> and Tefie.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yelverton(pn)">Yelverton,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname; perhaps 
from the AS. <etym lang="oe">Culfre</etym>, a 
Culver, and <etym lang="oe">Tun</etym>, a Town; 
q. Culver-town.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="York(pn)">York,</form> <xpln lang="en">the next City in esteem 
to London, in England; in the 
AS. <etym lang="oe">Euer ric</etym>, and <etym lang="oe">Eofer&shy;
wic</etym>; In the time of the Ro&shy;
mans it was called <etym lang="la">Eboracum</etym> 
or <etym lang="la">Eburacum,</etym> from the River 
<etym lang="la">Vre</etym> or <etym lang="la">Vrus,</etym> now called 
<etym lang="en">Owse,</etym> which washeth it; as 
the Euberones and Eureux, 
that are nigh the River Ourt. 
It is a place memorable for 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk5r">
the Death of two Emperours 
Severus, and Constantius Chlo&shy;
rus, as also for the Nativity of 
Constantine the Great. </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ystwich(pn)">Ystwich,</form> <xpln lang="en">in Card. perhaps from 
the C. Br. <etym lang="cb">Ystwith,</etym> bound up, 
from the barrenness of the 
Land, which giveth but small 
increase.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ythell(pn)">Ythell,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Welsh Christ. Name; 
a Contract of the Gr. <etym lang="gk">Eutha&shy;
lius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Yutland(pn)">Yutland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Teut. <etym lang="tt">Iut&shy;
land;</etym> a part of Cimb. 
Chersonesus, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Gothick 
Land, or the Land of the 
Goths.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="Z"><alpha>Z</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zealand(pn)">ZEaland,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Belg. 
<etym lang="bl">Zeeland,</etym> and <etym lang="bl">See&shy;
land,</etym> a Province both 
of the Netherlands, 
and Daneland, the one was 
the Seat of the ancient Co&shy;
dani, the other of the Mat&shy;
tiaci, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  in Eng. <etym lang="en">Sea Land,</etym> 
so called from its Situation; 
because the Sea formerly 
washed it on both sides.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zouch(pn)">Zouch,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Sirname, (i. e.) <etym lang="en">de 
la Zouche;</etym> the Fr. <etym lang="fr">Zouche,</etym> 
denotes a Trunk of a Tree.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zutphen(pn)">Zutphen,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Town and Coun&shy;
try in the Netherlands, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
<etym lang="en">Southfen;</etym> see <etym lang="en">South,</etym> 
and <etym lang="en">Fen</etym> in the Common 
Names.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zuyder Zee(pn)">Zuyder Zee,</form> <xpln lang="en">between Zea&shy;
land, and Holland, (<term lang="la">q.d.</term> ) 
in English the <etym lang="en">Southern-&shy;
Sea,</etym> that is with respect to 
Holland, which it washeth 
on the South side; see 
South, and Sea, in the 
Com. Names.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 
</section> 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk5v"> 
<section type="Proper Names"> 

<heading>
Proper Names of Men and Women now 
commonly used, coming from the Hebrew, Greek, 
and Latin, truly derived, with the Signification 
of the Name in the Original; together with the 
Name, as 'tis both in Hebrew and Greek in their 
respective Characters; very useful for Young 
Scholars.
</heading>

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="A"><alpha>A</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Aaron(pn)">AAron,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same in all Languages: In the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B7;&#x05D4;&#x05B2;&#x05D4;&#x05DF;</etym> 
which comes from the root <etym lang="he">&#x05D4;&#x05B7;&#x05DF;</etym> a Mountain. In the Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F7C;&nu;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Aaron.</etym> By interpretation, belonging to the 
Mountains.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abel(pn)">Abel,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same in all Languages. Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D4;&#x05B8;&#x05D1;&#x05B6;&#x05DC;</etym>, Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&beta;&epsilon;&lambda;</etym>, Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Abel.</etym> By interpretation, Vanity.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Abraham(pn)">Abraham,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same in all Languages. Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05D1;&#x05E8;&#x05B8;&#x05D4;&#x05B7;&#x05DD;</etym>, which 
is derived from <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05D1;</etym>, father, and <etym lang="he">&#x05E8;&#x05B8;&#x05DD;</etym>, high, God himself ad&shy;
ding the letter <etym lang="he">&#x05D4;</etym>, that the name should signifie a Multitude, he 
having promis'd to Abraham a numerous issue. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&beta;&rho;&alpha;&#x1F70;&mu;</etym>, 
Lat. <etym lang="la">Abraham,</etym> or <etym lang="la">Abrahamus;</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  renown'd or honoured Father.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Adam(pn)">Adam,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same in all Languages: In the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05D3;&#x05B7;&#x05DD;</etym>, from 
the root <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05D3;&#x05B7;&#x05DD;</etym>, he was asham'd. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&delta;&#x1F70;&mu;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Adam</etym> or 
<etym lang="la">Adamus.</etym> It signifies originally, shame.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="&AElig;neus(pn)">&AElig;neas,</form> <xpln lang="en">the same with the Lat. <etym lang="la">&AElig;neas,</etym> which comes immediately 
from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&iota;&nu;&#x1F73;&alpha;&#x03c2;</etym>, which again may be deriv'd &#x1F00;&pi;&#x1F78; &tau;&omicron;&#x1FE6; <etym lang="gk">&#x1F00;&#x1F77;&nu;&omicron;&upsilon;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  from praise, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  praise worthy, or commendable.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Agar(pn)" lexeme="Hagar(pn)">Agar or Hagar,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D4;&#x05B8;&#x05D2;&#x05B8;&#x05E8;</etym>, which comes from the 
Verb <etym lang="he">&#x05D2;&#x05D5;&#x05E8;</etym>, to go on pilgrimage, to fly. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F0C;&gamma;&alpha;&rho;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Hagar.</etym> By 
interpretation, a Stranger, Traveller, or Pilgrim.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Alexander(pn)">Alexander,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Alexander,</etym> this immediately from the 
Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&lambda;&#x1F73;&xi;&alpha;&nu;&delta;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, which is drawn from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F00;&lambda;&#x1F73;&xi;&omega;</etym> to help, and <etym lang="gk">&#x1F00;&nu;&shy;
&delta;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym> the Gen. of <etym lang="gk">&#x1F00;&nu;&#x1F72;&rho;</etym>, a man; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  a manly or valiant helper or 
assistant.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amon(pn)">Amon;</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05DE;&#x05D5;&#x05DF;</etym>, Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&mu;&#x1F7C;&nu;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Amon,</etym> all the same, 
derived more immediately from the Root <etym lang="gk">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05DE;&#x05B7;&#x05DF;</etym>, which in Ni&shy;
phal signifies, to be true or faithful.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk6r"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Amos(pn)">Amos;</form> <xpln lang="en">In Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05DE;&#x05D5;&#x05E5;</etym>, Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&mu;&#x1F7C;&#x03c2;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Amos,</etym> all the same; 
It signifies originally stout or strong <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05DE;&#x05E5;</etym>, <etym lang="la">robustus fuit</etym> is the 
radix of it.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Andrew(pn)">Andrew,</form> <xpln lang="en">derived from the Greek <etym lang="gk">&#x1F08;&nu;&delta;&rho;#x1F73;&alpha;&#x03c2;</etym>, or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Andreas,</etym> 
which is again drawn &#x1F00;&pi;&#x1F78; &tau;&omicron;&#x1FF6; <etym lang="gk">&#x1F00;&nu;&delta;&rho;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, &kappa;&alpha;&tau;' &#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;, for his 
Courage and Manliness.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="B"><alpha>B</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Baptist(pn)">BAptist,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Christen-Name of a Man; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&#x1F71;&pi;&tau;&iota;&sigma;&tau;&alpha;</etym>, 
or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Baptista,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  a Baptizen, perhaps the first 
among the Greeks that used that Office, they call'd Bap&shy;
tist, which might afterwards by common use grow into 
a Proper Name; as we often find Names deriv'd from Office: 
for instance Usher, which before was Noel, by being Gentle&shy;
man Usher to King John, took his Name with his Office. John 
the Baptist.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barbara(pn)">Barbara,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christen-Name; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Barbara.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Barnabas(pn)">Barnabas,</form> <xpln lang="en">In the Syriack <etym lang="sy">&#x05D1;&#x05E8;&#x05E0;&#x05D1;&#x05D0;</etym> <etym lang="syt">Barnaba</etym>, Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&rho;&nu;&#x1F71;&beta;&alpha;&#x03c2;</etym>, Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Barnabas,</etym> derived from the Syr. <etym lang="sy">&#x05D1;&#x05B7;&#x05E8;</etym> <etym lang="syt">bar</etym>, a Son, and <etym lang="sy">&#1504;&#1489;&#64285;&#1488;</etym> 
<etym lang="syt">nabi</etym>, comfort, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Son of Consolation; for so he is call'd in 
Act. 4.36. &#x1F51;&iota;&#x1F78;&#x03c2; &pi;&alpha;&rho;&alpha;&kappa;&lambda;&#x1F75;&sigma;&epsilon;&omega;&#x03c2;, one main gift of a Prophet being 
placed in Consolation and Exhortation.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bartholomew(pn)">Bartholomew,</form> <xpln lang="en">in the Syr. <etym lang="sy">&#x05D1;&#x05E8;&#x05EA;&#x05F3;&#x05DC;&#x05DE;&#x05D9;</etym> <etym lang="syt">Bartholomai</etym>, derived from 
<etym lang="sy">&#x05D1;&#x05E8;</etym> <etym lang="syt">bar</etym>, a Son, <etym lang="sy">&#x05EA;&#x05F3;&#x05DC;&#x05B6;&#x05D4;</etym>, <etym lang="syt">thole</etym>, hanging or leaning downward, and 
<etym lang="gk">&#x05DE;&#x05D9;&#x05DD;</etym> <etym lang="syt">Majim</etym>, waters: <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Son of a Water-drawer: Gr. 
<etym lang="gk">&Beta;&alpha;&rho;&theta;&omicron;&lambda;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&#x1FD6;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Bartholomaeus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Benedict(pn)">Benedict,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Christen-Name; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Benedicta</etym> <term lang="la">idem</term>. It signifies, she is blessed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Benjamin(pn)">Benjamin,</form> <xpln lang="en">of an Hebr. original, from <etym lang="he">&#x05D1;&#x05B6;&#x05DF;</etym> <etym lang="het">ben</etym>, a Son, and <etym lang="he">&#x05D9;&#x05BD;&#x05DE;&#x05D9;&#x05DF;</etym> 
<etym lang="het">jamin</etym>, the right hand. <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the Son of my right hand, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  as dear 
to me as my right hand. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Beta;&epsilon;&nu;&iota;&alpha;&mu;&#x1F76;&nu;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Benjamin,</etym> all 
the same.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bennet(pn)">Bennet,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Man's Name, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Benedictus,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  he is blessed.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bettrice(pn)" lexeme="Beatrice(pn)">Bettrice, or Beatrice,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a Woman; from the Lat. 
<etym lang="la">Beatrix</etym>, She that Blesseth, a woman Blesser.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="C"><alpha>C</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="C&AElig;sar(pn)">C&AElig;sar;</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&#x1FD6;&sigma;&alpha;&rho;</etym>, or the Lat. <etym lang="la">C&aelig;sar,</etym> these from 
the Lat. <etym lang="la">c&aelig;saries,</etym> that is, hair, wherewith he was born: 
or <etym lang="la">&agrave; c&aelig;siis oculis,</etym> from his Gray Eyes: But most probably <etym lang="la">&agrave; c&aelig;so matris utero,</etym> from his Mothers Belly being cut 
before she could be deliver'd of him.</xpln></wordentry> 
</page> 

<page sig="Kk6v"> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Charity(pn)">Charity,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Charitas,</etym> this from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&#x1F71;&rho;&iota;&#x03c2;</etym>, id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Catharine(pn)">Catharine,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a Woman, from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&alpha;&theta;&alpha;&rho;&#x1F77;&nu;&alpha;</etym>, so 
call'd q. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F71;&theta;&alpha;&rho;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  pure or chast.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Christian(pn)">Christian,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Christiana,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  belonging to Christ.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Christopher(pn)">Christopher,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&rho;&iota;&sigma;&tau;&omicron;&phi;&#x1F79;&rho;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, which is again derived 
from <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&rho;&iota;&sigma;&tau;&#x1F78;&#x03c2;</etym>, Christ, and <etym lang="gk">&Phi;&#x1F73;&rho;&omega;</etym>, to suffer or endure; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  I bear 
Christ, according to the Fable of St. Christopher's, carrying 
Christ on his back through the Sea. He Preached the Gospel 
in Lycia, and was Beheaded under Dioclesian the Emperor.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Chrysostom(pn)">Chrysostom,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&rho;&upsilon;&sigma;&#x1F79;&sigma;&tau;&omicron;&mu;&omicron;&sigma;</etym>, or the Lat. <etym lang="la">Chrysostomus;</etym> 
which are deriv'd from <etym lang="gk">&Chi;&rho;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, golden, and <etym lang="gk">&Sigma;&tau;&#x1F79;&mu;&alpha;</etym>, a mouth, 
q. d. golden mouth, so call'd, &kappa;&alpha;&tau;' &#x1F10;&xi;&omicron;&chi;&#x1F74;&nu;, for his extraordinary 
Eloquence. He was Bishop of Constantinople in the year 401.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cicely(pn)">Cicely,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">C&aelig;celia.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clare(pn)">Clare,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name, from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Clara,</etym> clear.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Clemens(pn)">Clemens,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Roman Name, signifying one mild and benign; from 
<etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1F73;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, glory, and <etym lang="gk">&Mu;&#x1F73;&nu;&omicron;&#x03c2;, &epsilon;&omicron;&#x03c2;, &tau;&#x1F78;</etym>, the mind; Clemency being 
truly the glory of the mind. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&lambda;&#x1F75;&mu;&eta;&#x03c2;</etym>, <etym lang="gk">&eta;&nu;&tau;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cornelius(pn)">Cornelius,</form> <xpln lang="en">derived to us from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cornelius,</etym> which may 
come from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Cornu,</etym> a horn; or more likely q. <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&epsilon;&rho;&#x1F75;&lambda;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
<term lang="la">i.e.</term>  <etym lang="gk">&Kappa;&#x1F73;&rho;&alpha;&#x03c2; &tau;&omicron;&#x1FE6; &#x1F21;&lambda;&#x1F77;&omicron;&upsilon;</etym>, a beam of the Son.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="D"><alpha>D</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Daniel(pn)">DAniel,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D3;&#x05BC;&#x05B8;&#x05E0;&#x05B4;&#x05D9;&#x05D0;&#x05B5;&#x05DC;</etym>, which is again com&shy;
pounded of <etym lang="he">&#x05D3;&#x05BC;&#x05B8;&#x05DF;</etym>, or <etym lang="he">&#x05D3;&#x05BC;&#x05E0;&#x05B4;&#x05D9;</etym>, a Judge, (which comes of 
<etym lang="he">&#x05D3;&#x05BC;&#x05B8;&#x05E0;&#x05B4;&#x05D9;</etym>, to judge) and <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B5;&#x05DC;</etym>, God; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  the judge 
of God. In Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&alpha;&nu;&iota;&#x1F72;&lambda;</etym>, in Lat. <etym lang="la">Daniel.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="David(pn)">David,</form> <xpln lang="en">from the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D3;&#x05B8;&#x05D5;&#x05B4;&#x05D9;&#x05D3;</etym>, which comes from the Root <etym lang="he">&#x05D3;&#x05BC;&#x05D5;&#x05D3;</etym> 
<etym lang="het">dodh</etym>, beloved, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  beloved of God. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&alpha;&beta;&#x1F76;&delta;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">David.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Denis(pn)" lexeme="Dennis(pn)">Denis or Dennis,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Proper Name both of a Man and Wo&shy;
man; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&iota;&omicron;&nu;&#x1F7B;&sigma;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, or <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&iota;&omicron;&nu;&upsilon;&sigma;&#x1F77;&alpha;</etym>, q. d. belonging to 
Bacehus; these from <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&iota;&#x1F79;&nu;&upsilon;&sigma;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> Bacchus, which is again derived 
from <etym lang="gk">Dia,</etym> one of the Islands of the Cyclades, consecrated to 
him after his Marriage with Ariadne, and the City <etym lang="gk">Nysas</etym> where&shy;
in he reign'd; Or from <etym lang="gk">Du</etym> or <etym lang="gk">Dy,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  Lord, and <etym lang="gk">Nysa</etym> by a Meta&shy;
thesis for <etym lang="gk">Sina,</etym> <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  Lord of Sina, says Lloyd.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Deodate(pn)">Deodate,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Man's Name; from the Lat. <etym lang="la">Deodatus,</etym> <term lang="la">i.e.</term>  given of 
God, or given to God.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dorcas(pn)">Dorcas,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&omicron;&rho;&kappa;&#x1F70;&#x03c2;, &#x1F71;&delta;&omicron;&#x03c2;, &#x1F21;</etym>. It 
signifies originally a wood or wild Goat.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dorothy(pn)">Dorothy,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Delta;&omega;&rho;&#x1F79;&theta;&epsilon;&alpha;</etym>, which is again

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Elizabeth(pn)">Elisabeth,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name, from the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B1;&#x05DC;&#x05D9;&#x05E9;&#x05B5;&#x05D1;&#x05B7;&#x05E2;</etym> <etym lang="het">Elische&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Enos(pn)">Enos,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Man's Name; from the Hebr. <etym lang="gk">&#x05D0;&#x05B1;&#x05E0;&#x05D5;&#x05E9;&#x05C1;</etym> a Man, which comes 
from the root <etym lang="gk">&#x05D0;&#x05B8;&#x05D1;&#x05B7;&#x05E9;&#x05C1;</etym> to be sick; for man is infirm and subject 
to many Diseases. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&nu;&#x1F7C;&#x03c2;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Enos,</etym> id.</xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Ephraim(pn)">Ephraim,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Man's Name; from the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D0;&#x05B6;&#x05E4;&#x05B0;&#x05E8;&#x05B7;&#x05D9;&#x05B4;&#x05DD;</etym> <etym lang="het">id</etym>. It sig&shy;
nifies in the original unfruitful. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&phi;&rho;&alpha;&#x1F76;&mu;</etym>, Lat. <etym lang="la">Ephraim,</etym> or 
<etym lang="la">Ephraimus.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Eve(pn)">Eve,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Womans Name, originally from the Hebr. <etym lang="he">&#x05D7;&#x05B7;&#x05D5;&#x05B8;&#x05D4;</etym> <etym lang="het">Chava</etym>, 
so call'd because she was the Mother of all Living. Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F18;&nu;&alpha;</etym>,

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="G"><alpha>G</alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="George(pn)">George,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a Man; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&epsilon;&#x1F79;&rho;&gamma;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, and this 
from <etym lang="gk">&gamma;&#x1FC6;</etym>, the Earth, and <etym lang="gk">&#x1F40;&rho;&gamma;&#x1F77;&zeta;&omicron;&mu;&alpha;&iota;</etym>, to incite or stir up; <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  
a Ploughman or Tiller of the Ground. In Lat. <etym lang="la">Georgius.</etym> </xpln></wordentry> 

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Gregory(pn)">Gregory,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Man's Name; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&Gamma;&rho;&eta;&gamma;&#x1F79;&rho;&iota;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, which may 
possibly be drawn from <etym lang="gk">&gamma;&rho;&eta;&gamma;&omicron;&rho;#x1F73;&omega;</etym> to watch, <term lang="la">q.d.</term>  watchful, as was 
Gregory the Great, being almost in continual study.</xpln></wordentry> 
</wordgroup1> 

<wordgroup1 type="a" object="H"><alpha>H</alpha> 
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Hierom(pn)" lexeme="Ierom(pn)">HIerom or Ierom,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name of a Man; from the Gr. <etym lang="gk">&#x1F39;&epsilon;&rho;&#x1F79;&nu;&upsilon;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym>, 
and this again possibly, from <etym lang="gk">&#x1F35;&epsilon;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> holy, and <etym lang="gk">&nu;&#x1F79;&mu;&omicron;&#x03c2;</etym> a Law.</xpln></wordentry>
